headline: Examining Romanian Fault Lines
text: The Romanian director Lucian Pintilie made his first film in 1965, the year Nicolae Ceausescu became general secretary of the Romanian Communist Party. During the subsequent decades of Ceausescu’s dictatorship, which ended in 1989, Mr. Pintilie, like many independent-minded Eastern European artists, tried to work within the system and then went into exile, leaving for the West in 1973 and returning after Ceausescu was gone.

headline: So You’re Pregnant? Sometimes That’s the Easy Part
text: Early on there’s the birth of a baby, with doctor, nurse and father-to-be all singing, “Push it out, push it on out” like a high school football cheer. Vaginas are mentioned so often that you may wish Eve Ensler had never made the word fashionable in polite company. Then, just as you’re writing off “Rated P for Parenthood” as a bad, demographically opportunistic mash-up, a new mother sings a lovely middle-of-the-night lullaby to her infant son, and her husband offers her $50 to take his turn getting out of bed to tend to the baby. (She negotiates and gets $100 and “coffee from the fancy place.”)

headline: In Moscow, Facing a Question of Balancing or Going Quietly
text: The diagramed deal was the second board of the final of the Top 8 team event at the 10th Slava Memorial Cup, played in Moscow last month. It was a situation of interest to bidding theorists and featured a textbook defense.

headline: Back Home, Some Eternal Verities Prove Irksome
text: The playwright Mark Snyder is a native of Ohio, where he has set “As Wide as I Can See,” a drama now at the Here Arts Center. Given the play’s rigorous balance, it appears he bears a pronounced ambivalence toward the state.

headline: Universal Lures Top Country Executive From EMI
text: As its takeover of half of EMI is being reviewed by regulators in the United States and Europe, the Universal Music Group has hired one of EMI’s top record executives for its country division.

headline: The Blink of an Eye? Oh, Please
text: According to Harry Shum, a Microsoft computer scientist, computer users will visit a Web site less if its loading time is slower than its competitors by 250 milliseconds, or one-quarter of a second. That is less time than a single eye blink.

headline: Pittsburgh Cuts Loose a Revered Receiver
text: During his 14 years as a receiver for the Pittsburgh Steelers, Hines Ward attained a revered status.

headline: For Chinese Women, a Basic Need, and Few Places to Attend to It
text: BEIJING — Wang Jianyi, 26, was in a huge hurry. She had been riding the bus for three hours. At each rest stop, the line outside the women’s toilet was too long for her to use the restroom.

headline: Academy Wishes Its Future Really Did Belong to the Young
text: Well, that’s a wrap. After months of lobbying and hoopla the little gold guys have found their new homes on mantels and office shelves, and my self-referential stint as the Carpetbagger is drawing to a close for the season.

headline: A Detergent Emerges as a Star at Daytona
text: If not for the track fire that delayed the Daytona 500 for two hours Monday night, few would have known that Tide detergent can launder grape juice stains and a track burned by a jet fuel fire.

headline: West Virginia: Mine Security Chief Gets 3-Year Prison Term
text: The former chief of security for the Upper Big Branch mine, where 29 miners died in an explosion in 2010, was sentenced Wednesday to three years in prison. The official, Hughie Elbert Stover, 60, was convicted in October of lying to federal officials and obstructing the investigation into the explosion at the West Virginia mine. Mr. Stover was also sentenced to two years of supervised release and ordered to pay a $20,000 fine. Last month, a higher-ranking official, Gary May, was accused of conspiring to defraud the government in connection with the investigation.

headline: The Los Angeles Schools Chief, on Teacher Ratings
text: To the Editor:

headline: Anna Lou Dehavenon, Who Drew Attention to the Homeless, Dies at 85
text: Anna Lou Dehavenon, an urban anthropologist, was documenting the lives of women living in a Bronx homeless shelter in the 1980s when she had an epiphany.

text: To the Editor:

text: What can world leaders do to prevent another humanitarian disaster from taking place in Sudan?

text: The classical music reporter Daniel J. Wakin discusses the Venezuelan music education program founded by José Antonio Abreu.

headline: Delaware Court Declines to Block Kinder Morgan’s El Paso Corp. Deal
text: 10:24 p.m. | Updated with El Paso statement

headline: Churches Can Go Back to Schools, for Now
text: Two weeks after churches had to stop holding worship services in New York City public schools, a federal court sent pastors and congregations a different and welcome message on Wednesday: go back, at least for now.

headline: Defense and Dempsey’s Shot Give U.S. a First in Italy
text: GENOA, Italy — It took 11 games over eight decades, but the United States men’s soccer team can now boast that it has beaten Italy. The victory, on a chilly night, came in a friendly and not in a tournament, but it was sweet nonetheless for an American team being reshaped by its coach, Jurgen Klinsmann.

headline: Venezuela: Fuel Still Flows to Syria
text: The head of the state-run oil company, Petróleos de Venezuela, has said that the company will continue to ship diesel fuel to Syria despite efforts by the United States and other countries to isolate the government of President Bashar al-Assad of Syria. “If they need diesel and we can supply it there is no reason not to do it,” Rafael Ramírez, the oil company president, who is also the minister of oil and mining, said on Tuesday. He confirmed that company had sent two tankers, each containing 300,000 barrels of diesel, to Syria. The State Department said it would continue to work with other countries to increase pressure on Mr. Assad to cease his crackdown on political opponents and to step down. President Hugo Chávez of Venezuela has long sided with Middle Eastern countries like Syria and Iran in defiance of Western sanctions.

headline: Genetically Altered Bird Flu Virus Not as Dangerous as Believed, Its Maker Asserts
text: The scientist who made a deadly bird flu virus transmissible in mammals, touching off public fears of a pandemic, said Wednesday that the virus he created was neither as contagious nor as dangerous as people had been led to believe.

headline: For Keselowski, a Steady Climb on Twitter
text: A minute-by-minute analysis of Brad Keselowski’s Twitter messages during the Daytona 500 on Monday night showed that his following grew steadily, rather than explosively, according to an analysis by Twitter.

headline: A Civil Right to Unionize
text: FROM the 1940s to the 1970s, organized labor helped build a middle-class democracy in the United States. The postwar period was as successful as it was because of unions, which helped enact progressive social legislation from the Civil Rights Act to Medicare. Since then, union representation of American workers has fallen, in tandem with the percentage of income going to the middle class. Broadly shared prosperity has been replaced by winner-take-all plutocracy.

headline: Smartphones Have Led, and Desktops Will Follow
text: BARCELONA, Spain — These days much of the action in the world of gadgets is happening in smartphones — like their sophisticated design and the apps that run on them. That has left desktop and laptop computers looking a little dull in comparison.

headline: Bad Feelings Lingering Over Braun’s Victory
text: JUPITER, Fla.

headline: Winter Month Indicator?
text: The price of gasoline rose higher this February that in any other previous February. Some analysts worry that this could portend very high gas prices this summer.

headline: Israel’s Last Chance to Strike Iran
text: Tel Aviv

headline: School Shooting Suspect Was Accused of Earlier Assault
text: CHARDON, Ohio — The teenager held in a shooting rampage at a high school in a suburb of Cleveland that killed three students and injured two had a troubled past, accused in 2009 of choking and punching a person, according to court documents released here on Wednesday.

headline: My Morning Jacket and Jackson Browne to Headline Newport Folk Festival
text: My Morning Jacket and Jackson Browne will be the headliners at the 2012 Newport Folk Festival in July, the organizers announced on Thursday. As it has since it started in 1959, the festival will return to Fort Adams State Park on Narragansett Bay in Newport, R.I., on July 28 and 29 with a lineup featuring its usual mix of traditional folk groups and folk-rock bands. The first day’s bill will include Iron & Wine, Dawes, Deer Tick, Blind Pilot and Sharon Van Etten. On the second day, Conor Oberst, Punch Brothers, the Head & the Heart, and Tune-yards will play, along with several other acts. There will be a number of not-strictly-folk performances. The Preservation Hall Jazz Band, the celebrated traditional jazz outfit from New Orleans, will play the first day. The electric blues guitarist Gary Clark Jr. is slated to do a set on the second day, as is Tom Morello, the guitarist from Rage Against the Machine who also performs original folk songs as The Nightwatchman.

headline: Former Goldman Partner Now a Self-Fashioned Political Pundit
text: For many former Goldman Sachs partners, an active retirement means traveling the world, becoming a regular on the gala circuit and playing hundreds of holes of golf a week.

headline: In Relay Practice, Yankees Have an Answer for Valentine
text: TAMPA, Fla. — The timing that Derek Jeter displayed in making the famous flip relay to Jorge Posada in the 2001 playoffs was remarkable. The timing the Yankees displayed by practicing the same play Wednesday was too rich to believe.

headline: A Big Day’s Coming
text: On Sunday, we commemorate one of the most seminal moments in American history, the inauguration of President William Henry Harrison.

headline: Substantial Growth in Ads Is on the Way to Facebook
text: Facebook’s hundreds of millions of users could soon be faced with a lot more advertising — in their newsfeed, on their mobile devices and even when they log off.

headline: Davy Jones, Monkees Singer, Dies at 66
text: Davy Jones, by long-held public consensus the handsomest and most popular of the Monkees, the collectively young, longhaired, wildly famous and preternaturally buoyant pop group of the 1960s and afterward, died on Wednesday in Indiantown, Fla. He was 66.

headline: Talking to North Korea, Again
text: North Korea has repeatedly vowed to rein in its nuclear program, only to renege, so skepticism is demanded. Still, the Obama administration is right to try again.

headline: After Many Tough Choices, the Choice to Quit
text: WASHINGTON — The looming Senate vote on a Republican plan to give employers the right to withdraw health care coverage based on religious and moral convictions put Senator Olympia J. Snowe in a tough but familiar position: weighing her own views as a Republican centrist against pressure from fellow Republicans to support the party position.

headline: Window Into Developer’s Relentless Quest to Get a Yonkers Project Approved
text: For Forest City Ratner, it had become a make-or-break moment: The developer had already spent roughly $70 million on a proposed 81-acre luxury mall and housing complex in Yonkers, but was one vote shy of winning the City Council’s approval.

headline: To Avoid Last-Minute Suit, Shell Asks U.S. Court to Rule
text: HOUSTON — In an attempt to avoid a last-minute challenge from environmental groups that could delay its plans to begin drilling for oil this summer off the coast of Alaska, Shell asked a federal court on Wednesday to review its Alaska Arctic oil spill response plan and decide whether it complied with the law’s requirements.

headline: Update on New York Redistricting
text: Each state must redraw its political maps to reflect the 2010 census, but New York, which has approved neither legislative nor Congressional districts for this year’s elections, is among the last to comply. Redistricting has become increasingly urgent because of the calendar; the state’s Congressional primary is scheduled for June 26, and its legislative primary on Sept. 11.

headline: Virginia’s Gift to Gunrunners
text: In 1993, Virginia enacted a one-per-month limit on gun purchases after a federal study showed that two out of five handguns taken from New York City crime scenes were purchased in Virginia’s freewheeling gun markets. Now the state seems determined to resume its destructive “iron pipeline” role. On Tuesday, Gov. Bob McDonnell signed a law repealing the gun purchase limit.

headline: Iran Invokes the West to Motivate Voters
text: WASHINGTON — In the days leading up to Iran’s parliamentary elections on Friday, the supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, and other top officials have been crisscrossing their country to issue stern warnings against a vast Western conspiracy, driven by panic, to undermine the vote. The official news media have amplified the campaign: “U.S. Dreads Iranians’ Turnout in Elections,” read one typical banner on Press TV, the state-run English-language vehicle.

headline: Reforming the Postal Service
text: All the free-market enthusiasts in Congress should have no problem with the determination of Patrick Donahoe, the postmaster general, to make the gravely troubled mail system “smaller, leaner and more competitive.” Yet most lawmakers have decried or ducked money-saving options like eliminating Saturday mail delivery and consolidating mail-processing centers — crucial parts of Mr. Donahoe’s reform plan. Their resistance is even stronger to possibly closing 3,653 of the nation’s 32,000 post offices, even though more than 3,000 offices have only two-hour workdays or less than $27,500 in annual revenues.

headline: Black Eye for Ticket Reseller
text: It was the kind of disturbance that could have happened anywhere alcohol flows free. But an outburst early Monday at an Oscars party in Connecticut has also cast a shadow over a fast-growing and controversial side of the entertainment business: the online market for scalped tickets.

headline: Free-Speech Argument in Appeal of Disbarred Lawyer’s Sentence
text: Throughout her long career, the disbarred lawyer Lynne F. Stewart has rarely minced words or stood mute. But her propensity for speaking her mind is now at the crux of an appeal of her 10-year sentence in federal prison.

headline: Cavs’ Irving, a No. 1 Pick, Is Exceeding Expectations
text: As much as any coach in the N.B.A., Byron Scott knows the value of coaching a team directed by a sterling floor general. Scott ran the floor with Magic Johnson as a part of the Showtime Lakers in the 1980s and ran off screens while backing up Reggie Miller for the 1995 Eastern Conference finalist Indiana Pacers, whose point guard was Mark Jackson.

headline: Saudi Arabia May Be Tied to 9/11, 2 Ex-Senators Say
text: WASHINGTON — For more than a decade, questions have lingered about the possible role of the Saudi government in the attacks on Sept. 11, 2001, even as the royal kingdom has made itself a crucial counterterrorism partner in the eyes of American diplomats.

headline: Clinton Urges Iranian Group to Complete Move
text: WASHINGTON — Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton said on Wednesday that a decision on whether to remove an Iranian opposition group from the list of terrorist organizations would depend in part on whether more than 3,000 of its members cooperate in moving to a new location inside Iraq.

headline: For Impatient Web Users, an Eye Blink Is Just Too Long to Wait
text: Wait a second.

headline: A Doo-Wop Shop Prepares to Close, Signaling the End of a Fading Genre
text: CLIFTON, N.J. — The end is near for Ronnie I’s Clifton Music after 40 years on Main Avenue — yet another victim of the Internet, the economy, and changing tastes in music and shopping.

headline: Iran Prepares for Elections
text: Candidates and their supporters on the ground geared up for parliamentary elections in Iran that are slated for Friday.

headline: Brothers to Renew Rivalry on the Ice
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Eric Staal, the Carolina Hurricanes’ captain, was having a miserable season until New Year’s Day. Since then he has performed like the player who won a Stanley Cup and an Olympic gold medal.

headline: Born to Not Get Bullied
text: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

headline: In Return to the Honda Classic, Woods Is Irritated by Some Questioning
text: PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla. — Tiger Woods’s decision to play the Honda Classic for the first time since he was a 17-year-old amateur gave instant credibility and increased visibility to a tournament once considered the weak link of the Florida swing.

headline: President Offers Theme of Nation Seeing a Comeback
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama has a new message: America has gotten its groove back.

headline: New Light on Days Before Rutgers Student’s Death
text: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J. — After discovering that his roommate had set up a webcam in their room and watched him kissing a man, Tyler Clementi sent an e-mail to the resident assistant in the dormitory that said, “I feel my privacy has been violated, and I am extremely uncomfortable sharing a room with someone who would act in this wildly inappropriate manner.”

headline: Manhattan Man Indicted in Pipe Bomb Case
text: A Manhattan man arrested last year on charges that he planned to detonate pipe bombs in New York City has been indicted on terrorism charges, the authorities announced Wednesday.

headline: The Return of Sniglets
text: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — If you watched a television show called “Not Necessarily the News” on HBO in the mid- to late-1980s, you will appreciate this one. Although the practice of making up nonsense words existed well before then, the comedian Rich Hall popularized and renamed them as sniglets for a whole new generation. Sniglets, Mr. Hall said, are words that don’t appear in the dictionary but should.

headline: Fading Sounds of Doo-Wop
text: Ronnie’s I’s Clifton Music in New Jersey is about to close after 40 years: a sign, many say, that doo-wop is on its last legs.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Republican Who Bluntly Backed Gay Marriage Loses Some Support Back Home
text: ALBANY — With a blunt one-liner — “They can take the job and shove it” — describing his disregard for the political consequences of his decision to support same-sex marriage last year, Senator Roy J. McDonald, a Republican from Saratoga, became a hero to gay rights groups.

headline: Retirement Throws Maine’s Senate Race Into ‘Chaos’
text: PORTLAND, Me. — Senator Olympia J. Snowe’s surprise announcement that she will retire set off frantic political calculations throughout Maine on Wednesday, with former governors, members of the state’s Congressional delegation and many others hurriedly weighing runs for office that they had previously ruled out.

headline: Democrats Favored to Pick Up Snowe Seat
text: The retirement of Senator Olympia J. Snowe of Maine is about as damaging to a party’s electoral prospects as these things get, turning a seat that Republicans were very likely to retain into one they will probably lose.

headline: After a Costly Scandal, Binghamton Begins Rebuilding
text: VESTAL, N.Y. — Three years ago, Binghamton University students flooded onto the floor of the Events Center here, celebrating its first berth in the N.C.A.A. tournament. The university had made the expensive and controversial choice to compete at the Division I level less than a decade earlier, and the decision appeared to have paid off.

headline: Romney Debases the G.O.P. Base
text: So far, the base of the Republican party has sent Mitt Romney a message: They’re not yet convinced that he’s their guy.

headline: Knicks Turn Slow Start Into an Easy Finish
text: To measure just how far the Knicks have come, how much has changed in a short period, one could count the number of bodies used, or the standing ovations they enjoyed or the unmitigated giddiness that overtook Madison Square Garden on Wednesday night.

headline: Turnaround King Tries to Convince Investors He Hasn’t Lost a Step
text: Over the last decade on Wall Street, Wilbur L. Ross Jr. has been called many names, including a vulture, a turnaround king and Mr. Distress.

headline: More Blacks and Latinos Admitted to Elite New York High Schools
text: The number of black and Latino students who were accepted at one of eight highly selective high schools in New York City increased from last year, according to admissions statistics released on Wednesday by the city’s Education Department. The uptick for the two groups reverses a years-long decline in admissions to the schools, where admittance is based on a single test.

headline: Tensions Raise Specter of Gas at $5 a Gallon
text: HOUSTON — Gasoline for $5 a gallon? The possibility is hardly far-fetched.

text: ACE HARDWARE this week is introducing an ad campaign for a new line of premium paints.

headline: U.S. Judge Strikes Down F.D.A. Cigarette Labels
text: A federal judge on Wednesday declared unconstitutional a Food and Drug Administration requirement that tobacco companies prominently display graphic warning labels on cigarette packages.

headline: Missed Opportunity for Rivals of Romney, but Another Looms

headline: Romney Sets Off Furor on Contraception Bill

headline: Candidates Scramble to Create Differences
text: DETROIT — Facing big hurdles here in Mitt Romney’s native state, Rick Santorum seized on the novel tactic of attacking his rival for agreeing with him.

headline: Queens School Faces Heavy Demand on Eve of Kindergarten Deadline
text: For thousands of New York City parents preparing to send their children to kindergarten this fall, application season can be a time of stress because some crowded public schools can’t guarantee a seat. One elementary school in the Queens neighborhood of Ridgewood is among those feeling the squeeze.

headline: William Gay Dies at 70; Writer Tied to Tennessee
text: William Gay, a self-taught novelist from rural Tennessee who emerged from obscurity in his late 50s with critically praised books in the Southern Gothic style, died last Thursday at his home, a log cabin in Hohenwald, southwest of Nashville. He was 70.

headline: For Some Women, the Misery of Mumbai’s Dance Bars Looks Like a Big Step Up
text: “Beautiful Thing,” a book about Mumbai’s notorious sex industry, and the news it brings about young women’s lives “will break your heart several times over,” Dwight Garner writes in the New York Times.

headline: North Korea: Have We Seen This Movie Before?
text: HONG KONG — It’s a fair question: Is North Korea acting in good faith, offering a monitored shutdown of a nuclear facility in exchange for a quarter-million tons of food aid? Or is this a kind of diplomatic “Groundhog Day,” fated to end once again with the Americans duped and angry over more North Korean perfidy?

headline: Face of Hope Reflects Calm in Kashmir
text: In rural Kashmir, “people will listen with great care to any man who tells them how he plans to bring roads, electricity, jobs and good schools to their villages, which have been impoverished by decades of strife,” Manu Joseph writes in the International Herald Tribune.

headline: In Illinois Town, Scenes of Devastation
text: Updated | 4:30 p.m.At least 12 people were killed in three states after a powerful storm system ripped across the Midwest and South. As our colleagues Monica Davey and A.G. Sulzberger reported, the storms left pockets of devastation, reducing blocks and businesses in some areas to rubble.

headline: Green Oasis
text: A new food co-op sprouts in Clinton Hill.

headline: News Quiz | March 1, 2012
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries in today’s paper.

headline: Blast in Istanbul Injures 10 Police Officers
text: HATAY, Turkey — Ten police officers were injured on Thursday when a booby-trapped motorcycle exploded in front of the headquarters of the Turkish governing party in Istanbul, officials said.

headline: March 1, 1954 | Puerto Rican Nationalists Open Fire on House of Representatives
text: On March 1, 1954, the Puerto Rican nationalists Lolita Lebron, Rafael Miranda, Irving Flores Rodriguez and Andres Figueroa Cordero entered the United States Capitol’s House of Representatives chamber and began firing at members of Congress, injuring five.

headline: Syrian Forces Overwhelm Stronghold of Rebels in Homs
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The Syrian Army overwhelmed the main rebel stronghold in the embattled city of Homs on Thursday, setting the stage for its elite soldiers to turn their attention — and superior firepower — to other insurgent redoubts farther north, despite the increasing international pressure for a cease-fire and humanitarian access.

headline: Test Yourself | English, March 1, 2012
text: This question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article “A Hollywood Insider and a Map of the Stars.”

headline: Two American Soldiers Die in Shooting at Afghan Base
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Two more United States soldiers were killed in southern Afghanistan on Thursday when an Afghan soldier, apparently in league with a civilian, killed an Afghan tower guard and attacked a barracks with gunfire and a rocket, officials said.

headline: Postcard From a New London
text: The world’s eyes will be fixed on London this summer as athletes march into town for the 2012 Olympic Games. The image of the city presented by TV networks will more than likely be familiar: “The global TV audience will be treated to a romanticized version of the city, with helicopter shots of Big Ben competing for time against footage of Buckingham Palace guards staring stone-faced into the distance and double-decker buses bouncing unsteadily through too-narrow streets,” writes Craig Taylor in this Sunday’s New York Times Magazine.

headline: Republicans and Fiscal Responsibility
text: Simon Johnson is the Ronald A. Kurtz Professor of Entrepreneurship at the M.I.T. Sloan School of Management and co-author of “White House Burning: The Founding Fathers, Our National Debt, and Why It Matters to You.”

text: 1. Does everyone drink like Winston Churchill?

text: The Olympic Stadium and the Shard.

headline: ‘Oh, London, You Drama Queen’
text: An invisible bridge spans the Thames at Blackfriars. Victorian pilings jut from the river, the railway they once supported long gone. Dangling above them on this cold day, helicopters surveilled thousands of strikers and supporters processing loudly through central London. It was Nov. 30, 2011, and two million public-sector workers were on strike.

headline: True Londoners Are Extinct
text: Later this year, thousands of Olympians will march into London under flapping flags, and the global TV audience will be treated to a romanticized version of the city, with helicopter shots of Big Ben competing for time against footage of Buckingham Palace guards staring stone-faced into the distance and double-decker buses bouncing unsteadily through too-narrow streets. By the end of the ceremonies, you’ll have seen the city’s bridges so many times that you’ll wish they had all fallen down years ago.

headline: What Would You Name Your Neighborhood?
text: There are many neighborhoods within New York City, from SoHo to Bushwick to Hell’s Kitchen. Each name has a story. What goes into naming a neighborhood? What makes one neighborhood in the same area different from another? What makes your neighborhood unique? What might you name it if you were in charge of giving it a new name? Why?

headline: A Criminal Virus Born of Russia and the Soviet Past Spreads
text: A network of immigrants from the former Soviet Union conspired to steal more than a quarter of a billion dollars by manipulating the insurance laws in the state of New York, reports William K. Rashbaum.

headline: Tibetan Writer Says China Is Blocking Her From Award
text: BEIJING — A prominent Tibetan writer living here in Beijing said on Thursday that the police had placed her under house arrest to prevent her from receiving a prize for culture from the Dutch Embassy.

headline: Meet Gurgaon’s Top Cop: Former Engineer K.K. Sindhu
text: K.K. Sindhu, 50, became the police commissioner of Gurgaon, the fast-growing outsourcing city south of New Delhi, last November. The Indian Police Service officer studied civil engineering and worked as a resource officer with the federal Ministry of Water Resources before joining the police service in 1986.  “Policing is much better,” he said in a recent interview with India Ink.

headline: A 1,400-Horsepower Tank, Batteries Included
text: Some hybrid vehicles are engineered to be as light as possible. This one is projected to weigh around 140,000 pounds, fully equipped.

headline: Fantasy Focus: Market Value vs. Performance Value
text: One way to get ready for your fantasy baseball auction or draft is to project out the stats of all the relevant players and convert those stats to dollar values (or draft slots). For example, if you think Justin Verlander will win about 18 games, strike out 240 batters and have an earned run average of 3.00 and a WHIP of 1.05, your algorithm might say he’s worth $30 in a $260-budget, 12-team A.L.-only league. (This is a rough estimate, and your mileage may vary.) You might also decide those numbers make him an early second-round pick in your 15-team mixed league draft.

headline: Mount Holyoke College Announces Tuition Freeze
text: Mount Holyoke College has announced that it will not increase tuition or room and board for the 2012-2013 academic year.

text: Q.

text: In a sign that tensions are still running high in the Maldives, hundreds of supporters of the island nation’s former president blocked the current president from addressing Parliament on Thursday.

text: The Internet speed maestros are now facing a daunting new challenge in mobile computing — with its explosion in traffic, vast tracts of slow-poke bandwidth, and varied software on smartphones. I wrote an article about this issue for Thursday’s New York Times.

text: LONDON — Tata Communications, which is controlled by India’s largest conglomerate, said on Thursday that it might bid for Cable and Wireless Worldwide of Britain to complement its operations in developing countries.

headline: The Vanity of the Bonfires
text: With deadly protests still raging in Afghanistan following claims that U.S. military personnel inadvertently destroyed Korans, commentators are wondering about the fallout.

headline: Scouting the Draft: Memphis’s Dontari Poe
text: There were plenty of winners and losers at the scouting combine, but perhaps no player helped his stock more than Memphis defensive tackle Dontari Poe.  The numbers are staggering: 6-4, 346 pounds, a 4.98 40-yard dash, and 44 bench press reps.  He has a muscular physique despite weighing as much as two DeSean Jacksons, and he looked incredibly athletic in position drills.  I had to take a look.

headline: Financial Rally Sends Shares Higher
text: Stocks advanced on Thursday, sending the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index to the highest level since 2008, as financial shares rallied and government data showed that initial jobless claims declined to a four-year low.

headline: How Temple Run Became More Popular Than Zynga Games
text: A team of three software developers made a single iPhone game that has become as addictive as all of Zynga’s mobile games combined. Temple Run, a free game in the App Store, has become a smash hit, with over 40 million downloads since its release in August.

headline: High School Admissions Letters Go Out to Students
text: On Wednesday the city said  that more black and Latino students were accepted into the city's elite public high school in the admissions process. On Thursday, more eighth graders will learn which schools admitted them -- from letters distributed at their schools or sent home.

headline: Officials Rule No Payout on Greek Swaps

headline: Thursday Reading: Getting a Jump on Spring Cleaning

headline: Illinois Town All Too Versed in Taking a Hit
text: HARRISBURG, Ill. — Even before a tornado tore through this small southern Illinois city, leaving residents cowering inside closets as ceilings tore away, huddling under mattresses showered with glass and metal and wood, hiding inside bathtubs that had somehow lost their bathrooms, Harrisburg had seen trouble.

headline: The Guardians of the Underground’s Guardians, a k a, the Elites’ Elite

That would be the board of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, which earns this lofty appellation because people who determine what happens each day to the elites must surely be deemed even more elite. And who are those elites, plural? Subway riders, of course.

headline: Live Performance Will Be Bigger Part of PEN World Voices Festival
text: In an effort to extend its reach and “celebrate the written word in action,” the annual PEN World Voices literary festival, to be held this year from April 30 through May 6, will include not only panels, readings and lectures but also events that wed literature and live performance. Among the collaborations scheduled is one that will pair the Kronos Quartet with the writers Tony Kushner, Marjane Satrapi and Rula Jebreal and another that will feature puppetry on the High Line by the Processional Arts Workshop.

headline: How Windows 8 Transforms Enterprise Computing
text: On Wednesday, Microsoft demonstrated its new operating system, Windows 8, which is expected later this year. It is a critically important piece of software for Microsoft, which still depends on Windows and Office for most of its revenue.

headline: Peter Jackson’s West Memphis Three Documentary Acquired by Sony Pictures Classics

headline: Daily Report: Facebook’s Big Ad Push
text: Facebook’s users could soon be seeing a lot more advertising, Tanzina Vega reports on Thursday in The New York Times. headline: A City Under Siege

It tells the story of the Ottomans’ successful siege of Constantinople through the eyes of Sultan Mehmet II, with a neat subplot about a cross-dressing female cannon maker who made victory possible.

headline: U.S. Defendants Leave Egypt Amid Growing Backlash

headline: New! Improved! Russian Political Ads!
text: In the 1980s, when I covered the Soviet Union, we used to joke about the primitive state of Russian advertising, which was largely confined to billboards with stirring slogans like “Communism Equals Soviet Power Plus Electrification of the Entire Country.”

headline: Running Wilde: A Gangster Version of ‘Earnest,’ Directed by David Hyde Pierce
text: In a 2012 Williamstown Theater Festival summer season that includes a new play by Katori Hall and a musical adaptation of “Far From Heaven,” it takes a very special revival of “The Importance of Being Earnest” to catch our eye. And the production of that classic Oscar Wilde farce that David Hyde Pierce plans to direct there might just meet that standard.

headline: Complete Text of Syrian Rebel Statement on Retreat From Homs District

headline: Biennale Amid the Souks and the Arab Spring
text: MARRAKESH — Marrakesh is already well-anchored as an exotic winter getaway for Europeans, Americans and well-heeled Moroccans. But in this city of medieval souks and alleyways, not to mention palatial out-of-town villas, a larger ambition blooms. Some residents, native and non-native, want the city to become a genuine art destination, one that does not just rely on the past.

headline: Many Americans Struggle to Save for Emergencies
text: Many Americans appear to be struggling to save for emergencies and other needs, two recent surveys reveal.

headline: Theater Talkback: Howard Kissel, A Man Who Relished Culture
text: Certain faces, when glimpsed in crowded rooms or public places, are beacons of reassurance, confirmations that your world is still on its axis. For me, the cultural critic Howard Kissel, who died at 69 last week, had one of those faces. And whenever I would register its presence at the theater (which wasn’t hard to do, since Howard had a face that naturally loomed), I would feel a click of relief.

headline: When Doctors Don’t Tell the Truth
text: Every spring, a former patient and his elderly parents would drive two hours to the hospital carrying chocolates for the staff — an epicurean celebration of the man’s successful liver transplant a few years earlier. The patient, tall, in his 30s and with sandy-brown hair, handed out the boxes, and his parents, their parched-earth faces beaming with joy, shook everyone’s hands.

headline: The British Are Here
text: Craig Taylor had a rough time when he first moved to London from Canada a dozen years ago. Someone tried to pick his friend’s pocket. A scam artist took advantage of him. Wandering around with an ancient A-Z street atlas, he often felt “lonely, duped, underprepared, faceless, friendless.” But something about the city got under his skin, so he resolved to push beyond his own experience and take its measure. Happily for us, the result is “Londoners,” a rich and exuberant kaleidoscopic portrait of a great, messy, noisy, daunting, inspiring, maddening, enthralling, constantly shifting Rorschach test of a place, as befits the book’s subtitle, “The Days and Nights of London Now — As Told by Those Who Love It, Hate It, Live It, Left It, and Long for It.”

headline: The Republicans’ ‘If Only’ Candidates

headline: How the Grinch Stole the Lorax
text: Since its publication in 1971 “The Lorax,” by Dr. Seuss, has occasionally been caught up in squalls of controversy, most of it cooked up by people choosing to be outraged by the book’s mild allegorical moral of ecological responsibility. In our own globally warmed, ideologically fevered moment there has been a minor flurry of predictable, pre-emptive bloviation aimed at Universal’s movie version, “Dr. Seuss’ The Lorax,” which is supposedly part of a left-wing Hollywood conspiracy to brainwash America’s children into hating capitalism and loving trees.

headline: It’s the Name Game

Ms. Sussman, a photographer working on a project about the world’s oldest living things, is searching for moss. Very old moss. She sent this dispatch to Lens last week.

headline: Links For the 1st of March
text: Monsanto: First the good news: France has called for a ban on Monsanto GMO corn. Now the bad: A federal judge in New York has dismissed a lawsuit, filed by more than 80 farmers and agricultural organizations against Monsanto, which sought to protect organic farmers from litigation if their crops became contaminated by Monsanto’s GMO seeds. From 1997 to 2010, Monsanto sued 144 farmers for patent infringement, a number that the judge said “is hardly significant when compared to the number of farms in the United States” (just try telling that to the 144 farmers).

headline: Now the Plutocrat Takes on Capitalism
text: When we last checked in on the investor and one-time magazine subject Jeremy Grantham a few weeks ago, he had just published an op-ed in The Financial Times declaring the United States a plutocracy. (Recall, his firm manages around $100 billion in assets.) Since then, his quarterly letter has appeared, and this time it isn’t simply the American political-financial complex in his sights, but capitalism itself. (Recall again the man’s authority: $100 billion.)

headline: Rick Santorum and Religious Freedom
text: In a piece tinged with hysteria and largely devoid of evidence, the New Yorker’s George Packer accuses of Rick Santorum of seeking to overthrow the Constitution’s ban on an establishment of religion, compares American religious conservatives to “Salafists” and theocrats (I have some dim memory of the days when Packer was worried about overheated rhetoric in American politics), and implicitly analogizes Santorum to the Muslim extremists who have sought to execute a young man named Hamza Kashgari for blasphemy.

headline: Obama Seeks to End Subsidies for Oil and Gas Companies
text: NASHUA, N.H. — With his re-election fate increasingly tied to the price Americans are paying at the gas pump, President Obama asked Congress on Thursday to end $4 billion in subsidies for oil and gas companies and vowed to tackle the country’s long-term energy issues while shunning “phony election-year promises about lower gas prices.”

headline: Mark Morris Dance Group Headed to China
text: The Mark Morris Dance Group will make its first foray into China, performing in Guangzhou and Macao from May 25 to June 2, the company said on Thursday. A contingent of 18 dancers and six musicians will make the trip. On the program: “Festival Dance,” “Grand Duo” and “V” in Guangzhou and the “Eleven” and “Double” sections from “Mozart Dances” and the work “Grand Duo.” The visit will include master classes, workshops and question and answer sessions with Mr. Morris, the company said. Mark Morris Dance Group will begin a series of performances at the Brooklyn Academy of Music tonight.

headline: Digital Notes: Indies Settle With LimeWire, and Kim Dotcom Speaks Up
text: A New LimeWire Settlement: An organization that represents independent record companies around the world has settled its lawsuit against LimeWire, the defunct file-sharing service. The size of LimeWire’s settlement payment was not disclosed, but the organization, Merlin, said the amount was “commensurate” with the $105 million settlement the major labels reached with LimeWire last year. (Merlin estimates its members’ market share in the United States at about 10 percent.) Merlin was founded in 2008 partly as a result of the indies’ frustration at not sharing in other industry settlements as well as not getting equity in MySpace Music, as the major labels did.

headline: Next Geoffrion Takes the Ice in Montreal
text: In the whoosh of one pre-deadline trade, Blake Geoffrion went from a relatively obscure young player in Nashville to a prodigy upholding a proud legacy in Montreal. This could only happen in the world of the Canadiens, in whose Bell Centre hang the jerseys of Geoffrion’s great grandfather, Howie Morenz, and his grandfather, Bernie “Boom Boom” Geoffrion.

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | Balmain
text: Backstage at Balmain, everyone was singing “Happy Birthday” (in English) to the woman in charge of the hairstylist Sam McKnight’s team. “Can I interest you in a small sandwich?” someone asked, gesturing towards the catering table. “Here’s a Coca-Light,” Karlie Kloss said, smiling, as she got up from McKnight’s chair. Her hair was loose and just a little wavy — what McKnight described as “so nothing,” created by letting hair dry without heat or product. For the few girls with unruly strands, he tamed them by straightening and working back in some wave. “The clothes are quite full on,” he said of a collection apparently inspired by Faberge eggs. Tom Pecheux was in McKnight’s camp. “Barely anything,” was his description of skin massaged with cream like Estée Lauder’s Idealist. Makeup was merely a light touch of concealer and contour in Sculpt or Shadowy with brown or black mascara on brows. “Why not? They are gorgeous girls,” he said. “Balmain is usually about glowing, fresh bombshells; these girls are slightly more rough and grungy.”

headline: What Next for Gas Prices?
text: As I write in Thursday’s Times, gasoline prices keep going higher and higher.

headline: British Museums Buy Second Titian for More Than $70 Million
text: The National Gallery in London announced on Thursday that it had secured funding to purchase Titian’s “Diana and Callisto” together with the National Galleries of Scotland for $71.7 million, thereby ensuring that the work, along with another great painting by the 16th-century master, would stay on public view.

headline: Congressional Redistricting Plans Go to a Judge
text: ALBANY – Legislative leaders, unable to agree on how to reduce New York’s Congressional delegation by two seats, submitted competing plans late Wednesday night for a federal judge to consider as she develops a redistricting plan that could be imposed by the court.

headline: Rick Santorum on Obama and Unemployment
text: On President Obama and Unemployment

headline: U.C.L.A. Fends Off Criticism of Discipline Problems
text: The U.C.L.A. basketball team and athletic department are on the defensive, rebutting a Sports Illustrated article about alleged serious player discipline problems. The article by George Dohrmann was published Wednesday and detailed alleged partying, drug and alcohol abuse, fights between current and former players and the failure to maintain discipline by Coach Ben Howland.

headline: Jazz Musicians Expand Pension Protest
text: The musicians’ union for New York City has begun an advertising campaign and plans to expand protests outside of jazz clubs as part of its efforts to win pension benefits for jazz artists, union leaders said Thursday.

headline: European Leaders Challenged by Rise in Joblessness
text: BRUSSELS — At their first summit meeting in recent memory at which financial markets were not baying at the door, European leaders on Thursday sought to show they could confront the social cost of fighting the sovereign debt crisis, whose severity was underlined by new jobless figures that hit a euro-era high.

headline: Driving School Owners Charged in Test Cheating Scheme
text: He said he knew little to no English. Not a problem, he was told. But the driving test was in English, he said in his native Mandarin, so how could he possibly pass?

headline: The Perils of Coming of Age in a Trailer Park
text: It takes real talent to make something beautiful out of a trailer park. “Girlchild,” Tupelo Hassman’s lacerating debut novel, is the story of Rory Dawn Hendrix, a young girl growing up in the Calle, a cluster of mobile homes on a plot of dust outside Reno, Nev. Ms. Hassman is such a poised storyteller that her prose practically struts. Her words are as elegant as they are fierce. A voice as fresh as hers is so rare that at times I caught myself cheering, and it wasn’t necessarily for the kid.

headline: Guest Post | Tools and Tips for World Read-Aloud Day
text: Are Read Across America Day (on March 2) and World Read Aloud Day (on March 7) on your calendar this year? If not, we hope you’ll consider adding them — especially after hearing what this guest blogger has to say about the many interesting ways the age-old activity of reading aloud can be reconceived for 2012.

headline: A Parent Says: Enough of the Blame Game With Teachers
text: The teacher data reports have been released. Now what? A parent at Public School 321 in Park Slope says that for starters, "we must stop these attacks on our teachers.  It is no way to treat one another  and it is no way to improve education.''

headline: Tutoring Services Providers Must Be Held to Higher Standards
text: State education officials should be setting performance standards for private and nonprofit companies that provide tutoring services to children in low-performing schools, instead of trying to get the federal government to let them use tutoring funds for other services, the writer says.

headline: Behind the Crackdown on Insider Trading
text: If anyone had not already realized it, insider trading is the “hot” white-collar crime these days. Look no further than the new public service announcement by Michael Douglas — and his character Gordon Gekko — disclaiming that “greed is good” by encouraging tips to the F.B.I. about insider trading.

headline: Apps to Stem the Flood of Catalogs and Junk Mail
text: Last fall, I wrote about a service from Catalog Choice that helps you reduce unwanted catalogs and junk mail by using snail mail.

headline: Vikings Finally Have Deal on Stadium
text: After years of fits and starts, the Minnesota Vikings moved a big step closer to having a new home when the state’s top political leaders unveiled a tentative agreement to build a $975 million stadium next to the aging Metrodome in Minneapolis.

headline: M. Wells Owners Plan a Steakhouse in Queens
text: Hugue Dufour and Sarah Obraitis, the married couple who owned M. Wells — the wildly popular diner-style restaurant in Long Island City, Queens, that lost its lease and closed last summer — plan to open a new restaurant in the same neighborhood in late fall.

headline: ‘American Idol’ Tops Wednesday Ratings
text: A two-hour edition of “American Idol” – which focused on the top 12 female performers – provided another easy ratings win for Fox on Wednesday. According to Nielsen estimates, the singing competition averaged just over 17 million viewers, although it suffered another slight drop in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic when compared to last week. The downward trend for “Idol” in adults 18-to-49 has allowed “Modern Family” on ABC to get within striking distance in the advertiser-beloved category; it was just one tenth of a ratings point below “Idol.”

headline: A Well-Deserved Defeat for the Religious Right
text: I was glad to see the Senate defeat the Blunt amendment today, rejecting an attempt by religious conservatives to weaken the separation of church and state.

headline: My Bumpy Night at Roberta’s
text: You know that moment when a server circles back to your table to ask if everything is all right? Usually they do this within a minute or two after placing the plate in front of you. Sometimes they do it so soon you haven’t even had a chance to taste the food.

headline: Reform Bill Scaled Back as Italians Apply Politics
text: ROME — The Italian Senate on Thursday approved a set of measures aimed at fostering economic growth, but critics said that some proposals had been watered down, a sign of the roadblocks facing Prime Minister Mario Monti as he tries to turn around Italy’s stagnant economy.

headline: Bundesbank Fears Risks in European Central Bank Lending Policy
text: FRANKFURT — A day after the European Central Bank showered the Continent’s banking system with cash, the German central bank appeared to be growing more openly restive about the risk of lending to banks that would go out of business without access to cheap money.

headline: Life of a ‘Salesman’
text: The veteran stage actor Bill Camp talks about his performance in Arthur Miller’s classic play.

headline: Monster Worldwide Puts Itself in Play
text: Shares of Monster Worldwide surged on Thursday after the company’s chief executive said that the board and management were pursuing “strategic alternatives to increasing shareholder value.”

headline: AT&T Sets Clearer Limits on ‘Unlimited’ Plans
text: AT&T has clarified the limits of its unlimited data plan. The company on Thursday published a Web page describing what kind of data use might lead to customers being throttled, or having their data connections slowed down.

headline: A Wild-Card Snub and the Expectation of Local Preference
text: While the nomadic nature of the professional tennis tours does not allow for any player to establish a firm home-court advantage, preference to native players in terms of wild cards and scheduling has become an accepted and expected part of the sport.

headline: Restaurant to Pay Workers in Wage-Theft Case
text: A West Village hookah lounge and restaurant has agreed to pay $200,000 in back wages and penalties for underpaying about 25 employees, many of them immigrants, and firing two workers who reported the violations to the authorities, the New York attorney general announced in a statement on Thursday.

headline: Chita Rivera Will Be a Suspect When ‘Mystery of Edwin Drood’ Returns
text: Chita Rivera will return to Broadway as Princess Puffer in a new production of Rupert Holmes’s musical “The Mystery of Edwin Drood,” marking its first return to Broadway since its 1986 Tony Awards triumph.

headline: New Plan: Yankees Look to Cut Payroll
text: TAMPA, Fla. — Strange rumblings about fiscal restraint and lower payrolls have been emanating from the Yankees for several months, and Hal Steinbrenner, the managing general partner of the team, confirmed Thursday that he wants the payroll to be cut by about $20 million, down to the critical threshold of $189 million, within two years.

headline: Quandary Considered: Talking With Teenagers (and Their Parents) About Guns
text: Last Friday, I wrote about a quandary that I thought of as something we all share: the question of talking to our teenagers and older children, and the parents of the teenagers and older children around us, about guns.

headline: Cellphone Interference
text: I went on a long walk with a friend I’ve known for ages. She made innumerable cellphone calls. She worried about: the modest cost of an upcoming trip, whether she should negotiate a lower price on the cabin, the destination, whether her companion would enjoy herself, and wrapping up plans. I was fed up and exhausted, and we were an hour from home. Finally, I said: “I don’t want to get involved. This is your bad trip.” This happens fairly often with her. Should I throw in the towel?

headline: 10 Questions With Rick Santorum
text: After losses in Arizona and Michigan, the Republican presidential candidate Rick Santorum seeks new momentum for next week’s Super Tuesday contests. Mr. Santorum, the former Pennsylvania senator, aims to move beyond controversies over his views on social issues and emphasize economic proposals — including his signature idea of eliminating corporate taxes for manufacturing firms. Before flying to Washington state, he sat down in an Atlanta airport on Thursday with John Harwood of The Times and CNBC. What follows is a condensed, edited version of their conversation. (Full video, divided by chapter.)

headline: TimesCast | Conservative Blogger Dies
text: March 1, 2012 - Andrew Breitbart, a conservative activist who published undercover videos and revealing photographs aimed at liberals and Democrats, died at the age of 43.

headline: Teachers Find Errors in Data Reports, but Record Will Remain
text: Teachers have found many errors in their data reports, and city education officials acknowledge that the rankings are imprecise. Still, the records will probably remain as they were reported a week ago, as a permanent assessment of teacher performance.

headline: In Knots
text: Writing in Salon in 2009, Laura Miller noted that the canon favors books about “men in boats” over “women in houses,” and it’s true: the boat is the beloved vessel of the Great American Novel. There’s also the road, the battlefield, the ball field, the farm, but for better or worse, from “Moby-Dick” to “Spartina,” nothing has captured the Odyssean spirit of the American story — or the splendor and ravages of testosterone — like a boat traveling through open waters. Unless it’s that other favorite setting, the boarding school.

headline: In Filings, Disney Rebuffs Criticism of Shareholders Advisory Service
text: LOS ANGELES — The Walt Disney Company on Thursday went on the attack against a shareholder advisory service that earlier in the week criticized the entertainment conglomerate’s management structure and the compensation it awards its chief executive, Robert A. Iger.

text: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of the Fall 2012 Fashion Week in Paris. Here, the model Ming Xi of Ford Models before (left) and after (right) transforms, with makeup by Lucia Pieroni and hair by Luigi Murenu.

text: CHARDON, Ohio — Prosecutors on Thursday formally filed murder charges against T. J. Lane, the teenager accused of methodically killing three students and wounding two others in a shooting rampage on Monday in a high school cafeteria east of Cleveland.

headline: Death of Man Hit by Train Not a Suicide, Medical Examiner Says

headline: A Father and Son Reunion on the Way to the Abyss
text: Early in “Being Flynn,” the new movie directed by Paul Weitz, Jonathan Flynn slides behind the wheel of a yellow cab as his voice, on the soundtrack, gives vent to a barrage of misanthropy. It is hard for a movie lover not to detect a wink in this otherwise perfectly ordinary scene, since Jonathan is played by Robert De Niro, the most famous taxi driver in movies. “Being Flynn” is a much milder movie than “Taxi Driver,” pursuing intimate themes rather than big ideas, but Jonathan Flynn and Travis Bickle are linked by the discrepancy between self-image and reality and also by Mr. De Niro’s gift for portraying alienated men at odds with themselves.

headline: High School Admissions on Twitter
text: Eighth graders in New York City schools took to social media to share their high school admissions decisions, anxieties, disappointments.

headline: High School Admissions:  'When I Opened My Envelope, I Was Shaking'
text: More than 77,000 eighth graders learned over the last two days where they will be going to high school in the quintessentially New York process of matching students to schools. One student who got into her first choice, Pace High School, said "I'm still shaking from happiness.''

headline: Pictures of the Day: India and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from India, Syria, the Maldives and Ohio.

headline: From Styles: Online Shopping’s Makeover
text: An article in Thursday’s Styles section looks at the way various virtual-closet Web sites like Pintrest, Clothia and Stylitics are changing the way we shop online.

text: A new exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, explores the intertwined collections of the siblings Leo, Gertrude and Michael Stein.

text: Like the family it chronicles, “The Steins Collect: Matisse, Picasso and the Parisian Avant-Garde,” at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, is fragmented and contentious, with flashes of brilliance.

headline: Flex-Fuel Amendment Makes for Strange Bedfellows
text: Faced with a bill that would require 80 percent of gasoline-burning cars and trucks to be compatible with ethanol and methanol by the 2018 model year, stakeholders who typically disagree on critical issues find themselves in a rare position. They agree.

headline: Riders on the Storm
text: It is an almost inviolable rule that Hollywood attempts at surf movies are not received well by surfers. Part of it has to do with a studio tendency toward surf tropes and clichés (“Cowabunga!” “Hang Ten!”). More of it has to do with the nature of the sport itself: it breeds localism. Not just the xenophobic, occasionally violent expressions of localism that enforce the pecking order, but, more prevalent, a fierce love of place. To learn the personality of a particular wave is to become intimate with the contours of a landscape, to map that landscape and make it yours. Surfers will say that the character of a break influences the local culture. In other words, a filmmaker who wishes to get a surf spot right by its locals has his work cut out for him.

headline: French Journalists Escape Syria for Lebanon
text: Updated | 6:11 p.m. Two French journalists who were trapped inside the Syrian city of Homs for more than a week arrived safely in Lebanon on Thursday, according to Le Figaro, the newspaper for which they both work.

headline: Jazz Listings
text: Jazz

headline: A Hidden Fee Is Set to Rise
text: INSIDE the interest rate quoted on your home mortgage lies a small hidden fee that has been charged by government-sponsored entities like Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac for more than three decades. It’s an add-on rate known as the guarantee fee.

headline: Midas Touch in St. Petersburg: Friends of Putin Glow Brightly
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Russia — Arkady R. Rotenberg, a former judo coach, is now a billionaire industrialist, having made a fortune selling pipe to the state-owned gas monopoly, Gazprom.

headline: Israel Plans Interceptor Missile Test and Gives Neighbors Early Notice
text: JERUSALEM — Israel, in an unusual move, announced on Thursday that it would soon conduct the first test of an advanced antiballistic missile system designed to intercept incoming missiles from enemies like Syria and Iran.

headline: You Don’t Mess With Them
text: People are wondering how the Christian right will react to the new ABC comedy “GCB,” based on a novel called “Good Christian Bitches,” but it’s a silly question. Long before there was a Bible Belt, this kind of woman was in the Bible — Jezebel was the first true mean girl (Revelation 2:20).

headline: I’ll Be Your Mirror, Or Maybe Your Killer
text: In the first moments of “Beautiful Bone,” a duet choreographed and performed by Molly Lieber and Eleanor Smith, Ms. Lieber clutches Ms. Smith’s head to her breast. The gesture is tender and aggressive, an embrace and a smothering. The ambiguity is arresting, and the remainder of the dance, which had its debut at the Chocolate Factory on Wednesday, sustains it.

headline: Jerusalem Under Siege, a Sorceress Intervenes
text: CHICAGO — Given the current bloody turmoil in the Middle East you could imagine an opera director seizing on Handel’s “Rinaldo” for its contemporary relevance. The story tells of Christian forces during the First Crusade, led by their determined general, Goffredo, and the heroic knight Rinaldo, as they lay siege to Jerusalem to take down its king, Argante. The formidable king is abetted by and enamored of Armida, the imperious queen of Damascus, an expert in sorcery.

headline: From Bucks: Apps to Cut Down Catalog Clutter
text: Our colleagues over at Bucks, The Times’s personal-finance blog, have a cool post on apps that can help cut down on catalog junk mail.

headline: Rising Even While Seated
text: The tenor saxophonist Ted Brown remained seated during his first set at the Kitano Hotel in Murray Hill on Wednesday night, and his playing often felt so retiring and interior that it barely met the minimum requirements for performance. This was a matter of aesthetic inclination, as Mr. Brown demonstrated in the finer moments of the set. You might have caught yourself leaning slightly forward then, as if to catch the nuance of an absorbing story gently told.

headline: Sizing Up Health Impacts a Year After Fukushima
text: Health impacts from the radioactive materials released in the Fukushima Daiichi meltdowns will probably be too small to be easily measured, according to experts assembled by the Health Physics Society for a panel discussion on Thursday. And the area cordoned off by the Japanese government as uninhabitable is probably far too large, the experts said.

headline: Theater Listings: March 2 — 8
text: Theater

headline: In Arizona, the Bigoted Birther is Back
text: There is an argument that it’s best to ignore crazy people. You have nothing to gain by reasoning with the guy on the subway shouting about the end of the world. But what if the crazy guy’s a prominent law enforcer, and what if he’s shouting about the president of the United States?

headline: Serving Nostalgia at Nitehawk Cinema and IFC Center
text: If you watched last Sunday’s Academy Awards show, you’d know that going to the movies means different things to different people. For Reese Witherspoon, growing up, it was a family outing; for Brad Pitt, it was an escape from reality. For Matthew Viragh, owner of the Nitehawk Cinema, which opened in the Williamsburg neighborhood of Brooklyn last June, it’s nostalgia.

headline: Conversations With the Stars of the Movie ‘Goon’
text: Just in time to join the debate about fighting in hockey, along comes the comedy “Goon,” the No. 1 movie in Canada and now available on demand to American cable subscribers ahead of its theatrical opening on March 30.

headline: Cracking the Curious Case of Picasso’s Ghost Subject
text: A 1904 Picasso hanging in the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum in New York depicts a skeletal woman, her eyes hollow, her cheeks sunken as she presses down with all her might on an iron. The painting, “Woman Ironing,” from Picasso’s Blue Period, has long been considered one of the institution’s most important works. It has also been one of its greatest mysteries. For years conservators have known that beneath the surface lies the ghost of a figure — a three-quarter-length view of a man with a mustache — which Picasso had painted over.

headline: A Buyout Fund, First Backed by LVMH, Carves Its Own Niche
text: While it may share the same first letter as LVMH Moët Hennessy Louis Vuitton, and counts the French luxury conglomerate as an investor, L Capital would like everyone to know that it is its own firm.

headline: 36 Hours: Austin, Tex.
text: THE laid-back capital of Texas has long been a haven for countercultural types, with tattoo artists, bohemian coeds and techies biking side by side along the glistening shores of Lady Bird Lake. But these days, Austin is more chic than shabby. New upscale restaurants — many that rely on local, organic ingredients — are popping up all over the city, along with bars featuring artisanal concoctions. Meanwhile, the South by Southwest (SXSW) music, film and interactive festival (this year March 9 to 18) continues to draw an affluent crowd of technology geeks and celebrities. On April 27 to 29, Food and Wine Magazine will court foodies with its first culinary fête in Texas. Then, in November, the Circuit of the Americas Formula One track will open, drawing race car fans from around the world. But the old Austin isn’t hard to find: You can still hear the twang of a country guitar in many doorways and chug of Lone Star at just about any bar.

headline: 36 Hours in Austin, Tex.
text: New upscale restaurants and bars are popping up all over the city, but the old Austin isn’t hard to find.

headline: Andrew Carnegie Was Here
text: ANDREW CARNEGIE’S colossal, understated mansion at Fifth Avenue and 91st Street is closed until 2013 while the current resident, the Cooper-Hewitt museum, renovates the interior. The last of the Carnegies left the 1902 house in 1946, but Carnegie, a steel magnate, affected a much wider swath of his hill than just his Fifth Avenue blockfront.

text: An ad ran by Mitt Romney's 1994 campaign for Senate, attacking Ted Kennedy's record on jobs.

headline: In Paris, Celebrating Karl Lagerfeld
text: It’s easy to forget that in addition to Chanel, Fendi and his newly reintroduced signature collection, Karl Lagerfeld, for the last four seasons, has also designed a collection for Hogan, a division of the luxury Italian footwear company Tod’s. Mr. Lagerfeld makes multitasking look second nature, so his Hogan collection was the subject of a special celebration this evening in the midst of Paris Fashion Week.

text: The New York International Children’s Film Festival has grown into a supremely confident teenager.

headline: A Sale of Knives by an Eccentric Maker
text: The reclusive blacksmith William W. Scagel lived off the grid in the woods near Muskegon, Mich. From the 1920s to the ’60s, he manufactured luxury knives there, with ergonomically curved horn and antler handles, powering his home and workshop with a windmill, old submarine batteries and a Cadillac engine.

headline: NBC News to Expand Presence on Radio
text: NBC News, the top-rated network news division on television, is eying growth opportunities in an old-fashioned medium, radio.

headline: Sculptures That Answer Back
text: It sounds like a cliché to say that the radicalism of art from the ’60s and early ’70s has often been sanitized from art history. But you get an idea of what was considered feasible — and what’s been left out of the canon — when you look at the work of Juan Downey.

headline: We’re Fabulous, but Are You?
text: In recent years Eric Fischl has displayed a remarkable obliviousness to possible perceptions of his work. In 2000 he created a memorial to the tennis star Arthur Ashe in the form of a giant, Rodinesque bronze sculpture of a lumpy, naked man in the act of serving. Installed outdoors at the National Tennis Center in Flushing Meadows, Queens, it became for many fans of the game a source of consternation that the figure was nude, did not resemble Ashe and held in one hand only the stump of his racket.

headline: A Survey of a Different Color
text: One of the best Whitney Biennials in recent memory may or may not contain a lot more outstanding art than its predecessors, but that’s not the point. The 2012 incarnation is a new and exhilarating species of exhibition, an emerging curatorial life form, at least for New York.

headline: A Personal Landscape in Patagonia
text: Thick clouds hang low over the rugged landscape, where freshly-slaughtered pigs and lambs can be found just as easily as leather-faced men on horseback. Shadowy figures emerge from mist-covered paths, lending an air of mystery to Jorge Uzon’s images of remote towns in Chile’s Patagonia region. Rendered in black and white, his photographs feel quiet and intimate.

headline: Collecting Emotion, and Not in Tranquillity
text: Paula Van der Oest’s “Black Butterflies” is a rending biographical portrait of the poet Ingrid Jonker, who has been called the South African Sylvia Plath because both women destroyed themselves at an early age and had what might be called “daddy issues.” Plath was 30 when she died of carbon monoxide poisoning in 1963. Jonker drowned herself two years later at 31.

headline: Vietnam’s Nuclear Dreams Blossom Despite Doubts
text: HANOI, Vietnam — Inside an unheated classroom at the Institute for Nuclear Science and Technology here about 20 young government technicians from Vietnam’s incipient nuclear power industry kept on their winter jackets on the first morning of a 10-day workshop on radiation.

headline: A Bold Plan to Reshape the Central Valley Flood Plain
text: Jacob Katz stood shin-deep in a flooded rice paddy that is often dried out at this time of year. He thrust his hand into a writhing mass of baby salmon in his net and plucked three of the silver fry from the wind-whipped water’s surface.

headline: Stations File Suit Against Diller’s Internet Distribution Company
text: Local television stations in New York filed two lawsuits on Thursday against Aereo, a start-up company backed by Barry Diller’s IAC/InterActiveCorp that seeks to distribute the stations via the Internet to paying subscribers.

headline: Trading Up Amid the Bulldozers
text: EVERY now and then when a new furnished model would open at Meadowbrook Pointe, an age-restricted condominium community of flats, town houses and villas in Westbury that will eventually have 720 units, Carol Uffer would stroll over from her two-bedroom villa within the complex to take a look.

headline: Longing for the Beauty That Is Rome in the Form of Earthly Goddesses
text: Gianni, the gentle mama’s boy and alter ego of Gianni Di Gregorio, the 63-year-old director and star of the wistful Italian comedy “The Salt of Life,” is every man who reaches a certain age and feels his vitality waning. Gazing into the mirror, he notices the heavy bags under his eyes and his sagging chin and is seized with a longing for his lost youth.

headline: Revising the Limits for the Unlimited
text: Sometimes, all-you-can-eat does not mean all you can eat.
