headline: ‘Rehab’ Loans to the Rescue
text: AFTER months of searching for a mother-daughter home that they could afford in the Bergen County town where they were renting, Adrian and Rosanna Mercado came upon a Victorian with enough room for them to live upstairs and Mrs. Mercado’s parents to live on the first floor. The only problem was that the century-old house was in serious need of repairs.

headline: The Extraordinary, Glimpsed in the Ordinary
text: These are not the parts of New York City that fire the imagination: salad bars, subway entrances, roll-down security gates, the stairs of the M15 bus, open truck windows from which drivers’ thick elbows hang like Sunday hams.

headline: Obesity and the Military: A Retired General’s View
text: To the Editor:

headline: ‘Miracle’ Leads to Pairing With Woods and Westwood
text: PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla. — On Wednesday night Miguel Angel Carballo sent a message to his fans that said, “I need a miracle.”

headline: Tracing the Great Recession to a Memo 40 Years Ago
text: “Heist: Who Stole the American Dream?” is a documentary polemic that comes out swinging. Immediately after the film’s opening scene of an Occupy Wall Street demonstration, a chipper narrator announces:

headline: Back to the ’70s, When a Traffic Jam Could Be Art
text: “Do you feel that?” Constance Lewallen, a curator at the Berkeley Art Museum and Pacific Film Archive, said to a group of journalists and students. The crowd, gathered just inside the museum entrance, stopped, looking perplexed.

headline: Adult Responsibilities, but a Child’s Sensibility
text: Next year’s Oscars, if they were to include the just-for-fun idea of outstanding performance by a setting, should have a nominee in “Boy.” This movie from New Zealand, filmed in a Maori village near the Bay of Plenty, belongs in the pantheon of quaint and quirky locales that make for memorable films.

headline: Justin Kurzel on 'The Snowtown Murders'
text: The director Justin Kurzel discusses his film about the case of a serial killer in Australia.

headline: Home-Court Edge Begins With Ball
text: Before each season, the managers for the U.C.L.A. men’s basketball team do not compile reports on opposing players or strategies. Instead, they are responsible for figuring out the brand of basketball used by the Bruins’ opponents.

headline: Expanded Playoffs Coming for 2012
text: VIERA, Fla. – Mark DeRosa, the veteran infielder for the Washington Nationals, had just finished praising baseball’s expanded playoff field Thursday when he realized he did not know the format would work. Told that each league will now feature a play-in game between two wild cards, DeRosa took a moment to absorb the idea.

headline: The Unfinished Fight Over Contraception
text: CAN we still be arguing about a woman’s ability to control her own fertility? Almost 50 years ago in Griswold v. Connecticut, the Supreme Court struck down state restrictions on contraception because they violated a right to privacy. But the issue has not gone away. Rick Santorum injected it into the presidential race by indicating that Griswold should be overturned so that states could ban contraception altogether. And the Senate just voted down a Republican effort to allow employers and health insurance companies to refuse coverage for contraceptives if they had moral or religious objections.

headline: At One McDonald’s, Even Calls to the Police Have Been Supersized
text: Scott James is a columnist for The Bay Citizen.

headline: A Boatload of Lore Smuggled From Cuba
text: More than half a century has passed since the Cuban Revolution, and for perhaps a generation American policy has tilted forward, anticipating the post-Castro era. But if Fulgencio Batista’s flight and Fidel Castro’s rise seem the stuff of newsreels (or  “The Godfather: Part II”) to most Americans, those convulsive early years of the Communist regime remain very present to those who fled the island.

headline: A Fragile Child Brings Her Parents a Strong Marriage
text: WHEN Chloe Kiev broke her arm on the monkey bars at Coleytown Elementary School in Westport, Conn., her parents were asked if they planned to sue. Those who have watched the marriage of Johanna and Marshall Kiev mature were not surprised at the response.

headline: Puppies, Paintings and Philosophers
text: DENVER

headline: 2012 Whitney Biennial
text: Images from the exhibition at the Whitney Museum of American Art in New York City.

headline: A Boy Pays for Mother’s Mistakes
text: “The Snowtown Murders,” an Australian true-crime story that’s unrelenting in its singular vision of suburban rot and teenage vulnerability, is at times very tough to watch. But for those who do, this distressing infiltration of a family of young boys by a charismatic psychopath rewards with a stylistic talent that feels entirely new.

headline: Bullfighter’s Return Stuns a Hardened Sport
text: MADRID — Five months after surviving a horrifying goring, Juan José Padilla, one of Spain’s leading bullfighters, wears a patch over his left eye and cannot chew any food, even after a series of surgeries to reconstruct part of his face.

headline: Will Wall Street Ever Face Justice?
text: Sacramento

headline: When the Math Says ‘Buy’
text: AS a creature of habit, Monica Giannelli was content to remain in the Greenwich Village apartment where she had lived for 10 years, ever since arriving in New York.

headline: 3 Ex-Nassau County Officers Accused of Failing to Arrest Police Fund-Raiser’s Son
text: Three former high-ranking officials of the Nassau County Police Department were indicted Thursday on charges that they failed to arrest a student suspected of stealing more than $10,000 in electronic equipment from his high school because he was the son of a prominent police fund-raiser.

headline: A Robin Hood in a Chinese Western
text: Despite its wealth of talent and unflagging energy, the Chinese action comedy “Let the Bullets Fly” could have trouble translating its home box-office success to Western shores. At least 30 minutes and several scams too long, the plot passes from amusing to confounding long before the final double-cross.

headline: House Passes Bridge Bill After an Earmark Debate
text: WASHINGTON — The House overwhelmingly approved legislation Thursday to allow construction of a new $700 million bridge between Minnesota and Wisconsin, a project that has drawn comparisons to earmarks and required a Congressional exemption from a landmark environmental law.

headline: Humbled, but Still Short of Humility
text: PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla.

headline: Welcome to Uganda. Please Look Around.
text: Not quite a travelogue, not quite an art show, Kimi Takesue’s “Where Are You Taking Me?” is a cinematic trip to Uganda that explores both the viewed and the viewer.

headline: Slate to Begin a Monthly Review of Books
text: Slate will introduce a monthly book review on Friday, the latest expansion of literary criticism online as stand-alone book review sections in newspapers have dwindled.

headline: Growing Old Single
text: The percentage of unmarried older Americans has been rising. More than one-third of baby boomers are either divorced or never married.

headline: Getting Bobby to Come Out and Play
text: Unexpectedly flouting its doomy title, “Last Days Here” invests the standard, washed-up rock-star tale with surprising sweetness. Observing the drug-fueled descent and attempted resuscitation of Bobby Liebling, the self-destructive frontman of the 1970s metal band Pentagram, Don Argott and Demian Fenton’s unfussy documentary hopes for redemption in the way that comedy movies hope for a best picture award. Which is to say, very cautiously.

headline: Santorum, Defender of Free Market, Pushed in Congress to Protect Big Steel
text: WASHINGTON — As he seeks the Republican nomination for the presidency, Rick Santorum has presented himself as a defender of the free market and opponent of bailouts for Wall Street and the auto industry, saying he has been consistent in putting his principles ahead of political pressures.

headline: Habitats | Kew Gardens, Queens
text: Murray and Carol Berger moved to their four-bedroom house in Kew Gardens, Queens, in 1957.

headline: A Whole-Hearted, Hands-On Life
text: IN 1957, when Murray and Carol Berger moved to a red brick house with white columns in Kew Gardens, Queens, the neighborhood was considered highly desirable. Gracious brick and Tudor homes sat behind lush front lawns. Towering pin oaks, planted when the community was founded in 1910, lined quiet winding streets. The commute to Manhattan — just 16 minutes to Penn Station aboard the Long Island Rail Road — couldn’t have been easier.

headline: Making a Print and Making a Statement
text: Watching Manfred Kirchheimer’s “Art Is ... the Permanent Revolution” you might be reminded at first of airless instructional art programs on public television: three printmakers — Paul Marcus, a woodcutter; Sigmund Abeles, a painter and etcher; and Ann Chernow, a painter and lithographer — quietly discuss the role of artists as sociopolitical commentators while each prepares a piece. Mr. Marcus’s concerns military torture; Mr. Abeles’s presents suicide bombers; Ms. Chernow renders a cemetery tableau about oil and war. Each also explains the chosen technique as the film (and their work) progresses.

headline: Erwin Frankel Dies at 76; Brought World Music to U.S.
text: Erwin Frankel, a radio host and concert promoter who broadened the American cultural palette by introducing audiences to Andean pan flute music, the whirling dervishes of Turkey, and the notion of belly dancing as an art form fit for Carnegie Hall, died on Feb. 18 in New York City. He was 76.

headline: Pletcher Loses a Derby Favorite but Retains Hope
text: Todd Pletcher says that he is handling his stable’s latest setback just fine, that he has learned never to dwell on the negative. Or maybe he has just grown used to getting bad news at the worst possible time.

headline: That Screaming in Washington, Again
text: Brian Malone’s documentary “Patriocracy” feels as if it were made by someone who had been out of the country since the Clinton administration and upon re-entering was shocked at the polarized, dysfunctional state of the federal government. It spends a long time telling us what anyone who has been paying even a little attention to public life already knows: that politicians have paralyzed the legislative process with a rancorous sort of trench warfare.

headline: Devastated Towns Regroup
text: Residents sifted through piles of debris where their houses had stood a day after a powerful storm system tore through parts of the Midwest and South.

headline: Yelp Prices Its Offering at $15 a Share
text: Yelp, the online hub for local business reviews, priced its initial public offering at $15 a share on Thursday, above its expected range.

headline: Awaiting a ‘Trash to Treasure’ Moment
text: NICK BLANCHARD tells the story of the Hollywood location scouts who came calling on his parents one day, in their clapboard house at 4144 Victory Boulevard in Travis, on the west shore of Staten Island.

headline: Looking Ahead to Dying Young
text: Churning out his propulsive garage punk from the age of 15, Jimmy Lee Lindsey Jr., better known by the stage name Jay Reatard, made music as though aware that he wouldn’t be around for very long.

headline: Serbia, Once Outcast, Is Candidate to Join E.U.
text: BRUSSELS — Serbia formally became a candidate for European Union membership late Thursday in a significant advance for the nation, once ostracized for its role in the Balkan wars of the 1990s.

headline: Braun’s Lawyer Critical of Collector in Drug Test
text: Ryan Braun, it appears, does not want to talk anymore about the collector who took his urine sample last October that ultimately turned out to be positive.

headline: A Teenage ‘Home Alone’ Gone Wild
text: The Oscars are swell, but once in a while a film comes along that is so courageous it deserves consideration for the Nobel Prize. An entire generation has been born and gone to college since the Beastie Boys defined that most basic of civil liberties: You’ve got to fight for your right to party. The makers of “Project X,” knowing how short the teenage memory is, have now boldly, raunchily made the declaration again, preventing millions of young people from growing up without understanding that every 17-year-old is entitled to a drunken, deafening, topless, drug-filled, sex-crazed, property-destroying, life-endangering birthday.

headline: The Machiavellian Temptation
text: In the 19th century, there was a hydraulic model of how to be a good person. There are all these torrents of passion flowing through you. Your job, as captain of your soul, is to erect dams to keep these passions in check. Your job is to just say no to sloth, lust, greed, drug use and the other sins.

headline: 50th Anniversary of a Scoring Feat That’s as Much Legend as Record
text: When Wilt Chamberlain scored 100 points against the Knicks on March 2, 1962, he did so in semi-obscurity. There were no televisions cameras, few reporters and only 4,124 spectators at Hershey (Pa.) Sports Arena, where Chamberlain’s Philadelphia Warriors occasionally played home games.

headline: In a Yearlong Test, iPads Will Replace TVs in the Back Seats of Some Cabs
text: Two major additions are coming to the city’s taxis: iPads and more ads.

headline: For Obama and Netanyahu, Wariness on Iran Will Dominate Talks
text: JERUSALEM — Nearly four years ago, when Senator Barack Obama was running for president and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel was head of the opposition, they met here in what aides described as a warm atmosphere.

headline: More Americans Rejecting Marriage in 50s and Beyond
text: On the day she decided to sell her wedding ring, Katie Dunn tucked the gleaming band into a Ziploc bag. The ring had been designed for her nearly two decades earlier, with swirls of yellow and white gold symbolizing the romance she had prayed would endure. But as she approached her 60s, her dreams and her marriage dissolved in resentment and regret.

headline: A Rebel’s Tale
text: A Bollywood screenwriter might blush to come up with the story of a national champion runner who becomes more famous as an outlaw. But Tigmanshu Dhulia’s uneven, absorbing Hindi film “Paan Singh Tomar,” based on real events, falls into the category of truth is stranger than cinema.

headline: Four Fiscal Phonies
text: Mitt Romney is very concerned about budget deficits. Or at least that’s what he says; he likes to warn that President Obama’s deficits are leading us toward a “Greece-style collapse.”

headline: Back to Nature With Wii and Cheez-Its
text: “The Woods,” Matthew Lessner’s satirical look at consumerist technoslackers who drop out of society and hope to start something of their own — a commune? a movement? — by heading back to nature in the Pacific Northwest is good for a handful of sight gags. An early shot of a young man unwinding an endless orange extension cord as he walks into the forest announces what’s ahead.

headline: Mets Prospect and Ace Share Road to Recovery
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — These two pitchers stand far, far apart in the baseball life cycle.

headline: A Bar That Survived Prohibition Is Set to Be Uprooted Over a Lease
text: Wednesday night was like any other at Bill’s Gay Nineties Restaurant and Piano Bar on the East Side of Manhattan.

headline: Robert R. McElroy Dies at 84; Documented Art ‘Happenings’
text: Robert R. McElroy, a photographer who documented the evanescent when he snapped hundreds of images of the Happenings art movement, a free-spirited blend of art and performance in the late 1950s and early ’60s, died on Feb. 22 at an assisted-living center in White Plains. He was 84.

headline: The Sun Shines Again in Miami
text: MIAMI

headline: Why Iran’s Election Is a Farce
text: Paris

headline: A Bad Amendment Defeated
text: Only one Senate Republican — Olympia Snowe of Maine, who is retiring — voted against a truly horrible measure on Thursday that would have crippled the expansion of preventive health care in America. The amendment, which was attached to a highway bill, was defeated on a narrow 48-to-51 vote. But it showed once again how far from the mainstream Republicans have strayed in their relentless efforts to undermine the separation of church and state, deny women access to essential health services and tear apart President Obama’s health care reform law.

headline: Home for Good
text: Los Angeles County is often called the national capital of homelessness, with more than 51,000 people lacking shelter on any given night. Homelessness there has proved to be a very tough problem to solve, especially with governments so short of revenue. But Home for Good, a collaboration by governments, businesses and charitable groups announced last month that it was making progress toward the goal of ending chronic and veteran homelessness in the county by 2016.

headline: For Many Asian New Yorkers, Smoking Is Still a Way of Life
text: On a cool, damp afternoon in Flushing, Queens, Seung Jun stood outside on Main Street on Thursday, a smoker among his peers. He unsheathed a Parliament and took a long drag, as though he were taking in a breath of relief.

headline: Novak Another Out-of-Nowhere Sensation
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Steve Novak is 28 and stands 6 feet 10 inches, and as he gets ready for the Knicks’ next game on Sunday, he is just a few 3-pointers away from being a full-fledged cult hero. Or maybe he already is.

headline: Beth Israel to Pay $13 Million for Inflating Medicare Fees
text: Beth Israel Medical Center has admitted that it fraudulently inflated its fees for services to Medicare patients, deliberately deceiving the federal government into paying many millions of dollars more than their treatments actually cost.

headline: Romney Reopens Whatever-It-Takes Playbook
text: When Gov. Rick Perry began rising in the polls, Mitt Romney was ready with a potent debate-night assault: under Mr. Perry, illegal immigrants in Texas received a $100,000 tuition break.

headline: Where the Jobs Are, the Training May Not Be
text: As state funding has dwindled, public colleges have raised tuition and are now resorting to even more desperate measures — cutting training for jobs the economy needs most.

headline: Andrew Breitbart, Conservative Blogger, Dies at 43
text: Andrew Breitbart, a conservative blogger and activist who built a national media persona  by putting undercover video on the Internet to bring discredit and disgrace to his liberal targets, died on Thursday in Los Angeles. He was 43.

headline: Greek Crisis May Test the Value of Swaps
text: The restructuring of Greece’s debt that is scheduled to start next week may well demonstrate how effective credit-default swaps are.

headline: The Speaker and the Rainmaker
text: Once again the mighty campaign dollar trumps all. On Saturday, Speaker John Boehner is scheduled to gather in Florida with rich Republican donors, shoulder to shoulder with Representative Vern Buchanan, who is leading the fund-raising of House Republican candidates nationwide.

headline: Azerbaijan’s Leaders Yield After a Rare Public Protest
text: MOSCOW — In a rare outbreak of civil unrest in Azerbaijan, a crowd of angry protesters massed outside the home of a provincial governor on Thursday, demanding his ouster as the house was consumed in flames, apparently the result of an arson attack. The national government responded by dismissing the governor.

headline: Not What Albany Needs
text: For the second year in a row, Gov. Andrew Cuomo appears to have wrestled New York State’s budget into shape, this time sparing more devastating cuts to the state’s neediest schools and hospitals. Even the state comptroller, Thomas DiNapoli, who is often at odds with Mr. Cuomo, reported recently that, over all, the new budget proposal for 2012-13 “made progress toward aligning state spending with revenue on a recurring basis.”

headline: Successful in Business, and Tied to Putin
text: Some of Vladimir Putin’s friends and family who have become wealthy during his years as Russia’s leader.

headline: The Monkey House Ends a 111-Year Run in the Bronx, a Victim of Zoo Evolution
text: Jose Ortiz, a 50-year-old taxi driver who grew up a few blocks from the Bronx Zoo, remembers how young he was when the creatures in the Monkey House captured his imagination.

headline: Public Relations Defined, After an Energetic Public Discussion
text: AN effort to update the definition of public relations for an age of social media and spin doctors suggests why many people think the public relations industry could use some help with its public relations.

headline: A Devastated Town Regroups
text: Residents of Harrisburg, Ill., sifted through piles of debris a day after a powerful storm system tore through parts of the Midwest and South.

headline: Law Has Polling Firms Leery of Work in New Hampshire
text: New Hampshire’s attorney general is threatening legal action against some of the nation’s most prominent polling firms, invoking a state law against spreading negative information through poll questions in a way that could limit public opinion surveys in one of the nation’s most politically contested states.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: March 1, 2012

headline: Yankees Take a Break to Brush Up on Their Comedic Skills
text: TAMPA, Fla. — The Yankees went through their annual off-field team-bonding exercise Thursday, an annual spring rite that Manager Joe Girardi plans for his players to increase team camaraderie.

headline: Prom Night, Bloody Prom Night
text: O.K., everybody, please remember that we’re on our very best behavior tonight. There’ll be no hooting, no teasing, no smart-aleck remarks. We will not — I repeat not — make fun of the girl with the really bad reputation. Lord knows, the poor child has suffered enough already. Is that understood? Good. Now sit down and enjoy the show.

headline: Islands Unto Themselves
text: Administrivial New Puzzle Blog Alert! If you love doing cryptic crosswords, hopefully you’ve discovered the ones that Joshua Kosman and Henri Picciotto construct over at The Nation. Now, they’ve started a new blog called Word Salad, which will discuss the cryptic puzzles and more! Check it out here.

headline: A Round to Remember for Love
text: PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla. — In his 18th career start at the Honda Classic, Davis Love III equaled the course record of 64 at PGA National Resort and Spa. Love’s round included a hole-in-one at the par-3 fifth.

headline: Update on New York Redistricting
text: Each state must redraw its political maps to reflect the 2010 census, but New York, which has approved neither legislative nor Congressional districts for this year’s elections, is among the last to comply. Redistricting has become increasingly urgent because of the calendar; the state’s Congressional primary is scheduled for June 26, and its legislative primary for Sept. 11.

headline: Moving On, Santorum Avoids Mention of Michigan Delegate Issue
text: SPOKANE, Wash. — Rick Santorum implied Thursday night that he had won the primary on Tuesday in Michigan, where he actually lost the popular vote to Mitt Romney and, as of now, is behind him in delegates.

headline: When Game Changers Become Name Changers
text: Since the birth of professional athletics in the mid-19th century, athletes have made a habit of changing their names — to hide their ethnic heritage and to celebrate it, to draw attention and to remain anonymous, to proclaim everything from religious devotion to a desire for world peace to affection for the movie “Teen Wolf.”

headline: America’s Future
text: The Op-Ed columnist Thomas L. Friedman and Bill Gates discuss the future of American competitiveness, innovation and education and the state of the current political debate.

headline: Now a Knicks Backup, Davis Adapts
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Baron Davis had his first impressive outing as a Knick on Wednesday night against the Cavaliers, tallying 8 assists and 4 points in only 15 minutes.

headline: Joe Thompson Dies at 93; Helped Preserve the Black String Band
text: “I got the name of being a pretty good fiddle player,” Joe Thompson once said. “I even been to Carnegie Hall playing fiddle.”

headline: Manhattan’s Population Density, Past and Present
text: How population density in Manhattan has changed in the past 100 years.

headline: $51 for 2 Minutes: German Pay Phones Anger Troops
text: When Specialist Reynald Matias was heading to Afghanistan with his Army unit late last year, their chartered flight stopped to refuel at Leipzig-Halle Airport in Germany. During a brief layover, he called his wife in Tacoma, Wash., using his debit card on a pay phone in the terminal’s troops-only transit lounge.

headline: Should College Be for Everyone?
text: Should as many people as possible be encouraged to attend college, or is the value of  higher education exaggerated?

headline: Leaps of Faith
text: For the past three and a half years, Republicans have struggled to explain a great conundrum. If they are the party of authentic America with a mystical connection to the will of the people, then how, exactly, did Barack Obama get elected president?

headline: For Nazareth, a Loss Not Reflected in the Score
text: They lost their coach in January and will lose their school in June.

headline: How the Auto Industry Fared in February
text: How the auto industry, automakers and the most popular cars and trucks fared in February.

headline: In Patagonia, Caught Between Visions of the Future
text: COCHRANE, Chile — At the end of a 200-mile stretch of mostly unpaved highway, nearly impassable during the long winter months and only marginally better in summer, sits the quiet community of Cochrane.

headline: A Conservative Leader Was Less So in Congress
text: WASHINGTON — As president of the Club for Growth, the politically active free-market advocacy group, Chris Chocola wields tremendous power, rating members of Congress on their fiscally conservative purism. Those who fail to meet the club’s tests can expect a club-backed primary opponent, or at least a negative advertising barrage that leaves them trembling.

headline: On the Market in New York City
text: An Upper East Side co-op, a Clinton Hill co-op and a Greenwich Village one-bedroom.

headline: On the Market in the Region
text: An 1888 Victorian with a mansard roof in Garden City, N.J., and a four-bedroom colonial in Teaneck, N.J.

headline: Getting Competitive With Yoga, Sort Of
text: The United States Yoga Federation hosts the ninth New York Regional and National Yoga Asana Championship at the Hudson Theater in Midtown Manhattan this weekend.

headline: Officials Speak of Origin of Gun in School Attack
text: When the 17-year-old T. J. Lane opened fire on students at Chardon High School, killing three and wounding two, the authorities say, he held a .22 caliber Mark III Target Rimfire pistol, a semiautomatic handgun made by Ruger that retails for $449 to $559.

headline: Corrections: March 2
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Everybody Inhale
text: IN a crowded place like Manhattan, there are moments when a certain question flits across people’s minds.

headline: Poll Finds Wide Support for Birth Control Coverage
text: The close divide in a Senate vote Thursday over whether employers can refuse insurance coverage for contraception mirrors a sharp partisan divide among the public, according to a national poll and interviews with women around the country.

headline: Bill’s Defeat a Blow to Home-Schooled Athletes
text: A bill that would have allowed home-schooled children in Virginia to play varsity sports at public high schools was defeated Thursday by a state Senate committee. The so-called Tim Tebow bill, named after the N.F.L. quarterback who was home-schooled in Florida but played football at a public school, was killed by an 8-7 vote of the Virginia Senate’s education and health committee. The bill had passed the state’s Republican-controlled House of Delegates last month.

headline: Peres Says U.S. Must Put All Iran Options on Table
text: Days before Israel’s president, Shimon Peres, was to meet with President Obama, Mr. Peres said on Thursday that the United States must make clear to Iran that “all options are on the table,” but he acknowledged that there was disagreement over where to draw the “red line” that would set off military intervention.

headline: The Burden of Budget Cuts
text: As state budgets for education decrease, colleges look first to cut back the most expensive majors like engineering, fine arts and nursing.

headline: A Warning on the Accuracy of Primary Polls
text: After another wild polling ride in Michigan, it is time for a reflection on just how accurate primary and caucus polls have been — both in an absolute sense and as compared with past years. This discussion, of course, also has implications for the FiveThirtyEight forecast model, which is based upon the polls.

headline: Nine Tables, Fast Service, Racket Welcome
text: “TABLE tennis is an addiction,” Saleem Majied confessed one recent Thursday night.

headline: Neighborhood Joint | The Brooklyn Table Tennis Club
text: The Brooklyn Table Tennis Club in Midwood plays host to a crowd that reflects the eclecticism of the borough.

headline: Gingrich Narrows Focus to Georgia for Super Tuesday
text: ATLANTA — With 10 states up for grabs on Tuesday, Newt Gingrich has retreated to Fortress Georgia.

headline: Gingrich Barnstorms Georgia
text: Newt Gingrich’s campaign strategy starts with winning Georgia, then capturing Alabama, Mississippi and Kansas.

headline: South Africa: Former Youth Leader Replies to Party
text: Julius Malema, the former leader of the Youth League of the African National Congress, fired back at the party that expelled him Wednesday, telling government radio that he was “not a soldier who is prepared to fall in the battle, I will die with my boots on.” Despite a rowdy show of support from close allies in his home province of Limpopo, response to his expulsion was relatively muted. Mr. Malema’s controversial proposals, like nationalizing the country’s mines, won some support among the impoverished youth, but his criticism of President Jacob Zuma landed him in front of a party disciplinary tribunal. Mr. Malema was initially suspended from the party for five years, but an appeals committee increased the penalty to expulsion, arguing that he showed no remorse.

headline: Preferring to Watch Putin Vote From Afar
text: Dasha Yurkevich, a blonde 9-year-old girl in a sailor’s hat and a green sweater dress, stood in front of the Russian Consulate in San Francisco last December, carrying a sign saying “It’s Not Fair” in Russian. She was part of a small protest against alleged Russian ballot-box tampering in the Dec. 4 Duma, or congressional, elections.

headline: An Eye on the Sky for Texas
text: John Nielsen-Gammon, the Texas state climatologist, has a standard joke: A few years ago, before the start of the most intense drought in state history, almost nobody in Texas knew he existed.

headline: GTT ★
text: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

headline: The Closer: Barkley May Have a Point
text: Charles Barkley is not a fan of Michael Jordan’s tenure as owner and chief decision-maker for the Charlotte Bobcats.

headline: ‘Photographic Autobiography’ of Rolling Stones Will Mark Band’s 50th Anniversary
text: The Rolling Stones are marking the band’s 50th anniversary with a new book, their publisher is expected to announce on Friday. Hyperion will release ”The Rolling Stones at Fifty,” a ”photographic autobiography” with images that have not been seen before and new text from the band.

headline: NYT Front Page for 03/02/2012
text: NYT Front Page for 03/02/2012

headline: Word of the Day | eulogy
text: eulogy •\ˈyü-lə-je\• noun

headline: At UTEP, Success Is Not All About Graduation Rates
text: In the farthest corner of West Texas — nestled between the Franklin Mountains and the United States-Mexico border, hundreds of miles from any other public university in the state — the University of Texas at El Paso and its fortress-like buildings occupy one of the state’s most exotic campus settings.

headline: Hard Times Claim a Storied Press Outpost in Austin
text: If only Molly were here to see this.

headline: Tata and Vodafone Eye Cable and Wireless
text: Tata Communications, which is controlled by India’s largest conglomerate, said on Thursday that it might bid for Cable and Wireless Worldwide of Britain to complement its operations in developing countries, Julia Werdigier wrote for the Deal Book in The New York Times.

headline: Obama Gets a Facebook Upgrade
text: On Thursday, another Facebook user adopted the site’s new Timeline feature, regaling followers with the minutiae typical of the world’s cyber capital of oversharing.

headline: Pennsylvania: Ultrasound Bill Is Shelved
text: The State House majority leader announced on Thursday that a bill requiring ultrasounds before abortions would not be considered soon. The shift followed a national uproar over a similar proposal in Virginia, which as originally worded would have forced women to have vaginal ultrasounds. The majority leader, Mike Turzai, a Republican, canceled a debate on a bill that critics said would require invasive procedures and interfere with doctor-patient relations. A spokesman, Stephen Miskin, said, “Until there is a consensus within the House and the medical community, it won’t be scheduled for a vote.”

headline: Wilt Chamberlain’s 100-Point Game
text: A snapshot of Wilt Chamberlain’s performance and those who have come the closest to his 100-point game.

headline: Montana: Judge Sends Racist Joke About Obama
text: The chief federal judge in Montana has apologized for forwarding to some of his friends an e-mail with a racist joke about President Obama, and he initiated himself a complaint of judicial misconduct. Judge Richard F. Cebull told The Great Falls Tribune, which received a copy of the joke from a recipient, that he is opposed to Mr. Obama’s politics and sent it in that spirit. He admitted the joke — involving suggestions of bestiality and the president’s mother — was racist, but he said he personally was not. Judge Cebull, nominated by President George W. Bush, sent a letter to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit asking for the misconduct investigation.

headline: Dignity and the Wealth of Nations
text: The significance of the Russian presidential elections this weekend can be understood by reading “Why Nations Fail,” a book written by two U.S.- based academics being published this month, Chrystia Freeland writes.

headline: Georgia: Court Delays Ruling on Immigration Laws
text: A federal court in Atlanta said Thursday it would wait until the United States Supreme Court decided the constitutionality of Arizona’s strict immigration law before ruling on similar laws in Georgia and Alabama. Georgia and Alabama created two of the nation’s toughest immigration laws last year, modeled in part on Arizona’s, allowing the police to inspect the citizenship status of criminal suspects.

headline: Texas: Primary Election Set for May 29
text: A federal three-judge panel in San Antonio ruled Thursday that the state’s long-delayed primary election would be held on May 29, with a runoff on July 31. The judges had twice pushed back the primary because of a redistricting dispute. Black and Hispanic groups sued the state over the electoral maps drawn by the Republican-controlled Legislature, saying the maps discriminated against minorities. With the new May 29 date, Texas will hold one of the last primaries in the country, weakening its ability to influence the Republican presidential race.

headline: Straight Shots on ‘Idol,’ at Last, Courtesy of Jimmy Iovine
text: “American Idol” narrowed the field to 13 final contestants this week, but the real star of the climactic show on Thursday turned out to be Jimmy Iovine, the famed producer and record executive, who injected some much needed candor into the proceedings.

headline: Newswallah: To Learn About the Poor, Live With Them
text: Katherine Boo’s recently published “Behind the Beautiful Forevers” is the latest in a series of narrative non-fiction books coming out of India. The book is set in Annawadi, a slum located near Mumbai’s international airport. Its central characters include Abdul, a garbage sorter, members of his family and neighbors.

headline: In Delhi and Mumbai, Dueling Fashion (and Fashion Weeks)
text: In recent weeks it has been hard to miss the crowds of designers, stylists, paparazzi and models in India’s top two cities — as well as eager crowds of fashionistas sporting everything from leopard prints to rhinestones to strappy sun dresses.

headline: News Quiz | March 2, 2012

headline: Iran’s Government Declares Huge Turnout in First National Vote Since ’09 Protests
text: WASHINGTON — Iran’s government declared an enormous turnout for the parliamentary elections held Friday, calling it another “epic” sign of support for Iranian theocracy and a thumb in the eye of the West.

headline: March 2, 1877 | Hayes Declared Winner in Disputed Presidential Election
text: On March 2, 1877, only three days before his inauguration, the Republican Rutherford B. Hayes was declared the winner of the 1876 presidential election, defeating the Democrat Samuel J. Tilden in one of the most disputed elections in American history.

headline: Venezuela’s Gladiators
text: CARACAS, Venezuela — Two men with knives face off in a pit. Hundreds gathered around are egging them on, while on the walkway above others are picking their winner and placing bets. The men in the pit have been given no real choice: refusing to fight is generally punished by death.

headline: Tornado in Illinois
text: WHERE is Harrisburg, Ill., situated in the state?

headline: Syria Blocks Red Cross Aid to Rebel Enclave in Homs
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The Syrian authorities on Friday blocked without explanation an officially sanctioned Red Cross convoy laden with food and medical supplies from entering a devastated neighborhood in the central city of Homs, one day after the army overwhelmed the main rebel stronghold there after a brutal monthlong siege.

headline: Can Kindness Become Cool?
text: Lady Gaga started her Born This Way Foundation, with the goal of empowering and supporting children and fostering a more accepting environment. Do you think she can succeed in affecting the culture of cruelty that often finds its way into interactions among young people?

headline: Pakistan Battles Militants, in Worst Fighting in Months
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — The government here cemented its grip on power on Friday with strong gains in Senate elections that represented a psychological victory for the beleaguered president, Asif Ali Zardari, and should ensure his party’s influence for another three years.

headline: Fantasy Focus: Early Spring Notes
text: The big news of the week was the Astros’ curious decision to shift Brett Myers from the rotation to the closer role. This has already been dissected at length, so I’ll keep it short, but while Myers is a No. 3 starter at best in terms of talent, he threw 439 innings over the past two years for Houston and that has a lot of value, particularly in keeping the bullpen fresh. It’s also curious given that the Astros actually have some talent in the bullpen: David Carpenter, Wilton Lopez, Juan Abreu (12.0 K/9IP in Class AAA), and yes, even Brandon Lyon. Either way, this is really about the future for Houston, which apparently feels that to a contender at the trade deadline, a shut-down reliever has more value than a No. 3 or 4 starter. The Astros may be right there, but this does nothing but make it more likely that Houston drafts No. 1 over all in the 2013 draft.

headline: Scouting the Draft: Alabama’s Dre Kirkpatrick
text: In my scouting report on the L.S.U. prospect and consensus top cornerback Morris Claiborne, I mentioned that I have him rated very closely with Alabama’s Dre Kirkpatrick.  After reviewing more tape of Kirkpatrick, I maintain that ranking.  The only thing stopping Kirkpatrick from truly battling Claiborne to be the top cornerback off the board in April is an arrest in January in which he was charged with possession of a small amount of marijuana.

text: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton. He has some financial interests in the health care field.

headline: Putin Says He Might Seek a Fourth Term as President in 2018, ‘if Things Are Going Well’
text: MOSCOW — Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin, who is likely to win a third presidential term on Sunday, said in an interview released on Friday that he might run for president for a fourth time in 2018, which would lengthen his term as Russia’s paramount leader to 24 years.

headline: Taking the Bait: Of Salt, Start-Ups, Financial Numbers and Insurance
text: Since closing in November for the long blizzard of a winter that never arrived, we mined some salt from the sea, posted a business plan for expansion to Brooklyn, and detailed the delay games of insurance companies. Lovely readers had things to say about each and every move, and we loved fielding their questions and observations.

headline: Daily Report: Zynga Hopes to Find You New Friends
text: Zynga announced a new gaming platform that is intended to make it easier to play social games like FarmVille, Words With Friends and Mafia Wars, reports David Streitfeld on Friday in The New York Times. The platform, which is to be introduced in a trial version on Zynga.com later this month, is intended in part to reduce Zynga’s reliance on Facebook. Most Zynga games are played on that social network, which derives 12 percent of its revenue from Zynga.

headline: Pakistan Builds Web Wall Out in the Open
text: PARIS — Many countries censor the Internet, but few spell out their intentions as explicitly as Pakistan.

text: “And just how long have we got the magic?”

headline: When It Rains, It Will Really Pour
text: Early last year I attended a conference in Sacramento where state and federal scientists warned emergency planners, insurance executives and others about the danger of a superstorm riding into California from warmer Pacific waters on an “atmospheric river” and inundating everything in sight.

headline: Austerity, American Style
text: Via Mark Thoma, Antonio Fatas has a good piece on the exceptional weakness of government spending in this recovery. I thought I might add to that observation.

headline: Regional English, Tweet by Tweet
text: The Dictionary of American Regional English, the recently completed landmark project we profiled recently, is based largely on research by a team of fieldworkers who fanned out across the country some 50 years ago in vans called Word Wagons, querying Americans about their ways of talking about kitchen implements, farm animals, bodily ailments, misbehaving children, stupid neighbors and more.

text: Greek Crisis May Test the Value of Swaps  |  The restructuring of Greece’s debt that is scheduled to start next week may well demonstrate how effective credit-default swaps are.

headline: Don’t Crimp My Ride
text: NAIROBI — What if the New York City subway disappeared tomorrow? This is the situation facing Kenyan commuters. The government has proposed a law to phase out the vans used by privately run transportation services in favor of smaller taxis and larger buses. And the operators of those classic 14-seaters, the matatus, are threatening a massive general strike across the country next week.

text: U.S. citizens concerned about a new law requiring them to sign up, and pay, for Turkish national health insurance are breathing sighs of relief this weekend.

headline: Narrow Choices for Iranian Voters
text: LONDON — Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, Iran’s supreme leader, was among the first to vote in parliamentary elections on Friday, having assured the electorate that the poll would represent “yet another firm slap in the face of world arrogance.”

headline: Divorce Rates Among Boomers to Reshape Old Age
text: The Times reports this morning that a growing number of men and women in their 50s and 60s are opting out of marriage and venturing into old age on their own. The surge has been driven by several factors, including longevity, economics and evolving social mores, according to sociologists.

headline: Friday Reading: More Older Americans Rejecting Marriage
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

The 7,000-square-foot space houses the studios of eight young artists, a gallery and a residency program. “We’re a bit bootleg and off the beaten path,” says Isaac Brest, 24, one of the founders. headline: Paperback Row
text: THE YEAR WE LEFT HOME,  by Jean Thompson (Simon & Schuster, $15.) A Midwestern family struggles for economic and emotional stability in Thompson’s warmhearted novel. Over the course of 30 years, the Ericksons — including Ryan, who longs to escape his rural roots, and his sister Anita, for whom marriage and motherhood became traps more than prizes — weather the aftermath of war, farm foreclosures and bittersweet homecomings.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: THE LIFESPAN OF A FACT,  by John D’Agata and Jim Fingal (Norton; paper, $17.95.) An essayist insists that his only responsibility is to truth and beauty, not factual accuracy. His fact checker begs to differ. A fiery argument ensues.

headline: Roland Mouret: Fall 2012 RTW
text: Paris

headline: Up Front
text: On this week’s cover, Eleanor Henderson reviews Amber Dermont’s first novel, “The Starboard Sea.” Henderson — an assistant professor at Ithaca College in Ithaca, N.Y., where she lives with her husband and two sons — is no stranger to the Book Review’s cover; her own debut novel, “Ten Thousand Saints” (one of our 10 Best Books of 2011), was reviewed there last year. Like Dermont’s book, it also delved into the confused and sometimes reckless lives of adolescent boys. “One of the things that most impresses me in ‘The Starboard Sea’ is Dermont’s access into the experience of a teenage boy,” Henderson said in a recent e-mail. “I tend to be annoyed when readers get excited by a writer who ‘crosses over’ into a character of the opposite gender, as though the opposite gender is some unidentified species or something. But Dermont’s commitment to seeing the world through a boy’s eyes seems complete to me, and I think it’s because of her powerful crush on her own narrator, Jason. I feel the same way about Jude, the 16-year-old protagonist of my novel — in high school, I would have liked to have a boyfriend like him, as screwed up as he is. All writers should be a little in love with their characters, I think. Because Dermont was, I fell for Jason, too.”

headline: Nervous System
text: Alexander Hoffmann is having a very bad day. It starts in the wee hours of the morning, when he startles an intruder in his palatial home in Geneva. The man, who bypassed the security system, is determinedly sharpening the family cutlery and has brought along some bondage gear. He slams Alex over the head with a fire extinguisher and flees. Alex, a hedge fund executive with so much money that being part of the 1 percent might seem unambitious, has to go to the hospital for scans and stitches.

headline: Right Face
text: One of the peculiarities of modern conservatism is that the most coruscating examinations of its doctrines are often issued from dissidents within its own ranks. Some of the more recent renegades include the Christian evangelical David Kuo, who served in George W. Bush’s administration; the economist Bruce Bartlett, who was a Reagan administration official; and the commentators Damon Linker and David Frum. But perhaps no one remains a more improbable critic than David Brock.

headline: Homeward Bound
text: So these two sociologists go into a bar and the man says to the woman, “What have you been up to?”

headline: Poisoned in Body and Spirit
text: Eliza Factor’s first novel, “The Mercury Fountain,” explores what happens when a life driven by ideology confronts implacable truths of science and human nature. It also shows how leaders can inflict damage by neglecting the real needs of real people. Though the action takes place between 1900 and 1923, the resonances feel alarmingly contemporary.

headline: Changing of the Guard
text: The central character of “An Ermine in Czernopol,” Gregor von Rezzori’s mid-20th-century masterpiece, first published in 1958, is not a person at all, but a city. Czernopol — less an invented place than the distilled essence of a number of post-imperial Eastern European cities, including the author’s own birthplace — is a smug little latter-day Sodom, squalid and venal and defiantly backward, except in one crucial respect. “Laughter in Czer­nopol,” the narrator tells us, “had been elevated to an art form, a folk art of unparalleled authenticity . . . well endowed with the most vivid references, not to mention all manner of innuendoes.” As you can perhaps imagine, this makes the town a lively place to visit.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Wine Enthusiast: A look at the sort of wine and cocktails the passengers drank on the maiden/final voyage of the Titanic. “Corks that survived the sinking later identified Champagne selections from Moët and Heidsieck & Co.” … — Robert Simonson

headline: After Sunset
text: The question of whether, say, India or Nigeria are “better off” because of British imperialism contains an inherent contradiction: before colonialism there were no states called India or Nigeria. But to prove the horrors of imperial rule — or to dispute the historians who recommend that the United States self-consciously adopt Britain’s former “burden” — one has only to examine the catastrophic choices of British colonialists that continue to influence events today.

headline: The Missing Pages
text: “It’s possible to make books of a certain fascination,” Thornton Wilder once said, “if you scrupulously leave out the essential.” Wilder was commenting on “The Education of Henry Adams,” that masterly autobiography in which Adams purposefully excluded any direct mention of his wife, Clover, their marriage or her shocking suicide. In fact, posterity has occasionally hinted that Adams was partly responsible for Clover’s death, as if omitting her from “The Education” suggests guilt rather than a surfeit of feeling. Adams did tell a friend that the “great calamities in life leave one speechless,” and three years after Clover died he wrote that he was still “sad, sad, sad.” He then burned some of the diaries he kept during his marriage. If Clover left a suicide note, he must have burned that too. “Wisdom,” he declared, “is silence.”

headline: Parting Words
text: When Brenda Wineapple closed her laptop on “Sister Brother,” her dual biography of the siblings Gertrude and Leo Stein, she cried. Stacy Schiff, having written the final words of “Cleopatra,” was still worried. “I lived a little bit in fear of her,” she explains. When Doris Kearns Goodwin finished “Team of Rivals: The Political Genius of Abraham Lincoln,” she built more shelves in her library annex (once the family garage) to hold all the books she had acquired.

text: Ann DemeulemeesterDesigner: Ann DemeulemeesterDate and Location: Thursday, Mar. 1, Théâtre de Chaillot, 1, place du TrocadéroPhotos: slide show

text: Good morning. Expect mostly cloudy skies today, with temperatures up to the mid-40s. Prepare for rain tonight, though.

headline: Leading Off: Glory Slip-Sliding Away
text: If you haven’t noticed — and based on regular-season ratings in most places this side of Vancouver, there is a good chance you haven’t — there is some weird stuff going on in the N.H.L. We not only have the game’s best player, Sidney Crosby, missing most of the season while in indefinite concussion limbo, but we also have the player who once battled him for that status, Alex Ovechkin, playing as if he wants to be traded to Omsk, and the once and always proud Montreal Canadiens sitting dead last in the Eastern Conference.

headline: For a Call Home, a Hefty Price
text: Phone calls to loved ones are a crucial lifeline for deployed soldiers to remain connected to the lives left behind while serving their country. An article in The Times on Friday looks at how calls made from pay phones at lounges in Leipzig-Halle Airport in Germany,  are coming at unusually steep costs to American troops.

headline: Yelp Shares Surge on Debut
text: Yelp got its first day pop after all.

headline: The Most Welcoming Wine Region
text: PARIS — Of all the wine regions in France, the Loire Valley, some of whose red wines are featured in my column this week, might be my top choice for wine tourism.

headline: NBC Finds a Winner in ‘The Voice’
text: The cellphone of NBCUniversal’s chief executive, Stephen B. Burke, rang early on the morning of April 28 last year. Alan Wurtzel, the company’s president of research, was so excited that he had trouble speaking. “We got a 5.1,” he finally said. Mr. Burke was at the gym, and given the background noise, he figured he wasn’t hearing correctly. “I said, We got a 5.1 in the key demographic,” Mr. Wurtzel repeated, which meant that Nielsen estimated that 11.8 million viewers in the all-important 18-to-49 demographic had tuned in — a breakout number for a new show.

headline: Big Ticket | Sold for $15,587,000
text: A penthouse that sold for $15,587,000 at the Laureate on the Upper West Side was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: Santorum’s Woman Problem
text: Rick Santorum, the improbable presidential aspirant, opposes abortion, thinks birth control promotes immorality, objects to women serving in combat positions, and has criticized “radical feminists” for encouraging women to join the workforce. He doesn’t have much respect for modern women, and modern women don’t have much respect for him—a feeling they’re expressing by voting for his rival. Polling in Arizona showed that Mitt Romney carried female voters by 17 percentage points. It was closer in the Michigan primary, 5 percentage points, but everything was closer in Michigan.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Tributes From Both Sides for Andrew Breitbart and Lego Goes Pink
text: Andrew Breitbart, the conservative blogger and provocateur who attracted a lot of vitriol from his opponents while alive, was celebrated by colleagues and admirers after his sudden death from an apparent heart attack on Wednesday. A note at the top of the Drudge Report, where Mr. Breitbart once worked, read in part: “I still see him in my mind’s eye in Venice Beach, the sunny day I met him. He was in his mid 20’s. It was all there. He had a wonderful, loving family and we all feel great sadness for them today…”

headline: Orlando Wants to Show the Commissioner It’s M.L.S. Ready
text: KISSIMMEE, Fla. — Major League Soccer Commissioner Don Garber visited Orlando Thursday for a series of meetings with the owners of the Orlando City club, the team’s supporters and local political leaders to explore the city’s viability as a future M.L.S. expansion market.

headline: Comrades, Optimize!
text: While many look back on the Soviet Union and fixate on the politics, purges and wars, the British writer Francis Spufford, in his latest high-wire act, has devoted Stakhanovite study and considerable literary muscle to another endeavor. He tells the story of “an idea,” the dream that mobilized a generation, created one of history’s largest industrial monsters and ultimately doomed it to failure. “Red Plenty,” as its title suggests, is the story of the Bolshevik promise of abundance.

headline: A Place of Our Deepest Desires
text: The jacket of Geoff Dyer’s “Zona” describes it as “A Book About a Film About a Journey to a Room.” It is also a hall of mirrors in which the author watches himself watching (and remembers himself remembering) a movie that, according to his impressively detailed description, ends with a character looking at us, looking at her.

headline: Expletives Deleted
text: I’m fairly sure it’s a faux pas to compare a novel and a television show, but I mean it as a compliment to both when I say that Thomas Mallon’s new novel, “Watergate,” bears a certain resemblance to “The West Wing.” Like that much-loved NBC drama, “Watergate” shifts among various men and women — mostly men — working inside and outside the White House. Even when the action becomes convoluted, we’re propelled forward and kept highly entertained by the colorful characters, the delicious insider details, the intelligence of the dialogue.

headline: For Romney and Voters, Sometimes a Missed Connection
text: 10:49 p.m. | Updated The full version of this post is available here.

headline: Yankees’ First Lineup Missing Only a Few Names
text: TAMPA, Fla. — For the first time since Oct. 6, 2011, there is a Yankees lineup. Derek Jeter will be leading off for the first preseason game of 2012, against the University of South Florida at 1:05 p.m. Friday.

headline: Shake Shack Is Heading to New Haven
text: The global ambitions of Danny Meyer’s Shake Shack are well known: It has already opened branches in Washington, Dubai and Kuwait City. But the New York hamburger chain may be out to boost its educational pedigree as well with its first toehold in an Ivy League town: New Haven.

headline: Veiled Witness in Rutgers Case Tells of Noticing Webcam
text: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J. — As he and his new boyfriend lay naked on a bed in a nondescript dormitory room at Rutgers University, the man sensed he was being spied on.

headline: Kodak’s Amateur Photographers: New York
text: While the Eastman Kodak Company’s early picture contests were national — and by the 1930s, international — there was no shortage of submissions from intrepid New York photographers.

headline: Volvo Recalls 17,000 Models for Potential Flaw in Air-Bag Deployment System
text: Volvo says it is recalling 17,000 of its 2012 S60, XC60, S80 and XC70 models because the front and side air bags may not deploy properly, according to a document posted Friday to the Web site of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

headline: Success in College Can Start on the Ballfield
text: The parade for the Giants' Super Bowl victory, which attracted many school-age children, brings to mind the importance of sports in shaping college-ready minds, says one principal.

headline: When I Needed Help
text: Recently major eye surgery left me almost blind, jelly-legged, unable to drive, shop, cook my own meals, do the laundry, shower, safely climb the stairs — all the tasks we take for granted. All the tasks many of the frail elderly cannot do for themselves, that they generally do not want strangers in the house helping them to do.
