headline: Cupcake-Dispensing A.T.M.’s? What’s Next?
text: Comes word  that an expanding Los Angeles-based cupcake chain will open 24-hour cupcake vending machines at three Manhattan locations this year. The chain, Sprinkles Cupcakes, which has a store on Lexington Avenue near 61st Street, tells The Daily News that the pink machines will pop up in Midtown and Downtown and on the Upper West Side.

headline: What the Nanny Saw
text: Vivian Maier’s photographs enveloped me in longing — not for Chicago or black-and-white photography but for the perspective of a waist-level viewfinder on a twin-lens reflex camera. Just look at Maier’s man in a bow tie or the girls in their winter coats or her gloomy self-portrait. It’s the world seen at the eye level of an 8-year-old.

headline: Blood Sugar Sex Fatherhood
text: The most memorable image of the Red Hot Chili Peppers has to be of you guys onstage wearing nothing but tube socks over your penises. Can you still get away with that at 49?  The mood hasn’t struck me in some time — maybe since the ’90s — but if we were at the right place at the right time and Flea looked over at me and said, “Let’s go play this encore with socks,” I’m not above it.

headline: ‘Downton Abbey’ and the Fantasy of a Bygone Era
text: I agree with Ms. Chocano’s thoughtful description of “an imagined ideal of an enlightened aristocracy whose conservatism included a sense of responsibility, not disdain, toward those dependent on it,” and I’d add that the pleasure of “Downton Abbey” is watching noble characters endeavor to do what is right and responsible toward others irrespective of the direct personal consequences. Today we’re faced with the sorry spectacle of so-called leaders in business and politics seemingly always advancing their own interests, or those of their narrowly defined group, while disingenuously claiming allegiance to the greater good. The fantasy of “Downton Abbey” stands in stark contrast to our current reality.

headline: Who Made Those Little Trees Air Fresheners?
text: Little Trees air fresheners the world over owe their rearview-mirror-dangling existence to a chance encounter some 60 years ago in Watertown, N.Y. On that particular day, Julius Samann listened to a milkman complain about one of his occupational hazards, the stench of spoiled milk. It turned out he was talking to just the right guy. Samann, a German-Jewish chemist who fled the Nazis, had studied Alpine tree aromas in the forests of Canada. He was interested in the technology used to transport and disseminate them.

headline: The Curious Burden of the Giants Fan
text: Your essay on the New York Giants was a capsule of my life, although fortunately I was able to watch this year’s Super Bowl with my 80-plus mom at her home in Hackensack. As my parents divorced when I was about 4, and I lived with my mom, she was the one who took me to Yankee Stadium to watch the Giants play, and where I remember having my first sip of beer courtesy of another die-hard fan when I was the ripe old age of 7 or 8. Here it is, 50 years later, and nothing has changed. She always explores the many ways in which they might screw up during the game, for these are all her children and she feels for them, but when they win, her joy is indescribable.

headline: Greece Confronts Its Spartan Future
text: Russell Shorto’s depiction of rugged Spartan entrepreneurship amid the misery of modern-day Greece is an understandable attempt at journalistic balance. Yet there can be no denying the systemic rot that has brought this storied nation to its knees. For all of Angela Merkel’s mishandling of the sovereign-debt crisis, the German chancellor is not the chief villain in this Greek tragedy. Decades of public profligacy, societal indolence and fiscal duplicity have made Athens the moribund man of Europe. If they wish to restore a proud nation’s dignity, today’s Greeks ought to heed the words of one of history’s greatest Stoics, the Roman emperor Marcus Aurelius: “Stop dithering around. In every confrontation, render what is just; from every impression, extract what is true.”

headline: Hail the Artisanal Pickle Maker!
text: I’d like to see an article on how to obtain funding for all these artisan endeavors. I’m sure most people would love to start their own business, but the financial barriers to entry prove too difficult.

headline: Operating Under the Influence
text: My neighbor passes out drunk on the stoop, waking me with agonized groans; he blasts music at crazy hours; and he enjoys adult entertainment at embarrassing volumes. He is a surgical assistant at the local hospital, and I suspect he goes to work intoxicated. If an anonymous letter got him fired, patients would be safer, and with no salary, he’d soon have to move out. Game, set, match. But would I be overstepping my bounds? What if he starts a downward spiral that ends terribly? Would I be responsible? NAME WITHHELD, NEW YORK

headline: Sampling Small Plates on a ‘Food Safari’ in London
text: Dining out often means making one decision after another. There is the question of where to eat. Then, once you’ve settled on a neighborhood and restaurant, you’ve got to figure out which items to order from the menu.

headline: Psst, You in Aisle 5
text: I’ve had fun with marketers for years. When I sign up for anything that requires personal information, I choose my identity at random. I report that I’m a 19-year-old female high-school graduate in the highest income bracket, a 39-year-old Latino male “homemaker” with “some postgraduate/advanced degree” or a 75-year-old woman who describes her style as “fashion forward.” It certainly makes the offers I get from retailers a lot more interesting.

headline: Two Women Joined by Justin Timberlake
text: In 2010, Nikki Glaser, a stand-up comic, and Sara Schaefer, a blogger for “Late Night With Jimmy Fallon,” met at a party and bonded over their affection for Justin Timberlake. Both felt a real connection, and despite the fact that they didn’t know each other, decided that it would be fun and funny to start their own podcast about, basically, getting to know each other. They also decided they would record it in front of a few friends in the living room of Schaefer’s Brooklyn apartment.

headline: Jonathan Chait’s Sense of Snowe
text: Perfect:

headline: The Ending Was Worth the Journey for a Star at Iona
text: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y. — Each of Mike Glover’s 12 tattoos carries personal significance, but none is more emblematic than the eight italicized words inked on his lean left calf: “If You Don’t Know Me Don’t Judge Me.”

headline: Alan Alda Asks, What is a Flame?
text: The actor Alan Alda has long been a student and communicator of science, first through the Scientific American Frontiers TV program and now as a coach and mentor to scientists eager to convey their work to the public. His main outlet for that work is The Center for Communicating Science, a project of the School of Journalism at Stony Brook University on Long Island.

headline: Ohio Poll Shows Santorum and Romney Tied
text: Mitt Romney’s recent victories in Michigan and Arizona may have given him a slight lift in Ohio, but Rick Santorum is still a strong and viable candidate for a number of voter groups, despite his loss in Michigan.

headline: Turkey Bars Loans to Museums in New York and London
text: As part of a campaign to block loans to foreign museums with disputed objects in their collections, Turkey is refusing to lend artifacts to the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York and the British Museum and the Victoria and Albert Museum in London, The Art Newspaper reported. The Met told the newspaper that a dozen antiquities in its collection are now being claimed by Turkey, but would not identify the individual items, saying the matter was “under discussion with the Turkish authorities.” And Tolga Tuyluoglu, who runs Turkey’s culture and tourism office in London, confirmed to the newspaper that claims for the return of two artifacts in the British Museum and the Victoria and Albert are being pursued, adding that his government wants to resolve the issues “before discussing loans for exhibitions.” The British Museum had requested loans of 35 items for its current exhibition “Hajj: Journey to the Heart of Islam,” but the ministry of culture blocked them, leaving the museum to find alternatives on short notice.

headline: Weekend Fare
text: A meatball contest on Friday from 7 to 10 p.m. at Brooklyn Kitchen, 100 Frost Street (between Manhattan and Leonard Streets), in Williamsburg, Brooklyn — featuring chefs from restaurants like Roberta’s, Gramercy Tavern, Riverpark, Vesta, The Meat Hook and The Meatball Shop — benefits programs that offer cooking lessons in public schools and programs teaching students about urban agriculture. A panel of experts will judge the contest, and a popular vote will also take place. Tickets are $50, available online.

headline: Winehouse Foundation Establishes Scholarship
text: A foundation set up in memory of the singer Amy Winehouse  after her death last year from alcohol poisoning will provide a scholarship to a London theater school where she studied voice as a girl, the Winehouse family said. The scholarship to the Sylvia Young Theater School will go to a child whose family cannot afford to pay the tuition, the singer’s father, Mitch Winehouse, told Reuters.

headline: Choosing to Have a Child With Down Syndrome
text: I support abortion rights. I’ve had two abortions. I’ve body-blocked protesters trying to stand in the way of women entering a women’s health clinic that provides abortions. I teach about reproductive rights in classes. I have a bumper sticker advocating abortion rights. I’ve written about abortion and gotten hundreds of e-mails, many of them angry in tone, from those who disagree with me.

headline: Rebranded Marlins, but Same Brash Guillen
text: Jupiter, Fla.

headline: Hothouse Flower
text: “We lived in Harlem just, like, at the beginning of its gentrification . . . but my mom had our apartment since she was 18, she worked a retail job, but she worked on commission, so she made like, maybe, 75 or $80,000 a year, but our rent was so cheap since it was, like, rent-controlled, so our rent was, like, $300 a month for a two-bedroom apartment, so we always had extra money. I grew up very spoiled . . . like I had everything: I had computers, I had video games, I had dress-up clothes, I had lipstick, I had heels — not like, actual heels, play heels — I had dolls, I had birds, I had hamsters — my mom did a really good job of keeping me stimulated.”

headline: Transit Worker Falls 15 Feet in Subway Shaft
text: A transit worker fell about 15 feet in a subway ventilation shaft beneath a grate on East 14th Street Friday morning, the Fire Department said. He was not seriously injured.

headline: Blackmail, Big Money and Gross-Outs Galore
text: If you’ve ever found yourself surfing after midnight through the cable wasteland, you may have chanced across “Tim and Eric Awesome Show, Great Job!” on “Adult Swim,” the Cartoon Network’s quirky programming block for insomniacs. Surreal live-action sketches in saturated color, lo-fi parodies of television ads and infomercials, and hits of gross-out humor predominate, courtesy of Tim Heidecker and Eric Wareheim, creators adept at cheesy effects. The show comes in at a digestible 15-minutes that ends before you know it, the satires side by side with the late-night sales pitches.

headline: Manager Quits Mortuary Where Body Parts Were Lost
text: WASHINGTON — A manager at the heart of a scandal at the Dover Air Force Base mortuary in Delaware, Quinton R. Keel, has resigned, an official familiar with the case said on Friday.

headline: Three Hitchens Books Returning to Print
text: Three books by Christopher Hitchens that had gone out of print will be revived in paperback and e-book, the publishers of the titles said. Twelve, an imprint of the Hachette Book Group, will release the three books on April 10. The titles are “The Missionary Position,” a study of Mother Teresa; “No One Left to Lie To,” a best-selling examination of Bill Clinton; and “The Trial of Henry Kissinger.” Mr. Hitchens, a prolific author and columnist, died in December at the age of 62 of pneumonia, a complication of esophageal cancer.

headline: A Princeton Dean Is Named to Lead Brown
text: Christina Hull Paxson, the dean of the Woodrow Wilson School of Public and International Affairs at Princeton, will become president of Brown University on July 1. She succeeds Ruth J. Simmons, who said in September that she would step down.

headline: Home Prices Resume Their Fall
text: Home prices in most parts of the country appeared to bottom out in the summer of 2009 and to begin a slow recovery. But now they have fallen below 2009 levels in most markets, according to the Standard & Poor’s/Case-Shiller indexes released this week. Markets where prices peaked in 2007, rather than earlier, generally seem to be suffering the most now.

headline: Nanci Griffith, a Texan in Ireland, Singing Her Politics
text: The singer-songwriter Nanci Griffith, who began a tour to promote her 20th album this week in Ireland and the United Kingdom, weaves politics and storytelling in her songwriting. From her roots in Texas to Ireland, her adopted homeland — and her new home in Nashville, where she has always been just beyond the fringes of mainstream country music — Ms. Griffith is an American songwriter with an international cult following.

headline: Big-Dollar Individual Campaign Giving and the Tie to Citizens United
text: Much has been written about Citizens United, the 2010 Supreme Court decision that enabled corporations and labor unions to spend unlimited sums to support or oppose political candidates, so long as the spending was independent of the campaigns.

headline: Jeff Han from Perceptive Pixel visits The New York Times
text: Jeff Han, founder of Perceptive Pixel, has come a long way from the classic 2006 TED demo, one of the very first YouTube sensations. He visited The New York Times yesterday and brought his company’s new 27 inch desktop model to demo.

headline: A Fight to the Last Pike
text: Among the many props that John Brown took with him on an 1857 fund-raising tour across New England was a bowie knife that he allegedly took from a vanquished foe during his “Bleeding Kansas” campaign. While passing through Connecticut, he met with a blacksmith named Charles Blair, who helped him use the knife as a model for a double-edged spear, mounted on a six-foot-long wooden shaft. Brown explained to Blair that such spears, cheap enough to churn out in mass quantities, would be kept by Free State Kansans “in their log cabins” as a last-ditch defense for themselves and their cause.

headline: James Atlas, Veteran Publisher and Author, Will Edit for Amazon
text: The longtime publisher and author James Atlas has signed up with Amazon to edit a series of biographies, he said this week, following in the footsteps of another veteran, Laurence Kirshbaum, the publisher and agent who jumped to Amazon Publishing last year.

headline: The Kids Who Shouted the News
text: Dan Barry narrates over a gallery of images and artifacts from the time when newsboys — the town criers of the cities, street-hardened ragamuffins — captured the country’s imagination.

headline: Read All About It! Kids Vex Titans!
text: THERE is no sugar-pushing nanny traveling by umbrella this time, no conflicted lion seeking therapy from a meerkat and a warthog. Even so, the premise for “Newsies the Musical,” the latest Disney property to reach Broadway, seems just as rooted in Disneyesque whimsy: A dese-and-dose scrum of newsboys unites to lead a strike against the most powerful media titans of Old New York.

headline: Townsend Harris Teacher Wins $25,000 Milken Award
text: Rafal Olechowski, an English teacher who loves to teach 19th-century romantic poets, was surprised to learn during a school assembly that he had won a prestigious prize for his teaching.

headline: Home Prices Declined to New Lows in 2011
text: HOME prices in the United States, which seemed to begin to recover in 2009, fell to new lows in 2011, according to the Standard & Poor’s/Case-Shiller index of prices.

headline: The Best Part About Global Warming
text: A POPULAR cold-weather complaint of recent winters — if the world is getting warmer, why is there 15 inches of snow in Central Park right now? — has been quietly laid aside this year. Schoolchildren who had anticipated snow days and sledding will tell you that the weather has been disappointingly mild; in fact, since record keeping began, the park has experienced only one warmer winter, in 2001-2.

headline: Washington State Lawmaker Will Not Seek Re-election
text: Representative Norm Dicks, the top Democrat on the House Appropriations Committee and the dean of Washington State’s Congressional delegation, announced on Friday that he would not seek re-election.

headline: Obama Backs Student in Furor With Limbaugh on Birth Control
text: 8:50 p.m. | Updated  WASHINGTON — The election-year fight over the administration’s birth control policy escalated Friday, with two unlikely figures — a Georgetown University law student and the conservative radio host Rush Limbaugh — taking center stage in the politically charged conflict and pulling much of official Washington into the fray.

headline: The Daily Shoe | Nina Ricci
text: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

headline: A Genuine Motherwell? Make Sure Before Buying
text: TALES about art forgeries are almost always intriguing. Maybe that’s because of the big amounts paid by unwitting buyers. Or that the people involved invariably emerge as characters worthy of a thriller.

headline: From France Avec L’Amour: Another Honor for Harvey Weinstein
text: LOS ANGELES — The kid from Queens is now the toast of France.

headline: Chain of Avoidable Errors Cited in Koran Burning
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — American and Afghan officials investigating the Koran-burning episode that has brought relations between the countries to a new low say that the destruction could have been headed off at several points along a chain of mishaps, poor judgments and ignored procedures, according to interviews over the past week.

headline: Inside the List
text: HOWL: “The Wolf Gift,” Anne Rice’s first non-Christian novel since she publicly left the faith in 2010 (after a 12-year return to the Catholic Church of her youth), is at No. 5 on the hardcover fiction list this week. Rice is as responsible as anyone for pop culture’s current fascination with vampires — her 1976 novel “Interview With the Vampire” represented a “tectonic shift” and a “radical innovation,” as the essayist Victoria Nelson puts it in her forthcoming book “Gothicka,” “because it was the first to tell the story from the vampire’s point of view.” Now Rice has turned her attention to that other pop-Gothic standby, the werewolf. Her new novel once again mixes vaguely philosophical inquiries about good and evil with standard horror trappings: “His fingers, or were they claws, touched his teeth and they were fangs! He could feel them descending, feel his mouth lengthening! . . . His voice was guttural, roughened. . . . His hands were thickly covered with hair!” Hmmm. A growth spurt, a deeper voice, hair in new places — if you’re smirking here, well, Rice knows that werewolf stories have always echoed the truly scary specter of puberty. On Amazon, where she’s a prolific reviewer of other people’s work, she weighed in last June on “The Company of Wolves,” a 1984 movie by Neil Jordan (who also directed the big-screen version of “Interview”). She called it a masterpiece. “Werewolf films have for decades dealt with the emerging sexuality of adolescents,” she wrote. “But this film outdoes them all. . . . It’s in a class with films like Cocteau’s ‘Beauty and the Beast.’ It goes deep to the very core of what the werewolf myth has always been about.” Disappointingly, Rice hasn’t written an Amazon review of Glen Duncan’s elegant, feral novel “The Last Werewolf,” which spent three weeks on the extended list last summer.

headline: Maryland Women’s Lacrosse Looks for Rebound Against Virginia
text: Very few teams in collegiate sports can get through an entire season unscathed. The Maryland women’s lacrosse team, though, encountered a bump in the road sooner than it wanted to, when it lost to Duke in its fourth game of the season and Atlantic Coast Conference opener last weekend. The loss was only the fifth for the Terrapins since the opener of the 2009 season, with 67 victories in that span.

headline: Graphic Books Best Sellers: Four at Four
text: At No. 4 on the graphic books hardcover best-seller list this week is “Fantastic Four: Season One,” written by Roberto Aguirre-Sacasa and illustrated by David Marquez. It’s the first in a series of graphic novels from Marvel Entertainment that chronicles the early days of some of its biggest heroes, including Spider-Man, the X-Men and Daredevil. “Fantastic Four: Season One” has impressive art and puts a modern spin on some of the genre’s tropes. My colleague Adam W. Kepler and I favorably reviewed the book last month.

headline: Virginia Court Rejects Climate Skeptic’s Demand for Records
text: Virginia’s crusading attorney general faces a flashing stop sign in his pursuit of a leading climate scientist. On Friday, the Virginia Supreme Court ruled that the attorney general, Kenneth T. Cuccinelli, does not have the authority to demand records of e-mails or grant applications sent by the scientist, Michael E. Mann, who formerly taught at the university and is now a professor at Penn State.

headline: New High Schools Seek Students in Round Two
text: The founding principals of three new schools in the city talk to Brian Lehrer about their search for new students to fill up their seats for their fall openings.

headline: New to the Neighborhood: Schools Opening This Fall
text: Nearly one in ten students who applied in the first round of the city's high school admissions process did not receive a match. But there are still options for parents and students, including new public and charter high schools opening this fall.

headline: Sentence of the Week: Bronze Age Beefcake Edition
text: And here we are: the final Sentence of the Week before our big Sentence of the Year competition, the runup to which began last March with Charlotte Brontë, my first SOTW winner. Let’s make it count. Our candidates (interspersed with my comments) are:

headline: Marrakesh’s White Elephant Becomes an Art Star
text: MARRAKESH — It was not quite planned this way, but the biggest star of the 4th Arts Biennale in Marrakesh may turn out to be an unfinished opera house, the town’s great white elephant. Conceived in Pan-Arabic style and started 20 years ago, it was never finished and grandly squats outside the city ramparts, part mosque, part decaying Luxor temple.

headline: Bankruptcy’s Odd Twist With Union Contracts
text: The pilots union has sued AMR, the parent company of American Airlines. And the complaint, at the end of this post, illustrates nicely one oddity in the bankruptcy code with regard to collective bargaining agreements — a point that is relevant in the many other cases pending currently that involve questions of unionized employees.

headline: The Wealth of Experience
text: “I’VE been doing this so long I don’t even think about it,” Hussein Chalayan said on Friday as models cheered after a stellar show. “It’s just instinctual.”

headline: F.C.C. Asks for Guidance on Whether, and When, to Cut Off Cellphone Service
text: WASHINGTON — The Federal Communications Commission is reviewing whether or when the police and other government officials can intentionally interrupt cellphone and Internet service to protect public safety.

headline: Giant Jurassic Fleas Packed a Mean Mouth
text: Scientists have discovered the world’s oldest fleas to date — bloodsuckers that lived among (and possibly on) dinosaurs.

headline: Temple Discovers That Three Is Not a Crowd in the Backcourt
text: PHILADELPHIA — Forward Scootie Randall was playing the best basketball of his Temple career late last season when a foot injury sidelined him for the Owls’ final seven games before the N.C.A.A. tournament. But his injury turned out to be a fortuitous development for Temple because it spawned one of the nation’s best three-guard lineups.

text: An interview with the chief executive of Yelp as the company goes public; James B. Stewart on the inside story behind NBC’s ‘The Voice'; Examining pay at banks.

headline: A.I.G. Sheds Stake in Blackstone
text: The American International Group has sold its $500 million stake in the Blackstone Group, severing a longtime direct investment in the private equity giant, a person briefed on the matter told DealBook on Friday.

headline: U.N. Faults NATO and Libyan Authorities in Report
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — NATO has not sufficiently investigated the air raids it conducted on Libya that killed at least 60 civilians and wounded 55 more during the conflict there, according to a new United Nations report released Friday.

headline: One More Reason to Do Research Before Buying Art
text: Paul Sullivan writes in his Wealth Matters column this week about the limits of insurance coverage when that expensive piece of art hanging in the foyer turns out to be a forgery.

(The title is a mispronunciation of Attenborough, as in David, the living legend of science and natural history television.)

headline: Cambodia’s Sweet Spot
text: ON a sunny weekday in Kep, a seaside village about halfway along Cambodia’s coast, the crab market was heaving. Women in straw hats and rubber boots stood knee deep in the surf shouting out prices, periodically darting into the sea to pull writhing specimens out of wicker baskets. Children of all ages ran through the stalls; it seemed as if the entire town had congregated in this one main square.

headline: The Week Ahead
text: “RENDEZ-VOUS WITH FRENCH CINEMA,” the Film Society of Lincoln Center’s annual glimpse into the state of that art, this year grows richer with the addition of “Rendez-Vous +” (through Thursday), a sidebar showcasing documentaries, older movies and at least one certifiable classic: Jean Grémillon’s “LUMIÈRE D’ÉTÉ,” presented in a newly restored version by the Cinémathèque Française.

headline: When Innocence Isn’t Enough
text: EDWARD LEE ELMORE turned 53 in January. For more than half his life, the soft-spoken African-American who doesn’t understand the concept of north, south, east and west, or of summer, fall, winter and spring, was in a South Carolina prison, most of it on death row.

headline: High Line Art Announces Spring Lineup
text: On Friday, High Line Art, the public art program of the New York park built on a historic elevated rail line, announced its plans for its spring 2012 season. Work on view will include, in April, a new contribution by the Scottish artist David Shrigley to the High Line Billboard series, presented on a 25-by-75-foot billboard next to the park on Tenth Avenue at West 18th Street, and films and videos in the High Line Channel series, an outdoor program featuring projections on a building to the east of the High Line at West 22nd Street after dark.

headline: Ego and Envy, So It Is Written

text: In a contribution to a recent Dot Earth post, William D. Nordhaus, a Yale University economist who has spent many years examining the costs and benefits of various climate policies, angrily rejected a description of his work used by 16 scientists questioning concerns about global warming in an op-ed article in The Wall Street Journal.

text: BEDFORD, Mass. — Ever since Rosey the Robot took care of “The Jetsons” in the early 1960s, the promise of robots making everyday life easier has been a bit of a tease.

headline: On, Then Off, Then Back on the Map
text: LIKE Kep, many coastal idylls are discovered, lost, and then found again. Sometimes it is the end of a civil war or political turmoil that puts them back in commission. In other instances, new or repaired infrastructure makes them more accessible. Here are a few destinations that have recently reentered the travel mix.

headline: One Day, One Deliveryman, $40 in Tips
text: Saturday dinner rush, as recorded by a reporter on a bicycle who sometimes struggled to keep up. Including lunch, Lin Dakang said he made about $40 in tips.

headline: Spain Adjusts Deficit-Reduction Target at European Summit
text: BRUSSELS — Spain announced Friday that a deepening recession meant it would have to abandon its deficit-reduction targets for this year, and a European summit meeting that had looked to be surprisingly routine after two years of crisis ended with another test for the credibility of the euro zone.

headline: Hitting the Slopes to Recover From the Wounds of War
text: WHITEFISH, Mont. — From a distance, Billy, a Green Beret, looked like any other snowboarder, traversing the slopes with apparent ease. Only up close could other winter revelers see that he had a prosthetic leg.

headline: For a Game in Costa Rica, ‘Friendly’ Is a Relative Term

headline: Vintage New York Scenes in Kodak Archives
text: In the fall of 1943, a Harlem resident named Sidney Bernstein took a street portrait of Earl Johnston, a young boy in Far Rockaway, Queens. Someone named J. Johnston — presumably one of Earl’s parents — signed a release that allowed Mr. Bernstein to submit the photo to a picture contest.

headline: Rescued Journalists Describe Conditions in Syrian City
text: Updated | 5:39 p.m. As my colleagues Neil MacFarquhar and Alan Cowell report, the Syrian authorities on Friday went back on a promise to allow a Red Cross convoy with food and medical supplies into Baba Amr, a rebellious neighborhood in the city of Homs where thousands of residents have endured weeks of heavy bombardment.

headline: Breaking Up Bank of America, in Song
text: Public Citizen has a message for Bank of America: Size matters.

text: Subjects include an early bloom for flowers, the debate over a Whole Foods in Brooklyn, and the closing of a legendary Doo Wop record store.

headline: N.F.L. Inquiry Says Saints Set Bounty for Hits
text: During the past three seasons, while the National Football League has been changing rules and levying fines in an effort to improve player safety, members of the New Orleans Saints’ defense maintained a lucrative bounty system that paid players for injuring opponents, according to an extensive investigation by the N.F.L.

headline: The Munchkins Are a Problem: One Mom's Struggle to Direct the Fifth-Grade School Play
text: Helene Stapinski, author of "Five-Finger Discount," somehow wound up directing the fifth-grade play at her son's school. She writes, "Who knew when I signed up that my life would be thrown into chaos for 10 months? That I would risk my mental health and household order -- and even my marriage -- all for the sake of a few bows. I certainly didn’t. Nor did I know that by some small miracle, it might all be worth it." This is the first installment of her report from stage right (or is it stage left?), which will be presented on Fridays on SchoolBook.

headline: Union Rat Lands at Manhattan School of Music
text: Nearly three years after forming a union, teachers of pre-college students at the Manhattan School of Music are locked in a dispute with the administration over wages as they seek their first collective bargaining agreement. On Friday, they brought out the inflatable rat and distributed leaflets near the school’s entrance on Broadway and 122nd Street.

headline: A.O. Scott on Dr. Seuss Books and Adaptations
text: In his review of “The Lorax” in today’s paper, A.O. Scott writes:

headline: Leader of the Pack
text: Years of traveling have taught Bruce Pask exactly what to bring — and where it all fits.

headline: How Head Start Can Make a Difference
text: Head Start, the government’s program for giving preschool training to children from low-income families, has become something of a political football as both parties champion their efforts to spend government funds more efficiently.

headline: Santorum Remains Modest Favorite in Ohio
text: In Michigan, the betting market Intrade always had Mitt Romney favored — even when he fell behind Rick Santorum in the polls. That prediction looked prescient in the end.

headline: The Evidence on E.M.D.R.
text: This week, readers of the Consults blog posed questions about eye movement desensitization and reprocessing, or E.M.D.R., a psychological therapy pioneered by Francine Shapiro that uses eye movements and other procedures to process traumatic memories. The therapy has been used increasingly to treat post-traumatic stress disorder and other traumas. You can learn more about how E.M.D.R. therapy is done here. Below, Dr. Shapiro addresses reader questions about the current state of research on E.M.D.R. therapy.

headline: Editor’s Letter
text: Timelessness, when it comes to matters of style, is a misguided virtue. You don’t really want clothes that are timeless (and we all know that the years can get the better of any garment: that leather aviator jacket you swore you’d have forever? suddenly looks like Indiana Jones, the first go-round); you want to wear things that are relevant to, but not necessarily restricted by, the way you live now. It’s that tough trick of being on trend without being trendy.

headline: “In the Company of Animals: Art, Literature, and Music at the Morgan”
text: A new exhibition at the Morgan Library & Museum explores the relationship between animals and the artistic imagination.

headline: The Beasts Without and Within
text: When Odysseus, disguised as a beggar, returned home after 20 years of war and wandering, his aged dog, Argos, knew him instantly. “Infested with ticks, half dead with neglect” and lacking the strength even to drag himself toward his master, Argos thumped his tail, nuzzled low, and dropped his ears in grateful recognition. Then the “dark shadow of death closed down on Argos’ eyes.”

headline: Big Data’s Grass-Roots Revolution
text: The Big Data revolution may be raising more questions than it is answering. Who owns my behavior? Where does my government begin and end? Should I be able to bet on the outcome of a trial?

headline: Yucking It Up on Yahoo, Like a Grown-Up
text: LIKE any network executive Erin McPherson spent the winter half-crazed over content decisions. She sifted through pitches, sat through pilots, took conference calls over the Christmas holiday from a bedroom in her parents’ Colorado home.

headline: Looking Back at Complaints About Saints’ Dirty Play
text: Some fans won’t be shocked by Friday’s news about the Saints’ defense:

headline: Baseball Officially Expands Playoff Format
text: Major League Baseball expanded its playoff format to 10 teams Friday, adding a second wild-card in each league.

headline: What to Watch This Weekend
text: Go to any “what to watch this weekend” post and it will immediately sing the praises of another North Carolina versus Duke matchup. What could be better than that? The bitter rivals are ranked No. 6 and No. 3. Duke won the first meeting in Chapel Hill on a wild tell-all-your-friends-to-watch-the-highlights 3-pointer by Austin Rivers (with dad Doc in the stands cheering) after the Tar Heels squandered a huge lead. Yes, the Tar Heels will be motivated to rectify that but will have to do it in the bandbox that is Cameron Indoor Stadium.

headline: Springsteen: More Fanfares for Those Common Men
text: The New York Times’s pop critics Jon Pareles and Jon Caramanica discuss Bruce Springsteen’s album “Wrecking Ball,” to be released Tuesday by Columbia.

headline: Iranian News Media Portray Elections as a Blow to the U.S.
text: Iran’s state news media reported that voting in parliamentary elections in Iran on Friday was a huge — even “epic” — success.

headline: Dreaming Small
text: Steven Kaplan of Rego Park, Queens, spent six years building a replica of his desired car, a tiny Morgan three-wheeler.

headline: Beets? Arugula? Make a Smoothie!
text: In the latest Recipes for Health, Martha Rose Shulman creates smoothies for grown-up tastes. Using ingredients commonly found in salads or on a dinner plate, Ms. Shulman creates unique and refreshing smoothies that can work as a snack or a meal.

headline: Cable’s New Pack of Girls, Trying on the Woman Thing
text: WASN’T this supposed to be the television season of the young woman? It was only last September when the arrival of network sitcoms like “Whitney,” “2 Broke Girls” and “New Girl” heralded the possibility that the urban exploits of women in their 20s, once largely invisible to television programmers, would become a genre as established as the gross-out crime procedural. But while those comedies found their followings, they also took criticism for their crassness, their fixations on punch lines about lady parts and their oddly inauthentic depictions of the women at the heart of those shows.

headline: What Do Beethoven and Stravinsky Have in Common? Listen Closely
text: The New York Philharmonic is devoting most of March to the Modern Beethoven, a festival with two potentially illuminating, if not particularly novel, goals. One is to explore the connections among Beethoven’s symphonies and three worthy but less traveled 20th-century works. The other is to make the Beethoven symphonies sound fresh, even to listeners who have been hearing them their whole lives.

headline: TimesCast | Russia to Vote
text: Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin is expected to win a third presidential term in Sunday’s Russian election.

headline: TimesCast | Ruling on a Hijab Ban
text: March 2, 2012 - A panel that dictates international soccer rules will decide on Saturday whether women can wear a hijab while competing at the World Cup and Olympics.

headline: With Citigroup Stabilized, Parsons Decides to Retire
text: 5:32 p.m. | Updated

headline: Greek Official Warns Debt Holdouts
text: MADRID — For the hedge funds who are looking to sue Greece instead of taking a 75 percent loss on their bonds, the head of Greece’s debt management agency has some blunt advice: Think twice before racking up those big legal bills.

headline: DealBook’s Week in Review
text: The average Wall Street bonus was down to $121,150; the biggest buyout was a Texas-size bust and Gordon Gekko is cooperating with the F.B.I. A look back on our reporting of the past week’s highs and lows in finance.

headline: Too Good for the Hood
text: Highlights from the complete set of René Lalique auto mascots to be auctioned March 10 in Amelia Island, Fla.

headline: A World Away, a Wish Answered
text: EIGHT years ago, when I was 22, I woke up next to a man I realized I didn’t love and wondered what I was doing with my life. “I have to go,” I thought. But it was Christmas Eve, and I was expecting him to propose the next morning.

headline: Tesla’s Official Word on a Customer’s Battery Failure
text: A letter from Tesla’s vice president of service to a Roadster owner, explaining the company’s decision to decline a warranty replacement of the car’s battery.

headline: Digital Notes: Online Distributor Makes Deal With Universal for Physical Sales
text: A Digital Distributor Gets Physical: INgrooves, a distributor for digital music, is moving into physical sales through a deal with the Universal Music Group to take over Fontana, Universal’s independent arm in North America. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: Little Mermaid Goes Punk
text: “SHOUT out to Tumblr,” said Zombelle, a blue-haired singer who performed last weekend at an unnamed warehouse in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. The concert was billed as the city’s first Seapunk Alien Disco Indie Rave, but only a handful of the 20-somethings clutching cans of Budweiser seemed to know precisely what “seapunk” even meant.

headline: An Older Beauty Sings Over Spilt Beer
text: ZURICH — About 15 years ago the mezzo-soprano Cecilia Bartoli seemed to be taking New York by storm. Featured in three new productions at the Metropolitan Opera from 1996 to 1998, she even had a book to seal the stardom deal: Manuela Hoelterhoff’s “Cinderella and Company,” published in 1998, told the story of the contemporary opera industry through the lens of Ms. Bartoli’s career.

headline: Do the Right Thing
text: Intolerance and character assassination are so ubiquitous in political discourse that it’s important to take note when someone calls out bad behavior, withstands it, or bothers to apologize for it.

headline: Time to Pick the Winner of the Pulp Fiction Contest
text: Update, March 7, 4:30 p.m. | The polls are now closed. You may continue to recommend your favorite story-ettes, but the voting is now done. We have our winner. Details soon.Update, March 5 | Click to read the actual opening of “Atlantic Avenue” and a profile of its author.

headline: Hot Turbo Time Machine: Buick Races Back to ’70s
text: TESTED 2012 Buick Regal GS

headline: Pro-Am Winners Are Helped by Imperfect Bidding and Play
text: The Night of the Stars tournament was held on Feb. 23 at the Wimbledon Bridge Club in London.

headline: Why Tuition Has Skyrocketed at State Schools
text: I have an article today about the states’ long-term divestment from public higher education, and what that means for students.

headline: Lalique’s Glass Menagerie, Too Cool to Ride on Radiators
text: PART weird bestiary, part alien zodiac, the crystalline characters of René Lalique appear far too ethereal to ride on the noses of mere motorcars. Perhaps that is why these automotive mascots — “hood ornament” is too mundane a characterization — are among the most treasured automotive accessories.

headline: Amelia Concours Is Also a Birthday Party
text: AS the first major concours d’élégance each year, the winter event at Amelia Island, Fla., gets the first shot at celebrating automotive milestones. Such is the case this year with the 50th anniversary of the Ferrari GTO and the Shelby Cobra.

headline: Wedding Q&A
text: A Bridal Shower Without the Bride

headline: Auto Ego: Three Wheels and a Spare
text: Steven Kaplan, a semi-retired assistant director at Head Start, spent seven years rebuilding his cherry-red, three-wheel Morgan replica.

headline: Yohji Yamamoto: Fall 2012 RTW
text: Paris

headline: Super Tuesday Voters: What’s Driving Your Choice?
text: Do you live in one of the states holding nominating contests on March 6, Super Tuesday? What are the issues close to home that are driving your vote?

headline: Out There | Live From the Whitney Biennial
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Now Online | T Spring Men’s Fashion 2012
text: The men’s spring fashion issue of T is filled with actors of every stripe. Our cover star Dustin Hoffman dissects his career with Giles Foden, Paul Dano brings morning into midday with a pajama shirt, and Willem Dafoe talks about his distinctive features with Joan Juliet Buck. There’s also a behind-the-scenes look at “Of Men and Mavericks,” the Curtis Hanson-directed film about surfing, starring Gerard Butler. Inside you will find cocktail-inspired grooming products, a primer on how to pack smarter and our must-haves: Italian suits, canvas kicks and weekend watches. When you’re done shopping, read the essay by the photojournalist Trevor Snapp about his assignments around the globe, Suzy Menkes on the runway’s military moment and Will Self on the hip-hop star Azealia Banks. And don’t forget our fashion portfolios: “Freshly Pressed,” with the likes of Martin Amis and Richard Ford, showing off the season’s stand out shirts, and “Riffraff Revisited,” in which the art collective Still House cleans up cool. See more from the issue >>

headline: Pace of Ocean Acidification Has No Parallel in 300 Million Years, Paper Says
text: A new scientific paper suggests that the ocean is acidifying at a rate that is many times faster than at any time in the last 300 million years. The change is occurring so rapidly that it raises “the possibility that we are entering an unknown territory of marine ecosystem change,” said the paper, published this week in the journal Science.

headline: Fitting, in Many Ways
text: A SURPRISING number of people harbor a secret fondness for their grandparents — or at least for their grandparents’ things, that is. Whether it is Granddad’s old leather box for his collars or Grandma’s battered alligator handbag, the attraction is usually the same: the object represents a time when men and women dressed and lived with greater dignity and elegance than Mom (in mom jeans) or Dad (in dad jeans) do. Some grandparents had grandeur.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Iran and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Iran, Syria, South Korea, South Carolina, Washington, China, India and New York.

headline: Attack by Limbaugh Awakens a ‘Stop Rush’ Campaign
text: Some of the same activists that persuaded advertisers to boycott Glenn Beck’s television show on Fox News in 2009 are now mobilizing against Rush Limbaugh in the wake of his verbal attacks on a Georgetown University law school student this week.

headline: Dinner? Paris? Invite Everyone!
text: BEFORE Facebook, Couchsurfing.org, and even before the Internet, Jim Haynes was helping the world connect. In the late 1980s, he wrote five travel books, each containing short biographies of people from Russia and Eastern Europe who were willing to accept travelers into their homes.

headline: Racing (Briefly) Along the Iditarod Trail
text: THE dogs howled and barked and moaned with excitement. The noise grew to a crescendo; they were ready to run. I listened, transfixed, beside the sled.

headline: Restaurant Review: MeroToro, Mexico City
text: With their first restaurant, Contramar, in the Colonia Roma neighborhood of Mexico City, Gabriela Cámara and Pablo Bueno accomplished what must have seemed impossible: they had satisfied the high-altitude, landlocked city’s taste for straight-from-the-boat, beachside-style seafood.

headline: Hotel Review: St. Regis Princeville Resort
text: THE UPSHOT

headline: Fliers’ Reading List
text: To the Editor: Regarding “High-Brow Lit for High Fliers” (Feb. 19), I’m glad the writer discovered the value of contemporary mystery and thriller writers for modern plane travel. I’ve got my Nook, and it’s the only way to remove oneself from the tedious experience of flying. I can take half a dozen books without weighing down my handbag.

headline: Rum and Reggae? Not Here
text: OUTSIDE Treasure Beach, on Jamaica’s rural southern coast, a half-dozen oxen are blocking the one potholed road into town. When the taxi driver honks, they turn, stare and stand their ground.

headline: Hut-to-Hut Skiing
text: To the Editor: Regarding “A Cool Glide” (Feb. 19), sounds like a nice hut system in the works. A word of advice: If you’re the type who starts a trip at 9 p.m. without a headlamp, treks in winter without a sleeping bag and finds a 200-foot vertical gain over a half-mile “steep,” you may want to stay away from the 10th Mountain Division huts and other Western hut systems. We don’t want you to get in trouble, or put others in danger trying to rescue you. Adam Serafin

headline: Solentiname’s Distinctive Art
text: Paintings by local artists depict the islands as a paradise of impossibly lush flora, exotic birds and people happily going about their daily lives.

headline: In Lush Nicaragua, Legacy of a Priest
text: THE Solentiname Islands in Nicaragua are familiar to aficionados of primitivist art. Paintings by local artists depict the islands as a paradise of impossibly lush flora, exotic birds, distinctive hanging birds’ nests and people happily going about their daily lives.

headline: Overnighter | Bratislava, Slovakia
text: The Slovak capital offers rich history, unusual local flavors, stunning architecture and vibrant restaurants and night life.

headline: A Vienna Getaway Minus the Crowds
text: ATMOSPHERIC churches, romantic cobblestone lanes, cool new cafes or quirky museums: What do locals in the Slovak capital of Bratislava recommend visitors see first?

headline: Terry Richardson’s Photographs Provoke and Reveal
text: Mr. Richardson has become known for a kind of glossed-up 1970s porn chic that is popular in high fashion.

headline: Open but Undeveloped
text: The area around Kep in Cambodia is still in that traveler’s sweet spot — mostly itself, but with roads and a few boutique hotels here and there for those who want them.

headline: The Naughty Knave of Fashion’s Court
text: AT 10:45 a.m. on Valentine’s Day, Terry Richardson arrived at the Smile, a farmhouse restaurant near his Lafayette Street studio. The fashion photographer was wearing a blue plaid shirt he bought for $5 on eBay, his hair a halo of speckled gray framing his customary black glasses. He is taller than he appears in photographs, usually alongside someone famous, his thumb turned up in what has become a signature gesture. Accompanied by Amanda Silverman, a friend and publicist, he sat at a table in the back and ordered a bowl of granola with honey.

headline: A Kit With Few Instructions Inspires an Improv Act
text: LIKE many homes in the Rego Park section of Queens, the one owned by Steven Kaplan and his wife, Dalia, is made of red brick and has a short driveway that slopes down from the street to a small garage below.

headline: Tesla Battery Failures Make ‘Bricking’ a Buzzword
text: AN uproar recently ignited on automotive blogs over a post about a Tesla Roadster whose battery needed replacement after its owner parked the car, low on charge and unplugged, for more than two months. The battery, which had fully discharged, could not be revived.

headline: Prunes and Pork, Still in Season
text: BY the time it gets to be March, we can be fooled into thinking winter has passed (especially this year). And whether the winter has been mild or frightful, we start to yearn for spring and lighter fare.

headline: Top Obama Adviser to Appear at ‘Super PAC’ Meeting
text: David Plouffe, a top political adviser to President Obama, is scheduled to appear at a West Coast fund-raising meeting Friday for the “super PAC” backing President Obama’s re-election bid, according to several people familiar with the event.

headline: Frolicking With Bubbly Saints and Marching With the Band
text: As choreographers go, Mark Morris isn’t particularly mysterious. The starting point of all of his dances is a nearly religious adherence to music, but beneath that surface, it’s the range that makes you wonder, what drives such a fervent mind?

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, March 2
text: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

headline: Does Couples Therapy Work?
text: WE’VE all had that horrible experience: you throw a party or invite a couple over for dinner, and they start fighting, right there in front of you — the character assassination, the barely controlled anger, the neurotic transference of their cooled sexual attraction onto, say, the hygiene of the family dog, all of which makes you want to fake choking and hide. Surely bearing witness to couples’ quarrels feels less bad to the pros, those credentialed and compensated marriage and family therapists whose job it is to help significant others work through issues and pain?

headline: G.M. Again Pauses Production of Chevy Volt
text: DETROIT — General Motors said on Friday that it planned to halt production of the Chevrolet Volt for five weeks beginning later this month because dealers had more than they needed.

headline: Never Fear: The Rock Stars in Blue Will Zoom in, by Van, to Save the Day
text: I’m not proud of this opening line, but I’m going with it anyway: It’s not easy being blue. At least on TV.

headline: Meet the Mushrooms
text: Melissa Clark demonstrates how to clean and work with different kinds of mushrooms.

headline: Barley, Celery Root and Mushroom Salad With Scallion Vinaigrette
text: Time: 90 minutes

headline: Jump-Starting Spring With Mushrooms and Barley
text: MUSHROOM barley soup, as nubby as oatmeal, is the kind of thing my grandmother used to simmer on the stove all winter long. The barley partly dissolved after a few hours, thickening the broth until it was dense and shiny and slightly sticky.

headline: Have An ‘Unlimited’ Data Plan With AT&T? Tips on Watching Your Data Usage
text: AT&T on Thursday clarified the limitations of its “unlimited” data plan. You can use a certain amount of gigabytes, and after that, your smartphone’s Internet speeds are subject to being slowed down, a practice known as throttling. Just how much you get slowed down is a mystery, but people who have been throttled say the Internet connections on their phones became so slow they were unusable.

headline: As Wolves Diminish, Moose Flourish
text: John Vucetich, a wildlife ecologist from Michigan Technological University, leads the wolf-moose Winter Study at Isle Royale National Park.

headline: More Fluoridated Water, but Not in New Jersey
text: In a federal study of 2008 data, New Jersey and Hawaii were the only states where less than a quarter of the population using a public water supply received fluoride in the water.

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, March 2
text: More Photographs

headline: Tacos That Fit in the Palm
text: Before Taquería Auténtica, a full-service Mexican restaurant seating 27, opened in August in Bloomfield, it had a yearlong rollout in Newark. The restaurant grew out of a food truck there, having started life as a stand at the Montclair Farmer’s Market in 2009.

headline: Adventurous Addition to the Pizza Landscape
text: OSTERIA PROCACCINI has aspirations. It aims for something beyond the culture of the slice: a pizza topped with clams; salads with beets and arugula or pear and gorgonzola. Though not perfect, it is a success. The restaurant, which opened early last year in Kingston, several miles northeast of Princeton, is a worthy addition to the pizza landscape in central New Jersey.

headline: Saints’ Vilma and Others React to Bounty Report
text: It seemed as if it was going to be a pretty average Friday afternoon in Jonathan Vilma’s off-season.

text: Paris

headline: Friday Night Music: Feist
text: Is this the way to live? Is it wrong to want more?

headline: An Interview With Gareth Pugh
text: Suzy Menkes speaks with the designer about the power of fashion films, his latest collection and his mentor Rick Owens.

headline: Mets Prospects Get First Chance to Impress
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — The Mets played their first intrasquad game of the season on Friday, giving their coaches, front office officials, and a smattering of their fans an up-close view of some of the organization’s top prospects.

headline: Powerful Storms Cut Across Southern and Midwestern States
text: Last Updated | Saturday | 10:16 a.m. | Rescue workers in southern Indiana were still sifting through mountains of debris from demolished homes and buildings this morning to look for more victims from Friday’s deadly tornadoes, which killed at least 31 people in Indiana, Kentucky and Ohio.

headline: The Art of Making Beer: Not Just for Professionals
text: PORT JEFFERSON, N.Y.

headline: A New Look, but Is It Dior?
text: PARIS

headline: The Packard Plant, a Symbol of Bygone Detroit, May Be Demolished
text: DETROIT – Decades removed from the era when its 3.5 million square feet hummed with activity, the historic but derelict Packard Motor Car Company plant appears closer than ever to a date with the wrecking ball.

headline: Moving Military Newspaper to Base Raises Concerns on Independence
text: WASHINGTON — The military newspaper Stars and Stripes, a hometown daily for troops deployed from Bastogne to Long Binh to Baghdad, has been ordered to vacate its headquarters here and move to a military base 30 miles away. It is a cost-cutting effort that has outraged staff members worried that they will lose their journalistic independence and also has attracted new high-level attention from Congress.

headline: Amid the Informality, Inspired Italian Flavors
text: NEW CANAAN has attracted several new restaurants, one of which — the Tuscan Osteria and Mercato — has taken over a large and comfortable space formerly occupied by a furniture store. Guests enter through the mercato, past baskets of produce and gleaming cases of fresh meats; in the dining area (separated from the shop by a charming brick archway), banquettes, brick walls and arches provide a rustic contrast to the white-tablecloth formality. Behind the dining area is a barroom, with tables and television screens placed off to the side of the long and lively bar.

headline: At Lanvin, the Delights Come Before the Party
text: Friday night was the 10th anniversary of Alber Elbaz’s role as the designer of Lanvin, a period in which he transformed the label from a dusty whatsit to an in-the-know commodity. Everybody in fashion loves Mr. Elbaz, too. He’s a self-effacing, charming, utterly enthusiastic designer who likes his audience to have a good time, so he invited every guest at his runway show to his big birthday party that followed:

headline: Too Many Medical Tests, Too Little Care?
text: To the Editor:

text: To the Editor:

headline: In Debut on Market, Yelp Stock Surges 64%
text: Yelp may not yet be profitable, but investors still gave the company rave reviews in its debut.

headline: Pork and Prunes, a Classic Duo
text: In this week’s City Kitchen, we’re featuring the classic French bistro duo of roast pork and prunes. Though it is often made with pan-fried chops or larger pork roasts, I decided to use the popular and user-friendly cut called pork tenderloin. Even though it can be a bit pricier than other cuts, especially if purchased from a better butcher, there is no waste. I’ve found that a lean trimmed tenderloin weighing about a pound provides enough meat for four generous portions.

headline: To Rinse or Not To Rinse?
text: For years, I never allowed raw mushrooms, which figure prominently in my column this week, to touch water. I feared they’d bloat up and become enormous, waterlogged things that would never crisp in the pan. I wasn’t alone. This was the prevailing wisdom as passed down from veritable Chefs. And it may have been wrong.

headline: Calling for an End to Phony Military Discharges
text: To the Editor:

headline: Video Imagines Syrian First Lady’s Outrage Over Gaza War Applied to Killing in Homs
text: A video blogger has remixed footage of an interview Asma al-Assad gave to CNN in 2009, in which Syria’s British-born first lady decried the Israeli bombardment of Gaza, to make it seem as if she was speaking out against the violent crackdown on dissent currently under way in Syria.

headline: Old-World Charm, Maybe a Tableside Torch
text: IT’S easy to miss La Catena, which occupies one of the unprepossessing storefronts lining a long shopping strip in Ardsley. But you’ll need a reservation if you want to go there on a Saturday night. Diners have discovered this wonderfully old-fashioned Italian restaurant, which still operates in yesteryear’s formal yet friendly European style, delivering unrushed service from a gracious, attentive staff.

headline: Weekend Preview: Liverpool-Arsenal Is a Good Start to the Day
text: Rob Hughes previews the top matchups in Europe this weekend.

headline: Afghanistan and Vietnam
text: To the Editor:

headline: A House in the ’40s, Songs of Today
text: Suavely dragging on their cigarettes, tippling from their pocket flasks, and striking grandly languorous poses, the characters in the new musical “February House” look as if they stepped out of some fabulous movie Bette Davis forgot to make. But don’t be deceived. As soon as they open their mouths, it’s clear that while their outfits, the masterly work of Jess Goldstein, speak nostalgically of the 1940s, their songs absolutely, unconditionally sing of today — and herald the arrival of a major talent on the musical theater scene.

headline: Rocky Mountain Watering Holes
text: In Denver, quirky state alcohol laws, a storied brewing culture and a patchwork of well-carved neighborhoods have created ideal conditions for start-up breweries.

headline: Craft Brewing Finds a Welcoming Atmosphere
text: DENVER — Each time Scott Witsoe opens up his one-man brewery in a drab industrial park near downtown, he gets a rush of euphoria, a sensation quickly eclipsed by panic.

headline: French Journalists Return Home After 9 Days Trapped in Syria
text: VILLACOUBLAY, France — After escaping from the central Syrian city of Homs, where for nine days they were trapped in the besieged neighborhood of Baba Amr, two French journalists returned to France on Friday evening.

headline: Making Prints, and Leaving an Impact
text: EAST ISLIP, N.Y.

headline: The Week’s Business News in Pictures
text: The European debt crisis unfolded further, with Greece adopting emergency measures for borrowers and Spain abandoning its deficit-reduction goals. Gasoline prices rose, but the Federal Reserve held to its forecast for modest economic growth. Yelp had its initial public offering.

headline: CBS and MSG Looking Into Broadcasting Dodgers
text: CBS and Madison Square Garden are separately exploring the possibility of making a media rights deal with the Los Angeles Dodgers, two people briefed on their strategies said on Friday.

headline: Sounds Creamy and Abrasive
text: The voice of the St. Louis cabaret performer Craig Pomranz comes in two flavors.

headline: The Imperishable Presence of Citizen Hearst
text: William Randolph Hearst was born in California in 1863. William Randolph Hearst died in California in 1951. His most famous home, at San Simeon, is in California. His tomb is in California. And it was in California, 125 years ago Sunday, that he laid the foundation stone of his media empire, when his name appeared for the first time in The Daily Examiner of San Francisco as “W. R. Hearst, Proprietor.”

headline: Officials Tell of Fake Labels Hidden Beneath Fake Labels
text: NEWARK — With skin fashioned like hightop moccasins, they looked like popular UGG brand boots. But tags on their heels read “XMX,” and they had generic tread on their bottoms.

headline: A New Tenant, a Ruckus and a Corpse on the Stairs
text: The little landlady turned 89 years old last year in the house where she spent more than 50 of those years, the sort of warm home that breathed like a person, inhaling and exhaling loved ones.

headline: American Music Influenced by Europe
text: OVER the past decade, Copland House and the Caramoor Center for Music and the Arts, two of Westchester County’s leading cultural institutions, have forged a collaborative relationship. But on March 11, that relationship will briefly turn competitive. By chance, both institutions have scheduled concerts on that day, and both concerts explore perspectives on America that are framed, implicitly or explicitly, by views of Europe.

headline: At Angie’s List, the Reviews Are Real (So Is Angie)
text: INDIANAPOLIS

headline: Idaho Senator to Push Gay Rights Bill From the Outside
text: BOISE, Idaho — Lawmakers next door in Washington State just voted to legalize same-sex marriage. Here, they will not allow a bill to be formally filed that would protect gay people from basic forms of discrimination in areas like education, employment, public services and real estate transactions.

headline: Your Reviews of Angie’s List
text: All of the attention on Friday was on Yelp and its successful initial public offering. But I find Angie’s List to be much more intriguing from a consumer perspective.

headline: The Lin Songs Remain the Same: They Fall Short
text: There was Jeremy Lin on Wednesday night, blood streaming from his nose after taking a hit from Omri Casspi during the Knicks’ victory over the Cavaliers. Walking off the court, he tilted his head back, two red streaks spilling into his mouth — a hero defeated. But before long he was back in the game, and it was clear: here is a man in need of a worthy theme song.

headline: They’re Young, in Love and Willing to Commit (Minus Any Strings)
text: The hero and heroine of the Bollywood romance “London Paris New York,” written and directed by the newcomer Anu Menon, talk a lot about freedom. And as the title suggests, they search for it far from India and home.

headline: A Fox Hunt, With a $205,000 Prize
text: In Sunday’s Automobiles section, I write about a rare complete set of Lalique glass radiator ornaments consigned by RM Auctions for its coming sale, scheduled for March 10 in conjunction with the Amelia Island Concours d’Élégance in Florida.

headline: Of Bricks and Batteries: The Anatomy of a Controversy
text: In Sunday’s Automobiles section, Bradley Berman writes about bricking, a term that describes what happened to the battery pack of a Tesla Roadster electric sports car that had been left unplugged for an extended period and rendered useless — in other words, a brick.

headline: Albee Is Ready to Revisit His Past
text: When Edward Albee wrote “The Lady From Dubuque” in the late 1970s, at the time his most explicit play about mortality, he was coming off his second Pulitzer Prize for drama (for “Seascape”) and was deep in the throes of alcoholism. He lashed out at actresses like Ingrid Bergman, who were offered the title role but questioned the work’s surrealist dimensions; at the same time, as he later told his biographer, Mel Gussow, he was too drunk too often to fix problems that even he saw in the second act.

headline: Week in Pictures for March 2
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include an early bloom for flowers, the debate over a Whole Foods store in Brooklyn, and the closing of a legendary doo-wop record store.

headline: Santorum Calls for Investigation of Michigan Republican Party
text: Rick Santorum has asked the Republican National Committee to investigate the actions of the Michigan Republican Party, which on Thursday switched its decision to award a delegate to Mr. Santorum, giving it to Mitt Romney instead.

headline: Why Don’t We Read About Architecture?
text: “Buildings are everywhere,” writes Alexandra Lange, “large and small, ugly and beautiful, ambitious and dumb. We walk among them and live inside them but are largely passive dwellers in cities or towers, houses, open spaces, and shops we had no hand in creating.”

headline: A Grammy Winner Tests Himself
text: Writing for musical theater is the hardest thing the Grammy-winning songwriter Mike Reid, of Nashville, has ever done, he says, adding, “I’m not smart enough to know why, but it is.”

headline: When a Road Opened Under the Hudson
text: Hoboken, N.J.

headline: Starving Iran Won’t Free It
text: THERE’S an old saying, attributed to the British Foreign Office in colonial days: “Keep the Persians hungry, and the Arabs fat.” For the British — then the stewards of Persian destiny — that was the formula for maintaining calm; it still is for Saudi Arabian leaders, who simply distribute large amounts of cash to their citizens at the first sign of unrest at their doorstep.

headline: Contest Whose Winners May Not Succeed
text: New York’s BigApps contest, now in Version 3.0, has won no small amount of praise. Using data supplied by public agencies, Web developers compete for $50,000 in prizes, awarded based on voting by the public and a panel of judges. Voting on this year’s entries ends on Thursday.

headline: A Twist on Posthumous Baptisms Leaves Jews Miffed at Mormon Rite
text: “When you hear that your zayde, who died in Auschwitz, has become a Mormon, well, baruch ha-shem!” — blessed be God! — “that’s just what he always wanted.”

headline: Only Crippling Sanctions Will Stop Iran
text: Brussels

headline: Reviewing the Buick Regal GS
text: In Sunday’s Automobiles section, Lawrence Ulrich drives the 2012 Buick Regal GS, the sportiest version of a sedan that began life as a European corporate relation, the Opel Insignia.

headline: Satellite Images From Syria
text: Sometimes pictures are worth much, much more than a thousand words.

headline: Israel Guards Against Increased Terror Peril From a Laxly Patrolled Sinai
text: NEGEV DESERT, Israel — For decades, the striking ridges and shady passes of the western Negev Desert along Israel’s border with Egypt were an alluring gateway to the pristine beaches of the Sinai Peninsula.

headline: Rules Board to Consider Ending Ban on Hijabs
text: The long-disputed issue of whether Muslim women’s soccer players should be allowed to wear headscarves in games will be addressed Saturday at a meeting of the sport’s international rules board.

headline: The Poverty of an Idea
text: Clinton, N.Y.
