headline: Before Games, Religious Questions
text: With 500 students, increasing academic prestige and an established soccer team, Iman Academy SW, an Islamic school in Houston, was seeking membership in 2010 to the Texas Association of Private and Parochial Schools, a group that organizes competition among more than 200 schools in the state.

headline: In Stormy Weather, Grey Goose and Halibut
text: Hints of spring send hopeful diners in search of outdoor space, but when cold rain blows in, windows overlooking the street are the next best thing.

headline: In Washington Caucus, Expect the Unexpected
text: Only one pollster has been brave enough to survey Washington, which will hold its Republican caucus on Saturday. That firm, Public Policy Polling, polled the state once in mid-February and again this week.

headline: Model-Morphosis | Ginta Lapina at Lanvin
text: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of the Fall 2012 Fashion Week in Paris. Here, the model Ginta Lapina of Women Model Management before (left) and after (right) transforms, with makeup by Pat McGrath and hair by Guido Palau.

headline: Furor Over Report Hints at a Chinese Policy Debate
text: SHANGHAI — When the World Bank and a Chinese research organization called on Beijing policy makers this week to scale back the power of state-owned companies, reform-minded economists offered praise. But not everyone is pleased.

headline: In New Jersey, a Battle Over a Fluoridation Bill, and the Facts
text: For all its renown as an engine of pharmaceutical and biotechnology progress, New Jersey has long lagged in what public health officials call one of the 10 biggest health advances of the last century: fluoridating its water.

headline: From Police Beat to Prayer Beads
text: FOR more than 20 years, he was Officer James Georges of the New York Police Department. Now he goes by the ancient Egyptian name Baba Heru Semahj.

headline: Out of the Bronx, a Gymnast Sets Sights on Gold
text: It would usually take an hour or more, depending on traffic, for Damaris Orozco to drive her youngest son a world away, from the far edge of the Bronx to World Cup Gymnastics in suburban Westchester County. At first it was a couple of times a week. But John Orozco was 9 when coaches saw Olympic potential. Soon, it was six days a week, even seven.

headline: You Can’t Spell ‘Bowling’ Without L-I-N.
text: Fans and news media, still ever-hungry for new factoids on all things Jeremy Lin, got another morsel at Friday night’s 13th Annual Knick Bowl on Pier 60 of Chelsea Piers.

headline: Putin Gains as Foes Offer Little Threat
text: MOSCOW — The subject up for discussion was Russia’s educational system. But for Vladimir V. Zhirinovsky, who will challenge Vladimir V. Putin in Sunday’s presidential elections, it was just another occasion for a jaunt into crazy land.

headline: For Stroller Maker, Bankruptcy Is Latest Setback
text: For years, Maclaren strollers have carried babies — along with a certain prestige — on the sidewalks of well-heeled neighborhoods from Park Slope to Palo Alto.

headline: Gillis Leads and Woods Rescues His Round
text: PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla. — Tom Gillis may hold a share of the 36-hole lead at the Honda Classic, but he has no illusions about his place in golf.

headline: Deadly Tornadoes Pound the South and the Midwest
text: A frantic day and night of fast-moving tornadoes and severe thunderstorms churned across the South and the Midwest on Friday, leaving behind at least 27 deaths, hundreds of injuries and countless damaged buildings in several states.

headline: The Yankees Explain Their Fiscal Austerity
text: TAMPA, Fla. — On Thursday, Hal Steinbrenner, the Yankees’ managing general partner, declared that the Yankees would cut roughly $20 million from their payroll over the next two years. That would get them under baseball’s $189 million luxury-tax threshold, which serves as a kind of soft salary cap.

headline: Crushing Homs
text: After a month of merciless bombardment, the forces of President Bashar al-Assad of Syria have taken Homs, the main rebel stronghold. Many of the brave residents have fled the city or been killed, adding to a death toll now estimated at more than 7,500 since the unrest began.

headline: Apps Seek to Help Phone Users Track Data
text: BARCELONA, Spain — Cellphone carriers are forcing customers to think about how much data they are slurping up as they watch YouTube and stream music from Pandora. In the United States, customers with unlimited plans who use a lot of data have found themselves forced into a network slow lane.

headline: How Graffiti Goats Became a Symbol of ... Something
text: KINGSTON, N.Y. — The red goats of Kingston came from nowhere. One day there were new, clunky white planters in the stockade district and then, mysteriously, in October they became canvases for about 37 stenciled goats, red on white, like ghost goats from another world.

headline: Builders of Casino Empire Split, and the Bitter Accusations Fly
text: MACAO — For more than a decade, they were the odd couple of gambling.

headline: Balancing Parenthood and Politics
text: Weekends are rarely a respite for Scott M. Stringer, the Manhattan borough president and a likely contender in the 2013 mayoral race; he has treated politics as a 24/7 job since he was a teenager rounding up votes for his cousin, Congresswoman Bella Abzug. But a recent entry into fatherhood has forced Mr. Stringer, 51, to reconsider Sunday priorities. His schedule of parades and rallies now must make room for feedings and naptime with 3-month-old Max, his son with Elyse Buxbaum, 39, an associate director at the Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum. The couple, who married in 2010, live on the Upper West Side.

headline: How to Pay for Pensions
text: State and local governments everywhere are in sticker shock over the rising cost of public-employee pensions and scrambling to manage those obligations. New York State has taken a reasonable approach that allows public employers to pay a portion of their yearly contributions to New York’s $140 billion public pension fund and to pay the remainder in installments, with interest, over a decade.

headline: A Better Chance to Succeed
text: The Obama administration is rightly pushing colleges to raise graduation rates and to make sure that more students graduate on time. To help achieve those goals, the community college systems that enroll about 11 million students need to end the practice of shunting students who are prepared for college into non-credit remedial classes that chew up financial aid while making it far less likely that they will ever graduate.

headline: Archives on a 20th-Century Diaspora Are Being Put Online
text: Jews are known for their wanderings, even if those have not always been at their own instigation, and one of the most sweeping chronicles of their migrations has been stored at the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee, a relief and rescue organization that is almost 100 years old.

headline: Carlyle Acquires Stake in Brazilian Toy Chain
text: The Carlyle Group, a private equity firm in Washington, said Friday that it had acquired an 85 percent stake in Ri Happy, Brazil’s largest toy chain, for an undisclosed amount. The firm plans to invest 200 million Brazilian reais ($116.8 million) in the toy retailer over the next three years. “This is a segment with significant growth potential in Brazil,” said Juan Carlos Felix, Carlyle’s managing director for Brazil. Since its first Brazilian investment in late 2009, Carlyle has steadily increased its exposure to the country’s consumer market. It owns major stakes in CVC, a tourism operator, and Scalia, a major Brazilian lingerie retailer. With Ri Happy, Carlyle is trying to find opportunity in Brazil’s fragmented toy market. The company has an online store, 114 brick-and-mortar locations and 2,300 employees.

headline: In the Sky Above
text: Sometime in the next few nights, if the sky is clear, go out and find the western horizon just after dark. Look for the Moon and the two bright objects below it — the planets Jupiter and, closer to the horizon, Venus — all in a rare moment of alignment. Mercury will have just set, and in the east, Mars will be rising. If you’re able to watch the sky for several nights in a row, into early March, Jupiter and Venus will appear to be getting closer and closer to each other while the Moon drops behind, even as it swells toward full moon on March 8.

headline: Zollie Volchok, an N.B.A. Showman, Is Dead at 95
text: Zollie Volchok, a onetime theater manager and entertainment promoter who as general manager and president of the Seattle SuperSonics lured legions of fans to their arena and helped lead the franchise to its only N.B.A. championship, died Sunday in Seattle. He was 95.

headline: An Amateur Snapshot of Kodak’s Early Days
text: Was this the first Kodak moment?

headline: Saved by Taco Bell
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — Welcome back, Byron Walden. It’s been quite a while since we’ve had the pleasure of doing one of your puzzles, but we understand; you’ve been a busy guy, what with holding down a full-time job as a math professor and welcoming your first child into the world.

headline: Rooting for Santorum
text: I’m rooting for Rick Santorum to win the Republican nomination. Seriously.

headline: In Court Filing, Taymor Says ‘Spider-Man’ Producers Are Trying to Ruin Her Reputation
text: 1:11 p.m. | Updated  Julie Taymor, who filed suit after she was fired as director of the $75 million Broadway musical “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark” last March, said in court papers Friday that the producers’ counter-suit was “highly sensationalistic, false and misleading” and aimed at “assassinating her character and professional reputation.”

headline: James Q. Wilson Dies at 80; Originated ‘Broken Windows’ Policing Strategy
text: James Q. Wilson, a wide-ranging social scientist whose “broken windows” theory of law enforcement laid the groundwork for crime reduction programs in New York, Los Angeles and other cities, died on Friday in Boston. He was 80.

headline: Santorum and the Sexual Revolution
text: Rick Santorum wants to bring sexy back ... to the 1950s, when he was born.

headline: With Lin and Davis, Knicks Look to Spread the Wealth
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — As their practice drew to a close Friday, the Knicks conducted a full-court scrimmage. Nearing the end of a stretch of the schedule in which they have played only one game in nine days, the players competed passionately and vigorously. Amar’e Stoudemire attacked the rim. Carmelo Anthony was vocal. Iman Shumpert and J. R. Smith oozed confidence.

headline: A Pipe Dream Comes to Life
text: IN 1976, my membership certificate for Keen’s English Chop House’s Pipe Club arrived in my parents’ mailbox, a gift from my godfather, James Elkins McIlvain. I hadn’t yet turned 2. I never did ask Uncle Jim whether the gesture was a hope that I, too, would one day puff away at his favorite hangout, or if he merely giggled at the image of an infant inhaling from such an instrument — it looked as if it should be filled with opium rather than aged tobacco — like some sort of diaper-clad burgher.

headline: Harvard Avoids Upset at Columbia
text: With Harvard in town and the Knicks off, fans crammed into Columbia’s sold-out Levien Gym using their deductive reasoning: might Jeremy Lin show up?

headline: Colorful Owner’s White Horse Is the Bettors’ Favorite
text: A blue horse has never won the Gotham Stakes, and that will not change Saturday at Aqueduct. The field consists of four bays, four dark bays, four chestnuts and a nearly white horse, Hansen, who is drawing all the attention because he is the 2-year-old champion and because his co-owner and breeder wanted to color his mane and tail blue for the race.

headline: Tornadoes Hit South and Midwest
text: Several tornadoes, spawned by powerful storms that steamrolled across multiple states in the South and Midwest on Friday, caused critical injuries and widespread damage from Alabama to south-central Indiana.

headline: Bill Cunningham | To a Man
text: The most innovative fashion statements made by guests at the recent New York fashion shows came not from women but from creative young men.

headline: Democratic State Senator, His District Threatened, Focuses on Party’s Future
text: Michael N. Gianaris, a Democratic state senator from Astoria, Queens, was in bed at 11:30 one night in January when a reporter called. Republicans were drafting new Senate districts to reflect the 2010 census, and word had leaked of what they had in store for Mr. Gianaris: his neighborhood would be appended to the district of a fellow Democratic senator.

headline: Romney Trying to Recast Wealth to Be Seen as Asset
text: BELLEVUE, Wash. — Mitt Romney is best known as a private equity specialist, but he is trying to transform himself into a primary care physician for an ailing nation.

text: March 2, 2012

text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: Documenting the Wanderings of 20th-Century Jews
text: The vast archives of the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee contain documentary and photographic records of the migration of the Jewish people since the World War I years.

headline: Food Co-op Politics Leave a Bad Taste
text: Many years ago, after graduating from college to a $15,600-a-year job as an editorial assistant, I moved to Park Slope, celebrating my pioneering spirit. It was the late 1980s, long before the affluent enclaves of Brooklyn had become an ever-expanding temple to all the different things that might be done with Tuscan kale. The Park Slope Food Co-op was the center of culinary interest, such as it was. I wanted to love it, but a brief flirtation confirmed my suspicions that the co-op was a place where people in overalls behaved unpleasantly toward you and where arriving at consensus over the price of a plum took longer than the first and second phases of the Strategic Arms Limitations Talks.

headline: ‘Super PACs,’ Not Campaigns, Do Bulk of Ad Spending
text: The crucial role the “super PAC” now plays in modern presidential politics has been on vivid display in the week before the Super Tuesday primaries, as these outside groups have all outspent the campaigns and become their de facto advertising arms.

headline: Bruce Pask on Packing
text: Bruce Pask, a world traveler and the men’s fashion director for T Magazine, checks in to the Ace Hotel in New York to talk through eight travel tips.

headline: Accord Reached Settling Lawsuit Over BP Oil Spill
text: BP and the lawyers for plaintiffs in the trial over the 2010 oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico have agreed to settle their case.

headline: Amid Tension, a Day to Vote
text: Iranians took part in the first national vote since the disputed presidential election of 2009.

headline: British Premier Changes Horse Stories Mid-Scandal
text: LONDON — British papers have dubbed it “horsegate.”

headline: Canada: Agency Investigates Complaints of Mass Irregularities in 2011 Election
text: The independent federal elections agency, Elections Canada, said Friday that it was investigating more than 31,000 complaints of voting irregularities related to automated telephone calls during the last election. While it gave no details in its brief statement, accusations that the governing Conservatives used such calls to suppress voting during the May 2011 election have dominated the political debate recently. Court documents indicate that calls claiming to be from Elections Canada were made to supporters of other parties, telling them falsely that their voting stations had been moved, often over great distances. Those documents also suggest connections between the calls and the Conservative Party. Prime Minister Stephen Harper and other Conservatives have denied any wrongdoing.

headline: Maurice André, Trumpeter, Dies at 78
text: Maurice André, a virtuoso credited with having transformed the trumpet from a workaday cog in the back of the orchestra into a seductive solo instrument in front, died on Feb. 25 in Bayonne, in southwest France. He was 78.

headline: Mapping the N.B.A.
text: The world of sports geekdom has always been about the numbers. Increasingly, though, it may be about the maps.

headline: Newswallah: Bollywood Edition
text: Irrfan Khan: In “Paan Singh Tomar,” Irrfan Khan plays a sportsman who becomes a bandit. The actor discusses his “life’s most demanding role.”

headline: Updated: Goal Line Technology Takes Another Step Forward
text: 8:46 a.m. | Update On Saturday in Bagshot, England, the I.F.A.B. decided to proceed with the testing of two-goal line technologies before a vote in July, which could lead to the use of the winning system in the 2014 World Cup in Brazil.

headline: Virginia: Court Rules for University
text: The Virginia Supreme Court ruled Friday that the state attorney general, Kenneth T. Cuccinelli, does not have the authority to demand records of e-mails or grant applications sent by a climate scientist who taught at the University of Virginia. Mr. Cuccinelli since 2010 has sought to force the university to release documents for five grant applications made by the scientist, Michael E. Mann, and related e-mails, saying he suspected that Dr. Mann used fraudulent climate data to secure grants. A lower court also denied the request, saying Mr. Cuccinelli presented nothing to back up his accusation. Dr. Mann, the author of influential research charting a marked rise in global temperatures, has long been a target of climate change skeptics like Mr. Cuccinelli. The State Supreme Court agreed with the university that Mr. Cuccinelli exceeded his authority. “Today, the court effectively held that state agencies do not have to provide state-owned property to state investigators looking into potential fraud involving government funds,” Mr. Cuccinelli said in a statement critical of the ruling. Dr. Mann said he was pleased, adding, “It’s sad, though, that so much money and resources had to be wasted on Cuccinelli’s witch hunt.”

headline: Study Shows Danger of Diesel Exhaust
text: Miners exposed to high levels of diesel exhaust have three to five times the risks of lung cancer as workers in occupations where diesel exhaust exposures are less intense, according to a study by government researchers. The study, by researchers from the National Cancer Institute and the National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health, shows the dangers of diesel exhaust not only in workplace settings but also for anyone living in urban areas, the researchers said. The study will be published Monday on the Web site of the Journal of the National Cancer Institute, despite letters sent by a lawyer for a mining consortium warning of legal consequences to publishing the results.

text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
text: Jammu and Kashmir: The first-ever winter festival in the hill station of Gulmarg will be held March 9-11. The three-day event will include adventure sports and performances by bands from across the country. The organizers expect a crowd of 2,000 people to attend the festival (The Indian Express).

headline: On the Lanvin Express With Alber Elbaz
text: I had such a sinking feeling after the Lanvin show on Friday night: I didn’t want it to end. The last dozen or so models were really decked out in party wear — furs, jewels, over-the-top patterns, real babes — and I was just getting into it when the house lights dimmed.

text: Today’s Times

headline: Apocalyptic Vision of London Rankles the Locals
text: LONDON — Oh, dear. We Londoners appear to have abandoned our proverbial good manners and even our legendary chirpy sense of humor in response to a New York Times Magazine special that offers a dystopian vision of our great city just months before it hosts the Olympic Games.

headline: This Sunday: London in Pictures
text: More work from Idris Khan, the artist behind this week’s cover image.

headline: Reagan, Obama, Austerity
text: A followup on the effects of austerity at the state and local government level, which have led to a decline in government purchases of goods and services that stands in stark contrast to earlier recoveries. I pursued this a bit more, and have a startling calculation to offer.

headline: Japanese Prime Minister Says Government Shares Blame for Nuclear Disaster
text: TOKYO — Prime Minister Yoshihiko Noda of Japan acknowledged on Saturday that the government shared the blame for the disaster at the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant, saying that officials had been blinded by a false belief in the country’s technological infallibility, even as he vowed to push for the idled reactors to be restarted.

headline: What They’re Saying About the Saints’ Bounties
text: Why did the Saints pay players to injure opponents? Because they, like other franchises that have used a similar system, thought it would help them win. And by all appearances it worked: The Saints won the Super Bowl in the 2009 season, and their defense during that playoff run was as violent and intimidating as had been seen in the league for quite a while.

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | Christian Dior
text: “Slick and tight,” is how Orlando Pita described the low ponytails backstage at Dior. He was careful to use his T3 Control Hairspray to make sure the deep side part was secure with hair scraped diagonal across the forehead — no comb indentations or wet-looking strands. The difference between this ponytail and others was that it was really low, lying against the neck and perfectly coiffed with a strand wrapped around the band. Pita gestured to a model in her street clothes and a bright red bag. “They’re wearing their scarves and kissing friends,” he said of the girls’ potential to create flyways while running around backstage. By the time they’re ready to hit the runway, he would be certain the look was once again perfect. Makeup was more understated — no lip, full lashes and CoverGirl 1-Kit Eye Enhancers in Swiss Chocolate with Mink shadow and gold shimmer all the way to the temple. For the face, it was Lush Berry and Plush Peach CoverGirl & Olay Simply Ageless Blush. “We played with many versions of natural,” Pat McGrath said. “This is very fresh, very pretty.”

headline: Towns Search for Survivors After Widespread Storms
text: MARYSVILLE, Ind. — Here in this small farmland community, a single water tower emblazoned with the town’s name — the most commanding structure in the town — appeared to be the only thing not battered by the storms that cut a swath through southeastern Indiana.

headline: Face Time | Kristin Chenoweth
text: This past New York Fashion Week, I popped by Kristin Chenoweth’s apartment to help her with her makeup and chat before she darted off to Nanette Lepore’s Fall 2012 ready-to-wear show. She thought a simple ponytail and sweet pink cheeks and lips would compliment her dress, so I whipped out my Clinique Chubby Stick in Woppin’ Watermelon and L’Oréal True Match Blush in Tender Rose. Kristin effortlessly applied a strip of lashes — my favorite Andrea Modlash in #53…perfection! As she got ready, she told me how excited she was about the season opener for her new ABC show, “GCB” (Good Christian Belles). I know where I’ll be this Sunday evening at 10 p.m. — glued to my television!

headline: Tourism Up, Mexico Aims for Non-U.S. Visitors
text: Last year 22.67 million travelers visited Mexico, breaking the record set in 2008. The United States was the source of the largest number of visitors, but the increase was also driven by travelers from other countries.

headline: That Well-Lighted Agent of Desire
text: THE seven films in which Josef von Sternberg directed Marlene Dietrich constitute one of the most dazzling runs of creativity in the history of the movies. Released by Paramount Pictures between 1930 and 1935, these are works of breathtaking formal beauty, profound moral philosophy and devastating wit.

headline: Duke and North Carolina Prepare to Write Another Chapter
text: One of the most heated rivalries in college sports will add another chapter to its storyline Saturday evening, this time with a regular-season championship hanging in the balance. North Carolina (26-4, 13-2 Atlantic Coast Conference) and Duke (26-4, 13-2 A.C.C.) will face off in historic Cameron Indoor Stadium at 7 p.m., as the Tar Heels will try to atone for their collapse against the Blue Devils in Chapel Hill nearly one month ago, and win their fifth regular-season title in the last six years. The last time Duke hosted North Carolina to end the season, in 2010, the Blue Devils won by 32 points in what was the most one-sided victory in the history of the rivalry — something that Duke senior Miles Plumlee will be hoping to replicate in his final game on Coach K Court.

headline: Variety: A Sharp Diagramless
text: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE — When I finished this one, I thought it looked, minus the blood, sweat and tears, like a midcentury painting with its scattered, chunky rectangles of black space.

headline: High School Players Forced to Choose in Soccer’s New Way
text: Professional sports leagues in the United States have long relied on high schools to help cultivate the country’s best athletes. Rosters in Major League Baseball, the N.F.L. and the N.B.A. are filled with former scholastic stars, many of whom hold tightly to their quintessentially American memories of homecoming, letterman jackets and games played under the Friday night lights.

headline: Bearing Witness in Syria: A Correspondent’s Last Days

We were also crossing from peace into war, into the bloodiest conflict of the Arab Spring, exploding just up the rocky and sparsely wooded mountain we had to climb once inside.

headline: Steady Rangers Ready for Up-and-Down Bruins

As the teams head into their game Sunday afternoon at Madison Square Garden, Bruins Coach Claude Julien has been patient with his defending Stanley Cup champions, while Rangers Coach John Tortorella relentlessly pushes buttons.

headline: 30 Seconds With Rod Gilbert: Out of Game, Not Out of Goals
text: In the 1960s and ’70s, Rod Gilbert played wing on the Rangers’ Goal-a-Game, or GAG, line, with Jean Ratelle and Vic Hadfield, compiling 406 goals and 1,021 points over 16 seasons, with 34 playoff goals. Gilbert, who wore No. 7 and was the first Ranger to have his number retired, was inducted into the Hockey Hall of Fame in 1982.

headline: When Living in Limbo Avoids Living on the Street

A perennial Stanley Cup contender, the Red Wings are known as a clean team, ranked among the bottom four N.H.L. clubs in penalty minutes in seven of the last eight seasons, and among the bottom four in fighting majors in each of the last 15 seasons.

text: A string of violent storms demolished small towns in Indiana and cut off rural communities in Kentucky as an early season tornado outbreak killed more than 30 people, and the death toll rose as daylight broke on Saturday’s search for survivors.

headline: Romney Advisers Chide Santorum on Delegates
text: DAYTON, Ohio — Mitt Romney’s campaign has said from the very beginning that the Republican nominating contest would likely be a long slog to get the 1,144 delegates needed to win the party’s nomination. And as the campaign made clear in a conference call on Saturday afternoon, it believes that Rick Santorum made a crippling stumble going into Super Tuesday, the March 6 primaries in which 10 states are in play.

headline: The Port Huron Statement at 50
text: THEY are mostly in their 70s now, those quixotic college students who drafted the Port Huron Statement at a ramshackle A.F.L.-C.I.O. education retreat northeast of Detroit in 1962. Today, their “agenda for a generation” survives most famously as a punch line from the 1998 film “The Big Lebowski” in which the stoner protagonist proclaims himself an author of “the original Port Huron Statement, not the compromised second draft.” Purists like Jeff “The Dude” Lebowski might dissent, but last month the historian Michael Kazin pronounced the final draft “the most ambitious, the most specific and the most eloquent manifesto in the history of the American left.”

headline: Confessions of a ‘Bad’ Teacher
text: I AM a special education teacher. My students have learning disabilities ranging from autism and attention-deficit disorder to cerebral palsy and emotional disturbances. I love these kids, but they can be a handful. Almost without exception, they struggle on standardized tests, frustrate their teachers and find it hard to connect with their peers. What’s more, these are high school students, so their disabilities are compounded by raging hormones and social pressure.

headline: U.S. Backers of Israel Pressure Obama Over Policy on Iran

The Platonic ideal of an alienating Facebook profile — one that will keep potential seatmates far, far away — should look something like this:

headline: Genes on the March
text: MY mother always said I must be part Mongolian, because of my lotus-pale complexion and squid-ink black hair. “Something you’re not telling me?” I was tempted to ask. But I knew she’d visited Mongolia with my father long after I was born. What I didn’t know is that one out of every 200 males on earth is related to Genghis Khan.

headline: The Truth About the Doomsday Virus?
text: Two months ago we warned that a new bird flu virus — modified in a laboratory to make it transmissible through the air among mammals — could kill millions of people if it escaped confinement or was stolen by terrorists. Now Ron Fouchier, the Dutch scientist who led the key research team, is saying that his findings, which remain confidential, were misconstrued by the press.

headline: We Know How to Spell Relief

headline: The Scholar and the Rascal
text: THE right-wing provocateur Andrew Breitbart and the neoconservative scholar James Q. Wilson, who died within 48 hours of each other last week — Wilson at the age of 80, Breitbart so unexpectedly at 43 — had one important thing in common: They were both prominent conservatives who arguably left their most enduring legacy in the lives of affluent, cosmopolitan liberals.

headline: Take the Subway
text: OUR plan was to meet for lunch at noon in Moscow. It was to be just myself and Fyodor Lukyanov, the editor of the journal Russia in Global Affairs. He picked the restaurant. It had been snowing that day, and the Moscow traffic — already nearly impossible because the city, which 15 years ago had 300,000 cars and today hosts nearly four million registered vehicles — was even more impossible than usual. Soon the e-mailing between us started. I was first: “I’m running a few minutes late.” Lukyanov said the same a few minutes later. Then me again: “I am going to be 20 minutes late.” He then saw my 20 minutes and raised me 20. In the end, I was 50 minutes late, and I beat him by two minutes. We sped through an interview about Russian foreign policy in 30 minutes, before I rushed out so as not to be late for my next appointment. As we hurriedly put on our coats, Lukyanov had one piece of advice for me, and it wasn’t that the U.S. should stay out of Syria.

headline: French-German Border Shapes More Than Territory
text: SÉLESTAT, France — This ancient town in the center of Alsace boasts the extraordinary Humanist Library, dating from the 15th century. But less proudly, Sélestat also has an unemployment rate of about 8 percent, much higher than towns just across the border in Germany.

headline: Creating a Niche, and Earning a Promotion
text: WHEN you’re an employee of a company, no matter the size, it’s common to see co-workers promoted, or transferred to a different department. But there is another way to move around: by creating a new position for yourself. I did this several years ago, though I wasn’t actively looking for a different job.

headline: A War on Women?
text: My Sunday column focuses on the growing number of states that are adding new restrictions to abortions, cutting family planning or taking other steps that in some cases seem patronizing and insulting to women. The most remarkable example is Texas, which has received little attention that subjects many women who want an abortion to a vaginal ultrasound and forces them to hear a description of the fetus. And there’s more, as I recount in the column. I find all this deeply offensive– what about you? I’d welcome your comments.

headline: Coach Who Preached Violence Rewarded It for Years
text: By the time Josh Evans got to the Houston Oilers in 1995, the bounty system — and Gregg Williams — were fixtures. Williams coached the linebackers then, but by 1997, the team had moved to Tennessee and Williams was the defensive coordinator. The bounties remained in place.

headline: The Fall of the House of Underwood
text: For Josie Underwood, much was in a name. Her hilltop home, Mount Air, “the dearest old home in the world,” lay just a mile northeast of Bowling Green, Ky., overlooking the Louisville and Nashville Railroad that ran three-quarters away, across the Barren River. Fields of corn and wheat waved heavy in the rich bottomland looping around the north and east sides of the 1,000-acre farm, one of the largest in the region. It was, as one Pennsylvania visitor claimed, “The realization of all he had read and imagined of a hospitable Southern home.” Among its most distinguishing features, he noted, was the knot of slave cabins that lay off the home place’s east gable.

headline: Celebrating Where San Francisco’s Black Roots Run Deepest
text: When Michelle Long saw workers throwing out documents at her San Francisco church, Bethel African Methodist Episcopal, at a conference 12 years ago, she decided something had to be done — so she became the church archivist.

headline: Companies Foreclose; Blight Follows
text: Every few weeks, Alvin Chandra cleans up the garbage that has accumulated in the vacant lot next to his granite fabrication plant on Adeline Street in West Oakland — soiled mattresses, worn-out sofa beds and piles of used fast food containers.

headline: Taking Development Out of the Schools
text: Sam Borden writes Sunday about a rules change that has split the forces of soccer development in the United States. An excerpt: The United States Soccer Federation announced a new policy recently that will uncouple high school soccer and the training of top youth players, a move that is unique among major team sports in this country and, some believe, is indicative of a trend in the way the United States develops elite athletes. The shift by the federation applies to its top boys teams around the country, requiring players on those teams — known as Development Academy teams — to participate in a nearly year-round season and, by extension, forcing them and their soccer moms and dads to decide whether they should play for their club or play for their school. Read the article here, and join the discussion in the comments.

headline: Stan Stearns, Photographer of John F. Kennedy Jr.’s Salute to Father, Dies at 76
text: Stan Stearns, whose iconic photograph of John F. Kennedy Jr. saluting his father’s coffin on Nov. 25, 1963, helped encapsulate a nation’s grief, died Friday at a hospice near Annapolis, Md. He was 76.

headline: Hansen Takes Charge in the Gotham and Steadies His Shaky Derby Profile
text: It wasn’t just that Hansen won the Gotham Stakes at Aqueduct on Saturday, but how he won. He was coming off a second-place finish in the Holy Bull Stakes at Gulfstream, where he stumbled at the start, darted feverishly to the lead, tired late and acted nothing like the kind of horse who could win the Kentucky Derby, but he did everything right at Aqueduct.

headline: They’re Gaga Over The Lady
text: HONG KONG — Much of her country is gaga for The Lady, as she is known, and crowds in Myanmar are swarming her campaign speeches and pro-democracy rallies. Daw Aung San Suu Kyi was, of course, born this way: Her late father, General Aung San, led the fight for Burma’s independence from Britain and remains a national hero.

headline: Bulwinkleland
text: A brightly colored Quonset hut on a West Oakland street appears to be sprouting sunflowers, but it is actually the studio and home of Mark Bulwinkle, an artist. The structure and surrounding land are crammed with sculptures featuring whimsical and sometimes diabolical images of cavorting animals and people. Covering nine city lots, Bulwinkleland — as the artist calls his homestead — is jaw-dropping.

headline: A Young Bush Works to Nurture Hispanic Roots Within the Republican Party
text: The seeds of political ascension for a member of the Bush family may have been planted in an Austin eatery whose name conjures up images of Janis Joplin jam sessions.

headline: Austin Auteur Tries Traditional but Stays Eccentric
text: Among followers of the independent film scene, the name Bob Byington usually inspires a knowing, if furtive, smile of recognition: Mr. Byington, an Austin-based writer-director, is one of those best-kept secrets that fans prefer to keep to themselves, for fear that if everyone knows about him, he won’t seem nearly as cool.

headline: In Battle for Political Conquest, Ethnicity Sets the Boundaries for Both Parties
text: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor at The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

headline: Another Sunday Offers Another Chance for McIlroy to Claim No. 1 Ranking
text: PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla. — As Rory McIlroy stalks his third PGA Tour victory, the greatest impediment is not PGA National’s Bear Trap, the three consecutive holes beginning with No. 15 that McIlroy has played in 13 over par in 15 career rounds.

headline: New Plans to Improve Performance at T.S.U.
text: With a mere 3 percent of Texas Southern University students graduating within four years — and less than a quarter earning their degree in a decade — the school’s president, John Rudley, knows that people are asking “What’s wrong with this institution?” and “What are they going to do about it?”

headline: Mets Say Davis Has Valley Fever
text: The Mets said they believed first baseman Ike Davis had valley fever, a fungal infection of the lungs. Davis has not been showing any outward symptoms, is not contagious and is not taking medication, the team said in a statement. The team said the infection was expected to resolve itself on its own.

headline: Tar Heels Prove Too Much for Duke and Win A.C.C.
text: DURHAM, N.C. — Duke season highlights were playing on the scoreboard above center court at Cameron Indoor Stadium on Saturday night before the Blue Devils took on North Carolina in the Atlantic Coast Conference regular-season finale. It was not hard to guess which play drew the loudest cheers: a 3-pointer at the buzzer by the freshman Austin Rivers that beat the Tar Heels in the teams’ previous meeting this season.

headline: Alex Webster, Giants Running Back and Coach, Dies at 80
text: Alex Webster, a powerful running back who helped propel the Giants to six division titles and a National Football League championship in the late 1950s and early ’60s and later became their coach for five seasons, died Saturday in Port St. Lucie, Fla. He was 80.

headline: Washington Keeps Romney on Winning Track
text: With 77 percent of the vote counted in the Washington caucuses, Mr. Romney won about 36 percent of the straw-poll vote there. His total may vary slightly as additional votes trickle in, but it should remain somewhere in that range, and he has been declared the winner by The Associated Press.

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | Vivienne Westwood
text: “We need lots more sequins! We don’t have enough sequins!” the makeup artist Val Garland said backstage at Vivienne Westwood. She was calling for more of her custom opalescent sequin tears to be applied to Botticelli-inspired faces. “They’re beautiful, celestial beings looking up to the heavens, crying in ecstasy,” she said of the models with red-pink or “tea-stained” lids. The look was created using M.A.C. copper walnut Sculpting Cream all around and inside the eye along with Fascinating Eye Kohl. A shell highlighter was applied along the jawline, to create the effect of gazing up into light. Mahogany and Vino lip pencils lined a mouth that was then touched with Naturally Defined Sculpting Cream and set with Prep and Prime finishing powder. Then, came the tears. Sam McKnight made a pretty and wild nest of hair using Pantene Volume Mousse and Volume and Body Hairspray and pulling two sides back leaving half the hair down, then looping it over and through where it was already tied. It took only a few pins to secure the style after he pulled out strands using what he described as a “simple, childlike gesture.” He thought the whole elegant mess might be made by a young girl — channeling Caravaggio, of course.

headline: ‘Dr. Seuss’ The Lorax’ Has Huge Opening Weekend
text: Pent-up demand for a family film and a well-executed marketing campaign by Universal Pictures sent “Dr. Seuss’ The Lorax” into the box-office stratosphere over the weekend. With an estimated $70.7 million in ticket sales in North America, “The Lorax,” about a mustachioed critter with a tree-saving mantra, was a huge No. 1 despite poor reviews. (In The New York Times, A.O. Scott called it “a noisy, useless piece of junk.”

headline: Philosophy by Another Name
text: Every professional philosopher, or student of philosophy, knows how linguistically confusing the name of our discipline can be when talking to people outside the field. They immediately assume you are in the business of offering sage advice, usually in the form of unargued aphorisms and proverbs. You struggle to explain that you don’t do that kind of philosophy, at which point you may well be accused of abandoning your historical calling — unearthing and explicating the “meaning of life” and what the ultimate human goods are. You may then be castigated for not being a “real philosopher,” by contrast with assorted gurus, preachers, homeopaths and twinkly barroom advice givers. Our subject then falls into disrepute and incomprehension.

headline: Dozens of Yemeni Soldiers Reported Dead in Militant Attack
text: ADEN, Yemen — Islamist militants bombarded an army encampment near the city of Zinjibar in southern Yemen on Sunday, and dozens of soldiers and militants were reported killed. Zinjibar is one of two cities that the Yemeni government has sworn to take back by force from the militants’ control.

headline: Rangers Make It Three in a Row Against the Bruins
text: The Rangers have beaten the Boston Bruins all three times they have played this season, and the reason, simply put, is goaltending. It is why the Rangers are in first place in the Eastern Conference, and why, over the past six weeks, the Bruins have tumbled from within a whisker of first place into the jumble of teams far below.

headline: A Rootless Writer, Anchored by Woe
text: The novels of Joseph Roth, with the three-generation family saga “Radetzky March” in the forefront, have enjoyed a remarkable resurgence of interest in recent years, so much so that Roth is now often mentioned in the same breath as Kafka and Robert Musil as one of the greatest German-language writers of the 20th century. But in the absence of a biography Roth the man has remained largely an unknown to readers, at least in the English-speaking world.

headline: Quaint Martian Odyssey With Multiplex Stopover
text: “John Carter,” Disney’s $250 million, 3-D sci-fi epic, which opens on Friday, is based on a novel, Edgar Rice Burroughs’s “Princess of Mars,” that is 100 years old and was already a little dated when it came out. Burroughs, better known for his Tarzan saga, published it in monthly installments in the All-Story Magazine starting in February 1912. It was the first thing he ever wrote, after a lifetime of failing at just about everything else, and he was clearly learning on the job.

headline: Playing It Safe in Programming Philharmonic
text: Ideally, being the music director of a major symphony orchestra involves more than planning seasons and conducting concerts: it offers a chance to be a cultural leader and educator. Alan Gilbert’s predecessor at the New York Philharmonic, Lorin Maazel, showed scant interest in those aspects of the job. Since arriving in 2009 Mr. Gilbert has embraced them.

headline: Bouquets and Bravas for the Met’s Sudden Aida
text: As often happens with cover singers at the Metropolitan Opera the soprano Latonia Moore had less than a day’s notice to take over a major part, in her case the title role of Verdi’s “Aida” on Saturday afternoon. Violeta Urmana, scheduled to sing, was ill. (Sondra Radvanovsky had filled in for her on Tuesday.) So with just some studio coaching sessions and no rehearsal onstage, Ms. Moore, a 33-year-old Houston native, made her Met debut in the last performance of the revival of the company’s 1988 production this season, with Marco Armiliato conducting. The audience loved her. When Ms. Moore took her solo curtain call at the end, she received an ecstatic ovation.

headline: Heroine Is Chosen for Last Williams Play
text: The coming production of “In Masks Outrageous and Austere” — the final full-length play written by Tennessee Williams and a work that has never been produced for the stage — has found its heroine, the producers are to announce on Monday. Shirley Knight, left, a Tony, Emmy and Golden Globe award winner, will play Babe Foxworth, a wealthy Southern belle who is kidnapped. Ms. Knight has brought many of Williams’s characters to life in the past, most notably Heavenly Finley, in the film version of “Sweet Bird of Youth” (1962), for which she received an Academy Award nomination for best supporting actress. In a telephone interview Ms. Knight described this character as “fierce and wonderful” and compared her with other strong women from Williams’s plays like “The Glass Menagerie” and “Sweet Bird of Youth.” She added: “There is a whole other dark comedy quality to it. It’s very funny. It is unique, but you know it is his voice. It’s Tennessee. It couldn’t be anybody else.” The play is scheduled to run from April 5 to May 26 at Culture Project and is to be directed by David Schweizer. Williams wrote the manuscript over a span of four years until his death, in 1983, and it was kept out of the public eye for years by Gavin Lambert, who worked with Williams on it and to whom he entrusted the manuscript. Mr. Lambert released the play shortly before he died, in 2005, and the work eventually reached Mr. Schweizer. Ms. Knight recalled a missed opportunity in which she was meant to star in Williams’s “Red Devil Battery Sign,” but the production fell apart after his death. She sees this casting as a second chance. “I feel like somehow this came to me for a reason,” she said. “I was meant to do this.”

text: HENRYVILLE, Ind. — Residents of this small community filtered into church on Sunday, turning to their faith for solace two days after a tornado leveled the town’s center.

headline: Film Actors Join Paul Weitz Play
text: Topher Grace, above, who took many a bong hit as the sweetly geeky Eric Forman on the Fox series “That ’70s Show,” will continue his string of anxiety-ridden characters in his professional stage debut this spring in Paul Weitz’s new comedy, “Lonely, I’m Not,” at the Off Broadway Second Stage Theater, the company has announced. Mr. Grace, 33, will play a man who once earned seven figures in corporate life but is now trying to rebuild his life after a divorce and a nervous breakdown. Starring opposite Mr. Grace will be Olivia Thirlby, below left, as a young businesswoman with her own troubles. Ms. Thirlby is perhaps best known as the friend of the title character in the 2007 film “Juno,” and she also played a comely campaign intern in the Off Broadway production of “Farragut North” in 2008. Both actors have already worked with Mr. Weitz, a writer and director who shared an Academy Award nomination for adapted screenplay for the 2002 film “About a Boy.” Mr. Grace starred in Mr. Weitz’s film comedy “In Good Company” in 2004, and Ms. Thirlby is in his newest movie, “Being Flynn.” “Lonely, I’m Not,” to be directed by Trip Cullman (“Assistance”), is scheduled to start previews on April 10 and to open on May 7. Second Stage previously mounted three other Weitz plays: “Privilege,” “Show People” and most recently “Trust,” starring Zach Braff.

headline: A Prize for a Playwright
text: Jennifer Haley has been named the 34th winner of the Susan Smith Blackburn Prize for her play “The Nether.” The international award is given annually to a female playwright with an outstanding body of work in the English language. Ms. Haley, a native of Texas who lives in Los Angeles, received $20,000 and a signed and numbered print by Willem de Kooning that he created for the prize. She was nominated by the Center Theater Group of Los Angeles. “The Nether” — a futuristic tale in which virtual reality has become the primary vehicle for human interaction and existence — was one of eight plays chosen to be given workshops and performed as part of the 2011 O’Neill Playwrights Conference in July. The Philadelphia Theater Company PTC@PLAY festival will present a staged reading on Wednesday.

headline: Photos of the Moment | Maison Martin Margiela

headline: Amid New Looks, a New Way to See
text: PARIS

headline: Sol Schiff, ‘Mr. Table Tennis,’ Dies at 94
text: Sol Schiff, whose rocketing, flat forehand propelled him to national and world table tennis championships in the 1930s when he was still in his teens, and who later earned the unofficial title “Mr. Table Tennis” as an ardent advocate for his sport, died Feb. 26 in Brooklyn. He was 94.

headline: State-by-State Analysis: Romney Could Win Majority of Super Tuesday Delegates
text: Although the Super Tuesday states are a mix of favorable and unfavorable terrain for Mitt Romney, his situation has improved enough that he could be on track to win an outright majority of the delegates on the night.

headline: A Good Week to Be a U.S. Soccer Fan
text: Puff out your chests, fans of American soccer, because it was a good week to be you. The national team beat Italy for the first time on Wednesday, then sent its newly confident players back to their clubs to try to do even better.

headline: Deepwater Oil Drilling Picks Up Again as BP Disaster Fades
text: HOUSTON — Nearly two years after an explosion on an oil platform killed 11 workers and sent millions of gallons of oil gushing into the Gulf of Mexico, deepwater drilling has regained momentum in the gulf and is spreading around the world.

headline: Four Candidates, the Next Four Months
text: By the time mid-March rolled around in 2008, all of Hillary Rodham Clinton’s Democratic rivals for the White House except one, Barack Obama, had dropped out of the race.

headline: The Big East Is Still Paying for a Fumble
text: Beginning Tuesday, teams and fans will converge on Madison Square Garden for the 32nd Big East Conference men’s basketball tournament. Since the conference began using the Garden for its annual carnival in 1983, the tournament has become a popular launching pad for March Madness.

headline: In Queens, Cold Weather Brings Heat to Handball
text: A steady ribbon of steam rose from a stainless steel pot at a park in Queens, a small flame licking at its underside. Every so often, Washington Giovanni Cardenas lifted the lid to pluck a round morsel from the roiling water.

headline: Elections in Iran Favor Ayatollah’s Allies, Dealing Blow to President and His Office
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — With the bulk of seats decided in Iran’s parliamentary elections, it appeared on Sunday that the supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, has gained the ironclad majority he needed not just to bring the country’s president to heel, but to eliminate the position entirely.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Teams Could Be Held Liable for Injuries Traced to Bounties
text: The New Orleans Saints will almost certainly receive fines, suspensions and/or the loss of draft picks because of the bounty system administered by the former defensive coordinator Gregg Williams that encouraged Saints players to injure opponents — and for the apparent cover-up by team officials that followed. But that could be just the beginning of their punishment.

headline: The Diabetes Dilemma for Statin Users
text: San Diego, Calif.

headline: For Rondo, Memorable Game Amid Uncertainty
text: BOSTON — Rajon Rondo did something Sunday that no N.B.A. player had done in more than two decades. His triple-double of 18 points, 17 rebounds and 20 assists not only helped the Celtics beat the Knicks, 115-111, in overtime, but it also thrust him into the rarefied company of the Hall of Fame point guard Magic Johnson.

headline: With Pub Crawl Replacing St. Patrick’s Day Parade in Hoboken, Arrests Drop
text: After the annual St. Patrick’s Day parade in Hoboken, N.J., led to dozens of arrests last year, the mayor decided to put a stop to a ritual that while beloved by many longtime residents, had become increasingly rambunctious in recent years.

headline: James Trager, Brought Facts to the Masses, Dies at 86
text: In 1898, as history students learn, the battleship Maine blew up in Havana’s harbor, but that was also the year the Bayer Company offered a new opiate cough medicine called Heroin, and the year the Kellogg brothers introduced cornflakes, which were so unpopular at first they grew stale on grocers’ shelves.

headline: Mets Await a Key Ruling Amid More Negative News
text: A federal judge’s ruling Monday in Manhattan will determine the fate of the Mets’ owners in their protracted legal fight against the trustee for the victims of Bernard L. Madoff.

headline: Williams Set for Meeting With N.F.L. Officials
text: Gregg Williams, the former New Orleans Saints defensive coordinator who is at the center of the N.F.L.’s investigation into a bounty system that rewarded players for injuring opponents, will meet again with league security officials Monday in New York.

headline: U.S.-Afghanistan Talks Falter Despite Leeway on Detention Facilities
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — The prospects for a long-term American strategic partnership with Afghanistan appeared to be dimming over the weekend, as negotiations foundered despite a new American willingness to move up the transfer of detention centers to the Afghans to as soon as six months from now, Afghan and American officials said.

headline: Lucio Dalla, Italian Troubadour, Dies at 68
text: ROME — Lucio Dalla, the Italian songwriter and singer whose music became the soundtrack for the lives of generations of Italians, died on Thursday in Montreux, Switzerland, where he had been performing. He was 68.

headline: Scion Aims Online Videos at Young Buyers
text: IN Toyota’s view, its Scion brand of automobiles is not just for anyone. The cars are for the young and fashionable — they are called “influencers” these days — who spread the word about the vehicles after encountering the company’s art, music or comedic marketing.

headline: The Bright Side of Being Hacked
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Hackers operating under the banner Anonymous have been poking a finger in the eye of one private company after another for two years now.

headline: For No. 1 Seeds, Road to Title Comes With Bumps

headline: Russian Turnout Includes Thousands of Eager Election Observers
text: MOSCOW — A small army of first-time election observers fanned out across Russian polling places, and hundreds of thousands of citizens watched ballot boxes via a vast network of Web cameras on Sunday, in what amounted to a huge experiment in public scrutiny of the voting process.

headline: Actress’s Privacy Lawsuit Challenges a Web Site
text: LOS ANGELES — Junie Hoang is famous now, in a 15-minutes sort of way.

headline: Update on New York Redistricting
text: Each state must redraw its political maps to reflect the 2010 census, but New York, which has approved neither legislative nor Congressional districts for this year’s elections, is among the last to comply. Redistricting has become increasingly urgent because of the calendar: the state’s Congressional primary is scheduled for June 26, and its legislative primary for Sept. 11.

headline: Instead of Victory Party, Spartans Get Tie for First
text: EAST LANSING, Mich. — The actions seemed at odds with the emotions on Sunday, as Michigan State somberly celebrated raising a Big Ten championship banner to the Breslin Center’s rafters.

headline: DVRs and Streaming Prompt a Shift in the Top-Rated TV Shows
text: For almost a decade, identifying the most popular show on television has been easy: “American Idol,” case closed.

headline: Rodriguez Flashes Some Power, but Notes That It’s March, Not October

headline: Looking Ahead to Economic Reports This Week
text: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data will include the I.S.M. nonmanufacturing index for February and factory orders for January (Monday); ADP employment for February, revised fourth-quarter productivity and consumer credit for January (Wednesday); weekly jobless claims (Thursday); and unemployment for February, trade deficit for January and wholesale trade inventories for November (Friday).

headline: Ham, Holidays and Other Puzzles as Medical College Shifts Its Religious Affiliation
text: VALHALLA, N.Y. — New York Medical College was planning to change its affiliation to Jewish from Catholic when an employee approached Rabbi Moshe D. Krupka in the cafeteria, voice raised and finger wagging, and demanded, “When you take over, will I be able to eat my ham sandwich here?”

headline: Instruction for Masses Knocks Down Campus Walls
text: The pitch for the online course sounds like a late-night television ad, or maybe a subway poster: “Learn programming in seven weeks starting Feb. 20. We’ll teach you enough about computer science that you can build a Web search engine like Google or Yahoo.”

headline: Anger and Compassion for Arab Justice Who Stays Silent During Zionist Hymn
text: JERUSALEM — It was supposed to be a passing of the torch, yet another solemn state ceremony at the president’s residence in Jerusalem. But the retirement last week of Israel’s chief justice and the swearing in of her successor turned into a kind of Rorschach inkblot test about the nature of Israeli democracy.

headline: Finding Your Book Interrupted ... By the Tablet You Read It On
text: Can you concentrate on Flaubert when Facebook is only a swipe away, or give your true devotion to Mr. Darcy while Twitter beckons?

headline: McIlroy Holds Off Woods and Shows Who’s No. 1
text: PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla. — Since he was grip-high to a driver, Rory McIlroy’s signpost has been Tiger Woods. Growing up in Northern Ireland, McIlroy studied the details of Woods’s career as if memorizing a road map.

text: At a carwash in an industrial patch of Astoria, Queens, Adan Nicolas, a Mexican immigrant, is preparing to open the newest front in New York City’s labor battles.

headline: Hard-Working Teachers, Sabotaged When Student Test Scores Slip
text: For 15 years, Anna Allanbrook has been the principal of Public School 146 in Brooklyn, one of the highest-achieving elementary schools in the city. In that time, she has never had a more talented and hard-working bunch than the current team of fifth-grade teachers. The five have lunch together daily, using the time to plan. They stay until 7 p.m. on Fridays to prepare for the following week. On Thursday night, most of them helped at the science invention fair until it was past 8 p.m.

headline: Lebanon Expects Influx of Refugees From Syria
text: ANTAKYA, Turkey — As many as 2,000 people fleeing the war in Syria were believed to be headed toward the Lebanese border on Sunday, a United Nations official said, signaling a growing humanitarian crisis in Syrian cities and villages as the government has pursued its opponents on new fronts.

headline: Budget Cuts May Threaten City Programs for Children
text: It has become an annual New York drama: cutbacks in the mayor’s proposed budget loom, with threats of firehouses being shut down, arts programs slashed and senior centers closed, only to be followed by restorations in the City Council. Yet the drama does not have a happy ending for everyone, and some of the cutbacks are eventually enacted.

headline: Brazilian Slum Dwellers Push Back Against Olympic Development
text: Residents in some favelas, or slums, who are facing eviction ahead of the 2016 Olympics are pulling together and standing their ground.

Perseverance Pays for Notre Dame’s Peters
text: HARTFORD — Devereaux Peters pulled herself to her feet and shook her head in dismay after a sequence in which she grabbed an offensive rebound, missed a layup, then lost the basketball as she tumbled into a row of Notre Dame cheerleaders waving sparkly pompoms.

headline: Even Smiles Count, However Exacting the Competition
text: To warm up backstage before the ninth New York Regional and National Yoga Asana Championship, some competitors slid their legs behind their heads and others curled into back bends. Michael Colwill, 46, stood still in a purple Speedo and practiced bowing. Perfecting a gentle smile, he stood on a yoga mat, secured to the stage with electrical tape, and gazed out serenely at the nearly 700 theater seats.

headline: Sharing a Part of Activist History in the East Village
text: From the street, the brick tenement on Avenue C looked like any other building. But inside on Saturday afternoon, about 30 people gathered to look at a storefront space covered with graffiti and murals.

headline: Drill Baby Drill, Redux
text: It’s campaign season and the pandering about gas prices is in full swing. Hardly a day goes by that a Republican politician does not throw facts to the wind and claim that rising costs at the pump are the result of President Obama’s decisions to block the Keystone XL pipeline and impose sensible environmental regulations and modest restrictions on offshore drilling.

headline: Veto the Maps
text: New York’s Legislature is reportedly planning to offer Gov. Andrew Cuomo a bipartisan and utterly sleazy redistricting deal. If he will approve their new gerrymandered districts for the next decade, Assembly and State Senate leaders will propose a constitutional amendment they promise will improve the way the state draws election districts — in 2022. Mr. Cuomo must keep his promise and veto the Legislature’s self-serving maps.

headline: Equal Protection on Sewer Bills
text: Sometimes, what seems to be a case with an obvious, common-sense answer ends up at the Supreme Court. Such is the curious case of the municipal sewer bill and the Constitution. The issue in Armour v. Indianapolis, which the court heard arguments on last week, is whether the city violated the equal protection rights of residents who prepaid their sewer bills and were not given a refund after the city changed its sewer fee policy.

headline: Sweeter Than Marmalade: A Shy Couple’s 30-Year Romance
text: While watching “I ♥ Alice ♥ I” at the Irish Arts Center, my attention kept shifting between the disarmingly shy lesbian couple portrayed onstage and the man and woman sitting in front of me, almost as if they were part of the performance.

headline: Meet Sam Schwartz
text: IF you live in New York, commute to New York, or occasionally visit what Russell Shorto called the island at the center of the world, you have experienced the indignity of our city’s transportation hell. You have endured the screeching, flood-prone subways. You have surrendered exorbitant carfare to escape our eyesore airports, then lurched along congested highways, over creaking bridges and into our truck-clotted city streets. You have dodged the camping homeless at the Port Authority bus terminal, or wandered lost in the miasmal misery of Pennsylvania Station. New York City welcomes you with open arms — like the zombies in “The Walking Dead.”

headline: States of Depression
text: The economic news is looking better lately. But after previous false starts — remember “green shoots”? — it would be foolish to assume that all is well. And in any case, it’s still a very slow economic recovery by historical standards.

headline: For Mets’ Early Risers, Bacon, Eggs and a Workout
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — The sun began to rise over Digital Domain Park, the Mets’ spring training home, at 6:42 Sunday morning.

headline: We’ve Met Before? Of Course! I Remember It Well.
text: VALDOSTA, Ga. — To be in public life as long as Newt Gingrich has means that you have met a lot of people. And when you are running for president, many, many of those folks expect to be personally remembered.

headline: Locked in Struggle for Supremacy
text: WAVERLY, Iowa — At Joe’s KnightHawk, chicken wings cost 45 cents on Wednesdays, orange and black are the preferred colors, wrestlers are celebrities and the weapon of choice for Milboy’s Army, fund-raisers for Wartburg College wrestling, is a checkbook.

headline: Limbaugh Advertisers Flee Show Amid Storm
text: Emboldened by Rush Limbaugh’s public apology over the weekend to a law school student whom he had called a “slut” and a “prostitute,” critics of the radio talk show host are intensifying their online campaign against his advertisers.

headline: Van Barfoot, Medal of Honor Recipient, Dies at 92
text: Van Barfoot, a Medal of Honor recipient in World War II whose fight to fly an American flag outside his home 65 years later drew national attention, died on Friday in suburban Richmond, Va. He was 92.

headline: Apple’s Job Creation Data Spurs an Economic Debate
text: Apple has made its first attempt to quantify how many American jobs can be credited to the sale of its iPads and other products, a group that includes the Apple engineers who design the devices and the drivers who deliver them — even the people who build the trucks that get them there.

headline: Putin Wept
text: Perhaps the only unexpected aspect of Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin’s victory in Sunday’s Russian presidential election was the tear in his eye as he stepped to the microphone to address supporters outside the Kremlin walls in Moscow. Video tagged #putinwept by one incredulous blogger appeared to show Mr. Putin tearing up as he was introduced by the outgoing president, Dmitri Medvedev.

headline: Competitive Yoga
text: The Hudson Theater in Midtown Manhattan hosted the ninth New York Regional and National Yoga Asana Championship on Friday, Saturday and Sunday.

headline: A Chinese Scholar, Summoned for Tea
text: HONG KONG — The Chinese security apparatus has shown itself to be remarkably adept at chasing down artists (Ai Weiwei), putting bloggers under house arrest (Woeser) and locking up Nobel laureates (Liu Xiaobo). They have been less efficient at reining in larcenous government billionaires. The same state security forces, the guobao, that so eagerly go Scarface on Tibetans and poets just as happily go silent on the most brazen of Communist Party crooks.

headline: The Museum of Reclaimed Urban Space
text: A new museum will document how activists in the East Village transformed abandoned properties into permanent housing or community gardens.

headline: Amid Capeci, Who Led Magazine Face-Lifts, Dies at 50
text: Amid Capeci, an art director who helped redesign Rolling Stone and Newsweek as they struggled to reconnect with subscribers in an Internet Age landscape of browsers, died on Tuesday in New York. He was 50.

headline: Extreme Poverty Drops Worldwide
text: The world has achieved its first Millennium Development Goal of cutting extreme poverty in half ahead of the 2015 deadline, a study by the World Bank shows.

headline: A Wrestling Rivalry
text: Wartburg College in Iowa and Augsburg College in Minnesota have won every Division III wrestling title since 1995.

headline: Other People’s Suffering
text: The publication last week in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of “Higher Social Class Predicts Increased Unethical Behavior” provided fresh fodder for the liberal critique of the Republican Party and the corporate ethic.

headline: Before Super Tuesday, Big Names Rally to Romney
text: COLUMBUS, Ohio — A reluctant Republican Party is increasingly showing signs of rallying around Mitt Romney in the presidential race, with leading members of Congress and influential conservatives signaling that a coast-to-coast burst of voting on Super Tuesday should mark a moment to start concentrating on defeating President Obama.

headline: A Harsh Reality for Newspapers
text: Last year, researchers at the Project for Excellence in Journalism persuaded six companies that own 121 newspapers to share private data about the financial performance of many of their papers. And the findings were grim.

headline: Chávez Says Tumor Was Malignant
text: QUITO, Ecuador — President Hugo Chávez of Venezuela said Sunday that a tumor removed from his pelvic region during an operation in Havana was malignant, indicating that the cancer he was treated for last summer had returned.

headline: Kentucky Wins, Looking Like a Champion
text: GAINESVILLE, Fla. — After a steady march through the Southeastern Conference, No. 1 Kentucky is poised for March and the N.C.A.A. tournament.

headline: ‘Good Wife’ Watch: Alicia and the Blondes
text: Well, that didn’t last long. Viewers who’d hoped that Will Gardner’s six-month suspension might divert “The Good Wife” from his sad-sack storyline were in for a disappointment when Sunday’s episode, “After the Fall,” ultimately offered him and the firm an easy out.

headline: Wondering if Abramovich Is Thinking About a Do-Over
text: Roman Abramovich’s biggest problem today is that some of the men who could help him sort out Chelsea’s problems were dumped by him for causing them. That’s the problem with having a quick trigger: use it haphazardly and you run the risk of a self-inflicted wound.

headline: In China’s Annual Assessment, Wen Is Optimistic
text: BEIJING — Prime Minister Wen Jiabao opened the annual meeting of China’s handpicked legislature on Monday with a markedly upbeat assessment of the state of the nation, saying that threats posed by bad local government debt and soaring real estate prices were under control, that the economy was robust and that “the people’s well being is improving.”

headline: Givenchy’s Wild Horses
text: It seems to be all about the bodyguard this season. At Dior the other day, before the show started, three dudes parked themselves in front of Robbie Myers, the editor-in-chief of Elle, and myself. When they finally moved off, I knew how a bear must feel after a winter in her cave. Ah, light!

headline: Russian Leader Orders Review of Oil Tycoon’s Conviction
text: MOSCOW — President Dmitri A. Medvedev ordered Russia’s prosecutor general on Monday to verify the legality of the conviction of Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, the former billionaire whose imprisonment has been widely condemned as politically motivated.

headline: Gunmen in Uniforms Kill 20 Police Officers in Iraq
text: BAGHDAD — At least 20 police officers were killed in western Iraq early Monday by dozens of gunmen masquerading as black-clad SWAT teams out to make a high-level arrest, local security officials said.

headline: March 5, 1946 | Winston Churchill Warns of Soviet “Iron Curtain”
text: On March 5, 1946, Winston Churchill delivered his famous “Iron Curtain” speech, officially titled “Sinews of Peace,” at Westminster College in Fulton, Mo. After being introduced by President Harry Truman, Churchill, the former prime minister of Britain and now the opposition leader, warned of the threat posed by the Soviet Union, a World War II ally of Britain and the United States.

headline: Test Yourself | Math, March 5, 2012
text: Test your math skills with this question created by Bobson Wong at Math for America from the article “A Hit That Has Outlasted 10,000 Chandeliers.”

headline: Remembering Alex Webster, Giants Star and Coach
text: Alex Webster was an important part of one of New York’s legendary teams, the Giants of the late ’50s and early ’60s. For the first time, pro football players became celebrities in the media and financial capital of the world. Webster died Saturday morning in Port St. Lucie, Fla. He was 80.

headline: News Quiz | March 5, 2012
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s front page.

headline: The Problem With Exit Polls in Indian Elections
text: The results of elections in five states will be announced Tuesday. In Uttar Pradesh, India’s largest state, exit polls released over the weekend indicate that the party of the current chief minister, Mayawati, is headed for certain defeat. The incumbents in the other four states — Punjab, Uttarakhand, Goa and Manipur — are also expected to suffer defeats or lose seats.

headline: New Deal Utopias
text: Jobs, housing and the role of government: issues that today have sometimes become little more than fodder for political debate once spurred a nation into action. Over the past few years, Jason Reblando has been photographing several utopian communities that were built almost 75 years ago as part of the New Deal to stimulate employment and improve living conditions.

headline: What Is Your Reaction to the Rush Limbaugh Controversy?
text: Last week on his talk show, Rush Limbaugh attacked Sandra Fluke, a Georgetown University Law School student who had spoken publicly in favor of the Obama administration’s birth control coverage policy, as sexually promiscuous and politically motivated, calling her a “slut” and a “prostitute.” In the days that followed, President Obama telephoned Ms. Fluke to express his support, some Republicans, including House speaker John A. Boehner criticized Mr. Limbaugh, many advertisers withdrew ads from the show, and, on Saturday, Mr. Limbaugh offered an apology. Read about the events and tell us what you think.

headline: Where the Books Are
text: WHERE is the warehouse that stores 20th century volumes “in case of digital disaster”?WHERE do all of the shipments come from?

headline: Death Toll Rises in Attack on Yemeni Army Base
text: ADEN, Yemen — The death toll in the ambush by militants from Al Qaeda on a military post in southern Yemen grew on Monday, making it the deadliest attack on the armed forces in the past year.

headline: Counselor’s Calendar | March Checklist for Juniors
text: The Choice is introducing an occasional series called Counselor’s Calendar, intended to keep students on track — month by month — as they go through the admissions process. This series will provide timely information for students about what they need to know and do, and when, so they are well prepared for the college application process — and for college itself.

headline: A.I.G. to Raise $6 Billion to Repay Government Bailout
text: HONG KONG — The insurance giant American International Group is looking to raise $6 billion by reducing its stake in its Asian insurance unit, part of a broader effort to repay the federal government.

headline: The Great Wall of Thailand
text: BANGKOK — The king of Thailand doesn’t usually issue stern warnings. Then again, the flood that struck here last year was by no means usual, even by the standards of this flood-prone country: it was by far the costliest natural disaster in Thailand’s history. And so late last month, the king announced that the government should prevent deforestation, which is believed to have aggravated the disaster, and punish any “greedy civil servants” who get in the way.

headline: A Voice App Unapologetically Unlike Siri
text: Siri is perfectly lovely bit of artificial intelligence, but she isn’t always cooperative. Ask Siri to book airplane tickets, make a dinner reservation or find a song on Pandora, and she politely declines.

headline: This Week in Small Business: An Immense Fiscal Cliff

headline: Trial Run: Monday Morning Beauty Tip
text: When I first laid eyes on a pink, amoeba-shaped sponge that claimed to briskly whisk away new deodorant stains, my first thought was “silly and unnecessary.”

headline: Russia After Putin
text: The once and future president of Russia, Vladimir Putin, cried on Sunday night as he declared overwhelming victory in the election. A lot of my friends felt like crying, too. It hurts when you are told you do not exist, which is exactly what happened to the more than 50 percent of Russians who, according to independent exit polls, voted against Putin only to hear him claim that he had garnered more than 60 percent of the vote.

headline: Sleep Disorders Can Cause Behavioral Problems
text: Sleep-disordered breathing — snoring, mouth breathing and apnea (abnormally long pauses in breathing during sleep) — can affect anyone, but a recent study shows that particularly in very young children, there is more than a good night’s sleep at risk.

headline: Top JPMorgan Trader to Start Own Hedge Fund

headline: Channel Surfing: ‘Ice Pilots NWT’
text: Does the mundane become interesting if you make it colder? Is iced coffee more exciting than plain old coffee? Frozen yogurt more spunky than regular yogurt? Not really.

headline: Complaint Box | Wrong-Way Runners

So when I began jogging around the Central Park Reservoir a couple of years ago, I noticed immediately the signs that instructed me — and everyone else — to proceed in a counterclockwise direction. What’s more, I immediately obeyed them.

headline: Departures Offer Commentary on Current State of Congress
text: When a century of seniority and experience voluntarily walks away from Congress, it is a watershed moment.

headline: Meet the Superheroes of Delhi

headline: Three Tibetans Die After Self-Immolations
text: BEIJING — Three Tibetans killed themselves by self-immolation in two different Tibetan regions of western China over the past three days, to protest China’s repression of Tibet, according to reports by Tibetan exile groups and Radio Free Asia, which is financed by the United States government.

headline: Striking Oil, Artistically, in Midtown

headline: Egyptian Lawmaker Forced to Resign Over Nose Job
text: CAIRO — The first political scandal of Egypt’s fledgling electoral democracy erupted Monday after an Islamist lawmaker was expelled from his ultraconservative party, accused of fabricating a story that he was viciously beaten by masked gunmen.

headline: ‘The Simpsons’ Tips Its Crown to ‘Game of Thrones’
text: Commencing its next 500 episodes in regal – or is that regicidal? – style, “The Simpsons” began on Sunday night with an introductory sequence that paid homage to the opening credits from “Game of Thrones” (and which we were pointed to by the good folks at The Daily What). It’s an intricate tribute to that feudal HBO drama (whose own new episodes resume April 1), but c’mon, “Simpsons” team, not a single “Wiggum is coming” joke?
