headline: Daily Report: How Many Jobs Has Apple Created?
text: Apple has made its first attempt to quantify how many American jobs can be credited to the sale of its iPads and other products, Nick Wingfield reports in Monday’s Times. The total includes the Apple engineers who design the devices and the drivers who deliver them — even the people who build the trucks that get them there.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: Top JPMorgan Trader to Start Own Hedge Fund  |  Mike Stewart, the global head of proprietary trading at JPMorgan Chase, is leaving the bank to start his own hedge fund, according to a person with direct knowledge of the matter.

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | Kenzo
text: “She’s grown up a little bit,” said the hairstylist Anthony Turner backstage of the directive Carol Lim and Humberto Leon gave for this season’s Kenzo girl. “She’s met the man of her dreams — and he’s a rich man.” In contrast to last collection’s loose braids, this girl has hair that’s “the day-after-the-night-before,” meaning a mussed-up version of her date look that led to, well, spending the night. “She had a little romp on the Upper East Side.” To create this effect, Turner used Tigi Catwalk Sessions Series Strong Mousse with a flat brush to blow-dry hair and then pull it into a tight, low ponytail, pinning the folded-over ends up and then destroying the look a little with his fingertips. Wet Look Gel was dabbed on messy ends and the hairline at the face so that when light hit it would look as though the girl had gotten caught in the rain on her way back downtown. For more grown-up makeup, Yadim used M.A.C. Black Track Fluid liner to draw a thick contour with a bit missing; he erased part of the end with the swipe of a wet Q-tip. On cheeks was Taupe creme blush and highlighter on all the planes of the face. Then there was what Yadim called “the surprise of the show” — a changing gradient of lipstick meant to match the clothes that show the girl within the different rooms of her new man’s pad. There was, appropriately, Sin, Dare You, Ruby Woo, Russian Red, So Chaud and Girl About Town mixed with Dare You.

headline: Why Ticketmaster Wants to Be Your Friend
text: If you want to know why companies are so hot on social networking, consider this: Ticketmaster recently began asking customers to post their purchases on Facebook. Since then, the company says, it has made $5.30 in additional ticket sales each time someone has done so. That value increases to $8 when the customer also posts the location of the seats using Ticketmaster’s seating chart.

headline: It’s Been a Nonwinter, but It’s Not Over Yet
text: A winter like this impels one to turn to the poet François Villon, who is most famous for having written, to show off a bit of my high school French, “Où sont les neiges d’antan?” Or if you prefer, “Where are the snows of yesteryear?”

headline: What We’re Reading
text: The New York Post: The elite restaurant Per Se, given a B grade by a city health inspector, called an official at health department, which canceled two violations, bumping the grade to an A. Undue influence? Nope, says the department; anyone can question a violation. But one lawyer for restaurants says they normally have to take those questions to a city tribunal. — Patrick Farrell

headline: Redpoint and BV Capital Form Brazilian V.C. Firm
text: Redpoint Ventures and BV Capital’s eVentures have begun a new venture capital firm called Redpoint eVentures based in São Paulo, Brazil — the latest illustration of the country’s growing Internet start-up ecosystem.

headline: Sony Says Michael Jackson Recordings Were Stolen From Its Site
text: This could be bad for Sony, in many senses of the word: that media giant has confirmed that several tracks recorded by Michael Jackson were stolen from its Web site after it was hacked, BBC News reported. Sony has not said what Jackson tracks were taken, but in 2010 it closed a $250 million deal with the singer’s estate to acquire his back catalog (including best-selling albums like “Thriller” and “Bad”) and to release previously unheard recordings, beginning with a posthumous album, “Michael,” that went on sale in December of that year. Last April a Sony online network for its PlayStation game consoles was hacked, compromising the personal data of some 77 million users; the Sony Music Japan site and Sony Ericsson online store were also hacked in the following weeks. The BBC said the Jackson tracks were taken during this time. In May two British men, James Marks and James McCormick, were arrested in connection with the hacks and are to go on trial next January.

headline: Leading Off: A Glorious Climb for Pat Summitt
text: Were this a normal season, the sight of the Tennessee women’s team winning a Southeastern Conference championship would strike everyone as so normal it would hardly be worth a lingering look. Were this a normal season, the questions would have immediately gone to whether the Lady Vols were primed for another national championship. And, were this a normal season, Coach Pat Summitt would have stayed on the sideline beaming as her players climbed the ladder to cut down the nets and soak up the adulation.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: More Advertisers Drop Limbaugh and ‘Modern Family’ Tops ‘Idol’
text: A seventh advertiser, ProFlowers, has abandoned Rush Limbaugh’s show after his attack last week in which he called a law student who testified in favor of insurance coverage for birth control a “slut” and a “prostitute,” writes Brian Stelter. Mr. Limbaugh apologized for his word choice but his critics have continued their assault. Still, the boycott won’t have a large financial impact on Mr. Limbaugh, who is estimated to make $50 million a year through his lucrative syndication deal with Premiere Networks.

headline: The Aipac Primary
text: COLUMBUS, Ohio – Iran represents one of the world’s most grave foreign policy challenges, but don’t look for much gravity in the speeches to American Israel Public Affairs Committee this week by the top three Republican presidential candidates. There will be plenty of empty fist-shaking and ridicule of President Obama at the pro-Israel lobbying group, but not a single new thought for preventing Iran from developing a nuclear weapon.

headline: El Paso Delays Vote on Kinder Morgan Deal by a Few Days
text: The El Paso Corporation said on Monday that it had pushed back a meeting for shareholders to vote on the company’s planned $21.1 billion sale to Kinder Morgan by a few days, to allow shareholders to weigh a Delaware judge’s criticism of the deal process.

headline: London Calling
text: Last fall, National Geographic Traveler ranked London No. 3 on its list of the world’s “Top 10 Literary Cities.” It’s a mystery it didn’t finish first: what other burg belongs in the running for the all-time City of Writers title? (Nos. 1 and 2 were also in the British Isles, for what that’s worth.) As a Stanford University site called Authorial London puts it, “A comprehensive Web site for literary London would occupy an entire server.” See for yourself — check out the pantheon hosted there. And note that it’s pretty much just an old-timer’s wing.

headline: Victory Over Iowa Keeps Northwestern Hoping
text: EVANSTON, Ill. – In the past two weeks, two coaches of ranked men’s basketball teams have voiced their support for Northwestern’s inclusion in the N.C.A.A. tournament after the Wildcats (18-12, 8-10 Big Ten) pressured their squads in Big Ten battles.

headline: Maclaren Stroller Company Files for Bankruptcy in U.S.
text: Looking for a high-end stroller whose maker you can depend on? You might want to skip the Maclaren. Dealbook reports that its North American division filed for Chapter 7 bankruptcy at the end of December last year, meaning that it plans to liquidate the business, although its showroom in SoHo remains open, and its products are still for sale (of the “top 10 best standard strollers” on the Web site Diapers.com, two are still Maclarens). Among the bankruptcy creditors are seven families whose children were injured by one of its foldable models, recalled in 2009 for its notorious ability to amputate the tip of a child’s finger.

headline: Holder Outlines Policy on Killing Terrorism Suspects
text: 6:29 p.m. | Updated Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. gave a speech on Monday afternoon describing the Obama administration’s view that it is lawful to kill American citizens accused of joining Al Qaeda, at least under certain circumstances.

text: Lawyers, as everyone knows, can cost a lot of money.

headline: The 'Magic' of Student-Teacher Relationships
text: A teacher who blogs about her experiences teaching in a Bronx middle school writes: Often teachers who pull the best out of a troubled student are considered to be transforming -- even magical. But kids who succeed because of us are not kids who have the tools to succeed in the long run. Relationships matter -- but they aren’t enough.

headline: Media Deals and Novels From One Busy Mind
text: As writers’ offices go, Olaf Olafsson’s is a bit of a surprise. It is a giant lair in a futuristic skyscraper, with enough room for both a desk and a big table, along with an expansive view of Central Park. With its abundant light and helpful assistant out front, it’s not exactly the kind of dark warren where the author of sprawling historical novels would find himself.

headline: Santorum and Romney Court Blue-Collar Voters in Ohio
text: ZANESVILLE, Ohio — If Mitt Romney defeats Rick Santorum in the bellwether primary here on Tuesday, it will be in no small part because he managed to win over one of the most hotly contested and elusive segments of the electorate: white working-class voters.

text: In this week’s Dining section, David Tanis and I both write about winter dishes to make during this very mild non-winter we’ve been experiencing in New York City. His view is, weather be darned, cook up your favorite hearty dishes and eat them anyway (as evidenced in his wonderful-sounding pork roast with prunes).

headline: Scandals in Hong Kong Raise Fears About China
text: HONG KONG — A string of scandals involving both the current leader of Hong Kong and those vying to succeed him is threatening to stain what many residents here consider a source of pride: a city largely free of corruption.

headline: A Capitol Dilemma
text: By the end of February 1862, construction of the enlarged Capitol building in Washington had been suspended for nine and a half months. The federal government had begun the project 12 years earlier, intending to add new House and Senate wings at either end of the original building, topped by a majestic cast-iron dome above the old central section. But now the country was deep in civil war, and the building was left towering but unfinished.

headline: Obama Presses Netanyahu to Resist Strikes on Iran
text: WASHINGTON — With Israel warning of a possible military strike on Iran’s nuclear facilities, President Obama urged Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu at the White House on Monday to give diplomacy and economic sanctions a chance to work before resorting to military action.

text: LAS VEGAS — For Vegas die-hards bored with the $750 tasting menu at Guy Savoy, the $250 Elton John tickets at Caesars or the $200,000 baccarat bet at the Bellagio, this city is serving up a new way to find high-priced thrills.

headline: Out of Community Colleges and Into For-Profits

headline: They Pledge Allegiance to the Frat: ‘Animal House’ Musical Is Planned
text: On Monday, the 30th anniversary of the death of John Belushi, his fans and former colleagues are commemorating the occasion in different ways: with solemn reflections on his loss, lively celebrations of his talent and the announcement of a new project based on one of his best-known films.

headline: Former Iceland Leader Tried Over Financial Crisis of 2008
text: LONDON — Iceland opened a criminal trial on Monday against its former prime minister, Geir H. Haarde, becoming the first country to prosecute one of its leaders over the financial crisis of 2008.

headline: The Frankies’ New Daughter: Francesca
text: The two Franks of Italian cuisine, Falcinelli and Castronovo, are “going to Spain,” as Mr. Castronovo put it. They are turning one of their three signature Frankies Spuntino restaurants — the one they call ” Frankies 17,” on the Lower East Side, into Francesca, a Basque-style bar and restaurant serving pintxos, the popular tapas-style snacks from northeastern Spain.

headline: Speaking of the Dead
text: Early last week, Katie Roiphe wrote a piece for Slate bemoaning the “increasing fashion for … negative obituaries,” in which critiques of the deceased, from Jan Berenstein to Christopher Hitchens, are “timed as the dead person’s possessions are still being retrieved in plastic bags by their relatives from the hospital.” By week’s end, the death of Andrew Breitbart had inspired not only a variety of examples of exactly this form, but also a number of eloquent defenses of its virtues. Here is David Frum:

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
text: Baha Mar, a resort in Nassau, Bahamas, that is scheduled to open in late 2014, chose SK&G, Las Vegas, as advertising agency of record, to handle assignments like brand strategy, creative and media services. Billings were not disclosed.

headline: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
text: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week. Questions can be sent to stuarte@nytimes.com.

headline: Chevy Volt and Opel Ampera Are Jointly Named European Car of the Year
text: GENEVA — In a ceremony Monday that opened the 82nd Geneva auto show, the Chevrolet Volt and Opel Ampera, the European version of the Volt, were jointly named the European Car of the Year.

headline: Palace Coup | Jaipur’s Literary Festival
text: Jaipur, India, may be called “The Pink City,” but in truth it’s gray and dusty, a wonderful place of crumbling beauty. Now in its fifth year, the DSC Jaipur Literature Festival, which was held inside a 200-year-old palace at the end of January, is breathing new life into this very old town. The event draws an increasingly curious cross-section of India’s vibrant literary scene: authors, publishers, readers, schoolchildren, old poets, young journalists, socialites, minor royalty, major art collectors, literary aspirants, Nosy Parkers — in short anyone who has ever felt the power of a good book.

headline: A Fantasy Fiction Writer on London’s Real-Life Dystopia
text: China Miéville wrote one of the articles in this week’s issue on London. He is the author of award-winning fantasy fiction, including “Embassytown,” “Kraken,” “The City & the City” and the Bas-Lag series. We spoke about being an Olympic dissident, a “genre” novelist and a lifelong Londoner.

headline: Ads for Lawn-Care Brand Take a Highland Fling
text: A new campaign is celebrating the green, green grass of home with a new brand character who is meant to bring to life a familiar line of lawn-care products.

headline: Understanding Shoreline Erosion
text: A vehicle carries radar and light detection and ranging (lidar) instruments that measure water movements at the surface and use the data to calculate even small movements of sand beneath the waves.

headline: A Surf-Worthy New Tool to Study Erosion
text: DUCK, N.C. — Researchers who study the beaches of the Outer Banks have long noticed that storms cause particularly severe erosion in areas they call hot spots. But at first they did not know why.

headline: A North Carolina Lifeline Built on Shifting Sands
text: RODANTHE, N.C. — Last August, when Hurricane Irene sliced across the Outer Banks, it cut Highway 12, Hatteras Island’s lifeline, in two places. Engineers rushed to repair the damage, filling and repaving a washed-out stretch of roadway here and building a bridge over a newly formed inlet a few miles to the north.

headline: Tate Modern Buys 8 Million Works by Ai Weiwei
text: The Tate Modern in London announced on Monday that it had purchased one of Ai Weiwei’s famous installations of life-size, hand-painted porcelain “Sunflower Seeds.” It bought 8 million of the 100 million seeds that were on view in a giant installation at the museum a year and a half ago. The mini-version was bought directly from the artist, officials at the Tate said, and the remaining 92 million seeds have been returned to Mr. Ai.

headline: Expect a Wild Big Ten Tournament
text: A rough Big Ten regular season has finally settled things, sort of, having ended Sunday with a three-way tie for the title when Michigan, Michigan State and Ohio State all finished at 13-5.

headline: Syria Permits U.N. Visits, but Escalates Its Attacks
text: Syria’s government made diplomatic gestures on Monday toward seeking an end to the uprising that has convulsed the country, agreeing for the first time to allow visits by the top United Nations relief official and by the newly designated envoy who represents the United Nations and the Arab League.

headline: Mealtime Moneyball: Hacking Seamless
text: For young Wall Street types, few deals matter more than the ones taking place at 7 p.m. on Seamless.

headline: Lincoln Center Theater to Stage Odets Revival and New Durang Play
text: The Tony Award-winning director Bartlett Sher will stage a revival of Clifford Odets’s 1937 drama, “Golden Boy,” on Broadway in November for Lincoln Center Theater, and a new Chekhov-inspired play by Christopher Durang will also run this fall at that company’s Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater, executives for Lincoln Center Theater announced on Monday.

headline: Germany Not Amused by Belarus Leader’s ‘Better a Dictator Than Gay’ Jibe
text: One day after President Aleksandr Lukashenko of Belarus rejected criticism of his authoritarian rule from Germany’s gay foreign minister by saying it was “better to be a dictator than gay,” the German government fired back, sarcastically welcoming the Belarussian leader’s apparent confirmation that he is indeed a dictator.

headline: Santorum Slumps in Super Tuesday Polls
text: Rick Santorum got a rough result in the Washington caucuses on Saturday, finishing third in a state he had seemed to have a reasonable shot of winning. Now, Mr. Santorum’s slump is carrying over into the polls in crucial Super Tuesday states.

headline: As Advertisers Recoil, Limbaugh Says, ‘So Be It’
text: Defending himself against a growing ad boycott, Rush Limbaugh told his audience on Monday that the companies that have defected from his radio program have decided “they don’t want you or your business anymore.”

headline: Muslim Leaders Rally in Support of Police Dept.
text: About three dozen American Muslim leaders and activists assembled outside the headquarters of the New York Police Department on Monday morning to defend and commend the Police Department for its surveillance of Muslim communities.

headline: Super Tuesday Primaries
text: Mitt Romney edged out Rick Santorum in Ohio, but failed to deliver a knockout punch as Mr. Santorum picked up several states.

headline: Are Women Enemies of Our Own Free Time?
text: Old-timers, counseling the young on investments, used to advise buying land. “They’re not making any more of it,” went the refrain. Maybe that’s one reason we’re so perpetually interested in talking about time: how we spend it and how it slips away. Not only aren’t “they” not making any more of it (you get what you get, even if you do get upset), but it can’t be bought at any price.

headline: McCain Calls for U.S.-Led Airstrikes Against Syria
text: Senator John McCain, a leader among Senate Republicans on military matters, called on Monday for the United States to lead airstrikes against Syria’s armed forces to protect the rebels and civilians there, much as it did in Libya last year.

headline: London, Illuminated
text: Chris Levine refers to himself as a light artist; he signs off his e-mail with “Light” or “With Light and Good Feelings.” And it was this e-mail that inspired us to commission him for the London issue:

text: Whether he’s right or wrong about the value of negative obituaries, David Frum is right about this, in a column on the comparison between Rush Limbaugh’s “slut” comments and the similar remarks that have befouled the careers of various left-wing entertainers:

headline: Photo Replay: March 5
text: The day in sports included the British Gas swimming championships in London and the Canadian curling championships in Saskatoon, Saskatchewan.

headline: Large Private Sector Investors Agree to a Swap of Greek Debt
text: LONDON — Greece moved closer Monday to avoiding default when a large group of private sector bondholders said that it would participate in a restructuring through a bond swap.

headline: RelayRides Takes Peer-to-Peer Car Sharing Nationwide
text: Peer-to-peer car-sharing services have only been active in a few American cities. RelayRides, a start-up financed in part by General Motors, announced Monday that it had expanded its offering nationwide. An owner of a qualifying car can earn cash, in any state, by renting out a personal vehicle on a short-term basis.

headline: A New Way to Blow Off Steam in Vegas
text: Machine Guns Vegas — an upscale, indoor shooting range complete with skimpily dressed, gun-toting hostesses — opened last week a half-mile from the Strip, with an armory of weapons.

headline: At a Harlem Transfer School, a High-Tech Celebration of Student Achievement
text: At Harlem Renaissance High School, a transfer school, graduating seniors hosted family and members of the community at an expo, where they displayed their work and videos chronicling their journey to graduation.

headline: O’Bama Shirt Gets More in Touch With Irish Roots

headline: For Hoyas, a Fight in China Forged Team Unity
text: WASHINGTON — On the night of Aug. 18, hours after the Georgetown men’s basketball team was involved in a disturbing brawl with a Chinese professional team, many of the Hoyas gathered in the hotel room of a team manager at the St. Regis Beijing.

text: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

headline: A Granddaughter Returns to Pakistan
text: The last time I wandered the dust-laden streets of Karachi, in 2007, Benazir Bhutto was still alive, Pervez Musharraf was president, Imran Khan was more renowned for his cricket career and former lovers than for his politics, and Asif Ali Zardari was in intermittent self-imposed exile, desperately dodging corruption charges. Pakistanis were wildly paranoid about India, blamed their extremist undercurrents on Afghan refugees and were deeply suspicious of the United States. I returned for a visit late last year, and as soon as I set foot in the gritty city of Karachi again, I knew that everything had changed and nothing had changed.

headline: For Jewish Sabbath, Elevators Do All the Work
text: “Don’t get in that one!” a woman cried, standing in front of an open elevator door, a quiet toddler in her arms.

headline: On First Anniversary of Tsunami, Looking Back Through a Canny Lens
text: Reporters pride themselves on finding stories that they believe should be told. Sometimes, however, a photo enhances and amplifies a report so much that it eclipses the written record.

headline: A New Credit Card Lets Customers Make The Rules
text: Updated 6:10 p.m. | To provide more details.

headline: Rush Limbaugh Is Really Sorry That He Had to Apologize
text: Last Friday, I wrote about people who actually bother to apologize for offensive and harmful behavior. Sincere admissions of guilt deserve special attention, in part because it’s now standard for national figures to either hide from their mistakes or just go through the motions of pretending they’re sorry.

headline: Reader Idea | Debates on Persuasive Language That Extend Outside of Class
text: Here is another in our Great Ideas From Readers series.

headline: ‘Once Upon a Time’ and ‘GCB’ Help Lift ABC
text: The continued steady performance of “Once Upon a Time,” combined with a decent showing for the series premiere of “GCB,” gave ABC a ratings win on Sunday. That network drew the most viewers in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic for the night, while CBS finished first in total viewership.

headline: In China, Sobering Signs of Slower Growth
text: GUANGZHOU, China — The nights are a little darker now here in the main metropolis of southeastern China, at the center of one of the country’s largest export hubs.

headline: Céline: Fall 2012 RTW
text: Paris

headline: Childbirth: Identical or Fraternal? Not Always Clear
text: A British study suggests that many parents of twins are misinformed as to whether their babies are fraternal or identical because doctors themselves are confused.

headline: Too Often, Doctors Overlook Narcolepsy
text: Clea Howard is hardly a tuned-out, uninterested high school student. She likes to be busy: In addition to maintaining an excellent scholastic record at a demanding high school an hour from her Brooklyn home, she studies art, takes dance classes and plays soccer.

headline: Amateurs Are New Fear in Creating Mutant Virus
text: Just how easy is it to make a deadly virus?

headline: A Temporary Eco-Minded Restaurant Pops Up in Milan
text: The Cube, the temporary, eco-sustainable restaurant atop Milan’s Galleria Victor Emanuel designed by the Milanese architects Park Associati, opened its doors late last year. Conceived by Electrolux, a Swedish appliance brand, the Cube is a four-month project in which Michelin-starred chefs assume two-week residencies to experiment with locally sourced ingredients and regional cuisines.

headline: Answers in Medicine Sometimes Lie in Luck
text: The hospital I work at has no 13th floor.

headline: Pregnancy Prevention and the Taxpayer
text: Between the flap at the Susan G. Komen for the Cure and the squall about the Obama administration’s directive that health insurance plans cover the cost of birth control, contraception is shaping up as one of the year’s biggest political land mines.

headline: TimesCast | Romney's Momentum
text: Mitt Romney makes his final pitch in Canton, Ohio ahead of the Super Tuesday primaries, when 437 delegates from 10 states are at stake.

headline: Soccer’s Sound of Team Spirit
text: BUENOS AIRES — Arsenal must score five goals more than the visiting Italian powerhouse A.C. Milan on Tuesday to advance to the quarterfinals of the Champions League, Europe’s most prestigious soccer tournament. Though such a comeback has happened only three times in the tournament’s 57-year history, some know better than to rule it out.

headline: Caucus Video: Romney’s Momentum
text: Mitt Romney makes his final pitch in Canton, Ohio ahead of the Super Tuesday primaries, when 437 delegates from 10 states are at stake. Ashley Parker reports.

headline: Mental Health: Use of Statins May Lower Depression Risk
text: The use of statin drugs to lower cholesterol in people with stable coronary artery disease is associated with a significantly reduced risk for depression, a new study reports.

headline: Sizing Up the Top 25
text: New to the rankings: No. 24 Gonzaga, No. 25 Iowa State

headline: Regimens: Antibiotic Dosage May Vary in Pregnancy
text: A new study suggests that the correct dose of antibiotics in pregnancy may be different for African-Americans from what it is for other women.

headline: Not Again With The Pivot
text: Steve Pearlstein is a good guy; that’s why the piece he posted on Ezra’s blog fills me with such despair.

headline: Is There Still a Place in Business for a Handshake Deal?
text: Even though I was a girl, my father taught me early in life that nobody likes a wimpy handshake. As I got older, I found myself agreeing with him, especially in a business setting. While we try to decipher clues about personalities based on the firmness — or lack thereof — of someone’s grasp, studies have gone as far as linking the strength of one’s handshake to life expectancy. But do handshake deals lead to healthy relationships in business?

headline: Kovalchuk Demonstrating to Devils How Star Can Also Be Team Player
text: NEWARK — Brayden Schenn, a Philadelphia Flyers rookie center, found out the hard way last month that Ilya Kovalchuk was not just on the ice to draw a big paycheck, or even to score lots of goals. Schenn challenged Kovalchuk to a fight after a scrum. Kovalchuk took him on.

headline: Romney in Ohio: Want College? Can’t Afford It? Too bad.
text: YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio – The high school senior who stood up at Mitt Romney’s town hall meeting here today was worried about how he and his family would pay for college, and wanted to hear what the candidate would do about rising college costs if elected. He didn’t realize that Mr. Romney was about to use him to demonstrate his fiscal conservatism to the crowd.

headline: Triceratops’ Quiet Cousin, the Torosaurus, Gains New Legitimacy
text: NEW HAVEN — Growing up in Calgary, Alberta, Daniel Field idolized John R. Horner, the well-known paleontologist who helped inspire Michael Crichton’s novel “Jurassic Park” and won a MacArthur “genius award” in 1986.

headline: Super Tuesday Delegate Projection Update
text: There has been enough movement in the polls in the past 24 hours to warrant revisiting our delegate projections from Sunday. I now have Rick Santorum trailing Mitt Romney by about 150 delegates, and also falling behind Newt Gingrich, who has some favorable momentum in the delegate-rich Southern states.

headline: Venture Capitalist Pioneer Talks Taxes, Tech and Facebook
text: Even as the market remains wobbly and the economy weak, Frederick R. Adler, the venture capitalist pioneer, is optimistic about the country’s prospects.

headline: No Sign of Progress in Afghanistan Talks Embittered by Koran Burnings
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — The United States and Afghanistan appeared to make no headway here on Monday in high-level negotiations on a long-term strategic partnership that have been embittered somewhat by the Koran burnings last month. Elsewhere, further violence left three people dead, including two children killed in a suicide attack on the main NATO military base where the Korans were desecrated.

text: What is a flame?

headline: Nigeria to Import Morphine in Pain Relief Initiative
text: Nigeria’s health minister announced last week that the country would immediately buy 55 pounds of morphine for the nation’s hospitals and would form an alliance with a new nonprofit organization, the Global Access to Pain Relief Initiative.

headline: Seasoned in Boston, Hopeful in Houston
text: Kissimmee, Fla.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Russia and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Russia, Congo, India and Iraq.

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | Chloé
text: Recall that picture of Kate Moss in a loose pink tank top surrounded by Christmas lights? It was images like this one — shot in the 1990s by Corinne Day — that inspired the beauty look at Chloé. Backstage before the show, the stylist Camille Bidault-Waddington stood near the hairstylist Paul Hanlon as they worked together on perfecting center-parted tousled, mussed hair. “Shake it,” Hanlon said to the model. “It’s nice with a little shape around the face, no?” he asked Bidault-Waddington. As for makeup, Aaron De Mey channeled what he called “a girl with supercool clothes on the streets of Paris, with no makeup — undone.” This meant M.A.C. Strobe Cream on cheeks with hardly any concealer, and the rest of the face matte. Lips were covered in Peach Stock from the Pro Line, a sort of “’70s watercolor.” Eyebrows were the emphasis, filled in with pencil and gel.

headline: Syracuse’s Next Challenge: the Dreaded Double Bye
text: Although Syracuse powered through its regular season with just one loss — a feat matched by Kentucky, making them the first and second teams to do so in a major conference since 2004-5 — there is one drawback to the Orange’s success as it heads to the Big East tournament: the vaunted double bye.

headline: Town and Country From Pedro Lourenço
text: Town and country has been a popular theme among designers this season. Let’s see, there was Christopher Bailey’s men’s wear show for Burberry in Milan in January, when the models wore tight tweeds and carried umbrellas with molded animal heads for handles. Then there was Tommy Hilfiger, at his women’s show in New York, calling his collection “town and country” and showing models in tailored military coats.

headline: City Reverses Policy on Tutoring Limits
text: Some 3,500 New York City public school students will not lose free tutoring services this week, now that the city has reversed its decision to limit the services for financial reasons.

headline: The battle of the Outer Banks; a cry in the dark; and falling asleep too easily.
text: The battle of the Outer Banks; a cry in the dark; and falling asleep too easily.

headline: Where ‘L’ Stands for Large, Fiat Traditionalists Grant 500L Cautious Approval
text: POSITANO, Italy — The 500L nameplate is greatly admired by members of the Positano 500 Club, a small owners’ group here that seeks to preserve, protect and defend the classic Italian microcars of 1957-75.

headline: Red-Tailed Hawk Found Dead in Central Park
text: A red-tailed hawk was found dead in Central Park on Sunday, a week after the body of Lima — a companion of the much-watched red-tail Pale Male — was discovered under a tree.

headline: A Heart Helper May Come at a Price for the Brain
text: After a heart attack and quadruple bypass surgery in 2010, Steve Colburn of Portland, Ore., began taking a cholesterol-lowering statin at the maximum dose. Soon, he began experiencing memory problems.

headline: Australia’s Changing View of the Dingo
text: Thirty-two years ago, 9-week old Azaria Chamberlain disappeared from a campsite in the Australian outback, and her mother’s claim that a dingo took the child caused a storm of public outrage and disbelief.

headline: Hunger Pangs as Nation’s Pie Shrinks

headline: Is Copenhagen Brilliant?
text: How is a relatively small north European capital supposed to compete with the likes of London, Berlin, New York and Shanghai — well, Berlin, New York and Shanghai anyway, after what we learned about London from the China Miéville piece in this week’s The New York Times Magazine.

headline: Study Linking Abortion and Mental Health Problems Is Called False
text: The Journal of Psychiatric Research, which in 2009 published a research article purporting to show a a link between abortions and long-term mental health problems, this month offered a critique of the research, saying that the authors’ analysis “does not support their assertions that abortions led to psychopathology.”

headline: Middle Ground in Decanting
text: WINE lovers rarely agree on the best methods of serving and drinking. Case in point: decanting, the practice of pouring wine from the bottle into another container before serving.

headline: Why Banking Chiefs Shouldn’t Tell Jokes
text: At JPMorgan Chase‘s investor day last week, Jamie Dimon told a roomful of investors and analysts what was supposed to be a joke.

text: BAMIYAN, Afghanistan — Khalil Reza is a champion. His mother calls him a hero. He calls himself a skier.

headline: Sharing the Goods
text: It is a family feud as longstanding and reliable as the swallows’ return to Capistrano: Congressional campaign committees want more fund-raising help from the president, and the president, despite fat coffers, is reluctant to give it.

headline: Super Tuesday, State by State
text: The closest that Americans get to a national presidential primary comes every four years when a large group of states hold their primaries and caucuses on the same day.

headline: Rutgers Defendant Wrote of Keeping ‘Gays Away’
text: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J. — A former Rutgers University student sent a message to a friend about wanting to “keep the gays away” and urged her to watch a feed from a webcam that he had trained on a bed where he expected his roommate to have a tryst with another man, according to text messages shown in court on Monday.

headline: Talking Out of Turn
text: Q. I watch television through a small antenna attached to my HDTV. Sometimes the sound and picture get increasingly out of sync as a show goes on. The sound usually precedes the picture. Why does that happen?

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Soaring E-Book Prices and Pinterest Photos
text: Here are some interesting things that the tech reporters and editors for The New York Times found on the Web recently. There are more here.

headline: 3 Arrests in Beating Death Overheard by Landlady
text: Two men and a woman have been arrested in the beating and strangulation death of a Bronx construction worker, the police said Monday. The woman told investigators that she was a prostitute and had been hired by the victim, Gene Lewis, 40, but felt threatened by him and called the men to hurt him.

headline: Lactose Intolerant, Before Milk Was on Menu
text: Since it was discovered in 1991, preserved in 5,300 years’ worth of ice and snow in the Italian Alps, the body of the so-called Tyrolean Iceman has yielded a great deal of information. Scientists have learned his age (about 46), that he had knee problems, and how he died (by the shot of an arrow).

headline: Ricardo Morales, Star Clarinetist, Reverses His Decision to Join the New York Philharmonic
text: The New York Philharmonic appeared to have scored a coup nearly a year ago when Ricardo Morales, the stand-out principal clarinetist of the Philadelphia Orchestra, agreed to jump ship. Now, the Philharmonic said he has changed his mind. The orchestra announced on Monday that Mr. Morales, who was to have started in the position in September, has decided to stay in Philadelphia “for family reasons.”

headline: A Stand-Up Joke Is Born
text: The night after Christmas, the comedian Myq Kaplan did something most people would find terrifying. He told around 20 minutes of new jokes to a packed audience.

headline: Her Name Was Eileen. His? Halper. Albert Halper.
text: There you have it: The first 169 words of “Atlantic Avenue,” by Albert Halper, the 1956 novel that touched off — “inspired” being too highfalutin a word — City Room’s 2012 Pulp Fiction contest.

headline: Gingrich Campaign Asks Judge to Dismiss ‘Eye of the Tiger’ Lawsuit
text: Lawyers for Newt Gingrich and his presidential campaign have asked a federal judge in Chicago to dismiss a copyright infringement lawsuit brought against the candidate for using the song “Eye of the Tiger” to pump up crowds at campaign stops and political conferences dating back to 2009, according to court documents filed on Monday.

headline: A Quest to Understand How Memory Works
text: At 82, the Nobel Prize-winning neuroscientist Dr. Eric R. Kandel is still constantly coming up with new ideas for research.

headline: Creating a Cableless Living Room
text: A guide to canceling your cable and replacing it with a computer.

headline: Old Collaborators’ Tension and Release
text: The conductor Lorin Maazel and the Vienna Philharmonic, though both have complex and sometimes prickly personalities, have through 50 years of collaboration maintained a warm professional friendship. That was made clear in the Playbill for their three Carnegie Hall concerts over the weekend.

headline: Rivera Hits the Mound
text: TAMPA, Fla. — Mariano Rivera threw his first batting-practice session Monday and is scheduled to throw one more, possibly Friday, before he pitches in a Grapefruit League game. Rivera threw 28 pitches on Field 2 at the Yankees’ complex, and declared afterward that he would be ready for both his first spring training game and opening day, April 6.

headline: No Animals Were Harmed in the Making of This Fossil
text: The famous feathered dinosaur archaeopteryx seems to have had a penchant for fossilizing in painful positions, with its head cranked backward at a severe angle. The contorted posture is so common in dinosaur fossils that it has its own name: opisthotonus, from the Greek “tonos,” meaning tightening, and “opistho,” behind.

headline: García Lorca’s Favorites Enliven Flamenco’s World
text: In addition to being a great poet and playwright, Federico García Lorca was a folklorist who sought to defend Spanish culture against commercialization. He was also a musician, and in 1931 he recorded a seminal collection of Spanish folk songs, reharmonized, with himself at the piano and the dancer La Argentinita singing.

headline: New Albums From Todd Snider, Nite Jewel and Floratone
text: TODD SNIDER

headline: Election Year Offers Students Livelier Civics Lessons
text: With Super Tuesday upon us, when 10 states will hold Republican primary elections, we are asking teachers and students: How have you been covering the election season in the classroom?

headline: New Works for a Moody Continent
text: AMSTERDAM — Even in plush economic times, a festival of new ballets is a risky undertaking. How to find studio hours for all the dancers and choreographers? How to get a collection of new pieces working technically — lighting, décor, staging — at the same time? And then the crucial issue: Will the works be any good?

headline: All in the Framing: The Schoenberg That Isn’t Scary
text: Musicians eager to persuade audiences that Schoenberg’s music is not so fearsome usually accomplish that by cheating a bit. Instead of performing the post-tonal works that most people have in mind when they say they dislike Schoenberg, they choose youthful scores like “Verklärte Nacht,” “Pelleas und Melisande” or, if they have the budget, “Gurre-Lieder” — intensely Romantic works, composed long before serialism was a glint in the composer’s eye.

headline: Knotty Challenges in Health Care Costs
text: The numbers, the projections, make health economists shudder.

headline: Recapturing Chloé’s Charm
text: Clare Waight Keller may have found her groove at Chloé. After a tepid start last season, the designer came back with a very strong collection full of distinctive color — pale pink, lemon, dusty blue, deep red, camel — and standout, pretty sportswear. Although she had a few clunker coats (too heavy) and weird leather culottes with crinkled hems, she created a look with cute jogging pants, airy sweaters with an underlayer of white lace showing, coats based on quilted linings, and some lovely lace tops and dresses. I especially liked that Ms. Keller was comfortable with the notion of a sweater and a skirt, doing them in the Chloé spirit.

headline: French Laundry
text: White was a big trend at the New York fall shows. London designers loved vivid digital prints, Milan feminine colors and matte finishes. But laundry-fresh white has again surfaces at the Paris shows, with the shock of white at Céline (in an oversize coats and wide trousers) and at Stella McCartney (in cotton shirts and embossed double-crepe trousers and short, full skirts).

headline: ‘Hawaii Five-0’ Star Seeks Treatment
text: Alex O’Loughlin, below, the star of the CBS drama “Hawaii Five-0,” will miss the production of at least one episode this month, potentially creating a challenge for the show’s writing and producing staff. A representative for the actor, who plays a state police detective, told news organizations that after a recent shoulder injury, “Alex is taking a short break to receive supervised treatment” for problems related to prescription pain medication. CBS Television Studios, which produces the drama, said in a statement that it respected and supported Mr. O’Loughlin’s decision to take time off and declined to comment further. The remake of “Hawaii Five-0,” now in its second year on CBS, has filmed 19 episodes this season and has 4 more to go. Despite Mr. O’Loughlin’s absence, CBS said that it expected the show to complete its season order.

headline: Footnote
text: Pinchas Zukerman, the violinist and conductor, said on Monday that he would step down as music director of Ottawa’s National Arts Center Orchestra after his contract expires at the end of the 2014-15 season.

The competition, whose laureates include stars like Joyce DiDonato and Eric Owens, offers cash prizes and performance opportunities, sometimes pairing young singers with veteran artists in recital.

headline: Tagliabue Honored
text: The former N.F.L. commissioner Paul Tagliabue, who was instrumental in the league’s efforts to diversify its coaching and front office ranks, has been honored by the Jackie Robinson Foundation with its Robie Humanitarian Award. Tagliabue was to receive the award at the foundation’s annual gala in New York City on Monday night.

headline: Disposal of 9/11 Remains
text: To the Editor:

headline: Protesters Urge Mayor to Spare Programs for Children
text: Parents, City Council members and Bill de Blasio, the city’s public advocate, gathered in front of City Hall on Monday to protest proposed cuts to child care and after-school programs. One parent said, “I can’t be there when that bell rings at 2:45.”

headline: David Hollander
text: The latest installment in Vincent Dilio’s series of portraits from the art scene in Marfa, Tex.

headline: Students Protest Tuition Increases
text: A noisy protest mostly from public college students from New York State upset with legislation that would allow tuition increases.

headline: Merriment, Mischief and a Few Dead Critters
text: The ultimate American id boy is up to his old tricks in “The Adventures of Tom Sawyer” at the New Victory Theater, an amiable if slightly too well-behaved adaptation of Mark Twain’s novel, by Laura Eason.

headline: Report: N.C.A.A. Investigates Syracuse Over Failed Drug Tests
text: Syracuse announced Monday that the N.C.A.A. was investigating its men’s basketball program after Yahoo Sports reported that at least 10 former players since 2001 had failed tests for a banned recreational substance or substances and that the program did not adhere to the university’s drug policy when it came to disciplining them.

headline: In Rejection, F.D.A. Wants More Data From Merck
text: The Food and Drug Administration on Monday rejected an application by Merck to combine a cholesterol-fighting pill with the generic version of Lipitor.

headline: Video of Anti-Putin Protests in Russia
text: Thousands of protesters rallied in Moscow’s Pushkin Square on Monday to condemn the election of Vladimir V. Putin as illegitimate, chanting “Russia without Putin!” and “Putin is a thief!” before the riot police moved in and made hundreds of arrests. Hundreds of anti-Putin protesters were also detained in St. Petersburg earlier in the day.

headline: Chris Christie Endorses Scott Brown in Senate Race
text: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey on Monday endorsed Senator Scott P. Brown, the Massachusetts Republican locked in a high-profile race against Elizabeth Warren, a Democrat.

headline: Kenzo Would Not Be Upstaged
text: PARIS

headline: Coping With a Snarled City
text: In May, a NATO summit meeting will bring thousands of visitors to Chicago. The mayor, Rahm Emanuel, has already apologized to residents for any disruption. But all the extra people and traffic will surely also affect business travelers visiting the city at the same time.

headline: Ex-F.D.A. Chemist Sentenced to 5 Years in Insider Case
text: A federal judge sentenced a longtime chemist with the Food and Drug Administration to five years in prison for using confidential information about drug applications pending with the agency to make nearly $4 million in illegal trading profits.

headline: "On Air"
text: Winning Our Future, a "super PAC" backing Newt Gingrich, released a new ad on Monday arguing for Mr. Gingrich as the most electable candidate.

headline: Boras Says Mets Need New Ownership
text: Scott Boras, considered baseball’s most prominent player agent, strongly suggested Monday night that the sport and the Mets themselves would be better served if the team’s current owners are replaced.

headline: Knicks and Rangers Prices Rise Again
text: Success breeds success, according to one saying. In sports, it also breeds higher ticket prices.

headline: Selling Gingrich, the Fighter
text: Winning Our Future, the pro-Newt Gingrich “super PAC” responsible for the commercials that featured a computer-animated, bobble-headed President Obama, is at it again with a new ad that promotes the former House speaker’s moxie. Or, as the ad puts it, “The guy’s a fighter, and he ain’t afraid to hurt nobody’s feelings.”

headline: White House to Host Group of 8 Meeting at Camp David
text: President Obama has boasted for months about hosting the annual summit of the Group of 8 industrialized nations this May in his hometown of Chicago, but on Monday, the White House without explanation announced a shift to the secluded setting of the Camp David presidential retreat in Maryland.

headline: Digital Records May Not Cut Health Costs, Study Cautions
text: Computerized patient records are unlikely to cut health care costs and may actually encourage doctors to order expensive tests more often, a study published on Monday concludes.

headline: U.S. Law May Allow Killings, Holder Says
text: WASHINGTON — Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. asserted on Monday that it is lawful for the government to kill American citizens if officials deem them to be operational leaders of Al Qaeda who are planning attacks on the United States and if capturing them alive is not feasible.

headline: Protests Over Tuition Increases Jolt the Capitol
text: ALBANY – About 300 students, most of them from public universities in New York, rattled the Capitol on Monday with an outburst of loud protests, in the gallery of the Senate Chamber and outside the governor’s office.

headline: Apple and Google to Meet With Senator Over Privacy
text: Senator Charles E. Schumer, New York Democrat, says Apple and Google have agreed to meet with him to discuss a privacy loophole on smartphones that gives apps unfettered access to people’s personal photos.

headline: Jurors Told to Keep Talking in Financier’s Fraud Trial
text: The judge in the fraud trial of the financier R. Allen Stanford ordered the jury on Monday to return to deliberations after it said it could not reach a unanimous verdict in its fourth day of reviewing the evidence.

headline: 2012  Presidential Race Is ‘the Worst I’ve Ever Seen,’ Barbara Bush Says
text: Barbara Bush, the former first lady, is back on the campaign trail — this time for Mitt Romney — and once again, she’s not biting her famously sharp tongue.

headline: The View from Bay Ridge, 1960
text: As is well known, even notorious by now, the Republican presidential candidate Rick Santorum recently stated that he “almost threw up” after reading John F. Kennedy’s famous 1960 campaign speech on the proper relation between church and state in American politics. Santorum has become the most highly visible face of culturally and politically conservative Catholicism as a result of this and other statements. A cradle Catholic myself, I was moved to re-read that speech and as a result I didn’t “almost” cry – I flat out cried. Cried in gratitude to J.F.K. and his speechwriter Ted Sorensen for being so transcendentally right and for erasing, with some 1,500 well-chosen words, a vile cloud of suspicion that had hung over our nation’s Catholics.

headline: News Corp. Faces Inquiry of Ex-Arm for Bribery
text: As News Corporation seeks to contain a widening investigation into illegal information gathering at its British publishing unit, the company may face fresh allegations at another problematic subsidiary.

headline: Keep Up the Pressure on Myanmar’s Generals
text: Milan

headline: Texas Teacher Pension Buys Bridgewater Stake
text: The Teacher Retirement System of Texas just went from hedge fund investor to hedge fund owner.

headline: For Richardson, a Former Jet, Teenage Friend’s Dream Comes True
text: Tony Richardson met Tyler Nelson in 2009, at a Make-a-Wish Foundation event before the Super Bowl that February.

headline: Leadership Rift Emerges in Pakistani Taliban
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — The Pakistani Taliban faced the prospect of a damaging leadership rift on Monday when the abrupt dismissal of a senior commander provoked an angry reaction in the militants’ ranks, offering the Islamabad government a fresh opportunity to weaken a foe that in recent years has killed thousands of Pakistanis and tried to detonate a crude car bomb in Times Square in 2010.

headline: At Chechnya Polling Station, Votes for Putin Exceed the Rolls
text: GROZNY, Russia — While there were charges of fraud in Russia’s presidential election Sunday, officials throughout most of the country appeared to be on notice to avoid the appearance of cheating in obvious ways like ballot stuffing. But some here seem not to have gotten the memo.

headline: Camp David, Not Chicago, to Host G-8
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama has boasted for months about playing host to the annual summit meeting of the Group of 8 industrialized nations this May in his hometown, Chicago. But on Monday, without explanation, the White House announced a shift to the secluded setting of Camp David, the presidential retreat in Maryland.

headline: After Ratings Drop, Ford Reworks Touch Screens
text: DEARBORN, Mich. — The Ford Motor Company began adding touch-screen control systems to some of its most popular models two years ago as a way to stand out from the rest of the industry and draw in new customers.

headline: India: Italians Jailed in Two Deaths
text: An Indian court on Monday ordered that two Italian marines who were accused of killing two Indian fishermen last month be moved to a jail from a guest house while officials investigate. The Italian government, which has argued that Italy should investigate because its sailors were involved and the episode happened in international waters, called the decision “unacceptable.” Indian officials say the marines shot at the fishermen near the coast of Kerala State after mistaking them for pirates.

headline: Maker of a Hair-Straightening Product Settles Lawsuit
text: The manufacturer of the popular hair-straightening product Brazilian Blowout, the subject of government inquiries and health complaints, said on Monday that it had agreed to settle a class-action lawsuit for about $4.5 million.

headline: Airlines Have a Manifesto, and Travelers Should, Too
text: AS they say in the Navy when seas get rough, stand by for heavy rolls. If you think that airplanes are crowded now, if you worry about service to smaller and midsize cities, if you’re alarmed by rising airfares, just wait.

headline: A Friendlier Cellphone Brand
text: DECLARATIONS of love for cellphone companies are few and far between. Dropped calls, rising prices, spotty service and strict contracts make many customers want to throw their hands — and their phones — in the air.

headline: After Barnard Gets Obama for Speech, Tensions With Columbia Bubble Up
text: Ivy League schools usually cloak their jealousies in politesse, but President Obama’s decision to give the commencement speech at Barnard, and not Columbia, his alma mater across the street, has unleashed online exchanges as nasty as any hair-pulling, eye-gouging schoolyard brawl.

headline: Lin’s Star Turn Demands Learning in the Spotlight
text: DALLAS

headline: Santorum Sticks to a Bare-Bones Style
text: WESTERVILLE, Ohio — On the eve of Super Tuesday, more than two full months into the presidential nominating season, Rick Santorum’s campaign is still a bare-bones operation, with little of the slickness that many presidential campaigns exhibit by this time in the process.

headline: Wide Sentencing Disparity Found Among U.S. Judges
text: A new analysis of hundreds of thousands of cases in federal courts has found vast disparities in the prison sentences handed down by judges presiding over similar cases, raising questions about the extent to which federal sentences are influenced by the particular judges rather than by the specific circumstances of the cases.

headline: Rick Santorum Isn’t Crazy
text: Media pundits have been beating up on Rick Santorum for saying that the assertion of an absolute separation of church and state makes him want to throw up, for attacking John F. Kennedy’s pledge to be “a president whose religious views are his own private affair” and for declaring that “the idea that the church can have no influence in the operation of the state is absolutely antithetical to the objectives and visions of our country.”

headline: Healthy Labels, Not Stealthy Labels
text: Research suggests that consumers spend only about one second looking at nutrition information when making myriad choices. A parent dashing through the grocery store aisles with kids in tow has to decide, in that one second, which is better: Triscuit vs. Saltines vs. Wheat Thins vs. Ritz? This is why Americans need a simple, standardized and truthful label on the front of all packaged foods.

headline: ‘Officers, Why Do You Have Your Guns Out?’
text: White Plains

headline: Welcome Trend in College Tuition
text: A small but growing number of private colleges are freezing tuition and rethinking policies that have driven up prices to unsustainable levels. According to the National Association of Independent Colleges and Universities, which represents more than 950 private colleges, 15 have announced tuition freezes for the 2012-13 school year. The group includes two well-known, selective schools, Mount Holyoke College and Sewanee, the University of the South. Before the recession, such freezes were rare.

headline: Diving Board Is Set to Begin a Second Career in the Theater
text: Juliet’s balcony may never be the same.

headline: Fed Study of Student Debt Outlines a Growing Burden
text: A report released Monday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York renews concerns about the growing debt load of college students and graduates.

headline: Poorly Told Political Fortunes
text: With his time served on the trail in 2008 and the money he had going into 2012 and his momentum coming out of Florida, Mitt Romney was supposed to be turning much of his attention to the fall by now, not looking over his shoulder and sweating Ohio.

headline: Making the Flight, Missing the Airport
text: I’M one of those lucky people who never have a nervous thought when flying. Once I’m up in the air, I think it’s absolutely delicious. Sometimes seatmates recognize me and may want some real estate advice, and that’s fine. I don’t mind talking on occasion. But I’m usually focused on what I have to do when I get to where I’m going.

headline: A Weakened Miranda Rule
text: The Supreme Court recently did significant damage to the Miranda rule, which requires that suspects in custody be told of their right to remain silent and to have a lawyer present, and that any statements they make could be used against them in criminal proceedings.

headline: Ralph McQuarrie, Artist Who Helped Bring ‘Star Wars’ to Life, Dies at 82
text: Ralph McQuarrie, the artist who transformed George Lucas’s rudimentary concepts and earliest scripts into lush, vivid images of intergalactic expanse and light-saber combat that became the visual core of the “Star Wars” saga, died on Saturday at his home in Berkeley, Calif. He was 82.

headline: Former Independent Governor to Run for Snowe’s Senate Seat
text: Former Gov. Angus King of Maine, an independent who served two terms from 1995 to 2003, announced Monday night that he would run for the seat that Senator Olympia Snowe is giving up.

headline: Chandler Says He’ll Tape Up and Play On
text: DALLAS — Knicks center Tyson Chandler is coping with multiple injuries to his left hand and wrist and will probably be playing through pain for the rest of the season.

headline: The Rediscovery of Character
text: The obituaries for James Q. Wilson, the eminent social scientist, generally emphasized his “broken windows” theory on how to reduce crime. That’s natural. This strategy, which contributed to the recent reduction in crime rates, was his most tangible legacy.

headline: As an Adviser, Goldman Guaranteed Its Payday
text: Lloyd C. Blankfein had a script for his phone call.

headline: Judge Cebull’s Racist ‘Joke’
text: Apologizing for atrocious behavior is better than not trying to apologize. Rush Limbaugh’s nonapology to Sandra Fluke for calling her a prostitute was a good example. But sometimes even a seemingly sincere apology is not enough.

headline: Iran, Israel and the United States
text: President Obama and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel share responsibility for the strains in their relationship. But there should be no doubt about Mr. Obama’s commitment to Israel’s security. When he warns that an Israeli attack on Iran could backfire, and that “there is still a window” for diplomacy, he is speaking for American and Israeli interests.

headline: Ronnie Montrose, Hard-Rock Guitarist, Dies at 64
text: Ronnie Montrose, an influential guitarist whose band, Montrose, was a mainstay of hard rock in the 1970s and the launching pad for the singer Sammy Hagar, died on Saturday at his home in Brisbane, Calif. He was 64.

headline: A Union Stands Up for Players
text: “I hate bullies,” said DeMaurice Smith.

headline: Senate to Choose an Insider Trading Bill
text: WASHINGTON — Senate leaders, eager to avoid a freewheeling, unpredictable debate on Congressional ethics, are considering simply accepting a House-passed bill to ban insider trading by lawmakers.

headline: A Dutch Angel’s Cellphone Number Is in Demand
text: ’S HERTOGENBOSCH, the Netherlands — High on the cathedral in this trim Dutch town, amid a phalanx of stone statues of local noblemen, crusaders, saints and angels, one figure stands out. Smiling faintly, with lowered eyelids, one of the angels wears jeans, has a laptop bag slung over one shoulder and is chatting on a cellphone. The angel gets about 30 calls a day on the phone.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: March 5, 2012

headline: Charges Weighed for Lawyer Who Revealed Witness’s Name
text: A federal district judge in Brooklyn has asked the United States attorney’s office there to review whether to pursue criminal contempt charges against a lawyer who revealed in court papers in 2010 the identity of a businessman who had pleaded guilty in an organized-crime case and cooperated with the government.

headline: Report Links Ex-Detainees to Terrorism and Insurgency
text: WASHINGTON – National security officials on Monday reported that the number of “confirmed” cases in which former detainees previously held at the prison at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, engaged in terrorist or insurgent activity after their transfer  had risen to 95 from 81 – out of the 599 prisoners released – from October 2010 to December 2011.

headline: Chinese Heroism Effort Is Met With Cynicism
text: FUSHUN, China — Some national heroes are born in the crucible of war. Others have far less dramatic origins.

headline: In Caucus States, a Chance for (Almost) Every Candidate
text: The states holding Republican caucuses on Tuesday have received little attention as compared with high-profile primary states like Ohio and Georgia. But the caucuses in Alaska, Idaho and North Dakota — in addition to awarding 87 delegates — will help decide how the overall Super Tuesday scoreboard is reported and may seem more important in the rear-view mirror. In 2008, Barack Obama’s wins in the caucus states on Super Tuesday helped him to win more delegates from the evening, and turned what was initially perceived as a relatively poor performance for him into one that gave him some degree of momentum.

headline: Yankees Think That for Pineda, Changeup Is in Good (and Big) Hands
text: CLEARWATER, Fla. — From the base of the palm to the tip of the middle finger, Michael Pineda’s right hand approaches 10 inches long, meaning his hand is almost a foot.

headline: So What?
text: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — One of the nice things about constructing crossword puzzles as a hobby is that you are not under any deadline pressure and can ruminate on theme material or how to stack long entries in a themeless puzzle as much as you like. Wesley Johnson is just such a constructor, and he is back today after a seven-year absence.

headline: Who Am I? Why Are We Here? Oh, Hello, Death
text: Edward Albee throws a mean party. Just check out the elegant, savage soiree taking place at the Pershing Square Signature Center, where “Edward Albee’s The Lady From Dubuque” opened on Monday night in a scintillating revival. One small thing you should probably know, though, in case you’re not on speaking terms: Death is on the guest list.

headline: Rematch for UConn and Notre Dame
text: HARTFORD — The hard-working Connecticut sophomore center Stefanie Dolson took an uncontested back-door pass from Tiffany Hayes, banked in a layup, and broke into a big smile as she headed upcourt, as if the Huskies had reasserted themselves a little too easily Monday.

headline: Update on New York Redistricting
text: With just 16 weeks until its Congressional primary, New York still has no approved political districts, causing increasing consternation among elected officials, potential challengers and government reform groups. New York is now among the last states in the nation to tackle the redistricting required as a result of the 2010 census. And the urgency is growing: the state’s Congressional primary is scheduled for June 26, and its legislative primary for Sept. 11.

headline: Former Staten Island Ferry Springs Leak and Lists
text: A former Staten Island ferry, decommissioned in 2007 after more than four decades of service, was tilting sideways on Monday after springing a leak last week about 60 miles north of New York City, and it might have to be dismantled, the authorities said.

headline: U.S. Remains Opposed to Drug Legalization, Biden Tells Region
text: MEXICO CITY — Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. delivered a blunt message on Monday to leaders in Latin America who are contemplating opening the door to the legalization of illicit drugs: The United States will not budge in its opposition.

headline: Japan’s Women Repeat Their Win Over U.S.
text: In the teams’ first meeting since the exhilarating final of last summer’s Women’s World Cup, Japan on Monday again vanquished the United States again on Monday.

headline: Antics Aside, Coach Gains His First Berth in N.C.A.A. Tournament
text: SPRINGFIELD, Mass. — Long before Loyola’s Jimmy Patsos became a college coach best known for drawing technical fouls, pirouetting along the sideline and sitting 10 rows deep in the stands during games, he worked at a place where his antics fit better.

headline: Was That Twitter Blast False, or Just Honest Hyperbole?
text: WASHINGTON — Mark W. Miller did not think Cincinnati should be spending money on a streetcar project, and he said so on Twitter. He urged his hundreds of followers to vote against the project, which was on the local ballot last November.

headline: Oblivious to Court Battle, Mets Drop Their Opener
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — If Mets players were at all unsettled by the legal tribulations of their owners, which continued to unfold Monday morning in Manhattan, they did a fine job hiding it.

headline: A Tribe Confronts Its Neighbor Over Liquor
text: The Oglala Sioux Tribe has filed a federal lawsuit against stores that sell beer in Whiteclay, Neb., Anheuser-Busch and several other American brewers, accusing them of encouraging consumption of beer.

headline: At Tribe’s Door, a Hub of Beer and Heartache
text: WHITECLAY, Neb. — Four rickety metal shacks that line the main road in this town of maybe 10 people sell an average of 13,000 cans of beer and malt liquor a day. The nearest sizable city is two hours north. But just 240 yards north — across the state line in South Dakota — is the sprawling Pine Ridge Indian Reservation, where alcohol has been banned since the 1970s.

headline: McCain Calls for U.S.-Led Airstrikes in Syria
text: Senator John McCain called on Monday for the United States to lead airstrikes against Syria’s armed forces to protect the rebels and civilians there, much as it did in Libya last year. Mr. McCain said, however, that the stakes were much higher in Syria. In a post on The Caucus, John H. Cushman Jr. writes:

headline: Candidates Hammer Obama Over Iran, but Approaches Differ Little
text: WASHINGTON — To rein in Tehran’s nuclear ambitions, Mitt Romney says he would conduct naval exercises in the Persian Gulf to remind Iran of American military might. He would try to ratchet up Security Council sanctions on Iran, targeting its Revolutionary Guards, and the country’s central bank and other financial institutions. And if Russia and China do not go along, he says, the United States should team up with other willing governments to put such punitive measures in place.

headline: Should U.S. Food Aid Be Made in China?
text: HONG KONG — Somewhere, presumably, ships are about to be loaded with protein bars, animal crackers and oatmeal, the cargo bound for North Korea as part of a new diplomatic bargain with the United States. The bare bones of the deal are this: The North has agreed to a monitored shutdown of its main atomic reactor in exchange for a quarter-million tons of U.S. food aid.

headline: Numberplay: Math as a Spectator Sport
text: Move over, Super Bowl, the MoMath Masters Tournament is here! Well maybe not, but the final rounds of the First Math Masters, which enlivened the highly successful fund-raising gala for the Museum of Mathematics, provided the same thrills, tension, quick thinking under pressure, and the collective sharp intakes of onlookers’ breaths, as a true sports event does. At the end of it all, as with professional athletes, you had to admire the skills of the finalists and their amazing ability to perform so well in front of an audience and under intense time pressure.

headline: A Possible Last Hurrah for a Liberal Lion of Ohio
text: TOLEDO, Ohio — Representative Dennis J. Kucinich, a liberal icon who tried twice to win the Democratic nomination for president, was fighting for his political life in a mostly empty meeting hall in central Toledo.

headline: Black Students Face More Discipline, Data Suggests
text: Black students, especially boys, face much harsher discipline in public schools than other students, according to new data from the Department of Education.

headline: Cato Institute Is Caught in a Rift Over Its Direction
text: WASHINGTON — From its perch in a spacious brand-new headquarters blocks from the White House, the Cato Institute has built on its reputation as a venerable libertarian research center unafraid to cross party lines.

headline: Champions League Preview: Arsenal’s Wenger Going for Broke
text: Given the 4-0 first-leg deficit his team is seeking to overcome, it would not have been surprising if Arsenal’s Arsène Wenger had announced that he was planning to start St. Jude up front against A.C. Milan. Instead, he hinted that he had something more exciting in mind.

headline: Supreme Court Seeks Clarification on Jurisdiction in a Human Rights Case
text: WASHINGTON — Six days after hearing arguments in a major human rights case about whether corporations may be sued for complicity in torture abroad, the Supreme Court on Monday instructed the parties to address an even broader question.

headline: Preschoolers in Surgery for a Mouthful of Cavities
text: SEATTLE — In the surgical wing of the Center for Pediatric Dentistry at Seattle Children’s Hospital, Devon Koester, 2 ½ years old, was resting last month in his mother’s arms as an anesthesiologist held a bubble-gum-scented mask over his face to put him under. The doctors then took X-rays, which showed that 11 of his 20 baby teeth had cavities. Then his pediatric dentist extracted two incisors, performed a root canal on a molar, and gave the rest fillings and crowns.

headline: Running Robot Breaks Speed Record
text: A design firm financed by the Pentagon has broken a 23-year-old speed record for legged robots. Boston Dynamics, founded by Marc Raibert, a former M.I.T. roboticist, released a video on YouTube on Monday of its four-legged Cheetah prototype running on a treadmill at 18 miles per hour. The treadmill is designed to support speeds up to 50 m.p.h., but the company said it planned to test the Cheetah outside the lab as soon as possible. The previous record was 13.1 m.p.h., set at M.I.T. in 1989. Boston Dynamics, based in Waltham, Mass., has designed a range of mobile robots with financing from the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency. Previous designs, like BigDog, have been machines intended to follow walking soldiers in the field with loads of up to 1,000 pounds. The company said that while Cheetah was a research project, both military and civilian applications were possible, including emergency rescue and the navigation of rugged terrain.

headline: March 6, 1857 | Supreme Court Issues Dred Scott Decision
text: On March 6, 1857, in its Dred Scott decision, the Supreme Court ruled that Mr. Scott, a slave who had spent part of his life in non-slave territory, could not sue for his freedom in a federal court because, as the March 7 New York Times summarized, “Negroes, whether slaves or free, that is, men of the African race, are not citizens of the United States by the Constitution.”

Mr. Pinault stood between his wife, the actress Salma Hayek and the YSL muse extraordinaire, Catherine Deneuve.

headline: Even Dairy Farming Has a 1 Percent

headline: What Have You Done to Earn Money?
text: Joshua Johnson tap dances on the New York City subways to pay for college. Cameron Stephens knew he was unlikely to find paid work in a poor economy, so he just worked at an Atlanta farmer’s market, free, until someone noticed — and started paying him. What have you done, at any point in your life, to earn a bit of money — or to gain valuable job skills, even if you worked with no pay?

headline: More Violence in Syria as Forces Scramble to Scrub Signs of Assault on Homs
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — With the Syrian military’s wholesale assault on the central city of Homs over, antigovernment protests descended into skirmishing in several towns and cities across the country on Tuesday, while opponents and supporters of President Bashar al-Assad traded barbed remarks about ending the violence.

text: The crushing defeat by the ruling Indian National Congress Party and the Nehru-Gandhi dynasty in Uttar Pradesh “calls into question their political mandate at a time when the party and family were already struggling to advance their policy agenda in New Delhi,” Vikas Bajaj and Hari Kumar write in The New York Times.

headline: Fantasy Focus: The Industry Weighs In
text: Twenty-five of the best fantasy players in the industry flocked to Arizona during the weekend for the League of Alternative Baseball Reality auctions. This year was the first to include a mixed-league format (that 15-team draft was held online a week earlier), but the American League-only and National League-only leagues provide the first true data points in the industry for what players are likely to cost in similar settings throughout the next month.

headline: Black Students Face Harsher Discipline, Study Says
text: Black students, and boys in particular, are more likely to be harshly disciplined in school than other students, according to new data from the U.S. Department of Education. The new information, from the department's Civil Rights Data Collection’s 2009-10 statistics, shows that while black students make up a fraction of the enrollment at schools surveyed -- 18 percent -- they account for 35 percent of first-time suspensions and 46 percent of second-time suspensions.

headline: Scouting the Draft: South Carolina’s Stephon Gilmore
text: Another day, another cornerback prospect.  I have already provided scouting reports for L.S.U.’s Morris Claiborne,Alabama’s Dre Kirkpatrick, Georgia’s Brandon Boykin, North Alabama’s Janoris Jenkins, and Virginia’s Chase Minnifield.  Today, I will try my hand at cornerback Stephon Gilmore of South Carolina.

headline: Leisure Island
text: When it comes to hedonistic pleasures — clothing-optional beaches, mega-yachts — St. Bart’s isn’t exactly lacking. But until recently, the island had one curious deficiency: a scarcity of high-end spas. (Hôtel Guanahani’s Clarins center was the only game in town.) Then last fall the Isle de France spa overhauled its treatments with the help of Natura Bissé, a company known for its anti-aging technology. Le Sereno added a Christian Liaigre-designed spa with an indoor-outdoor waterfront pavilion (above) and a menu heavy on products from the local brand Ligne St. Barth. And the Hotel Christopher just opened a spa with sea-facing treatment rooms and 15 different massages.

headline: John Galt Wants Price Support
text: Lots of people have been having fun with the latest Max Abelson piece on whiny Wall Streeters. One thing Mike Konczal points out is that this is in part the whine of rentiers, angry that their wealth isn’t yielding the return they want:

headline: Almost Dawn in Libya: A Shared War
text: Dark storm clouds and a raging sea greeted the photographer Bryan Denton when he first arrived in the eastern Libyan city of Benghazi. It was the afternoon of Feb. 24, 2011, just days after the city’s residents had expelled troops and officials loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, marking the birth of Libya’s uprising.

headline: Image of the Day: March 6
text: Shiromani Akali Dal supporters celebrate in Amristar, Punjab.

headline: El Paso Corp. Chief Defends His Actions in Kinder Morgan Deal
text: After taking heat from a Delaware judge over his role in selling the El Paso Corporation to Kinder Morgan for $21.1 billion, El Paso’s chief executive is publicly defending himself.

headline: When the Leader Goes, Should the Statues Follow?
text: As it became apparent that the Bahujan Samaj Party, led by Mayawati, will no longer be returning to power in Uttar Pradesh, India’s most populous state, a very pressing question arose:

headline: Donald M. Payne, First Black Elected to Congress From New Jersey, Dies at 77
text: Representative Donald M. Payne, a former chairman of the Congressional Black Caucus who achieved a long-held goal of becoming the first black congressman from New Jersey, died on Tuesday in Livingston, N.J. He was 77.

headline: Perella Weinberg and Greenhill Add Senior Executives
text: Two boutique investment banks announced the hiring of senior-level executives on Tuesday, picking up veteran investment bankers to bolster their ranks.

headline: India’s Supreme Court to Hear Dispute on Drug Patents
text: MUMBAI, India — While China was becoming the world’s shop floor, India took its place as the world’s pharmacy, and in recent decades has been the largest provider of cheap, lifesaving medicines in poor countries across the globe.
