text: Paris

headline: From Believers, and Nonbelievers, a Showing of Political Muscle
text: Religion has been wrapped up in New York civic life to an uncommon degree of late, with all the Abrahamic faiths involved. The combination of the sacred and the secular is inevitably combustible.

headline: Obama ‘Has Turned His Back’ on Israel, Santorum Says
text: Rick Santorum on Tuesday called Iran “a nightmare for all freedom-loving people in the world,” promising that if he is elected president, “we would find no gap between Israel and the United States because our interests are united.”

headline: Santorum and Romney Court Blue-Collar Voters in Ohio
text: COLUMBUS, Ohio -- Republicans cast their votes in 10 states on Tuesday to help decide how to award the biggest batch of delegates so far in the party’s presidential nominating contest, with Mitt Romney and Rick Santorum engaged in a particularly competitive fight in Ohio.

headline: Your Misguided Search for a Money Guru
text: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah. His new book, “The Behavior Gap,” was published earlier this year. His sketches are archived here on the Bucks blog.

headline: Points West
text: For Yodit Eklund, the 26-year-old designer behind Bantu swimwear, the beaches along Africa’s West Coast are a source of inspiration — so she photographed her recent collection there (including the suits above, on the road to Assinie-Mafia in Ivory Coast). She wonders why ‘‘some of the best beaches in the world’’ are surfed only by locals. Here, Eklund’s favorite spots.

headline: The Economic Impact of the Pill
text: The recent controversy over contraception and health insurance has focused on who should pay for the pill. But there is a wealth of economic evidence about the value of the pill – to taxpayers, as my colleague Motoko Rich writes, as well as to women in general.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: The San Francisco Chronicle: In the Santa Rita Hills of western Santa Barbara County, Jon Bonné sees evidence of a stylistic change, as he finds more wines that are lively, structured and leaner rather than hefty and opulent. — Eric Asimov

headline: Former Apple Executive Plots Next Wave of Mobile Ads
text: Lars Albright helped Apple begin its first foray into mobile advertising after the company bought his company, Quattro Wireless, for nearly $300 million in 2010. Now Mr. Albright believes he has come up with a plan to offer mobile ads that are tougher for users to ignore than traditional promotions.

headline: Looking to Stretch Design Language, Land Rover Shows Evoque Convertible Concept
text: GENEVA — Introduced here Tuesday, a topless version of the two-door Range Rover Evoque is designed to show “what’s possible” for Land Rover, according to John Edwards, the brand’s director.

headline: Morning Buzz, March 6: High-Tech Transit Updates
text: Good morning. Brace for another sunny, but cold, day as temperatures will most likely rise to the low 40s before dropping again later in the evening.

headline: Daily Report: Imagining the New iPad
text: It’s the day before Apple is expected to unveil the newest version of its iPad, and the rumor frenzy shows no sign of abating.

headline: ‘Hope Is Not a Foreign Policy,’ Romney Says
text: Mitt Romney vowed on Tuesday to “bring the current policy of procrastination toward Iran to an end” if elected president, saying at  a huge conference of the American Israel Public Affairs Committee that he would impose “crippling sanctions,” station carriers and warships “at Iran’s door,” and suspend all diplomatic relations.

headline: Hakaan: Fall 2012 RTW
text: Paris

headline: Tribeca Festival Announces First Slate of Films for 2012
text: If it doesn’t include new works from James Franco and Harmony Korine, is it really a film festival? The organizers of the Tribeca Film Festival will not have to contend with that existential question this year: among the offerings announced on Tuesday as part of its 2012 lineup are “Francophrenia (or: Don’t Kill Me, I Know Where the Baby Is),” a hybrid documentary/fiction feature directed by Mr. Franco and Ian Olds, and “The Fourth Dimension,” directed by Mr. Korine, Alexey Fedorchenko and Jan Kwiecinski.

headline: Santorum’s Super Tuesday Message: Romney Is a Liar
text: CUYAHOGA FALLS, Ohio – Rick Santorum closed out his Super Tuesday campaign by coming quite close to calling Mitt Romney a liar.

headline: Leading Off: Madness of a Different Kind
text: The N.F.L. really hopes you are immersed in the joyful spectacle of college basketball. Virginia Commonwealth is back in the N.C.A.A. tournament! Isn’t that awesome? Of course, it would take you being immersed in just about anything other than that ugliness inherent in the bounty scandal. Saint Mary’s, what a fabulous story! Can the Gaels pull a Butler? But the league figures, if you can sidestep all the moral and ethical issues pockmarking college sports and still embrace the game, you’re getting great practice for N.F.L. season. Because there’s at least a 10-morals pileup awaiting you at your next N.F.L. viewing. Did you see that double-overtime Davidson victory to make the tournament? Oh my!

headline: Army Recommends Court-Martialing 4 Soldiers in Death of Private
text: An American military investigator has recommended that four more soldiers be court-martialed in connection with the death of Pvt. Danny Chen, a Chinese-American soldier from New York City who apparently killed himself last fall in Afghanistan, the military said in a statement on Tuesday.

headline: Jaguar XF Sportbrake Won’t Join the Westward Wagon Train
text: GENEVA — The new Jaguar XF Sportbrake introduced here won’t be coming to America, but not for the reason that most readily comes to mind.

headline: Chanel’s Fortress of Solitude
text: The Parisian fashion house always takes the show design awards, using the cavernous space of the Grand Palais in lots of different ways: constructing an enormous carousel, a gigantic lion, even an airplane cabin for the recent summer 2012 couture show.

headline: The Preschool Cavity Epidemic
text: Eleven cavities? One toddler? Before you jump to any conclusions about the kind of neglect that would leave a 2 1/2-year-old in that position, read Preschoolers in Surgery for a Mouthful of Cavities.  Catherine Saint Louis, a Times reporter, writes, “dentists nationwide say they are seeing more preschoolers at all income levels with 6 to 10 cavities or more.”

headline: Fox Pulls Plug on ‘Terra Nova’
text: The most expensive television show of the season, the time-traveling family drama “Terra Nova,” won’t be coming back to the Fox network.

headline: Broadway and Morris Street, 8:19 A.M.
text: N.Y. See: Demonstrators held mock pink slips in Lower Manhattan as part of a rally to highlight the plight of unemployed Americans.

headline: Mitt’s Grueling Journey
text: In today’s column on the winding, surprising road to Super Tuesday, I make reference to an NBC/Wall Street Journal poll with some distressing news for Mitt Romney: the percentage of voters who view him unfavorably is 11 points higher than the percentage of voters who view him favorably. That’s a spread that has widened and worsened since the primaries began. And some additional observations about it, along with some historical context, are in order.

headline: F.B.I. Offers Reward for News of Former Agent Missing in Iran
text: The Federal Bureau of Investigation offered a $1 million reward on Tuesday for information about a former F.B.I. agent who disappeared in Iran five years ago.

headline: Voting on Super Tuesday, From Massachusetts to Georgia
text: Republicans are voting in 10 states, choosing 20 percent of their convention delegates.

headline: Shark Fins Are Loaded With a Neurotoxin, Study Finds
text: Shark fins contain high levels of a potent neurotoxin that scientists have linked to neurodegenerative diseases like Alzheimer’s and Parkinson’s, according to a recent study published in the journal Marine Drugs.

headline: The All-Big East Fear Monger Team
text: You are not allowed to say it before, during or after a game, and in most basketball circles you are not allowed to say it ever. But that doesn’t change the fact that there are and always will be players who freak you out, and this year’s Big East tournament crop is no exception.

headline: Kennedy Center Announces 2012-2013 Season
text: Washington can take occasional breaks from politics this fall when the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts opens its 42nd season. On Tuesday, Michael M. Kaiser, the center’s president, unveiled highlights of the 2012-2013 program, which include celebrations of Woody Guthrie’s and Bob Marley’s music; a new production of Fernec Molnár’s “Guardsman,” adapted by Richard Nelson and directed by Gregory Mosher; debuts of Lar Lubovitch Dance Company; a new production of “Show Boat” by the Washington National Opera; a weeklong residency with Chinese pianist Lang Lang; and the comedian David Alan Grier.

headline: Paulson’s Post-Traumatic February
text: Pulses may be quickening at Paulson & Company, the hedge fund giant, after one of the firm’s main funds lost 1.5 percent in February.

headline: Police Dept. Employee Accused of Assaulting Girlfriend
text: A New York Police Department employee was arrested at 9:30 p.m. on Monday after the police said he assaulted his girlfriend and locked her in the bathroom while the couple’s young daughter was in another part of their home.

headline: Now, Tables for (Almost) Everyone
text: “Come gather in the living room,” the staff told assisted living residents on Monday afternoon at Harbor’s Edge, a retirement village in Norfolk, Va. “We have an important announcement.”

headline: Digital Notes: Indie Distributors Merge and Live Nation Buys Setlist.fm
text: Indie Distributors Merge: The Orchard and IODA, the two largest independent distributors of digital music, are merging, the companies announced on Tuesday. The combined firm, to be called the Orchard, will be something of a super-indie, with $130 million in revenue and deals to release the music of thousands of labels and music groups, from the Barsuk and Daptone labels to the London Symphony Orchestra and Sesame Workshop. The news was first reported on Monday night by Billboard.

headline: Gingrich Promises to Move American  Embassy to Jerusalem on ‘Day 1’
text: Less than an hour after former Gov. Mitt Romney vowed to make Jerusalem his first foreign destination if elected president, one of his rivals for the Republican nomination, former House Speaker Newt Gingrich, went one better, promising to move the American Embassy from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem on “Day 1” of his prospective presidency.

headline: Arrests Sow Mistrust Inside a Clan of Hackers
text: For months, The Real Sabu, as he called himself on Twitter, boasted, cursed and egged on his followers to take part in computer attacks against private companies and government agencies worldwide.

headline: New York’s Best Bars for Watching British Football
text: “A true Londoner would never support Manchester United, I was told,” Craig Taylor writes in this week’s London-centric issue of the magazine. When I ran into my friend Sulimon on Sunday at Brooklyn’s Black Horse Pub to watch Man U. play my team, Tottenham Hotspur, he disagreed. Born and bred in Brixton, Sulimon resolutely counts himself as a true Londoner — but he has been a United supporter since age 5. “A true Mancunian can never be a United supporter,” he said by way of correction. “They’re all Man City supporters. The rest of the country supports United.” Fighting words.

headline: Super Tuesday Live Coverage
text: Ten states vote on Tuesday, and The Times will provide updates and analysis throughout the day, with live coverage of results beginning at 5 p.m. Eastern.

headline: On Our Radar: Alien Plants in Antarctica
text: Scientists working in Antarctica have inadvertently introduced alien plants and tiny animals there that are likely to spread as the climate warms, researchers report. Scouring the clothes and boots of scientists and tourists visiting the continent, they found that most were carrying nonnative plant seeds. [BBC]

headline: Refinancing Fees Are Reduced for Some F.H.A. Borrowers
text: In what it described as part of an initiative to lift the housing market, the Obama administration said Tuesday that it would make refinancing less expensive for certain borrowers with mortgages backed by the Federal Housing Administration.

headline: Vegetarian Spring Rolls With Shredded Kohlrabi
text: Spring rolls are quite easy to make, and make a light and delicious lunch, appetizer, side dish or snack. You can find the rice flour spring roll wrappers in Asian markets.

headline: With EXP 9F, Bentley Joins the Luxury-Crossover Gold Rush
text: GENEVA — Coming off a record performance in 2011, with particularly robust sales in China, Bentley sees a limitless sales horizon. Dealers, meanwhile, want more hardware to display in their showrooms. So the Volkswagen Group subsidiary decided to go where almost every other automaker in search of sales has gone before it: to crossovers.

headline: Fascination and Fear as Robots Gain Speed
text: This Cheetah is not cute.

headline: Panetta Warns Iran: ‘We Will Act’
text: Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta pledged to an influential pro-Israel lobbying group on Tuesday that if the pressure of diplomacy and sanctions failed to stop Iran from building a nuclear weapon, the United States was fully prepared to take military action as a last resort.

headline: Kohlrabi and Celery Root Purée
text: This simple combination tastes so good to me, it hardly needs embellishment. The butter is optional. If you miss old-fashioned buttery mashed potatoes, let this be a stand-in.

text: 8:07 p.m. | Updated

headline: Bantu Swimwear
text: A look at Yodit Eklund's collection, shot alongside its inspiration, Africa’s West Coast.

headline: A Book Cover He’d Prefer to Forget
text: It was an attention-getter of a painting: Neighborhood lowlifes eyeing a blond woman. Maybe you notice the yellow dress. Maybe you notice that it has slipped off one shoulder. Maybe you notice the bra strap that has been exposed. Maybe you notice the red necklace, the red purse and the red shoes. Probably you notice something else.

headline: Channel Surfing: ‘Through the Wormhole: Will We Survive First Contact?’
text: The Science Channel has labeled March “Are We Alone?” month, and Tuesday night a new episode of the always interesting series “Through the Wormhole” gets aboard the extraterrestrial bandwagon with “Will We Survive First Contact?” Um, there’s good news and bad news.

headline: Keeping His Park Safe
text: Jim Schultz has been a climber and pruner for the city’s Department of Parks and Recreation ever since he started working for the agency in 1997. Here, Mr. Schultz, 47, who is clearly passionate about what he does, describes some work he and his crew did last month at Crotona Park in the Bronx.

headline: On Iran, Questions of Detection and Response Divide U.S. and Israel
text: WASHINGTON — When President Obama and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel met in the White House on Monday, the main subject was how to calibrate the resumption of negotiations with Iran while continuing to accelerate sanctions and sabotage against its nuclear program. But they remained divided on two central questions: If Iran decided to race for a nuclear weapon, would the West detect that in time to stop it? And even if it were detected, would an airstrike be the best option?

headline: Fox Cancels the Prehistoric Drama ‘Terra Nova’
text: One of the television season’s most ambitious new series, the drama “Terra Nova,” about a family sent back into the prehistoric past, got word late Monday that it will have no future on the Fox network.

headline: Bach at One Series Returns in New York
text: Bach at One, the flagship series of Trinity Wall Street’s music program at St. Paul’s Chapel, which was suspended in January, returned on Monday afternoon in a modest way. Julian Wachner, the director of music and arts, conducted 12 members of the Trinity Choir in a shortish program of motets, two by Bach, one by Heinrich Schütz. The Trinity Baroque Orchestra was represented merely by continuo players: Avi Stein, organist, and Katie Rietman, cellist.

headline: Winston’s Hiccup
text: “I think I’ll write a book today,” the writer Georges Simenon was said to tell his wife at breakfast. “Fine,” she would reply, “but what will you do in the afternoon?” Winston Churchill was similarly prolific, and not just in the field of letters [1]. In his later years, he liked to boast that in 1921 he created the British mandate of Trans-Jordan, the first incarnation of what still is the Kingdom of Jordan, “with the stroke of a pen, one Sunday afternoon in Cairo” [2].

headline: Live Blog: President Obama’s News Conference
text: President Obama held his first news conference of the year on Tuesday. We carried the play-by-play.

headline: With New Hardware, Square Begins Taxi Rollout
text: If you’ve ever been in a rush and in a taxi cab in New York, then you know how it feels to swipe your credit card at the end of the ride and wait for the receipt to pop out so you can sign it and hand it back to the driver. This procedure does not exactly take a New York minute. (Often, you even have to convince the driver to take your credit card.)

headline: Stanford Convicted by Jury in $7 Billion Ponzi Scheme
text: HOUSTON — A federal jury on Tuesday convicted R. Allen Stanford, a Texas financier, on 13 out of 14 counts of fraud in connection with a worldwide scheme that lasted more than two decades and involved more than $7 billion in investments.

headline: Judge Issues Congressional Redistricting Proposal
text: ALBANY – A federal magistrate, seeking to break a legislative stalemate over how to redraw the state’s Congressional districts to reflect the 2010 census, has released her own proposed map that could be imposed by the court.

headline: Dire Poverty Falls Despite Global Slump, Report Finds
text: WASHINGTON — A World Bank report shows a broad reduction in extreme poverty — and indicates that the global recession, contrary to economists’ expectations, did not increase poverty in the developing world.

headline: Top Six Episodes of ‘You Had to Be There’
text: Nikki Glaser and Sara Schaefer, the co-hosts of the free weekly comedy podcast “You Had to Be There,” whom I wrote about in Sunday’s magazine, are the best girlfriends you wish you had.

headline: Alabama Congressman, Under Investigation, Defends Himself in Ad
text: If voters in the Sixth Congressional District of Alabama did not know that their representative, Spencer Bachus, was the subject of an Congressional ethics inquiry, they do now, thanks to an attack ad approved by … Spencer Bachus.

headline: Singing and Drama Bring NBC a Prime-Time Win
text: NBC took full advantage of weakened competition Monday night to score an impressive prime-time performance.

headline: Reviving the Constitution
text: Ever since the George W. Bush administration decided to trash the constitution, the Geneva conventions and federal law, the thought of a government lawyer talking about justice in the age of terrorism has made me cringe. Although I hoped to lose this automatic reflex when Barack Obama took office, I’ve been distressed by many of his national security moves (like his administration’s persistent use of the state secrets privilege to deny justice to victims of officially sanctioned abduction and torture).

headline: The Principal's Role in Teacher Evaluations
text: A principal writes that he is concerned that a large portion of a teacher's evaluation is to be taken out of the hands of principals. "I am disturbed by this, not just because I think this will lead to inaccurate ratings and will pressure teachers in unproductive ways (it will), but also because I believe it speaks to a growing distrust of or disrespect for principals,'' Phil Weinberg says.

headline: Minnesota School District Reaches Agreement on Preventing Gay Bullying
text: After years of accusations that it had failed to stop antigay bullying and a spate of student suicides, Minnesota’s largest school district has agreed to sweeping changes designed to prevent harassment based on sexual orientation in a plan that federal officials call a national model.

headline: The Destructive ‘Too Much Homework’ Myth
text: Across the country, voices are raised in protest over the skyrocketing homework load inflicted on American students. Parents challenge teachers to re-evaluate homework policies. Anti-homework nonprofits circulate no-homework pledges. Writers and filmmakers make careers out of their anti-homework stance. The current generation of schoolchildren, they say, is enslaved by four to five hours of homework a night, toiling into the wee hours of the morning with no time for family or friends, driven to drugs, cheating and mental illness.

headline: Across the Primary States, Voters Weigh Principles and Pragmatism
text: MARIETTA, Ga. — Voters here in the suburbs north of Atlanta have plenty of affection for Newt Gingrich, who represented the region in the House of Representatives for two decades. But that does not necessarily mean they were all voting for him Tuesday in the Republican presidential primary.

headline: "Obama's Allies"
text: Representative Spencer Bachus released an ad attacking President Obama.

headline: Santana Pitches Well in First Appearance
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. – A brisk day of work became another baby step in the closely-watched return of Mets pitcher Johan Santana.

headline: Charged as Madam, and Defended as Entrepreneur and Pig Rescuer
text: According to Manhattan prosecutors, Anna Gristina is a well-connected madam who made millions of dollars running a brothel on the Upper East Side that catered to wealthy clients, where passers-by say fancy cars were seen idling past midnight. And when she was arrested last month, they said, she was with a Morgan Stanley banker whom she had just met about expanding her business.

headline: A New East Asian Import: Ozone Pollution
text: Ozone produced in East Asia can travel all the way to the western United States, where it directly contributes to ground-level concentrations of the pollutant, according to a new study in the Journal of Geophysical Research.

headline: Obama Challenges Republicans on Iran
text: President Obama challenged his Republican critics to make a case to the American people for a military strike against Iran’s nuclear facilities if they really believe that that is the right course to follow, throwing down an election-year challenge to the men who are vying to succeed him and who say that his Iran policy has been too weak.

headline: Infiniti Emerg-E Concept: Upstaging the Europeans?
text: GENEVA — One of the showstoppers here is Infiniti’s voluptuous Emerg-E hybrid sports car, a stunning design concept with DNA extracted from the Lotus Evora.

headline: Romney’s Advice on Selecting a College: Let Affordability Be Your Guide
text: This week in Opinion, David Firestone reflects on an exchange between Mitt Romney and a high school senior who was worried about paying for college. The student wanted to know what Mr. Romney would do about the rising costs of college, if elected president.

text: March 6, 2012 — President Obama discusses Iran at a White House press conference. (Video: NBC)

headline: Trading ‘Small Forward’ for ‘Scoring Rebounder’
text: Statistics in basketball are, by nature, a qualitative means to an evaluative end. They exist to inform how well or how poorly a certain task is performed with the coldest precision; those measurements of frequency, accuracy and efficiency may not always have the context necessary to hold a life of their own, but they serve an incredibly useful descriptive purpose and guide the analysis of the game on a fundamental level.

headline: Gingrich Predicts He’ll Carry Georgia ‘Decisively’
text: DULUTH, Ga. — On the day his home state of Georgia went to the polls, Newt Gingrich was confident enough to risk another round of “Newt Skywalker” jokes by scheduling a detour to the U.S. Space & Rocket Center in Huntsville, Ala.

headline: Random House to Reissue Updike Works to Mark His Birthday
text: Random House will mark John Updike’s birthday this month with the re-release of some of his most beloved works, including the “Rabbit” series, the publisher said on Tuesday. Mr. Updike, who was born on March 18, 1932, died in 2009 after a career that produced 60 books as well as essays, criticism and poetry.

headline: Pistons, Kuester Make Peace with Past
text: John Kuester’s two seasons coaching the Detroit Pistons were not happy or successful ones, ending with his firing last June. But it seems that time, and his new job as an assistant with the Lakers, has healed the deep rifts between Kuester and his former players.

headline: Meet Jonathan Foley, ‘Climate Pragmatist’
text: Late in 2010, Jonathan Foley, who directs the Institute of the Environment at the University of Minnesota, wrote “Becoming a Climate Pragmatist,” an essay published online then and the following spring in the institute’s magazine, Momentum. You can get a feel for his work and views in the video above in which he explains 2009 research on “planetary boundaries.” I also encourage you to read his 2011 paper, “Solutions for a Cultivated Planet.”

headline: Google Revamps Android Marketplace as Google Play
text: On Tuesday, Google unveiled Google Play, a one-stop-shop for all of Google’s software services and applications.

headline: Spain Struggles to Unite Regional Leaders on Cuts
text: MADRID — The Spanish government is struggling to discipline the regional governments that it blames for exacerbating the country’s fiscal problems as it faces pressure from the European Union to rein in its deficit.

text: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

headline: Voter Portraits: The 2012 Primaries
text: Throughout the 2012 primary season, The Times will be checking in with voters as they cast their ballots to see what is driving them to the polls.

headline: How Ohio Voted Last Time
text: The polling for Tuesday’s presidential primary in Ohio shows a close race. That was not the case in 2008, when 60 percent of Ohio Republicans favored Senator John McCain of Arizona, and 31 percent voted for former Gov. Mike Huckabee of Arkansas. By then, the race was essentially over. Indeed, Mr. Huckabee withdrew the next day.

headline: Needing Big Run Again, UConn Opens Title Defense With Listless Win
text: There was an eerie symmetry to the University of Connecticut’s arrival at Madison Square Garden on Tuesday for this year’s Big East tournament.

headline: Behind the Texas Pension’s Deal With Bridgewater
text: The Teacher Retirement System of Texas recently bought a stake in Bridgewater Associates, the world’s largest hedge fund. It’s a novel investment for a public pension, so DealBook dug deeper into the purchase.

headline: Keep an Eye Out for Dumplings

headline: In California, Open Season on Trophy Hunting
text: My grandfather, who died in 1929, more than two decades before I was born, was a confirmed trophy hunter, a founding member of the Boone & Crockett Club. A family album with 1880’s-era photographs of his hunts shows beautiful and empty landscapes near Jackson Hole, Wyo. It also shows a moose killed in the woods of Minnesota, along with the hunters themselves and their prized hunting dogs.

headline: McQueen: Changing the Perspective
text: Everybody seems to be talking about three-dimensional fashion, and the future. Tonight, at Salle Wagram, the same place where Alexander McQueen staged his dance-marathon collection, his successor, Sarah Burton, gave a magical rendering of both. The show started calmly with snowy white bell-shape coatdresses and laser-cut calf skin, resembling lace. All the models wore helmetlike white-blond wigs, their eyes shielded by visors. Then Ms. Burton turned up the volume, first with feathery and fur coats (like dandelion heads before the wind catches them), and gradually the shapes became monumental in scale. Ms. Burton’s presentation was beautiful, but the monumental aspect was riveting — how it affects your eye. Tomorrow, in the McQueen showroom, I’ll take a closer look.

headline: Critic’s Notebook: Lessons in Looking

headline: Tips From the Times Travel Show
text: This weekend was The New York Times Travel Show at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center, where exhibitors, some clad in native costumes, dole out brochures, advice and even free Thai noodles. And for the second straight year, I was a panelist. Also for the second straight year, I was faced with a difficult post-presentation choice: stay backstage to feast on the tray of free chocolate chip cookies put out for speakers, or roam the exhibition hall upstairs, grilling the travel industry representatives for money-saving tips that don’t appear in brochures.

headline: Asked & Answered | Paul Dano
text: On the afternoon before his New York City premiere of “Being Flynn,” directed by Paul Weitz and based on a profanely titled book by Nick Flynn, the actor Paul Dano waits at the window of an unassuming West Village luncheonette. In a black beanie, thin-rimmed spectacles and gray A.P.C. button-down shirt, which he purchased at half-off, Dano orders a green tea and chicken ratatouille sandwich. Fuel for a day of hustling ahead, he says. (Hustling, for Dano, is having to dine like this with reporters like me.) “It’s not really why I signed up to be an actor,” says the 27-year-old in a thoughtful but unapologetic manner. Dano is a smart guy with an interesting face. He’s not too cocky and he still blushes from time to time, but it’s clear he can hold his own against even the most intimidating actors (his former co-star Daniel Day Lewis, in their Oscar-winning, nightmare-inducing film, “There Will Be Blood,” comes to mind). It’s part of why Paul Weitz cast him opposite Robert De Niro in “Being Flynn,” in which Dano plays the troubled, 20-something Nick Flynn trying to cope with the reemergence of his narcissistic alcoholic father, Jonathan Flynn (De Niro). “At first, I immediately got over the fact that he’s Robert De Niro,” says the actor of his established co-star. “But there was this one day. …”

headline: Post-Chemo, New Hair, New Outlook
text: ONE Friday afternoon early this year, in a limestone town house on the Upper East Side, the topic of conversation was “cancer things, like lymphedema,” said Sherry Kreek, who is undergoing chemotherapy for breast cancer.

headline: Aliens of All Varieties, Wandering in the Desert
text: Hari Kunzru’s latest novel, “Gods Without Men,” reads like an unlikely mash-up of David Mitchell’s willfully complex 2004 novel, “Cloud Atlas,” and Steven Spielberg’s classic 1977 U.F.O. movie, “Close Encounters of the Third Kind,” seasoned with some borrowings from David Foster Wallace and Don DeLillo. The book is, at the same time, a wildly ambitious novel that spans centuries; a gripping thriller about a missing child; and a sort of sci-fi tale about pilgrims of various sorts being drawn to a mysterious rock formation in the desert in search of contact with aliens or some sort of higher meaning.

headline: A Taste of Home From Ethiopia
text: Comfort food was not meatloaf and mashed potatoes for Hiyaw Gebreyohannes. He is Ethiopian, from a family that immigrated to Djibouti and then Canada before settling in Michigan, and when he finally landed in New York, he hankered for his mom’s home-style collard greens, split peas, lentils and such. Not finding stores that sold them ready to eat, he has created a line of fresh, organic and vegan prepared foods called Taste of Ethiopia, which he makes at Hot Bread Kitchen, in La Marqueta in Harlem. They include tart, slightly bitter collards, called gomen, with some jalapeño heat; a golden turmeric-infused salad of cabbage and carrots, tekele gomen (shown above at right); split yellow peas, or kik (at center), intensified with turmeric and the sweet heat of ginger; and spicy red lentils, or misir (at left), at once mellow and rustic with cumin and berbere, the Ethiopian spice blend. He also makes spongy injera bread. Mr. Gebreyohannes is no novice when it comes to food: his mother owns Ethiopian restaurants in Michigan and he was involved in an African-fusion restaurant in Midtown.

headline: Deficits and Virtue
text: Ezra Klein and Mark Thoma both weigh in on the utterly bizarre claim that the large budget deficits we’re currently running are the result of a loss of self-control — as opposed to the result of the worst financial crisis since the 1930s, which has both savaged revenue and required a large rise in safety-net spending. Moreover, as Ezra points out, these deficits actually serve a useful purpose! Without the automatic stabilizers that led to rising deficits as the economy plunged, we might well be living in a full remake of the Great Depression.

headline: It’s Not Junk if I Made It
text: FOR Americans of a certain age, memory lane is paved in Ho Hos. This coiled snack cake was my gateway Hostess confection, tucked into my lunch with a wax-paper-wrapped peanut butter and grape jelly sandwich. I would eat them with some slightly warm milk, courtesy of the unsmiling lunch lady, whom I would run into later in life in an unsavory darts bar. Sometimes my Ho Hos were traded for Ding Dongs, the hockey-puck shaped treats that struck me as a lowbrow alternative to my working man’s tiny bûche de Noël.

headline: Nicolas Loves Barack
text: It’s Super Tuesday night in America — the biggest night of the Republican nominating season that will end in the selection of the party’s candidate to challenge Barack Obama in November, as pretty much everyone on the planet knows. As part of The New York Times’s live blogging of Super Tuesday night, our colleague Michael Shear over on The Caucus political blog has just put up a post about how Nicolas Sarkozy, France’s embattled president, facing the first round of his own re-election contest in just 48 days, has endorsed Mr. Obama for a second term. Given the Republicans’ deep animosity to most, if not all, things French — as we recently reminded the world on Rendezvous (oops) — as well as the penchant of Mitt Romney, the former Massachusetts governor and Republican front runner’s, to accuse Mr. Obama of wanting to impose European-style socialism on the United States, Michael says he is certain the White House will rush right out and start making the advertisements touting Sarko’s endorsement. To read his post and to follow all the news of Super Tuesday, including the state-by-state vote counts,  go to The Caucus’s live blog . (Search for “Merci Beaucoup?”)

headline: Looking Back | Stefano Pilati’s Eight Years at Yves Saint Laurent
text: Stefano Pilati showed his last women’s collection for Yves Saint Laurent in Paris yesterday, leaving the house after eight years as creative director. A look back at the designer’s oeuvre brings expertly tailored suits, directional proportions and many must-have women’s accessories — the big square-buckle belt (spring ’05), the strappy star stiletto (spring ’08) and the cage boot (spring ’09), among them — to the fore. For men, Pilati made clothes that were dressed up, grown-up, controlled. For women, he had more fun and introduced things like tulip skirts and tunics, leading fashion into silhouettes that shocked and then lasted. (Can one count the number of tulip skirts that were made and worn between 2005 and 2007? Did the tunics that Pilati showed with leggings in his fall 2006 collection not prompt Skinny Jean Mania?). Balancing severity with sexiness, always, Pilati exits YSL with a legacy of looks for the books, from fall ’06’s flower-pouf capelet to fall ’07’s A-line tuxedo mini and the most recent chain-mail racer dress. See our slide show >>

headline: Five Figures Circling, Backward, Across a Blueprint of the Whitney
text: The crucial word in “Devotion Study #1 — The American Dancer,” Sarah Michelson’s contribution to the 2012 Whitney Biennial, is “study.” Like much of Ms. Michelson’s work, this one is relentless, formally severe, unafraid to push repetition to extreme ends. But her focus here is even narrower, zoomed in on a detail from last year’s acclaimed, endurance-testing work “Devotion.” For almost 90 minutes, while a metronome ticks, dancers walk backward in circles.

headline: Dreamers’ Songs Adrift, Shifting Through Multiple Dimensions
text: In an onstage interview at her Making Music concert at Zankel Hall on Monday evening, the Finnish composer Kaija Saariaho explained her approach to “From the Grammar of Dreams,” a 2007 setting of Sylvia Plath texts, by making a fascinating distinction between wakefulness and dreaming. When you are awake, she told Jeremy Geffen, the moderator, you speak in sentences that move sequentially through time. But when you dream, your speech can be four-dimensional.

headline: Saints’ Coach and G.M. Accept Responsibility on Bounties
text: New Orleans Saints General Manager Mickey Loomis and Coach Sean Payton finally acknowledged on Tuesday the N.F.L.’s investigation into the Saints’  bounty system, which paid players to injure opponents. The acknowledgment came four days after the league said Loomis and Payton were aware of the system and did nothing to stop it even, in Loomis’s case, after the owner Tom Benson told him to put a stop to it.

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | Alexander McQueen
text: “I’ve always done something outrageous,” explained the manicurist extraordinaire Marian Newman backstage at Alexander McQueen. For at least the past five collections, she said she’d veered away from a natural nail. This season called for something different. “A beautiful, ethereal woman” is how she described the girls with fingernails painted soft white, toenails sheer pink or beige. “A pure girl, almost like a statue,” was how Peter Philips imagined the models at McQueen. He used Chanel’s Mat Lumiere foundation on most of the girls as the primary makeup with a little brow pencil and Rouge Coco Shine lip balm. Eyelashes were curled, but only, Philips admitted, for the purpose of backstage photography, as everyone was to wear futuristic, mirrored glasses/visors, which clipped around the sides of the head. Guido Palau had the difficult task of sourcing 36 wigs in a platinum, almost yellow blond, with four in gray to go with the pink looks in particular. The wigs were fitted with identical hairlines and cuts to “take the personality away,” according to Palau. He was channeling manga racer characters with the slicked-back androgynous look he created with a heavy dose of Redken Forceful 23 Hair Spray. The idea was to contrast the beautiful  super-romantic clothes with a futuristic hairstyle.

headline: Despite Kremlin’s Signals, U.S. Ties Remain Strained After Russian Election
text: MOSCOW — Now that Russia’s presidential campaign is over, the Kremlin signaled on Tuesday that it was prepared for its relationship with Washington to get back to normal, potentially including swift cooperation on containing Iran’s nuclear program amid the prospect of a military strike by Israel.

headline: Pay Only for Drugs That Help You
text: IT’S hard not to be outraged by the fact that the United States spends $2.6 trillion per year on health care, far more than any other country, and has no better medical outcomes to show for it. Everyone agrees that we need to cut waste from the system. And it’s understandable that, with reports of individuals taking $100,000 cancer drugs only to prolong survival by a few months, the high cost of drugs is one of the first targets.

headline: New Orleans Group Promotes Hurricane Awareness
text: NEW ORLEANS — For most city officials here, making plans to evacuate tens of thousands of residents from the wrath of a hurricane brings to mind a tangle of logistics: bus routes, out-of-state shelters, fresh water supplies, public safety. But for one young transplant named Robert X. Fogarty, evacuation means 12-foot-tall sculptures placed strategically around town.

headline: McIlroy, the World’s No. 1 Golfer, Takes a Playful Shot at Tennis
text: DORAL, Fla. — No shot Sunday at the Honda Classic — not even his 8-foot birdie putt at No. 13 with the fans’ roar from Tiger Woods’s birdie-eagle finish ringing in his ears — was as nerve-racking for Rory McIlroy as the ones he hit with a tennis racket Monday night during a rally with Maria Sharapova in front of 18,000 fans at Madison Square Garden.

headline: Gingrich Takes Georgia, Keeping Campaign Alive With a Southern Strategy

Polling then suggested that he might achieve no better than a squeaker victory in his home state, an embarrassment that could have led him to withdraw.

headline: AARP Study Says Price of Popular Drugs Rose 26%
text: The prices of drugs used most widely by older Americans rose by nearly 26 percent from 2005 to 2009 — nearly twice the rate of inflation — according to a report issued Tuesday by AARP.

headline: The Wrong Approach to Discipline

The agency, which is negotiating policies with some of these districts, needs to push for procedures that keep children in school.

headline: Manning Reaches End of the Line With the Colts

headline: Police Leader’s Evolving Efforts to Defend Surveillance

But the meeting was already drawing criticism, underscoring how precarious the commissioner’s scattershot style of aggressively defending his department’s counterterrorism efforts could be.

headline: Bruno Ricciotti
text: Mr. Ricciotti, 39, is the chief executive and a principal of Bond New York, an independent residential real estate brokerage. The company is involved in both rentals and sales, and represents new developments like the Ellison condominium in Harlem.

text: Regardless of the financial condition of their state, voters in Tuesday’s Republican primaries considered the economy the top issue influencing their choice.

headline: The Republican Primary Voters’ Religious Test
text: One detail in tonight’s exit polls, which are run by the television networks and The Associated Press, caught my attention. More than six in 10 primary voters in Ohio, Tennessee and Georgia said it’s important to share a candidate’s religious beliefs. In Tennessee alone, three-quarters took that position. So much for not having a religious test to get into office!

headline: Eastern Libya Demands a Measure of Autonomy in a Loose National Federation

headline: Florida Higher Education May Face Big Budget Cuts

headline: Lawmaker’s Death May Bring Battle for Successor

headline: College Hunt Starts Earlier at New Breed of Schools

Similarly, Léman Manhattan, a for-profit school downtown, starts the formal college search process with its freshmen; in addition, seventh- and eighth-grade students can visit campuses on a three-day trip in the spring.

headline: With Eyes Open Wide, Teenager Gets a Look at the Major Leaguers

headline: Rutgers Student Saw Twitter Posts by Roommate About Spying
text: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J. — As Dharun Ravi posted Twitter feeds about using a webcam to see his Rutgers University roommate in a sexual encounter with another man, one of those reading intently was the roommate himself, Tyler Clementi, an investigator testified on Tuesday.

headline: Romney Appears the Ohio Winner; Santorum Strong

headline: In First Game, Fitter Hughes Finds Life in Fastball

headline: Robert B. Sherman, a Songwriter for Disney and Others, Dies at 86

Sherman, half of the fraternal songwriting team that wrote the ubiquitous paean to togetherness, “It’s a Small World (After All)”, and that in films like “Mary Poppins” and “Chitty Chitty Bang Bang” etched dozens of tunes and volumes of lyrics into the permanent memories of generations of children and their parents, died Tuesday in London. He was 86.

headline: Penn Loses, Securing Title and Bid for Harvard

The two have combined for 51 men’s basketball championships in a league known as the Ancient Eight, and so it has not been unusual for this final matchup in downtown Philadelphia or suburban New Jersey to settle the league title and an automatic bid to the N.C.A.A. tournament.

headline: An Update on New York Redistricting

headline: Do Electronic Medical Records Save Money?
text: Experts have long argued that computerized patient records will save the health system money by helping doctors reduce the number of redundant or inappropriate tests they order. headline: America Is Stealing the World’s Doctors
text: It was not an unusual death. Kunj Desai, a young doctor in training at University Teaching Hospital in Lusaka, Zambia, had seen many that were not so different and were equally needless. Still, this was the one that altered all his plans. “A guy came in, and he had a stab wound,” Desai recalled, “and his intestines got injured.” The operation was delayed, and the wound became infected. “Whatever he was eating would come out of his belly,” Desai said. A carefully managed diet would have helped the man heal, but there were no dietitians at the hospital nor any IV drips of liquid nutrients with which to feed him. “He withered away to probably about 100 pounds when he died.”

headline: Finding Sanctuary in Japan
text: When the earthquake and tsunami hit Japan last year, all but two of the 65 homes in Aramachi, a small community in Rikuzentakata, were destroyed. Sixteen residents died. That evening, 50 survivors crowded into a small building at the Buddhist temple complex that had been at the heart of this community of farmers for centuries. Cold, wet and scared, they spent the night praying and mourning.

How would you explain basic scientific concepts to a child?

headline: Fantasy Focus: The Old and the Boring
text: Baseball, like many other endeavors in life, goes through cycles. Whether it’s a juiced ball (or juiced body part) era, or a high-mound era, the only constant in the game is change. At one point there was an inefficiency in the game in which only a handful of teams were doing advanced statistical analysis (which subsequently influenced front office decisions, rather than being tossed to the side). Since the Athletics’ run of success and the publication of “Moneyball” – perhaps even before its publication – everybody has a phalanx of number-crunchers, and many of them have risen to the level of general managers, or at least are sympathetic to those types.

headline: Maxell’s AirStash Outsources Your Data

Using a related iPhone or iPad app, you can view the files stored on the AirStash — music, documents, photos, and movies — essentially adding up to 32GB of extra storage to your phone or tablet.

headline: Tip of the Week: Bing Without the Bling
text: Like Microsoft’s Bing search engine, but find the large photo background distracting? If you would prefer to just focus on search task at hand, go to the URL box in your browser, type in the address http://www.bing.com/?rb=0 and hit the Enter key. A plain gray background should appear behind the Bing search box. If you like the look of Bing without bling, bookmark this version of the site for future use.

headline: 6 British Soldiers Are Killed in Afghanistan
text: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan — British forces suffered their deadliest attack in six years when an armored vehicle struck an explosive device in southern Afghanistan, killing six soldiers, the British government announced on Wednesday.

headline: What Happened to the Girls in Le Roy
text: Before the media vans took over Main Street, before the environmental testers came to dig at the soil, before the doctor came to take blood, before strangers started knocking on doors and asking question after question, Katie Krautwurst, a high-school cheerleader from Le Roy, N.Y., woke up from a nap. Instantly, she knew something was wrong. Her chin was jutting forward uncontrollably and her face was contracting into spasms. She was still twitching a few weeks later when her best friend, Thera Sanchez, captain of one of the school’s cheerleading squads, awoke from a nap stuttering and then later started twitching, her arms flailing and head jerking. Two weeks after that, Lydia Parker, also a senior, erupted in tics and arm swings and hums. Then word got around that Chelsey Dumars, another cheerleader, who recently moved to town, was making the same strange noises, the same strange movements, leaving school early on the days she could make it to class at all. The numbers grew — 12, then 16, then 18, in a school of 600 — and as they swelled, the ranks of the sufferers came to include a wider swath of the Le Roy high-school hierarchy: girls who weren’t cheerleaders, girls who kept to themselves and had studs in their lips. There was even one boy and an older woman, age 36. Parents wept as their daughters stuttered at the dinner table. Teachers shut their classroom doors when they heard a din of outbursts, one cry triggering another, sending the increasingly familiar sounds ricocheting through the halls. Within a few months, as the camera crews continued to descend, the community barely seemed to recognize itself. One expert after another arrived to pontificate about what was wrong in Le Roy, a town of 7,500 in Western New York that had long prided itself on the things it got right. The kids here were wholesome and happy, their parents insisted — “cheerleaders and honor students,” as one father said — products of a place that, while not perfect, was made up more of what was good about small-town America than what was bad. Now, though, the girls’ writhing and stuttering suggested something troubling, either arising from within the community or being perpetrated on it, a mystery that proved irresistible for onlookers, whose attention would soon become part of the story itself.

headline: Austerity Chic
text: If the British economy is flagging, it’s no worse than it was in 1948, when London’s last Summer Olympics earned the nickname the “Austerity Games” — an irony that hasn’t gone unnoticed. Luckily the city’s museums are stepping in to burnish its brand: two exhibitions focused on postwar British design are making the case that the country’s economic tribulations have always coincided with periods of creative ascendancy. “British Design 1948 to 2012,” opening March 31 at the Victoria and Albert Museum, charts artistic upticks after the war, during the oil crisis in the ’70s and after the recession in the ’80s, when the “creative salvage” movement spurred the careers of designers like Tom Dixon. “Designing Women,” at the Fashion and Textile Museum, which opened March 16, focuses on the midcentury modern textile designs of Lucienne Day, Jacqueline Groag and Marian Mahler, and plays up a heroic moment of British ingenuity: three women inspired by the Bauhaus and the Secessionists rejected the chintzes and florals of the ’30s and ’40s and helped democratize modernism.

headline: My Three Problems This Week
text: Every now and then, I like to toss out some nagging problems that I don’t have answers for to see if anyone has suggestions to offer (here are three similar posts from August 2010, March 2011 and May 2011). So without further ado, here are some new problems:

headline: Image of the Day: March 7
text: Devotees dressed as Lord Krishna, play with colors at a temple in Amritsar, Punjab.

headline: A Jail Term for Jaguar Smugglers
text: On Monday, I watched an agent from the Fish and Wildlife Service haul a clear trash bag stuffed with what looked like a large swath of spotted material into a Miami courtroom. Inside was a pair of smuggled jaguar skins.

headline: Despite Sluggish Activity, Deal Makers Optimistic
text: For deal makers, 2012 has been a drag so far. But ever an optimistic lot, it appears that more than a few of them believe an upturn is around the corner.

headline: Now Streaming | Miu Miu Fall 2012 Women’s Collection

headline: The Top Man at ‘Mad Men’ Isn’t Mad Anymore

headline: The ‘Mad Men’ Season That Almost Wasn’t: An Interview With Matthew Weiner, Part 1
text: Get ready to disconnect your rotary telephone, pour yourself a cocktail or 10 and tell your secretary-turned-fiancée you won’t be receiving any visitors: in two weeks, “Mad Men” returns for its fifth season on AMC after a 17-month absence. When we last saw the men and women of the struggling Sterling Cooper Draper Pryce agency in a new installment of the show – in October 2010 – the year was 1965 and Don Draper (played by Jon Hamm) had made a seemingly out-of-nowhere offer of marriage to his assistant and nanny, Megan (Jessica Paré); Betty (January Jones) was at a crossroads; Peggy (Elisabeth Moss) was in ascendance; Joan (Christina Hendricks) was pregnant with a child that may have been fathered by Roger (John Slattery); Lane (Jared Harris) was British; and Pete (Vincent Kartheiser) was a win-at-all-costs jerk.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: A Mirror Can Be a Dangerous Tool for Some C.E.O.’s  |  We’ve recently seen some illustrations in the takeover world of the dark side of the chief executive, Steven M. Davidoff writes in the Deal Professor column. Being powerful and visionary, or at least thinking one is, can lead a corporate chieftain to great heights, but also to extreme narcissism. And the victims are often shareholders.

headline: For Moose, an Easy Winter Turns Hard
text: John Vucetich, a wildlife ecologist from Michigan Technological University, leads the wolf-moose Winter Study at Isle Royale National Park.

headline: The City and the Union Talk Teacher Evaluations, Again
text: The two sides met on Tuesday, hours after the union asked the state’s labor review board to intervene. There was no progress and Chancellor Dennis M. Walcott criticized union leader Michael Mulgrew for not attending.

headline: Israeli Officials Voice Skepticism of Iran’s Nuclear Intentions
text: JERUSALEM — A day after global powers said they would resume nuclear talks with Iran, Israeli officials expressed skepticism on Wednesday of Tehran’s intentions and said it was necessary to maintain a credible military option if the talks were to have any chance of success.

headline: Yves Saint Laurent Gets a New Designer
text: Yves Saint Laurent and its parent company, PPR, announced Wednesday morning that Hedi Slimane had been named creative director, replacing Stefano Pilati.

headline: A Predictable Super Tuesday
text: Super Tuesday was a long and bumpy night full of highlights and low lights for each candidate that ended in an underwhelming but basically successful outcome for Mitt Romney. In other words, it was like pretty much everything else in the Republican primaries to date.

headline: Delphi C.E.O. Under a Microscope
text: It’s not a good time to be a chief executive in a Delaware court.

headline: Model-Morphosis | Margaret Qualley at Chanel
text: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of the Fall 2012 Fashion Week in Paris. Here, the model Margaret Qualley of IMG before (left) and after (right) transforms, with makeup by Peter Philips and hair by Sam McKnight.

headline: Daily Report: Hackers Can’t Trust Their Own
text: From a base of operations in his late grandmother’s sixth-floor apartment in a public housing project on the Lower East Side of Manhattan, Hector Xavier Monsegur, known as Sabu on Twitter, taunted law enforcement and urged fellow hackers to attack them, reports Somini Sengupta in The New York Times.

headline: Wednesday Reading: Bargain Rooms on Martha’s Vineyard and More Travel Tips
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: Europe’s Two Depressions
text: Barry Eichengreen and Kevin O’Rourke have a followup on their hugely influential article on quantitative comparisons of the Great Depression and the Great Recession. This time they point out that the slump wasn’t nearly as bad this time, and recovery began much sooner — but that the pace of recovery has clearly slowed.

headline: Leading Off: N.F.L., Never Figure on Loyalty
text: Let’s just take a few moments to appreciate what will transpire today in Indianapolis when the Colts cut Peyton Manning, which manages to be staggering despite being altogether unsurprising. Because we all knew it would happen. The desperation by the Colts’ owner, Jim Irsay,  to make this look like something other than a heartless business move told us that. And we have long since learned that loyalty and $5 will buy you a latte at Starbucks and exactly nothing in professional sports. Even Wayne Gretzky was traded, as was Joe Montana. If Abraham Lincoln had been an athlete, someone would have deep-sixed him as soon as his hook shot had lost its bite.

headline: Morning Buzz, March 7: A Lottery Lawsuit
text: Good morning. It will be sunny and clear today, with highs reaching the low 60s.

headline: Finally, Spain
text: I’ve always viewed Spain, not Greece, as the quintessential euro crisis country. With Rajoy’s government balking — rightly — at further austerity, the focus is now where it arguably should have been all along.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Details: Five things you probably don’t want to say or do at a decent cocktail bar. — Jeff Gordinier

text: Paris

headline: Spike in Food Prices Projected by 2013
text: In 2008 and in 2011, the world was rocked by riots and by revolutions coinciding with spikes in food prices. Now researchers are projecting that by 2013, food prices will soar to unparalleled heights, causing widespread hunger in the most vulnerable populations and social unrest, with an enormous potential for loss of human life.

headline: Picking Peyton Manning’s Next Stop
text: Peyton Manning’s best revenge would be winning the Super Bowl next season.

headline: Lena Dunham Brings a ‘Girls’ Touch to Brooklyn Academy Film Series
text: Before she was the creator and star of the coming HBO comedy “Girls” or the one-woman film-making bandwagon behind “Tiny Furniture,” Lena Dunham watched a lot of movies. They formed her authorial voice and directorial sensibility, but more to the point, they gave her plenty of options for a weeklong series she has organized in April at BAMcinématek, the film program of the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

headline: Followers of a TV Host Can Follow His Footsteps
text: Fans of the travel show host and writer Anthony Bourdain can now follow in his footsteps using a new application for iPad, iPhone and iTouch. The Travel Channel Layover Guide With Anthony Bourdain, being introduced this month, features his picks for restaurants, bars and attractions in the 10 cities he covered in the first season of his television show “The Layover” and content from his first show, “Anthony Bourdain: No Reservations.”

headline: Fear and Loathing at Murdoch’s Sun
text: LONDON — The news coming out of a British outpost of Rupert Murdoch’s international media empire seems to go from bad to worse. This week, two senior journalists at his top-selling Sun newspaper apparently attempted suicide amid the mounting pressures of a police investigation.

headline: Super Tuesday Victories for Romney, but Questions, Too
text: 1:04 p.m. | Updated Mitt Romney’s campaign on Wednesday prepared to portray his razor-thin victory in Ohio as another step toward an inevitable claim on the Republican presidential nomination in spite of a muscular challenge by his chief rival, Rick Santorum in Ohio.

headline: ‘Attractive Women’ With Limited Power
text: BEIJING — Mao Zedong once famously declared that “Women hold up half the sky”. But maybe that should be “Women hold up one-fifth of the sky”, with female representation in China’s legislature, the National People’s Congress, stuck at just over 20 percent for decades.

headline: Has Political Discourse Hit Rock Bottom?
text: They say hitting bottom is prelude to a rebound, at least for drug addicts, housing prices and bungee jumpers. Does that apply, I wonder, to political discourse?

headline: Miu Miu: Fall 2012 RTW
text: Paris

headline: Including More in All-Inclusives
text: MENTION the words “all-inclusive resort” and thoughts of bad buffets, watered-down drinks and wristband-wearing guests doing the conga may come to mind. But all-inclusive resorts, which have traditionally included basic accommodations and meals, are reinventing themselves with chic rooms, sophisticated restaurants, butlers and activities all wrapped into one price.

headline: Election Puts Pressure on Myanmar Dissident
text: WAH THI KA, Myanmar — Wah Thi Ka is a dust-choked village without electricity or running water, where no one has a laptop, where no one uses Facebook or e-mail and where sick residents sometimes die on their way to the nearest hospital because it is too far down a deeply rutted dirt road.

headline: American Express Incentives to Push Deals on Twitter
text: There’s a new way for American Express cardholders to earn rewards — but you have to be willing to Tweet for these savings.

headline: Facebook Chat With Andrew Rosenthal at 11 a.m.
text: Today at 11 a.m. EST, I’m hosting an hour-long Facebook conversation about the presidential campaign. The chat will take place on my Facebook page: http://www.facebook.com/AndrewMRosenthal

headline: Updates From Apple’s Unveiling of the New iPad
text: Apple on Wednesday unveiled a new version of the iPad with a higher-resolution screen and 4G capability, along with an update to its Apple TV box. It was the second major product presentation for Tim Cook, Apple’s chief executive; in October he led the introduction of the iPhone 4S.

headline: A Pioneering Cocktail Conference Turns 10
text: Two weeks ago, Arizona celebrated its first Arizona Cocktail Week. In January came the inaugural San Antonio Cocktail Conference. Last October, Oregon’s largest city played host to the second annual Portland Cocktail Week.

headline: Lamborghini Aventador J: For $2.75 Million, a One-Off Aural Assault
text: GENEVA — The Lamborghini Aventador J, or Jota after the Spanish pronunciation of the letter, is not the roadster version of the Aventador coupe. It is not meant to herald a new Lamborghini model line.

headline: For Veterans With Post-Traumatic Stress, Pain Killers Carry Risks
text: Veterans with post-traumatic stress disorder are more likely to be prescribed opioid pain killers than other veterans with pain problems and more likely to use the opioids in risky ways, according to a study published Wednesday by the Department of Veterans Affairs.

headline: Runway in Review
text: Alexander McQueenDesigner: Sarah BurtonDate and Location: Tuesday, Mar. 6, Salle Wagram, 39-41 avenue de WagramPhotos: slide show

headline: Raven-Symoné Headed to ‘Sister Act’
text: The former child star Raven-Symoné (“The Cosby Show”) will take over the lead role of disco singer Deloris Van Cartier in the Broadway musical “Sister Act” on March 27, the show’s producers announced on Wednesday. Raven, as she is known, will replace Patina Miller, who was nominated for a Tony Award last year for her performance, and who will depart the musical on March 18.

headline: The Joys of Twins
text: We are not supposed to judge a book by its cover. But in this case, let’s do just that. The cover of the new poetry collection “Take Two!,” with its twin toddlers bending upside down, polka-dotted tushies in the air, is quite possibly the cutest one to have crossed my desk in the run-up to spring.

headline: WWS594E, Economics of the Welfare State: Class 5
text: Notes (pdf).

headline: Why I Won’t Play Holi This Year
text: The Hindu festival of Holi, which celebrates the arrival of spring in India, involves dabbing of powdered color or gulaal on family members and friends.

headline: Players and Peers Laud the Coach Behind the Saints’ Bounties
text: The Gregg Williams who has become the face and focus of the Saints’ bounty scandal is the one so aggressive, with such boundless bravado, that he greeted his New Orleans players for the first time in 2009 with a telling command to knock out their opponents, mixing in a vulgarity for good measure.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: A Hacker Arrest and a ‘Terra’ Flop
text: A Times book critic, Dwight Garner, looks at the new crop of “Kindle Singles” – experiments in long-form journalism that don’t quite make book length. Many left him cold: magazine articles left unedited with a lot of filler thrown in. “But several — like John Hooper’s reportage on the Costa Concordia disaster, Jane Hirshfield on haiku and Jonathan Mahler on Joe Paterno — are so good they awaken you to the promise of what feels almost like a new genre: long enough for genuine complexity, short enough that you don’t need journalistic starches and fillers.”

headline: Audi Shows 2013 A3, a Redesign Nearly 10 Years in the Making
text: GENEVA — It has been been known for some time that Audi was prepping a redesign of its sporty, if dated, little A3. A sedan concept unveiled here last year confirmed as much. And details were leaked on the Internet some weeks ago.

text: Greek troubles hang over markets; Nicole Perlroth on the arrest of LulzSec computer hackers; and Eduardo Porter discusses the role of activism in improving global labor conditions.

headline: On Our Radar: Dredging the Savannah River
text: Conservation groups ask the South Carolina Supreme Court to nullify actions by a state board approving the deepening of the Savannah River. The project pits environmentalists and the state assembly against Gov. Nikki Haley, who supports the project. Beyond environmental considerations, South Carolina lawmakers say the dredging effort would give Savannah a competitive advantage over Charleston by allowing larger container ships to reach the Georgia port. [The Post and Courier]

headline: Journalist in India Is Arrested in Bombing Against Israeli
text: NEW DELHI — An Indian journalist has been arrested as part of an investigation into the bombing last month of a van carrying the wife of an Israeli diplomat, an attack for which Israeli officials have  blamed Iran.

headline: Hey, Sergio, What’s With the Beard?
text: GENEVA — It took a reporter from Poland to ask the question that was on everybody’s mind at the press conference conducted at the Geneva auto show Tuesday by Sergio Marchionne, the chief executive of Chrysler and Fiat.

headline: Drudge Shows His Hand on Romney
text: If there were any lingering doubts about who Matt Drudge wants to win the Republican nomination, his Web site’s homepage should dispel them.

headline: Can UConn Make Another Run?
text: If Jeremy Lamb could go back a day, my guess is that he would have taken it a little bit easier on himself, not that it would have made much of a difference anyway. On Tuesday afternoon, against DePaul, he scored 25 points without breaking much of a sweat, and he did it all in a just-out-of-the-box pair of shoes that — in his words — were killing him.

text: The Girl

headline: ‘Are You There God? It’s Me, Margaret’ and Other Judy Blume Favorites to Be Released as E-Books
text: Judy Blume books, those dog-eared paperbacks that have taught children and teenagers about the mysterious parts of growing up for more than four decades, will be released in e-book format, her publisher said on Wednesday.

headline: How Different Groups Voted in Republican Primaries
text: How Different Groups Voted in Republican Primaries

headline: For Teenage Girls, Facebook Means Always Being Camera-Ready
text: It used to be that the only people concerned about getting caught in grungy sweat pants, sans makeup, were starlets stalked by the paparazzi. But in today’s hyper-public Internet age, young teenagers are relentlessly living their lives camera-ready — and it’s not a pretty picture.

headline: McIlroy the Golfer Takes a Shot at Tennis
text: DORAL, Fla. — No shot Sunday at the Honda Classic — not even his 8-foot birdie putt at No. 13 with the fans’ roar from Tiger Woods’s birdie-eagle finish ringing in his ears — was as nerve-racking for Rory McIlroy as the ones he hit with a tennis racket Monday night during a rally with Maria Sharapova in front of 18,000 fans at Madison Square Garden. McIlroy, 22, was in the audience to watch the exhibition between Sharapova, the former No. 1 player, and his girlfriend, Caroline Wozniacki, who began the year ranked No. 1 and is now No. 4. Toward the end of the match, which Sharapova won, 6-3, 6-4, Wozniacki summoned McIlroy from the stands and handed him her racket. More details can be found at the On Par blog.

headline: Romney Raises $11.5 Million in February
text: Mitt Romney raised $11.5 million during February, a campaign spokeswoman said on Wednesday, his second-best month of fund-raising so far during the campaign.

headline: Caffé Vita, a Seattle Staple, Squeezes Into Manhattan
text: Caffé Vita, a pioneer of Seattle’s independent coffee scene, will open a coffee shop and roaster on the Lower East Side on Monday. The store is tiny by the standards of Caffé Vita — the narrow storefront has room for only a counter and a drink rail — but there’s space enough for a small century-old Gothot roaster in back.

headline: Canadian Official Defends Oil Sands
text: Alison M. Redford, the premier of Alberta, said Wednesday that the debate over Canada’s oil sands development and the construction of the Keystone XL pipeline was tainted by a campaign of “misleading and false information” from opponents.

headline: Britain Rejects Plan to Split Up R.B.S.

headline: Huckabee, Santorum and the Republican Future
text: My post-Super Tuesday Campaign Stops column considers the success that Rick Santorum has enjoyed reconstituting Mike Huckabee’s 2008 coalition, and what it might portend for the future of the Republican Party:

headline: U.S. Defense Officials Say Obama Reviewing Military Options in Syria
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama has asked the Pentagon for military options on Syria, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Gen. Martin E. Dempsey, told the Senate on Wednesday. But both General Dempsey and Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta said the administration still believed that diplomatic and economic pressure was the best solution for protecting Syrians from the Assad regime.

headline: IDC Sizes Up the Big Data Market
text: IDC published a report on Wednesday that forecasts the Big Data market will be, well, big.

headline: Broker With Ties to Accused Brothel Operator Is Identified
text: The Morgan Stanley broker who was with Anna Gristina, the woman accused of running a brothel on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, when she was arrested has been identified as David Spencer Walker.

headline: Last Chance to Vote in Pulp Fiction Contest
text: Attention guys and dolls. We are closing the voting in our Pulp Fiction contest at 4:30 p.m. today, Wednesday, March 7, 2012. Any votes received after that time will not be tallied. Shortly after that, we will announce the winner.

headline: Russian Riot Grrrls Jailed for ‘Punk Prayer’
text: The Russian protest leader Aleksei Navalny ridiculed the authorities on Wednesday for jailing two young mothers suspected of belonging to a feminist punk band inspired by the American riot grrrl movement.

headline: Love and Tears at Peyton Manning News Conference
text: If you could picture the polar opposite of the acrimony of Brett Favre’s departure from Green Bay, that’s what we just saw in a news conference in Indianapolis.

text: Greek troubles hang over the markets, Nicole Perlroth on the arrest of LulzSec computer hackers, and Eduardo Porter discusses the role of activism in improving global labor conditions.

headline: Among Online Entrepreneurs, Subscriptions Are All the Rage
text: After Alex Zhardanovsky sold his online ad company, AzoogleAds, he went looking for a new business concept. His search took him from skin care to weight-loss products to prize giveaways. The answer that finally came to him — pet food — was inspired by sheer inconvenience. “If you’re a dog owner like I am, you go out and buy food every three or four weeks,” Mr. Zhardanovsky said. “But you usually don’t realize you need it until you’re out.”

headline: Bloomberg Praises a Charter-to-Charter Turnaround
text: At a benefit, the mayor praised Democracy Prep, the first charter management organization to take on the task of restructuring a failing charter school. It has taken over Harlem Day and replaced it with the Harlem Prep Charter School.

headline: A Private Service for Davy Jones
text: Plans for a public memorial service for Davy Jones, the singer with the Monkees who died of a heart attack last week, are still up in the air.

headline: In Alabama, 2nd Corruption Trial Ends in Acquittals
text: For the second time, federal prosecutors in Alabama have failed to convince a jury that politicians, lobbyists and a casino owner committed crimes in their failed attempt to get the State Legislature to legalize some forms of gambling.

headline: TimesCast | March 7, 2012
text: The race for the Republican nomination is far from over | A new season of "Mad Men" begins on March 25 after a 17-month hiatus.

headline: Vain Glorious | Amber Wave
text: Amber is a mysterious ingredient. While the color can instantly be imagined, the scent of the warm, resinous base that relates fragrances like Valentina by Valentino and Rochas Absolut, eludes the senses. What exactly does amber smell like? These three new fragrances encapsulate the bittersweet aroma of the popular note.

headline: It’s Moderately Super Wednesday!
text: Gail Collins: David, you were right. You predicted that the Republican presidential race was going to drag on into the summer, like one of those reality TV shows about hoarders that simultaneously appall and mesmerize onlookers.

headline: Have You Tried Selling With a Subscription Model?
text: There’s nothing new about selling products on a subscription basis. But, in a story just published in The Times, Darren Dahl writes that companies are finding creative ways to use the Internet to sell products that have not traditionally been sold by subscription.

headline: After an Emotional Farewell, Manning and the Colts Look to Move On
text: By just after 3 p.m. Wednesday, the paperwork was done and the surreal move had been made. “Indianapolis Colts release quarterback Peyton Manning,” the announcement read, and a decision that seemed unimaginable little more than three months ago was final.

headline: Video Offers Glimpse of Obama at Harvard
text: A video has surfaced of a young Barack Obama — back when he was president of the Harvard Law Review, not the president of the United States. The footage shows him speaking on behalf of Derrick Bell, the first tenured African-American professor of law at Harvard University, who was in the middle of a protest for diversity. Buzzfeed licensed the video, which it says came from a Massachusetts television station.

headline: Auto Overcapacity Gives Leaders Another Issue to Ponder
text: GENEVA — While Europe has been preoccupied with the euro crisis, another storm has been gathering that could also take a grievous toll on jobs and growth.

headline: Showdown in the Senate
text: We encourage viewers to use the “full screen” button — above, at right.

headline: Masha Gessen Talks About the Reign of Vladimir Putin
text: The journalist Masha Gessen is a citizen of both Russia — where she was born and now lives, in Moscow — and the United States. Her newest book, “The Man Without a Face: The Unlikely Rise of Vladimir Putin,” is a scathing account of Mr. Putin’s reign. Shortly after after the Russian elections on March 4, in which Mr. Putin won a contentious six-year term, Ms. Gessen discussed on e-mail his rise to power, the use and abuse of that power and the chances for change. Below are excerpts of the conversation.

headline: Super Tuesday Facebook Chat
text: Today at 11 a.m. I hosted an hour-long chat with readers on Facebook. I really enjoyed the experience and want to thank everyone who asked a question, as well as those who just followed along.

headline: ‘Too Many Foreigners’ in France, Sarkozy Says
text: President Nicolas Sarkozy, facing a tough re-election fight this year, declared on Tuesday night that there were “too many foreigners” in France and that he would move to limit their numbers.

headline: Photo Replay: March 7
text: Sports photos of the day from around the world, from basketball at Madison Square Garden to badminton in England.

headline: Perk Street Does Away With Its 2 Percent Debit Card Rebate
text: Another 2 percent rebate in the card business has bitten the dust.

headline: A Salute to France and World Premieres for New York City Ballet Gala
text: The New York City Ballet’s spring benefit will have more than its usual share of French glamour and celebrity chic. The gala, to be held on May 10, will have a French theme, the company announced on Wednesday, and will feature the world premieres of two ballets. Peter Martins, the company’s ballet master in chief, will choreograph a work to a score by the French composer Marc-André Dalbavie, and the French choreographer and former principal dancer Benjamin Millepied will stage the debut of  a piece set to a commission by the young contemporary classical composer Nico Muhly, their fourth collaboration.

headline: Clip: Gerhard Richter Painting
text: A scene from the documentary that looks at the artist Gerhard Richter and his creative process.

headline: For Maine Senate Seat, Democrats Take a Chance
text: Eager to preserve their majority in the Senate, Democrats are rolling the dice in Maine on a popular independent former governor who is seeking Senator Olympia J. Snowe’s seat, in the hope that he sides with them next year if elected.
