text: To the Editor:

headline: Theater Competition Rescues Students From Their Own Dramas
text: Performing Shakespeare can save children’s lives. That is the persuasive argument of Alex Rotaru’s documentary “Shakespeare High,” an inspiring, if too short and overcrowded, examination of the competition among high schools at the 90th annual Drama Teachers Association of Southern California Shakespeare Festival.

headline: A Place More in Keeping With the Plan
text: WHAT with medical school, internship, residency, fellowship and work, Christopher Leggat moved often — 10 times in 10 years.

headline: Art City
text: Images from art shows around New York City, including the Armory Show at Piers 92 and 94.

headline: New York State’s Campaign Against Smoking
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Bad Impression Outlasts a Bridge’s New Paint
text: The Hell Gate Bridge looks like hell.

headline: Quandary Considered: Pregnant, When a Friend Is Struggling With Infertility
text: M., who has the happiest of quandaries — from her point of view — has a phone call to make.

headline: Searching for Herself, She’s Odd and Familiar
text: Movies and literature do not lack for coming-of-age stories about young women in odd circumstances, but “Attenberg,” Athina Rachel Tsangari’s new film, belongs in its own category. With an eccentric, beguiling blend of detachment and empathy — the camera sometimes lurking like a spy, sometimes trailing along like a shy, devoted friend — Ms. Tsangari observes the curious activities of Marina, a 23-year-old in the midst of an identity crisis that feels both highly idiosyncratic and weirdly familiar.

headline: The Lease: A Contract With Muscle
text: YOU loved your apartment when you first moved in. But now your girlfriend has joined you, and the “charming” space the ad promised has started to feel intolerably cramped. Or the street noise, once a minor distraction, has become an infuriating obsession. Or you’ve landed your dream job — in Los Angeles.

headline: Highest Court in Mississippi Upholds 9 Pardons
text: Bringing a definitive close to the legal controversy that has swarmed since former Gov. Haley Barbour of Mississippi gave pardons to nearly 200 felons in his last days in office, the Mississippi Supreme Court ruled on Thursday that the judicial branch did not have the power to void those pardons.

headline: For Florida State Center, Military Was a Steadying Influence
text: Bernard James, a 6-foot-10 Florida State forward, truly could not walk down a sidewalk and chew gum at the same time when he was 12. He wore size 15 shoes, and his hands were the size of a catcher’s mitt at the end of scraggy arms, which added to his imbalance. He referred to his feet as clown’s feet, and schoolmates referred to him as St. Bernard, as if he were a big goofy dog.

headline: Silence Goes Beyond Golden; It Could Save Two Lives
text: Among the many lessons in “A Thousand Words” is how to manufacture a slick and generic Hollywood comedy-drama. In the simplicity of its premise it embodies the notion of high-concept entertainment. In its execution it demonstrates how technical efficiency can drain the life from a story.

headline: Schools, Shops and Transit, in a Pretty Package
text: THE hot spot here seems to be the Mall at Short Hills, a posh center with 160 stores covering 1.3 million square feet. Off an exit ramp of State Route 24, it has a Bloomingdale’s, a Macy’s, a Neiman Marcus, a Nordstrom and a Saks Fifth Avenue, plus dozens of specialty shops — and, of course, valet parking.

headline: Syrian Kurds Flee Into Iraqi Refugee Limbo
text: QAMISHLI, Iraq — Inside a muddy village named for a failed revolt against Syrian authorities, a history of flight and exile is repeating itself.

headline: An Industry’s Failure to Verify, After Trusting
text: As the financial crisis intensified in mid-2008, the largest of the monoline insurance companies that had guaranteed payments on complicated securities retained an investment bank to evaluate the risks it had taken on in a small part of its portfolio — a group of 15 collateralized debt obligations.

headline: Molycorp, a Rare Earth Mining Firm, Is to Merge With a Processor, Neo Material
text: HONG KONG — One of the West’s two main rare earth metal mining companies announced on Friday that it was buying one of the world’s two main rare earth processing companies for $1.3 billion, the latest in a series of deals that are rapidly consolidating the industry.

headline: What Is the Place of Unions Today?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Immersed in Anger and Smothered by Loneliness
text: Thematically somber but visually luminous, “Dissolution,” the remarkable new work from the Israeli-American filmmaker Nina Menkes, explores a soul stained by blood and smothered by loneliness.

headline: Boldface Buildings in the Cold Light of Now
text: AT the height of the condo building boom in Manhattan, when it seemed as if a shiny new building was being announced every week, developers took a page from the motion picture industry and seized on star power to sell their projects.

headline: Trial Shows Benefit in Using Prostate Cancer Drug Early
text: Johnson & Johnson said Thursday that its new drug for prostate cancer was effective when used earlier during treatment than it is now, potentially broadening its use and also posing a competitive threat to a rival drug, Dendreon’s Provenge.

headline: Setback on AIDS Drug Is Re-evaluated
text: The failure of a daily pill to protect healthy African women against AIDS may not have been the pill’s fault but the women’s reluctance to take it, scientists at an important AIDS conference in Seattle were told this week.

headline: The Perils of Piecemeal Intervention
text: SYRIA’S rebels are in retreat, President Bashar al-Assad’s loyalist forces are laying waste to their former strongholds, and the death toll is mounting: the latest United Nations reports put it around 7,500. As the body count has increased, so, too, have calls for outside intervention. It’s time for the West to step in — but only after honestly debating what it will take to stop the carnage.

headline: A Dinner Date With the Obamas
text: President Obama and Michelle Obama shared dinner with three campaign supporters on Thursday, the third event in his “Dinner With Barack” contest and the first that included the first lady.

headline: Anarchist Percussionists and a Belly as an Instrument
text: Should my colleagues Allan Kozinn and Anthony Tommasini, classical music critics both, take on this review? They’d assess the efforts of a gang of anarchist percussionists out to thwart the establishment with their revolutionary piece “Music for One City and Six Drummers.” The musicians’ skullduggery, in four movements, sends them to a hospital where a patient with a resonant belly and his medical equipment become their instruments. But I don’t think this bunch would care about reviews; they’re committed to their outsider status, as good outsiders are.

headline: Hands Off the Heavens
text: OUTER space has become the next frontier for American national security and business. From space, we follow terrorists and intercept their communications, detect foreign military deployments, and monitor a proliferation of unconventional weapons. Our Global Positioning System gives us targeting and tactical advantages, spacecraft create image-rich maps, and satellites beam data around the world.

headline: In a Park Fountain, All of Those Coins Add Up
text: One at a time, those coins people toss into the pink granite fountain at Bryant Park add up: penny, penny, nickel, quarter, euro.

text: ‘A DAY OF REFLECTION’

headline: Spare Times
text: ‘TORN IN TWO: THE 150TH ANNIVERSARY OF THE CIVIL WAR’ (Tuesday; display continuing Friday through April 28) For an exhibition consisting largely of maps, pictures are worth a thousand words. This display at the Grolier Club, organized by the Norman B. Leventhal Map Center at the Boston Public Library, includes period maps, newspapers and other items related to the Civil War that tell the stories behind the conflict, from the tensions that led to it to the battles that defined it. (Included, above, is an 1864 Currier & Ives lithograph with Lincoln and the Confederate leader Jefferson Davis tugging on a map of the United States held by Gen. George B. McClellan, a Union Army general who unsuccessfully ran for president against Lincoln.) Other pieces include a map used by Lincoln to plot troop movements; the war itself led to a remapping of major battle areas. headline: Weber’s Future Uncertain After First-Round Loss by Illinois
text: INDIANAPOLIS — With the outside world talking about his vanishing job security, Bruce Weber showed his team a motivational video on the eve of what could have been his last game as coach at Illinois. Weber said the video showed a Carnegie Mellon professor, who had been dying of cancer, talking about his new outlook on life.

headline: High School Star Is in a Hurry, Leaving Records Behind
text: NEWARK — One recent morning at St. Benedict’s Prep, Edward Cheserek was asked how long it took him to get to a practice at Branch Brook Park, about a mile away.

headline: Mastering Fish as an Edible Art Medium
text: Opens on Friday in Manhattan.

headline: A Throwback Player, With a Wardrobe to Match
text: Marty Reisman wears vintage Borsalino fedoras because no one makes a good hat anymore.

headline: The Trees Are All Right
text: In most of the American West, the trees are not the right height, which may frighten Mitt Romney, and some of them are so old as to challenge the biblical view of creation that Rick Santorum wants taught in schools.

headline: Arrests Prompting Hard Look at Top Hockey Program
text: BOSTON — The students, trustees and employees of Boston University received an e-mail from Robert Brown, the university’s president, on Wednesday concerning the men’s hockey team. He was not congratulating the Terriers on their 21-win season or wishing them luck in their opening game in the Hockey East playoffs Friday.

headline: Amid Finger-Pointing, Hurricane Relief Lags
text: Nearly four years after Hurricanes Ike and Dolly wreaked havoc on the Texas coast, thousands of Texans are still waiting for housing assistance. The long-term disaster recovery effort financed by the federal government has made little headway. But where two state agencies faltered, another is stepping in.

headline: A Smug Education?
text: THE Republican presidential candidate Rick Santorum recently set off a ruckus when he attacked America’s colleges as “indoctrination mills” from which God-fearing Americans should keep their distance. Calling President Obama a “snob” for urging all Americans to go to college, he joined a long tradition that runs from Andrew Carnegie, who more than a century ago described colleges as places that prepare students for “life upon another planet,” to Newt Gingrich, who has claimed that alumni donations are often used “to subsidize bizarre and destructive visions of reality.”

headline: Israel: Soldier Is Stabbed and Fires Back
text: An Israeli soldier was stabbed in the neck on Thursday while trying to make an arrest in a West Bank village, the Israeli military reported. The soldier opened fire on his Palestinian assailants, killing one man and wounding another, the military said. It was not immediately clear whether the man who was killed had taken part in the knife attack. The soldier was part of a force that had gone to Yatta, south of Hebron, to rearrest a Palestinian man, Khaled Mahamra, who had been released from prison in the fall as part of an exchange for Gilad Shalit, the Israeli soldier who was held captive for five years in Gaza. Palestinian news reports said that the Palestinians were shot during clashes as they tried to prevent the arrest. The military said that Mr. Mahamra was suspected of transferring funds to establish a terrorist network in the West Bank.

headline: Haunted Home Looks Great by Lantern Light
For Knicks, Distraction by Addition
text: The optics are troubling for any Knicks fan who has spent a moment poring over the standings or pondering the counterintuitive influence of Carmelo Anthony.

headline: Let’s Have a Baby and Look for Love Later
text: Like the girly sitcoms currently speckling the television schedule, “Friends With Kids” comes fully equipped with jokes about vaginal elasticity (in this case lack thereof) and other formerly unmentionable female concerns. As limiting in their way as the football-watching, belly-scratching preoccupations of the sitcom man of yore, these quips have become de rigueur in a certain kind of entertainment directed primarily at women, badges of progressiveness that often serve only to veil the retrograde themes lurking behind them.

headline: Activist Investor Charts Plan to Revitalize Yahoo
text: Daniel S. Loeb is getting back into the activist arena.

headline: Ignorance Is Strength
text: One way in which Americans have always been exceptional has been in our support for education. First we took the lead in universal primary education; then the “high school movement” made us the first nation to embrace widespread secondary education. And after World War II, public support, including the G.I. Bill and a huge expansion of public universities, helped large numbers of Americans to get college degrees.

headline: With November in Mind, House Passes a Jobs Bill
text: WASHINGTON — The House overwhelmingly approved legislation on Thursday to ease small businesses’ access to investments and capital markets, a sign that the shadow of the November election is pressing Congress into action.

headline: Here Comes the Bride’s Understudy
text: “I’ve gone man vegan,” Katie (Kelly Macdonald) says early in “The Decoy Bride,” explaining that she has given up on ever finding love. “They say after the first six years that you don’t miss them anymore.”

headline: Couple’s Mutual Attraction and Mutual Disaster
text: Sacrificing clarity in favor of atmosphere, “Apart” watches the romantic spasms of a disturbed young couple bedeviled by muddled plotting and impenetrable lighting. Bathed in the bilious hue of a 7-Eleven parking lot at 3 a.m. — a look favored by all too many digital-camera wielders — almost all of the film’s remarkably static scenes reveal too little and confuse too much.

headline: Iran Is Pressed on Access for Nuclear Inspectors
text: The six world powers that have agreed to resume negotiations with Iran over its disputed nuclear program issued a blunt request on Thursday that the Iranians allow international inspectors unfettered access, most notably to Parchin, a large restricted military complex that the inspectors suspect may house a testing chamber for explosives used in atomic weapons triggers.

headline: Rising G.O.P. Star From Staten Island Draws on Political Gifts to Fend Off Critics
text: Working his way down the St. Patrick’s Day parade route on Staten Island last Sunday, Representative Michael G. Grimm stopped to talk to nearly every reveler. An aide in an Irish fisherman’s sweater proffered Mr. Grimm’s tiny Yorkie, Sebastian, for people to pet. Mr. Grimm stopped regularly to exchange brotherly greetings with fellow Marine veterans.

headline: City Is Ordered to Provide Back Pay in Fire Department Bias Case
text: New York City must pay as much as $128 million in back wages to minority candidates who took the Fire Department’s screening test but were never hired, according to a ruling by the federal judge who had deemed the test discriminatory.

headline: Hey, Mets! I Just Can’t Quit You.
text: In 2005, I wrote a column saying that maybe it was time to abandon the New York Mets and become a fan of the Washington Nationals. My reasoning was sound. We were raising our kids in Washington. We had Nats season tickets. We were acquiring Nats paraphernalia. It would be so easy to join the fold.

headline: Perry Pledges to Finance Texas Women’s Health Program
text: Responding to intensifying criticism about the Texas government’s decision to exclude Planned Parenthood from a health care program for low-income women — a move that the federal government considers illegal — Gov. Rick Perry said at a news conference on Thursday that the state would use its own money to operate the program if Washington stops financing it.

headline: Referee Steers Clear of A.C.C. Tournament
text: ATLANTA — When the referee Karl Hess called John Clougherty, the supervisor of officials for the Atlantic Coast Conference, and said he did not want to be a distraction at the tournament here this week and would not officiate, Clougherty tried to talk Hess out of his decision.

headline: Google Remixes Old Campaigns, Adding a Dash of Digital Tools
text: GOOGLE is going all Marty McFly on Madison Avenue, sponsoring a back-to-the-future project that reimagines classic campaigns from the “Mad Men” age for modern sensibilities — and technologies.

headline: Uncertainty at UConn
text: Connecticut has become the most fascinating team in college basketball in March. No program flashes its range of extremes, from winning the N.C.A.A. tournament last season to a program that may be spiraling toward oblivion this year.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: March 8, 2012

headline: Spanish-Language TV Dramas Heat Up Miami
text: MIAMI — Blanca Soto moved to Los Angeles from Mexico to make a better life. After a decade of struggling there, she relocated to Miami where she works 10-hour days, six days a week.

headline: Telling the Truth Like Crazy
text: One summer day in 2009, a woman walked into the police station house of the 81st Precinct, in Brooklyn, to report that her car had been stolen. She was well into her second day of trying to file a report, having already spoken to five or more officers in two precincts and was waiting, exasperated, for a lieutenant to turn up as he had promised.

headline: State Cuts Squeezing the Elderly Poor and Their Doctors
text: After Dr. Javier Saenz completed his family-medicine residency in 1985, he returned home to the Rio Grande Valley to open a practice in the impoverished town of La Joya.

headline: What Do I Know About Poverty?
text: What’s real-world experience worth? Does it matter?

headline: M.L.S. in Midst of Stadium Games in N.Y.C.
text: For nearly all of his 13 years as the commissioner of Major League Soccer, Don Garber has evangelized in all corners of North America for what he likes to call “soccer-specific stadiums.” And in nearly ever city from Toronto to Houston, and hamlets in between like Chester, Pa., and Frisco, Tex., the drill was basically the same: award a franchise, then get a deal done for a stadium … eventually … by cajoling local governments to foot at least part of the bill.

headline: At Doral, a Career Reflected in a Round
text: DORAL, Fla. — If not for the throng of Spanish-speaking fans who threw their voices behind Sergio García on Thursday, he would have been the forgotten player of this W.G.C.-Cadillac Championship.

headline: New Apps Connect to Friends Nearby
text: Smartphones have become indispensable for some people to find nearby cool new places for a bite or a drink.

headline: Vacant Queens House Used for Sex Crimes, Police Say
text: In January, with a team of contractors renovating his three-family home in Ozone Park, Queens, Tsung Chen came by to inspect the work. What he saw surprised him: the locks had been changed.

headline: A Not-Quite Confirmation of a Memo Approving Killing
text: WASHINGTON — For months, the Obama administration has refused to confirm or deny the existence of a Justice Department memorandum that approved the targeted killing of a United States citizen, Anwar al-Awlaki, who died in a drone strike in Yemen last September.

headline: Cathy Horyn's Runway Report
text: Cathy Horyn reports on the trends from Paris Fashion Week, including collections from Comme des Garcons and Chanel.

headline: Edith Pearlman Wins National Book Critics Award
text: Edith Pearlman won the National Book Critics Circle Award for fiction at the Tishman Auditorium of the New School on Thursday for “Binocular Vision,” (Lookout Books), a story collection that has elicited praise from reviewers for its delicate and wry character portraits.

headline: Yankees Hope Reliever’s Foot Injury Is Just a Sprain
text: TAMPA, Fla. — The Yankees have enjoyed a smooth first few weeks of spring training, but the relative calm of camp was given a jolt Thursday when one of the team’s best pitchers sustained a foot injury in a household accident.

headline: Sexual Violence and the Military
text: The rate of sexual assaults on American women serving in the military remains intolerably high. While an estimated 17 percent of women in the general population become victims at some point in their lives, a 2006 study of female veterans financed by the Department of Veterans Affairs estimated that between 23 percent and 33 percent of uniformed women had been assaulted. Those estimates are borne out in other surveys, and a recent Pentagon report on sexual assaults at the service academies found that in the 2010-11 academic year, cadets and midshipmen were involved in 65 reported assaults.

headline: Trucking Company Workers Are Indicted in Fraud Scheme
text: Five trucking company employees used an elaborate scheme to steal more than $5 million in union benefit money, according to an indictment unsealed on Thursday in Federal District Court in Brooklyn.

headline: We Thought They Were Worried About Costs
text: As part of their broader campaign to repeal health care reform, House Republicans are determined to kill off an independent board that is supposed to help rein in federal spending on Medicare.

headline: Second-Seeded Marquette Sent Home by Louisville
text: After its best finish in seven seasons in the Big East, second-seeded Marquette opened the conference tournament in disappointing fashion, making an abrupt exit Thursday night, falling to seventh-seeded Louisville, 84-71, in the quarterfinals.

headline: The N.Y.P.D. and Muslims
text: Mayor Michael Bloomberg of New York, Commissioner Raymond Kelly of the New York Police Department and their supporters have reacted with defensiveness and hostility to the disclosure of constitutionally suspect surveillance of law-abiding Muslims in New York City, Long Island, New Jersey and beyond.

headline: The G-String Brigade Faces a Destitute Age
text: The bravery-in-theater award this year goes to ... no, not one of those flying masked men from “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark.” The winners are Tina Shepard and Jack Wetherall for fearlessly recreating their 1983 performances in the Talking Band’s “Hot Lunch Apostles” at La MaMa.

headline: Wide Open Spaces
text: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — Wow. That’s a lot of white space.

headline: Florida Prep School Copes With Shock and Loss
text: JACKSONVILLE, Fla. — Stretching out along the banks of the St. John’s River, the Episcopal School of Jacksonville is where the city’s elite send their children for academic success steeped in spirituality.

headline: Typhoon
text: There is a boat in my barn. I put it there last October, yet it surprises me every time I go down to get a bale of hay. A previous owner called it the Judy of Gloucester — still painted on the stern — but its manufacturer called it a Typhoon, a name I like to think was taken from the novel by Joseph Conrad. You can pack a lot of plans and illusions into a dirt-cheap, 40-year-old sailboat only 19 feet long in a barn 140 miles from the sea.

headline: Pelfrey Has Rough Outing in Spring Training Debut
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Normally, a rough spring training start by a veteran pitcher would not be worth a second thought.

headline: Police Officer Guilty of Falsifying Information
text: A New York City police officer was convicted on Thursday of lying under oath and filing false information to obtain a search warrant, the second conviction in what prosecutors described as a scheme to cover up illegal searches of vehicles.

headline: E-Book Undercutting
text: Book publishers are frustrated with Amazon’s strategy of pricing e-books low.

headline: As Stars Rally for Candidate, Rival Objects
text: BOSTON — Elizabeth Warren may be running for the United States Senate in Massachusetts, but her campaign is getting deep support 3,000 miles away in California, where the other day, Cher was speaking glowingly of Ms. Warren’s candidacy.

headline: Weekend Miser
text: The alternative punk-pop group Betty has been together a long time. While most garage acts don’t last more than a year or two, this all-girl, now all-woman group is celebrating its 25th anniversary. And with a series of $10 performances at 92YTribeca, the Miser can afford to celebrate with them.

headline: Devils and Kovalchuk Show Signs of Surging
text: NEWARK — The game was stopped early in the third period Thursday so a crew could use shovels to clear the ice of hundreds of baseball caps. Ilya Kovalchuk had his second hat trick in less than a month, and the Devils had fired a warning shot to the N.H.L.

headline: Loss to Minnesota Is a Big Blow to Northwestern
text: INDIANAPOLIS — Northwestern guard Reggie Hearn sat in the corner of the locker room sniffling back tears. A few seats away, Alex Marcotullio stared blankly. And Drew Crawford told reporters no, the pressure to become the first team in program history to make the N.C.A.A. tournament had not gotten to them.

headline: Online, a Distant Conflict Soars to Topic No. 1
text: KAMPALA, Uganda — Jason Russell said he never knew he was driving into a war zone. At 24, he had just graduated from the University of Southern California after studying film, he said, and was out looking for a story to tell.

headline: Music Is the Stuff That Runs the Jalopy
text: The Jalopy was conceived as a space where artists could collaborate and make money through teaching, as well as performing.

headline: Jubilation Amid Banjos and Harmonies
text: LIKE some soulful machine stalled at the mouth of the Battery Tunnel, the Jalopy brings a joyful ruckus to the edge of Red Hook, Brooklyn. In rowdy roots-music style, this theater, bar and clubhouse conservatory dares visitors to be carried, shouting and singing, toward jubilation.

headline: Illegal Immigrants Get Scholarships While Aid Bill Idles
text: Among all the numbers that populate Nataly Lopez’s life — including phone digits, addresses, pass codes and friends’ ages — there is one that she never forgets: the cost of a semester’s tuition at Baruch College, where she is a sophomore.

headline: Court Blocks Parts of Law on Migrants in Alabama
text: A federal appeals court has blocked two parts of a tough new Alabama immigration law.

headline: Hacker, Informant and Party Boy of the Projects
text: In his Lower East Side apartment, the nights were racket-filled and without end. Neighbors lived with the pounding music and the sound of a pit bull being chased around the living room. The revelry sent scores of calls to the city’s complaint line.

headline: Benedict Freedman, Author of ‘Mrs. Mike,’ Dies at 92
text: Benedict Freedman, whose first novel, “Mrs. Mike” — based on the true story of a young woman’s life in the Canadian wilderness at the turn of the century — was a sensation after it was published in 1947 and inspired a Hollywood feature film, died on Feb. 24 at his home in Corte Madera, Calif. He was 92.

headline: Biron Is Flat as Rangers Find Reason to Worry
text: OTTAWA — When a team has as big a lead in its conference as the Rangers have had for the last several weeks in the East, there is a tendency to manufacture crises just to keep things interesting. The latest involves the recent performance of Martin Biron, the backup goalie.

text: Jimmy Ellis, the soulful lead singer of the Trammps, whose 1970s hit “Disco Inferno” was immortalized in the film “Saturday Night Fever,” died on Thursday in Rock Hill, S.C. He was 74.

headline: An Update on New York Redistricting
text: New York is now among the last states in the nation to tackle the redistricting required as a result of the 2010 census. And the urgency is growing: the state’s Congressional primary is scheduled for June 26, and its legislative primary for Sept. 11.

headline: A Professor, a Thriller, Not a Microchip in Sight

This may seem like a surprising move for someone who graduated from Cornell University with a degree in English, but it has led to a singular career.

headline: How the Kony Video Went Viral
text: Since three young filmmakers first traveled to Uganda in 2003, they have been determined to use film and activism to help stop the rebel leader Joseph Kony’s brutal tactics and the use of children as soldiers. But it was not until this week that their nonprofit organization,  Invisible Children, helped make Mr. Kony, the leader of the Lord’s Resistance Army, a household name.

headline: Are Men Useless? (Government Says Yes)
text: Are men useless, at least when it comes to caring for a family?

headline: White House Works to Shape Debate Over Health Law
text: WASHINGTON — The White House has begun an aggressive campaign to use approaching Supreme Court arguments on the new health care law as a moment to build support for the measure seen as President Obama’s signature legislative achievement, hoping to shape public opinion on an issue at the center of the battle for the White House and Congress.

headline: U.S. and Afghanistan Agree on Prisoner Transfer as Part of Long-Term Agreement
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Seeking to break an impasse on a broader strategic arrangement, the United States agreed Friday to greatly accelerate its transfer of imprisoned insurgents to Afghan government control, but will retain a veto over which ones can be released, American officials said.

headline: News Quiz | March 9, 2012
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries in today’s paper.

headline: March 9, 1862 | The Monitor and Merrimac Face Off in Battle of Hampton Roads
text: On March 9, 1862, during the Civil War, the Monitor and the Virginia (also known as the Merrimac) clashed to a draw at Hampton Roads, Va., in the first battle between two ironclad warships.

headline: Going Viral Against Vice
text: “Kony 2012,” a 30-minute video about the Ugandan war criminal Joseph Kony, has become an unlikely viral hit. In the hope of seeing the leader of the Lord’s Resistance Army captured before the end of the year, it calls on viewers to support the U.S. Special Forces troops currently helping with the hunt for Kony in Central Africa.

headline: Since the Tsunami, Fewer Tears
text: A little less than a year ago, the photographer Hiroko Masuike was living with a group of Japanese tsunami and earthquake survivors who had found shelter inside an ancient Buddhist temple after their community was destroyed.

headline: How Well Do You Think Standardized Tests Measure Your Abilities?
text: Standardized tests, like the SAT, the ACT or other national, international or state exams that measure all students at a certain educational level, are increasingly being used to judge how countries, states, schools and even individual teachers are doing. What standardized tests have you taken in your school career? How have your teachers prepared you for them? How well do you do on those kinds of tests in general? How well do you think the ones you have taken have measured your intelligence and abilities? Why?

headline: The Politics of Pandering in India
text: “Defeat is usually an orphan,” Dan Morrison wrote for Latitude blog in The New York Times. “But the election debacle of Congress, India’s ruling party, in Uttar Pradesh on Tuesday has a clear patrimony: pandering to the state’s 36 million Muslims,” he writes.

headline: U.N. Relief Chief Tells of Horrific Destruction in Syria and Official Resistance to Aid Plan
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The top United Nations relief official offered a somber view on Friday of the aid crisis caused by the uprising in Syria, saying she had witnessed horrific destruction during her two-day visit and had encountered resistance by the government to accept her emergency aid proposal, which would give United Nations relief workers unrestricted access to stricken areas.

headline: Q&A: Repairing Personal Folders in Microsoft Outlook
text: Q. Windows keeps giving me a message about an error in my Outlook file and that I should use an “Inbox Repair Tool” to fix it. Is this for real, and if so, what do I do?

In his Op-Ed piece for The New York Times, he suggested “four steps that might weaken the isolation of at least the children of the new upper class.” Among them:

headline: Scouting the Draft: Clemson’s Brandon Thompson
text: The featured prospect of today’s scouting report will probably be higher on my board than anyone else’s.  Clemson defensive tackle Brandon Thompson is a very athletic lineman who will be a run-stuffer from the start, yet he still possesses the skills needed to turn into a dominant pass-rusher.

headline: SXSW Interactive 2012: Saddle Up and Geek Out

headline: A Conversation With: Chief Minister D.V. Sadananda Gowda
text: D.V. Sadananda Gowda became the chief minister of Karnataka state, of which Bangalore is the capital, last summer amid a $3.5 billion scandal involving the illegal mining of iron ore. He recently visited Mumbai to meet investors and corporate executives.

headline: Tax Cheats Become Italy’s Public Enemy
text: ROME — When five officials from Italy’s internal revenue service entered the Dal Duca restaurant in Rome’s trendy Trastevere neighborhood one night two weeks ago, they were not there to eat.

headline: Radiohead’s Runaway Guitarist
text: On the morning of Sept. 12, 2011, a white Land Rover with a dragon on the door ferried the Radiohead guitarist Jonny Greenwood, his longtime recording engineer Graeme Stewart and Radiohead’s co-manager Chris Hufford to Alvernia Studios, about an hour outside Krakow, Poland. For several years, when he’s not recording or touring with Radiohead, Greenwood has pursued a second career as a composer of orchestral music, and this day he was cutting new versions of two of his classical pieces, “Popcorn Superhet Receiver” (17 minutes, inspired in part by the sound of radio static) and “48 Responses to Polymorphia,” both of which are unabashed tributes to the early-’60s output of the Polish composer Krzysztof Penderecki, whose compositions abandoned melody in favor of dense, dissonant tone clusters. Greenwood’s recordings will be featured on an album due out in March on Nonesuch Records, along with two new performances of Penderecki’s work conducted by Penderecki himself.

headline: Playing the Customer Service Rating Game
text: I have a good friend who recently had to do one of the most painful and stressful things we have to do in life. She had to make funeral arrangements for her husband, who had died unexpectedly. At the end of an unpleasant meeting at a funeral home where several attempts were made to up-sell her on funeral-related items, the undertakers concluded with this request: “You are going to be getting a survey from J.D. Power and Associates, and it’s important that we get a good rating. …”

headline: Ziggo Plans I.P.O. to Raise $983 Million
text: LONDON –The Dutch cable company Ziggo said on Friday that it was planning to raise up to 774 million euros ($983 million) through an initial public offering, the largest listing in Europe this year.

headline: Europe Doesn’t Like Sarkozy Either … And Few Other Leaders
text: LONDON — A political opinion poll with a difference was released on Friday, offering some intriguing insights into the popularity of Europe’s top national leaders.

text: LONDON — Barclays said on Friday that it had awarded its chief executive, Robert E. Diamond Jr., £6.3 million ($10.3 million) in compensation for last year, a reduction in pay as profit at the British bank slipped.

headline: London Stock Exchange to Buy Stake in Clearinghouse
text: LONDON – The London Stock Exchange Group agreed on Friday to buy up to a 60 percent stake in LCH.Clearnet, an independent clearinghouse for financial transactions, for 463 million euros ($612 million).

headline: Prediction Markets and Elections
text: Justin Wolfers, a University of Pennsylvania economics professor on leave at Princeton this year, has written frequently about prediction markets like Intrade. You can find research papers on the topic on his Web page and on the page of Eric Zitzewitz, a Dartmouth professor. The patterns in the data have made Professor Wolfers believe that these markets — where traders effectively bet on the outcome of real-world events — are a better guide to the future than experts are.

headline: What the Creator of ‘The Sopranos’ Taught the Creator of ‘Mad Men’
text: There’s no guaranteed way to create a hit television series, but it helps when you’ve trained with someone who’s already done it. It worked for Matthew Weiner, the “Mad Men” creator, who was hired by David Chase, the creator and show runner of “The Sopranos,” to write for that  influential HBO drama in its final seasons. The experience provided Mr. Weiner with crucial writing credits, and the lessons he learned from Mr. Chase continue to resonate in his work on “Mad Men.”

headline: Help for College Students Who Are Illegal Immigrants
text: With the Dream Act bill in limbo in Albany, the New York Immigration Foundation, with help from the Korean American Community Foundation and labor groups, and the support of the Fund for Public Advocacy,  put up the money to help 10 undergraduates in the City University of New York pay their tuition. More than 100 students applied for the aid, The Times says.

headline: Tribe and Prejudice
text: LONDON — “There is not a threat to Pakistan from Taliban ideology,” Imran Khan, Pakistan’s former cricket captain and current political favorite, told The Guardian in a lengthy interview in Islamabad last week. Bad timing. That week also saw some of the worst atrocities committed against Pakistan’s religious minorities — the kind of sectarian violence more befitting of the hard-line regime in 1990s Afghanistan than of a modern democracy.

text: Since Super Tuesday, I’ve been reading a lot of coverage that ignores the challenges that the delegate count poses to Rick Santorum. Here’s one quick test to see if you have a good sense for this stuff. Is Illinois a must-win state for Mr. Santorum?

headline: U.S. Extends Its Run of Strong Job Growth Another Month
text: After a stretch of economic expansion so weak that Main Street struggled to detect any improvement, three consecutive months of solid employment growth have begun to lift the mood of consumers and the unemployed.

headline: Daily Report: Portrait of a Hacker
text: In The New York Times on Friday, N.R. Kleinfield and Somini Sengupta paint a portrait of Hector Xavier Monsegur, known on the Internet as Sabu. As a federal informant, Mr. Monsegur, 28, helped bring down a group of politically motivated “hacktivists” in Europe and the United States, who were indicted on Tuesday on computer crime charges.

headline: The Perils and Promise of Free Agency
text: The funny thing about free agency is that everyone acknowledges that it begins with a frenzy of overspending and wishful, if not outright irrational, decision-making. Yet, every year, free agency somehow manages to once again begin with a frenzy of overspending and wishful, if not outright irrational, decision-making. Mistakes of the past are repeated enough to make George Santayana roll over in his grave.

headline: Life on Moors
text: In the North of England, at the Western edge of Yorkshire, the accents are incomprehensibly thick, the ghosts are palpable, and the moors, dotted with sheep, seem to go on forever. Everywhere is the dry stone walling — assembled by hand with no mortar — that has lasted for centuries and defines field boundaries and ownership. This is the obdurate, timeless landscape that bred the celebrated Brontë sisters and fertilized their singular literary imaginations, which have held readers spellbound since 1847, when their novels first appeared under male pseudonyms.

headline: The Brick in the Wall Leaves a Gaping Hole
text: The batsman Rahul Dravid announced his retirement from international cricket on Friday afternoon at a news conference with the measured strokes and grace he was lauded for on the cricket field.

headline: Friday Reading: In Texas, a Bachelor’s Degree for $10,000
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: Comparing Recessions and Recoveries: Job Changes
text: The United States recovery continued to show more fruits in the workplace in February, with the Labor Department reporting a net gain of 227,000 jobs for the month. It was the third straight month of gains exceeding 200,000 — and in fact, the job growth for the previous two months was revised upward by a total of 61,000.

headline: H.P. Attempts to Take On Amazon’s Cloud Service
text: Within two months, Hewlett-Packard will offer a large and powerful cloud computing service similar to Amazon Web Services, but with more business-oriented features, according the head of the project.

headline: Creating a Sound That’s All His Own
text: George Braith has not taken a break since he first picked up the saxophone in seventh grade. “When you stop playing, you lose something,” he said. “You got to keep it going.”

headline: Jobs Figures Keep Improving
text: 1:10 p.m. | Updated  to correct figures.

headline: Leading Off: In College Sports, the Shadows Lurk
text: The problem with the bargain you make with yourself when you try to enjoy big-time college sports is, even in the midst of all the fun and pageantry at the best time of the year, the shadows keep closing in. It’s possible to imagine this is all fun and innocence for about four minutes now. A buzzer sounds, the cheering fades and reality is soon storming the court and smashing all the illusions to pieces again.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Insatiable Critic: Gael Greene realizes that her anonymity has been compromised at Empellón Cocina when the chef, Alex Stupak (above), sends out “the bowl of chicharrones with a tumbler of tomatillo-caper salsa that comes unbidden.” And suddenly, here comes the carrot salad that is black, muddy, silken and tangy — with, well, depths. “It’s like eating a Caravaggio,” she writes. — Glenn Collins

headline: Up Front
text: Douglas Coupland has a knack for making terms stick. He popularized “Generation X.” Ditto “McJob.” And in his review of Hari Kunzru’s new novel, “Gods Without Men,” he may have done it again, by delineating an entire literary genre: “Trans­lit.” (See his review for the definition.) Coupland’s innovations aren’t restricted to the written word, however. The author of 13 novels, a story collection and seven books of nonfiction, he is also a visual artist who has exhibited in North America, Europe and Asia. (His art is on display through March 11 at the Armory Show in New York.) Much of his work has examined the collision of technology with culture, body and spirit. “Aliens didn’t come down to Earth and give us technology,” he said via e-mail. “We invented it ourselves. Therefore it can never be alienating; it can only be an expression of our humanity.”

headline: Ambitious, but in a Polite Sort of Way
text: HERE is how the promising comedy career of Ed Helms almost didn’t begin. As an ambitious Oberlin College undergraduate, he traveled on spring break to NBC’s 30 Rockefeller Plaza headquarters to interview for an internship at “Late Night With Conan O’Brien.”

headline: Edible Selby | Inn Absentia
text: Forty or so miles north of Venice, on the slopes of Cartizze — prime prosecco country — is a charming stone house called Osteria Senz’ Oste. Depending on whom you ask, the name translates to “Tavern Without Host” or “Bar Without Barkeep,” and the place is exactly that. There for the taking are fresh bread, cheese, artisanal salami, chestnuts, cookies and many varieties of sparkling wine, all on the honor system — or, as the proprietor, Cesare De Stefani, phrases it, “trust in the people.” De Stefani, who produces the salami and prosecco nearby, asks that visitors simply leave money for what they eat and drink in a locked box on site. “I thought how nice it could be for a tourist or friend to arrive here and discover my vineyard and the old house,” he says, “finding fresh prosecco wine to be tasted in the absence of the landlord.”

headline: In Ford Country, a New King Exerts Dominion
text: On Friday, Ford introduced the 2013 F-Series Super Duty Platinum pickup truck. As its name would suggest, the Platinum commands a premium price. In fact, the truck will be the most expensive model in the F-Series portfolio, surpassing even the $68,000 King Ranch Super Duty.

headline: At Least Grover Norquist Is Consistent
text: Here’s the strange thing about Republicans who take a hard line on illegal immigration — and who among them doesn’t, these days? They profess to want smaller government that spends little, and yet demand all-out war on illegal immigrants through radically expanded police powers and blank-check spending on fences and troops at the border.

headline: An Ambitious Chinese Party Chief Admits His Failure to Oversee an Aide
text: BEIJING — Jockeying to salvage his political career, the embattled Communist Party chief of Chongqing championed his success in running the central Chinese metropolis on Friday, even as he admitted failing to supervise a trusted aide who recently fled to an American consulate, causing a national sensation.

headline: In India, Bank Moves To Stimulate Economy
text: MUMBAI, India — In a move meant to relieve growing stress in its financial system, India’s central bank on Friday sharply reduced the amount of money banks have to hold in reserve. The action came ahead of a scheduled policy meeting at which the bank was expected to cut the reserve ratio, but less sharply.

headline: Mortgage Crisis Inspires Churches to Send Lenten Season Message to Banks
text: During the recent weeks of Lent, the Rev. Ryan Bell has led his Southern California congregation into the penitential spirit of the season. He has preached about the prophet Isaiah’s admonition “to loose the bonds of injustice.” He has replaced his church’s ebullient praise songs with somber, reflective music. He has sent his members a list of ordinary comforts to give up until Easter, with suggestions from caffeine to Facebook.

headline: Weekend TV Guide, March 9-11: Tracking U.S. Players
text: Major League Soccer returns to action this weekend, and one cannot help but notice that the league is approaching its 17th season with a bit of swagger. While TV ratings continue to disappoint, M.L.S. boasts a star-laden defending champion (the Los Angeles Galaxy), an ambitious new club (the Montreal Impact) and a television deal with a high-profile network that is looking to make some noise. M.L.S. Commissioner Don Garber should be proud.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: A Facebook Founder Buys TNR and Google Channels Alka-Seltzer
text: The New Republic magazine, once described as the flight magazine of Air Force One, is being sold again, this time to Chris Hughes, a founder of Facebook who also ran President Obama’s online campaign in 2008, write Brian Stelter and Michael de la Merced. Mr. Hughes will focus his energies on the tablet version of the magazine, which will continue its print version. “Five to 10 years from now, if not sooner, the vast majority of The New Republic readers are likely to be reading it on a tablet,” he said. Richard Just will remain the editor.

headline: Book Review Podcast
text: This week, Hari Kunzru on his new novel, “Gods Without Men”; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; Charles Duhigg discusses the science of habits; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host.

headline: Quest Software Agrees to Buyout
text: Quest Software, a provider of database applications and other corporate I.T. must-haves, said Friday that it had agreed to be taken private by a New York-based venture capital and private equity firm, Insight Venture Partners.

headline: Image of the Day: March 9
text: Kashmiri devotees offer prayers at the shrine of a Sufi saint in Srinagar, Jammu and Kashmir.

headline: The Kony Kerfuffle
text: DJIBOUTI — The only person I’ve ever met who was in the Lord’s Resistance Army (L.R.A.) is a Ugandan man named Francis. He was abducted by the group sometime in the late 1990s, when he was a teenager, and forced to march from central Uganda to what is now South Sudan. During a firefight with the Ugandan national army, Francis escaped with his best friend. They had never spoken aloud. The L.R.A. enforced silence on marches.

headline: Peter Marino Likes Playing Bad Cop
text: You’re one of the most-sought-after architects on the planet. You were brought up in Queens, but I can’t quite place your accent. It sounds vaguely European. My parents spent a lot of money so I wouldn’t sound like I came from Queens. I went to speech class.

headline: The 2.26.12 Issue
text: EIGHT DAYS A WEEK

headline: The Internship Rip-Off
text: I took an unpaid internship that I figured would give me experience and help me land somewhere in six months. Instead I’m picking up coffee and dry cleaning and performing other tasks that the company would otherwise have to pay someone for. I know this is the status quo for internships, but it violates the law, and it feels deeply unethical. Taking legal recourse would hurt my career prospects. Is there anything I can demand of this company in exchange for my slave labor? NAME WITHHELD, NEW YORK

headline: Why Is That Nice Girl From ‘Friday Night Lights’ Fighting a Bunch of Ninjas?
text: A little while back, I went to the movies. There was a trailer for “G.I. Joe: Retaliation,” in which I saw Tyra Collette, the headstrong high schooler from “Friday Night Lights,” learning ninja moves. That was followed by a trailer for “Ghost Rider: Spirit of Vengeance,” during which I caught a mercifully brief glimpse of Stringer Bell from “The Wire.” And then the actual movie I came to see, “Mission Impossible: Ghost Protocol,” began, and there was Sawyer from “Lost,” walking briskly through a train terminal before being taken down by an assassin’s bullet. “I can’t believe they killed him off in the first scene!” I whispered to my friend. “Why?” she asked. “Who is that guy?” I gave her a look of horror that was probably disproportionate to the situation, but I was shaken. “That’s Sawyer,” I gasped, “from ‘Lost’! He’s one of ours.”

headline: Hot Tub, Ice Machine
text: The real challenge of Ouray is the mixed climbing competition: a treacherous route of ice and rock.

headline: Who Made That Butterfly Chair?
text: The Hardoy chair, also known as the sling or butterfly chair, owes much of its renown as a midcentury Modernist icon to the perspicacious eye of a Rust Belt department-store scion, Edgar Kaufmann Jr. In 1940, three Argentine architects (members of an association known as Grupo Austral) presented the chair at a Buenos Aires exhibition. The design so impressed Kaufmann, then an industrial-design curator for the Museum of Modern Art, that he promptly imported one for his parents’ new weekend house, Frank Lloyd Wright’s Fallingwater. He imported another for the museum too.

headline: Last Fling of an Octogenarian
text: Where I grew up, there lived a man named David. He drove a Jaguar, spoke with a BBC accent and dressed only ever in a suit and tie. His air was patrician, which disguised — perhaps this was the point — the fact that as a child he was sent to England from South Africa by a wayward mother and brought up, modestly, by strangers.

headline: Room and Boards
text: OWNER: Ryan Sheckler, 22

headline: Morning Buzz, March 9: Trump Talks Football
text: Good morning. Not as pleasant as yesterday, today will be mostly cloudy with a high of 51 degrees.

headline: Christian Vautier: Right-Bank Sweets on the Lower East Side
text: With chocolate, freshness counts. And it’s all but guaranteed at Christian Vautier Le Concept, a new boutique and cafe on the Lower East Side where truffles, chocolate-enrobed bonbons and other confections — including caramels, chocolate spreads, and fruit jellies — are made daily.

headline: Identity Companies: Paid to Know About You
text: I was at the Montgomery & Co. investor conference in Los Angeles this week, where 186 promising start-ups present their businesses to over 1000 potential investors. The companies are private, so they don’t give away too much financial information.

headline: Seven Lean Years
text: OK, definitely a better jobs report than we have become used to. And terrific news for Obama; another six months of news like this and he’ll be in very good shape for reelection.

headline: I’m Honored
text: A correspondent tells me that Fox News has declared me a “menace to society”.

headline: Lionel Richie to Enter Apollo Theater Hall of Fame, and Then, He Says, ‘An Epidemic of Duets’
text: In a week when Lionel Richie learns he’s going to be inducted into the Apollo Theater‘s Legends Hall of Fame and is announced as a star of ABC’s summer singing competition, “Duets,” we expected his excitement would have him dancing on the ceiling or partying all night long. But this former Commodores frontman-turned-solo singer-songwriter instead referred to another title in his smoother-than-smooth back catalog.

headline: Open-Source A.W.S.: Creating a Thousand Clouds
text: Amazon Web Services, the cloud computing service of Amazon.com, has sparked a boom in powerful and flexible computing over the Internet. Now the same technology is entering the corporate mainstream, through open-source cloud computing.

headline: Lineup Swap Won’t Benefit Fields or Shumpert
text: When Linsanity struck in New York, the Knicks began floating on cloud nine. Good chemistry and an even better Cinderella story propelled the team to a successful February.

headline: Lloyds’ Chief Eligible for Share Bonus
text: LONDON – Lloyds Banking Group, which is partly owned by the British government after a bailout, said Friday that its chief executive, António Horta-Osório, could be eligible for a share bonus of £3.35 million, or $5.3 million.

headline: Table Talk | Ngam’s Model Chef
text: Hong Thaimee’s life as a former model was filled with designer clothes as she graced the pages of glossy society magazines and became the face of such brands as Pantene and Nescafe in her native Thailand. When Thaimee would slip into a dress by Lanvin, her favorite label, she would describe the experience as “living in a fairly tale.”

headline: Marriages by Fran Drescher
text: The actress Fran Drescher is the officiant for two same-sex marriages at the Out NYC hotel in Manhattan.

headline: Pint-Size Oliviers Tackling Big Themes
text: THE appeal of child actors is deceptively straightforward: They embody innocence or the shock of its loss. But the danger of overacting is ever present, as is the possibility that a child expected to act naturally may seem more stilted than an adult. Audiences can be sensitive about children cast in fraught situations and suspicious of sentimental ploys, no matter how noble the directorial intent.

headline: On Our Radar: A Rare-Earths Merger
text: Molycorp, one of the West’s two main rare-earth metal mining companies, agrees to buy Neo Material Technologies, one of the world’s two main rare earth processing companies, for $1.3 billion. Rare earth metals are vital to making a range of high-tech products, including large wind turbines and electric cars, as well as oil refining. [The New York Times]

headline: Still Dictating Orders, This Time at the Altar
text: UNTIL quite recently, Fran Drescher was known primarily for her comedic roles on television, including her latest in “Happily Divorced,” in which she plays a woman who learns that her husband is gay, divorces him, but then remains a close friend of the man.

headline: Business Day Live | March 9, 2012
text: What new hiring means for the United States economy; keeping economic data secret before it is made public; and James B. Stewart on why Americans hate bailouts, even when they work.

headline: Bookshelf: Poetry
text: Five new picture books introduce children to the art of poetry.

headline: The Officiant Among Us
text: FOR generations, getting married meant solemnly standing before an authority figure charged with upholding the rules of civil society or religious traditions.

headline: Bookshelf: Poetry
text: OUTSIDE YOUR WINDOW A First Book of Nature. By Nicola Davies. Illustrated by Mark Hearld. 108 pp. Candlewick Press. $19.99. (Picture book; ages 3 to 8)

headline: The Marriage Plot
text: When Elizabeth Weil and Dan Duane married in July 2000, they made a straightforward pact: no cheating, no dying. Other less dramatic problems might lie on the horizon, like money (both are writers) and religion (she’s Jewish, he’s not). Over time, neither of these issues created difficulties, but nine years and two daughters later Weil came up with the idea of improving their good marriage by undertaking a year of marital-skills improvement — a project she wrote about for The New York Times Magazine. Reluctantly, her husband agreed to the plan, even though both were aware of an old saying: “If you’re going to poke around the bushes, you’d better be prepared to scare out some snakes.”

headline: Lost Generations
text: When an adviser to President Obama was quoted in The New Yorker as saying that the administration’s policy in Libya was “leading from behind,” he initiated a season of hand-wringing about American decline, as if he had announced that the president was implementing a secret plan to make a second-rate country even worse. But whether America is leading from — or falling — behind affects more than our foreign policy. It also affects how it feels to be an American, which is a central concern of American novelists.

headline: Paperback Row
text: THE HEMLOCK CUP: Socrates, Athens and the Search for the Good Life,  by Bettany Hughes (Vintage, $17.95.) Socrates, an enigma for 25 centuries, left no written legacy, and our knowledge of him comes mainly from three contemporaries — his pupils Plato and Xenophon, and the parodist Aristophanes. Hughes outlines Socrates by illuminating the world as he experienced it; the result is a multifaceted book that includes gritty details of daily life in Athens and a vivid history of the Peloponnesian War.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: THE STARBOARD SEA,  by Amber Dermont (St. Martin’s, $24.99.) Dermont’s captivating debut novel, whose narrator is a boarding school student and a sailor, takes pleasure in the sea and in the exhilarating freedom of being young.

headline: The Finer Points of the Game
text: There’s a lot more to playin’ ball than just playin’ ball. If you’ve spent time inside a hoops gym or run fives at the local street-ball hot spot, you get this. I don’t think I’m exaggerating when I say that pickup basketball, along with all the armchair philosophy that colors it, taught me the world.

headline: Surviving the Season
text: Fifteen-year-old Willo was born after the onset of a new ice age that has left Europe in winter’s grip in S. D. Crockett’s atmospheric first novel, “After the Snow,” a post-apocalyptic thriller for the post-global-warming era. A strong survivor, he lives with his family of “stragglers” in the hills outside the city. He wears a coat of hand-stitched skins and a dog skull as a fierce kind of hat, and when his family is taken away by the government, he goes out in search of them, following the voice of a dog inside his head. Traveling across a harsh, cold, snow-­covered terrain filled with wild packs of dogs, Willo heads into the city, a bleak realm of starvation and violence. Along the way, he falls for a girl and discovers his family secrets, as well as the deep truth of who he is and where he belongs.

headline: Cast Aside
text: Two and a half years ago, in the midst of the global swine flu pandemic, the Egyptian government of Hosni Mubarak had the ill-informed idea of protecting its citizens by slaughtering every pig in Cairo. Soldiers invaded sties kept by a group of Coptic Christians called the zabaleen and, amid howls of protest, butchered thousands of the animals. What the regime hadn’t considered was that the swine fed off the tons of garbage gathered every day by the zabaleen — Arabic for “trash collectors” — who eke out a living by sorting and reselling recyclables. Without the pigs, the city was soon buried in waste.

headline: Honest, Fair, Courageous and Strong
text: History is not simply what happened in the past; it is also what we choose to remember. That is why these four picture-book biographies — each portraying a spunky and clever, yet overlooked, heroine — are so welcome. It’s such books as these that recall women’s lives to our historical memory, and they make for terrifically entertaining reading, too.

headline: ‘Eminent Outlaws’
text: To the Editor:

headline: And That’s a Fact
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Other Side of Paradise
text: Until about 30 years ago, most schoolchildren in Hawaii learned a version of the state’s history that went something like this: Christian missionaries came over in the early 1800s and handed the Hawaiians a single god, a written language and their very first muumuus. Later, American officials supported a group of well-intentioned gentlemen, many of them descendants of those missionaries, who replaced the monarchy with a democratic system. Eventually, the United States magnanimously annexed the tiny island republic. Sure, native Hawaiians gave the world entertaining things like the hula and surfboards. But really, they were the luckier ones, receiving the trifecta of monotheism, democracy and American appropriation.

headline: Whispers in the Palace
text: Grigori Rasputin: faith healer, mad monk, priapic charlatan, resilient victim of assassination . . . and family man? Kathryn Harrison tackles all his identities in her new novel, “Enchantments.” This splendid and surprising book circles through time and around stories both real and imagined, lending a tender perspective to familiar historical events as experienced by two central characters — Rasputin’s daughter Maria, known as Masha, and Alyosha, the hemophiliac Romanov heir — whose physical and emotional suffering acutely remind us of the human lives behind the legends.

headline: Making Plastic Credit Cards Smarter at SXSW
text: On Friday, people at the South by Southwest Interactive festival in Austin, Tex., will be among the first who are able to test a new way to make an old form of commerce a bit smarter.

headline: Yankees’ Robertson Has Bone Bruise in Foot
text: 5:06 p.m. | Updated After four medical tests and experts poring over the results, David Robertson got the diagnosis he was hoping for Friday. Instead of something more sinister, Robertson has a bone bruise on the top of his right foot, Yankees Manager Joe Girardi said, and he is not expected to miss significant time. Read the full article here.

headline: Parental Quandary: Pregnant, With a Job Interview
text: Another reader wrote me with good news this week, in fact, two pieces of good news. S. is pregnant — and, after six months of freelancing while staying home with her toddler (and juggling to make financial ends meet), she just got an interview for a steadier gig.

headline: World of His Fathers
text: Anthony Shadid, who died in February at the age of 43 while reporting the crisis in Syria, was one of the most intelligent, experienced and well-­informed journalists covering the Middle East. In his writing, he showed a depth of intellectual inquiry and a skepticism toward conventional wisdom matched by few other correspondents.

headline: M.L.S. Preview: Five Players With a Story to Write
text: The new M.L.S. season will be full of story lines, from a star-studded champion looking to defend its title to an expansion franchise looking to make a good first impression. But there will also be a host of players looking to atone, to impress, to improve. Here’s a look at five who could write happy endings for their teams and themselves before the summer is out, and before the trophy is awarded.

headline: Confident Men
text: Last fall saw the publication of “Confidence Men,” a headline-­generating account of the first two years of economic policy making in the Obama White House by Ron Suskind, a leading ­inside-Washington writer. In “The Escape Artists,” Noam Scheiber, a senior editor at The New Republic, covers many of the same meetings, egos and behind-the-scenes debates. In both books, the president comes across as cerebral, well intentioned and initially naïve — no match for obstructionist Republicans in Congress. Both authors portray Obama’s former chief economic adviser, Lawrence Summers, as the quintessential turf-obsessed senior White House aide. Scheiber also shares Suskind’s disappointment that the Obama administration did not act more aggressively to combat the economic crisis it inherited from George W. Bush.

headline: Mystery Endures After Verdict Is In
text: Anatomy of a Murder

headline: Between Semesters, Digital Innovation
text: ON a chilly February afternoon a line of people coiled around MoMA PS1 in Long Island City, Queens, and disappeared down the block. It was Super Bowl Sunday, but despite a smattering of Giants gear, the young-looking crowd had committed the day to “From Scratch,” a five-hour performance of continuous improvisation by Nicolas Jaar, an even younger-looking electronic musician and producer.

headline: Marrying Up
text: Seventy-five years ago, Edward VIII swapped his kingdom for a divorcée, the American-born Wallis Warfield Simpson. At this advanced date, could there possibly be anything new to add to the mountain of autobiographies, biographies, memoirs, novels and films that have accreted on this subject? The answer, surprisingly, is yes. In “That Woman,” Anne Sebba boldly recasts the relationship that was once considered the “most romantic love story of the last century” as “a tale of gothic darkness with a Faustian pact at its core.” The king, in Sebba’s telling, emerges as a man who today might be looked on as something of a stalker.

headline: A New Persian Empire Plants a Personal Flag
text: IN the beginning there was the word ... Persian.

headline: From Parables to Pointillism
text: Anaïs Mitchell

headline: Versions
text: If you’re a poet outside the Anglophone world, and you manage to win the Nobel Prize, two things are likely to happen. First, your ascendancy will be questioned by fiction critics in a major English-­language news publication. Second, there will be a fair amount of pushing and shoving among your translators (if you have any), as publishers attempt to capitalize on your 15 minutes of free media attention.

headline: Can’t Help Myself
text: Human consciousness, that wonderful ability to reflect, ponder and choose, is our greatest evolutionary achievement. But it is possible to have too much of a good thing, and fortunately we also have the ability to operate on automatic pilot, performing complex behaviors without any conscious thought at all. One way this happens is with lots of practice. Tasks that seem impossibly complex at first, like learning how to play the guitar, speak a foreign language or operate a new DVD player, become second nature after we perform those actions many times (well, maybe not the DVD player). “If practice did not make perfect,” William James said, “nor habit economize the expense of nervous and muscular energy, he” (we, that is) “would therefore be in a sorry plight.”

headline: Standing Alone
text: Paul Grüninger, a Swiss police commander, had a simple explanation for why he broke the law to help Jewish refugees flee Austria in 1938. His daughter remembered that he would repeat the words “I could do nothing else.” It is a humble answer, as if to say that anyone would have done the same.

headline: El Paso Shareholders Approve Kinder Morgan Takeover
text: Casting aside the controversy, shareholders of the El Paso Corporation have approved Kinder Morgan’s bid, originally valued at $21.1 billion.

headline: Strangers Abroad
text: Luxembourg sounds perfect for a spy looking for a nice dull place to retire to. As Chris Pavone dryly notes in his smartly executed first novel, THE EXPATS (Crown, $26), “nobody dreams of living in Luxembourg.” Nevertheless, a burned-out C.I.A. operative named Kate Moore grabs her chance to quit the agency and reinvent herself when one of the grand duchy’s secretive private banks hires her husband, Dexter, to redesign its electronic security systems.

headline: Fiction Chronicle
text: HISTORY OF A PLEASURE SEEKER By Richard Mason. Knopf, $25.95.

headline: Rules for When the Chicks Return to the Nest
text: MY teenage sons are still in high school and middle school and, as is the norm, live at home. So perhaps it’s a little early for me to be writing about what rules to lay down if and when they move back after college.

headline: Unemployment by Job Category
text: The national unemployment rate held steady at 8.3 percent in February, mainly because more people started — or resumed — looking for work. But depending on the industry, unemployment rates are all over the map.

headline: Weekend Fare
text: Friday is National Meatball Day, and a number of restaurants are offering specials to celebrate. At Casa Nonna, 310 West 38th Street (Eighth Avenue), in the Garment District, an all-you-can-eat meatball special served with a side of pasta and a full carafe of wine is $35. Another Friday-only special is being served at Zero Otto Nove, 15 West 21st Street (between Fifth and Sixth Avenues), in the Flatiron District, offering a 10-ounce meatball that weighs as much as two baseballs, bathed in a tomato sauce and topped with goat cheese for $5. Through Sunday, Carmine’s, 2450 Broadway (West 91st Street), on the Upper West Side, will offer a complimentary order of six meatballs for every reservation of eight or more diners.

headline: 2012 Mazda 3
text: With the new Skyactiv engine, the Mazda 3 is now the best performer in its class and has the best mileage, a pretty unbeatable combination.

headline: Off the Charts: Relative Strength in U.S. Business Orders
text: According to a survey of manufacturers and service companies, United States companies are reporting stronger order flows than those in most other countries, while Germany is no longer reporting strong numbers, and orders are weakening sharply in some other members of the euro zone.

headline: What Do Jonny Greenwood, Neil Young and Miles Davis Have in Common?
text: Alex Pappademas’s article on Jonny Greenwood in this week’s magazine  touches on the Radiohead guitarist’s work as a composer for films like “There Will Be Blood” and “We Need To Talk About Kevin.”
