headline: Business Day Live: New Hiring
text: What new hiring means for the United States economy; keeping economic data secret before it is made public; and James B. Stewart on why Americans hate bailouts, even when they work.

headline: An Outsider to Blind Passion Surveys Its Wrath
text: THERE is a fine line between mad love and pure madness. In “The Deep Blue Sea” Hester, the beautiful wife of a judge, falls hopelessly for a younger ex-fighter pilot who forgets her birthday, a slight that plunges her into suicidal despair. The film begins as she awakens from an unsuccessful act of desperation, and unfolds mostly over the course of a single day, exploring Hester’s unraveling through flashbacks.

headline: John Ross’s Big Mistake
text: On March 22, 1862, John Ross, the principal chief of the Cherokee Nation, sent a hastily written letter to Brig. Gen. Albert Pike, the Confederacy’s representative in Indian Territory. Composed less than six months after Pike had negotiated an alliance between the Confederacy and the Cherokee Nation, Ross’s letter underlined his fear that the Cherokee Nation was teetering on the edge of destruction.

headline: When Love Conquers All, Even the Loss of Two Jobs
text: Updated, 5:34 p.m. | For two men in St. Louis, it seemed like a romantic way to spend their 20th anniversary: a weekend in New York, with a marriage ceremony in Central Park on Friday and a Broadway show, “Priscilla: Queen of the Desert,” on Saturday.

headline: What’s Up? New Orders in the U.S., but Not in Most of Europe
text: BUSINESSES in the United States say that the level of new orders is continuing to rise, even as it weakens in most European countries.

headline: More [Good] News about [Bad] Gestation Crates
text: Another significant victory in the fight to ban sow gestation crates: Compass Group USA—whose U.K. parent company is the largest food service company in the world—announced that it plans to eliminate the crates from its U.S. pork supply chain by 2017.

headline: Has the He-covery Become a She-covery?
text: The “he-covery” may be over.

headline: No. 2 Official in S. Carolina Steps Down Over Charges
text: ATLANTA — The lieutenant governor of South Carolina, Ken Ard, resigned on Friday and pleaded guilty to criminal charges of spending campaign funds on personal expenses and fabricating donations.

headline: L.A. Times Drops Restaurant Review Stars
text: Asserting that a star grading system was a bad fit for the Southern California dining scene, The Los Angeles Times announced on Thursday it would stop running stars with restaurant reviews. The paper said reviewers could not use stars to appropriately judge broad differences in dining choices, such as “a food truck, a neighborhood ethnic restaurant, a one-time-only pop-up run by a famous chef, and a palace of fine dining.”

headline: Dynegy Bankruptcy Examiner Finds Fraudulent Transfer
text: The report from the court-appointed examiner in the Dynegy bankruptcy case is out, and it’s a bombshell.

headline: Inside the List
text: OFF AND RUNNING: One recurring knock against Ernest Hemingway is that late in his career, he fell back on lazy imitations of the terse machismo that had made him famous. But any writer with a distinctive style runs the risk of self-parody. Consider Tom Wolfe, who used exclamation points and electric Kool-Aid prose to help reinvent journalism before moving on to Technicolor zeitgeisty novels like “The Bonfire of the Vanities” and “A Man in Full.” Wolfe’s new novel, “Back to Blood,” won’t be released until this fall. But the book’s description on Amazon makes it sound like the sort of sprawling social novel that might have been churned out by a white-suited Tom Wolfe cyborg. Here it is: “As a police launch speeds across Miami’s Biscayne Bay — with officer Nestor Camacho on board — Tom Wolfe is off and running. Into the feverous landscape of the city, he introduces the Cuban mayor, the black police chief, a wanna-go-muckraking young journalist and his Yale-marinated editor; an Anglo sex-addiction psychiatrist and his Latina nurse by day, loin lock by night — until lately, the love of Nestor’s life; a refined and oh-so-light-skinned young woman from Haiti and her Creole-spouting, black-gang-banger-stylin’ little brother; a billionaire porn addict, crack dealers in the ’hoods, ‘de-skilled’ conceptual artists at the Miami Art Basel Fair, ‘spectators’ at the annual Biscayne Bay regatta looking only for that night’s orgy, yenta-heavy ex-New Yorkers at an ‘Active Adult’ condo and a nest of shady Russians.”

headline: Wes Anderson Film to Open Cannes Festival
text: 1960s New England will find a new home on the French Riviera: Wes Anderson’s “Moonrise Kingdom” will open the Cannes Film Festival in May, festival organizers announced on Friday. Mr. Anderson’s seventh feature, set in 1965, takes place on an island off the New England coast. With a cast that includes Bill Murray, Bruce Willis and Frances McDormand, it’s the story of a romance between a pair of precocious 12-year-olds who run away, presumably to somewhere really picturesque.

headline: Toyota Recalls Nearly 700,000 Vehicles for Potential Brake Light and Air-Bag Failures
text: In an example of how small flaws can lead to big bills, Toyota announced this week that a trace of silicone grease and a steering-wheel flutter were behind two recalls covering nearly 700,000 vehicles, according to documents the automaker filed with the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

headline: 2012 Geneva Motor Show
text: While the vehicles featured at the show demonstrated the makers’ commitment to building greener cars, it was less certain that customers were ready to buy them.

headline: The Get | Pomellato’s New Pom Pom Pieces
text: Known for its decadent baubles, the Milanese jewelry house Pomellato is adding something new and improvisational to its couture Pom Pom collection this spring. “Each piece embodies the freedom of creativity and is created around stones whose rarity, magnitude and irregular shapes render them unique,” the C.E.O., Andrea Morante, says. These additions to Pom Pom — which was introduced in 2007 — include 12 rings, 11 bracelets and 3 earrings set “in a more daring way, one that breaks the rules of traditional fine jewelry,” Morante says. Take, for example, the chandelier earrings, whose asymmetrical aquamarines are suspended almost haphazardly between pink sapphires and white diamonds, or the cocktail ring made of a cushion-cut red tourmaline bursting from a bed of flat, rose-cut diamonds. Each piece is one of a kind and timing is everything — the collection arrives at Bergdorf Goodman on March 15.

headline: The Munchkins Are a Problem: Drama Club Drama
text: In last week's installment of "The Munchkins Are a Problem," Helene Stapinski wrote about how she reluctantly agreed to help produce the fifth-grade play at P.S. 29 in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn. This week the Drama Club holds it first meeting. Note to other play parents: leave the weapons props at home.

headline: Mitt Romney Likes Grits
text: Back in January Maureen Dowd observed that Mitt Romney has more than a little in common with George H.W. Bush. They share “gee-whiz language, hokey humor, awkward stage presence, sense of entitlement and noblesse oblige.” Michael D. Shear elaborated on that theme in the Caucus blog yesterday: “As Mr. Bush tried to do, Mr. Romney is working to bridge two worlds inside the Republican Party: an establishment wing with which he feels comfortable and a rabble-rousing wing that has a big influence over policy and ideology.”

headline: Discovering Kohlrabi (It’s a Vegetable)
text: What’s a kohlrabi? Before you start cooking with it, take our quick quiz to test your kohlrabi smarts.

headline: How India Became America
text: Pondicherry, India

headline: TimesCast | March 9, 2012
text: Dozens of youth activists win in Russia's municipal elections | Understanding hyperpolyglots, a community of people committed to learning dozens of languages.

headline: The Frontrunner and His Rivals
text: This post-Super Tuesday analysis from NBC’s First Read embodies everything I find exhausting and frustrating about the horse-race coverage of the Republican primary:

headline: Franzen, Chabon and Lahiri Named to the American Academy of Arts and Letters
text: The writers Jonathan Franzen, Michael Chabon and Jhumpa Lahiri are among the new members named to the American Academy of Arts and Letters, The Associated Press reported. Other new members named to the group, which was founded in 1898 and is based in Upper Manhattan, include the artists Kara Walker and Lynda Benglis, the architect Elizabeth Diller, and the composers Stephen Jaffe and Tobias Picker. The new class will be officially welcomed to the 250-member society at a ceremony in May, where the artist Chuck Close will give an address.

headline: The Enthusiast: ‘Margin Call’
text: This week’s Enthusiast comes from Chris Pavone, author of the new novel “The Expats,” a thriller about an American couple living in Luxembourg.

headline: Would You Like Extra Ice, Sir?
text: In this YouTube video, a passenger on a recent Delta flight captured two unlikely seatmates in first class: a couple of penguins from Sea World. “This is video proof that penguins CAN fly,” wrote the poster.

headline: For Woman Charged as Madam, Unusual Tie to Law Enforcement
text: A woman prosecutors say is a well-connected madam has boasted of ties to law enforcement as she ran a brothel from a building on the Upper East Side, even though no police officers or public officials have been charged with crimes in the case against her.

headline: Some Dos and Don’ts About Leverage, Simply Put
text: I RECENTLY came across a report on the value of taking on some debt that was so simply worded and straightforward that I was startled. Those types of reports, typically, are anything but easy to understand. They’re also usually trying to sell something that is complicated.

headline: New N.C.A.A. Rules We’d Like to Break
text: With a new scandal, infraction or allegation coming out every two to three seconds in the college sports world, we thought it might be time to update and simplify the N.C.A.A. rulebook, especially as it pertains to student-athlete conduct.

headline: Graphic Books Best Sellers: Bane and Doomsday Return
text: The 1990s were a glorious time for comic books, particularly at DC Comics: Superman was murdered by Doomsday, Batman had his spine shattered by Bane, and Wonder Woman ran around with biker shorts and a leather jacket. Two of the stories are revisited on the graphic books best-seller lists this week. At No. 5 on the hardcover list is “Superman: Reign of Doomsday,” which features the return of the foe who temporarily vanquished the Man of Steel. This time Superman has Superboy, Supergirl, Steel and other allies in his fight. At No. 4 on the paperback list is “Batman Versus Bane,” in which the villain, who temporarily put the Dark Knight in traction, returns to plague Gotham City. Bane is also one of the villains in this summer’s film “Dark Knight Rises,” the concluding chapter in the Batman trilogy directed by Christopher Nolan.

headline: Fraud Found in Jobs Effort; Blow to Bloomberg
text: City investigators have discovered evidence of large-scale fraud in one of the agencies leading Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s signature initiative to find jobs for unemployed New Yorkers.

headline: Pakistan Picks New Director for Spy Agency
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — The prime minister of Pakistan appointed a new general to run the country’s most powerful intelligence agency on Friday, signaling an important change in the military leadership at a pivotal moment in relations with the United States.

headline: An Impotent Outlaw in the American West
text: Opens on Friday in Manhattan.

headline: Seedco Report March 2012
text: An Investigation charges one of New York City’s largest non-profit job placement agencies, systematically reported false placements to the city’s Department of Small Business Services.

headline: Israeli Airstrikes Kill Militants in Gaza
text: GAZA — Israeli airstrikes killed up to 10 Palestinians, most of them militants, in the Gaza Strip on Friday and early Saturday, and militants fired barrages of rockets at southern Israel in the worst cross-border fighting in months.

headline: Book Review Podcast: Hari Kunzru’s Searchers in the Desert
text: In the New York Times Book Review, Douglas Coupland reviews Hari Kunzru’s fourth novel, “Gods Without Men.” The book focuses on a married couple and their 4-year-old autistic son who goes missing, but it also hops through time following several other characters and their relationships to a mysterious rock formation in the Mojave Desert. To describe the novel, Mr. Coupland coins the term Translit, which he explains like this:

headline: Tim Speaks: Videos of a Young Polyglot Reaching Out to the World
text: A gallery of videos Timothy Doner recorded of himself speaking languages like Hindi, Pashto and modern Hebrew.

headline: Adventures of a Teenage Polyglot
text: SOME people pick up a little Hebrew before their bar mitzvahs, or learn Spanish from their mothers, or can speak some Japanese from a semester abroad.

headline: Adapting, Revising, Provoking
text: BROADWAY audiences have spoken. “The Gershwins’ Porgy and Bess” is a big hit at the Richard Rodgers Theater, where it opened in January. The run has been extended through September.

headline: Early Exhilaration, With Flourishes
text: ALTHOUGH Carnegie Hall has made admirable strides in recent years, especially since it opened Zankel Hall in 2003, it has never been in the vanguard of the early-music movement. Until now.

headline: Looking Back With Darkness And Insects
text: Mattituck, N.Y.

headline: Real Fake Chicken
text: The Op-Ed columnist Mark Bittman visits a factory that is perfecting a new type of vegetarian substitute for chicken.

headline: A Syrian Boy’s Grief on Page 1
text: Of the few photographers who’ve managed to make pictures in the midst of Syria’s violent uprising,  Rodrigo Abd, who shoots for The Associated Press, has stood out.

headline: Playing Charley in ‘Death of a Salesman’
text: The veteran stage actor Bill Camp talks about his performance in Arthur Miller’s classic play.

headline: Charting the Stages of Teacher Data Report Grief
text: A Queens English teacher writes: "The feeling when your teacher data report arrives by e-mail is akin to going over the crest of a roller coaster, realizing you’ve lost your wallet, and stepping where the last stair ought to have been, all rolled into one nauseating package. It’s an event that you know may have drastic implications for your career, but you also know the result is as random as a scratch-off lottery ticket. "

headline: On the Market in the Region
text: A four-bedroom colonial in New Rochelle, N.Y., and a five-bedroom colonial in East Freehold, N.J.

headline: On the Market in New York City
text: A Greenwich Village co-op, a Bed-Stuy brownstone and an Upper West Side triplex.

headline: Vanessa Mongeon and Chris Piccioni
text: AT the end of one of the roughest stretches of his life, Chris Piccioni was hardly on the prowl. He had lost custody of his children during a two-year divorce and had seen them move away with their mother to Los Angeles.

headline: Guest Post | Teaching About Japan, One Year After the Disaster

headline: John Mayer Cancels His Tour
text: Four and a half months after undergoing surgery to remove a growth from his vocal cords, John Mayer said on his blog on Friday  that the condition had returned and he had no choice but to “take an indefinite break from live performing.”

headline: TimesCast | Understanding Hyperpolyglots
text: March 9, 2012 - John Leland explores the growing virtual community of people committed to learning dozens of languages.

headline: Caucus Click: Autograph Lines for Romney
text: Mitt Romney signed placards and posters at a campaign event at a farmers’ market in Jackson, Miss.

headline: Chris Christie’s Tough Talk
text: Chris Christie supporters almost invariably describe the governor of New Jersey as a “tough talker” and a “straight shooter.” His reputation is that of the non-politician’s politician willing to “level with the American public,” to speak “hard truths.”

headline: The Week Ahead
text: IF you like your entertainment blood chilling instead of heartwarming — and failed to succumb to the magnolia-scented charms of “The Help” — you might consider spending time with “THE MAIDS,” which opens on Thursday in a Red Bull Theater production. Like “The Help,” an Oscar nominee for best picture this year, “The Maids” considers the problems of sorely put-upon domestics, who are routinely humiliated by their affluent, self-centered employer. But because “The Maids” was written by Jean Genet, one of the most subversive dramatists ever, sentimentality doesn’t figure in this coruscating one-act drama from 1947. The fire of homicidal rebellion glows in the hearts of the play’s title characters (who were inspired by an infamous French murder case of 1933). And they do their darnedest to fan that spark into flame by acting out fantasies of their much-loathed mistress’s destruction. Jesse Berger directs this in-the-round presentation of Genet’s identity-bending chef-d’oeuvre. Ana Reeder and Jeanine Seralles portray the sisters in servitude, while the wonderful J. Smith-Cameron (of television’s “True Blood” and the movie “Margaret”) is the eminently killable lady of the house. Through April 1, the Theater at St. Clements, 423 West 46th Street, Clinton, (212) 325-3101, redbulltheater.com; $25 to $75.

headline: Legislators Recall Governor Who Didn’t Mingle
text: BOSTON — Well into Mitt Romney’s tenure as governor of Massachusetts, a state legislator named Jay Kaufman developed a nagging suspicion: the governor had no idea who he was.

headline: Former Times Executive Received $24 Million, According to Proxy Statement
text: Janet L. Robinson’s total compensation package when she left The New York Times Company in December was about $24 million, according to the company’s proxy statement filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission on Friday.

headline: Debt Insurance in Greece Must Pay Out, Ruling Says
text: Greece’s debt restructuring will prompt payouts on credit-default swaps tied to the country’s government bonds.

headline: TimesCast | Russia's Young Opposition
text: March 9, 2012 - Inspired by the recent growing protests against Vladimir Putin, hundreds of young Muscovites decided to run in municipal elections last weekend, and dozens won.

headline: Officials Hinder Inquiry Into Afghan Air Force on Smuggling, Two Americans Say
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Afghan defense officials are impeding an investigation into accusations that members of their air force are smuggling opium and weapons and that an Afghan officer who shot and killed eight American service members last year may have been involved in the suspected trafficking, two American officials said.

headline: Remembering ‘Video Music Box’
text: Clips from the pioneering rap music television show include KRS-One and A Tribe Called Quest performing live and music videos by Public Enemy and MC Lyte.

headline: Big Ticket | Sold for $88,000,000
text: The sale of an $88 million penthouse at 15 Central Park West was entered into the city record books this week, enshrining it as both the most expensive transaction of the week and the highest price ever paid for a Manhattan apartment.

headline: Failed Raid to Rescue Hostages in Nigeria Stirs Italy’s Anger
text: ROME — The failed attempt to rescue a Briton and an Italian who had been held hostage for months by an Islamist militant group in Nigeria set off diplomatic sparring on Friday, after Italian leaders complained that Britain had kept them in the dark about the raid, which left both hostages dead.

headline: Grumbles for Britain’s Hurdler From Michigan
text: ISTANBUL — At this stage, it takes something remarkable for a woman to draw a bigger crowd than Sally Pearson of Australia at a hurdles event. But the sniping surrounding the nomination of the American-born hurdler Tiffany Porter as British team captain at the world indoor track and field championships was enough to do the trick.

headline: After Backing a Dark Horse, Lin’s Agent Is Riding High
text: Of all the manifestations of Linsanity — the deployment of endless puns, the resolution of the MSG-Time Warner impasse that blacked out Jeremy Lin’s games, the array of Lin jerseys on Spike Lee’s person — one of the most telling might have been the sight of a man laughing inside a pharmacy near San Antonio last week.

headline: Summers Urges Europeans Not to Neglect Growth
text: PARIS — Greece skirted disaster Friday with a landmark bond swap deal that clears the way for billions of euros in bailout funds. But, in the view of one of the world’s leading economists, who is also a former top policy maker, the fiscal straitjacket constructed by European leaders to avoid the need for a rerun of the Greek problems in other countries may create fresh issues in the euro zone.

headline: Replacement for Klugman Also Bows Out of ‘Twelve Angry Men’
text: There have been a few substitutions, but the jury in the George Street Playhouse’s production of the courtroom drama “Twelve Angry Men” may finally be set. A few days after it was announced that he would replace Jack Klugman as Juror No. 9, David Canary has also withdrawn from that role.

headline: One Crime Show Gains in Ratings, Another Falls
text: Two television dramas made moves in opposite directions Thursday night, with CBS’s “Person of Interest” showing continued signs of emerging as a new crime hit for that crime-centric network, while the well-reviewed “Awake” on NBC, a more psychological crime drama, slid sharply in its second week on the air.

headline: During Factory Visit, Obama Hails Jobs Report
text: PETERSBURG, Va. – President Obama is not claiming mission accomplished, but on Friday he hailed the latest monthly report of jobs growth by saying, “Day by day, we’re restoring this economy from crisis.”

headline: Just Over the Fence
text: To the Editor: Re “The Country Just Over the Fence” (Feb. 26): You think Nogales built the fence? The only point you have correct is that it looks like the Berlin Wall, and for the United States, a country that prided itself on being a melting pot and helping to bring down the wall in Berlin, how eerie that we turned around and built one of our own.

headline: Job Strength in Health Care and Energy
text: If there are two areas of domestic policy where the Republicans are particularly critical of the Obama administration, they are health care and energy.

headline: Brains of Bee Scouts Are Wired for Adventure
text: Some honeybees are known to be thrill-seeking adventurers — the David Blaines of their hive, so to speak. Known as scouts, they fearlessly leave their hives and search for new sources of food and new hive locations for the rest of the colony.

headline: Coppola’s Italy for Guests, Not Moviegoers
text: BESIDES being a filmmaker and a winemaker, Francis Ford Coppola has owned hotels and resorts since the 1980s. With his latest, Palazzo Margherita, palazzomargherita.com, in Bernalda, Italy, he now owns five properties. His first, the Blancaneaux Lodge in Belize, was a result of his developing an affinity for the jungle, “as people do,” he said, while filming “Apocalypse Now” in the Philippines 35 years ago.

headline: Obama Names Technology Adviser
text: President Obama has appointed Todd Park to be his top technology adviser, the White House announced on Friday.

headline: New Chapter for Berlin School
text: HUNDREDS of revelers packed a cavernous auditorium in Berlin last month to hear the French singer and actress Charlotte Gainsbourg in concert for a magazine party on the eve of the Berlin film festival. Jake Gyllenhaal and Naomi Campbell were among the guests. After it ended, Andy Warhol paintings and a Frank Stella sculpture were installed as part of a gallery that opened the next day. Two restaurants and a photography gallery were also unveiled, setting the space well on its way to becoming Berlin’s latest cultural hot spot.

headline: The Mets Are Born
text: The Mets played their first-ever spring training game 50 years ago on March 10, 1962.

headline: Hotel Review: DoubleTree by Hilton in Amsterdam
text: THE UPSHOT

headline: A Chicken Without Guilt
text: IT is pretty well established that animals are capable of suffering; we’ve come a long way since Descartes famously compared them to nonfeeling machines put on earth to serve man. (Rousseau later countered this, saying that animals shared “some measure” of human nature and should partake of “natural right.”) No matter where you stand on this spectrum, you probably agree that it’s a noble goal to reduce the level of the suffering of animals raised for meat in industrial conditions.

headline: Proof That There’s Fun After 40 Miles Per Gallon
text: ASK the hipster waiting in line for a new iPad. Buyers and critics alike are easily seduced — sometimes too easily — by the new.

headline: Qaeda Media Arm Steps Up Local Coverage in Yemen
text: Once the source of English-language militant propaganda aimed at a global audience, the media arm of Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula has been increasing its output of videos in recent weeks in an apparent effort to win local supporters in Yemen, where Qaeda militants control a small area of the south.

headline: Enzo Ferrari’s Legacy Comes Home
text: MODENA, Italy

headline: Looking for a Ray of Light in Europe’s Clouds of Gloom
text: GENEVA

headline: A Champion’s Take on Racing Safety
text: AS the auto racing season begins, there are ample reminders that drivers, like other professionals, sometimes make career changes.

headline: Retailers Add Gadgets for Shoppers at Ease With Technology
text: When Nadia Karim goes shopping, she doesn’t wait around for salespeople. She saves items from apps and Web sites on her cellphone as a shopping list. And as she browses one store — recently trying on Sam Edelman flats at Nordstrom — she uses the phone to check out styles at competitors like Macy’s.

headline: Welcome Racing Fans!
text: The 2012 Formula One season takes off in Melbourne next weekend, with the Australian Grand Prix, and the IHT has published its preview. But the big news for readers of this site is that the Formula One blog, the first ever by a regular F1 correspondent, started back in 2006, has now moved to a new home, with a broader mission.

headline: Kansas Offers Santorum Chance for Big Delegate Grab
text: It’s winner-take-all, sort of, in Kansas’ caucuses on Saturday.

headline: The Uncertain Cost of Helping Illegal Immigrants Go to College
text: Much of the public debate surrounding proposals to allow illegal immigrants to receive state financial aid for college has centered on questions of legality: Would such legislation legitimize the status of people in the country without authorization?

headline: The Web Is Awash in Reviews, but Not for Doctors. Here’s Why.
text: For all the debate about which Web sites have the best model for reliable reviews — paid or unpaid, anonymous or real name, Angie’s List or Yelp or TripAdvisor — one thing is certain: a robust ecosystem exists online for restaurant and hotel reviews that has changed those industries for the better.

headline: For a Shell Executive, Much Head-Scratching
text: Europe is generally considered greener than the United States, but its oil executives certainly share American oil executives’ enthusiasm for drilling.

headline: Illinois Needs Another Help Wanted Ad After Firing Weber
text: Illinois Coach Bruce Weber has been on the way out for about half of this college basketball season, which is what a 2-12 slide to end a season will do, so Friday’s actual firing of Weber came as a bit of mercy for the embattled coach. Athletic Director Mike Thomas certainly did not need much time to think about things after the final straw, the Ilini’s loss to Iowa Thursday in the first round of the Big Ten tournament.

headline: More Than an Onion Understudy
text: Leeks are a key ingredient in this week’s City Kitchen recipe. Though readily available, they don’t necessarily end up in everybody’s shopping basket. We think of them as a stand-in for onions, but they really are so much more.

headline: Outside Las Vegas, an Ace of a Bike Trail
text: AS the desert sun neared its apex and Lake Mead glittered against the brown desert, the water break I was taking on Nevada’s newest bike trail was interrupted by a couple of fellow riders.

headline: Consumer Protection Bureau Opens Student Loan Complaint System
text: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau announced on Monday that it had opened a student loan complaint system for issues regarding student loans. The system was put in place for students to voice their issues with lenders.

headline: Why Job Growth Is Likely to Slow
text: If you looked only at the monthly jobs report, you could start getting pretty optimistic about the American economy. The largest, broadest survey of employment — a survey of businesses — shows the best job growth in more than five years over the last 12 months, with the pace mostly accelerating in recent months. The other survey that the Labor Department does — of households — shows even faster job growth, suggesting that the business survey may be understating the economy’s strength.

headline: Maryland Women’s Lacrosse Defend Home Streak Against Syracuse
text: This weekend’s game against No. 4 Syracuse would not seem to be a huge challenge for No. 2 Maryland in their women’s lacrosse matchup. The Terrapins are 11-0 all time against the Orange and are playing at home, where they are carrying a 36-game home winning streak, the fifth best in all of Division I sports.

headline: In Geneva, Surveying the Motor Show’s Pricey, and Priceless, Playthings
text: The Geneva motor show is not a sensible-shoes affair. It is the de facto home show for many makers of rarified, ultrahigh-performance automobiles. Jerry Garrett, who covered the press-preview days of the show’s 82nd iteration, photographed a number of these cars, some of which were, and may forever remain, concepts. A selection appears below.

headline: Your Reviews of the Physician Review Web Sites
text: In this week’s Your Money column, I tried to figure out why it has taken so long for physician review Web sites to truly take hold. Yelp has reviews of nearly every restaurant in most major cities, and TripAdvisor has hotels pretty well covered. So why is there a lack of advice on which doctor to choose?

headline: Origin of Country
text: Saturday night. We’re cruising up North Chester on our way to a Basque feast at Noriega’s, when something catches our eye across the median. Bryce hangs a U-ie so we can get to the source: a makeshift church in an empty warehouse. “Sinners Welcome” reads the gothic script banner hung on a rolled up metal grate, and a young man with a shaved head and vacant eyes asks if we know the Lord. Bryce and I nod reflexively. Inside, past rows of folding chairs, another man is at the lectern, trying to strangle salvation out of an electric guitar. It’s not pretty, though maybe it isn’t supposed to be. A few yards away, on the sidewalk, three teenage girls furiously suck on cigarettes, like there are nutrients or redemption in them. A heavyset woman on a scooter motors toward us.

headline: An Interview With Carlos Miele
text: The Brazilian fashion designer talks about his background as an artist, bringing Brazilian culture to the catwalk and the future of his brand.

headline: Week in Pictures for March 9
text: Subjects include a dispute over a winning lottery ticket, and a replica of Michelangelo’s David making its way into Manhattan.

headline: Winter Park, Fla.: An Old-Time Resort Looks Ahead
text: A sophisticated Disney neighbor, but without the lines.

headline: Pictures of the Day: The West Bank and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from the West Bank, Syria, Nigeria and India.

headline: Evita’s Buenos Aires
text: Sixty years after her death, Eva Perón’s legacy continues to spread throughout this city.

headline: When Debating the Auto Bailout, Consider Lehman’s Fate
text: Would Americans be better off if General Motors and Chrysler had simply gone bankrupt, without benefit of taxpayer assistance?

headline: Norman St. John-Stevas, Dapper Tory Dismissed by Thatcher, Dies at 82
text: LONDON — Norman St. John-Stevas, a Conservative politician who coupled a dandified manner with keen intellectual and aesthetic sensibilities, and who presented a ready target for Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher when she began culling left-leaning Tory dissidents from her cabinet in the early 1980s, died on March 2 at his home here. He was 82.

headline: Extended Race Could Pose Financial Challenges for Romney
text: The ticking sound you hear in the background of the Republican presidential primary is the fund-raising clock.

headline: Restaurant Review: The Room Palma, Palma, Majorca
text: There was a time when the Santa Catalina neighborhood of Palma, on the Mediterranean island of Majorca, bustled mostly by day. The market that gives the barrio its name, which opens at dawn, was packed with fishermen, bakers and vegetable mongers. But at night the streets were mostly dead. In recent years, though, farm- and sea-to-table restaurants have begun popping up in the streets that fan out from the market and they’re drawing crowds.

headline: Clyde Frazier’s: A Hoops Star’s Home Court
text: At Clyde Frazier’s Wine and Dine, the name is only the beginning of the homage to Walt “Clyde” Frazier, the former New York Knicks guard-turned-sportscaster. The new restaurant, bar and lounge on the West Side of Manhattan has a wood-paneled room with a hoop and regulation foul line that diners will be able to use.

headline: Where Heaven and Earth Come Closer
text: TRAVEL, like life, is best understood backward but must be experienced forward, to paraphrase Kierkegaard. After decades of wandering, only now does a pattern emerge. I’m drawn to places that beguile and inspire, sedate and stir, places where, for a few blissful moments I loosen my death grip on life, and can breathe again. It turns out these destinations have a name: thin places.

headline: Cabbage Flexes Its Muscles Three Ways
text: GREEN cabbage is not one of the sexier seasonal vegetables. Lacking the ruffled charm of kale or the dappled appeal of delicata squash, it is a pale, stalwart presence at the farmers’ market, there all winter long and ready when you want it — if you ever do.

headline: From the Everyday, the Extraordinary
text: There are many words to describe the performance style of Jodi Melnick, but needy isn’t one of them. Martha Graham used to say that the center of the stage was wherever she was; the same is true of Ms. Melnick. Somewhere deep in the bones of this choreographer and dancer lies a laudable power to take ordinary gestures and give them opulence. One by one, movements disappear and re-form, like a stop-motion animation.

headline: Ode to Cabbage
text: There is more to cabbage than cole slaw or soup. Melissa Clark demonstrates how to make pasta with caramelized cabbage.

headline: Evita’s Buenos Aires
text: EVERY city has its heroes — people who, for whatever reason, leave an indelible mark. Washington is awash in monuments to past presidents. New Yorkers work and live in a grid of ancestral icons: Rockefeller Center, Peter Cooper Village, Astor Place. And Paris is studded with plaques honoring luminaries from Joan of Arc to Victor Hugo to Edith Piaf.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Google Slows Book Scanning and a Grim Twitter Picture
text: Here are some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web on Friday. There are more here.

headline: Nymph Out of Water, Disturbing the Peace of City Dwellers
text: BRUSSELS — The first act of Stefan Herheim’s production of Dvorak’s “Rusalka” takes place not in the libretto’s idyllic forest clearing but in an anonymous European city. Lights flicker behind the curtains of the apartments overlooking a quiet square, as people watch television.

headline: Peer Pressure? How About, Like, Fighting to Death?
text: HERE’S a pop math quiz: “The Hunger Games,” a best-selling novel by Suzanne Collins about children killing children, is recommended for readers 12 and older. The “Hunger Games” movie, which shows kids killing kids, is angling for a PG-13 rating when it hits theaters March 23. To complicate matters, many readers under the age of 12 are dying to see the movie. Meanwhile, Jennifer Lawrence, the film’s star, is 21. She got the book at the behest of her mother, a reader and fan.

headline: Parent Un-Trapped | Let’s Hear It for the Boys
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: African Critics of Kony Campaign See a ‘White Man’s Burden’ for the Facebook Generation
text: Updated | Saturday | 12:13 p.m. As my colleagues David Goodman and Jennifer Preston explain, a viral marketing campaign to raise awareness of the suffering inflicted on African children by the warlord Joseph Kony has dominated social media conversations this week, despite concerns that the young Americans behind it might be spreading factual inaccuracies and wasting donors’ money.

headline: Capitalizing on Cabbage
text: This week’s column is about using cabbage three distinct ways to bring out different aspects of the vegetable. I made a crunchy raw slaw with Vietnamese flavors, a caramelized cabbage and penne dish inspired by cucina povera, and a potato-leek soup variation in which cabbage adds a soft sweetness to the mix.

headline: Robertson’s Diagnosis Comforts the Yankees
text: TAMPA, Fla. — After four medical tests and after several experts pored over the results, David Robertson got the diagnosis he was hoping for Friday. Instead of something more sinister, Robertson has a bone bruise on the top of his right foot, Yankees Manager Joe Girardi said, and he is not expected to miss significant time.

headline: Romera Is Said to Be Closing
text: Romera New York, the temple of “neuro-gastronomy” that drew curious diners and corrosive reviews, is closing at the end of Saturday, just a half-year after opening, Eater reports.

headline: At the Enzo Ferrari Museum, Housing 2 Legacies
text: As Eric Sylvers writes in Sunday’s Automobiles section, the Enzo Ferrari Birthplace Museum opens this weekend in Modena, Italy. Built next to the home where the founder of Ferrari was born, the museum was the last work of the star architect Jan Kaplicky.

headline: Photo Replay: March 9
text: The day in sports included the world indoor track championships in Istanbul and World Cup skiing in Sweden.

headline: Taking a ‘Softly, Softly’ Tack at London’s Night of the Stars
text: The Night of the Stars charity game at the Wimbledon Bridge Club in London last month featured a Who’s Who of British bridge stars. In addition Fulvio Fantoni, a professional bridge player, flew in with his wife, Iolanda, at his own expense.

headline: Giants Release Jacobs in Money-Saving Move
text: After seven seasons and two championships, Brandon Jacobs is no longer a Giant.

headline: Changing Attitudes Toward Debt
text: After the last few years, when the economy went through the depths of a recession, debt seems to have become a bad thing. After all, consumers took on too much debt — through credit cards and mortgages, mainly — in the years leading up to the recession. Banks were too free in lending them money. And now, with unemployment still high, a lot of college students who took out huge loans are having trouble keeping up with the payments.

headline: What to See at SXSW?
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — A Bob Marley doc? A martial arts thriller? A few feral children? Now is that moment before the film portion of the South by Southwest festival begins and audiences are sussing out what to tackle in this year’s robust program. Currently the longest line at the festival is for registration, but soon lines will form at several of the screening sites, including the historic Paramount theater, where the opening-night film, Drew Goddard and Joss Whedon’s “Cabin in the Woods,” will be shown.

headline: Romney Releases His Playlist
text: The 19-song playlist released Friday by Mitt Romney on Facebook, called “On the Road,” has surely been vetted by his campaign to make his image a little more down-home.

headline: Louis C.K. Withdraws as Host of Radio and Television Correspondents’ Dinner
text: The comedian Louis C.K. has withdrawn from his role as the host of a dinner for the Radio and Television Correspondents’ Association in Washington, a press representative for the comedian said on Friday.

headline: A Love Story Naturally, Without Microphones
text: The Dicapo Opera Theater’s delightful production of “The Most Happy Fella,” Frank Loesser’s tender, tough and melodically soaring 1956 work, boasts something no musical currently on Broadway can offer: natural sound.

headline: Two Novelists Take on the Haggadah
text: AFTER a lengthy interview with President Obama in the Oval Office two weeks ago, Jeffrey Goldberg, a national correspondent for The Atlantic, had one more question, and it had nothing to do with Iran.

headline: Airy Parcel, Hearty Flavors
text: A SOUFFLÉ from mashed potatoes might sound like a contradiction in terms at first: Soufflés are light. Mashed potatoes? Not so much. But the two textures can complement each other, resulting in a dish that tastes light but has an underlying heartiness.

headline: Memory, in All Its Elusiveness and Ability to Shock
text: Were it just another weak and underwritten play, “Flight” might be easy to dismiss. Yet because it trafficks in unearned emotions by exploiting the Holocaust, Alzheimer’s disease and dementia, the story treads close to being objectionable as well as ineffective.

headline: Leek and Potato Soufflé With Ham and Fontina
text: Time: About 1 hour

headline: Name Calling: Philosophy as Ontical Science
text: This is a response from the author to readers who commented on his previous essay for The Stone, Philosophy by Another Name.

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, March 9
text: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

headline: Near Orlando, Fla., a Sophisticated Alternative to Disney
text: BESIDES the parts of town within the magical world of Disney, one of the most pedestrian-friendly neighborhoods in the Orlando, Fla., area is Winter Park, a brick-street enclave just northeast of downtown. Though businesses there have historically catered to the 9-iron set — in the late 1800s, it became the state’s first planned community and earned status as one of the more popular resort towns of that era — forward-thinking shops and restaurants have started appearing along the two main thoroughfares, Park Avenue and New England Avenue. With them arrives a fresh, design-centric energy that comes close to rivaling anything you’ll find at Disney, but without the long lines and crowds. Click the slide show for photos from Winter Park.

headline: The Birds of Block Island
text: The photographer Katherine Wolkoff is known for her silhouettes of the human figure, including the ones featured in a recent cover story for the magazine.

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, March 9
text: More Photographs

headline: Up and Over One of the Three Sisters
text: Follow Matt Villano along one of the hardest hills on the River Mountains Trail.

headline: Out at Sea, Relaxing in the Philippines
text: WE were floating gingerly over a forest of antler-shaped coral when I heard a Swede who was snorkeling with me shout. I popped my head above water and caught only a fragment of his declaration in the slosh of waves: “Monster in a hole.”

headline: An Aimless Sailing Trip Off Palawan
text: Cutting anchor from civilization and all its modern amenities by exploring some of the most remote islands in the Philippines.

headline: White Trumps Black in Urban Cool Contest
text: One hundred seventy degrees Fahrenheit is the approximate temperature to which chicken should be cooked. It’s also the temperature that was recorded on some asphalt roofs in New York City last July during a heat wave that set a record for electricity use.

headline: Nuclear Disaster in Japan Was Avoidable, Critics Contend
text: TOKYO — A year after a huge earthquake and tsunami caused nearly catastrophic meltdowns at a nuclear plant, Japan is still grappling with a crucial question: was the accident simply the result of an unforeseeable natural disaster or something that could have been prevented?

headline: Perry Jones III Gets His Postseason
text: A year ago, the magazine published my cover story on Perry Jones III, then a freshman basketball star at Baylor University and a top N.B.A. prospect. That same week, the N.C.A.A. announced that it was suspending him for receiving improper benefits — primarily, modest sums of money lent by his summer-league coach to his mother so his impoverished family could stay in its home. Jones was not even aware of the loans, which had been paid back.

headline: A Memorable Ride
text: The children of “Soul Train,” glued to the TV Saturday mornings, reminisce about what the show — its music, its fashion, its spirit — meant to them growing up.

headline: Reviewing the Mazda 3
text: In Sunday’s Automobiles section, Lawrence Ulrich reviews the 2012 Mazda 3, the first car from the automaker to be sold in the United States with Mazda’s Skyactiv suite of efficiency-bolstering technologies.

headline: Midair Surprises, and Other Special Effects
text: There is a distinguishing wit about Pam Tanowitz’s choreography. Without trying to make her audience laugh, she seems to have a rare instinct for how steps, positions and groupings can be connected or taken apart to inventive, entertaining and surprising effect. Meanwhile, her keen feeling for footwork keeps supplying a bubbling stream of air into her dances.

headline: Don Cornelius, Host of ‘Soul Train,’ and His Legacy
text: With his sharp suits, exuberant Afro and too-cool-for-school demeanor, he was revered by generations of Americans, black and white.

headline: The Children of Old Tehran Go Hollywood
text: That “Shahs of Sunset,” a reality show about affluent, not-so-young Iranian-Americans in Los Angeles, is coming out while war with Iran is being discussed might seem opportunistic. But “Shahs” could actually serve a valuable function. You can imagine the average contemporary Iranian watching it and thinking: “Ah, that’s why we needed the revolution. To get rid of these people.”

headline: When the Music Stopped for Don Cornelius
text: LOS ANGELES

headline: That ’70s Style, Reinvented
text: Sometimes the road to a hit single starts with a drink to calm the nerves. A year ago Nate Ruess, the frontman of the pop-rock trio Fun., was anxious about meeting Jeff Bhasker, the producer and hit maker behind artists including Kanye West and Beyoncé, so he arrived early at the bar in the Bowery Hotel on the Lower East Side “and had a little to drink just to make sure I was loosened up.”

headline: Will There Be “Pink Slime” in Your Child’s School Lunch?
text: “Pink Slime:” it’s tasty (well, probably not), nutritious (oops, not that either) and cheap (got that right) and it’s probably found in a hamburger near you. Most particularly, in the hamburger or cheeseburger that almost certainly graced the lunch menu at your child’s school this month.

headline: Your Standard Grandeur, and a Touch of Modern Grit
text: There is a dull, quotidian sheen to the phrase “standard repertory,” although it’s primarily the more extraordinary works that are eventually categorized as such. There is of course nothing “standard” about much of Beethoven’s sublime music, unless the performance is stale.

headline: Closing the Gap Between Rich and Poor
text: To the Editor:

headline: Week in Pictures for March 9
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include a dispute over a winning lottery ticket, and a replica of Michelangelo’s David making its way into Manhattan.

headline: A Candidate’s Character
text: To the Editor:

headline: Making Money Keeping Marriage Sexy
text: HowAboutWe started like a typical dating site, targeting lonely singletons.

headline: Netanyahu’s Restraint
text: To the Editor:

headline: A True Bistro, and a Destination
text: ALAIN’S BISTRO is in a particularly unattractive span of Nyack — a small, generic strip mall just off the highway and not far from the Tappan Zee Bridge. But you’ll see the restaurant’s glow before you even enter. And once in, you will be quickly enveloped by a welcoming, warm sensibility.

headline: Nine-Person Team to Decide Fate of Mets’ Owners
text: The federal judge presiding over the trial of the Mets’ owners said Friday that a nine-person jury will decide if the men willfully blinded themselves to signs that Bernard L. Madoff may have been engaged in illicit activity during their many years of investing with him.

headline: Giants Release Jacobs; Should Jets Consider Signing Him?
text: Brandon Jacobs, who always said what he thought — not always pleasing fans with his play or with his mouth — but who ultimately helped the Giants win two Super Bowls as a bulldozing running back, was released by the team on Friday.

headline: Nardelli Steps Down From Most of His Cerberus Roles
text: Robert L. Nardelli is ending his formal ties to Cerberus Capital Management, the private equity firm that installed him as the chief executive of Chrysler nearly two years before the carmaker filed for bankruptcy.

headline: California’s Depression
text: To the Editor:

headline: Paying for Contraception
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Winning Layout in Australia
text: When an expert declarer is in a contract that looks hopeless, he will look for a winning layout. His play won’t always work, but sometimes it will, and then he will probably be mentioned in bridge news.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Sun Spot
text: While there were many conflicting statements, fashion did its historical job of mirroring the world of today, which is a jumble.

headline: Oh, to Bring ‘Gold’ Home, and Perhaps the Bacon
text: DRESSED all in black, their silhouettes stark against the sparkling white ice, Meryl Davis and Charlie White, the only American ice dancing team to ever win the world championships, zoom around the rink, their bodies perfectly synchronized as they twirl, glide, step and spin, first to a samba and later to Strauss.

headline: Off Broadway Faces Perils of Prosperity
text: The lamentations over the slow death of commercial Off Broadway theater have subsided, at least for a while. It’s true that over the past decade the city has lost at least a half-dozen spaces once devoted to presenting new work unsuitable for Broadway, including the Variety Arts in the East Village, the Promenade Theater on the Upper West Side (now a Sephora) and the Century Center off Union Square. I suppose we can consider it a happy coincidence that none has become a Duane Reade. The result has sometimes been a stampede to Broadway by shows that by all rights should remain Off Broadway. Witness the recent quick flop of the musical “Lysistrata Jones.”

headline: We’ll Always Have Darth
text: “DADDY, let’s play ‘Star Wars.’ I’ll be Dark Vader. This is my light saver.”

headline: One Year Later, Egyptian Women Subjected to ‘Virginity Tests’ Await Justice
text: Egyptian protesters had a grim anniversary on Friday, one year after soldiers cleared demonstrators from Cairo’s Tahrir Square, and forcibly subjected some female detainees to “virginity tests.”

headline: The Adventure Ends, So Take a Good Look
text: When Commander Shepard set out in 2007’s Mass Effect to establish humanity’s place in the cosmos and protect our species from extinction, no one knew if a video game could deliver a science-fiction saga to rival the best of television and film.

headline: When Today’s Deal Is Tomorrow’s Regret
text: HOW much is a $150 coupon worth? For Matt Sumell, the cost turned out to be one new relationship, as well as a little bit of pride.

headline: Each Teacher Wonders, Is This the One?
text: A WEEK and a half ago, the day after the school shooting near Cleveland, a student stood in the doorway of my Bronx college classroom. He was eating half a bagel with cream cheese. It was a month into the semester, 45 minutes into the class period. I didn’t remember ever having seen him before.

headline: A Card-Counting Mix of Bibles, Blackjack and Cash
text: Colin Jones has toiled in the cacophonous, windowless, artificially lighted corridors of casinos across the country in an effort to beat the house with math. He has worked to master the art of card counting, long scorned by casino operators, in which players try to gain an advantage over a blackjack dealer by keeping track of all the cards seen, and then adjusting their bets.

headline: Letters
text: Therapeutic Thoughts

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,892 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American this week:

headline: Raising a Pint to Style and Substance
text: ST. PATRICK’S DAY is not the only occasion for lifting a pint, but it is certainly one of the grandest. Whether you are looking to celebrate the day or the year in general, you might try one of these tavern restaurants. All offer great beers in convivial settings.

headline: Seven Testify to Character of Defendant in Rutgers Dorm Case
text: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J. — Several acquaintances of a former Rutgers University student who is accused of using a webcam to spy on his roommate having a sexual encounter with another man testified on Friday that they had never heard the defendant say anything disparaging about gay people.

headline: Friday Night Music: Sarah Jarosz Does Edgar Allan Poe
text: Update: Yes, I do know how to spell Poe’s name, but not, apparently, while riding New Jersey Transit.

headline: M.L.S. Preview: Five Questions for Commissioner Don Garber
text: Don Garber took over a teetering 12-team league when he was hired as Major League Soccer’s commissioner in 1999, and saw it reduced to 10 clubs two years later. In the decade since, he has diversified its ownership, overhauled its finances and built a foundation that has made the league an established player in the North American sports landscape, with 19 teams, a national television contracts in the U.S. and Canada, and a string of player development success stories ranging from Clint Dempsey and Carlos Bocanegra to Jozy Altidore and Brek Shea. On the eve of the league’s season openers, he answered, via email, questions from the Goal blog. For more from Garber, you can follow him on Twitter @thesoccerdon.

headline: Political Geography: Kansas
text: On the Republican nominating calendar, Kansas is among the most favorable stops for Rick Santorum, the former Pennsylvania senator.

headline: A Hockey Trailblazer Who Missed His Chance
text: His memory had dimmed, and glaucoma had robbed him of sight. At 92, Herb Carnegie was living in an assisted-care home in northern Toronto.

headline: Kony’s Victims and the Kony 2012 Video
text: The recent Kony 2012 viral video has attracted widespread controversy, as well as scrutiny of the organization Invisible Children. While it has stirred questions about the role of westerners advocating to end mass atrocities in Africa, as well as useful dialogue on non-profit fiscal management, the debate has obscured the key point. Joseph Kony’s immediate capture and delivery to the International Criminal Court (ICC) would be an unambiguous victory for humanity. It is the solution for which affected Africans have desperately, unanimously pleaded.

headline: Though One More Rally Is Set, a Protest Wanes in Post-Election Russia
text: MOSCOW — Excessive cheerfulness is not a trait generally associated with Russians, and Russian intellectuals in particular, which is one reason this city’s three-month-old opposition movement has been so unusual.

headline: Unlikely Star Shines in the Big Ten
text: INDIANAPOLIS — It’s a good thing the rise of Jeremy Lin has prepared the public for anything. During Wisconsin’s 79-71 victory over Indiana in the quarterfinals of the Big Ten tournament Friday, a small group of Badgers fans began chanting, “M.V.P, M.V.P.,” as the unheralded senior guard Rob Wilson went to the free-throw line.

headline: Vonn Caps Title Run by Mastering a Weakness
text: That Lindsey Vonn won her fourth World Cup overall championship on Friday was not surprising. The victory was historic — she is now second in overall titles among female skiers — but Vonn this year has so dominated her competition that the race has been anticlimactic for months.

headline: Wary but Loyal, Aide Answered Call From Giffords to Run
text: TUCSON — When Gabrielle Giffords began her first run for Congress in 2005, Ron Barber retired from his job and volunteered to help her. When she took office, Mr. Barber immediately signed on as her district director, hiring local staff members and arranging her events back home.

headline: A Thai Journey Down Memory Lane
text: WANIDA REID took a roundabout route to opening a restaurant. Born into a political family in Bangkok, she remembers lingering in the kitchen and helping the housekeeper prepare food for her parents’ frequent dinner parties. As a teenager she immigrated to New York to live with an aunt and took the surname of her uncle, a military officer. Before long, she had enlisted in the Army herself, working as a translator in Japan. Later, she studied cosmetology, did some modeling and ran a series of beauty salons, while raising a daughter and traveling the world at every opportunity.

headline: Pitcher by Trade, Barber by Skill
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — When the Mets traded for Ramon Ramirez this winter, they got a right-hander with a lively fastball, a deceptive delivery and a good command of a pair of scissors.

headline: The Phony Settlement
text: Forgive me for repeating myself, but I’m going to start this column with an anecdote about Ken Feinberg that I’ve told before.

headline: A Breach of Trust
text: The hard-fought deal that settled last year’s debt-ceiling fight made painfully deep cuts in spending, but it promised one thing: a year’s peace from the destructive Congressional battles that led to threats of government shutdowns and defaults. By signing the pact, Republican and Democratic leaders set spending levels for 2013, putting off further budget wars until after the election.

headline: YouTube Subtracts Racy and Raucous to Add a Teaching Tool
text: Educators are giving YouTube — long dismissed as a storehouse of whimsical, time-wasting and occasionally distasteful videos — another look. As Google, YouTube’s parent company, fine-tunes a portal that lets schools limit students’ access to selected content, the video-sharing Web site is gaining popularity as a trove of free educational materials.

headline: From Nickname to Label
text: At Martha Clara Vineyards in Riverhead, the principal owner, Robert Entenmann, 83, is nicknamed Five-O.

headline: Pad Thai, and a Whole Lot More
text: PAD THAI, the dish that defines Thai food for many people, is often a disappointment: overly sweet, dry or just plain dull. Not so at Mukda Thai Cuisine in Hicksville. Here, the stir-fry of rice noodles is only slightly sweet, and the meat in it — we ordered chicken — exceptionally moist. Best of all, it is served with a wedge of lime for an acidic counterpoint and with bean sprouts that provide crunch and a fresh taste.

headline: Changing the Chemistry of Earth’s Oceans
text: The oceans have always served as a sink for carbon dioxide, but the burning of fossil fuels since the beginning of the industrial revolution, especially over the last 40 years, has given them more than they can safely absorb. The result is acidification — a change in the chemical balance that threatens the oceans’ web of life.

headline: Losing It All for Another Drink
text: For Lee Remick, it was the brandy Alexanders. Admirers of the 1962 film “Days of Wine and Roses” remember that her character, a bright-eyed late-Eisenhower-era executive secretary, never touches alcohol until a charming, single public relations man (Jack Lemmon) comes along and introduces her to that particular dessert-sweet drink. So it may come as a surprise, in the Schoolhouse Theater’s worthy production of the story, to see that character repeatedly swigging from a bottle of vodka in her first scene.

headline: Two Screws Were No Match for a Brazen Subway Art Thief
text: A skateboarder, a rabbi, a balloon lady, an accordion player, a crying baby, a fisherman and a guy in a bear suit step onto the subway.

headline: In a Flurry of Birdies, Watson and Rose Dismantle Doral
text: DORAL, Fla. — The renovation of Doral’s Blue Monster started a year early, the vision and tools wielded by the fanciful golfer Bubba Watson and not the noted architect Gil Hanse, whom the property’s new owner, Donald Trump, has entrusted with the project.

headline: Better Numbers
text: The job market is showing slow and steady improvement. In February, 227,000 jobs were added. It was the 24th straight month of private-sector job gains, and the third month in a row of gains well above 200,000, the best three-month stretch in nearly two years.

headline: Duke Is Short on the Court, but on Top in the Win Column
text: ATLANTA — For a few possessions here Friday night, it looked as if Duke might not get a rebound that did not hit the ground first.

headline: Despite the Army’s Obstruction, Egyptians Work to Build a Democracy
text: CAIRO

headline: Doubts Grew Slowly Over a Palate Above Suspicion
text: Rudy Kurniawan was always the authority on fraudulent wines.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: March 9, 2012

headline: The Week’s Business News in Pictures
text: China’s forecast of a relatively modest 7.5 percent growth rate suggests that its decades of growth may be winding down. In Texas, a jury convicted the financier R. Allen Stanford in a $7 billion fraud, and Greece won bondholders’ approval for a debt restructuring.

headline: Harry Wendelstedt, Umpire in Five World Series, Dies at 73
text: Harry Wendelstedt, who was an umpire in five World Series during a 33-year major league career and who taught hundreds of aspiring professional umpires at his Florida school, died on Friday in Daytona Beach, not far from Ormond Beach, where the school is based and where he lived. He was 73.

headline: Twin Spotlights on Dance
text: NEWARK

headline: The Bad News Is Good News
text: There was one brief shining moment last week when Mitt Romney appeared to be saying something sensible about sex.

headline: Bearcats Arrive, and Orange Exit
text: Most of Cincinnati’s quiet run toward the upper tier of the Big East standings has been motivated by an effort to erase the stain of an incident in the season’s second month: an ugly brawl with intracity rival Xavier that resulted in four suspensions for both teams.

headline: Mitt, Grits and Grit
text: “I’m learning to say ‘y’all,’ and I like grits. Things, strange things are happening to me.”

headline: N.Y.U.’s Plan for Expansion Draws Anger in Community
text: It is perhaps the largest project ever proposed for Greenwich Village, and it has angered many residents in the area as few issues have recently. Opponents say the development would mar one of New York’s signature neighborhoods.

headline: Austin, Proud of Eccentricity, Loses a Favorite
text: Every city has its characters, but other places tend to tolerate them with a smirk or a sneer. In Austin, Tex., it’s more of an embrace.

headline: Fighting War Crimes, Without Leaving the Couch?
text: Do social media campaigns like “Kony 2012” give young people a false sense of accomplishment, detracting from real action?

headline: Discreetly Digital, Erotic Novel Sets American Women Abuzz
text: “Fifty Shades of Grey,” an erotic novel by an obscure author that has been described as “Mommy porn” and “Twilight” for grown-ups, has electrified women across the country, who have spread the word like gospel on Facebook pages, at school functions and in spin classes. Or as the handwritten tag on a paperback copy in a Montclair, N.J., bookstore helpfully noted, “Yes, this is THE book everyone is talking about.”

headline: From Private to Public
text: The successful private debt swap by the Greek government will leave most of its debt in the hands of public sector lenders.

headline: Corrections: March 10
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Jewish Film Festival Has Local Ties
text: DURING its first 15 years, the Hartford Jewish Film Festival established itself as an international heavyweight, growing from five films to about two dozen features and documentaries focused on Jewish issues. This year’s festival, the 16th, comes with a strong local bent, with at least three Connecticut residents speaking about their involvement in a particular film immediately after its screening.

headline: Freed From Bondage, Into a Nowhere Land
text: Little-known fact: the day after the end of the Civil War coincided with the start of Passover. Jews in the North and Jews in the South sat down at their Seder tables to commemorate the release of the Israelites from bondage in Egypt. As Matthew Lopez posits in his tough and evocative play “The Whipping Man,” some of those Passover celebrants must have been Southerners who had themselves only just been freed.

headline: Taking a Mulligan
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — What a nice surprise on a Saturday. I love the ocean, and opening with something that made me think of the EBB AND FLOW of the tide is a mesmerizing way to gain a toehold in the toughest grid of the week.

headline: Principal Is Removed Over Findings of Falsified Student Records
text: The principal of a Bronx middle and high school was removed from the school on Friday after the New York City Education Department found that for years, the staff had falsified student transcripts and given credit for courses not taken. The practice led to an artificially high graduation rate and students’ receiving diplomas they had not earned.

headline: Thin Men and Other Signature Works of a Long Career
text: Riverhead, N.Y.

headline: Solid in Kansas, Santorum Seeks to Build Margin
text: WICHITA, Kan. — “We chased all the candidates out of Kansas!” Rick Santorum boomed as he took the podium one day before Saturday’s caucuses in the state, which his two leading rivals are not seriously pursuing.

headline: Signs of Encouragement in the Jobs Reports
text: Jobs are up again but long-term unemployment has edged down.

headline: A Keeper of a Vast Garden of Art in the Hills of Brazil
text: BRUMADINHO, Brazil

headline: Knicks, Unable to Contain Bucks, Lose Fourth Straight
text: MILWAUKEE — Losing at Boston, Dallas and San Antonio is one thing. Dropping a key midseason game at Milwaukee, where the Bucks had only won twice in their last nine home games, is another.

headline: Answers to Questions About New York
text: Photographer in the Sky

headline: Ad Campaign for Marines Cites Chaos as a Job Perk
text: The war in Iraq is over, the troop reduction in Afghanistan is under way and America’s next war front is far from clear. If you are a military recruiter, how do market your product?

headline: Health Care Exchange Rules to Be Set
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration is about to carry out a major provision of the new health care law by issuing standards for health insurance exchanges, the markets where consumers and small businesses will be able to buy coverage from competing private plans.

headline: Separation Anxiety Over Lost Anchor(s)
text: She came from Harlem, her broadcasts exemplifying the spirit of the city she served: vibrant, feisty, occasionally profane.

headline: Nazareth Gets Revenge and Shot at Another Title
text: After losing its city basketball crown earlier this month, Nazareth appears to have regained solid footing as it seeks to defend its state title.

headline: Tips From Airline Menu Makers
text: Airlines are investing in the meals they serve in their upper-class cabins by hiring star chefs and experimenting with flavors. Some experts talk about what they’ve learned.

headline: Vying for Campus President, Illegal Immigrant Gets a Gamut of Responses
text: COLLEGE STATION, Tex. — Jose Luis Zelaya stood with a crowd of other students waiting to hear the news. It was election day at Texas A&M University here, and he was running for student body president. A victory for Mr. Zelaya, a 24-year-old graduate student from Honduras, would make history at Texas A&M: He would become its first Hispanic student body president — and the first illegal immigrant to hold the position.

headline: The Ways of the Jedi
text: In a Midtown rehearsal space, Flynn Michael teaches lightsaber skills and finding the hero within.

headline: On 50-Year-Old Tape, Sounds of Mets’ Awkward First Steps
text: It was 50 years ago Saturday that the Mets played their initial spring training game, an 8-0 loss to the St. Louis Cardinals. There was nothing surprising in that result, considering the Mets went on to win only 40 games all season, a record for futility that still stands.

headline: Training New Jedis in the Force
text: ON a recent weeknight, Flynn Michael walked through his Jedi academy, a dimly lighted room not in some galaxy far, far away, but rather in a rehearsal space overlooking a death star of traffic on Eighth Avenue in Midtown Manhattan.

headline: In Uganda, Few Can See Kony Video
text: KAMPALA, Uganda — Uganda’s Public Enemy No. 1, Joseph Kony, became an overnight Internet sensation to the rest of the world this week, but many here knew little or nothing about the explosive online campaign.

headline: German Leader and I.M.F. Chief Split Over Debt
text: BERLIN — With a deal on Greek debt finally done, Europe will shift its attention to two of its most powerful women, friends who have dueling views about what needs to be done to prevent future Greek-like meltdowns from spreading to other economies.

headline: India Eyes Muslims Left Behind by Quota System
text: MUZAFFARNAGAR, India — Along the narrow lane known as Khadar Wallah, Muslims and low-caste Hindus have lived side by side for years, bound by poverty, if not religion. Yet recently, Muslims like Murtaza Mansuri have noticed a change. Their neighbors have become better off.

headline: Hatch Weighs In on Tax Status of ‘Super PACs’
text: Senator Orrin Hatch, Republican of Utah, joined the fight over the tax status of “Super PACS” on Friday, accusing Senate Democrats of a “politically motivated witch hunt” for their efforts to rein in tax-exempt political groups.

headline: The Science of Hanging Out
text: For Danielle Goldman, 17, a senior at the Bronx High School of Science, Sunday begins on Friday night, when she finishes her homework so she’ll have the weekend free. “I don’t wait till the last minute,” she said. This work ethic — along with a project that studied neurotransmitter levels in adolescents with mood disorders — helped make her one of 40 finalists in this year’s Intel Science Talent Search, which concludes on Tuesday. A $100,000 award will go to the winner. She lives in Astoria, Queens, with her parents and the family’s parrot, Puppy. She plans to attend Columbia College.

headline: Netanyahu Says U.S. and Israeli ‘Clocks’ Differ on Iran’s Threat
text: JERUSALEM — Addressing his home audience after talks with President Obama in Washington this week, the prime minister of Israel, Benjamin Netanyahu, acknowledged that differences still existed in the Israeli and American timetables for contending with the Iranian nuclear program.

headline: Rangers Sustain Third Loss in a Row
text: CHICAGO — The Rangers are coming home, and not a moment too soon, because they are reeling now.

headline: Peter Bergman, Satirist With the Firesign Theater, Dies at 72
text: Peter Bergman, a founding member of the surrealist comedy troupe Firesign Theater, whose albums became cult favorites among college students in the late 1960s and ’70s for a brand of sly, multilayered satire so dense it seemed riddled with non sequiturs until the second, third or 30th listening, died on Friday in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 72.

headline: With Extension to Sanchez, Jets Give Up on Manning
text: The Jets committed to a franchise quarterback on Friday night — their own. They bowed out of the Peyton Manning sweepstakes with a flourish, agreeing with Mark Sanchez on a new five-year contract that could be worth as much as $68.5 million. It is a handsome reward for a player whose progress stagnated last season, when the Jets lost the final three games and missed the playoffs.

headline: Crime, Queens and Escaping Slavery
text: IN “The Gods of Gotham” (Amy Einhorn Books, $25.95), the novelist Lyndsay Faye draws on the historian Tyler Anbinder’s “Five Points,” original newspaper accounts, other nonfiction and the argot of the age to vividly conjure mid-19th-century New York.

headline: Leonardo Cimino Dies at 94; Distinctive Actor
text: Leonardo Cimino, who once thought his singular appearance would make an acting career improbable but who ended up spending more than 60 years as an in-demand character actor whose roles included gangsters, grandfathers, the pope, Vincent van Gogh and “Scary German Guy,” died on March 3 at his home in Woodstock, N.Y. He was 94.

headline: Britain: Court Hands Qaddafi Son’s Mansion to Libya
text: The Libyan government won a court order on Friday granting it possession of a $16 million London mansion bought by the playboy son of the former Libyan leader Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi with what a high court judge ruled were stolen Libyan government funds. The eight-bedroom house, with an indoor swimming pool, whirlpool bath and suede-lined home cinema, was bought by Saadi Qaddafi, 38, only months before the Arab Spring protests erupted that led to the overthrow of his father. Mr. Qaddafi, now in Niger, had a reputation of using the London house for cocaine parties and entertaining prostitutes, according to bodyguards who worked at the house.

headline: Frisner Augustin, Haitian Vodou Drummer, Dies at 63
text: Frisner Augustin, a Haitian vodou master drummer whose deep knowledge of traditional rhythms and leadership of the Brooklyn-based Troupe Makandal made him a major force in preserving and popularizing his Afro-Haitian heritage, died on Feb. 28 in Port-au-Prince, Haiti. He was 63.

headline: Kingmaker of Little Russia
text: COUNCILMAN LEWIS A. FIDLER peers at the audience in a low-ceilinged room on Coney Island Avenue with the expectant smile of the newly betrothed.

headline: The Power to Kill
text: President Obama, who came to office promising transparency and adherence to the rule of law, has become the first president to claim the legal authority to order an American citizen killed without judicial involvement, real oversight or public accountability.

headline: Louisville Defense Overwhelms Fighting Irish
text: A relentless Louisville defense dismantled third-seeded Notre Dame, 64-50, in the second semifinal of the Big East men’s basketball tournament on Friday night.

headline: A Comeback of Olympian Proportions
text: INDIAN WELLS, Calif. — In a late match on Court 7 of the BNP Paribas Open Thursday evening, an eight-time Grand Slam champion was quietly playing the biggest match of her comeback.

headline: Scenes From a Dying Empire
text: “Any time wall texts are mounted next to the works in an exhibition, a familiar tension arises between words and images, reading and seeing,” Martha Schwendener wrote in The New York Times. There is some danger of this with the art exhibition “Princes and Painters in Mughal Delhi, 1707-1857,” because the context in which the images were made is so complex that it requires explanation, she writes.

headline: Ohio: Rules Tightened for Wells
text: State officials on Friday instituted stricter rules for oil and gas industry disposal wells like one that scientists have linked to minor earthquakes in Youngstown. The rules, contained in a report by the Ohio Department of Natural Resources, will require a well owner to conduct and analyze geophysical tests on a new well before disposal begins and will prohibit drilling into deep Precambrian rocks that are more likely to contain seismic faults. The report found a “compelling argument” that the quakes in Youngstown since last March were induced by the disposal of waste liquids from the drilling process called hydraulic fracturing. The state will require the installation of pressure monitoring systems at all wells and electronic record-keeping by trucking firms that bring the waste liquids to the wells.

headline: Wars Over Regulation of Rent Are Only a Sideshow
text: With a certain regularity, New Yorkers are given the opportunity to engage in a satisfyingly maddening if futile pastime: decrying the obscenities of rent regulation.

headline: Reserve Bank Moves to Stimulate Economy
text: “In a move meant to relieve growing stress in its financial system,” India’s central bank on Friday sharply reduced the amount of money banks have to hold in reserve, Vikas Bajaj writes in The New York Times. The action came ahead of a scheduled policy meeting at which the bank was expected to cut the reserve ratio, but less sharply, he writes.

headline: Events in New Jersey
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: India Eyes Muslims Left Behind by Quota System
text: “Along the narrow lane known as Khadar Wallah, Muslims and low-caste Hindus have lived side by side for years, bound by poverty, if not religion,” Jim Yardley writes in The New York Times. “Yet recently, Muslims like Murtaza Mansuri have noticed a change. Their neighbors have become better off.”

headline: Events in Westchester
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: Events in Connecticut
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.
