text: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: In the Hills of Brazil, an Oasis of Contemporary Art
text: A look at Inhotim, a contemporary 5,000-acre art complex in the hills of southeast Brazil.

headline: Government Bail Letter: Rudy Kurniawan
text: A U.S. attorney request that a judge deny Rudy Kurniawan bail asserting that he poses a risk of flight.

headline: Close Friends on a Collision Course Over Europe
text: Christine Lagarde, the head of the International Monetary Fund, who is French, and Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany are close. “They are on a first-name basis,” write Nicholas Kulish and Annie Lowrey. “They frequently exchange text messages. Shortly after Christmas, Ms. Lagarde brought Ms. Merkel a trinket from Hermès and received a recording of the Berlin Philharmonic playing Beethoven from Ms. Merkel, a classical music lover.”

headline: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
text: Jammu and Kashmir: Chief Minister Omar Abdullah said on Friday that militancy in the state during the past two decades has orphaned more than 26,000 children and widowed more than 8,000 women, Kashmir Live reports. He also said the state government is considering the idea of creating a Truth and Reconciliation Commission to inquire into the “alleged cases of forced disappearances” from the state, but it still needs a “consensus from other stakeholders” including the central government, the newspaper reports.

headline: The Boss Pays Tribute to Soul, and Rocks the Apollo, Too
text: Bruce Springsteen thrilled a crowd of V.I.P.’s at the Apollo Theater in Harlem on Friday night, stomping through the angry folk-rock tunes from his new album, giving the crowd muscular versions of hits from his early career and doing a few soul tunes to honor the place where he was standing.

headline: Peyton Manning’s Free-Agent Tour Starts in Denver
text: Peyton-palooza touched down in Denver on Friday for the first visit of Peyton Manning’s free-agent tour. The Broncos, who captivated the N.F.L. last season when they made  the playoffs with Tim Tebow at quarterback, are said to be a serious contender for Manning, who would allow team executive John Elway to gracefully transition the team away from the option offense it had to run with Tebow, without alienating the hordes of Tebow fans who clamored for him to start last season.

headline: Beyond Mile-High Grub: Can Airline Food Be Tasty?
text: ONE of the world’s busiest airports, Hartsfield-Jackson in Atlanta, lies a mere 1,026 feet above sea level. Which, it turns out, is perfect for your taste buds.

headline: Your Airline Food Experiences
text: If you’re traveling domestically in an airline’s coach class, a hot meal may seem like an increasingly distant memory — and perhaps not a fond one. Even for passengers in first and business classes, who still expect dining to be part of the flight, serving up appetizing cuisine is no easy feat for the airlines. High altitude can dull the taste buds and present particular challenges in food storage and preparation.

headline: Depth Makes Vancouver a Dark Horse in M.L.S.
text: The absence of relegation in Major League Soccer means that a team can become champions one year after finishing at the bottom of the pile. Landon Donovan and Dwayne De Rosario sparked the San Jose Earthquakes past the Los Angeles Galaxy in the 2001 M.L.S. Cup final a year after the Earthquakes finished last. Donovan almost repeated the feat with Los Angeles.

headline: The Early Word: Jobs

headline: From Jets to Sanchez: When an Extension Looks Like an Apology
text: Did the Jets just say sorry to Mark Sanchez by adding three years and $40.5 million to his contract?

headline: The Endangered Mediterranean Diet
text: LONDON — Spanish doctors meeting in Madrid this week have sounded the latest warning that the country’s traditional Mediterranean diet is under threat.

headline: Redskins Bet Future on Trade to Acquire Robert Griffin
text: As the Jets began a late-night conference call to announce that quarterback Mark Sanchez had agreed to a contract extension, signaling their withdrawal from the pursuit of Peyton Manning, multiple reports said the Washington Redskins, who also were interested in Manning, had completed a blockbuster trade to acquire the second overall draft pick from the St. Louis Rams.

headline: Students Seek Books For a Peopled Planet
text: I’m in the early stages of designing a crowd-shaped-and-shared online learning tool on the core issues shaping the human journey in this century (i.e., the issues at the right side of Dot Earth’s homepage). You can call it a syllabus, an online textbook, a course.

headline: The Lonesome Ghosts of a City’s Past
text: “To me, they’re almost like a sleepwalker’s view of the city,” the filmmaker Jem Cohen said of the ghostly Polaroids he has taken of New York over the past 30 years. “I might walk around for a whole night, but only shoot one or two pictures.”

headline: Worth the Cost of the Trip for the Ropa Vieja Alone
text: In the year since restrictions on travel to Cuba were eased for those on cultural exchange itineraries, new trips to the island have focused on art, history and music. Now there’s one for foodies.

headline: Q.P.R.’s Ghost Goal
text: One week after the International Football Association Board voted to continue testing goal-line technology, an apparent goal by Clint Hill of Queens Park Rangers went unrewarded Saturday at Bolton. To make matters worse for Q.P.R., relegation-threatened Bolton scored a late goal to win, 2-1, in England’s Premier League.

headline: The Swedish One Percent
text: Via Mark Thoma, Daron Acemoglu and James Robinson react to Allan Meltzer claiming that the top one percent is surging everywhere, even in Sweden, so it’s not a proper political issue.

headline: Anti-Putin Protesters Struggle to Keep Up Steam
text: MOSCOW — Thousands of people thronged a concourse along a main street in Moscow on Saturday to denounce President-elect Vladimir V. Putin and to cry out together, one more time, for political freedom. They waved the flags of opposition parties, in a kaleidoscopic swirl; wore white ribbons that said, “Russia demands change”; and chanted now-familiar refrains: “Russia without Putin!” and “Russia will be free!”

headline: The Stupid, It Freezes
text: I don’t look at the WSJ much these days; it really has gone downhill since you-know-who took over, and I find that I almost never find anything there that isn’t covered better either in the Times or in the FT.

headline: Things Money Can and Cannot Buy Revive the 76ers
text: PHILADELPHIA — The itinerary was a sports fan’s dream: Friday in Miami to watch the resurgent 76ers play the Heat; hop on a private jet to Atlanta to catch the 76ers take on the Hawks on Saturday; head to Indianapolis for the Super Bowl on Sunday; then rush to Philadelphia to see the 76ers play the Los Angeles Lakers at home.

headline: Teixeira’s Work on Bunt Has Helped His Swing

headline: Variety: A  Somewhat Cranky Acrostic
text: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE — The author of today’s quote wrote a series of books detailing the everyday life in Canada of his character Samuel Marchbanks. Marchbanks lived a simple life and spent his time humorously pondering many of the things we still wonder about today. In fact, the beginning of the passage that contains today’s quote reads as follows:

headline: Mets Infield Prospect Hounded By a Perplexing Run of Injuries
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — The last time Reese Havens was able to practice with his teammates was Feb. 28. The next morning, he walked into the Mets’ spring training complex and told the manager that he had been feeling soreness in his back.

headline: N.C.A.A. Builds Solid Brackets From a Shaky Foundation
text: The N.C.A.A., tired of hearing criticism from data geeks and television commentators about how it selects and seeds the 68-team men’s basketball tournament, had a brilliant insight a couple of years ago. If these pundits were so smart, why not invite them into the process and see if they could do any better themselves?

headline: Fighting Continues in Syria
text: Syrian troops pushed ahead with a new assault on the northern region of Idlib on Saturday, shelling one of the centers of the uprising against President Bashar al-Assad’s rule and sending families fleeing for safety as armed rebels tried to fend off the attack.

headline: Lights! Cameras! (and Cheers) for a Rock Weighing 340 Tons
text: LOS ANGELES — It was 4:35 a.m. on Saturday when the block-long transporter carrying a 340-ton, 21-foot-high boulder wrapped in white plastic pulled up in front of the Los Angeles County Museum of Art.

headline: Everybody Wants a Piece of Nerlens Noel
text: EVERETT, Mass. — Nerlens Noel is a 6-foot-10 basketball star considered the best prospect from the Boston area since Patrick Ewing. He is the top-ranked high school senior in the country, and hailed as the best shot blocker of his generation. The 17-year-old son of working-class Haitian immigrants, he could be worth $10 million in about 16 months when he is eligible for the 2013 N.B.A draft.

headline: Deficits Push N.Y. Cities and Counties to Desperation
text: ALBANY — It was not a good week for New York’s cities and counties.

headline: WeatherMob, a Social Network Around the Local Forecast
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — A mobile social network built around the weather sounds as likely to be a hit as a social network around ailing pets or French cheeses. But after landing in a very gray and gloomy Austin for South by Southwest, the dreary weather has been among the hottest topics of conversation.

headline: For Rangers, a Chance to Sort Things Out
text: After losing three straight games on the road, the Rangers can take comfort knowing they will be in New York for 12 straight days.

headline: A Trip Inside the N.C.A.A. Bubble
text: With the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament approaching, Nate Silver was given the chance to step into the shoes of the selection committee, which chooses and seeds the 68 teams that will take part in March Madness. As it turns out, there is an element of statistical madness — the Ratings Percentage Index — embedded in the selection process itself. Read More.

headline: N.F.L. Free-for-All
text: Free agency after the lockout was a scramble last year once the new N.F.L. labor deal was signed. Teams were unsure when free agency would begin, and at least one front-office staff went home for the night to rest up for what it thought would be a frenzied start the next day, before racing back to the office when the league suddenly let the signings begin.

headline: Golfer Robert Rock Has a Head for the Game, but No Hat
text: DORAL, Fla. — In the two months since Robert Rock stared down Tiger Woods to win the Abu Dhabi Championship, many people have tipped their caps to him. They include the American real estate mogul Donald Trump, who introduced himself last week and complimented Rock on his game, his victory over Woods and his hair, which is thicker than Trump’s wallet.

headline: Sprinting to London, and Not the N.F.L.
text: NAMPA, Idaho — Florida running back Jeff Demps affirmed his decision to focus on a track career by skipping the N.F.L. combine last month.

headline: Hits, and Misses, in a War on Bribery

headline: Erving’s Record Forgotten, but Not Gone

The news was repeated in newspapers and on television and radio, where it was also reported that Williams “broke the Nets’ N.B.A. franchise record.”

headline: Remembering Japan’s Catastrophe
text: A year after a huge earthquake and tsunami caused nearly catastrophic meltdowns at a nuclear plant, Japan is still grappling with the crucial question of whether the disaster was avoidable.

text: The N.H.L. game today is played at a sprint, with line changes every 40 seconds and players crashing into one another at breakneck speeds, and the bodies have been piling up.

text: This interview with  Jim Whitehurst, president and chief executive of Red Hat, the provider of Linux and other open-source technology, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: Violence Continues for Israel and Militants
text: GAZA — Cross-border violence between Israel and militant groups in Gaza continued Saturday, as Israeli airstrikes that began Friday afternoon killed several more Palestinian militants and militant groups fired scores of rockets into southern Israel, breaking months of relative calm.

text: IF you saw $20 on the ground, would you stop to pick it up? Silly question.

headline: With Kara Goucher
text: One of the United States’ top female distance runners, Kara Goucher, gave birth to her son, Colt, in September 2010. Seven months later, she finished fifth at the 2011 Boston Marathon in 2 hours 24 minutes 52 seconds, her best time by a minute. A hip injury tempered the remainder of Goucher’s 2011 season, but she recovered sufficiently to finish third at the Olympic marathon trials in January in Houston, qualifying for the London Games with Shalane Flanagan and Desiree Davila.

text: THINK how convenient it would be if you could recharge electronic devices without ever having to plug them in — or even take them out of your briefcase.

text: Mike Conley’s no-nonsense style of playing point guard might not receive a lot of notice, but it has the Memphis Grizzlies climbing the Western Conference standings and starting to look like a team that no one will want to face come playoff time.

headline: As Security Concerns Remain, Christians Flee Iraq
text: Iraq’s dwindling numbers of Christians, driven from their homes by attacks and intimidation, are beginning to abandon the safe havens they had found in the country’s north, discouraged by unemployment and a creeping fear that the violence they had fled was catching up to them.

headline: Exodus From North Signals Iraqi Christians’ Slow Decline

headline: Catamounts Go Back to the Tournament
text: STONY BROOK, N.Y. — John Becker’s strange journey to the Vermont coaching job began 18 years ago in Washington. He was a part-time assistant coach at Gallaudet University, the nation’s leading college for the deaf and the hearing-impaired.

headline: Democrat Is Giving Up House Seat to Focus on Race for Governor

text: When Roron Chen went to a public clinic to try to see a doctor, she was put on the waiting list at the San Mateo Medical Center. A California state law requires counties to provide health care to people like Ms. Chen who cannot afford health insurance and have no other alternatives.

headline: William Hamilton Dies at 87; Known for ‘Death of God’
text: William Hamilton was a tenured professor of church history at a small divinity school in Rochester in April 1966 when Time magazine created a sensation with a cover article featuring some of the ideas he had been writing about for years in journals read mainly by ministers and theologians.

headline: Japan Finds Story of Hope in Undertaker Who Offered Calm Amid Disaster
text: KAMAISHI, Japan — Amid the grief of finding her mother’s body at a makeshift morgue in this tsunami-ravaged city last March, Fumie Arai took comfort in a small but surprising discovery. Unlike the rest of the muddied body, her mother’s face had been carefully wiped clean.

headline: 21 Days of Rage for Some EBay Sellers

headline: Maxwell S. Keith Dies at 87; Replacement Lawyer in Manson Case
text: Maxwell S. Keith, who defended two members of the so-called Manson family in their notorious cult murder trials, stepping in after the lawyer for one of them disappeared under mysterious circumstances, died on Tuesday in Templeton, Calif. He was 87.

headline: Smartphones Should Know Their Place at Work
text: Q. Your company allows employees to bring their own portable electronic devices — like phones and tablets — to the office. Does that mean you should feel free to use them whenever you see fit?

headline: Yotam Ottolenghi
text: Yotam Ottolenghi is an Israeli-born chef and cookbook author known for dishes that emphasize vegetables. He lives in London, where he and his Palestinian business partner own four  popular food shops and restaurants.

headline: Farewell to the Monkey House
text: THE Monkey House at the Bronx Zoo, oldest of the ornate Beaux-Arts animal houses that once lined the zoo’s stately, central Astor Court, closed late last month. Officially named the Primates’ House upon its opening in 1901, it was one of the last surviving remnants of the old city zoo. As with the Ape, Lion and Elephant Houses along Astor Court’s Neoclassical piazza (designed by Heins & La Farge, a firm best known for its elaborately tiled New York City subway stations) visitors entered through a portico limned with totemic terra-cotta animal carvings and action scenes up along the frieze. Once inside, we would pass a series of reeking, brashly lighted tiled rooms in which the only concessions to the exhibits’ natural homes were a chained log, a corner-propped limb and a front nameplate with a black dot on the silhouette of the captive’s native continent.

headline: The Go-Nowhere Generation
text: AMERICANS are supposed to be mobile and even pushy. Saul Bellow’s Augie March declares, “I am an American ... first to knock, first admitted.” In “The Grapes of Wrath,” young Tom Joad loads up his jalopy with pork snacks and relatives, and the family flees the Oklahoma dust bowl for sun-kissed California. Along the way, Granma dies, but the Joads keep going.

headline: Crosby May Play Against the Rangers
text: CANONSBURG, Pa. — Sidney Crosby will not make his long-awaited return from concussion and neck injuries in the Pittsburgh Penguins’ nationally televised Sunday matinee against the Boston Bruins.

headline: Nuclear Risk and Fear, from Hiroshima to Fukushima
text: Next month will see the publication of “The Rise of Nuclear Fear,” a fresh look at the history of perceptions of nuclear risk by the physicist and historian Spencer Weart, who builds this book on his 1988 work “Nuclear Fear: A History of Images.” Weart is best known to Dot Earth regulars as the author of the essential guide to 100 years of research pointing to a human influence on climate, “The Discovery of Global Warming” (here’s my 2003 review of that book for The Times).

headline: Lingerie and Enlightenment
text: ON my father’s side of the family were several generations of respected New York lawyers and judges. My maternal grandmother married the deacon of the Flatbush Dutch Reformed Church in Prospect Park in Brooklyn. Eventually, the borough took some of their family land by eminent domain to develop the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.

headline: Appeal of Death Row Case Is More Than a Matter of Guilt or Innocence
text: No one saw Rob Will shoot and kill Harris County Deputy Sheriff Barrett Hill in the still-black morning hours in a Houston bayou on Dec. 4, 2000. No physical evidence linked him to the murder.

headline: Elections Have Scandals, Even the Ones on Campus
text: Most politicians in Texas spent February awaiting final word on the state’s redrawn political maps. Court delays pushed the state’s primary date from Super Tuesday — when Texas could have exercised some influence — to the end of May.

headline: Not-So-Crazy Republicans

headline: Mitt’s Rich Predicament
text: MITT ROMNEY may be as close to a walking, talking dollar sign as presidential politics has ever witnessed. If money were made flesh, it would apparently have fair skin, flawless hair and an off-key tropism toward patriotic anthems.

headline: When States Put Out the Unwelcome Mat
text: There is one area, besides copper mining and home foreclosures, where Arizona is a national leader. It’s at the front of a movement by states and local governments to seize control of immigration from the federal government. In 2010 it passed a law, S.B. 1070, that made the mass deportation of undocumented immigrants its official policy with a grab bag of enforcement schemes that turned federal immigration infractions into state crimes. Among other things, the law required immigration checks by local police, required immigrants to carry papers with them, and made it illegal for the undocumented to live or look for work in the state, or for people to knowingly hire, harbor or transport them.

headline: Locals Try to Make Themselves Heard at SXSW
text: Bruce Springsteen & the E Street Band’s performance at a so-called intimate venue will most likely be the big story of this year’s South by Southwest. But another part of the SXSW tradition is discovering and championing new talent.

headline: Nuclear Fallout
text: I GREW up in Arvada, Colo., in the shadow of a nuclear bomb factory, so I read the just-released report on the Fukushima meltdown in Japan with special interest. Coinciding with the first anniversary of the Fukushima Daiichi disaster, the 400-page report details the extensive misinformation supplied to the public by the Tokyo Electric Power Company (Tepco) in collusion with Japanese officials.

headline: Pass the Books. Hold the Oil.

headline: Immigration Decreases, but Tensions Remain High
text: PHOENIX — The impact of steep declines in the number of migrants illegally crossing the border with Mexico in recent years has rippled across Arizona and other border states, with federal and local law enforcement seeing big drops in crime related to illegal immigration.

headline: Are You Now and Have You Always Been?
text: What a difference a redistricting can make. As he adjusts to a new, more Democratic district, Representative Timothy Johnson, an Illinois Republican, is trying to back out of the powerful orbit of Grover Norquist, the conservative antitax campaigner who has managed to corral 95 percent of House Republicans into signing a simplistic pledge to never, ever increase taxes.

headline: They Have Very Short Memories
text: House Republicans, Senate Democrats and President Obama have found something they can all support: a terrible package of bills that would undo essential investor protections, reduce market transparency and distort the efficient allocation of capital.

headline: East Oakland Park May Get a Third Act
text: In Tyrone Carney Park in East Oakland, there are no swings on the playground swing set. Rusted basketball rims loom over a cracked asphalt court, riddled with weeds. The abandoned park has become a dumping ground for discarded couches and plastic lawn furniture.

headline: Dickey Hit Hard by Nationals
text: VIERA, Fla. − After pitching flawlessly during his first spring training start, R.A. Dickey was hit hard Saturday by the Washington Nationals, giving up five runs in three innings. Dickey needed close to 30 pitches to get out of the first inning, and all the hits against him were hard, sharp liners that went for singles or doubles.

headline: Prisons Rethink Isolation, Saving Money, Lives and Sanity
text: PARCHMAN, Miss. — The heat was suffocating, and the inmates locked alone in cells in Unit 32, the state’s super-maximum-security prison, wiped away sweat as they lay on concrete slab beds.

headline: What I Learned From Getting Knocked Around
text: I KNEW nothing about football when I started playing sophomore year in high school, but patient coaches made it clear that the answer to most questions I had about their beautifully complicated sport was that I should run full speed into another human being. Eventually, I stopped raising my hand to ask, in part because my shoulder hurt too much.

headline: Obama Plans Big Effort to Build Support Among Women
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama’s re-election campaign is beginning an intensified effort this week to build support among women, using the debate over the new health care law to amplify an appeal that already appears to be benefiting from partisan clashes over birth control and abortion.

headline: Security Fears Lead Groups to Rethink Work in Afghanistan
text: WASHINGTON — The management at a company that does aid and development work for the American government knows that some of its employees in Afghanistan are keeping weapons in their rooms — and is choosing to look the other way. At another company in the same business, lawyers are examining whether the company can sue the United States Agency for International Development for material breach of contract, citing the deteriorating security in Afghanistan.

headline: Eichler’s Modernist Homes
text: Joseph Eichler, who is best known for revolutionizing affordable midcentury home design in suburban California, is rarely associated with high-end high-rises. Yet the Summit, a luxury condominium on Russian Hill with big windows and sharp angles, attests to Eichler’s contribution as a home developer to San Francisco’s skyline.

headline: Wright Out for Another Week
text: VIERA, Fla. — David Wright, who has been suffering from an oblique injury, will miss another week of spring training games, Manager Terry Collins said.

headline: Beyond ‘Broken Windows’
text: JAMES Q. WILSON, who died last week at the age of 80, was unquestionably the pre-eminent political scientist of the last 50 years. Curiously, the commentary surrounding his death has largely focused on his justly famous “broken windows” theory — and to a lesser extent, his penetrating 1993 book, “The Moral Sense” — yet these works are only a small part of his extraordinary contribution to sound thinking about government, politics and public policy.

headline: Tracing Odysseus’s Footsteps
text: My Sunday column is my second and last from my Greece visit, and is a bit out of the ordinary. It essentially tells of a three millennium-old detective story that may now be solved, and I apologize for inflicting my own quixotic interest in Homer on my readers. I feel a bit like the guy in the plane who insists on showing his neighbor photos of his recent trip….

headline: Centrist Women Tell of Disenchantment With Republicans
text: As baby showers go, the party Mary Russell attended to celebrate her niece’s first child was sweet, with about a dozen women offering congratulations over ice cream and cake.

headline: The Hassett Test
text: Mark Thoma catches Kevin Hassett playing for Team Republican; really, no surprise. But Mark’s catch has me thinking: what, if anything, would make reasonable, moderate conservative intellectuals accept that the GOP no longer offers them a home?

headline: Got $100,000? Have a Cookie: Banks Try Luring the Top 10%
text: LARCHMONT, N.Y. — Wine and cheese in the vault. After-hours appointments to suit busy schedules. And loads of marble and mahogany with not a teller in sight.

headline: On Twitter, Best and Worst #airlinefood Experiences
text: Airline meals can vary, as evidenced by comments from readers who described some of their in-flight meals on Twitter. Many have been sobered by servings of something unrecognizable and colorless on their trays. Others, however, told of creative and flavorful dishes, mostly aboard foreign airlines.

headline: Snippets of Saturday at SXSW Interactive
text: We’re posting quick updates from South by Southwest Interactive on our brand-new Tumblr. Here are some of Saturday’s posts:

headline: In Europe, a Tournament With a Big Payday for Women
text: The European Women’s Individual Chess Championship, which is being held in Gaziantep, Turkey, has set two precedents: its prize fund is larger than the one for this year’s men’s championship, and it is the first tournament to have a dress code of its own.

headline: Suspended Broncos May File a Lawsuit
text: Lawyers for Ryan McBean and D. J. Williams, two of the three Denver Broncos suspended for violating the N.F.L.’s drug policy, are likely to file a lawsuit in state court in Colorado as soon as Monday in an attempt to overturn the rulings.

headline: Reyes Conspicuous by His Absence
text: VIERA, Fla. — Where’s Jose?

headline: Focusing on Pineda, but Not Too Much
text: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla. — The new Yankees pitcher Michael Pineda’s pitching line was not overly impressive Saturday, but Manager Joe Girardi was pleased with the effort he saw. Pineda threw two and two-thirds innings and allowed one run on four hits, with three walks and one strikeout.

headline: Top 10 Defensive Backs in Free Agency
text: Disclaimer: Remember, roughly 90 percent of free agents are free agents only because their last team did not want them.

headline: Fastest Over 60 Meters, Gatlin Eyes Gold in 100
text: ISTANBUL — It was not just the gold medal that left Justin Gatlin feeling redeemed at the world indoor track and field championships. It was the time.

headline: Revisiting the Big School vs. Little School Debate
text: When you are forced to revisit a previously held belief or even an old memory that has remained dormant for a significant amount of time, it has always fascinated me how there can be an immediate visceral response when given the right prompt, even if that response doesn’t necessarily line up with your current way of thinking.

headline: The Caucus Click: The Week in Pictures
text: A look back at the week on the campaign trail, from the Super Tuesday battlegrounds to stops in Mississippi and Alabama.

headline: A Course So Tamed That Even Seven Under Par Is Not a Cause for Joy
text: DORAL, Fla. — Without the nature-powered wind machine to accentuate its piercing blue waters and thick rough, the Blue Monster at Doral Resort is a model not ready for her cover shot. That the course is in dire need of a face-lift was made plain Saturday at the W.G.C.-Cadillac Championship when the No. 1 player in the world, Rory McIlroy, produced the best round of the day, a seven-under-par 65, and was dissatisfied.

headline: With a Solemn March, the Bowery Mourns Its Tent of Antiquity
text: The big green tent near the Bowery at East Houston Street had been patched so many times that it was now more plastic than canvas. Its purpose was to shield the contents underneath — which on any given day could include 19th-century furniture, World War II-era military patches or what was said to be the head of a mummy — from the elements and who knew what else.

headline: Knicks View Chandler as Defense’s Partial Cure
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — The Knicks expect Tyson Chandler back Sunday to help cure some of the defensive issues that, during their 0-4 record on the road last week, undid much of what they accomplished during their Linsanity-fueled seven-game winning streak.

headline: For Tar Heels, Last Shot and Next Opponent Are Both a Surprise
text: ATLANTA — North Carolina’s Kendall Marshall has been labeled a guard with limited scoring value, and for good reason. He hunts teammates, not shots, and when the shot clock gets to a single digit or it is the end of the game, Marshall is usually passing to other options ahead of him in the offense, like the swingman Harrison Barnes or the 7-footer Tyler Zeller.

headline: In G.O.P. Nomination Race, Geography Has Been Destiny
text: Rick Santorum’s victory in the Kansas caucuses on Saturday wasn’t much of a surprise, but his margin was toward the high end of expectations as he took 51 percent of the vote to Mitt Romney’s 21 percent. It was the largest margin of defeat for Mr. Romney in caucus or primary to date, although he lost the “beauty contest” primary in neighboring Missouri by almost as large a margin.

headline: The Caucus Click: The Week in Pictures
text: A look back at the week on the campaign trail, from the Super Tuesday battlegrounds to stops in Mississippi and Alabama.  Go to the slide show.

headline: The Monitor’s ‘Brave Fellow’
text: Henry A. Wise, a lieutenant in the Union Navy, interrupted a meeting of the Cabinet on Sunday, March 10, 1862 with important news for the president. Lt. John L. Worden, who had been injured in battle the day before, was at Wise’s home. Worden wasn’t just any wounded officer: as the commander of the Navy’s first ironclad, the Monitor, he had taken on the Confederacy’s own fearsome iron-plated vessel, the Merrimack, in a lengthy duel. During the fighting a shell had exploded outside the Monitor ’s pilothouse just as Worden was looking out its slit. Lincoln immediately adjourned the discussion, saying he had to go “around to see the brave fellow.”

headline: Corrections: March 11
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Sam A. Myers, Veteran Advance Man, Recovering From Heart Attack
text: Sam A. Myers, well known in Washington as the advance man shepherding Democratic presidents, vice presidents and presidential candidates through their many trips, foreign and domestic, was receiving get-well wishes on Saturday from his current and former charges as he recovered from a major heart attack.

headline: For Stosur, a Happy Return to the U.S.
text: INDIAN WELLS, Calif. — This week at the BNP Paribas Open, the 27-year-old Australian Samantha Stosur is playing her first tournament in the United States since stunning Serena Williams, 6-2, 6-3, in the 2011 United States Open final.

headline: A Title for Nazareth, but the Celebration Is Bittersweet
text: On a bittersweet Saturday in Queens, Nazareth High of Brooklyn crushed Moore Catholic, 68-46, to capture the championship of the New York State Girls’ Catholic High School Athletic Association tournament.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: March 10, 2012

headline: For Izzo, Tough Style Is Also a Winning One
text: INDIANAPOLIS — In the corner of a crowded locker room, in a hushed voice, Michigan State forward Adreian Payne sounded ashamed. He wanted desperately to please his coach, Tom Izzo, whose factory-like program specializes in toughness and churns out Final Four appearances, but Payne acknowledged he hadn’t yet adjusted to Izzo’s coaching style.

headline: Romney Looks to Illinois Primary in Battle With Santorum
text: With a challenging string of contests in the next week, Mitt Romney is eyeing Illinois as the place to make a stand in his Republican presidential nomination race with Rick Santorum.

headline: How India Became America
text: “Another brick has come down in the great wall separating India from the rest of the world,” Akash Kapur writes in the Sunday Review of The New York Times about Starbucks and Amazon entering the Indian market. “Amazon has already started a comparison shopping site; Starbucks plans to open its first outlet this summer.”

headline: Chris Boneau, Robert Bucci
text: Chris Alan Boneau and Robert Joseph Bucci were married Friday morning at the Manhattan Marriage Bureau. James Mitchell, a member of the New York City Clerk’s Office, officiated.

headline: Ira Rosenblum and Kenneth Karpel
text: Ira Rosenblum and Kenneth Karpel are to be married Sunday at Water’s Edge, an event space in Long Island City, Queens. Rabbi Sharon Kleinbaum is to officiate.

headline: Sharon Mayeri, Matthew Chesler
text: Sharon Joy Mayeri, the daughter of Israella Friedland Mayeri of Brooklyn and Harold Mayeri of Pawling, N.Y., was married Saturday evening to Matthew Lawrence Chesler, a son of Diane L. Chesler and Evan R. Chesler, both of Scarsdale, N.Y. Rabbi Jonathan E. Blake officiated at Bridgewaters, a party space in Manhattan.

headline: Sarah Wolff, Jeremy Wien
text: Sarah Eppler Wolff, the daughter of Nancy Eppler-Wolff and John H. Wolff of Riverdale, the Bronx, was married Saturday evening to Jeremy Scott Wien, a son of Rochelle B. Wien and Robert W. Wien of Chappaqua, N.Y. Rabbi Barry Dov Katz officiated at 583 Park Avenue, an event space in Manhattan.

headline: Rachel Mercier, Andrew Pascal
text: Rachel Havens Mercier and Andrew Benjamin Pascal were married Friday in the town hall of Cambridge, N.Y., where Janet DeCarlo, its town justice, officiated. On Saturday evening, Matthew Bronson, a friend of the couple, led a Jewish cultural ceremony that incorporated blessings and the breaking of a glass at the Canfield Casino in Saratoga Springs, N.Y.

text: Ainsley Fuhr and Orin Samuel Kerr were married Saturday evening at the Hotel du Pont in Wilmington, Del. Rabbi Michael S. Beals officiated.

headline: Abby Cook-Mack, David Sandler
text: Abby Cook-Mack and David James Sandler were married Saturday evening at the Angel Orensanz Foundation in New York. Rabbi Jessica D. Zimmerman officiated.

headline: Elizabeth Johanningmeier, Nicholas Fifer
text: Elizabeth Victoria Johanningmeier and Nicholas Duane Fifer were married Saturday evening at the University of South Florida Contemporary Art Museum in Tampa, Fla. David A. Waterman, a friend of the bride who became a notary public for the occasion, officiated.

headline: Verna Hsu and Yujin Chung
text: Verna Chi-Fung Hsu and Yujin David Chung were married Saturday evening at the Fairmont San Jose in San Jose, Calif. Kathy Wilkerson, a Universal Life Minister, officiated.

headline: Shannon Stewart and Paul Vierthaler
text: Shannon Stewart and Paul August Vierthaler were married Saturday evening at the Berg Event Space in Kansas City, Mo. The Rev. Hubert Neth, a United Methodist minister, officiated.

headline: Elizabeth Tegins and Thad Sharp
text: Dr. Elizabeth Eileen O’Toole Tegins and Thad Tyson Sharp were married Saturday at the Ballinahinch Church in Ballinahinch, Ireland. The Rev. Patrick Burke, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: Christina Estrada, Daniel Teczar
text: Christina Michelle Estrada and Daniel James Teczar were married Saturday evening at Christ the King Catholic Church in Dallas. Msgr. Donald F. Zimmerman, the church’s pastor, performed the ceremony.

headline: Caitlin Holcomb and Matthew Kaprocki
text: Caitlin Morgan Holcomb and Matthew Edward Kaprocki were married Saturday evening at the Southern Museum of Flight in Birmingham, Ala. The Rev. Keith H. Lewis, an Anglican priest and a retired Air Force chaplain, officiated.

headline: John Blair, Beto Sutter
text: John Ernest Blair and Luiz Roberto Sutter were married Tuesday evening at Out NYC, a hotel in New York. Fran Drescher, the comedian and actress, who is also a Universal Life minister, officiated.

headline: Louisville Wins Title in Bittersweet Glimpse of Big East’s Future
text: The last time that Louisville and Cincinnati met in a league tournament title game, the Cardinals beat the Bearcats in the Metro Conference final in 1981. The three-decade gap, the defunct conference and the far-flung location of the two teams in relation to Madison Square Garden provided a fitting parallel as the Big East peeked into its future Saturday night.

headline: Communist Bling: It’s All the Rage in China
text: HONG KONG — They arrived at the annual meetings in Beijing — and these were card-carrying Communist Party members, mind you — as if they had just descended from Cleopatra’s barge, or at least had maxed out their other cards, the platinum ones, at Dior, Vuitton and Hermès.

headline: U.S. Sergeant Is Said to Kill 16 Civilians in Afghanistan
text: PANJWAI, Afghanistan — Stalking from home to home, a United States Army sergeant methodically killed at least 16 civilians, 9 of them children, in a rural stretch of southern Afghanistan early on Sunday, igniting fears of a new wave of anti-American hostility, Afghan and American officials said.

headline: M.L.S. Preview: Five Questions for the Red Bulls
text: The Red Bulls will be back in the national spotlight Sunday afternoon when they play Dallas in Frisco, Tex., in the first game to be carried by the NBC Sports Network as part of its new contract with Major League Soccer. (All of the league’s current TV deals expire in 2014, which could make for some interesting musical chairs, but that’s a matter for another posting.) In 2011 the Red Bulls logged a league-record 16 ties (and in an odd twist, that record was tied by Chicago!) and narrowly made the playoffs, only to be bounced in the first round by the eventual champion, the Los Angeles Galaxy. Red Bulls management is under the gun to produce more than a win in the Emirates Cup, hosted last summer by Arsenal. Here are five questions they face entering the season:

headline: 10 Years of Making Every Penny Count
text: LONDON — Loyalty and longevity are rare traits in the world of professional sports. In Premier League soccer, keeping a team manager who has not won a trophy in 10 years is almost unheard of.

headline: Economists And Post-Crisis Policy
text: Henry Farrell and John Quiggin have posted their fascinating paper on the rise and (temporary, I think) fall of Keynesian economics in the aftermath of the financial crisis.

headline: Egyptian Military Court Acquits Doctor Accused of Performing ‘Virginity Tests’
text: CAIRO — A military court on Sunday acquitted an army doctor who had been accused of performing forced “virginity tests” on women detained by soldiers when they broke up a street protest a year ago.

headline: ‘Game Change’ and Loyalty
text: On the day after “Game Change,” which debuted on HBO last night, most conversations are no doubt turning to Sarah Palin.

headline: Threats and Killings Striking Fear Among Young Iraqis, Including Gays
text: BAGHDAD — A recent spate of killings and intimidation aimed at gay Iraqis and teenagers who dress in brash Western fashions is sending waves of fear through Iraq’s secular circles while casting doubt on the government’s will to protect some of its most vulnerable citizens.

headline: Shooting in Afghanistan
text: A United States service member left his base and killed at least 16 civilians in southern Afghanistan on Sunday, officials said. Afterward, residents of Panjwai gathered outside the base in protest.

headline: Disruptions: TV Makers Ignore Apps at Their Own Peril
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Every night, I get home from work, drop onto the couch and sit there surfing the Web or watching videos on my 3 1/2-inch iPhone screen. My big-screen HDTV sits powered off on the other side of the room.

headline: An Anniversary of ‘Heartbreaking Grief’ in Japan
text: NIHONMATSU, Japan — Nobody knows whether Hiroshi Yokoyama’s elderly parents tried to outrun the tsunami that engulfed their home in Namie on the Fukushima coast a year ago.

headline: Rivals Call Romney a Weak Choice for G.O.P. Nomination
text: WASHINGTON — With two key Southern primaries on the horizon this week, Rick Santorum and Newt Gingrich sharpened their attacks against Mitt Romney on Sunday, as Mr. Santorum bluntly declared that his leading rival “can’t close the deal,” and Newt Gingrich called Mr. Romney the party’s weakest front-runner since 1920.

headline: ‘The Lorax’ Stays on Top at the Box Office
text: A fuzzy orange cartoon character humiliated Eddie Murphy and one of Pixar’s top directors at the weekend movie box office. For the second weekend in a row, “Dr. Seuss’ The Lorax” (Universal Pictures) — featuring that fuzzy character and the voice of Danny DeVito — was North America’s No. 1 movie. It took in an estimated $39.1 million for a new total of about $122 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box office data.

headline: All Eyes on Santana
text: 5:01 p.m. | Updated  Johan Santana threw 42 pitches over two and two-thirds innings, 22 of them for strikes, against the Miami Marlins. He gave up two hits and one walk while getting two strikeouts.

headline: U.N. Envoy Leaves Syria Empty-Handed
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — After a second day of meetings with President Bashar al-Assad of Syria, a United Nations envoy left Damascus on Sunday without securing a deal to end the nearly year-old conflict, which ground on with heavy shelling in the northern province of Idlib.

headline: Wozniacki’s Golf Viewing Cut Short
text: There are celebrity couples who barely acknowledge they’re together, and then there’s Rory McIlroy and Caroline Wozniacki. The two world-class athletes, as perhaps befits a pair whose initial flirtation was conducted on Twitter, are treating their romance as if it’s an open book.

text: There’s a new modifier on the TV grid, and we should all be afraid.

headline: Chandler Returns, but With Stars Benched Late, Knicks Keep Losing
text: When time ran out on another halfhearted rally, as the minutes dwindled and the boos rained down, $37 million of star power sat fixed on the Knicks’ bench, the players’ expressions as sour as their performance.

headline: Why the A.C.C. Tournament Should Get Back to Its Roots
text: ATLANTA — Walking around Philips Arena this week were some former Atlantic Coast Conference stars: Len Elmore, the Maryland center/forward. Mike Gminski, the Duke center. Eric Montross, the North Carolina center. You couldn’t help thinking back to when they played, back to when the A.C.C.’s core product was basketball.

headline: A Few Unusual Suspects Drop By
text: Befuddlement is a common condition among audience members at concerts of contemporary classical music, probably causing some potential listeners to stay away. But is it really such a bad thing to be confused by how a sound is produced, or to wonder why a piece takes the form it does? To the contrary, a concert presented by the Talea Ensemble at the Tenri Cultural Institute on Friday evening showed how perplexity could charm and delight.

headline: French Baroque Rays of Light Pierce Lenten Shadows
text: The soprano Montserrat Figueras, who died in November, was an important figure in the early-music world. A singer with an expressive, dark-hued voice, she often performed with her husband, the viola da gamba player Jordi Savall, and their two children.

headline: Viewing Impressionism From the Periphery and the Present
text: For orchestras visiting New York standard operating procedure is to bring a program of blockbusters meant to show off the players’ power and agility, and the firmness of the conductor’s control. The St. Louis Symphony followed the script in past visits, but since David Robertson took over its podium in 2005, inventive programming has prevailed over showiness.

headline: Just a Mom With Play Dates (and a Beretta)
text: There are two salient quirks in “The Expats,” Chris Pavone’s novel about Americans abroad. The first is Luxembourg, a place about which Mr. Pavone can be sure most readers know very little. The second is well-calibrated monotony. This book’s abundant treacheries and tricks arise from the fact that its heroine, Kate Moore, is bored stiff.

headline: No Pole-Vault Record, but the Return of a Champion
text: ISTANBUL — On a Sunday afternoon dominated by American athletes, the pole-vault runway was back to being a zone reserved for Yelena Isinbayeva of Russia, just as it was when gold medals were a foregone conclusion, not a point of conjecture.

headline: As Fed Officials Prepare to Meet, They Await Clearer Economic Signals
text: WASHINGTON — The scheduled meeting Tuesday of the Federal Reserve’s policy-making committee is unlikely to resolve the foremost question confronting the central bank: What happens next?

headline: NYT at SXSW
text: Jenna Wortham, Brian Stelter, and Alexis Mainland of The Times participate in a Google Hangout with guests from Glancee and Buzzfeed.

headline: ‘Ishtar’ Lands on Mars
text: LOS ANGELES — In 1987, shortly before the release of “Ishtar,” Columbia Pictures realized the film was going to flop in catastrophic fashion. But rather than cut advertising spending to minimize the financial damage — as the studio’s top marketer advised — Columbia did the opposite, pouring even more money into ads.

headline: A Crusading Suffragist Is Restored to Church Membership
text: To her many admirers, Elizabeth Bartlett Grannis was a humanitarian, social reformer and pioneering suffragist. To the First Church Disciples of Christ, which Grannis had attended faithfully for five decades, she was a “disturber of the peace.”

headline: Exploring Identity and Race Through Two Minds
text: Dean Moss and Reggie Wilson are black. They are American. They are successful, male, midcareer choreographers who have long been engaged in pushing and prodding their art form, seeing where and how it can go.

headline: A Few Final Words From Our Pulp Fiction Contestants
text: As we waded through your 500 submissions, there were sentences that, for better or worse, jumped out at us, made the eyes do a double-take, like the sight of a dame that – ahh, never mind.

headline: Gaza Fighting Continues, Despite Truce Efforts
text: GAZA — Egypt and Hamas, the Islamic movement that rules Gaza, made efforts to restore calm on Sunday, as cross-border fighting between Israel and smaller Palestinian groups in Gaza simmered for a third day.

headline: Wolverine Weekend
text: Volunteers spend a weekend learning to track wolverines across Montana's rugged Helena National Forest.

headline: Matches Made in the Wilderness, in the Name of Science
text: HELENA NATIONAL FOREST, Mont. — On most beautiful winter Saturdays, Erika Nunlist, a college freshman, can usually be found backcountry skiing in the Rockies. But Ms. Nunlist chose to spend a recent sparkling day searching for greenish lumps of wolverine excrement.

headline: For a Vanderbilt Fan, a Sweet Sunday
text: Seventeen years ago, as a sophomore at Vanderbilt, I covered the Southeastern Conference men’s basketball tournament for the student newspaper. We weren’t very good; in my four years, the Commodores reached the N.C.A.A. tournament once, when I was a senior in 1997. We lost in the first round to Xavier.

headline: Stratford Festival Names Artistic Director
text: The Stratford Shakespeare Festival in Ontario announced that Antoni Cimolino would be its next artistic director, starting with the 2013 season. Mr. Cimolino has been a part of the festival for 25 years, starting as an actor before rising through the ranks to his current post as general director. “This great theater changed my life as it has changed the lives of countless others in its almost 60 seasons,” Mr. Cimolino said in a statement. He will succeed Des McAnuff, who is overseeing the Broadway transfer of the festival’s production of Andrew Lloyd Webber’s “Jesus Christ Superstar” to the Neil Simon Theater, currently in previews before its March 22 opening. In his final season as artistic director Mr. McAnuff will direct the festival’s productions of “Henry V” and “A Word or Two,” starring Christopher Plummer. Referring to Mr. Cimolino, Mr. McAnuff said, “He and I know that this will be a graceful and elegant transition.”

headline: Words of Wisdom From Jeff Bridges
text: The Dude is putting his wisdom on paper. Jeff Bridges, below, the Oscar-winning actor from “Crazy Heart” who also starred memorably in “The Big Lebowski,” is writing a book with his friend Bernie Glassman, founder of the spiritual social-action group Zen Peacemakers. The publishers said the book intends to “explore the meaning of life, laughter, the movies and trying to do good in a difficult world.” Blue Rider Press, an imprint of Penguin Group USA, is to release the book, tentatively titled “The Dude and the Zen Master,” this fall. “On a movie set I do my best to keep my head and heart open,” Mr. Bridges said in a statement. “My favorite part of the whole deal is jamming with the other artists, getting to know them, sharing the excitement of what we’re up to, and inspiring each other. That means intimacy. I look for that in life as well.” David Rosenthal, the publisher of Blue Rider Press, called the book “a spiritual guide, an entertainment and an exceptional lesson in true friendship.”

headline: From Clubbed Thumb
text: The Obie Award-winning New York theater company Clubbed Thumb has announced its lineup for the 17th annual Summerworks festival, which will run from May 26 to June 30 at the Here arts center in the South Village. The festival, which highlights original works by American playwrights, is to feature three new plays; Susan Soon He Stanton’s “Takarazuka!!!” directed by Lear deBessonet (”On the Levee”); Ethan Lipton’s “Luther” directed by Ken Rus Schmoll (“A Map of Virtue”); and Peggy Stafford’s “Motel Cherry” directed by Meghan Finn (“3 2’s; or AFA”).

headline: Untamed and Unabashed
text: Four years ago a British singer named Charli XCX began releasing hilarious, knowing and sometimes absurd electro-pop songs. She poked at the pieties of too-cool downtown girls on “Art Bitch” and of too-cool rich girls on “!Franchesckaar!” She tossed off ditties that sounded like adult parodies of children’s music, like “I Wanna Be Darth Vader.” She sounded world-weary but still lighthearted, a club kid zoned out on Adult Swim cartoons, a Lady Gaga preamble.

headline: Sculpture and Mania of a Muse
text: Bad choreography crops up all too often, and yet nobody else today, now that Maurice Béjart and Roland Petit are no longer with us, makes the kind of awful ballet that is Boris Eifman’s forte. Ken Russell’s more sensationalist movies seem like models of restraint beside Mr. Eifman’s lurid, overemphatic, far-from-coherent oeuvre. Mr. Eifman flaunts all the worst clichés of psycho-sexo-bio-dance-drama with casual pride while he rushes headlong to commit a whole new set of artistic felonies.

headline: The Old Raiders Didn’t Need Bounties to Be Brutal
text: OAKLAND, Calif.

headline: A Refusal to Take Any Options Off the Keyboard
text: Herbie Hancock didn’t leave his funk and electronics behind just because he was booked by Jazz at Lincoln Center. On Friday night at the Rose Theater he led a trio that visited both his acoustic and his plugged-in repertory. Mr. Hancock switched, sometimes within the same tune, between his Fazioli grand piano and a Korg Kronos synthesizer. He was eager to juxtapose the multileveled intricacy of his piano improvisations with quacking, wriggling synthesizer tones, hopping between profundity and comedy.

headline: From G.I. Joe to Jim Crow, a Difficult Homecoming
text: Moonlight and magnolias, a Southerner says in “Deep Are the Roots,” are “our oldest clichés.” In this play by Arnaud d’Usseau and James Gow they’re part of the sweet seductions of a place where the genteel and brutal exist side by side, sometimes in the same person.

headline: Santana Remains Sharp in Second Start
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Continuing his recovery from shoulder surgery in 2010, Mets pitcher Johan Santana looked sharp Sunday in his second spring training start.

headline: For China, Big Deficit in Trading Last Month
text: SHANGHAI — China said Saturday that its monthly trade deficit reached $31.5 billion in February, its weakest performance in over a decade and the latest indication of slowing growth in the nation’s economy.

headline: A Theater Tied by Heartstrings to the Old Country
text: She sang her usual repertory of tug-your-heartstring staples like “Mother’s Eyes,” “Jerusalem of Gold” and “Long Live the King.” And after almost every song people flocked to the lip of the stage to hand Tamara Gverdtsiteli outsized bouquets wrapped in plastic. They moved their lips along with the lyrics. They whistled, shouting from the audience, “Tamara, we love you so much.” And they wept.

headline: Do Electronic Records Cut Health Costs?
text: To the Editor:

headline: This Year’s Tony Honors
text: The 2012 Tony Honors for Excellence in the Theater, given to individuals and organizations that are not eligible in the established Tony Award categories for Broadway shows, will go to the musical licensing executive Freddie Gershon; the production supervisor Arthur Siccardi; and the Theater Development Fund’s Open Doors arts education program, the Tony administration committee is to announce on Monday. Mr. Gershon is being honored for creating the Broadway Junior Collection of Music Theater International, his licensing agency, to provide 30- and 60-minute versions of Broadway musicals for elementary and middle schools to produce. Mr. Siccardi has overseen technical and production needs for more than 200 Broadway shows since 1977, including “Annie,” “Dreamgirls,” “My One and Only,” “Sunset Boulevard,” “Billy Elliot: The Musical,” “Mamma Mia!” and the continuing revival of “Chicago.” The nonprofit Theater Development Fund, best known for operating the TKTS discount ticket booths, founded Open Doors in 1998 with the playwright Wendy Wasserstein (“The Heidi Chronicles”). The program recruits theater professionals to be mentors to New York City high school seniors by accompanying them to Broadway and Off Broadway shows and discussing career options in the theater. The honors will be presented at a private cocktail reception on June 9, the evening before the Tony Awards ceremony.

headline: Defending Science: An Exchange
text: Last fall, after Michael Lynch’s essay “Reasons for Reason” appeared in The Stone, he began correspondence with the physicist, mathematician and writer Alan Sokal about the nature and limits of scientific rationality. The following exchange is adapted from that original dialogue.

headline: Woods Leaves With Leg Injury
text: DORAL, Fla .— A week after he posted the best closing round of his pro career to spur talk of a resurgence,Tiger Woods failed to complete the final round of the W.G.C.-Cadillac Championship on Sunday, casting doubt on his participation in the Masters next month.

headline: Saving Detroit
text: To the Editor:

headline: Report Shows Depth of the Distress in Europe
text: FRANKFURT — While the European Central Bank’s emergency loan program late last year helped avoid a banking crisis, there is doubt over whether the action will promote economic growth by encouraging lending to businesses and consumers, according to a new report by the Bank for International Settlements.

headline: Youth Triumphs in Australia at Surfer’s Paradise Congress
text: The final of the Open Teams at the Surfer’s Paradise Congress in Broadbeach, Queensland, Australia, on March 3 was between Liam Milne, Michael Whibley, Andy Hung, Nabil Edgtton and Nye Griffiths from Australia, and Alexander Smirnov from Germany; and Michael Ware from New Zealand, Fiona Brown from England, Jon Sveindal from Norway, Geo Tislevoll, a Norwegian now living in New Zealand, and Tom Hanlon and Hugh McGann from Ireland.

headline: Asleep at the Controls
text: THE Fukushima meltdowns, which began a year ago this week, were a disaster — but also, at least in the United States, an opportunity. Everyone was awake and interested. Thoughtful questions, wild speculation and genuine, heartfelt public concern about nuclear safety were everywhere.

headline: A Link to the Old Country
text: The Millennium Theater has emerged as the cultural hub for the largely Russian neighborhood of Brighton Beach, Brooklyn.

text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — Welcome back to another week of crossword puzzles! It’s always nice to take the first puzzle off the top of the week’s pile and see Lynn Lempel’s byline.

headline: America Is Stealing the World’s Doctors
text: Kunj Desai, a Zambian-born doctor of Indian descent, now practices in Newark, New Jersey, where salaries are nearly ten times that at home, and he is surrounded by modern facilities.

headline: The Field of 68 Includes a Striking Number of Weak Teams
text: As one of the last four teams to earn a bid to last year’s N.C.A.A. tournament, Virginia Commonwealth was perhaps the biggest beneficiary of the bracket’s expansion to 68 teams, making an improbable run to the Final Four. The new format, now in its second year, led to a number of low-wattage teams receiving invitations to this year’s tournament.

headline: A Code of Conduct for Content Aggregators
text: AUSTIN, Tex.

headline: What Your Bracket Says About You
text: There is a good chance that you will fill out an N.C.A.A. basketball tournament bracket for an office pool sometime in the next three days. There is an even better chance that you spent the last four months focused on your family and career, not glued to ESPN. Therefore, you have only a passing familiarity with most of the teams in the tournament, and your bracket selections are just a series of guesses.

headline: Obama a Frequent Flier to 2012 Swing States
text: If there is one thing a president has to do in an election year, it is to find a way to balance official duties with campaign travel. Too much focus on official duties can make an incumbent look isolated and aloof. Too much electioneering risks exposing the president to attacks that he is losing focus on the nation’s problems.

headline: Wily, Elusive Foragers Invade Upstate New York
text: PERU, N.Y. — They roam by night, picking cornstalks clean, making off with apple crops. They have almost no natural predators, but they have razor-sharp tusks and a seemingly bottomless appetite for plants and animals. Their population can triple in one year.

headline: Hanging From the Rafters, Lasting Symbols of Success and Pride
text: Duke’s Cameron Indoor Stadium has wall-to-wall indoor carpeting, but it is not stretched out on the floor — it is stretched across the rafters.

headline: A Strong Debut Amid Talk of the End
text: TAMPA, Fla. — If the Yankees could write their own formula for opening day and beyond, it would probably replicate what happened here Sunday. C. C. Sabathia looked sharp and was not scored upon, and the next pitcher in the game was Mariano Rivera, who threw one perfect inning.

headline: Updates From SXSW Interactive, With a Video Chat
text: In between the panel sessions and festival events on Saturday, Jenna Wortham, Brian Stelter and Lexi Mainland of The Times connected with Matt Buchanan, an editor at BuzzFeed, and Andrea Vaccari, the chief executive of the mobile app maker Glancee, to catch up on the goings-on. Watch the video above.

headline: New Layer of Content Amid Chaos on YouTube
text: For a glimpse at the next phase in YouTube’s evolution, look no further than a stray crutch and a $20 birthday cake for Justin Bieber.

headline: Nonfiction Curriculum Enhanced Reading Skills, Study Finds
text: Children in New York City who learned to read using an experimental curriculum that emphasized nonfiction texts outperformed those at other schools that used methods that have been encouraged since the Bloomberg administration’s early days, according to a new study to be released Monday.

headline: Alone in Public Housing, With a Spare Bedroom
text: After 40 years living in her Manhattan apartment, Shirley Jones has accumulated a lifetime of mementos: pictures of yawning babies, colonies of tiny figurines, photographs of relatives, and a small collection of stuffed animals crowded onto a chair in the living room. Ms. Jones, 70, moved into her apartment, in the Amsterdam Houses on West 63rd Street, with her son when she was 30 years old and has lived there ever since.

headline: Lawyer for Banks Accuses MBIA Chief of Insider Trading
text: The nasty litigation between a group of banks and the bond insurer MBIA just got nastier.

headline: Health Care Act Offers Roberts a Signature Case
text: WASHINGTON — When Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. takes his usual center seat on the Supreme Court bench on March 26, he will begin presiding over an extraordinary three days of arguments that will determine the fate of President Obama’s sweeping health care law.

headline: Spotting the Trends, Before They Break Out
text: MARKETERS have long tried to track trends among consumers and then race to capitalize on them. At the turn of the last century, Lillian Russell appeared in advertising for Coca-Cola. The craze for the cowboy character Hopalong Cassidy at the dawn of the television era generated licensed merchandise like lunch boxes and roller skates. And most recently, countless basketball fans went wild for Jeremy Lin.

headline: A Site That Aims to Unleash the Scrapbook Maker in All of Us
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — Seeking attention for your start-up? You may want to look beyond the Internet-savvy throngs clogging the sidewalks and bars here.

headline: Lower Profile, but No Longer Overlooked by N.C.A.A.
text: At his home in suburban Indianapolis on Sunday night, Butler Coach Brad Stevens watched the N.C.A.A. tournament selection show with his wife, his two children and some family friends.

headline: A Way Forward on Judicial Ethics
text: Last Tuesday, an alliance of government watchdog groups delivered 100,000 signatures to the Supreme Court along with a letter from hundreds of law professors calling on the justices to voluntarily adopt the code of conduct that applies to all other federal judges and to reform how they handle requests for recusals.

headline: Courtside Troupe Seeks Dancers Who Defy Age and Other Stereotypes
text: As she stood in front of a dance studio mirror, Shirley Koehler struggled to keep up with a barrage of instructions from the choreographer: spin and stomp, twirl, nod and flex. And finally, slap your backside.

headline: The Nuclear ‘Implementation Study’
text: President Obama and his advisers are in the middle of a once-in-a-decade study of the nuclear arsenal and nuclear war plans. For strategic and budgetary reasons, they need to further reduce the number of deployed weapons and the number kept in reserve. If this country can wean itself from its own dependence, it will be safer and will have more credibility in its efforts to contain the nuclear ambitions of Iran, North Korea and others.

headline: Labor Leaders Plan to Apply New Clout in Effort for Obama
text: As the A.F.L.-C.I.O. prepares to endorse President Obama on Tuesday, labor leaders say they will mount their biggest campaign effort, with far more union members than ever before — at least 400,000, they say — knocking on voters’ doors to counter the well-endowed “super PACs” backing Republicans.

headline: What Greece Means
text: So Greece has officially defaulted on its debt to private lenders. It was an “orderly” default, negotiated rather than simply announced, which I guess is a good thing. Still, the story is far from over. Even with this debt relief, Greece — like other European nations forced to impose austerity in a depressed economy — seems doomed to many more years of suffering.

headline: Penguins Rolling While Awaiting Crosby
text: PITTSBURGH — One of the biggest mysteries in hockey is how the Pittsburgh Penguins have done so well for so long without Sidney Crosby, who is considered the world’s best player.

headline: Corrections: March 12
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Devils End 5-Game Streak by the Flyers
text: NEWARK — Anton Volchenkov, a Devils defenseman with only one goal this season, formed a 2-on-1 early in the third period Sunday with Ilya Kovalchuk, who had four goals in his previous three games. Philadelphia defenseman Nicklas Grossman wisely leaned toward Kovalchuk.

headline: Bigotry on the Playing Field
text: Intolerance seems to be part of the message sent to student-athletes on the sporting fields of Texas. Only under legal pressure and public criticism did the Texas Association of Private and Parochial Schools, which organizes competitions for more than 200 schools, recently agree to accommodate an Orthodox Jewish school and reschedule a basketball game that would have violated the Sabbath.

headline: Newark Runner Loses
text: Edward Cheserek of St. Benedict’s Prep in Newark had his first loss of the season at the National High School Indoor Track and Field Championships at the Armory in Upper Manhattan. Cheserek lost the mile to Brad Nye of Kaysville, Utah, 4 minutes 8.67 seconds to 4:09.07. Cheserek earlier won the two-mile in 8:50.53.

headline: Wall Street Protesters Complain of Police Surveillance
text: On Nov. 17, Kira Moyer-Sims was near the Manhattan Bridge, buying coffee while three friends waited nearby in a car. More than a dozen blocks away, protesters gathered for an Occupy Wall Street “day of action,” which organizers had described as an attempt to block the streets around the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: March 12, 2012

headline: Attack May Derail Effort to Force Taliban Into Talks
text: WASHINGTON — The outrage from the back-to-back episodes of the Koran burning and the killing on Sunday of at least 16 Afghan civilians imperils what the Obama administration once saw as an orderly plan for 2012: to speed the training of Afghan forces so that they can take the lead in combat missions, all while drawing the Taliban into negotiations to end more than a decade of constant war.

headline: For the 76ers, Strength in Numbers, Not in Stars
text: An 8-foot pull-up jump shot from a middling power forward after nice interior ball movement may sound more like good offense in a recreational league than a rally-killing play in the star-laden N.B.A.

headline: Founding Family Decides to Leave Crystal Cathedral
text: GARDEN GROVE, Calif. — After decades at the pulpit here, the family of the Rev. Robert H. Schuller has cut its ties with the Crystal Cathedral, the Orange County megachurch he founded.

headline: At Lunch, Bloomberg and Obama Discuss Future
text: They traded thoughts about education, ruminated on the state of immigration and discussed the federal deficit.

headline: Confession Spun Across the Miles
text: He cannot stop talking, this stranger on a train. And though much of what he says isn’t pleasant, you can’t stop listening, either. There is, after all, something mesmerizing about confession in a smoky railroad car, delivered by someone you’ll never see again.

headline: Young Arms and Curveballs: A Scientific Twist
text: For decades, it has been an article of faith for parents of young pitchers: Do not let them throw curveballs. The reason was simple. Contorting elbows — all in the service of ever more competitive baseball at ever younger ages — puts more strain on the joint than arms can handle.

headline: Boy’s Death a Homicide; Man Charged
text: The death of a 23-month-old Brooklyn boy on Saturday has been ruled a homicide, and the companion of his mother has been arrested and charged in the case, the authorities said Sunday.

headline: Familiarity With Drugs Helps a Group Speak for Users
text: SAN FRANCISCO — With a couple of old desks, a beat-up couch and an off-white white board, the office space at 149 Turk Street, in this city’s seedy Tenderloin district, is hardly remarkable. A collection of worn detective novels sits on the bookshelf, a couple of American flags hang limply from the wall and a coffee machine constantly percolates in the back kitchen.

headline: Late Goal Jolts Rangers Out of Their Slump
text: In the final seconds of overtime, with the Rangers on the power play, Brad Richards would not have been faulted if he decided to shoot the puck. He had the hot hand, having already scored two goals to help carry the Rangers to overtime against the Islanders.

headline: Commenting on Congress
text: There are Web sites that cover the actions and inactions of Congress. And there are Web sites that let voters contact their members of Congress and comment. CQ Roll Call wants to bridge the two.

headline: Latest Stress Tests Are Expected to Show Progress at Most Banks
text: In another milestone in the banking industry’s recovery from the financial crisis, the Federal Reserve this week will release the results of its latest stress tests, which are expected to show broadly improved balance sheets at most institutions.

headline: The Timeless Torches
text: A dance troupe tied to the New York Liberty of the W.N.B.A. held tryouts.

headline: Buckeyes Guard Has Mind Wired for Defense
text: Aaron Craft was sitting in math class during his junior year at Liberty-Benton High School in Findlay, Ohio, when he noticed the teacher had written 60 decimals from the mathematical constant, pi, on the chalkboard. Craft, who says he can retain information remarkably well, typed the number into his calculator and began to study.

headline: Security Forces Kill at Least 5 in China
text: BEIJING — Two outbursts of violence involving fatal shootings by security forces took place last week in areas of China where ethnic tensions are running high, according to weekend reports by a Tibet advocacy group and Radio Free Asia.

headline: Tight G.O.P. Primaries Suggest Less-Predictable South
text: HUNTSVILLE, Ala. — They stood beneath a Saturn V rocket, baby-carrying mothers, cross-armed men, workers in coveralls and financial planners, listening as Rick Santorum told them who they were and why they mattered.

headline: New Internet TV Network to Feature Larry King
text: Carlos Slim Helú, the Mexican billionaire, is financing an Internet television network called Ora.tv that will feature Larry King, the former CNN interviewer, in a return to the interviewer’s chair.

headline: Henry Doesn’t Like Losing, or Questions About Losing
text: When Thierry Henry scored in the first game of his off-season loan to Arsenal, he looked as if he would have been willing to stand around for hours, hugging each and every member of the crowd of nearly 60,000.

headline: Wildcat’s Blocks Induce Headaches
text: Anthony Davis, a freshman center for top-seeded Kentucky, has witnessed it often. An opponent maneuvers into the lane — Davis’s lane — and his eyes start darting around like pinballs.

headline: A Video Campaign and the Power of Simplicity
text: EVEN as the Internet era has accelerated the news cycle, sometimes to mere minutes, there is still one idea that holds true: you need a lash before you can have a backlash.

headline: Bid for Grain Operator in Canada Sets Up Fight
text: OTTAWA — Viterra’s announcement late on Friday that it has become the subject of possible takeover bids has prompted investor interest and may lead to political controversy within Canada this week.

headline: Killings Add to Worries at Soldier’s Home Base
text: JOINT BASE LEWIS-McCHORD, Wash. — It has been just four months since a military jury on this military base convicted the ringleader of a rogue Army unit that shot Afghans for sport. In 2011, at least 12 soldiers here committed suicide. Last week, Senator Patty Murray criticized a military hospital here for overturning 285 diagnoses of post-traumatic stress disorder.

headline: Lawrence Anthony, Baghdad Zoo Savior, Dies at 61
text: Lawrence Anthony, who abandoned a career in insurance and real estate to play Noah to the world’s endangered species, most spectacularly in rushing to the smoldering Baghdad Zoo after the American invasion of Iraq in 2003, died on March 2 in Johannesburg. He was 61.

headline: Leftist Party Wins in Slovakia Parliamentary Election
text: BERLIN — Voters in Slovakia gave the left-wing former prime minister Robert Fico a sweeping mandate to return to power after less than two years in opposition, as results released Sunday showed that his party won a landslide victory in the parliamentary election on Saturday.

headline: Russian Activists See Political Reprisal in Court Case
text: MOSCOW — Just a day after the latest, and possibly last, of the large protest rallies of the election season in Russia, prosecutors in a district court in Moscow filed formal charges on Sunday against the husband of one of the protest movement’s leaders, stirring fears of politically motivated legal reprisals.

headline: Military Points to Risks of a Syrian Intervention
text: WASHINGTON — Despite growing calls for the United States to help stop the bloodshed in Syria, senior Pentagon officials are stepping up their warnings that military intervention would be a daunting and protracted operation, requiring at least weeks of exclusively American airstrikes, with the potential for killing vast numbers of civilians and plunging the country closer to civil war.

headline: For Creators of Games, a Faint Line on Cloning
text: In any commercialized art form, be it movies, literature or fashion, the creators often tread a fine line between inspiration and shameless copying. Some small video game makers say that line seems to have all but disappeared.

headline: Quiet Tar Heel Knows How to Lead
text: In a program with a history of flashy and outsize personalities, North Carolina forward Tyler Zeller prefers to operate quietly.
