text: outstrip •\ˌau̇t-ˈstrip\• verb

headline: Stairs at Home Remain a Childhood Hazard
text: When Chris Garbrandt’s 6-month-old son, Will, started crawling last October, she realized the stairs in her split-level home in Nashport, Ohio, were an obvious hazard.

headline: Jay McMullen, CBS Investigative Journalist, Dies at 90
text: Jay McMullen, whose career as an investigative journalist for CBS News included early uses of hidden cameras and undercover reporting, died Saturday at a hospice in Greenwich, Conn. He was 90.

headline: Looking Ahead to Economic Reports This Week
text: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data will include retail sales for February and business inventories for January (Tuesday); import prices for February and the current account deficit for the fourth quarter (Wednesday); weekly jobless claims, the Producer Price Index for February and the Philadelphia Fed index for March (Thursday); and the Consumer Price Index for February, industrial production for February and the Thomson Reuters/University of Michigan consumer sentiment index for March (Friday).

headline: Marquette Star Sees a Challenge in an Award
text: When the Marquette senior forward Jae Crowder attended the Big East’s preseason media day in New York last fall, he was a bit stunned to learn that he had received honorable-mention all-conference recognition.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Use of Public Transit Grew in 2011, Report Indicates
text: In another indication that more people are getting back to work, Americans took 200 million more rides last year on subways, commuter trains, light-rail systems and public buses than they did the year before, according to a new report by a leading transit association.

headline: Selection Day: Photo Replay
text: A look at the celebrations and heartbreaks of college basketball’s selection day.

headline: Sarkozy, in Rousing Talk, Takes Conservative Stands
text: PARIS — President Nicolas Sarkozy, trailing in opinion polls six weeks before the election, gave a rousing address to some 50,000 supporters on Sunday, striking strongly conservative notes on immigration, Islam and protectionism.

headline: Greek Leaders Turn Focus to Preparing for Elections
text: ATHENS — With the ink not yet dry on a complex agreement to write down more than $130 billion of Greek debt, Greece’s political leaders leaped into full campaign mode on Sunday to prepare for national elections expected in late April or early May.

headline: Photo Replay: March 11
text: A look at the day in sports, from dog sled racing in Alaska to wrestling in Serbia.

headline: The Reproduction of Privilege
text: Instead of serving as a springboard to social mobility as it did for the first decades after World War II, college education today is reinforcing class stratification, with a huge majority of the 24 percent of Americans aged 25 to 29 currently holding a bachelor’s degree coming from families with earnings above the median income.

headline: An Update on New York Redistricting
text: New York is now among the last states in the nation to tackle the redistricting required as a result of the 2010 census. And the urgency is growing: the state’s Congressional primary is scheduled for June 26, and its legislative primary for Sept. 11.

headline: At the Intersection of Politics, Religion and Government
text: The Muslim Brotherhood operates many enterprises intended to assist Egyptians in need, including hospitals, markets and schools.

headline: Final Four Predictions
text: Pete Thamel, The New York Times college basketball reporter, offers his predictions on the men’s N.C.A.A. tournament Final Four.

headline: Why Not a Massacre Tribunal in Afghanistan?
text: HONG KONG — An arrest, a presidential apology, local outrage and anger, a plea for calm and the promise of investigations — that’s the usual rapid-reaction scenario after incidents like the apparent slaughter of 16 Afghan civilians, 9 of them children, by an American sergeant.

headline: ‘The Good Wife’ Revisits Some Core Themes
text: Sex, lies and real estate: it was a return to the bedrock themes of Season 1 on “Long Way Home,” Sunday night’s episode of “The Good Wife” on CBS.

headline: An Indigenous Language With Unique Staying Power
text: ASUNCIÓN, Paraguay — Legislators on the floor of Congress deliver speeches in it. Lovers entwined on Asunción’s park benches murmur sweet nothings with its high-pitched, nasal and guttural sounds. Soccer fans use it when insulting referees.

headline: Keeper of Islamic Flame Rises as Egypt’s New Decisive Voice
text: CAIRO — For more than a dozen years, Khairat el-Shater guided his family of 10 children, his sprawling business empire and Egypt’s largest Islamist movement, the Muslim Brotherhood, all from a prison cell.

headline: Can Sarkozy, the Candidate, Make Voters Forget Sarkozy, the President?
text: Nicolas Sarkozy, the incumbent French president, has been fighting a seemingly uphill battle for re-election. Polls put him behind his leading challenger, François Hollande, the Socialist candidate. And even Mr. Sarkozy has conducted himself at times as if the race was already lost. He made bizarre remarks in late January to journalists, ostensibly off the record, where he seemed negative, even morose, about his chances, and last week he was talking again about losing.

headline: News Quiz | March 12, 2012
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries in today’s newspaper.

headline: CNN Is Said to Be in Talks to Acquire Mashable
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — CNN, a unit of Time Warner, and the social news Web site Mashable are in advanced talks that may lead to an acquisition of the site, three people briefed on the talks said.

headline: March 12, 1947 | Truman Doctrine Announced
text: On March 12, 1947, in a speech before a joint session of Congress, President Harry S. Truman asked Congress to grant economic and military aid to Greece and Turkey to help those countries resist Communism. The speech established what became known as the Truman Doctrine, a policy “to support free peoples who are resisting attempted subjugation by armed minorities or by outside pressures.”

headline: An Afghan Comes Home to a Massacre
text: PANJWAI, Afghanistan — Displaced by the war, Abdul Samad finally moved his large family back home to this volatile district of southern Afghanistan last year. He feared the Taliban, but his new house was nestled near an American military base, where he considered himself safe.

headline: Test Yourself | Math, March 12, 2012
text: Test your math skills with this question created by Scott Matthews at Math for America from the City Room blog post “On the Train, Tap Dancing to Pay for College”

headline: Four Mao Too Many
text: BEIJING — Last Wednesday I tried to close my bank account. I won’t pretend that the Bank of China is the most Orwellian institution in the world, but in terms of human suffering inflicted by bureaucracy, it has to make the long list.

headline: Fantasy Focus: On the Outside Looking In
text: Each spring we seem to see multiple guys who appear to be no-brainers for their teams’ lineups or rotations, but for whatever reason (overpaid veterans ahead of them, lack of experience, etc.), they are left on the bench or in Class AAA to start the season. In these cases, just remember this mantra: talent always wins out in the end. The end may not come until May or June, but it will come. Let’s look at a few of these guys.

headline: Massacre Is Reported in Homs, Raising Pressure for Intervention in Syria
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Syrian opposition activists said on Monday that soldiers and pro-government thugs had rounded up scores of civilians in the devastated central city of Homs overnight, assaulted men and women, then killed dozens of them, including children, and set some bodies on fire. Syria immediately denied responsibility.

headline: Focus on Independence May Hamper First-Generation Students Once on Campus
text: 2:41 p.m. | Updated Stanford University has published an interview with Hazel Markus, one of the authors of the study, about the impact of college culture on first-generation students.

headline: The Great Gatsby Comes to India
text: In January, Alan Krueger, chairman of President Barack Obama’s Council of Economic Advisers, gave an important policy address in Washington in which he addressed the growing problem of inequality in America, an issue that has come to define the president’s re-election campaign.

headline: Top 10 Wide Receivers in Free Agency
text: Disclaimer: Remember, roughly 90 percent of free agents are free agents only because their last team did not want them.

text: Disclaimer: Remember, roughly 90 percent of free agents are free agents only because their last team did not want them.

headline: This Week in Small Business: Another Jobs Bill!
text: What’s affecting me, my business and other small-business owners this week.

headline: How Important Is It to Have a Driver’s License?
text: Long a symbol of new-found freedom and a quintessential rite of passage, many teens dream of obtaining their drivers’ license as soon as they are eligible. Does that describe you? Do you have–or want–your license? Do your friends? If you live in a big city or other place where few people have cars, are there other independence-related rites of passage that compare to getting one’s driver’s license? Has their relevance changed over time?

headline: Poll: Santorum and Romney Remain Tied
text: Republican primary voters across the country continue to be divided over Mitt Romney and Rick Santorum, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll, a split between the front-runners that has remained relatively unchanged over the last month.

headline: 2 Video Web Sites in China Plan a Merger
text: SHANGHAI — Youku, a leading Chinese online video Web site, is buying its biggest domestic competitor, Tudou, in an acquisition valued at $1.1 billion.

headline: China Talks of More Lending but Less Currency Growth
text: BEIJING — As China seeks a soft landing for its bubble-prone economy, senior economic officials said on Monday that they might encourage bank lending, while also hinting that the country’s currency might not appreciate as rapidly as it has in recent years — a contentious issue in the United States presidential election this year.

headline: Daily Report: Pinterest’s Low-Key Approach
text: Tech start-ups are thronging to the South by Southwest Interactive conference in Austin, Tex., hoping to jump-start their new businesses by cozying up to Silicon Valley venture capitalists and influential bloggers. But Jenna Wortham reports in Monday’s New York Times that they might do better to study the more low-key approach of Pinterest, the hottest start-up of the moment.

headline: If Cutting Carbon Emissions Isn’t Working, What’s Next?
text: What if it is too late to save the climate by cutting greenhouse gas emissions? What if the amount of carbon dioxide already added to the atmosphere by human activity is so great that it is going to produce big temperature changes no matter what, with big shifts in rainfall and in ocean chemistry?

headline: The Closet Question: Who Would Wear This Stuff?
text: Those who know Jessica Simpson and Nicole Richie just from their less-intellectual pursuits might be surprised to learn, through the new NBC series “Fashion Star,” that they can actually sound quite smart when in their element. Here’s another surprise delivered by this addictive little show, which has its premiere Tuesday night: “Project Runway” didn’t exhaust the possibilities of fashion-designer television.

headline: Sealy Investor Calls for Board Shake-Up
text: A top investor in the Sealy Corporation is pushing to remake the board of the mattress maker, taking aim at a single shareholder, Kohlberg Kravis Roberts.

headline: Opinion Report: The Nuclear Arsenal
text: From the editorial page

headline: Mark Federman: Catch Students Before They Fall
text: Many students at East Side Community High School on East 12th Street in Manhattan enter the 6-12 school performing below grade level. Yet somehow 90 percent of graduates go on to college. The principal, Mark Federman, said students get personal attention and respect: "We have kids who act like knuckleheads and we have moments where we have to be tough with them. But we’re looking for kids to do the right thing. We have a lot of faith that they can do the right thing."

headline: What We Told the State Education Commissioner
text: What would you say if you unexpectedly ran into the state education commissioner? Two activist parents raised big issues with John B. King Jr. during a brief encounter recently in a cafeteria in Albany.

headline: Promising Results Found With Core Knowledge Reading Method
text: Children at 10 schools who were taught reading using a curriculum designed by the education theorist E.D. Hirsch Jr.’s Core Knowledge Foundation have significantly outperformed students taught at other schools under a variety of other methods, most of which fell under the definition of “balanced literacy,” an approach that was promoted citywide by the former schools chancellor, Joel I. Klein, beginning in 2003.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: Lawyer for Banks Accuses MBIA Chief of Insider Trading  |  The nasty litigation between a group of banks and the bond insurer MBIA just got nastier.

headline: A Reminder of the Danger of City Streets
text: It was the sort of news story that is usually buried deep inside the papers, if it is reported at all. A woman named Margaret Myers was walking home in East New York, Brooklyn, a few nights ago when she was run over by a car as she crossed a street. Ms. Myers died later in the hospital.

headline: Pepsi Chief Shuffles Management to Soothe Investors
text: Indra K. Nooyi’s vision of PepsiCo as a company that sells nutritional products — not just sodas and salty chips — has been hailed as a sound long-term strategy by management consultants and nutritionists almost since her arrival at the company nearly six years ago.

headline: Monday Reading: All-Inclusive Resorts Get More Sophisticated
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: Iranian Ceremony to Honor ‘Separation’ Director Is Canceled
text: A ceremony in Iran to honor the Academy Award-winning director Asghar Farhadi was canceled on Monday after the authorities there denied permission for the event, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Trustee Sought for Dynegy Bankruptcy
text: The United States trustee has filed a motion seeking the appointment of a trustee in the Dynegy Holdings bankruptcy case, citing “gross mismanagement by current management.”

headline: Leading Off: Sharpen Your Pencils
text: Today is the official N.C.A.A. tournament day to exhale, which any day now will have an official corporate sponsor. Of course, if you have any rooting interests in what is now called the First Four, this cannot be a long exhale because the games start Tuesday. But even though the N.C.A.A. can monkey with its format, it cannot accelerate the basic timetable, which says the tournament does not start until your bracket says it does. And that would be Thursday. So go ahead and throw a few inhales in with the exhale.

headline: Slowdown in China Weighs on Wall St.
text: Stocks were mixed on Monday in light trading as investors weighed whether an economic slowdown in China could lead to an easing of monetary policy.

headline: The Trials of Kozlov
text: MOSCOW — A few hundred people tried to save a man on Sunday. They came to Presnensky court in central Moscow, filled the courtroom, the lobby in front of it and the space outside on the street. They were of different ages, well-known writers and entertainers as well as college students and office workers. Many of them had met one another during the protests of the last three months — which, for now, have moved to this courthouse.

headline: Losing the Belt
text: A number of people have asked me for a quick, easy explanation of the difference between a government and a family — basically, what’s wrong with the argument that when times are tough the government should tighten its belt.

headline: Miller Buckfire Hires Restructuring Executive
text: Miller Buckfire, a boutique investment bank, moved to bolster its restructuring practice, announcing on Monday that it had hired Ron Kubick as a managing director.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: What ‘John Carter’ Says About Hollywood, and Sharing Credit Online
text: The Walt Disney Studios sci-fi movie “John Carter” was a big bust this weekend, Brooks Barnes reports in an article with a headline that says it all — “Ishtar Lands on Mars.” The North American box office total of $30.6 million means that Disney is likely to have to write down its losses on the movie, which cost an estimated $350 million to make and market. Why did Disney keep spending to market “John Carter” when it was clear that the film would not be successful, as Columbia Pictures did in 1987 for Ishtar? The relationships.

headline: Differing Schools of Thought, Differing Styles of Play
text: POTSDAM, Germany — Women’s soccer in the United States has always been at the top of the game. The most recent Women’s World Cup, however, showed that the women’s game is developing strong teams all over the world.

headline: Monday Motorsports: Tony Stewart Earns First Sprint Cup Win of 2012
text: Tony Stewart won early races in the 2011 Sprint Cup chase by managing his fuel supply as other frontrunners wantonly burned through theirs. On Sunday in Las Vegas, Stewart, the defending champion, did not conserve his gas; he stepped on it to preserve a late-race advantage over Jimmie Johnson.

headline: Stroke Victim Wins Right to Seek Legal Euthanasia
text: LONDON — A British stroke victim paralyzed from the neck down and suffering from so-called locked-in syndrome won the right on Monday to seek changes in a law that would enable a doctor to end what he has called “intolerable life” without risking murder charges.

headline: Citi Names Peter Tague Co-Head of Mergers
text: Citigroup has named Peter Tague co-head of the bank’s global mergers and acquisitions team, a promotion that comes as the bank’s advisory business struggles to compete with those of other Wall Street giants.

headline: A Hacker Charms and Disappoints
text: Skilled, profane and bombastic, the hacker who called himself Sabu had loyalists and critics. He also had admirers who marveled at his antics from afar, even as they disdained his tactics. That admiration helped explain the attraction of the Anonymous movement that Sabu came to represent.

headline: For Duluth, a Fourth Consecutive Trip to the Final Five

headline: On Our Radar: Saluting a Colossus of Chemistry
text: Accolades flow in for F. Sherwood Rowland, who won the Nobel Prize in chemistry two decades after reporting that chlorofluorocarbons were destroying the ozone layer. He died on Saturday at age 84. “He saved the world from a major catastrophe,” a dean at the University of California, Irvine, says. [The Christian Science Monitor]

headline: Murray’s Struggles at Indian Wells Continue
text: INDIAN WELLS, Calif. — Despite being able to beat No. 1 Novak Djokovic only eight days earlier in Dubai (albeit in warmer, faster conditions), No. 4 Andy Murray of Britain crashed out of the BNP Paribas Open in his first match, losing, 6-4, 6-2, in the second round Saturday night to 92nd-ranked Guillermo García-López of Spain.

headline: Business Day Live | March 12, 2012
text: Stephen Gallagher, chief market strategist of Société Générale, on market risk from Europe and what the results of stress tests might mean for the banking industry.

headline: Belle on Wheels
text: If there’s a barometer of the rise of urban cycling, it’s the proliferation of bike-share programs. Just ask Alison Cohen, president of Alta Bicycle Share, which is opening New York’s 10,000-bike system this summer. “Right now most New Yorkers think, ‘Should I take the subway? Should I take a cab? Should I walk?’ ” Cohen says. “We want to make cycling the fourth option.” It’s already an option in Milan, home to the designer Marta Ferri, pictured here on one of the elegant bikes from that city’s program and in clothes from her namesake label. For two and a half euros, visitors can buy a daily subscription to Milan’s BikeMi program on its Web site, where a station map locates available bicycles and parking spots, updated in real time. Milan is flush with bike shops as well. Ferri recommends Rossignoli, for a selection of traditional Italian bikes, and Turbolento, for an expert tuneup. She also suggests cruising the bike lane that surrounds the 95-acre Parco Sempione. “Don’t forget to explore narrow streets and alleys for glimpses of private gardens,” Ferris adds. “Milan is a secret city. Most of her beauty is hidden.”

headline: For Northwestern, One More Year (That’s 74 Straight) Without a Bid
text: EVANSTON, Ill. – For the first time in the 74-year history of the N.C.A.A. tournament, the Northwestern men’s basketball team found itself on the bubble on Selection Sunday. For the 74th consecutive year, the Wildcats, the only team from a major conference to have never received a bid to the N.C.A.A. tournament, were not among the teams selected.

headline: Brooklyn Museum to Honor ‘First’ Women
text: On April 18, as part of the fifth anniversary of the Brooklyn Museum’s Elizabeth A. Sackler Center for Feminist Art, the museum will present the First Awards, given to 15 women who were first in their fields. Among the honorees are Sandra Day O’Connor; Jessye Norman; Toni Morrison; Connie Chung; the choreographer and director Susan Stroman; Faye Wattleton, a former president of Planned Parenthood; and Chief Wilma Pearl Mankiller, the first female chief of the Cherokee Nation.

headline: A Surgeon’s Call to Duty
text: Dr. Jacques Bérès, a 71-year-old French surgeon, smuggled himself into Homs, Syria, to treat the wounded in a makeshift hospital.

headline: French Surgeon, 71, Saves Lives in Syria
text: PARIS — At the age of 71, Dr. Jacques Bérès, a veteran of war zones, left his comfortable Paris life last month to smuggle himself into Homs, the center of the Syrian revolt, to tend to the wounded and the sick.

headline: State of Utah Says It Is a Happy Backer of ‘John Carter’
text: LOS ANGELES — Nothing highlights the economic puzzlement of state-supported filmmaking like a good, old-fashioned megaflop. This morning’s example: Walt Disney’s “John Carter.”

text: From SXSW, Drew Goddard, the director and co-writer of “The Cabin in the Woods,” discusses his work.

headline: The Case for Agents
text: Chances are, it’s not going to turn out well for Nerlens Noel, the subject of Pete Thamel’s powerful and brilliantly reported article in Sunday’s Times.  Noel is a 6’10” high school basketball star who is highly coveted by at least half a dozen of the major college basketball powers. “The 17-year-old son of working-class Haitian immigrants, he could be worth $10 million in about 16 months when he is eligible for the 2013 N.B.A. draft,” writes Thamel.

headline: Grilled Fruit With Ginger Syrup
text: Mark Bittman brushes grilled banana, star fruit and pineapple with homemade ginger syrup.

headline: Video: Unlocking ‘The Cabin in the Woods’
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — In “The Cabin in the Woods,” a group of attractive young people head to, as you might guess, a cabin in the woods. But you probably won’t guess what happens next, and the filmmakers hope those who have seen won’t tell. The movie, which was co-written by “Buffy” creator Joss Whedon and “Lost” writer Drew Goddard, may best be classified as a horror film, but has a fun time tweaking that genre’s conventions.

headline: The Minimalist: Skewered Grilled Fruit With Ginger Syrup
text: Grilled fruit is unusual enough, but when you brush it with ginger syrup you get something really exciting. I learned this recipe from the chef Johnny Earles on the Emerald Coast of Florida (affectionately known as the Redneck Riviera) almost 25 years ago, and first wrote about it in 1998. He used pineapple, banana and star fruit (which looks more exciting than it tastes), but you can use any fruit that you can grill, indoors or out: stone fruit and melons would be nice, mangoes would be fantastic (the firmer the better) and apples and pears would make this a wonderful dish for fall.

headline: Europe Must Defend Itself
text: After President Barack Obama’s announcement this year of significant changes to the U.S. defense strategy, the world has mostly focused on the shift toward Asia and the Pacific. However. this is only one aspect of the new U.S. posture. It also has a great impact from a European defense point of view, as senior American strategists and NATO officials told me during the meeting of NATO defense ministers in Brussels last month.

headline: Brasserie Pushkin, a Lavish Russian Arrival
text: Andrey Dellos, who on Tuesday will open an elaborate Russian restaurant on West 57th Street called Brasserie Pushkin, founded Café Pushkin in Moscow in 1999 to resolve a puzzle that had confounded visitors to that city, and even some locals, for 35 years.

headline: BATS Global Markets Aims to Price I.P.O. at $16 to $18
text: BATS Global Markets, the third-largest stock exchange operator in the United States, said it planned to price its initial public offering at $16 to $18 a share, according to a filing submitted on Monday. At the midpoint of that range, BATS is on track to raise $107 million at a market value of $810 million.

headline: The Billionaire List Wars
text: A game of billionaire one-upmanship is raging — not between moneyed barons themselves, but over who is counting them, and how.

headline: In China, Part of Railway Collapses Despite Test Runs
text: BEIJING — China’s troubled state-run rail system suffered another setback with news reports Monday that a section of railway that already had undergone test runs has collapsed.

headline: A Luxury Condo Building With Views of the Skyline, and the Prison Next Door
text: If you want to live at 100 11th Avenue, a luxury condominium building in West Chelsea with a fancy architectural pedigree, it will probably cost you a couple of million dollars, or at least $10,000 monthly rent. For your grand fee, you will get wide open vistas of the Manhattan skyline and views of the Hudson River all the way down to the Statue of Liberty.

headline: Anti-Incumbent Sentiment Fuels Primary Fights in Deep South
text: Most of the attention in the Deep South may be on the Republican presidential race, but some surprises could be in store for the unsettled House delegations from Alabama and Mississippi, whose members are facing primary challenges on Tuesday.

headline: Springsteen Tops Charts in Britain
text: Bruce Springsteen has still got it as far as the British are concerned. His new album, “Wrecking Ball” (Columbia), was the top-selling long-play recording in the United Kingdom last week, according to the Official Charts Company. It was the ninth time Mr. Springsteen, 62, has scored a No. 1 album in Britain, going back to “Born in the U.S.A.” in 1984.

headline: In Appeal, W.T.O. Upholds a Decision Against Boeing
text: The World Trade Organization’s appellate body affirmed on Monday that Boeing had received at least $5 billion in improper subsidies from the United States government to develop its 787 Dreamliner and other jet models, giving it an unfair advantage over its European rival, Airbus.

headline: Brooklyn Fare Plans a Manhattan Outpost
text: The neighborhood between 34th and 42nd Streets around Tenth Avenue had better get itself a name.

headline: Justice Dept. Blocks Texas on Photo ID for Voting
text: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department’s civil rights division on Monday blocked Texas from enforcing a new law requiring voters to present photo identification at the polls, contending that the law would disproportionately suppress turnout among eligible Hispanic voters.

headline: Sears, Once Outfitter of Westward Expansion, Now Stocks Saris
text: Long before chants of “think global, buy local” hit the airwaves, Richard Warren Sears and Alvah C. Roebuck created America’s first major mail-order catalog store, Sears, Roebuck & Co. by shipping goods from Chicago to rural America in the late 1800s. Farmers rejoiced as their sewing machines and flour arrived for half the price offered by small town merchants.

headline: Bank Officials Cited in Churn of Foreclosures
text: Managers at major banks ignored widespread errors in the foreclosure process, in some cases instructing employees to adopt make-believe titles and speed documents through the system despite internal objections, according to a wide-ranging review by federal investigators.

headline: Stairs: A Childhood Hazard, and an Easy Fix

headline: Sleepless, Bored and in Pain, a Patient Watched
text: Just when it seems long past time for the age of memoir to be over — just when it seems impossible that any ailing person with literary inclinations could find anything new to say about illness, and the list of not-to-be-missed “patients are people too” books should be closed and locked — yet another book comes along.

headline: Would You Be O.K. With a Prison as a Neighbor?
text: New Yorkers are accustomed to living with extremes, whether it’s the economic diversity of the 6 train at rush hour, or the way a neighborhood can flip from glitz to grit in the space of one block.

headline: The Mississippi and Alabama Primaries
text: As the Republican campaign rolls into a state-by-state battle for delegates, Rick Santorum’s victories on Tuesday night elevated and strengthened his candidacy.

headline: Two Cheers for Double Standards
text: What is a double standard? It’s a double standard when you condemn an opponent for doing or saying something you would approve or excuse if it were said or done by one of your buddies. The double standard that is in the news these days concerns Rush Limbaugh, who called Sandra Fluke, a law student at Georgetown, a “slut” and “prostitute” because she told Congress that her university’s health plan should cover the cost of contraceptives.

headline: Solyndra Is Blamed as Clean-Energy Loan Program Stalls
text: More than $16 billion in loans authorized five years ago by Congress to develop fuel-efficient vehicles has yet to be disbursed, with applicants for the money complaining that the Energy Department is crippling plans for greener cars and trucks at a time of rising gas prices.

headline: Artifacts Show Sophistication of Ancient Nomads
text: Ancient Greeks had a word for the people who lived on the wild, arid Eurasian steppes stretching from the Black Sea to the border of China. They were nomads, which meant “roaming about for pasture.” They were wanderers and, not infrequently, fierce mounted warriors. Essentially, they were “the other” to the agricultural and increasingly urban civilizations that emerged in the first millennium B.C.

headline: The Miso Primer
text: Most people have had miso one of two ways: in soup (that probably accounts for 95 percent of its use in the United States) or with fish that’s been marinated in the stuff. As my recent piece on miso discusses, there are many more uses than that. But you might want a tiny bit more detail than I offered in print before you get started. Here are some of the basics.

headline: Images of Afghan Victims Spread Rage at U.S. Following Massacre
text: Updated | 1:54 p.m. As my colleagues Taimoor Shah and Graham Bowley report, following the rampage killing of at least 16 civilians, 9 of them children, by an American soldier in southern Afghanistan on Sunday, Afghans posted graphic images of the victims on blogs and social networking sites.

headline: Behind the Cover Story: Susan Dominus on Investigating a Mystery Illness
In Zoll Sale, a Rare Big Mandate for Brown Brothers Harriman
text: Little about Asahi Kasei’s $2.2 billion deal for Zoll Medical seemed surprising when it was announced on Monday.

headline: Those Not-So-Crazy Republicans
text: My column on Sunday argued that if the Republican electorate were really as bonkers and self-destructive as many journalists have made it out to be, then Mitt Romney probably wouldn’t have a near-lock on the party’s nomination. Rubbish, retorts Jonathan Chait: Romney is only winning because he’s running “against uncharismatic has-beens” with no organization, because he’s  “routinely outspent his opposition four-to-one or more,” and because he’s routinely tried to outflank his opponents on the right. Given enough institutional advantages and enough pandering, in other words, even a sane man can persuade lunatics to vote for him.

headline: Hulu Announces a Deal for Selling Its Original Shows Overseas
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — Acting just like a television network, the online video Web site Hulu is joining with a third-party distributor to sell its original shows overseas.

headline: Google to Announce Venture With Belgian Museum
text: PARIS — Google, which organizes the world’s information digitally, is linking up with a precursor that aimed to do something similar, on paper.

headline: Reasons That Vitamin D May Matter
text: At least once a week, someone, usually a woman over 50, asks me about vitamin D. Perhaps a routine checkup has revealed a deficiency, prompting the doctor to recommend an over-the-counter supplement or, in severe cases, large prescription doses to correct the problem.

headline: TimesCast | March 12, 2012
text: Details emerge about the attack in southern Afghanistan by an American soldier that left at least 16 civilians dead | A French surgeon recalls volunteering in the Syrian city of Homs.

headline: Showtime Sets Return Dates for ‘Homeland’ and ‘Dexter’
text: In the department of much-buzzed-about cable serials that don’t take 17 months between seasons, Showtime said on Monday that new episodes of its hit drama “Homeland” will resume on Sept. 30, along with additional installments of its long-running thriller “Dexter.” “Homeland,” which is produced by Howard Gordon and Alex Gansa and adapted from Gideon Raff’s Israeli series “Prisoners of War,” last fall introduced viewers to the bipolar C.I.A. officer Carrie Mathison; the rescued soldier Nicholas Brody (Damian Lewis); and Saul Berenson (Mandy Patinkin), a veteran analyst with a truly spectacular beard.

headline: Russian Opposition Urges U.S. to End Cold War Trade Sanctions
text: MOSCOW — Prominent organizers of antigovernment demonstrations in Moscow urged the United States Congress on Monday to end cold war-era trade restrictions against Russia, saying that leaving them in place would only help President-elect Vladimir V. Putin.

headline: Albany Redrawing Political Map With Old Lines of Thought
text: ALBANY — This was the year New York State lawmakers were going to stop protecting incumbents by gerrymandering political maps to improve their re-election chances.

headline: Out of Jail, Ex-Professor and His Crossbow Fight South Korea’s Judiciary
text: SEOUL, South Korea — The image on the cover of Kim Myung-ho’s self-published book neatly captures his attitude toward the South Korean judiciary. It shows Mr. Kim, a former mathematics professor, standing defiantly, a law book in one hand and a crossbow in the other.

headline: French Velorution
text: It is counterintuitive that Paris, the host city of the Tour de France finish line, was ever not a bicycling capital, but until it got a bike-share program — and an expanded network of bike lanes — cycling was not a mainstream mode of transportation there. Now it’s de rigueur, thanks to the Vélib’ system’s more than 20,000 bikes at 1,800 stations. The Vélib’ app, available on iTunes, tells you where to find the nearest station and the number of bikes there. And at a little more than $2 a day, the price is hard to beat. (Bring your American Express card, though; Vélib’ machines are not compatible with Visas and MasterCards that do not have a European chip.)

headline: Alderson Updates Injuries to Byrdak and Wright
text: 2:46 p.m. | Updated

headline: Gas Rewards Cards That Lessen the Sting of High Prices
text: With gas prices edging toward an average of $4 gallon, it may be time to consider a credit card that gives you cash-back rewards at the pump.

headline: Following Shooting, Bullying Is Again in the Spotlight
text: School communities are turning yet again to issues of bullying, guns and violence following the shooting rampage two weeks ago at Chardon High School near Cleveland. On WNYC's "The Brian Lehrer Show" on Monday, Jessie Klein, an assistant professor of sociology and criminal justice at Adelphi University, makes the case that bullying, while hardly a new phenomenon, is a growing crisis in American schools that stems from a culture of competition and aggression.

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
text: Scott Becher joined Zimmerman Advertising, Fort Lauderdale, Fla., part of the Omnicom Group, in a new post, as an executive vice president and managing director, leading the agency’s partnership marketing team. Mr. Becher had been leading his own agency, Sports and Sponsorships, for the last 15 years.

headline: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
text: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week. Questions can be sent to stuarte@nytimes.com.

headline: Targeted Killing
text: In my post last week about Attorney General Eric Holder’s recent national security speech, I focused on the good news, and promised I’d come back to the parts that I found disturbing. This enraged several readers, who more or less accused me of selling out the Constitution to assist the Democratic president, and apparently didn’t believe I’d come back to the topic in due time.

headline: Kevin Smith’s New Deal Celebrated at SXSW
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — The director Kevin Smith doesn’t have a movie at this year’s South by Southwest festival, but he does have a movie deal. He was on hand at a party this weekend to celebrate his partnership with the distribution company Phase 4 Films. The Canadian company will release a series of films under a “Kevin Smith and SModcast Pictures Presents” label. Mr. Smith will choose the films and take them on the road for special screenings, much like he did with his last film “Red State.”

headline: Ads for Method Celebrate the Madness
text: A brand that has been striving mightily to enliven one of the most prosaic categories in consumer marketing is putting on a “happy” face.

headline: Before Wolves May Be Hunted, Science, Faith and Politics Clash
text: Once again, science, religion and politics have become entwined in a thorny public policy debate. This time, however, the discussion is not about abortion, birth control or health insurance mandates.

headline: Tostadas With a Healthy Foundation
text: Years ago, when a series of sodden leftovers taught me what bad idea it was to reheat pies and quiches in a microwave, it occurred to me that the microwave might be a perfect tool to create a chip that isn’t fried. It’s bad for crusty things because it draws liquid out from the center of foods, so crusts always become soggy. But if you put a plain corn tortilla in the microwave and zap it until all of the moisture is drawn out of it, the result is something resembling a chip.

headline: M.L.S. Week 1: Oh Canada, Oui
text: An old soccer rivalry was reanimated Saturday in the Pacific Northwest when the expansion Montreal Impact played their first game in M.L.S., losing to the Vancouver Whitecaps, 2-0.

headline: Next Goal for Delaware: Winning a Game in the N.C.A.A. Tournament
text: UPPER MARLBORO, Md.- The University of Delaware women’s basketball team completed what head coach Tina Martin calls stage two of their season goals on Sunday. The Hens won the Colonial Athletic Association conference tournament for the first time in school history.

headline: Childhood: Vitamin D Means Fewer Fractures for Girls
text: Higher amounts of vitamin D in the diet are associated with a lower risk for bone fractures in teenage girls, a new study has found.

headline: Romney on the Rope Line
text: Mitt Romney spoke to supporters at a campaign stop in Mobile, Ala., on Monday.

headline: Capturing a Vanishing View of Park Slope
text: “I knew it was going to go away, like everything does.”

headline: India Orders Bayer to License a Patented Drug
text: MUMBAI, India — India’s government on Monday authorized a drug manufacturer to make and sell a generic copy of a patented Bayer cancer drug, saying that Bayer charged a price that was unaffordable to most of the nation.

headline: Student Crossword | Basketball
text: Cleveland Cavaliers star who was sign-and-traded to the Miami Heat in 2010? Things that occasionally shatter during slam dunks? Knicks player who caused “Linsanity”? Play our crossword (PDF) this month to test yourself on the answers to these and many other basketball-themed questions.

headline: Caucus Click: Romney Works the Rope Line
text: After his campaign event in Mobile, Ala., was canceled due to rain, Mitt Romney spoke to supporters who waited outside along the rope line.

headline: Spain Agrees to a Further Deficit Reduction
text: BRUSSELS — European Union finance ministers won an agreement from Spain on Monday to take additional steps to reduce its bulging budget deficit in order to ease the latest threat to the euro zone, now that Greece has agreed with a majority of its private creditors on terms that will release bailout money.

headline: Prevention: Prostate Risk Is Lower After Circumcision
text: A new analysis has found evidence that circumcision may reduce the risk for prostate cancer.

headline: Promising Results for Specialized High School Tutoring Group
text: Alarmed by reports of declining numbers of black and Latino students in the city's elite high schools, two groups began offering free tutoring. One of them, the Science Schools Initiative, had 28 of its 64 students receive an acceptance letter.

headline: Join a Walking Tour From 1968
text: Many of you have joined us in our recent obsession with the whirlwind walking tour of 1968 Manhattan found in the filmmaker Hollis Frampton’s “Surface Tension.”

headline: Bruce Hornsby Musical Gets a Reading — and a New Name
text: The York Theater Company will present a reading of the Bruce Hornsby musical “Stranger” next week as part of its Developmental Reading Series. Titled “SCKBSTD” when it had its premiere last year at the Virginia Stage Company in Norfolk — the name referred to a vanity license plate — the dark musical is about a mysterious man who unnerves a small town as he drives around in an old Dodge. Based on an original story written by Mr. Hornsby, who wrote the music and lyrics, “Stranger” features lyrics by Chip deMatteo and a book by Clay McLeod Chapman.

headline: Asked & Answered | Paul Smith
text: Sir Paul Smith might be fashion’s biggest cycling fan. Long before he took up tailoring, Smith raced bikes, as a teenager in Nottingham, England. Though his competitive career ended early, after a bad accident when he was 16, his enthusiasm for the sport never wavered. A lover of cycling design, Smith has collaborated with Rapha on clothing and with Mercian on a limited line of cycles. Here, he offers sartorial tips for city cyclists.

headline: As Rockets Fly, New Conditions Shape Fight in Gaza
text: JERUSALEM — Cross-border fighting between Israel and Palestinian militant groups in Gaza continued for a fourth day on Monday, with the Palestinian death toll rising from Israeli airstrikes and the militants’ rockets reaching farther into Israel.

headline: Need Help Filling Out Your Bracket?
text: Stomach in knots trying to figure out the Murray State-Colorado State winner? Head spinning over which No. 12 seed will send home a No. 5? Feeling confused over why the first round is now the second round and wondering why those eight teams are playing on Tuesday? You need to make an appointment with The Times’s N.C.A.A. experts. Pete Thamel and Connor Ennis will be doing a 30-minute video hangout on The Times’s Google+ page on Tuesday at noon, holding Bracket Office Hours. So print out your bracket, plug in the webcam and bring along your questions.

headline: Things Adult Medicine Could Learn From Pediatrics
text: Twenty-eight years ago, I wrote about drawing blood for the first time, about the pain of the patient and the self-doubt of the medical student. In my first clinical experience, I was learning a strange new color code: red-top tube for blood chemistries, purple top for hematology, green top, yellow top, and so on.

headline: Springtime in Chelsea
text: Printed Matter, an art-book store in Chelsea, has been an indispensable resource for New York City’s art community for decades. The store, which often asks artists to design installations for its front window, most recently asked Sara Cwynar (who is also a designer here at the magazine) to create one with springtime as the theme. Cwynar looked to her personal archive of images and objects to create this green physical collage. The window will be up through March.

headline: Drilling Down: Facebook Timeline Changes the Game
text: In my latest This Week in Small Business post, Christopher S. Penn, a marketing specialist, offered some advice on making the best use of Facebook’s new Timeline feature. As a follow-up, I went back to Mr. Penn with a few questions.

headline: Romney Team Sees a Plus in Gingrich’s Persistence
text: BIRMINGHAM, Ala. — Mitt Romney has tried for weeks to snuff out Newt Gingrich’s presidential ambitions, but his stubborn survival has become a welcome relief for Mr. Romney.

headline: Study Disputes Oil Sands ‘Restoration’ Pledge
text: Most television viewers in Canada have witnessed attempts by the Canadian Association of Petroleum Producers to buff the environmental image of oil sands. One of its commercials depicts a pleasant forest that an oil company manager says was created on land reclaimed from an oil sands open pit mine.

headline: The Downside of Switching to a Tougher Conference
text: While everyone dissects the 68 men’s college basketball teams that will play in the N.C.A.A. tournament this week, it’s also worth pondering some that won’t be participating.

headline: TimesCast | After the Afghanistan Attack
text: March 12, 2012 - Details emerge about the attack in southern Afghanistan by an American soldier that left at least 16 civilians dead, 9 of them children.

headline: Behind the Poster: ‘In Masks Outrageous and Austere’
text: “In Masks Outrageous and Austere,” the final full-length play written by Tennessee Williams, is a darkly comic, highly theatrical work about a wealthy woman named Babe Foxworth who gets kidnapped by a mysterious corporate entity. The premiere production of the work — it’s never been produced for the stage — begins performances next month at Culture Project. Shirley Knight stars as Babe, and David Schweizer directs.

headline: High School Teammates May Have Tournament Reunion
text: I grew up in Ames, Iowa, a town of about 60,000, home of Iowa State University. I graduated from Ames High, loyal and true am I. But as proud as I am of being from Ames, I couldn’t imagine a day when the N.C.A.A. selection committee would be accused of conspiring a tournament matchup between two Ames High graduates.

headline: Oprah’s Network Gets Big Boost From Interview With Houston’s Daughter
text: It’s all about the bookings.

headline: How to Get Your Comments Past the Moderator
text: As most readers probably know, The Times moderates comments, meaning we delete the ones that don’t meet our standards. The rejection rate on this blog usually hovers around 5 or ten percent, but it’s been rising recently (up to 25 percent, in one case) so I figured I should provide a refresher on how to play by the rules.

headline: Small-Picture Approach Flips Medical Economics
text: CHICAGO — Even as she struggled to manage her Type 2 diabetes, Fannie Cline’s condition spiraled downward. It was not uncommon for Mrs. Cline, a 69-year-old retiree, to have dizzy spells, some so bad that they landed her in a hospital emergency room near her home here on the South Side.

headline: Beauty Spots
text: STAY DRY

headline: Researchers May Have Found Evidence of Lost Leonardo Masterpiece
text: Efforts to find a lost masterpiece by Leonardo da Vinci behind a fresco by Giorgio Vasari in Florence’s Palazzo Vecchio have shown possible signs of success, researchers in Italy say.

headline: What Europe Could Have Learned From the U.S. Bank Bailout
text: Was the United States government savvier about its banks than the Europeans?

headline: Front-Row View of the Madoff Civil Suit
text: The trial against Saul Katz and Fred Wilpon, the owners of the New York Mets, will be the first case related to Bernard L. Madoff’s Ponzi scheme that could provide insight into how Mr. Madoff interacted with long-time investors. But this being a civil suit, this case may not provide the closure that a typical criminal prosecution would bring.The trial in the lawsuit filed by Irving H. Picard, the court-appointed trustee representing victims of Bernard L. Madoff’s multibillion-dollar Ponzi scheme, is scheduled to begin next week.

headline: No Luck, but Grace Under Turbulence
text: THE first time I flew, I was 12 years old. I was alone and was going to Boston. We landed and were going down the runway and then stopped because emergency vehicles went roaring past us. I found out later that another flight hit a sea wall at Logan and everyone was killed.

headline: The Millennials Check In
text: The hotel industry, struggling to recover from the depths of the recession, has begun to contemplate a group of travelers it sees as crucial to its economic growth — those in their 20s to mid-30s who are obsessed with technology, social media and design.

headline: Look of The Moment | Audrey Tautou
text: The Look: Parisian Pouf. Spring’s favorite — white — turns girly on a sweet silhouette with full shoulders.

headline: Risks: More Red Meat, More Mortality
text: Eating red meat is associated with a sharply increased risk of death from cancer and heart disease, according to a new study, and the more of it you eat, the greater the risk.

headline: Religion and the Social Crisis
text: Yuval Levin has one of the most perceptive takes on Charles Murray’s “Coming Apart” that I’ve read to date:

headline: How Long Beach State Got In
text: LONG BEACH, Calif. — Three games in three days would decide everything, and Dan Monson, the Long Beach State men’s basketball coach, wanted to tune out his team’s players. He did not want to hear their music. He did not want to watch them eat.

headline: More Thoughts on ‘Game Change’
text: I notice that my post on “Game Change” drew more than the usual number of comments from readers, and the robustness of that reaction dovetails with the volume of e-mails and calls I’ve received from fellow writers and from political insiders I know. The issue of whether John McCain’s campaign workers did a great or lousy thing by sharing so many inside stories about Sarah Palin — and sharing stories in particular that cast her in a negative light — apparently provokes heated discussion.

headline: Magazine Reports That Ducati May Join Volkswagen Group Portfolio
text: Ducati was considered a relative bargain when the private equity firm Investindustrial expanded its ownership stake in the motorcycle manufacturer in 2008. Last year, reports surfaced that the firm was shopping Ducati to major automakers, with Daimler, the BMW Group, Mahindra & Mahindra of India and Volkswagen all on the short list of interested parties.

headline: App Smart Extra: More Singing Apps
text: Last week’s App Smart column featured apps for singers and aspiring vocalists, with Glee Karaoke and VoiceJam taking top billing.

headline: Sizing Up the Top 25
text: New to the rankings: No. 17 Louisville, No. 20 Vanderbilt, No. 21 New Mexico, No. 24 St. Mary’s.

headline: Group Suggests That Qaddafi Aided Sarkozy’s 2007 Campaign
text: PARIS — A spokesman for Nicolas Sarkozy on Monday sharply denied a suggestion by the investigative group Mediapart that the French president’s 2007 election campaign received up to 50 million euros, or more than $65 million, in illegal financial support from the late ruler of Libya, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.

headline: The Passing of F. Sherwood Rowland
text: I was saddened to learn today of the passing on Saturday of F. Sherwood Rowland, a remarkable scientist, engaged citizen and professor best known for sharing the 1995 Nobel Prize in Chemistry for work revealing the impact of synthetic chlorofluorocarbons on the atmosphere’s protective ozone layer. (Here’s the seminal 1974 Nature paper on these consequential chemical reactions in Nature by Mario J. Molina and Rowland.)

headline: Childbirth: A Different Way to Remove the Placenta May Save Mothers’ Lives, a Study Finds
text: Delivery without pulling on the umbilical cord may be a simpler way to keep some women from bleeding to death in childbirth, a new study has found.

headline: A New Chef at Adour
text: Adour, Alain Ducasse’s restaurant in the St. Regis hotel in Midtown, has a new chef: Julien Jouhannaud, who has worked with Mr. Ducasse for more than 10 years, most recently as the executive chef at Adour in the St. Regis in Washington.

headline: Senate Democrats Ready Jobs Bill, Aides Say
text: 4:31 p.m. | Updated Senate Democrats are expected on Tuesday to unveil their version of a small-business financing bill that passed last week in the House, with the Senate legislation including three of the six House provisions, as well as other measures to extend credit to small businesses, Democratic aides said.

headline: Revisiting the She-covery
text: Mike Konczal has a good post at the New Deal 2.0 blog, pointing out that much of the recent rise in female employment — the subject of my post on Friday — is a result of statistical fluctuations.

headline: Defendant Won’t Testify in Rutgers Case
text: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J. — Dharun Ravi sat largely expressionless for three weeks as friends testified in a courtroom here that he set up a webcam to spy on his roommate and another man as they had sex in his Rutgers dorm room in the days before the roommate, Tyler Clementi, committed suicide.

headline: With the New iPad, New Questions Over the Meaning of 4G
Merkel Defends Germany’s Nuclear Power Deadline
text: BERLIN — Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany defended over the weekend her government’s decision to phase out nuclear power by 2022 and replace it with renewable energy sources, dismissing critics who said the government would never make the deadline.

headline: The Massacre in Kandahar
text: I’ve been trying to think what I can add to the extensive coverage of the horrible massacre in the Kandahar region of Afghanistan. I haven’t come up with anything terribly original, but didn’t want to let this shameful event go unmentioned.

headline: Playing Up a Scotsman’s Lawn Expertise
text: A CAMPAIGN is celebrating the green, green grass of home with a new brand character who is meant to bring to life a familiar line of lawn-care products.

headline: Defense Lawyers Tangle in Brothel Case
text: A woman accused of running a brothel on the Upper East Side reappeared in court on Monday for a hearing, but much of the spotlight was stolen by her dueling lawyers.

headline: Pedal Pusher
text: Earl Blumenauer (above), who represents most of Portland, Ore., in Congress, insists that Washington, D.C., is a bikeable town. But then, Blumenauer would insist every city is a bikeable town. A passionate advocate of cycling, he founded the 170-member Congressional Bike Caucus and led a successful charge to put bike lanes up the middle of Pennsylvania Avenue. He bikes to work on Capitol Hill most days, and to the White House, occasionally confusing security guards. Blumenauer suggests visitors make good use of the city’s bike-share program, Capital Bikeshare, or rent a bike from the Bikestation at Union Station. He also recommends riding on the Capital Crescent Trail; along the C&O Canal; on the upper Rock Creek Trail; and at the National Arboretum, “a secret gem.”

headline: New York Is World’s Top City to Do Business, Study Finds
text: Anybody who has tried to hail a cab in Midtown during a rainstorm will not be surprised by the results of a survey released on Monday that ranked New York City as the most competitive city in the world.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Israel and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Israel, the West Bank, Afghanistan and India.

headline: Two Broncos Seek to Reverse Suspensions
text: Lawyers for Ryan McBean and D. J. Williams, two of the three Denver Broncos suspended last week for violating the N.F.L.’s drug policy, have asked a state court judge in Colorado to reverse their suspensions, arguing that the N.F.L.-appointed arbitrator mishandled their appeals.

headline: As It Warned, Yahoo Sues Facebook Over Patents
text: Yahoo stepped up its new feud with Facebook on Monday, suing the social-networking giant and accusing it of infringing on 10 patents tied to an array of Web technologies.

headline: North Carolina Loses 15 Scholarships in N.C.A.A. Ruling
text: North Carolina was the latest school to test the N.C.A.A.’s will to hand out tough punishments for programs run amok and found the N.C.A.A. still has some will to hand out tough punishments.

headline: Off Broadway Welcomes ‘Old Jews Telling Jokes’
text: One would be hard pressed to find a more honestly titled theater production than “Old Jews Telling Jokes,” an new Off Broadway show that promises to reinvent classic Jewish jokes and perform them on stage. Co-created by the authors Peter Gethers and Daniel Okrent and directed by Marc Bruni (“Fanny”), the project is inspired by the Web site oldjewstellingjokes.com which, true to its name, hosts videos of older Jewish raconteurs telling some of their favorite jokes.

headline: Approval Ratings, Gas Prices and Statistical Noise
text: 8:49 p.m. | Updated  This analysis was written and published before I had seen the results of the new New York Times/CBS News poll — which had President Obama’s approval ratings dropping all the way down to 41 percent. That certainly weighs the evidence more in the direction of Mr. Obama’s numbers having declined from their February peaks — and makes November’s election look more like a toss-up than one that leans toward Mr. Obama.

headline: Long Beach State’s Road to the Tournament
text: The 49ers won the Big West tournament, securing the league’s automatic bid to the N.C.A.A. tournament.

headline: New Worries About Sleeping Pills
text: Talk about sleepless nights.

headline: Fury Grows Over Afghan Killings
text: Afghan anger grew on Monday, a day after the massacre of at least 16 civilians, nine of them children, in a rural stretch of southern Afghanistan, allegedly by a veteran Army staff sergeant. Over at The Lede blog, our colleague Robert Mackey picked up on videos posted by one of the local Afghan news agencies, Pajhwok Afghan News. The videos show distressing, graphic images of the dead.

headline: Courage Far Beyond Fashion
text: IF you were to host a party for 500 guests to celebrate five courageous women from around the world, where would it be? How about the United Nations cafeteria?

headline: Surgery for Epilepsy Gains Urgency in Trial
text: Surgery for epilepsy is usually seen as a last resort for patients when medications do not work, and it is often delayed for many years after the failure of drug treatment. Now a randomized, controlled trial suggests that surgery as soon as possible after the failure of two antiepileptic drugs is a significantly better approach than continued medical care.

headline: Scene City: Diller-Von Furstenberg Awards
text: Tina Brown, Diane Von Furstenberg, Jessica Alba, Oprah and others celebrate International Women’s Day.

headline: Meatloaf Cakes
text: Adapted from Ann Romney

headline: Mitt Romney’s Blue-Collar Birthday Meal
text: RONALD REAGAN had his jelly beans, Poppy Bush had his pork rinds and Mitt Romney has his — meatloaf cakes?

headline: Can Corals Toughen Up After a Warming Crisis?
text: In 2010, record warm ocean temperatures across much of the tropics led to catastrophic coral bleaching. The devastation approached the scale of a 1998 calamity in which 16 percent of the world’s reefs died.

headline: Digital Notes: Sony Offers $8 Million Settlement Over Royalties
text: Ending a six-year dispute, Sony has offered an $8 million settlement in a class-action lawsuit over royalties for digital music. The case, originally filed by the Allman Brothers and Cheap Trick, was one of the first in what is now a wave of litigation by artists accusing major record companies of underpaying royalties by counting downloads as “sales,” like CDs, instead of as “licenses,” which pay much higher rates. (Royalties might be anywhere from 5 percent to 20 percent for sales, while 50 percent on a license is standard.)

headline: One Death That Haunts Many Lives
text: Carol Anshaw’s beautifully observed new novel, “Carry the One,” begins with a terrible accident in the summer of 1983: very late at night, after Carmen and Matt’s wedding, a car filled with some seriously stoned and sleepy wedding guests turns onto a two-lane road, accelerates through a dip, and then, suddenly, horribly, strikes a young girl named Casey Redman. She is dead at the age of 10.

headline: All the Jobs Are Moving to Mars
text: Ethan Lipton, a wry singer-songwriter whose heavy-lidded affability and retro facial hair make him look like a doomed sidekick in a ’70s cop movie, grinned upon learning that one collaborator after another had independently used the word Everyman to describe him. “Here, and I thought I was fancy,” he said.

headline: The Hawk Cam Is Back for Another Season
text: The Hawk Cam is rolling once more.

headline: The fabulous art of the nomads of Kazakhstan, the marriage formula; and lost in space.
text: The fabulous art of the nomads of Kazakhstan, the marriage formula; and lost in space.

headline: What’s Your Meatloaf Recipe?
text: A mix of ground beef, bread crumbs and onions, Ann Romney’s meatloaf recipe — her husband’s birthday favorite — breaks no new ground. But that’s not really the point. Meatloaf is not about new tricks. It’s about familiarity: the way you like to do it, the way you always do it, maybe even the way your great-grandmother did it.

headline: College’s Winter Break Finally Ends
text: The NBC comedy “Community” has finally come to the end of its gap semester.

headline: Sentence of the Month: February
text: Thanks to everyone who voted in our last Sentence of the Week competition. The winner — just beating out Richard Rorty (“Nietzsche, at his worst, gestured towards some narcissistic and inarticulate hunks of Bronze Age beefcake”) and John Jeremiah Sullivan (“She was complicated, deeper than the other teens on ‘One Tree,’ which in teen-show terms meant that she often wore flannel shirts”) — is Fyodor Dostoevsky:

headline: Discussing Manning, Romney Touts Ties to Football Team Owners
text: CENTREVILLE, Ala. — On Monday afternoon, Mitt Romney called into the Paul Finebaum Radio Network, an enormously popular daily sports talk show based out of Birmingham, Ala., that on most days concerns college football, and particularly the acrimonious partisan battle between Auburn and Alabama fans. It also routinely features some of the more colorful callers in the sports talk radio landscape.

headline: With Focus on Player Safety, General Managers Propose New Icing Rule
text: BOCA RATON, Fla. — Reacting to concerns over player safety, N.H.L. general managers moved closer to changing the league’s icing rule Monday.

headline: Two Cheers for Double Standards
text: In his Campaign Stops column, Stanley Fish writes:

headline: A Moscow Show Trial on the Bosphorus
text: Another post from a colleague, this time about Turkey, from Dani Rodrik at Harvard’s Kennedy School. Dani is a first-rate economist, who has staked out important ground as a critic of conventional wisdom on trade and development; you can read some of his ideas on his blog, where this will be cross-posted. He’s also personally involved in the matters discussed below: his father-in-law is the lead defendant in the case.

headline: Q&A: Screaming for Google Ice Cream
text: Q.

headline: Building A Caste Society
text: Thomas Edsall has an excellent piece on growing educational stratification in America, specifically how access to higher education is increasingly being denied to the children of the less affluent. And as he says, this is very much about policy. One graphic he links to (ppt) but doesn’t include is just stunning: here’s the declining value of Pell grants compared with college costs:

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Twitter Acquires Posterous, and Facebook Bigamy Case
text: Here are some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web on Monday. There are more here.

headline: Nate Silver’s March Madness
text: Nate Silver, the author of The Times’s FiveThirtyEight blog, presents the probability of each of the 68 teams winning the N.C.A.A. national championship.

headline: The Fineries of Ancient Nomads
text: A sampling of artifacts from the nomadic societies of the arid Eurasian steppes, which are on exhibit at the Institute for the Study of the Ancient World.

headline: Top Challenger in Egypt Vote Is an Islamist, and Moderate
text: CAIRO — One spent a career working beside Hosni Mubarak, the former president. The other spent years in his jails.

headline: A Little-Known Guest Arrives to Make an Impression
text: As the Boston Symphony Orchestra enters a second year without a music director, a parade of guest conductors continues to cross its podium. Some are legitimate candidates to succeed James Levine, who resigned last March, though two heavyweight contenders had to cancel appearances with the orchestra this season: Riccardo Chailly, for health reasons, and Andris Nelsons, for the birth of his baby.

headline: Overnight A, C and E Subway Riders, Time for Confusion
text: The traveling subway-repair show known as Fastrack brings it shut-down-the-trains-at-night-and-get-tons-of-work-done madness to the A, C and E lines this week, after successful runs on the 4, 5 and 6, the B, D, F and M and the 1, 2 and 3.

headline: In a Pasha’s Seraglio, Even Flowers Turn Frisky
text: The sublime and the ridiculous can coexist in disconcerting proximity. Witness Alexei Ratmansky’s 2007 production for the Bolshoi Ballet of the 19th-century ballet “Le Corsaire,” which on Sunday was broadcast live to cinemas worldwide (including in Manhattan). Actually “Le Corsaire” (“The Pirate”) in any modern production is often ridiculous. Only in Mr. Ratmansky’s version does it touch on the sublime — and more so in this broadcast than when I saw this staging live in 2007 in the relatively cramped conditions of the London Coliseum.

headline: Coming Soon: The Wearable, Online, All-the-Time Baby Monitor
text: From the department of the inevitable: the Exmobaby wireless, biosensor baby onesie. It’s washable, rechargeable and transmits information up to 100 feet. Soon, very soon, you can monitor your baby’s ECG, skin temperature, and movement, and have constant alerts sent to your PC or mobile phone.

headline: East Village Record Store Other Music Starts a Label
text: Other Music, the East Village record store that purveys everything from electronica to indie rock, is starting its own record label later this month with an eye toward showcasing underground music in New York and reissuing albums by foreign artists, one of the store’s owners, Josh Madell, said on Monday.

headline: Nymphs, a Moor, and Lovers Roam About
text: The New York Theater Ballet’s Signatures series juxtaposes old and new. Usually the vintage stuff — forgotten or rarely performed works by master choreographers — is best, but sometimes, as in the program performed on Friday at Gould Hall, the balance is more even.

headline: Premiere for Cello and Orchestra, Inspired by a Poem
text: Through its invaluable First Music program, the New York Youth Symphony has commissioned works from more than 100 emerging composers since 1984. The orchestra’s concert on Sunday afternoon at Carnegie Hall brought the premiere of “That Blue Repair,” a kind of mini-concerto by Chris Rogerson.

headline: Pairings: Coq au Vin Blanc
text: Just as Oregon borrows from Burgundy in vineyards planted with pinot noirs and chardonnays, that region also inspires dinner. The iconic boeuf bourguignon would not be the best choice with chardonnay, but this version of coq au vin, replacing Chambertin with chardonnay, couldn’t be better. I went light with it, omitting the bacon lardons. And I gave a nod to Oregon’s truffle crop by finishing the sauce with a gloss of black truffle butter. It’s a modest investment that elevates the dish. A generous slab of unsalted butter (especially if it’s high-fat European-style) could also bolster the sauce, though with less foxy intrigue.

headline: Oregon Chardonnay Speaks Up
text: IN the beginning, there was chardonnay, and it was not good.

headline: New Albums From VCMG, Brad Mehldau Trio and Henry Cole and the Afrobeat Colective
text: VCMG

headline: New York Times/CBS Poll
text: A New York Times/CBS survey shows that Republican primary voters remain divided over the leading candidates.

headline: Romantic Staples, With Texture and a Tangy Bite
text: The Dresden Philharmonic traces its history back nearly six centuries, to independent civic bands that flourished between the 16th and 19th centuries. But the orchestra as we know it today was actually founded in 1870, so depending on how you look at it, it is either one of the world’s oldest orchestras or nearly 30 years younger than the New York Philharmonic.

headline: How the Poll Was Conducted
text: The latest New York Times/CBS News poll is based on telephone interviews conducted March 7 through 11 with 1,009 adults throughout the United States. Of these, 878 said they were registered to vote.

headline: Life on Mars? Funds to Find Answer Fade
text: Just as NASA is on the cusp of answering the most fascinating questions about Mars — is there, was there or could there be life there? — the money needed to provide the answers is about to be abruptly withdrawn, a victim of President Obama’s budget request for 2013, scientists say.

headline: Excerpt: 'Community'
text: The NBC sitcom returns this week.

headline: Obama’s Rating Falls as Poll Reflects Volatility
text: Despite improving job growth and an extended Republican primary fight dividing his would-be opponents, President Obama is heading into the general election season on treacherous political ground, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.

headline: A Partnership Aims at Streamlining Security
text: CLEAR, the company that provided expedited airport security clearance to travelers who agreed to background checks, went out of business with heavy debts in 2009 — dashing expectations that private enterprise would soon become a major partner with the government at airport security checkpoints.

headline: Daylight Savings Links
text: Read these in sunlight at 6 p.m. while you get ready to complain about the heat:

headline: Inside the Stratfor Attack
text: 1:58 p.m. | Updated Adding clarification from the F.B.I. regarding how much of Stratfor’s data it was able to salvage.

headline: Facebook Confronts a Familiar Opponent in Fight With Yahoo
text: Yahoo‘s lawsuit against Facebook on Monday over allegations of patent infringement offered interesting nuggets of information, including the 10 technologies in question.

headline: At Elite Colleges, Too Much Hubris?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Ask About Raptors in New York City
text: Now that Hawk Cam 2012 is up and running, it’s time to Ask the Expert. New York City Audubon‘s director of conservation and science, Susan Elbin, responded to readers’ questions about the behavior, habitat, ecology and conservation of hawks and other birds of prey that live in the city. What are the major factors that put hawks — and other birds — at risk? What can humans do to help conserve and protect the wild birds of New York City?

headline: Taking the Plunge
text: Q. If I find myself in a free-falling elevator, is there any position that might increase my chance of survival? (Climbing on top of other people is not an acceptable answer.)

headline: Visions for the Last Section of the High Line
text: Initial designs for the third and final section of the High Line were released Monday by Friends of the High Line. Section 3 will wrap around the striking stretch of rail yards at the center of the Hudson Yards project.

headline: Where the Curly Haired Go to Be Coiffed
text: Looking for a blowout in Manhattan? The options are infinite and often overwhelming. Looking for someone to carefully coif your curls? You can count the options on one hand. Miss Jessie’s, the product line that specifically caters to curly manes, has just opened Miss Jessie’s CurlBar in SoHo, offering an alternative to Dry Bar. There, loyal disciples and newcomers alike can stop in or make an appointment for services like a wash & go or a curly haircut.

headline: Polling in Deep South Has Posed Challenges
text: The polls suggest a tight race in Alabama and Mississippi, which will hold their primaries on Tuesday. Our polling-based forecasts show Newt Gingrich with a very small lead in Alabama and Mitt Romney with an equally small one in Mississippi. Rick Santorum seems to have fallen to third in both states, but remains in striking distance.

headline: Refining the Formula That Predicts Celebrity Marriages’ Doom
text: In 2006, Garth Sundem and I confronted one of the great unsolved mysteries in social science: Exactly how soon will a given celebrity marriage blow up?

headline: Robertson Ditches the Boot
text: TAMPA, Fla. — Dave Robertson, without the protective boot on his foot, breezed through the clubhouse Monday afternoon without a trace of a limp. That was probably the most encouraging sign that he would indeed be ready for opening day.

headline: America’s Fossil-Fuels Jobs Boom
text: With gasoline prices spiraling higher and weighing on economic confidence, President Obama called over the weekend for further investment in a “clean-energy future.” But there is a flip side to that increasing pain at the pump: a huge jobs boom in fossil fuels industries.

headline: Team Tracks a Food Supply at the End of the World
text: One recent morning at the bottom of the world, Kim Bernard spotted two humpback whales gorging in the Southern Ocean not far offshore. Dr. Bernard, a biological oceanographer, was spending the austral summer at Palmer Station, the United States research outpost on an outcropping off the western Antarctic Peninsula.

headline: Devils Keep Pushing on Offense, and Keep Winning
text: NEWARK — Not only did the Devils lose a lot last season, but they were not much fun to watch, either. They were last in the N.H.L. in scoring, by a wide margin, and their power play was near the bottom of the league. No wonder they missed the playoffs for the first time in 14 years.

headline: Libya’s Franchise Fiasco
text: LIBYA’S new electoral law, passed by the National Transitional Council last month, provides guidelines for selecting the country’s first-ever democratic government. Many, including the United Nations, hailed the law’s passage as a significant step down Libya’s rocky political road.

headline: Sawfish Have Nose for Attacks, and for Strategy
text: A new study details the way the sawfish uses its trademark long, toothy snout to swiftly and fiercely attack prey.

headline: Chimpanzees Show Skills in Managing Conflict
text: A teacher might intervene when two fifth graders get rowdy on the playground, and it turns out that chimpanzees also have such arbitrators.

headline: When Snow Fleas Surface, Winter Study Comes to a Close
text: John Vucetich, a wildlife ecologist from Michigan Technological University, leads the wolf-moose Winter Study at Isle Royale National Park.
