text: He is as unlikely a trend spotter as they come, working in a cargo warehouse at Kennedy International Airport.

headline: At Detroit, Son Joins His Father for the Ride
text: DETROIT — Keri Gaither, the athletic director at the University of Detroit, apologized in advance for looking a little tired. Ray McCallum, the coach of the university’s basketball team, said he was not getting enough sleep, either.

headline: Jets Re-Sign a Leader on Defense for 3 Years
text: The Jets accomplished one of their off-season priorities, re-signing defensive tackle Sione Pouha to a three-year contract. Pouha, one of the league’s dominant run-stoppers last season, would have become an unrestricted free agent Tuesday.

headline: Contractor Pleads Guilty to One of Many Tax Charges
text: An 83-year-old demolition contractor who made and lost fortunes while repeatedly running into problems with the authorities pleaded guilty on Monday to failing to file state tax returns on his personal income for three years.

headline: Appeals Court Overturns Millennium Bomb-Plot Sentence; Calls it Too Light
text: LOS ANGELES — A federal appeals court on Monday overturned the 22-year prison sentence for Ahmed Ressam, the Algerian national known as the Millennium Bomber, who plotted to set off explosives at Los Angeles International Airport on Dec. 31, 1999. The court deemed the sentence too lenient.

headline: Conflicted, and Often Getting a Pass
text: NEW ORLEANS— “We are all totally conflicted — get used to it.”

headline: Trade Issues With China Flare Anew
text: HONG KONG — A month after Vice President Xi Jinping’s visit to the United States and Europe, the brief trade policy détente between China and its two biggest export markets is about to end.

headline: President Recapturing Groups Won by G.O.P. in 2010
text: While President Obama is locked in a tight race for re-election, the latest New York Times/CBS News poll found him faring well against the top Republican candidates among some important groups that abandoned Congressional Democrats in 2010.

headline: Bike Thief
text: The filmmaker Casey Neistat conducts an experiment in New York City, locking up his own bike and brazenly trying to steal it, to determine whether onlookers or the police would intervene.

headline: For Better or Worse, Cabrera Takes Over at Third
text: LAKELAND, Fla. — The Detroit Tigers’ Miguel Cabrera paused, searching his memory for his favorite position to play. He ran through the time he had spent during his professional career in right field, left field, shortstop, first base and third base, and said what he liked about each.

headline: S.E.C. Close to Bringing Cases on 2 Brokerage Firms
text: Federal regulators are close to bringing cases against two brokerage firms that trade stocks of privately held companies, the first legal actions resulting from a yearlong investigation into the buying and selling of shares of closely held Internet start-ups.

headline: Wine Dealer Was Trusted by His Allies
text: Like many other wine enthusiasts, Paul Wasserman trusted Rudy Kurniawan. They met in Los Angeles in 2002, when both were part of a group that gathered to taste Burgundies — not the old, rare bottles that were selling at auctions for thousands of dollars, but wines of recent vintages that were interesting to serious students.

headline: A Rejection of Discrimination
text: When Texas lawmakers were writing one of the nation’s most restrictive voter-identification laws last spring, they rejected a proposal to allow voters to use other forms of ID beyond a narrow list. They rejected another suggestion to help voters without an ID card apply for one. And when a lawmaker offered an amendment to offer free access to birth certificates in order to get a card, instead of charging $22, they rejected that, too.

headline: The Challenge of Stopping Griner and Baylor
text: Brittney Griner, Baylor’s 6-foot-8 junior center, may yet be considered the greatest player ever in women’s college basketball. But she has not won a national championship to help elevate her star into that firmament.

headline: ‘Bike Thief’
text: I was 20 years old when I moved to New York City on a Friday in June 2001. I brought all the clothes I could fit in a big duffel bag, along with my bicycle. Monday morning I was to report to my new job as a bike messenger. Saturday, my first full day in Manhattan, my bike was stolen.

headline: Go Ahead, Do Your Worst
text: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — I try to be fair in my puzzle write-ups, really I do.

headline: Rick Santorum Still Isn’t Crazy
text: The comments on my column about Rick Santorum and the separation of church and state were voluminous and often passionate. Once we set aside those readers who call religion a disease, a superstition and an obstacle to serious thought, and discount those who think that by identifying Santorum as a Republican and Justices Scalia, Thomas and Rehnquist as conservatives they’ve made an argument, and disqualify those who describe me as an “indoctrinated Catholic” (who knew?) and a “right wing kook” (please tell Fox News), we are left with some serious questions about the history of religion clause jurisprudence, the scope of the establishment clause, the status of secularism as a middle or common ground and the accuracy of Santorum’s account of John F. Kennedy’s speech to the Houston Baptists.

headline: Yet Another Curb on Abortion
text: Republicans on Capitol Hill chose an odd way to mark International Women’s Day on Thursday. The Judiciary Committee in the Republican-controlled House held a hearing to promote a mean-spirited and constitutionally suspect bill called the Child Interstate Abortion Notification Act.

headline: Dream Act for New York
text: The Dream Act is an aptly named-but-star-crossed piece of federal legislation that would open a path to legal status for young unauthorized immigrants who pursue college degrees or serve in the military. Its goal is to help ambitious youths who were brought here as children and are American in all but the paperwork.

headline: Use of Homeless as Internet Hot Spots Backfires on Marketer
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — Which product at this year’s South by Southwest technology conference received more attention than perhaps any other?

headline: Horror in Kandahar
text: The massacre of at least 16 civilians in three Afghan villages by an American soldier on Sunday was an unspeakable horror. The United States said Monday that an investigation is under way. It must be fast, transparent and conclusive so that Afghans can see that America is committed to justice and responsive to their outrage. The punishment must be swift.

headline: Is MF Global Getting a Free Pass?
text: It’s sure starting to look as if Jon Corzine is going to get away with it.

headline: F. Sherwood Rowland, Cited Aerosols’ Danger, Is Dead at 84
text: SAN FRANCISCO — F. Sherwood Rowland, whose discovery in 1974 of the danger that aerosols posed to the ozone layer was initially met with disdain but who was ultimately vindicated with the 1995 Nobel Prize in Chemistry, died on Saturday at his home in Corona del Mar, Calif. He was 84.

headline: On Eve of Albany Policy Push, Cardinal Focuses on Good Will
text: ALBANY — The cardinal explored the Capitol like a curious tourist on Monday, commenting loudly as he gazed from side to side at the paintings and historic treasures outside Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s office.

headline: Corrections: March 13
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: The Disappearance of Dolan
text: CHICAGO — An anniversary of sorts quietly passed on Monday, and the Knicks’ owner, James L. Dolan, celebrated in a manner appropriate to the occasion: by remaining blissfully, stubbornly silent.

headline: The Fertility Implosion
text: When you look at pictures from the Arab spring, you see these gigantic crowds of young men, and it confirms the impression that the Muslim Middle East has a gigantic youth bulge — hundreds of millions of young people with little to do. But that view is becoming obsolete. As Nicholas Eberstadt and Apoorva Shah of the American Enterprise Institute point out, over the past three decades, the Arab world has undergone a little noticed demographic implosion. Arab adults are having many fewer kids.

headline: Judge in Case From Yonkers Raises Doubts on Evidence
text: A federal judge in Manhattan indicated on Monday that she had serious questions about whether the government had proved a key part of its corruption case against a former Yonkers councilwoman accused of selling her vote to approve a proposed luxury mall and housing complex in return for thousands of dollars in secret payments.

headline: Link to a Young, Softer Steinbrenner Dies
text: George Steinbrenner was a collegian with a powder-blue Plymouth convertible when he met Mary Jane Schriner in the summer of 1949. She was 16 and dreaming of a writing career. He was 19, nearly a quarter-century from buying the Yankees.

headline: White House Outlines Plan to Help With Job Search
text: Obama administration officials said a proposal to consolidate two existing job training and placement programs would help hundreds of thousands of people get training they need to find work.

headline: In ‘Battle’ With Media, a New Tactic in Ecuador
text: QUITO, Ecuador — The fight goes on for Rafael Correa, the president of Ecuador, who has been in a relentless donnybrook with his country’s news media almost from the day he took office five years ago.

headline: President Obama’s Approval Rating Drops
text: New York Times/CBS News poll.

headline: European Airlines and Airbus Seek to Ease Emissions Rule
text: Airbus and Europe’s biggest airlines on Monday called on the European Union to find a compromise on aviation carbon curbs, warning that Europe’s emission limits on foreign carriers could lead to retaliation.

headline: Bitter Rivalry Thaws, if Briefly, on a Street in the Dominican Republic
text: TAMPA, Fla. — Maybe in some parallel universe, it would not be shocking to see David Ortiz, slugger for the Boston Red Sox, and Ivan Nova, starting pitcher for the Yankees, hugging, laughing and dancing together to commemorate an important baseball victory.

text: Hussy. Harlot. Hooker.

headline: Intel Talking to Networks About Internet TV Service
text: Intel has held preliminary talks with entertainment companies recently about creating a service for accessing television shows over the Internet.

headline: MF Global Customers Said to Get Offers for Their Claims
text: The thousands of MF Global customers whose lives and businesses were derailed after $1.6 billion vanished in the collapse of the brokerage firm have now received offers to sell their claims and recoup nearly the entire shortfall, people involved in the negotiations said.

headline: NYT at SXSW
text: Alexis Mainland of The Times hosts a Google Plus Hangout with Rick Webb, an angel investor and co-founder of the Barbarian Group, an Internet marketing firm.

headline: Mets Pack a Whole Lot of Troubles Into 2 Days
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — For the Mets, it is probably not quite the way they wanted to start the week. Their star third baseman, who has yet to play in a spring training game, gets a cortisone shot in the side. Their only left-handed reliever is prepped for unexpected knee surgery. Their bullpen catcher is arrested on drunken-driving charges several hours after attending a team bowling party. And a member of the 2011 Mets is suspended for 50 games after a second positive test for a recreational drug.

headline: Support for Afghan Fight Drops Among G.O.P. Candidates
text: Amid a series of bloody and troubling episodes in Afghanistan that have inflamed Afghan opinion against the United States, Rick Santorum and Newt Gingrich are now calling for a reassessment of American policy there — suggesting that it may be time to withdraw troops sooner than the Obama administration has planned.

headline: The New iPad Is Already Scarce
text: If you haven’t ordered the new iPad already online and you don’t plan to brave the lines likely to form later this week when it goes on sale in stores, don’t expect to get your hands on the device anytime soon.

headline: Young, Black and Male in America
text: Would pulling back on draconian drug laws be enough to fix the disproportionate number of black men behind bars? What else needs to be done?

headline: Snippets From SXSW Interactive: Monday Updates
text: We’re posting quick updates from South by Southwest Interactive on our Tumblr. Here is a sampling of Monday’s posts:

headline: Valentine and Red Sox Set to Visit Yankees
text: TAMPA, Fla. — The Boston Red Sox come to Tampa on Tuesday for the first time in spring training. More interesting is that it will be the first meeting between the Yankees and the Red Sox since Boston hired the outspoken manager Bobby Valentine in December.

headline: Rushworth M. Kidder, Ethicist, Dies at 67
text: Rushworth M. Kidder, an academic-turned-journalist who founded a research institute dedicated to mapping approaches to ethical dilemmas, propounding his ideas in books, speeches and seminars, died on March 5 at a nursing home in Davie, Fla. He was 67.

headline: Hague Court to Decide Where Former Dictator of Chad Will Be Tried
text: PARIS — International judges in The Hague are hearing a complex case this week that boils down to a single and unusual question: which country has the right to try Hissène Habré, the former president of Chad, who has been indicted in two nations in connection with political killings, torture and a host of other brutalities.

headline: Suspects Sought in Death of Chelsea Man
text: The police on Monday named two suspects in the death of a Chelsea man found bound and gagged with duct tape in his ransacked apartment this month.

headline: SXSW Video: Rick Webb, Angel Investor
text: Lexi Mainland chats in a Google Plus Hangout with Rick Webb, angel investor and co-founder of the Barbarian Group, at South by Southwest Interactive.

headline: Sports Replay: March 12
text: Soccer, spring training and other images from the day in sports.

headline: For Some in Vietnam, Prosperity Is a South Korean Son-in-Law
text: QUANG YEN, Vietnam — In the end, Bui Van Vui lived only three months in the new house that two of his daughters, married to men in South Korea, had helped him build here. Dying of throat cancer, he had exhorted the anxious contractor to hurry, scribbling on scraps of paper after he could no longer speak.

headline: Seattle Gets the Street View on the Quality of Its Lights
text: SEATTLE — This city has a noble notion of itself at the leading edge. Its jets, coffee, computers, environmental activism and philanthropy have all been celebrated for remaking the globe.

headline: G.O.P. Split Over a Bid to Revise Budget Deal
text: WASHINGTON — The House is bracing for a rancorous showdown over a 2013 budget plan that has already divided Republicans because of a push by conservatives to cut spending below the level both parties agreed to in last year’s deal to raise the federal deficit.

headline: The Hypocrite in Everyone Else
text: The continuous stream of reports detailing inconsistencies on the part of politicians makes it hard to believe that the rest of us might be as bad as they are.

headline: Explaining Paterno Firing
text: Penn State’s board of trustees issued a statement explaining its rationale for the firing of Joe Paterno on Nov. 9. In the statement, the trustees essentially reiterated that they moved to fire Paterno in part because he did not tell the police what he knew about a suspected 2002 sexual assault of a young boy by the former assistant Jerry Sandusky.

headline: Nitkowski’s Winding Path Could Lead Back to Flushing
text: Years ago, C.J. Nitkowski completed a kind of triple play for a New York ballplayer. He starred for St. John’s and played for the Mets and the Yankees among his eight major league stops in a career that stretched from 1995 through 2005.

headline: Knicks Play Better, but Their Losing Streak Gets Longer
text: CHICAGO — The ball had squirted loose, been gathered up, launched and bounced loose again, before finding its way, inevitably, back to Derrick Rose. A few steps and one leap later, Rose was in flight, soaring over the paint, between Baron Davis and Tyson Chandler and bearing down on the basket.

headline: Britain to Join Obama in Discouraging a Strike on Iran
text: WASHINGTON — Britain will add its voice to President Obama’s in discouraging an Israeli military strike on Iran when Prime Minister David Cameron begins a three-day visit here this week, a senior British diplomat said Monday.

headline: No Drastic Moves Planned by G.M.’s
text: BOCA RATON, Fla. — N.H.L. general managers and league officials, relatively satisfied with the measures they have taken to promote concussion safety over the past couple of years, are sticking with the status quo at their annual three-day meetings.

headline: Church Puts Legal Pressure on Abuse Victims’ Group
text: Turning the tables on an advocacy group that has long supported victims of pedophile priests, lawyers for the Roman Catholic Church and priests accused of sexual abuse in two Missouri cases have gone to court to compel the group to disclose more than two decades of e-mails that could include correspondence with victims, lawyers, whistle-blowers, witnesses, the police, prosecutors and journalists.

headline: Word of the Day | deference
text: deference •\ˈde-fə-rən(t)s, ˈdef-rən(t)s\• noun

headline: Champions League Preview: Inter and Bayern Plot Their Escapes
text: Arsenal’s memorable failure against Milan last week notwithstanding, no lead is insurmountable in the Champions League, especially when your team can run out some of the world’s best players to try to erase it. (Scratch that: 7-0 in the second half is pretty safe.) But there’s a big difference between staring at a 4-0 deficit, as Arsenal was entering the second leg, and trying to climb out of a 1-0 hole. Inter Milan and Bayern Munich are happy to be facing a one-goal deficit on Tuesday.

headline: Turkey: Court Frees 4 Journalists Accused in Plot
text: An Istanbul court on Monday released four journalists from jail, where they had been awaiting trial on charges that they were part of a plot to overthrow the government. Human rights groups have accused Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s government of repressing freedom of speech through a mixture of intimidation and arrests. Two of the journalists, the award-winning investigative reporters Nedim Sener and Ahmet Sik spent more than a year in prison after being accused of being part of an illegal terrorist group. Both men have denied the charges. According to the Journalists Union of Turkey, about 100 journalists are currently imprisoned. The government disputes that figure and insists that most of the jailed journalists were arrested for activities other than reporting.

headline: Iran: Critical U.N. Human Rights Report Denounced
text: Iran issued an angry rejoinder to a United Nations Human Rights Council report that castigated its record, calling the contents false, fabricated, biased and a reflection of manipulations by “certain Western countries and their cronies on the council,” a reference to the United States and its allies. First circulated last week, the 36-page report by Ahmed Shaheed, a former foreign minister from Maldives, found what he called evidence of a “striking pattern of violations of fundamental human rights guaranteed under international law,” offering numerous examples of illegal detentions and maltreatment of prisoners, dissidents, minorities and women. The report, commissioned after Iran’s crackdown on the political opposition following the disputed 2009 presidential election, also criticized Iran for its large number of executions. Iran’s own High Council for Human Rights said the report “amounted to nothing more than the repetition of a barrage of unsubstantiated and biased contentions.”

headline: Iraq: Gunmen Kill at Least 11 in Separate Attacks
text: At least six people were killed Monday by gunmen who robbed jewelry stores in the eastern Baghdad neighborhood of Shaab, security officials said. Militant groups frequently rob the stores to finance their operations. Two store owners were killed in the assaults, as well as two police officers and two soldiers, Iraqi security officials said. One attacker was killed, one was wounded and the rest escaped with gold and cash, the police said. Also on Monday, in Tarmiya, north of Baghdad, five bodyguards for a local council were assassinated, the Iraqi police said.

headline: At Funeral, Recalling Many Sides of Reporter
text: OYSTER BAY, N.Y. — No matter where she was, in some war-torn region on the other side of the world or on the Gothic campus of Yale University, Marie Colvin was always “trailing clouds of glory and pandemonium,” a former college roommate remembered on Monday.

headline: Coney Island Boardwalk Closer to Concrete
text: One speaker waved an ugly chunk of concrete, while another rhapsodized about the slant of sunlight on real wood. But in the end, the New York City Public Design Commission voted to allow the city’s parks department to install a section of plastic and concrete to replace aging wood planks on a small section of the Coney Island Boardwalk.

headline: An Update on New York Redistricting
text: New York is now among the last states in the nation to tackle the redistricting required as a result of the 2010 census. And the urgency is growing: the state’s Congressional primary is scheduled for June 26, and its legislative primary for Sept. 11.

headline: FiveThirtyEight Picks the N.C.A.A. Bracket
text: The long march of the Republican nomination hasn’t been very friendly to those political writers who were hoping to enjoy March Madness. But I did dust off the FiveThirtyEight N.C.A.A. forecasting model, which is back with a fresh set of projections for this year’s men’s field. You can find those forecasts here.

headline: U.S. Supporters of Iranian Group Face Scrutiny
text: WASHINGTON — For more than a year, prominent former American officials have been giving well-paid speeches in support of an Iranian opposition group that is fighting to reverse its 15-year-old designation by the State Department as a terrorist organization.

headline: India Starts Letting Students Do Lab Experiments Online
text: “India has begun work on a large online laboratory network, allowing students with Internet access to carry out scientific experiments remotely,” Christopher F. Schuetze writes in The New York Times.

headline: India Orders Bayer to License a Patented Drug
text: The Indian government on Monday “authorized a drug manufacturer to make and sell a generic copy of a patented Bayer cancer drug, saying that Bayer charged a price that was unaffordable to most of the nation,” Vikas Bajaj and Andrew Pollack write in The New York Times.

headline: On West Coast, Looking for Flotsam of a Disaster
text: SAN FRANCISCO — John Anderson, a plumber by trade and a beachcomber by passion, has been trolling the shores of the Olympic Peninsula in Washington State for more than three decades, and along the way has discovered almost every kind of flotsam one can imagine: toys, refrigerators, even the occasional message in a bottle.

headline: NYT Front Page for 03/13/2012
text: NYT Front Page for 03/13/2012

headline: Michigan: Detroit May Avoid Imposition of Outside Manager
text: State officials expect on Tuesday to present Detroit leaders with a proposed consent agreement aimed at saving the city from fiscal ruin, a spokeswoman for Gov. Rick Snyder said Monday. Details were in flux, but such a deal would, at least for now, prevent a more extreme fate in which the state would appoint an outside, emergency manager to take over operations in Detroit, which is at risk of running out of money this spring. Under a consent agreement between the state and its largest city, Detroit leaders, who had vehemently objected to an outside manager, would likely be required to meet certain measures, officials said, or risk the appointment of an outside manager later.

headline: Watch Your Language! (In China, They Really Do)
text: HONG KONG — Scaling the wall. Buying soy sauce. Fifty cents. A mild collision. May 35. Mayor Lymph. River crab.

headline: Albert Abramson, Holocaust Museum Backer, Is Dead at 94
text: Albert Abramson, who became a principal force in the creation of the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum in Washington by using the same pragmatic approach that had made him a successful developer of apartments, offices and malls, died last Tuesday at his home in Bethesda, Md. He was 94.

headline: Peter Novick, Wrote Controversial Book on Holocaust, Dies at 77
text: Peter Novick, a history professor at the University of Chicago who stirred controversy in 1999 with a book contending that the legacy of the Holocaust had come to unduly dominate American Jewish identity, died on Feb. 17 at his home in Chicago. He was 77.

headline: U.S. Officials Debate Speeding Afghan Pullout
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration is discussing whether to reduce American forces in Afghanistan by at least an additional 20,000 troops by 2013, reflecting a growing belief within the White House that the mission there has now reached the point of diminishing returns.

headline: News Quiz | March 13, 2012
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s front page.Good luck!

headline: Is Your Pilot Getting a Paycheck?
text: If you’re flying an Indian airline these days, that’s a legitimate question.

headline: March 13, 1964 | New York Woman Killed While Witnesses Do Nothing
text: On March 13, 1964, a 28-year-old woman named Catherine “Kitty” Genovese was raped and killed in two separate late-night attacks near her home in Kew Gardens, Queens. Police found that at least 38 people had seen the attacks or heard Genovese scream, but no one intervened and just one woman called the police.

headline: Test Yourself | English, March 13, 2012
text: This question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article “With a Solemn March, the Bowery Mourns Its Tent of Antiquity.”

headline: ‘Devastating, Unexplained Attack’ in Afghanistan
text: Note: The article and accompanying photographs contain graphic content that may not be appropriate for all students.

headline: Why Some Countries Go Bust
text: By his own admission, Daron Acemoglu is a slightly pudgy and fairly nerdy guy with an unpronounceable last name. But when I mentioned that I was interviewing him to two econ buffs, they each gasped and said, “I love Daron Acemoglu,” as if I were talking about Keith Richards. The Turkish M.I.T. professor — who, right now, is about as hot as economists get — acquired his renown for serious advances in answering the single most important question in his profession, the same one that compelled Adam Smith to write “The Wealth of Nations”: why are some countries rich while others are poor?

headline: Poland’s Great Adventure
text: “Poland is a country of endless Carnival and great disappointment. The Carnival is obvious, and the disappointment is explicable, because things were expected to be different.”

headline: Do Social Media Campaigns Like Kony 2012 Stunt or Stimulate Real Change?
text: After Invisible Children’s Kony 2012 video went viral, logging more than 70 million views in one week — some experts criticized the campaign, calling it dishonest and even dangerous. Others have suggested that campaigns like these give young people a false sense of accomplishment and discourage real engagement in social issues. What do you think? Have you watched “Kony 2012″? Do you feel like awareness campaigns like this stimulate or stunt real activism among young people?

headline: Militants Attack at Memorial for Massacre Victims
text: PANJWAI, Afghanistan — Militants riding motorcycles attacked a high-level Afghan government delegation during a memorial service on Tuesday in the village where an American soldier is said to have killed 16 people, mostly children and women, in a door-to-door rampage two days earlier.

headline: Peter Thiel, Who Paid Students to Drop Out, Will Teach at Stanford
text: Peter Thiel, a co-founder of PayPal who paid students to drop out of school, will teach at Stanford this spring, Reuters reports.

headline: Would a Higher Top Tax Rate Raise Revenues?
text: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of “The Benefit and the Burden: Tax Reform – Why We Need It and What It Will Take.”

headline: Cunningham Legacy to Continue in France?
text: Since the Merce Cunningham Dance Company disbanded on Dec. 31, the matter of keeping Cunningham’s dances and technique alive, in the classroom and onstage, has been in question. Robert Swinston, a veteran company member, has applied to become the director of the Centre National de Danse Contemporaine in Angers, France. If appointed, he plans to bring two former company members with him — Daniel Madoff and Melissa Toogood — and to start a small group that would perform Cunningham works as well as new dances.

headline: Trying to Decide Whether to See Red
text: BOCA RATON, Fla. — On Tuesday, Day 2 of the N.H.L. general managers meetings, a big topic on a busy agenda will be the move to put the red line back into effect. That would make two-line passes illegal, as they were before the 2004-5 lockout.

headline: Assessing Moss’s Signing With San Francisco
text: Before signing on with Jim Harbaugh, Randy Moss caught passes from him. Harbaugh, the Niners’ coach and a former N.F.L. quarterback, threw to Moss in a workout Monday morning.

headline: Gurgaon Rape ‘Peculiar Case,’ Police Say; Question Victim’s Statement
text: India Ink spoke Tuesday with K.K. Sindhu, Gurgaon’s commissioner of police, about a woman’s allegation that she was gang-raped in the outsourcing mega-city south of Delhi early on Monday morning.

headline: The Early Word: Competition
text: In Today’s Times:

headline: Most of City’s Voters Back Police’s Surveillance of Muslims, Poll Finds
text: Updated, 12:15 p.m. | As the controversy deepens over the New York Police Department’s efforts to monitor and map local Muslim communities, a majority of New York City voters say that the police have been effective in combating terrorism, and reject the notion that the department’s counterterrorism program has unfairly focused on Muslims, according to a poll released on Tuesday.

headline: Debt Crisis Provisions Hurt Bundesbank Profit
text: FRANKFURT — The Bundesbank, Germany’s central bank, said Tuesday that its profit plunged last year as it set aside money to cover risks from the sovereign debt crisis, a result that is certain to inflame a debate about the role the country plays in financing weaker countries in the euro zone.

headline: Manning vs. Tebow in Denver
text: When the Fifth Down last contemplated Tim Tebow, it was after the Broncos’ loss to the Patriots in the playoffs:

headline: Dozens Dead After Ferry Capsizes in Bangladesh
text: NEW DELHI — Rescuers were searching for survivors on Tuesday after a ferry carrying as many as 200 passengers capsized in Bangladesh, killing at least 24 people with many more feared dead.

headline: Uttar Pradesh Elections Sees Jump in Politicians Facing Criminal Charges
text: When Akhilesh Yadav brought his political party to power in Uttar Pradesh, the largest state in India, he declared that “no callousness in law and order will be tolerated” in the notoriously crime-infested land.

headline: In Latest Jobs Bill, a Billion-Dollar Business Is Now Small
text: Bipartisanship returned, however briefly, to Capitol Hill on Thursday, when the House passed, by an overwhelming margin, a bill ostensibly intended to make it easier for start-up companies to raise capital. “What this bill does is, it provides a real shot in the arm to entrepreneurs, small-business men and women, removes red tape, allows small businesses an easier time to go about starting up, as well as retaining and creating jobs,” Eric Cantor, the House majority leader, said after the Jump-Start Our Business Start-Ups Act sailed through the House on a 390-to-23 vote. (All 23 opponents were Democrats.)

headline: Penalties for Redskins and Cowboys Will Cost Them Cap Space
text: Two teams known for big spending will now have a lot less money to offer free agents.

headline: In India’s Northeast, Peace and Foreign Ties Quietly Spread
text: In this three part series, the author, a journalist from the Northeast, looks at the quiet transformation happening in once strife-torn region, which could affect trade and geopolitics throughout Asia.

headline: Daily Report: A SXSW Stunt Backfires on Marketer
text: It was a marketing idea that sounded good to someone.

headline: Same, Same But Different
text: An Israeli air strike on Gaza that killed the leader of the Popular Resistance Committees, Zuhair al-Qissi, on Friday led to four days of crossborder violence. Some 200 rockets rained on Israel, and retaliatory airstrikes killed 25 Palestinians.

headline: Turning Up the Heat With ‘Sun Don’t Shine’
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — After an unseasonably cold and rainy weekend here, the skies have cleared and sunlight has made its return. The warmth is being felt  on the streets and on the big screen, particularly in  “Sun Don’t Shine,” in South by Southwest’s Emerging Visions section.

headline: Slicing Silicon Thinner to Cut the Price of Solar Cells
text: A California company has unveiled a radical new way to make the silicon wafers that are the basic ingredient of most solar cells, cutting silicon consumption by 90 percent and eliminating the need to use glass and heavy backing to keep the cells rigid.

headline: Ex-Murdoch Executive Reportedly Arrested
text: LONDON — Rebekah Brooks, the former chief executive of News International, the British newspaper division of Rupert Murdoch’s media empire, was arrested early Tuesday on suspicion of obstruction of justice, according to a person with knowledge of the arrest. Her husband, Charlie, a friend of Prime Minister David Cameron from their days at Eton three decades ago, was also arrested, the person said.

headline: Events in Afghanistan Could Shape 2012 Race
text: So much about the 2012 presidential election is predictable: it will be about gas prices and health care; the deficit, spending and jobs; cultural issues and gender politics; immigration and federal taxes.

headline: Leaving ‘Well’ Alone
text: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style. (Some frequently asked questions are here.)

headline: Leaving ‘Well’ Alone
text: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style. (Some frequently asked questions are here.)

headline: Appetites of a Poetry Virtuoso in America
text: Several people in my life revere Jack Gilbert. They push photocopies of his poems solemnly across tables at me, as if they were salary offers or handguns or unusual drugs. Here, they say. Read this.

headline: Tuesday Reading: New Worries About Sleeping Pills
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: Unannounced Truce Calms Violence in Gaza
text: JERUSALEM — Both Israel and the Islamic Jihad militant group in Gaza indicated Tuesday that they would abide by an Egyptian-brokered truce ending four days of cross-border fighting, but each warned that maintaining the calm would depend on the actions of the other side.

headline: Opinion Report: Restricting Abortion
text: From the editorial page

headline: Fallout Continues Over Teacher Rankings
text: The release of the data reports for 18,000 New York City public school teachers continues to reverberate, not just in the city but around the state and across the country. A number of new, thoughtful articles have appeared in journals and other publications in the last few days, most highly critical of the release of the teacher rankings and predicting dire consequences.

headline: Las Vegas Sands Faces $375 Million Suit by Former Macau Partner
text: HONG KONG — Las Vegas Sands, the casino operator controlled by the billionaire Sheldon G. Adelson and his family, is facing a new $375 million lawsuit over how the company won a lucrative gambling license in Macau.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: MF Global Customers Said to Get Offers for Their Claims  |  The thousands of MF Global customers whose lives and businesses were derailed after $1.6 billion vanished in the collapse of the brokerage firm have now received offers to sell their claims and recoup nearly the entire shortfall, people involved in the negotiations said.

headline: Apollo to Acquire Water Park Operator for $703 Million
text: Apollo Global Management will buy Great Wolf Resort, the nation’s largest indoor water park operator, for $703 million, as the private equity firm pushes further into the hospitality and leisure industry.

headline: At Turnaround Meeting, the Big Question Was 'Why?'
text: More than 150 teachers, parents and students showed up at a hearing at Brooklyn Borough Hall Monday evening, questioning the mayor's plan to close and reopen 33 schools. Many were skeptical of the mayor's motivations. And some said the turnaround plan was unnecessary: "A lot of what they want to do with our new school is what we've been doing," said a teacher at John Dewey High School, one of the affected schools.

headline: Check In, Roll Out
text: Savvy hotels across the country are riding the urban-cycling trend, offering two wheels to guests at no additional charge.

headline: Syria Expands Assault, Hitting Rebel Enclaves in City in North
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Emboldened by faltering diplomacy and a Russian pledge to keep supplying weapons, Syria’s armed forces assaulted insurgent enclaves in the northern part of the country on Tuesday, invading the city of Idlib in an expanded campaign to crush the year-old uprising against President Bashar al-Assad.

headline: For Albany’s Latest Struggle, Blame Air-Conditioning
text: You want to know what the root of the trouble is in New York’s struggle to create new Congressional districts? It isn’t political sclerosis in Albany, though that is generally a safe bet. No, New York’s problem is air-conditioning. Truly. Air-conditioning has been hurting the state politically for more than half a century, and it will keep doing so.

headline: Afghanistan: When Even the Danes Turn on the War…
text: LONDON — “Denmark is in Afghanistan to secure Denmark.” That is the bald official message that has sustained a Danish contribution to NATO-led operations in Afghanistan for a decade.

headline: Image of the Day:  March 13
text: People throng employment offices in Uttar Pradesh after recent state elections to claim benefits promised by the winning Samajwadi Party.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Rebekah Brooks Arrested and Wi-Fi via the Homeless
text: The British police on Tuesday morning arrested Rebekah Brooks, the former top executive of Rupert Murdoch’s News International, and her husband, The Associated Press reported. The arrests are part of the investigation into phone hacking. A total of six people were arrested on suspicion of conspiracy to pervert the course of justice, the police said in a statement.

headline: Los Tigres del Norte Banned in Mexican City
text: The government of Chihuahua, Mexico, one of the cities most afflicted by violence in that nation’s drug war, has forbidden the norteño band Los Tigres del Norte to play there after a performance that included songs the government said glorified drug traffickers.

headline: Leading Aluminum Company’s Chairman Quits in Dispute
text: MOSCOW — A big shareholder in a leading aluminum company stepped down as chairman on Tuesday in a dispute with another wealthy Russian owner about whether the company, Rusal, should focus solely on aluminum or also keep a foothold in other mining ventures.

headline: Morning Buzz, March 13: Rockets in the Sky
text: Good morning. The day will start overcast and possibly rainy before breaking to a slightly cloudy 70 degrees by the afternoon.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Travel and Leisure: Noma was just the beginning: Adam Sachs on how Copenhagen got to be the new “epicenter of the food world.” As one chef puts it: “Noma is teaching us is to do our own thing. Not everyone has to forage and use sea buckthorn and pine needles. The point is to do something that other people don’t … ” — Jeff Gordinier

headline: British Regulator Fines Credit Suisse Executive
text: LONDON – The Financial Services Authority has fined Nicholas Kyprios, head of European credit sales at Credit Suisse, for disclosing confidential client information, the latest in a number of prominent actions by the British regulator.

headline: Nomad Land
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Marine Invaders, Coming to a Coast Near You
text: Molgula manhattensis, the sea grape, is a greenish globule that sticks to oyster shells and can ruin aquaculture. Didemnum vexillum, fondly referred to as “rock vomit,” forms yellowish spongy mats over not just rocks but nonmobile creatures as well, ultimately suffocating them. Diplosoma listerianum, which has no common name (D-List, anyone?), drapes itself in crusty layers over corals, grasses and other organisms.

headline: Press-ganging the Turkish Media
text: ISTANBUL — The British say it about the police force, but the same may be true of the press: that a country gets the one it deserves. Woe is Turkey.

headline: Terrell Thomas Agrees to New Deal with the Giants
text: 3:00 p.m. | Updated The Giants secured one of their biggest potential free agents on Tuesday shortly before N.F.L. free agency even began.

headline: Do Most Mississippi Republicans Think Obama Is a Muslim?
text: There is not a shred of truth to the rumor that President Obama is not really an American citizen, or that he’s secretly a Muslim.  And yet the stories won’t die, because people keep repeating them and unscrupulous politicians are happy to capitalize on them.

headline: Votes Are More Against Than For in 2 Southern States
text: HATTIESBURG, Miss. — Voters in Alabama and Mississippi went to the polls on Tuesday morning to settle what appeared to be a three-way-tie in the latest primaries for the Republican presidential nomination. A win in either or even both states for Mitt Romney, unforeseeable in the polls just days ago, seemed more and more possible in recent days, and could help his campaign’s claims that he is the inevitable nominee. It would also give Mr. Romney a victory in one of the most conservative parts of the country, and help ease concerns about his acceptance by the Republican base.

headline: In Egypt, Rival Ultras Meet to Show Common Cause
text: CAIRO — Mere months ago, fans of Al Ahly and Zamalek clashed on the streets. On Sunday night they stood side by side, red alongside white, a hand of one often resting in unspoken friendship on the shoulder of another.

headline: Trial Near, Mets Owners and Trustee Argue Fair and Foul
text: The owners of the Mets want the Hall of Fame pitcher Sandy Koufax to testify at their federal trial. The court-appointed trustee suing them says Koufax would be a distraction.

headline: Spokes People
text: New York isn’t the only major American city to go the way of the bicycle. Chicago is getting a public bike share this summer and 100 miles of new protected bike lanes by 2015, all part of Mayor Rahm Emanuel’s plan to make his city the most cyclist-friendly in the country. For now try Chicago B-Cycle, a bike share with a few stations near the Lakefront Trail, an 18-mile path along Lake Michigan. Cruisers, hybrids and more can be rented at the McDonald’s Cycle Center (312-729-1000), a state-of-the-art facility for commuters. Or buy your own: Working Bikes Cooperative (773-847-5440) sells restored discarded bikes on the cheap; J. C. Lind Bike Company (312-643-1670) and Copenhagen Cyclery (773-456-0024) carry the best Danish cargo bikes; Method Bicycle (312-965-8635) makes bespoke steel frames. Nothing heralds the city’s status as a cycling stronghold quite like the newly opened Heritage Bicycles General Store (above; 773-245-3005), a bike shop-cafe where you can order a custom bike, get a tuneup, scarf a soup-and-salad lunch and tank up on Stumptown coffee, an export from that other great bike town, Portland, Ore.

headline: Business Day Live | March 13, 2012
text: An I.B.M. executive talks about the changing digital landscape for retailers; Binyamin Applebaum previews a federal reserve meeting; and Start-ups compete for attention at South by Southwest.

headline: Palin-Focused Film ‘Game Change’ Draws Big Audience to HBO
text: Riding outstanding reviews and a flood of attention because of the controversy around its portrayal of Sarah Palin, the HBO film “Game Change” attracted a big audience for the pay-cable channel Saturday night.

headline: Honored for His Service After Two Decades on a City Bus
text: Jefrick R. Dean Sr. has worked for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority for 22 years. More than two decades of lurching on a city bus, dealing with the occasional unruly commuter, and delivering repeated tutorials in MetroCard swiping and general bus etiquette might drive lesser New Yorkers to distraction. But Mr. Dean, who will be 52 in July, has no plans to retire, which is good news to his passengers on the round-trip run from East New York to downtown Brooklyn.

headline: Business Day Live: Retail Sales Increase
text: An I.B.M. executive talks about the changing digital landscape for retailers; Binyamin Appelbaum previews a Federal Reserve meeting; and start-ups compete for attention at South by Southwest.

headline: Scale and Energy Booms, Continued
text: My posts on the North Dakota energy boom, and its lack of implications for state that actually have a significant number of people, have gotten quite a few comments. So I’ve hit on what I think is a useful comparison: North Dakota versus Pennsylvania.

headline: Wheelies: The Payload Edition
text: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: What Teaching Students Can Learn from Poor, Urban Schools
text: Hesston College is a small, two-year college in Kansas with the slogan “Start Here. Go Anywhere.” Last month, a group of education majors did go somewhere: their professor took them to observe education at work in the inner city of Tulsa, Okla. For Hesston students, accustomed to doing their classroom observation in fairly affluent and rural areas, the trip was what their professor described as “cross-cultural.”

headline: BB&T Restructures BankAtlantic Deal
text: The BB&T Corporation retooled its planned takeover of BankAtlantic on Tuesday in an attempt to appease a judge who previously blocked the deal for the beleaguered Florida bank.

headline: Out There | Fair Games
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Boston Mobster’s Companion to Plead Guilty to Helping Him Evade Capture
text: BOSTON — Catherine Greig, the companion of the Boston mobster James (Whitey) Bulger, is expected to plead guilty to charges that she helped him evade capture for 16 years, say relatives of his alleged murder victims who were briefed on the matter.

headline: N.F.L. Strips Cowboys and Redskins of Salary Cap Room
text: Free agency opens in the N.F.L. on Tuesday, but two teams known for big spending have a lot less to spend.

headline: Alabama Governor Says He Voted for Santorum
text: Rick Santorum received an Election Day gift on Tuesday morning when he learned that Gov. Robert Bentley of Alabama had voted for him in the state’s primary.

headline: Leading Off: The New Superpower
text: In the N.C.A.A. universe, the women’s basketball tournament continues to operate as its own smaller galaxy, its stars not quite as shiny, its bracket creating no madness. It’s through no fault of the women players, who have developed in great leaps and now boast another level of star in Baylor’s Brittney Griner, but as the men’s tournament fills our sky, you need a telescope to find the women.

headline: Thomas Puccio, Ex-Prosecutor and Lawyer for Notorious Clients, Dies at 67
text: Thomas P. Puccio, a tigerish New York lawyer who won fame prosecuting congressmen in the 1980s Abscam scandals, then switched sides and defended Claus von Bülow, corrupt politicians, an accused rapist who ran off to the ski slopes of Europe and other notorious clients, died on Monday in New Haven. He was 67.

headline: At Shareholder Meeting, Disney Commits to Hire 1,000 Veterans
text: LOS ANGELES — The Walt Disney Company’s senior executives decamped to Kansas City, Mo., on Tuesday to conduct their annual meeting for shareholders and made sure as always to bring a piece of positive news: Heroes Work Here.

headline: Rocking the Friendly Skies
text: Even the most devout lover of magazines draws the line at rooting about in the seat pocket in front of them for something good to read. Next time I’m on a plane, however, I just might do that, inspired by this fascinating article about a Chinese punk-rock band that an old high-school friend sent me on Facebook. Published in United Airlines’ Hemispheres Magazine, it profiles a band called Carsick Cars and contains a number of memorable details, including this:

headline: Tibetan Monk Sets Himself on Fire to Protest Chinese Rule
text: An 18-year-old Tibetan monk, Gepey, died Saturday after setting himself on fire to protest Chinese rule in Tibetan areas, according to Free Tibet, an advocacy group based in London.

headline: Who Bit My Border?
text: You probably don’t think much about the border between Indonesia and Papua New Guinea. And when you do, you might not think much of it. It looks so straightforward and simple: following the 141st meridian east, it neatly splits the island of New Guinea [1] in two almost equal halves. The western half is part of Indonesia, while the eastern half forms the bulk of the independent state of Papua New Guinea, which also consists of the Bismarck Archipelago [2] and several smaller islands.

headline: Q. and A.: Tracking the Elusive Wolverine
text: In Monday’s paper, I wrote about a new group called Adventurers and Scientists for Conservation that is working to link outdoors types with researchers who can benefit from their back-country skills and data-gathering. I reported from western Montana, where Gregg Treinish, the group’s founder, was jointly leading a weekend expedition of a dozen volunteers tracking the wolverine.

headline: Glencore’s Potential Bid for Viterra May Face Challenges
text: LONDON – Deals can be like city buses. You wait a long time for one, then two show up at once.

headline: Political Geography: Alabama
text: Our state-by-state profile of the Republican electorate — a mixture of analysis from local experts, demographic data and past voting results — lands today in the Deep South, first in Alabama, then in Mississippi.

headline: His District Likely to Be Cut, Congressman Eyes Gillibrand’s Senate Seat
text: WASHINGTON — Representative Bob Turner, a Republican who unexpectedly won a House seat in a closely watched special election last year, has decided to run for the United States Senate in New York, seeking to oust Kirsten E. Gillibrand, a Democrat.

headline: The High Cost of Insider Trading
text: The cost of insider trading is well known on Wall Street. Shuttered firms, frightened portfolio managers, costly lawsuits and expensive compliance.

headline: TimesCast | March 13, 2012
text: The former editor of News International is said to have been arrested | Truce calms four days of cross-border fighting in Gaza | High stakes for the Republican candidates in two Southern states.

headline: At One Mississippi Polling Place, Sharp Divisions
text: DIXIE, Miss. — Here in the heart of Dixie, Miss., a little town outside of Hattiesburg, voters filed into the Dixie Community Center in a trickle, often commenting on the mostly empty parking lot.

headline: ‘Bachelor’ Finale Brings an Uptick in Ratings
text: A parade of quickly collapsed reality show romances has not completely dimmed interest in ABC’s “The Bachelor.” The finale of the latest edition (Ben Flajnik picked Courtney for those keeping score) raised the show’s ratings enough to hurt the NBC songfest, “The Voice.”

headline: Newport Jazz Festival Announces Lineup
text: The Newport Jazz Festival will be anchored this year by the guitarist Pat Metheny, the drummer Jack DeJohnette and the vocalist Kurt Elling, among dozens of other acts, George Wein, a festival founder, announced on Tuesday.

headline: Adding a Colorful Gloss to a Black-and-White World
text: WASHINGTON — Random observations upon strolling through a new exhibition at the National Portrait Gallery here:

headline: Target of Llodra’s Racial Slur Says Fine Is Not Enough
text: INDIAN WELLS, Calif. — Save for the chilly breeze that often blows through the desert air after sunset, it is hard to imagine a more perfect setting for tennis than mountain-lined Indian Wells, home of the BNP Paribas Open.

headline: Kyrgyzstan Wants Military Role to End at U.S. Base
text: BISHKEK, Kyrgyzstan — One of Kyrgyzstan’s top defense officials told Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta on Tuesday that a crucial United States air base here should have “no military mission” when its lease expires a little more than two years from now. The request creates a potential hurdle to American plans to withdraw from Afghanistan in 2014.

headline: Share the Road
text: Bike shares are sprouting in cities all over the world: Taipei, Tel Aviv, Barcelona, Berlin and Mexico City, to name only a few. For the five mapped below, find out how many bikes and docks are at each station with the Spotcycle app.

headline: The View from B.Y.U.: A Team That Counts on Defense
text: Throughout the N.C.A.A. tournament, The Quad will feature posts from reporters at newspapers on campuses of teams that have the potential to be the Cinderellas of 2012.

headline: Mets’ Injuries Start to Wear on Collins
text: The Mets injury beat kept going Tuesday, and the frustration is starting to wear on Manager Terry Collins.

headline: The View from Iona: Suspense, and Then a Selection
text: Throughout the N.C.A.A. tournament, The Quad will feature posts from reporters at newspapers on campuses of teams that have the potential to be the Cinderellas of 2012.

headline: Obama Promises Thorough Inquiry Into Afghan Attack
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama pledged on Tuesday that a thorough investigation would be conducted into the bloody rampage by an American soldier in Afghanistan.

headline: Invitation to a Dialogue: Evaluating Teachers
text: To the Editor:

headline: Unspooling Laughs at SXSW
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — In addition to genre films, South by Southwest is known as a testing ground for comedies, a way for filmmakers and studios to gauge audience reaction.

headline: A Boy Sergeant Fights at New Bern
text: On March 13, 1862, an imposing convoy of Union transports lay at anchor in the middle of coastal North Carolina’s Neuse River. During the early morning hours, a portion of the convoy steamed toward land, pulling small boats packed with thousands of soldiers — a division-size invasion force commanded by Ambrose E. Burnside, a bewhiskered brigadier whose star was on the rise.

headline: Beltran Visits Mets; Says He Misses the Food
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Carlos Beltran returned here Tuesday with his new team, the St. Louis Cardinals, and said that his knees were good, that he missed the cooking in the Mets’ clubhouse and that he was eager to check out pitcher Jon Niese’s new nose.

headline: Employers Dangle Carrots for Behaviors That Help Lower Costs
text: More big employers are dangling financial incentives to persuade workers and their families to adopt healthier behaviors and help control health care costs, a new survey reports.

headline: General Motors and NASA Pair Up to Design Interstellar Work Glove
text: General Motors has retrained its focus on technology destined for outer space. Those awaiting the world’s first galaxy-hopping private aircraft, however, may be disappointed.

headline: A Greener Strategy for New York’s Runaway Sewage
text: New York State and city officials announced Tuesday that they had wrapped up an agreement under which the city would commit more than $2 billion in public and private investment to new environmental techniques to help prevent the flow of untreated sewage and storm water into city waterways when it rains.

headline: Dell to Buy Security Services Provider for $1.25 Billion
text: Dell said Tuesday that it had agreed to buy SonicWall, a privately held provider of data security measures for businesses, to continue expanding its corporate services offerings.

headline: Guidebooks, Schmidebooks: 5 Hidden Gems in New York City
text: How many times have you heard this?: “We stumbled on this place that wasn’t in our guidebook …” In this age of hyper-documentation, where there’s hardly a vending machine on Earth that hasn’t had the merits of its candy selection debated on TripAdvisor, guidebooks are still the trusty standby for travelers tackling a new city. Yet, in a way, they’re also the enemy: stick just to what’s in the guidebook, and making a “discovery” — a place best known to locals and a few intrepid travelers — becomes unlikely at best. Every trip needs a Christopher Columbus moment or two.

headline: On Bravo TV Show, Avery Says He’s Retired
text: Having been set free by his minor league team to pursue any and all television appearances without interference from a hockey season, Sean Avery was all smiles during an episode of “Watch What Happens Live!” on Bravo. When asked about his hockey future by Nicole Richie, Avery said: “I am officially retired. I threw my skates in the Hudson.”

headline: Citi Customers Can Deposit Checks With Their Phones
text: Citibank is the latest bank to add remote deposit capture, which lets customers snap a photo of a check with their phone and with the touch of a button, deposit it into their bank account. No trip to the A.T.M. required.

headline: One Schlep Forward
text: My dad and I waited at the Aeroflot check-in counter at Kennedy Airport, the only two people in line without payos, side curls, and zizit, the knotted threads that hang from the waists of Orthodox men. Six Hasids schmoozed in Russified Yiddish as a Hispanic porter pushed their trolley of bulging suitcases.

headline: Asked & Answered | Gideon Lewis-Kraus
text: The excerpt in our summer travel issue, ‘‘One Schlep Forward,’’ is about a Hasidic pilgrimage to Uman, Ukraine, one of three sacred journeys that Gideon Lewis-Kraus undertook for his forthcoming book, ‘‘A Sense of Direction’’ (Riverhead Books). (The others took him to an ancient cathedral in northwestern Spain and across the Japanese island of Shikoku.) A frequent contributor to N+1 and Harper’s Magazine, Lewis-Kraus recently returned to Japan to report on the relationship between cats and the Internet for Wired. In the following interview, he talks about his book and how taking a trio of pilgrimages has affected his more secular travels.

headline: She’s Back, Branding Irons in Hand
text: IT was a bleak afternoon on the outskirts of Manhattan’s garment district. At street level, wholesalers peddled costume jewelry and satin prom gowns.

headline: Crosby Eyes Thursday Return Against Rangers
text: Sidney Crosby will be in the lineup for the Pittsburgh Penguins when they play the Rangers at Madison Square Garden on Thursday night.

headline: Obama Campaign Fears Uphill Climb Raising ‘Super PAC’ Money
text: The warning came from David Plouffe, President Obama’s top political adviser: The Koch brothers and Republican “super PACs” have pledged hundreds of millions of dollars to defeat Mr. Obama, he told a dozen wealthy Democrats gathered in a Silicon Valley office suite. Do not believe what you read about all the money the president will raise himself, Mr. Plouffe urged them. He needs your help.

headline: Blue Bottle Coffee Comes to Midtown
text: On Tuesday morning, the newest Blue Bottle Coffee opened at Rockefeller Center. The small, sleek shop is located underground on the concourse level, and it’s built for speed. The room is divided into two sections, each with its own line and coffee setup: a Strada machine, extra-long drip bar, iced drinks, pastries and granola baked at the Blue Bottle Coffee roaster in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. It’s made-to-order coffee with the Midtown rush in mind.

headline: Prime Suspect Arrested in the Killing of Argentine Folk Singer
text: The police in Colombia have announced the arrest of the man they say is responsible for the killing of the Argentine folk singer Facundo Cabral, who was on tour in Guatemala last summer when he was shot to death on his way to the airport. The authorities described the man, Alejandro Jiménez González, a Costa Rican, as involved in the “leadership and direction of an organized mafia” engaged in money laundering and other criminal activities throughout Central America. According to news reports from Colombia, Mr. Jiménez, 37, was arrested when he arrived there on Monday aboard a cruise ship.

headline: Race, Republicans and Realignment
text: So long as I’m arguing with Jonathan Chait about the nature of the Republican Party, I should say something about his recent case for treating white ethnocentrism as the core of contemporary conservatism. Here, from his sometimes-perceptive, sometimes-less-so essay on the Republican Party in 2012, is Chait’s race-based read on the making and unmaking of a conservative majority:
