text: Photographs from the exhibition at the National Portrait Gallery.

headline: Reading Between the Tree Rings
text: Kevin Anchukaitis, an assistant research professor at the Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory  at Columbia University, is conducting a tree-ring study to analyze drought patterns in Guatemala.

headline: 2012 Fantasy Baseball Preview: Outfield
text: Jason and Justin Sablich provide fantasy sports advice on Bats, The Fifth Down and on Twitter (@5thDownFantasy).

headline: In Otherwise Dour Report From Fed, the Tiniest Touch of Optimism
text: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve on Tuesday offered a slightly more upbeat account of the American economy, but added that it planned to continue its efforts to improve growth.

headline: Terrorist Was Not Killed in Airstrike, Malaysian Official Says
text: MANILA — A major terrorist linked to Al Qaeda who the Philippine military maintains was killed last month probably escaped alive, a senior Malaysian police official said.

headline: In Missouri, Romney Attacks Obama for Rising Gas Prices
text: KIRKWOOD, Mo. — Standing in front of a jungle gym, Mitt Romney spoke to voters crowded onto picnic benches here Tuesday morning and attacked President Obama over rising gas prices.

headline: Hands Give a Lift, Now They Can Get One
text: DORIAN GRAY’S countenance may have had the texture of a baby’s behind, but did anyone ever look at his hands?

headline: Sarah Palin: Stop Using My Words Against Me
text: Sarah Palin is unhappy. A new Barack Obama campaign ad quotes her out of context, she says, as part of an effort by “the far Left” to divert everyone from the “real issues” that the president doesn’t want to talk about.

headline: Afghan Killings Reverberate in Congress
text: The case of an American soldier accused of killing Afghan civilians has roiled political support in Congress for the military campaign in Afghanistan, with a prominent Republican senator accusing his party’s candidates for president of undermining the nation’s military commanders.

headline: Organized Labor Sets Course for Election
text: ORLANDO, Fla. — As the A.F.L.-C.I.O.’s winter meeting opened here on Tuesday, its political director mapped out organized labor’s plans for the 2012 campaign and how unions will respond to what he says will be $500 million in “super PAC” ads backing Republicans.

headline: Goldman Hires a New P.R. Chief
text: Richard Siewert Jr., the man Goldman Sachs has been courting to lead its public relations effort, has been officially hired, according to an internal memo from the investment bank.

headline: N.C.A.A. Bracket Office Hours
text: The Times’s sports department experimented for the first time on Tuesday with Google+ video hangouts for a discussion about the N.C.A.A. tournament. Pete Thamel and Connor Ennis were on hand to answer questions and give their opinions about how to fill in this year’s bracket. Thanks to some technical issues, the conversation sometimes steered off course, but Pete, Connor and some Times readers still supplied plenty of food for thought for those looking to predict this year’s path to the Final Four.

headline: In a First, Europeans Act to Suspend Aid to Hungary Unless It Cuts Deficit
text: BRUSSELS — European Union finance ministers agreed Tuesday for the first time to punish one of their members for flouting the bloc’s budget rules, deciding to suspend payment to Hungary of nearly 500 million euros in development money next year unless it makes progress on reducing its deficit.

headline: Ray Dalio’s Former Assistant Tells All
text: Ray Dalio has been in the news quite a bit lately.

headline: Canada Bends Rules for Madonna Concert at the Plains of Abraham
text: OTTAWA — Although more than 252 years have passed since a battle was fought on the Plains of Abraham in Quebec City, it remains an area fraught with historical significance.

headline: Our Readers See Stars, and Ask Why
text: After The Los Angeles Times announced last week that its restaurant reviewers would no longer give out stars , a couple of commenters on Diner’s Journal suggested that The New York Times should follow suit.

headline: A Menagerie in the Lake
text: There was room enough for everyone in the Prospect Park Lake on Monday: from left, a double-crested cormorant, a Canada goose, a red-eared slider turtle, a ring-billed gull and a mallard seemed to coexist quite peacefully.

headline: Photo Replay: March 13
text: The day in sports included cricket in Bangladesh, Champions League soccer in Italy and horse racing at the Cheltenham Festival in England.

headline: Denmark Can’t Avoid the Radar
text: SOME chefs storm into the city like an invading navy, gunships of publicity thundering on the horizon.

headline: Acme
text: Inside the shabby-chic bistro from the Danish chef Mads Refslund.

headline: Site to Be Seen | Avenue 32
text: Live since December 2011, Avenue32.com is helping to usher in fashion’s next generation, one click at a time. The concept: showcase recent design-school graduates alongside industry staples (Preen, Thakoon Addition, and Dean Harris jewelry, for example) in the form of a comprehensive online shopping experience.”I worked for a young designer and know how many of them struggle to control the way their brands are portrayed online,” says Roberta Benteler, a co-founder of Avenue32.com, which is based in London but quickly converts pounds to dollars for United States visitors. “The site was born out of the desire to create a platform that supports the customers’ and designers’ needs alike with an exciting and fresh brand mix.”

headline: Five Dishes at Acme
text: This week I review the reborn Acme on Great Jones Street, a shabby-chic bistro with food from Mads Refslund, a Danish chef who helped found one of the world’s most celebrated restaurants. Foodies who come for Mr. Refslund’s cooking rub elbows with an art- and fashion-world crowd cultivated by Jean-Marc Houmard and some of Acme’s other owners at their previous restaurants, notably Indochine.

headline: Mets Make Room for Prospective Tenant
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — It looks like a giant unfinished basement, and smells like one. And the Mets’ future here could ultimately depend on whether this cavernous structure is finished, and furnished with another major league team.

headline: AOL Slashes Staff at AIM Unit; Wider Cuts Expected
text: Justin Sullivan/Getty Images

headline: Musicians Union Objects to Taylor Dance Company’s Use of Recorded Music
text: The New York musicians union has denounced the Paul Taylor Dance Company for performing at Lincoln Center without a live orchestra, which the company said was far beyond its means. The union, Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians, promised to distribute leaflets and provide outdoor performances to bring attention to the issue before the Taylor company’s first show of a 21-performance run at the David H. Koch Theater on Tuesday night.

headline: Political Geography: Mississippi
text: By the time Mississippi held its Republican presidential primary in 2008, Senator John McCain of Arizona had all but secured the nomination, so the results are not terribly helpful in foreshadowing today’s contest. Mr. McCain won the state with 79 percent of the vote. Mike Huckabee, the former Arkansas governor, earned just 13 percent, and Representative Ron Paul of Texas received 4 percent. Mitt Romney, the former governor of Massachusetts, had dropped out weeks earlier.

headline: Activism or Slacktivism? The ‘Stop Kony’ Campaign as a Teachable Moment
text: Note to Teacher | This lesson suggests showing photographs and videos of brutality wrought in Africa by Joseph Kony and the Lord’s Resistance Army. The slide shows, videos and articles contain graphic material that may not be appropriate for all students.

headline: Kerrey to Start TV Ads in Senate Race
text: Former Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska, who hopes to be the next Democratic senator from Nebraska, is about to air his first television advertisements.

headline: Rising Tide of Jobs Lifts Most States, Not All
text: The job market seems to be thawing and employers are gradually hiring, but a lot still depends on geography. Nevada continued its run as the state with the highest level of joblessness in January, with a 12.7 percent unemployment rate, down from 13.8 percent a year earlier, according to the Labor Department.

headline: The Brief Return of ‘the Woman Who Wasn’t There’
text: Readers will approach “The Woman Who Wasn’t There: The True Story of an Incredible Deception” knowing how it’s going to end. Tania Head, who claimed a place in the public’s heart for having narrowly escaped death in the south tower of the World Trade Center — “America’s most famous survivor,” the authors call her — will be revealed as an impostor.

headline: Is There a Chief Comments Moderator?
text: My post yesterday on Times commenting rules, and how to get through the @#&$* and Hitler filters, drew questions about the moderation process, starting with whether we have a chief moderator.

headline: A Few More Words of Advice About Your Bracket
text: Before the 2011-12 college basketball season began, The Quad ran an analysis that showed field goal percentage defense, assist-to-turnover ratio and rebounding margin are the statistics most correlated with teams reaching the Final Four.  With that in mind, we now answer a “six pack” of questions you might consider before filling out your brackets.  Of course, results may vary.

headline: Nasdaq Finishes Above 3,000, Its Best Since Dot-Com Bubble
text: Stocks rose to new heights on Tuesday, in part on stronger retail sales data, pushing the broad market to levels last seen in June 2008 and the Nasdaq composite index to close above 3,000 for the first time since 2000.

headline: Trying to Attract the Perfect Customer
text: In my last blog post, I wrote about how my advertising agency wound up spending a lot of time going after a customer we hadn’t initially identified as needing our services — and how we then analyzed our list of current customers and realized that most of those highly treasured companies on our roster sought us out, not vice versa.

headline: Planet Hollywood in Times Square to Cohabit With an Italian Restaurant
text: When the first Planet Hollywood opened near Carnegie Hall more than 20 years ago, it sparked a wave of casual restaurants cluttered with memorabilia from movies and other forms of entertainment.

headline: Metropolitan Opera Offers New App for for iPads
text: Now you can prop yourself up in bed with Aida, Salome and Gilda. The Metropolitan Opera said on Tuesday that it was extending its opera on-demand service to iPads through a new app. The app is free but the streaming service starts at $14.99 a month, giving viewers access to several hundred radio and television broadcasts and more recent “Live in HD” transmissions to movie theaters, with more to be added regularly.

headline: Top-Seeded Orange Lose Key Player on Defense
text: Syracuse announced Tuesday that center Fab Melo would not play in the N.C.A.A. tournament, a move that decreases the top-seeded Orange’s chances of playing for the national title.

headline: Insider Trading Charges Center on Alcoholics Anonymous Meetings
text: The government’s sweeping crackdown on insider trading has focused on hedge fund trading floors and corporate boardrooms. On Tuesday, it reached into Alcoholics Anonymous.

headline: Up to His Neck in Blood, Shark Heads and Deadlines
text: It seems impossibly retro in this computer-generated age, but at least one guy is still creating creepy movie effects out of resin and blood bottles.

headline: Deadly Mosque Arson in Belgium Attributed to Sunni-Shiite Friction
text: LONDON — An arsonist’s attack on a Shiite mosque in a Brussels suburb that left its 46-year-old imam dead provoked shock and grief among Belgium’s Muslim population on Tuesday, but the authorities there attributed the attack to tensions between the Shiite and Sunni communities — not a new case of the so-called Islamophobia hostility that has been rising in Europe.

headline: In Taurus Inquiry, Safety Agency Requests Information on 1.52 Million Additional Vehicles
text: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration has requested information on a further 1.52 million vehicles to assist in its investigation of 395,000 Ford Taurus and Mercury Sable models. The sedans became the subject of an investigation after owners claimed on the agency’s Web site that loose cruise control cables caused throttles to become stuck, resulting in unintended acceleration.

headline: In Alabama and Mississippi, Romney Competes in Unfavorable Terrain
text: Demographically, the primaries in Alabama and Mississippi on Tuesday should not be favorable to Mitt Romney.

headline: Why Children Need More Chores
text: Are Americans raising a generation of dependent children?

headline: S.E.C. Charges Three Former Mortgage Executives With Fraud
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission filed fraud charges on Tuesday against three former executives at Thornburg Mortgage, once the nation’s second-largest mortgage company after Countrywide Financial, saying that they hid the company’s deteriorating financial condition at the onset of the financial crisis in 2008.

headline: 15 of 19 Big Banks Pass Fed’s Latest Stress Test
text: The Federal Reserve had a key take-away from the latest round of stress tests: most big banks are in good shape.

headline: Saying Hello With Youthful Exuberance
text: For two young musicians out to make a lasting first impression, it would be hard to pick a more appropriate selection of pieces than those chosen by the violinist Benjamin Beilman and the pianist Yekwon Sunwoo on Monday evening at Merkin Concert Hall.

headline: On a Bench in Paris, a Look at a Life Not Yet Lived
text: Hindsight may always be 20/20, but the clarity of Simon Van Booy’s “Hindsight” is much harder to determine.

headline: China’s New Law on Detentions Puts Spotlight on ‘Black Jails’
text: China’s highest legislative body is expected to approve changes on Wednesday for dealing with accused criminals that the government says will protect suspects’ rights and activists worry enshrine a loophole that would legalize secret detentions for many political dissidents.

headline: Obama Files a Complaint Over China
text: WASHINGTON — If there was ever any doubt about the political salience of China in an election year, it was erased Tuesday, when President Obama stepped before cameras in the White House Rose Garden to announce a procedural move in a long-running trade dispute with China over rare earth metals.

headline: Specialists in Rare Earths Say a Trade Case Against China May Be Too Late
text: HONG KONG — Even as the United States, the European Union and Japan jointly filed a trade case Tuesday against China over its export restrictions on strategic rare earth metals, many specialists could not help wondering whether it was too little and too late for Western and Japanese manufacturers.

headline: TimesCast | Rebekah Brooks is Arrested
text: March 13, 2012 - Rebekah Brooks, the former chief executive of News International was arrested, according to sources. She was among six people taken into custody relating to the phone hacking scandal.

headline: Muddled Economic Picture Muddles the Political One, Too
text: WASHINGTON — The final major economic turning point of President Obama’s first term seems to have arrived. The question is which way the economy will turn.

headline: Charity Officer Is Charged With Stealing
text: ALBANY — The top financial officer for a Bronx charity started by State Senator Rubén Díaz Sr. was arrested on Tuesday on a charge of stealing at least $75,000 from the organization.

headline: Dolphins, Pursuing Manning,  Trade Brandon Marshall
text: As Jay Glazer first reported, the Dolphins kicked off the free-agency period with the first big move, trading wide receiver Brandon Marshall to Chicago for two third-round picks.

headline: The Tax Man Cometh for a Former Lehman Banker
text: The home of Bradley H. Jack, the former Lehman Brothers banking chief who has been arrested twice for allegedly forging drug prescriptions, may be sold at auction after he failed to pay property taxes. Bloomberg News reports Mr. Jack owes $271,923 on his 20-acre waterfront house in Fairfield, Conn.Read more »

headline: TimesCast | The Southern Primaries
text: March 13, 2012 - Hawaii, Alabama and Mississippi are voting on Tuesday for the Republican nominee.

headline: TimesCast | Truce Calms Gaza Violence
text: March 13, 2012 - An Egyptian-brokered truce has apparently ended four days of cross borderfighting between Israel and forces inside Gaza.

headline: Tokyo Tunes Up
text: That Tokyo’s subway system is one of the most efficient in the world hasn’t slowed a recent two-wheel invasion of the city’s streets. An aboveground alternative to the rush-hour crunch, bicycles also proved to be one of the more reliable forms of transportation after the 2011 earthquake; with trains halted and taxis in gridlock, desperate commuters bought out local bike shops. The city’s many flat roads are ideal for cruising, even if the numerous unnamed streets pose a challenge. Local riders swear by the navigation-meets-social-networking app Navinko, available on iTunes, but if you’ve left the iPhone at home, consider joining the Tokyo Great Cycling Tour, a guided one-day ride that includes rentals.

headline: A.F.L.-C.I.O. Endorses Obama
text: ORLANDO, Fla. — Although it came as no surprise, the A.F.L.-C.I.O., the nation’s main union federation, gave President Obama its powerful endorsement on Tuesday, promising to deploy hundreds of thousands of union volunteers on his behalf.

headline: Updates From Alabama and Mississippi Primaries
text: The Times is covering Tuesday’s primaries and caucuses and providing live updates and analysis. Follow along on the live dashboard and on Twitter (@thecaucus), get real-time results and dig deeper into the numbers with FiveThirtyEight.

headline: Study Warns of Economic Damage in a Keystone Pipeline Spill
text: A report released on Tuesday by Cornell University’s Global Labor Institute concludes that the economic damage caused by potential spills from the Keystone XL pipeline could far outweigh the benefits of jobs created by the project.

headline: Irish Coffee, American Ingenuity
text: FOR a holiday that has come to involve so much alcohol, St. Patrick’s Day is badly in need of a good drink. Beer, even tinted green, is too workaday. Stout is too stolid. Sweet liqueurs like Irish Mist and Baileys Irish Cream are just too everything.

headline: St. Bonaventure’s N.C.A.A. Double Feature
text: St. Bonaventure doesn’t get to celebrate many moments of basketball glory, but suddenly, it’s luck has runneth over. Not only has the women’s team risen to a new level, grabbing a No. 5 seed in the N.C.A.A. tournament after a 29-3 season, even after losing the conference tournament final to Dayton, but the men’s team made a surprising run through the Atlantic 10 tournament and grabbed an automatic bid when it toppled Xavier in the final on Sunday.

headline: New Pastry Chefs at Le Bernardin and Jean Georges
text: IN a coincidence on a cake plate, two of the city’s highest-profile pastry chefs left their jobs at the end of last year. Their replacements at Le Bernardin and Jean Georges have been named, and this next generation is now busily tending to the trade’s ganaches, meringues, herbal syrups and flecks of gold leaf.

headline: La Tour d’Argent Products Now Sold in New York
text: A line of products from La Tour d’Argent, the venerable Paris restaurant overlooking Notre-Dame, is now being sold in New York. Jars of preserves in uncommonly aromatic flavors, including raspberry-violet, orange with orange-flower water and apricot-amaretto, are among the standouts. The line also includes clementine, and strawberry made with two kinds of berries, the regular cultivated kind and a variety called gariguette, which comes from Provence and is similar to fraises des bois. Breton butter cookies, a tea blend and a fig and grape chutney are also available.

headline: I Was a Cookbook Ghostwriter
text: “YOU. Girl with the notebook. Out.”

headline: Right-Bank Sweets on the Lower East Side
text: With chocolate, freshness counts. And it’s all but guaranteed at Christian Vautier Le Concept, a new boutique and cafe on the Lower East Side where truffles, chocolate-enrobed bonbons and other confections — including caramels, chocolate spreads and fruit jellies — are made daily. It is owned by Mr. Vautier, a Parisian chocolate maker and the executive pastry chef at the Grand Intercontinental Hotel in Paris. “I did not want to have a French product sent over here to sell,” said Mr. Vautier, whose partner is Aditi Malhotra (right), a graduate of the French Culinary Institute. Ms. Malhotra, whose family has been in the hotel and restaurant business in India and New York, is making the chocolates, often with unusual fillings like Sichuan pepper ganache. She also makes pastries, including chocolate mousse, macarons and profiteroles. The bright shop, its springtime colors in step with the season, also offers teas and Dallis Brothers coffee.

headline: An Inconvenient Statement, Retracted
text: Energy Secretary Steven Chu on Tuesday walked away from his oft-quoted pre-Cabinet statement that the United States should deliberately raise gasoline prices to discourage consumption.

headline: For a Shamrock Toast, Drinks With Irish Ties
text: The lineage of Innis & Gunn beers is complicated. They are brewed and bottled in Scotland, but their claim to fame is the time they spend in whisky and rum casks, giving them rich, alluring depth. The latest, Irish Whiskey Cask Scottish Stout, with a shamrock-green label, is aged in Irish whiskey barrels. This brown beer, with 7.4 percent alcohol, evokes coffee and ginger in its aromas and tastes toasty, with a refreshing, bitter chocolate finish. In an odd way, it suggests Irish coffee.

headline: Volkswagen Has Fun Giving Away Über-Hard-to-Get Kraftwerk Tickets
text: Volkswagen of America has come up with a clever way to remind consumers of its German heritage — or should that be “klever”?

headline: New York State Set to Add All Convict DNA to Its Database
text: ALBANY — New York is poised to establish one of the most expansive DNA databases in the nation, requiring people convicted of everything from fare beating to first-degree murder to provide samples of their DNA to the state.

headline: It Probably Helps to Know the Secret Handshake
text: More than a dozen ordinary-looking white-collar types walk into the theater, chatting with one another in quiet voices. For a second, they seem as if they were part of the audience. But they’re actually the actors, and after much mingling, they sit down in rows of chairs on the stage, and an initiation begins.

headline: Syria’s Losing Battle to Control the News
text: Updated | Wednesday | 9:07 a.m. Nearly 12 months into the uprising in Syria, government attempts to stifle news coverage by barring independent reporters from the country are still being confounded by a network of activists who have now posted more than 40,000 video clips on YouTube, offering glimpses of protests and documenting a violent crackdown on dissent.

headline: The Basics, Still Filling an Arena
text: Primordial equals durable for the Black Keys, a two-man band — Patrick Carney on drums, and Dan Auerbach on guitar and vocals — originally from Akron, Ohio, and recently transplanted to Nashville. Visuals aside, their concert on Monday night could easily have taken place in 1973. It was a set full of stomping drumbeats and distorted guitar riffs carrying mostly declarations of woman trouble and other mental distress.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Making Highlight Work, and News Link Symbols
text: Here are some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web on Tuesday. There are more here.

headline: Which Cover Would You Choose?
text: For our latest cover, we came up with a lot of options. We narrowed them down to five and opened up our official N.Y.T. Magazine Polling Station. The rules are simple: the entire staff votes on their favorite cover by dropping a wooden chip (coffee stirrer) into an upside down paper cup with a slit cut into it. It’s the closest we ever get to a focus group (thankfully), and the staff seems to enjoy it. The polling station is located right in front of my office, so I get to listen to all of the heated debates. Full disclosure: The majority does not always rule, but it gives us a good idea about what people like and don’t like:

headline: For a Professional Midwest Palate, a First Taste of a Dirty-Water Dog
text: In her 30-some years as food critic for the Grand Forks, N.D., Herald, Marilyn Hagerty has reviewed the Dippin’ Dots at a hockey rink, sung the praises of grilled salmon with North Dakota Prairie Sauce, and made her way through countless portions of lutefisk. But she has never reviewed a hot dog.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Bangladesh and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Bangladesh, Belgium, India and Uganda.

headline: The-Dream
text: The-Dream, a k a the singer-songwriter and record producer Terius Youngdell Nash, performed at S.O.B.’s on Monday night.

headline: Linking Extreme Poverty and Global Terrorism
text: These days, I spend most of my time hiking the rolling hills and valleys of Kuria, a remote district in rural Kenya. I’m on a very different career path now than I was before, as a Marine patrolling streets and alleys in Iraq. In my new work, I travel from shamba to shamba (the Kiswahili word for farm) talking and working with farmers who live in extreme poverty. As we walk through their fields, I often see unwelcome flashes of my past. Peaceful Kurian villages transform into rows of Iraqi huts destroyed by rocket-propelled grenades. While gazing into the eyes of a Kurian farmer who is pleading with me to help her children who haven’t eaten in three days, my vision blurs and I’m looking into the eyes of a screaming Iraqi farmer who just had his family shot to pieces right in front of him. I watch our Kenyan farmers roll out their planting strings to properly space fertilizer and seed, and in my mind’s eye, I look through my scope at untrained, desperate farmers rolling out fuse lines that lead to poorly disguised road-side bombs next to the main supply route south of Baghdad. Two worlds, blurring together as I walk.

headline: After 244 Years, Encyclopaedia Britannica Stops the Presses
text: After 244 years, the Encyclopaedia Britannica is going out of print.

headline: R&B Purist, Wrapped in a Cloak of Hip-Hop
text: When something, or someone, gets under the skin of The-Dream, he makes it known. Last year, in the down time between major-label albums, he released “1977,” a free album through his Web site that was recorded under his real name, Terius Nash. The year before he’d split from his wife, the singer Christina Milian, and “1977” bore all the scars of a brutal heartbreak: he was petulant, nasty and unforgiving.

headline: Competing Narratives at SXSW
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — This year, eight films are vying for South by Southwest’s narrative prize. Below is a look at three of those films, with comments from their directors on how they aimed for something different in the cinematic approaches.

headline: Dining Calendar
text: For Passover

headline: High Gear
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Florida’s Stearns Keeps ‘Birther’ Doubts Alive
text: Facing a difficult primary campaign, Representative Cliff Stearns, Republican of Florida, has waded into the controversy over the legitimacy of President Obama’s birth certificate.

headline: A Disorder That Stops the Music
text: Just because you’re a hypochondriac, to paraphrase Joseph Heller’s wry comment on paranoia, doesn’t mean you aren’t sick. And the brilliant Canadian pianist Glenn Gould was, in a phrase uttered at a medical conference over the weekend, “a world-class hypochondriac.” He was also a perfectionist, easily frustrated.

headline: Female Voters and the Republican Primary
text: All of the talk about birth control and abortion laws seems to have had little effect on the ways women are voting for the two leading Republican candidates, Mitt Romney and Rick Santorum, at least according to exit polls in the primaries.

headline: Off the Menu
text: Opening

headline: Scorecard: Bank Stocks After the Stress Tests
text: Bank stocks climbed as the results of the Federal Reserve’s stress test were released on Tuesday, two days earlier than planned.

headline: What’s at Stake in Alabama and Mississippi
text: It’s hard to say who is going to win in Alabama and Mississippi on Tuesday night. Polls in these states have a poor track record, and they project a close race anyway, although Rick Santorum is somewhat off the lead lap in Mississippi.

headline: Digital Notes: Turntable.fm Says It Has Reached Deals With Labels
text: Sometimes it’s best to go legit.

headline: Ageless, Like Armani
text: THERE are no urine tests for fashion designers, no central governing body to verify if they are enhancing their performance in any way. When Giorgio Armani steps out for his warm bath of applause after each runway show, he looks strikingly the same: tight shirt caressing piles of muscle, skin the color of a lovely vintage bag from the Portobello Market, a bushel of hair long and white and slick. Some years ago, he arrived at his current age, and then just stopped. Cryogenics, Botox, rubdowns with salted blubber and lavender-scented gels: whatever he’s using, it’s working.

headline: New York Stagecraft Plies the High Seas
text: Before Diane Paulus reached Broadway directing rowdy hippies in “Hair” and tormented lovers in “The Gershwins’ Porgy and Bess,” she cut her teeth in big-budget theater by making sure that Minnie Mouse and Snow White didn’t trip over each other during “The Golden Mickeys,” a 50-minute musical awards-show takeoff she staged for Disney Cruise Line in 2003. Ms. Paulus found herself wrangling with Disney lawyers over the neckline for Cruella de Vil (designs for famous characters can be sacrosanct) and spending lavishly on the show (a forerunner to the so-called event theater that interests her).

headline: Ruth Barcan Marcus, Philosopher-Logician, Dies at 90
text: Ruth Barcan Marcus, a philosopher esteemed for her advances in logic, a traditionally male-dominated subset of a traditionally male-dominated field, died on Feb. 19 at her home in New Haven. She was 90.

headline: With Controversial Leader Gone, Charter Makes Bid to Stay Alive
text: The lawyer for Williamsburg Charter High School, a troubled Brooklyn school that the city’s Department of Education has flagged for closing, made a forceful case at a hearing on Tuesday for keeping the school open.

headline: Microfoundations, Micro Payoffs (Wonkish)
text: There has been an ongoing discussion in the econoblogosphere about the usefulness or lack thereof of “microfoundations” in macroeconomics, which in practice means trying to write down models in which aggregate behavior is justified in terms of the actions of utility-maximizing individuals with rational expectations. I upset even New Keynesians, such as Simon Wren-Lewis, with my observation that the crusade for microfoundations has had only one success, the prediction of stagflation after an extended period of high inflation, and that this success is 35 years old.

headline: Bain Defends Itself Amid Attacks on Romney
text: Bain Capital sent a letter to its investors late Tuesday that for the first time addressed the presidential campaign of the private equity firm’s founder, Mitt Romney, and defended its record on job creation.

headline: More Weight Given to More Partisan States
text: Both Democrats and Republicans use formulas that give states delegates based not just on their popluation, but also on party loyalty in past elections.

headline: Web Site Publishes Freedom of Information Requests Sought by California Congressman
text: An Internet site that promotes openness by the federal government has beaten Representative Darrell E. Issa to the punch, publishing copies of tens of thousands of Freedom of Information Act requests assembled for Mr. Issa last year as part of an investigation he is conducting into the federal government’s responsiveness to such inquiries.

headline: From North Dakota, a Fresh Eye on Street Food
text: Her glowing review of the Olive Garden in Grand Forks, N.D., has turned her into an Internet superstar. And so Marilyn Hagerty, restaurant critic for the Grand Forks Herald, came to New York on Tuesday to turn her critical eye on Manhattan’s food scene.

headline: In Private Equity I.P.O., a Shareholder Fear of Losing Favor
text: The Carlyle Group, one of the world’s largest private equity firms, is brimming with deal makers who have made billions for themselves and their fund investors. Yet they appear to be struggling to persuade people to buy into their most important deal yet — an initial public offering of the firm.

headline: U.S. Sets Roster for Olympic Qualifying
text: Regional qualifying for a berth in the London Olympics starts later this month, but United States under-23 national team coach Caleb Porter still has some spade work to do in filling the final spot on his 20-man roster.

headline: Exploring an Impetuous, and Tentative, Office Romance
text: Almost the only time you see the word “gamine” these days is in a sentence that also refers to the French actress Audrey Tautou, a market she cornered in the 2001 film “Amélie.” Ms. Tautou’s gamineness — gaminality? gaminocity? — is about all that her new film, “Delicacy,” has going for it. It’s a lightweight romance that occasionally shows a sense of humor but seems afraid to turn it loose.

headline: An Artist at Work, Looking and Judging
text: Gerhard Richter may not fling paint at the canvas, Jackson Pollock-style, but as Corinna Belz shows in her documentary “Gerhard Richter Painting,” he can be his own kind of action painter.

headline: The Alabama and Mississippi Primaries
text: Republicans voted in Alabama and Mississippi on Tuesday, as well as Hawaii and American Samoa.

headline: The Red Line and the Ringette Line: What’s the Difference?
text: BOCA RATON, Fla. — The N.H.L. general managers rejected a measure that would have made the two-line pass illegal, as it was before the 2004-5 N.H.L. lockout. So N.H.L. defensemen will still be able to make long-bomb passes from deep in their own end all the way to the far blue line – like this one by the Rangers’ Michael Del Zotto:

headline: Highlights of the Exit Polls in the Deep South G.O.P. Primaries
text: 10:32 p.m. | Updated The Times’s polling unit is analyzing the results of the exit polls in Alabama and Mississippi as Republicans in those states vote for a nominee. This post will be updated as we crunch more numbers.

headline: Forecasts for Ad Spending Become Rosier
text: A leading forecaster of advertising spending is increasing its predictions for growth this year and in coming years, both worldwide and in the United States.

headline: Auto Bailout Is Looking Better to the Public
text: Those Eminem and Clint Eastwood advertisements just might have worked: Americans seem to be changing their minds about the once-loathed auto bailout.

headline: Time Grows Short for Magic to Move Howard
text: ORLANDO, Fla. — The Magic chief executive Alex Martins said on Tuesday that the team had not made a decision on whether to trade the star center Dwight Howard, but that it would have several potential trading partners, including “plenty of teams that would take him without any assurances” of having him next season.

headline: Lawyers for Man Accused in Terrorism Plot Make Case for Dismissal
text: Lawyers for a man who was charged under a seldom-used state terrorism statute argued on Tuesday that the law was too unconstitutionally vague to be applied in this case and that the evidence presented to the grand jury was not legally sufficient to support the charges.

headline: Picking Up the Tempo at the Right Time
text: Peyton Siva added an unlikely flourish to the end of a season defined by struggle: a ride around the Madison Square Garden court atop the shoulders of his 6-foot-6 teammate Chane Behanan while Louisville celebrated a Big East tournament championship.

text: Donald F. Smith, a champion of high-style cabaret who founded both the Mabel Mercer Foundation and the New York Cabaret Convention, died on Tuesday in Manhattan. He was 79.

text: The race for the Republican presidential nomination arrived today in Alabama and Mississippi, where tight three-way contests could tip in favor of Mitt Romney, Rick Santorum or Newt Gingrich. We’ll be bringing you exit poll results, data-driven observations, historical context and the final electoral verdicts in both states.

headline: Who Gets the Breaks and Benefits
text: Tax breaks offered by the federal government tend to overwhelmingly favor the richest segment of the population, while entitlement benefits and other federal social benefits are more evenly distributed.

headline: Minoru Mori, Builder Who Changed the Face of Modern Tokyo, Dies at 77
text: TOKYO — Minoru Mori, a developer who helped shape Tokyo’s skyline with towering buildings and then turned his attention to China, died on Thursday in Tokyo. He was 77. The cause was heart failure, officials of his company, Mori Building, said.

headline: In Orlando, Heavy Choices and Risks
text: ORLANDO, Fla.

headline: March Madness? What About Midterms?
text: For student-athletes, the madness is year-round. Who is making sure they get an education?

headline: Caught in Egypt’s Political Cross-Fire
text: Washington

headline: After Tonight, What’s Next?
text: With the contests in Mississippi and Alabama almost over, the candidates will soon shift their attention to Missouri and Illinois.

headline: New Interest in Hacking as Threat to Security
text: WASHINGTON — During the five-month period between October and February, there were 86 reported attacks on computer systems in the United States that control critical infrastructure, factories and databases, according to the Department of Homeland Security, compared with 11 over the same period a year ago.

headline: The Human Cost of Animal Suffering
text: Until a couple of years ago I believed that the primary reasons to eat less meat were environment- and health-related, and there’s no question that those are valid reasons. But animal welfare has since become a large part of my thinking as well. And I say this as someone not known to his friends as an animal-lover.

headline: Iraq’s Tribal Chiefs Step Into the Breach With Swift Justice
text: ISHAQI, Iraq — Fearful of a future as violent as the past, and exasperated by corrupt and incompetent politicians, the men who hold power here have seized the moment of American departure and national political chaos to administer their own form of justice: expelling suspected insurgents and their families from this town with the threat of death.

headline: Obama Introduces Cameron to Hoops in Ohio
text: It might not be the most glamorous way for an American president to celebrate a visiting British prime minister. But on Tuesday evening, Prime Minister David Cameron found himself chomping on a hot dog and watching a college basketball game in Dayton, Ohio. He was there as a guest of President Obama, who was eager to introduce him to one of his passions.

headline: A New Species in New York Was Croaking in Plain Sight
text: The croak gave it away.

headline: 20 Charged as U.S. Says Heroin Ring Is Broken Up
text: CENTRAL ISLIP, N.Y. — They were accused of flooding the streets with millions of dollars’ worth of heroin, operating a major distribution ring that extended from Brooklyn to Suffolk County.

headline: Capitalism, Version 2012
text: David Rothkopf, the chief executive and editor-at-large of Foreign Policy magazine, has a smart new book out, entitled “Power, Inc.,” about the epic rivalry between big business and government that captures, in many ways, what the 2012 election should be about — and it’s not “contraception,” although the word does begin with a “C.” It’s the future of “capitalism” and whether it will be shaped in America or somewhere else.

headline: Nuclear Agency Head Calls for New Standards
text: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission needs to rewrite its standards to address what it considers “high consequence” events in view of last year’s nuclear accident at the Fukushima Daiichi plant in Japan, the commission’s director said Tuesday. Addressing 3,000 nuclear experts from 34 countries, the chairman, Gregory B. Jaczko, said that despite the disaster the plant probably met the agency’s safety goals because it did not result in big radiation doses to the general population. The accident’s immediate health consequences were “very close to nothing,” with “little to no” long-term health effects, he said. But the destruction of reactors, the mass evacuations and the destruction of property were “clearly unacceptable,” Mr. Jaczko said. The commission’s great challenge is to be “proactive” in identifying previously unforeseen risks, primarily natural disasters.

headline: For Two-Way Referee, It’s N.F.L. One Day, College Basketball the Next
text: Four years ago, Gene Steratore was working as an official in a men’s basketball game between Loyola (Md.) and Niagara. The game was tight, and at one point, Steratore made a critical call in Niagara’s favor that brought Loyola’s coach, Jimmy Patsos, stomping down the sideline in his direction.

headline: Day 1: Bills Seek Williams as Dolphins Trade Marshall; Manning Remains Unsigned
text: The most prominent free agent, Peyton Manning, remained unsigned Tuesday, but the impact of the passing game shaped the first day of N.F.L. free agency. The early blockbuster moves centered on teams vacuuming a deep class of wide receivers and the aggressive push by the Buffalo Bills to lure the top available pass rusher.

headline: Lawyers Give Final Presentations in Dorm Spying Case
text: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J. — In the days before he killed himself, Tyler Clementi did not act as though he was intimidated by the discovery that his roommate had used a webcam to watch him kissing another man, a lawyer for the roommate said Tuesday.

headline: Rivalry Kicks Off With New Face and Added Fire
text: TAMPA, Fla. — An eager contingent of about three dozen reporters from two continents peppered Bobby Valentine with questions Tuesday about the rivalry between the Yankees and the Boston Red Sox, and his new place in it.

headline: Scorecard for New Bank Stress Tests
text: Scorecard for New Bank Stress Tests

headline: Worker Tells Court He Lacked Math to Measure Crane Part
text: The employee responsible for finding a replacement part for a tower crane that ultimately collapsed on the Upper East Side in 2008, killing two workers, testified on Tuesday about his own difficulty with the basic math of measuring key components.

headline: Marilyn Hagerty, Food Critic
text: Marilyn Hagerty, a food critic from North Dakota, reviews a New York hot dog.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: March 13, 2012

headline: Santorum Takes 2 Races in South; Romney Is Third
text: BIRMINGHAM, Ala. — Rick Santorum captured twin victories in the Alabama and Mississippi primaries on Tuesday, overcoming the financial advantages of Mitt Romney and the Southern allegiances to Newt Gingrich on a night that amplified his argument that the Republican nominating fight is becoming a two-man race with Mr. Romney.

headline: In Spat With Law Student, a Governor’s Tongue Is, Once Again, Too Sharp to Hold
text: Among the targets of Gov. Chris Christie’s sharp tongue have been Democrats; Newt Gingrich; Raymond W. Kelly, the New York City police commissioner; and people who did not believe state flags in New Jersey should be lowered for Whitney Houston.

headline: Anthony and Knicks Can’t Play Together
text: As they steeled themselves late Monday for a grinding, gripping final 12 minutes in Chicago, the Knicks broke into two factions along the bench. At one end, a swarm of players gathered around the coaching staff. At the other, Carmelo Anthony sat stoically, a towel over his shoulders, alone.

headline: An Officer Had Backup: Secret Tapes
text: One night in October 2009, a team of police officers, led by a deputy chief, raided the home of a police officer named Adrian Schoolcraft, and dragged him out of his bed and to the psychiatric emergency room at Jamaica Hospital Medical Center. He was held for six days in a locked ward. No judge was involved. There was no hearing.

headline: Delegate System Gives Small States Outsize Clout at Convention
text: One person, one vote is not a concept that either party pays much heed to when it comes to nominating candidates for president — as was vividly underscored Tuesday by the seemingly outsize number of delegates that were at stake in the Alabama and Mississippi Republican primaries.

headline: Second Woman Denies Running a Brothel
text: A second defendant who was indicted last month and accused of running a brothel on the Upper East Side turned herself in to prosecutors on Tuesday.

headline: In Espada Fraud Trial, a Focus on Politics and Lavish Spending
text: In his quarter-century in New York politics, Pedro Espada Jr. has had a career marked by turbulence and accomplishment; despite multiple investigations and repeated accusations of fraud, he still rose to become majority leader of the State Senate.

headline: Corrections: March 14
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Campaign Finance Lessons for Disillusioned Asian-American Group
text: Concerned about the dampening effect that a fund-raising scandal involving the city comptroller could have on Asian-American voters, the New York City Campaign Finance Board held a workshop on Monday night on the dos and don’ts of campaign finance.

headline: Don’t Tread on Us
text: Hillary Clinton has fought for women’s rights around the world. But who would have dreamed that she would have to fight for them at home?

headline: The Fed Stays the Course
text: The Federal Reserve acknowledged on Tuesday that it is not certain which way the economy is going. It saw signs of improvement, but its outlook is cautious. It plans to continue near-zero interest rates through 2014 and bond purchases through June to keep borrowing costs low. The stock market responded enthusiastically. Without more help — from Congress, the White House and the Fed — it is hard to see how the fledgling recovery will take off.

headline: U.N. Leader Says Assad Must Shift Syria’s Course
text: UNITED NATIONS — President Bashar al-Assad of Syria should not delude himself that he can survive the Syrian uprising without significant reforms, the United Nations secretary general, Ban Ki-moon, said Tuesday.

headline: Keeping Score: Bryant Has the Stats Of a Not-Quite-M.V.P.
text: During his stint as the coach of the Cleveland Cavaliers, Mike Brown witnessed two most valuable player seasons by Cleveland’s prodigal son, LeBron James. Now the coach of the Los Angeles Lakers, Brown is pushing his new star, Kobe Bryant, for M.V.P. consideration.

headline: Breaking Down the Alabama Vote: Conservatives Divided
text: Voters in Alabama were closely divided on Tuesday over whom they favored for the Republican nomination. Perhaps most telling, more than half of Alabama voters said Mitt Romney’s positions on the issues were not conservative enough, while about the same number said that Rick Santorum’s and Newt Gingrich’s positions were just about right. That meant that Mr. Santorum and Mr. Gingrich essentially split the support of crucial conservative voting groups in the state known as “the Heart of Dixie.”

headline: Breaking Down the Mississippi Vote: Religious, but Pragmatic
text: With a very conservative electorate and potentially the highest number of evangelical Christians in any Republican contest this year, Mississippi would seem to be a better demographic fit for Rick Santorum or Newt Gingrich than for Mitt Romney.

headline: Detention for Immigrants That Looks Less Like Prison
text: On a patch of Texas farmland near the Gulf of Mexico, immigration officials on Tuesday unveiled one of the most visible results of a three-year-old plan to overhaul the nation’s immigration detention system: a brand-new center intended to provide a less penal setting for detainees.

headline: In Africa’s Vanishing Forests, the Benefits of Bamboo
text: In the district of Asosa, the land is thick with bamboo.   People plant it and manage the forests. They rely on its soil-grabbing roots to stabilize steep slopes and riverbanks, cutting erosion. They harvest it to burn for fuel, to make into charcoal sticks to sell to city dwellers and to build furniture.

headline: Hapi Holiday!
text: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — The quote above is an actual cheer from my old alma mater, the Bronx High School of Science.

headline: Gov. Cuomo’s Word
text: Gov. Andrew Cuomo vowed that he would veto politically warped and self-serving election maps. If he does not veto a shameful and cynical compromise being offered this week by legislative leaders in both parties, New Yorkers will be stuck with gerrymandered districts and Albany’s status quo for another decade.

headline: Help for Student Borrowers
text: The federal Consumer Financial Protection Bureau is right to take on the poorly regulated, private student lending industry. Too often, college students are lured by schools or lenders into ruinously priced loans, even when they are eligible for affordable federal loans that offer hardship deferments and broad consumer protections.

headline: Hurting Victims’ Advocates
text: The Survivors Network of those Abused by Priests, known as SNAP, has played a critical role in making public the horrific crimes of pedophile priests and holding the Roman Catholic Church accountable for the crimes. Now the church is using a tactic that could cripple SNAP by embroiling it in costly litigation in which it is not a party.

headline: Though Not at Their Best, Rangers Find a Way to Win
text: The Rangers’ performance Tuesday night against the Carolina Hurricanes was often erratic and undisciplined. But two positives emerged from the game at Madison Square Garden: the Rangers managed to win, 4-2, and the line of Brad Richards, Marian Gaborik and Carl Hagelin may be emerging, just at the right time, as a powerhouse.

headline: Iran May Not Open a Site to Inspectors
text: Iran signaled on Tuesday that it was unwilling to grant a request by international nuclear inspectors for unfettered access to a restricted military complex that they suspect may house a chamber designed to test explosives used in atomic weapons triggers.

headline: In Sudan’s Nuba Mountains, Government Rocket Attacks Sow Fear, Witnesses Say
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — Ryan Boyette, an American aid worker living in one of the most active war zones in Africa — Sudan’s Nuba Mountains — was in a thatch-roof office on a clear January day when he heard two thunderous blasts.

headline: Charges Not Dismissed in Yonkers Corruption Case
text: A federal judge who sharply questioned whether the government had proved a fundamental part of its corruption case against a former Yonkers councilwoman has refused, for now, a defense request made on Tuesday that she dismiss crucial charges before the case went to a jury.

headline: For Wartburg College, Titles Are Twice as Nice
text: The best and least heralded rivalry in sports can be found in Division III wrestling, where either Wartburg College in Waverly, Iowa, or Augsburg College in Minneapolis, has won the national championship since 1995.

headline: For Gingrich, an Alabama Celebration Deferred
text: BIRMINGHAM, Ala. — Newt Gingrich’s election night party is in a hotel ballroom next door, as it happens, to a party for the Alabama Republican Party. There are some differences between the two rooms.The party’s party has a repast of breaded portobello mushrooms and assorted cheeses. There are no snacks at the campaign’s party. There are white tablecloths at the Republican Party event; it is standing room only at Newt 2012, where a sparse crowd of about 100 is beginning to fill in.

headline: Rising Sea Levels Seen as Threat to Coastal U.S.
text: About 3.7 million Americans live within a few feet of high tide and risk being hit by more frequent coastal flooding in coming decades because of the sea level rise caused by global warming, according to new research.

headline: In El Salvador, Prisons Packed to the Bars
text: The country’s 19 prisons were built to hold a total of 8,000 prisoners — today, 24,000 are stuffed into them. And El Salvador is far from unique in Latin America.

headline: Inmate’s Lament: ‘Rather Be Dead Than Here’
text: SAN SALVADOR — In a prison called Hope, there is little of it to go around.

headline: Home Base of Accused Soldier Has Faced Scrutiny
text: JOINT BASE LEWIS-McCHORD, Wash. — A soldier from Los Angeles blamed the combination of dangerous deployments and the gloom and gray that units encounter when they return to this sprawling military base in the often cloudy Pacific Northwest.

headline: A Nation With Too Many Tax Breaks
text: With the presidential election in sight and a deadline looming at the end of the year to cut trillions from the deficit, the partisan debate over the budget has become an existential battle over the purpose of government.

headline: After Apology, National Advertisers Are Still Shunning Limbaugh
text: IN place of paid advertisers, public service announcements now fill some of the time between Rush Limbaugh’s monologues on radio stations, a consequence of an ad boycott against the conservative talk show host that is now nearly two weeks old.

headline: South’s One-Two Punch a Heavy Blow to Gingrich
text: BIRMINGHAM, Ala. — Hoping for one more rebirth, Newt Gingrich was bitterly disappointed on Tuesday, losing two primaries in the South, where he had staked his claim, and he will find it increasingly difficult to argue that he is the candidate Republicans are seeking in 2012.

headline: A San Francisco District Begins to Reduce Blight
text: SAN FRANCISCO — The names of the city’s storied neighborhoods roll off the tongue: Pacific Heights, North Beach, the Mission, Haight-Ashbury, the Castro.

headline: The Full Text of the Federal Reserve’s Statement on Interest Rates
text: The following is the full text of the statement released on Tuesday by the Federal Reserve:

headline: Wait. Wasn’t Obama Winning?
text: Why aren’t President Obama’s poll numbers higher? That’s the question unsettling the Washington conventional wisdom this week. Amid improving economic growth, a grim and grinding Republican primary campaign and the White House’s skillful exploitation of Rush Limbaugh’s boorishness, Obama’s reelection was being taken almost for granted in many political circles. But then came a pair of surveys – one from the Washington Post and ABC and one from the New York Times and CBS – that showed the president’s approval ratings sinking this month back toward the lower 40s after a steady winter climb.

headline: Santorum Speaks After Victories
text: Rick Santorum spoke to supporters after winning both the Mississippi and Alabama primaries.

headline: Detroit Officials Criticize State’s Proposal for Fiscal Oversight Panel
text: With Detroit expected to run out of cash this spring, state officials in Michigan proposed a restructuring deal with the city leaders on Tuesday that would establish a joint advisory board to address the city’s financial troubles without a state-appointed emergency manager.

headline: Despite Calls for Alternatives, Another American Is Expected to Lead World Bank
text: WASHINGTON — Once again, the next head of the World Bank will be an American.

headline: An Update on New York Redistricting
text: New York is now among the last states in the nation to tackle the redistricting required as a result of the 2010 census. And the urgency is growing: the state’s Congressional primary is scheduled for June 26, and its legislative primary for Sept. 11.

headline: Homework Trumps Gut Instinct in Retail Brokering
text: When Donald G. Fisher, the founder of the Gap clothing chain, began expanding in Manhattan in the 1990s, “he would stand in front of a space, see how many people walked by, and say, ‘Hey, this looks like a good spot,’ ” said Robert K. Futterman, the founder of the retail brokerage RKF, who represented the company in some leases.

headline: Bruce C. Ratner
text: Mr. Ratner, 67, is the chairman and chief executive of the Forest City Ratner Companies, which owns and operates 11 million square feet of property in the New York area, including the MetroTech Center in downtown Brooklyn and the Frank Gehry-designed 8 Spruce Street in Manhattan.

headline: Radulov, Who Left Predators for Russia, Nears Return
text: BOCA RATON, Fla. — Forward Alexander Radulov, whose departure from the Nashville Predators to Russia in 2008 touched off a brief signing war between the N.H.L. and the Kontinental Hockey League, is close to returning to Nashville.

headline: Road for Santorum Depends on the Next Move by Gingrich
text: Once again, Americans are waking up to headlines about multiple primary-night victories for Rick Santorum over the man who is still widely considered to be the most likely Republican nominee this year, Mitt Romney.

headline: The Closer: Redskins Shop for Bargains
text: On the first day of free-agent signings, the Redskins did not sign Randy Moss, an enigmatic future Hall of Famer. They did not throw $55 million at Vincent Jackson. They did not trade for the frequently disgruntled Brandon Marshall.

headline: New Solar Panels Blossomed Despite a Tough Year for the Industry
text: Last year seemed like a dark one for the solar industry: stiff competition from China drove American manufacturers to layoffs and even bankruptcy, while the low price of natural gas and the loss of a critical government subsidy weakened incentives for new solar developments. And then there was the long shadow of Solyndra, whose bankruptcy after receiving federal loans cast a pall over other green-energy endeavors.

headline: Do Statins Make It Tough to Exercise?
text: For years, physicians and scientists have been aware that statins, the most widely prescribed drugs in the world, can cause muscle aches and fatigue in some patients. What many people don’t know is that these side effects are especially pronounced in people who exercise.

headline: Crane Clips Scaffolding Under Brooklyn Bridge
text: A crane on a barge being towed by a tugboat accidentally hit the scaffolding on the underside of the Brooklyn Bridge about 8:15 p.m. Tuesday, damaging about 20 feet of scaffolding. The bridge appeared to be undamaged, officials said. The crane connected with some of the sheet metal under the bridge, said a United States Coast Guard spokesman.Vehicle traffic was never halted.

headline: Word of the Day | distill
text: distill •\di-ˈstil\• verb

headline: Tension Over a Campus Gift, and a Potential Recipient
text: NORTHFIELD, Mass. — As historic school campuses go, the one in this rural New England town is just about perfect, with pretty buildings of brick and stone scattered along a gentle hill.

headline: Gingrich Speaks in Alabama
text: Newt Gingrich spoke to supporters after losing the Mississippi and Alabama primaries.

headline: NYT Front Page for 03/14/2012
text: NYT Front Page for 03/14/2012

headline: Somalia: Islamist Rebels Vow to Eject Aid Agency
text: The Shabab Islamist militant group, which still controls a few large patches of Somalia, said Tuesday that it was expelling the Save the Children aid agency because it had distributed expired food and tried to bribe Shabab officials. The Shabab, who are vehemently anti-Western, have kicked out several other aid agencies in recent years. Save the Children, based in Westport, Conn., said that it was looking into the allegations and that it would continue its operations in other parts of Somalia. The Shabab’s area of control has been steadily dwindling in recent months.

headline: Hospitals With Radioactive Materials Expose Weakness in Antiterror Rules
text: WASHINGTON — Ten years into a campaign to make radioactive materials harder for terrorists to steal, Congressional auditors have found one hospital where cesium was kept in a padlocked room but the combination to the lock was written on the door frame and another where radioactive material was in a room with unsecured windows that looked out on a loading dock.

headline: China: New Aircraft Carrier Is a Vintage Soviet Model
text: China’s first aircraft carrier, a 1980s Soviet warship that has been refitted with modern weaponry, will go into service later this year, state-run media quoted a top navy official as saying on Tuesday. The carrier, once called the Varyag, has been undergoing sea trials since last August. The military unveiled a new carrier-based jet fighter last spring, the J-15 Flying Shark, but the ship currently sports only full-size models of aircraft, the newspaper China Daily stated. The paper quoted Rear Adm. Cao Dongshen, a deputy at this month’s annual meeting of the National People’s Congress in Beijing, as saying that the ship would be used for training, experiments and scientific research.

headline: A Family Feud, With Billions in the Balance
text: HONG KONG — It has been a bad week for the wealthiest woman in Asia.

headline: George Kerchner, Led a D-Day Maneuver, Dies at 93
text: George Kerchner, who as an Army Ranger was decorated for bravery in leading his company up the face of a towering cliff to seize a battery of German big guns overlooking the American invasion beaches of D-Day, died on Feb. 17 in Midlothian, Va. He was 93.

headline: Santorum Sweeps Two Southern States
text: Rick Santorum captured twin victories in the Alabama and Mississippi primaries on Tuesday, overcoming the financial advantages of Mitt Romney and the Southern allegiances to Newt Gingrich.

headline: Guatemala: Ex-soldier Sentenced to 6060 Years for 1982 Massacre
text: A former soldier was sentenced late Monday to 6060 years in prison for his role in the 1982 massacre of 201 Mayan peasants in the village of Dos Erres during Guatemala’s civil war. Pedro Pimentel Ríos, part of a group of 17 soldiers accused of the killings, was ordered to serve 30 years for each killing and an additional 30 years for crimes against humanity. A former member of the elite Kaibiles military unit, Mr. Pimentel was deported last July from the United States, where he had been employed as a maintenance worker in Santa Ana, Calif. Four other former soldiers were sentenced to similar terms last August for their involvement in the massacre. Guatemalan law allows convicts to serve a maximum of 50 years, but the sentence assures that Mr. Pimentel, who is in his 50s, will spend the rest of his life in prison.

headline: Jean Giraud, the Comic-Book Artist Known as ‘Moebius,’ Dies at 73
text: Jean Giraud, a French comic-book artist whose dark, intricately drawn fantasy worlds exerted a profound influence on graphic novels worldwide and on American science fiction films like “Alien,” “Tron” “The Fifth Element,” and “Avatar,” died on Saturday at his home outside Paris. He was 73.

headline: In Indian Homes, Phones and Electricity on Rise but Sanitation and Internet Lagging
text: India’s households have, overall, become more comfortable in the past 10 years, but hundreds of millions of people still lack basics like electricity, toilets and a convenient water source, according the Housing Census that was released Tuesday by Home Secretary R. K. Singh. The survey looks about 330 million households in India.

headline: Numbers Tell Only Part of Dravid’s Story
text: “It is hard to find anyone with a bad word to say about Rahul Dravid,” Huw Richards writes in The New York Times.

headline: News Quiz | March 14, 2012
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s front page. Good luck!

headline: Panetta Is Safe After Breach Near His Plane at Afghan Base
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — A tense visit to Afghanistan by Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta got off to an alarming start on Wednesday when a stolen pickup truck sped onto a ramp alongside a runway at a British military airfield and crashed into a ditch as Mr. Panetta’s plane was landing.

headline: Why I Am Leaving Goldman Sachs
text: TODAY is my last day at Goldman Sachs. After almost 12 years at the firm — first as a summer intern while at Stanford, then in New York for 10 years, and now in London — I believe I have worked here long enough to understand the trajectory of its culture, its people and its identity. And I can honestly say that the environment now is as toxic and destructive as I have ever seen it.

headline: India’s Billionaires Hit by Weak Economy
text: The number of Indian billionaires fell substantially in the past year, according to Forbes magazine’s recently released list of the world’s billionaires, while the numbers in emerging market rival Brazil rose dramatically. Increased transparency in Brazil and a slowing economy in India have contributed to this shift.

headline: 22 Children Die in Swiss Bus Crash
text: LOMMEL-KOLONIE, Belgium — In this tidy town on the Belgian-Dutch border, children at the ’t Stekske elementary school would dream from first grade on about the annual ski trip to the Alps, recalled Vicki Emmers, 28, a former pupil.

headline: March 14, 1900 | U.S. Officially Adopts Gold Standard
text: On March 14, 1900, Congress ratified the Gold Standard Act, which officially ended the use of silver as a standard of United Stares currency and established gold as the only standard. The New York Times reported that President William McKinley “used a new gold pen and holder” to sign the bill.

headline: Test Yourself | Math, March 14, 2012
text: Test your math skills with this question created by Pete Diamantis at Math for America from the Sunday Magazine article “Pie Fidelity.”

headline: Wen Calls for Political Reform but Sidesteps Details
text: BEIJING — Prime Minister Wen Jiabao issued a sharper and more urgent call on Wednesday for political change in China, warning that the nation risked a return to the chaos of the Cultural Revolution unless the governing Communist Party overhauled its leadership structure and cleared the way for economic reform.

headline: Homeless People as Internet Hot Spots?
text: WHAT is South By Southwest?

headline: Foxwoods Is Fighting for Its Life
text: Nearly everything about the Foxwoods Resort Casino is improbable, beginning with its scale. It is the largest casino in the Western Hemisphere — a gigantic, labyrinthine wonderland set down in a cedar forest and swamp in an otherwise sleepy corner of southeastern Connecticut. Forty thousand patrons pack into Foxwoods on weekend days. The place has 6,300 slot machines. Ten thousand employees. If you include everything — hotel space, bars and restaurants, theaters and ballrooms, spa, bowling alley — Foxwoods measures about 6.7 million square feet, more than the Pentagon.

headline: A Festival for Talent and Possibility
text: It was a gray day in Moscow as Fred Baldwin and Wendy Watriss ducked out of their hotel to meet their contact, whom they found two blocks away, his face nearly hidden in his raincoat. They hopped into a car and drove off, finally arriving at a small village just outside the suburbs.

headline: Iran’s President Unfazed in Parliamentary Grilling
text: Lawmakers in Iran subjected the president, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, to an unprecedented interrogation on Wednesday, questioning his economic policies, cabinet appointments and tense relationship with the supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, in a publicly broadcast parliamentary session that seemed intended to humiliate the president in the final few years of his tenure.

headline: How Do You Feel About Zoos?
text: When and where have you visited zoos in your life? How did those visits affect you? For many New Yorkers, the closing of the Bronx Zoo’s 111-year-old monkey house is the end of an era. Do you think, in general, that zoos are essential for educating humans about animals, or do you think they’re too cruel to the animals to be worth what they might bring to humans? Why?

headline: Women Give Rolling Stones Tribute What It Needs
text: Apologies to Adam Levine and the rest of Maroon 5, but the people most likely to have moves like Jagger, these days, are women. At least, that was the case on Tuesday night, at the benefit produced by the City Winery owner Michael Dorf at Carnegie Hall, where dozens of musicians took part in a tribute to the Rolling Stones. Performing all 21 tracks from the band’s classic collected-hits album, “Hot Rocks 1964-1971,” on the 40th anniversary of its release, it was the ladies who had Mick Jagger’s cocky strut and sex appeal, not to mention the outré outfits.

headline: Long View: The Origin of the Budget Briefcase
text: The elaborate ceremony of India’s Budget Day, in which the finance minister formally presents the country’s budget to Parliament, is in itself a giant colonial holdover, harking back to a similar budget speech that has been delivered by Britain’s Chancellor of the Exchequer for many decades.

headline: Syria Opposition Group Is Routed and Divided
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The main Syrian exile opposition group suffered a serious fracture on Wednesday as several prominent members resigned, calling the group autocratic, dominated by the Muslim Brotherhood and powerless to help Syrian rebels as government forces, having flushed insurgent strongholds in the north, swept into the rebellious southern city of Dara’a.

headline: More College Students May Be Asked to Declare Sexual Orientation
text: 3:08 p.m. | Updated  Officials of the University of California system have proposed asking incoming freshmen to identify their sexual orientation, a move that might cement such declarations as an emerging topic in the college admissions process.

headline: An App for Watching for Personal Data Breaches
text: Want to know if your identity has been stolen? Or if your or your child’s Social Security number is being pawned off on the Internet?

headline: How Is the Payroll Tax Cut Doing?
text: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago.

headline: Peyton Manning Is Said to Have a Final Four
text: After being dumped by the only N.F.L. team he has ever played for, Peyton Manning is being recruited as if he were a high school hot shot all over again. He’s probably flattered by the attention.  But he has never been one for drama, and he would surely like to get this over with. (The teams have their reasons for wanting it over, too.)

headline: Driving Ram’s Natural Gas Pickup Truck
text: INDIANAPOLIS — Chrysler’s Ram division claims to have built the first factory-direct pickup to run on gasoline and compressed natural gas, an alternative fuel that Fred Diaz, Ram’s president and chief executive, described as “a near-term, viable option for lessening this country’s dependence on crude oil.”

headline: Fantasy Focus: The Silent Auction
text: Through shrewd drafting, clever planning and superb trading, you won your keeper league last year. Congrats! Hope you enjoyed the spoils, money and adulation of your peers. But now that your keeper deadline is approaching, there may be one other residual from your victory. In many leagues, especially keeper leagues, draft picks are tradable. In fact, chances are you may have parted with some picks last season to ascend that peak. But now you have a surplus of players to keep, and it’s incumbent on you to maximize your value in trading them off. But it’s easier said than done – the other owners know that you have a surplus, and naturally value their picks, especially if they traded off some of their talent last season to compete better in the future. One method that worked well for me this year is the Silent Auction.

headline: Bombers Strike Twice in Southern Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Two deadly explosions struck in southern Afghanistan on Wednesday, claiming at least nine lives in the second day of violence since an American soldier went on a rampage and killed 16 civilians.

headline: Test Driving a Pilot Teacher Evaluation System
text: The big debate in education now is how to determine who’s an effective teacher. New York City set off a controversy by ranking teachers based on their students’ performance on state exams.  But city officials acknowledge test scores alone are no way to judge teacher quality. With that in mind, WNYC’s Beth Fertig visits a school that is trying out a system educators believe can be much more accurate.

headline: Poll Finds Most City Voters Support Release of Teacher Ratings
text: A majority of New York City voters approve of the public release of ratings for thousands of public school teachers, even though a plurality of voters believe that the ratings are flawed, a new poll has found.

headline: In Poll, New Yorkers Give High Grades to Letter Grades
text: Now those ABC’s have earned an A themselves.

headline: Congolese Warlord Convicted, in First for International Court
text: PARIS — Thomas Lubanga, a rebel leader from the Democratic Republic of Congo, was found guilty on Wednesday of recruiting and enlisting boys and girls under the age of 15 and using them in war, in the first ruling by the International Criminal Court since it began its work 10 years ago.

headline: Can ‘The Killing’ Make a Comeback?
text: In an ideal world — or, at least, in Veena Sud’s ideal world — we would be talking about her history as a Hemingway-loving women’s-studies major at Columbia, or the time she took a master class with Spike Lee at N.Y.U. film school, or her years as a gloomy loner growing up in Cincinnati, reading “Helter Skelter” and wearing a Jennifer Beals perm — anything, basically, other than the ending of the first season of the show she created for AMC, “The Killing,” and why so many people hated it so much.

headline: For ‘B Corps,’ a New Corporate Structure and a Triple Bottom Line
text: A native of Australia, Prue Barrett, 36, started Agrodolce for Fast Foodies, her first company, six months ago in Brooklyn. Her goal? Package and sell slow-cooked provisions – stocks for meat and fish, chutneys, caramelized onions – that can be mixed with fresh ingredients to build fast but wholesome meals.

headline: Daily Report: The End of the Line for Encyclopaedia Britannica
text: After 244 years, the Encyclopaedia Britannica is going out of print, Julie Bosman reports in Wednesday’s New York Times.

headline: A Reminder That Science Can Override Pressure
text: The recent death of F. Sherwood Rowland, who, working in 1974 with Mario Molina, discovered that the ozone layer was endangered by a lucrative class of chemicals, is a reminder of the perennial determination of industries to undermine scientific findings that could cost them money or markets.

headline: Post-Traumatic Filmmaking in Japan
text: IT has long been assumed that filmmakers should tread carefully in the wake of tragedy. Whether confronting war or genocide, a terrorist attack or a natural disaster, the importance of bearing witness bumps up against the danger of trivialization and exploitation. In the annals of catastrophe cinema Japan’s triple disaster has proved to be an unusually accelerated case. Within months of the powerful earthquake and tsunami of March 11, 2011, which killed thousands and caused the reactor meltdowns at the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant, there were already enough movies on the subject to constitute an all-but-instant subgenre.

headline: Side Show
text: In bike-mad cities like Amsterdam and Copenhagen, cargo bicycles — the station wagons of the bike lane — are staples. Usually equipped with storage cabs in the front or back of the frame, cargo bikes are used to haul groceries, yard-sale finds, even small children. Now they’re showing up stateside in cities like Portland, Ore., where this hybrid of sorts, called the Fremont, is produced. Conceived by the design firm Ziba and Signal Cycles, the bike features a small side trailer that holds an expandable, Filson-like canvas satchel. Go to ziba.com/thefremont.

headline: Day Made: Clint Eastwood’s Wife Gets a Reality Series

But it wasn’t until now that he could count himself in the rarefied company of Bruce Jenner and Kelsey Grammer as the husband of a reality-television star.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Santorum Wins and Pops Off at Fox News, and Horse Troubles at ‘Luck’
text: Rick Santorum’s victories in two Southern primaries on Tuesday raised the prospect of the Republican presidential primary becoming a two-man race between Mr. Santorum and the front-runner Mitt Romney. For that to happen, however, Newt Gingrich (who finished second in the primaries, in Mississippi and Alabama) would have to drop out of the race. On Tuesday night, Jeff Zeleny reported, Mr. Gingrich showed no signs of thinking that way: “The elite media’s efforts to convince the nation that Mitt Romney is inevitable just collapsed. If you’re the front-runner and you keep coming in third, you’re not much of a front-runner.”

headline: Beijing Expands Safeguards for Criminal Suspects
text: BEIJING — China’s national legislature enacted new safeguards for criminal suspects and defendants on Wednesday, but upheld the right of the police to hold certain suspects in secret residential locations for up to six months, ignoring a last-minute online campaign by critics to curb police authority.

headline: Another Tibetan Monk Sets Himself on Fire to Protest Chinese Rule
text: A Tibetan monk in his 30s, Jamyang Palden, set fire to himself on Wednesday in the town of Rongwo in the Chinese province of Qinghai to protest rule by China, according to Free Tibet, an advocacy group based in London.
