headline: What Shall We Call This Frog?
text: As The Times reports this morning, there’s a new frog in town, or at least a newly identified one: a variety of leopard frog first spotted on Staten Island in 2009 that has now been declared its own species, based in part on its unique one-cluck mating call.

headline: Peter Whitfield Talks About the History of Travel Literature
text: Peter Whitfield’s “Travel: A Literary History” covers a broad genre of writing that includes work by missionaries, empire builders, thrill seekers and satirists. The book ranges from the travel stories of the Bible and the ancient Greeks to 20th-century wanderers like Patrick Leigh Fermor and Bruce Chatwin. In a recent email exchange, Mr. Whitfield discussed his expansive definition travel writing, Christianity’s influence on the genre and the best travel books of the 20th century. Below are excerpts of the conversation.

headline: Climate Change Envoy to Lead Influential Institute
text: The World Resources Institute, a respected and highly data-driven environmental research organization, has named a new president: Andrew D. Steer, a British-born economist and human development expert who has spent the bulk of his career at the World Bank.

headline: Leading Off: First Four Gives Madness a Whirl
text: The thing about madness is, it’s rather tricky to pin down. It doesn’t like to be stereotyped. You know, always living up to that heart-stopping last-second shot at the end of a great game can be a lot of pressure. So, sometimes it throws a little variety into March instead. Like, oh, two gigantic comebacks at the end of scattershot games that people have a hard time remembering is the new N.C.A.A. first round. Oh, and maybe pulling the rug out from under the No. 1 seed’s star center by getting him ruled ineligible. Yeah, that kind of stuff.

headline: Zynga Plans to Sell $400 Million of Shares
text: Zynga said on Wednesday that it planned to sell additional shares, three months after the social game giant went public, to let some investors trim their holdings.

headline: At White House, Obama and Cameron Genial and Joking
text: Citing the common heritage and shared aspirations of their two nations, President Obama and David Cameron, the British prime minister, met at the White House on Wednesday morning, with an day-long agenda scheduled to include Afghanistan, unrest in the Middle East and the global economy.

headline: Lessons in Peace
text: Learning about the importance of peace can be tricky when your definition of war is your little brother clobbering you over the head with a toy truck. This month brings two very different picture books, both built around very different — you could say nearly opposite — ancient traditions: yoga and the hunt; but both bring an age-appropriate message about cultivating peace and harmony.

headline: Lured by Visions of Real Estate Profits, Nonprofit Group Stumbled
text: PATERSON, N.J. — At the height of the housing boom, a luxury development arose here that was carved out of a 19th-century brick-and-brownstone factory building, with 14-foot ceilings, oversize windows and granite countertops.

headline: How to Avoid That Cramped Seat
text: THERE you are, stuck in the middle seat again. This time you ended up in the row that doesn’t recline. The guy in front of you has leaned his seat all the way back, pushing the top of your laptop down just far enough to make it impossible to watch a video. You turn to the onboard menu, hoping a snack might ease your suffering. But by the time the flight attendants reach your seat, everything but the trail mix has been sold out. Sound familiar?

headline: F. Sherwood Rowland, Who Opposed Freon in Cars, Is Dead at 84
text: F. Sherwood Rowland, who won the Nobel Prize in Chemistry for connecting the abundance of chlorofluorocarbons, or CFCs, in the atmosphere to an expanding hole in the earth’s ozone layer, died Saturday at the age of 84. His work led in 1987 to the Montreal Protocol, an international treaty that called on industry to cease using ozone-depleting chemicals, a move that ultimately forced the automotive industry to redesign air-conditioning systems in vehicles.

headline: Report Maps U.S. Risks from Rising Seas in Warming World
text: Justin Gillis of The Times has summarized new research pointing to rising odds of costly coastal flooding coming from greenhouse heating of the planet. The nonprofit group Climate Central, which pursues a novel mix of original research and climate communication, is behind the new work, which is being published in the journal Environmental Research Letters. The group has produced a batch of maps and other resources building on the work.

headline: No Dribbling and No Passing, but Free Throws Are Nonstop
text: CENTRALIA, Kan. — With the start of the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament this week,  the country is once again contemplating the art of the free throw — mainly, why so many of the uncontested 15-foot, 1-point shots are missed.

headline: Q&A With Portland Timbers Owner Merritt Paulson
text: The Portland Timbers began their second season in Major League Soccer with a resounding 3-1 win against visiting Philadelphia Monday night before another full house at Jeld-Wen Field in Oregon. The Timbers have quickly evolved into one of the signature club operations in M.L.S. and burst into popular culture with a spot on the hipster satire TV show “Portlandia.” The video clip is above. There is a lot more to the Timbers than a shout-out on TV — the producers contacted the club and worked with the supporters group, Timbers Army in a natural fit for the club. Episode 8 of the show’s second season included cameos by the “Laverne & Shirley star” Penny Marshall and the Trail Blazer player LaMarcus Aldridge, and featured members of the rabid Timbers Army.

headline: Company in CityTime Payroll Scandal to Pay $500 Million
text: Updated 11:44 a.m. | The main contractor that ran the scandal-ridden CityTime automated payroll project for New York City will pay over $500 million to resolve a federal criminal investigation into its conduct, the federal authorities announced on Wednesday.

headline: Bancroft Prize for History Goes to Three Scholars
text: The Bancroft Prize, one of the most prestigious annual honors for historians, has been awarded to three scholars for books published last year.

headline: Cocktail Conference to Mix Whiskey With ‘Macbeth’
text: The quality of the drinking at the site-specific Off-Broadway show “Sleep No More” is going to climb steeply at the May 14 performance. There has always been a bar at the fictitious McKittrick Hotel, where this free-form, wordless, immersive deconstruction of “Macbeth” takes place. But you can’t take your drink with you as you follow the performers over the six-floor playing space.

headline: Live Blog: Obama and Cameron News Conference
text: President Obama and David Cameron, the British prime minister, appeared at a news conference at the White House Wednesday afternoon and we live-blogged the event. The heads of government discussed at length their not dissimilar approach to the war in Afghanistan, where both face disillusionment over the mission. Other issues raised were the ongoing economic sanctions on Iran and the conflict in Syria.

text: At comic book stores Wednesday is “X-Men: Season One,” the second in a series of graphic novels that chronicle the beginnings of Marvel’s biggest heroes. The first wave includes the Fantastic Four, Daredevil and Spider-Man.

headline: Romney Camp Shrugs Off Losses, Saying Lead Is Solid
text: Having fizzled once again in the South, Mitt Romney’s presidential campaign is increasingly arguing that outcomes are not the only things that matter. Their premise: Mr. Romney can — and will — win even while losing.

headline: Don’t Rile the Spy Who Came Out of the Flower Shop
text: The idea of the spy next door, trying to trade in stolen documents and silenced Walther PPKs for P.T.A. meetings and home repair, has been explored in films like “Mr. and Mrs. Smith” and the “Spy Kids” movies and in the recent NBC series “Undercovers.”

headline: On Our Radar: Leveling the Plowing Field
text: As developing countries struggle with weather extremes like drought that devastate crops, female farmers are not being factored into decision-making and strategizing, according to international agriculture experts. Women make up 43 percent of the agricultural labor force in those countries, they say, yet they struggle with restrictions on their ability to buy, sell or inherit land, open a savings account, borrow money or sell their crops at market. By failing to consider this, some Western aid efforts may miss the mark or even contribute to gender equalities, they add. [EurekaAlert]

headline: The Future: No Lattes, No Movies
text: Thanks to the Elder Index, I now know that if I were a single adult over age 65 in good but not excellent health, renting a one-bedroom apartment in Essex County, N.J. — where I actually do live, and where in a few years I will most likely be that reasonably healthy old person — I would have to pay $28,200 a year to meet my basic needs.

headline: The Jabra Supreme With a Boom Is a Bust
text: I had high hopes for the Jabra Supreme Bluetooth headset ($100). I like headsets with a boom (that protruding arm some headsets have) because it gets the microphone close to your mouth, usually meaning better sound quality on the receiving end and less yelling on the sending end.

headline: 6 Tips for Better Portraits
text: Why do people look so blank, so vacant, so unnatural in portraits? Peter Hurley, a leading head-shot artist for actors, celebrities and executives, said people look like badly embalmed cadavers because they try to pose, but lack the skill to look natural doing it. Even professional models, experts at a certain haughty look, seldom know how to look natural. “I have to deprogram them into something that is more real,” said Mr. Hurley.

headline: Video: Willem Dafoe, the Great Outdoors and ‘The Hunter’
text: AUSTIN, Tex. —The actor Willem Dafoe is no stranger to nature. When he was a child, he enjoyed fishing trips in Canada. But those brushes with the outdoors didn’t prepare him for the landscape of Tasmania.

headline: Afghanistan News Roundup: Panetta Visit and Bombings
text: 4:54 p.m. | Updated  Our colleague Elizabeth Bumiller reports that Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta is unhurt and safe in Kabul after his trip there got off to an unscripted start. A stolen truck sped onto a runway ramp at the British military airfield as his plane was landing. Pentagon officials said the Afghan driver emerged from the vehicle in flames. There is no further report on the man’s identity or condition.

headline: The President and His General
text: In the pantheon of Confederate commanders, the team of Robert E. Lee and his brilliant subordinate, Thomas J. “Stonewall” Jackson stands at the fore. The two had developed a mutual admiration while serving together in the Mexican War. Later, during the Civil War, Jackson’s lighting-fast brigades and audacious battlefield style provided Lee with an invaluable tool against often much larger Union forces.

headline: Rush His Shot? Absolutely!
text: Bob Fisher, 54, set 14 Guinness world records for free-throw shooting in the past 26 months, including making 33 in 30 seconds, earning him a spot in the loose fraternity of shooting showmen.

headline: Former Intern at ‘Charlie Rose’ Sues, Alleging Wage Law Violations

headline: After Massacre, Aerial Recording Caught U.S. Soldier’s Return
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — The American soldier accused of killing 16 Afghan civilians, mostly children and women, was recorded on surveillance video returning to his military outpost in southern Afghanistan after the attack, according to an Afghan government official who saw the video. The video appears to back up American officials’ insistence that there was only one gunman.

headline: A Groupon Alternative Aims to Offer Small Businesses a Better Deal
text: Constant Contact has been one of the big success stories when it comes to online companies that specialize in serving small businesses. Some half a million of them count on the company’s Web-based help in building, managing and creating marketing campaigns around customer e-mail lists.

headline: Memories of the Foul Line
text: Wednesday’s article about the fastest free-throw shooter in the, well, most anywhere, brought back fond memories of lonely, desperate moments at the foul line for people in the sports department. (O.K., mostly the memories were bitter, but nevertheless.)

text: David Cameron, the British prime minister, visits the White House | The International Criminal Court issues its first verdict | Rick Santorum wins in Alabama and Mississippi.

headline: Is SaveLocal a Better Deal Than Groupon?
text: Groupon, LivingSocial and other daily deal Web sites have by most accounts been a mixed blessing for small businesses. Yes, those half-off coupons hold out to small businesses the promise of unprecedented online reach to potential new customers. But that opportunity comes at the cost of having to offer bargain-basement discounts, with no guarantee that the bargain-seekers will ever return and pay full price.

headline: Santorum Wins the ‘Very Conservative’ Vote, Again
text: Rick Santorum certainly earned his victories last night in Alabama and Mississippi. The base of the Republican Party, particularly as it is represented in these primaries, is far to the right politically, angry and driven by an intolerant brand of evangelical Christianity.

headline: ‘We Live in Interesting Times’
text: David Brooks: I know you and Rick Santorum are not exactly ideological soul mates, but you’ve got to admit there’s something impressive going on here. Everybody counts the guy out and what happens? He works hard and just keeps winning.

headline: Rangers’ Sather Takes Time to Talk About Avery and Crosby
text: BOCA RATON, Fla. — Rangers General Manager Glen Sather usually blows past reporters on his way out of N.H.L. meetings without any comment to reporters beyond “not now boys, I’ve got a plane to catch.”

headline: After Knicks Win in a Rout, Expressions of Gratitude to D’Antoni
text: Despite obliterating the Portland Trail Blazers, 121-79, on Wednesday in Mike Woodson’s debut as interim coach, many Knicks players sounded mournful in the locker room when discussing the resignation of Mike D’Antoni. Jeremy Lin’s eyes were tinged with sadness.

headline: Voters Like Teachers’ Public Ratings and Restaurant Grading, Polls Find
text: Poll results released today find New York City voters broadly supporting two of the city’s rather controversial public-grading measures: effectiveness ratings for teachers and sanitary ratings for restaurants. In the poll on teacher ratings, SchoolBook reports, 58 percent of voters approved of the release of teacher data reports, even though a purality of voters found them flawed. On restaurant ratings, which are widely criticized by restaurateurs as misleading, support was overwhelming, Diner’s Journal reports, with 82 percent of voters supporting the issuing of letter grades.

headline: Welcome to the Goldman Firestorm
text: It would be hard to imagine a tougher start for Goldman Sachs‘s new public relations chief, Richard Siewert Jr.

headline: How Minnesota Got to the Final Five
text: Throughout the college hockey season, Slap Shot will feature reports about some of the country’s top-ranked teams.

headline: Points of View | Matt Ducklo and Matthew Monteith at Hermès
text: At a glance, the photographs on view in “Matt Ducklo & Matthew Monteith: Mind’s Eye,” which opens on Friday at the Gallery at Hermès, appear to be relatively straightforward shots of people looking at art. But for both photographers, there is an element of blind faith at work here. For the past six years, Ducklo has documented visually impaired visitors interacting with sculptures on touch tours of museums like MoMA and the Met. Monteith spent the better part of a year at the American Academy in Rome where he captured tourists looking at the city’s many monumental attractions, seeking the precise moment when the artwork infiltrates the viewers’ imagination and the act of looking becomes an act of seeing. “You don’t know how they are experiencing the work, but you know how it looks like they are experiencing it,” says Ducklo regarding the slippery nature of perception. At the very least, says Cory Jacobs, who curated the show, “the photos make you slow down and take notice of how quickly we tend to pass things by.”

headline: At Disney Channels’ Upfronts, Excited Shrieks and Hot Dogs and Pizza

headline: Amid the SXSW Avalanche, a Chance to Discover
text: Everybody wants in on South By Southwest Music, the annual convention and showcase that runs through Sunday in Austin. The vast majority of the more than 1,200 acts performing on, it seems, every level surface in Austin — clubs, outdoor stages, warehouses, ballrooms, garages, backyards, a bridge — are still hopefuls, trying to reach beyond a local following or a do-it-yourself Web presence. Official SXSW showcases are surrounded by unofficial ones with yet more performers. (Hail The Austin Chronicle and sched.org, which have — bless them — collated both official and peripheral events. ) Amid this avalanche of music, there’s still some chance to get discovered or discover something by serendipity.

headline: Senate Passes 2-Year Transportation Bill

Since 1985, the Arts for Transit program of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority has commissioned permanent works by both well-known and lesser-known artists for the subway and also the commuter rail system. But finding these works, in a system that can sometimes feel like a lab-mouse maze designed by a sadistic scientist, has never been easy.

headline: Interpreters, the Hidden Heroes of the Afghan War
text: In March 2010, a United States Army platoon was on patrol in Paktika Province in eastern Afghanistan when it encountered a large improvised explosive device, or I.E.D. The platoon had spent the day near Mullayan, a hostile area where several Afghan soldiers had recently been killed. As evening approached, one of the platoon members suddenly called for a halt. He had noticed some black rubber on the road. It was a buried I.E.D. Typically, if a bomb is located, United States forces must wait for an explosive-ordnance disposal team to disarm the device. But the sun was setting and the platoon would most likely be attacked at night. Faced with this predicament, the man who had found the I.E.D. calmly pulled out his knife, dug out the device and dismantled it. Thanks to him, every member of the platoon returned safely.

headline: Remember That Study Saying Abortion Makes You Crazy?
text: In 2009, the Journal of Psychiatric Research published a study that claimed to find a link between abortion and long-term mental illness. Right-wing groups seized on it as justification for a series of nasty laws requiring women to be counseled that having an abortion could, using the technical terminology, drive them bonkers.

headline: Two Documentaries on Bullying Take Different Approaches
text: I was bullied. From the third-grade boys who twisted my name up until I hated the sound of it, to the sixth-grade girls who wrote the mean notes about my glasses and braces and left them, quite purposely, for me to find, every time we moved when I was young, I found myself marooned in a new school where I felt neither safe nor happy. If I’m honest, I’d still prefer not to talk about it. What kind of kid was I, after all, that so many other children saw me as a target? How uncool can I possibly have been that I took it all so very seriously, when I should have just brushed away what was obviously unimportant?

headline: A Barefoot Rebellion Storms Lincoln Center
text: The Paul Taylor Dance Company season that opened at the David H. Koch Theater on Tuesday night is historic. Bringing this great troupe to Lincoln Center for its first season there, it shows how richly this company’s dancing projects into the heights and depths of the multitier house: a marvel. If you’re used to watching dance in the Koch Theater, then you can’t help feeling that the three dimensions of its stage space come alive in unfamiliar ways; the very air onstage seems to have a new texture.

headline: After 5 Books, a Measure of Peace
text: LONDON — It would be foolish to overthink the similarities between Edward St. Aubyn and Patrick Melrose, the protagonist of his celebrated series of five wrenchingly sad, laceratingly witty novels. Certainly there are parallels — both come from aristocratic privilege, both had horrific childhoods and horrific heroin addictions, both speak in hyperfluent prose — but they go only so far.

headline: The Musical Colors of the City of Light
text: Many things drew young American composers to Paris after World War I. The city was a cultural hotbed that took all modern music, from radical to eclectic styles, seriously. For those grappling with what it meant to be an American composer, living in Paris and gaining some perspective actually helped. Also, as Virgil Thomson put it, if you were going to be a starving artist, you might as well starve in a city where the food was good.

headline: A Harlem House That Can Baby-Sit
text: EXPANDING the footprint of their houses and apartments is a luxury few New Yorkers have. So it is not surprising that when Nicole Betancourt and Bray Poor, an artistic couple with two young children, decided they wanted a courtyard in their Harlem brownstone, they created one inside the house: By removing parts of the floor and ceiling, they carved out an interior opening that permits light, sound and smells to travel up and down three floors, keeping the family connected.

headline: A Pianist’s Escalating Insurgency

headline: Is It Safe to Play Yet?

headline: The Architect Harry Gesner, Still Riding That Wave
text: Harry Gesner’s life story is so exciting that a new monograph on his work reads like a John Buchan tale, or the next Laura Hillenbrand project, instead of the usual jargon-infested coffee-table book about a venerable architect. As “Houses of the Sundown Sea,” by Lisa Germany and out next month from Abrams, recounts, the movie-star-handsome Mr. Gesner surfs and water-skis like a pro; he survived Normandy, though he nearly lost both legs; he audited architecture classes at Yale, turning down a chance to study with Frank Lloyd Wright, who admired his drawings; he tussled with leading men, like Marlon Brando and Errol Flynn, and fell in love with leading ladies, like a young June Lockhart; he raided tombs in Ecuador; and, for a while, he was a single father to his first child and only daughter, whom he lost custody of when she turned 5 and her mother decided she’d like her back.

headline: Puzzle Solved, and a Lamp Is Born
text: The N1R table lamp by David Nosanchuk, a New York designer, started as an experiment in two-dimensional shapes. “I was interested in using lines and drawings to generate a series of horizontal and vertical plates that would come together and create this 3D puzzle,” Mr. Nosanchuk said.

headline: Drawing on Inspiration
text: WHEN I was 12 going on 20, and mashing stacks of black jelly bracelets up my arms, painting my fingernails a frosty blue and wearing my hot-pink-and-black tiger print tank top five out of seven days of the week, I fell in love. Hard. With John Taylor, the bass player for the band Duran Duran.

headline: Red-Carpet Treatment for Turkish Rugs
text: Stepevi, a Turkish rug company known for its rich, textural designs, will open its first North American outpost next week in SoHo. The company was started about seven years ago (although the family behind it has been in the business since the early 1900s) and currently has showrooms in London, Paris, Milan and Istanbul. SoHo was the natural next step, said Aysegul Yurekli Sengor, the managing director and wife of the founder, Cem Sengor.

headline: Shopping for Medicine Cabinets
text: Outfitting the bathroom with a cabinet that shows off what’s inside.

headline: Comments
text: A selection of recent comments from readers of the Home section, drawn from letters and postings at nytimes.com.

headline: Before Applying to U.S. Colleges, Indian Students Should Be Able to Answer ‘Why?’
text: Latha Ramchand, a native of Thiruvanandapuram, Kerala, who was raised in Mumbai, is now the dean of the C.T. Bauer College of Business at the University of Houston. Readers can post comments at the end of this essay.

headline: SXSW Interactive: The Comedown
text: At first, this year’s South by Southwest seemed like a bust. Gray skies, relentless rain, labyrinthine taxi and registration lines and traffic jams put a damper on the start of the show. But a few days in, after the sun came out in a blaze of glory, people pulled off their ponchos and started to mingle. After that, the conference was in full swing — and a couple of games on Foursquare’s foursquare court, dozens of panels, some barbecue and a cameo by a famous rapper later, the whirlwind week ended just as quickly as it began. Here are some of the crucial takeaways from the week.

headline: Lenses to Ease the Strain From Staring at Screens
text: If I moved my computer monitor close enough to see the screen clearly, it was nearly in my lap. If I left the monitor where it should be, I had to lean forward awkwardly. During my annual eye exam, I told my optometrist about my workstation discomfort and the strain it was causing my eyes, neck and back.

headline: Takeover Defense, Goldman Style (Circa 1960s)
text: It has not been a good day for Goldman Sachs, with an employee leaving and saying Goldman no longer is dedicated to its clients’ interests.

headline: Achieving a Runner’s High With a Little Data Help
text: Data analysis has infiltrated even amateur sports, largely because of the mobile phone’s ability to track performances on a moment-by-moment basis.

headline: Gastrointestinal Infection Deaths More Than Doubled
text: Deaths from gastrointestinal infections more than doubled in the United States from 1997 to 2007, to more than 17,000 a year from 7,000 a year, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention announced Wednesday. The infections cause vomiting and diarrhea. Of those who died, 83 percent were over 65. Two-thirds of the deaths were caused by a bacterium, Clostridium difficile, which people often contract in hospitals and nursing homes, and which has become virulent and resistant to treatment. The second leading cause was the highly contagious norovirus, which has been a scourge on cruise ships and in prisons, dormitories and hospitals.

headline: The Firestorm Over Goldman Sachs
text: To the Editor:

headline: For Futures Industry, MF Global as Topic A
text: Boca Raton, Fla. — It was the $1.6 billion gorilla in the conference room.

headline: Sensitivity Training for Eight-Legged Exhibits
text: IN a workroom on the fifth floor of the American Museum of Natural History in New York, six tarantulas are about to undergo sensitivity training.

headline: Exhibition Recalls Slam-Bang World of Pulp Magazines
text: COMIC book characters like Superman and Spider-Man have inspired devoted fans and been celebrated and vilified as they’ve leapt from printed page to live-action films, animated series, musicals and memorabilia. Yet were the pulps, those throwaway dime-store magazines of old, the forebears of such passionately followed multimedia crossovers? The exhibition “Orange Pulp: the Pulp Magazine & Contemporary Culture” makes a strong case.

headline: Titanic the Ship, 100 Years Later, Becomes a Bandwagon
text: MAYBE, if you are a Titanic-themed museum steaming along toward the outsize centennial of the ship’s sinking, size does matter.

headline: Set Aside a Day for Museums? Minnesota Thinks Bigger
text: MAY is typically the month for honoring mothers, the armed forces and the flowering of spring. In Minnesota, May is now Minnesota Museums Month, the country’s first monthlong, statewide celebration of museums. It is the creation of several Twin Cities museum administrators, who expect it to become an annual event.

headline: Trade Sanctions as a Test of U.S.-Russian Relations
text: To the Editor:

headline: Art Museums Giving It the Old College Try
text: EAST LANSING, Mich.

headline: Want to See Cuba? Your Museum Might Take You
text: SOME large American museums, and an increasing number of smaller ones, offer domestic and international trips — with Cuba currently all the rage — that enliven the museums’ images and at the same time help increase membership and raise money.

headline: Come for the Art, Stay for the Shopping
text: DRAWING on her experience as co-owner of the lifestyle store Zona, Franci Sagar has created an environment at the Museum of Arts and Design in which it is tempting to linger.

headline: With Technology, Adding Context to the Costume
text: WHEN Deborah Nadoolman Landis first began work for the coming show “Hollywood Costumes” at the Victoria and Albert Museum in London, she wanted to provide visitors with iPads that would let them observe an outfit, view a relevant movie clip and watch interviews with those involved with the film.

headline: Spreading American Art Beyond Its Borders
text: ELIZABETH GLASSMAN likes to call the Terra Foundation for American Art, which she heads, a “museum without walls,” but it wasn’t supposed to be that way.

headline: Using Tough Love, Crean Is Restoring Hoosiers to Relevance
text: BLOOMINGTON, Ind. — Tradition seemed lost, a new and less-esteemed identity was forming and, yet, Tom Crean said when he became Indiana’s coach in 2008, he expected to win national championships.

headline: For the New Barnes, Everything Old Is Old Again
text: THE Manhattan architects Tod Williams and Billie Tsien are known as modernists. But in much of their latest building — the new Barnes Foundation in Philadelphia — modernism wasn’t an option.

headline: Electronic Health Records
text: To the Editor:

headline: Meet the New Boss, in the Shadow of the Old Boss
text: FOR any museum director, the chance to lead a renowned institution is a career-defining moment — especially when his or her predecessor has run it for two decades or more. For Christoph Heinrich, now the director of the Denver Art Museum, the moment arrived in October 2008, when he was the museum’s curator of modern and contemporary art. He was driving to Aspen with Lewis Sharp, the museum’s longtime director, when Mr. Sharp suddenly asked if he would be interested in the top job.

headline: At Galleries, Cameras Find a Mixed Welcome
text: LAST year, Anne Hawley, the longtime director of the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum, in Boston, was admiring an 18th-century French painting at the Louvre.

headline: From Good to Great, for Curators
text: FOR two immersive weeks in January, 11 curators selected from museums large and small gathered by day at the Center for Curatorial Leadership in New York for classes taught by professors from Columbia Business School in topics from endowment management to moral leadership to organizational alignment — subjects entirely absent from the typical education of a museum curator.

headline: A Gallery for the Public to Curate
text: MUSEUMS are among the last bastions of high-culture authority these days. No matter how many comment cards visitors fill out, it’s unlikely that, say, the Metropolitan Museum of Art is going to initiate an exhibition or move a picture slightly to the left based on feedback from the public.

headline: Birmingham’s Civil Rights Institute Personalizes a Struggle
text: BIRMINGHAM, Ala.

headline: Who Wants to Donate to a Billionaire’s Museum?
text: WHEN Eli Broad, the art collector and philanthropist, decided to build a museum in downtown Los Angeles, he named it The Broad. That pretty much ruled out asking anybody else for money, said Barry Munitz, a governor of the Broad Foundation. The museum, about to break ground on a Diller Scofidio & Renfro building, will have an initial $200 million endowment and has no plans to seek outside funding, according to Joanne Heyler, who will be its director.

headline: Preserving the Past
text: To the Editor:

headline: How an Acquisition Fund Burnishes Reputations
text: IF Alex Nyerges, the director of the Virginia Museum of Fine Arts, has an extra spring in his step lately, it may have something to do with the $70 million gift the museum is receiving from a trust created long ago: $60 million of it was designated for the museum’s endowment for art purchases, pushing that total to more than $156 million.

headline: From Show and Look to Show and Teach
text: THERE have been many strange sightings outside the Whitney Museum of American Art’s Marcel Breuer building over the years: a giant bird’s nest precariously perched on the cantilevered entrance; a neon sign that spelled out “Negro Sunshine”; and a giant replica of a toy fire truck parked at the curb for nearly three months, to name a few. So it is hardly surprising that recent passers-by don’t seem at all curious at the sight of tall black shipping containers rising from the sculpture court.

headline: Obesity and Other Targets of Children’s Museums
text: CHILDREN’S museums do not usually have exhibitions that involve crawling through a giant digestive system.

headline: Teaching Children the Value of Pre-Web Pages
text: SQUEEZING paint from a tube is too tame for the sixth graders in Ida Owens’s art class. They prefer making their own with malachite (a green mineral), spinach and cochineal — or dried insects. “They love cochineal,” said Ms. Owens. “To them it’s working with bugs.”

headline: Hoping That Art Helps With Healing
text: Boston

headline: The Home-Schooled Don’t Just Stay at Home
text: IN June 2010, Lenora Todaro was looking for ways to build on her home-schooled 8-year-old twin boys’ interest in knights, castles and other aspects of medieval history. “I thought of architecture,” recalled Ms. Todaro, who then reached out to the Center for Architecture, a public gallery space in New York.

headline: HBO Ends Production on ‘Luck’
text: HBO said on Wednesday that it is ending further production on its high-profile drama “Luck,” one day after the announcement that a third horse involved in the show had been injured and euthanized.

headline: A Three-Bedroom Apartment in a Historic Macau Neighborhood
text: An apartment in Macau, a peninsula off southeastern China, in the historic Sai Van neighborhood.

headline: House Hunting in ... Macau
text: A THREE-BEDROOM APARTMENT IN A HISTORIC MACAU NEIGHBORHOOD

headline: Public Rebuke of Culture at Goldman Opens Debate
text: Until early Wednesday morning, Greg Smith was a largely anonymous 33-year-old midlevel executive at Goldman Sachs in London.

headline: What to See and Where to See It
text: A sampler of offerings at art museums across the country this spring and summer:

headline: Name It; Clients Are Called It
text: Are you a Muppet or a Clancy? A Bobblehead or a Clampett?

headline: As Syria Deals With Unrest, Olympic Team Keeps Its Focus for a Day
text: AMMAN, Jordan — King Abdullah International stadium was nearly empty. Syria’s soccer team, forced to play its home matches on foreign soil after an uprising against the rule of President Bashar al-Assad, had about 20 supporters in attendance for an Olympic qualifying match against Malaysia on Wednesday.

headline: For Museum of Negro Leagues, a Big Opportunity
text: KAUFFMAN STADIUM, home of the Kansas City Royals, will become the hub of Major League Baseball in July when it hosts the All-Star Game for the first time since 1973, the year it opened. And Bob Kendrick is hoping the attendant swirl of publicity will extend to the Negro Leagues Baseball Museum, about seven miles away at the fabled intersection of 18th and Vine Streets.

headline: Hospitals Aren’t Hotels
text: Pittsburgh

headline: Rescuing the Stories Behind Latino Art
text: Some of art history’s most telling monuments don’t end up under museum spotlights. They’re found, when and if they’re found, in desk drawers and office file cabinets that no one has cracked in years, or in library stacks, or in jumbles of personal papers boxed up in an artist’s studio.

headline: Broad or Dainty, Crocodilian Snouts Pack Same Chomp
text: Through the ages, the basic crocodilian plan for dispatching prey has been simple but effective: chomp down hard and hang on tight.

headline: Mets Off to a Fast Start in the Attrition Competition
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — The Mets may not have won a World Series in more than a quarter of a century, but when it comes to injuries, they have taken the title twice over the past four years and appear ready to contend again.

headline: The Negro Leagues Baseball Museum
text: The Negro Leagues Baseball Museum is hoping to capitalize on crush of out-of-town visitors expected when the All-Star Game comes to Kansas City in July.

headline: In Reactions to Two Incidents, a U.S.-Afghan Disconnect
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — The mullah was astounded and a little angered to be asked why the accidental burning of Korans last month could provoke violence nationwide, while an intentional mass murder that included nine children last Sunday did not.

headline: Defiant Orange Players Say They Can Still Win
text: PITTSBURGH — Syracuse guard Scoop Jardine stayed up to watch the N.C.A.A. tournament games Tuesday night. That meant that he enjoyed two furious comebacks — courtesy of Brigham Young and Western Kentucky — but was also forced to endure some harsh criticism of his own team, courtesy of just about every analyst on television.

headline: Jobs Bill Stalls as Congress Fights Over Agency
text: WASHINGTON — A fight over a small export credit agency is dividing Congress and holding up a popular bipartisan jobs bill.

headline: The Harvard of the South Meets the Vanderbilt of the North
text: ALBUQUERQUE — In academia, Vanderbilt aspires to be Harvard. In basketball, Harvard aspires to be Vanderbilt. But the phrase “Vanderbilt of the North” has yet to catch on in Cambridge, Mass., the way “Harvard of the South” has in Nashville.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,893 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American this week:

headline: A Thank You for Obama’s Donors, Dinner With Clooney and Cameron
text: Rock stars, Hollywood celebrities, and senior White House officials will all be in attendance at Wednesday’s state dinner, where President Obama will fete the British prime minister, David Cameron, on the occasion of Mr. Cameron’s visit to the United States.

headline: Goldman Executive’s Letter Draws Backers, Detractors and Satirists
text: If Greg Smith hoped to generate some buzz around his departure from Goldman Sachs, then he succeeded.

headline: On Eve of Prison, Blagojevich Keeps Talking, but Some Tune Out
text: CHICAGO — Rod R. Blagojevich stepped into his front yard on Wednesday for a last goodbye.

headline: Suspect in Afghan Deaths Flown to Kuwait as Evidence Arises That He Acted Alone
text: WASHINGTON — The American staff sergeant suspected of killing 16 Afghan villagers was flown to Kuwait from Afghanistan on Wednesday, American officials said.

headline: A Path to Opportunity Through the Greens
text: AZUSA, Calif. — Lizette Salas had been working toward the highest stage of women’s professional golf since age 7. The daughter of Mexican immigrants, she used golf to become the first in her family to earn a college degree. She had spent much of last year traveling to tournaments on the L.P.G.A. Futures Tour in a truck with her father, sometimes sleeping in rest areas to save money. So with the last full-status tour card on the line in December’s L.P.G.A. qualifying tournament, Salas put her lifelong survival instincts to work.

headline: Seeking to Preserve the Past, but Stumbling on the Present
text: MOSUL, Iraq — On land where Assyrian kings once reigned, an Iraqi farmer named Araf Khalaf surveyed the scrap of earth that has nurtured three generations of his family. It is little more than a mud hut and a scraggly vegetable patch, yet his land has become a battleground, one pitting efforts to preserve Iraq’s ancient treasures against the nation’s modern-day poor.

headline: Luring Stanley Cup Viewers With a Torrent of Games
text: TURNING the Stanley Cup playoffs into a must-watch television event lasting for weeks in the spring is no easy feat. Many Americans did not grow up with the game, few know who the players are and watching 10 weeks of playoffs is a big time commitment.

headline: Juveniles Don’t Deserve Life Sentences
text: Boston

headline: Contractor Strikes $500 Million Deal in City Payroll Scandal
text: A major government contractor agreed on Wednesday to pay a record $500 million to avoid federal prosecution for its role in the scandal-tarred CityTime project, an effort at modernizing New York’s payroll system. The project was plagued by widespread fraud and weak oversight and became a lingering embarrassment for Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s administration.

headline: Deal Reached for Former Site of St. Vincent’s Hospital
text: A new public school will be created and a historic building in Greenwich Village will be preserved as part of a deal intended to placate opposition to a plan to build luxury housing on the site of the former St. Vincent’s Hospital.

headline: Guest List for State Dinner Includes Big Names and Ordinary People
text: Most people have probably heard of the actor George Clooney by now. But the name Elaine Brye might not ring a bell outside of Winona, Ohio.

headline: Blagojevich Heads to Prison
text: Rod R. Blagojevich, former governor of Illinois, is to begin his 14-year sentence for corruption on Thursday.

headline: New iPad: A Polishing of the Old
text: On Friday, the new iPad goes on sale. Be sure to ask for it by name: the iPad.

headline: The Senate Overachieves
text: Good news, frustrated American citizens! Congress is not a clogged up, hidebound legislative slug after all.

headline: Receiver Is Given a Record Extension
text: Calvin Johnson might be the best receiver in the game, and the Detroit Lions paid him that way Wednesday, giving him an eight-year extension worth up to $132 million, the most for a receiver in history.

headline: V.C.U. Has Been There, Hopes to Do It Again
text: PORTLAND, Ore. – This time last year, Coach Shaka Smart and his Virginia Commonwealth Rams were just happy to be in the N.C.A.A. tournament. That was before V.C.U. won a First Four game, before it went on a tournament run for the ages, before it made the Final Four.

headline: Fortunes Turn, as Does Style, for Santorum
text: SAN JUAN, P.R. — The pickup truck that carried him through Iowa is long gone, replaced by a small motorcade of S.U.V.’s. There was a police escort, and a phalanx of Secret Service agents.

headline: Crosby Is Ready to Face the Rangers
text: Sidney Crosby is widely considered the best hockey player in the world. With Crosby returning to the Pittsburgh Penguins, who have won nine straight games, Thursday night at Madison Square Garden, Rangers General Manager Glen Sather believes the equation is simple.

headline: Despite Losses, Sticking to a Refrain
text: ROSEMONT, Ill. — Newt Gingrich was back on the campaign trail Wednesday, a day after losing two critical Southern primaries, focusing on the next Republican battleground — Illinois — as if his Tuesday’s losses were just a bump in the road.

headline: Divided on the Right
text: Just a few weeks ago, it seemed implausible that the Republican nomination fight would not be resolved by the August convention. But Rick Santorum’s primary victories in Alabama and Mississippi on Tuesday make that a real, if still distant, possibility. If the convention becomes as disorderly as the primaries, it will reflect a party consumed by anger and frustration, led around by its most extreme base, and lacking any sense of forward direction.

headline: Congress Presses Apple on App Privacy
text: Two congressmen sent Apple a followup letter Wednesday asking Timothy Cook, Apple’s chief executive, to provide questions about privacy problems within the company’s iTunes App Store.

headline: In New York, a Pep Talk to Big Donors
text: A day after losing Mississippi and Alabama to Rick Santorum, Mitt Romney took his campaign to a state where he had no public schedule, no time carved out to mingle with voters, and no rallies or town halls.

headline: Worker Who Hid Lottery Win Must Share $38.5 Million Prize
text: There were some dark twists in the plot line, inevitable, perhaps, when friends fight over $38.5 million in lottery winnings.

headline: Ovechkin Is Tested by Trying Season
text: UNIONDALE, N.Y. — Alex Ovechkin did not score the winning goal Tuesday for the Washington Capitals in their 5-4 victory over the Islanders. Matt Hendricks did. But Ovechkin had two goals in regulation and another in the shootout, and he broke into a triumphant gap-toothed smile as he was the first to hug Hendricks at the end of the game.

headline: Big Biters
text: Researchers found that the force of a crocodilian’s bite increases with the size of the animal.

headline: Espada and Son Lived Well, but Deny Theft From Nonprofit
text: In opening arguments on Wednesday in the trial of a former state senator and his son, who are accused of embezzling hundreds of thousands of dollars from a nonprofit health care network, there seemed to be little disagreement that the defendants had lived large.

headline: Mr. Sarkozy on the Low Road
text: President Nicolas Sarkozy’s re-election campaign in France is getting a little desperate, and more than a little ugly. Although new polls show him the likely top vote-getter in next month’s first-round voting, they also show him running well behind François Hollande of the Socialist Party in the decisive May runoff. To try and close that gap, Mr. Sarkozy has been fishing for far-right voters by assailing foreign immigrants, foreign imports and even the dietary laws of French Muslims.

headline: Questions as Banks Increase Dividends
text: Emboldened by the Federal Reserve’s passing grades on stress tests of banks, some of the nation’s biggest financial firms are racing to dole out billions of dollars in dividends.

headline: Death on Escalator M.T.A. Had Once Hoped to Replace
text: Officials with the Metropolitan Transportation Authority were trying on Wednesday to determine to what extent an escalator that they had hoped to replace at a Long Island Rail Road station may have caused the death of an 88-year-old woman.

headline: Hope for a Good Transportation Bill
text: Against heavy odds, Congress may yet produce a decent national transportation bill that would make needed investments in roads, bridges and mass transit without undermining environmental protections or providing handouts to big polluters.

headline: Clerical Abusers and the First Amendment
text: Religious institutions have constitutional protections, but they are not above the law. Unfortunately, that has not stopped the Roman Catholic Church and other religious groups from arguing that the First Amendment shields them from civil lawsuits for negligent supervision and retention of employees who sexually abuse children.

headline: Witness Intimidation Cited in British Hacking Scandal
text: LONDON — In what could prove to be one of the most damaging chapters yet in the scandal enveloping Rupert Murdoch’s tabloid newspapers in Britain, Scotland Yard arrested a former chief reporter for The News of the World on Wednesday on suspicion of intimidating a witness, the first time the police have raised the specter of witness tampering in the course of their investigations.

headline: A Drill to Replace Crucial Transformers (Not the Hollywood Kind)
text: The electric grid, which keeps beer cold, houses warm, and city traffic from turning to chaos, depends on about 2,100 high-voltage transformers spread throughout the country.

headline: Faith and Begorra
text: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — Happy almost Saint Patrick’s Day! I had a tough time parsing this theme, for want of an apostrophe. Since there can be no diacritical marks in an American crossword puzzle, it took me a while to get that we were speaking in brogue.

headline: Inspired by Brecht, and Zombies
text: From a show called “The Deepest Play Ever: The Catharsis of Pathos,” you’d expect overstatement, and that’s what you get with Geoffrey Decas O’Donnell’s musical satire, revived at the New Ohio Theater and retooled from a 2006 incarnation. What you don’t get is boredom, given its phantasmagorical riffing on Brecht’s “Mother Courage” (among countless influences cited in the program). Oh, there are more subtitles: “The Post-Post-Apocalyptical Allegory of Mother LaMadre and Her Son Golden Calf or: Zombies Will EAT Your Brain! An Epic Tragidramedy.”

headline: Private Businesses Fight Federal Prisons for Contracts
text: As chief financial officer of a military clothing manufacturer, Steven W. Eisen was accustomed to winning contracts to make garments for the Defense Department.

headline: Viral Video, Vicious Warlord
text: I’d like to thank the makers of the “Kony 2012” video for goading me to write about Joseph Kony. With about 100 million views, it is now one of the most viral videos of all time.

headline: New York Lawmakers Vote to Limit Public Pensions
text: ALBANY — Lawmakers on Thursday morning approved a hard-fought measure to cut the retirement benefits for future public employees in New York City and across the state, dealing a defeat to labor unions at the end of a dramatic all-night session.

headline: Jury in Rutgers Spying Case Asks Judge for Clarification
text: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J. — The jury in the trial of a former Rutgers University student accused of invading his roommate’s privacy by using a webcam to watch him in an intimate encounter began deliberations on Wednesday and asked the judge to define two crucial terms.

headline: With Video, Obama Looks to Expand Campaign’s Reach Through Social Media
text: When presidential candidates have a message they want voters to hear far and wide, they have typically turned to that old campaign standby: the television ad.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: March 14, 2012

headline: Russia May Let NATO Use Airfield as Afghan Hub
text: MOSCOW — The Kremlin expressed willingness on Wednesday to allow NATO to use an airfield in the heart of European Russia, in a city best known as Lenin’s birthplace, as a transit center for moving troops and “nonlethal” cargo into Afghanistan.

headline: Visiting History Where It Happened
text: Some of the most infamous scenes of the Civil Rights era unfolded in the blocks surrounding the Birmingham Civil Rights Institute.

headline: G.M.’s Breathe Easy as Meeting Ends
text: BOCA RATON, Fla. — The N.H.L. general managers meeting that concluded Wednesday had a very different feel from the previous two, when major on-ice injuries led the G.M.’s to recommend rules aimed at reducing an alarming spike in reported concussions.

headline: Women Figure Anew in Senate’s Latest Battle
text: WASHINGTON — With emotions still raw from the fight over President Obama’s contraception mandate, Senate Democrats are beginning a push to renew the Violence Against Women Act, the once broadly bipartisan 1994 legislation that now faces fierce opposition from conservatives.

headline: A Changed Coach Emerges From a Career in Ruins
text: PITTSBURGH — Technically, Southern Mississippi’s Larry Eustachy is not one of the first-time coaches in the N.C.A.A. tournament. Eustachy has actually been to the tournament three times before, including in 2000 when he led Iowa State to a 32-5 record and the Round of 8, and was named the national coach of the year by The Associated Press.

headline: In 1956, a Racial Law Repelled Harvard’s Team
text: It has been a long time since anyone in the nation noticed or cared where the Harvard men’s basketball team was playing. But Thursday, the Crimson will be among the competitors in the N.C.A.A. tournament for the first time in 66 years. Their dream is to get to the Final Four in New Orleans.

headline: Gingrich Casts Himself as the Key to Stop Romney
text: Confronted with intensifying pressure to get out of the presidential race, Newt Gingrich is trying a new argument for continuing his campaign: Conservatives cannot block Mitt Romney’s path to the Republican nomination without him.

headline: ‘Bromance’ Blooming
text: Although Gonzaga Coach Mark Few readily admitted he has no idea what a “bromance” is — “what is the term again?” he asked an inquiring reporter — he did not hesitate to agree that his affection for West Virginia Coach Bob Huggins might be strong enough to qualify for the label.

headline: Changing Universities and His Outlook, Iowa State Forward Excels
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — Iowa State’s Royce White settled into the car seat next to his grandfather for the eight-and-a-half-hour ride and immersed himself in honey buns and Adele. Those may seem to be odd choices for snack and entertainment for a muscled and agile 6-foot-8 forward who grew up in Minneapolis listening to hip-hop.

headline: ‘Ecosanctuary’ Plans for Wild Horses Add Tourism to the Mix
text: CENTENNIAL, Wyo. — This was prime horse country once, in the old Western working way of bridles, bits and sweat. Leather tack from those days still hangs, cracked and preserved in the arid dust, on the wall of the 1906 vintage hay loft at the Wilson place.

headline: Despite Southern Losses, Gingrich Still Has Eyes on Tampa
text: Palatine, Ill. – Flashing camera phones and a standing ovation greeted Newt Gingrich Wednesday night as he walked on stage to address more than 400 area Republicans gathered at a Lincoln Day Dinner in the suburbs of Chicago.

headline: Center Bulks Up; Wichita St. Flexes Muscles
text: PORTLAND, Ore. — The story of how Garrett Stutz helped transform Wichita State into an unlikely N.C.A.A. tournament contender began with a Pop-A-Shot rivalry with an 11-year-old.

headline: Pierre Schoendoerffer, French Filmmaker, Dies at 83
text: Pierre Schoendoerffer, a celebrated French film director and novelist whose experience as a prisoner during the Indochina War fueled his cinematic quests for meaning, and even beauty, in the travails of those who fought, died on Wednesday in a hospital near Paris. He was 83.

headline: Girlfriend of Crime Boss Changes Her Plea to Guilty
text: BOSTON — Catherine Greig, the girlfriend of James (Whitey) Bulger, changed her plea to guilty on Wednesday, softly admitting in court that she fled with Mr. Bulger in 1995 and helped the legendary crime boss hide out, avoiding trial for multiple murders, for 16 years.

headline: After School Tragedy, a Pre-emptive Strike Against Trauma

headline: Tom Murrin, Alien Comic Performance Artist, Dies at 73
text: Tom Murrin, a performance artist whose frenetic shows fashioned kooky narratives out of found objects and homemade masks and made him a longtime favorite in the downtown avant-garde arts scene in New York, died on Monday in Manhattan. He was 73.

headline: Announcing My Win-a-Trip Winner!
text: Congratulations to Jordan Schermerhorn of Rice University, the winner of my 2012 win-a-trip contest! We had a terrific field of contestants, and the Center for Global Development in Washington sifted them down to the finalists. In the end, I went with Jordan in part because I admired her writing and thought she would bring an unusual skill set and passion to the trip. She’s an engineer who wants to work in global health, and yet she has never been abroad, and she had very strong recommendations from her professors.

Madoff was engaged in illegal activity. The Mets are being sued by the trustee for Madoff’s victims for more than $300 million.

text: Noble Fleming, who for nearly 50 years sipped and sniffed from teaspoons and fine china cups to ensure the quality of tea for millions of Americans, died on Feb. 24 at a nursing home in Saint-Vaast-la-Hougue, France. He was 92.

text: For the first time, the federal government will directly attack the nation’s tobacco addiction with a series of advertisements highlighting the grisly toll of smoking, a campaign that federal health officials hope will renew the stalled decline in the share of Americans who smoke.

headline: Russia: 2 Arrested After Band’s Protest at Cathedral to Remain Jailed
text: A Moscow court ruled on Wednesday that two women accused of participating in a “punk prayer service” against Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin by a rock band made up of masked feminist activists in front of the altar of Christ the Savior Cathedral last month must remain in pretrial detention until April 24. The women, Maria Alyokhina and Nadezhda Tolokonnikova, were arrested on March 3, on the eve of Russia’s presidential elections, which Mr. Putin won after a wave of protests appeared to threaten his rule. They face up to seven years in prison. A video of the performance circulated on YouTube. Mr. Putin’s spokesman has said that he found the performance offensive. Russian Orthodox Church leaders have said that the band’s actions were blasphemous and that the women should be prosecuted, although not necessarily imprisoned. Yet some church activists have said that the case is politically motivated and have called for their immediate release. The women’s lawyers said there was no proof that they participated in the performance.

headline: Late-Night Comedians Riff on Goldman Op-Ed
text: Leave it to Stephen Colbert to rename Greg Smith, the Goldman Sachs investment banker who very publicly resigned on Wednesday and explained why in a New York Times Op-Ed column. He is “Banker-dict Arnold,” the Comedy Central satirist declared on his show Wednesday night, riffing on Benedict Arnold, the Revolutionary War traitor.

headline: Six Monks vs. One Warship
text: HONG KONG — Asia has seen varying displays of hard power and soft power in recent days, as the region struggles to come to grips with some frozen and seemingly intractable conflicts.

headline: Another Furor Over Planned Appearance by Rushdie

headline: Gambia: Ruling Party Faces Scarce Opposition for Parliament
text: Campaigning for Gambia’s March 29 parliamentary elections began on Wednesday, with President Yahya Jammeh’s party facing no opposition for more than half of the seats. Mr. Jammeh’s Alliance for Patriotic Re-Orientation and Construction will field candidates for all 48 seats, according to statement from the Independent Electoral Commission that was handed to reporters in Banjul, the capital. A group of opposition parties has pledged not to take part in the election, which they expect to be rigged. Mr. Jammeh has ruled the West African nation for 17 years.

headline: Tibet: Another Monk Sets Himself Afire
text: A Tibetan monk set fire to himself on Wednesday in the town of Rongwo in the Chinese province of Qinghai to protest rule by Beijing, according to Free Tibet, an advocacy group in London. The monk, Jamyang Palden, who set himself on fire in a square in front of the Rongwo Monastery, is believed to have survived. He was said to be in his 30s. The authorities took him to a hospital, but monks brought him back to the monastery for fear that he would be arrested, Free Tibet said. At least 27 Tibetans have set themselves ablaze in the last year, and at least 18 have died. About 500 monks gathered in the square after the self-immolation on Wednesday, and some held up pictures of the Dalai Lama, the exiled spiritual leader of the Tibetans, Free Tibet said. The International Campaign for Tibet, another advocacy group, said its sources had confirmed the self-immolation, which took place about 9 a.m. Rongwo is in the county of Rebkong, called Tongren in Chinese, an area on the border of Tibetan and ethnic Han lands.

headline: Struggling Kingfisher Announces Cutbacks
text: The Indian airline Kingfisher said Wednesday that “it would scale back overseas flights to cut costs and attract funding from skeptical investors, while the country’s aviation regulator accused it of reneging on a recovery plan and British Airways said it had suspended a code-sharing pact with the airline,” Reuters reports.

headline: Panetta Says He Was Not the Target of an Attack
text: ABU DHABI, United Arab Emirates — Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta said Thursday that he did not believe that the Afghan who crashed a stolen pickup truck near his plane, and then emerged from the truck in flames, was trying to attack him. But the Afghan was an interpreter working for coalition forces at the complex where Mr. Panetta was landing, raising the possibility that he knew someone of importance was arriving.

headline: March 15, 1965 | President Johnson Calls for Passage of Voting Rights Act
text: On March 15, 1965, addressing a joint session of Congress, President Lyndon B. Johnson called for new legislation to guarantee every American’s right to vote. “Open your polling places to all your people,” he declared. “Allow men and women to register and vote whatever the color of their skin. Extend the rights of citizenship to every citizen of this land.”Johnson made the speech in response to events in and around Selma, Ala., where civil rights leaders were organizing a voting rights campaign. Eight days earlier, state authorities violently suppressed a march by black demonstrators in an incident known as Bloody Sunday. Two voting rights demonstrators, a young black man and a white minister, were killed by white men in separate episodes around Selma.

headline: Fantasy Focus: Projecting Playing Time
text: A colleague of mine, Todd Zola, once said something to this effect: “If I could know in advance the rate stats (average/on-base percentage/slugging) for the entire player pool, or the number of games each would play, I’d rather know the playing time.” I took that to mean three things: (1) Playing time is often harder to predict than performance; (2) Opportunity often trumps skill; and (3) Performance often begets playing time, so you could infer that a less established player was both playing well and staying healthy if you knew he had 550 at-bats.

headline: Sports Tales Cast India as the Villain

Here is a list of projections made in in the 2011 budget and how they have measured up over the year.

The city had come to a near-standstill for what the government billed as a “Global March for Syria” — a celebration, went the official narrative, of steadfastness in the face of a foreign-inspired conspiracy that had fueled a year of senseless violence.

headline: Going Back to High School, Undercover With Badges and Baggage
text: Is popular culture like a river, flowing relentlessly forward so that no one ever steps in the same waters twice? Or is it like a coral reef — or, less organically, a landfill — formed out of the continuous accretion of new matter? If two wildly dissimilar objects have the same name, does it make any sense to compare them? If so, how? Please forgive the philosophical tenor of these questions: I’ve just seen “21 Jump Street,” and it has left me in a ruminative mood.

headline: Whisper of the Wild
text: Setting off in the predawn gloaming of central Alaska, we were the sounds of swishing snow pants, crunching boots and cold puffs of breath. As sunrise gradually lightened the late November sky, we took visible shape: a single-file parade on a narrow white trail traveling west, deeper into Denali National Park and Preserve. It was three degrees and so still that when we pulled up to rest, I heard no wind, no sibilant leaves, just a barely perceptible ringing in my ears. Tundra swans, kestrels and warblers had all flown south. Grizzlies were asleep in their dens. We tramped over frozen streams and paused to discover water still trickling faintly in hollows below. To the north, a morning blast of pink and orange brightened snow-shrouded Mount Healy at the edge of the Alaska Range; to the south — where the sun is always rising or setting during winter at a latitude just three degrees shy of the Arctic Circle — an alpine ridge remained covered in shadow and alder.

headline: The Liu Wen Express
text: Slipping into a pair of blue Marc Jacobs pants in the back of a rented van in Yongzhou, China, the model Liu Wen was feeling an unusual degree of jitters. Changing clothes on the go is standard practice for models shooting on location, and she liked the look: “It’s tomboy style,” she said. “I feel it’s my style.” And under most circumstances — long travel, bad weather, unexpected wardrobe glitches — China’s first bona fide supermodel has a reputation in the industry for being gracious and professional. But as the van pulled up to her old middle school, she peered worriedly out the curtained windows at a waiting crowd: hundreds of frantic teenagers in white uniform jackets, spitting images of her recent former self. “It’s getting crazy here,” she said. The students were chanting, “Liu Wen, Liu Wen” and were armed with cellphone cameras and notepads for autographs, eager for the return of their school’s most famous alum. “I’m not that big a celebrity,” she said. “I’m just an ordinary person.”

headline: Bleeding the Patient
text: Brad DeLong and Larry Summers have a paper in progress about fiscal policy in a liquidity trap; some of the analytics here. The bottom line, fleshed out with a lot of evidence, is one that others — including me and Christy Romer — have been arguing for a while: expansionary fiscal policy under these conditions doesn’t just aid the economy in the short run, it may well even improve the long-run fiscal prospect. And austerity may be self-defeating even in fiscal terms.

headline: Virginity Tests, a Trial for Egypt
text: CAIRO — On Sunday, an Egyptian military tribunal acquitted an army doctor of performing so-called virginity tests on seven female protesters last spring. This is not merely a setback for women’s rights in this patriarchal country. It’s also a troubling precedent for government accountability, one year after the revolution that toppled President Hosni Mubarak.

headline: Theater Talkback: The Trade-Offs From Page to Stage

Though they walk side by side through my life, occupying more waking hours than any other activities, the lines between them seldom blur. Reading is private, even in a subway car; theater is a collective experience, in which you’re always on the same page (literally if not figuratively) with a lot of other people.

headline: 36 Hours: Long Beach, Calif.
text: AT the mouth of the Los Angeles River, shipping cranes flex across the skyline — an industrial panorama that suits Long Beach’s gritty reputation. But while the city’s maritime character remains, its rough edges have been smoothed in recent years — the downtown waterfront transformed by redevelopment, the busy port now welcoming both cargo vessels and cruise ships. Along with its sandy shore, a compact downtown of low-rising Art Deco towers, and unassuming neighborhoods where Craftsman bungalows are ringed by tropical gardens, Long Beach has excellent museums, ethnic enclaves and a tangle of Southern California subcultures. Layered, urban and unexpected, it is a city apart from the sprawl and strip malls that define the outer edges of Los Angeles.

headline: 36 Hours: Long Beach, Calif.
text: Explore Long Beach’s museums, restaurants, jazz clubs and vintage boutiques.

headline: Unions Urge Curtailment of ‘Super PACs’
text: ORLANDO, Fla. — Leaders of the nation’s labor unions — which some experts say benefited from the Supreme Court’s Citizens United ruling in 2010 — said on Wednesday that the ruling needed to be overturned for the good of American democracy,

headline: Getting Doctors to Think About Costs
text: My first formal lesson on health care costs occurred one afternoon on the wards when I was a medical student. The senior doctor in charge, a silver-haired specialist known for his thoughtful approach to patient care, had assembled several students and doctors-in-training to discuss a theoretical patient with belly pain. After describing the patient’s history and physical exam, he asked what tests we might order.

headline: Baby’s First Bling
text: Last week we pierced our 6-month-old daughter’s ears. I know what you’re thinking: what kind of parents are you?

headline: Why Cisco Paid $5 Billion for NDS
text: On Thursday, Cisco Systems announced its intention to pay about $5 billion, including assumption of debt, for the  NDS Group, a British software company that serves the cable television industry. Underlining its intentions, Cisco also published a blog post about the acquisition.

headline: Coca-Cola and L’Oréal Offer Ambitious Goals for 2020
text: Two giant advertisers with ambitious goals to grow even larger offered their peers a glimpse of their strategies at a marketing meeting in New York.

headline: The Usual High Expectations Mingle With Uncertainty
text: KNOXVILLE, Tenn. — Pat Summitt plays games and puzzles on her iPad to help her remain alert. Her sense of humor remains acute, along with her ambition to win a ninth national championship. But anyone who has been around her can sense inevitable changes seven months after Summitt revealed that she had symptoms of early onset Alzheimer’s disease.

headline: Tortorella Won’t Discuss Crosby, Penguins; Lundqvist Still Out
text: John Tortorella is nothing if not consistent. As any follower of the Rangers would expect, Tortorella declined Thursday morning to share his feelings on the return of Sidney Crosby or the importance of tonight’s game against the Penguins at Madison Square Garden.

headline: What’s Really Happened to Rail Fares in the Last Nine Years
text: The annual presentation of the Railway Budget in Parliament is a staid affair usually featuring the minister in charge reeling off a list of new lines to be built or stations to be refurbished. For the last nine years, no minister has dared to announce an increase in ticket prices, though they have often raised the cost of transporting freight.

headline: Wall Street’s Latest Campus Recruiting Crisis
text: Wall Street, once a magnet for America’s best and brightest, is facing a recruiting problem.

headline: Dimon Urges High Road in Goldman Controversy
text: For JPMorgan Chase, now might be a good time to poach a few Goldman Sachs clients.

headline: Ruling Gives Edge to U.S. in Its Appeal of Citi Case
text: 6:15 p.m. | Updated with additional details

headline: Video Shows Large Protest by Tibetan Monks in China
text: A day after the self-immolation of a Tibetan monk and reports of large protests in response, the advocacy group Free Tibet posted new video and photographs offering a rare glimpse of monks inside the highly restricted and restive part of western China.

headline: Discovering a New Photo, Perhaps, of Ellis Island’s Annie
text: Updated, 2:02 p.m. | Annie Moore seems to resurface every St. Patrick’s Day, the poster child of immigration to America. Arriving in New York with her two younger brothers in 1892, the “little rosy-cheeked Irish girl” was the first foreigner greeted at the nation’s new immigration station on Ellis Island.

headline: Reyes to Play Against Mets, Short-Haired and Happy
text: JUPITER, Fla – Jose Reyes is set to be in the lineup Thursday when his new team, the Miami Marlins, meets his old team, the Mets. Reyes had not attended any of the three previous spring training games between the teams.
