text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: At Obama Rallies, Fainting Spells Resurge
text: 3:44 p.m. | Updated For President Obama, the fainting spells are back.

headline: Rolling Stones Say No Tour This Year. Maybe 2013
text: The Rolling Stones will not tour to celebrate their 50th anniversary, Mick Jagger and Keith Richards told Rolling Stone magazine in an item published on Wednesday. Mr. Richards, who is 68, said 2013 was a more realistic goal for the aging rockers.

headline: Interactive Feature: A Chorus of Criticism for Goldman
text: Since the financial crisis, Goldman Sachs has faced a wave of criticism from politicians, regulators, protesters and writers. Now, a Goldman executive who resigned publicly on Wednesday is joining the chorus of detractors.

headline: Business Day Live: Reaction Inside Goldman
text: Susanne Craig on the reaction inside Goldman Sachs to a public rebuke; why marriage is for rich people; and Evelyn M. Rusli discusses why brokers who trade private shares have run afoul of regulators.

headline: College, Farther and Farther Out of Reach
text: Last week I wrote about how state cuts to public colleges meant shifting more of the burden of educating students onto the federal government. As state subsidies fall, tuition rises, and needy students look to federal subsidies like Pell Grants and Stafford loans to make up the difference.

headline: TimesCast | March 15, 2012
text: The Taliban suspend peace talks with the United States | President Obama's campaign will release a 17-minute video.

headline: Courting Puerto Rico, Santorum Does Damage Control
text: SAN JUAN, P.R. — Rick Santorum spent part of Thursday trying to calm a firestorm of criticism he created here Wednesday when he said that if Puerto Rico became a state, it must make English its primary language. His remarks prompted one delegate who had been pledged to him to quit.

headline: Quandary Considered: Pregnant, With a Job Interview
text: S. is two months pregnant with her second child, and six months into a period of freelancing that’s left her and her husband juggling to make ends meet. This week — today, in fact — she has a job interview for a steady, at-home, part-time job at a small company.

headline: In New Space, Pearl Theater Will Feature a New McNally Play
text: The Tony Award-winning writer Terrence McNally (“Master Class,” “Ragtime”) will have a world-premiere production of his new play, “And Away We Go,” Off Broadway next year. The play travels through time to show the similarities among chaotic theater companies in ancient Greece, Elizabethan London, Versailles and 20th-century America.

headline: The View from Syracuse: Now, It’s Up to the Seniors
text: Syracuse’s seniors are the sparks for the Orange. When the team fell to Cincinnati in the Big East tournament semifinals. Scoop Jardine and Kris Joseph turned the ball over a combined nine times.

headline: Oklahoma State’s Parks Chases Elusive Wrestling Title
text: Throughout the college wrestling season, The Quad will follow some of the country’s top-ranked teams.

headline: A Meter So Expensive, It Creates Parking Spots
text: SAN FRANCISCO — The maddening quest for street parking is not just a tribulation for drivers, but a trial for cities. As much as a third of the traffic in some areas has been attributed to drivers circling as they hunt for spaces. The wearying tradition takes a toll in lost time, polluted air and, when drivers despair, double-parked cars that clog traffic even more.

headline: Obama Defends Energy Policy, Hitting Back at Presidential Candidates
text: LARGO, Md. – In what has become a weekly ritual, President Obama on Thursday defended his administration’s energy policy, in the face of relentlessly rising gasoline prices, to an American public that believes he can do more to ease the pain at the pump.

headline: Hammer Museum to Poll Public for a New $100,000 Art Prize
text: A former MTV executive who helped found the E! television network has announced a gift to the Hammer Museum in Los Angeles to begin a new $100,000 artist award that has overtones of reality television, The Los Angeles Times reported.

headline: Omnivore’s Delight
text: The first thing you are meant to see when you arrive in Tongeren, which bills itself as the oldest town in Belgium, is a statue of Ambiorix, the leader of the Eburones, the hometown tribe that defeated the Romans circa 55 B.C. But for some reason I miss this landmark in favor of a humongous branch of H&M dominating the village square.

headline: Louisville Becomes Center of Basketball World for Kentucky Schools
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — The KFC Yum! Center seats 22,400, which is a good-sized arena for a second-round game of the N.C.A.A. men’s tournament, and they needed every one of the seats for the Thursday-Saturday games.

headline: Live Updates: N.C.A.A. Men’s Tournament, Day 1 of Round 2
text: The first full day of the men’s N.C.A.A. basketball tournament features 16 games. Zach Hillesland will bring you up to speed with live updates. For the latest scores and full schedule of games, view our live scoreboard.

headline: Tough Tasks Ahead for India’s Youngest Chief Minister
text: Akhilesh Singh Yadav, 38, became India’s youngest chief minister on Thursday, after a short swearing-in ceremony in Lucknow as the top boss of Uttar Pradesh. Mr. Yadav is the new hot property in Indian politics, having bested both Rahul Gandhi and Mayawati in the U.P. elections, while managing to repackage his father’s rough-and-tumble Samajwadi Party with a message tapping into the aspirations of India’s youth.

headline: Much Light but Less Sweetness as Maastricht Art Fair Opens
text: MAASTRICHT, the Netherlands–The art dealers wanted fireworks to celebrate the 25th anniversary of the European Fine Art Fair here. But that idea was deemed too dangerous, so instead they settled for an installation of 20,000 cascading white LED lights that shimmers at the fair’s entrance.

headline: A Warning to Britain Over its Economy
text: LONDON — Fitch, the ratings agency, warned Thursday that Britain could lose its top investment grade because its economy might not be flexible enough to absorb economic shocks.

headline: Legislators Agree to Turn Teacher Evaluation System Into Law
text: Legislative leaders agreed Thursday to turn a new teacher evaluation system into law, bringing New York a step closer to ensuring that the state will hold on to $700 million in federal education aid. After two years of battles with the teachers' unions, legislative leaders and Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo had struck a deal to put the system in place -- a condition to receive federal Race to the Top money.

headline: Third Comeback’s a Charm for Brigham Young’s Steed
text: Brigham Young is back in the women’s N.C.A.A. tournament for the first time since 2007 and a lot of credit goes to the drive and leadership of senior point guard Haley Steed. The Cougars are a No. 10 seed in the Des Moines region, set to take on No. 7 DePaul in Rosemont, Ill. on Saturday.

headline: Photo Replay: March 15
text: Photo Replay: March 15

headline: In Toledo, Biden Makes a Working-Class Appeal
text: 9:28 p.m. | Updated  A revised version of this post is available here.

headline: Belarus Bars Critics From Leaving the Country
text: MOSCOW — In a move seemingly taken from a Soviet dictator’s handbook, the government of Belarus has apparently started barring opponents of President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko from leaving the former Soviet republic.

headline: Republican Senators Propose Medicare Changes
text: Four conservative Republican senators kicked off a conversation Thursday on changes to Medicare, releasing a proposal that would end the federal fee-for-service insurance program in 2014 and enroll all recipients into the health insurance plan now offered to federal employees.

headline: Companies Pledge Not to Help Pakistan Filter the Web
text: Rivals at birth, India and Pakistan are now both struggling to manage the irrepressible Internet.

headline: Silence Doesn’t Fly Here
text: On a five-hour flight, I was seated next to an extremely obese man. We couldn’t pull down the armrest between us because he was so big, and he took up 25 percent of my seat, too. I spent the entire flight with his body pressed into me. I knew I couldn’t relocate because the gate agent announced that our flight was oversold. But shouldn’t flight attendants be responsible for noticing and remedying these situations? I didn’t want to embarrass the guy, but I was very unhappy.Anna, Seattle

headline: Death’s Companion: Paperwork
text: Heidi Foreman’s father died in November. Ronald Foreman, a retired sporting goods manufacturer, had been struggling with poor health for several years, and he had been in a suburban Philadelphia hospital for treatment of chronic lung disease. But Mr. Foreman was determined to check himself out so that he could celebrate Thanksgiving with his family, and he did. He died at home at 85, his wife and children with him, a few days later.

headline: Exposing the Body, Baring the Soul
text: Francesca Woodman, the photographer who took her own life at 22 in 1981, is as close to a true saint as the putatively secular world of contemporary art can claim. The dreamy, formally playful and disarmingly erotic pictures Woodman made — mostly of herself partly unclothed or naked — project a self surrendering unreservedly to the spirit of art. When viewing the approximately 120 pieces in “Francesca Woodman,” a survey of her career at the Guggenheim Museum, it is hard to shake off the admittedly absurd notion that she was too purely an artist for this muddy world.

headline: Fawning by German Media Results in Bunny’s Death
text: First there was Knut the polar bear. Then there was Yvonne the cow.

headline: Your Favorite Moments From 1968 New York
text: If you know the city, it’s hard not to be fascinated with the peek into the past offered in “Surface Tension,” a minimalist 1968 film by Hollis Frampton that contains a zippy stop-motion trip that carries the viewer from the Brooklyn Bridge to the middle of Central Park in the space of 160 seconds. Since the Criterion Collection posted the clip on Facebook last week, we at City Room have been replaying it somewhat obsessively, and so have some of you.

headline: A Computer Case for Casual Friday
text: Maybe you don’t feel the need to armor your tablet or laptop with mucho macho materials but don’t want to leave it completely unprotected, either. There are plenty of laid back kinds of covers, but few so dressed down as the V Neck Sleeve from Computer Apparel.

headline: Bad Loans at State-Run Banks Add to India’s Woes
text: MUMBAI, India — When people talk about Europe’s “government debt problem” they mean something easy to describe: countries that borrowed more money than they can easily pay back. In India, it’s a bit more complicated.

headline: Moving Through Grief, Chair by Chair
text: A MISCONCEPTION among some people is that I wrote the novel “Kramer vs. Kramer” based on my own divorce and custody battle. “How is she doing with his son?” a woman once asked a friend of ours about my wife. Our friend answered, “They have two sons and they’re both hers.”

headline: Mark Webber: 2012 Formula One Cars Look ‘Ugly’
text: As followers of his Twitter account know, Mark Webber, the No. 2 driver for Red Bull in the Formula One series, is reliable for refreshingly candid assessments of his sport and its drivers. At a press conference held Thursday, three days before the Australian Grand Prix, Webber, an Australian, lobbed a characteristically blunt morsel toward motorsport journalists.

headline: Syria’s First Couple and the Banality of E-Mail
text: Updated | 5:43 p.m. As Syrians mark the first anniversary of the uprising against President Bashar al-Assad on Thursday — with government-orchestrated rallies of support broadcast live on state television and furtive messages promising continued defiance posted on YouTube — exiles trying to make sense of the conflict from afar have been eagerly reading a cache of e-mails, said to be the private correspondence of the regime’s first couple, provided to The Guardian by opposition activists.

headline: Crosby: ‘I Don’t Expect to Get Hit More Than I Did Prior’
text: Comeback No. 2 of the 2011-12 season for Sidney Crosby began Thursday at Madison Square Garden.

headline: Artist Bharti Kher Explores the Idea of Home
text: “The Hot Winds That Blow From the West” is a new solo show from Indian artist Bharti Kher which includes sculpture, painting and installations that examine the idea of home in an unexpected way that has become her signature.

headline: Samurai Shopper | The Empire Strikes Back
text: The Samurai Shopper is enjoying herself immensely with some gal pals at The Dorchester Hotel, where 13 variations on gin and tonic are offered at the bar, 10 on the menu, three not. The Dorch, as I like to call it, is a grand hotel with history and scandal buried beneath its chandeliers; it’s elegant but not mummified in upper crust. Eisenhower plotted his D-Day strategy here during World War II, as Commander of the Armed Forces. Less momentously, the Samurai Shopper plots her shopping sorties.

headline: Chancellor Says Some School Employees Were Not Properly Disciplined
text: Eight school employees with records of behaving inappropriately around students did not receive the proper punishment in the past, and should now be fired, according to a review released Thursday by Dennis M. Walcott, New York City’s schools chancellor.

headline: Grand, Old and Anti-Woman
text: Senator Lisa Murkowski of Alaska got it half right on Tuesday when she told her Republican colleagues that their party was at risk of being painted as anti-woman. It would be more accurate to remove the hedges and say flat out that the G.O.P. is anti-woman.

headline: Is the ‘Household Chemical Purge’ the New Baby-Proofing?
text: Have you purged your home of bisphenol A (known as BPA) yet? How about polyvinyl chloride (PVC)? In a world with books with titles like “Slow Death by Rubber Duck: The Secret Danger of Everyday Things” and documentaries like “My Toxic Baby,” it’s hard not to mock the urge to eliminate chemicals from our children’s environments, and equally hard not to see that we need to at least examine the chemicals in our children’s environments.

headline: Keeping Good Businesses From Going to Waste
text: In a previous post I brought up the topic of how failed business transfers can have a negative impact on local economies. I was surprised to see that it ignited several comments containing the term “creative destruction” — the concept that external forces like competition, globalization or technological advances force businesses to either adapt or fall by the wayside. Kodak would be a recent example. But the point I was trying to make about the failure of some small businesses to sell, or otherwise thrive after the owner decides to leave, is not about creative destruction. It’s about something much simpler: waste.

headline: United Technologies Prepares $3 Billion in Asset Sales
text: United Technologies said on Thursday that it planned to sell about $3 billion worth of assets to help pay for the company’s $16.5 billion takeover of the Goodrich Corporation.

headline: TimesCast | Taliban Suspend Peace Talks
text: March 15, 2012 - The Taliban suspend peace talks as Afghan President Hamid Karzai demands the United States accelerate its withdrawal from Afghanistan.

headline: Zeroing In on Lead in Hunters’ Bullets
text: Citing risks to birds and to human health, roughly 100 environmental groups formally asked the federal Environmental Protection Agency this week to ban or at least impose limits on lead in the manufacturing of bullets and shotgun pellets for hunting or recreation.

headline: Murray State Rallies Behind Smothering Defense
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — There was nothing spectacular about the way Murray State dominated Colorado State in the second half Thursday. The Racers did not make a pile of 3-pointers or necessarily run an efficient offense. What they did was smother the Rams with a ferocious man-to-man defense that ran Colorado State right out of the N.C.A.A. tournament.

headline: Ethiopia Hits at Bases Run by Militants in Eritrea
text: MOGADISHU, Somalia — Ethiopian forces have stormed into Eritrea, the Ethiopian government announced on Thursday, attacking several militant bases and stirring new tensions between the two archrivals.

headline: Cost of Long-Term Care Insurance Keeps Rising
text: There just hasn’t been a lot of good news about long-term care insurance lately. Private insurers have been dropping the product, and the Obama administration announced last fall that it was scrapping plans for a federally sponsored option.

headline: Wedding Q&A
text: Not Inviting the Kids, Politely

headline: The Odds Ever in Your Favor: Ideas and Resources for Teaching ‘The Hunger Games’
text: Updated | May 16, 2012

headline: Kansas State Squelches Southern Miss Comeback Story
text: PITTSBURGH — It was different this time, Southern Mississippi Coach Larry Eustachy said. Nine years after his embarrassing ouster at Iowa State led to treatment for alcoholism, Eustachy returned to the N.C.A.A. tournament Thursday and, though his stay was short-lived, the experience came with greater meaning.

headline: Art Critics’ Association Announces Awards for Best Shows of 2011
text: On Thursday, the American chapter of the International Association of Art Critics announced the winner of its annual AICA Awards honoring artists, curators and institutions for excellence in art exhibitions in 2011. The 24 winners, selected by the 400 critics and other art experts who make up the association’s membership, include an installation by Sarah Sze on the High Line (Best Project in a Public Space); the exhibition “Bye Bye Kitty!!!” at the Japan Society (Best Show in a Non-Profit Gallery or Space); the Metropolitan Museum of Art’s “Alexander McQueen: Savage Beauty” (Best Architecture or Design Show); and the Paula Cooper Gallery’s presentation of Christian Marclay’s “The Clock” (Best Show in a Commercial Gallery in New York). Awards will be presented at a ceremony at the Asia Society in New York on April 2.

headline: A Few Questions (and Answers) About the New iPad
text: The great thing about the Internet age is that you can publish whenever you like. My Thursday column, for example, hits newsprint on Thursday, but generally gets posted online the night before.

headline: N.C. State Pays Little Attention to Presidential Pick
text: COLUMBUS, Ohio — President Obama did not really take too many chances when made his N.C.A.A. tournament predictions. His Final Four included popular high seeds like Kentucky and North Carolina, as well as Ohio State and Missouri.

headline: New Lawyers for Woman Charged as High-End Madam
text: A court hearing for a woman accused of running a high-class brothel in Manhattan was upstaged Thursday by a rotating cast of defense lawyers, as two dueling lawyers were unexpectedly relieved by two others.

headline: Early 2013 Trial Planned for Defendants in CityTime Case
text: A day after a major government contractor agreed to pay $500 million to avoid prosecution for its role in the CityTime scandal, six of the eight remaining criminal defendants were told on Thursday to prepare for a trial in early 2013.

headline: TimesCast | Obama Campaign's Documentary
text: March 15, 2012 - Tonight the Obama campaign will release a 17-minute documentary "The Road We've Traveled," narrated by Tom Hanks.

headline: Henson Still Questionable for Tar Heels’ Tourney Opener
text: GREENSBORO, N.C. – North Carolina forward John Henson was not ruled out of Friday’s Midwest Regional second-round game against Vermont at Greensboro Coliseum, but neither Henson nor Coach Roy Williams sounded confident he would play with an injured wrist that is still swollen more than a week after he fell hard on it during the Atlantic Coast Conference tournament.

headline: Greece Urged by European Official to Do More
text: ATHENS — Greece has made progress in raising much needed revenue, impressively overshooting its tax collection targets, but more needs to be done to ensure that money gets to the country’s languishing economy, the head of the European Commission’s task force on Greece said Thursday.

headline: Them Apples | Paul Smith Celebrates 25 Years on Fifth Avenue
text: Sir Paul Smith, a k a the Prince of Prints, celebrated the 25th anniversary of his first stateside store in New York City last night with an especially colorful bash. The crowd, filled with fops wearing striped frocks and loud colors — the fabled downtown performer Joey Arias and the former Bananarama-er Siobhan Fahey were among the revelers — cheered loudly as Smith blew out his Fifth Avenue flagship’s birthday candles. Indeed, there was much to celebrate. The Flatiron location, once a wild frontier for retail, has been a neighborhood hub — a hot spot for expat Englishmen and local actors and musicians who’d hang out in the store’s suit room — since it opened in 1987. I worked there around that time (as an esteemed stock boy); the stacks of printed corduroy shirts, oversize paisleys and natty Prince of Wales suits were a far cry from the collegiate-preppy of my past, and I became hooked. Paul, as he was called pre-knighthood, visited the store often and was known for his pranks and silly sense of humor. True, his eccentric Englishness showed in the clothes via colored linings and purple pinstripes, brightly embroidered button holes and all kinds of prints: floral, animal, fruit and vegetables. Feeling comfortable with Smith’s impeccable fit and traditional tailoring, men continue to be emboldened to try his daring shirt and tie combinations, a hallmark of the Paul Smith look.

headline: Learning From the Spurned and Tipsy Fruit Fly
text: They were young males on the make, and they struck out not once, not twice, but a dozen times with a group of attractive females hovering nearby. So they did what so many men do after being repeatedly rejected: they got drunk, using alcohol as a balm for unfulfilled desire.

headline: The Weakness of the Churches
text: David French and Joseph Knippenberg have both written thoughtful responses to my post piggybacking on Yuval Levin’s point about the failure of America’s churches to address the ills of working class life. French is in enthusiastic agreement with our take, writing that “during my years in the pews, I’ve witnessed a moral collapse — and a corresponding collapse in positive influence over the real lives not just of our fellow congregants but also of our fellow citizens in need.” Knippenberg, though, is more skeptical. He writes:

headline: Louisville Survives First Game, for a Change
text: PORTLAND, Ore. — If a long flight on a charted jet can be considered a “five-hour ordeal,” as Coach Rick Pitino referred to Louisville’s travel schedule this week, then at least it led to a longer stay for the Cardinals in the N.C.A.A. tournament.

headline: Clocks Change, and Ratings Fall
text: In an odd twist, the time change due to daylight saving time apparently continued to depress television ratings among the networks for the fourth night in a row on Wednesday. Overall viewership in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic was down by 9 percent compared to last week and almost every show experienced a drop in ratings of some kind.

headline: Mario Williams to the Bills? Fans Worry, Then Rejoice
text: March is normally a very quiet month for Bills fans. We can turn our attention to the N.H.L. and March Madness safe in the knowledge that our team isn’t going to make a splash in the free-agent market. But that all changed Thursday as the Bills, yes, the Ralph Wilson-owned Buffalo Bills, who haven’t made the playoffs since the Clinton administration, signed Mario Williams, a standout defensive end who is widely considered the best defensive player on the free-agent market this season.

headline: Yanks Abroad: Middlesbrough’s Hines Could Be Another ‘Find’
text: As Middlesbrough continues to make a push for promotion to the England’s Premier League in the closing months of the season, it has received a boost from the strong play of central defender Seb Hines.

headline: At State Dinner, No Shortage of Opinions From Koch
text: The Obama administration is not done hearing from former Mayor Edward I. Koch.

headline: A Treasure Awaits for Vintage Pinup Collectors
text: Bunny Yeager built a racy career on a talent for snapping photographs of shapely young women stripped to their lacies. Ms. Yeager’s 1950s and ’60s boudoir shots, especially those of Bettie Page, the era’s most popular pinup, are influencing fashion photography to this day. As are, increasingly, a slew of pictures of Ms. Yeager vamping provocatively for her own lens.

headline: The View From Loyola: It Was a Long Road Back
text: Throughout the N.C.A.A. tournament, The Quad will feature posts from reporters at newspapers on campuses of teams that have the potential to be the Cinderellas of 2012.

headline: Subway Tap Dancer Gets Help With College
text: Joshua Johnson, the Harlem native who tap dances in the New York subway to help pay his way at Penn State, was profiled on City Room by Kristofer Ríos on March 4. Many commenters wanted to help, beyond tipping him on the Q line (here’s how), and one offered room and board in State College, Pa.

headline: Behind the Seams | The Film Project at Selfridges
text: To celebrate the opening of its Women’s Designer Galleries, Selfridges, the London department store, enlisted the talents of Emma Reeves to curate a series of fashion films. Each film had to feature a strong female protagonist — but not necessarily the designer’s clothing. Ann Demeulemeester worked with the actor Michael Pitt, who filmed his girlfriend, the model Jamie Borchert in a desert landscape. Rick Owens created an homage to his wife, partner and muse, Michelle Lamy, with the director Ruth Hogben. The Japanese brand Comme des Garçons’ contribution, “Silence, Genius at Work” (shown here), is an intimate encounter with the pianist Madeleine Malraux by Katerina Jebb, who has worked with the brand in the past on fragrance projects. “These things just propose themselves,” says Jebb of her current subject. Jebb’s aim was to make an abstract study of Malraux that did not follow any particular narrative path, or as she puts it, “an observation of nonspecific ambition,” who might as well be speaking about the designer Rei Kawakubo, who shows her nonspecific ambition on her sleeve every season. Says Jebb: “Perhaps the connection between Madeleine and Comme des Garçons is self-possession.”

headline: Pander Is As Pander Does
text: You have to love a good pander if you’re going to cover politics, or vote, or go on Twitter, or venture outside your house in an election year in places like Iowa or New Hampshire or Florida – or any state with an identifiable voting bloc.

headline: Maryland Is Latest State to Consider Smoking Ban in Cars Transporting Children
text: On Wednesday, the Maryland Senate passed a bill (PDF) that would prohibit smoking in vehicles when transporting a child under 8 years old, a move to protect children from secondhand smoke. If the bill is approved by the House and eventually enacted into law, Maryland would join a number of other states to ban smoking in vehicles when children were inside.

headline: Gold Star Families All, Regardless of Where a Soldier Fell
text: My son, Chief Warrant Officer 4 Gary Marc Farwell, flew Black Hawk helicopters through four combat deployments to Iraq and Afghanistan. Then on February 3, 2010, he and two other soldiers died when their helicopter crashed near Mannheim, Germany. After an extensive investigation, the Army could not determine the cause of the crash.

headline: Springsteen’s Message for the Hopefuls at SXSW: Just Go for It
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — There may be no better symbol for the fragmentation of pop music than the South by Southwest festival here, where more than 1,000 bands representing dozens or even hundreds of genres come to grab a sliver of blog attention or a Twitter hashtag. If everything works out as planned, a band can look forward to a deal for a TV commercial or one with a liquor company that’s looking for a new face. There are no stars, and the consensus is that there may never be again.

headline: Amanda Knox’s Ex-Boyfriend Signs Book Deal
text: One month after Amanda Knox snagged a $4 million book deal, her former boyfriend has picked up one of his own.

headline: Competing Rallies as Hungary Faces a Halt to Aid
text: BUDAPEST — The government and the opposition held rival rallies in downtown Budapest on Thursday, using the anniversary of the 1848 uprising against Hapsburg rule to stake out their positions in the politically fractured Hungary of today.

headline: Global Network Expels as Many as 30 of Iran’s Banks in Move to Isolate Its Economy
text: A global communication network vital to the banking industry announced on Thursday that it was expelling as many as 30 Iranian financial institutions — including the Central Bank — crippling their ability to conduct international business and further isolating the country from the world economy.

headline: Unerring From Outside, Wisconsin Routs Montana
text: ALBUQUERQUE — Even when things went wrong for Wisconsin, they turned out right.

headline: Hope for Bergtraum’s Comeback Is Far Away, in Students’ Homes
text: A teacher and union leader at Murry Bergtraum High School says breaking down community schools and replacing them with small boutique schools has left Bergtraum with too many students who are there by default. "The results were a changed academic and social demographic," he writes -- and the school's consequential designation by a tabloid as "Worst High School in NY." But he has a proposal to turn things around.

headline: A South by Southwest Letdown
text: Some nights at the South by Southwest Music festival are letdowns: missed connections, lines outside packed clubs that are going to outlast the set, bands whose MP3 at the SXSW site was better than their set. That’s how it went on Wednesday night. I was happy to get an infusion of roiling psychedelia from Royal Baths, to hear the sustained vocal purity of the folky Irish singer Foy Vance, and to see Filastine, who mingled jittery electronica with international percussion, well-coordinated video imagery and a live cellist (but who could use more melodic bits).

headline: Pictures of the Day: Switzerland and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Switzerland, Turkey, Chile and Afghanistan.

headline: The View From South Dakota State: A Tournament Debut and Energized Fans
text: Throughout the N.C.A.A. tournament, The Quad will feature posts from reporters at newspapers on campuses of teams that have the potential to be the Cinderellas of 2012.

headline: NBC News Stays on Top, While Its Newsmagazine Struggles
text: NBC News celebrated its status as the top news division in television with a presentation for advertisers Thursday in New York, led by Brian Williams, the anchor of its top-rated evening newscast.

headline: Duke’s Kelly Available Only for Spot Duty Against Lehigh
text: GREENSBORO, N.C. – Second-seeded Duke isn’t going to have a healthy Ryan Kelly when the Blue Devils face No. 15 Lehigh Friday in an N.C.A.A. tournament South Regional second-round game at Greensboro Coliseum.

headline: Interview: The Dardenne Brothers
text: Jean-Pierre and Luc Dardenne discuss their film “The Kid With a Bike.”

headline: Trailer: 'Napoleon'
text: A preview of the restored version of Abel Gance’s “Napoleon.”

headline: From a Mantelpiece Fern to the Front Page
text: Doug Mills didn’t have to concern himself with a crowd of jostling photographers when he shot the photograph that appeared on Thursday’s front page. He knew he had a good angle.

headline: Answers About Raptors in New York, Part 2
text: Now that Hawk Cam 2012 is up and running, Susan Elbin, New York City Audubon’s director of conservation and science, responded to readers’ questions about hawks and other birds of prey in the city. Her second set of responses appears below.

headline: Finding Spot for Crosby Is ‘Good Problem to Have,’ Penguins Coach Says
text: On Thursday against the Rangers, Penguins Coach Dan Bylsma will have all three of his world-class centers – Sidney Crosby, Evgeni Malkin and Jordan Staal — on the ice for only the 11th game in the last two seasons. That mean some players on this Penguins team that has won nine straight games and 21 of their last 26 will have their playing time reduced.

headline: 19th-Century Fern Fever, in England and Beyond
text: LONDON — Last month the historian Sarah Whittingham nearly tripped over a rope blocking access to a Victorian house museum parlor here. “I’m so drawn to it,” she said, referring to the room’s bay window, an 1870s protruding glass case originally meant for sheltering ferns.

headline: Jenny Holzer: ‘Endgame’
text: Skarstedt Gallery

headline: Sentences Linked to Protests Are Given in Moscow
text: MOSCOW — Two leaders of Moscow’s street protest movement and the husband of another were convicted in three separate judicial hearings on Thursday, increasing fears that something resembling a campaign of reprisals had begun.

text: James Fuentes

text: Greene Naftali

headline: Marquette Ensures B.Y.U.’s Rally Isn’t Enough This Time
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — Marquette was playing outside the rough-and-tumble Big East on Thursday, and for a half, the Golden Eagles looked like a disciplined and relaxed team as they built a double-digit lead over Brigham Young. They should have known B.Y.U. was not going to go easily.

headline: Adel Abdessemed: ‘Who’s Afraid of the Big Bad Wolf’
text: David Zwirner

headline: Gingrich Tangles With Obama on Gas Prices
text: Newt Gingrich used a campaign rally on Thursday afternoon to respond to President Obama’s charge earlier in the day that Republicans were pandering to voters by promising lower gas prices.

headline: Timely | Nyjah Huston, Board Certified
text: Nyjah Huston, 17, makes flying down a stairway railing on a skateboard look easy, as if anyone could flip the board under his feet in midair, then land on it, bones intact. “But you have no idea how much time and pain went into that,” says Huston, who lives in Laguna Beach, Calif., where his dad taught him to skate at age 5. He’s been skating professionally since he was 11 and last year won gold at the X Games in L.A. Home-schooled his whole life, Huston spends a few hours a day at the skate park and travels three months a year to compete in places like Australia, Spain and Costa Rica. Between competitions, he tools around Laguna listening to Wiz Khalifa in his Mercedes CLS 63 AMG (his deals with brands like Element and D.C. Shoes are lucrative) and fuels up on his mom’s vegan tacos. Only last year did he finally lop off the dreadlocks he’d had since childhood. “The back of my head feels lighter now when I skate,” he says.

headline: A Poet’s Collage, Sampling Included
text: Equal parts blues shout, church sermon, interpretive dance, TED talk, lit-crit manifesto and mixtape, the poet Kevin Young’s first nonfiction book, “The Grey Album: On the Blackness of Blackness,” is an ambitious blast of fact and feeling, a nervy piece of performance art.

headline: Composers Are Familiar, but Not the Compositions
text: If the chamber music world had the equivalent of an all-star game, its string quartet division might have fielded an ensemble similar to the one the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center assembled for its Tuesday evening concert at Alice Tully Hall. Six players, each from a different quartet (two of them — the Guarneri and the Vermeer — no longer active), united for a program that sidestepped predictable repertory in favor of rarities.

headline: The Grind House of My Father
text: ¿Por qué está hablando en español Will Ferrell en su nueva película? Well, in the Spanish-language comedy “Casa de Mi Padre” Mr. Ferrell, his hair darkened and his deadpan locked, stands knee-, sometimes bare-buttocked-deep in the corn. (Some call it maíz.) A quick-sketch routine stretched — amusingly, absurdly, thinly — to feature length, “Casa de Mi Padre” (“House of My Father”) stars Mr. Ferrell as Armando Alvarez, the eldest son of a rancher down Mexico, or rather down telenovela, way, where the men are brave, the women beautiful, the villains venal, the passions inflamed, the prose empurpled, the sunsets honeyed, and the dangers as numerous as the clichés.

headline: Is Missouri the Winner of Its Winner-Less Contests?
text: In February, Missouri held a Republican primary that had a winner but awarded no delegates. On Saturday, the party will hold caucuses that will ultimately help determine delegates. On paper, both events are of limited significance in the race for the Republican presidential nomination.

headline: Pricing Parking by Demand
text: How San Francisco’s pilot program to make sure there is at least one parking spot available is working.

headline: New York Couple’s Gift to Enrich Two Museums
text: For more than two decades Thea Westreich Wagner and her husband, Ethan Wagner, have been known to the art world as advisers perusing fairs, bidding at auctions and attending gallery openings and museum previews.

headline: Mississippi Madness
text: The Mississippi House passed its copycat version of Arizona’s extremist immigration law yesterday. It now heads to the Senate, where it is expected to pass and then be signed by Gov. Phil Bryant, who has endorsed it.

headline: Embracing Irish Music, a New York Tradition
text: YOU step into the crowded establishment, and it hits you: a rousing set of reels, played by a pickup band in the corner. There’s a fiddle, a guitar, a bodhran, a concertina, maybe a banjo or a flute or a tin whistle. Your foot starts tapping, you order a pint and you settle in for music summoning images of a damp, windswept isle across the Atlantic. But this isn’t St. Patrick’s Day. It’s the Landmark Tavern, on 11th Avenue in Manhattan, on almost any Monday evening.

headline: Wizard Of Whimsy
text: YOU don’t often go to a museum to groom a dog. Especially not an 18-foot-long, almost 11-foot-high dog, whose fuchsia fur requires a comb at least 25 inches wide.

headline: Up From the Basement, Slacker Metaphysics
text: The reluctance — or outright refusal — of ostensibly grown men to behave like adults is more than just a favored theme of modern movie comedy. It is an axiom, a principle, a worldview. The varieties of male immaturity seem almost infinite, even if the guys on screen are almost always white, middle class and at least presumptively, if not always successfully, heterosexual. Each of these man-children offers his own special blend of innocence and id, balancing the pitiable traits of slackness and aggression with more appealing qualities of sweetness and honesty.

text: ‘STUNT LAB’

text: Theater

headline: Thank Me. Your Nails Will, Too.
text: MY fingernails couldn’t breathe. You know those awful lead bibs they lay on you in the dentist’s office when you’re having X-rays done, the way those bibs make you feel you’re smothering? My nails felt like that.

headline: Spare Times for March 16 — 22
text: ST. PATRICK’S DAY WEEKEND (Friday through Sunday) St. Patrick’s Day on a weekend? For many, that’s a lucky occurrence in itself, with freedom from school or work to go to the annual parade on Fifth Avenue. Like last year’s, this year’s parade in Manhattan will stretch from 44th to 79th Streets, beginning Saturday at 11 a.m. (Revelers at last year’s event, above.) But it also means that people will have more time to take in other events. On Friday from 6 to 8 p.m., the New-York Historical Society, at Central Park West and 77th Street, will host an evening of music and historical displays about notable Irish citizens, including the former New York governor Alfred E. Smith. Beginning Saturday at noon, visitors to the Merchant’s House Museum, on East Fourth Street, can learn about the Irish immigrants who once toiled in the home there, with tours of the recently renovated servants’ quarters. And all weekend long, the food, politics and historic figures of the New York Irish — the good and the bad — will be covered on walking tours in Lower and Midtown Manhattan. Details for these events can be found in the Listings on this page. No need to party like there’s no tomorrow; there’s always Sunday brunch. (Anne Mancuso)

headline: Digital Notes: MTV.com Sees an Opening as MySpace Fades Away
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — Not long ago, MySpace was the central destination for online music, the place where fans could connect with seemingly every artist on earth. Since then the site’s popularity has plunged (and its new owners are trying to resuscitate it). But can anything take over from MySpace as music’s online agora?

text: Jazz

headline: Opera and Classical Listings
text: Classical

headline: Syracuse Avoids Becoming First Victim of No. 16 Seed
text: PITTSBURGH — On Wednesday, Syracuse Coach Jim Boeheim said he was “shocked” to see the Big South champion, North Carolina-Asheville, as a No. 16 seed in the N.C.A.A tournament. On Thursday, Boeheim very nearly experienced a shock of a different kind.

headline: Sacred, Sensual and Scholarly
text: New York never lacks for art, but as spring approaches, movable feasts of it seem to arrive in waves. Last week nearly a dozen fairs put extra servings of contemporary and Modern art on the table. Friday is the official beginning of Asia Week, a visual repast of more than 40 shows staged by New York and out-of-town dealers and spread mostly through galleries around the Upper East Side, on or just off Madison Avenue.

headline: Imaginative Leaps, Paradoxes Included
text: The three-week Paul Taylor season at the David H. Koch Theater piles on new repertory with staggering abundance. It remains true that the season demonstrates Mr. Taylor’s centrality to the tradition of American modern dance, and that it makes his choreography look impressively different by placing it in the context of a tall, deep and broad opera house. It is also true that its profusion of works old and new must make us rethink both Mr. Taylor’s history and that of modern dance. People watching his choreography for the first time this week have spoken of their immediate enthusiasm for his work; long-term aficionados have rejoiced both to recognize and to reconsider what they knew and loved. There are, however, problems.

headline: Mining the Words of Woody Guthrie
text: New Multitudes, a centennial tribute to Woody Guthrie, made up of the singer-songwriters Jay Farrar, Yim Yames, Anders Parker and Will Johnson, operates from within a cocoon of familiarity. Not with regard to the songs, exactly: all 12 on the group’s self-titled debut album, released last month on Rounder, began with previously unused scraps of writing from the Guthrie archives, freshly set to music.

headline: Paul Giamatti To Play Hamlet at Yale Rep
text: The film and television actor Paul Giamatti (“Sideways,“ “John Adams”) will play Hamlet next year at Yale Repertory Theater, during a 2012-13 season there that will include world premiere productions of plays by David Adjmi (“Stunning”), Sarah Ruhl (“In the Next Room, or the vibrator play”) and a new adaptation of the 1978 German film “In a Year with 13 Moons,” the theater announced on Thursday.

headline: Ornate Links Tethering Cultures in Flux
text: Big anthropological surveys are feats of cultural diplomacy, requiring years of negotiation and persuasion. And when regular diplomacy breaks down because of hostility or instability, museums feel the impact.

headline: Movie Listings for March 16 — 22
text: Movies

headline: Hopping Into Cultures, Skipping Across Centuries
text: As it turns out, the alt-classical movement that has become an explosive force in new music also has an early-music wing. And L’Arpeggiata, the flexible period-instrument ensemble that played the first of four programs in its Carnegie Hall Perspectives series at Zankel Hall on Wednesday evening, is determined to be this new division’s house band.

headline: Seeking a Father, Finding Humanity
text: The fast-moving boy in “The Kid With a Bike,” a quietly rapturous film about love and redemption from Jean-Pierre and Luc Dardenne, races along with frightening intensity, his little legs pedaling hard, his eyes fixed on a heart-heavy destination. What the 11-year-old Cyril (the newcomer Thomas Doret, touchingly serious) wants — what every muscle in his small, tensed body strains toward — is the father who left him at a children’s home, abandoning his only son to the kindness of strangers with as seemingly little regard and feeling as someone else might toss a pair of old shoes.

headline: Recession’s Toll on Health Coverage
text: It’s a startling reminder that when people lose their jobs, they typically also lose their health insurance coverage. The share of children and working-age adults who had insurance through an employer fell 10 percentage points during the last recession, according to a study released on Thursday by the Center for Studying Health System Change, a nonpartisan research group in Washington.

headline: From Inside a Bad-Guy Wrestler, a Brutal Artist Screamed for Release
text: There was always something artistically sinister about Damien Demento, the loony thug who thrilled World Wrestling Federation fans in the early 1990s with his stringy Fu Manchu beard-mustache combo, bear-claw poncho and bad-guy persona

headline: Substitute Teacher, Just Trying to Do Good by His Pupils
text: “Detachment,” the latest provocation from Tony Kaye, the director of the neo-Nazi drama “American History X” and the graphic abortion documentary “Lake of Fire,” belongs to a subset of shockers that know exactly which nerves to prick to produce intense reactions. Like-minded movies determined to blow the lid off your complacency include Larry Clark’s “Kids” and Darren Aronofsky’s “Requiem for a Dream.” But how much can you trust films that blend high-minded outrage with a tabloid-savvy sensationalism?

headline: An Exhibition in Easy Mode
text: WASHINGTON — On Christmas in 1980 a fifth-grade boy in Flushing, Queens, received his first computer, a Commodore VIC-20. It changed his life. A few months later, a third grader about 100 miles upstate, in Woodstock, also received his first computer, a Commodore VIC-20. It changed his life too.

headline: After ‘Luck,’ a Post-Mortem Debate
text: THE day after HBO announced that it was canceling “Luck,” its dramatic series set in the world of horse racing, a debate continued over the deaths of animals on its set, developments that ultimately forced the end of a series that had struggled to build a substantial following.

headline: In French Occupation, a Broader Resistance
text: Ismael Ferroukhi’s new film, “Free Men,” takes place in Nazi-occupied Paris, by now a familiar setting for morally serious period dramas. The story this movie has to tell is a bit unusual, though: it concerns the efforts by Muslim North African residents of the city to protect Jews and aid the Resistance.

headline: Literary Readings Are Free at KGB Bar
text: It’s not difficult to entertain a miser in New York. There are plenty of options for cheap entertainment in any borough. But when it comes to quality culture, a few of New York’s arts institutions seem to go the extra mile, while forgoing that extra dollar.

headline: ‘Byzantium and Islam’
text: Images from the exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

headline: Francesca Woodman
text: Images from the artist’s retrospective at the Guggenheim Museum.

headline: A Man Who Spewed His Seed Finds the Son Who’s No Prize Crop
text: The most memorable element of Robbie Pickering’s debut feature, “Natural Selection,” is Rachael Harris’s portrayal of Linda, a dutiful wife whose older husband, Abe (John Diehl), refuses to have sex with her. They are Christians living on the outskirts of Houston with no children. Both are sure she is barren, and Abe believes that sex for procreation is the only reason to copulate. The poor woman is jumping out of her skin.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Waiting for iPads, and Name-Dropping in the Valley
text: Here are some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web on Thursday. There are more here.

headline: Teenagers Perplexed About Faith and Sexuality
text: The likable main characters in Stephen Cone’s tenderhearted gem, “The Wise Kids,” are earnest Christian teenagers associated with a Baptist church in Charleston, S.C. The radiant, redheaded Brea (Molly Kunz), the minister’s daughter; the tall, skinny Tim (Tyler Ross), an aspiring filmmaker; and the intense, devout Laura (Allison Torem), whose prayers reiterate the words “amazing” and “awesome,” are high school seniors and friends who will soon go their separate ways. They are first seen rehearsing an Easter pageant directed by Austin (Mr. Cone), the pastor’s fresh-faced, young assistant, in which the boy playing Jesus falls off the cross (no deeper meaning implied).

headline: Paving Path to Fraud on Wall St.
text: Nearly 20 years ago, Bankers Trust was riding high. The bank, based in New York, had become known as an expert in then-newfangled derivative securities, and the profits were flowing in. In an era where commercial banks were often viewed as stodgy and unimaginative, it stood out as a shining light. Corporate treasurers sought its insights about ways to maximize income from idle cash. Wall Street firms scrambled to compete.

headline: Lady Macbeth, Where Are You When We Need You?
text: Why aren’t there more female leaders? Chrystia Freeland asks in her latest Page Two column. Some reasons, according to two researchers in Canada, are cultural strictures on what comprises appropriate behavior and who makes suitable leaders.

headline: Escaping a Dead Chicken, and an Invalid  Summons
text: Picture this, if you can: Patrick Beberfield, teddy bear of a man in a beige three-piece-suit and with a broad-striped jacket, dancing in a courthouse restroom in Lower Manhattan, Bible in one hand, dismissed summons in the other.

headline: Where Texas Republican Math Gets Complicated
text: ​Ross Ramsey, the executive editor at The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

headline: Vanderbilt Makes Sure Harvard’s Run Comes to End
text: ALBUQUERQUE — After 66 years away from the N.C.A.A. tournament, Harvard had its one shining moment.

headline: A Gang War in the Future
text: Crude, sketchy and scattershot, “The FP” wants desperately to win the love of cult- and B-movie lovers everywhere. A parody of 1980s sports dramas (like “Kickboxer”) and ’70s stoner action pictures (“The Warriors”), with dashes of “Flashdance” glam and a setting faintly recalling Southern-fried revenge movies (say, “Walking Tall,” but with shoulder pads), it falls all over itself to lampoon its midnight-movie forebears even as it borrows their contrivances.

headline: Howard, Eyes on a Championship, Is Staying With the Magic for Now
text: ORLANDO, Fla. — Dwight Howard declared his loyalty to Orlando on Thursday, but made it clear that it would only go so far. After agreeing with the Magic not to opt out of the final year of a contract that will pay him $19.2 million next season, Howard was asked why he did not negotiate a long-term extension if he loved the city so much.

headline: Travel Day Tomorrow
text: Probably no posting until late.

headline: A Village Where Europe Can Take a Stroll and Plot Its Future
text: MESEBERG, Germany — Under Communism, the lakeside 18th-century Baroque palace in this village in the state of Brandenburg housed nine families upstairs and a branch of the East German general store known simply as Konsum downstairs.

headline: Ackerman Won’t Seek Re-Election to Congress
text: WASHINGTON — RepresentativeGary L. Ackerman, a longtime member of Congress from Queens and Long Island, announced on Thursday that he would not seek re-election, an unexpected development that brings an end to a colorful political career.

headline: In New Documentary, Obama Confronts a Country on the Brink
text: The Obama campaign on Thursday night released “The Road We’ve Traveled,” a 17-minute video with a series of screenings at its campaign offices nationwide and a live stream on YouTube.

headline: Lean Times for Dewey & LeBoeuf
text: When the old-line law firms Dewey Ballantine and LeBoeuf, Lamb, Greene & MacRae merged in 2007, it was the talk of the legal industry. The combination created an international behemoth poised to benefit from the booming global economy.

headline: For Some Texas Inmates, Familiar Voices Over the Air
text: On Friday nights, in prison cells across East and Southeast Texas, a window opens to the outside world. For two hours, a Houston-based radio show breaks the isolation of the incarcerated, linking inmates to families, friends and life outside lockup.

headline: New Law Clears the Way for Airports to Drop T.S.A. Screeners
text: WASHINGTON — A new law makes it easier for airports to replace federal screeners with private contractors, and several airports, after years of passenger complaints, are lining up to make the change.

headline: Don’t Cut Pensions, Expand Them
text: ON Thursday morning the New York State Legislature agreed to a deal limiting pensions for future public employees. The state thus joins 43 others that have recently enacted legislation curtailing public retirement benefits.

headline: How Not to Attract Tourists
text: AS Americans, we like to imagine our country as we think of ourselves: open-hearted and welcoming; efficient and practical; easygoing, above all. These values are the foundation of our culture, of an open economy fueled by ideas and immigration, and of our soft power — America’s ability to change the world simply because it is admired.

headline: U.S. Seeking Use of Funds to Aid Russian Democracy
text: MOSCOW — The Obama administration is pushing to free $50 million in long-stalled aid to promote democracy and civil society in Russia, an effort that comes amid a drumbeat of accusations that the United States is meddling in Russia’s internal politics.

headline: Choosing to Break Up Monotony With Variety
text: HE is traveling “from sea to shining sea,” he declares, at a prodigious pace, visiting states with lots of electoral votes like California, New York and Texas as well as states with just a few like Nevada. And what he calls his “journey of epic proportions” is the subject of advertising worth tens of millions of dollars, on television and radio and on social media like Facebook and YouTube.

headline: MF Global Workers Expected to Be Called to Testify Before Congress
text: MF Global employees at the center of a federal investigation are expected to appear before a Congressional panel this month to shed light on the brokerage firm’s misuse of roughly $1 billion in customer money, according to people briefed on the matter.

headline: New Mexico Outlasts Long Beach State
text: PORTLAND, Ore. — The signs in the stands at the Rose Garden said “Woof!” and that is what New Mexico fans did as the final seconds ticked away. They barked and screamed and chanted, turning one corner of the stands here into the red sea of celebration that is their home arena, the Pit.

headline: An Update on New York Redistricting
text: New York is still grappling with the redistricting required as a result of the 2010 census. And the urgency is growing: the state’s Congressional primary is scheduled for June 26, and its legislative primary for Sept. 11.

headline: Natural Born Drillers
text: To be a modern Republican in good standing, you have to believe — or pretend to believe — in two miracle cures for whatever ails the economy: more tax cuts for the rich and more drilling for oil. And with prices at the pump on the rise, so is the chant of “Drill, baby, drill.” More and more, Republicans are telling us that gasoline would be cheap and jobs plentiful if only we would stop protecting the environment and let energy companies do whatever they want.

headline: The Myth of the ‘Student-Athlete’
text: People often dismiss philosophical disputes as mere quibbles about words.   But shifts in terminology can turn the tide in public debates.  Think of the advantage Republicans gained when discussion of the Affordable Health Care Act became discussion of “Obamacare.” (Conversely, suppose we talked about “Bush-ed” instead of “No Child Left Behind”).  Or consider how much thinking about feminism has changed with the demise of “men” as a term for people in general.

headline: The Cagey Phase
text: Presidents don’t fundamentally change personalities while in office, but different aspects of their personality arise at different times. The first two years of the Obama presidency were the audacious phase: doing many big things at once. It was audacious to promote a giant health care reform in the middle of an economic crisis. It was audacious to continue to support it even after a Republican won Ted Kennedy’s Senate seat.

headline: Neighborhood Joint | The Creek and the Cave
text: Behind the restaurant’s cheerful brick-walled dining room, there is an almost hidden black box theater: a kind of speakeasy for comedy.

headline: Building the Billikens for the Long Haul
text: COLUMBUS, Ohio — In recent days, Rick Majerus had to coach his assistants and players at St. Louis University on more than basketball, addressing topics like how to supply tickets to friends and the nature of the team’s travel accommodations.

headline: In China, a Rare View of Infighting by Leaders
text: BEIJING — A deep vein of intrigue has always pulsed through the messy process of sorting out power in China’s Communist Party.

headline: Bo Xilai Removal Signals Communist Party Change. No, Just the Opposite. Discuss.
text: How the mighty have fallen.

headline: The Abuse of Solitary Confinement
text: In the past three decades, solitary confinement has been embraced by the vast majority of states to control violence and impose discipline. There are at least 25,000 prisoners in solitary, while tens of thousands more are in other forms of segregation, which are only somewhat less restrictive.

headline: Bills Land Top Prize With a $50 Million Guarantee
text: The Buffalo Bills rarely have the money and have never had the glitz that help their rivals lure the most sought-after free agents. They have had to overcome economics, a lack of trendy nightclubs, long winters and, lately, the absence of success to attract players who have other options.

headline: Man Says Gifts to Lawmaker Were for Love
text: He met her about a decade ago, and it was love, unrequited, at first sight.

headline: Rabbi Moshe Hager, a Hasidic Leader, Dies at 95
text: Rabbi Moshe Yehoshua Hager, the leader of one the world’s largest Hasidic sects, the Viznitz Hasidim, and a participant in Israeli politics who encouraged moderation on issues like the expansion of settlements in the occupied territories, died early Wednesday in Bnei Brak, east of Tel Aviv. He was 95.

headline: A Greener Approach to Runoff
text: New York City may have found an affordable way to reduce the flow of untreated sewage into the city’s surrounding waterways whenever there is heavy rainfall. Under an agreement with the state announced Tuesday, the city plans to commit $2.4 billion in public and private money over the next 18 years in innovative techniques to prevent rainfall from overwhelming the city’s waste treatment plants.

headline: GTT ★
text: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

headline: Lakers Trade for Sessions; Fisher Exits
text: On an N.B.A. trading day in which quantity trumped quality, the biggest stars were regret, loyalty and savings.

headline: For Apple, Pressure Builds Over App Store Fraud
text: In a little over an hour, Ryan Matthew Pierson racked up $437.71 in iTunes charges for virtual currency that he could use to buy guns, nightclubs and cars in iMobsters, a popular iPhone game. One problem: Mr. Pierson, a technology writer in Texas, has never played iMobsters.

headline: Of Jobs, Loans and Timing
text: IF searching for a new job and refinancing a home are both on the agenda, you might be wondering which task you should finish first.

headline: Cuomo, Admitting Setbacks, Says He Asked for the Moon
text: ALBANY — Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo came back to earth this week.

headline: Books Without Borders
text: When we reached Tony Diaz, novelist and novice smuggler, by phone this week, he was in West Texas, 500 miles from his home in Houston and about a third of the way through a journey with three dozen comrades and serious contraband. That is, a busload of books.

headline: The Other 1 Percent
text: The yellow banners, the halftime tributes, the bloviating by politicians of both parties — it’s so easy for the 99 percent of us who aren’t serving in the military to act like we support them. We all love the troops, blah, blah, blah.

headline: For Detained Whistle-Blower, a Hospital Bill, Not an Apology
text: It was not until 6 in the morning on Nov. 1, 2009, that Officer Adrian Schoolcraft finally had access to a telephone. The night before, he had been brought to the psychiatric emergency room at Jamaica Hospital Medical Center on the orders of his police bosses.

headline: At City Council Hearing, Police Commissioner Fights Back
text: For the last few weeks and months, Raymond W. Kelly, the police commissioner of New York, had taken his lumps over various issues, from his department’s handling of Occupy Wall Street to its surveillance practices and its reliance on stop-and-frisk tactics. And with his scheduled appearance before the City Council on Thursday, more of the same was expected.

headline: Gloria Sachs, Fashion Designer for Working Women, Dies at 85
text: Gloria Sachs, a fashion designer who tapped into a growing market of women seeking understated elegance in clothes as they rose to new heights in the workplace in the 1970s and ’80s, died on March 12 at her home in Manhattan. She was 85.

headline: Previous Success for Witness in Mets Case
text: In the spring of 2003, Noreen Harrington, a 20-year veteran of Wall Street, picked up the telephone and called the office of Eliot Spitzer, then the New York attorney general, with a tip.

headline: No Way to Choose a Judge
text: In a serious setback for justice in Alabama, primary voters chose Roy Moore to be their candidate for chief justice of the State Supreme Court in November. He is now the odds-on favorite to win. You may remember that Mr. Moore lost that job in 2003 when a special ethics court removed him from the bench after he defied a court order to remove a Ten Commandments monument from the lobby of the state judicial building in Montgomery.

headline: For Shin, a New Look and New Hope on the L.P.G.A. Tour
text: PHOENIX — It says a lot about Jiyai Shin’s golf game that she recently colored her black hair a wheat hue to distinguish herself.

headline: Accused G.I. ‘Snapped’ Under Strain, Official Says
text: WASHINGTON — The American staff sergeant suspected of killing 16 Afghan villagers had been drinking alcohol — a violation of military rules in combat zones — and suffering from the stress related to his fourth combat tour and tensions with his wife about the deployments on the night of the massacre, a senior American official said Thursday.

headline: Catholics and Contraception: Boston, 1965
text: Michael Dukakis does not mince words. He admits to being “flabbergasted” by the debate between the Catholic hierarchy and the Obama administration over the mandate that requires employers to provide contraception coverage. “I thought birth control wasn’t an issue anymore,” he told me.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: March 15, 2012

headline: Home to Sting, Denzel and Now Barbara
text: THE residents of Manhattan’s most expensive luxury building — 15 Central Park West — include celebrities like Denzel Washington and Sting, not to mention financiers from hedge funds and Wall Street firms.

headline: On the Stump in Ohio, Biden Attacks G.O.P. Rivals
text: TOLEDO, Ohio — Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., the White House’s preferred emissary to the Rust Belt, swept into his political sweet zone on Thursday, touting the administration’s economic record to a spirited gathering at the United Auto Workers Local 12 hall. He talked up the American auto industry, praised President Obama’s convictions and criticized the Republican presidential candidates by name — repeatedly — accusing them of being “about protecting the privileged sector.”

headline: Rebirth of the Bonnies
text: NASHVILLE — Andrew Nicholson came to St. Bonaventure from Canada thanks to a cellphone he accidentally smashed with his size 18 sneakers, a sprained ankle that prevented bigger programs from recruiting him and the lure of a glistening new science building.

headline: Nothing Sweeter Than the Sound of a Bouncing Ball
text: Moments after Long Island University clinched its second consecutive N.C.A.A. tournament berth last week, the associate athletic director Greg Fox glanced toward press row. He spotted Richard Kurlander, the producer for the team’s radio broadcasts, wearing his headset, tears streaming down his cheeks.

headline: Streetscapes | Cuba
text: New York architects found Havana fertile ground a century ago.

headline: Havana’s New York Accent
text: EVEN in Cuba they know it’s a waiting game, waiting for the Castros to exit the stage, and for Cuba to open up. When Americans finally do arrive in quantity, New Yorkers will notice something familiar about Havana, for a string of New York architects found it fertile ground a century ago.

headline: Despite Rights Concerns, U.S. Plans to Resume Egypt Aid
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration plans to resume military aid to Egypt, American officials said on Thursday, signaling its willingness to remain deeply engaged with the generals now running the country despite concerns over abuses and a still-uncertain transition to democracy.

headline: Facts Conceded at Officer’s Rape Trial
text: After a prosecutor told jurors on Thursday that an off-duty police officer had threatened to shoot a 25-year-old woman in the face if she screamed or looked at him while he raped her in an Upper Manhattan courtyard last summer, the officer’s lawyer had his chance to dispel that image from the jurors’ minds.

headline: V.C.U. Defeats Wichita State to Continue Tournament Success
text: PORTLAND, Ore. — From the outset, many tabbed this Virginia Commonwealth-Wichita State contest as an underdog handoff, with last year’s least likely national semifinalist (V.C.U.) matched against the team voted most likely to succeed it. Funny how that worked out.

headline: A.C.P.T. 2012: How Far Would You Travel?
text: SPECIAL POST — For Mangesh Ghogre, it started with a desire to get into a good graduate school. In his case, the road to the American Crossword Puzzle Tournament has been especially long.

headline: Geithner, on Doing the Unpopular
text: One way to make politically unpopular acts popular is to recognize their unpopularity – and hope that the public comes to respect you for going ahead with them anyway.

headline: Old, Roomy and Stroller-Friendly
text: AFTER the birth of their daughter, Jeanne Rondeau and Chris Beach knew they would need larger quarters than their 600-square-foot one-bedroom in Fort Greene, Brooklyn.

headline: Bloomberg Plans Trip to Singapore and Vietnam
text: What will New York City be like without Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg? Next week may bring a clue.

headline: When the Mistress Is Away, the Mice Do Play
text: You can practically inhale the aroma of the gladioluses flooding the plush bedroom where Jean Genet’s eerie psychodrama “The Maids” is set, in the new Red Bull Theater production directed by Jesse Berger. The audience is arranged in a few tight rows on three sides of the boudoir upholstered in blood-red fabric. Peek-a-boo holes are cut in the walls of the bedroom, exquisitely designed by Dane Laffrey, and as you observe the strange ritual being enacted by a pair of seriously unhinged domestics, you can also take in the spectators opposite, complicit voyeurs like yourself.

headline: American Dreamer, Ambushed by the Territory
text: The curtain rises, and the floodgates open. How could it be otherwise? Because suddenly it’s all there before you: that set, that music and, above all, that immortal silhouette — the shadowed figure of a stooped man with sample cases, heavy enough to contain a lifetime’s disappointments.

headline: Stand for Something
text: Administrivial Tournament Alert! My bags are packed, I’m ready to go … and I’m on my way to the American Crossword Tournament, which is being held at the Brooklyn Bridge Marriott in New York City from March 16-18. The hungry emus will keep all of the normal fun and games running while I’m away, so keep commenting, but check back here throughout the weekend for EXTRA live blogging from the tournament itself, like the post right below this one.

headline: Working Hard at SXSW: Kimbra
text: There’s never been a better time in pop history for a woman with a geek streak: someone with the kind of mathematical mindset to construct computer-looped patterns and grooves that can swing.

headline: Life in the Sunrise Seat
text: LUCIE HOLT has come a long way from her childhood home in Battersea, the working-class neighborhood in southwest London where she grew up in the 1960s and ’70s. She and her brother and two sisters lived on the ground floor of a red-brick house framed by gardens.

headline: Linsanity Has Left the Building
text: The great lesson of Linsanity — at least, as we understood it in February — is that expertise can be flawed and impressions faulty. Jeremy Lin taught us not to assume too much, especially as it pertains to Jeremy Lin.

headline: Does Morality Have a Place on Wall Street?
text: Greg Smith was shocked by what he witnessed at Goldman Sachs but maybe it was just business as usual.

headline: Vengeance Comes With a Catch
text: Lurching through Werner Herzog’s wonderfully sleazy “Bad Lieutenant: Port of Call New Orleans,” Nicolas Cage’s character — a heroin-addicted cop encased in several layers of depravity — seemed, like the post-Hurricane Katrina images that had dominated our evening news, at once heroic and disgraceful. Returning to that city for the throwaway thriller “Seeking Justice,” Mr. Cage walks a similar moral high wire to play a very different character. Unfortunately, with very different results.

headline: Aide Says Spending by Espada Raised Issue
text: The first witness in the embezzlement trial of former State Senator Pedro Espada Jr. testified on Thursday that she saw Mr. Espada guide several schemes to steal money from the nonprofit health care network in the Bronx that he founded and ran for 30 years.

headline: Firm Romney Founded Is Tied to Chinese Surveillance
text: BEIJING — As the Chinese government forges ahead on a multibillion-dollar effort to blanket the country with surveillance cameras, one American company stands to profit: Bain Capital, the private equity firm founded by Mitt Romney.

headline: Q & A
text: Shareholder List Withheld by Agent

headline: Toning Down Spring Break
text: Today’s spring breakers — at least some of them — say they have been tamed in part by the fear of an unflattering appearance on Facebook or YouTube.

headline: A Photographer’s Testament of Youth
text: IN 1992, when Rineke Dijkstra was an unknown photographer from the Netherlands visiting the United States, she found herself shooting pictures on a beach in South Carolina while being watched intently by an extroverted 14-year-old blond girl.

headline: The Family That Squabbles Together
text: In a good dysfunctional-family movie, by the end you have some idea of why everybody dislikes everybody else. In a lazy one like “Reuniting the Rubins,” you’re left to wonder about this most vital of elements because the writer and director — in this case, Yoav Factor — took the shortcut of assuming that bickering for bickering’s sake was enough.

headline: Obama Campaign Video Serves Up a Heroic Vision of Catastrophe Averted
text: It’s not exactly “Morning Again in America.” If anything, a new straight-to-the-Internet campaign video of President Obama looks more like darkness at noon.

headline: Youth Chronicles
text: A look at the work of the photographer Rineke Dijkstra.

headline: Kentucky Routs Western Kentucky, but Calipari Won’t Rest
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — Kentucky Coach John Calipari was not taking anybody’s word for it that his team was an overwhelming favorite Thursday night against Western Kentucky and, for that matter, is the favorite to win the national championship. He exhorted his team when it was playing defense in front of the Kentucky bench spreading his arms wide while pleading loudly for guard Doron Lamb to play tighter defense. He threw up his arms in disgust several times at a misplay and whirled to tell the players on the bench how unhappy he was while flapping his arms.

headline: Gonzaga Sends West Virginia on the Short Road Home
text: PITTSBURGH — Much was made of No. 10 West Virginia playing seventh-seeded Gonzaga in this city about 75 miles from campus. But ultimately the only benefit for the Mountaineers appeared to be the relatively short drive home afterward.

headline: Rentals to the Rescue
text: SIDELINED several years ago by the economy, five apartment projects in Westchester — two each in Yonkers and Port Chester and another in Ossining — are finally getting under way again. The big difference this time around is that all are now to be built as rentals, whereas original plans were for four of the five to be condominiums.

headline: In the Eye of the Beholder
text: A BRICK pool house in the backyard of Cory Rooney’s colonial in Old Brookville doubles as a recording studio; at the moment he is using the space to write a new song with Jennifer Lopez. The cottage, a smaller version of the main house, is outfitted with mahogany floors, a full granite kitchen, a stone bath and a living area.

headline: Jackrabbits Give Baylor a Scare
text: ALBUQUERQUE — Baylor did not score until South Dakota State had 8 points. But it wasn’t until the No. 3-seeded Bears were down by 19-7 that they finally awoke and began contesting shots with fury.

headline: Behind Tacos, a Safe Harbor for Comedy
text: PSST. You. Yeah, you. Want to see something funny?

headline: Public Employee Retirement Cuts
text: New state and local employees will be covered under a retirement plan that is less generous than those for employees hired earlier.

headline: Chancellor Removes Eight Staffers After Misconduct Review
text: Chancellor Dennis M. Walcott has fired or removed eight school employees after a recent review of employees with substantiated cases of misconduct on file.

headline: For Purdue’s Hummel, Long Road Back Nears Its End
text: OMAHA — Unless something else happens to him between now and Friday night, Purdue forward Robbie Hummel will make his first N.C.A.A. tournament appearance in three years against St. Mary’s. Hummel, a senior, is trying to complete his comeback from twice tearing the anterior cruciate ligament in his right knee.

headline: Living In | Red Hook, Brooklyn
text: Once safely on New York’s fringes, this Brooklyn neighborhood is becoming more integrated into the fabric of the city.

headline: Outlier Near the ‘Center of the Universe’
text: WHEN Frank Galeano was growing up on Union Street in the 1960s, Red Hook next door had so many abandoned buildings that he and his friends used them as “clubhouses,” running extension cords from nearby streetlights.

headline: Chins Up After Last Year’s Disaster
text: If making a decent movie required only good intentions, then “Pray for Japan” would be off and running. As it is, though, this muddled collage of random impressions and personal histories, emerging from last year’s destruction of the Tohoku coastline by the earthquake and tsunami, doesn’t document a tragedy so much as repeat a mantra.

headline: Homeowners Guard Their Gutters
text: WHEN Helen Brontzman went outside her house in Haddonfield one recent morning to retrieve her newspaper, she noticed an unfamiliar hole in her garden. Looking up, she saw that the 20-foot-long copper downspout previously attached to her two-story brick colonial had been stolen. The following week, her neighbor across the street suffered a similar theft, as did a third near neighbor, an elderly woman.

headline: Coach Will Call Shots; Stars Will Take Them
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Mike Woodson has been around. He played for Bobby Knight in college and Red Holzman in the pros and once helped Larry Brown coach his way to his only N.B.A. championship. In recent years, he took a terrible Atlanta team and, as its coach, steadily made it more competitive.

headline: Crosby Climbs Aboard a Steamrolling Team
text: The Rangers’ general manager, Glen Sather, had declared Wednesday that the Penguins with a healthy Sidney Crosby were “the best team in the league,” and Pittsburgh proved his proclamation correct Thursday in a 5-2 victory at Madison Square Garden.

headline: A Shift in Focus, From Obama to Numbers
text: Suddenly, it is all anyone in Republican politics can talk about: 1,144.

headline: Wang Injured in Game Against Yankees
text: VIERA, Fla. — It was a familiar sight for the Yankees, seeing Chien-Ming Wang’s sinker leading to a metronome of ground balls and swings and misses. Unfortunately for Wang, he provided another familiar sight on Thursday afternoon, when he pitched against his former team in a Washington Nationals uniform.

headline: Mets Get a Glimpse of What They Once Had
text: JUPITER, Fla. — For the Mets, Thursday marked the first spotting this spring of a rare shortstop once ubiquitous to New York — the former Met Jose Reyes.

headline: 75 Charged in Deaths at Soccer Riot in Egypt
text: CAIRO — Egypt’s general prosecutor charged 75 people on Thursday in connection with a deadly soccer melee in Port Said last month, including the city’s top police official. Though he and other officers knew that violence was likely at the match, they let the perpetrators into the stadium without searching for weapons, then stood by and watched as they attacked, the prosecutor said.

headline: On the Market in the Region
text: A five-bedroom colonial in East Norwalk, Conn., and a five-bedroom Victorian in Yorktown, N.Y.

headline: On the Market in New York City
text: An Upper West Side co-op, a Battery Park City condo and a West Midwood house.

headline: Gospel Singer Wows ‘Idol’ Judges
text: Joshua Ledet, a young gospel singer from Louisiana, was the standout on “American Idol” this week, delivering a soaring performance of “When a Man Loves a Woman” that not only wowed the judges but prompted Percy Sledge, who made the song a hit, to write the show and praise him.

headline: Norfolk State Adopts Touch Made Famous by a Celtic
text: OMAHA — It takes gumption to walk up to someone you do not know and initiate a conversation. That has never been a problem for the Norfolk State assistant coach Wilson Washington, a former Nets forward.
