text: BUSINESS DAY

headline: NYT Front Page for 03/16/2012
text: NYT Front Page for 03/16/2012

headline: For Santorum, Trying to Tamp Down a Firestorm Over Puerto Rico Remarks
text: SAN JUAN, P.R. — Rick Santorum had hoped that by visiting Puerto Rico this week, he might pick up some of the commonwealth’s delegates to add to his column in his race against Mitt Romney for the Republican presidential nomination.

headline: Jets’ Sanchez Says a Meeting With Holmes Cleared the Air
text: Mark Sanchez flew to Orlando, Fla., a few weeks ago, but not for a Disney World vacation. His objective: a face-to-face meeting with Santonio Holmes. They ate. They spoke. And, according to Sanchez, they laughed.

headline: Lessons Learned From #Kony2012
text: After releasing a video that now counts 100 million online views about Joseph Kony’s brutal tactics as leader of the Lord’s Resistance Army in central Africa, Invisible Children is responding to tough questions about its organization and its approach – on Twitter and in another video.

headline: The Closer: A Sad End for Oden
text: After a flurry of activity at the trade deadline, Portland found itself with one too many players. To solve the logjam, the team released a former top overall draft pick, Greg Oden.

headline: Backlash Aside, Charities See Lessons in a Web Video
text: It has galvanized young Americans, inspired a flood of donations and stirred a backlash from critics. But for some in the nonprofit world, the reaction to the unprecedented success of an advocacy video about the murderous African warlord Joseph Kony can be summed up in a word: envy.

headline: Word of the Day | misapprehension
text: misapprehension •\(ˌ)mis-ˌa-pri-\-ˈhen(t)-shən\• noun

headline: N.C.A.A. Men’s Tournament Photo Replay: March 15
text: Second-round action included Syracuse surviving a scare, and No. 5 Wichita State falling to No. 12 Virginia Commonwealth.

headline: Indiana Rolls Past New Mexico State
text: PORTLAND, Ore. — Fourth-seeded Indiana (26-8) dominated No. 13-seed New Mexico State (26-7) late Thursday at the Rose Garden.

headline: UConn Falls Behind Early and Cannot Catch Up
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — UConn Coach Jim Calhoun fumed from the sideline as his indifferent big men allowed Iowa State to drive right to the rim for baskets or snatch offensive rebounds. After the Huskies’ 6-foot-10 Andre Drummond watched Iowa State’s 6-5 Chris Babb toss in a short floater in the lane in the first half, Calhoun could only throw his hands up in disgust.

headline: G.O.P. Strategy for Hispanic Voters: It’s the Economy
text: PUEBLO, Colo. — For many years, and multiple election cycles, Republicans talked about the growing Hispanic vote in America like moonstruck, misunderstood boys at a high school dance. They could not connect, despite believing that they shared much in common, especially with socially conservative, religious Hispanic voters who would one day realize how charming Republicans could be.

headline: Shirt Sales Tell Tale of a Lin Fadeaway
text: One of the first real signs that Jeremy Lin’s wild wave of celebrity was cresting came March 11, in an afternoon game at Madison Square Garden. For the first time in a month, Lin spoke afterward to a manageable crowd of reporters in front of his locker, not to a throng in the press conference room.

headline: Israel: Soldier Stabbed on Train
text: An Israeli soldier was stabbed and wounded Thursday while traveling on Jerusalem’s light railway on the way to her base, the Israeli military said. Witnesses said that the assailant fled the train when it pulled into a station in northeast Jerusalem. Soon after, a Palestinian man suspected of stabbing the woman was detained at the Qalandiya checkpoint between Jerusalem and the West Bank city of Ramallah, according to the military.

headline: Ethiopian Abused in Lebanon Said to Have Committed Suicide
text: An Ethiopian domestic worker, depicted in a video last week being assaulted outside her country’s consulate in Lebanon, has committed suicide, according to local media reports.

headline: State Will Overhaul Its Handling of Test-Tampering Complaints
text: The state Education Department announced on Thursday that it would hire a team of investigators and lawyers to overhaul and modernize the state's handling of test tampering complaints. Among the recommendations: create a new test security unit made up of investigators and lawyers, take over investigations of serious claims of test tampering, increase penalties for school staff members who are found cheating and mandate that any person who learns of test tampering report it to the state.

headline: Ohio State Too Much for Loyola to Handle
text: PITTSBURGH — The last time a No. 15 seed faced a No. 2 seed in this city during the N.C.A.A. tournament was 1997, and an unheralded school from Baltimore — Coppin State — pulled off the upset, shocking South Carolina. Fifteen years after that memorable game, however, Loyola (Md.) could not come close to matching its neighbor’s historic performance.

headline: Can India’s ‘Mr. Fix It’ Spur Growth?
text: The stakes are high for India’s finance minister, Pranjab Mukherjee, as he delivers the annual statement of the Union Budget.

headline: Chelsea’s Di Matteo Is Managing Just Fine, Thank You Very Much
text: It seemed appropriate for Chelsea that the first significant rebound from the departure of André Villas-Boas should happen in the Champions League, a competition that has claimed more than one managerial victim in the Roman Abramovich era. Ever since Abramovich bought the London club in 2003, the Champions League has represented the promised land. Even the Special One, José Mourinho, couldn’t deliver what his arrival had been billed to guarantee.

headline: Britain: 2 Sentenced for a Robbery Videotaped During the Riots Last Year
text: The videotaped robbery of a Malaysian student during last summer’s rioting, which drew nearly six million hits on YouTube and a personal condemnation by Prime Minister David Cameron, resulted in prison terms for the two muggers on Thursday. The video, filmed by a passerby, showed the two men pretending to help the student, Ashraf Rossli, after another youth in a London neighborhood had robbed him of his bicycle and broken his jaw. After helping Mr. Rossli to his feet, the two men stole his cellphone and other items from his backpack. The bicycle thief, sentenced separately, received a seven-year prison term. One of the men who looted the victim’s backpack, Reece Donovan, 24, was sentenced to five years in prison, and the other, John Kafunda, 22, received a term of four years and three months. Of the 3,000 people arrested for robbery, violence and property destruction during the riots, nearly 1,000 have been jailed, with average sentences of 14 months.

headline: Xavier Tries to Heal a Self-Inflicted Wound
text: GREENSBORO, N.C. — Xavier Coach Chris Mack is fond of telling his team that the games everybody remembers most are the ones played in March. That may be true, but it’s going to take quite a run in the N.C.A.A. tournament to make people forget about the game that has already defined the Musketeers this season.

headline: Spring Break Gets Tamer as World Watches Online
text: KEY WEST, Fla. — Ah, Spring Break, with its copious debauchery, its spontaneous bouts of breast-baring, Jager bombing and après-binge vomit.

headline: Hope for a Bergtraum Comeback Is Far Away, in Student Homes
text: A teacher and union leader at Murry Bergtraum High School says breaking down community schools and replacing them with small boutique schools has left Bergtraum with too many students who are there by default. "The results were a changed academic and social demographic," he writes -- and the school's consequential designation by a tabloid as "Worst High School in NY." But he has a proposal to turn things around.

headline: Crosby Blends In as Penguins Stand Tall Against Rangers
text: Sidney Crosby sat back in his stall, a black Penguins cap low over his smiling face, telling reporters that he was glad he had not wrecked his team’s winning streak.

headline: House G.O.P. Hesitates on Birth Control Fight
text: WASHINGTON — House Republicans, unsure how to proceed, have slowed their efforts to overturn a federal rule requiring employers, including religious institutions, to provide female employees with free health insurance coverage for contraceptives.

headline: Bad Loans at State-Run Banks Add to India’s Woes
text: “When people talk about Europe’s ‘government debt problem’ they mean something easy to describe: countries that borrowed more money than they can easily pay back,” but in India, it’s a “bit more complicated,” Vikas Bajaj writes in The New York times.

headline: Early Glimpse of Missouri Caucuses Shows Support for Santorum
text: BRUNSWICK, Mo. — Mitt Romney and his campaign advisers pride themselves on vigorously pursuing every delegate in every corner of the country in their quest to secure the Republican presidential nomination.

headline: Colorado Holds Off U.N.L.V.
text: ALBUQUERQUE — The Colorado Buffaloes carried the momentum from their four-game sweep of the Pacific-12 Conference tournament into the Pit and stormed to a 20-point lead over Nevada-Las Vegas.

headline: Meet the Principals
text: Here's a look at some of the principals who gathered on Long Island this week to be photographed for a new ad protesting the implementation of a new teacher evaluation system. All together, almost 100 principals from around the state showed up at South Side High School in Rockville Centre on Monday afternoon to pose for the ad, which will be published in the Legislative Gazette and other publications next week.

headline: A Rare Tough Race for Jackson in Chicago
text: CHICAGO — It was a Saturday morning and Representative Jesse L. Jackson Jr. of Illinois was dashing from news conference to news conference, racking up new political endorsements for the list he has been flaunting here lately. By the end of the day he had squeezed in a speech at an education conference, held a get-out-the-vote rally and made an appearance at an event for a candidate running for the State Legislature.

headline: Service Economy Keeps India Afloat
text: India’s poor industrial growth is dragging down the overall economy, according to the Economic Survey released on Thursday, while the service sector appears to be keeping the economy afloat at its current growth rate of just under 7 percent.

headline: Hatch Supporters Make Strong Showing in Utah Caucuses
text: PLEASANT GROVE, Utah – The Tea Party-inspired drive to oust Senator Orrin G. Hatch, a six-term Republican, got a bit more complicated on Thursday night.

headline: Democratic Senators Issue Strong Warning About Use of the Patriot Act
text: WASHINGTON — For more than two years, a handful of Democrats on the Senate intelligence committee have warned that the government is secretly interpreting its surveillance powers under the Patriot Act in a way that would be alarming if the public — or even others in Congress — knew about it.

headline: Maine: Court Approves Resort Near Moosehead Lake
text: The Maine Supreme Judicial Court has cleared the way for a development project in the forested Moosehead Lake region. The court found that state regulators did not violate procedural rules when they approved the project in 2009. The developer, Plum Creek, has proposed building two resorts and hundreds of houses near Moosehead Lake in the west central part of Maine, with additional land set aside for conservation. A lower court had found that the state’s Land Use Regulation Commission had not followed proper procedure before signing off on the project.

headline: North Korea Says It Will Launch Satellite Into Orbit
text: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea announced Friday that it planned to launch a satellite into orbit next month, threatening to scuttle a new agreement with the United States that had briefly raised hopes of easing diplomatic and military tensions surrounding the North’s nuclear weapons program.

headline: Texas Schools Face Bigger Classes and Smaller Staff
text: SAN ANTONIO — Ask Phyllis Causey what time she goes to lunch, and the third-grade teacher will give a very specific answer: 11:55 a.m.

headline: A Performance of Relentless Stillness, With Live Score
text: Eiko, the female half of Eiko and Koma, the contemporary movement arts duo who have performed together for some 40 years, hurled her small frame onto an oblong pile of canvas and feathers on the floor of the Yerba Buena Center for the Arts.

headline: When a Phone Disappears at Airport Security, No One’s in Charge
text: ​Scott James writes a column for The Bay Citizen.

headline: Inquiries on Violence at Occupy Protests Move Slowly
text: More than four months after an Occupy demonstration shut down the Port of Oakland and devolved into violence, at least nine separate investigations into the ways police officers dealt with the protests in Oakland and on University of California campuses in Davis and Berkeley remain unresolved.

headline: Budget 2012-13: Overview of the Economy
text: Economic growth:

headline: Budget 2012-13: Taxes
text: Individual income up to 2 lakh, or 200,000 rupees ($4,000) will be exempt from income tax.

headline: Online Sex Trade Is Flourishing Despite Efforts to Curb It
text: Early this month, the social networking Web site itspimpin101.net fell into disarray after its founder, Kelly Surrell, was fatally wounded in a shooting while driving his Bentley in East Oakland.

headline: News Quiz | March 16, 2012
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries in today’s newspaper.

headline: Budget 2012-13: Infrastructure, Industry and Agriculture
text: Infrastructure: 60,000 crore, or 600 billion rupees in tax free bonds for infrastructure building.

headline: SXSW: What a Difference a Year Has Made for Sharon Van Etten
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — If you’ve been to more than one South by Southwest, it’s easy to get cynical and think it’s just the same thing year after year, with more expensive branding deals. You see some of the same bands over and over, and hear the same gimmicks and retro signifiers, and things start to blend together. (For a few years there it didn’t help that every other band name seemed to include Crystal, Bear or Wolf.)

headline: March 16, 1968 | U.S. Soldiers Massacre Vietnamese Civilians at My Lai
text: On March 16, 1968, during the Vietnam War, United States troops under the command of Lt. William L. Calley Jr. carried out a massacre of about 500 unarmed men, women and children in the village of My Lai.

text: This question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article “Lights! Cameras! (and Cheers) for a Rock Weighing 340 Tons.”

text: WHO conducted research about sea levels and potential flooding in the United States?

headline: Amelia and the Animals
text: Robin Schwartz was looking to do something with her young daughter, Amelia.

headline: Should the R Rating for ‘Bully’ Be Changed?
text: Teenagers and others – including some members of Congress – are petitioning to have the rating lowered from R on the movie “Bully,” a documentary that tells the stories of five young people subjected to harsh treatment by their peers. Do they have a case? Are movie ratings important? Should the MPAA reevaluate the movie’s rating? Does a film like this have the potential to help more people talk about bullying and bring about change?

headline: Budget 2012 Analysis: Did Mukherjee Deliver?
text: This morning, I asked whether Finance Minister Pranab Mukherjee would step up to the plate and deliver a budget statement which would do anything to try to boost India’s anemic growth performance.

headline: 4 Gulf States Shun Syria as Turkey Warns Citizens to Leave
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Syria’s diplomatic isolation deepened on Friday as four more Persian Gulf states moved to close their Damascus embassies in protest of the violent suppression of a year-old uprising.

headline: New Details Show Panetta Was at Risk in Attack
text: WASHINGTON — An Afghan interpreter in a speeding truck tried to run down a top American commander and his British deputy, forcing the two and others to scatter as Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta’s plane taxied toward them at a military base in Afghanistan, defense officials said on Friday.

headline: Bye Bye, Bo
text: One day Prime Minister Wen Jiabao makes a strong call for political reform. The next day Bo Xilai, the charismatic head of the megalopolis of Chongqing, is axed. A rare public firing by the Chinese Communist Party, Bo’s dismissal on Thursday has commentators wondering what’s in store for China’s leadership transition later this year.

headline: Why Go to College? Readers Weigh In
text: Recently, we posed the question “Why go to college at all?” and asked Dale J. Stephens, the founder of UnCollege and something of a heretic in the world of higher education, to share his reasons why college need not be a foregone conclusion.

headline: North Korean Groundhog Day Comes Late
text: Just two weeks ago, Mark McDonald, Rendezvous’s Asia blogger, asked whether North Korea’s deal to trade food for the resumption of negotiations to abandon its nuclear program were in good faith or  a kind of diplomatic “Groundhog Day.”

headline: The Early Word: Courting the Hispanic Vote
text: In Today’s Times:

headline: Capital Gains vs. Ordinary Income
text: In a column titled “Capital Gains, Ordinary Income and Shades of Gray,” the Harvard economist N. Gregory Mankiw, who advises Mitt Romney in his presidential campaign, offers a fine teaching piece on the tenuous and often confusing line between ordinary income and capital gains under our tax code. As Professor Mankiw reminds us, the highest tax rate on ordinary income is now 35 percent while that on capital gains is only 15 percent.

headline: Bills Relevant With Mario Williams, but Realism Needed
text: O.K., so maybe we didn’t foresee the Buffalo Toronto Bills making the biggest splash in free agency this off-season. As the esteemed Bills writer Mark Gaughan pointed out in The Buffalo News, “In the 20 years the NFL has used an unrestricted free-agent system, the biggest Buffalo signing was a $7 million-a-year deal given to guard Derrick Dockery in 2007.” Williams’s annual salary is more than double that. In all, he’s reeling in $50 million in guarantees.

headline: Fantasy Focus: Notable Health Risks
text: Here’s my general feeling about what to do with some of the bigger health risks entering 2012:

headline: Cisco’s Bold Networking Start-Up
text: Three of Cisco’s top engineers with a strong record in building some of the company’s most important products are in negotiations to create a new type of network switch for data centers, according to people with knowledge of the talks.

headline: Daily Report: Pressure Builds Over App Store Fraud
text: Consumers are beginning to complain that Apple’s iTunes Store, and in particular its App Store, which the company portrays as the safest of shopping environments, is not so secure, report Brian X. Chen and Evelyn M. Rusli on Friday in The New York Times.

headline: Karzai Lashes Out at NATO Over Deaths
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — The last thing President Obama did before going to bed Thursday night was to call President Hamid Karzai, whose day was just getting started here.

headline: Hello, My Name Is Dunk — I Mean Doug — Anderson
text: OMAHA — Doug Anderson’s first name might as well be Dunk. The most compelling reason — maybe the only reason — to watch Detroit take on Kansas in Friday night’s late Midwest Regional mismatch is to see what manner of flying tomahawk monstrosity the 6-foot-6 Anderson drops on the second-seeded Jayhawks.

headline: Whit Stillman’s Family Album
text: The filmmaker talks about photographs from his youth.

headline: Solving Problems: Hiring, Visiting Competitors, an Old Web Site
text: Thanks to everyone who took the time to chime in on the three problems I wrote about last week. As usual, I got good advice from the commenters. Here’s a summary, with some further thoughts on what actions I’ll be taking.

headline: Exclusive Preview: 'Damsels in Distress'
text: A scene from Whit Stillman's new film, starring Greta Gerwig.

headline: Whit Stillman and the Song of the Preppy
text: Looking more like a wayward preppy trying to get into the Harvard Club without a tie than a legendary indie filmmaker mounting a comeback, Whit Stillman limped up to a RED digital camera and peered at a set dressed to resemble a girl’s dorm at a coed liberal arts college. This was back in October 2010. Since the start of the month, Stillman had been leaving his Manhattan sublet before sunrise and commuting to Staten Island, where, amid the banana trees and Greek Revival architecture of the Snug Harbor Cultural Center and Botanical Garden, he was shooting “Damsels in Distress,” his first movie in 12 years. Dressed in khakis, a white shirt and a blue blazer, Stillman was in some distress himself, having strained the plantar fascia of his right foot running in loafers for a subway train. He would be 59 in January — more than twice the age of most of his cast and crew — and given his perfectionist tendencies in the editing room, he would surely be 60 by the time the movie was released. “I don’t like to say I’m pushing 60,” he said. “I prefer to say I’m pulling 59.”

headline: Archbishop of Canterbury to Step Down at End of Year
text: LONDON — After a decade of struggling inconclusively to keep the worldwide Anglican Communion from breaking apart over intractable issues like women clergy, gay bishops and same-sex marriage, the Most Rev. Rowan Williams, the archbishop of Canterbury, announced Friday that he would step down at the end of the year to take up a senior position at Cambridge University.

headline: When Barack Met David: A Trans-Atlantic Love Story
text: LONDON — This is intended as a quick catch-up for American readers who may have inexplicably missed the top news story of the week: you just had a visit from the British prime minister. And, by the way, his name is David Cameron.

headline: India Proposes Higher Taxes and Slower Spending
text: MUMBAI — India’s finance minister said Friday that the country would raise taxes and slow growth in spending in an effort to lower its swelling budget deficit.

headline: Where Are the Republican Elder Statesmen?
text: As the Republican primaries drag on, some in the party are longing for a savior — an elder statesman or wise veteran who has the stature to quietly pull a candidate aside and nudge him out of the race for the good of the party.

headline: Battle of the Buyout Kings: Who Took Home the Most in 2011?
text: In the private equity world’s perennial battle for the title of wealthiest magnate around, it appears that Stephen A. Schwarzman has maintained his lead for another year.

headline: On Our Radar: Focus Returns to Fuel Efficiency
text: As gasoline prices head higher, a look at some  fuel-efficient models. [Associated Press]

headline: Why Receivers Have Ruled Free Agency
text: If the first three days of free agency told us anything, it’s that the wide receiver position is considered more valuable than ever. Six of our top 10 free-agent receivers are already signed, while several others have been picked up or given new contracts. Traditional thinking has long been that a good offense needs a playmaking star at No. 1 receiver, a reliable possession target at No. 2 and a darting third-down maestro in the slot at No. 3. But look closer at the transactions this week and you’ll see that these roles are becoming less relevant.

headline: Having Your Ducks in a Row Bodes Well for Reality-TV Success
text: Even reality takes practice, a lesson that has not been learned by many makers and stars of workplace reality shows. They think that a moderately unusual occupation — alligator wrangling, sports-memorabilia hawking, storage-locker rummaging — and a camera are all that is necessary to make a watchable show.

headline: Head of British Financial Regulator to Step Down
text: LONDON – Hector Sants, the chief executive of Britain’s financial regulator, will step down at the end of June, as part of a major overhaul to the country’s policing of financial markets.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: Lean Times for Dewey & LeBoeuf  |  Five years after the merger that created Dewey & LeBoeuf, the corporate law world is again abuzz over the firm, but for less auspicious reasons.

headline: Financial Crisis, the Musical
text: LONDON – Bankers are the stars of a new musical comedy that opened this month in the West End, the capital’s theater district.

headline: About the Rampage in Panjwai
text: DURHAM, North Carolina — When I read that a U.S. soldier went berserk last weekend in Panjwai, Afghanistan, rampaging door-to-door and slaughtering 16 Afghan villagers, I thought first of the victims and then of the doors.

headline: Opinion Report: Solitary Confinement
text: From the editorial page

headline: What They Said: Budget 2012-13
text: Finance Minister Pranab Mukherjee presented the annual budget in Parliament on Friday. The proposals in the new budget have evoked mixed reactions from Mr.Mukherjee’s political colleagues and analysts.

headline: Friday Reading: Spring Break Gets Tamer Amid Online Viewing
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: Eight School Employees Cited for Sexual Allegations
text: The spate of arrests in recent weeks of school employees for sexual misconduct culminated on Thursday with eight more names being added to the roster of shame. Four of the eight were school aides and have already been fired. The other four are tenured teachers who are awaiting hearings but who have been removed from the classroom.

text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: High-End Takeout at Gastronomie 491
text: There is no shortage of restaurants along Columbus Avenue in the West 80s where you can pick up or arrange delivery of a pizza, a container of dumplings or some mac and cheese. Still, Nicole Ahronee (above), a former jewelry designer who lives in the neighborhood, felt a need for a market and cafe dedicated to those who enjoy fine dining at home.

headline: Deutsche Bank Announces Management Shake-Up
text: LONDON – Deutsche Bank announced changes to its management team on Friday, a sign that the incoming co-chief executives of the German bank are looking to put their stamp on the group before they assume joint control.

headline: Morning Buzz, March 16: A Stolen Rabbit in SoHo
text: Good morning. Today will be overcast with a 50 percent chance of precipitation, possibly including thunderstorms, and highs in the low 60s.

headline: Fill-In | When the Food Writer Is a Ghost
text: Fill in the blanks in the first several paragraphs from the Dining article “I Was a Cookbook Ghostwriter.” Use your own words and phrases, or choose from an alphabetized list of the words that were removed.

headline: Afghan Prison’s Invasive Searches of Female Visitors Stir Fear of Slipping Rights
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Women visiting relatives at a notorious men’s prison on the edge of Kabul have in recent weeks been subjected to invasive body-cavity searches at the order of the prison’s commandant, who has told guards and American officials that the measure is needed to keep out contraband, Western and Afghan officials said.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: The Kitchn: Beer, cheddar, chives: all excellent things to add to a bread dough for St. Patrick’s Day. … — Julia Moskin

headline: German Museum Ordered to Return Collection of Posters Seized by Nazis
text: BERLIN— Germany’s leading historical museum must return a collection of more than 4,250 rare posters seized by the Nazis to the American son of a Jewish dentist who fled Germany, the country’s highest court for civil affairs in Karlsruhe ruled on Friday.

headline: Hope for a Bergtraum Comeback Is Far Away, in Student Homes
text: A teacher and union leader at Murry Bergtraum High School says breaking down community schools and replacing them with small boutique schools has left Bergtraum with too many students who are there by default. "The results were a changed academic and social demographic," he writes -- and the school's consequential designation by a tabloid as "Worst High School in NY." But he has a proposal to turn things around.

headline: U.P.S. Still Talking to TNT Over $6.4 Billion Takeover
text: LONDON – The United Parcel Service said on Friday that it was still talking to the Dutch shipping company TNT Express about a potential takeover, which values the European outfit at roughly 4.89 billion euros, or $6.4 billion.

headline: Strange Justice
text: Texas justice has rarely been kind to homosexuals. Take, for example, the case of Calvin Burdine, who was sentenced to death in 1984 for the murder of his male companion. Burdine’s court-­appointed lawyer, when not dozing, referred to his client as a “fairy.” The prosecutor, meanwhile, demanded the death penalty by arguing that gays actually look forward to the rewards of prison life. “Sending a homosexual to the penitentiary,” he claimed, “certainly isn’t a very bad punishment for a homosexual.” Astonishingly, a federal appeals panel first upheld the verdict on the grounds that nothing in the law guarantees a defendant the right to a fully conscious attorney. Burdine eventually won a new trial, at which he was again convicted, but this time sentenced to life in prison — a veritable candy store, it was said, for a “pervert” like him.

headline: A Life in the Balance
text: This much we know to be true: On a cold winter weekend in early 1982, somebody murdered 76-year-old Dorothy Edwards. Apparently she knew the perpetrator, since she let him into her handsome home on a quiet side street in Greenwood, S.C. The crime itself was horrific. She was beaten with a blunt object, stabbed repeatedly — one ear was almost severed — probably sexually assaulted; her body was stuffed into a bedroom closet, where it was discovered on Monday afternoon, Jan. 18. The next day the police arrested Edward Lee Elmore, a 23-year-old handyman whom Edwards had recently hired to do a few odd jobs around the house. He was formally charged with first-degree murder on Jan. 21, tried in the second week of April, found guilty by a jury that deliberated for two and a half hours, and sentenced to death.

headline: Tending His Gardens
text: In August 1827, a 33-year-old slave named James F. Brown ran away from a plantation in Maryland. Before he escaped, he wrote a letter explaining his actions and vowed that once he had earned enough money he would reimburse his owner, Susan Williams, to prove “that I dont mean to be dishonest but wish to pay her every cent that I think my Servaces is worth.” Brown’s letter reveals much about his character. He was orderly and moderate. He hated to do something that was “criminal” but felt he had no choice. His had not been a hasty or unreasonable decision. He was only taking the freedom that had rightfully been given by his previous master, who had promised it before his death.

headline: Fear Factor
text: With Osama bin Laden dead, American troops leaving Iraq, the economy still sputtering and Congress locked in yet another budget showdown, one thing that seems clear is that Washington will very likely cut military spending sometime soon. This will come as welcome news to David C. Unger, author of “The Emergency State” and an editorial writer for The New York Times. In this angry new book, Unger deplores what he sees as Washington’s obsession with security and overreliance on military and intelligence capabilities, arguing that they are dangerous perversions of the country’s Jeffersonian traditions.

headline: The Enthusiast
text: When John Leonard died in 2008, it did not immediately register that we had lost one of the last and best of a nearly extinct breed, the lifelong book reviewer. Some might prefer the more dignified label “literary critic,” or “cultural critic” (he did write extensively about television and other subjects); but Leonard himself did not insist on dignity. His roots and manner were journalistic — he fit into the world of newspapers (including The New York Times Book Review, which he edited in the 1970s), magazines (Harper’s, The Nation, New York), radio (“Fresh Air”) and television (“CBS Sunday Morning”) — and that casual, accessible tone may be why, for all his erudition, he is usually not discussed in the same breath with other literary arbiters who radiated more gravitas.

headline: The Embalmer of Small Things
text: Right now a novel’s length seems a neutral force. Over here, you have Haruki Murakami and Peter Nadas lying silent for years, then storming the shores of consciousness with thousand-page dreadnoughts; over there, the Argentine writer César Aira, pumping out books of one-tenth the size that can still put knots in your brain.

headline: While You Were Gone
text: The darkly comic world of Heidi Julavits’s latest novel contains warring psychics, missing people who’ve deliberately vanished themselves, twisted avant-garde filmmakers, absent mothers, striving academics, plastic surgery enthusiasts, Sylvia Plath obsessives — and the people who love to hate and pursue all of them. Beneath this hyperactivity, the novel deals, fundamentally, with the “economics of revenge” and a daughter’s search for her mother. It is told in Julavits’s signature style: sharp-eyed, sardonic, hilarious.

headline: Means of Escape
text: There is an ancient class of vessels, found in Roman tombs, called lachrymatories: tiny glass flasks, often shaped like tears, into which mourners are said to have collected the spill of their weeping eyes. This entrancing image flitted through my mind as I read Peter Cameron’s new novel, “Coral Glynn.” By the end of this sad, beautiful, absorbing story of love missed, love lost, love found, I was thinking that this must be what it’s like to slip into a bath of hot tears.

headline: The Devil They Know
text: “Satantango,” the latest novel by the Hungarian writer Laszlo Krasznahorkai to be translated into English, takes place over a few rain-sodden days in a dying hamlet. The local estate has been closed, its animals hocked, its mill shut down. Perhaps a dozen residents remain. Like the surrounding buildings, they are rife with rot.

headline: Unwinnable Wars
text: Irina Ellison, a 30-year-old university lecturer, has seen her father die from Huntington’s disease, his motor skills destroyed, his memory erased. Genetic testing has told her she is likely to meet the same fate. Cleaning out her father’s study after his death, she finds a letter to a Russian chess champion named Aleksandr Bezetov in which her father asked: How do you play a game when you know it is lost from the start? Aleksandr never replied. “Looking for a last adventure” and moved by the “alluring symmetry” of finding answers to her father’s question, Irina decamps to Russia to track down the chess player and demand an answer.

headline: Against Interpretation
text: In courts and law schools across America, the most intense legal battles are fought over theories of constitutional interpretation. From the originalists on the right to the living constitutionalists on the left, each of the warring camps claims that it has discovered the true faith and accuses its opponents of hypocrisy. Now comes Judge J. Harvie Wilkinson III with a bracingly clear and bipartisan message: All the theories are bunk! According to Wilkinson’s “Cosmic Constitutional Theory,” “the theories have given rise to nothing less than competing schools of liberal and conservative judicial activism, schools that have little in common other than a desire to seek theoretical cover for prescribed and often partisan results.” As a result of their cosmic theorizing, Wilkinson concludes, liberal and conservative judges and justices are too quick to second-guess the choices of legislatures, and the casualty is “our inalienable right of self-governance.”

headline: Without Gods
text: During the 19th and early 20th centuries, religion lost influence, but the religious impulse lingered on. Some people sought salvation in the secular religions of politics — in Communism, fascism and various utopian experiments. Others saw artists, musicians and writers as Holy Men, who could provide transcendence and meaning, revealing timeless truths on how to live.

headline: Reclaiming the Kremlin
text: A joke from Soviet times describes the minister of agriculture on a trip to Sweden, marveling at the acres of irrigated hothouses, the markets piled high with vegetables and fruits, comparing this profusion with the barren shelves of home.

headline: Putin’s List
text: Were an announcement made by President Obama that the White House intended to draw up a list of 100 books all Americans would be made to study and then be tested on, few would mistake it for a surefire vote winner. But during this year’s presidential campaign season, another candidate evidently thought it was. In January, during the run-up to Russia’s March 4 election, the front-runner, Vladimir Putin, proposed “a canon of 100 Russian books that every school leaver will be required to read at home . . . and then write an essay about one of them.” Reading, according to Putin, is not just an elective individual activity, but one that has decisive implications for the nation. “State policy with regard to culture must provide appropriate guidelines,” he wrote in an essay in the Nezavisimaya Gazeta newspaper, and culture shapes “public consciousness and . . . patterns of behavior.” The Kremlin’s duty, Putin explained, is to counter the decline in literacy and restore Russia as “a reading nation.”

headline: Up Front
text: Cristina García’s fiction — from her first novel, “Dreaming in Cuban,” through her fifth, “The Lady Matador’s Hotel” — is known for traversing continents, cultures and generations, and for telling the stories of families, friends and strangers thrown to­gether and torn apart in uncertain times. “This age of upheaval, dislocation and migration offers extraordinary and unprecedented opportunities for human reinvention,” she said via e-mail. “How does one construct and reconstruct identity in a changing world? This has remained my core obsession from my very first book.”

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: GODS WITHOUT MEN,  by Hari Kunzru (Knopf, $26.95.) Related stories, spanning centuries and continents, and all tethered to a desert rock formation, emphasize interconnectivity across time and space in Kunzru’s relentlessly modern fourth novel.

headline: Paperback Row
text: 1861: The Civil War Awakening,  by Adam Goodheart (Vintage, $16.) Goodheart’s exhilarating account leads us through the months between Abraham Lincoln’s election to the presidency in 1860 — followed quickly by the secession of the Confederate States — and July 4, 1861, when Lincoln delivered his first message to Congress, laying out the case for war.

headline: When the Voice in Your Head Just Keeps Talking
text: ARDENT, even obsessive, fans of the novelist David Foster Wallace almost rival their idol in the torrents of words they use to detail their devotion. And if there is one constant within this torrent, it’s the extent to which readers see their own consciousness reflected in his novels and essays. Writing in 2008, soon after Wallace hanged himself at 46, A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times of Wallace’s astounding voice: “Hyperarticulate, plaintive, self-mocking, diffident, overbearing, needy, ironical, almost pathologically self-aware (and nearly impossible to quote in increments smaller than a thousand words) — it was something you instantly recognized even hearing it for the first time. It was — is — the voice in your own head.”

headline: The Possibility of an Island
text: "You want to know why I am the way I am?" Zita Cobb asked. She’s a slender woman in her early 50s, with close cropped hair that gives her a certain iron-pixie mien. She has the distinct composure one often finds in people who’ve done well in the business world, brisk good humor layered over a fierce intensity. She was speaking in her office in a small building on Fogo Island, a freckle of land that lies off the northeast corner of Newfoundland, Canada, with a population of 2,700 or so scattered across a series of fishing communities with names like Seldom, Joe Batt’s Arm and Tilting. It’s a place so singular and remote that it has its own peculiar time zone, 1.5 hours ahead of Eastern Standard Time — though in truth it feels like it’s hundreds of years behind: when it’s 10 p.m. in New York, it’s 1825 on Fogo Island.

headline: Apple and Google: Redwoods in the Web Garden
text: The consumer Internet was thought to be a verdant garden where thousands, and perhaps millions, of flowers would bloom. Much of that has come to pass, but the Web turns out to be a mighty fine place for giant redwoods as well. Apple and Google — with a combined market capitalization of about $750 billion — have become so large that they all but blot out the sun, threatening to leave offline businesses struggling in the shadows to survive.

headline: Desserts to Your Door, From Baking Bean
text: Clarice Lam (right), the executive chef of The Chocolate Room, in Park Slope and Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, has introduced her own oven-to-door pastry service, with delivery throughout New York City. Called The Baking Bean (her nickname is Bean, for her runway-ready figure), it takes orders by phone and online for an array of cakes, pies, tarts, cookies, croissants, chocolate bark and other candies, none of which duplicate what Ms. Lam makes for the Chocolate Room.

headline: Leading Off: Ignominy Makes N.C.A.A. Visit
text: You know the N.C.A.A. tournament is off to a wobbly start when the banner moment of the first day of its Round of 64 was a Connecticut player missing a meaningless dunk at the end of an ignominious defeat for the defending champion, followed by No. 1 seed Syracuse staving off an even more ignoble fate by the length of a misguided referee’s whistle. On each sideline, there were two suddenly old men raging against the universe, and their crowning achievement is Jim Boeheim can say he didn’t become the coach of the first No. 1 team to be bounced by a No. 16. How inspiring.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Teens From ‘Bully’ Protest R Rating, and Lessons of ‘Kony 2012’
text: Teenagers and parents who appear in the documentary “Bully” made a personal appeal to Christopher Dodd, the head of the Motion Picture Association of America, to change the movie’s rating to PG-13 from R, The Hollywood Reporter reported. The film, which was produced by Harvey Weinstein, who joined the parents, tells the story of bullying in middle school and high school. It received the R rating because of some of the language used, which is particularly unfortunate, the parents say, because it means those who most need to see the movie, won’t be able to.

headline: Morgan Stanley Chief Told Managers Not to Exploit Goldman’s Woes
text: Greg Smith can probably scratch Morgan Stanley off his list of future employers.

headline: Image of the Day: March 16
text: Indian batsman Sachin Tendulkar becomes the first cricketer to score 100 centuries in international cricket.

headline: The Limits of a Duty of Trust and Confidence
text: To prove insider trading, the government must show that passing the information involved a breach of a duty of “trust and confidence” to maintain its confidentiality. The Securities and Exchange Commission filed civil charges  that test the limits of what can constitute that duty when it accused a broker of trading on and passing information he learned through a relationship formed at Alcoholics Anonymous.

text: Phoenix

headline: In Delhi, Business Leaders Greet Budget With Grumbles
text: They came dressed mournfully in dark blazers to watch the finance minister of India deliver the federal government budget for the forthcoming financial year.

headline: Reading Club | ‘Navigating Love and Autism’
text: Update: Deadline extended to April 6.

text: 4:02 p.m. | Updated  to add report from Seattle.12:02 p.m. | Updated to add brief report from San Francisco Apple store.

headline: For Ryan Braun, the Road Awaits
text: PHOENIX – There were two roster sheets on the bulletin board in the Milwaukee Brewers’ clubhouse Thursday. One was the travel list for a charity game in Tucson, the other the travel list for a game in Surprise, Ariz. The players traveling were highlighted in yellow. Ryan Braun’s name was not highlighted at all.

headline: Big Ticket | Sold for $17,070,000
text: A three-apartment penthouse combination that sold for $17.07 million in the Laureate on the Upper West Side was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: At War Shout Back: The Sergeant, the Strain of War and a Call for Your Thoughts
text: A clearer, though still quite incomplete, picture is emerging of the American staff sergeant accused in the killings of 16 Afghan villagers on Sunday in the Panjwai district of Kandahar Province.

headline: The View From St. Bonaventure: Two Teams to Cheer For
text: Throughout the N.C.A.A. tournament, The Quad will feature posts from reporters at newspapers on campuses of teams that have the potential to be the Cinderellas of 2012. Pete Thamel of The Times has a story on St. Bonaventure here.

headline: Drunken Fruit Flies
text: Male fruit flies that were denied the opportunity to mate turned to alcohol more often than those that were permitted to copulate, scientists find.

headline: Inside the List
text: APOCALYPSE THEN: The historian Elaine Pagels has been a popular, though polarizing, figure ever since she introduced readers to early competing views of Christianity in her 1979 book “The Gnostic Gospels,” which won the National Book Award and the National Book Critics Circle Award. That book, her first for a mainstream audience, received a mostly dismissive review in our pages from the Rev. Raymond E. Brown, a biblical scholar and Catholic priest who concluded, in his last sentence, that the gnostics’ chief adversary, “crusty old Irenaeus,” had been “right, after all, to regard the gnostics as the crazies of the second century.” But Pagels’s analysis of the early church struck a nerve, and not just at the time. As Laura Miller noted recently in Salon, a “badly garbled version” turned up in “The Da Vinci Code” in 2003 and “proceeded to blow the minds of many readers.” Coincidentally (or not), 2003 is also the year Pagels scored her first New York Times best seller, “Beyond Belief: The Secret Gospel of Thomas.” Her next book, a study of Judas written with the Harvard professor Karen King, also landed here, in 2007, and now Pagels is back. Her latest effort, “Revelations: Visions, Prophecy, and Politics in the Book of Revelation,” enters the hardcover nonfiction list at No. 10. Reviewing the book in The New Yorker this month, Adam Gopnik highlighted Pagels’s argument that Revelation is “essentially an anti-Christian polemic . . . written by an expatriate follower of Jesus who wanted the movement to remain within an entirely Jewish context, as opposed to the ‘Christianity’ just then being invented.” Gopnik continued: “The scarlet whores and mad beasts in Revelation are the Gentile followers of Paul — and so, in a neat irony, the spiritual ancestors of today’s Protestant evangelicals.”

headline: Business Day Live | March 16, 2012
text: India’s plan to tackle public debt, and Apple’s new iPad goes on sale.

headline: The Gay Film That Changed Your Life
text: With several new books, films and film series, gay people are trying to preserve their film history at a time when young gay audiences and mainstream Hollywood alike don’t seem interested in becoming consumers or conservators of gay cinema, as this article from Arts & Leisure documents. To get a sense of which gay films are worth another look, or a first one, ArtsBeat asked several notable figures to talk about the gay film that changed their lives. Their answers, edited and excerpted below, ranged from the traditional (“Boys in the Band”) to the daring (“Querelle”) to the head-scratching (“Bless the Beasts and the Children”). Leave your own answers in the comments section.

headline: Keepers of the Gay Film Legacy
text: IN front of the IFC Center in the West Village on a recent Monday night a largely gay crowd waited in line for a sold-out screening. It wasn’t the latest gay rom-com that had packed them in but rather “Come Back to the Five and Dime, Jimmy Dean, Jimmy Dean,” Robert Altman’s 1982 film, based on Ed Graczyk’s 1976 play, about female friends who reunite at a Texas Woolworth’s on the 20th anniversary of James Dean’s death. The film’s gay cred is considerable: besides starring Cher — goddess to drag queens everywhere — it features Karen Black as a sympathetic transsexual character.

headline: Vengeful Streak Puts Ivanovic on a Winning Streak
text: INDIAN WELLS, Calif. — Ana Ivanovic is generally regarded as one of the nicest people in tennis. With a quick smile and an approachability perhaps betrayed by her model-like looks, Ivanovic, a former W.T.A. No. 1 and 2008 French Open champion, manages to stay polite and above the media cattiness that can ensnare other players of her caliber.

headline: Parental Quandary: My Son’s Girlfriend Is Bulimic
text: D.’s son’s girlfriend is sick, and both she and her son know it. After every meal she eats in D.’s house, she throws up in the bathroom. There’s no mystery here: D’s son knows his girlfriend has a problem, and he’s talked to her about it. D.’s older son’s girlfriend has talked to her — and even recommended a therapist. But nothing has changed. D. feels like she should do something — but what?

headline: Subaru Recalls 320,000 Foresters to Replace Noncompliant Part on Rear Seat Belt
text: Subaru is recalling about 320,000 of its 2009-12 Foresters because the rear seat belt may not securely hold a child safety seat or restraint, the automaker informed the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

headline: Washington Square South, 10:31 A.M.
text: A meal for hawks, high above Washington Square Park.

headline: Crispy Chips and Tostadas: From the Microwave?
text: The traditional tostada is made by toasting or frying a tortilla into a crispy flat chip that is covered with beans, cheese and other toppings. But in this week’s Recipes for Health, Martha Rose Shulman comes up with a surprising solution for cooks who don’t want to deep-fry their dinner but still enjoy a crispy tostada. Ms. Shulman makes the case that the microwave is the perfect place to make crispy and healthful tostadas and tortilla chips.

headline: Business Day Live: The New iPad Goes on Sale
text: India’s plan to tackle public debt, and Apple‘s new iPad goes on sale.

headline: Where Divorce Can Be Denied, Orthodox Jews Look to Prenuptial Contracts
text: CHICAGO — Before a packed house of 350 men and women at a Jewish educational center, Beverly Siegel suggested three questions that religious Jewish women should ask before divorcing: “Do I get a get? Do I not get a get? Hmm, what kind of get should I get?”

headline: Vain Glorious | Thakoon for Nars
text: In one of the season’s more colorful collaborations, the designer Thakoon Panichgul of Thakoon has made a limited-edition series of lacquers for Nars based on the brights from his spring runway. “The prints in that collection were inspired by the rich color palette of India — the spices, the holy festivals,” Panichgul says. According to the designer, when the Nars team, who did the beauty look for the show, first saw the color boards, “we immediately realized that it made perfect sense to do a nail project together.” The Thakoon for Nars polishes ($18) will be available May 1. Go to narscosmetics.com.

headline: Dance in India
text: Scenes from Nrityagram, a village far from the madding crowd that is completely given over to the pursuit of dance.

headline: In India, Eternal Rhythms Embody a National Spirit
text: NRITYAGRAM, India

headline: Economic Indicator: Where You Eat
text: The relative sales trends of different types of restaurants provide an indication of the health of the economy. When Americans feel better about their finances, they are more likely to eat at restaurants with full service, including bringing the food to the table, rather than at restaurants with limited service. At the moment, both the restaurant sales and the falling unemployment rate indicate the economy is doing better than the Gross Domestic Product figures would seem to show.

headline: Barcelona and Real Madrid on Opposite Sides of Champions League Draw
text: Barcelona will take on Milan in the quarterfinals of the UEFA Champions League in the highest profile of four matchups drawn Friday morning in Switzerland. The first legs of the home-and-home quarterfinals will be played March 27 and 28, with the returns on April 3 and 4.

headline: In Sit-Down Restaurants, an Economic Indicator
text: Have you been eating more at restaurants with waiters rather than fast-food joints?

headline: The Rookie of the Year, One Year Wiser
text: ONE year later there was no jaw-dropping upset, no demure acceptance speech, no fresh affront to Justin Bieber’s watchful fan cabal. This time around Esperanza Spalding caused less of a stir at the Grammy Awards, where she’d prevailed as best new artist in 2011, shocking a field that included Mr. Bieber and another platinum-selling megastar, the rapper-crooner Drake.

headline: Live Updates: N.C.A.A. Men’s Tournament, Day 2 of Round 2
text: The second full day of the men’s N.C.A.A. basketball tournament features 16 games. Zach Hillesland will bring you up to speed with live updates. For the latest scores and full schedule of games, view our live scoreboard.

headline: Worries for Wizards
text: The Chinese company with the license to make Harry Potter clothing has run into a bit of a problem. Its auditor quit with a letter that makes it sound as if it suspects fraud.

headline: Weekend Fare
text: Saturday is St. Patrick’s Day, and here are some specials at restaurants across the city — from flowing taps of beer to boiled bacon and cabbage:

headline: Jury Finds Spying in Rutgers Dorm Was a Hate Crime
text: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J. — A former Rutgers University student was convicted on Friday on all 15 charges he had faced for using a webcam to spy on his roommate having sex with another man, a verdict poised to broaden the definition of hate crimes in an era when laws have not kept up with evolving technology.

headline: Mortal Cops Cling to Life on the Air
text: A RECENT episode of the police drama “Southland” ended with a gang member stabbing Detective Lydia Adams in the stomach during a routine arrest. Only the audience knew she was pregnant and running late for an ob-gyn checkup.

headline: An Outsider Who Followed His Own Path
text: SEVEN years ago, at his home in Marino, Italy, near Rome, the enormously prolific German composer Hans Werner Henze fell into a mysterious semi-coma. Weeks went by without signs of improvement. All thought the end was near, and goodbyes were said. After two months, to everyone’s surprise, Mr. Henze suddenly woke up, rose from his bed and calmly went back to work on his 15th opera, “Phaedra.”

text: PORTLAND, Ore.

headline: How Wall Street Has Fared After Bear’s Fall
text: Friday is the four-year anniversary of Bear Stearns‘s fire sale to JPMorgan Chase for $2 a share, one of the signal moments of the financial crisis.

headline: Monkey Bar’s Belinda Chang Resurfaces
text: Belinda Chang, who had many people in the restaurant business wondering where she went after leaving Monkey Bar about two months ago, is back on the scene. She has become the beverage director for the Culinary Concepts Hospitality Group, a company in partnership with Starwood Hotels that uses menus created by Jean-Georges Vongerichten.

headline: Dear FloFab: What’s the Etiquette for the Tight-Table Squeeze?
text: Florence Fabricant gives advice on the fine points of entertaining at home and eating in restaurants. Have a dining dilemma? Ask FloFab.

headline: Mar. 19 — 24
text: THE Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden’s striking but bunkerlike circular Washington building, designed by Gordon Bunshaft, has prompted many an artist and designer to dream of intervention. Next year, if things stay on track, the museum will realize a long-planned project to cover its interior courtyard with a temporary inflatable bubble, an architectural soufflé that will meld the outside and inside of the museum and provide space for installations and performances. But in the nearer term the doughnut-shaped structure will become the plaything of the artist Doug Aitken, who is turning it into a movie in the round.

headline: The Attack on Voting Rights
text: I’ve written fairly often here about voter ID laws. Republican-controlled state legislatures frame these measures as attempts to combat voter fraud (a fictitious problem). But it’s an open secret that they disproportionately affect minorities, the poor and other groups who tend to support Democratic candidates, making it more difficult for them to participate in elections.

headline: The View From Duke: Are the Blue Devils Underrated?
text: Is it possible the Duke Blue Devils may be underrated heading into the N.C.A.A. tournament?

headline: Bell Canada Agrees to Buy Astral Media for $3.4 Billion
text: OTTAWA — Bell Canada, Canada’s largest telecommunications company, extended its move into the media business on Friday by agreeing to pay 3.38 billion Canadian dollars (about $3.4 billion) for Astral Media, the owner of several prominent cable television channels including HBO Canada.

headline: Author, Author!
text: In 1861, a former slave named Harriet Jacobs published her autobiography, adding her “testimony to that of abler pens to convince the people of the Free States what Slavery really [was].” Quoting the book of Isaiah, she asked her audience to “give ear unto” her “speech” as she told the tale of her escape from bondage.

headline: The Druids
text: An Irish band sympathetic to the I.R.A. perform at Kelly Ryan's Bar in the Bronx.

headline: The Butterfly Plans a Summer Landing
text: In the Altamarea Group of restaurants (Marea, Ai Fiori and others), Eben Freeman is to cocktails and drinks what Michael White is to food. As “head of bar operations and innovation,” he has taken the lead in The Butterfly, a small restaurant and bar scheduled to open this summer.

headline: Dynegy Defends Its Actions After Accusations of ‘Fraudulent’ Transfer
text: Dynegy is striking back.

headline: The View From St. Louis: Billikens, Explained
text: During the N.C.A.A. tournament, The Quad will feature posts from reporters at newspapers on campuses of teams that have the potential to be the Cinderellas of 2012.

headline: Look of The Moment | Léa Seydoux
text: The Look: Plum Brandy. A jewel-tone top with a modest neckline and long sleeves tucks sleekly into the cinched waist of a full gypsy skirt.

headline: At SXSW, Springsteen Draws an All-Star Guest List
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — Bruce Springsteen, of all people, used the word “Twitterverse” during his South by Southwest concert at ACL-Live at the Moody Theater, a 2,700-capacity room here where the public television series Austin City Limits is staged. On Thursday morning in his SXSW keynote speech he had praised the Animals, particularly the song “We Gotta Get Out of This Place” — about the son of a hard-working father, looking for a better life — as the source for “every song I’ve ever written.” (The Animals didn’t write the song; it’s by Barry Mann and Cynthia Weil.) Mr. Springsteen then demonstrated how similar the Animals’ bass line in “Don’t Let Me Be Misunderstood” was to the one in his own “Badlands,” accusing himself of “successful theft” (although he actually switched it from a minor to a major key and changed its contour.)

headline: Will Lin Start? The New Coach Says Yes
text: 1:16 a.m. | Updated Jeremy Lin would be starting for the Knicks at point guard Friday night. Of that, there was no doubt, Coach Mike Woodson said before the game.

headline: Fans Rush Back for the Return of ‘Community’
text: Maybe absence really does lead to fondness: The return of NBC’s cult-favorite “Community” on Thursday night generated the show’s best ratings for this season by far, and the best entertainment numbers for NBC in that time period in 14 months.

headline: Clooney Among Protesters Arrested at Sudan’s Embassy in Washington
text: The actor George Clooney, his father, Nick Clooney, and Representative James P. Moran of Virginia were among more than a dozen protesters arrested Friday outside the Sudanese Embassy in Washington. The arrests were confirmed by a spokeswoman for the congressman and a spokesman for the Secret Service, which made the arrests.

headline: Fresh Takes on the Job Market for the Unemployed
text: Ron Lieber, the Your Money columnist, appeared on the WNYC radio program The Takeaway on Friday to discuss listeners’ stories about being unemployed and trying to get back into the job market. Callers asked about moving to take a new job, supplementing income after a cut in pay and starting a small business. You can listen to the complete segment here.

headline: With Visit to Goldman, Bloomberg Says, Chin Up
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg thought Goldman Sachs could use a friend.

headline: Green Bay Looks to Play Bigger than Seeding
text: Wisconsin-Green Bay’s women’s basketball team is done questioning the N.C.A.A.’s wisdom in seeding it seventh in the Kingston region. The Phoenix felt they merited a better seed, due to their 30-1 record and winning the Horizon League’s regular season and tournament titles.

headline: Book Review Podcast: David Oshinsky on Lawrence v. Texas
text: This week, David Oshinsky discusses the landmark U.S. Supreme Court case Lawrence v. Texas; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; Bill Keller talks about two new books examining Vladimir Putin; Phillip Lopate remembers the critic John Leonard; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news.

headline: TimesCast | March 16, 2012
text: The leader of the Anglican Church announces his resignation | The author Jonathan Haidt on why America is so divided.

headline: Disney’s ‘Alice’ Musical Is Said to Hire Rob Ashford
text: The Broadway director and choreographer Rob Ashford (“How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying”) has been hired for a stage musical adaptation of Tim Burton’s 2010 film version of “Alice in Wonderland,” according to Variety. A spokesman for the producer, Disney Theatrical Productions, declined to comment on Friday, and Mr. Ashford did not return a phone call seeking comment.

headline: Morgan Miller and Minh Nguyen
text: RELATIONSHIPS born of the passion and excitement of the presidential campaign trail are known to be fickle. With ballots counted and confetti swept away, only the most resilient survive the succeeding election cycles.

headline: First Woman to Win Man Asian Prize Condemns North Korea, China
text: HONG KONG — Kyung-sook Shin, the first woman to win the Man Asian Literary Prize, used the black-tie gala dinner in Hong Kong on Thursday to make a statement about North Korea.
