headline: Draw Something, a New Twist on Pictionary, Charms Mobile Gamers
text: Every so often, a new mobile gaming craze sweeps across smartphone screens around the world — think Angry Birds, Words With Friends, Tiny Tower.

headline: Trees Up for Grabs in New York City
text: New York City will start giving away trees on Saturday, just in time for spring planting.

headline: How to Be a Pioneer Woman Without Ever Leaving the Couch
text: Every night before I peel the plastic seal off a cup of tapioca and watch “The Real Housewives of Beverly Hills” on my big-screen TV, I read a chapter of “Little House in the Big Woods” to my daughters, who are 5 and 3. For the first few chapters, Pa mostly tramps around in the woods, shooting at things. First Pa shoots a deer and smokes the meat. Next he catches a bunch of fish and salts the meat. One lucky day, he wanders up on a bear that’s about to eat a pig. He shoots the bear, then lugs it home, along with the bonus pig. The family celebrates!

headline: Obama Calls Karzai and Reaffirms Withdrawal Date
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama called President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan early on Friday morning and reaffirmed with him that American troops will complete their withdrawal by the end of 2014, the White House said in a statement.

headline: Yanks’ Pettitte, 39, Signs On for Comeback
text: TAMPA, Fla. — Saying he was “ready to go back to work,” Andy Pettitte announced Friday that he was returning to the Yankees.

headline: Dennis Kozlowski’s Homecoming, of Sorts
text: Nearly seven years after he reported to prison, L. Dennis Kozlowski has a view of Central Park from his home once again — only the new place is a little smaller.

headline: Who Made That Lawn Mower?
text: Before a British inventor named Edwin Beard Budding conceived of the mower, the cropped lawn was the province of the landed gentry, who would employ teams of men to trim grass with scythes. But lawn care was far from Budding’s mind when he invented the push mower. His original brief was to solve a mechanical problem for a clothing mill regarding the production of guardsmen’s uniforms. Budding was asked to come up with a way to “cut all the tufts and bobbly bits off the nap of the cloth,” writes Brian Radam in “Lawn Mowers and Grasscutters: A Complete Guide.” Budding soon realized the device had other applications. In 1830, he filed a patent for a machine that, when pushed and pulled, would cause a cylindrical blade to rotate over a stationary shear, cutting grass and collecting the clippings. The mower may have put the scythe men out of work, but it enabled the English fashion for grass carpets.

headline: The 3.4.12 Issue
text: How flattering to have the world’s best newspaper dedicate an issue to our very own capital city. . . . [It is] a beautifully photographed, earnestly researched cultural brochure for Manhattanites who have bought their Olympic Games tickets and booked rooms at the Dorchester but remain anxious not to make a faux pas. . . . Most bizarre was the advice that the item that could best illustrate the notorious expense of London was the price of a box of imported Lucky Charms (a kind of sugary American cereal). Apparently, they sell for $14 in a [Primrose Hill] grocery. Believing this to be typical of the cost of eating in London could lead many an innocent American to make an expensive mistake. And this summer, there’ll be no shortage of unapologetic London shopkeepers, hoteliers and cabbies to help them make it.

headline: Why Are They Always Apologizing?
text: Your exquisitely perceptive article on Londoners gets everything right, except what they really mean by “sorry” — although the writer is correct in concluding that it doesn’t mean “sorry.” When I emigrated to New York in 1959 (from Essex, no less), I was repeatedly asked why I was always apologizing, whereupon I stopped saying “sorry” and asked myself the same question. Clearly, I realized, it means, “Whatever you or I just did to the other and whose fault it is, let’s just forget about it and move on.” Not bad for one word.

headline: 'Oh London, You Drama Queen'
text: This year’s Olympics are going to be magnificent. Only a minority of people share your snobbery toward the Games (which is evident by the number of people who tried to get tickets). The fact remains that although there will be inconveniences, the majority of Londoners cannot wait to welcome the world to their city. Because let’s face it, this city and it’s people are pretty bloody fantastic! Down with the gloomsters!

headline: Midtown’s Irish Elite
text: For the last five years, Billy Redmond has been the proud owner of a million-dollar apartment in the heart of Manhattan. “I’ve been in it once,” he said. “It’s lovely!” We were sitting 3,000 miles away, talking property on a drizzly winter evening, over a pint at a famous Dublin pub called Doheny & Nesbitt. Redmond, a balding and gregarious insurance broker, was explaining his reasons for buying, sight unseen, a condominium unit in a project called the Centria, in a city he had visited only twice, briefly, as a tourist.

headline: Minority Report
text: My daughter’s biological father is Hispanic; the man I married when she was a year old, and who subsequently adopted her, is white, as am I. Now she’s a teenager. While filling out her school applications, I checked the box marked Hispanic. My husband felt that was dishonest, saying she is not culturally Hispanic. Furthermore, he says, she is not suffering from any disadvantages as a result of her family’s background and she doesn’t need any special consideration. I say we should simply offer the truth. What do you think? NAME WITHHELD

headline: True Londoners Are Extinct
text: This charming, chatty article [by Craig Taylor], much like the city itself, in which one becomes immersed in a series of local scenes and remarks, seems to have aroused angst on both sides of the Atlantic. When I was a teenager 30 years ago, London was my first trip alone from home. The weather was awful, the food was awful and the 6-pound-a-night hotel was awful — and I fell instantly in love. Comparisons with New York, Paris, Dubuque, anywhere else, are odious. London is an ancient artifact, a unique collection of ever evolving cultural habits, a collection of people joined by the common interest of liking the idea of it. Even the Welsh boy Dylan Thomas saw in her “the long friends, the grains beyond age, the dark veins of her mother.” For the open-minded, it is alwaysa delight.

headline: Building the American Dream in China
text: Daniel Gillen is afraid of heights. The young American architect didn’t think to tell me this until we had already climbed up a construction ladder and started walking gingerly across the curved roof of an unfinished building in northeastern China.

headline: How My Daughters Learned to Eat Like the French
text: When we first moved to France, social gatherings involving food made me anxious. Despite their French father, our daughters had thoroughly North American eating habits; Sophie, 5, and Claire, 2, often whined (a serious faux pas), reacted negatively to food being served (even worse) or refused to eat (the worst offense of all). But our family’s invitation to a reunion dinner with Philippe’s university friends was nonnegotiable.

headline: What a Buyer Wants
text: LUXURY ROOFTOP GARDENS

headline: Is Tammy Baldwin Our First Gay Senator?
text: When writing about your Senate campaign in Wisconsin, the press consistently refers to you as the “first out lesbian” elected to Congress. Are we to assume that Congress is full of closeted lesbians?  That’s never been the way I’ve construed it. I think it was written in a similar fashion when I was first running for the State Assembly back in 1992. So much attention was focused on whether the electorate was ready, whether this sort of history could be made.

headline: In Havana, Family-Run Dining Goes Upscale
text: ON a mild January night, the unlighted street in the artsy Havana neighborhood of Vedado was quiet and filled with shadows. But as my companions and I climbed the steps of Le Chansonnier, the glow of chandeliers gleamed invitingly through the wrought-iron windows, and a low burble of music drifted onto the street.

headline: Private Dining in Havana
text: Family-run restaurants are gaining popularity in Cuba’s capital city.

headline: ‘Napoleon’ Is Lost, Long Live ‘Napoleon’!
text: SOON after Abel Gance’s “Napoleon” had its premiere in Paris in 1927, he wrote a letter to his audience, soliciting open eyes and hearts. “I have made,” he wrote, “a tangible effort toward a somewhat richer and more elevated form of cinema.” He had created a film towering in ambition, scale, cost, narrative and technical innovations, and believed that nothing less than “the future of the cinema” was at stake. His audacity had merit. The origins of the widescreen image can be traced to “Napoleon,” which also featured hand-held camerawork, eye-blink-fast editing, gorgeous tints, densely layered superimpositions and images shot from a pendulum, a sled, a bicycle and a galloping horse.

headline: Day 2 at South by Southwest
text: Scenes from the South by Southwest Music festival in Austin, Tex.

headline: A Forecast for Low Returns, and Advice for Investors
text: THE stock market seems to have found its footing lately, touching levels not seen since early 2008.

headline: Sleepwalking in Fantasy Worlds Like This One
text: SARA DRIVER, the subject of a series that begins at Anthology Film Archives this week, recently confessed to feeling a bit sheepish about the idea of a retrospective in her honor. Her compact body of work is composed of two features, one medium-length film and a short, and she has not directed since 1994. “Instead of a retrospective I’m calling it a flashback,” she said with a laugh.

headline: Slide Show: Scenes From Day 2 of the South by Southwest Music Festival
text: More Photographs

headline: Jean Renoir’s Plunge Into the American Mire
text: A RIVER runs through the work of Jean Renoir, manifesting itself in various forms — from the Seine in “Boudu Saved From Drowning” (1932) that delivers a force of nature disguised as a shambling bum to the doorstep of a bourgeois bookseller to the Ganges that curls through the background of “The River” (1951), providing an eternal context to the story of a first love.

headline: F1 and Its Champions Hit the Track in Melbourne
text: MELBOURNE — Formula One cars hit the race track Friday for the first time this season in the opening practice sessions for the Australian Grand Prix on Sunday. Just about the only certainty in the results was that the record six world champions taking part in the series this year are, for their part, in top shape.

headline: A Rare Setback for Maryland Lacrosse
text: The No. 6 Maryland Terrapins women’s lacrosse team has surely gone through some highs and lows this past week. After a shoddy offensive performance led to a late-game loss to No. 4 Syracuse on Saturday, the Terps made a complete 180 and dominated Richmond Tuesday night in an 18-9 win.

headline: Supreme Court to Release Same-Day Recordings of Health Care Arguments
text: 5:23 p.m. | Updated The Supreme Court announced on Friday that it would release same-day audio recordings of the arguments over the constitutionality of the health care overhaul law.  The arguments will be heard over three days starting on March 26.

headline: Share a Car, Risk Your Insurance
text: At first glance, the idea of person-to-person car sharing appears to be the perfect solution to any number of problems.

headline: He Was Robbed, Then Became Champion
text: Before Sergio Martinez became a most unlikely boxing world champion, he spent his formative years as the most likely robbery victim in the small Argentine barrio he called home. Thieves did not rob Martinez once, or twice. They robbed him at least 10 times.

headline: Caucus Click: A Place for Romney at Breakfast
text: A waitress taking orders while a crew from Fox News sets up before a Romney campaign event on Friday at Pancakes Eggcetera restaurant in Rosemont, Ill.

headline: Crash and Boom
text: On a rainy Saturday night in Lisbon, A Vizinha, a rustic cafe lined with tins of sardines and sacks of rice, was packed with the city’s young style set — new-media girls in baggy sweaters and floral scarves, skinny boys with fussy facial hair and engineer caps. They had come here, to Bica, a grubby hillside neighborhood, for a show: an organist, David Maranha, and jazz drummer, Gabriel Ferrandini, were churning out a chaotic and deafening soundscape. It growled and hummed, shrieked and snapped, above a single-note drone from a maxed-out little amp.

headline: Help Us Choose Our Summer Movies Cover
text: Few special sections of The New York Times promise as much escapist pleasure as the annual Summer Movies issue of Arts & Leisure. As a result, the editors usually commission an illustration — illo is the in-house term of art — for the cover that tends to be playful, wistful or just plain fun. This spring, we asked students at the Savannah College of Art and Design to submit their own illustrations to be considered for the cover of this year’s section, which will be published the first week of May. Some 100 entries were narrowed down by faculty members, and 25 were sent to The Times. Our editors narrowed the field down to 10 finalists, and here are their submissions.

headline: In New York City, Island Music Dance Clubs
text: Where to go in New York to hear island music.

headline: ‘This American Life’ Retracts Episode on Apple’s Suppliers in China
text: 5:23 p.m. | Updated The weekly public radio program “This American Life” said on Friday that it was retracting a critical report about Apple’s suppliers in China because the storyteller, Mike Daisey, had embellished details in the narrative.

headline: The Clubs of Curaçao
text: The island has several places to watch and dance to live music.

headline: Sampling Caribbean Sounds
text: The Caribbean doubles as a stunningly prolific and diverse music studio. Every island produces a home-grown soundtrack, inimitable in language, accent, tempo and rhythm. Jamaica’s is the one you know best. Roots reggae in the vein of Bob Marley is still alive and well, but to truly experience contemporary Jamaican music, visit the capital, Kingston, and get to know dancehall music at one of the city’s nightly street dances, like Weddy Weddy Wednesday on Burlington Avenue, at the home base of Stone Love, one of Jamaica’s most famous sound systems. Or spend an evening at Club Fiction (67 Constant Spring Road; 876-631-8038; fictionloungeja.com), where you’ll hear some of the island’s best D.J.’s spin the latest dancehall.

headline: Songs of Politics, Imported From Ireland
text: “Live music tonight,” read the little sign outside Kelly Ryan’s bar in the Bronx on Thursday. “The Druids, direct from Ireland.”

headline: 14 Music Videos From the Caribbean
text: For this week’s travel section, Baz Dreisinger writes about the island of Curaçao and its music scene. But the music scene can be heard all over the Caribbean. Below is a small sampling of some of the popular bands.

headline: Curaçao After Dark
text: ON one of many late nights in Curaçao, I found myself in a musical tower of Babel. The setting: a sleek iron-and-glass nightclub, Tu Tu Tango, near Willemstad, the Caribbean island’s capital. The crowd: well-heeled local men in their 30s, high-heeled ladies in skintight get-ups, Dutch women in sundresses, 20-somethings wearing gold chains and Yankees caps. The soundtrack: a mix of English, Spanish, hip-hop argot, Jamaican patois, Portuguese — or was that Papiamentu, Curaçao’s native Creole? Beats evoked Puerto Rico, Holland, Brazil, the Jersey Shore. Just when I felt primed to classify, the rhythm morphed and the language veered off to another continent.

headline: More Island Music: New York City
text: There is one Caribbean island that does not demand a long flight: Manhattan. The number of West Indians in New York City renders it unofficially tropical even during cruel winters, which means Caribbean music pervades the city’s night-life scene.

headline: The View from Detroit Mercy: Father and Son Lead Resurgence
text: Throughout the N.C.A.A. tournament, The Quad will feature posts from reporters at newspapers on campuses of teams that have the potential to be the Cinderellas of 2012.

headline: Niners Reportedly Competing for Peyton Manning
text: And you thought March Madness was limited to college basketball ….

headline: Local Previews of the London Games
text: MOST fans of the Olympic Games will be consigned to watch from their living room sofas or follow along on their office computers as the 2012 Summer Games in London begin this July.

headline: Peer-to-Peer Car-Sharing and Big Insurance Questions
text: In this weekend’s Your Money column, I look at the many insurance questions that come up about the burgeoning peer-to-peer car-sharing industry. The basic question is this: If you turn your car into a Zipcar, in effect, what are the odds that you could end up in some sort of trouble if someone rents your car and then crashes it and hurts someone?

headline: The Munchkins Are a Problem: Casting About for Poppies Among the Dorothys
text: The Drama Club has been formed and the next step in producing "The Wizard of Oz" for the fifth-grade play is casting. Helene Stapinski, a reluctant -- and inexperienced -- parent producer, marvels at the children's bravery. "How on earth can they get up there like that and sing in front of me?" she asks in the latest installment of "The Munchkins Are a Problem." "Don’t they know I have no idea what I’m doing? That each and every one of them is better than I could ever be?"

headline: Ivanovic vs. Bartoli: Breaking It Down
text: Ana Ivanovic walked to the baseline at 3-3, 40-15 in the first set of her quarter-final encounter with Marion Bartoli at the BNP Paribas Open in Indian Wells and rocked a 112 m.p.h. ace down the middle to hold serve.

headline: Billy Campbell, of AMC’s ‘The Killing,’ Enjoys Sailing Tall Ships
text: BILLY CAMPBELL, a leading man in AMC’s newest drama, “The Killing” (its second season starts April 1), didn’t have much sailing experience before 2000 when he signed up to be part of the crew of the Sorlandet, a 186-foot Norwegian square-rig sailing ship built in 1927.

headline: Another Comment About Your Comments on Comments
text: I wrote the other day about our comments policy and warned readers that moderators look out for obscenity, irrelevance, spamming, trolling, Hitlering and just plain uncalled-for personal meanness. Our community manager wrote a follow-up post answering some of your questions. And that, of course, led to even more questions.

headline: Despite Bold Talk on Syria, Turkey Sees Limits of Its Power
text: ISTANBUL — As the lethal crackdown by the Syrian government intensifies, Turkey has been struggling in the face of a spiraling crisis on its doorstep that is exposing the limits of its leadership in the region.

headline: 5 Spots for 7 Pitchers, One Named Pettitte
text: The news that the left-handed pitcher Andy Pettitte is coming out of retirement to attempt a comeback with the Yankees gave the team’s preseason a jolt of electricity.

headline: Cody Simpson Gets His Toys ‘R’ Us Moment
text: It’s been a busy week for Cody Simpson. The tween dream from Australia released a new single, “So Listen,” a collaboration with the hip-hop star T-Pain, and is in the studio wrapping up his first album. And he announced plans to join Big Time Rush on its summer tour. Next on the 15-year-old Simpson’s ascension to pop idol: the cover of a Toys “R” Us catalog.

headline: Golden Ticket
The Computer’s Next Conquest: Crosswords
text: What’s a 10-letter word for smarty pants?

headline: India’s Blast Inquiry Tests Ties to Israel and Iran
text: NEW DELHI — The Indian warrants issued this week for three Iranian citizens in connection with an attack last month in which assailants on a motorcycle attached a magnetic bomb to the back of an Israeli diplomatic vehicle here, coupled with new accusations about the bombing, seem certain to worsen the deepening crisis between Israel and Iran.

headline: Syrian Volunteers Pick Up Land Mines Planted by Their Army
text: Human Rights Watch called on Syrian government forces to stop planting land mines along the country’s borders with Turkey and Lebanon this week, citing the danger posed to refugees fleeing the violent crackdown on dissent in the country.

headline: Graphic Books Best Sellers: Teenage Dreams
text: On the hardcover list this week is “Superior” (at No. 8), written by Mark Millar and illustrated by Leinil Yu. The story is about a nerd with multiple sclerosis named Simon Pooni who finds himself with the powers of a fictional hero named Superior. The special abilities, however, come at a price.

headline: Four Artists, in Their Own Words
text: These four artists have moved farther afield — beyond the Brooklyn quartet of Williamsburg, Greenpoint, Bedford-Stuyvesant and Bushwick — to find compatible and affordable neighborhoods.

headline: Follow the Drips of Paint
text: THE race to anoint the latest neighborhood for New Yorkers eager to pursue careers in the arts is never-ending.

headline: To Be a Hotel and Gay in New York
text: ON a recent Saturday night at the new XL nightclub on West 42nd Street, revelers danced with abandon on a sunken floor while the D.J. Manny Lehman spun a percussive house mix, lights flashed, go-go boys undulated on raised platforms and bartenders busily mixed cocktails. I’m really not the party-all-night type, but I stayed pretty late, given that my bed was a short walk away through a couple of glass doors that lead to a Manhattan hotel lobby.

headline: Six Gay Hotels Where the Welcome Mats Have Always Been Out
text: Chelsea Mews Guesthouse344 West 15th Street (212) 255-9174 chelseamewsguesthouse.com

headline: Rutgers Official Says Verdict Will Not Affect Admissions
text: A Rutgers University official said he did not expect a jury’s decision to convict Dharun Ravi of hate crimes will negatively affect admissions at the New Jersey school.

headline: Longhorns’ Rally Falls Short
text: NASHVILLE —  Entering Texas’ game against Cincinnati Friday, the Longhorns’ Rick Barnes found himself in an unusual role for a coach who has been to 17 consecutive N.C.A.A. tournaments.

headline: Dim Corner of SoMa Brightens
text: NEAR the corner of Mission and Seventh Streets in San Francisco on a recent Sunday, a woman and her 30-something son sidestepped two scruffy men passed out against the side of a building. “This is where the restaurant is?” she asked skeptically, turning to her son, who was taking her to brunch at the recently opened AQ  (1085 Mission; 415-341-9000; aq-sf.com).

headline: Hotel Review: Surf & Sand Resort in Laguna Beach, Calif.
text: THE UPSHOT

headline: In Racist Chant at N.C.A.A. Game, Echoes of European Hooligans
text: A racist chant by some members of the University of Southern Mississippi’s band during an N.C.A.A. basketball tournament game sparked outrage and an immediate, regretful response from university officials.

headline: Wolfpack Prove They Belong
text: COLUMBUS, Ohio — After North Carolina State narrowly sneaked into the N.C.A.A. tournament, Coach Mark Gottfried gathered his players and urged them not to be happy with just being a part of the bracket. The theme of the meeting was simply to stay hungry.

headline: A Time of Green Matzo Balls and Yiddish Theater
text: Come with us back in time to the Jewish Rialto. We’re on Second Avenue and 12th Street, outside Maurice Schwartz’s fabled Yiddish Art Theater, on our way to the Rumanian-Jewish restaurant Moskowitz & Lupowitz, managed by Louis Anzelowitz. “And the telephone exchange is Gramowitz,” the old joke goes.

headline: For Romney and Santorum, a Battle of Chicago Versus Illinois
text: It is tempting to think of Illinois as being displaced on the political map — a Northeastern state trapped in the body of a Midwestern one.

headline: Styled to a T | Krochet Kids
text: The People

headline: Asked & Answered | Krochet Kids
text: Real men don’t eat quiche, but it seems that they do crochet. That’s the lesson learned in talking to the men behind Krochet Kids International, a nonprofit that teaches women in impoverished nations how to crochet, exports their goods and then gives back the proceeds from the sales. The three founders — Kohl Crecelius, Stewart Ramsey and Travis Hartanov — recently took part in a conference call to chat about how the group came together. What follows is an edited version of that conversation.

headline: Homegrown Fashion in Central Berlin
text: In Berlin, Mitte may have gone mainstream, but its alleys still become the fashion strasse of the moment.

headline: Having Twins With a Surrogate — in India
text: After weeks in the heat at a fertility clinic in northeastern India, I received the most profound and life-altering gift one could possibly imagine: two beautiful daughters from our surrogate, Vaina, courtesy of the medical magic of Dr. Naina Patel.

headline: G.O.P. Freshmen Not as Defiant as Reputation Suggests
text: WASHINGTON — House freshmen have been caricatured as the face of Republican intransigence in Congress, portrayed as a diverse and cacophonous mob standing in the way of Republican leaders and legislative compromise.

headline: Putin Needs Higher Oil Prices to Pay for Campaign Promises
text: MOSCOW — In American presidential politics, high oil prices are a problem. For Vladimir V. Putin’s new presidential term in Russia, they will be a necessity — crucial to fulfilling his campaign promises to lift government spending by billions of dollars a year.

headline: TimesCast | Head of Church Resigns
text: March 16, 2012 - The leader of the Anglican Church announces his resignation.

headline: Expert Answers on E.M.D.R.
text: July 30 12:45 p.m. | Updated Dr. Shapiro responds to additional reader questions about E.M.D.R. and fibromyalgia, memories of child abuse, the costs and length of treatment, controversies surrounding the treatment, whether its effective for sexual perpetrators, and more. See her responses below.

headline: Moving Uptown to the Intersection of Avalon and LaCrosse
text: ORANGE, Calif.

headline: Another Step Forward for Hyundai
text: The redesigned Azera makes the most of its second chance, fully justifying its reintroduction to the big sedan class.

headline: Bin Laden Plot Against Obama Outlined in Documents
text: WASHINGTON — A terrorist whom Osama bin Laden wanted to assassinate President Obama was himself killed in a drone strike last year, shortly after evidence of the plot showed up in documents seized by the SEAL team that killed Bin Laden in Pakistan.

headline: Investing With a Long-Term View
text: The stock market has been doing better lately. Some economic gauges are indicating growing strength in the American economy. So why are some financial advisers to wealthy families telling their clients to prepare for a sustained period of low investment returns?

headline: As Black as We Wish to Be
text: Paris

headline: Send Us Your Questions for the S.B.A.
text: It has been a challenging time for the Small Business Administration — though, in truth, it’s almost always a challenging time for the S.B.A.

headline: After Albany All-Nighter, Lawmakers Say: No More
text: ALBANY – Three lawmakers have a plea for Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and the leaders of the State Legislature: No more all-nighters.

headline: Creighton Overcomes Low-Scoring Effort
text: GREENSBORO, N.C. — Creighton brought gaudy offensive numbers and boy wonder appeal to the N.C.A.A. tournament with Doug McDermott, the sophomore all-American who came in averaging 23.2 points per game. But Alabama and its equally intimidating defense still forced the game it wanted: A tight, low-scoring grind that was almost enough to knock off the No. 8 Bluejays.

headline: Arkansas Freshman Takes Heat on Tax Proposal
text: When Representative Rick Crawford this week broke with his Republican Party and proposed a millionaire’s surtax, it was hailed in some circles as a crack in the ice that could turn into a significant breach.

headline: Jeff, Home and the Duplass Brothers
text: In “Jeff, Who Lives at Home,” the main character, Jeff (Jason Segel), finds beauty in the mundane. When writing and directing their films, the brothers Jay and Mark Duplass say they often approach their characters the same way Jeff approaches the world: with an eye open to possibilities. “Jeff, Who Lives at Home” is their fourth feature in theaters. They answered questions about it during an interview at the Toronto International Film Festival last fall.

headline: The Derby for ‘Mr. Euro,’ and Lots of Other Top Jobs, Is Just Getting Started
text: BRUSSELS — Having failed to secure the presidency of the European Central Bank last year, Germany may get a chance to name the next “Mr. Euro.”

headline: Record Prices at Amelia Auctions
text: AMELIA ISLAND, Fla.

headline: For GMC, 100 Years of Hard Labor
text: TO many people shopping for new vehicles, there is little to differentiate the trucks sold by Chevrolet and GMC beyond the logos on the grilles. But to collectors, GMC holds claim to a hard-working personality distinctly its own.

headline: What’s In a Nameplate?
text: GMC, which is celebrating its 100th year, holds claim to a hard-working personality distinctly its own.

headline: T’s Spring Travel Issue
text: The spring travel issue of T kicks off in China, where the model Liu Wen leads a tour through her home province of Hunan, charting remarkable changes in her native land (and in herself). The personal journeys continue with Daphne Merkin’s meditation on the allure of Haworth, England, home to the Brontë sisters; Gideon Lewis-Kraus’s pilgrimage to Ukraine with his gay dad and 50,000 Hasids; Ethan Hauser’s trip to California in search of the Bakersfield sound; and Lynn Yaeger’s spree through a mammoth Belgian flea market. Elsewhere, Jim Lewis reports from Newfoundland on an ambitious plan to save tiny, gorgeous Fogo Island, and Kevin Gray finds that in the midst of crisis, Lisbon’s creative scene is flourishing. Along the way, we touch down in Mumbai’s hottest neighborhood, check out the biggest New York hotel opening of the year and serve up a smart and stylish guide to the most bike-friendly cities around the globe. See all stories from the issue >>

headline: Links Pursued in Killings of 3 French Army Parachutists
text: PARIS — Investigators in southwestern France searched Friday for a suspected serial killer after two shootings over the past week left three parachutists in the French Army dead and another critically wounded. The motive for the attacks was unknown, as the antiterrorism police and specialists in serial murders were called to assist in the investigation, officials said.

headline: Childhood: 940 Saturdays, and You’re Done
text: Nine hundred and forty Saturdays: I didn’t do that math, Dr. Harley Rotbart, author of “No Regrets Parenting,” did. Between the day your child is born, and the time he or she turns 18, you get 940 Saturdays — and 260 of them, Dr. Rotbart just reminded me, are gone by her fifth birthday.

headline: Did History Play a Role in D’Antoni’s Departure?
text: While many have brushed off Mike D’Antoni’s departure as the Knicks’ coach as a product of his stubbornness, for the real answer to why D’Antoni resigned, we would be wise to look at his past.

headline: Buried Beneath Jewels, an Aromatic Treasure
text: UNLESS your pantry happens to resemble a Middle Eastern or South Asian market, you will probably need to do a little shopping to make this traditional Persian rice dish with the lovely name, javaher polow, or jeweled rice. But it is well worth it, and most good supermarkets can supply what you require.

headline: Battery S.U.V. Conversions From Amp Qualify for $7,500 Federal Rebate
text: Amp Electric Vehicles, the Cincinnati-based start-up, converts the Jeep Grand Cherokee to run purely on battery power. The conversion process is not cheap, with the Amp Cherokee, featuring a 40-kilowatt-hour battery pack and a manufacturer-estimated range of more than 100 miles, listing for just under $60,000 in 4-wheel-drive form.

headline: A Rebate for Low-Flush Toilets
text: Low-flush toilets may soon grow more appealing under a Bloomberg administration plan to get New Yorkers to conserve more water.

headline: Perfect for Roast Chicken (and Impact): Javaher Polow, or Persian Jeweled Rice
text: I was going to roast a chicken for dinner guests the other night, and wondered what to serve with it. Javaher Polow, or Persian Jeweled Rice, came to mind. It is a dish I absolutely adore, studded with dried fruits, fragrant with saffron and spices and showered with almonds and pistachios. It never fails to impress and is so delicious I would eat it even without the chicken.

headline: As Cars Are Kept Longer, 200,000 Is New 100,000
text: HOW far can a modern car really go? Given the increasing age of vehicles on American roads, we may be on the verge of finding out.

headline: Editor’s Letter
text: A few months ago, Stephen Heyman, who oversees our coverage of books, gave me a copy of Gideon Lewis-Kraus’s “A Sense of Direction” (forthcoming from Riverhead Books) and urged me to read it. It’s an account, by a young essayist, of undertaking various pilgrimages; and it culminates with his account of a trip to Uman, Ukraine, for the High Holidays with his brother and father — a gay ex-rabbi who came out at age 46, much to the confusion of his grown sons. A small excerpt of that story appears in the pages that follow, and I hope you will find it as charming and disarming as we do. On the one hand, it’s like a literary version of Mike Mills’s “Beginners,” almost entirely populated by Hasids; on the other, it’s a wonderful exploration of the stories we tell ourselves to justify and impart narrative weight to our curiosities and compulsions.

headline: Design Break: Airline Safety Cards
text: As a graphic designer, I pay particular attention to the designs I come across in daily life. A beautiful menu design may influence my approach for a feature on a restaurant, or a clever billboard advertisement may inspire me to play with a new integration of text and imagery.

headline: St. Patrick’s to Undergo a Three-Year, $177 Million Renovation
text: Take one good, long last look at St. Patrick’s Cathedral, a defining landmark of New York City. It is about to disappear for two or three years under a cocoon of scaffolding, inside and out, that will permit a $177 million rehabilitation project to unfold, the most extensive work at the cathedral in generations.

headline: China’s Hunger for Ivory is Killing Cameroon’s Elephants
text: HONG KONG — The killing began in early January and has continued for months.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Afghanistan and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Afghanistan, Belgium, West Bank and Yemen.

headline: TimesCast | Is America Divided?
text: The author Jonathan Haidt talks with The Times’s Sam Tanenhaus on why America is so divided.

headline: Gators Find Their Strength Under the Boards
text: OMAHA — Last March, Virginia forward Mike Scott and guard Jontel Evans made a pact that neither would cut his hair until the Cavaliers qualified for the N.C.A.A. tournament. So when Virginia took the court Friday against Florida for its first N.C.A.A. tournament appearance since 2007, both had abandoned cornrows and poof-out looks for closer-cropped cuts, with Evans’s mother handling the scissors.

headline: Early Signs of Spring at Amelia Island
text: The Amelia Island concours, the premier East Coast event for connoisseurs of high-end automobiles, set a sales record this year.

headline: DealBook’s Week in Review
text: Greg Smith introduced Muppets into the Goldman Sachs lexicon, a casino lawsuit was revived in Macau, Yahoo sued Facebook, and the S.E.C. won a legal victory against Judge Jed S. Rakoff. A look back on our reporting of the past week’s highs and lows in finance.

headline: In Hong Kong Elections, Some Chinese See Enviable Openness
text: HONG KONG — The three candidates to become the next chief executive of Hong Kong engaged in a vituperative, televised debate on Friday evening in an election campaign that is being closely followed in mainland China.

headline: In a Month Full of Riches, A Globally Seasoned Feast
text: Some nights a critic’s job feels impossibly good and divinely difficult: how even to begin to get at, through words, the quicksilver, complex art you’ve just experienced? What to say to readers, other than “Please stop reading and purchase a ticket for this show”?

headline: Composers Versus Tyrants in a Festival’s Conclusion
text: The New York Philharmonic and its audience have been chest-deep in Beethoven this month, thanks to the orchestra’s Modern Beethoven festival, conducted by David Zinman.

headline: When You See Your Opponents Err, It’s Time to Cash In
text: MEMPHIS — The opening event at the Spring North American Championships here was the Baldwin North American Open Pairs. Played on Wednesday and Thursday, it was won by two Canadians from Ontario, Jordan Cohen and Barry Senensky. They finished less than a board ahead of a married team, Rozanne and Bill Pollack of Basking Ridge, N.J. Third were Mark Itabashi of Murrieta, Calif., and Steven Love of Laguna Niguel, Calif.

headline: No Longer Lonely, a Birthday Boy Plays at His Party
text: When asked on Thursday night at Symphony Space if he had any advice for younger composers, David Del Tredici said, “Follow your bliss, follow your inspiration.”

headline: Chic in Review | Winners, Losers and Nominees
text: All the fashion news of the week that’s fit to reprint.

headline: Jets Sign Stanton and Schilens
text: After three days of relative inactivity on the free-agent front, the Jets signed a No. 2 quarterback and bolstered their receiving corps Friday.

headline: Reviewing the Hyundai Azera
text: In Sunday’s Automobiles section, Lawrence Ulrich reviews the Hyundai Azera, which sits between the Sonata and Genesis in the ascendant Korean automaker’s sedan firmament.

headline: Republicans Reportedly to Propose Trimming Discretionary Spending
text: Republicans on the House Budget Committee are settling on a new cap for discretionary spending in the coming fiscal year, dipping slightly below the spending limit set in July after hard-fought negotiations over raising the nation’s statutory borrowing limit.

headline: Caucus Click: Obama Hovers Over Chicago
text: President Obama took Marine One to Chicago to attend fund-raising events on Friday.

headline: Kony 2012 Director Is Detained and Hospitalized
text: Updated | 11:17 p.m. Jason Russell, who directed and starred in the “Kony 2012” video that has been viewed more than 100 million times this month, was detained by the San Diego Police Department on Thursday, accused of masturbating in public and vandalizing cars, NBC San Diego reports. He was later hospitalized after an evaluation.

headline: From Far Away, Teams Come Together
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — The geographic diversity represented on the rosters of Murray State and Iowa State roster is one of the more interesting storylines here.

headline: Culinary Comforts by Way of Poland
text: SHORTLY after moving to New Jersey, with its rich Italian-American culture, I began wishing I had been born with that genetic understanding of parmesan, guanciale, truffles and olives. Now, after a couple of visits to Rozmaryn, in Trenton, I’m feeling the same way about Polish ingredients like cabbage, pork, beets and potatoes.

headline: In Puerto Rico, Romney Weighs In on Statehood
text: SAN JUAN, P.R. — Mitt Romney arrived here Friday afternoon and marveled at what he described as “an aggressive and energetic — enthusiastic audience,” who chanted his name and applauded as he took a makeshift stage at a private aviation terminal.

headline: Friday Night Music: More Sarah Jarosz
text: Substance tomorrow, maybe; right now I’m tired, I’m decompressing from a couple of very hard weeks, and I want some simple pleasure. So here it is:

headline: Fighting Absurdity With Absurdity
text: In his famous satirical essay “A Modest Proposal,” Jonathan Swift suggested that impoverished Irish citizens should sell their children as food for the rich. “A young healthy child well nursed, is, at a year old, a most delicious nourishing and wholesome food,” he wrote, countering heartlessness attitudes towards the poor with absurdity.

headline: A Long Soak Brings Out Dried Corn’s Earthy Flavor
text: I’VE long adored hominy, the earthy dried corn kernels you find in pozole, the chile-laced Mexican stew. But until recently, I had never actually made it from scratch. Laziness is to blame. The canned hominy can be gummy, but it is so convenient, and so much easier to find in my neighborhood than the dried kernels, that I always end up taking that shortcut.

headline: Bonnies Forget to Shoot a 3 at the Most Crucial Time
text: NASHVILLE — St. Bonaventure last won an N.C.A.A. tournament game in 1970, and even that victory came with a caveat. Bob Lanier injured his knee, keeping him from playing in the Final Four and costing the Bonnies a possible shot at John Wooden’s mighty U.C.L.A. Bruins.

headline: Going Beyond Standard Diner Fare
text: FROM the outside, the restaurant Relish resembles the string of diners that occupied this building in Kings Park for more than 50 years. The inside, though, reflects the renovations carried out by Donny Brown, one of the two owners, before Relish opened in September, and the decoration by his wife, Christy. The spare but appealing dining rooms have apple-green booths and banquettes, cream-colored wainscotted walls, attractive framed mirrors and wall sconces filled with fresh flowers.

headline: Generation Y Stands Up for Itself
text: To the Editor:

headline: Winter Greens in Spring
text: Winter greens are tastiest in springtime. Melissa Clark demonstrates how to trim and slice kale and collard greens.

headline: North Korea in Contrast
text: The few Western photographers allowed to visit North Korea in the last two decades have returned with remarkably similar images. The highly secretive Communist government allowed them to photograph little else but the extravagant pageants honoring their supreme leader, Kim Jong-il, or the immaculate subways in Pyongyang.

headline: Hoyas Advance Behind Their Size and Shooting
text: COLUMBUS, Ohio — Since appearing in the Final Four in 2007, Georgetown has been synonymous with N.C.A.A. tournament futility. But the Hoyas’ 74-59 win over Belmont on Friday represented a first step toward changing that.

headline: Arguing Over a Lesson in Security From 9/11
text: At a hearing Wednesday on the Police Department’s security plans for the new World Trade Center site, the head of the area’s community board broached a topic she called “the elephant in the room”: the location of a permanent command center for the so-called World Trade Center campus.

headline: Regulating Nuclear Power
text: To the Editor:

headline: Please Won’t You Be My Inspiration?
text: FOR decades he showed up in his trademark cardigan and sneakers. He sang to us and smiled. And in the measured cadence of his familiar voice he spread the unconditional love: “You’ve made this day a special day, by just your being you. There’s no person in the whole world like you, and I like you, just the way you are.”

headline: Thwarting Church Secrecy
text: To the Editor:

headline: Untouchable Pensions May Be Tested in California
text: When the city manager of troubled Stockton, Calif., had to tell city council members why it was on track to become the biggest American city yet to go bankrupt, it took hours to get through the list.

headline: The Week in Pictures for March 16
text: Subjects include auditions for the Liberty’s dance troupe, a subway mural that appealed to a thief and a luxury condo with a prison next door.

headline: For Murray State Player, Game Begins on Top
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — Murray State wore bright yellow sneakers in its N.C.A.A. tournament victory over Colorado State on Thursday, matching the trim on its uniforms. The shoes were the second-most noticeable aspect about the Racers.

headline: Better Than Chicken
text: To the Editor:

headline: G.O.P. Primary Voters
text: To the Editor:

headline: Italian That Throws a Few Curveballs
text: A TINY shopping strip on a quiet stretch of Quaker Ridge Road is an unlikely spot for a terrific Italian restaurant, but that is where you will find Da Giorgio. And it may well be that the restaurant’s patrons wish it were even more inconspicuous. The place is small — the long, narrow dining room seats only 45 — and regulars know they need a reservation, especially on weekends.

headline: How to Trim Collard Greens and Kale
text: This week’s recipe, a pozole-inspired pork stew, calls for collard greens, but if you’d like to substitute kale, go right ahead. The video above will even show you how to trim both. Then be sure to give the greens a good rinse in a colander before adding them to the pot.

headline: N.Y.U.’s Expansion
text: To the Editor:

headline: Syracuse Prepares for Kansas State’s Size
text: PITTSBURGH — In the aftermath of Syracuse’s surprisingly tight victory over North Carolina-Asheville on Thursday, Coach Jim Boeheim said more than once that Fab Melo’s absence had nothing to do with the Orange’s inconsistent play. When top-seeded Syracuse faces No. 8 Kansas State in the Round of 32 on Saturday, however, the center position — and the hole left by Melo, who was declared ineligible Tuesday — figures to be more significant.

headline: London Is Eating New York's Lunch
text: Why is London so attractive to wealthy traders? One of the reasons is the relative lack of enforcement against criminal activity. New York authorities have prosecuted 66 people for insider trading, with 57 convictions or guilty pleas since 2009. By contrast, the Financial Services Authority in the U.K. has secured very few criminal convictions: the first major one being in 2009, when Christopher McQuoid, former general counsel at TTP Communications, went to jail for telling his father-in-law to buy shares when he heard that Motorola was planning to take over the company.

headline: The Gambling Epoch
text: You know how history books help you keep track of things with their pithy period labels? The Roaring ’20s. The Industrial Revolution. The Pleistocene Epoch. The Ages of Reason, Enlightenment, Gilded, Stone, Bronze and Dark.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Inside the New iPad, and Satellite Surveillance

headline: Sound and Fury, Set in the 20th Century
text: Even the bleakest of Shakespeare’s tragedies, like “Macbeth,” are punctuated by an occasional moment of comic relief. Verdi wanted to avoid making his “Macbeth” too pretty, and broke with bel canto convention when writing the music for the opera. But the dark-hued score is sometimes incongruously lightened by his trademark cheery oom-pah-pah orchestral accompaniments, which (in his early works in particular) often results in an odd pairing of serious lyrics and upbeat music.

headline: No Magic for Vermont as North Carolina Romps
text: GREENSBORO, N.C. — North Carolina has a glorious history in the N.C.A.A. tournament, complete with five national championship banners. Vermont has had its moment, too — in 2005, when the Catamounts arrived as 13th seeds and knocked off No. 4 Syracuse, one of those magical upsets that only a tournament like this can produce.

headline: Fed Revises Its Numbers on Stress Test for Citigroup
text: The Federal Reserve made an error in its stress test of Citigroup that led it to overstate a crucial measurement of losses on the bank’s mortgages, the central bank acknowledged on Friday.

headline: Romantic Rendezvous for Spring
text: WITH spring on the horizon and a bit of romance in the still-nippy air, a tête-à-tête at a charming French restaurant can be a perfect bridge between winter and the warm-weather pleasures of dining en plein air. Here are three favorite spots, offering good food, attentive, intelligent service and inviting atmospheres that encourage, if not romance, a cozy kind of joie de vivre.

headline: The Power Couple
text: Cynthia Rowley and Bill Powers are seen and photographed everywhere and they really don’t care if you think they’re overexposed, overcommitted, over-stimulated, caffeinated or otherwise.

headline: A Young Nation Acquires a Taste for Splendor
text: Just because rebels were dumping tea into Boston Harbor doesn’t mean they didn’t want nice teapots. And furniture. And coats of arms.

headline: Everywhere at Once
text: THE runway presentation at the futuristic IAC Building on the West Side Highway had gone off without a hitch. The boldface guests had come backstage and said their congratulations — Rebecca Romijn, Lauren Bush, Kelly Rutherford and Allison Sarofim among them. The news media had done interviews, and the staff was headed to Acme, the new NoHo hot spot.

headline: Norfolk State Shocks No. 2-Seeded Missouri
text: OMAHA — As a first-time participant in the N.C.A.A. tournament — the Division I version, anyway — Norfolk State is understandably unfamiliar with certain traditions. Center Kyle O’Quinn, for instance, briefly forgot that he was supposed to shake hands with his Missouri counterpart at midcourt during pregame introductions before backtracking to do it.

headline: Week in Pictures for March 16
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include auditions for the New York Liberty’s dance troupe, a subway mural that appealed to a thief, and a luxury condo with a prison next door.

headline: It’s About Immigrants, Not Irishness
text: Brooklin, Me.

headline: Bill Cunningham | On Point
text: It’s as true as ever: American fashion is dominated by comfort. The first definitive fashion trend of spring is the flat ballet slipper.

headline: N.C.A.A. Men’s Tournament Photo Replay: March 16
text: Tournament action included No. 15 Norfolk State upsetting No. 2 Missouri and Florida State outlasting St. Bonaventure.

headline: The New iPad Screen, Under a Microscope
text: When most people get their new iPad today, they probably won’t do what Lukas Mathis, a science and software engineer from Switzerland, did with his new tablet.

headline: It’s Not Easy to Catch a Glimpse of This Apartment Burglar
text: Nathan Fenton popped the question 10 years ago, and she said yes, and they got married, left New York for a while, returned and found an apartment in Washington Heights, where he arrived one afternoon last week and stuck his key in the door. It did not budge.

headline: U.S. Identifies Army Sergeant in Killing of 16 in Afghanistan
text: The military on Friday identified the soldier accused of killing 16 Afghan villagers earlier this week as Staff Sgt. Robert Bales, a 38-year-old father of two who had been injured twice in combat over the course of four deployments and had, his lawyer said, an exemplary military record.

headline: How Charter Schools Can Hurt
text: MY daughter is a kindergarten pupil at P.S. 261 in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn. She started there in September, and she loves everything about it: her friends, her teachers and her school-related activities, like Girl Scouts. Intense excitement accompanied both the post office project earlier this year and the Halloween Day Characters Parade, in which her class dressed up as the Three Little Pigs.

headline: Must. Sleep. Now.
text: COILED viper-like within the word “insomnia” is the terrifying “omnia.” Why does sleeplessness seem all-powerful? Because some nights I can’t get down into the Valley regardless of how many Dolls I lash to my burro.

headline: Gupta’s Lawyer Says Goldman Executive Was Source of Insider Tips
text: Federal prosecutors have recordings of a Goldman Sachs executive leaking confidential information about technology stocks to Raj Rajaratnam, the former hedge fund billionaire convicted of insider trading, a lawyer disclosed Friday during a court hearing.

headline: West Coast Works Come to the East End
text: “Pacific Standard Time: Art in L.A., 1945-1980,” an aggregation of dozens of exhibitions at museums and galleries that got under way in Southern California last fall, celebrates the emergence of Los Angeles as a contemporary art center after World War II. On the East Coast, meanwhile, a much more modest show, drawn from the collection of a single art patron, pays homage to the same phenomenon. That show, “EST-3: Southern California in New York: Los Angeles Art From the Beth Rudin DeWoody Collection,” is at the Parrish Art Museum in Southampton.

headline: Art Between the Cracks
text: BUT is it art?

headline: My Roommate, Gloria
text: IF young feminists believed in fairy tales, then moving to New York City and winding up with Gloria Steinem as your roommate would definitely count as one.

headline: City Removes John Dewey High School Principal
text: New York City's Department of Education removed the principal of a Brooklyn high school from his position on Friday, a decision that caught school staff by surprise and fueled complaints that the city was trying to quash protests against Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's education policies.

headline: Magic’s Howard Clouds Future for Nets and Williams
text: Orlando, Fla.

headline: On the Ice and Under It, Nature Thrives
text: Expectations are high when David Attenborough and the BBC Natural History Unit get together. Beginning with “Life on Earth” in 1979, they have set the standard for plush nature shows studded with arresting moments, and their latest, the seven-episode “Frozen Planet” (beginning on Sunday on Discovery), has its share of spine-tinglers.

headline: California Concerts, Awash in Cellists
text: LOS ANGELES — On its face, the Los Angeles Philharmonic’s subscription concert at Walt Disney Concert Hall on Thursday evening might have seemed routine. The program, conducted by Neeme Jarvi, followed an old formula — overture, concerto, symphony — and the repertory was familiar: Dvorak’s “Carnival” Overture and his Cello Concerto, with Ralph Kirshbaum as soloist, followed by Shostakovich’s Fifth Symphony.

headline: Gloria Steinem, a Woman Like No Other
text: IN 1970, when the Senate was first debating passage of the Equal Rights Amendment, a featured speaker was Gloria Steinem, a 36-year-old magazine writer with a growing reputation as a forceful advocate of women’s issues.

headline: Editor Not Ready to Write an Ending
text: Robert Silvers, the editor of The New York Review of Books, received a lifetime achievement award from the National Book Critics Circle last week, and next month he will get another, from The Paris Review. Neither award is likely to stop the kind of speculation that invariably takes place whenever too many New York intellectuals remain too long in one room: Mr. Silvers can’t stay on forever, presumably, so who is going to succeed him?

headline: Ups and Downs of Hip-Hop Pioneers
text: MICHAEL WRIGHT, better known to the world as Wonder Mike, the old-school M. C. on the 1979 Sugarhill Gang hit “Rapper’s Delight,” is “a precision guy,” he said in a recent phone interview.

headline: Rosie O’Donnell Talk Show Is Canceled by OWN
text: Rosie O’Donnell’s 7 p.m. talk show on OWN, Oprah Winfrey’s struggling cable network, is being canceled after just five months.

headline: Artists Find Benefactors in Web Crowd
text: In the last year alone, money troubles have pushed the New Mexico Symphony to close, New York City Opera to slash its budget by two-thirds and the State of Kansas to eliminate all public financing for the arts.

headline: Modern Movement With an Ancient Monster
text: Although Martha Graham started out opposed to ballet, in her later years she invited a few ballet stars to perform with her company. These were mainly men — Rudolf Nureyev, Mikhail Baryshnikov — and in Graham, the men are often just props. Margot Fonteyn made an appearance, and after Graham’s death, so did Natalia Makarova, but they did not attempt signature Graham roles.

headline: No Surprise: Meat Is Bad for You
text: I did not intend to broadcast an anti-meat mini-series this week, but there are so many angles to this argument that sometimes one gets carried away.

headline: Marquette Looks Up, but Won’t Slow Down
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — Football was canceled at Marquette on Dec. 9, 1960. Yet there is a team on campus that looks as if it could move the chains 10 yards, take down a running back or trample a quarterback.

headline: Kansas State Sets Up Melting Pot on the Plains
text: PITTSBURGH — Kansas State’s Angel Rodriguez heard the chants. It was impossible for him not to hear them, standing at the foul line late in the first half Thursday and trying to make his free throws as some members of the Southern Mississippi band chanted, “Where’s your green card?” in his direction.

headline: Immigration Detainees Get a ‘Better’ Prison
text: Federal officials this week unveiled a new immigration detention center in rural Karnes County, Tex., the first designed and built to reflect the Obama administration’s effort to stop treating all detainees like criminals. The center is brightly painted and looks more like a school than a prison, with dormitory-style rooms, a gym, library, medical office and soccer field. Detainees can move around freely, exercise, watch TV and use computers. They can also attend their hearings in rooms hooked up for video conferencing with judges in Houston and San Antonio.

headline: Surprise at India’s Polls Reveals a New Kind of Leader
text: NEW DELHI

headline: The High Price of a Baseball Winning Streak
text: It could have been 1955 again. At the Paper Mill Playhouse in Millburn, it was the opening night of a new production of “Damn Yankees,” and the orchestra began the overture. Those familiar songs — “Heart” (“miles and miles and miles of heart”), “Whatever Lola Wants,” “Goodbye, Old Girl” — were instant reminders of why this Faustian baseball musical won seven Tony Awards 56 years ago. This is a first-rate, frequently thrilling revival, even if it does have one disappointing flaw. But that comes later.

headline: Ackerman Had to Safeguard Pride Before Retiring, Colleagues Say
text: On Thursday afternoon, Representative Gary L. Ackerman was visited at his home by Rory I. Lancman, a state lawmaker and political rival. Mr. Lancman, who was mulling a run against Mr. Ackerman, dropped by to say that he had had a change of heart and would not run after all.

headline: Randall Terry Loses His Delegate to the Democratic Convention
text: The Oklahoma Democratic Party has ruled that Randall Terry, the anti-abortion leader who captured 18 percent of the vote in the state’s Democratic primary on March 6, is not entitled to a delegate to the National Democratic Convention.

headline: Gov. Cuomo Succumbs
text: By agreeing to a deeply flawed deal with state lawmakers, Gov. Andrew Cuomo gave in to Albany’s secretive and undemocratic ways of doing business.

headline: Teacher Accusing Officer of Rape Says She Feared Being Killed
text: The teacher who prosecutors say was raped at gunpoint by a drunken off-duty police officer last August wept on Friday as she testified that she had feared her attacker would kill her even if she followed his commands to remain silent and keep her eyes closed.

headline: In Missouri, the G.O.P. Fight for Delegates Enters Round 2 (Post-Beauty Contest)
text: BRUNSWICK, Mo. — Mitt Romney and his advisers pride themselves on vigorously pursuing every delegate in every corner of the country in their quest to secure the Republican presidential nomination.

headline: Road to Ruin
text: More and more as the years dissolve, every time I get behind the wheel I think how remarkable it is that anyone who drives, or rides — or in New York City, walks — is alive.

headline: 49ers Join the Teams Contending for Manning
text: It only seems as if Peyton Manning has been looking for a new job for much longer than a week, with the helicopters and private jets and endless footage of him as he gets into another car.

headline: From Bondage, Art
text: The first museum exhibition devoted to Winfred Rembert’s work offers a harrowing account of a man’s odyssey through the Jim Crow South.

headline: A Republican Talks Sense on Taxes
text: Just when House Republicans are about to provoke a new budget war, one of their own members has broken ranks and proposed a tax increase on the rich. Representative Rick Crawford, a freshman Republican from Arkansas, says the only serious way to begin cutting the deficit is to combine new tax revenue with spending cuts. On Thursday, he introduced a bill calling for a 5 percent surtax on incomes exceeding $1 million.

headline: Odyssey Through Jim Crow Era, Carved in Leather
text: Most histories of the segregated South and the civil rights movement have taken the form of books, films or music. Winfred Rembert’s is carved in leather. You could call it folk art, since he wasn’t trained in any art school — he learned the craft in prison — and like many folk narratives, it is couched firmly in the details of simple, everyday life. But the work on view at the Hudson River Museum in Yonkers, which has distinct echoes of Jacob Lawrence, Elizabeth Catlett, Romare Bearden and Mexican revolutionary art, also offers a harrowing account of one man’s odyssey through the Jim Crow South.

headline: This Trickster Season
text: The clock jumped ahead to spring on March 11. The calendar will jump ahead to spring in the early morning on Tuesday. And spring itself? Here in the Northeast, it has been wandering around, premature and a little lost, all winter long.

headline: Woods’s Distractions Detailed by His Ex-Coach
text: It may say just about everything you need to know about being part of Tiger Woods’s inner circle that Hank Haney, his swing coach from 2004 to 2010, became paralyzed with fear over asking Woods for a popsicle.

headline: Justice Department Investigation Is Sought in Florida Teenager’s Shooting Death
text: MIAMI — Nearly three weeks after an unarmed teenager was killed in a small city north of Orlando, stirring an outcry, a few indisputable facts remain: the teenager, who was black, was carrying nothing but a bag of Skittles, some money and a can of iced tea when he was shot. The neighborhood crime watch volunteer who got out of his car and shot him is white and Hispanic. He has not been arrested and is claiming self-defense.

headline: When Businesses Can’t Stop Asking, ‘How Am I Doing?’
text: A commercial transaction, in its simplest form, involves a customer paying for goods or services. But these days, that is just the first step.

text: Let’s take a look at sex and state legislatures.

headline: Price of Gas Matters to Voters, but Doesn’t Seem to Sway Votes
text: WASHINGTON — Stacy Hawks is angry that the rising price of gasoline is squeezing the profits of her father’s produce company and draining the wallets of friends who drive trucks. She is angry that the government has not acted to reverse the trend.

headline: Oysters, Vinyl and an Expert Sound System
text: Let there be spring. Let there be oysters and music and people in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, who don’t make us all feel old.

headline: He Helped Split a Jackpot, but His Share Is Still Zero
text: Perfeito Esteves was the fill-in guy on a paving crew laying asphalt on Interstate 80, a few miles from the Delaware Water Gap. It was his first day on the job, and a couple of the other men on the crew asked if he wanted to join their betting pool and chip in $2 for lottery tickets.

The Rams belong to the Colonial Athletic Association and became a darling of last season’s tournament. Their latest win, over Wichita State on Thursday, solidified that image.

text: On Wednesday, Howard Schultz, the chairman and chief executive of Starbucks, will take the podium at his company’s annual meeting and talk about the importance of morality in business.

text: COLUMBUS, Ohio — From the age disparity between their coaches to their opposite styles of play, St. Louis’s 61-54 victory over Memphis in the West Region on Friday night was a study of contrasts.

headline: Ohio (Just Ohio) Ousts No. 4 Michigan
text: NASHVILLE — The Michigan football coach Brady Hoke dismissively refers to rival Ohio State as Ohio, a mocking nickname that’s a quirk of one of the country’s fiercest rivalries.

headline: G.O.P. Leaders Attack Democratic Senator, but Leave Candidate Selection to the Primary
text: ROCHESTER — As New York Republicans gathered on Friday to begin choosing a candidate for the United States Senate, they directed sharp attacks at the Democratic incumbent, Senator Kirsten E. Gillibrand, accusing her of blindly following President Obama and having an unremarkable record after three years in office.

headline: U.S. Clarifies Policy on Birth Control for Religious Groups
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration took another step on Friday to enforce a federal mandate for health insurance coverage of contraceptives, announcing how the new requirement would apply to the many Roman Catholic hospitals, universities and social service agencies that insure themselves.

headline: Pushing the Envelope
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — I’ll admit it: I have a totally innocent, completely professional, cruciverbal crush on David Quarfoot. There, I said it.

headline: In Belarus, a Plea for Mercy That May Be Too Late to Help
text: MOSCOW — Any moment now, in a basement or courtyard somewhere in Belarus, two young men are to be put to death. They were arrested, tried and convicted for carrying out a deadly bombing last year at a subway station in Minsk, the Belarussian capital.

headline: The Week’s Business News in Pictures
text: A renewed interest in food on airlines and a highly public resignation by a Goldman Sachs executive director were among the week’s top stories.

headline: Rutgers Case Jurors Call Digital Evidence Crucial
text: Dharun Ravi was not accused of causing the death of Tyler Clementi, his Rutgers University roommate who jumped off a bridge after Mr. Ravi used a webcam to spy on him kissing a man in their dorm and then talked about it on Twitter.

headline: Santana Throws 65 Pitches, Giving Up 5 Runs
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Johan Santana was scheduled to throw 60 pitches Friday against the Detroit Tigers as part of his recovery from shoulder surgery. He ended up throwing 65 pitches over two and two-thirds innings, getting roughed up in the process by the Tigers. He gave up five hits and five runs, four of them earned.

headline: A.C.P.T. 2012: How to Make a Tournament Float
text: SPECIAL POST — If you ever need help pulling off a heist, Helene Hovanec is the woman to call. To pull off a heist successfully, so I’ve heard, you need a combination of smarts, cunning, bravery and stealth, and Ms. Hovanec, who has been responsible for coordinating the American Crossword Puzzle Tournament for Will Shortz since 1993, has all of these qualities in abundance.

headline: Jogging Shoes and Magic Tricks
text: Sunday, when many find respite from the burdens of the workweek, is a different kind of escape for Thomas Solomon, who makes his living breaking out of handcuffs and leg restraints. Mr. Solomon, 47, an escape artist and magician who lives in SoHo, may not always stick to his strict regimen of rehearsals on the weekend, but he does try to keep fit by jogging and by reading up on the voluminous literature of magic. He is scheduled to be handcuffed on Sunday by New York police officers and make an escape from a cold, outdoor water tank at the New York Aquarium in Coney Island.

headline: Police Detain Maker of Uganda Video
text: SAN DIEGO — A co-founder of Invisible Children, the nonprofit organization whose video “Kony 2012” has become an Internet sensation, was detained by the San Diego police on Thursday, after they said he was found in the street in his underwear, screaming and interfering with traffic.

headline: Health Law Hearings: Justices Plan Daily Tapes
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court announced on Friday that it would release same-day audio recordings of the arguments over the constitutionality of the health care overhaul law.  The arguments will be heard over three days starting on March 26.

headline: In Dance, ‘Crazy Is Good’
text: “WE’RE at war here,” Denise Vale declared to the eight elite modern dancers rehearsing on the stage, make that battlefield, of the darkened Joyce Theater on Thursday.

headline: Fast and Fearless Lehigh Stuns Duke
text: GREENSBORO, N.C. — Lehigh took an eight-game winning streak into the N.C.A.A. tournament and did not seem to notice that its opponent in the South Region on Friday was a few levels higher than its Patriot League competition.

headline: Knicks Win Second Straight Under Interim Coach
text: Strip away the week’s tumult, the stunning change on the bench and the consternation that followed, and you would swear that the Knicks were still riding high on the fumes of their February magic.

headline: At the PTA, Clashes Over Cupcakes and Culture
text: THE Cupcake Wars came to Public School 295 in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, in October.

headline: Purdue Hangs On Against St. Mary’s
text: OMAHA — Robbie Hummel wasn’t dazzling in his first N.C.A.A. tournament action in three years, and Purdue squandered a 13-point second-half lead. But Terone Johnson and Lewis Jackson made sure Hummel and the Boilermakers earned a chance to play one more game.

headline: Sentiment Aside, a Move Has Its Risks
text: The Yankees understand the folly of sentimental decisions. When they need to be bloodless, they can. Ask Bernie Williams and Jorge Posada, who gathered their championship rings and went home when the Yankees decided they were no longer useful.

headline: Chris Hackett and the Madagascar Institute
text: A builder and an art collective known for fabricating flamethrowers, jet-powered carnival rides and other devices built for mayem.

headline: Building a Better Apocalypse
text: ON Chris Hackett’s personal periodic table, the world’s most interesting, and abundant, substance is an element he calls obtainium. Things classified as obtainium might include the discarded teapot that he once turned into a propane burner, or the broken beer bottle he used to make a razor, or the 9-millimeter shell casings he acquired some time ago, melted in a backyard foundry (also made of obtainium) and cast into brass knuckles for a girlfriend.

headline: Colorado Win Boosts Pac-12, Too
text: ALBUQUERQUE — There were plenty of reasons for the Pacific-12 to add Colorado when it expanded to a dozen teams last year: expansion of conference territory, entry to another top-20 Nielsen television market and the addition of a football program that won a national championship in 1990 and was a perennial top-25 team until a recent decline.

headline: Lessons on Vice, Liberties and the Law
text: Last weekend in Missouri, Rick Santorum, proclaiming his commitment to those places not on the coasts, took an opportunity to denigrate New York City, reviving a conservative meme that casts urbanism as the sinful twin of a mythic and decent real America. Anyone seeking further evidence of the candidate’s Victorian orientation could find it in this particular strain of cultural partisanship, which imagines cities not as they now are but as they once were, long ago — squalid places ripe for moral renewal.

headline: Events in Connecticut
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: Rick Santorum, Then and Now
text: Rick Santorum’s failed 2006 re-election bid to the Senate helped shape the conservative positions that characterize his presidential campaign today.

headline: Venezuela: Chávez Returns Home
text: President Hugo Chávez returned home from Cuba on Friday, three weeks after flying to Havana to have a cancerous lesion removed from his pelvic region. His arrival was broadcast live on national television as he walked off the plane and was met by cabinet ministers and an escort of white-clad cadets holding gleaming swords. “I have promised I am going to live, and we will live and continue victorious,” he said in a speech from the tarmac. Mr. Chávez, 57, was diagnosed with cancer last year and twice had surgery in Cuba. Last month he said tests had found a lesion in the same spot as last year’s cancer, requiring another operation. He will now undergo radiation therapy. Mr. Chávez has never said exactly what kind of cancer he has. He is running for re-election in October and the return of his illness casts a shadow over the campaign.

headline: Events in Westchester
text: Comedy

headline: Hong Kong: Woman Jailed for Role in Helping Pregnant Mainlanders
text: A 41-year-old woman from mainland China was sentenced on Friday to nine weeks in prison for having taken a job with a mainland health care company that involved arranging for at least two other mainland Chinese women to travel to Hong Kong to give birth. While she pleaded guilty and was sentenced for working in Hong Kong without obtaining approval from the immigration authorities, the high-profile prosecution was part of an effort by the Hong Kong government to stanch a surge in mainland Chinese women traveling to Hong Kong to give birth in the semiautonomous territory.

headline: The 2006 Ad Wars
text: The 2006 campaign for Rick Santorum’s Pennsylvania Senate seat featured a flood of advertisements. Watch a selection of the negative ads run by each candidate’s campaign.

headline: Events in New Jersey
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: A Passionate Persona Forged in a Brutal Defeat
text: Rick Santorum’s prospects for re-election to the Senate were not rosy when friends and advisers urged him in 2005 not to risk making things worse.

headline: Vatican: Leaks Set Off Inquiry
text: Pope Benedict XVI has appointed an investigative panel to determine how high-level documents claiming corruption and mismanagement at the Holy See were leaked to the Italian news media, according to an article published by the Vatican newspaper, L’Osservatore Romano. The Vatican secretariat of state, which oversees the administration of the Holy See, will also initiate “a thorough investigation” of all Vatican departments, and an internal tribunal will conduct a criminal investigation. Vatican observers say that the scandal has unsettled the church hierarchy, giving rise to rumors of internal discord.

headline: Romney Is Endorsed by Chicago Tribune
text: ARLINGTON HEIGHTS, Ill. ­– The Chicago Tribune endorsed Mitt Romney on Friday, four days before a primary that is seen as crucial firewall for Mr. Romney, a former Massachusetts governor.

headline: Events on Long Island
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: Point Guard Is Leading St. John’s Somewhere
text: Nadirah McKenith is the starting point guard for the St. John’s women’s basketball team because she has to be labeled something. Although only 5 feet 7 inches, she cruises into the lane to block shots, seize rebounds or take charges, often adjusting her headband as she heads upcourt.

headline: Afghanistan: Copter Crash Kills 14
text: A Turkish helicopter crashed into a house in Kabul on Friday, killing at least 12 Turkish service members and 2 civilians. The deaths were the single largest loss of life for Turkey in Afghanistan. NATO said that it was investigating the cause of the crash, but that there was no insurgent activity in the area when the helicopter went down.

headline: Eritrea: Raid Called a Diversion
text: The government said Friday that the recent Ethiopian attack inside Eritrea was “provocative” but that Eritrea “will not be entrapped by such deceitful ploys,” signaling a possible easing of tensions. Ethiopia announced Thursday that it had sent forces inside neighboring Eritrea to attack rebel bases, which raised worries that the two countries might go to war again. From 1998 to 2000, Eritrea and Ethiopia fought over a disputed border town, killing more than 50,000 people. Relations have been poisonous since then, with Ethiopia accusing Eritrea of harboring militants who have killed tourists inside Ethiopia. On Friday, Eritrea’s Foreign Ministry said that Ethiopia staged the recent attack to divert attention from the border issue and Ethiopia’s “myriad internal problems.”

headline: Caucuses Buzz in Utah as Hatch Rallies Allies
text: PLEASANT GROVE, Utah — Becoming a delegate to the Utah Republican Convention does not usually confer automatic access to the corridors of power, each delegate being just one of 4,000 seated when the gavel bangs down next month to open the event.

headline: Dishing Dirt on Woods and His Rivals
text: One subject readers are probably eager to read about in Hank Haney’s new book about his time as Tiger Woods’s swing coach is Woods’s relationships with other golfers.

headline: Form Holds for Michigan State
text: COLUMBUS, Ohio — The prelude to Michigan State’s 89-67 victory over Long Island University on Friday involved a team from the Mid-Eastern Athletic Conference that was playing some 750 miles away in an arena in Omaha.

headline: An Irish Tradition With an Only-in-America Star
text: GREENVILLE, Ohio — For those feeling down about the United States and its place in the world, meet Drew Lovejoy, a 17-year-old from rural Ohio. His background could not be more American. His father is black and Baptist from Georgia and his mother is white and Jewish from Iowa. But his fame is international after winning the all-Ireland dancing championship in Dublin for a third straight year.

headline: Simin Daneshvar, Eminent Iranian Author, Dies at 90
text: Simin Daneshvar, who was the most potent surviving symbol of the vibrancy of 20th-century literature in Iran, died on March 8 in Tehran. She was 90.

headline: Jerome Albert, Who Helped Bring Space Age to Coney Island, Dies at 74
text: Jerome Albert, who with his father, Dewey, created and operated Astroland, the space age-themed amusement park that breathed new life into the Coney Island Boardwalk in the 1960s, a time when it was losing its lure, died on Thursday at his home in Manhattan. He was 74.

headline: A Call to Fire Prosecutors in Botched Stevens Trial
text: WASHINGTON — Senator Lisa Murkowski of Alaska called on Friday for the summary dismissal of two federal prosecutors who came under particular criticism in a report about the botched ethics trial of Senator Ted Stevens, while lawyers for the two complained that their clients had been smeared.

headline: Tibetans Protest in Northwest China
text: BEIJING — Thousands of Tibetans took to the streets of a city in China’s northwest Qinghai Province on Saturday after the death of a farmer who set himself on fire at a Buddhist religious site, according to Tibetan exile groups. It was the second large protest in Qinghai this week.

headline: Cuts Threaten Access to College Placement Tests
text: Because of a federal budget cut, thousands of low-income students across the nation may not be able to afford the fees for their Advanced Placement exams this spring — exams that could save them thousands of dollars in college tuition.
