headline: Xavier Regains Early Season Form to Beat Notre Dame
text: GREENSBORO, N.C. — Xavier spent the better part of a season trying to rediscover the team that was once ranked as high as No. 8 before tumbling out of the national consciousness back in December.

headline: Obama Parries Criticism as Fund-Raising Eats Into His Schedule
text: ATLANTA — Friday marked another stage in President Obama’s springtime metamorphosis into full-fledged campaigner: his first daylong trip out of the capital devoted solely to fund-raising. He gripped and grinned through five campaign events in Chicago and Atlanta, where the actor and producer Tyler Perry played host to Mr. Obama at his house and television studio.

headline: South Florida Muscles Past Temple
text: NASHVILLE — Inelegant would be the most polite way to describe the way that South Florida plays basketball. The Bulls are a burly group wed to the weight room, artless on offense and unrelenting on defense.

headline: Kansas Coasts Past Detroit
text: OMAHA — Doug Anderson of Detroit delivered one of his highlight-reel dunks midway through the first half, a flying reverse on a fast break that left Kansas Coach Bill Self shaking his head and the Titans with a 2-point lead.

headline: Mexico Official Resigns
text: Mario Vázquez Raña, an Olympic official from Mexico, resigned Thursday from various high-ranking positions, citing an internal political battle over his succession. Vázquez Raña, 79, stepped down as president of the Association of National Olympic Committees, a post he had held for more than 30 years. He also surrendered his spot on the International Olympic Committee’s executive board and his presidency of the Olympic Solidarity Commission, which gives grants to national organizations to help athletes from smaller countries.

headline: Higher Taxes and Slower Spending Proposed in the Budget
text: Finance Minister Pranab Mukherjee said Friday that the country would raise taxes and slow growth in spending in an effort to reduce its swelling budget deficit, Vikas Bajaj writes in The New York Times.

headline: Blast Inquiry Tests Ties to Israel and Iran
text: The warrants issued by Indian authorities this week for three Iranian citizens in connection with an attack last month in which assailants attached a magnetic bomb to an Israeli diplomatic vehicle here, coupled with new accusations about the bombing, seem certain to worsen the deepening crisis between Israel and Iran, Jim Yardley writes in The New York Times.

headline: Surprise at India’s Polls Reveals a New Kind of Leader
text: “Akhilesh Singh Yadav came through New Delhi this week for a victory lap of sorts, more than a week after he upended Indian politics,” Jim Yardley writes in the Saturday Profile of The New York Times, about India’s youngest chief minister.

headline: The Weekend Word: Liability to Asset
text: Today’s Times:

headline: F1 Qualifier: The World Turned Upside Down Down Under
text: MELBOURNE — Formula One qualifying today proved that we are set for a completely different season from the last two. Sebastian Vettel and his Red Bull team do not look set to dominate again, as Lewis Hamilton took the 20th pole position of his career in a McLaren Mercedes, while his teammate, Jenson Button, finished second. In third was the surprise Romain Grosjean of the Lotus team, who has returned to Formula One after a couple of years away and a false start in his first effort in 2009.

headline: Two Blasts Strike Near Security Agencies in Syria
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Two large explosions, believed to be car bombs, struck the Syrian capital, Damascus, on Saturday morning, hitting intelligence and security buildings in busy sections of the city and killing or wounding dozens of civilians and security personnel, Syrian state news media reported.

headline: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
text: Jammu and Kashmir: Noori, the first cloned Pashmina goat in the world, was born last week in the Kashmir valley. A team of six scientists and three researchers from the Sher-e-Kashmir University of Agriculture Science and Technology pioneered the breakthrough (The Indian Express).

headline: Scouting the Draft: U.S.C.’s Nick Perry
text: I have analyzed four edge rushers in this year’s draft class: Whitney Mercilus of Illinois, Courtney Upshaw of Alabama, Melvin Ingram of South Carolina and Quinton Coples of North Carolina.  Consensus rankings have Coples as the draft’s top rusher, followed by Upshaw/Ingram (interchangeable), then Mercilus.

headline: Harbaugh, Manning, Alex Smith and Circle of Quarterback Life
text: In the Bay Area, Jim Harbaugh’s relationship with Alex Smith was the focus of much of the coverage of the 49ers’ renewed interest in Peyton Manning.

headline: Soldier Assassinations Mystery in France
text: LONDON — French police this weekend were investigating the motive behind the killing of three soldiers in two separate shootings in southwestern France, including a potential link with the military’s role in the Afghan war.

headline: Last Nazi Death Camp Guard to Be Tried Dies Free
text: LONDON — John Demjanjuk, a convicted Nazi death camp guard, died on Saturday in a home for the elderly in southern Germany at the age of 91.

headline: Belarussian Is Executed Over Attack on Subway
text: MOSCOW — A man sentenced to death in connection with the bombing of a subway station in Belarus has been executed, the man’s family said Saturday.

headline: A Camp Where Extreme Is the Name of the Game
text: For children these days, summer camp isn’t just about making s’mores and tubing down creeks.

headline: After Camps, New Horizons
text: Pete Pin spent five months last year photographing a small Cambodian community that has settled in the Bronx. The quiet photographs — of a woman cutting green beans on the floor, of a man walking in winter’s first snow — are part of a long-term project documenting Cambodian refugees in the United States.

headline: Two Walks Through Paris in Spring
text: Paris is known as a great city for walks, and on Sunday, that may be truer than usual.

headline: The New Cardinal Takes On an Old Cathedral
text: Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan likes to tell a story about a cleric at Christ Church in Manhattan — Episcopal, Presbyterian, Methodist; he’s not entirely certain — complaining good-naturedly about the enormous influence of St. Patrick’s Cathedral. It seems that a prospective donor, arriving at Pennsylvania Station, instructed a cabdriver to take him to Christ Church.

headline: Budget Madness
text: I think I need a shower. Talking Points sends us to a badly written article in The Hill about the CBO’s latest budget estimates. If you read the article very, very carefully, you might be able to figure out that the CBO only shows Obama increasing deficits relative to a very unrealistic baseline, which among other things assumes that all the Bush tax cuts expire; relative to CBO’s “alternative” scenario, which represents a continuation of current policy, Obama actually cuts deficits substantially. But a casual read — and the headline — would leave you with the impression of Obama the wild spender.

headline: Photos of The Moment | Blood Orange at SXSW
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: End of ‘Luck’ and Racing’s Future
text: As has happened many times, a dead horse has set back the hopes of thoroughbred racing of ever again becoming a major sport.

headline: A.C.P.T. 2012: The Puzzlers Descend on the Marriott
text: SPECIAL POST — Saturday morning is a special time at the A.C.P.T.

headline: Outdoor Skating, Winter’s Joy in Canada, Feels Effects of Changing Climate
text: OTTAWA — Outdoor ice skating rinks are the hubs of many Canadian communities, the basis of national legends (particularly the backyard rink where Wayne Gretzky learned to play hockey) and the source of some of its best-loved stories (“The Hockey Sweater” by Roch Carrier). Now a study by climate scientists suggests that they may be doomed.

headline: Jack White Shows He’s Still Into Blues-Rock
text: From the looks of it, Jack White was turning country. The guitarist and singer who has led the White Stripes, the Raconteurs and the Dead Weather appeared at the Stage on Sixth with a band that included a pedal steel guitar, bass fiddle, mandolin and violin along with keyboards and drums.

headline: When Colleges Dedicate Courts, Squabbles Often Follow
text: When teams took the floor Thursday for the Round of 64 of the N.C.A.A. tournament’s South Region in Louisville, Ky., they were in KFC Yum Center, but they were playing on Denny Crum Court. The East Region teams competed in the Pit in Albuquerque but played on Bob King Court.

headline: Rutgers Verdict Repudiates Notion of Youth as Defense
text: He was just a jerky kid.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: Variety: A Really Tough (for Me) Cryptic
text: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE — It’s not you, it’s me. I’m obviously not ready for cryptics outside of the Cox & Rathvon realm, because this one Nothnagled me into oblivion.

headline: Number of Women Coaching in College Hockey Dwindling
text: MINNEAPOLIS — For five years, Laura Slominski approached her job as a college women’s hockey assistant coach with the same passion that had made her an all-conference forward and captain at the University of Minnesota. It seemed a natural extension of her wish to teach and mentor young women.

headline: Gulf Widens Between U.S. and a More Volatile Karzai
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — The Americans in Afghanistan are “demons.”

headline: After Surprising Loss, Duke Faces an Uncertain Future
text: Following Duke’s shocking upset loss to Lehigh in the first round of the N.C.A.A. tournament, just one thing is clear: the Blue Devils were not dynamic enough to live up to expectations in 2012. What follows now for Duke fans and players is a summer of uncertainty.

headline: Flyers Goalie Ilya Bryzgalov Finds His Groove
text: UNIONDALE, N.Y. — Just 35 seconds after giving up his first goal in nine days, Philadelphia Flyers goaltender Ilya Bryzgalov was scored on Thursday. He slammed his stick on the ice. He did not appear to be thinking about the record he had set.

headline: The Future Is Another Country
text: Simon Wren-Lewis has another very good blog post, this time on the very weak case for demanding fiscal austerity right now, even if you believe fiscal consolidation is needed in the long run. I want to tie this together with Brad DeLong’s preview of DeLong-Summers on fiscal policy in a liquidity trap.

headline: Closing the Book on an October Epic
text: The Texas relief corps collapsed in an extra-inning loss to the Cardinals in the 2011 World Series. Now the Rangers want to put it in the past. Read Tyler Kepner’s full story here.

headline: John Demjanjuk, 91, Dogged by Charges of Atrocities as Nazi Camp Guard, Dies
text: The stranger settled in Cleveland after World War II with his wife and little girl. He became an autoworker and changed his first name from Ivan to John. He had two more children, became a naturalized American, lived quietly and retired. His war and the terrors of concentration camps were all but forgotten.

headline: Prized Recruit Happy Back Home in Delaware
text: NATIONAL HARBOR, Md. — Late one night in February 2009, the Delaware women’s basketball coach, Tina Martin, received a startling text message from Elena Delle Donne, one of the sport’s most hyped prospects in years.

headline: Same As They Ever Were
text: Rick Perlstein takes on the perception that conservatives have gotten crazier, and argues that they haven’t — they were always like this. It’s an excellent read, and you should go read it.

headline: A.C.P.T. 2012: Meet Dr. Fill
text: SPECIAL POST — Most people who come to the A.C.P.T. show up with a good supply of pencils, some lucky talismans and perhaps a sweater to stay warm in the chilly ballroom. Dr. Fill, a special guest of the tournament this year, showed up with just a briefcase.

headline: A Monument to a Sioux Warrior, Its Completion Date Somewhat Unclear
text: CRAZY HORSE, S.D. — It was to be the largest sculpture in the world: a granite portrait of a Sioux leader on horseback whittled out of a mountain in the Black Hills here. In scale and complexity, the carving would dwarf the imposing collection of presidential profiles on nearby Mount Rushmore.

headline: Spy Chief and Torturer for Qaddafi Is Captured
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — Abdullah el-Senussi, the former intelligence chief and brother-in-law of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, was arrested Saturday at an airport in Mauritania, the authorities there said, in the most significant capture of a former official of the Qaddafi government since the apprehension of the dictator’s son Seif al-Islam by Libyan fighters in November.

headline: Twelve More Partners Leave Dewey Law Firm
text: Twelve partners at Dewey & LeBoeuf resigned late Friday, the latest in a wave of departures for the beleaguered law firm.

headline: Closing the Book on an October Epic, the Rangers’ Bullpen Moves On
text: SURPRISE, Ariz. — Lisa Nathan did not sleep well last Oct. 27. Her husband, Joe, was beside her in bed at their home in Knoxville, Tenn., watching Game 6 of the World Series on television. As the fortunes of the Texas Rangers and the St. Louis Cardinals cratered and spiked, Joe Nathan could not help waking up Lisa, over and over, with bursts of spontaneous excitement: Oh, my God! This is crazy! Wow!

headline: How Not to Attract Tourists
text: “As Americans, we like to imagine our country as we think of ourselves: open-hearted and welcoming; efficient and practical; easygoing, above all,” Mark Vanhoenacker writes in The New York Times. “These values are the foundation of our culture, of an open economy fueled by ideas and immigration, and of our soft power — America’s ability to change the world simply because it is admired.”

headline: Bands, Bands, Bands
text: Three of Friday’s keepers:

headline: Zeroing In on Mystery of an Old Site Called Hades
text: WASHINGTON — For decades, affluent families have flocked to Spring Valley, a quiet neighborhood hugging the northwestern boundary of the nation’s capital. True to its name, magnolias are blooming and daffodils carpet the yards.

headline: 30 Seconds With Robert Griffin III
text: Robert Griffin III’s career statistics at Baylor were impressive: 10,366 passing yards, 78 touchdowns and only 17 interceptions. He also rushed for 2,254 yards and 33 touchdowns. But there is one number in particular that has raised his profile. Griffin, the 2011 Heisman Trophy winner, ran the 40-yard dash in 4.41 seconds last month at the scouting combine.

headline: Regulatory Staff Endorses Gas Pipeline for New York City and New Jersey
text: A proposed natural gas pipeline that has faced opposition from groups in both New York and New Jersey has won the endorsement of the staff of the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, which has final approval over the $850 million project.

headline: Defiant St. Louis Church Wins Archdiocese Suit
text: ST. LOUIS — A decadelong dispute between the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of St. Louis and a local Polish parish has taken a big step forward with a state judge’s ruling that the parish has rightful control of its assets and property.

headline: Ellison Puts His Money Where His Forehand Is
text: INDIAN WELLS, Calif. — The most powerful man in the stadium sits in the front row, behind the north baseline, wearing a baseball cap and fist-pumping for his favorite players.

headline: Baseball Balance Found in Tsunami Aftermath
text: TOKYO — Asking the driver to slow down, Arizona Diamondbacks reliever Takashi Saito gazed out the car window trying to remember where his grandparents’ house was. It was not that he forgot; everything in the vicinity had been reduced to rubble that was strewn on either side of a now desolate road that seemingly stretched to nowhere.

headline: Unhappy With the Owners, Many Fans Root for a Mets Loss in Court
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Even before their trial starts Monday, the owners of the Mets, Fred Wilpon and Saul Katz, have been found guilty by one jury of their peers: Mets fans.

headline: Photo Hack Day winners visit The New York Times
text: The three first-, second- and third-place winners of the February 26 Photo Hack Day visited The New York Times to demo the projects and talk about what’s next for them and their work.

headline: Keeping Score: Tournament’s Stars Dim After March
text: March brings the word bracket to the national lexicon and turns previously little-known college basketball players into stars.

headline: Can’t Acknowledge Failure? Don’t Apply
text: This interview with  Tracey Matura, general manager for the Smart car unit of Mercedes-Benz USA, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: Shopping Fast Doesn’t Necessarily Mean Shopping Well
text: The first week of N.F.L. free agency is often described as a feeding frenzy, but that metaphor does not really fit. Schools of mackerel do not swim away from tiger sharks with $42.5 million contracts.

headline: Conscious of Safety, but Condoning Fights
text: Canadiens General Manager Pierre Gauthier made perhaps the most intriguing statement during last week’s meetings with his N.H.L. counterparts.

headline: In Yemen, New Leader Faces Threats in the South
text: ADEN, Yemen — For all the challenges that Yemen’s new president faces, none may be more imperative than the unsettled state of the south, where many are eager for secession and a security breach has allowed an Al Qaeda affiliate to grow strong.

headline: Combative Pitino Critiques Officials
text: PORTLAND, Ore. — Louisville Coach Rick Pitino believes the level of criticism of the officiating in this N.C.A.A. tournament is unwarranted. Except, that is, when he is the one criticizing.

headline: Barriers to Change, From Wall St. and Geneva
text: EVEN now, after all we’ve been through, something is still wrong with Wall Street.

headline: Out of N.B.A., Working for U.S.A.
text: When Mike Krzyzewski takes a seat on the United States bench to lead a team full of N.B.A. players at the London Olympics this summer, he could well be joined by two unemployed assistants but no coaches with N.B.A. jobs.

headline: Getting to 1,144
text: Mitt Romney needs about half of the remaining delegates to secure the Republican nomination before the convention in August.

headline: The Danish Doctor of Dread
text: The way we negotiate anxiety plays no small part in shaping our lives and character.  And yet, historically speaking, the lovers of wisdom, the philosophers, have all but repressed thinking about that amorphous feeling that haunts many of us hour by hour, and day by day. The 19th-century philosopher-theologian Soren Kierkegaard stands as a striking exception to this rule. It was because of this virtuoso of the inner life that other members of the Socrates guild, such as Heidegger and Sartre, could begin to philosophize about angst.

headline: With Pettitte in Mix, Rotation Is Rattled
text: TAMPA, Fla. — Now that the exclamation point has settled in — Andy Pettitte is back! — here come the question marks.

headline: Our Workplace: How Three Companies Innovate
text: The reshaping of the modern workplace also involves new approaches to innovation. Here, executives at Google, General Electric and DreamWorks Animation summarize their companies’ paths to creativity.

headline: All Odds Aside, G.O.P. Girding for Floor Fight
text: CHICAGO — For the first time in a generation, Republicans are preparing for the possibility that their presidential nomination could be decided at their national convention rather than on the campaign trail, a prospect that would upend one of the rituals of modern politics.

headline: Back to Missouri, in Search of a Second Victory
text: HAZELWOOD, Mo. — Rick Santorum dashed from caucus to caucus in affluent neighborhoods of suburban St. Louis on Saturday morning, frantically wooing voters in an effort to secure a dominating victory in the Missouri caucuses. The goal was to keep alive momentum from this week’s victories in Alabama and Mississippi as he goes in to Tuesday’s hard-fought primary in Illinois.

headline: Romneys Make a Push Through Puerto Rico
text: BAYAMÓN, Puerto Rico — Mitt Romney and his wife, Ann, came to Puerto Rico for a short trip, and left, in the words of Mrs. Romney, knowing “how to par-tay.”

headline: Spring Training With a Flash
text: Adoring baseball fans waiting for their heroes. Sock drills by minor league pitchers. Pre-workout rookie skits. And 8-year-olds shagging fly balls hit over the fence during batting practice.

headline: Second Effort by Jardine Leads Top-Seeded Syracuse to the Round of 16
text: PITTSBURGH — Syracuse has endured all measure of scandal and strife over the past few months. After its latest problem — the ineligibility of center Fab Melo — the Orange became a popular upset pick among bracket analysts. Without Melo, the thinking went, Syracuse would have an abyss in the heart of its vaunted zone defense that would be impossible to overcome.

headline: Letters: Trying to Catch Runaway Tuition
text: To the Editor:

headline: King of the Sky
text: Ron Akana, 83, may be the longest-serving flight attendant in the United States.

headline: 63 Years Flying, From Glamour to Days of Gray
text: DENVER — As the crush of passengers boarded United Flight 618 to Hawaii here last month, they passed by a silver-haired flight attendant in bifocals who greeted them with an “Aloha, welcome aboard.”

headline: A.C.P.T. 2012: Puzzle 1 Update
text: SPECIAL POST — With Puzzle 5 about to start, the stats for Puzzle 1 are starting to roll in.

headline: Sergeant’s Wife Kept a Blog on the Travails of Army Life
text: She detailed her pregnancy, with her husband a world away. She described the knot she got in her stomach from missing him. She wrote of her disappointment after he was passed over for a promotion.

headline: Portrait of Army Sergeant Accused of Killing Afghans Emerges From Wife’s Blog and Public Records
text: After an extraordinary six-day blackout of public information, a complex portrait of Staff Sgt. Robert Bales is emerging from public records and his wife’s blog posts a day after he was identified as the solider accused of killing 16 Afghan villagers.

headline: Suspect’s Multiple Tours Call Attention to War Strain
text: WASHINGTON — Staff Sgt. Robert Bales, the soldier accused of killing 16 civilians in Afghanistan last week, was deployed four times to Iraq and Afghanistan over a decade, a record of combat that at the very least suggests high levels of stress. He was particularly upset about being sent to Afghanistan, his wife wrote last year on her blog, and the family had hoped to be stationed in Germany, Italy or Hawaii instead.

headline: Sims Is Hoyas’ Playmaker in the Post
text: COLUMBUS, Ohio — Henry Sims spent his summer working with the former Georgetown big men Roy Hibbert and Jeff Green to try to perfect his role in the Hoyas’ offense. The off-season work made the 6-foot-10 Sims the most recent Georgetown center to serve as the linchpin of the Hoyas’ Princeton offense.

headline: Pettitte Drawn Back Into a Brotherhood
text: Tampa, Fla.

headline: In New Office Designs, Room to Roam and to Think
text: SEATTLE

headline: When Office Technology Overwhelms, Get Organized
text: HOW do you think most workers would respond if you asked them, “Do you feel more productive now than you did several years ago?” I doubt that the answer would be a resounding yes. In fact, even as workplace technology and processes steadily improve, many professionals feel less productive than ever.

headline: Open Doors, From Open Minds
text: With offices designed by NBBJ, the Gates Foundation and Russell Investments embrace the idea that less space per worker can enhance the working environment, not degrade it.

headline: Making Sure Your Exit Music Is Loud and Clear
text: WE’VE all dreamed about it at one time or another — that exquisite moment when we finally muster the courage to tell the boss what we really think.

headline: U.S. Faces a Tricky Task in Assessment of Data on Iran
text: WASHINGTON — While American spy agencies have believed that the Iranians halted efforts to build a nuclear bomb back in 2003, the difficulty in assessing the government’s ambitions was evident two years ago, when what appeared to be alarming new intelligence emerged, according to current and former United States officials.

headline: Helping Managers Find, and Fix, Their Flaws
text: MANY management coaches teach executives specific skills toward becoming better mentors, delegators or supervisors.

headline: A.C.P.T. 2012: Inside the Judges’ Room
text: SPECIAL POST — I’ve competed and I’ve judged. Judging is better. You might feel differently.

headline: That Wishful Thinking About Tax Rates
text: AT least since Calvin Coolidge, politicians have trumpeted the supply-side benefits of cutting marginal income tax rates. Lower rates will unleash economic growth and the cuts will largely pay for themselves — or so it’s often said. Yet careful studies find little evidence of such effects. Perhaps it’s time to reform tax policy based on facts, not worn-out assumptions.

headline: War Is Brain-Damaging
text: FIVE years ago I saw a television report about Iraq war veterans in California who were being treated for a new kind of brain injury. I was stunned to watch a female soldier who could no longer recognize her daughter. So I tracked down the therapist treating her and began a nine-month journey in which I interviewed dozens of vets with traumatic brain injuries and their families, eventually turning their heart-wrenching stories into a play.

headline: Can Joachim Gauck Make Germany Likable?
text: Washington

headline: Woodson’s Approach Runs Straight Line From Broad Ripple to N.B.A.
text: Knicks Coach Mike Woodson could perhaps receive no higher compliment than being called “a man’s man” by Bill Smith, a coach who regularly made men of boys. But Smith, Woodson’s coach at Broad Ripple High School in Indianapolis, refused to take credit. He did for Woodson only what Jumping Johnny Wilson and Dr. Sander J. Kleis had done for him.

headline: Age and Its Awful Discontents
text: MY mother died in 2004, two days short of her 94th birthday, and 40 years and two months to the day after the death of my father. He died at 65; for the preceding four or five years he had been in poor health.

headline: First, They Came For The Golf Courses
text: Speaking of madness on the right: Ted Cruz, who apparently has a reasonable chance of being a US Senator from Texas, decries George Soros’s plot to eliminate the world’s golf courses.

headline: In Mexico, a Kidnapping Ignored as Crime Worsens
text: MATAMOROS, Mexico — They have spotted their stolen vehicles at stoplights, driven by the same gunmen who used them to take their entire family captive last July. They have reported the brazen abduction to every branch of Mexican law enforcement, only to be ignored, or directed someplace else.

headline: The Soul of the New Hacktivist
text: IN 1988, a Cornell graduate student, Robert Tappan Morris, let loose a computer worm on the fledgling version of the Internet. He said it was meant to be an experiment, but the code he wrote spun out of his control, affecting roughly 50,000 computers connected to the network at the time. Mr. Morris, who happened to be the son of a National Security Agency scientist, became one of the earliest convicted hackers.

headline: In Need of a Game Change, Santorum Plays Small Ball
text: What was Rick Santorum doing in Puerto Rico this week?

headline: Police Powers in New York
text: Attorney General Eric Holder is rightly reviewing the constitutionally suspect surveillance practices that the New York City Police Department has employed against law-abiding Muslims. The Justice Department should also review other practices — chief among them, stop-and-frisk — that have virtually eliminated the presumption of innocence and that treat citizens, and even entire communities, as suspect even after they are proved innocent.

headline: A Memorial Effort Spans Decades and Generations
text: It was to be the largest sculpture in the world: a granite portrait of a Sioux leader on horseback whittled out of a mountain in the Black Hills here. In scale and complexity, the carving would dwarf the imposing collection of presidential profiles on nearby Mount Rushmore.

headline: Fluoridation Debate, Redux
text: Remember all of that cold-war-era paranoia about fluoridation in drinking water? It is hard to believe, but decades after its value in preventing tooth decay was clearly demonstrated, questions are again being raised.

headline: Southern Upstart, New York Swagger
text: OMAHA — Three times in the final minutes of Norfolk State’s 86-84 upset of Missouri on Friday, a Spartans supporter in the stands behind press row called out to Marv Albert, who was about 30 feet away broadcasting the game on TNT.

headline: The Banks Win, Again
text: Last week was a big one for the banks. On Monday, the foreclosure settlement between the big banks and federal and state officials was filed in federal court, and it is now awaiting a judge’s all-but-certain approval. On Tuesday, the Federal Reserve announced the much-anticipated results of the latest round of bank stress tests.

headline: Obama Sets Gas Prices? Just Another G.O.P. Myth
text: Jeff Bingaman, chairman of the Senate energy committee, complained the other day of “widespread misunderstanding” about rising oil prices. He was being senatorially polite.

headline: Cat Got Your Brain
Bypassing the Password
text: IMAGINE sitting down at your work keyboard, typing in your user name and starting work right away — no password needed.

headline: Why Bilinguals Are Smarter
text: Editor’s Note: We’re resurfacing this story from the archives to show you how learning a second language can improve how you think.

headline: Movement According to Martha Graham
text: Denise Vale, the colorful rehearsal director for the Martha Graham Dance Company in Manhattan, teaches the style she learned under Martha Graham.

headline: Staten Island Man Is Fatally Stabbed While Celebrating His Engagement
text: Antonio Lacertosa had wanted to see what was going on when an argument broke out outside a restaurant on Staten Island where he and his fiancée were celebrating their recent engagement with friends and relatives early Saturday, one of his sisters said.

headline: Is Elvis a Mormon?
text: TRUST Mitt Romney to be on top of the latest trend of the superrich: the trophy basement.

headline: Agonies of an Archbishop
text: IN February of 2008, the archbishop of Canterbury, the Most Rev. Rowan Williams, delivered an address on the fraught subject of “Islam in English Law.” The speech, which circled around the question of whether a civil justice system could accommodate Islamic legal codes, was learned, recondite and occasionally impenetrable. The headlines it generated were not: The head of the Church of England, the newspapers blared, had endorsed Shariah law in Britain. Which he had — sort of, kind of, in the most academic and nuanced and trying-not-to-offend-anyone way imaginable.

headline: The Caucus Click: The Week in Pictures
text: Candidates sought to earn delegates in Missouri, Illinois, Alabama and Puerto Rico.

headline: Kamala Harris
text: Kamala Harris is California’s attorney general and the first woman of African and South Asian descent to serve in that position. She recently wrested $18 billion from financial institutions accused of mortgage misdeeds for her state’s beleaguered homeowners.

headline: My Personal To-Do List? The Concierge Has It
text: WHEN Jonathan Swanson, a warehouse associate at Mercedes-Benz USA, was planning his honeymoon, he didn’t log on to a travel Web site or start a Google search. Instead, he picked up the phone and called Circles, a 24-hour personal concierge service that is a free benefit available to Mercedes-Benz USA employees.

headline: Obama Sips a Guinness, Again
text: President Obama, whose Irish lineage and Guinness-drinking cred were confirmed on a visit to Ireland last May, dropped in at an Irish bar on St. Patrick’s Day to sip another pint of Guinness and banter with patrons.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, March 18
text: Politics will again be a major part of the Sunday talk shows, with the Republican nominating contest shifting to Illinois on Tuesday. On ABC’s “This Week” and CNN’s “State of the Union,” Rick Santorum will talk about the momentum he has gained from his victories in Alabama and Mississippi last Tuesday, and Mitt Romney will make another appearance on “Fox News Sunday.”

headline: Sold on Backpage.com at 16
text: The Op-Ed Columnist Nicholas D. Kristof interviews a former child prostitute who speaks out against sex trafficking on Backpage.com.

headline: Disruption Closes a Missouri Caucus Before Vote
text: 8:31 p.m. | Updated ST. PETERS, Mo. – Voters here in St. Charles County did not get a say on Saturday in who will be the next Republican presidential nominee after a disorderly caucus caused organizers to adjourn before delegates were selected.

headline: Haney’s Book on Woods Is About Golf, but Also Gets Personal
text: Tiger Woods and his people have been quick to dismiss the coming book by his former coach Hank Haney, “The Big Miss,” which will be released later this month. In an interview with ESPN.com, he called it disappointing, self-serving and about money. He grew angry with questions about the book at a news conference at the Honda Classic last month, after excerpts were released by Golf Digest.

headline: Ohio State Sends Gonzaga, March’s Original Underdog, to Early Exit
text: PITTSBURGH — One day after surprising victories by Norfolk State, Lehigh and Ohio shredded N.C.A.A. tournament brackets, it would have been fitting if seventh-seeded Gonzaga — the so-called original Cinderella story — pulled an upset of its own against No. 2 Ohio State on Saturday.

headline: The Caucus Click: The Week in Pictures
text: A look back at the week on the campaign trail, with photographs from Missouri, Illinois, Alabama and Puerto Rico.  Go to the slide show.

headline: Rear-End Collisions
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — Wow, what a weekend for puzzles. Three of my favorite constructors — David Quarfoot, Byron Walden and Mike Nothnagel — contributed outstanding grids that made for an exciting solving weekend.

headline: Where Pimps Peddle Their Goods
text: I WENT on a walk in Manhattan the other day with a young woman who once had to work these streets, hired out by eight pimps while she was just 16 and 17. She pointed out a McDonald’s where pimps sit while monitoring the girls outside, and a building where she had repeatedly been ordered online as if she were a pizza.

headline: The Living After the Dying
text: I SAT down to watch “How to Survive a Plague,” a new documentary about the history of the AIDS epidemic, expecting to cry, and cry I did: at the hollowed faces of people whittled to almost nothing by a disease with an ugly arc; at the panicked voices of demonstrators who knew that no matter how quickly research progressed, it wouldn’t be fleet enough to save people they loved; at the breadth and beauty and horror of the AIDS quilt, spread out across the National Mall, a thread of grief for every blade of grass beneath it.

headline: Forget the Money, Follow the Sacredness
text: In the film version of “All the President’s Men,” when Robert Redford, playing the journalist Bob Woodward, is struggling to unravel the Watergate conspiracy, an anonymous source advises him to “follow the money.” It’s a good rule of thumb for understanding the behavior of politicians. But following the money leads you astray if you’re trying to understand voters.

headline: My Life’s Sentences
text: In college, I used to underline sentences that struck me, that made me look up from the page. They were not necessarily the same sentences the professors pointed out, which would turn up for further explication on an exam. I noted them for their clarity, their rhythm, their beauty and their enchantment. For surely it is a magical thing for a handful of words, artfully arranged, to stop time. To conjure a place, a person, a situation, in all its specificity and dimensions. To affect us and alter us, as profoundly as real people and things do.

headline: With Return of Crosby, Penguins Don’t Miss a Beat
text: NEWARK — At the N.H.L. general managers meeting in Florida last week, Lou Lamoriello of the Devils was asked how he felt about the imminent return of the Pittsburgh superstar Sidney Crosby.

headline: Your Brain on Fiction
text: AMID the squawks and pings of our digital devices, the old-fashioned virtues of reading novels can seem faded, even futile. But new support for the value of fiction is arriving from an unexpected quarter: neuroscience.

headline: The Way We Read Now
text: THE case against electronic books has been made, and elegantly, by many people, including Nicholson Baker in The New Yorker a few years ago. Mr. Baker called Amazon’s Kindle, in a memorable put-down, “the Bowflex of bookishness: something expensive that, when you commit to it, forces you to do more of whatever it is you think you should be doing more of.”

headline: Sunday Dialogue: How to Rate Teachers
text: Readers react to an educator’s ideas for fairer evaluations.

headline: Reader Comments on the Trafficking of Girls Online
text: I’ve often written over the years about human trafficking abroad, from Cambodia to India to Pakistan. But we don’t have the moral authority to complain about other countries until we clean up our own act, and today I focus on sex trafficking right here at home. In fact, the young woman whose story I tell in my column, Alissa, was sold by pimps right outside my office in mid-town Manhattan. (You can also watch a video of Alissa giving me a tour of the streets.)

headline: Manning Works Out for Titans
text: Quarterback Peyton Manning worked out for the Tennessee Titans on Saturday morning, completing a cycle of workouts and physicals for the three teams that are known to be finalists to sign him after a weeklong frenzy that has dominated free agency. Manning is likely to pick his new team this week.

headline: Bolton’s Muamba ‘Critically Ill’ After Collapsing During F.A. Cup Game
text: Bolton midfielder Fabrice Muamba was in “critically ill” condition in a London hospital late Saturday after collapsing late in the first half of an F.A. Cup quarterfinal against Tottenham at White Hart Lane.

headline: Russia’s Scandalous ‘It Girl’ Remakes Herself as an Unlikely Face of Protest
text: MOSCOW — It is tempting, these days, to imagine that the political change that took place in Moscow this winter was a mirage. With Vladimir V. Putin’s first-round victory on the books, and major antigovernment protests called off for the moment, most people seemed to slide back, with regret or relief, to routines they abandoned five months ago.

headline: Ethel Winter, Dancer With Martha Graham, Dies at 87
text: Ethel Winter, who brought natural lyricism and startling passion to the Martha Graham Dance Company as a leading dancer there from the 1940s through the ’60s, and who mentored hundreds of students at the Juilliard School, at the Graham school and abroad, died on March 10 in Manhattan. She was 87.

headline: In Iceland, a Teenage Duel and a Battle of the Sexes
text: Iceland has a rich chess tradition. The country has 12 grandmasters, which may be the largest number, per capita, in the world. And as host of the 1972 world title match between Bobby Fischer and Boris Spassky, it has a place in chess history.

headline: Murry Bergtraum Wins 14th Girls’ City Title in a Row
text: Overcoming what its coach called “a season-long, emotionally draining situation,” Murry Bergtraum of Manhattan won its 14th straight girls’ city basketball title Saturday.

headline: St. Patrick’s Day Parade
text: It was a sea of green on Fifth Avenue as big crowds gathered for New York City’s 251st annual St. Patrick’s Day Parade.

headline: With a Vital Substitution, Marquette Escapes
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — Marquette’s Davante Gardner, a 6-foot-8 sophomore, sat and sat on the bench in the second half Saturday while two guard-oriented teams slugged it out trying to find consistent points in a ragged offensive game. Gardner later said he did not play well in the first half and did not expect Coach Buzz Williams to be put him back in the game.

headline: Scores Arrested as the Police Clear Zuccotti Park
text: 1:09 a.m. | Updated  Scores of Occupy Wall Street protesters were arrested on Saturday night as police officers swept Zuccotti Park in Lower Manhattan and closed it.

headline: Militants Free American No One Knew Was Missing
text: BAGHDAD — An American man who said he had been kidnapped nine months ago by Iraqi militants was handed over to United States officials in Baghdad on Saturday night in a bizarre and murky series of events that caught diplomats here by surprise.

headline: A.C.P.T. 2012: Tournament Update After Puzzle 4
text: SPECIAL POST — The leader board has changed markedly.

headline: A Legend-to-Star Conversation at Michigan State
text: COLUMBUS, Ohio — Earlier this week, when Magic Johnson called Michigan State Coach Tom Izzo, the Spartans’ current star, Draymond Green, happened to be sitting in the office. So Izzo passed the telephone to Green so he could talk to Johnson, a Spartans legend.

headline: Once Ignored, a Mountain Hawk Has Gained Everyone’s Attention
text: GREENSBORO, N.C. — The scouts did not notice, the phone did not ring all that often and the scholarship offers did not pour in for C. J. McCollum when he was a 5-foot-6 high school guard in Ohio hoping to play college basketball.

headline: Romney Brushes Off Criticism Over Bain Purchase in China
text: Mitt Romney reacted yesterday to Bain Capital’s purchase of a Chinese video surveillance company, while the Obama campaign accused him of “utter hypocrisy” on China.

headline: Ohio Star Passed Up the Majors
text: NASHVILLE — As upsets percolated all over the country Friday and office-pool wagers turned into donations, the question again arose about how teams like Ohio, Lehigh and Norfolk State could compete with traditional powers like Michigan, Duke and Missouri.

headline: Isner Pushes Past Djokovic and Into the World Top 10
text: INDIAN WELLS, Calif. — John Isner is the sort of underdog who takes out the goliaths not with a slingshot, but with a rocket launcher.

headline: Coptic Pope Dies in Egypt Amid Church’s Struggles
text: CAIRO — Pope Shenouda III, who led the Coptic Orthodox Church in Egypt for four decades, expanding the church’s presence around the world as he struggled, often unsuccessfully, to protect his Christian minority at home, died on Saturday after a long illness, state media reported.

headline: Crosby Carries Penguins Past Devils
text: NEWARK — Sidney Crosby sparkled in Game 2 of his second comeback tour, helping the Pittsburgh Penguins to their 11th win in a row, a 5-2 domination of the Devils on Saturday at Prudential Center.

headline: A Missed Shot and an Unlikely Star Lift Wisconsin
text: ALBUQUERQUE — With Vanderbilt trailing by 59-57 and with the clock down to its dying seconds, guard John Jenkins had the shot he wanted — from the right side, beyond the 3-point arc. He knew it. His teammates knew it. So did Wisconsin.

headline: Santorum Sees in Illinois a Direct Path to Nomination
text: EFFINGHAM, Ill. — Rick Santorum told crowds in Illinois’s conservative downstate that a victory Tuesday would be the key to his nomination.

headline: 911 Calls Add Detail to Debate Over Florida Killing
text: MIAMI — It was raining the night of Feb. 26 when George Zimmerman, a crime watch volunteer, set out to patrol his neighborhood in his sport utility vehicle, as was his habit. Several break-ins had been reported in the area in recent weeks, and Mr. Zimmerman was especially alert.

headline: Corrections: March 18
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: You Think You’re a Frequent Flyer
text: PARIS — Singapore Girl he is not.

headline: Majerus Is Back, and Reporters Are Happy
text: COLUMBUS, Ohio — Coach Rick Majerus has St. Louis in the Round of 32 in his fifth season with the program. But the ninth-seeded Billikens, who will face No. 1 Michigan State, are not the only beneficiary of Majerus’s pearls of wisdom.

headline: Indiana Holds Off V.C.U. as Resurgence Continues
text: PORTLAND, Ore. — Just when it seemed Virginia Commonwealth would add another basketball program steeped in tradition to its list of N.C.A.A. tournament victims the last two seasons, Indiana continued its basketball resurgence instead.

headline: N.C.A.A. Men’s Tournament Photo Replay: March 17
text: Wisconsin edged out a victory over Vanderbilt, and Ohio State held tough against Gonzaga in tournament action.

headline: Youth Hostel
text: At the Fisherman’s Wharf Youth Hostel at Fort Mason, a bunk runs less than $30 per night and includes a decent breakfast. About 20,000 visitors from more than 90 countries — including North Korea, Saudi Arabia and the Cook Islands — stayed here last year, experiencing the Bay’s prime real estate at a subprime price.

headline: Knicks Ride Defense and Bench to Third Straight Win
text: INDIANAPOLIS — In what Jeremy Lin called a “horrible defensive first quarter,” the Knicks’ starters looked as if they had forgotten the urgency that Coach Mike Woodson has preached, while playing about nine miles from where Woodson went to high school.

headline: Unemployed Is Bad Enough; ‘Unbanked’ Can Be Worse
text: Joey Macias has lived without a bank or credit union account for more than a year. To pay his bills, Mr. Macias, a 45-year-old San Francisco resident, waits for his unemployment check to arrive in the mail and then cashes it at a Market Street branch of Money Mart, the international money-lending and check-cashing chain. He keeps any leftover cash at home or in his wallet.

headline: Norfolk State’s Roots Run Through New York City
text: Norfolk State had only just polished off its upset of second-seeded Missouri on Friday night when Chuck Granby’s phone started ringing. And ringing.

headline: Scientists Look Far to the North to Explain Young Whale in San Francisco Bay
text: Recent sightings of a gray whale and her infant calf swimming near Alcatraz and Sausalito in San Francisco Bay illuminated a likely repercussion of melting polar ice, scientists said.

headline: Path for a Housing-Aid Plan Runs Through a Tangle of Competing Interests
text: San Francisco civic leaders are bickering over new subsidies for affordable housing in the most expensive city for renters in the United States.

headline: Not Every Election Is Such a Big Drama
text: Ross Ramsey, the managing editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

headline: Push Comes to Shove Over Water Restrictions
text: FLOYDADA — J. O. Dawdy, who has been a farmer for 36 years, is so worried about getting enough groundwater that he is considering a lawsuit to protect his right to it.

headline: 2 Arrests in Death of Man Found in Chelsea Apartment
text: Two suspects in the death of a Chelsea man found bound and gagged in his apartment two weeks ago were arrested in Orlando, Fla., on Thursday and brought back to New York about 9 p.m. Saturday night, the police said.

headline: Kentucky Is Just Too Good for Iowa State
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — Kentucky should at least be susceptible to some anxiety in a close game, something that exposes their youthfulness and hinders this blur of talent. They have a senior, Darius Miller, who comes off the bench, but they start three freshmen and two sophomores, and they should show some cracks when pressured.

headline: It’s Not Texas, but the Barbecue Can Fool You
text: Can you take barbecue out of Texas and still call it Texas barbecue? A growing number of restaurateurs born or bred in Texas say you can, and they are opening establishments across America where customers can be indoctrinated into the unique tradition of Lone Star barbecue — smoked meat ordered by the pound, served on butcher paper, without sauce or utensils.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: March 17, 2012

headline: The One Who Got Away
text: NASHVILLE — After scoring 30 points in a stunning upset of Duke on Friday, the world got its introduction to Lehigh guard C.J. McCollum. He hails from Canton, Ohio, and his outburst will live forever in slow-motion highlights.

headline: Rural Community Colleges Battle Financial Squeeze
text: SNYDER — The coffers at Western Texas College are about as dry as the windswept West Texas plains that surround it. Reductions in state financing have been a literal drain — last year, the college cut costs by emptying its N.C.A.A. competition-size pool.

headline: Avalanche’s Goalie Masters the Rangers
text: After the Pittsburgh Penguins drew closer in the standings, the last thing the Rangers needed was to run into a hot goaltender. But that was what happened when they faced Semyon Varlamov at Madison Square Garden on Saturday night.

headline: Caught in the Cross-Fire
text: Villagers in southern Yemen are often caught in the cross-fire between government soldiers and Qaeda-aligned militants attempting to impose strict Islamic law.

headline: Driving Harrison Barnes
text: GREENSBORO, N.C. — Back when North Carolina forward Harrison Barnes and Creighton’s Doug McDermott were helping Ames, Iowa, High to 53 consecutive victories and two state championships from 2008-10, they were more than just teammates.

headline: Late Surge Powers Baylor Over Colorado
text: ALBUQUERQUE — For 32 minutes, underdog Colorado answered every Baylor run with a surge of its own. Then Brady Heslip and the Bears said, “Enough.”

headline: Christine Terada and Keith Schuricht
text: Christine Ayumi Terada and Keith Kaiji Schuricht were married Saturday at the Loulu Palm Estate, a party venue and plantation house in Haleiwa, Hawaii, on the Island of Oahu. The officiant was the Rev. George W. Scott, a minister of the United Church of Christ and the chaplain of the Punahou School in Honolulu, which the bride attended.

headline: Rebecca Emmanuel and Henry Rooney
text: Rebecca Ribka Emmanuel, a daughter of Karen S. Emmanuel and Tsegai Emmanuel of Ruston, La., was married Saturday to Henry Michael Rooney, the son of Joann P. Rooney and Michael F. Rooney of New Rochelle, N.Y. The Rev. Hiruy Bereket Gebremichael performed the ceremony at the Zion Lutheran Church in New Orleans.

headline: Jasmine Benyamin, Ash Lettow
text: Jasmine Benyamin and Ash James Lettow were married Saturday at the Cornerstone Gardens in Sonoma, Calif. The Rev. Dr. Joseph Indano, a Presbyterian minister, led a ceremony that included Lutheran, Roman Catholic and Assyrian traditions.

headline: Bianca Harris, Barry Jonas
text: Bianca Blair Harris and Barry Jonathan Jonas are to be married Sunday at the Tarrytown House Estate, a hotel in Tarrytown, N.Y. Cantor Moshe Weiss is to officiate.

headline: Sarah Becker and Zachary Zimmerman
text: Sarah Rachel Becker, a daughter of Dr. Margaret A. Yacovone and Dr. Jeffrey A. Becker of Silver Spring, Md., is to be married Sunday evening to Zachary Kardon Zimmerman, a son of P. K. Fields and Scott K. Zimmerman, both of Los Angeles. Rabbi Alan C. Stein is to officiate at Oheka Castle in Huntington, N.Y.

headline: Lauren Manning, Timothy O’Malley
text: Lauren Elizabeth Manning and Timothy Patrick O’Malley were married Saturday at the Breakers, a resort in Palm Beach, Fla. The Rev. Robert Duggan, a retired Roman Catholic priest, officiated.

headline: Tabitha Oman and Myron Manternach
text: Tabitha Russell Oman and Myron Gerard Manternach were married Saturday evening at the Tabard Inn in Washington. Judge Pauline Newman of the United States Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit, whose chambers are in Washington, officiated.

headline: Barbara Karenko, William Saxton
text: Dr. Barbara Ann Karenko and William Michael Saxton were married Saturday evening at the Cairnwood Mansion, an estate in Bryn Athyn, Pa. The Rev. Frank F. Sparks, an American Baptist minister, officiated.

headline: Margaret Peterson, Andrew Laird
text: Margaret Gabrielle Peterson, a daughter of Andrea H. Peterson and Carl E. Peterson of New Canaan, Conn., was married in Darien, Conn., Saturday to Andrew Charles Laird, a son of Vicki J. Laird and William C. Laird of Metamora, Ill. The Rev. Paul G. Murphy, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Thomas More Catholic Church, where he is the pastor.

headline: Laura Sirulnik, William Zysblat
text: Dr. Laura Raquel Sirulnik and William Zysblat were married Thursday at their home in New York. David G. Beslow, a Universal Life minister and a nephew of the bridegroom, officiated.

headline: Benjamin Miller and Sean Reisman
text: Benjamin Edward Miller and Sean Peter Reisman were married Friday at the Staten Island Marriage Bureau. Edison Stewart, a deputy city clerk, officiated. On March 31, Rabbi David Gruber is to lead a religious ceremony at the Saint Paul Hotel in St. Paul.

headline: Elizabeth Marshall and Jeffrey Leeds
text: Elizabeth Sunderland Marshall and Jeffrey Thomas Leeds were married Friday evening at their home in New York. Former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani officiated.

headline: Catherine Milne, Matthew Bloom
text: Catherine Elizabeth Milne and Matthew Adam Bloom were married Saturday evening at the Deering Estate, a historic mansion, in Miami. The Rev. Nelson Velez, who is affiliated with St. Jude Counseling Ministries, officiated. Rabbi Arthur Pedowitz participated in the ceremony, which included Christian and Jewish elements.

headline: Siva Rights the Cardinals’ Ship
text: PORTLAND, Ore. — As New Mexico mounted a late comeback, Louisville turned to the player who revived its championship hopes over the past month. Sure, guard Peyton Siva produced relatively ordinary statistics Saturday, but he also calmed the Cardinals and quelled the comeback.

headline: Billionaire Founder of Red Bull Dies in Thailand
text: HONG KONG — A founder of the Red Bull empire, a self-made Thai billionaire who came up with the original formula for the high-octane energy drink, has died in Bangkok.

headline: Action-Packed Win for a Top Middleweight
text: Sergio Martinez was expected to dominate his unheralded opponent Saturday night, but midway through the fight, he found himself a little off balance and struggling to land meaningful punches. Still, Martinez, the middleweight champion, did not panic.

headline: Officials Are Saying: Get Out of the Lane
text: GREENSBORO, N.C. — Two controversial calls by officials came in the first two days of the N.C.A.A. tournament’s main draw, but that doesn’t necessarily mean there is a larger controversy brewing.

headline: Wisconsin to Meet Minnesota for Title
text: Throughout the college hockey season, Slap Shot will feature reports about some of the country’s top-ranked teams.

headline: Purdue’s Tall Challenge
text: OMAHA — Kansas, with the 6-foot-10 power forward Thomas Robinson and the 7-foot center Jeff Withey, brings a significant inside presence to its third-round Midwest Region matchup against Purdue on Sunday. That’s something the perimeter-based Boilermakers usually can’t handle. Purdue is 0-7 against teams with productive post players, and 22-5 against everybody else.

headline: Dharun Ravi Case Raises Issue of Homophobia in Indian-American Community
text: I suppose it was inevitable. These days South Asian faces are prevalent in every arena of all-American life — doctors, lawyers, actors, designers, politicians, rappers, activists, socialites, Little Leaguers, Girl Scouts. But now, thanks to former Rutgers student Dharun Ravi, it appears we have assumed a new mantle: the bully.

headline: Arrests at Zuccotti Park
text: Scores of Occupy Wall Street protesters were arrested on Saturday night as police officers swept Zuccotti Park in Lower Manhattan and closed it.

headline: Florida Braces for Hostile Neutral Crowd
text: OMAHA — Billy Donovan knows what it’s like to be an N.C.A.A. tournament darling (see: Providence, 1987). And he knows how much crowds at N.C.A.A. tournaments love darlings. (Ditto.)

headline: North Korean Missile Could Be in Japanese Cross Hairs
text: HONG KONG — The last time this happened, when North Korea said it was launching a satellite using a long-range missile, Japan said it had the right to shoot the thing down.

headline: Newswallah: Long Reads Edition
text: “I live in a house of slamming doors and broken dreams. I am no longer myself, I am convinced that I am starring in somebody’s tragic film,” Meena Kandasamy writes in an intensely moving and personal tale of domestic violence in Outlook magazine. Kandasamy, a poet, activist, translator and scholar, shares her harrowing experience of being married to a violent man and subjugated to severe emotional and physical abuse. Having discovered that he was previously married and has yet to divorce his wife, she leaves him and finds that her marriage is not valid – there is no point in asking for a divorce.  Finding no recourse in the law, and no possibility of punishment, she seeks solace in family, friends and poetry.

headline: Henson and Tar Heels Holding Breath
text: GREENSBORO, N.C. — The verdict is not in on John Henson, the 6-foot-11 North Carolina forward who missed the opening game of the N.C.A.A. tournament with an injured left wrist. The top-seeded Tar Heels might not know until the 5:15 p.m. game time on Sunday if he will play against No. 8 Creighton in a Midwest Region third-round game at Greensboro Coliseum.

headline: In Delhi, Rushdie Issues a Battle Cry
text: “Back in the day, when he was a playboy in London, the most common nickname for him was ‘Im the Dim’ ’’ – Salman Rushdie about the Pakistani cricketer-turned-politician Imran Khan in a speech Saturday in India

headline: Manningham to 49ers, Who Await Manning Decision
text: The 49ers have given Peyton Manning another reason to choose San Francisco. On Saturday, the team agreed to terms on a two-year deal with the former Giants wideout Mario Manningham, as first reported by ProFootballTalk.com.

headline: Statehood Support Should Help Romney in Puerto Rico
text: Forecasting the outcome of the Republican primary in Puerto Rico is tricky. No polling has been done in the race, and it is an outlier in almost every sense.

headline: On the National Mall, Art in the Round
text: The landscape of Washington appears fixed, iconic. The Capitol building, the monuments — Washington, Jefferson, Lincoln — are all instantly recognizable and they are illuminated each evening. But this spring the skyline is changing. The Hirshhorn Museum has commissioned a groundbreaking work of what’s being billed as “liquid architecture” from the artist Doug Aitken, a site-specific installation that will envelope the Hirshhorn’s spherical building with 11 high-definition screens and alter the cityscape of the National Mall from March 22 to May 16.

headline: The Collapse of Employment-Based Coverage
text: Reed Abelson at Economix points us to a startling study on the effects of the Great Recession on health insurance. You can see similar trends in the Census data, but for whatever reason this survey — carried out by a highly reputable group — is even stronger. Here’s the key picture:

headline: A.C.P.T. 2012: An Upset!
text: SPECIAL POST — There has been an upset!

headline: A Hardware Store’s Four-Legged Star
text: Franklin is classified on Facebook as a public figure in Brooklyn, N.Y. His “likes” include “Babe: Pig in the City” and Crest Hardware and Urban Garden Center, a plug for the store in Williamsburg where he can often be found rooting through mulch. He has blue eyes, the inspiration for his name — as in Frankie Blue Eyes — and mellows out while listening to classic rock radio.

headline: A Casino for Gamblers Who Don’t Smoke
text: In efforts to rejuvenate Atlantic City, casinos and resorts have leaned on celebrity chef-run restaurants, sprawling spas and mega-nightclubs. The latest opening adds a new dimension: a smoke-free environment. Casinos are exempt from New Jersey’s nonsmoking law, but when the 1,800-room Revel opens in stages starting April 2, it will be Atlantic City’s only nonsmoking casino resort, intended to appeal to the 81 percent of American adults who do not smoke.

headline: A.C.P.T. 2012: Going Into the Finals
text: SPECIAL POST — In an unprecedented turn of events, two people who will likely be in the finals are going in with errors from the Saturday puzzles.

headline: In Yemen, U.S. Teacher Is Shot Dead by Two Men
text: An American teacher affiliated with a missionary organization was shot and killed by two men on a motorcycle in the central Yemeni city of Taiz on Sunday, according to Yemeni officials.

headline: Disruptions: Time to Review  F.A.A. Policy on Gadgets
text: SAN FRANCISCO — On Monday morning I’m going to drive to the airport, check in for my flight to New York, then head to the airport bookstore for a stack of magazines to read on the plane. I’ll do this reluctantly because I will carry both an Amazon Kindle and an Apple iPad packed full of reading material in my bag.

headline: Ambassador Defends Afghan President’s ‘Demon’ Comments
text: Afghanistan’s ambassador to the United States sought to defend his president, Hamid Karzai, on Sunday after the Afghan leader was criticized for comparing the United States to a “demon.”

headline: The View from St. Louis University: A Tough Matchup With the Spartans
text: During the N.C.A.A. tournament, The Quad will feature posts from reporters at newspapers on campuses of teams that have the potential to be the Cinderellas of 2012.

headline: Santorum Won’t Be Pinned Down on Brokered Convention
text: Rick Santorum on Sunday refused to say how he intends to play the endgame of his fight for delegates with Mitt Romney, even as his campaign was preparing behind the scenes for a brokered convention.

headline: Porn in the USA
text: No special insight — I just wanted dibs on this now that Rick Santorum has decided to focus on our most pressing national issue.

headline: How Bad The Debate Is
text: Many pundits still like to pretend that we’re having something resembling a rational national debate, with members of both parties saying reasonable things given their views about how policy works. And when you find a politician saying something not at all reasonable, there’s a lot of false equivalence — surely both sides do it, even if you don’t have any, you know, actual examples from one side.

headline: Peace March in Damascus Is Cut Short by Authorities
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The Syrian authorities briefly detained 11 members of one of Syria’s most moderate opposition groups during a demonstration in central Damascus on Sunday. The move signaled an expanded crackdown and dismayed the protesters, who have called for dialogue with the government and, unlike many other activists, have opposed the use of violence in the yearlong uprising.

headline: Belarus Censured for Executing 2 in Subway Bombing
text: MOSCOW — Belarus confirmed in a government television report on Saturday night that the two men convicted of bombing a subway station last year in its capital had been put to death.

headline: Doubled Over
text: “I have to go back to the hospital,” the man told his worried wife. A terrible abdominal pain had been his constant companion for the last 10 days and had steadily worsened over the past 48 hours. As they drove back to Mount Sinai Hospital in New York City, the hospital they left just five days earlier, the car was quiet; she was frightened, and he was focused on the pain that seemed to intensify with every passing minute.

headline: Santorum Faults G.O.P. for Favoring Urban Wealthy
text: HERRIN, Ill. – Rick Santorum has accused President Obama of waging class warfare, of dividing America, “the 99 versus the 1.”

headline: For Red Bulls, Prognosis Negative
text: Two games. Two goals allowed in each. Two losses. Too much?

headline: Excerpt: ‘Falling Slowly’ From ‘Once’
text: Steve Kazee and Cristin Milioti in a scene from the musical “Once,” at New York Theater Workshop. The show has transferred to Broadway. (Video courtesy of the production.)

headline: Ethics Fight Over Domain Names Intensifies
text: PARIS — A boardroom dispute over ethics has broken out at the organization that maintains the Internet address system after its most important supporter, the United States government, reproached the group for governance standards said to fall short of “requirements requested by the global community.”

headline: Romneys Make Pitch to Women Before Illinois Primary
text: MOLINE, Ill. — With the Republican primary race turning into a long and protracted slog for delegates that could potentially last until the convention, Mitt Romney and his wife, Ann, made an appeal on Sunday morning to a coveted group of swing voters: women.

headline: Hawks Steering Debate on How to Take On Iran
text: WASHINGTON — Even before President Obama declared this month that “I have Israel’s back” in its escalating confrontation with Iran, pro-Israel figures like the evangelical Christian leader Gary L. Bauer and the conservative commentator William Kristol were pushing for more.

headline: ‘21 Jump Street’ Leads the Way at Movie Theaters
text: Movies based on television shows often lead to box-office disaster (“Bewitched” in 2005, “Land of the Lost” in 2009), which makes the ones that do succeed quite impressive: Over the weekend, a comedic remake of “21 Jump Street” was a big No. 1 at North American theaters, selling an estimated $35 million in tickets. “21 Jump Street,” starring Jonah Hill and Channing Tatum and released by Sony and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, cost about $42 million to make and succeeded because — brace yourselves — it was actually funny. It received strong reviews, and moviegoers under age 25, the target audience, gave the film an A score in exit polls.

headline: How ‘Hunger Games’ Built Up Must-See Fever
text: SANTA MONICA, Calif. — Selling a movie used to be a snap. You printed a poster, ran trailers in theaters and carpet-bombed NBC’s Thursday night lineup with ads.

headline: Freud’s Radical Talking
text: Death is supposed to be an event proclaimed but once, and yet some deaths, curiously enough, need to be affirmed again and again, as if there were a risk that the interred will crawl back up into the world of the living if fresh handfuls of dirt are not tossed on their graves. One such member of the living dead, accompanying the likes of God and Karl Marx, is Sigmund Freud. How often one hears, thanks recently to the fetishization of neuroscience, that psychoanalysis is now bunk, irrelevant, its method decadent and “dangerous,” as the recent David Cronenberg film, “A Dangerous Method,” informs us.

headline: Brazil Bars Oil Workers From Leaving After Spill
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — A Brazilian court has ordered 17 employees from two American companies, the oil giant Chevron and the rig operator Transocean, to surrender their passports, barring them from leaving Brazil as authorities prepare to file criminal charges in days in connection with an offshore oil spill involving the companies.

headline: The Delirious Spirit of the Tarantella
text: The tarantella, according to timeworn southern Italian tradition, is a folk-dance style with a mission. According to some sources, the conventional form of the dance is named for Taranto, the coastal city in Apulia where it took hold. A more colorful explanation, widely accepted in the 16th and 17th centuries, held that the dance’s accelerating triple-time whirl helped to sweat out the effects of tarantism: a delirious condition caused by the bite of an indigenous wolf spider, the tarantula.

headline: The Power of Plutocratic Pettiness
text: Via Rich Yeselson, Alec MacGillis has a fantastic piece in the New Republic (unfortunately paywalled) about how hedge fund managers’ love for Obama has turned into blind, spitting hatred. His main argument is that it’s all about feeling disrespected:

headline: Santorum and the Ghost of Arlen Specter
text: Rick Santorum continues to be haunted by his previous support for Arlen Specter, his one-time fellow Republican senator from Pennsylvania.

headline: N.C. State Sends Georgetown to Another Early Exit
text: COLUMBUS, Ohio — After President Obama selected North Carolina State to advance to the Round of 16, Wolfpack Coach Mark Gottfried sought to explain the pick as simply a move to curry favor among the state’s voters in the coming presidential election.

headline: Syrians Mourn Bombing Victims
text: In Damascus, while some Syrians attended a funeral for victims of Saturday’s bombings, others demonstrated nearby in support of President Bashar al-Assad.

headline: Isner Gambled Against Djokovic and Won Plenty
text: John Isner’s biography at the ATP Tour Web site lists playing poker as one of his hobbies.

headline: Even a Player Who Made It Knows the Value of a Backup Plan
text: “I’m a living example that hard work and perseverance pays off. It was a hard road for me. Everybody is not going to be in my shoes, and you’re going to have to be able to decide what you want to do in life when hit with that harsh reality that you didn’t make it.” — Royal Ivey

headline: Spirited Strings Enliven Work of a Composer Once Banned
text: The composer Erwin Schulhoff, born in Prague in 1894, was one of many artists whose works were branded as degenerate by the Nazis. Schulhoff, of German-Jewish descent, also faced persecution because of his left-wing political beliefs. He died in 1942 in the Wülzburg concentration camp in Bavaria.

headline: Mortgages for Drilling Properties May Face Hurdle
text: The Department of Agriculture is considering requiring an extensive environmental review before issuing mortgages to people who have leased their land for oil and gas drilling.

headline: Cross the River, Find the Passion
text: On Thursday evening at Alice Tully Hall, Bogna Bartosz was singing the alto part in Bach’s Magnificat in D (BWV 243). Her aria, “Esurientes implevit bonis,” comes near the end, and she dispatched its burbling runs with perfect evenness. Not a single note popped out or receded unduly: the line was one scrupulous, straight shot.

headline: A.C.P.T. 2012: And the Winner is …
text: SPECIAL POST — Well, you know by now, right?

headline: From ’60s Patchouli and Free Love to Darker Days a Half-Century Later
text: Lauren Groff’s “Arcadia” is so immersed in the life of a hippie commune that patchouli ought to waft off its pages. It’s a novel of the 1960s and ’70s in which acid is dropped, groats are served, “Froggie Went A Courtin’ ” is sung, a cult leader is worshiped and somebody literally hugs a tree. An outhouse at Arcadia smells like wet muskrat. Children are reared in a Kid Herd. This does not sound like everyone’s cup of rose-hip tea.

headline: In Crosswords, It’s Man Over Machine, for Now
text: Score one for humans and their subtle, quirky, pattern-matching brains.

headline: A Wave of Military Memoirs With You-Are-There Appeal
text: Now that American involvement in Iraq and Afghanistan is winding down, the warriors are telling their stories.

headline: Feeding Hunger for ‘The Hunger Games’
text: The Hollywood reporter Brooks Barnes reports on Lionsgate’s new interactive marketing campaign for “The Hunger Games.”

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: News From the Advertising Industry
text: Accounts

headline: Yale Rep Casting
text: Tracy Letts, Johanna Day, Glenn Fitzgerald and Parker Posey will portray suburban couples who share the same last name in “The Realistic Joneses,” a new play written by Will Eno (“Middletown”), commissioned by the Yale Repertory Theater. The theater is to announce the casting news on Monday. Mr. Letts and Ms. Day will play Bob and Jennifer Jones, who learn that their new neighbors John and Pony Jones (Mr. Fitzgerald and Ms. Posey) have more in common with them than a surname. Directed by Sam Gold (“Seminar”), the production is scheduled to run at Yale Rep from April 20 to May 12, with opening night set for April 26.

headline: Lutheran Pastor Elected as Germany’s President
text: BERLIN — A rights activist and former Lutheran pastor was overwhelmingly elected as Germany’s 11th postwar president on Sunday, putting former East Germans in the nation’s two highest offices at a time when it is being called on to assume a greater leadership role in Europe.

headline: In Memphis, Pre-emptive Bid Paints Picture for Declarer
text: MEMPHIS — At the North American Championships here the two-day Lebhar Imp Pairs was decided on Saturday evening. The winners by a convincing margin were Hailong Ao of Herndon, Va., and Jian-Jian Wang of Clarksville, Md.

headline: You Need a Rubens? Sorry, Sold
text: MAASTRICHT, the Netherlands — There’s nothing unusual about hearing French, Italian, German or even Russian spoken at the European Fine Art Fair. But this year, as the doors to the cavernous convention center here opened for the invitation-only preview on Thursday, Chinese was also a noticeable part of the mix.

headline: Pacific Northwest Ballet Wins $25,000 Grant
text: Pacific Northwest Ballet has been named the second recipient of the Rudolf Nureyev Prize for New Dance, a $25,000 grant designed to encourage large ballet companies to create new works. The award was presented in Seattle on Friday to Peter Boal, the company’s artistic director. The ballet plans to use the money to commission a new work by Alejandro Cerrudo, the resident choreographer for Hubbard Street Dance Chicago, with a New York premiere at the Joyce Theater during the 2013-14 season.

headline: Former Rodale Publisher Joins Harper Imprint
text: Karen Rinaldi, the former publisher of Rodale Books, will join the Harper imprint of HarperCollins in April to start a line of health and wellness books, the publisher said Sunday. Ms. Rinaldi, as a senior vice president and executive editor, will publish roughly 24 titles a year on subjects like science, nature, sports, food, relationships and the environment. Jonathan Burnham, the publisher of Harper, said in a statement that Ms. Rinaldi would “help generate a list that stands for the very best and newest in the field.” Harper has published fiction by Ann Patchett, Barbara Kingsolver and Michael Chabon, and “Going Rogue” by Sarah Palin. It has also acquired a memoir by Amanda Knox, the Seattle student who was acquitted in October of charges that she murdered her roommate and was freed from an Italian prison.

headline: Henson Returns for Tar Heels
text: GREENSBORO, N.C. — North Carolina fans can breathe a sigh of relief. The junior forward John Henson is back.

headline: Speaking Less Than Truth to Power
text: The controversy that has erupted over Mike Daisey’s solo stage show “The Agony and the Ecstasy of Steve Jobs” raises a knotty issue that deserves examination in the light of the increasingly blurred lines, in various media, between entertainment and journalism.

headline: C-Span Founder to Step Down as Chief Executive
text: Brian Lamb, who created the revolutionary nonprofit cable television network C-Span in the late 1970s and has been its public face ever since, is handing it over to two lieutenants, Rob Kennedy and Susan Swain.

headline: Seeking Comfort, and Innovation, at South by Southwest
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — Maybe it’s just because it conforms to some Northerner’s stereotype I have about Texas, but at South by Southwest almost anything Americana-flavored — country, folk, alt-country, cowpunk — sounds great to me. You encounter it even before you show your badge to anyone, in the Waylon Jennings on the van radio from the airport or the twangy din from the musicians who set up along Sixth Street, the chaotic festival thoroughfare here. And during the festival itself, it can be a comfort from some of the fly-by-night indie trends as well as a source of innovation.

headline: Europe’s Two Depressions
text: A note to myself: European industrial production post 1929, from League of Nations, versus European industrial production post 2007, from Eurostat. Better this time, but not as much as you might think — and stalling:

headline: It’s Not Personal, It’s Business
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — A pleasure and a breeze to solve, which is what a Monday New York Times puzzle should be, right?

headline: Art Critics’ Awards
text: The American chapter of the International Association of Art Critics has announced the winners of its annual awards for artists, curators and institutions for excellence in art exhibitions in 2011. The 24 winners, selected by the 400 critics and others who make up the association’s membership, include an installation by Sarah Sze on the High Line (best project in a public space); the exhibition “Bye Bye Kitty!!!” at the Japan Society (best show in a nonprofit gallery or space); the Metropolitan Museum of Art’s “Alexander McQueen: Savage Beauty” (best architecture or design show); and Paula Cooper Gallery’s presentation of “The Clock” by Christian Marclay (best show in a commercial gallery in New York). Awards will be presented on April 2 in New York.

headline: Michigan State Reaches Familiar Territory
text: COLUMBUS, Ohio — Led by Draymond Green, No. 1-seeded Michigan State held off No. 9 St. Louis on Sunday, 65-61, advancing to the Round of 16 for the 10th time in Coach Tom Izzo’s 17 seasons leading the Spartans.

headline: Russian Prima Ballerina Beyond the Ballet Domain
text: Back in the Iron Curtain days when the Russian defectors Rudolf Nureyev, Natalia Makarova and Mikhail Baryshnikov galvanized the West with their dancing, a great sense of adventure generated from their intense curiosity to master as wide range of new styles as possible. But only the men ventured far into modern dance. Ballet technique is at its most specific when applied to its leading women, few of whom have roamed outside its privileged and brilliant enclosure. Today, however, one Russian ballerina exhibits some of the old Nureyev-Baryshnikov eagerness to move beyond the ballet domain: Diana Vishneva.
