text: GoMo, with apologies to the Energizer Bunny, keeps going and going.

headline: Ohio’s Cooper Has Seen the Dark Side
text: 8:16 p.m. | Updated NASHVILLE — When players like Lehigh’s C.J. McCollum or Ohio’s D.J. Cooper put on a transcendent performance in the N.C.A.A. tournament, they are showered with adulation and publicity that is usually lacking for lower-profile programs.

headline: Looking Ahead to Economic Reports This Week
text: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data will include housing starts for February (Tuesday); existing home sales for February (Wednesday); weekly jobless claims and leading economic indicators for February (Thursday); and new-home sales for February (Friday).

headline: A Fan Base Without Borders
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — It was a hot Texas afternoon on a small outdoor stage, with an audience of perhaps 100 people. But the New Zealand songwriter Kimbra was elegantly styled — asymmetrical pale-blue designer dress, deep red lipstick — and grinning like a trouper as she led her band on Thursday afternoon. It was her fourth of eight performances at the 26th annual South by Southwest Music Festival, the four-day music-business convention enfolded by five nights of showcases that ended on Saturday night, bringing more than 2,000 acts — songwriters, bands, rappers, D.J.’s and more — to perform all over Austin, with a long Internet afterlife.

headline: Mayor’s Ties to Hometown Fade, but for a Few, They Are Still Felt
text: MEDFORD, Mass. — David Honeycutt stepped into John Brewer’s Tavern, his family’s sports bar just outside this blue-collar Boston suburb, days before the start of his senior year at Columbia, tipped off that the mayor of New York was eating lunch beneath a wall covered with Red Sox pennants and big-screen TVs.

headline: Father and Son Find Bliss at Creighton
text: GREENSBORO, N.C. — Two years ago, Greg McDermott was in the Big 12 as Iowa State’s coach, and his son Doug had signed a letter of intent to play for Northern Iowa. Two years later, they are both at Greensboro Coliseum with No. 8 Creighton, facing top-seeded North Carolina in the N.C.A.A. tournament Sunday.

headline: A Touch of Lombardi in Norfolk State’s Past
text: OMAHA — Sure, Norfolk State has eight players and two coaches from New York City. But the New York metropolitan influence there began long before Coach Anthony Evans took over in 2007.

headline: Traffic-Free Plaza Roils Little India in Queens
text: The new pedestrian plaza on 37th Road in Jackson Heights, in the heart of Little India, is an oasis of calm, a much-needed stretch of open space in a traffic-glutted area of Queens. Or, it is a glaring example of disastrous city planning, a blighted, unlovely esplanade that has all but decimated commerce in the neighborhood.

headline: Tar Heels Romp, but Point Guard Fractures Wrist
text: GREENSBORO, N.C. — North Carolina was not likely to make a run at a national championship this year without John Henson, the 6-foot-11 forward who was the defensive player of the year in the Atlantic Coast Conference. But just when the Tar Heels got Henson back, they lost their point guard.

headline: The Downside of a Balmy Winter? Long Walks With the Dog Aren’t Carefree
text: Annette Kowalczyk, a retiree, and her trusty dog, Beau, were extraordinarily active last month, relishing long walks through her suburban Chicago neighborhood — a pleasant change from last winter, when icy sidewalks and bitter cold made their favorite pastime downright treacherous.

headline: For 2 Titans of U.S. Court in Newark, Bad Blood
text: NEWARK — One of the powers that be in the courthouse here is a federal judge who used to be a congressman. Another is New Jersey’s top federal prosecutor, who used to be a Justice Department official in Washington.

headline: Theater, Disguised as Real Journalism
text: Is it O.K. to lie on the way to telling a greater truth? The short answer is also the right one.

headline: Hurray for Health Reform
text: It’s said that you can judge a man by the quality of his enemies. If the same principle applies to legislation, the Affordable Care Act — which was signed into law two years ago, but for the most part has yet to take effect — sits in a place of high honor.

headline: Under Pressure, New York Moves to Soften Tough Medicaid Audits
text: New York State was paying for the medical care of dead people when Gov. George E. Pataki and the State Legislature created the Office of the Medicaid Inspector General to curb billions of dollars in fraud and misspending by health care providers.

headline: Florida Crushes Norfolk State’s Hopes for Another Upset
text: OMAHA — Norfolk State’s unexpected victory over Missouri on Friday as a No. 15 seed inspired many of its alumni and students to mobilize and travel here for Sunday’s third-round game with Florida. Some flew. Others, like members of the Spartans volleyball team, made the 21-hour drive from Norfolk and found tickets on their own, since the university sold out its allotment.

headline: Playing at No Cost, Right Into the Hands of Mobile Game Makers
text: Still paying 99 cents to download a smartphone game? That’s far too much. More developers are now giving their games away — and then charging for extra features.

headline: Apple’s Big Cash Pile: The Odds Are Against a Big Deal
text: March 19, 3:19 p.m. | Updated No surprises here. Apple announced on Monday that it would begin paying out a dividend, as well as institute a $10 billion stock-buyback program.

headline: Falling In and Out of War
text: WHEN you’ve been wrong about something as important as war, as I have, you owe yourself some hard thinking about how to avoid repeating the mistake. And if that’s true for a mere kibitzing columnist, it’s immeasurably more true for those in a position to actually start a war.

headline: Drifting Right, Illinois Is Test for Romney
text: CHICAGO — Illinois has been known for choosing Republicans of a moderate brand, in the mold of James R. Thompson, the state’s longest serving governor, or Mark Steven Kirk, the United States senator elected in 2010. So for Mitt Romney, who has had to defend himself against the moderate label elsewhere, a primary here — with its large prize of delegates and the symbolism of President Obama’s backyard — would seem a welcome, natural fit.

headline: Surprise Increase in Rates Is Credited to Signs of Recovery
text: Investors will be closely watching for another rise in interest rates when trading resumes on Monday, after the bond market’s sharpest move in nearly six months caught some traders by surprise last week.

headline: For Knicks, the Leaders Are Leading
text: INDIANAPOLIS — Written on a board in the Knicks’ locker room before their 102-88 victory over the Indiana Pacers on Saturday night were four familiar lines:

headline: ‘Garage Universities’ Are Bracing for School Reform
text: QUITO, Ecuador — There are no ivy-covered walls at Alfredo Pérez Guerrero University. No quad. No soccer fields. The entire campus fits in four small, rented buildings on the fringes of a modest residential neighborhood. Its main entrance is on a busy street, between a furniture shop and a store that sells remote-controlled toy cars and airplanes.

headline: To Clean Up Subway Station, an Unlikely Tool: Bird Calls
text: Considering the setting, the sound is difficult to place: a song of the wild, evoking, perhaps, a disturbed rooster accompanied by a small chirping bird.

headline: The Wrong Way to Shake Up Congress
text: Incumbents in Congress usually have a huge fund-raising advantage over challengers. Big donors correctly assume they will probably be in office for years, and curry favor with contributions that only wealthy challengers can match. So why not try to neutralize this advantage by spending money on behalf of challengers?

headline: Bar Dispute May Have Led to Fatal Queens Shooting
text: An argument at a Queens bar may have led to the shooting that took the life of a woman as she was chatting with her husband and another relative on her front porch early Sunday, neighbors and the police said.

headline: Coach Is Driven Up a Wall, but Louisville Climbs Higher
text: PORTLAND, Ore. — They sat next to each other at a news conference, the coach and the sophomore guard who drives him crazy, two native New Yorkers intent on returning Louisville basketball to prominence.

headline: Data Shows Home Prices Fall in China
text: Home prices in China posted the worst performance in a year in February, the country’s National Bureau of Statistics said Sunday, with the prices in almost half of the cities monitored by the government falling from a year ago as China maintained curbs on the property market.

headline: Pennsylvania and the Death Penalty
text: In the past year, the appalling injustice of Pennsylvania’s death penalty system has been the subject of review and debate among the state judiciary, lawyers and the media. Two new judicial reports and a recent death sentence for an indigent defendant in Philadelphia further bolster the case to abolish the system.

headline: In Swisher’s View, His New Physique Pales Next to His New Mind-Set
text: TAMPA, Fla. — When Nick Swisher talks about the stress he felt last season, he comes across like a walking contradiction.

headline: Justice After Senator Stevens
text: The Department of Justice has acknowledged pervasive prosecutorial misconduct in the corruption trial of the late Senator Ted Stevens. It needs to take an even closer look at the powers and responsibilities of its prosecutors, after a scathing new report on the case by a court-appointed investigator.

headline: Prospect of Jury Trial in Mets’ Madoff Case May Push Sides Toward Settlement
text: As in any civil case, there has always been a chance that the owners of the Mets and the trustee for the victims of Bernard L. Madoff’s Ponzi scheme could settle before trial. But across the past year of acrimony, that prospect has often seemed remote.

headline: From Football Captain to Accused Killer
text: Childhood friends of Staff Sgt. Robert Bales, who is accused of killing 16 Afghan civilians in a March 11 rampage, recall an outgoing young man. But several deployments and an accumulation of disappointments reveal glimpses of a darker story line.

headline: On a Corruption Bill, the Senate Gets It Right
text: A month after both houses of Congress raced to ban insider trading by lawmakers and their staffs, legislation has not been approved for final passage because key differences between two versions of the bill are unresolved.

headline: Momentum Swings Ohio’s Way
text: NASHVILLE — With nine and a half minutes remaining in No. 12 South Florida’s game with No. 13 Ohio, the pace, tenor and score of the game all appeared to be in South Florida’s favor Sunday night. Bulls wing Jawanza Poland soared to the basket and flushed home an alley oop, giving the Bulls a 5-point lead.

headline: New Nielsen Ratings to Measure TV and Online Ads Together
text: Nielsen says it is ready to sell what many advertisers have been clamoring for: a system that standardizes ratings for television and online ads.

headline: Another Pint of Melancholy
text: Sometimes how cool you look depends on where you’re standing. When I first saw the musical “Once” at the New York Theater Workshop last December, it registered as a little too twee, too conventionally sentimental, for the East Village. Yet on Broadway — at the Bernard B. Jacobs Theater to be exact, where “Once” opened on Sunday night — what is essentially the same production feels as vital and surprising as the early spring that has crept up on Manhattan.

headline: Hopes and Fears for Parent Trigger Laws
text: Do trigger laws, which let parents change the way a school is run, help students or charter school owners?

headline: Federer Ties a Record in Masters Tournaments
text: INDIAN WELLS, Calif. — Roger Federer has not won a Grand Slam title in more than two years, but he continued his somewhat more subtle recent assault on the record books Sunday. On a cold, windy day, Federer claimed his record-tying 19th Masters 1000 title, beating John Isner, 7-6 (7), 6-3, in the final of the BNP Paribas Open.

headline: At Home, Asking How ‘Our Bobby’ Became War Crime Suspect
text: He was not the star, just a well-regarded young man who seemed to try to do the right thing. That was Robert Bales, “our Bobby,” friends said. He was a busy, popular kid, but he made time for the autistic man down the block. Other neighborhood boys admired him. As a high school linebacker, he was good enough to be captain, but also gracious enough to help a more talented player take over his starting position. It was good for the team, he said.

headline: Best News for the Mets: These Stats Don’t Count
text: The Mets have not won in their last nine Grapefruit League games, ensuring that they will spend a rare day off Monday with the worst winning percentage of any team in spring training.

headline: Xavier Makes Sure Lehigh Doesn’t Score Another Upset
text: GREENSBORO, N.C. — Lehigh players received a standing ovation from the crowd at Greensboro Coliseum on Sunday when they sat down to watch a portion of North Carolina’s game against Creighton before the Mountain Hawks faced Xavier in the Round of 32.

headline: Mike Silverstein, a Founder of Nina Footwear, Dies at 85
text: Mike Silverstein, a founder of Nina Footwear, a women’s shoe company that grew from a SoHo loft to an international concern selling around 10 million pairs of shoes a year, died on March 12 in Manhattan. He was 85.

headline: Romney Prevails Easily in Puerto Rico G.O.P. Primary
text: VERNON HILLS, Ill. — Mitt Romney hailed his victory on Sunday in the Puerto Rico primary as another step in a slow march to the Republican presidential nomination, a winning streak he is aggressively working to repeat here in the Illinois primary on Tuesday.

headline: Chaleo Yoovidhya, Who Created Red Bull Beverage, Is Dead
text: Chaleo Yoovidhya of Thailand, who earned billions by creating and marketing Red Bull, the energy drink that has added a caffeinated jolt to countless all-nighters and parties, died on Saturday in Bangkok.

headline: A Tale of Greek Enterprise and Olive Oil, Smothered in Red Tape
text: ATHENS — It was about a year ago that Fotis I. Antonopoulos, a successful Web program designer here, decided he wanted to open an e-business selling olive products.

headline: N.C.A.A. Tournament Photo Replay: March 18
text: The No. 15 seeds saw their tournament runs ended as Florida thrashed Norfolk State and Xavier beat Lehigh.

headline: Drones at Issue as U.S. Rebuilds Ties to Pakistan
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Making up is never easy. But as Pakistan and the United States try to restart their troubled relationship after a year of spectacular crises, the difference could come down to drones.

headline: Kansas Rallies Past Purdue and Into Final 16
text: OMAHA — The black-hinged brace on Robbie Hummel’s right knee offers a constant reminder of the two anterior cruciate ligament tears that kept him sidelined for Purdue’s last two N.C.A.A. tournament appearances.

headline: A New Village Built From Scratch
text: The Yurok tribe in Humboldt County, Calif., near the Oregon border, is attempting to build a traditional village where young Yuroks can come and renew their cultural and spiritual values.

headline: A Vision of Reviving Tribal Ways in a Remote Corner of California
text: KLAMATH, Calif. — From a forested bluff, Willard Carlson Jr. stands watch over Blue Creek where its indigo eddies meet the gray-green riffles of the Klamath River. The creek is sacred to Yurok Indians like himself: it flows into high country, a pilgrimage point and a source of curative power for tribal healers. The Yurok consider it their “golden stairway” and weave its stepped pattern into their basketry.

headline: News, the Good and the Bad

headline: Finance Minister Takes Over Greece’s Socialist Party

headline: Eternal Rhythms Embody a National Spirit
text: February 20 was President’s Day in the United States, but in India, “it is the day when the god Shiva is honored as Nataraja, Lord of the Cosmic Dance,” Alastair Macaulay writes in The New York Times. “Innumerable sculptures, going back over at least 11 centuries, depict him balanced on one bent leg. And the placing of each of his limbs signifies a different aspect of his mastery of the elements of existence.”

headline: March 19, 1920 | Senate Rejects Treaty of Versailles for Second and Final Time

headline: A Spring Sprung Too Soon Is Death Blow to a Butterfly

headline: Koodankulam Nuclear Project Gets a Green Light
text: Speaking out Monday in favor of going ahead with work on the Koodankulam nuclear reactors, Chief Minister J. Jayalalitha of Tamil Nadu put an end to the deadlock over the project. Ms. Jayalalitha issued a statement saying that in accordance with a cabinet decision on Monday, “immediate steps will be taken” to help open the plant.

headline: Leading Off: Ohio Big in Elections, and N.C.A.A. Tournament Too
text: Of all the possible outcomes from the first weekend of the N.C.A.A. tournament, it was more likely you would have chosen two No. 15 upsets and a Duke platform-dive out of the first round than predicted we would all be talking about the state of Ohio. Yes, Ohio. If you’re a presidential candidate, you know this state well. If you’re a basketball fan, not so much. Sure, Ohio State flew high for a while this season and yes, once Bob Huggins willed Cincinnati into the national conversation for a referee-terrifying stretch of seasons, but, really, not since the days of Oscar Robertson has anybody focused the college basketball klieg lights here for more than a few minutes. And there are several generations of basketball fans who are now searching Wikipedia to find out who Oscar Robertson is. (Trust us, the Big O was big.)

text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The Syrian authorities briefly detained 11 members of one of Syria’s most moderate opposition groups during a demonstration in central Damascus on Sunday. The move signaled an expanded crackdown and dismayed the protesters, who have called for dialogue with the government and, unlike many other activists, have opposed the use of violence in the yearlong uprising.

headline: On Our Radar:  A Plastic-Eating ‘Monster’

headline: ‘Good Wife’ Watch: Everything’s a Negotiation
text: Such mixed feelings. In a key scene of Sunday night’s “Good Wife” episode, “Gloves Come Off,” I enjoyed seeing Diane (Christine Baranski, wonderful as always) cut Alicia Florrick down to size when Alicia (Julianna Margulies) ambushed her at the elevator and demanded an immediate answer to her request for more money. “Well,” Diane said, her face a mask of disappointment. “Everybody changes. End of the week, Alicia. Or you can clean out your desk right now.”

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Feeding ‘Hunger Games’ Fans, and the Theater of Journalism
text: The marketing effort behind the movie “The Hunger Games” has been a marriage of traditional methods — billboards, magazine covers — and social-media promotions guided by Lionsgate’s marketing division, Brooks Barnes writes. No doubt the film, which opens on Friday, had a built-in advantage because of the many young fans of the book series. Even so, feeding the flame online has been a preoccupation for a year for Lionsgate, with a strategy that included hooking in the blogs, a series of well-timed contests at Twitter and Facebook, a YouTube channel, a Tumblr blog, etc.

headline: Video Shows Damage in Syrian Capital
text: Updated | 1:53 p.m. Residents of the Syrian capital, Damascus, reported heavy fighting early on Monday in one of the few areas of the city where the opposition has taken to the streets. As my colleague Anne Barnard reports, “The fighting started around 2 a.m. or 3 a.m. with several explosions, activists and residents said, followed by automatic-weapons fire and helicopters circling with searchlights, in a wealthy area of the city’s Mezze district that is home to business people, United Nations offices and diplomatic residences.”

headline: Senate Debates So-Called Small-Business Bill
text: The Senate has taken up the House’s so-called JOBS bill, which ostensibly makes it easier for small companies, and many large ones as well, to seek investment in the capital markets, and there are conflicting and confusing reports about what will become of the House’s handiwork on the Senate floor. Though described as a small-business bill, the House’s legislation, as we reported on Tuesday, eases disclosure and oversight requirements for small and giant corporations alike, and some critics of the House’s work had hoped Senate Democrats would temper some of the JOBS bill’s more controversial provisions.

headline: My Beautiful 5-Pound Cabbage

I bought one for $2, took it home and weighed it: five pounds on the dot. It made five terrific meals, all with ingredients I had on hand.

text: Rick Santorum spoke to reporters as he greeted supporters on the rope line.

headline: A Wall St. Firm Advises Greece, With Discretion
text: ATHENS — In unmarked offices here on a dusty block choked with strip clubs and burned-out buildings, several dozen employees of a Wall Street firm spent months poring over bank loan portfolios as Greece struggled with its debt crisis.

headline: Hollis Frampton’s Mysterious Woman in White
text: The sped-up stroll through 1968 Manhattan that makes up the middle portion of Hollis Frampton’s conceptual film “Surface Tension” has a cast of many hundreds if not thousands: the men, women and children who flash by walking down the street, holding hands, ducking into doorways, reclining on the lawn in Central Park.

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
text: Walt Barron joined Peter Mayer Advertising, New Orleans, in a new post, vice president and director for planning and strategic development. He had been a group strategy director at McKinney, Durham, N.C.

headline: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
text: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week. Questions can be sent to stuarte@nytimes.com.

headline: A Sixth Season of ‘Jersey Shore’ Is Spawned at MTV
text: Despite declining ratings – to say nothing of declining civilization – and the pregnancy of a cast member, MTV isn’t ready to say goodbye to “Jersey Shore” just yet. On Monday the cable channel announced that it had ordered a sixth season of the reality series that gave the world Michael Sorrentino (better known as the Situation) and Nicole Polizzi (a k a Snooki), who in turn will be giving the world a Snooki Jr. in the months to come.

headline: Hennessy Goes ‘Wild’ for the Pursuit of Achievement
text: Captain Ahab had his white whale. Don Quixote had his quest to restore the age of chivalry. Dorothy wanted to find a way to get home to Kansas. Now, a campaign for a Cognac seeks to celebrate aspiration and the pursuit of goals.

headline: A Chinese Activist Disappears
text: Liu Ping, the subject two weeks ago of a Female Factor article and a Rendezvous post by Didi Kirsten Tatlow, has disappeared, Chinese human rights activists said on Monday.

headline: Federer vs. Isner: Breaking It Down
text: You never exactly know when, if at all, you will have a chance to beat Roger Federer in an ATP Tour final.

headline: A Speed Record on the Power Grid
text: It’s not Guinness Book of World Records material, but electric company technicians and researchers may have set a speed record in replacing a transformer as part of a drill to determine how the power grid could recover from an attack or a natural disaster.

headline: Caucus Click: Santorum Calls Romney a ‘Government Heavyweight’
text: Rick Santorum, in response to being called an “economic lightweight” by Mitt Romney, called the former Massachusetts governor a “government heavyweight” as he spoke to reporters on Monday morning at a campaign stop in Dixon, Ill.

headline: Rocket Plunge to Deep End of the Planet
text: For centuries, the daredevils known as submariners have slipped beneath the waves in vehicles made for horizontal travel. Their craft are basically underwater ships. Even submersibles, small vessels that dive unusually deep, follow the horizontal plan.

headline: For Librarian, a Less Wholesome Job That Wasn’t
text: Mistaken identity is an occupational hazard for people who are mentioned even fleetingly on the Internet. Still, consider Peter Agree’s shock when he searched the Web for references to his mother.

headline: Calories Are Everywhere, Yet Hard to Track
text: Americans are having a passionate love affair with something they cannot see, hear, feel, touch or taste. That something is calories, billions upon billions of which are consumed every day, often unwittingly, at and between meals.

headline: Throttling Victor Claims His Prize From AT&T
text: Over the weekend, Matt Spaccarelli, the California student who won a small-claims court fight against AT&T over its throttling, or slowing of data, of his smartphone, received the $850 check that the cellphone carrier had to pay in damages. Their fight is over for now, but to Mr. Spaccarelli, the issue of throttling remains largely unaddressed.

headline: Really? Carrying a Cold Bottle Aids Exercise
text: THE FACTS

headline: A British Invasion of Brands
text: “I think Americans are much more into ‘Downton Abbey’ than we are,” Nicky Kinnaird, the British founder of the London-based beauty store Space NK, said recently with a laugh. “That’s just fine for us. They may not be able to wear the period clothes in real life, but they can spray on an English scent and feel like they’re there.”

headline: The White Sox Do a 180
text: GLENDALE, Ariz. — When the Chicago White Sox named Robin Ventura their manager in early October, they informed their employees via e-mail. As soon as the message landed, Jerry Reinsdorf heard an emphatic reaction to the hire.

headline: Mark Thompson, Head of the BBC, to Step Down
text: Mark Thompson, who has overseen the British Broadcasting Corporation’s television channels, radio stations and Web sites since 2004, will depart the public broadcaster later this year, he said Monday.

headline: Prominent French Families Battle Over a Missing Monet
text: PARIS — More than 70 years after it was plundered by the Nazis, a missing painting by Monet that depicts the shimmering blue rapids of the Creuse River has pitted two of the wealthiest and most prominent families in France against each other.

headline: Encyclopedias, Wikipedia and Times Topic Pages: Research Resources and Ideas
text: Last week, Encyclopaedia Britannica announced that, after 244 years, it was going out of print. That inspired us to collect and update our resources and ideas around how and where to research, and to pose questions for students about searching for and using information in the digital age.

headline: Santorum Sees Parallels Between Himself and Reagan
text: DIXON, Ill. — Standing before the statue of a young Ronald Reagan on horseback, Rick Santorum repeatedly drew parallels to the “insurgency” both represented in the Republican Party, and he called on Illinois voters to give him an upset victory in the primary on Tuesday.

headline: Bisher, the Loss of a Legend
text: The press room at the upcoming Masters just got a lot quieter and a lot less fun. For the first time in more than 50 years, legendary Atlanta columnist Furman Bisher won’t be filling it with his booming laugh and charming cantankerousness. Bisher always showed up like a force of nature, so full of life and bluster that people managed to be surprised when he died Sunday at age 93. He had battled time like he battled his sports column topics, relentlessly and with such flair that you always thought he would win.

headline: Case Study | The Pull of Pelforth
text: There are thousands of beers made in or imported to the United States, hundreds of which are dark. I love dozens of them, and certainly appreciate the cornucopia of splendid beers available here. And yet the one I crave in my heart of hearts — and brave ridicule to mention — is a large-production, molasses-dark, blue-collar French beer called Pelforth Brune, brewed since 1937 in the town of Lille, near the Belgian border.

headline: Unraveling Some Mystery Surrounding the Homes of a Reclusive Heiress
text: On the top floor of 907 Fifth Avenue, there is an apartment with intricately carved plaster ceilings, dark wood paneling and ancient wood-framed windows, flecked with bits of stained glass, that look out onto the entire expanse of Central Park. But perhaps the most remarkable characteristic of this imposing space is not its detail, but the fact that nobody has lived there for decades.

headline: Three Officials Announce Bids to Replace Ackerman
text: At least three elected officials in Queens have decided to compete against one another in the Democratic primary in June to fill the seat of Representative Gary L. Ackerman, who unexpectedly announced his retirement last week.

headline: Uganda Attempts to Counter Image Presented by ‘Kony 2012’
text: He has posted a long video to YouTube and sent Twitter messages to celebrities, but so far Prime Minister Amama Mbabazi of Uganda has yet to match the explosive virality of the original campaign against the wanted warlord Joseph Kony.

text: THE HYPOTHESIS

headline: Romney Assails Regulatory Drain on Economy
text: CHICAGO — Mitt Romney came to the University of Chicago Monday afternoon, the day before Illinoisans head to the polls to vote in their Republican primary, and assailed President Obama’s economic policies in a 19-minute speech that was the first major policy address he has given in weeks.

headline: After Critics Notice, ‘Mad Men’ Replaces a Song, for Historic Accuracy
text: Much of the recent coverage of the return of “Mad Men” has celebrated the show’s scrupulous attention to 1960’s detail. On Monday, TV reporters got a sense of how seriously the show’s creator, Matthew Weiner, takes that obligation.

headline: Ebola: Advances Suggest Possible Cures for Fearsome Hemorrhagic Fevers
text: Ebola and its relatives, like Marburg virus, above, are considered among the most fearsome in nature. People infected with these long, wire-shaped filoviruses often bleed to death from every orifice, so the bugs make ideal villains for apocalyptic films like “Outbreak” and “28 Days Later.”

headline: Bartender Will Bring His Busy Past to The Butterfly
text: The bar program at The Butterfly — the new Michael White restaurant scheduled to open in TriBeCa this summer — will be part Wisconsin, part Eben Freeman.

headline: A Map of Taste
text: Q. Are taste buds really divided into sections on the tongue that sense four different flavors?

headline: TimesCast | Fighting in Damascus
text: March 19, 2012 - In Syria on Monday, clashes erupted in a wealthy district of Damascus.

headline: Why Titans Might Have Missed on Manning
text: For the last few weeks, the Titans owner Bud Adams has been reminding people that he’s 89 years old. He did so again on Monday in an interview with The Tennessean, upon learning that the Titans would not land Peyton Manning.

headline: Verizon Fined $140,000 After Electrocution Death
text: Updated, 5:03 p.m. | Verizon was fined more than $140,000 — the maximum allowed by law — for safety violations after the 2011 electrocution death of a technician in Brooklyn, the Occupational Safety and Health Administration announced on Monday.

headline: Killings of Officer and 5 Others Detailed as Mob Trial Begins
text: The off-duty police officer was ambushed by gunmen, and left to die in the street outside his home in Brooklyn.

headline: Other Voices: When Narrative Comes Before Truth
text: The environment writer Keith Kloor, blogging on climate and communication at Collide-a-Scape and the Yale Forum on Climate Change and the Media,* is an able and dogged pursuer of reality amid heaps of online invective and hype.

headline: The New York Times Magazine in Amsterdam
text: Starting Thursday, March 22, “The New York Times Magazine Photographs” exhibition at Foam museum in Amsterdam will be showing photographs that have appeared in the magazine over the past 30 years. The exhibition is co-curated by Kathy Ryan, our photo director, and Lesley Martin of Aperture Books, and will feature works from contributing photographers like Lee Friedlander, Nan Goldin, Jeff Koons, Inez van Lamsweerde and Vinoodh Matadin. Below, a selection of memorable photographs that will be on display.

headline: TimesCast | Theater as Flawed Journalism
text: March 19, 2012 - A theatrical success is revealed as flawed journalism.

headline: Daisey Revises ‘Steve Jobs’ Monologue After Dispute Over Facts
text: Mike Daisey, the theater monologist who has come under criticism for embellishing details about a Chinese factory for his one-man show about Apple, “The Agony and the Ecstasy of Steve Jobs,” changed some of the disputed language during the show’s final performances at the Public Theater over the weekend, according to a spokesman for Mr. Daisey and executives at the Public.

headline: Political Malpractice, Deficit Edition
text: Greg Sargent has more bang-your-head-against-the-wall material about the Obama administration’s “pivot” to deficits. Quoting a new book by David Corn:

headline: How Long Does It Take to Recover From a Marathon?
text: I ran my first marathon this month. It went well, and despite my fears, I had fun. I met my goals — qualified for the Boston Marathon with nearly half an hour to spare and came in second in my age group. But the big surprise was my coach’s advice the next day.

headline: Added Sugars Pile Up on Children’s Plates
text: Older children consume more sugar than younger ones do, boys consume more than girls, and white children consume more than black or Mexican-American children, according to a new report from the National Center for Health Statistics. And they all consume too much.

headline: Santorum Writings Voice Strikingly Consistent Views
text: He objected to Mitt Romney’s insistence that the tenets of Mormonism are not in conflict with traditional Christianity. He said there was good reason to doubt the theory of evolution and argued that intelligent design should be taught in schools. And when critics questioned Rick Santorum on even the most innocuous matters, like his support for stronger federal oversight of pet stores, he fired back.

headline: Carr and Stelter on a Retraction by ‘This American Life’
text: David Carr, the Media Equation columnist, wrote on Monday  about the decision by the public radio show “This American Life” to retract an episode on the factories in China that make Apple devices. The episode was based on a one-man show by Mike Daisey, “The Agony and the Ecstasy of Steve Jobs.” Mr. Carr and Brian Stelter discussed the differences between theater and journalism.

headline: ‘Desperate Housewives’ Case Ends in Mistrial
text: LOS ANGELES—Like so much else in “Desperate Housewives,” the motivation behind Edie Britt’s death will remain a mystery for at least a little longer.

text: 525 Broome Street (Sullivan Street), SoHo; (646) 596-8778; lanikainy.com.

headline: Numberplay: Picking Items from a Bag
text: Probability calculations are notoriously tricky, and the correct answers are often counterintuitive. As Martin Gardner put it: “In no other branch of mathematics is it so easy for experts to blunder as in probability theory.” In the early days of probability, it was commonplace for even great mathematicians to make mistakes. Nowadays the theory is well-established, and straightforward techniques for determining probabilities are available. But even in modern times, experts can often get egg on their faces in simple probability problems, as was seen in the famous brouhaha caused by the Monty Hall problem.

headline: Don’t Know Much About (Musical) History
text: Too funny not to share. From SXSW, a cute sing-along of “This land is your land”, led by Bruce Springsteen:

headline: Now, About Your Bracket (Monday Edition)
text: With the first week of the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament complete, the value of The Quad’s analysis on the statistics most correlated to reaching the Final Four has become clearer.

headline: U.S. War Game Sees Perils of Israeli Strike Against Iran
text: WASHINGTON — A classified war simulation held this month to assess the repercussions of an Israeli attack on Iran forecasts that the strike would lead to a wider regional war, which could draw in the United States and leave hundreds of Americans dead, according to American officials.

headline: Under Pressure From Regulator, MBIA Pays No Bonuses
text: MBIA did not award bonuses to its top executives in 2011, but only after its regulator pressured the beleaguered bond insurer to withhold the payouts, people briefed on the matter said.

headline: The Annual Appointment Loses Some Relevance
text: For nearly three generations, women have been taught that annual Pap smears, mammograms and visits with their doctor were essential to good health.

headline: $200 Million Write-Down for ‘John Carter,’ Disney Says
text: Walt Disney Studios said on Monday that it would take a write-down of about $200 million tied to the science-fiction megaflop “John Carter.”

headline: Report on Ousted China Official Shows Effort at Damage Control
text: BEIJING — Communist Party leaders sacked Bo Xilai, the powerful party chief of metropolitan Chongqing, after being told that he had schemed to remove his police chief and impede a corruption investigation involving his family, according to a preliminary report on Mr. Bo’s actions circulated among government officials.

headline: Lani Kai
text: Inside the cocktail lounge in SoHo, which has expanded its dinner menu to include Hawaiian-inspired dishes.

headline: Gut Infections Are Growing More Lethal
text: Gastrointestinal infections are killing more and more people in the United States and have become a particular threat to the elderly, according to new data released last week.

headline: Caucus Click: A Taste of Jazz for Romney in Illinois
text: Mitt Romney greeted patrons at a campaign stop on Monday at Charlie Parker’s Diner in Springfield, Ill.

headline: Double Trouble From Mountain Pine Beetles?
text: The evolution of mountain pine beetles to produce two generations of beetle per year instead of one has probably been a factor in the unparalleled damage that insects have caused in pine forests in the western United States and Canada over the last decade, according to a new study.

headline: Digital Notes: Judge Sides With Megaupload Over Police Raid
text: Judge Faults Police Over Megaupload Raid: In the latest twist in the story of Megaupload, a New Zealand judge has ruled that the police used the wrong kind of order when raiding the home of the site’s founder, Kim Dotcom, leaving open the possibility that millions in assets could be returned to him. Justice Judith Potter of the High Court concluded that in carrying out the raid on Mr. Dotcom’s home in Auckland in January, the police made a mistake by using a restraining order that gave Mr. Dotcom no chance to offer a defense, according to a report by The New Zealand Herald. Justice Potter granted a new order on a temporary basis, but said she would still rule on whether Mr. Dotcom would be get his property back.

headline: Apple Sells 3 Million New iPads in First Weekend
text: 5:09 p.m. | Updated  Adding information on preorders.

headline: In the Kellogg Family, Dad’s in a Booth, Nick’s at the Hoop
text: NASHVILLE – The Ohio sophomore guard Nick Kellogg hit two critical 3-point shots late in the second half to propel the No. 13 Bobcats to the Round of 16 of the N.C.A.A. tournament.

headline: Williams Partners to Buy Caiman Eastern Midstream for $2.5 Billion
text: Williams Partners agreed on Monday to buy Caiman Eastern Midstream, a subsidiary of Caiman Energy that focuses on processing shale gas and liquids in the Marcellus Shale, for $2.5 billion, in the latest deal in the oil and natural gas patch.

headline: Times Square Lights Up City’s Economy, Study Finds
text: Times Square may be the place hardened New Yorkers go out of their way to avoid, but its importance as a magnet for commerce as well as tourists has risen rapidly in the last few years, according to a study to be released this week.

headline: Romney Misleads on Obama and Energy Prices
text: In a television interview on Sunday and a Web video released on Monday, Mitt Romney said that President Obama has sought higher gasoline and energy prices and called on the president to dismiss three cabinet officers Mr. Romney claims have abetted him.

headline: ‘Walking Dead’ Finale Caps Record Season
text: The season finale of AMC’s horror drama “The Walking Dead” posted spectacular ratings on Sunday night and was the most-watched episode in the series.

headline: The Link Between Reading Level and Dropout Rates
text: In 2010, President Obama, along with Secretary of Education Arne Duncan, Gen. Colin Powell and his wife, Alma Powell, co-chairwoman of America’s Promise Alliance, a youth organization, introduced Grad Nation, a plan to reverse America’s high school dropout rate. Even putting aside the obvious benefits to individual students, they argued that high school graduates fuel the economy, while dropouts cost  taxpayer dollars. The alliance’s latest report, issued on Monday, shows that we’re making progress, but not fast enough — and highlights some of the reasons that every year, more than a million students don’t make it to graduation on time, if at all.

headline: At Heart of Health Law Clash, a 1942 Case of a Farmer’s Wheat
text: WASHINGTON — If the Obama administration persuades the Supreme Court to uphold its health care overhaul law, it will be in large part thanks to a 70-year-old precedent involving an Ohio farmer named Roscoe C. Filburn.

headline: A Night of Winners and Almost Winners
text: Part of the fascination of singing competitions is the lovely, flawed idea that you can use them to extrapolate the current and future states of opera.

headline: Greece’s Socialist Party Changes Leaders
text: ATHENS — Greece’s finance minister, Evangelos Venizelos, formally assumed the leadership of the beleaguered Socialist Party on Monday, saying he would strive to put the country back on the path to economic recovery and restore the faith of austerity-weary citizens.

headline: Cheers Come Early at an Old-Fashioned Affair
text: Throughout the first movement of Grieg’s Violin Sonata No. 2 in G, there is a restless triplet theme. The violinist plays it; the pianist nervously echoes. They chase their way up and down the scale before the movement seems to close with a flourish, the violinist playing two sweeping chords in the work’s home key.

headline: Even Before Broadway Openings, ‘Newsies’ and ‘Evita’ Show Box Office Strength
text: The new Disney stage musical “Newsies” got off to a strong start on Broadway last week, grossing $735,991 for its first six preview performances at the Nederlander Theater – or about $123,000 per performance, more than the musical “Rent” grossed when it set the Nederlander house record of $864,321 for eight performances in 2008. The new box office data was released on Monday at the same time that Disney Theatrical Productions – which mounts the film studio’s properties on Broadway – announced that “Newsies” would run through August 19, instead of closing as originally planned on June 10.

headline: Mick Taylor to Play the Iridium
text: Mick Taylor, the guitarist best known for his work with the Rolling Stones during the early 1970s, will perform six shows at the Iridium in May, the club announced on Monday. Mr. Taylor joined the Stones in 1969 at 20 after playing with John Mayall’s Bluesbreakers for several years. He brought a smooth, lyrical guitar style to the band’s often jagged sound and is credited with helping shape some of its best albums, among them “Let It Bleed,” “Sticky Fingers” and “Exile on Main Street.”

headline: Slimmer Majority of Americans Champions Renewables, Poll Finds
text: The partisan battle over the cause of the increase in gasoline prices has escalated as the average price of a gallon has crept closer to $4, with Republicans accusing President Obama for investing too much in alternative sources of energy at the expense of conventional fuels and Democrats blaming geopolitics and instability around the Persian Gulf.

headline: Illinois Tip Sheet: Must-Reads From a Political Pro
text: Illinois might be the Land of Lincoln and Barack Obama, but it’s just as famous for Al Capone and Rod Blagojevich.

headline: Storms Passed, an R&B Realist Sings of Survival
text: The soul singer Bettye LaVette knows about suffering. In her rendition of the grinding blues lament “The Forecast (Calls for Pain),” at the Café Carlyle last week, this song of deep foreboding culminated with her repeated feral cries of the word “pain.”

headline: Singing Gershwin Ella Style, Salt Added
text: Who would dispute that George and Ira Gershwin, Ella Fitzgerald and Nelson Riddle were pop-jazz Olympians whose combined talents on the 1959 album “Ella Fitzgerald Sings the George and Ira Gershwin Song Book” resulted in a masterpiece of the LP era? Any notion of recreating that album, or even part of it, in concert is a daunting challenge. The list of contemporary musicians who could equal their talents is very short.

headline: Jets Fill Hole by Signing Safety LaRon Landry
text: The Jets bolstered their depleted safety ranks Monday by signing LaRon Landry, who spent the previous five seasons with Washington. Landry, the Redskins’ first-round pick in 2007, joins the starter Eric Smith and Tracy Wilson as the only safeties under contract for the Jets.

headline: The Get | Alexandra Moosally’s Carrot Necklace
text: This spring, the jewelry designer Alexandra Moosally is adding edibles to her selection of whimsical gold and pavé pieces. The most delicious one of the bunch: a carrot charm necklace made of 18-karat rose gold with sparkling white diamond tops. “I grew up in a large Mediterranean family with a lot of focus on food,” says Moosally, who also added an apple (for New York City), an artichoke (her favorite) and a cherry (for the girly girls) to her Foodie collection this season. More than a menu item, too, the carrot is symbolic of Moosally’s past life as a lawyer. (She practiced law for eight years; the “carrot and stick” idiom, in which the stick stands for punishment and the carrot for reward, is one she keeps close.) Consider us on our best behavior.

headline: Woman Leaves Trail of Trash-Can Fires in Midtown
text: A woman who the authorities said was in her 50s led police officers and firefighters on a chase through Midtown Manhattan on Monday for more than an hour, as she set at least 15 trash cans on fire.

headline: Supreme Court Challenges to Obama’s Health Care Law
text: Over three days starting March 26, the Supreme Court heard challenges to President Obama’s signature achievement, the 2010 health care law.

headline: Pictures of the Day: France and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from France, Egypt, Afghanistan and Indonesia.

headline: What Hath Bell Labs Wrought? The Future
text: In today’s world of Apple, Google and Facebook, the name may not ring any bells for most readers, but for decades — from the 1920s through the 1980s — Bell Labs, the research and development wing of AT&T, was the most innovative scientific organization in the world. As Jon Gertner argues in his riveting new book, “The Idea Factory,” it was where the future was invented.

headline: Readers Respond: Robert Bales and the Strain of War
text: Last Friday, we asked you, our readers, to write in with your thoughts on what the case of Staff Sgt. Robert Bales means inside the military, and what implications the killings might have for the larger war effort. You didn’t disappoint in your responses. With nuanced and thoughtful comments, At War readers took up the issues that existed well before the case against Sergeant Bales created a reason for so much introspection across the armed services.

headline: Pastor’s Fiery Remarks at Santorum Rally Reverberate
text: Rick Santorum attended a revival-type church service on Sunday night in Louisiana, where the Rev. Dennis Terry, pastor of the Greenwell Springs Baptist Church, offered some fire and brimstone in a videotaped sermon that on Monday was going viral because of his fiery comments.

headline: The Brontës Are Here to Mess With Your Head
text: “I feel like I’ve just been to therapy.”

headline: Amid Wall Street Giants, a Firm Thinks Small and Exclusive
text: When courting new business, Wall Street’s deal makers often point to their long client lists as proof of deep industry knowledge.

headline: Ruffled Feathers on the Way to Swanhood
text: Too sophisticated for its intended audience and too shrill for the grown-ups in tow, “Lucky Duck” is a rare miscalculation for the New Victory Theater. This raucous reboot of “The Ugly Duckling” fable ends up nestling uneasily between bratty and brainy. It’s neither fish nor waterfowl.

headline: Amazon.com to Acquire Manufacturer of Robotics
text: Amazon.com is buying an army of robots.

headline: To Infinity and Beyond: Bart, Lucy and the Gang
text: We who live within get-the-shotgun distance of Grovers Mill, the spot in central New Jersey that Orson Welles chose for his panic-inducing “War of the Worlds” landing in 1938, are naturally reluctant to endorse the promulgation of fake alien arrivals via a broadcast medium. But there’s a darned good one in progress on the Science Channel, part of a month of programs on the theme “Are We Alone?”

headline: Family Tree’s Startling Roots
text: Thirty-nine lashes “well laid” on her bare back and an extension of her indentured servitude was Elizabeth Banks’s punishment for “fornication & Bastardy with a negroe slave,” according to a stark June 20, 1683, court document from York County, Va. Through the alchemy of celebrity and genealogy, that record and others led to the recent discovery that Banks, a free white woman despite her servitude, was the paternal ninth great-grandmother of Wanda Sykes, the ribald comedian and actress.

headline: Sony Extends Contract of Music Executive
text: Sony has extended the contract of the man who will oversee its music publishing business, a division that is poised to greatly expand if Sony’s bid for EMI is approved.

headline: Albums From Wiz Khalifa, Melanie Fiona and Lost in the Trees
text: WIZ KHALIFA

headline: A Master of Timing, Even When the Music Has No Beat
text: The gala for the Paul Taylor Dance Company last week featured a film that began by telling the history of American modern dance in three stages: First there was Martha Graham, then there was Merce Cunningham, “then there was Paul Taylor, who let the sun shine in.” A burst of applause followed from the audience, and then the film turned its focus to Mr. Taylor’s “Aureole,” created 50 years ago.

headline: More About Chefs, Their Recipes and Who Writes Cookbooks
text: What is a ghostwriter, anyway?

headline: Uptown Palazzo Project
text: When the Andrew Freedman Home opened in the Bronx in 1924, it looked like a limestone luxury liner sailing up the Grand Concourse, a grandiosity that advertised its odd function: a privately endowed retirement home for the formerly well-to-do, those who might have lost their money but not their manners or manorial tastes.

headline: Strolling in the Park, Succumbing to Temptation
text: If New York City Opera is to have any success in its new manifestation as a scaled-down, roving company, then every production will have to be a must-see event. It finally has one, with the director Christopher Alden’s new production of Mozart’s “Così Fan Tutte,” which opened at the Gerald W. Lynch Theater of John Jay College on Sunday afternoon.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Mobile Data Leaks, and Rising and Falling Game Apps
text: Interesting things that reporters and editors for The New York Times found on the Web on Monday. Find more Scuttlebot items here.

headline: By Her (Couture) Hair You Shall Know Her
text: IT wasn’t your traditional sample sale. On a recent lunch hour, a stream of well-coiffed professional women descended upon a salon in the Flatiron district of Manhattan. They weren’t tearing through boxes of designer shoes or ripping through racks of clothing. These women came looking for something more personal: wigs.

headline: Santorum Waves Away Economics
text: MOLINE, Ill. — Defying almost all conventional wisdom about the 2012 election, Rick Santorum said the race would not turn on the economy and so it wasn’t important if unemployment and growth rates rose or fell.

headline: In Illinois, Santorum’s Chance at Nomination Is Slipping Away
text: A quick glance at the map might tempt you into thinking that the Republican nomination is roughly an even battle between Mitt Romney and Rick Santorum, with Mr. Romney tending to prevail in the Northeast and the West, and Mr. Santorum in the Midwest and the South.

headline: British Journalists Held for a Month in Libya Had Reported on Revenge Attacks
text: Two British journalists detained last month by a Libyan militia that accused them of spying were released without charge by Libya’s government and allowed to fly home on Monday, Reuters reports.

headline: For E.V. Drivers, a Stretch of Oregon Interstate to Relieve Range Anxiety
text: Until better batteries are developed, most electric cars will be range-challenged. But with the opening of the first section of the so-called West Coast Electric Highway on March 16 in Oregon, battery vehicles can travel for longer distances, at least along and immediately beyond the corridor.

headline: Hi! I’m a Nutria
text: In this animated short by the filmmaker Drew Christie, a rodent living in Washington State defends criticism that he is an invasive species and asks, “How long does it take to become a native?”

headline: Paul Taylor Dance Company

headline: Scouting the Draft: Wisconsin’s Peter Konz

headline: ‘Hi! I’m a Nutria’
text: According to family legend, my grandfather and his brother, after realizing that they were knee deep in a losing venture, released their nutria in western Washington State in the early 1960’s. They had been raising the rodents to sell for their fur, which would be made into coats and hats. Since my grandfather died before I was born, I have never been able to fully corroborate these events. However, this episode has forever been emblazoned in my mind as both an act of short-sighted ecological vandalism and a sign of humanity.

headline: The Perfect Proposal: A Victory and a ‘Yes’
text: TUCSON — As competitions go, the USA Swimming Grand Prix meet last month was decidedly low-key, another in a series of mile markers leading to the Olympic trials in June. So why, before the 100-meter backstroke final, did Matt Grevers feel as nervous as he had at the 2008 Summer Games in Beijing?

headline: Spring Gets Ahead of Itself
text: THE first day of spring isn’t what it used to be. In fact, over the past several decades spring weather has been arriving earlier in most parts of the United States. This shift affects all aspects of life — from when flowers bloom to when animals migrate and have babies — the very things that make spring magical.

headline: Strained by Sanctions, Iran Eases Money Policy
text: Pressured by tightened Western economic sanctions and a burgeoning black market for dollars, with Iranian citizens desperate to buy them, Iran’s central bank has loosened its strict foreign exchange policy, allowing money traders there to sell dollars for rials at the unofficial market rate, rather than the artificially fixed official rate.

headline: Supreme Court Examines Roles of Jury and Judge in Setting Fines

But the real issue in the case, as the justices’ questioning made clear, was whether the court remained committed to the logic of a 2000 decision that said the Constitution sometimes bars judges from making factual findings that lead to increased punishments.

headline: When the Good Do Bad

headline: The Sentence as a Miniature Narrative
text: I like to imagine a sentence as a boat. Each sentence, after all, has a distinct shape, and it comes with something that makes it move forward or stay still — whether a sail, a motor or a pair of oars. There are as many kinds of sentences as there are seaworthy vessels: canoes and sloops, barges and battleships, Mississippi riverboats and dinghies all-too-prone to leaks. And then there are the impostors, flotsam and jetsam — a log heading downstream, say, or a coconut bobbing in the waves without a particular destination.

text: McLEAN, Tex. — No one can remember if the brassiere factory on Kingsley Street here put up barbed wire to keep intruders out. These days, hundreds of strands of barbed wire draw people in.

headline: Injustice in a Sentencing Law
text: The Armed Career Criminal Act has long been a source of confusion for federal judges who are required to apply it in criminal cases. The act ratchets up sentences to a mandatory minimum of 15 years for felons who illegally possess guns and have three prior violent felony convictions. Some judges have misinterpreted this statute, with grievous results, as happened in the case of John Joel Foster. He could end up serving 15 years in prison rather than 27 months for possession of a firearm because the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit wrongly categorized 20-year-old crimes as violent felonies.

headline: Seeding the Southern Continent
text: The word is propagule. It means any detachable part of a plant that can be used for reproduction — a spore, a seed, a broken bit of stem or root. The burrs that stick in your socks after a walk in the woods are propagules. Wherever humans have gone, we have inadvertently carried propagules with us, changing patterns of biodiversity as we do so. As it happens, we carry propagules even to Antarctica, one of earth’s most pristine places.

headline: Interviews with a medical power couple; a disturbing rise in gastric distress; and a filmmaker takes the plunge.

headline: After Dropping Gloves, Rangers Clinch Playoff Spot

headline: The New Suburban Poverty
text: In many of America’s once pristine suburbs, harbingers of inner-city blight — overgrown lots, boarded up windows, abandoned residences — are the new eyesores. From the Midwestern rust-belt to the burst housing bubbles of Nevada, California and Florida, even in small pockets of still affluent regions like Du Page County, Ill., the nation’s soaring poverty rates are visibly reclaiming last century’s triumphal “crabgrass frontier.” In well-heeled Illinois towns like Glen Ellyn and Elgin, unkempt, weedy lawns blot the formerly manicured, uniform and tidy landscape.

headline: Florida: Civil Rights Inquiry Into Teenager’s Shooting
text: The Justice Department has opened a civil rights investigation into the case of a black teenager killed by a volunteer community watch member in Florida, according to a statement from the department. The teenager, Trayvon Martin, 17, was fatally shot while walking in a gated neighborhood near Orlando on Feb. 26. The volunteer, George Zimmerman, 28, who is white and Hispanic, said he had acted in self-defense. The Justice Department’s civil rights division, the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the United States attorney’s office for the Middle District of Florida are investigating the “facts and circumstances” of Mr. Martin’s death, according to the department statement.

headline: Mulgrew to Walcott: Use Loan Forgiveness to Retain Teachers
text: In a letter on Monday to Chancellor Dennis M. Walcott, Michael Mulgrew, the president of the teachers' union, reminded city officials that any loan forgiveness program for teachers must be negotiated. But Mr. Mulgrew offered conditional support for the mayoral proposal, with the recommendation that it be used to keep experienced teachers in the system and discourage the kind of turnover that robs pupils of teachers with proven abilities.

headline: China: Thief Who Stole Museum’s Purses Is Sentenced
text: Shi Baikui, a 27-year-old farmer, was sentenced on Monday in Beijing to 13 years in prison for stealing nine 20th-century purses encrusted with gold and jewels from an exhibition at the Palace Museum in the Forbidden City last May. Five of the purses were found on the palace grounds, apparently dropped as the thief fled. The court said that Mr. Shi had thrown away the remaining four purses the day after the theft after realizing they would be hard to sell; three of the purses are still missing. The official Xinhua news agency said that the total value of those three purses was $23,800.

headline: Arizona: Giffords Aide Will Seek a Full Term
text: Ron Barber, who was a top aide to Representative Gabrielle Giffords and was injured in the same shooting that nearly killed her, said Monday that he would run this fall in the newly created Southern Arizona Congressional district. Mr. Barber has been campaigning to complete Ms. Giffords’s term in a June special election, in which he will face one of four Republicans seeking their party’s nomination. Mr. Barber had not publicly said he would not run for the full term in the fall, but several Democrats said last month that they expected him only to complete Ms. Giffords’s term. Four Democrats had already begun collecting signatures to get on the ballot for the August primary. Mr. Barber said that he spoke to each of them Monday and that he expected at least two to step out of the race. “What I learned quickly is that the campaign is really exciting and energizing,” Mr. Barber said Monday. “I realized that I might be able to make some impact in half a year, but that it would take longer to make a real impact.”

headline: Searchers Find Body of Balloon Pilot Who Saved 5 Before Being Swept Off
text: ATLANTA — A hot-air balloon pilot who was swept thousands of feet into the clouds by a surprise storm seconds after five skydivers leapt to safety was found dead in the deep south Georgia woods Monday, his deflated balloon draped over the basket that held his body.

headline: An American Jihadist in Somalia Claims His Colleagues Want to Kill Him
text: Updated | Tuesday | 10:52 a.m. Omar Hammami, an Alabama native who traveled to Somalia in 2006 to join a radical Islamist group, has apparently come to regret his choices.

headline: A Ferrari Crash in Beijing Leads to More Political Intrigue
text: HONG KONG — The real March Madness, at least in Asia, has been the precipitous fall of Bo Xilai, one of China’s most flamboyant (and now disgraced) Communist Party bosses. The story has read like a John le Carré rewrite of Raymond Chandler, with the forced singing of “red anthems” from the Maoist era, rumors of cloak-and-dagger corruption, the Eliot Ness of China staging a late-night attempt to defect to the United States, his subsequent detention by State Security agents (under what is creepily being called “vacation-style treatment”) and an unprecedented public smackdown of Mr. Bo by Prime Minister Wen Jiabao.

headline: Why Germans Believe Joachim Gauck Can Redeem Their Country

headline: Attacks Strike as Iraq Plans to Welcome Arab Leaders

headline: If Bilingual Is Good, Is Trilingual Better?
text: “Being bilingual, it turns out, makes you smarter,” Yudhijit Bhattacharjee writes in an op-ed in The New York Times. “It can have a profound effect on your brain, improving cognitive skills not related to language and even shielding against dementia in old age.”

headline: March 20, 1995 | Japanese Cult Carries Out Sarin Gas Attack on Tokyo Subway

headline: The Best Nanny Money Can Buy
text: It took Zenaide Muneton 20 seconds to convince me that she was the perfect nanny. Short and dark-haired, she has a goofy, beaming smile and knows how to make everything fun for a little kid. Time to brush your teeth? She shakes her hands and does a pantomimed teeth-brushing dance. Bath time? She pumps her arms up and down in a going-to-the-tub march. After I told her I’d love to hire her, she smiled and thanked me.

headline: Romance and Ruin, All in the Air
text: For the most part, the photographs recount celebratory moments plucked from a history riddled with tragedy. They chronicle the early days of the dirigible, or airship, up to the fateful 1937 crash of the Hindenburg over Lakehurst, N.J., which killed 36 and put a quick end to the age of the airship.

headline: Into Thin Air
text: Last month, North Korea agreed to suspend nuclear efforts and missile launches in exchange for U.S. food aid. Last Friday, it announced that it would use a long-range missile to launch a satellite into orbit in mid-April, to mark the 100th anniversary of state founder Kim Il-sung’s birthday. Whither the negotiations?

headline: Where Is the Line Between Truth and Fiction?
text: On Friday, “This American Life” retracted its presentation of Mike Daisey‘s solo theater show “The Agony and the Ecstasy of Steve Jobs” after discovering that Mr. Daisey had fabricated portions of it. Is it acceptable that the show — which helped shine a spotlight on labor practices at factories in China that manufacture Apple products — is true in spirit but not, in many ways, in fact? Or, as some critics contend, was Mr. Daisey being disingenuous and misleading in presenting the story as nonfiction when many parts were fictionalized?

headline: Syrian Insurgents Accused of Rights Abuses
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Armed Syrian defectors took their uprising into the heart of a heavily guarded and wealthy district of Damascus on Monday, clashing with security forces in what activists and residents called the most intense fighting in such a strategic area since the protests against President Bashar al-Assad began a year ago.

headline: Three for Three in College Acceptances, With Nine More to Go
text: A letter. An e-mail. A phone call. All methods that colleges use to notify students of admissions decisions. It seems as if every day, a friend of mine is being accepted somewhere. Every day, certain hopes are being fulfilled, while others are being diminished.

headline: The Early Word: Illinois
text: Mitt Romney went to President Obama’s Chicago neighborhood on Monday to show how tough he could be if he becomes the Republican presidential nominee. In a Political Memo, Jim Rutenberg and Jeff Zeleny write that the results in the Illinois primary today could test whether Mr. Romney “can regain for good” the sense that he will inevitably become the party’s nominee.

headline: Fantasy Focus: Precious Dollars
text: With Tout Wars, an elite mixed-league auction, coming up this weekend, I am completing the final steps in my preparation. Last season, the 15 teams in the league (which has a $260 budget) purchased 45 players for $1 each. Three of each team’s 23 starting spots filled with the minimum bid may not seem all that high, but that does translate to 13 percent of the player pool, which should serve as an indication that there is an art to controlling the endgame by carefully nominating players after your opponents have all fallen to maximum bid positions of $1.

headline: The Origin of Modern Republican Fiscal Policy
text: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of “The Benefit and the Burden: Tax Reform — Why We Need It and What It Will Take.” He also talks with Catherine Rampell about this post on today’s Business Day Live video.

headline: Deutsche Borse to Appeal Blocked Merger with NYSE Euronext
text: Deutsche Börse has decided to appeal the decision by European antitrust regulators that blocked its planned merger with NYSE Euronext.

headline: In India, History Literally Rots Away
text: Nations such as Russia and China destroyed historical documents and artifacts in fits of revolutionary zeal. India has taken a much easier route: it has allowed many priceless papers and other items to slowly disintegrate in, or be stolen from, institutions starved of funding, bereft of proper facilities and trained staff, and lacking proper security.

headline: Pakistani Parliament Demands End to U.S. Drone Strikes
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — A major parliamentary review of relations with the United States opened on Tuesday with calls for an end to drone strikes and for an unconditional apology for an American attack that killed Pakistani soldiers last November.

headline: As Woes Recede, Europe’s Public Offerings Find Favor
text: LONDON — After months of economic uncertainty caused by the European debt crisis, investors are starting to venture back into the Continent’s financial markets.

headline: 2013 SL65 AMG Muscles In on SLS AMG Roadster
text: Though AMG, the in-house performance division at Mercedes-Benz, has been wringing triple-digit horsepower and torque gains from the German brand’s V-8 engines, its engineers have not wrenched on the automaker’s stout 6-liter V-12 in a few years.

headline: Tensions With Iran: Accidents Can Happen
text: LONDON — It is supposed to be a time of hope and new beginnings for the people of Iran as on Tuesday they began celebrating the 13-day New Year festival of Nowruz. But the omens are not good.

headline: Making Sense of Campaign Fund-Raising Totals
text: It has become a ritual every four weeks — the moment when the presidential campaigns reveal how much cash they hauled in over the previous month.

headline: The Mystery of Why Manning Chose Denver
text: For weeks, we’ve been waiting for Peyton Manning to tell us where. Now we’re waiting for him to tell us why. Why Denver?

headline: After 2 Years of Testing, Venmo Opens Payment Service to Public
text: After more than two years in beta testing, Venmo, a mobile payments service that lets people send money to their friends, is opening its doors to the public on Tuesday.

headline: Shares Fall on Concerns of a Slowdown in China
text: Stocks declined on Tuesday, ending a three-day advance for the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index, as commodities fell on concern about a Chinese economic slowdown.

headline: Of Human Bondage
text: LONDON — After I announced the dates for my wedding last year, colleagues and acquaintances in Pakistan began asking whether I was having a “love marriage” or an “arranged marriage.” I didn’t think the question was inappropriate or offensive: arranged marriages — in which a third party, often a family member, plays matchmaker with the consent of the couple — remain the norm in conservative societies and across many socioeconomic groups. I had expected to be grilled.

headline: Daily Report: Some Sites Bypass Google Maps
text: When it comes to offering online maps to their users, some companies have been leaving Google Maps and setting out for less familiar territory, Quentin Hardy reports in Tuesday’s New York Times.

headline: High Schools Scramble to Use Credit Recovery Before Policy Ends
text: One of the creative accommodations that has developed in this era of data-driven education is about to come to an end, and some city high schools and their students are making a last-ditch effort to take advantage of it.

headline: A Race Out the Door
text: UPDATED | In an opinion article, a teacher writes: "Recent policy changes send mixed messages regarding the importance of experienced teachers in the classroom. On the one hand, everyone is saying that an effective teacher is the most important factor in a child’s success. But they’re doing everything within their power to push experienced teachers out of the classroom."

headline: Jefferies Posts $77 Million Quarterly Profit
text: 3:49 p.m. | Updated

headline: House G.O.P. Lays Down Marker With New Budget Plan
text: WASHINGTON — House Republicans thrust their vision of a smaller government, a flatter tax code and a free-market Medicare system into the 2012 election season on Tuesday, banking that fears over surging federal deficits will trump longstanding voter allegiances to popular government programs.

headline: Political Geography: Illinois
text: As FiveThirtyEight has discussed, the political and cultural divide between the Chicago area and the rest of Illinois is stark.

headline: Tuesday Reading: The Annual Exam for Women Loses Some Relevance
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: Deutsche Bank Cuts Top Managers’ Pay
text: Anshu Jain, the incoming co-chief executive of Deutsche Bank, took a 23 percent cut in his compensation last year after the European sovereign debt crisis and turmoil in financial markets prompted a loss in the investment banking division.

headline: The $180,000 Nanny: Worth Every Penny?
text: For an article titled “The Best Nanny Money Can Buy” in next Sunday’s Times Magazine, Adam Davidson talked with Zenaide Muneton, a nanny represented by the Pavillion Agency, which specializes in finding domestic workers for New York City’s wealthy. When you add in the perks — an annual bonus and a $3,000-a-month rental apartment — she makes considerably more than that $180,000 salary. She accompanies her employers on vacations and does an impressive tooth-brushing dance.

headline: A Florida Law Gets Scrutiny After a Teenager’s Killing
text: MIAMI — Seven years after Florida adopted its sweeping self-defense law, the shooting of Trayvon Martin, an unarmed black teenager, has put that law at the center of an increasingly angry debate over how he was killed and whether law enforcement officers have the authority to charge the man who killed him.

headline: Indian Jewelers Put Their Work on World Stage
text: “For centuries, India has been the world’s back office for jewelry making. A main supplier of precious stones, the country was also the world’s sole source of diamonds until they were discovered in Brazil in 1729,” Gayarti Rangachari Shah writes in The New York Times.

headline: Why It’s Sometimes O.K. to Bad-Mouth an Old Boss
text: There is now one more person out of work in this great country of ours, Greg Smith. If you haven’t heard, he is the man who recently quit his job at the investment bank Goldman Sachs, doing so in dramatic fashion.

headline: Face Time | Isabelle Fuhrman
text: I met up with the beautiful young actress Isabelle Fuhrman during her recent trip to New York. Fuhrman, who is in “The Hunger Games” (opening March 23), was with her lovely mother, Elina, so we got to have some real girls time — it was fun! Isabelle’s energy, honesty and curiosity were refreshing. So was her interest in her latest discovery, makeup. I would recommend seeing “The Hunger Games.” I have a feeling she will rock it as well as she does a red lip!

headline: We Ain’t Got Dames: Edna Everage Plans Her Retirement
text: Take a long last look at Dame Edna Everage and say goodbye, possums: at the end of a coming stage tour she will take off her garish glasses and wisteria-colored wig and return to being Barry Humphries, the actor and comedian who has portrayed the outspoken, outrageous character in various incarnations for more than half a century.

headline: Glencore to Buy Viterra of Canada for $6.2 Billion
text: OTTAWA — A consortium led by Glencore International reached a deal to acquire Viterra, the largest Canadian grain handler, for $6.2 billion, a widely anticipated transaction that will expand the commodities trader’s presence in agriculture.

headline: A Trip Abroad That’s Unlikely to Inspire the Mayor
text: A good thing about a mayor who believes he already knows pretty much all he needs to know is that he’s not likely to acquire really bad habits as he floats around the world.

headline: Image of the Day: March 20
text: Storm destroys hundreds of homes and disrupts life in Jammu and Kashmir.

headline: Into the Apocalypse With an Unruffled Tour Guide
text: How well should a historian write? That’s a complicated question, but it’s hard to disagree with George Orwell, who thought that any exemplary book should not only be an intellectual but “also an aesthetic experience.”

headline: Fury in Israel at Remark Linking Gaza to Toulouse
text: JERUSALEM — Israel’s leaders on Tuesday strongly censured the European Union’s foreign policy chief, Catherine Ashton, for remarks made a day earlier in which she was perceived as having equated the killing of three children at a Jewish school in France with the death of children during the fighting in Gaza.

headline: Teixeira’s Exit Creates a Job Opening at FIFA
text: NEWS ITEM: SÃO PAULO (Reuters) — Ricardo Teixeira severed his ties with football’s international governing body on Monday, a week after he resigned as head of the Brazilian Football Confederation and organizer of the 2014 World Cup. Teixeira said he was stepping down from FIFA’s executive committee for personal reasons. He had been a member of the committee since 1994 and until recently was seen as a possible successor to FIFA president Sepp Blatter.

headline: Do You Have to Be Rude to Manage Like Steve Jobs?
text: Over the years there have been questions about the management style of Steven P. Jobs, co-founder of Apple. Many have asked if Mr. Jobs was, well, to be blunt, a jerk.

text: Good morning. We’ll have a mix of sun and clouds today with temperatures rising to the mid 60s.

headline: Times Changes Policy on Visits to Web Site
text: 10:12 a.m. | Updated One year after The New York Times Company introduced a pay wall on the Web site of its flagship newspaper, the company said Tuesday it would now require visitors to the site to pay for access after reading 10 free articles, down from the threshold of 20 that was established when the system was initiated.

headline: Linsanity to Make Its Mark on Volvo Cars
text: Jeremy Lin, the New York Knicks’ breakout point guard, shared a podium with executives from Volvo Cars in Manhattan on Monday afternoon to announce a two-year marketing partnership.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Reuters: The 8-ounce Sweet Burn? $4.99. The 16-ounce Field of Greens? $7.99. And so, the first Starbucks juice bar (called Evolution Fresh) opened Monday in Bellevue, Wash., near Seattle. Coming next: the national rollout. On the menu are vegetable juices, smoothies, wraps, soups and of course, mucho quinoa and kale. No baristas at the Mighty Wurlitzer, though: the juice mashers are called “mixologists.” — Glenn Collins

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Rick Santorum, Journalist; and ‘John Carter’ Slays Disney Earnings
text: Newt Gingrich isn’t the only Republican candidate with a long written record. Rick Santorum, writes Jeremy W. Peters, has built up a large journalistic résumé over his career, with contributions to many newspapers and a two-year stint as a columnist for The Philadelphia Inquirer. But unlike Ron Paul, who has disavowed some of the articles that appeared under his name, Mr. Santorum will have no trouble owning up to his work, which includes attacks on climate change scientists and Hollywood (although he found the movie “Juno” to be “heartening”).

headline: Something Old, Something Fresh
