headline: The Right Angle
text: Ward Bennett (1917-2003) was one of design’s great American success stories. He left home at 13, created dresses and window displays, met Brancusi and studied painting with Hans Hofmann — before he was 30. When he turned to design, his clients included David Rockefeller, Gianni Agnelli and Jann and Jane Wenner. Bennett used industrial materials before they were chic and insisted that his furniture be comfortable. Many of his designs went out of production, leaving aficionados to hunt the secondhand market. But now Herman Miller is adding several Bennett pieces (including the Scissor chair and I-Beam table shown here) to its Herman Miller Collection, a portfolio of products for home and office that also includes classics by the Eameses, Nelson and Noguchi; contemporary designers like Sam Hecht, Leon Ransmeier and Ayse Birsel; and the Italian brands Magis and Mattiazzi. (The collection will make its debut this month; go to hermanmiller.com) As Ben Watson, the company’s executive creative director, says, “We are celebrating our design heritage, but we’re not just looking backward.”

headline: Leading Off: A Match Made in Legend Heaven
text: Now that it is done, it seems so obvious. Of course Peyton Manning would sign with Denver. There’s the legendary quarterback-turned-personnel-guy; a seasoned, adaptable coach; a defense so good that Tim Tebow could win going 3 for 27. And hey, Manning stays in the horse family, going from the Colts to the Broncos. Even Darwin would approve.

headline: Bernanke, Back to the Classroom
text: The Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, looks like a professor. He talks like a professor. Indeed, he used to be a professor.

headline: Their Better Halves?
text: You know the political season is heating up when the spouses begin appearing here, there and especially on television talk shows, and on Monday night we had a twofer: on “Piers Morgan Tonight,” Karen Santorum, who assured us that Rick won’t trample over women’s freedoms as much as he sometimes seems to itch to, and on the “Late Show with David Letterman,” Michelle Obama, who told us how exceedingly intelligent Bo, the first Portuguese water dog in the White House, is.

headline: On Our Radar: Madagascar’s Biodiversity
text: Why are so many species almost entirely limited to Madagascar? Scientists hypothesize that some animals arrived there on floating islands carried by ocean currents after plate tectonics separated Madagascar from Africa and other continents. [LiveScience]

headline: James Beard Awards Are Late (but Welcome) to the Bar
text: The outstanding-wine-program category of the James Beard Awards was born the same year the food-world prizes were first given out: 1991. Now, 21 years later, the Beard Foundation has finally gotten around to honoring the other half of every restaurant’s liquor regimen.

headline: Doubts About High-Stakes Tests and Their Effect on Teachers
text: At a panel discussion on high-stakes testing Monday night, the chief academic officer of New York City's public schools said that principals were not alone in being concerned about the state's new teacher evaluation system. He also has qualms.

headline: Decoding the Secret Service Names

headline: In China, Call to End to Physicals for Government Applicants
text: HONG KONG — The Beijing Yirenping Center, a civil rights group, called on Monday for an end to physical examinations that the government administers to applicants for civil service posts to determine whether they have sexually transmitted diseases.

headline: Barclays Sheds ‘Capital’ From Its Investment Bank’s Name

headline: Citi Credit Card Lets You Redeem Points at the Register
text: When I went to pay for a sandwich  at a Manhattan cafe last week, the credit card I pulled out of my wallet elicited three consecutive “Wows” from the cashier. “I see a lot of credit cards,” he told me, “and I’ve never seen one like that before.”

headline: Calling All Carnivores
text: Ethically speaking, vegetables get all the glory. In recent years, vegetarians — and to an even greater degree vegans, their hard-core inner circle — have dominated the discussion about the ethics of eating. From the philosopher Peter Singer, whose 1975 volume “Animal Liberation” galvanized an international movement, to the novelist Jonathan Safran Foer, who wrote the 2009 best seller “Eating Animals,” those who forswear meat have made the case that what we eat is a crucial ethical decision. To be just, they say, we must put down our cheeseburgers and join their ranks.

headline: Mining Tax Clears, but Gillard on Shaky Ground
text: SYDNEY — Prime Minister Julia Gillard celebrated on Tuesday the passage of a controversial tax on profits generated by Australia’s enormous mining boom, a much needed legislative victory for the embattled leader, who recently survived an embarrassing leadership challenge from within her own Labor Party.

headline: Spring Comes to a City Woodland
text: For weeks now, something resembling spring has hung awkwardly in the air. January was oddly balmy, February disquietingly snowless. Even with the calendar still declaring winter, forsythias, phlox and magnolias were already abloom.

headline: Debunking Sugar-Consumption Myths
text: The sugar mythology:* Kids get their sugar from soda and fruit juice.* They’re overwhelmed with sugar in processed school lunches and from school vending machines.* Low-income kids are the ones who are really in trouble, what with the no-fresh-food deserts and the fast-food marketing and the obesity crisis.

headline: 10 Questions for Jim Messina
text: Jim Messina, a top adviser to President Obama, left the White House a year ago to manage Mr. Obama’s re-election campaign. His task is creating an incumbent president’s version of the political machine that the 2008 campaign manager, David Plouffe,, now a top White House official, built for an insurgent promising “change we can believe in.” John Harwood of The Times and CNBC sat down with Mr. Messina at the campaign’s Chicago headquarters. What follows is a condensed, edited version of their conversation.

headline: Regulators Approve New Derivatives Rules
text: Regulators approved new rules for the $600 trillion derivatives market on Tuesday, aiming to raise competition and impose more rigorous risk management on an industry that played a central role in the financial crisis.

text: The late Theodore J. Forstmann was a colorful financier known for the prodigious collection of companies he bought and sold, from Gulfstream Aerospace to General Instrument to IMG.

headline: Wantful, Gift-Giving Start-Up, Announces Funding
text: When it comes to sending people birthday and Christmas gifts, I would likely win the award for: “Worst. Gift-giver. Ever.” Not only do I pick terrible presents for people, but worse, I have half-written birthday cards stuffed around my house that never actually made it to the post office.

headline: How Housing Prices Burden the Economy
text: Matthew Yglesias, the Moneybox columnist for Slate, is the author of “The Rent Is Too Damn High,” a short new electronic book. The title refers to an obscure political party in New York: The Rent Is Too Damn High Party. In the book, Mr. Yglesias argues that high rent — by which he means both rents and purchase prices — is a major drag on the American economy and society. “The real value of Yglesias’s book,” John Mangin wrote at The Washington Monthly’s Web site, “lies in its explanatory power, and in its potential to recast an important issue.”

headline: Vatican Inquiry Finds Progress in Irish Abuse Scandal
text: VATICAN CITY — The Roman Catholic Church in Ireland has made “excellent” progress in addressing a sexual abuse scandal and reporting new abuse cases directly to the Vatican, but would-be priests need better screening and training, according to a summary of a nearly yearlong investigation issued by the Vatican on Tuesday.

headline: Illinois Votes in Rare Turn in Spotlight
text: PEORIA, Ill. — Entering the First English Lutheran Church on Tuesday morning, voters in the Illinois Republican primary had to first walk between two network news trucks parked out front. Through one windshield, one could see a monitor glowing in the predawn with live footage from inside the church gymnasium, where eight voting booths stood waiting.

headline: Another Pastor Controversy
text: Political campaigns have a way of repeating themselves. In 2008, Democrats blamed President George W. Bush for high gas prices; now Republicans are blaming President Barack Obama for high gas prices. In 2008, Mr. Obama promised he’d reduce the country’s dependence on foreign oil; now the Republican candidates are promising to reduce the country’s dependence on foreign oil.  In 2008, Mr. Obama had a “pastor controversy;” now it’s Rick Santorum’s turn.

headline: Russia Seems To Soften Its Support For Syria
text: MOSCOW — The foreign minister of Russia, the Syrian government’s most powerful supporter, used some of his harshest language on Tuesday in criticizing President Bashar al-Assad of Syria and his violent repression of a year-old uprising there, saying that Mr. Assad had committed many mistakes and that “no one is inviting him to Moscow” should he resign.

headline: All Hail Sealand
text: I was about 10 years old when I declared the independence of my bedroom. On a blank page ripped from my school notebook, I meticulously traced the room’s floor plan. From National Geographic’s maps, I borrowed the colored edge and dotted line that mark international borders. The threshold of my room now marked the entrance to my own separate kingdom (or republic; I hadn’t quite figured that out yet).

headline: The Strange Career of Frank Dawson
text: Francis Warrington Dawson, my great-grandfather, was born in London in 1841. That wasn’t his original name, however: Christened Austin John Reeks, he was born into an educated, upper-middle-class Catholic family. After graduating from school, he took a European Grand Tour before university; then his father declared bankruptcy. An aunt, Mrs. Dawson, offered to pay his university tuitions, but died shortly thereafter. Instead, Austin took up writing as a career.

headline: Invisible Evidence Restores a van Gogh Attribution
text: It was a van Gogh, then it wasn’t a van Gogh and now it’s a van Gogh again, maybe this time for good.

headline: Humpback Whales Yield Some Sonic Secrets to Science
text: David Rothenberg, a musician and environmental philosopher, is a fairly frequent voice on this blog when the subject is animal sounds and behavior. His latest book, “Survival of the Beautiful,” is on aesthetics and evolution. You may have caught his recent “jam” with emerging cicadas. Rothenberg, who wrote the widely discussed book on whale communication, “Thousand Mile Song,” reflects below on some recent research focused on the remarkably variable songs of humpback whales. Here’s his “Your Dot” contribution on the evolving music of humpbacks:

headline: Tony Winners Join ‘Prince of Broadway’

headline: China Quietly Relaxes Controls on Foreign Capital
text: HONG KONG — The Chinese government has begun making it much easier for foreign investors to put money into China’s stock market and other financial investments, in a slight relaxing of more than a decade of tight capital controls.

headline: Baked Giant White Beans With Cabbage
text: This slow-baked bean and cabbage dish is luxurious in both taste and texture. The limas become soft and pillowy after their long, slow simmer, while releasing some of their starch into the bean broth; the cabbage sweetens over time and almost melts into the velvety broth. Baked beans with cabbage traditionally contain a ham bone or some salt pork for flavor, but I get that rich umami flavor with Parmesan rinds.

headline: New York Maps Viable Offshore Wind Power
text: A new study mapping out habitats in and around the waters off New York was released on Tuesday, bringing the state a step closer to determining the potential for wind energy projects offshore.

headline: A Legacy of Pain
text: In today’s column I wrote about Rick Santorum and American Catholicism and the church’s child sexual abuse crisis, and I wanted to circle back to that last item in this post, which is also a postscript.

headline: For Titanic Anniversary, the Books Go On and On
text: In her book “How to Survive the Titanic,” an elegant account of the infamy that hounded J. Bruce Ismay, the chairman of the company that owned the ship, after he fled the sinking giant in a lifeboat, Frances Wilson writes, “The need felt by survivors to tell their tales was, from the start, overwhelming and the need of those who were not on board to read their accounts, to see the films, to repeat the experience and work it through, to raise the Titanic and watch her go down again and again is one of the shipwreck’s most peculiar effects.”

headline: The View from St. Bonaventure: Ready for a Rematch With Marist
text: During the N.C.A.A. tournament, The Quad will feature posts from reporters at newspapers on campuses of teams that have the potential to be the Cinderellas of 2012.

headline: U.S. General Sees No Sudden Afghan Drawdown
text: WASHINGTON — The top allied commander in Afghanistan told Congress on Tuesday that he would not be recommending further American troop reductions until late this year, after the departure of the current “surge” forces and the end of the summer fighting season.

headline: Bobcats Battling N.B.A. and A.C.C.
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Ordinarily, the dominant color among fans attending Charlotte Bobcats games is blue. Saturday was St. Patrick’s Day, however, so Time Warner Cable Arena was a sea of green. During timeouts, a man dressed as a leprechaun, wearing curved springs on his legs, used a lacrosse stick to hurl T-shirts into the crowd.

headline: Comics Are Now Selling Laughs by the Download
text: Stand-up comedians of a certain era knew they had arrived when Johnny Carson invited them to a desk-side seat on “The Tonight Show.” A generation later, the gold standard was getting a solo comedy special on HBO. But in the Internet era, the yardstick for success has been redefined.

headline: In Auckland, New Zealand, a Frugal Trifecta
text: Auckland is New Zealand’s biggest city and the place you’ll almost certainly fly into if you come from the United States. It’s also quite a pleasant spot. That may sound like damning with faint praise – you don’t fly halfway around the world for pleasant. But New Zealand is probably best known for its scenery and countryside and outdoor adventure, so having a pleasant gateway to get adjusted is a great bonus — and not something you get everywhere (looking at you, Managua).

headline: In the Bronx, Painting Together at an Open-Air Gallery
text: TATS Cru put out the call on Friday.

headline: Gay Donors, Key Group for Obama, to Plot Strategy in Washington
text: Hundreds of leading gay donors will travel to Washington in late April to plan strategies and marshal financial commitments for state and federal elections around the country, according to people with knowledge of the meeting.

headline: Santorum Campaign Sees Delegate Gap Narrowing
text: CHICAGO — As Rick Santorum awaits the results of the Republican presidential primary here Tuesday that may or may not go his way, his campaign contends that it is gaining steam in the less visible – but more important – contest for delegates.

headline: A Measured Rebuttal to China Over Solar Panels
text: The Commerce Department said on Tuesday that it would impose tariffs on solar panels imported from China after concluding that the Chinese government provided illegal export subsidies to manufacturers there.

headline: Motus Motorcycles: Desirable Machines With Dear Prices
text: Ever since Motus Motorcycles, an Alabama start-up that plans to market a line of V-4 sport-touring bikes this year, blipped onto my radar screen about a year ago, one nagging question took precedence: How much?

headline: Beats Electronics Said to Be Pursuing MOG  Online Music Service
text: In a deal that could signal the arrival of a prominent new player in digital music, Beats Electronics, the company that has transformed the high-end headphone market with its Beats by Dr. Dre line, is in the process of buying MOG, an online music service.

headline: Conflicts Arise When Parents Are Asked to Close School Money Gap
text: After years of budget cuts, families are reaching into their own wallets more and more to pay for basics, like school supplies, as well as pooling enough funds to hire school staff. Kyle Spencer, a New York Times contributor, and Beth Fertig of WNYC spoke on "The Brian Lehrer Show" about SchoolBook’s effort to collect information from parents on their public education spending.

headline: Thousands Mourn Coptic Pope in Cairo
text: CAIRO — In front of a tearful crowd of thousands including members of Egypt’s emerging political class, a funeral service was held on Tuesday for Pope Shenouda III, the popular and charismatic leader of the Coptic Orthodox Church, who died on Saturday.

headline: How Penn State Won Its Second Consecutive N.C.A.A. Wrestling Title

headline: Answers About Raptors in New York, Part 3
text: New York City Audubon’s director of conservation and science, Susan Elbin, has been responding to readers’ questions about hawks and other birds of prey in New York City. Following is her third and final set of responses, with additional answers provided by her colleague, John Rowden, the associate director of citizen science and outreach for New York City Audubon.

headline: Many Americans Struggling to Pay Medical Bills
text: All eyes will be on the United States Supreme Court next week as it hears arguments in the challenge to the Affordable Care Act. But while debate over health care reform swirls in the political arena, roughly a third of Americans are in families struggling in some way to pay medical bills, a recent study finds.

headline: European Banks Would Have Passed Fed’s Stress Test
text: LONDON — After years of turmoil in the financial markets, regulators in both the United States and Europe have put banks through the wringer to see if they would be able to weather future shocks.

headline: Climbing a Volcano in Search of Old Trees
text: Kevin Anchukaitis, an assistant research professor at the Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory at Columbia University, is conducting a tree-ring study to analyze drought patterns in Guatemala.

headline: As Injuries Mount, Red Wings’ Fortunes Turn
text: Detroit Red Wings Coach Mike Babcock frequently says for his team there is a fine line between being one of the best in the N.H.L. and simply being average.

headline: After Deal Talks Sputter, Alibaba and Yahoo Said to Meet Again
text: Just one month after deal talks between Yahoo and its Asian partners collapsed, the sides are coming together once again.

headline: TimesCast | Drone Strikes Anger Pakistan
text: March 20, 2012 - A Pakistani parliamentary committee called for an end to United States drone strikes.

headline: Life Imitates Art: Rangers-Devils Brawl and ‘The Good Wife’
text: The brawl that opened Monday’s Rangers-Devils game could not have been a surprise to anyone who saw the starting lineups, which included both teams’ top fighters, or anyone who’d watched the games between the teams this season. This one merely upped the ante.

headline: North Dakota Defeats Minnesota in the W.C.H.A.; N.C.A.A Is Next for Both
text: Throughout the college hockey season, Slap Shot will feature reports about some of the country’s top-ranked teams.

headline: Lundqvist Gets ‘Real’ with Gumbel on HBO
text: Goaltender Henrik Lunqvist, who has steadily guided the Rangers to first place in the Eastern Conference this season, will be showcased on HBO’s “Real Sports with Bryant Gumbel” when it airs tonight at 10 p.m. Eastern time.

headline: ‘Harry Potter’ Actor Is Jailed for Role in London Riots
text: In his performances as Vincent Crabbe in the “Harry Potter” movies Jamie Waylett is known for his physical menace and mischief making, but these real-life qualities have seen the actor sentenced to two years in jail for his involvement in the 2011 London riots, BBC News reported.

headline: Brooklyn Students Propose Ways to Improve Relations at Shared Campuses
text: Brooklyn teenagers on a new youth council have made recommendations for improving relations at co-located schools, campuses where several schools share the same building. The students spent 10 weeks studying three big campuses and presented their findings to community members and a schools official on Monday. Hear and read about their ideas.

headline: Dueling Iranian New Year Greetings from Obama and Khamenei
text: The leaders of Iran and the United States issued starkly divergent New Year messages to Iran’s home audience on Tuesday, with President Obama calling for a new relationship that would end Iran’s prolonged isolation, and Ayatollah Ali Khamenei exhorting fellow citizens to beware of enemy plots and to buy only domestically made products.

headline: Candidates Look to Exceed Expectations in Illinois
text: The pattern is pretty clear now.

headline: Obama Exempts Japan and 10 European Nations From Iran Sanctions Law
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration on Tuesday exempted Japan and 10 European nations from biting sanctions intended to punish those who continued to purchase oil from Iran.

headline: The American Flag: A Street Style Star at SXSW 2012
text: Among all the cut-off jeans and boots donned at SXSW, the American flag emerged as an unlikely favorite.

headline: The Ryan Budget 2.0
text: The new House Republican budget looks a lot like last year’s House Republican budget, and is likely to earn the same sort of reactions: If you loved Paul Ryan 1.0 you’ll love 2.0 as well; if you considered the first iteration a nightmare of social Darwinist cruelty then the second iteration probably won’t change your mind. But for those of us who considered last year’s document a brave rough draft in need of substantial improvement, the good news is that it has been significantly improved: The proposed Medicare reform, which is the centerpiece of the budget and far and away its most important and courageous component, has been revised in the direction of the proposal that Oregon Democrat Ron Wyden and Ryan co-sponsored earlier this year, which means that it includes (among other things) a more realistic vision of how fast the proposed “premium support” for Medicare recipients would grow and a traditional fee-for-service Medicare as one of the options competing for those premium-support dollars. For a longer version of why this shift makes sense, I recommend reading Yuval Levin’s Weekly Standard piece on Medicare reform; for the shorter version, suffice to say that Ryan 2.0 addresses the fairest liberal attack on the original budget’s Medicare proposal, making its vision for entitlement reform more plausible as policy and politics alike.

headline: Pro-Romney Group Spent More Than $12 Million in February
text: A “super PAC” supporting Mitt Romney spent more than $12 million in February, most of it on ads attacking his rivals, as Mr. Romney battled them in seven primaries and caucuses that month, according to campaign filings released on Tuesday. The group, Restore Our Future, raised about $6.4 million, more than some of the candidates in the race are expected to report.

headline: Motherlode Book Club: ‘Some Assembly Required,’ in Progress
text: The six members of the Motherlode Book Club panel for Anne and Sam Lamott’s “Some Assembly Required” are reading Ms. Lamott’s story of finding out that her son, Sam (whom many of us think of as the baby from “Operating Instructions”), was about to become a father at age 19. The subtitle is “A Journal of My Son’s First Son.”

headline: TimesCast | Illinois Primaries
text: March 20, 2012 — Republican voters go to the polls in the Illinois primary as Mitt Romney and Rick Santorum continue to battle for the nomination.

headline: Former Merce Cunningham Dancers to Teach Choreographer’s Works
text: Four former Merce Cunningham company dancers have received fellowships to teach some of the choreographer’s works this spring and summer. The fellowships, $6,000 each, represent the latest effort to keep the Cunningham flame alive after his  death in 2009 and the company’s dissolution last year.

headline: Caucus Video: Illinois Holds Republican Primaries
text: Republican voters head to the polls in the Illinois primary as Mitt Romney and Rick Santorum continue to battle for delegates. Michael D. Shear reports.

headline: Brooklyn Teacher Accused of Sexually Abusing Student
text: A physical education teacher at a Brooklyn high school was arrested on Tuesday after the police said he grabbed the buttocks of a 16-year-old female student. He is at least the sixth New York City school worker charged in two months with a sexual offense against a student.

headline: Saying No to an Optional Iris Photo Has Its Consequences
text: As fellow Occupy Wall Street protesters who had been arrested on Saturday were being arraigned, Dallas Pesola remained in a holding cell on Sunday night, essentially being punished for not submitting to what was supposed to be a voluntary photograph of his irises.

headline: Does Motivation Matter? Debating the Legal Category of Hate Crime
text: Overview | Should crimes committed out of intolerance and bigotry be prosecuted and sentenced differently than other crimes? In this lesson, in the context of the Dharun Ravi case, students debate whether or hate crime laws protect against intimidation and bigotry or whether they are unnecessary and unfair.

headline: ESPN’s Web Site for Women Adds a Sponsor
text: An effort by ESPN to appeal to women is getting some additional marketer support as a brand becomes the first in its category to advertise with the company, according to ESPN.

headline: 2 Federal Reserve Nominees Make It to a Confirmation Hearing
text: WASHINGTON — Two of the White House’s nominees to fill vacancies on the Federal Reserve board moved closer to confirmation on Tuesday after a routine Senate hearing.

headline: Dan Hurley Leaving Wagner to Coach Rhode Island
text: Dan Hurley is leaving Wagner and to become the men’s basketball coach at Rhode Island. He will be introduced at a news conference Wednesday, Rhode Island officials said Tuesday.

headline: From 1982, Glasses More Than Full
text: ATLANTA

headline: Old-Fashioned or Newfangled, the Old-Fashioned Is Back
text: AS is his habit, Matthew Weiner, the creator of “Mad Men,” is revealing few details about the fifth season of the hit series, which will return to AMC on Sunday after a 17-month absence. We don’t know if the charismatic sphinx Don Draper has married his secretary or pulled his flailing advertising firm out of the fire. But one prediction is a safe bet: Mr. Draper will dip his beak into an old-fashioned or three.

headline: Home of Chicago Rail Cars Set to Undergo Renovation
text: CHICAGO — At its peak, the town of Pullman housed upward of 12,000 people in a parklike setting 12 miles south of downtown Chicago. They worked at the Pullman Palace Car Company, and spent their time and money in housing, schools, churches and stores built just for them by George Pullman, the company’s founder and one of the world’s wealthiest men.

headline: Woodson’s Challenge: Scoring Production
text: After the departure of Mike D’Antoni, the Knicks won their first three games under the replacement coach, Mike Woodson. They have not only won, but have done so convincingly. Over the span, the Knicks have outscored their opponents by an average of 23.7 points.

headline: A Chance to Meet the 'Hunger Games' Cast
text: Melena Ryzik interviews four "Hunger Games" fans waiting in line at a Manhattan Barnes and Noble to meet the film's cast.

headline: Shoot First, Claim Self-Defense Later
text: In late February, 28-year-old George Zimmerman called 911 to report that a “real suspicious guy” was walking down the street in Sanford, Fla. He decided to follow the “suspicious guy,” and later that night Mr. Zimmerman shot and killed him with a 9 mm handgun. The “suspicious guy” was a black 17-year-old named Trayvon Martin. He was unarmed, carrying only a bag of Skittles, a can of iced tea and a cellphone.

headline: Act Now! Send Us Your Questions for Karen Mills and the S.B.A.
text: As we recently announced, Karen Mills, the administrator of the Small Business Administration, will be stopping by The Times Thursday morning for an interview.

text: “Thankyouthankyouthankyouthankyouthankyouthankyou.” Quick pause for breath. “Ohmygodohmygodohmygod.”

headline: Photo Replay: March 20
text: The Broncos introduced their new quarterback, Peyton Manning, at a news conference in Colorado, and the world women’s curling championships continued in Lethbridge, Alberta.

headline: Southern Miss Revokes Band Members’ Scholarships After Taunts
text: Southern Miss responded to one of the uglier moments of the N.C.A.A. tournament by revoking the scholarships of five of its pep band members for taunting Kansas State guard Angel Rodriguez. The school announced the discipline on Tuesday.

headline: North End Grill
text: Inside Danny Meyer’s new seafood restaurant in Battery Park City.

headline: Veteran Crew Sets Imaginative Course
text: AT times I wondered if North End Grill was trying to look dull on purpose.

headline: Experiences in Nature From Our Readers and an 18th-Century Philosopher
text: Kim Tingley’s article in this week’s magazine  explores the work being done by Davyd Betchkal and his team in Alaska to preserve the quickly disappearing sounds of pure nature. It has inspired many commenters to write about their own experiences in nature and the silent tranquility they found everywhere from Joshua Tree National Park to the Yukon Territory, or even on a Navy destroyer in the middle of the Pacific Ocean. This commenter from Seattle only tells us that the experience can be attended by the fear that an investment banker will inevitably arrive, buy the land and start “herding cattle with a helicopter.”

headline: In Search for Alien Life, Researchers Enlist Human Minds
text: HAT CREEK, Calif. — On a chilly morning last week, Jill Tarter sat in a makeshift corner office facing the Allen Telescope Array, pondering a set of parallel lines that striped a window in her MacBook.

headline: Five Dishes at North End Grill
text: Under review this week is North End Grill, Floyd Cardoz’s welcome return after his 12-year run at the Indian-fusion restaurant Tabla. This time, he’s not tethered to any one cuisine, giving him freedom to cook simple dishes like scrambled eggs and whole grilled turbot. Still, he retains a profound understanding of how to build flavors through spices, as became clear in my phone conversation with him this week. Here are some dishes worth trying at North End Grill, and the stories behind them.

headline: Mexican Quake Posed No Threat to President’s Daughter
text: Malia Obama, the president’s older daughter, was never threatened by the earthquake Tuesday afternoon that shook central and southern Mexico, where she was visiting with a school group, according to a spokeswoman for the president’s wife, Michelle.

headline: Illinois Congressional Primaries Make Captivating Undercard
text: The highest-profile primary in Illinois on Tuesday may be between Mitt Romney and Rick Santorum, but a slew of interesting House primaries are also on the stove, many of them proxies for various political engagements around the country.

headline: Alderson Says Settlement Won’t Change Much Right Away
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Mets General Manager Sandy Alderson said Tuesday that the settlement reached between the club’s owners and the trustee representing the victims of Bernard L. Madoff’s vast fraud would have a negligible short-term effect on the Mets’ payroll.

headline: The Caregiver’s Bookshelf: Dying by Degrees
text: Ira Byock has been writing books about the way Americans die since 1998, when he published “Dying Well.” For most of that time, he has been appalled.

headline: Another Teacher Arrested on Sex Abuse Charges
text: A physical education teacher at a Brooklyn high school was arrested on Tuesday after he grabbed the buttocks of a 16-year-old female student, the police said. He is at least the sixth school worker charged in two months with a sexual offense against a student.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Humane Robots and Hot iPads
text: Here are some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web on Tuesday. There are more here.

headline: The Checklist | Top 10 Polyvore Pages
text: Last month, T introduced a shopping page called The Checklist and in partnership with Polyvore.com, the social fashion site that lets users become virtual editors, asked readers to style the story’s star pieces into outfits. Nearly 2,000 people participated in the challenge (1,986, to be exact), submitting a terrific range of looks from the 77 items on tap. Among the most frequently used were the Converse sneakers and the structured handlebar Prada bag (although no one recommended wearing these things together). One user created two pants-driven layouts that made our list (tinker23, from Turkey, apparently loves pointy-toed pumps and hoop earrings — so easy to get behind this spring). Another user, catv41, proposed a mustard/navy color combination anchored by black accessories that I would wear tomorrow if I could. These looks — and all that didn’t make the cut — were a delight to discover. I look forward to more incredible outfit-making with even more fashion must-haves next month.

headline: The Line Drawn by the ’82 Bordeaux
text: This year is the 30th anniversary of the 1982 vintage in Bordeaux, possibly the most significant wine vintage ever. Well, maybe that’s an exaggeration, but certainly the most significant of the last 50 years, and arguably of the 20th century.

headline: H.P. to Merge Business Units
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Hewlett-Packard said Wednesday it will merge its personal computer and printing divisions in an effort to cut costs, improve its designs and become more efficient.

text: Photographs from Egypt, Iraq, France and Syria.

headline: Updates From the Illinois Primary
text: The Times is covering Tuesday’s primary and providing live updates and analysis. Follow along on the live dashboard and on Twitter (@thecaucus), get real-time results and dig deeper into the numbers with FiveThirtyEight.

headline: Raising Multilingual Children (or Not)
text: Marcus Mabry, editor at large at The International Herald Tribune, is raising his twins to be trilingual, an act of parental aggression that I’m having a hard time not taking personally. It’s not even that either he, or his partner, speaks another language as a native. It’s just that he’s trying to do what’s best for them, and so he speaks to them only in French, while their nanny speaks to them in Mandarin, and his partner speaks English.

headline: Must-Have Gadgets for the Kitchen? Think Again
text: EVERY kitchen has one. The ingenious asparagus peeler. The automatic paper-towel dispenser. The whiz-bang electric pepper grinder.

headline: What Kitchen Tools Have You Bought and Barely Used?
text: In this week’s Dining section, William Grimes has rounded up tales of kitchen-gadget woe — home cooks and even pros who enthusiastically bought a milk frother or a salmon poacher only to let it languish, unused, in a closet or drawer. Do you have kitchen equipment that you bought and then barely touched? Neglected tools that are hidden away in the closet or the basement, or even kept in plain view on the countertop, a monument to ambitions unrealized?

headline: Upending Notions of Gender Identity
text: MONTCLAIR, N.J. — The clothes make the man, as that old saying goes. But they also unmake, obfuscate and misdirect — not just the man but also the woman, and the entire spectrum of gender and sexuality between and beyond those two poles.

headline: Newest Knick in the Spotlight: The Bench
text: In his six, mostly middling seasons at the helm of the Atlanta Hawks, Mike Woodson wasn’t exactly known as a coach prone to freelancing or experimentation. Famous more for his isolation-friendly offensive system – a steadfast reliance on Joe Johnson helped earn it the description “Iso Joe” – and point guard leashes that bordered on choke collars, Woodson leaned heavily on his stars, and rarely delved very deeply into his bench.

headline: Printed Ballots Were Too Wide for Scanners in Some Illinois Precincts
text: Some of the printed ballots in 25 of 110 Illinois jurisdictions were slightly too wide to fit into the optical scanners and will have to be trimmed or hand counted, officials said Tuesday afternoon.

headline: Woman Suspected in Midtown Trash-Can Fires Turns Out to Be a Man
text: The police search for a middle-aged woman suspected of starting 15 trash-can fires in Midtown on Monday ended Tuesday with the arrest of a man, not a woman, who has been living on the streets outside Pennsylvania Station, the Fire Department said.

headline: Turning Giggles and Snickers Into a Hoot
text: It’s hard to imagine anything funnier on a New York stage right now than a man struggling to stuff his body through a clothes hanger.

headline: Dutch Church Is Accused of Castrating Young Men
text: BRUSSELS — A young man in the care of the Roman Catholic Church in the Netherlands was surgically castrated decades ago after complaining about sexual abuse, according to new evidence that only adds to the scandal engulfing the church there.

headline: An Early Start to Allergy Season
text: A mild winter that ended with a flourish of warm weather was a welcome surprise for many Americans. But for the 25 to 35 percent of people who suffer from hay fever, the early arrival of warm weather meant an unusually early start to allergy season.

headline: From a Forgotten Composer, A Familiar Romantic Story
text: It is often clear why works that arts organizations might describe as forgotten gems have gathered dust. But Franz Schmidt’s two-act opera “Notre Dame” proved a worthy find during a vibrant concert performance by the American Symphony Orchestra, conducted by Leon Botstein, on Sunday afternoon at Carnegie Hall.

headline: My Big Italian Dream Party
text: EVER since my first dinner party, when I lived in a tiny flat in London and struggled over a menu of shrimp Creole while making sure I had eight forks for the eight people squeezing around my budget Ikea dining slab, few things have made me happier than sitting around a table with a hand-selected group of friends.

headline: Corn Chips, Garnished and Sauced. Loco? Right.
text: Escondido, Calif.

headline: Gracious Dining, Alive and Well at NoMad
text: For the past few years, the Breslin and the John Dory Oyster Bar in the Ace Hotel have made a good case for heading to the largely commercial wedge of Midtown Manhattan between Madison Square and Herald Square. A new restaurant called the NoMad, set to open on Monday in the hotel and the neighborhood of the same name, clinches the argument. The area’s cobbled-together nickname (it means North of Madison Square Park) might even stick.

headline: A Tour of Paintings, in Verse
text: The concept of the museum audio guide, with an expert nattering on in your ear, telling you what to think and why, has always seemed particularly loathsome. But if more such guides contained ekphrastic poetry, the idea might be a little more appealing.

headline: Broadway Musicals Hang on for Payoffs Beyond Weekly Gross
text: Why are the musicals “Sister Act,” “Priscilla Queen of the Desert” and “Godspell” still running on Broadway?

headline: In North Brooklyn, Another Gay Bar Closes
text: One Wednesday in February at Veronica’s, the boss lined up shot glasses on the bar, opened a bottle of tequila and passed it down the line to her 14 employees.

headline: A Conversation With the ‘Mad Men’ Cast and Creator
text: If you’re a fan of the AMC series “Mad Men,” you still have five more excruciating days to wait for that show’s long awaited fifth-season premiere on Sunday. In the meantime, you can tide yourself by watching a recording of a a Times Talk event featuring that show’s cast members and creator. The conversation occurred on Tuesday evening with the “Mad Men” show runner Matthew Weiner and stars Jon Hamm, January Jones, John Slattery, Christina Hendricks, Vincent Kartheiser and Jared Harris, and was moderated by New York Times culture reporter Dave Itzkoff.

headline: Off the Menu
text: Opening

headline: Looking Back to the 1800s for a Properly Bitter Cocktail
text: In today’s ramped-up bar culture, the sweetness of Curaçao or Triple Sec, the orange liqueurs used in many classic cocktails, did not satisfy David Wondrich, the drinks historian and expert. So he worked with Alexandre Gabriel, the president of Cognac Ferrand in France, to develop a drier bitter orange Curaçao, like the kind made back in the 1800s.

headline: Pastry Straight to Your Door
text: Clarice Lam, the executive chef of the Chocolate Room in Park Slope and Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, has introduced her own oven-to-door pastry service, with delivery throughout New York City. Called the Baking Bean (her nickname is Bean, for her runway-ready figure), it takes orders by phone and online for an array of cakes, pies, tarts, cookies, croissants, chocolate bark and other candies, none of which duplicate what Ms. Lam makes for the Chocolate Room. The baked goods are high quality and handsome. Though seasonality is a core value, Ms. Lam said, she does stretch the boundaries, with several strawberry pies and tarts on her introductory lineup. She is also offering a dessert club, with delivery of a different indulgence every week.

headline: U.S. Stores Learn How to Ship to Foreign Shoppers
text: Macy’s has long marketed itself as a shopping destination for visitors to the United States. It offers a savings card with a 10 percent discount for foreign shoppers, custom programs for tour groups and travel agents, and a tourism Web site that lists shopping events and recommended hotels near Macy’s flagship stores.

headline: Romney’s Slightly Exaggerated Advertising Edge
text: If Rick Santorum loses in Illinois on Tuesday, you might hear him or one of his advisers lamenting how badly he was outspent on the airwaves. There are ways to make the discrepancy seem very large.

headline: A Taste of the New
text: Images from some of the films appearing in the New Directors/New Films series.

headline: Dining Calendar

headline: How Spring Break for President Obama’s Daughter Became News
text: “We can confirm that Malia Obama is safe and was never in danger.”

headline: Discovering Great Films Scaled Small
text: “Street Vendor Cinema,” a short film from Brazil that will be shown at the New Directors/New Films festival, spends some time with an energetic auteur practicing his art — and trying to hustle a little cash — in a busy São Paulo shopping area.

headline: The Electric-Guitar Man and a Brooklyn Rock Quintet in Full Sonic Bloom
text: “You can pick up some earplugs there on the left,” an usher said, greeting audience members as they filed into Merkin Concert Hall on Saturday evening. Where Rhys Chatham, a composer, guitarist and trumpeter long associated with the outer reaches of New York’s downtown music scene, goes, warnings about excessive volume will surely follow. This is, after all, a composer who wrote a symphony for 400 electric guitars.

headline: Taking the Temperature of the New iPad
text: Is Apple’s new iPad too hot to handle?

headline: Africa’s Daughters, With Stories To Share
text: George Balanchine once dismissed the notion of abstraction in dance, arguing that as soon as you place a man and a woman onstage, you have a story.

headline: Its Own Supporting Line: Another Festival for the Warm and Generous Cello
text: LOS ANGELES — Strike up a conversation with one of the cellists playing in the New York subways on Wednesday to celebrate Bach’s 327th birthday, and you may make a friend for life.

headline: PGA Tour Announces Changes to Qualifying and Schedule
text: ORLANDO, Fla. — As much as Brett Wetterich hated the thought of going to the PGA Tour’s qualifying school, he loved the opportunity.

headline: Captive in Cramped Box, and Cellphone Is No Use
text: Because Jeremy Reins (Stephen Dorff), the protagonist of “Brake,” finds himself confined in the trunk of a moving car with no memory of how he got there, the movie is already being compared to the 2010 thriller “Buried.” In that one, Ryan Reynolds played a nonmilitary truck driver in Iraq who awakens bound and gagged in a pine box under the desert sand. Jeremy is a Secret Service agent taken captive in New York in an elaborate terrorist plot to shut down Washington and assassinate the president.

headline: Seeking an Elixir of Youth
text: “THE Kids Don’t Stand a Chance,” one of the lighter, more ornery songs from the debut album of the neo-prep champions Vampire Weekend, filled the room at the newly reopened Rothmans as I happened to be fingering a pair of teal shorts by Ted Baker ($125) that were begging for boat shoes and a boat deck.

headline: Alaïa’s Streamlined Autumn
text: Does Azzedine Alaïa have a sixth sense for knowing when poor old fashion is baroque?

headline: Indie, Sure, but With a Disco Beat
text: “First Wave,” the final song on Ital’s debut album, “Hive Mind” (Planet Mu), clocks in at more than 10 minutes, one of three on this five-song album that do. It starts out clinical and tough, but it’s not long before it gives in to bliss: what sound like digitized strings begin to swell, buttressed by rollicking drums that provide a proper four-on-the-floor exuberance, carrying things forward.

headline: TV Digs Will Harm Patrimony, Scholars Say
text: Ric Savage is accustomed to wrestling, but for most of his career it was against guys named the Junkyard Dog and Skull Von Krush.

headline: Restoration Comedy, Of a Sort
text: Sometimes it’s best not to think too hard and just embrace the idiocy. If you’re able to bring that mind-set to “Bent,” a screwy comedy NBC introduces on Wednesday night, you’ll have a pretty good time.

headline: The Snails of War
text: The electric snail is here. There’s an electric cockroach too.

headline: Viterra Deal Gives Glencore Influence in Global Wheat Trade
text: OTTAWA — Glencore International, the Swiss commodities trader, entered the North American agriculture market on Tuesday with a widely anticipated deal to acquire Viterra, the largest Canadian grain company, for $6.2 billion.

headline: Justices Back Mayo Clinic Argument on Patents
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court unanimously ruled on Tuesday that medical tests that rely on correlations between drug dosages and treatment are not eligible for patent protection.

headline: Join Us for an N.C.A.A. Video Hangout
text: After a couple of days of madness in the form of Manning, Tebow and the Wilpons, it’s time to turn the sports conversation back to the N.C.A.A. tournament and the Round of 16, which begins Thursday night. The Times’s college basketball experts — Pete Thamel, Greg Bishop and Connor Ennis — will be holding a Google-plus video hangout Thursday at 3:30 p.m. EDT to discuss the first weekend and look ahead to this week’s games. And we’d like to invite selected readers to join them in the conversation. If you are available for 30 minutes beginning at that time and would like to hang out with us, use the comment area below to tell us what kind of a college basketball fan you are, who you root for, and what you think about the tournament so far. Please also include a link to your Google-plus profile page and note that to participate in the hangout you will need a Google-plus profile and a video camera-enabled computer.

headline: Crime, Punishment and the Rutgers Case
text: To the Editor:

headline: How We Went Nonnuclear: The Kazakh Envoy’s View
text: To the Editor:
