headline: Eventbrite Moves Into Mobile Payments With a Credit Card Reader
text: Eventbrite, a ticketing start-up based in San Francisco, is making a leap into the hardware business.

headline: Small Donors Fuel Santorum’s $9 Million Month
text: Rick Santorum raised $9 million in February and spent $7.8 million as the Republican presidential contest narrowed to a battle with Mitt Romney for the nomination, according to documents filed with the Federal Election Commission Tuesday night.

headline: FlipShare Videos Get a Reprieve
text: When Cisco Systems said it would stop making its popular Flip video cameras, it also announced that it would eventually shut down its FlipShare video sharing and storage service. Last May it put a 30-day expiration date on videos and photos stored there. Anything more than 30 days old would be erased.

headline: Inside, Your Hooptie Sounds Like a Lamborghini
text: Anyone who has ever pretended to turn a bicycle into a motorcycle by putting playing cards in the spokes will want to take a look at the XLR8 app.

headline: City Seeks to Become a New Internet Address
text: Businesses have long jockeyed for an address on Fifth Avenue — and the city is now hoping it can create a similar phenomenon online.

headline: New Headphones From 50 Cent
text: Seeking to become the next hip-hop artist turned audiophile, the rapper 50 Cent recently unveiled a line of high-end headphones and accessories from SMS Audio.

headline: Q&A: Visiting LinkedIn Profiles Unannounced
text: Q.

headline: Justices Limit Suits Filed Over Family Leave Act Violations
text: WASHINGTON — By a 5-to-4 vote that split along ideological lines, the Supreme Court on Tuesday ruled that state workers may not sue their employers for money for violating a part of the federal Family and Medical Leave Act.

headline: Live Coverage: the Illinois Primary
text: Welcome to FiveThirtyEight’s live blog of the Republican primary in Illinois. We’ll have updates throughout the night with exit poll results, data-driven analysis, historical context and the final verdict of Illinois voters.

headline: For India’s Dominant Party, Electoral Setback Stirs Self-Doubt
text: NEW DELHI — After the policy paralysis and political acrimony of last year, India’s coalition national government had hoped this year would be different. Yet already the government is troubled by infighting among coalition allies. And the Indian National Congress Party, which leads the coalition, has been further weakened by lackluster showings in recent state elections.

headline: Comparing Party Budget Plans
text: How the 2013 budget plan laid out by House Republicans on Tuesday compares with President Obama’s proposal released last month.

headline: At 49, Moyer Chases History
text: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz. – The oldest pitcher in major league history was Satchel Paige, who pitched three innings for the Kansas City Athletics on Sept. 25, 1965, when he was 59 years old. It is a nice distinction for Paige, a Hall of Famer whose best years were spent in the Negro leagues. But it was a stunt devised by the maverick owner Charles O. Finley.

headline: Saudi Arabia May Include Women on Its Olympic Team
text: The Summer Olympics in London could be a watershed event for international sports as every participating nation is expected to field at least one female athlete, including three Muslim countries — Saudi Arabia, Qatar and Brunei — that have previously sent only male competitors.

headline: As Israel’s Military Pursues Enemies on Twitter, Some Citizens Reach Out on Facebook
text: Updated | Wednesday | 5:28 p.m. Last week, as rockets were fired into and out of Gaza, the Israeli military also moved to take the high ground on what an official described as the “second battlefield” of social networking sites, by beginning a campaign to discredit Palestinian bloggers who had misidentified images on Twitter.

headline: Software Licenses Help Oracle Beat Estimates
text: Oracle, the biggest maker of database software, exceeded analysts’ estimates for quarterly profit and new license sales on Tuesday, a sign of buoyant demand for programs that help companies organize data and run operations.

headline: Getting Ad Agencies Into Reality TV
text: CONTESTANTS on reality competition shows perform tasks like seeking spouses, racing around the world, eating bugs, losing weight, living in houses rigged with cameras and working for Donald J. Trump. A new series is arriving with a contest all its own: wooing advertisers to say yes to campaigns.

headline: In Louisiana, Ad Spending Heats Up
text: Mitt Romney had a significant spending advantage in Illinois as he and a “super PAC” supporting him outspent Rick Santorum and his allies by more than seven to one.

headline: Inequality Undermines Democracy
text: Americans have never been too worried about the income gap. The gap between the rich and the rest has been much wider in the United States than in other developed nations for decades. Still, polls show we are much less concerned about it than people in those other nations are.

headline: Kony Is Not the Problem
text: IN northern Uganda, the dry season is used to burn bushes; the fire drives snakes and other predators away. On the Ugandan side of the border with South Sudan, below a mountainous ridge along the Nile, is a village called Odrupele by locals. It is a place teeming with snakes.

headline: California: Sheriff Won’t Quit
text: Mayor Edwin M. Lee of San Francisco said on Tuesday that he would seek the removal of Sheriff Ross Mirkarimi, who was sentenced to counseling and probation on Monday after pleading guilty in a domestic violence case. Sheriff Mirkarimi said he did not intend to resign. Mr. Lee said Sheriff Mirkarimi’s behavior during an incident on Dec. 31, in which he grabbed and bruised his wife’s arm, fell “below the standards of decency and faith” expected of elected officials. The mayor appointed Vicki Hennessy interim sheriff while the case is investigated by the San Francisco Ethics Commission.

headline: Bill Meant to Help Start-Ups Hits Roadblocks in the Senate
text: WASHINGTON — The Senate postponed action Tuesday on legislation to ease the ability of small and start-up companies to raise money from investors after Democrats failed in two tries to make changes to the bill.

headline: Reports Show Adelson’s Enduring Support of Gingrich
text: Sheldon Adelson, the Las Vegas casino mogul, and his family gave another $5.5 million to the “super PAC” backing Mr. Gingrich in February, almost single-handedly financing his continuing bid for the White House.

headline: Casting Begins for Tebow, the Sequel
text: Now that Peyton Manning has signed with the Broncos, it is time to speculate on where Tim Tebow will land after the Broncos inevitably trade him. Tebow speculation is similar to Manning speculation: no outcome is too far-fetched, and every team has something to gain — and perhaps a little to lose — by acquiring the incredibly popular, athletic, erratic-armed lefty. Here is a breakdown on what a Tebow trade could mean for each N.F.L. team.

headline: Russia: President Urges Military to Defeat U.S. Missile Shield
text: President Dmitri A. Medvedev told top Russian military officials on Tuesday that they must be prepared to beat the United States’ missile defense system at all phases of its development, even as talks continue on modifying the system to assuage Russia’s concerns. “We are not closing the door on dialogue,” he said. “But we need to prepare ourselves.”

headline: Analyzing the Illinois Exit Polls
text: The Times’s polling unit is combing through the exit polls of voters leaving the Illinois primaries for insights. This post will be updated as we crunch numbers throughout the night.

headline: In Barclays Center’s Shadow, Awaiting What’s Next
text: Triangle Sports has occupied the same three-cornered site on Flatbush Avenue in Brooklyn since 1916. But in January, the store’s owners put the 1,570-square-foot parcel on the market.

headline: Longshoremen’s Union Remains Defiant Over Diversity Plan
text: Putting an end to discrimination in hiring on the docks around New York Harbor is proving to be nearly as hard as rooting out corruption.

headline: Former Underboss Offers Primer on Mob Life
text: It was summer 1999, and a meeting between the leadership of the Bonanno and Colombo crime families was under way in an apartment off Third Avenue, in Fort Hamilton, Brooklyn.

headline: A Quandary for Banks in Britain
text: LONDON — Quietly sipping coffee, 16 owners of small British businesses sat in front of their laptops listening to Ed Goodman, a business trainer, explain how best to buy Google ads and create a profile on Facebook to promote their companies.

headline: Air Canada Supplier Says It Will Liquidate
text: OTTAWA — After rejecting an offer of emergency financing from Air Canada, Aveos Fleet Performance said on Tuesday that it was liquidating its aircraft maintenance business and laying off all of its 2,600 employees.

headline: Mayoral Hopefuls All Make Time for Teachers’ Union Leader
text: Michael Mulgrew, the president of the New York teachers’ union, has not been the most popular figure at City Hall under Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg. They have been at odds over almost everything, like Mr. Bloomberg’s push to close underperforming schools and his insistence on putting charter schools in district school buildings.

headline: At 49, Jamie Moyer Is Slower, but Not Stopping
text: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz. — On Sept. 13, 1932, in the first game of a doubleheader at Ebbets Field, a Brooklyn Dodgers pitcher named Jack Quinn threw five shutout innings to beat the St. Louis Cardinals. Quinn was 49 years 74 days old, the oldest pitcher to win a major league game.

headline: Suspect in Staten Island Killing Is Held in Illinois
text: A suspect wanted in the fatal stabbing of a bridegroom-to-be on Staten Island Saturday was captured on Tuesday in Illinois by law enforcement agents who had tracked him to an aunt’s home there, the authorities said.

headline: Generic Drugs Proving Resistant to Damage Suits
text: Debbie Schork, a deli worker at a supermarket in Indiana, had to have her hand amputated after an emergency room nurse injected her with an anti-nausea drug, causing gangrene. She sued the manufacturer named in the hospital’s records for failing to warn about the risks of injecting it. Her case was quietly thrown out of court last fall.

headline: Oil Under Our Noses
text: Durham, N.C.

headline: Is a Calorie a Calorie?
text: I was looking forward to “Why Calories Count,” the new book by Marion Nestle and Malden Nesheim. I figured gaining an advanced education in calories might allow me to better understand diet and weight gain. These two are not faddists but clear thinkers: actual scientists. But of course there is more to weight gain than the calorie.

headline: Bernanke, as Professor, Tries to Buff Fed’s Image
text: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve’s chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, spent the better part of an hour Tuesday afternoon carefully explaining to a class of college students why the United States abandoned the gold standard in the 1930s.

headline: U.S. Exempts Japan and 10 Other Countries From Sanctions Over Iran Oil
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration on Tuesday exempted Japan and 10 European nations from the prospect of biting sanctions intended to punish countries that continue to buy oil from Iran, but it left open the fate of other major importers, including China, India and South Korea.

headline: Broncos’ Soft-Sell Approach Helped Manning Make His Hard Decision
text: ENGLEWOOD, Colo. — John Fox and John Elway were discussing various personnel issues Monday morning, doing their best to take their minds off trying to figure out what decision perhaps the most prominent free agent in N.F.L. history might make.

headline: The Careless House Budget
text: As he rolled out his 2013 budget on Tuesday, Paul Ryan, the House Budget Committee chairman, correctly said that he and his fellow Republicans were offering the country a choice of two very clear futures. The one he outlined in his plan could hardly be more bleak.

headline: Romney Is Victor by Wide Margin in Illinois Vote
text: CHICAGO — Mitt Romney swept to victory in the Illinois Republican primary on Tuesday, using the full force of his campaign and an argument that he has the best chance of defeating President Obama to overcome doubts among the more conservative voters at the heart of his party.

headline: ‘Super PACs’ Supply Millions as G.O.P. Race Drains Field
text: The Republican presidential candidates are running low on campaign cash as expensive primaries in states like Maryland, New York and Pennsylvania loom, leaving them increasingly reliant on a small group of supporters funneling millions of dollars in unlimited contributions into “super PACs.”

headline: Ex-Marine From Indiana Takes Deal on Gun Charge
text: A former Marine whose arrest at the Empire State Building on a gun-possession charge last September prompted outrage among supporters of gun rights pleaded guilty on Tuesday to a misdemeanor weapons-possession charge.

headline: In Sun’s Glow, It’s Still Business, but Not as Usual
text: It is a rhetorical question heard again and again in stuffy, sun-deprived offices on a beautiful day in spring. Man, wouldn’t it be great to have our meeting outside today? Employees laugh, pause wistfully and then get down to business — inside. Well, most do.

headline: Wrong Ways to Fight Assad
text: President Bashar al-Assad is so willing to kill his people that he could hold on to power for years. The forces opposing him have won support from the international community starting the moment they began standing up to Mr. Assad, but they can ill afford self-inflicted wounds. Some elements of the opposition now risk jeopardizing their cause and further stoking dangerous sectarian animosities if they adopt brutal and illegal tactics.

headline: Jets Said to Show Interest in Making Room for Tebow
text: When General Manager Mike Tannenbaum hinted in the off-season at a shakeup among the Jets quarterbacks, it was presumed that his biggest move would be adding a younger and more credible backup to Mark Sanchez. That player might not wind up being Drew Stanton, who was signed last week, but Tim Tebow, the polarizing cross-cultural phenomenon made expendable when Denver signed Peyton Manning.

headline: Pennsylvania Rises in Importance for Santorum After Loss in Illinois
text: GETTYSBURG, Pa. — It may seem an odd choice, holding a rally here in Pennsylvania to “celebrate” the results of the Republican presidential primary in Illinois.

headline: Cruel and Unusual Punishment for 14-Year-Olds
text: The Supreme Court in 2005 justly banned the death penalty for minors convicted of murder. In 2010, it banned life without parole for youths convicted of crimes other than murder. In two cases argued before the court on Tuesday, the justices should take the next step and ban life without parole for youths convicted of murder.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: March 20, 2012

headline: The Fairest of Them All?
text: A look back at some of the film and television adaptations of fairy tales.

headline: Release Alan Gross
text: When he was arrested in Havana in late 2009, Alan Gross, a subcontractor for the United States Agency for International Development, was helping Cuba’s Jewish community get better access to the Internet. A Cuban court last year found him guilty of participating in a “subversive project of the U.S. government that aimed to destroy the revolution through the use of communications systems out of the control of authorities,” and sentenced him to 15 years in prison. He has languished in a military hospital ever since. His lawyer says he has lost more than 100 pounds and suffers from severe arthritis. As an act of mercy, the Cuban government should release Mr. Gross.

headline: Want Loyal Customers? Giving Them Hope Helps
text: It is not a reach to say that over the last couple of years Fred Wilpon has made considerable efforts to convince news media folks and fans alike that he is a man of impeccable character. Consistent in his talking points, Wilpon, the Mets’ owner, has said time and again that beyond his consuming dedication to his team, he is a regular guy — as privileged guys go — and hardly the Madoff-enriched monster that Irving H. Picard was making him out to be.

headline: Killings Could Stall Election’s Nationalist Turn
text: PARIS — The Jewish school in Toulouse that was terrorized by an unknown gunman on a motorbike will reopen on Wednesday as a statement of courage and continuity. The hundreds of mourners who filled the stone courtyard of the palatial redbrick town hall there on Tuesday morning, joining others across the country in a moment of silence, will return grimly to their daily lives.

headline: Supreme Court Revisits Issue of Harsh Sentences for Juveniles
text: WASHINGTON — At a pair of Supreme Court arguments on Tuesday, the justices returned to the question of what the Constitution has to say about harsh sentences imposed on juvenile offenders.

headline: Ohio Universities Resume a Rivalry, 50 Years Later
text: The wait was almost unbearable. Before top-ranked Ohio State could take on No. 2 Cincinnati in the 1961 N.C.A.A. championship game in Kansas City, Mo., the consolation game had to finish.

headline: In Speech, Romney Assails Obama for Lack of Leadership
text: Mitt Romney claimed an “extraordinary victory” in Illinois on Tuesday night and quickly attacked President Obama for a lack of leadership during the past several years.

headline: Paul D. Taylor
text: Mr. Taylor, 56, is the president of Stonehill & Taylor, an architecture and interior design firm based in New York. The company specializes in the hospitality industry, and its projects have included the Ace and Crosby Street hotels, along with the Plaza Hotel before its recent sale. It is currently working on the NoMad Hotel in Manhattan and a new extended-stay brand for Hyatt.

headline: Heart of Darkness
text: Washington

headline: Pettitte Looks Sharp in His Official Return
text: TAMPA, Fla. — Andy Pettitte thought “it was going to be a lot more awkward.” What he felt instead, in his first official day back with the Yankees, was “like I never left.”

headline: ‘Hunger Games’ Brings Out Legions of Fans, and Inflatable Mattresses
text: “Thankyouthankyouthankyou.” Quick pause for breath. “Ohmygodohmygodohmygod.”

headline: Save a Mind, Draft a Body
text: The arrest of Staff Sgt. Robert Bales has raised questions about multiple deployments. Would military conscription help alleviate the stress of combat?

headline: Alderson Sees the Mets’ Future, and Counsels Patience
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Fred Wilpon said Monday morning that his next order of business, with his legal issues now on the way to being settled, would be to travel to Florida to return the Mets to prominence.

headline: Long Live the Queen
text: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — All hail THE QUEEN OF SOUL, ARETHA FRANKLIN!

headline: For Syrians, No Easy Exit From Conflict
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Syria is locked in an ominous and violent stalemate: With overwhelming firepower and a willingness to kill, President Bashar al-Assad could hold on to power for months or even years, keeping the opposition from controlling any territory and denying it breathing space to develop a coherent, effective leadership, according to analysts, diplomats and Syrians involved in the uprising.

headline: Gingrich Says He Will Stay in Race and Stop Romney
text: Newt Gingrich said Tuesday night that “phase one” for himself and Rick Santorum in the days ahead must be stopping Mitt Romney from getting enough delegates to claim the Republican presidential nomination.

headline: Illinois Primary | Mitt Romney
text: Mitt Romney won in Illinois and used his victory speech to focus to the economy. Courtesy of MSNBC.

headline: Ulu Grosbard, 83, Broadway and Film Director, Dies
text: Ulu Grosbard, a director whose affinity for naturalistic drama shaped critical successes like the original Broadway production of David Mamet’s “American Buffalo” and the film version of John Gregory Dunne’s novel “True Confessions,” has died in Manhattan. He was 83.

headline: ‘Right to Work’ Bills Face Uncertain Future in an Election Year
text: ST. PAUL — For the first time in more than three decades, Minnesota Republicans are basking in majorities in both chambers of the state Legislature, so on matters that need no signature from the Democratic governor, they can do as they please. Priority No. 1, to some: put a measure on the ballot that would allow workers to avoid paying fees to unions they choose not to join. Critics view the proposed measure, which would amend the state Constitution, as a plain attack on unions.

headline: Coptic Pope’s Death Adds to Fears in Egypt’s Time of Transition
text: CAIRO — A tearful crowd of thousands that included members of Egypt’s emerging political class attended a funeral service Tuesday for Pope Shenouda III, who spent four decades as the popular and charismatic leader of the country’s Coptic Orthodox Church.

headline: U.S. Announces Olympic Qualifying Roster
text: United States Under-23 Coach Caleb Porter named his final 20-man roster for the Olympic qualifying tournament on Tuesday night. Fourteen of the players Porter chose play for M.L.S. clubs, and more than a dozen have competed in a World Cup at the youth level. Several — Brek Shea, Juan Agudelo, Freddy Adu — have played prominent roles with the senior national team.

headline: Illinois Primary | Rick Santorum
text: Rick Santorum spoke to supporters in Gettysburg, Pa., after finishing second in Illinois.

headline: Studies Link Daily Doses of Aspirin to Reduced Risk of Cancer
text: Taking aspirin every day may significantly reduce the risk of many cancers and prevent tumors from spreading, according to two new studies published on Tuesday.

headline: Knicks Increase Intensity, and Winning Streak Hits Four
text: The smile is back on Carmelo Anthony’s face, broad and beaming and wholly subject to interpretation. There is happiness there, to be sure, but also likely relief and perhaps some satisfaction.

headline: As Reactors Age, the Money to Close Them Lags
text: WASHINGTON — The operators of 20 of the nation’s aging nuclear reactors, including some whose licenses expire soon, have not saved nearly enough money for prompt and proper dismantling. If it turns out that they must close, the owners intend to let them sit like industrial relics for 20 to 60 years or even longer while interest accrues in the reactors’ retirement accounts.

headline: A Cheap Drug Is Found to Save Bleeding Victims
text: For months, a simple generic drug has been saving lives on America’s battlefields by slowing the bleeding of even gravely wounded soldiers.

headline: Romney Wins Illinois Primary
text: Mitt Romney swept to victory in the Illinois Republican primary on Tuesday.

headline: Despite Illinois Loss, Santorum Rallies Forces at Gettysburg
text: GETTYSBURG, Pa. — Rick Santorum delivered his own Gettysburg address twice Tuesday night after he lost the Illinois primary in a blowout to Mitt Romney.

headline: New Zealand Reeling from ‘Marmageddon’
text: HONG KONG — Marmite is either “vile” or it’s “black gold.” A person on Twitter said it was “ample proof of evil’s existence.” Its Facebook page has 780,000 followers, although somebody on there said it tasted “foul, like sugary truck grease.’’

headline: Mistakes Were Made
text: Mitt Romney has good reason to be exasperated with the way his slow progress to the Republican nomination has been covered in the press. Again and again, he’s won supposedly-decisive primary victories, only to have the press turn around and insist that actually, it’s the next big primary that is the crucial one, the make-or-break moment, the contest that could throw the whole race into chaos. First Florida was going to be decisive, then Michigan, then Ohio. Romney won all three, but the goal posts kept moving, and suddenly it was Illinois that threatened to cast his nomination into doubt.

headline: Romney and Santorum: Illinois Primary Speeches
text: Mitt Romney and Rick Santorum spoke after polls closed in Illinois.

headline: Mexico: Quake Rattles Country, but No Major Damage
text: A strong earthquake shook a large swath of central and southern Mexico on Tuesday, swaying buildings in Mexico City and sending office workers scurrying for cover but causing no major damage or injuries, the authorities said. The epicenter of the 7.8 magnitude quake was near the border of Oaxaca and Guerrero States, about 200 miles south of the capital. A pedestrian bridge in Mexico City collapsed on a small bus, but there were no reported casualties. The White House said President Obama’s 13-year-old daughter Malia, who was on vacation in Oaxaca with classmates, was safe.

headline: Santorum Campaign Takes New Tack on Gingrich
text: GETTYSBURG, Pa. — The Santorum campaign appears to be taking a slightly new tack on Newt Gingrich’s continued presence in the race.

headline: Reactors Facing Suspended Animation
text: Twenty operating nuclear power reactors across the nation lack sufficient funds for their decommissioning.

headline: Corrections: March 21
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Close G.O.P. Primary in House Race; Jackson Survives Challenge to Defend Seat
text: Representative Adam Kinzinger, a freshman Republican, narrowly defeated Representative Donald Manzullo, who has served in the House for two decades, on Tuesday in the only primary between two sitting congressmen in Illinois and one of the most closely watched Congressional primaries in the nation.

headline: The Closer: Time for Willis to Move On
text: At some point, being left-handed and having been named to two All-Star teams will no longer be enough to get Dontrelle Willis another chance. But it does not appear he has reached that point yet.

headline: Lowdown Hudson Blues Festival Announces Lineup
text: Buddy Guy and Neko Case will be the headliners at the second annual Lowdown Hudson Blues Festival, which will be held July 11 and 12 in a plaza outside the World Financial Center in Lower Manhattan, organizers said.   Buddy Guy, who is 74, is considered one of the most influential blues guitarists of modern times, having influenced everyone from Stevie Ray Vaughn to Jimi Hendrix.   Other acts on the bill include Charles Bradley, the Brooklyn born R&B singer, and John Mayall, the elder statesman of British blues whose 1960s band was a launching pad for guitarists like Eric Clapton and Mick Taylor.  The festival is free to the public and is presented by Brookfield Office Properties, which owns the World Financial Center.  The concerts will run from 6 p.m. to 9:30 p.m.

headline: Making the Case for Running Shoes
text: For the past few years, proponents of barefoot running have argued that modern athletic shoes compromise natural running form. But now a first-of-its-kind study suggests that, in the right circumstances, running shoes make running physiologically easier than going barefoot.

headline: NYT Front Page for 03/21/2012
text: NYT Front Page for 03/21/2012

headline: Word of the Day | omnipotent
text: omnipotent •\äm-ˈni-pə-tənt\• adjective

headline: Mediator Assigned in Dispute Over 33 Schools
text: A state panel has given the go-ahead for a mediator to intervene in a dispute between the city's Education Department and the teachers' union over an evaluation system for the teachers at 33 low-performing schools. The city strongly objects.

headline: Campaigning in Illinois
text: The contest in Illinois largely came down to a battle between Mitt Romney, who leads in delegates, and Rick Santorum, and in recent days the two campaigned furiously across the state.

headline: For India’s Dominant Party, Electoral Setback Stirs Self-Doubt
text: “After the policy paralysis and political acrimony of last year, India’s coalition national government had hoped this year would be different,” Jim Yardley writes in The New York Times. Instead, things have gotten worse.

headline: Both Sides Declare Victory in Bumpy Race for a Brooklyn Senate Seat
text: Wackiness turned to nastiness and back again in the short but bitter special election in South Brooklyn to replace a state senator who had pleaded guilty to corruption charges. But the biggest twist of the race was its outcome — or lack thereof when election night ended.

headline: Brunei to Send Its First Female Athlete to the Olympics
text: HONG KONG — The International Olympic Committee banned South Africa from the Olympics for nearly 30 years, until 1992, because of the repugnant official policy of apartheid that kept black athletes from competing. Nevertheless, the I.O.C. has continued to allow three nations that discriminate against female athletes to continue to participate in the Games.

headline: Veteran Crew Sets Imaginative Course
text: “At times I wondered if North End Grill was trying to look dull on purpose,” Pete Wells writes about Mumbai-born Floyd Cardoz’s newest restaurant in The New York Times.

headline: Suspect in France Remains in Standoff With Police
text: TOULOUSE, France — A 23-year-old Frenchman of Algerian descent claimed responsibility on Wednesday for the methodical killings of four men and three children in this region over the past 10 days, officials said, after barricading himself in a small apartment building in Toulouse surrounded by hundreds of police officers.

headline: News Quiz | March 21, 2012
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s front page.Good luck!

headline: The Rising Death Toll in Syria
text: A calendar of the estimated number of deaths in the country each day since the beginning of the uprising.

headline: Has Poverty Really Dropped in India?
text: Remember when the public was outraged at the idea that the poverty line should be 32 rupees, or 63 cents, a day in urban areas?

headline: March 21, 1960 | South African Police Kill 69 Black Protesters in Sharpeville Massacre
text: On March 21, 1960, South African police officers opened fire on a crowd of black protesters who had surrounded a police station in Sharpeville, killing 69 people.

headline: Test Yourself | Math, March 21, 2012
text: Test your math skills with this question created by Scott Matthews at Math for America from the article “Budget Cuts May Threaten City Programs for Children.”

headline: The Death of Trayvon Martin
text: WHO was Trayvon Martin?WHO is George Zimmerman?

headline: Fighting Returns to Areas Syria Had Declared Secure
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The Syrian military’s widening struggle against insurgents, even in places it had declared secure, again flared into deadly violence on Wednesday, as forces carried out a daylong bombardment in the city of Homs and deployed tanks and helicopters to rout rebels in clashes just outside the capital, antigovernment activists reported.

headline: Photographing the World, Longing for Home
text: Ed Kashi’s new book “Witness Number 8: Photojournalisms” (Nazraeli Press 2012) is a collection of images, diary entries and letters to his wife, Julie Winokur. Mr. Kashi spoke about the book with James Estrin this month at the National Press Photographers Association’s Northern Short Course in Fairfax, Va. Their conversation has been edited.

headline: How Productive and Organized Are You?
text: Are you overwhelmed, with too many things to get to every day? How organized are you about your homework and the other tasks you have to perform? Are you distracted by technology, even while it sometimes helps you work more quickly? What systems do you have to accomplish your goals? What organizational tips would you give to others? Read what David Allen, author of “Getting Things Done,” says about how to focus and meet your goals, then tell us about your own experiences.

headline: Rappers Welcome 2 Releases: An Album’s and a Colleague’s
text: There have been two Odd Future sagas unfolding over the last year and a half. In full public view this Los Angeles hip-hop collective has become an unlikely mini-juggernaut of the post-record age, creating a significant touring and merchandise business with only the Internet behind it — not radio or video — and redefining narrow ideas about the hip-hop underground.

headline: Happier, Perhaps, to Attend a State University Instead of an Ivy League School
text: When I first started the application process, almost every day somebody would ask me if I was applying to Cornell University. It seemed to be the logical choice, with its top-ranked animal science program and veterinary school. I guess people just assumed that with my grades and ACT score, I would be shooting for an Ivy League school.

headline: Marital Status and the Recession
text: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago.

headline: Fantasy Focus: An N.F.B.C. Satellite League
text: I’m excited to be back in the N.F.B.C. Main Event fold this season. I’ll be drafting in the second Main Event weekend in Las Vegas on March 31. To help get ready for that, I participated Monday night in a Satellite event that essentially lays out the same as the main, at least in format. It’s a 15-team mixed league with 30 roster spots (14 hitters, nine pitchers and seven reserves), with no trades allowed.

headline: The Early Word: Split Focus
text: In Today’s Times:Illinois primary voters decided on Tuesday that Mitt Romney had a better chance than other Republican candidates of beating President Obama in November, Jeff Zeleny and Jim Rutenberg wrote. But with his rivals showing no signs of stepping aside as the contest bounds to the next battleground, Louisiana, Mr. Romney cannot afford to turn his full focus to Mr. Obama for at least two months, they write.

headline: Hines Ward Retires, Starting Hall of Fame Debate
text: Wide receiver Hines Ward announced his retirement on Tuesday …

headline: North Korea Warns It Will Not Tolerate Criticism at Nuclear Forum
text: SEOUL, South Korea — As global leaders prepared to travel to Seoul for a nuclear security summit meeting, North Korea warned on Wednesday that any criticism of its nuclear weapons program would be considered a “declaration of war.”

headline: Should Jets Trade for Tebow?
text: The Jets helped start Tebowmania, allowing him to score a game-winning touchdown in November. Now, with the show about to close in Denver, is he headed to Broadway? (If this were a play, Jets fans, would it be a comedy? A tragedy?)

headline: Tip of the Week: Going from Gmail to Google Docs
text: Gmail users who cut and paste e-mail messages from the Gmail Web site into text documents for printing may want to try out the optional Create a Document feature that lets you quickly create a Google Doc from a message.

headline: Mark Leyner, World-Champion Satirist, Returns to Reclaim His Crown
text: There is a clip online of the Charlie Rose show from 1996, in which Rose invited three young novelists to talk about the future of American fiction, and this clip is often — and thanks to the Internet, may forever be — cited by anyone writing the history of Mark Leyner. That’s because Rose’s panel comprised David Foster Wallace, promoting “Infinite Jest”; a young and anxious-looking Jonathan Franzen, the author, at that time, of “Strong Motion”; and Leyner, the most intense, and in a certain sense, significant young prose writer in America.

headline: Jungleland
text: “We have snakes,” Mary Brock said. “Long, thick snakes. Kingsnakes, rattlesnakes.”

headline: From Young Adult Book Fans to Wizards of Change
text: This week, Suzanne Collins’s “The Hunger Games” hits the big screen. As the latest wildly popular young adult (Y.A.) novel becomes a film franchise, it’s not just box office dollars that will be captured, but potentially nascent citizens.  At least that’s the goal of the social campaign called “Hunger Is Not a Game” which aims to connect fans to the global food justice movement.

headline: The Micro-Multinational: Getting Started in Foreign Markets
text: Even though TerraCycle is a small business with just under $20 million in revenue and just more than 100 employees, we are operating in more than 21 countries and we have plans to open in five more in the coming months — all with local staff, operations, bank accounts, incorporations and headaches. All in all, about 35 percent of our annual revenue comes from outside the United States, and our foreign business is growing faster than our domestic business.

headline: Convicted Fund Manager Ordered to Pay Morgan Stanley $10.2 Million
text: A federal judge has ordered Joseph F. Skowron, a onetime star hedge fund manager now serving jail time for insider trading, to pay $10.2 million to his former employer, Morgan Stanley.

headline: Losing a Precious Sliver of East River Sky
text: The men of the Fulton Fish Market along South Street did not suffer outsiders gladly. In the early 1980s, however, they warmed to a newcomer from Brooklyn named Barbara Mensch. She was a photographer. She had just moved into an old salting house a block away on Water Street. They let her see the living market in its predawn hours and capture their words and faces: a loader named Philly, a retailer named Heschy, a journeyman named Sweet Pea and a fillet man named Vinny the Bone.

headline: Daily Report: Shake-Up at Hewlett-Packard
text: 10:11 a.m. | Updated with official announcement.

headline: A Hunger Artist
text: DHAKA, Bangladesh — On Monday, in a display of rank opportunism, the celebrity anticorruption campaigner Anna Hazare jumped onto the bandwagon of a leading Indian environmentalist who is on the 42nd day of a hunger strike to protect the Ganges River.

headline: Kidnapped British Woman Is Freed in Somalia
text: LONDON — A British tourist seized by Somali raiders from a secluded, upmarket resort on the Kenyan coast more than six months ago in an attack that claimed her husband’s life was set free on Wednesday, ending a gripping drama that had helped fuel Kenya’s rationale for invading southern Somalia.

headline: Repairing the Damage at India’s National Archives
text: When he took charge of the National Archives of India in May 2010, Mushirul Hasan inherited a rudderless institution. The job of director general had been vacant for several years, and past directors had been bureaucrats. Mr. Hasan became the first scholar in 30 years to oversee an institution that contained a dazzling array of material from the Mughal, British and post-independence periods of Indian history.

headline: The Better to Entertain You With, My Dear
text: Fairy tales can come true, the old song goes; it can happen to you, apparently, if you’re young at heart. Whether one believes this hopeful sentiment, and regardless of the age of one’s internal organs, there’s no doubt that fairy tales have for the past couple of years — and into the foreseeable future — been coming pretty regularly to screens both big and small, achieving, you could say, at least the kind of quasi-truth that movies and television can concoct.

headline: On Our Radar: Obama’s Energy Blitz
text: After taking heat over gasoline prices, President Obama plans to visit a photovoltaic plant in Nevada and oil fields in New Mexico to underline his “all of the above” energy policy. [USA Today].

headline: Tech Mahindra to Merge With Satyam
text: The Indian software company Tech Mahindra plans to merge with Mahindra Satyam in a $1 billion deal that will create a top player in technology services.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: Convicted Fund Manager Ordered to Pay Morgan Stanley $10.2 Million  |  A federal judge has ordered Joseph F. Skowron, the onetime star hedge fund manager serving jail time for insider trading, to pay $10.2 million to his former employer Morgan Stanley.

headline: Reconciling Gandhi With Ambedkar
text: Mohandas K. Gandhi and B.R. Ambedkar were the men of the hour at Columbia University on Tuesday evening.

headline: Flim-Flam Fever
text: Way back in 2010 I declared that Paul Ryan — who was rapidly becoming the darling of the “fiscal responsibility” crowd — was a fraud, a flim-flam man. Very Serious People were very seriously annoyed — they’d anointed him, and they didn’t want to hear anything negative. They even gave him a “Fiscy”, an award for fiscal responsibility.

headline: A New Companion for ‘Doctor Who’
text: When you are an essentially immortal being from another planet who can traverse space and time, you don’t always pick up on changes great and small. But a momentous transition is coming for “Doctor Who,” the popular BBC science-fiction series (shown in the United States on BBC America) and the enigmatic Doctor of its title: in its upcoming season, the Doctor, played by Matt Smith, will get a new companion, to be played by Jenna-Louise Coleman, the show’s producers said on Wednesday.

headline: Hindu Victory Could Ease Indian Anger With Russia
text: LONDON — Russia extricated itself from an embarrassing spat with India on Wednesday when a provincial appeals court definitively rejected an attempt to ban a version of the Bhagavad Gita, one of Hinduism’s most holy texts.

headline: Political and Construction Hurdles for Malaysia Rare Earths Plant
text: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia — A controversial rare earth metal refinery in Malaysia encountered further obstacles this week, with the country’s political opposition refusing to participate in a parliamentary committee set up to investigate the safety of the plant and with hints that the refinery could face further construction delays.

text: Pain hurts.

headline: The Courtship of Mr. Mulgrew
text: These days, among a certain group of mayoral hopefuls, the United Federation of Teachers president, Michael Mulgrew, is the most popular man in the room. With more than a year to go before the next mayoral election, the candidates are pursuing Mr. Mulgrew -- and the money and political machine he can bring to a campaign.

headline: Wednesday Reading: Is a $180,000 Nanny Worth the Price?
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: Why Has India Become the World’s Top Arms Buyer?
text: India has replaced China as the world’s largest arms buyer, accounting for 10 percent of all arms purchases during the past five years, a Swedish research group said.

headline: Deputy Succeeds Greek Finance Minister, Now Socialist Party Leader
text: ATHENS — The Greek government on Wednesday appointed the deputy finance minister to run the ministry temporarily after his boss resigned to lead the country’s Socialist party.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Romney Must Slog On, and Studios Pursue ’50 Shades’
text: Mitt Romney won the Republican presidential primary in Illinois, beating his nearest opponent, Rick Santorum, by a sizable margin and adding substantially to his lead in delegates, Jim Rutenberg and Jeff Zeleny report. But if Mr. Romney thought the victory would give “closure” to the nomination fight, there was no such indication from his opponents who continue to be buoyed by “super PACs.”

headline: G.O.P. Nomination Becoming a One-Man Race

headline: Drug Giants Back New Venture Capital Fund
text: Johnson & Johnson and GlaxoSmithKline, the pharmaceutical giants, are teaming up with the venture capital firm Index Ventures on a 150 million euro ($199 million) fund targeted at the life sciences sector.

text: Good morning. It will be partly cloudy today with patches of fog, but, hey, highs will be in the low 70s.

headline: Obama Tours Four States to Defend Energy Policy
text: BOULDER CITY, Nev. — Against the desert backdrop of the nation’s largest solar energy installation, President Obama on Wednesday assailed Republican critics of his clean energy policies as “the flat earth society” even as he sought to demonstrate his own support for domestic oil and gas production.

headline: Soul Sisters
text: Most of us don’t think of craft as holy. But it certainly was for cloistered nuns of the 17th through 19th centuries, who made reliquaries of rolled or “quilled” paper that was adorned with beads, shells, coral, fabric and other materials. Nearly 150 of these pieces will be on view in “Quilling: Devotional Creations From Cloistered Orders” at the Pinacoteca Giovanni e Marella Agnelli in Turin, Italy, from April 5 through Sept. 2. A number of works in the show are owned by the photographer Nan Goldin, who shot some of the pieces in the exhibition. In addition to the reliquaries, the exhibition also includes miniature 19th-century reconstructions of nuns’ cells, like the one at right, which are as spare as the reliquaries are ornate.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: The New York Daily News: George Clooney will find time in his busy schedule of making movies and political activism to start his own brand of tequila. — Robert Simonson

headline: Beijing Switches Sides in the Race for Hong Kong’s Chief Executive
text: HONG KONG — China’s leaders have begun actively supporting a populist to become the next chief executive of Hong Kong in elections this Sunday, abandoning their previous private support for a wealthy civil servant whose candidacy has been plagued by scandals, local politicians and political analysts said Wednesday.

headline: Occupy Protesters Are Arrested at Union Square Park
text: Several protesters were arrested early Wednesday after scores of Occupy Wall Street demonstrators converged on Union Square Park in Lower Manhattan, the authorities said.

headline: Tours of Asia’s Wild Side
text: CULTURAL trendsetters have long flocked to Asia for a taste of exotic cuisine, bustling cities and mystical temples. Now adventurous travelers are turning to the region’s wild frontiers for stunning natural landscapes and wildlife diversity.

headline: Wolfish
text: The Big Bad Wolf is a villain of long standing. But in recent picture books, the famed brute has taken a real punishing — belittled, undermined and otherwise made fun of.

headline: JPMorgan Adds Small Foothold in China
text: JPMorgan Chase is poised to move further into China, agreeing to buy a 19.9 percent stake in a small Chinese trust company, according to a person briefed on the matter.

headline: Americans Split Over Whether Recovery Will Endure
text: Despite recent improvements in the economy, Americans are divided about whether the upswing will continue for the rest of this year, In fact, Americans are split about evenly, a new survey shows.

text: After my Sunday column criticizing Village Voice Media for providing a forum for sex traffickers on its Backpage.com websites, Village Voice has struck back. It has just gone on line with an article “What Nick Kristof got wrong”:

headline: Pickle Tongs, a Melon Baller and Other Gadget Regrets
text: We asked readers to tweet us with the kitchen tools they bought but then abandoned to the closet, drawer or basement, or to share their tales of woe in the comments section here. Below are just a few of the neglected tools in question, culled from Twitter; we’ll post more as the day progresses. Share yours by tweeting us at @nytdining with the hashtag #gadgetregrets.

headline: Jeb Bush Backs Romney and Urges End to G.O.P. Battle
text: 11:20 a.m. | Updated CHICAGO — Former Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida said Wednesday that he was endorsing Mitt Romney‘s bid for the Republican presidential nomination, and urged his party to bring the divisive primary to a close and coalesce behind Mr. Romney’s candidacy.

headline: Noah Hawley Talks About His New Novel, ‘The Good Father’
text: In Noah Hawley’s novel “The Good Father,” a young man named Daniel Allen is accused of assassinating a popular Democratic senator running for president. Daniel’s father, Paul, a doctor who was absent for much of his son’s childhood, sets out to prove Daniel’s innocence while contemplating how he may have failed as a parent. I recently spoke with Mr. Hawley about the book via e-mail. Below are excerpts of the conversation.

headline: Look of The Moment | Jennifer Lawrence
text: The Look: Jewel Toned. A bombshell silhouette with a pleated skirt and plunging neckline — in prefall’s favorite emerald green — would make Marilyn proud.

headline: Afghan Officials Deny French Suspect Escaped Their Prison
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Countering reports that the suspect in seven killings in France was one of hundreds of men who escaped from an Afghan prison in 2008, Afghan officials said Wednesday that a man by the same name had indeed escaped then, but was a citizen of Afghanistan, not France.

headline: Delle Donne and Delaware Make Early Exit
text: The run of Delaware and its scoring star, Elena Delle Donne, in the N.C.A.A. tournament ended Tuesday night when No. 11 Kansas pulled off a big second-round upset. The Jayhawks defeated the No. 3-seeded Blue Hens, 70-64, in Little Rock, Ark.

headline: Leading Off: Tebowmania Shipping Out
text: Now that the great Peyton Manning relocation saga has settled to an orange-hued conclusion, the real fun is about to happen. That’s because Manning arriving in Denver means an entire circus has to pick up and leave. Somewhat surprisingly, the Manning-signing part was quite calm and, well, very Peyton-like. The Tim Tebow-leaving part is what could start to feel like an N.F.L. reality show run amok. Because anything involving Tebow never quite seems to go like everyone thinks it will. It might be the man’s true genius.

headline: A Cloud of One’s Own
text: As consumers use their mobile devices more and more to enjoy music, television and movies, they are facing a capacity crunch as those devices quickly fill up. For instance, I can’t fit even half of my iTunes library on my iPhone, and my iPad is near capacity with movies and TV shows.

headline: What Took Him So Long?
text: Mitt Romney’s victory in Illinois seems likely to finally — finally! — silence the “it’s still wide open/anything can happen” chorus. In this week’s Campaign Stops column, I look at three failures that prevented the Romney campaign from silencing that chorus much sooner:

headline: British Budget Adheres to Austerity While It Cuts the Top Tax Rate
text: LONDON — The British government said Wednesday that it was sticking to its austerity program as it presented a budget of tax and benefit changes intended to spur economic growth. The opposition criticized it as benefiting higher earners.

headline: The Pacifist Red Wings? Let’s Go to the Tape
text: Critics of fighting in the N.H.L. should have their day in the sun at Madison Square Garden on Wednesday night, where the Red Wings will face the Rangers in what should be an exciting, fast-paced game played by two highly skilled teams.

headline: Report Cites Continued Problems for Workers at Abu Dhabi Cultural Site
text: Conditions for migrant workers on Saadiyat Island in Abu Dhabi — the site of future branches of the Louvre and Guggenheim museums — have improved, but problems continue, Human Rights Watch said in a progress report issued on Wednesday. Activists, artists and others have been monitoring the treatment of workers who are building this sprawling cultural center and resort in the Arabian Gulf, where a New York University campus, a performing arts center, golf courses and hotels are also being constructed.

headline: Stone Links
text: A gathering of recent philosophy-related links.

headline: IFC to Unlock New Episodes of R. Kelly’s ‘Trapped in the Closet’
text: In the space of a blog post we couldn’t possibly summarize the story to date of R. Kelly‘s musical serial “Trapped in the Closet,” the continuing narrative of a homewrecker named Sylvester; Cathy, the married woman with whom he had an affair; her cuckolded husband, Rufus; and such dramatis personae as Roxanne, Twan, Pimp Lucius and Rosie the Nosy Neighbor. It’s 22 chapters long (so far), and boy is it confusing, even if you’ve seen it. But R. Kelly will have further opportunities to untangle this narrative — or to complicate it even more — in a new series of “Trapped in the Closet” episodes that have been ordered by the IFC cable channel.

headline: For Butler, a Different Tournament but a Familiar Opponent
text: In 2010 and 2011, the Butler Bulldogs were college basketball’s favorite Cinderella story. But this season has sometimes been a struggle and the Bulldogs are now playing in the College Basketball Invitational tournament. Matt Rhinesmith, a sports reporter for The Butler Collegian, will file occasional posts for The Quad about the team’s season.

headline: Palmer Is Latest to Criticize Use of Belly Putter

headline: Korean Oil Firm Is Part of Group Buying El Paso Assets
text: The consortium of firms buying the El Paso Corporation’s exploration and production businesses has grown a little larger and has drawn overseas interest.

headline: Helping One Big Client, but Wanting to Spread Out

headline: How Do You Escape the One-Big-Client Trap?
text: Our latest case study looks at the Four Horsemen Toy Design Studio and the company’s efforts to diversify its revenue streams so it is not dependent on one big client, Mattel. Based in Bloomington, N.J., the company is owned by four men — Chris Dahlberg, H. Eric Mayse, Jim Preziosi and Eric Treadaway — and has three other employees who help with sculpting, painting and shipping. The company takes in revenue of more than $500,000 a year, the bulk of it from its work for Mattel.

headline: Patience Now, Offense Later
text: PEORIA, Ariz.

headline: Mr. Phillips Goes to Washington
text: As his train pulled into Washington in March 1862, Wendell Phillips, the man known as “abolition’s golden trumpet,” caught sight of “one of those unfinished round buildings used to turn locomotives in,” and asked his seatmate “what that engine house was.”

headline: Toulouse Victims Buried in Israel
text: JERUSALEM — The journey from Toulouse, France, ended here, in the sprawling cemetery known as Har Hamenuchot, or the Mount of Rest, in the Jerusalem hills. The four victims of the shooting outside a Jewish school, three of them children, were buried on Wednesday in a joint funeral that was attended by thousands.

headline: French Lawyer Says Shooting Suspect Was Petty Criminal Before Radicalization
text: 1:20 p.m. | Updated  As my colleague Scott Sayare reports, the French police early on Wednesday cornered a man suspected of killing seven people, including three children at a Jewish school this week, and kept him holed up in a Toulouse apartment during a tense and protracted standoff.

headline: Myanmar Invites Americans and Europeans to Monitor Vote
text: The United States said on Wednesday that it was “encouraged” that Myanmar had invited American and European representatives to monitor elections on April 1, a milestone for Myanmar as it emerges from decades of military dictatorship.

headline: Money Makes the Campaigns Go Round, and Round
text: The Republican primaries are starting to feel like the debates earlier in the election cycle – they keep happening and pundits declare a winner, but nothing seems to change. Last night, Mitt Romney won Illinois on the strength of the more moderate voters around Chicago. He stands to get three times as many delegates as Rick Santorum and has what looks like an insurmountable lead. And yet, Mr. Santorum keeps going — and going and going. And so does Newt Gingrich.

headline: Voice Mail From Harvard Makes the Choice Tough to Call
text: Late on a Tuesday night, I take a break from homework. Glancing at my phone, I see I have a new voice mail from hours ago.

headline: Need Experienced Teachers? Here's an Idea
text: The author, who began his teaching career in a New York City school before going to the suburbs, proposes a new kind of teaching fellowship that would bring veteran teachers close to retirement into failing schools, where they would work as mentors for new younger teachers. The idea could benefit the children who most need their help, he writes.

headline: TimesCast | March 21, 2012
text: French shooting suspect is cornered | Syrian conflict enters a period of prolonged instability.

headline: Image of the Day: March 21
text: On the eve of World Water Day, a girl watches as water trickles down from a pipe into her bucket.

headline: In Louisiana, Santorum Pushes for More Drilling
text: HARVEY, La. — Rick Santorum began his fight for the Louisiana primary here on Wednesday morning, telling a small crowd that he would deliver more jobs to the gulf region by easing the permitting process for oil and gas drilling.

headline: Santorum Puts a Stress on History, in Hopes of Making It
text: In Gettysburg, Pa., on Tuesday night, Rick Santorum stood on the grounds where more lives were lost than in any other Civil War battle, and where Abraham Lincoln issued his stirring call for unity and democracy. Mr. Santorum, who had just lost the Republican primary in Illinois, called the presidential race the “most important election since the election of 1860.”

headline: The Common Sense Catholics
text: Rick Santorum doesn’t just wear his religion on his sleeve, he billboards it in neon. Still, for all the flash and sparks generated by an ostentatiously Catholic candidate’s crusade for the presidency, one thing has been missing from most discussions: the actual Catholic voter.

headline: In Honor of Bach’s Birthday, a Gift for Listeners
text: For all celebrants of Johann Sebastian Bach’s 327th birthday (and all Bach lovers, for that matter), on Wednesday, a record label is offering a promotional gift: nine hours of Bach’s music for 99 cents on Amazon, available through Friday. The company,  eOne Music – the label formerly known as Koch – says it is selling the downloads to publicize its plans to reissue recordings by the Bach Guild, a label started in 1948 to make the composer’s works more widely available. EOne Music said it also planned new recordings.

headline: Stringer Calls for Immediate Removal of 'Pink Slime' Products
text: The Manhattan borough president, Scott M. Stringer, on Wednesday demanded that the city immediately remove any products in school lunches containing a low-cost meat filler known to its critics as "pink slime." City officials said they plan to phase out those lunch products, which include meatballs and beef paddies, by September.

headline: Saints Coach Is Suspended for a Year Over Bounties
text: In a powerful rebuke to one of the game’s most successful teams, the National Football League suspended New Orleans Saints Coach Sean Payton for a year without pay on Wednesday for his role in a bounty program that promised money to players if they injured opponents and knocked them out of games.

headline: Motherlode: Anne and Sam Lamott
text: KJ DellAntonia interviews the mother and son duo who co-wrote Some Assembly Required.

headline: Care by Consensus
text: Naomi Cotter finally retired at 73, after 24 years spent directing a student legal clinic at Harvard Law School and then several more more working for a mediation service. “I was worn out,” she told me. “I’d worked my entire life, and I just wanted time.” Now 75, Ms. Cotter spends her days going to the theater and concerts and seeing friends; she’s considering whether to take art courses.

headline: After Hours of Uncertainty, Jets Complete Deal for Tebow
text: About eight hours after announcing a trade for Tim Tebow, the Jets actually completed it Wednesday night, ending a surreal day in which one of the most popular and polarizing athletes in the country was sent to the N.F.L.’s most prominent city.

headline: Stuckey, Detroit’s Holdover and New Hope
text: Rebuilding teams are not only tasked with scouting and development, but also with internal identification; every franchise in transition will inevitably have some remnants from the previous era, and it’s the charge of a discerning general manager to scour those holdovers for future value.

headline: GSN Plans to Add Reality TV to Its Game Show Roster
text: The GSN cable channel plans to expand into reality television for the 2012-13 season, the channel’s programming and advertising executives said at an upfront breakfast on Wednesday.

headline: Imagining Carbon Emissions in Underground Exile
text: In a perfect world, greenhouse gas emissions would be on the decline in the near future, with fossil fuels replaced by clean sources of energy like wind and solar. But current emissions are so daunting that the chances of the planet’s cleaning up its act in a timely manner are slim.

headline: Your Say: After Toulouse, Do You Feel Less Secure?
text: French and international media have been filled with reports of spreading insecurity across France: first, as a result of the assassinations last week of three French soldiers of North African descent; then, because of a shooting rampage on Monday outside a Jewish school that claimed the lives of three children and a rabbi.

headline: Radulov Could Join Predators on Thursday
text: 5:32 p.m. | Updated Alexander Radulov is in Nashville and ready to go as soon as Thursday against the Penguins. As originally reported here and elsewhere and as confirmed by Radulov and Predators General Manager David Poile at Wednesday’s Bridgestone Arena news conference, Radulov has no commitment to go back to the K.H.L. next season. Rather, his Russian club, Salavat Yulaev Ufa, retains his K.H.L. rights for 2012-13 if, and only if, he decides to return to Russia next season after the July 1 expiration of his N.H.L. contract with Nashville.

headline: Did Punishment Fit Crime for Saints?
text: Here are the N.F.L.’s punishments for the Saints’ system of paying players for hits that knocked opponents out of games.The sanctions for individuals were more harsh than most people probably expected, and perhaps lighter in terms of money and draft picks lost.

headline: The Political Geography of Gasoline Prices
text: Many readers were not convinced by my article in Saturday’s paper pointing out the lack of evidence that gasoline prices affect the outcomes of presidential elections.

headline: At Daytona Bike Week, Demolition on Two Wheels
text: NEW SMYRNA BEACH, Fla. — With the Daytona 500 falling a week after its traditional third Sunday of February, another marquee event in the greater Daytona Beach area, Bike Week, was consequently pushed forward. The annual gathering of roughly 500,000 bikers, which concluded Sunday, fell smack in the middle of the traditional collegiate spring break and the N.C.A.A. basketball tourney, as bikers and co-eds shared the beach and the bars.

headline: Prague Railways Introduces Ladies-First Compartments
text: Czech Railways recently rolled out a new feature that has raised more than a few eyebrows — “Ladies Compartments.” These designated six-seater areas, introduced at the start of the year, are part of a marketing strategy intended to improve service for women who want special assistance or priority seating. But the move was immediately criticized as being discriminatory against male passengers.

headline: For Wisconsin’s Brianna Decker, Hockey’s Top Honor
text: DULUTH, Minn. — Surrounded by her teammates, coaches, and family, Wisconsin’s junior forward Brianna Decker received the Patty Kazmaier Memorial Award on Saturday to honor her for season-long success.

text: A scene from Dan LeFranc's new play at Playwrights Horizons. (Video courtesy of the production.)

headline: U.S. Notes Europe’s Progress in Easing Its Debt Crisis
text: WASHINGTON — For the United States, the looming threat from the long-simmering European sovereign debt crisis seems finally to have started to subside.

headline: New Focus on Publicizing Information About Political TV Ads
text: Local broadcasters, by law, have to disclose the identities of those who buy political advertisements, as well as detailed information about the purchases. They print out the data and store it at their offices for the public to see, theoretically. But few members of the public ever get a chance to.

headline: Circus Aside, Can Tebow’s Rushing Help Rescue Jets?
text: Here is some initial reaction on Denver’s trade of Tim Tebow to the Jets. It feels a little strange just writing it. The Broncos sent Tebow and a seventh-round pick for a fourth-round pick and a sixth-round pick in this year’s draft.

headline: Bad Gun Laws
text: The Trayvon Martin killing has brought some much-needed attention to Florida’s Stand Your Ground law, which did away with the longstanding legal principle that there is a “duty to retreat” from dangerous situations, and lowered the standard for using lethal force in response to a perceived threat. As The Times story put it, the law “grants immunity to people who act to protect themselves if they have a reasonable fear they will be killed or seriously injured.”

headline: The ‘I Know Nothing’ Defense
text: Michael W. Peregrine, a partner at the law firm McDermott Will & Emery, advises corporations, officers and directors on issues related to corporate governance, fiduciary duties and internal investigations.

headline: After 2 Amendments, Senate to Vote on Jobs Bill
text: The JOBS bill, which aims to make it easier and quicker for small companies to raise money from investors, is scheduled for a vote on Wednesday afternoon after the Senate considers two amendments to tighten rules on how companies raise financing online, and to strengthen other provisions approved by the House.

headline: In Zimbabwe, Sentenced for Watching News Reports
text: JOHANNESBURG — A court in Zimbabwe decided not to imprison six activists who had been arrested while watching news videos of the Arab Spring uprisings, sentencing them instead on Wednesday to 420 hours of community service and fining them $500 each.

headline: Yankees’ Value Up, Mets’ Down
text: The Yankees are worth $1.85 billion, up nine percent from 2011, Forbes magazine said Wednesday.

headline: A Season of Confounded Expectations
text: The north woods of Maine, where our family of five is spending a year, is a place defined by winter. The intense cold shapes everything that lives in these woods. The long legs of the moose enable it to walk in deep snow. The meadow voles and red squirrels tunnel through the snow. The local people are paragons of self-reliance. Winter is the defining season of northern New England. Even more so than football or baseball season.

headline: MF Global Executive Subpoenaed by House Panel
text: A Congressional subcommittee voted on Wednesday to subpoena an MF Global executive at the center of a federal investigation into wrongdoing at the firm.

headline: Boy Band Becomes First British Group to Open at No. 1 on Billboard Chart
text: Bring on the new boy-band invasion.

headline: Descending to the Challenge: Developing Documentaries About the Deep Ocean
text: Overview | What do we know about the deepest reaches of the ocean floor, and how do scientists explore this remote habitat? In this lesson, students investigate deep-sea geology, chemistry and biology, learn about the technologies scientists use to explore these areas, and write a treatment for a documentary about the ocean floor.

headline: Ristretto | We Are the 5 Percent
text: If you want to order the most unconventional, unexpected drink at an espresso bar, ask for an espresso.

headline: Fox and MLB Network to Collaborate on Pregame Show
text: Fox Sports’ Saturday baseball 30-minute pregame show emanated from its Los Angeles studio for years. More recently, it was less a show than a 10-minute segment hosted from a game site by Chris Rose.

headline: Wachtell Defends Staggered Boards
text: Despite a campaign led by a Harvard Law School professor to remove them, staggered boards still have an outspoken defender in Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz.

headline: U.N. Council Backs Plan for Ending Syria Conflict
text: Overcoming months of bitter division, the United Nations Security Council delivered a diplomatic setback to President Bashar al-Assad of Syria on Wednesday, unanimously embracing efforts by Kofi Annan, the former secretary general, to negotiate a cease-fire in the year-old Syrian conflict, funnel aid to victims and begin a political transition.

headline: Presidential Statement on the Joint Special Envoy on Syria
text: In this statement, which was read aloud during a formal session of the Security Council on Wednesday, expresses its “gravest concern at the deteriorating situation in Syria, which has resulted in a serious human rights crisis and a deplorable humanitarian situation.”

headline: TimesCast | French Suspect Cornered
text: March 21, 2012 — French police surrounded the apartment building of a man suspected of killing seven people in the last ten days.

headline: TimesCast | Fighting Continues in Syria

text: The day in sports included greyhound racing in Brighton, England, and the French swimming championships in Dunkirk.

headline: A Quiz Asks: How Insulated Are You?
text: Unless you’ve been living in a cave (as opposed to a bubble), you have probably heard about the new book by Charles Murray, “Coming Apart,” in which he describes a widening gulf between educated, wealthy white professionals and their less educated, less affluent, working-class white counterparts.

headline: Justices’ Ruling Expands Rights of Accused in Plea Bargains
text: WASHINGTON — Criminal defendants have a constitutional right to effective lawyers during plea negotiations, the Supreme Court ruled on Wednesday in a pair of 5-to-4 decisions that vastly expanded judges’ supervision of the criminal justice system.

headline: Little, and Learning to Be Artists
text: A new exhibition displaying art by New York City public school students opened Tuesday at Studio Gallery in Midtown Manhattan. The show, called "Littlest Learners," features the work of prekindergarten through second-grade students from 25 schools in Manhattan, Brooklyn, Queens and the Bronx.

headline: Is the New iPad Screen Too Good for the Web?
text: Apps, games and e-books may look great on the new iPad’s high-resolution “retina” display, but it’s unclear whether Web sites will get the same treatment.

headline: European Union Plans Retaliation in Public Contract Bidding
text: BRUSSELS — In a move likely to increase tensions over protectionism in international trade, Chinese, American or Japanese companies could be blocked from bidding for public contracts in Europe if their home countries are thought to be excluding bids from European firms.

headline: Gadget Regrets, Part II: Meat Pounders, Oyster Knives and Mandolines
text: Readers have been tweeting and posting comments naming the kitchen tools they thought they would cherish, but now barely use. A selection of tweets is below; you can read another batch here. Share your tale of kitchen-tool woe by tweeting us at @nytdining with the hashtag #gadgetregrets.

headline: Zynga Buys Mobile-Game Maker
text: Zynga announced on Wednesday that it has acquired OMGPOP, a mobile-game maker, for an undisclosed sum. The acquisition comes as Zynga, the maker of popular Facebook games like CityVille and FarmVille, tries to expand its mobile offerings and become less dependent on the social network.
