headline: Lynton Will Take On Expanded Role at Sony in U.S.
text: 8:15 p.m. | Updated  LOS ANGELES — Michael Lynton, the chairman and chief executive of Sony’s filmed entertainment unit, will soon take charge of the Japan-based company’s United States operations in an expanded role as chief executive of Sony Corporation of America, according to people who were briefed on the expected change.

headline: Somber Scenes in France and Israel as Shooting Victims Are Eulogized
text: While a tense standoff continued throughout the day on Wednesday in the French city of Toulouse — where a gunman who took responsibility for the methodical killings of four men and three children over the past 10 days was surrounded by hundreds of police officers — the victims of the attacks were remembered at services in France and Israel.

headline: How Did TBS Become No. 1 on Cable? It’s a Familiar Story
text: TBS has found the formula for cable television success. Buy repeats. Then repeat.

headline: Holy Cow: Reacting to the N.F.L.’s Punishment of the Saints
text: The news that the Jets had traded for Tim Tebow and that the N.F.L. had handed down draconian penalties against the Saints hit the Internet within minutes of each other Wednesday. Both were shocking in their own way, even though we had plenty of hints they were possible.

headline: The Most Fun With an Etch A Sketch Since Kindergarten
text: A Romney adviser’s simile comparing the campaign to a very old toy utterly transfixed the new media.

headline: It Has Come to This: Even ‘NCIS’ Suffers Spring Dropoff
text: It seems that even CBS’s venerable “NCIS” franchise is not immune to a spring downturn in the ratings. According to Nielsen, “NCIS” fell to a season low in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic on Tuesday night while “NCIS: Los Angeles” tied a season low in that advertiser-beloved category. The drop was unexpected, as the last new episodes from three weeks ago had better numbers despite facing stiffer competition in the form of a Tuesday edition of “American Idol” on Fox. The shows still maintained their dominance in total viewers, with 18.6 million and 16 million, respectively.

headline: Romney to Lincoln: You Can Fool All the People (in the Fall)
text: I’ve been covering politics for so long that I sometimes wonder if I’m too cynical and if my expectations for politicians are too low. But then something happens to convince me that they’re not.

headline: Low-Income Students Won't Have to Pay for A.P. Exams
text: UPDATED | The city's Department of Education says it has found money to pay for the Advanced Placement exams this spring for low-income students, despite a cut in the federal subsidy for the exams.

headline: Three-Play Cycle by Tom Murphy Among Highlights of Lincoln Center Festival
text: From the Olympics to Lincoln Center: A three-play cycle by the major Irish dramatist Tom Murphy will be offered at the Lincoln Center Festival this summer, after performances in Galway, Ireland, and the Cultural Olympiad in London, Lincoln Center said on Wednesday in announcing its 2012 program. The cycle, called DruidMurphy, is being presented by the Druid Theater Company of Galway and is directed by Garry Hynes. It will be the company’s third visit to the festival. Other theatrical productions include a Sydney Theater Company presentation of “Uncle Vanya,” directed by Tamas Ascher. The cast includes Cate Blanchett. Mikhail Baryshnikov will star in a new play, “In Paris,” and Alan Cumming will appear in a one-person production of “Macbeth” by the National Theater of Scotland.

headline: Santorum Plays to His Audience, Toy in Hand
text: MANDEVILLE, La. – Wielding a classic red Etch A Sketch toy on stage before a crowd of Tea Party supporters on Wednesday, Rick Santorum made a mockery of Mitt Romney’s campaign, pointing out that he would not be redrawn.

headline: How a Master of Stand-Up Sells the Joke
text: Close your eyes, and Todd Barry sounds like an impossibly cool combination of Jack Nicholson in his prime and a smug jazz D.J. after a few bong hits. Open them, and he’s a short, middle-aged, bald comic with a paunch.

headline: As Hoverflies Grow, So Do Their Acting Skills
text: Hoverflies don’t sting, but to repel predators they sometimes pretend to. And to aid in the deception, they look remarkably like wasps and bees.

headline: Rent Is the Least of This Landlord’s Worries
text: Chekhov once said that a gun appearing in the first act of a play shouldn’t be left unfired. Here’s a corollary: A character who says “My gut tells me I can trust you” probably shouldn’t trust that person.

headline: A Visitor Returns With Friends in Tow
text: New York has become accustomed to regular visits by the Nrityagram Dance Ensemble, which refines its art in a village outside Bangalore in southern India dedicated to that purpose. Each visit here is a gift, but for the one that began at the Joyce Theater on Tuesday, the group has brought something extra: friends.

headline: Now Collaborating | Tommy Ton and Club Monaco
text: Tommy Ton, the street style photographer behind the big-time blog Jak & Jil, celebrated his collaboration with Club Monaco last night at the company’s flagship on Fifth Avenue in New York. “The idea was for me to design something that was essential for everyday use,” Ton says. “I pretty much don’t go anywhere without a backpack, so that style was instant.” Traveling almost constantly to fashion weeks around the world requires a lot from the shutterbug, and his carryalls. Which is, perhaps, why it took almost two years to get the two bags — a backpack for guys, a canvas messenger for gals — off the ground. “They were refined again and again to make sure that they were functional and not too throwaway,” Ton says. “Inspiration came from just observing friends and” — no surprise here — “people on the street!”

headline: Pictures of the Day: Israel and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Israel, France, Bahrain and Myanmar.

headline: Making Connections
text: Technology is a key to the shopping experience. Young buyers use e-mail and the Web not just for research, but also to build trust.

headline: Tributes for Mikulski, Congress’s Longest-Serving Woman
text: When Senator Barbara A. Mikulski was sworn into the Senate in 1987, there was no “dean of women” to mentor female lawmakers. One of two women in the Senate at the time, Ms. Mikulski wasn’t even allowed in the Senate gym, Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky said Wednesday.

headline: Armageddon and Other Playthings
text: Judith McPherson, the plucky heroine of Grace McCleen’s debut novel, “The Land of Decoration,” is a smart but extremely literal-minded 10-year-old English schoolgirl. She grows up, as Ms. McCleen did, in the midst of Christian fundamentalists. She has been raised with the guarantee that Armageddon is near.

headline: Emulating Saxophone Styles Across Decades, in Standards and Abstractions
text: There’s an intriguing, good-humored wariness in the playing of the tenor saxophonist Bill McHenry. His tone is dry as cardboard but smooth and rarely stern, and as an improviser he treads meaningfully, choosing his moments, guarding against wasteful expenditure. As a bandleader he prefers soft direction, presenting loose guidelines and then letting the chips fall. This can make for a Zen logic of care and surrender, rigor and relinquishment. But it can also yield an aimless disconnect and a sense of vaguely unfulfilled intention.

headline: Holy Cow: Reacting to the Jets’ Attempt to Trade for Tebow
text: Almost anything involving Tim Tebow draws such an inordinate amount of attention, it’s a wonder the man can step out of his house. Trade him to the walking-tabloid-headline Jets, as the Broncos are trying to do, and expect this to reach another stratosphere.

headline: Back to Midwest Olive Garden After Tastes of New York
text: She came, she ate, she reviewed.

headline: Girl Scout Leaders to Parents: Stop Selling Cookies
text: Who sold you your last batch of Thin Mints? Judging by the response to my frustrated tweet, I’m not the only one buying cookies from colleagues and friends who are distinctly not girls. We’ve restocked our annual supply of crispy, chocolate-coated, Girl Scout-branded disks annually for years now — and I can’t remember the last time either I or my husband was asked to buy a box of cookies by an actual Girl Scout.

headline: Hungary Pressed to Ease Judiciary and News Media Laws
text: BUDAPEST — The Council of Europe is pressing Hungary to make further statutory changes to protect the independence of the judiciary and the news media, saying that recent amendments, while welcome, are not enough.

headline: Designing for Women in the Know
text: In the United States, Giambattista Valli has only recently come into his own.

headline: Catering to the Valli Girls
text: IN the season between his last show for the house of Emanuel Ungaro in the fall of 2004, and the start of his own business in the spring of 2005, Giambattista Valli adopted a curious look that has since become one of his many signatures. On almost any occasion at which Mr. Valli, 45, appears, he wears a pearl necklace, usually contrasted against his thin frame, a fitted black sweatshirt and loose black jeans. It is hard to say whether the look is more Coco Chanel or Barbara Bush.

headline: Homes for $530,000
text: Properties in Richmond, Va., Washington State and Columbus, Ohio.

headline: What You Get for ... $530,000
text: RICHMOND, VA.

headline: In Terms of Web Traffic, It’s Obama in a Landslide
text: Political campaigns might be using sophisticated digital advertising techniques to attract potential voters to their Web sites, but data released by Nielsen on Wednesday shows that it is President Obama who still holds the lion’s share of Web site visits.

headline: Plan to Search for More American Remains in North Korea Halted
text: WASHINGTON — The on again, off again effort to recover from North Korean territory the remains of Americans killed in the Korean War is off again, the Pentagon said Wednesday, a victim of the deteriorating diplomatic and security relations of the moment.

headline: A Youth at Home at the Keys
text: Benjamin Grosvenor, the 19-year-old English pianist who made his New York recital debut at the Frick Collection on Sunday afternoon, seemed the picture of casualness and humility when he walked onstage fresh faced, tieless and dressed in black. But no one who has heard his recent recording of Chopin, Liszt and Ravel works (from Decca) would have been surprised by the contrast between his easygoing appearance and the ferocity of his sound. At the Frick, as on the recording, he proved a formidable technician and a thoughtful, coolly assured interpreter.

headline: The Eye of Beauty, Revisited
text: HERB RITTS died nearly 10 years ago, at age 50. Since then the world that he dominated as a photographer — fashion, beauty, celebrity — has changed dramatically, leaving a stillness where his energetic ideas once existed. As the years go by, as images of a hyper-glamour become the norm, as visual memories seem almost a grab bag of tricks, you become more aware of what a giant the man was. He was certainly a link to George Hoyningen-Huene and Edward Weston; he also belongs in the tradition of Richard Avedon, Louise Dahl-Wolfe and Irving Penn. More simply, you cannot imagine the 1980s and ’90s in America without the photographs of Herb Ritts.

headline: Kraft, ‘Mondelez’ and the Art of Corporate Rebranding
text: Soon, people may have to learn how to pronounce a new name for the maker of Oreos and Cadbury Creme Eggs. It’s “mohn-dah-LEEZ.”

headline: Moving Into a Black-and-White World Where Graphic Texture Trumps Dialogue
text: Juliacks is a comic artist whose work — crude, ornate, subjective and dreamy — is not for those who prefer their narrative crisp and tidy. But “Swell,” her graphic novel about a bereaved family, a daughter in particular, is an immersive experience for brave readers. Now a production based on it has come to the Living Theater as part of the Culture Project’s Women Center Stage Festival, straining mightily to conjure the story’s lush stream of consciousness.

headline: Eye on Beauty, Revisited
text: Last September, in an interview with Richard Gere, the actor mentioned that the Getty Museum was planning an exhibition of the photography of Herb Ritts. The two were good friends; Mr. Gere serves on the board of The Herb Ritts Foundation, and, of course, he is the guy in that iconic 1978 photo taken in a service station in the California desert, in front of a jacked-up Buick. The two had stopped to fix a flat, and Mr. Ritts had said, simply, “Let’s take some shots here.”

headline: You Write the Tebow Playbook
text: One thing about Tim Tebow that everyone can agree on is that he is not a conventional N.F.L. quarterback. Some even think he’s better running the ball than passing it. How should the Jets use him? As a drop-back passer? As a third-down running back? Or as something entirely novel? Whether you’re an offensive coordinator in the N.F.L., a high school coach or just a fan who likes to diagram plays on a napkin, send us your best idea for one that the Jets should incorporate into their playbook to take advantage of Tebow’s skills. Be serious. Or be whimsical. Give it a shot and use this form to send us your idea.

headline: Hot Spots That Don’t Stay Home
text: Ah, the Internet! The source of so much goodness. The font of e-mail, news, chat, TV, blogs, books and Facebook. What would we do without it?

headline: In Full Swing

headline: Only the Half of It

Her own outfit on any given day might incorporate a schoolgirl mini, which she wears with tights; a long jersey column; or a leather skirt, its hemline dipping just below the knee.

headline: Senate Delays Vote on Start-Ups Bill for 2 Amendments

headline: How Do You Say ‘Disagreement’ in Pirahã?

headline: Shopping for Floor Lamps

headline: Floor Lamps
text: A DESIGN firm with a name like Rich Brilliant Willing creates certain expectations: if nothing else, one might assume the founders have a bit of attitude. In fact, they are just three amiable guys diligently turning out furniture and objects with a utilitarian edge in their Lower East Side studio. The company name is a play on their names: Theo Richardson, Charles Brill and Alex Williams.

headline: Trays With Character
text: For its latest collection of trays, the Italian housewares company Alessi enlisted the help of eight Chinese architects. “We’re used to working with different industrial designers and cultural backgrounds,” said Alberto Alessi, the company’s managing director, noting that Alessi frequently collaborates with American, European and Japanese designers. “But we were missing the Chinese, so I thought it was time to extend our scouting.”

text: A selection of recent comments from readers of the Home section, drawn from letters and postings at nytimes.com.

headline: Marfa Style Hits Los Angeles
text: It’s hard to believe that Adam Silverman, a partner in Heath ceramics and studio director of Heath Los Angeles, had never been to Marfa before last year. The small Texas town, made famous by Donald Judd, has been a mecca for those in the worlds of art and design for decades.

headline: Ready for Folding or Holding
text: The furniture produced by BDDW is unattainable for many. But Tyler Hays, the owner and designer, also makes lower-priced pieces for a new company called Lostine, the brainchild of the lighting designer Robert Ogden.

headline: Sales at John Robshaw, Conran Shop and Others
text: John Robshaw bean bags and poufs are marked down 20 percent online, through March 29 (the Samoa bean bag, regularly $225, is $180); (212) 594-6006, extension 13, johnrobshaw.com.

headline: Keeping the Clutter Busters in Line
text: This week, the National Association of Professional Organizers kicks off its 24th annual conference, held this year in Baltimore. NAPO, as the trade group of about 4,200 members is more colloquially known, aims to organize the organizers — organizing being a professional specialty that didn’t have a name until the early 1980s. These days, however, thanks to Oprah and Dr. Phil, the Learning Channel and HGTV, there are few of us who don’t have a passing familiarity with clutter busters and their ilk. In a secular culture, clutter may be the closest thing we have to original sin. Following this metaphor, the organizer is both clergy and personal savior.

headline: The Road to the Round of 16 Included a Bloody Brawl
text: One player lay at midcourt, blood pouring off his face. Another was throwing punches at every opponent he could see. A third stood on the scorer’s table, egging on a howling crowd at the Cintas Center in Cincinnati. Expletive-laced challenges were hurled back and forth. All the while, a national television audience watched as one of college basketball’s fiercest rivalries exploded into chaos.

headline: FedEx Agrees to Pay $3 Million to Settle a Bias Case
text: The United States Department of Labor has reached a $3 million settlement with the ground delivery unit of FedEx to resolve allegations that the company discriminated against 21,635 job seekers at two dozen FedEx facilities in 15 states.

headline: Chile: Landmark Gay Rights Ruling
text: The Inter-American Court of Human Rights ruled that Chile must pay damages to a judge who was denied custody of her three daughters by the Supreme Court in 2004 because of her sexual orientation. The ruling by the human rights court, a judicial entity of the Organization of American States, requires Chile’s government to pay the judge, Karen Atala, left, $50,000, in addition to $12,000 in court costs. The February ruling, which was made public on Wednesday in Chile, is the latest development in a multiyear legal battle waged by Judge Atala, a lesbian who had lost custody of her daughters to her ex-husband, also a judge. Judge Atala’s lawyer called the decision “historic” for Chile’s legal system. Justice Minister Teodoro Ribera said Wednesday that Chilean authorities had acted to protect the “superior interests of the children involved,” but he also said Chile would respect the ruling.

headline: Coach Surmounts Injury and Team Beats Odds
text: While preparing his Massachusetts-Lowell team for its first-round game in the N.C.A.A. men’s hockey tournament Friday, Norm Bazin will not preach about seizing the moment or feeling lucky to be alive. Bazin has never used his personal story as motivation this season, his first with the River Hawks, who ended a 16-year drought by making the tournament.

headline: Man for Man, It’s a Clash of Styles
text: BOSTON — Wisconsin and Syracuse have played only twice in their long basketball histories, and the Badgers’ victory came in 1927. The score was 31-24. Sounds like Bo Ryan’s kind of game.

headline: Catholic Voters and Rick Santorum
text: In a column in Campaign Stops, Timothy Egan writes:

headline: Federal Jury to Get Corruption Case From Yonkers
text: A federal jury in Manhattan is to begin deliberations on Thursday in the corruption trial of a former Yonkers city councilwoman who is accused of accepting almost $174,000 in secret payments from a longtime associate in return for dropping her opposition to two development projects.

headline: No-Show Jobs and Overstaffing Hurt New York Harbor, a Report Says
text: Corruption has been ingrained in the docks around New York Harbor for so long that the movie most identified with it was filmed in black and white. But 58 years after the release of “On the Waterfront,” no-show jobs held by relatives of mobsters and other well-connected people continue to vex government officials trying to make the ports more efficient and more competitive.

headline: Fox Show Will Start Worldwide
text: Television shows typically have their debuts in the United States first and arrive in other countries later — sometimes months or even years later.

headline: Eyes on Masters, Woods Hopes to Block Out Pain
text: ORLANDO, Fla. — It was a sight seen too often lately: Tiger Woods wincing in pain on the golf course.

headline: Scene of the Toulouse Standoff
text: A Frenchman suspected of recent shootings in Toulouse barricaded himself in a small apartment building surrounded by hundreds of police officers. The standoff lasted more than 30 hours.

headline: Conservative Activist Fails to Notice Bono Impersonator Is Not Bono
text: Jason Mattera, a conservative activist known for ambushing liberal celebrities and politicians — by pretending to be a fan in search of a picture, and then firing off confrontational questions at close range — was forced to retract a video interview with Bono he unveiled with some fanfare this week, when it emerged that the man he mistook for the lead singer of U2 recently was, in fact, a Bono impersonator.

headline: Why Panic? A Couple’s Nest Egg Better Left Alone
text: IMAGINE for a moment that your fairy godmother had appeared on Jan. 1, 2000. She told you that, over the coming decade, there would be two recessions, high unemployment and a major financial crisis that reverberated around the globe.

headline: 3 Years On, Ponzi Scheme Still Haunts a Victim
text: Marble Falls, Tex.

headline: In Overtime, Tight Race for Senate Rests With Vote Counters
text: The drama of a contentious Brooklyn special election for a State Senate seat moved into an unmarked warehouse on Wednesday, and as officials began reviewing votes, uncertainty increased alongside absurdity. Because the longer the contest drags on, the shorter the time the winner will serve the 27th District, which will cease to exist in its current form in 2013.

headline: Closing of Far Rockaway Charter School Will Go to Court
text: Peninsula Preparatory Charter School, an elementary school in Far Rockaway, Queens, was granted a temporary restraining order on Wednesday, putting the city's plans to close the school on pause.

headline: In March, the Spartans’ Thoughts Turn to Winning
text: PHOENIX — Last week, Coach Tom Izzo and the Michigan State Spartans advanced to the regional semifinals of the N.C.A.A. tournament. That is almost the same as saying there is an N.C.A.A. tournament. Izzo’s teams so often find themselves among the final 16, he should have his own region: East, South, West and Izzo.

headline: French Gunman Seen as Homegrown Militant
text: PARIS — For European law enforcement officials, Mohammed Merah, the 23-year-old suspect in the killing of seven people in southwestern France, represents the kind of insidious terrorist threat that they fear most: a homegrown militant consumed by visceral grievances who identifies with Al Qaeda but operates on his own.

headline: Never Before
text: Journalistic convention requires that when there are two identifiable sides to a story, each side gets its say, in neutral fashion, without the writer’s thumb on the scale. This rule presents a challenge when one side of a controversy obviously lacks merit. But mainstream journalism has learned to navigate those challenges, choosing evolution over “intelligent design,” for example, and treating climate change naysayers as cranks.

headline: Brotherhood Reconsiders Plan to Sit Out Presidential Race in Egypt
text: CAIRO — Muslim Brotherhood officials said on Wednesday that the group was debating whether to field its own candidate in Egypt’s upcoming presidential contest, after failing to persuade several outside figures to run with the group’s backing.

headline: Draw Something Draws a Bundle in Sale to Zynga
text: It took six years for the game developer Omgpop to become an overnight sensation — and only six weeks to cash in to the tune of $200 million. With its simple yet endearing Draw Something mobile app generating massive traffic, Omgpop surveyed its potential suitors and sold itself Wednesday to the biggest social media player, Zynga.

headline: A Sluggish Star Finds New Energy
text: Philadelphia

headline: Seeking Empowerment
text: Buying a first car is a milestone. Young car shoppers tell how they want to be treated (or acknowledged) in a dealer’s lot or showroom.

headline: Mayor Warns of the Pitfalls in Social Media
text: On Twitter, he is @MikeBloomberg, a popular online avatar with more than 230,000 followers. His official Foursquare account leaves tips about Shake Shack and Kennedy International Airport. And his Facebook page energetically promotes the programs and values of New York City Hall.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: March 21, 2012

headline: Henry Drops In on Muamba
text: Red Bulls striker Thierry Henry paid a trans-Atlantic house call to London Wednesday, dropping in on his former Arsenal teammate Fabrice Muamba, who suffered cardiac arrest last Saturday playing for Bolton in a game in England’s Premier League.

headline: Pity the Poor Gun Lobby
text: There is nothing so dangerous as a lobbying organization that’s running out of stuff to lobby about.

headline: Home Builder Stocks at Highest Point in 2 Years After 6-Month Rise
text: After a bullish report on housing at a late summer investment conference in Dallas, the officials at Federated Investors decided to sink a few million dollars into the shares of the home builder Lennar.

headline: Libya Resists International Court’s Claim on War Crimes Case
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — Libya’s interim authorities escalated their face-off against the International Criminal Court on Wednesday over custody of the most significant confidants to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi taken prisoner since his ouster and death: his son Seif al-Islam el-Qaddafi and his brother-in-law Abdullah Senussi. The battle over the men’s fate is an early test of the former rebels’ commitment to the rule of the law.

headline: Respecting Differences
text: Avoid the fist bump: younger customers are looking for respect from sales personnel, not someone who is trying to act young.

headline: Killing, With the Law on Your Side
text: Do Stand Your Ground laws provide too much criminal immunity when innocent people are shot by someone who feels threatened?

headline: Shot to Death in Florida
text: It would have been tragic enough if the shooting of an unarmed teenager by a self-appointed neighborhood watch captain in Florida were the first to show the lethal folly of so-called Stand Your Ground laws. But, in fact, these outrageously dangerous laws have been adopted in many states, making it easy for shooters who kill to claim self-defense.

headline: The Fight Against Modern Slavery
text: President Obama, in convening the annual meeting of his cabinet-level task force on human trafficking last week, noted the work the administration has done in law enforcement, aid to victims and diplomatic pressure to help the millions around the world who toil “under the boot of modern slavery.”

headline: German Bond Prices Decline, Unsettling Confidence in a Safe Haven
text: FRANKFURT — Havens can pose their own risks.

headline: Santana’s Off-Speed Pitches Confound the Cardinals
text: JUPITER, Fla. — The sight of baseball bats spinning through the air, end over end, told the story of Johan Santana’s outing Wednesday afternoon.

headline: Early Spring Sets Much of U.S. Awash in Color and Pollen Dust
text: ATLANTA — Spring, with its promise of flip-flops and daffodils, can have a dark side. Take this one, which hit so early in many parts of the nation that the headaches are outweighing the sunny benefits.

headline: Samuel Glazer Dies at 89; Popularized Drip Coffee
text: Samuel Glazer, a co-founder of the company that gave the world Mr. Coffee, one of the first and most popular automatic drip coffee makers to appear on American kitchen counters, died on March 12 in Cleveland. He was 89.

headline: Please Stop Apologizing
text: THIS week, Robert De Niro made a joke about first ladies, and Newt Gingrich said it was “inexcusable and the president should apologize for him.” Of course, if something is “inexcusable,” an apology doesn’t make any difference, but then again, neither does Newt Gingrich.

headline: Two Players, Two Illnesses, Two Wins
text: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla. — Two women who have battled illnesses produced victories in first-round matches at the Sony Ericsson Open.

headline: Mets Start Getting Their Financial House in Order
text: Fred Wilpon and Saul Katz looked relieved as they entered the Manhattan federal courthouse shortly after 8 a.m. on Monday even though a trial that could have cost them more than $300 million was scheduled to begin in about an hour.

headline: Mel Parnell, 89, Dies; Dominated Yanks
text: Mel Parnell, who won more games for the Boston Red Sox than any other left-handed pitcher and who especially endeared himself to Sox fans as a Yankee killer, died on Tuesday in New Orleans. He was 89.

headline: Sanford McDonnell, Aerospace Leader, Dies at 89
text: Sanford N. McDonnell, who succeeded his uncle as chairman of the aerospace company McDonnell Douglas and, through the 1980s, modernized its management systems, remade the corporate culture and sharply increased earnings, died on Monday at his home in Clayton, Mo. He was 89.

headline: State Senator Loses Support of Local G.O.P.
text: ALBANY — Senator James S. Alesi, one of four New York State Republicans who voted in favor of same-sex marriage last year, is unlikely to receive the nomination of the main Republican committee in his district, setting the stage for a difficult re-election race that could have implications in the fight for control of the State Senate.

headline: No Livelihood, but One Lively Soundtrack
text: You know those thoughts that wake you up at 3:35 in the morning? The ones that so many Americans are having now, in this age of high unemployment and rising prices, about the bottom falling out of their safe little worlds.

headline: A High-Gear Trip Through Life, From Soup to Nuts
text: It would probably be wise to eat dinner before attending “The Big Meal,” a new play by Dan LeFranc that opened Wednesday night at Playwrights Horizons. The consumption of plates of everyday foods — chicken fingers and fries, spaghetti, mashed potatoes — becomes charged with ominous portent in this comic drama about love, marriage, child rearing and the general brisk rush of human life, in which you turn around and find that youth has vamoosed and taken with it a lot of your dearest held assumptions about the way things would turn out.

headline: Aching For Punning Accuracy
text: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — A soundalike theme today, courtesy of Alan Arbesfeld, with one twist: the pairs of homophones are all mixed up. It’s your job to straighten them out. Wait, strike that: It’s your job to appreciate the punny cluing that results from the mix-up.

headline: With Film Passé, Fujifilm Highlights Its Other Units
text: FUJIFILM, seeking to recast its film-centered identity, is starting a brand campaign featuring medical imaging and other technological innovations that stem from its long history of chemical coatings research.

headline: Romney’s Day to Relish Is Marred by Aide’s Gaffe
text: WASHINGTON — Mitt Romney sought to use the coveted endorsement of Jeb Bush on Wednesday to amplify his call for Republicans to rally behind his candidacy and get on with the mission of ousting President Obama.

headline: Pushing Back Against Austerity
text: Political leaders across Europe have begun to push back against the campaign of Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany to put the Continent’s economies into a straitjacket of unrelenting fiscal austerity. It is about time. Two years of insisting that weak economies carry out tax increases and spending cuts have brought nothing but recession and deepening indebtedness.

headline: Death of Florida Teen Spurs Outcry and Action
text: Last Updated | 10:50 a.m. Thursday Outrage over the fatal shooting of Trayvon Martin, 17, in central Florida continued to grow across the country on Wednesday, with at least two thousand people rallying Wednesday night in New York City and Miami. Civil rights leaders are planning more demonstrations in other cities in the coming days, including a rally Thursday night in Sanford, Fla.

headline: Faith Has Often Had a New York Accent
text: New York often gets a bad and clichéd rap for being a godless city. Isn’t Brooklyn, after all, the borough of churches? In all likelihood, there are more seriously religious people of more differing faiths in New York than in any city in America. Tim Tebow will have plenty of company, and he will be joining a robust and eclectic lineup of religious New York athletes.

headline: Toll of Mexican Crime Wave, Written in Faces on the Wall
text: ECATEPEC, Mexico — When residents of this poor industrial city look to the hills, they now see the faces of crime victims staring back at them. Enormous photographic portraits cover concrete homes as part of a community art project that captures what has become a Mexican obsession: visualizing victimhood or, more broadly, turning cold, mind-numbing data back into real people.

headline: Hooking Up a New TV: Which Wire Goes Where?
text: A map to navigating which cables go where in the back of a modern television.

headline: Where the Famous Shop, Cycling Is the Cause Célèbre
text: On any given day, you might see Jake Gyllenhaal. Or Matthew Broderick or David Byrne. David Beckham has been said to swing by, just for some much-needed air.

headline: To Quinn, No City Child Should Miss Kindergarten
text: Not everyone in Christine C. Quinn’s hometown went to kindergarten when she was growing up in the early 1970s. Her family parish, St. Patrick’s, in Glen Cove, N.Y., on Long Island, did not even enroll students for parochial school until first grade.

headline: Bike-Sharing at N.Y.U. Offers a Hint of How City Program Could Work
text: It is the kind of news the city’s Transportation Department would love to report someday: a New York City bike-share program that attracts all types of cyclists, from budding entrepreneurs to university professors, and does not lead to stolen bikes or injured riders.

headline: Splashy Move, but Suspect Thinking
text: If N.F.L. success were measured by jerseys sold and attention garnered, by winning not the turnover battle but the competition for most magazine covers, the Jets would have more than one Super Bowl championship, from more than 40 years ago.

headline: The Knicks, 5-0 Under Woodson, Are Flying
text: PHILADELPHIA — A storied N.B.A. rivalry, long dormant and coated in cobwebs, rumbled back to life Wednesday night, with enough tension, tenacity and promise to last deep into the spring.

headline: Student-Driven PAC Aims to Blunt G.O.P. in South
text: LITTLE ROCK, Ark. — The last Democratic stronghold in the South is in the care of a new set of guardians: graduate students, mostly.

headline: On His Birthday, Callahan Gives Rangers Breathing Room
text: Ryan Callahan celebrated his 27th birthday Wednesday night by scoring 2 minutes 42 seconds into overtime, giving the Rangers a 2-1 victory over the Detroit Red Wings at Madison Square Garden and putting them 3 points ahead of the Pittsburgh Penguins in the race for Eastern Conference supremacy.

headline: With a Strong Spring, Hughes Makes His Case
text: PORT CHARLOTTE, Fla. — Joe Girardi wants a difficult decision, and Phil Hughes is doing his best to accommodate him.

text: Conservatives may not like liberals, but they seem to understand them. In contrast, many liberals find conservative voters not just wrong but also bewildering.

headline: Inventing Hotels With Chinese Characteristics
text: HONG KONG — China is Eldorado for the world’s major hotel companies, which, among them, have opened hundreds of multistar hotels across the country in recent years.

headline: The Convention of ’76
text: As the Republican race goes on longer and longer, with Rick Santorum and Newt Gingrich hoping to keep Mitt Romney from getting to their convention in Tampa with enough delegates to lock up the nomination, there’s a wary sense of excitement among reporters whose fondest dream is of a convention where a nominee is actually chosen, instead of merely being royally acknowledged. So it’s worth thinking back to 1976, the last time a race was actually settled at a Republican convention.

headline: No More Dancing for Buzz Williams
text: PHOENIX — Buzz Williams is dancing at the same time he is promising he will not.

headline: McDonald’s Says Its Chief Will Retire This Summer
text: Jim Skinner, the chief executive who steered a floundering McDonald’s to the best financial performance in its history, will retire this summer, the company announced late Wednesday.

headline: McClatchy Chief to Lead The A.P.
text: The Associated Press, tapping a longtime newspaper executive for one of the pre-eminent jobs in journalism, said late Wednesday that Gary Pruitt would be its next chief executive, succeeding Tom Curley, who is retiring.

text: WASHINGTON — Eric Fehrnstrom is Mitt Romney’s David Axelrod.

headline: Calls Grow for Leader of Komen to Step Down
text: Calls for the resignation of Nancy G. Brinker, the founder and chief executive of Susan G. Komen for the Cure, the breast cancer charity, grew Wednesday amid news that a second high-profile executive was leaving the group.

headline: Maker Pulls Pesticide Amid Fear of Toxicity
text: SAN FRANCISCO — A manufacturer has pulled a controversial pesticide from the American market, surprising both growers and environmentalists who have warned that it poses serious hazards.

headline: Ban Lifted, R.O.T.C. to Return to Harvard’s Campus
text: Harvard announced on Wednesday that it would open a campus office for the Army R.O.T.C. later this year, a move the Army believes will lead to greater participation in the program by Harvard undergraduates.

headline: Family Men on Their Own
text: Thousands have left everything behind to work at an oil drilling site in North Dakota, hoping for a financial comeback.

headline: Quiz: The Diaper-Changing Index
text: Do you like waking up at night to care for a crying baby? How about changing diapers? Did you complain last time you had to cancel plans because you had a sick child?

headline: Study Shows House Members Profit
text: WASHINGTON — One accusation long directed at Congress is that lawmakers come to this capital city not just to serve the American people but also to enrich themselves and their families.

headline: Paul Allen Gives Millions for Brain Research
text: Paul G. Allen, a co-founder of Microsoft, announced on Wednesday that he would commit $300 million over the next 10 years to turn the Allen Institute for Brain Science, a nonprofit organization he established to build a database of neural information, into a center for basic neuroscience investigation.

headline: For Romney, a Long Drive to a Likely Finish
text: Mitt Romney’s victories in Illinois and Puerto Rico this week have expanded his lead over Rick Santorum by roughly 60 delegates, putting him ahead by 300 delegates over all.

headline: Indicators Fall in China and Europe
text: FRANKFURT — A main indicator of business sentiment in Europe unexpectedly fell deeper toward recession territory Thursday, compounding concerns about the global recovery after signs of slowing manufacturing in China.

headline: City Criticizes Police Chief After Shooting
text: MIAMI — Facing mounting protests over the shooting death of an unarmed black teenager by a neighborhood watch volunteer, the Sanford City Commission voted on Wednesday that they had no confidence in the city’s police chief.

headline: Justices Allow Challenge to E.P.A. Control of Wetlands
text: The Supreme Court ruled unanimously on Wednesday that an Idaho couple had the right to file an immediate court challenge to a federal Environmental Protection Agency decision designating their property as wetlands and forbidding them from building a home there.

headline: Tebow Pledges to Put Team First With Jets
text: There was a moment during the Jets’ internal discussions about Tim Tebow when General Manager Mike Tannenbaum looked at his coach, Rex Ryan, and his new offensive coordinator, Tony Sparano, and a thought washed over him. Both coaches were left dazed last season by a patented last-minute comeback by the Tebow-led Denver Broncos, Ryan on Nov. 17, and Sparano, formerly of the Miami Dolphins, on Oct. 23.

headline: NYT Front Page for 03/22/2012
text: NYT Front Page for 03/22/2012

headline: House G.O.P. Budget Riles Some on the Right, and Democrats See a Campaign Issue
text: WASHINGTON — House Republicans pressed forward on Wednesday with a politically freighted budget and tax plan, taking fire from the left and the right, as well as from the powerful senior citizens lobby, AARP, which said the plan “lacks balance” and “jeopardizes the health and economic security of older Americans.”

headline: Challenge to Gay Marriage Fails in New Hampshire
text: CONCORD, N.H. — An attempt to repeal New Hampshire’s same-sex marriage law failed on Wednesday in the House of Representatives, with members of the Republican-dominated chamber voting 211-116 to kill the bill.

headline: Court Appears to Be Wary Hearing Free-Speech Case
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Wednesday seemed unsympathetic to the claims of a protester who said his free speech rights had been violated when Secret Service agents protecting Vice President Dick Cheney arrested him after he made critical remarks about the Bush administration’s war policies.

headline: To Cut Costs, Postal Service Turns to Rural Stores
text: WASHINGTON — The Postal Service, which has proposed closing 3,700 offices, is setting up services inside small grocery stores as it tries to maintain service while trimming billions of dollars in costs.

headline: White Teenager Who Drove Over and Killed Black Man Is Sentenced to Life
text: ATLANTA — Deryl Dedmon, a white teenager who drove a pickup truck over a black man in the parking lot of a Jackson, Miss., motel, pleaded guilty to murder on Wednesday and was sent to prison for life.

headline: Liter by Liter, Indians Get Cleaner Water
text: “As evening falls in Chuddani, a village of about 500 homes, 45 kilometers, or 28 miles, from Delhi, people arrive by bicycle, motorbike, tractor and on foot with jugs that they fill with water from faucets outside a neat blue shed,” Amy Yee writes in The International Herald Tribune.

headline: U.S. Exempts Some From Iran Oil Sanctions, but not India
text: The Obama administration on Tuesday exempted Japan and 10 European nations from the prospect of biting sanctions intended to punish countries that continue to buy oil from Iran, but it left open the fate of other major importers, including China, India and South Korea, Steven Lee Myers writes in The New York Times.

headline: Naming Your India Book: A Pocket Guide
text: “On 05 May Faber is publishing the new book from Oliver Balch, India Rising: Tales from a Changing Nation. I’m attaching information but in brief, Balch has traveled India in search of the human stories behind the country’s huge expansion and booming economy. “ —  E-mailed press release, March 21

headline: New York State Draft Report on Abuse
text: The report was commissioned by Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo in response to The Times’s investigation of abuse, neglect and fraud at state homes for the developmentally disabled.

headline: State Faults Care for the Disabled
text: ALBANY — Nearly 300,000 disabled and mentally ill New Yorkers face a “needless risk of harm” because of conflicting regulations, a lack of oversight and even disagreements over what constitutes abuse, according to a draft state report obtained by The New York Times.

headline: News Quiz | March 22, 2012
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s front page. Good luck!

headline: Hunt Called Off for Thousands of U.S. Soldiers in North Korea
text: HONG KONG — There are 5,500 missing American soldiers buried in North Korea. Buried, of course, is not exactly the right word.

headline: Suspect in French Killings Slain as Police Storm Apartment After 30-Hour Siege
text: TOULOUSE, France — Mohammed Merah, a 23-year-old former garage mechanic who claimed responsibility for the brutal slayings of four men and three children, was shot dead on Thursday when security forces stormed the apartment where he had barricaded himself for more than 30 hours.

headline: March 22, 1972 | Equal Rights Amendment for Women Passed by Congress
text: On March 22, 1972, the Senate passed the Equal Rights Amendment to the United States Constitution, which proposed banning discrimination based on sex. The E.R.A. was sent to the states for ratification, but it would fall short of the three-fourths approval needed.

headline: Test Yourself | English, March 22, 2012
text: This question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article “In Sun’s Glow, It’s Still Business, but Not as Usual.”

headline: Must-Have Gadgets for the Kitchen? Think Again

headline: Soldiers Overthrow Mali Government in Setback for Democracy in Africa
text: DAKAR, Senegal — Soldiers in Mali, a West African nation often cited as a democratic model, overthrew the elected government on Thursday, looted the presidential palace, arrested ministers and declared that they had seized power.

headline: Post-Traumatic Stress’s Surprisingly Positive Flip Side
text: Sgt. Jeffrey Beltran pulled a heavily creased Post-it note from the pocket of his fatigues, unfolded it and looked over a list he jotted down earlier that day: pick up an order of beef lo mein, take his dress uniform to work (jacket, pants and boots), do schoolwork. Beltran’s Army-issue organizer is also filled with these reminders, and he checks them every so often to jog his memory — folding and unfolding them throughout the day. Beltran’s life is filled with sticky notes because his short-term memory is no longer reliable, a result of what the Army calls a mild traumatic brain injury that he suffered in an I.E.D. attack in Iraq in 2005.

headline: The Limits of American Exceptionalism
text: Simon Johnson is the Ronald A. Kurtz Professor of Entrepreneurship at the M.I.T. Sloan School of Management and co-author of “White House Burning: The Founding Fathers, Our National Debt, and Why It Matters to You.”

headline: A Hard Trek to Humility
text: Time operates curiously in Afghanistan’s remote and inhospitable Wakhan Corridor. Tucked away in the country’s northeastern corner, the region’s 12,000 residents live very much the same as their ancestors did centuries ago.

headline: N.F.L.’s Full Report on Discipline for Saints
text: “Any hopes the Saints had of becoming the first N.F.L. team to play in the Super Bowl on their home field in Super Bowl XLVII disintegrated with today’s news.”  Jeff Duncan, Nola.com

headline: What’s the Coolest Thing You’ve Ever Seen in a Museum?
text: Yes, we’ve asked this question before, back in 2010, but we loved the answers we got. Inspired by a recent special section on museums, we’re asking again. Have you ever been to a science, art, history or children’s museum? What are some of the most interesting or memorable things you saw there? Why?

headline: On Hunting for Scholarships, and Coming Up Empty
text: I am still sitting at my desk, pondering the decisions I’ve made in my application process. I am still logging in to my different student accounts to check my application status, and of course. I am still waiting. Beside me on my white desk are two large books that will play a heavy role in deciding the school I will eventually attend: Peterson’s “Scholarships, Grants & Prizes” and College Board’s “Getting Financial Aid”.

headline: The Early Word: Etch A Sketch
text: In Today’s Times:With an endorsement in hand from former Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida, Mitt Romney is seeking to rally the Republican establishment around what his campaign sees as his inevitable nomination so he can get on with the task of challenging President Obama, Jeff Zeleny and Jim Rutenberg write. But even as Mr. Romney tried on Wednesday to parlay the endorsement from Mr. Bush into wider gains, a campaign aide made a remark that turned into a major distraction, comparing the campaign’s pivot from the primary campaign to the general election to an Etch A Sketch.

headline: Tim Tebow Speaks About Trade to  Jets
text: One of Tim Tebow’s main goals is to spread the word of God. He has been given the biggest stage in the country in which to do it: New York.

headline: Sean Payton Meets Enemy: It’s Us
text: Coach Sean Payton had reportedly been expecting a four-game ban and was very upset by the season-long suspension over the Saints’ bounty system. If he’s moved to pass blame, he should look not at Commissioner Roger Goodell but rather to  the American people. (This after he first looks in the mirror, of course.)

headline: Caramelized Endive Soup With Blue Cheese
text: Time: 45 minutes.

headline: Hangop met Boerenjongens (Drained Buttermilk With Soaked Raisins)
text: Time: About 24 hours, largely unattended.

headline: Old-Fashioned Dutch Hutspot (Potato-and-Carrot Mash) With Brisket
text: Time: 3 hours or more, largely unattended.

headline: Who Doesn’t Love Boerenjongens?
text: When I was in the Netherlands, looking for someone with whom I could cook “Dutch,” I expected to find a grandmother. You know, some kind of stolid old-timer to show me the way of traditional Dutch home cooking. Yet I kept being steered by friends and journalists to the 43-year-old food writer Janneke Vreugdenhil, who grew up near Rotterdam and now lives in The Hague.

headline: Watching ‘Mad Men’ With My Mother
text: My mom didn’t watch “Mad Men.” Despite the insistence of television critics, her bohemian friends, my siblings and myself, she held out. “Your father and I watched the first episode,” she said. “It was slow.” She shrugged. I shrugged it off, too — until we went shopping together at Banana Republic. I had taken her there to drop a hint about what I wanted for my birthday, happily trying on dresses from the “Mad Men” collection, frocks in bright floral prints with skirts as wide as bells or as tight as snakeskin. I twirled.

headline: A Business Coach Joins the Business Group (and Raises the Vision Thing)
text: At the last meeting of our business group, we were joined by Susan Martin, a business coach who has worked with entrepreneurs for 12 years. Before becoming a coach, she ran her own sweater design and manufacturing company. Based on her experience and those of other entrepreneurs, Ms. Martin finds that owners often become mired in the minutiae of running their businesses, neglecting their long-term visions for their companies. The result can be working in a business that doesn’t meet your needs.

headline: Debate Is Over on Tebow’s True Value
text: Last season’s relentless arguments over Tim Tebow are finally, decisively over.

headline: P.T.S.D. Can Yield Positive, Yet Sometimes Deadly, Results
text: Just as my story about the Army’s program designed to help boost resilience in soldiers was approaching its final edit for The Times Magazine, news broke of the killing of 16 Afghan civilians by an American soldier. As details emerged, and Staff Sgt. Robert Bales was accused of committing this atrocity, I was stuck by the similarities between him and many of the soldiers I interviewed for this article.

headline: Sea Lions and Sustainable Development
text: Aliette Frank, a postdoctoral scholar at Royal Roads University, explores sustainable community development on the coast of British Columbia.

headline: Why Choose a Women’s College?
text: Debora L. Spar is the current President of Barnard College, a liberal arts college for women affiliated with Columbia University, located in New York City. Founded in 1889, Barnard attempts to give young women both the intimate setting provided by a small liberal arts college, and the resources of a large university. Debora Spar became President of Barnard College in 2008 after a teaching career at Harvard Business School. Spar is the also the author of six books and numerous articles. She recently visited the Cathedral and John Connon School in Mumbai, where she spoke to students from ten different institutions.

headline: Why We Look to Distinguish Robert Bales From Mohammed Merah
text: LONDON — Misfit, lunatic or cold-bloodied terrorist? As the presumed Toulouse serial killer Mohammed Merah died during a police raid on Thursday, France was searching for the true motivation behind his murderous rampage.

headline: Watson Nears $6.6 Billion Deal for Actavis
text: Watson Pharmaceuticals is expected to bid as much as 5 billion euros ($6.6 billion) for the Swiss drug maker Actavis Group in a deal that would create one of the world’s largest generic drug manufacturers, according to people with direct knowledge of the matter.

headline: Coyotes in New York City: A Bonus?
text: In March 2010, a wild coyote led the police on a chase through Lower Manhattan. The vagabond was ultimately caught in a parking lot in TriBeCa.

headline: Romney Campaign Gaffe Steps on Good News, Again
text: If Mitt Romney’s Etch A Sketch moment on Wednesday taught his campaign anything, it’s probably this: There is little room for missteps.

headline: Tested by a Picturesque Dystopia
text: There’s a short anxious scene in the new film “The Hunger Games” when its 16-year-old heroine, Katniss Everdeen (Jennifer Lawrence), races through a deep, dark forest; falls down a hill; and rolls and rolls, only to rise up and thrust herself again into the unknown. Katniss, the lethally tough linchpin from Suzanne Collins’s trilogy and now a rather less imposing film heroine, is a teenage survivalist in a postapocalyptic take on a familiar American myth. When she runs through that forest, and even when she falls, there’s something of the American frontiersman in her, as if she were Natty Bumppo reborn and resexed.

headline: Examples Show That Tebow Could Make Sanchez Better
text: Chase Stuart is a contributor to SmartFootball.com, Footballguys.com and Pro-Football-Reference.com.

headline: A Conversation With: Former Railways Minister Dinesh Trivedi
text: Dinesh Trivedi, the now ex-railways minister, proposed an increase in passenger fares last week citing safety and modernization of the railways as primary concerns. The move resulted in his dismissal by West Bengal chief minister and his boss, Mamata Banerjee, who said the fare increase was unacceptable and demanded a rollback.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: TOP STORIES

headline: Quinn's Quest for 'Kindergarten for All'
text: Thousands of children each year don’t enroll in kindergarten — and too often those are poor or disabled kids who need it most. Christine C. Quinn, the City Council speaker, is trying to change that, The Times reports.

headline: India’s Archives: How Did Things Get This Bad?
text: Why has modern India had such a difficult time preserving its history?

headline: Opinion Report: Stand Your Ground
text: From the editorial page

headline: Bain Affiliate to Buy Leveraged Loans From Lloyds
text: LONDON — Sankaty Advisors, a unit of the private equity firm Bain Capital, agreed on Thursday to buy a portfolio of leveraged loans from the Lloyds Banking Group with a value of £500 million, or $793 million.

headline: Thursday Reading: Early Spring Brings Pollen and Pests
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: Styled to a T | Oeuffice
text: The Guys

headline: With a Third Title, Cornell Wrestler Kyle Dake Records a First
text: At the N.C.A.A. tournament in St. Louis last weekend, Cornell junior Kyle Dake became the first wrestler to win three national titles in three weight classes. Wrestling at 157 pounds for the Big Red, Dake went 35-0 this season. Last season he won the title at 149 pounds and as freshman he took it at 141 pounds.

headline: To Stop Iran, the G.O.P. Should Back Obama
text: These days, Republicans are seizing every opportunity to hammer President Obama for both high gas prices and his Iran policy.

headline: Producer’s Exit Adds to Uncertainty at ‘The Office’
text: The executive reshuffling and air of uncertainty that have lately dominated Dunder Mifflin are now a behind-the-scenes reality at “The Office” as well. Paul Lieberstein, the show runner on that NBC sitcom (who also plays the twitchy human resources officer, Toby Flenderson), is preparing to leave the series to work on an “Office” spinoff, The Hollywood Reporter said.

headline: A Balancing Act for the Police Department
text: In the binary system offered by Machiavelli — “it is better to be feared than loved, if you cannot be both” — the New York Police Department loses on either count.

headline: Tesla’s Ambitions Fueled by Customer Down Payments
text: After reading about Tesla Motors’ new electric sedan three years ago, Rob Stelling drove 100 miles to the carmaker’s showroom in Menlo Park, Calif., and put down $40,000 in cash to make an early reservation for the Model S.

headline: Introducing the Romney Magic Numbers Calculator
text: The Republican nomination race, as we have noted, has become less a battle between Mitt Romney and Rick Santorum  and more one between Mr. Romney and the math: how certain is Mr. Romney to reach the 1,144 delegates required to clinch the nomination before the convention in Tampa, Fla., and when will he do it?

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: A Serious Turn for Etch A Sketch and the Muppets
text: The comment on CNN by a senior adviser to Mitt Romney that the candidate would be like an Etch A Sketch, easily resetting his campaign for the general election, became an instant Internet meme. The distraction from the comment, made Wednesday morning, had serious consequences for Mr. Romney, Jeff Zeleny and Jim Rutenberg write: it shifted the focus from his argument that he had, in effect, won the nomination with his victory in Illinois on Tuesday. And it diluted the lift he received from the endorsement by Jeb Bush on Wednesday. By the end of the day there were interactive Web sites, mocking Twitter hashtags, a Web ad for Democrats, Sarah Wheaton writes; also, Mr. Romney’s opponents, Rick Santorum and Newt Gingrich, brought Etch A Sketch toys to their campaign events.

headline: Clip: 'The Raid: Redemption'
text: A scene from the martial arts film "The Raid: Redemption," directed by Gareth Evans.

headline: For Indian Women, Divorce Is a Raw Deal
text: Much has been written about divorce being on the rise in India, sometimes accompanied by hand-wringing about the egos and inflexibility of younger couples, who seem less willing than their parents to stay in marriages they are not happy with.

headline: On Our Radar: A Very Warm March
text: Gambling that no frosts will materialize, some farmers are taking advantage of the warmest March since record-keeping began to plant what they hope will be bumper crops. [Reuters]

headline: ‘Surface Tension’ Revisited
text: Using a little math, a few partial dry runs and Google street view, the New York Times revisited the route taken in the 1968 Hollis Frampton film “Surface Tension.”

headline: Following, and Filming, in Hollis Frampton’s Footsteps
text: By now you’re either with us or not in our recent obsession with the filmmaker Hollis Frampton’s “Surface Tension,” in which he captured 1968 Manhattan in 160 seconds of stop-motion.

headline: Morning Buzz, March 22: A 32-Year-Old Case Is Solved
text: Good morning. Today will be mostly sunny and climb to 75 degrees, which means you can celebrate this International Goof-Off Day properly: outside.

headline: Goldman’s Muppet Scan and the Innocent E-Mails
text: In an odd footnote to the Greg Smith fracas, Reuters reports that Goldman Sachs has started scanning internal e-mails for instances of the term “muppet” and other derogatory phrases.

headline: Image of the Day: March 22
text: Fire gutted hundreds of shops in a market in Kolkata, West Bengal.

headline: Eye Candy | ‘Supreme Beings’
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: What We’re Reading
text: The New York Daily News: The feds say pink slime (in meat shown above, right) — filler made from beef scraps and connective tissue — is safe and not all that prevalent. But the New York City schools are banning it all the same, following the example of McDonald’s and Taco Bell. — Patrick Farrell

headline: Poetry Pairing | ‘Secret Life’
text: This week’s Poetry Pairing matches Li-Young Lee’s “Secret Life” with a March 20 City Room blog post, “Spring Comes to a City Woodland.”

headline: Images of French Gunman Joyriding in 2010 Broadcast on French Television
text: Updated | 11:59 a.m. As my colleagues Scott Sayare, Steven Erlanger and Richard Berry report, the 23-year-old Frenchman who claimed responsibility for killing four men and three children died on Thursday, after jumping from a window as security forces stormed the apartment in Toulouse where he had been holed up, the French interior minister said.

headline: The Politics of Nostalgia
text: JOHANNESBURG — Nostalgia for former President Thabo Mbeki is washing over South Africa these days. A book about his presidency by the civil servant who ran his office sold out before it even hit the shelves last week. Weeks earlier, a prominent Sunday newspaper had boldly asserted on its front page, “Mbeki Is Back.”

headline: Daily Report: Watching Twitter Use
text: While Twitter has become an enormously influential communication tool around the world, especially with marketers, Wall Street firms are wary of it because of regulatory concerns, reports William Alden in The New York Times’s DealBook.

headline: Photo Essays From the Magazine
text: Slide shows by renowned photographers.

headline: CME Board to Shrink — to 30 Directors
text: Many hands make light work, but the CME Group seems to have decided that there’s a limit, at least in the boardroom. The Chicago-based exchange plans to pare down its unusually large board — to an expected 30 members after its May 23 annual meeting, from 32 today.

headline: Groundwater Crisis Unfolds in Times Square
text: To mark World Water Day, digital animations conveying the gravity of global declines in groundwater just went on display on two billboards in Times Square. The animations, based on satellite data provided by NASA and the University of California, Irvine, and statistics from the United States Geological Survey, will be shown several times each hour through April 22.

headline: NYSE Won’t Appeal E.U. Rejection of Deutsche Borse Merger
text: While Deutsche Börse is appealing European antitrust regulators’ rejection of its planned merger with NYSE Euronext, its would-be partner won’t join the legal battle.

headline: Chinese Lawyers Chafe at New Oath to Communist Party
text: BEIJING — China’s Justice Ministry has issued a requirement that new lawyers and those reapplying for licenses swear an oath of loyalty to the Communist Party, another step in a campaign to rein in lawyers who continue to challenge the political and legal systems by which the party maintains power.

headline: Business Day Live | March 22, 2012
text: FedEx agrees to settle bias case; Tesla Motors' interesting approach to financing its operations; and an end to easy money, as interest rates rise.

headline: Construction Worker Killed in Building Collapse in Manhattan
text: A construction worker died Thursday after a century-old, two-story warehouse under demolition as part of Columbia University’s expansion collapsed in a hail of concrete, bricks and steel that engulfed three workers.

headline: Business Day Live: Financing an Electric Car
text: FedEx agrees to settle bias case; Tesla Motors’ interesting approach to financing its operations; and an end to easy money, as interest rates rise.

headline: Room for Growth
text: A look at New York University’s proposed building plans for their superblock near Washington Square Park in Greenwich Village.

headline: A Land-Use Battle
text: New York University’s latest expansion plan has inspired neighborhood protests.

headline: Common Sense in New Hampshire
text: When David Bates, a New Hampshire state representative, first introduced a bill aimed at overturning the state’s marriage equality law, he was dismissive of public opinion polling that showed about 60 percent of New Hampshire residents opposed repeal.

headline: Painting by Numbers, to Whitney Biennial
text: San Francisco

headline: Color and Light
text: A look at the work of the artist Andrew Masullo.

headline: Another Etch A Sketch Gaffe?
text: 5:12 p.m. | Updated Etch A Sketch, a toy known to generations of children, makes it easy to wipe away the past. There is an investor who might wish he or she could use it to void a trade made Thursday.

headline: Don’t Cry for Her, Argentina; She Landed the Big Role
text: EVITAS tend to be formidable women — Patti LuPone, Madonna, Elaine Paige — so Elena Roger, the Argentine actress who stars in the Broadway revival that opens April 5, stuns at first glimpse.

headline: Spotted on the Street | Hazel Honeysuckle
text: The Girl:  Hazel Honeysuckle, a burlesque performer, pinup/fashion model and graphic designer.

headline: Chronicling Americans’ Comeback From the Great Recession
text: The Great Recession has officially been over since June 2009, but a slow recovery and lingering unemployment continue to pose challenges for many Americans. On Thursday, the crew of Your Money told some of these stories from around the country in a special section, “The Comeback Chronicles.”

headline: Motherlode Book Club Video: Anne and Sam Lamott on His Unexpected Fatherhood
text: “Sam,” I asked, “What’s the first thing your mom said to you when you told her Amy was pregnant?”

headline: Amid Threats, BMW Guggenheim Lab Withdraws Plan for Installation in Berlin Neighborhood
text: The BMW Guggenheim Lab, a touring think tank of sorts that stopped on New York’s Lower East Side last summer, is devoted to exploring issues of future cities. But in Berlin, the project has run up against an issue very much of the present: gentrification.

headline: Video of Mali Coup Announcement
text: As my colleague Adam Nossiter reports, junior army officers took control of the presidential palace and a television station in the West African state of Mali in what appeared to be a coup attempt.

headline: Dubai to Build Modern Art Museum and Opera House
text: In 2008 Dubai announced plans to build a series of cultural projects including libraries, theaters, museums and an opera house. But when the global economic crisis hit that year, the projects stalled.

headline: Northwestern Lacrosse Stars Provide Two-Way Dominance
text: EVANSTON, Ill. — Remember Tim Tebow’s Heisman season for Florida? The quarterback dominated the Southeastern Conference, tearing down records held by both quarterbacks and running backs.

headline: But I Love My Pizza Stone: Defending the Dismissed Gadgets
text: We asked readers to share their regrets about the kitchen gadgets they bought with enthusiasm, only to abandon them soon afterward. Hundreds of comments and tweets later, a few tools have turned up over and over again, tools that other cooks may rely on, even cherish: pizza stones, food processors, mandolines, pasta machines, bread makers, slow cookers, rice cookers, garlic presses, copper pots and pans and ice cream makers.

headline: How Far Would You Go for a Financial Comeback?
text: How far would you go to pull yourself and your family back from the financial brink? That’s the question I explored for an article that appears in the “Comeback Chronicles,” in the special Your Money section on Thursday.

headline: Another Gaffe at Etch A Sketch?
text: The day after an aide to Mitt Romney referred to Etch A Sketch in what was widely viewed as a gaffe, the stock traded for its highest price in eight years. It is at least possible that the buyer did not understand how rare that was — or what a high price he or she was paying, Floyd Norris reports for The Times’s Economix blog. Read more »

headline: It Riles a Village
text: I WENT to find my aunt Ruth in Judson Church among the disgruntled at a public hearing last month about New York University’s latest proposal to expand its Greenwich Village campus. It was a couple of weeks before the local community board denounced the proposal outright. A light mist was falling. I climbed the church steps. Beyond the long tables, where children drew with crayons, a bobbing sea of homemade placards demanded, “Flowers Not Towers.”

headline: The Case of the Talkative Parrot
text: Between raucous beach crowds and demented traffic, Miami wasn’t an obvious choice for a writing retreat. But when my husband and I came here on vacation 12 years ago, I felt it capture me, a jinn’s twist from the bottle. I fell for the emerald drip of palm fronds, the braiding scents of gardenia and plumeria. We bought a house on a quiet street. Our neighbors played daylong tournaments of dominoes in the backyard, the hours marked by the slapping of tiles. Blocks away at the Biltmore, the quinceañeras posed beside the turquoise pool, dressed in their whipped-cream gowns. And we settled in, happy with our decision.

headline: She’s Gone Missing
text: I gawk at the chair where I’d left Mom waiting for me. She’s gone. I scan the lounge, a midsize room of muted grays and whites. There’s a disheveled young man stretched out on the blue sofa, a few students eating lunch at the tables, a row of anonymous computer stations by the wall. Panic flutters in my throat.

headline: Michigan Basketball Defections May Include Burke
text: The optimistic glow that had enveloped Michigan’s men’s basketball team in the final weeks of the season has quickly faded, after a poor showing and loss in the first round of the N.C.A.A. tournament and now the news of three players transferring and one thinking of bolting early to the N.B.A.

headline: Former Goldman Employees Form Union in Japan
text: TOKYO – A Goldman Sachs employee on Thursday recounted in a faltering voice how he toiled away in the back offices of the bank’s Japanese operations for nearly a decade before being told last year that his job was being eliminated.

headline: Greece’s Sovereign Debt Lesson
text: The credit default swaps auction on Monday drew a curtain on Act 1 of the Greek sovereign debt drama.

headline: At Delta Terminal, Restaurants Line Up for Takeoff
text: As part of its expanded presence in New York, Delta Air Lines has taken over Terminal C at La Guardia Airport — the former U.S. Airways terminal, adjacent to its own Terminal D, and is adding a huge roster of restaurants, cafes and takeout spots, many steered by big-name chefs.

headline: An Ad That Never Was
text: An ad created by George W. Bush’s team in 2000 featured the comedian Ben Stein reprising his role from “Ferris Bueller’s Day Off” and mocking Al Gore’s accomplishments in a pop quiz.

headline: Unaired D.N.C. Ad
text: An unaired ad from the 2000 presidential campaign that featured a song titled "The Ballad of George W. Bush."

headline: Unaired McCain-Palin Ad
text: An unaired ad from John McCain's 2008 presidential run attacked Barack Obama for never serving in the military.

headline: Business Day Live | Tesla Financing
text: March 22, 2012 - Tesla Motors' interesting approach to financing its operations.

headline: Guilty Plea Expected in New York Housing Agency Bribery Case
text: A former senior official at the New York City agency that helps build affordable housing is expected to plead guilty on Friday to charges related to accepting $600,000 in bribes and kickbacks.

headline: In Defense of Boomerang Kids
text: Boomerang kids — those young adults who left the family home only to move back in because they can’t make it on their own — have gotten a bad rap.

headline: Behind the Action of ‘The Raid: Redemption’
text: In the Indonesian action thriller “The Raid: Redemption,” a SWAT team gets more than it bargained for when it raids an apartment building in the slums of Jakarta to take down a drug lord. The gangsters and thugs who inhabit the building won’t go down without a fight, or several of them. The action mixes martial arts with gunplay, and throws in a few machete swings for good measure. The film has been winning over genre enthusiasts on the film festival circuit, playing at Toronto, Sundance and South by Southwest. Before its release on Friday, it will have two screenings tonight as part of the New Directors/New Films festival in New York.

headline: Digital Notes: Spotify Adds Apps, and Kim Dotcom Gets His Benz Back
text: More Spotify Apps: Last year, Spotify introduced a dozen or so apps to make browsing for music easier on the service (and also to make it look more like iTunes). On Thursday, 12 more apps arrive, most from record labels and distributors promoting their music, including Sony Legacy; the Warner Music Group; Def Jam; and the indies Domino and Matador. Also among the new apps: the Complete Collection, which displays full album artwork and liner notes; TweetVine, which makes playlists from Twitter trends; and Classify, a guide to classical music from X5, a maker of digital compilations.

headline: Red Meat Blues
text: A question that I’m constantly asked by people who know that I spent more than five years as The Times’s restaurant critic is what my most memorable meal was. It’s impossible to single one out. But a dozen or so experiences indeed eclipsed the others, and they included an evening at Alain Ducasse at the Essex House, a Manhattan restaurant that has since closed. I recall the night so vividly because it was such an insanely over-the-top paean to the farthest reaches of fatty excess.

headline: RIM’s BlackBerry Dethroned by Apple on Its Home Turf
text: Research in Motion can no longer say “There’s no place like home.” The BlackBerry maker is losing adoring fans in its own territory, Canada, to Apple’s iPhone.

headline: Gregory Doran Named New Artistic Director of Royal Shakespeare Company
text: After a six-month search for a new artistic director, the Royal Shakespeare Company has chosen Gregory Doran, who has been affiliated with the ensemble, first as an actor and then as a stage director, since 1987.

headline: Orcel to Join UBS as Co-Head of Investment Banking
text: LONDON – Andrea Orcel, the chairman of global banking and markets at Bank of America, has been tapped to be the co-head of investment banking at UBS, the bank announced on Thursday.

headline: The Real Artists of Marfa | AdventuresOf
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Are the Good Times Never Coming Back?
text: There is growing chatter in economics circles about the unsettling possibility that the nation may never recover completely from the recent recession.

headline: Wright Talks About Chipper Jones’s Retirement Announcement
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — David Wright on Thursday expressed his longtime admiration for Chipper Jones, who announced earlier in the day that he would retire after the 2012 season.

headline: In Oklahoma, Obama Declares Pipeline Support
text: RIPLEY, Okla. — President Obama stood in a red-dirt field before acres of stacked pipeline pieces on Thursday to illustrate his support for expedited construction of the southern leg of the Keystone XL oil pipeline. But his public declaration for the project pleased neither the industry and its Republican allies nor environmentalists.

headline: TimesCast | March 22, 2012
text: The French slaying suspect is killed | Soldiers declare a coup in Mali | The rising cost of youth sports.

headline: 36 Hours: Vientiane, Laos
text: Now is the time to explore this city’s small-town charms before it joins the modern world.

headline: 36 Hours in Vientiane, Laos
text: NESTLED in a curve of the Mekong River, Vientiane, Laos, is a place where monks in orange robes outnumber tourists, and French colonial roofs and gilded temples form the skyline. Along the dusty streets of the capital of Laos, you’re more likely to spot a polished Volkswagen bug puttering along than a traffic jam. And in the town center, butterflies and birds flutter among the frangipanis. But with the recent introduction of more international flights, several ambitious infrastructural and commercial projects, and an increasingly cosmopolitan restaurant and cafe scene, Vientiane is quickly changing. Now is the time to explore the city’s small-town charms before it joins the modern world.

headline: U.S. Coach Is Going From Sonnets to Scrums
text: Mike Tolkin, the newly appointed head coach of the United States men’s national rugby team, steps in front of his audience and begins speaking.

headline: In Resolution, U.N. Council Presses Sri Lanka on Civilian Deaths
text: GENEVA — The United Nations Human Rights Council passed an American-backed resolution on Thursday pressing the Sri Lankan government to investigate the deaths of tens of thousands of civilians in the final stages of the civil war with the Tamil Tigers.

headline: U.S. Intelligence Report Warns of Global Water Tensions
text: WASHINGTON — The American intelligence community warned in a report released Thursday that problems with water could destabilize countries in North Africa, the Middle East and South Asia over the next decade.

headline: Leading Off: Seeing Good in the Tebow Trade
text: As Dinah Washington once sang, what a difference a day makes (you can assess the Esther Phillips uptempo version here, if you want). After a Wednesday afternoon of sniping and head-scratching about the trade of Tim Tebow to the Jets (not to mention a little suspense over whether the deal would actually get done), the mood definitely took a Tim turn.

headline: 7-Year Manhunt Ends in Rural Australia
text: SYDNEY — A police raid in an isolated stretch of the Australian outback early Thursday morning led to the capture of one of the country’s most wanted men, a murder suspect who had evaded arrest for nearly seven years by hiding out and living rough in some of the region’s most inhospitable land.

headline: How a Retired Couple’s Portfolio Weathered the Recession
text: Back in 2008 and 2009, when the financial markets seemed as if they might tumble indefinitely, it took a lot of discipline to remain invested — particularly if you were retired or nearing retirement.

headline: Learning From Other Patients
text: Several years ago, I was invited to give a lecture to a group of patients who had received organ transplants at the hospital where I was working. The evening started well — patients I had cared for greeted me warmly, and everyone seemed interested in the talk I had prepared. But as soon as I was finished, the audience started asking questions, and I began to feel a creeping sense of doubt about my performance.

headline: Steven Millhauser Wins Prize for Short Stories
text: Steven Millhauser won the Story Prize on Wednesday for his collection “We Others,” a book that the judges called “a powerful and intriguing collection of stories, marked by page after page of beautifully written, intelligent and sensitive prose.” The award, which is given annually to the author of an outstanding collection of short fiction, is accompanied by a $20,000 prize.
