Mr. Millhauser, who teaches at Skidmore College, is the author of several short story collections and seven novels, including “Martin Dressler,” for which he won a Pulitzer Prize in 1997.

headline: Looks Aren’t Everything, but They Make College Acceptance Letters More Enticing
text: Over the past few weeks I have been meticulously checking my mail, both physical and digital, and so far I am extremely happy with the results. I have been accepted into all of my SUNYs (Stony, Geneseo, Binghamton and University at Buffalo) and still wait for the privates (Vassar and Wesleyan). As for CUNYs, I have been accepted into Hunter, Baruch, City College and Brooklyn. But, I have been accepted through regular decision and not into the Macaulay Honors program, which makes finances of greater importance.

headline: Senate Passes Start-Ups Bill, With Amendments
text: WASHINGTON — Depending on who is speaking, a bill approved by the Senate on Thursday to make it easier for small companies to raise money will either improve the economy by creating jobs or cause unwitting investors to get swindled.

headline: G.M. Tries to Understand a New Generation
text: To help General Motors adapt to young car buyers, researchers at MTV Scratch talked to thousands of people from the so-called “millennial” generation about their impressions of cars, technology and what makes them different from their parents’ generation. Watch a few of the research interviews that informed Scratch’s five-year strategic plan for Chevrolet.

headline: As Young Lose Interest in Cars, G.M. Turns to MTV for Help
text: DETROIT — Ross Martin, 37, is a published poet and a former drummer in an alternative rock band. Wearing Nike high tops and loosefitting jeans, he is the kind of figure who wouldn’t attract a second glance on the streets of Brooklyn, where he lives.

headline: Notes From a New Zealand Newbie
text: Compared with the culture recalibration required of Americans when they travel to some far-off parts of the world, arriving in New Zealand is a rather smooth experience. Kiwi society functions in a way both recognizable and reassuring to Americans: everyone speaks English, people shake hands when they meet, and they eat bacon and eggs for breakfast. There is no bowing or cheek-kissing or shoulder-covering or rampant unpunctuality to get used to. New Zealanders even call soccer soccer. (The sport played by hand — and foot — with an oblong ball is rugby.)

headline: 15-Year Inquiry Faults Ex-Leader and Finds Corruption Widespread in Irish Politics
text: DUBLIN — After 15 years of hearings, a tribunal in Ireland has concluded that “corruption affected every level of Irish political life” and that a former prime minister, Bertie Ahern, had failed to tell the truth about more than $275,000 he received while in office. But the tribunal said it could not conclude that Mr. Ahern had taken bribes.

headline: Insider Trading Ban for Lawmakers Clears Congress
text: WASHINGTON — The Senate gave final approval on Thursday to an ethics bill that bans insider trading by members of Congress, clearing the measure for President Obama, who called for such legislation in his State of the Union address two months ago.

headline: Unaired Negative Bain Ad
text: An ad from Ted Kennedy’s 1992 Senate campaign attacked Mitt Romney over his tenure at Bain capital.

headline: Right Message. Wrong Messenger.
text: In December, Senator Dick Durbin introduced legislation that would authorize the televising of oral arguments before the Supreme Court. It went nowhere. Yesterday, Sen. Kirsten Gillibrand called on lawmakers to approve the bill, saying that “accountability doesn’t end with Congress or the President.”

headline: Transatlantic Recovery Stories
text: Just a thought: the latest conservative line is that America may be recovering, but the recovery would be much faster if it weren’t for Obama. Also, the same people believe that the Cameron government in the UK is wonderful, and we should be doing austerity here too.

headline: A ‘Superstar’ Standard
text: The song “I Don’t Know How to Love Him,” from the Andrew Lloyd Webber-Tim Rice musical “Jesus Christ Superstar,” has crossed over from the world of musical theater to become a standard covered by singers from the worlds of jazz, pop and rock.

headline: Seeking a Sustainable Path for Coffee, and Coffee Farmers, in Haiti
text: Todd Carmichael, a founder of the coffee roaster La Colombe Torrefaction, is an interesting mix of entrepreneur, adventurer (Antarctic speed trekker), showman (a reality TV show on coffee hunting is coming) and philanthropist. His latest venture combining all of these traits is a line of coffee, called Lyon, sales of which will generate money for environmental initiatives supported by the Leonardo DiCaprio Foundation. The coffee blend includes beans that Carmichael is obtaining from Haitian sources that, he says, sidestep predatory loan sharks and middlemen who have hampered the climb out of poverty by Haitian coffee growers. I recently had an e-mail exchange with Carmichael about his experience building relationships with coffee growers in rural Haiti.

headline: The Etch A Sketch Doctrine
text: Gail Collins: David, Mitt Romney won big in Illinois. Does this mean we don’t have to talk about Rick Santorum and Newt Gingrich anymore? I have to admit I’m getting pretty tired of them.

headline: Reading Transtromer
text: To the Editor:

headline: Rezzori and Cervantes
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Not-So-New Genre
text: To the Editor:

headline: Chinese Art? All Roads Lead to Hong Kong
text: FROM the moment you walk into the annual spring sale, there is a tension, bracing even for Hong Kong. Money, beauty and power mingle; paddles flash as serene Song dynasty bowls and exuberant Ming vases go under the gavel for millions of dollars.

headline: The Irish Model Continues to Shine
text: Remember how Ireland’s vigorous recovery proved Keynesian economics — and smarty-pants Keynesian economists — wrong?

headline: Behind the Scenes at The New York Times Magazine Photo Show in Amsterdam
text: The staff at Foam museum in Amsterdam have been hard at work this week hanging  The New York Times Magazine Photographs exhibition, which opens tonight at 6. If you are in Amsterdam, join us tomorrow at 7:30 p.m. for a panel discussion with our photo director, Kathy Ryan, along with contributing photographers Hellen van Meene and Erwin Olaf, led by Marcel Feil of Foam.

headline: So You Want to Go to Myanmar?
text: IT’S rare that a country bursts onto the tourism scene with quite as much vigor as Myanmar. After decades of isolation, it is Asia’s newest hot spot, offering richly layered history, spectacular natural beauty and the edginess that comes with a country still in transition. Since the ruling military junta began to loosen its grip on the government in November 2010, signs of progress — like the release of some political prisoners earlier this year and elections scheduled for April 1, with the opposition leader Daw Aung San Suu Kyi running for a seat in Parliament — have led Western nations, including the United States, to consider dropping long-held economic sanctions.

headline: Edible Selby | Crude Awakening
text: In the stripped-down interiors at the Brooklyn restaurant Isa — exposed tree branches, piles of firewood — there is a hint of the menu to come. All the tapas-size dishes and entrees at the woodsy eatery are studiously simple: raw scallops with apple and celery; sardines roasted with olives; beef tartare with smoked oil and juniper berries. It’s the newest (and much buzzed-about) vision from Taavo Somer, the architect behind the downtown New York institution Freemans, and Ignacio Mattos, the former chef of Il Buco, both of whom use the word “primitive” to describe the space and the food. “It’s nothing that a home cook couldn’t do,” Mattos says. “You can do it with two hands, a knife and a little bit of fire.” More…

headline: Credit Suisse Names Sole Head of Investment Banking
text: LONDON – James L. Amine took over as sole head of Credit Suisse’s global investment banking department on Thursday after Luigi de Vecchi, who ran the unit with him, took a sabbatical for personal reasons.

headline: Restaurant Review: Hortensia, in Tokyo
text: Upon leaving this tranquil subterranean Tokyo restaurant, you might be moved to write a haiku.

headline: Now Is the Season for Japan
text: ONE bright early spring morning this month, I took myself to Ryoanji, the Kyoto temple that is home to the world’s most celebrated rock garden. There was not a single other foreigner in the place. Not even many Japanese were visible across the 120-acre compound (I’d scheduled my trip for spring break, when clamorous school tours are less in evidence).

headline: For Wisconsin, It Could All Come Down to the 3
text: In the Sweet 16, Wisconsin’s success could ultimately be defined by its outside shooting.

headline: With High Gas Prices, Buyers Shift Their Focus Downward
text: The Toyota Prius C, with a combined E.P.A. fuel-economy rating of 50 miles per gallon, is in such demand that a dealer in Florida reportedly levied a $7,000 premium on the $19,710 vehicle, a scaled-down version of the class-leading hybrid. Toyota, which began sales of the C on March 12, moved more units in its first three days than either Chevrolet, with its plug-in-hybrid Volt, or Nissan, with its purely electric Leaf, managed in all of February.

headline: The Lure of History in a Malaysian City
text: ON the tranquil grounds of the Cheng Hoon Teng Temple, Malaysia’s oldest Taoist house of worship, late afternoon visitors bowed and offered burning wands of incense to a gilded statue of the Goddess of Mercy, the deity for whom the temple was founded in the 1600s. Tourists quietly watched or focused cameras on the structure’s ornate, figurine-covered roof.

headline: Booming Again in West Texas
text: A combination of rising oil prices and new technology has set off a new oil boom in the Permian Basin in West Texas, reviving fields once thought to be played out.

headline: A Tally of Green Jobs
text: For the first time, the federal government on Thursday released an estimate of the number of so-called green jobs in the United States economy, saying that 3.1 million people are employed in the production of goods and services that benefit the environment.

headline: Theater Talkback: Mike Daisey, Continued
text: The fracas that has erupted over truth, lies and “The Agony and the Ecstasy of Steve Jobs” continues to percolate through the news media, as commentators air their views on the discovery, thoroughly dissected on an episode of the radio program “This American Life,” that Mike Daisey, the author of the monologue, had essentially fabricated some portions of his exposé about abusive practices at a Chinese factory where Apple products are manufactured.

headline: Professional’s Eye, Tourist’s Perspective
text: AS a photographer in Southeast Asia, I’ve been to Ha Long Bay, in northern Vietnam, many times for work and on vacation, hosting visiting friends. After accepting an assignment to shoot the bay for the Travel section’s annual Where to Go issue, I decided to approach the trip simply as a tourist, going on the same tour as everyone else. Rather than work from a distance, looking for the best overall shots of the bay itself, I shot everything from a tourist’s perspective.

headline: U.S. Inches Toward Goal of Energy Independence
text: MIDLAND, Tex. — The desolate stretch of West Texas desert known as the Permian Basin is still the lonely domain of scurrying roadrunners by day and howling coyotes by night. But the roar of scores of new oil rigs and the distinctive acrid fumes of drilling equipment are unmistakable signs that crude is gushing again.

headline: Sense, Sensibility and Sentences: Examining and Writing Memorable Lines
text: Overview | What can a single sentence accomplish? In this lesson, students share favorite sentences, look closely at what makes them great, paraphrase them, then evaluate the results. They also work with sentences that are “mini-narratives” and write some of their own, before writing full-fledged short stories based on other students’ sentences.

headline: Cuomo and Bloomberg Rescue a Lawmakers’ Conference
text: ALBANY — Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg are bailing out a conference for Latino state legislators after several major labor unions pulled their support over the Legislature’s approval last week of reduced retirement benefits for newly hired public workers.

headline: Using Patient Surveys to Rate Hospitals
text: To the Editor:

headline: John Edwards Denies Prostitute’s Claims
text: John Edwards, the former United States senator and presidential candidate, adamantly denied on Thursday a claim by a prostitute who worked for an upscale Manhattan escort service that she slept with Mr. Edwards in 2007.

headline: When Scouting Film Locations Leads to Asia
text: SINCE the late 1970s, Dow Griffith has traveled to 86 countries as a location manager for the film industry. It’s a fast-paced job that at any given moment has him scouting the world for a place that could look like Earth 1,000 years after humans abandoned it or the surface of Mars or a prehistoric jungle. Once he has found the right spot, he puts down roots and gets to know the area intimately, he said in an e-mail from Manila, where he recently spent time working on “The Bourne Legacy,” which will be released on Aug. 3.

headline: Letters to the Travel Editor
text: To the Editor: Regarding “How to Avoid That Cramped Seat” (Practical Traveler, March 18), I recently flew to London on a Delta 767 with a frequent-flier ticket. I had a selection of lousy seats to choose from when I got my ticket online. But at the check-in counter I asked for a better seat and was given a premium economy seat. It turned out that I had two seats, window and aisle, to myself that were also in an exit row with five feet of leg room.

headline: Deadline Nears for World Bank Nominees
text: The deadline for nominations to become president of the World Bank is 6 p.m. Friday. Thus far, the only named candidate is Jeffrey Sachs, the development economist and director of the Earth Institute at Columbia University.

headline: NBC Renews ‘Smash,’ Its Much-Hyped Broadway-Based Drama
text: Undoubtedly with some sense of relief and satisfaction, NBC announced Thursday it would bring back “Smash” for a second season.

headline: Bloomberg Pledges $220 Million to Global Antismoking Effort
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg committed $220 million of his personal wealth on Thursday to fighting tobacco around the world, which brings the total he has donated to the cause to more than $600 million.

headline: The Playwright and the Radical
text: SNACKING on pastries and tea at her cloth-covered dining table, Leepee Joseph, 95, worked to put into words the odd experience of seeing her longtime home, a light-filled apartment on the eighth floor of a sturdy brick building on West 10th Street in Greenwich Village, recreated onstage in the play “4000 Miles.”

headline: Lawsuit Seeking Information on Cyclist’s Death Gains Support
text: For as long as there have been bicyclists and motorists sharing the streets of New York City, there have been cyclist deaths. Bicycle safety advocates have long criticized the New York Police Department for not thoroughly investigating the deaths of cyclists and for not being aggressive in pressing criminal charges against drivers.

headline: Fretting Over Carbon Footprints
text: The critically acclaimed stories in Helen Simpson’s earlier books have featured glittering, economical portraits of women in contemporary Britain, but immediately recognizable on this side of the Atlantic — women who are navigating the treacherous shoals of romance, or juggling careers and children, or dealing with the discontents of domesticity. Over the years these women have grown older, transiting the vain decade of their 20s and the more sober decade of their 30s, and slowly settling into the slough of middle age.

headline: The Disruptive Power of iMessage
text: You could argue that Apple has changed the way we do things several times. The way we buy music, use our phones, operate our computers and so on. But the world has pretty much overlooked one of Apple’s greatest ideas yet: messages.

headline: Tebow Joins the Circus
text: Regardless of Tim Tebow's abilities on the field, the Jets just traded for a journalists' dream, says William C. Rhoden.

headline: Teenagers Today! When I Was Young, I Loved My ‘Dork-Mobile’
text: It was a royal blue, 1992 Honda Civic that I embellished with bumper stickers to proclaim my political views and music tastes, proclamations that these days we routinely make via Twitter. My sister called it “the dork-mobile.”

headline: Video: Tebow Joins the Big Apple Circus
text: Regardless of Tim Tebow’s abilities on the field, the Jets just traded for a journalists’ dream, says William C. Rhoden.

headline: Happy Birthday, Klimt: Neue Galerie Celebrates
text: Beginning in May the Neue Galerie, whose collection of paintings and drawings by Gustav Klimt is considered by many to be the best in the country, will honor the 150th anniversary of his birth with an exhibition of his work. On view will be greatest hits from the collection, like the gold-flecked 1907 portrait of Adele Bloch-Bauer that the museum’s co-founder Ronald S. Lauder bought for $135 million in 2006. The show will also feature paintings and drawings from Mr. Lauder’s personal collection and that of his family.

headline: Are Unpaid Internships Fair?
text: Readers were divided over the question of unpaid internships in response to a recent column by The Ethicist, “The Internship Rip-Off.”

headline: More Data Thefts Affect Individuals, Verizon Report Finds
text: Of the 855 data thefts that were reported to law enforcement authorities last year, 97 percent could have been avoided through basic, relatively inexpensive safety measures, according to an annual report released on Thursday by Verizon.

headline: Barney Frank Wants Simpler Volcker Rule by Labor Day
text: Barney Frank, the Massachusetts Democrat who is the co-author of the Dodd-Frank financial regulatory overhaul, is questioning how regulators will enforce a central provision in his law.

headline: ‘Hunger Games’ Ticket Sales Are on Fire
text: At midday Thursday, Fandango said it was selling 10 tickets per second for “The Hunger Games,” the latest indicator of off-the-charts interest from moviegoers for the PG-13 tale of Katniss Everdeen and her survival skills.

headline: Structure, Not Numbers
text: When Paul Ryan and the House Republicans released their budget proposal last year, most of the criticisms from liberals focused on the budget’s sweeping and controversial Medicare overhaul. In this year’s budget, the Medicare reforms have been amended in ways that address at least some of last year’s critiques, and so the smartest liberal commentary (see, for instance, Ezra Klein and Jonathan Cohn) is focusing instead on everywhere else that the Republican budget envisions reducing spending — slowing Medicaid growth, rolling back Obamacare, keeping discretionary spending nearly flat, etc. — and how implausible, irresponsible and cruel these cuts would inevitably be.

headline: An Urbane and Unexpected Leap From West to East
text: Japanese Art Deco sounds like an oxymoron. Rightly or wrongly, we — we Americans, that is — are likely to envision the Japanese in the 1920s and ’30s as almost entirely focused on militarism and expansionism. Yet, as an exhibition at Japan Society proves, there were more than enough time and resources in that era for Japanese artists, designers and consumers to cultivate their own version of Art Deco, that excruciatingly suave Western style of art, design and décor.

headline: On the Market in the Region
text: A four-bedroom colonial in Huntington, N.Y., and a four-bedroom Tudor in Westfield, N.Y.

headline: On the Market in New York City
text: A Morningside Heights co-op, a Chelsea co-op and a Ditmas Park Victorian.

headline: In Singapore, Head for the Hill, Hip Duxton Hill
text: Duxton Hill’s tranquil, pedestrian-friendly streets make for an easy afternoon stroll among independent shops and cafes.

headline: A Pop Shop for a New Generation
text: Entering the Brooklyn Museum’s “Keith Haring: 1978-1982,” which focuses on his early career, I worried that the show was going to be one big, marketable nostalgia trip. The loud strains of David Bowie, Grace Jones and the B-52s emanating from the galleries were not auspicious. Nor was the sight of a Pop Shop full of merchandise just outside the exhibition. (Haring didn’t open his first one, on Lafayette Street, until 1986.)

headline: Radish Moon’s Enchanting Children’s Illustrations
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Dismal Premiere for ‘Bent’ on NBC
text: The series premiere of “Bent” on NBC could only muster 2.6 million viewers. In the 18-to-49 category, it was NBC’s lowest-rated in-season comedy premiere ever.

headline: New York Arts of Pacific Asia Show
text: 7 W New York

headline: Thomas Kovachevich: ‘Alpenglow’
text: Showroom 170

headline: Josephine Meckseper: ‘Manhattan Oil Project’
text: Art Production Fund

headline: Oded Hirsch: ‘nothing new’
text: Thierry Goldberg

headline: Florida Police Chief Steps Aside in Fatal Shooting
text: Updated | 7:50 p.m. The embattled Florida police chief overseeing the investigation into the fatal shooting of 17-year-old Trayvon Martin temporarily stepped down Thursday, a day after the Sanford City Commission voted 3-to-2 that it no longer had confidence in him.

headline: The Ads That Never Were
text: Every presidential campaign has commercials that never make it to the airwaves (or YouTube), for reasons including national affairs and inconsistent messages. Below is a selection of four ads from recent presidential campaigns that never got final approval.

headline: After a False Start, a Progressive School Gets Ready to Open
text: A year after city education officials made the controversial decision to take the space allotted to a planned progressive elementary school and hand it to a KIPP charter school instead, the jilted school has found a home. The Bridge Castle School will open next year in Washington Heights with a plan to attract English- and Spanish-speaking children, as well as those with incarcerated family members.

headline: Environmental Jeremiad, Complete With Ukulele
text: Outfitted in caps and gowns, the singer Nellie McKay and her musicians trouped onto the stage of Feinstein’s at Loews Regency on Tuesday evening with mischievous smirks on their faces. Along with the show’s title, “Silent Spring — It’s Not Nice to Fool Mother Nature,” the costumes signaled what was ahead: a zany homemade one-woman musical comedy with an educational agenda and more wardrobe changes to come.

headline: An Ebullient Mozart Sets Up a Ferocious Beethoven
text: There is no easier sell in classical music than the late quartets of Mozart and Beethoven.

headline: In Cuba, Church’s Uneasy Balancing Act
text: HAVANA — Just in the past few days, with a visit here by Pope Benedict XVI looming, the Rev. Roberto Betancourt has witnessed firsthand the difficult position Cuba’s Roman Catholic Church finds itself in as it wields its newfound influence but still struggles to fill its pews.

headline: The Selling of a Politician, and the Ads Almost Broadcast
text: Modern campaigns are often scientifically plotted operations that leave little to chance. Nowhere is this more obvious than with advertising, which is carefully fashioned from polling, focus groups and demographic research.

headline: Karl Rove Is Not Impressed
text: There is no disputing Karl Rove’s political skills. I don’t mean to say I admire him: He’s dedicated to causes I find repugnant. But when Mr. Rove strikes, you have to pay attention, because he’s wicked good—in the Massachusetts and original sense of that word—at playing the public.

headline: Pictures of the Day: France and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from France, New York, Belgium and Indonesia.

headline: Motown Restoration for Ebony and Ivory
text: “Special Piano” has been scrawled on masking tape across a pile of broken parts at the Steinway & Sons factory in Astoria, Queens. Since December, with financing from Paul McCartney, the company’s restorers have been rebuilding this Victorian rosewood instrument used for recordings by Motown stars including Marvin Gaye, Smokey Robinson and Stevie Wonder.

headline: Beware an Internet Lothario
text: To all the women out there looking for love or at least a date on the Internet, be on the lookout for any prospects going by the name Hayden.

headline: Workouts on (Virtual) Water
text: WHEN it comes to cardio equipment at the gym, the treadmill and elliptical take center stage. Though many fitness clubs have a few rowing machines, they’re often relegated to a forgotten corner. In New York, however, some workout centers are trying to give more attention to this overlooked way of staying in shape.

headline: Time Out New York Lounge at New World Stages
text: There is a latent performer in every New Yorker: a burgeoning jazz singer, a part-time musician, a student of improvisation. Perhaps that’s part of what attracted us to the bright lights and big stages of this city in the first place. Haven’t we all been caught singing some classic Queen or “Jesus Christ Superstar” on the gym treadmill at one time or another?

headline: Quandary Considered: My Son’s Girlfriend Is Bulimic
text: D.’s quandary: her son’s 18-year-old girlfriend throws up in her house after every meal. The young woman is bulimic, and it’s an open secret, if it’s a secret at all: D. has talked to her son, who has talked to his girlfriend, as has D.’s older son’s girlfriend. They’re dealing with it, the teens insist. They’ll handle it. And at 18, maybe D. should let them — or maybe she should contact one of the girl’s divorced parents, even though her son has asked her not to.

headline: She’ll Take Manhattan, but Hold the Jeans
text: DARKNESS fell on a brisk Saturday night, and droves of the young and the raucous flooded the entrance and lobby of the Dream Downtown hotel in Chelsea. It happened to be my hotel for this stay, since I’d gotten a killer deal on the Internet.

headline: Rentals Offered, With Bragging Rights
text: A DEVELOPER that has played a big role in converting boardrooms into bedrooms in the financial district is preparing to leave its largest mark yet on the neighborhood.

headline: While the U.S. Moves Toward Energy Independence ...
text: The nation’s reliance on foreign oil has fallen sharply since 2005, when imports made up 60 percent of the liquid fuel used. A surge of new domestic production and a decline in consumption has transformed the United States’ energy outlook.

headline: A.I.G. Repays Additional $1.5 Billion to Government
text: The American International Group said on Thursday that it had repaid an additional $1.5 billion owed to the Treasury Department, further reducing the bailed-out insurer’s government lifeline.

headline: For Paganini, a Wild and Devilish Lifestyle Fueled Some Virtuoso Compositions
text: With his sex, drugs and rock ’n’ roll lifestyle, Paganini (1782-1840) provided plenty of fodder for 19th-century gossipmongers. A womanizer and gambler, he further fueled his legend by frequent concert cancellations, often stemming from a range of ailments including syphilis and depression. His prodigious technique gave rise to rumors that he was in league with the Devil.

headline: Spiders and Bacteria Are Tops in Space Lab Contest
text: A zebra spider spins no webs, but instead catches its prey by leaping onto it. But in space, a zebra spider would zip off in a straight line instead of a trajectory curved by gravity, missing its target.

headline: Living In | Throgs Neck, the Bronx
text: The landscape in Throgs Neck has been transformed over the last several decades. But it is still largely a working- and middle-class neighborhood, relaxed and friendly.

headline: Fluid Reasons for a Constant Allure
text: THE landscape in Throgs Neck, in the southeastern corner of the Bronx, has been transformed over the last several decades. Before, open fields flanked areas of three-season bungalows overlooking Long Island Sound and other expanses of water. Now the area is mostly bustling and built up — and sewn into the city fabric by expressways.

headline: Building Sonic Textures On Buzzes and Pulses
text: Collaboration, the odder the better, is the engine that drives the Ecstatic Music Festival at Merkin Concert Hall. You can think of Judd Greenstein, the composer who assembles its programs, as a mischievous matchmaker who dreams up blind dates that seem as likely to create sparks as to create harmony.

headline: Heading to Auction, a Rocket That Launched a Legend
text: The Toleman TG184-2 racecar driven by Ayrton Senna da Silva in 1984, his first full season in a career that would include three world championships, is part of a sale scheduled for May 16 conducted by Silverstone Auctions.

headline: Changes in F.H.A. Fees
text: FEES charged on mortgages backed by the Federal Housing Administration are set to change this spring; they’ll go up for some and down for others.

headline: Xavier’s Wells Is Still a Question Mark for Friday
text: ATLANTA — Xavier guard Dez Wells tried to bounce around on the court as best he could here Thursday during the Musketeers’ light practice at the Georgia Dome in preparation for Friday night’s Round of 16 game with Baylor in the N.C.A.A. tournament.

headline: Oblivious to the Battle Raging Outside
text: There was no question that “Mad Men” would get around to the civil rights movement. From the start, racism was the carbon monoxide of the show: a poison that couldn’t always be detected over the pungent scent of cigarettes, sexism, anti-Semitism, alcoholism, homophobia and adultery, but that sooner or later was bound to turn noxious.

headline: Mummy Dearest
text: Perhaps every autobiographical first novel serves its author as Jeanette Winterson’s did — as “a story I could live with.” But “Oranges Are Not the Only Fruit,” buoyant and irrepressible, was published in 1985, for its author half a lifetime ago, and what one can live with changes over time.

headline: For Indiana’s Sheehey, an Assist from Fab Melo
text: Fab Melo, the Syracuse center, heard the news that Tom Crean, the Indiana coach, would be in the south Florida gym that September day in 2009. Melo already had his ticket punched; he had his pick of Division I schools. Now, Melo wanted to help a not-so-well-known guard, Will Sheehey, who was a senior and new teammate at Sagemont High School in Weston, Fla.

headline: Boozy Nights of a Ravaged Dreamer
text: The ravaged James Tyrone on display at City Center Stage II in the Pearl Theater Company’s sure-footed revival of “A Moon for the Misbegotten,” as played by Andrew May, has got a certain quality. He’s downright ... unexceptional.

headline: Movie Listings for March 23-29
text: Movies

headline: A New Vision of a Visionary Fisherman
text: The art of Forrest Bess (1911-77), like that of Vincent van Gogh, may be in danger of being overtaken by his life story. Especially now, when the work of this eccentric visionary painter — who spent the bulk of his maturity as a fisherman  on the Gulf of Mexico, living on a spit of Texas beach — is having an especially intense New York moment.

headline: TimesCast | A Coup in Mali
text: March 22, 2012 — In Mali, unexpected unrest as a group of junior military officers attempt a government coup.

headline: Student Communicators Tackle Deadly Plastics, Dirty Water
text: Here are two videos that caught my attention today. The first, above, portrays how plastic trash can end up killing marine life. It was created by Alexis van Dijk, a student at Marymount Manhattan College whom I met after speaking there last night on my notion of a “Knowosphere.” I like it because it avoids overstatement and simply reminds viewers that it’s worth considering the long-distance impacts of choices we make every day.

headline: Fantasy Focus: When Punting Saves Might Make Sense
text: In a typical 5×5 Rotisserie league, and by this I mean one with nine generic pitching slots, it can make a lot of sense not to draft any closers. (This is emphatically not the case in a league with specific relief slots to fill, or one with a low innings cap, which enhances closers’ value.)

headline: Pop/Rock Listings for March 23-29
text: Pop

headline: A Heart Needs One Thing, Society Wants Another
text: “I thought, I know what this one is about,” Terence Davies said at a recent screening of his new film, “The Deep Blue Sea,” adapted from a play by Terence Rattigan. He was explaining why, when he was invited by the Rattigan Trust to film one of that playwright’s works, he had chosen this 1952 tale of adultery and romantic despair. (It was previously brought to the screen in 1955, starring Vivien Leigh in a role performed, in Mr. Davies’s version, by Rachel Weisz.)

headline: Jazz Listings for March 23-29
text: Jazz

headline: Classical Music and Opera Listings for March 23-29
text: Classical

headline: Dance Listings for March 23-29
text: Dance

headline: Robert Bales and the Case for a Measured Approach to Alcohol in Combat
text: When we first heard the news that a lone American soldier was accused of killing 16 Afghan civilians, and desecrating the corpses of nine, we had the same gut suspicion: alcohol had to be involved.

headline: Where the Streets Smelled Like Beer
text: THE New-York Historical Society’s exhibit “Beer Here: Brewing New York’s History,” to open on May 25th, is another example of the society’s novel approach to presenting local history, in this case with beer tastings. In portraying this foamy story, the exhibit also covers the tale of two of New York’s most important brewers, George Ehret and Jacob Ruppert. They competed for the same markets with back-to-back breweries in Yorkville, but were anything but rivals.

headline: A Sliver of a Silver Lining for the Movie Industry
text: The Motion Picture Association of America, releasing its annual snapshot of global moviegoer trends on Thursday, looked on the bright side, as its job requires.

headline: Museum and Gallery Listings for March 23-29
text: Art

headline: A Harlem Resurgence
text: Sales seem to be rebounding in Harlem. Prices are rising, and inventory has fallen.

headline: After a Short Nap, Harlem Is Back
text: FOR a time, Claudia Aguirre and Joel Feazell lived happily in a two-bedroom one-bath co-op on the Upper West Side with their two daughters. But as the children grew, the space became increasingly cramped. In particular, they needed another bathroom. They began to hunt for a larger apartment, which eventually led them north of 110th Street. There, they spent months researching condominiums, co-ops and, finally, brownstones.

headline: Brooklyn Race Will Change Route to Accommodate Bigger Field
text: New York Road Runners will reconfigure the course of the Brooklyn Half Marathon so that nearly three times as many runners can join the race in May. At the same time, Road Runners will nearly double the entry fee to offset the higher amount it must pay the Police Department to direct traffic.

headline: Gifts With Strings Attached
text: IN her will, Sonja Stein, a Manhasset resident who died in 2009, bequeathed her twin East Marion summer homes — a five-bedroom Victorian with a broad front porch, and a similar four-bedroom shingle house next door that she used as a guesthouse — to the Oysterponds Historical Society. She asked that the historic homes, along with 14 acres next to Dam Pond, be preserved in perpetuity and that the land remain unencumbered by development.

headline: A Photographer Who Never Sees a Mayor’s Bad Side
text: Over 25 years, as one of New York’s official photographers of mayors, Ed Reed has shadowed four. They have struck contrasting poses and projected divergent personalities. He has photographed them from every angle. But he is the kind of guy who doesn’t volunteer a negative word about any of them.

headline: High Marks for Transit Hubs
text: WANT to know which New Jersey train stations have the most plentiful supply of parking spaces relative to town population? There’s a list for that. Or what about stations in the areas with the greatest number of jobs? There’s a list for that. Or transportation hubs with the densest populations? There’s a list for that as well.

headline: Slowdown in Fairfield County
text: LIKE the relatively warm weather that has caressed Connecticut in the past few months, the brightening economic picture has put many people in an upbeat mood, especially in the real estate industry.

headline: Q & A
text: Leaky Bathtubs: Who Pays?

headline: Tibetan Self-Immolations Rise as China Tightens Grip
text: MAQU, China — Like many children of Tibetan nomads, Tsering Kyi started school relatively late, at age 10, but by all accounts she made up for lost time by studying with zeal.

headline: In Attack Mode, Santorum Leaves Himself Open
text: Important presidential campaign lesson of the day: When trying to score off your rival’s supposed gaffe, avoid being hit by the rebound.

headline: Jumps, Turns and Breathtaking Feats, Aligned With Dense Structures
text: What everyone soon notices in Paul Taylor’s choreography is the striking simplicity of his dance language. It’s remarkable how frequently basic features recur in many of his finest works: walking, running, falling, tilting, kneeling; opening arms from a halo position or holding them in one large upturned arc; shifts of weight through the pelvis. Since some of them also feature athletic jumps and turns that obviously call for very strong training, there’s no question these dancers are virtuosos. The vocabulary, however, is not especially sophisticated. The jumps and turns, though often breathtakingly fast, don’t extend the lexicon.

headline: Spare Times for March 23-29
text: Around Town

headline: Access to the Country and to Croissants
text: BACK in 2007, when housing prices were at their peak, Hervé and Dacotah Rousseau couldn’t afford a place in Manhattan. Instead, for around $400,000, they bought a house in Putnam County.

headline: Bad Guys Upstairs, Gore Down the Hall
text: If it’s not obvious from all the bashing, smashing and machete-ing in the frenetically violent “The Raid: Redemption” where the redemptive part kicks in, there’s a reason. As it happens, the title of this Indonesian action flick was changed because “The Raid” alone wasn’t available in the United States. That’s too bad because the apartment complex teeming with villainy in which much of the story takes place — and into which some dozen and a half Special Forces officers storm — turns out to be a massive roach motel. Characters check in, but they don’t check out. It’s no wonder that so many of the dead, who pile up quickly, register as a queasy, macabre joke.

headline: Choose Your Adventure: Ending the Unfinished
text: The Brentano String Quartet has consistently offered imaginative programming ideas, and the most memorable have been about juxtaposing old and new works. Its current project, celebrating the group’s 20th anniversary, is Fragments, a two-part series in which unfinished works by great composers of the past are paired with responses to those pieces by living composers, commissioned for the occasion.

headline: Bagging the Bag
text: A friend and neighbor is developing a line of yoga bags. When she finished her samples, she gave me one. I offered her some feedback and thanked her. But I knew I’d never use the bag, so I offloaded it to my cleaning lady. My brother thinks this was wrong. If I didn’t want it, she could have given the sample to someone else. But I think returning the bag would have been insulting. Aren’t we free to do with gifts as we like?

headline: Lumière | YSL in the U.S.A.
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Spare Times: For Children, March 23-29
text: ‘The Neverending Story’

headline: Tax Policy: Much Talk, Few Details
text: If approached the right way, there could actually be some widespread agreement on tax reform coming out of the current election.

headline: U.S. Relaxes Limits on Use of Data in Terror Analysis
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration is moving to relax restrictions on how counterterrorism analysts may retrieve, store and search information about Americans gathered by government agencies for purposes other than national security threats.

headline: TimesCast | French Suspect Killed
text: March 22, 2012 — After a 30-hour standoff, French security forces shot and killed 23-year-old Mohammed Merah, who claimed he killed seven people over 10 days and that he had Al Qaeda training.

headline: A Family Fairy Tale, Twice Told
text: MAC and I met on Craigslist, but not in the usual way. At the time I was 22, manically conducting the sputtering finale of a relationship I wasn’t ready for, and living in my first postcollege apartment, the type of place one rarely finds in a lifetime, at least in New York: two floors at the top of a converted brownstone in Park Slope, Brooklyn, half a block from Prospect Park and ridiculously inexpensive. It came with four bedrooms, two bathrooms, a winding staircase (up which box springs did not fit), and a roof deck with a view of the Statue of Liberty. It also came with three roommates, one of whom moved out a few months after I moved in.

headline: How Do You Measure the Spark of Creativity?
text: An English teacher in Queens writes: "Great teaching, like great writing, is nuanced, complex and much larger than the sum of its parts. Good principals and administrators 'know it when they see it.'"

headline: Goodbye Malaria, Hello Condos
text: IT can seem hard to believe, but there was a time when people didn’t value Central Park for its views.

headline: I Realized Colleges Look Beyond Grades
text: Jonathan O., a college student, shares his experience on the College Board's BigFuture website.

headline: When a Rental Needs a Repair
text: ONE of the advantages of being a renter is that when the roof starts leaking or the hot-water heater dies, the repair is not your responsibility — in theory, that is.

headline: Adobe’s Photoshop CS6 is Free, for Now
text: As of today you can get about $700 worth of the latest Adobe Photoshop software free. But there is a catch.

headline: Heat, Humidity, Rain and Excitement as Formula One Arrives in Kuala Lumpur
text: KUALA LUMPUR — The Formula One circus arrived in Kuala Lumpur Thursday for the Malaysian Grand Prix on Sunday and it was promptly treated with a massive contrast in atmosphere to that in Melbourne last weekend: As I write, the air temperature is above 30 degrees Celsius and the humidity 68 percent.

headline: How Much Is Public School Costing Your Family?
text: Any public school parent knows free doesn’t really mean “free” when it comes to education: whether the supply list or the prom tickets, the extras (and sometimes the not-so-extras) cost money.

headline: Longtime Wall Street Lobbyist to Retire
text: Steve Bartlett, one of Wall Street’s go-to lobbyists in the industry’s fight over financial regulation, has announced that he will retire at the end of the year.

headline: Experts Debunk College Search Myths
text: College experts weigh in on common college search myths in a video on The College Board's BigFuture website.

headline: Q&A: Going Back Into a Time Capsule for a Password Reset
text: Q.

headline: In a Divided City, Many Blacks See Echoes of White Superiority
text: CAPE TOWN — For countless foreign visitors, Cape Town is an indelible symbol of the beauty and promise of post-apartheid South Africa. Beyond its gorgeous scenery and great wines, its very logo — an outline of majestic Table Mountain superimposed over a rainbow — emphasizes its historic mix of races and cultures, and its most famous resident, Desmond Tutu, is revered as a symbol of tolerance, inclusiveness and forgiveness.

headline: The World Is Ending; Check Your To-Do List
text: “Live every day as if it were your last” is a piece of corny wisdom I never quite understood until Abel Ferrara’s new film explored an obvious corollary: Your last day — or, as it happens, the whole planet’s last day — will be just like every other one. Mr. Ferrara makes this point with ingenuity and characteristic thrift by using found news footage to provide images of apocalypse. Crowds gather in St. Peter’s Square; candlelight processions wind through the streets of unidentified cities.

headline: Blunder of Blunders
text: DeLong and Summers on fiscal policy in a depressed economy is out. The headline point is the argument that austerity when you’re in the liquidity trap may well worsen, not improve, your long-run fiscal position; I’ve been making the same point for a couple of years, but Brad/Larry present some evidence from the birth of Eurosclerosis and the downgrading of US potential output estimates since the crisis began.

headline: Manicure Part Deux
text: Stephanie Rosenbloom removes the top layer of her polish and gets a few bonus days of wear.

headline: Theater Listings: March 23-29
text: Theater

headline: ‘Keith Haring: 1978–1982’
text: Images from a new exhibition at the Brooklyn Museum.

headline: Hurtful Words: Take Offense, or Turn Away?
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Deadbeat, He’ll Never Live Up to His Name
text: The Lower East Side of Manhattan depicted in “The Trouble With Bliss” is neither the hip, bohemian enclave nor the emerging yuppie frontier of popular imagination. It is more like a zanier downscale version of the Upper West Side of “Seinfeld,” itself an anachronism, given the area’s real estate boom.

headline: BATS Goes Public at $16 a Share, at the Low End of Expected Range
text: BATS Global Markets, one of the largest stock market operators in the country, priced its initial public offering on Thursday at $16, at the low end of expectations, according to people briefed on the matter.

headline: Affordable Housing
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Great Reinvention of That Sceptred Isle
text: NEW HAVEN — It is easy to mock the entire enterprise, as the caricaturist George Cruikshank did in 1812, in a satirical print on display at the Yale Center for British Art here. At a meeting of Cruikshank’s “Antiquarian Society,” its president ecstatically holds forth without anybody paying him the slightest bit of attention.

headline: N.C.A.A. Hangout
text: Pete Thamel, Greg Bishop and Connor Ennis of The Times talk college basketball with readers.

headline: The Diaspora Is Remixed
text: For all its professed liberalism and even radicalism, the art world is considerably less diverse than many of the institutions its products criticize. Government agencies, large corporations and the military — at least in this country — can make the art world look like a segregation-era backwater. This puts enormous pressure on young black artists who have come up through the system to speak not only as individuals but also for a large population — particularly when they show in museums, which don’t just exhibit art but also frame it in the context of a larger historical narrative.

headline: Facebook Gobbles Up Patents From I.B.M.
text: The patent chest held by an old technology giant, I.B.M., is proving to be a good war chest for the new technology giant, Facebook.

headline: Talking N.C.A.A. Tournament With Times Reporters
text: We’ve been experimenting with video hangouts on Google-plus, setting up our sports reporters with readers for conversations about the N.C.A.A. tournament. On Thursday, Pete Thamel, Greg Bishop and Connor Ennis of The Times and five readers talked about the opening weekend, looked ahead to the Round of 16 and ventured into some other college sports topics. We said that we’ve been “experimenting,” so please excuse some of the technical glitches. You’ll notice, for instance, that the camera seems to have a particular affection for Mr. Thamel early on. Turns out we had it locked. We hope you enjoy the conversation and consider joining us for future hangouts.

headline: A Dance Movie Without a Lot of Moves
text: Tempting as it is to believe that no disability is insurmountable when you have a slavish Latin lover by your side, it will take a better film than “Musical Chairs” to convince us. Pairing Mia (Leah Pipes), an Upper East Side ballroom dancer, with Armando (E. J. Bonilla), a lithe Puerto Rican striver from the Bronx, this mawkish rom-com mines class, ethnic and ambulatory boundaries for cheap laughs and cheap-looking visuals.

headline: Whitney Houston Drowned, Coroner Says
text: LOS ANGELES — The singer Whitney Houston, who was found dead in her hotel room on the eve of the Grammy Awards last month, accidentally drowned in a bathtub, the Los Angeles County coroner said on Thursday. Cocaine and heart disease also played a role in her death, the coroner said.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Apple Buyback Math and Pictures of Desolation
text: Here are some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web on Wednesday. There are more here.

headline: Previously Unpublished Vonnegut Novella to Be Released
text: A previously unpublished novella by Kurt Vonnegut will be released on Friday by RosettaBooks, close to 60 years after it was written, the publisher said on Thursday. The 22,000-word novella, “Basic Training,” was rejected by the Saturday Evening Post in the late 1940’s, long before Mr. Vonnegut had become famous through works such as “Slaughterhouse-Five” and “Cat’s Cradle.” After Mr. Vonnegut died in 2007, a trove of his unpublished work remained in Indiana, where he was born. RosettaBooks chose the novella from hundreds of other works that Mr. Vonnegut’s literary executor had made available.

headline: The Domino Effect of Just One Drink
text: There is something appealingly messy about “Come On Eileen,” the first feature from Finola Geraghty and one of the few to face alcoholism from a female point of view — and a middle-aged one at that. Unlike Meg Ryan’s sloshed housewife in “When a Man Loves a Woman,” whose adorable inebriation prompted us to wonder if gin could make our complexions glow like that, Jackie Howe’s Eileen wears her wrinkles and thickening waist with the same pride as her abundant auburn hair.

headline: ‘Hangover Part III’ Is Coming Next Summer
text: Consider the competition slate for the Cannes Film Festival officially scrambled. Or, you know, maybe not: on Thursday, Warner Brothers announced that it was preparing a third installment in the “Hangover” series, its bawdy, billion-dollar grossing comedy franchise about three friends whose travels invariably result in collective memory loss followed by farcical efforts to retrace their troublemaking steps.

headline: Federal Charges in the Death of James C. Anderson
text: Prosecutors unsealed federal hate-crime charges for the racially motivated murder of James Craig Anderson in Jackson, Miss.

headline: A Documentary in Which All Bets Are Good Ones
text: “All In: The Poker Movie” needs one more word in its title, in the interest of accuracy. It ought to be “All In: The Poker Propaganda Movie.”

headline: An Eccentric World
text: Two exhibitions in New York shed new light on the artist Forrest Bess.

headline: Proof That Science Can’t Find You Love
text: More of a stridently insistent pitch than a fully engaging movie, “Losing Control” centers on a young scientist who gets the engagement jitters and decides to test whether there are other fish in the sea. Armed with a performance chart and the oblivious belief that her China-bound boyfriend will stand by and wait, Samantha (Miranda Kent) seeks out and judges men when she’s not plugging away at a stalled doctoral project involving sperm samples in a Harvard Medical School laboratory.

headline: Obsessed by the Circumstances of Her Birth
text: More slickly packaged than most faith-based fare, “October Baby” gussies up its anti-abortion message with gauzy cinematography and more emo music than an entire season of “Grey’s Anatomy.” But not even a dewy heroine and a youth-friendly vibe can disguise the essential ugliness at its core: like the bloodied placards brandished by demonstrators outside women’s health clinics, the film communicates in the language of guilt and fear.

headline: General Says Afghans Need Big U.S. Force Beyond 2012
text: WASHINGTON — The senior allied commander in Afghanistan suggested on Thursday that he might not advocate any further drawdown of the American force in Afghanistan going into 2013 once the so-called surge forces ordered by President Obama leave this fall.

headline: Tebow Who? Giants Re-Sign David Carr
text: One day after the Jets made Tim Tebow the most famous backup quarterback in the N.F.L., the Giants also addressed their reserve quarterback situation —  with significantly less fanfare.

headline: Drug Dosage Was Approved Despite Warning
text: Four months before a best-selling Alzheimer’s drug was set to lose its patent protection, its makers received approval for a higher dosage that extended their exclusive right to sell the drug. But the higher dosage caused potentially dangerous side effects and worked only slightly better than the existing drugs, according to an article published Thursday in the British Medical Journal.

headline: U.S. Sergeant Faces 17 Counts of Murder in Afghan Killings
text: Staff Sgt. Robert Bales will be charged on Friday with 17 counts of murder and various other charges, including attempted murder, in connection with the March 11 attack on Afghan civilians, a senior United States official said on Thursday.

headline: PBS Agrees to Revisit Documentary Schedule
text: Under intense public pressure from independent documentary filmmakers, including a Twitter campaign, PBS on Thursday agreed to find a new home next season for the award-winning film series “Independent Lens” and “POV.”

headline: In Search of a French Philosopher, and Herself
text: As the title of Julia Haslett’s unsatisfying documentary suggests, “An Encounter With Simone Weil” is as much about Ms. Haslett as it is about Weil, the French philosopher, mystic, teacher, labor sympathizer and, briefly, worker in a Renault factory. Weil’s statement that “attention is the rarest and purest form of generosity” resonated so strongly for Ms. Haslett that she set out to discover more about Weil, who died in England in 1943 at 34. (Afflicted by tuberculosis, she often refused food in solidarity with those suffering under German occupation.)

headline: Bank of America Tests Rental Program as Alternative to Foreclosure
text: Bank of America said Thursday that it would offer a small number of customers facing foreclosure the option to remain in their homes and rent the property instead. The program highlights how investors are increasingly interested in becoming landlords on troubled properties.

headline: Top State Court Says Judges Can’t Demand Cash-Only Bail
text: ALBANY — Responding to concerns that low-income defendants often have trouble making bail, New York State’s highest court ruled on Thursday that state judges may not require that defendants post bail in cash.

headline: 9 Graduates Lose Case Against New York Law School
text: Amid a challenging time in the legal industry, a growing chorus of law-school graduates are bemoaning the lack of job opportunities.

headline: Putts Elude Els, and So Could Masters
text: ORLANDO, Fla. — The 8-iron from the right rough had a chance to go into the hole on the ninth green, narrowly missing by a couple of inches. The birdie putt from 4 feet, however, had no chance, sliding by for a painful par.

headline: Neighborhood Joint | Louis Shoe Rebuilders
text: Louis Shoe Rebuilders, on the ground floor of the Empire State Building, was founded a decade before the skyscraper towering over it was completed.

headline: Where the Sheen on Your Shoes Says, ‘Respect’
text: IT’S 8 a.m. in the Empire State Building, and a businessman is getting his shoes shined. The avalanche of his day will soon begin, but now the weight of his worries rests on two brass foot fixtures. Other men, wearing crisp suits and attention-grabbing watches, ease into the stations next to him, thumbing through Playboy magazines and newspapers. The sharp scent of worked leather wafts from the back room, where old repair machines with names like the Landis Aristocrat stitcher and the Auto-Soler toil away.

headline: N.F.L. Players Union Wants to Conduct Its Own Inquiry Into Bounty Program
text: The N.F.L. players union said Thursday that it still wanted to conduct its own investigation into the New Orleans Saints’ bounty system after Commissioner Roger Goodell suspended Coach Sean Payton for a year.

headline: Nissan Promotes Next New York Taxi as a Sign of Its Innovation
text: TAXICABS crowd the movies and TV shows about New York just as they crowd the streets of New York, as evidenced by “On the Town,” “Taxi,” “Taxi Driver,” “Night on Earth” and “Cash Cab.” Now comes a campaign that celebrates the city’s taxi fleet, or at least what it is to look like beginning in fall 2013.

headline: The Severability Doctrine
text: THE Obama administration has made a curious strategic choice in its defense of the constitutionality of the health care reform act. The central issue before the Supreme Court, which will begin hearing oral arguments on Monday, is whether the act’s requirement that everyone buy health insurance — the so-called individual mandate — exceeds Congress’s constitutional power.

headline: The Relationship School
text: Usually when you visit a school you walk down a quiet hallway and peer in the little windows in the classroom doors. You see one teacher talking to a bunch of students. Every 50 minutes or so a chime goes off and the students fill the hallway and march off to their next class, which is probably unrelated to the one they just left.

headline: House Votes to Kill a Medicare Cost Panel
text: WASHINGTON — In a rebuff to President Obama, the Republican-controlled House passed a bill on Thursday to abolish a Medicare cost control board created by the new health care law.

headline: A Transgender Candidate Is Hoping to Make History
text: Zoning. School overcrowding. The design of New York’s transportation system.

headline: AT&T Accused of Improperly Billing for Service for Deaf
text: The Justice Department has accused AT&T of knowing that a calling service it offered for the deaf was being used by Nigerian swindlers and others to steal from American merchants.

headline: Democrats Reject Christie Choice for New Jersey’s Top Court
text: TRENTON — Democrats voted down one of Gov. Chris Christie’s two nominees to the New Jersey Supreme Court on Thursday, handing the hard-charging Republican governor an unusual high-profile defeat.

headline: Paranoia Strikes Deeper
text: Stop, hey, what’s that sound? Actually, it’s the noise a great political party makes when it loses what’s left of its mind. And it happened — where else? — on Fox News on Sunday, when Mitt Romney bought fully into the claim that gas prices are high thanks to an Obama administration plot.

headline: The Church Lady State
text: When people complain about liberal overreach they always bring up the nanny state. You know, sorting your garbage to see if a banana peel slipped in with a cellophane wrapper; energy-efficient light bulbs; neutered language in the public square to make sure no one is ever offended.

headline: North Carolina’s Marshall Does Not Practice
text: ST. LOUIS – North Carolina’s standout point guard Kendall Marshall (right wrist surgery) did not practice Thursday and still does not know if he can play against Ohio in the Round of 16 on Friday night.

headline: Nearly 22 Months Later, Kendrys Morales Returns to Angels
text: TEMPE, Ariz. – Albert Pujols might not be the only slugger the Los Angeles Angels add to their lineup this season. On Thursday, for the first time since May 29, 2010, the Angels used Kendrys Morales in their lineup.

headline: A Broader Right to Counsel
text: The right to a jury trial is extolled as a fixture of American justice, but a vast majority of people charged with crimes never see a trial. Plea bargaining defines the criminal justice system: 97 percent of federal convictions and 94 percent of state convictions come through guilty pleas negotiated between prosecutors and offenders.

headline: Jets Facing a Tricky Situation at Quarterback
text: It often happened to Doug Flutie when his Calgary Stampeders needed a quarterback sneak. Out of the game he went, and in came a strong and physical runner named Steve Taylor to gain that final yard. The switch prevented Flutie from absorbing some big hits, but it also had an unintended consequence.

headline: Witnesses Testify That Espada Used Nonprofit Group’s Checks to Pay for Personal Services
text: A videographer who was hired by former State Senator Pedro Espada Jr. to film a private birthday party testified on Thursday that she had been pressured by Mr. Espada’s assistant to lie about the work she performed and claim in an invoice that she had actually filmed a public event.

headline: Taking On Police Tactic, Critics Hit Racial Divide
text: ALBANY — Black and Latino lawmakers, fed up over the frequency with which New York City police officers are stopping and frisking minority men, are battling what they say is a racial divide as they push legislation to rein in the practice.

headline: Fixing New York’s Budget
text: Gov. Andrew Cuomo and legislative leaders are scrambling to conclude negotiations on the $132.5 billion 2012-13 state budget by March 31. As they push to finish their main piece of business, a few important items in the budget deserve notice:

headline: Out of Bounds
text: Commissioner Roger Goodell has taken a good step toward repairing the National Football League’s reputation for dirty play, gratuitous violence and neglect of player safety. To punish the New Orleans Saints for tolerating the payment of bounties to players for targeting and injuring opponents, Mr. Goodell suspended its head coach, Sean Payton, for a year without pay.

headline: In Hearings, Titanic’s Story Took Shape
text: On an April night 100 years ago, a ship of the Cunard lines called the R.M.S. Carpathia moved up the Hudson River in a ferocious rain, sailing past the line’s home berth at Pier 54, instead going north to Pier 59, near 18th Street.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: March 22, 2012

headline: Syrian Activists Say U.S. Journalist Is No Spy
text: Syrian activists in the city of Homs, who are struggling to draw attention to what they describe as a continued assault by forces loyal to President Bashar al-Assad on rebellious districts, took time out from that work on Thursday to issue a statement defending an American journalist accused of spying on them for the government.

headline: Hip Device Phaseout Followed F.D.A. Data Request
text: Johnson & Johnson executives decided in 2009 to phase out a hip implant and sell off its inventories for use in patients just weeks after the Food and Drug Administration asked the company in a letter for added safety data about the implant, administration documents and corporate records show.

headline: I Like Ike (and His Memorial)
text: Philadelphia

headline: In Shift, a Queens School Will Sell Land to the City
text: A financially troubled private school in Jackson Heights, Queens, has agreed to sell an athletic field to New York City rather than follow through on a controversial plan to sell it to a private developer.

headline: A Class Trip Meant Much to Mexico
text: MEXICO CITY — After weighing the risks of traveling to Mexico, the parents of one American teenager decided to allow her to join a school trip to Oaxaca, where students volunteered at an orphanage, visited archaeological sites and sipped vanilla milkshakes on the honey-colored town plaza.

headline: Inching Toward Energy Independence
text: The oil and gas industry is vastly increasing production, reversing two decades of decline. Michael Levi, an energy expert at the Council on Foreign Relations, discusses the trend.

headline: Wisconsin Misses in Final Seconds, and Orange Advance
text: BOSTON — As Syracuse streaked through its most unusual of seasons — winning games in bunches on the court and enduring explosive scandals off it — there was always a plan in place.

headline: A Glitzy Execution in a Religious Revival
text: Spoiler alert! Oh, just kidding. It will surely come as a surprise to no one that the title character in “Jesus Christ Superstar” does not come to a happy end, drifting blissfully into old age and obscurity on the sands of Judea. His gruesome death is depicted with unusually lavish flair in the director Des McAnuff’s flashy revival of the pop-rock musical by Tim Rice and Andrew Lloyd Webber that opened Thursday night at the Neil Simon Theater.

headline: Ice Cream Gobbler’s Woe
text: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — I knew I was going to like this puzzle as soon as I scrawled in BRAIN FREEZE in the northwest. It’s been used once before in the New York Times crossword, and as painful as it is, it’s such a fun entry that I’m surprised it’s not used more often.

headline: SAS Makes Its Bid to Democratize Data Analysis
text: SAS Institute, the world’s largest private software company, has built its lucrative business by being the pioneer of sophisticated data-analysis tools. SAS software, down to its own programming language, is used by most large corporations for things like detecting credit card fraud for banks and fine-tuning pricing for retailers.

headline: At Mayor’s Spring Dinner, Rivalry Is Served
text: They converged, one by one, on a nondescript Manhattan high-rise, stepping out of sport utility vehicles and hurrying in with briefcases: a quiet gathering of New York City government’s highest-ranking officials.

headline: Islam in the Melting Pot of Marseille
text: Why has Marseille been more peaceful than the rest of France? Is it a model of peaceful integration that could be repeated elsewhere?

headline: The Aftermath in Toulouse
text: Mohammed Merah, the man who claimed responsibility for killing three French soldiers, a rabbi and three young children at a Jewish school, was killed by French security forces on Thursday. But his murderous rampage is likely to fuel anxiety over the threat of homegrown terrorism.

headline: Does It Matter Whether God Exists?
text: Discussions of religion are typically about God. Atheists reject religion because they don’t believe in God; Jews, Christians and Muslims take belief in God as fundamental to their religious commitment. The philosopher John Gray, however, has recently been arguing that belief in God should have little or nothing to do with religion. He points out that in many cases — for instance, “polytheism, Hinduism and Buddhism, Daoism and Shinto, many strands of Judaism and some Christian and Muslim traditions” — belief is of little or no importance. Rather, “practice — ritual, meditation, a way of life — is what counts.” He goes on to say that “it’s only religious fundamentalists and ignorant rationalists who think the myths we live by are literal truths” and that “what we believe doesn’t in the end matter very much. What matters is how we live.”

headline: Seeking Out Tough Opposition, N.C. State Reaps the Rewards
text: ST. LOUIS — One of Mark Gottfried’s tasks after taking over as coach at North Carolina State involved overhauling the Wolfpack’s cupcake-laden nonconference schedule. Rather than wait a year, Gottfried convinced Athletic Director Debbie Yow to cancel a contract with Houston Baptist, a mid-major, and pull out of the eight-team Las Vegas Invitational, which featured four mid-majors.

headline: The Cardinals Keep Surging, Eliminating a No. 1 Seed
text: PHOENIX — Louisville, which lost in the first round of the N.C.A.A. tournament the last two seasons, which dropped consecutive games less than a month ago, which supposedly lacked the toughness or inside presence of Michigan State, won another game Thursday.

headline: Shooting Focuses Attention on a Program That Seeks to Avoid Guns
text: SANFORD, Fla. — Last August, Wendy Dorival got a call about setting up a local neighborhood watch. As the volunteer coordinator for the Police Department here, she gets such calls regularly, and the city already had at least 10 active watch groups. So she thought nothing of this call, from George Zimmerman.

headline: ‘Jesus Christ Superstar’
text: Scenes from the Broadway revival at the Neil Simon Theater.

headline: Angry at Pension Vote, Unions Plan to Skip Hispanic Event
text: ALBANY — It is a tradition of the annual spring conference for Hispanic legislators in the capital: a union-sponsored breakfast where lawmakers rub shoulders with labor leaders, whose endorsements are coveted come election season.

headline: In Cape Town, Apartheid’s Scars Run Deep
text: For countless foreign visitors, Cape Town symbolizes the beauty and promise of post-apartheid South Africa, a historic mix of races and cultures. But for many black South Africans, this city is the last bastion of white rule.

headline: Rise of Ohio Coach Fueled by Drive (and Coffee)
text: Ohio University Coach John Groce once drank nearly five cups of coffee a day. Sometimes, he would chase them with Mountain Dew. The caffeine binges ended a few years ago when he took a trip to the doctor because an eye began to twitch.

headline: Stronger Hand for Judges in the ‘Bazaar’ of Plea Deals
text: For years, the nation’s highest court has devoted the majority of its criminal justice efforts to ensuring that defendants get a fair day in court and a fair sentence once a trial is concluded. But in two decisions on Wednesday, the Supreme Court tacitly acknowledged that it has been enforcing an image of the system that is very different from the real, workaday world inhabited by prosecutors and defense lawyers across the country.

headline: N.C.A.A. Tournament Photo Replay: March 22
text: Michigan State lost to Louisville to became the first No. 1 seed knocked out of the tournament, and Syracuse survived a close game with Wisconsin.

headline: No. 15 Not a Jets Prime Number, but Pretty Close
text: In the team’s 52-year history, the most distinguished Jet (or Titan) to wear No. 15 was Babe Parilli, a backup quarterback to Joe Namath. Parilli was 38 and his years as a starter with the Boston Patriots were behind him. Parilli’s distinction will end when Tim Tebow, the Jets’ newest backup, puts on his No. 15 jersey.

headline: Three Plead Guilty to Hate Crimes in Killing of Black Man in Mississippi
text: ATLANTA — Federal hate-crime charges for the racially motivated murder of James C. Anderson in Jackson, Miss., were unsealed Thursday, leading to three guilty pleas from white men who admitted they used to drive into the city from a neighboring county determined to find blacks to assault.

headline: The Electoral Math of Romney’s Stance on Trade With China
text: WASHINGTON — Among all the elements of Mitt Romney’s 59-point economic plan, his vow to crack down on China’s trade policy would seem the most out of place.

headline: A Jayhawks Star Triumphs After Tragedy
text: ST. LOUIS — Summers for Kansas Coach Bill Self mean leisurely mornings. Usually he arrives at his Allen Fieldhouse office in Lawrence, between 9:30 and 10 a.m., to the sound of players dribbling and shooting on the adjacent practice court.

headline: Crisis in Toulouse Alters Campaign’s Tone in Sarkozy’s Favor
text: PARIS — With the candidate of the National Front, Marine Le Pen, calling for a “war on these fundamentalist political religious groups who are killing our children,” it was easy for President Nicolas Sarkozy to take the high road in the sharp political reaction to the terrorist acts of Mohammed Merah, who was killed by the police on Thursday in Toulouse after himself claiming responsibility for killing seven people.

headline: Murray Lender, Who Gave All America a Taste of Bagels, Dies at 81
text: Murray Lender, who with his brothers took over what started as their father’s bakery in a backyard garage and built it into a business that brought the bagel — the “Jewish English muffin,” as he called it — into kitchens across the country, frozen, died on Wednesday in Miami. He was 81.

headline: Ron Erhardt, Super Bowl-Winning Offensive Coach, Dies at 81
text: Ron Erhardt, who devised the offensive schemes for two Super Bowl championship teams with the Giants in the Bill Parcells era, died on Wednesday in Boca Raton, Fla. He was 81.

text: WASHINGTON — President Obama loves basketball, as everyone is reminded in March — especially in an election year in which he has been jumping through you-know-whats to assert as much.

headline: Valentine Fumes as Yankees Settle for Tie
text: FORT MYERS, Fla. — Before Thursday’s spring training game at Fenway South, Red Sox Manager Bobby Valentine and his Yankees counterpart, Joe Girardi, chatted amiably on the field. But things were not nearly as cordial after the game, and may not be going into the regular season.

headline: The Wildcat: Loosely Applied, Sparingly Used
text: Tim Tebow and the Broncos ran exactly zero Wildcat plays during the 2011 regular season.

headline: U.S. Rejects Environmental Reviews on Mortgages Linked to Drilling
text: WASHINGTON — Federal agriculture officials will not require an extensive environmental review before issuing mortgages to people who have leased their land for oil and gas drilling, according to a notice released by the Department of Agriculture this week.

headline: Tonino Guerra, Poetic Italian Screenwriter, Dies at 92
text: Tonino Guerra, a prolific Italian screenwriter and poet whose roster of film collaborators, including Michelangelo Antonioni, Federico Fellini, Andrei Tarkovsky and Theo Angelopoulos, amounted to a who’s who of European cinema’s golden age, died on Wednesday at his home in Santarcangelo di Romagna, in northern Italy near the Adriatic coast. He was 92.

headline: Joining the Winner’s Circle
text: AMES, Iowa — Cathy Krieger arrived at Hilton Coliseum here last Monday primed to yell and stomp her feet for her beloved Kentucky Wildcats. So did her mother, grandmother and aunt, all in Kentucky T-shirts, as well as two daughters of a neighbor. All eagerly shook the blue-and-white pompoms passed out by Kentucky’s cheerleaders.

headline: China: Vietnamese Fishermen Detained
text: China has detained 21 Vietnamese fishermen in the South China Sea, according to reports on Thursday that cited Vietnamese officials. An official from Quang Ngai Province, where the fishermen are from, told The Associated Press that they were detained on March 3 near the Paracel Islands, which are controlled by China’s military. Vietnam claims sovereignty over the islands, whose territory it once shared with China. The Vietnamese official said China was demanding $11,000 for the release of the fishermen. Tensions over the territorial disputes in the South China Sea have been rising in recent years.

headline: When the Ground Goes Bump in the Night
text: CLINTONVILLE, Wis. — It was a quiet night last Sunday when the sounds began, and some residents have barely slept since.

headline: Finally, Texas May Play Role in G.O.P. Race for President
text: Texas is usually flyover country in the battle for the Republican presidential nomination.

headline: Portugal: Strike Disrupts Transportation
text: The Lisbon subway and some of Portugal’s major rail and ferry routes were shut down Thursday as workers staged a strike to protest labor law changes and austerity cuts. The strike crippled parts of the transport network, but its impact was limited because a major union did not take part. The one-day strike was called by the largest labor confederation, which opposes an overhaul of labor legislation that will make it easier and cheaper for employers to lay off employees.

headline: Garcia Prefers to Stay With Yankees, but Would Consider Trade
text: TAMPA, Fla. — By rule, the Yankees are not allowed to trade Freddy Garcia before June 16 without his permission. But if the Yankees find a trade partner that suits Garcia — a team that offers him a chance to be in the starting rotation — then Garcia will probably give his approval.

headline: Player Has Promise and Plenty of Critics
text: ATLANTA — Baylor forward Quincy Acy leaned into the microphone and muttered, “It’s Bash Perry Day,” on the interview dais. The questions were coming at Baylor’s Perry Jones III about his erratic season, as if points were the only measure of a game: 22 points one night, 5 another. Why doesn’t he shoot more? Why the fluctuation in point totals? He was expected to be a superstar this season, but there were nights when he looked all reputation: 2-for-12 shooting at Missouri, 3 for 14 at Texas.

headline: Union College May Be Small, but It Has Extra-Large Dreams
text: BRIDGEPORT, Conn. — Playoff beards are also fashionable among college hockey players, except for those who play at Union College. The Dutchmen must shave before class each Monday morning, no matter the time of year.

headline: Redeeming a Life in Photography

Instead, she would have to endure the old slights, which hurt as much as ever, against her husband, Sid Grossman: That he was the Communist in the Photo League. That he cared more about politics than art. That his life was summed up more by what others said than by what he did.

headline: Pick a College. Reconsider. Repeat Until April 1.
text: April 1, the day high school seniors eagerly await, is fast approaching. This date signals the time when most seniors find out the admission decisions from all their colleges. Some may hear a few days earlier or later depending on the college, but for most seniors, this is the day to which the entire college process has led. In some respects, this day is the beginning of the most difficult part of the college process: the decision.
