headline: Fantasy Focus: Yes, Just Spring Statistics, But …
text: The general rule is to ignore almost all spring training stats, not only because the data sample is small but also because there is simply no way to know if an established player is tinkering with his mechanics or working on a new pitch. However, performance in March shouldn’t always be totally overlooked, as it can affect playing time for those battling for jobs, and it can clarify health matters. So while it’s probably safe to ignore Robinson Cano’s current .182/.222/.333 line and Roy Halladay’s 6.59 earned run average, here are a few players who are having terrific or extremely poor springs that may mean something in the regular season. (All statistics are current through Thursday.)

headline: Arab Institute in Paris Reopens  Exhibition Rooms With Lavish Displays
text: In years past, the exhibition halls of L’Institut du Monde Arabe in Paris looked a lot more forlorn than did its lovely, lacy Jean Nouvel-designed exterior. Last month, after closing for two years for a five-million-euro renovation, the institute reopened with refreshed galleries in which to display hundreds of works of art and artifacts as well as video and audio meant to bring the Arab-speaking world to life.

headline: How to Manage (and Avoid) Entitled Employees
text: Last week, I met a good friend and fellow small-business owner, George Elliman, for a drink. George is the publisher of an Austin, Tex., lifestyle magazine, Tribeza. When we get together, we always talk shop. This time, the subject of employees who have an overdeveloped sense of entitlement came up, and we quickly went from shooting the breeze and peeling beer labels to pleas of, “Don’t get me started!”

headline: Hello, Cruel World
text: The 1.7 million members of the Class of 2011 witnessed, within the four-year span of their college careers, one of the greatest bull markets in United States history and the worst economic crisis since the Great Depression. Last spring, they shed their caps and gowns and joined a kind of B.A. bread line. Unemployment among recent liberal-arts graduates, at 9.4 percent, was higher than the national average, and student-loan debt, at an average of nearly $25,000, had reached record levels. Worse still, the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics was reporting that only 5 of the 20 jobs projected to grow fastest over the coming decade would require a bachelor’s degree. Though the statistics still show that a college degree correlates with both higher income and lower unemployment in the long run, diplomas didn’t seem very valuable when they were handed out last May.

headline: Tebow, Manning and Pat Robertson
text: Steve Politi of The Star-Ledger makes a valiant try in arguing that people are overreacting about the impact of Tim Tebow’s arrival in New York, writing that “a lot of people not from around here” are telling us “how this experience is going to completely rock our world, as if this is some kind of distant sports outpost.”

headline: From Engineering Marvels, a Turnaround in U.S. Oil Output
text: As Eric Lipton and I write in The Times, oil production is increasing rapidly in the United States even as gasoline consumption is falling.

headline: Credit Suisse Cuts Chief Executive’s Pay in Half
text: LONDON – Brady W. Dougan, the chief executive of the Swiss financial giant Credit Suisse, experience a 54 percent cut in his compensation last year after the firm reported its first quarterly loss in three years.

headline: Fears About North Korea and Iran Will Dominate Nuclear Summit Meeting in Seoul
text: SEOUL, South Korea — President Obama will join the leaders of more than 50 countries here next week for a nuclear security summit meeting, where fears about two rogue states, North Korea and Iran, will loom over a gathering ostensibly about the perils of nuclear terrorism.

headline: The Parsis, Once India’s Curators, Now Shrug as History Rots
text: In the course of over one year of archival research in India, I have been heartened to see how, in a few institutions like the National Archives, the country’s rotting history now has a fighting chance of survival. However, I have been deeply dismayed by one observation: the inability of my own community, the Parsis, to properly protect our own history and heritage. In many ways, the Parsi experience reflects a colossal stumbling block toward proper historical preservation in India: a dearth of public activism, support and interest, even amongst the educated and affluent.

headline: Delivering Verse in Naughty Positions
text: Cheek by Jowl’s production of “’Tis Pity She’s a Whore” never seems to get out of bed. This is not to suggest that Declan Donnellan’s overheated, modern-dress interpretation of John Ford’s notorious 17th-century tragedy, which runs through March 31 at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, is in any way sleepy or sluggish.

headline: Etch A Sketch Highlights Missed Opportunities for Romney’s Rivals
text: I’m sympathetic to the notion that the news media’s coverage of the Etch A Sketch comments made by one of Mr. Romney’s top aides has been excessive. At the same time, the comments made by the adviser, Eric Fehrnstrom, will serve to remind voters of a major issue in the campaign: that Mr. Romney has substantially altered his positions on a wide range of issues since he ran for governor in Massachusetts in 2002.

headline: Are There Lessons in the Trayvon Martin Tragedy?
text: As the days go on, reaction has been building nationwide to the shooting death of Trayvon Martin, the unarmed 17-year-old who was killed by a self-anointed neighborhood watchdog in Sanford, Fla. Surely the case is playing out in classrooms and over dinner tables in New York City. So parents, teachers: what impact has the shooting had on you, and what lessons, if any, can be taught out of this unspeakable tragedy?

headline: Friday Reading: Getting to Know New Zealand on the Cheap
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: Daily Report: New Rules on Anti-Terror Data Mining
text: The Obama administration is moving to relax restrictions on how counterterrorism analysts may retrieve, store and search through data on Americans that was gathered for purposes other than national security threats, Charlie Savage reports on Friday in The New York Times.

headline: Entire Clans and Villages Fleeing Syria, Inquiry Finds
text: A United Nations commission on rights abuses in the Syria conflict offered grim new details on Friday of the government’s repression, including the uprooting of extended clans and villages forced to flee into neighboring countries by security forces bent on crushing armed resistance.

headline: China Moves to Stop Transplants of Organs After Executions
text: HONG KONG — China said on Friday that within three to five years it planned to end the practice of transplanting organs from executed prisoners, a step that would address what for decades has been one of the country’s most criticized human rights issues.

headline: France After, and in Spite of, Toulouse
text: Despite the failure of the French state to catch Mohammed Merah before his murderous rampage, the events of the last few weeks have nonetheless altered the tone of the French presidential campaign, tilting it, at least for now, in favor of Nicolas Sarkozy, the incumbent who has been trailing his main rival in the polls. Read Steven Erlanger’s analysis.

headline: After Palin, Expect a More Intense Vetting Process
text: Let’s say you’re moving steadily toward wrapping up the Republican presidential nomination and you allow yourself to begin thinking ahead to the question of a running mate.

headline: Bookshelf
text: The interior designer Marco Pasanella is now enjoying a robust second act as a vintner, but first he had to triple his mortgage, max out his credit cards and risk his marriage. He details his metamorphosis in a new memoir, “Uncorked” (Clarkson Potter, $24). File this under perfect pairings: The psychedelic dot enthusiast Yayoi Kusama illustrates a new edition of “Alice’s Adventures in Wonderland” (Penguin Global, $35). It appears at the same time as her big Tate Modern museum show, which moves to the Whitney in June. Mona Talbott’s “Zuppe” (The Little Book Room, $19) is as much a collection of inspiring Italian soup recipes — like puréed pea with mint — as it is a window into the eco-conscious, seasonal kitchen of the American Academy in Rome. And “The Uninvited Guests” (Harper, $25), a devilish comic novel by Sadie Jones, is set inside “a strange, shallow red-brick manor house” in “Downton Abbey”-era England.

headline: From Mourning to Electioneering
text: The Mohammed Merah siege is over. The French national of Algerian descent who  claimed responsibility for killing three French paratroopers, a rabbi and three Jewish school children died during a police raid yesterday. One immediate question now is how the rampage will play out in the upcoming French presidential elections.

headline: Fill-In | ‘Hunger Games’ Fan Mania
text: Directions: Fill in the blanks in this article from the New York Region section, “‘Hunger Games’ Brings Out Legions of Fans, and Inflatable Mattresses.”

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: G.M. Looks to Add a Little MTV, and Whitney Houston’s Death
text: It would once have been a slam-dunk assignment: getting young people excited to buy cars. Next, getting squirrels interested in acorns. But as a new generation of first-car buyers arrive on the scene, carmakers are seeing a significant lack of interest, Amy Chozick reports. General Motors has hired MTV Scratch, which consults on making brands more attractive to young people, to rethink the car buying and car driving experience, ranging from the test drive to the dashboard.

headline: What’s 4 + 4 + 4?
text: ISTANBUL — The answer is 12, the number of years that legislation now steamrolling its way through the Turkish Parliament would require children to spend in school. The law proposes to increase compulsory schooling by four years, up from eight grades.

headline: An Étoile Is Born
text: PARIS–In the best theatrical tradition, the leading lady was injured, the talented newcomer stepped in at the 11th hour, and, lo! a star was born. Quite literally so at the Opera Bastille Thursday night, where the Paris Opera Ballet director, Brigitte Lefèvre, came onstage at the end of the company’s performance of “La Bayadère” to announce that Ludmila Pagliero, who had just danced the role of Gamzatti, had been promoted to the coveted and elusive title of “étoile,” or “star.”

headline: ‘Old’ Anti-Semitism and ‘New’ in Europe

headline: On Our Radar: Polluted Rivers
text: The Ohio River ranks first among American waterways in toxic discharges from industry, followed by the Mississippi and the New River in Virginia and North Carolina, based on 2010 figures. Industrial facilities dumped 226 million pounds of toxic chemicals into American waterways that year, according to federal statistics. [Environment California]

headline: Leading Off: Shield Your Eyes, the Tournament Is Back On
text: If you were looking for beauty in this N.C.A.A. men’s tournament, you have clearly come to the wrong place. It is also notably lacking in buzzer-beaters, successful teams from west of the Mississippi and unless Ohio can topple North Carolina Friday night, mid-majors smiting the system. But if the tragic fashion trend in uniform design hasn’t been enough to make you cringe by the opening tip-off, many of the games themselves have taken on the qualify of getting a cavity filled without Novocaine.

headline: State Senate Race Spotlights a Feeble Democratic Party
text: Taken together, the Democratic Party of Brooklyn and Queens is the El Cid of city politics: Inside its impressive looking armor, there is barely a pulse.

headline: The Macro Wars Are Not Over
text: Noah Smith has a post on the current state of the macro controversy that’s justifiably getting a lot of attention.By and large I agree with his points: Keynesian revivalists like Brad DeLong and yours truly have not managed to get a dramatic reversal in policy, nor have we persuaded the freshwater side that it’s all wrong. But we have managed to change the conversation.

headline: Lay on Macduff, and Quaff Thee a Duff
text: THERE are a few Simpsonisms — Ned Flanders’s “okely-dokely” and, of course the famed “d’oh” — in Rick Miller’s “MacHomer,” a one-man show in which he puts Shakespeare’s words into the mouths of Homer, Marge and 50 other characters from “The Simpsons.” But Mr. Miller, a Canadian comedian and actor perhaps best known here as host of the short-lived hidden-camera TV show “Just for Laughs,” estimates that about 85 percent of the text is from the original.

headline: Who Wants to Operate With Power Tools?
text: As a physician assistant practicing in oncology for the last 30 years, I can speak to the competencies of nonphysician medical providers (physician assistants and nurse practitioners) who are able to cover many, if not most, of the challenges of everyday medicine. The cost of training these providers is a fraction of the time and money invested in physicians, and if programmatically applied in countries like Zambia could go a long way in meeting the challenges of health care provision. Rather than bemoaning the choices facing physicians like Dr. Kunj Desai, advocating for programs that could lessen the impact of whatever choice he makes is the only real choice that countries like Zambia can make.

headline: What Happened to the Girls in Le Roy
text: The stigma regarding mental illness continues to exist. The phrase “it’s all in their heads” is quite offensive to individuals whose illness is psychologically based — literally in their minds. Why do we find

headline: Why Talk Therapy Is on the Wane and Writing Workshops Are on the Rise
text: 1. In Which the Author Reveals a Scandalous Motive for Attending Grad School

headline: Rare Grooves, All Night Long
text: Another revival for Northern Soul.

headline: Who Made That Granola?
text: You can trace breakfast cereal back to gruel-eating ancient Greeks, but it wasn’t until the 19th century that the idea of eating cold cereal was embraced. In 1863, Dr. James Caleb Jackson, a health reformer who believed illness was rooted in the stomach, began experimenting with cold cereal to augment the mineral-spring treatments at his sanitarium in upstate New York. He baked graham flour into brittle cakes, which he then crumbled and baked again. It was not an immediate success; in fact, it was edible only when soaked in milk overnight. Even so, Jackson’s granula, as he called it, would soon have competition. It was not long before Dr. John Harvey Kellogg, a Michigan man with a sanitarium of his own, was also promoting a healthful cold cereal. Kellogg ran the Battle Creek Sanitarium, popular with luminaries like Amelia Earhart. He, too, was a digestive evangelist, and in the late 1870s or early ’80s, Kellogg combined wheat flour, oatmeal and cornmeal into a mixture that he also called granula. Jackson sued. Kellogg duly switched the “u” to an “o,” and by 1889, he was selling two tons of granola a week. Kellogg went on to invent the cereal flake, which led to the Kellogg’s cereal empire, which led to Froot Loops and Cocoa Krispies.

headline: You Can’t Ruffle Sandra Lee
text: For years you have pooh-poohed the notion that you’re the next Martha Stewart. But Kmart dropped Stewart’s Everyday line in 2009, and your Sandra by Sandra Lee home line is about to be introduced at both Kmart and Sears. Do you feel as if you’ve knocked a giant from the top of the mountain?  I’m the only personality that has Sears and Kmart. That’s not something that anyone in my category has been able to do. But I’m not arrogant that way. Martha’s not thrown off anywhere. Did she throw Julia Child off? Julia was Julia, Martha is Martha and I am me. Period.

headline: A Suitable Man
text: I wept when I read this fine story aloud to my wife. We are in our 60s, friends and lovers for 10 years and married for the past 18 months. We are deliriously happy together, not least because she enjoys my reading to her as much as I do. It is not trips to Paris but these little everyday moments that matter most and, as the essay shows, that remain available to the very end.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: The Wall Street Journal: He marshaled a national roll-out of specialty coffee drinks. He championed expanded menus and double-lane drive-throughs. He’s 48 years old. And he’s the first African-American chief executive of McDonald’s. His name is Don Thompson (above), and he’ll take over the chain’s 33,000 restaurants in 119 countries in June when the current leader, Jim Skinner, retires. (If you don’t subscribe to the Journal, check out the Chicago Tribune.) — Glenn Collins

headline: Forehead Lift
text: A slide show depicting forehead lifts.

headline: Divisions and Irritation in Food Co-op’s Debate
text: A graphic designer came to buy ingredients for dinner. So did an entrepreneur and a musician, an engineer and a law firm employee — all streaming into the Park Slope Food Co-op in Brooklyn for its bounty of organic produce, artisan cheese and fair-trade coffee.

headline: Equities Edge Higher as Iran Sanctions Raise Oil Prices
text: Stock prices rose modestly on Friday, trimming the second weekly drop so far this year for the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index, as gains in commodity and energy companies amid rising oil prices offset an unexpected decline in new-home sales.

headline: Floating in Time, Hiding in Sight
text: RECENTLY I met the Japanese jazz pianist Masabumi Kikuchi at a West Village restaurant about 10 blocks from the Chelsea apartment where he has lived for half his life. Mr. Kikuchi, 72, belongs in a line with the most aesthetically stubborn jazz musicians, those who sidestep traditional notions of technique and embody more than they express: Thelonious Monk, Miles Davis, Paul Bley, Paul Motian. Even among them he’s an extreme case.

headline: No Apologies
text: On our Op-Ed page yesterday Bill Maher called for an end to fake outrage  and “playacted hurt,” and asked Americans to stop apologizing.

headline: Chin Augmentation
text: A slide show explaining a surgical procedure to reshape or enhance the size of the chin.

headline: Paperback Row
text: THE ILLUMINATION,  by Kevin Brockmeier (Vintage Contemporaries, $15.) Human pain has been made literally visible in Brockmeier’s deeply felt novel: headaches and broken bones glow with an otherworldly light. In the aftermath of a fatal car accident, the narrative follows a journal of love notes, written by a husband to his wife, as it passes through the hands of a data analyst, a photographer, a schoolboy, a missionary, a writer and a street vendor.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: FLAGRANT CONDUCT: The Story of Lawrence v. Texas: How a Bedroom Arrest Decriminalized Gay Americans,  by Dale Carpenter (Norton, $29.95.) Carpenter stirringly describes the 2003 Supreme Court decision that overturned the Texas sodomy law.

headline: Up Front
text: William Saletan, Slate’s national correspondent, has written previously for the Book Review about the rights of embryos, the risks of genetic enhancement and the mysteries of human individuality. This week, assessing “The Righteous Mind,” by Jonathan Haidt, he approaches a topic of equal magnitude: Can the study of human nature explain our ethical convictions and remedy our political conflicts?

headline: Gardens of Unearthly Delights
text: At 65, the British scholar Marina Warner is a veteran magus, and an adept mythographer of the vast global traditions of magic, metaphor and myth. Also an accomplished novelist, she augments her learning with her narrative skills. As a fan of her prolific enterprise for the last ­quarter-century, I regret that I have never met her, so delightful is her verve.

headline: Seeing Is Unbelieving
text: Unless the pursuit of dreadfulness results in a tie, each year will possess its own worst book. But identifying the winner in this dubious competition poses difficulties. Surely even a well-read literary editor of The New Republic must wonder whether among all those inevitably unturned pages lurks something even more atrocious than his favorite candidate. How then could Leon Wieseltier select THE ATHEIST’S GUIDE TO REALITY: Enjoying Life Without Illusions (Norton, $25.95), by Alex Rosenberg, as the “worst book” of 2011?

headline: On the Origin of Everything
text: Lawrence M. Krauss, a well-known cosmologist and prolific popular-science writer, apparently means to announce to the world, in this new book, that the laws of quantum mechanics have in them the makings of a thoroughly scientific and adamantly secular explanation of why there is something rather than nothing. Period. Case closed. End of story. I kid you not. Look at the subtitle. Look at how Richard Dawkins sums it up in his afterword: “Even the last remaining trump card of the theologian, ‘Why is there something rather than nothing?,’ shrivels up before your eyes as you read these pages. If ‘On the Origin of Species’ was biology’s deadliest blow to super­naturalism, we may come to see ‘A Universe From Nothing’ as the equivalent from cosmology. The title means exactly what it says. And what it says is ­devastating.”

headline: Mar. 25 — 31
text: A FAMILY reunion of sorts is taking place at the Vineyard Theater, where the new musical “NOW. HERE. THIS.” opens this week. The gang that brought the world “[title of show],” the infectious and seriously self-referential musical with a similarly eccentric title, has reunited to create a show that promises to be just as idiosyncratic and as personal as their first.

headline: Fiction Chronicle
text: DOGMA By Lars Iyer.Melville House, paper, $14.95.

headline: Sealy Challenges Activist Investor
text: The Sealy Corporation is striking back against a top investor that is pushing to remake the board of the mattress maker.

headline: Prisoner of Fashion
text: The humor in this first novel is nothing to laugh at. Though you’re not really supposed to get that until you’re nearly done.

headline: Mall Rats
text: Nobody ever hated the contemporary world with as much intensity and conviction as J. G. Ballard. In five decades of unforgiving literary production, he drowned it, scorched it, flayed it with whirlwinds, deluged it with Martian sand, even transformed it into a crystalline jungle populated by jewel-skinned crocodiles, people and parrots. His characters have been sodomized in car crashes, driven crazy by scientific researchers, hounded by billboards and forced to observe atrocities looping endlessly on movie screens until even Zapruder’s exploding bullets seemed as mundane and predictable as elevator music. For Ballard, who died in 2009 at the age of 78, the true horrors of our collective future don’t concern what might happen hundreds of years from now in a spaceship; rather, they reverberate in the very ordinary now-ness of freeway overpasses, sports stadiums, high-rise apartment complexes and gated communities. In other words, don’t bother watching out for zombies or mutant beasts or whatever. The ones you really need to watch out for are those mall-walkers.

headline: Masters
text: Golf fans these days live in what amounts to a twilight era of one-man rule: that of Tiger Woods, still clinging to the throne even as usurpers rise up around him. Before Woods there was a duumvirate at the top of golf — Jack Nicklaus and Arnold Palmer — and before them there was the triumvirate of James Dodson’s new book: Sam Snead, Byron Nelson and Ben Hogan. More at the top is better, it turns out, or at least more interesting, and Dodson’s book evokes an era when golf was more vivid and less corporate than it seems now.

headline: The Sixth Ward
text: In 1845, Edgar Allan Poe’s poem “The Raven” appeared in The New York Mirror; the New York Knickerbockers organized themselves into an official baseball club; and the New York City Police Department was established. There’s nothing about Poe or the Knicks in Lyndsay Faye’s rollicking historical novel, THE GODS OF GOTHAM (Amy Einhorn/Putnam, $25.95), but she does offer a sensational account of what early police work was like for those untested and ill-trained “copper stars” who patrolled the city in 16-hour shifts, trying to keep members of the populace from robbing, swindling, thrashing, raping and murdering one another.

headline: I Was Wrong About Paul Ryan
text: No, I haven’t lost my mind. He’s still the same flim-flamming fiscal phony he always was.

headline: Compatibility Tests
text: Adam Levin’s new story collection, “Hot Pink,” is about how love — family love, romantic love, love between friends — turns us into people we never thought we’d become. Today you’re one person, tomorrow — enter love, and all bets are off. You could turn out to be anybody.

headline: A Wedding and a Funeral
text: A very good book is not only more satisfying, memorable and coherent than its lesser neighbors on the shelves. It’s also more relaxing to read. That wary inhalation as you take in the first lines — Will I believe in these characters? How distracted will I be by implausible dialogue, or forced plotlines? — lasts a page or two and then gives over to a long, slow breath of relief. You don’t have to worry. This writer knows exactly what she’s doing. She won’t let you down.

headline: Life and Limb
text: “There was a restless instinct in the family, an appetite for geography and change.” Presentiments like this come early and often in Peter Behrens’s otherwise impressive new novel, “The O’Briens,” which follows four generations of an Irish family from the wilds of Quebec at the turn of the 20th century through British Columbia, California, New York, Montreal, Europe and finally to Maine in the 1960s. The dominant figure is Joe O’Brien, who, while still an adolescent, supports the family by cutting and delivering firewood to his neighbors. His father has died in the Boer War, his mother is sickly and his younger siblings are dependent on him.

headline: Edison Illuminated
text: The tantalizing thing about electricity, that fundamental force that lights our nights and floods our nanocircuits, is that no one has ever been able to say just what it is. Easy enough to see and feel what it does — even taste it, as schoolboys do when they grab each other’s tongues and touch a battery. But when electricity isn’t going someplace, it has no color, no character.

headline: Why Won’t They Listen?
text: You’re smart. You’re liberal. You’re well informed. You think conservatives are narrow-minded. You can’t understand why working-class Americans vote Republican. You figure they’re being duped. You’re wrong.

headline: Inside the List
text: THE ICK FACTOR: For his academic research into morality, the psychologist Jonathan Haidt — his new book, “The Righteous Mind,” is at No. 6 on the hardcover nonfiction list — likes to ask the kind of hypothetical questions that are more commonly the province of seventh-grade slumber parties. Would you drink apple juice if you knew a sterilized cockroach had touched it? Would you sign a nonbinding contract to sell your soul? If you find your dog dead on the road, killed by a passing car, is it O.K. to carry it home and cook it up for dinner? Haidt’s book is a serious study of divergent moral viewpoints in politics and religion, but he obviously gets a kick out of confronting his subjects with the ick factor: “If you are not a liberal or libertarian Westerner,” he writes in his first chapter, “you probably think it’s wrong — morally wrong — for someone to have sex with a chicken carcass and then eat it.” Haidt doesn’t say where he comes down on the chicken question, but he did tell The Boston Globe recently that his book initially stemmed from a desire to advance liberal positions. “When I switched over into studying politics in 2004,” he said, “I did it expressly to help the Democrats beat the Republicans. I wanted to use moral psychology to help my team! But in the process of learning about all sides, and delving deeply into political psychology, I sort of lost the partisan fervor, and now I’m fascinated. That’s what I hope moral psychology can do for people — replace demonization with fascination.”

headline: U.S. Sergeant Charged With 17 Counts of Murder in Afghan Killings
text: Staff Sgt. Robert Bales was charged on Friday with 17 counts of premeditated murder and six counts of assault and attempted murder in connection with a March 11 attack on Afghan civilians, American forces in Afghanistan said.

headline: Obama Speaks Out on Trayvon Martin Killing
text: 1:20 p.m. | Updated President Obama spoke in highly personal terms on Friday about how the shooting in Florida of a 17-year-old black youth named Trayvon Martin had affected him, saying that “if I had a son, he’d look like Trayvon.”

headline: Learning to Worship Together in a Combined Parish
text: St. Augustine Church in the Bronx long sat atop a slight hill, like a beacon to the surrounding African-American community for whom it was home and haven. Today, the cavernous church is silent, closed down earlier this year after mounting costs and dwindling resources.

headline: How Much Is That Jersey in the Window?
text: Same formula, much better result.

headline: Assuming the Right Locks for the Part
text: FROM the first Shakespearean performer ever cast as Ophelia, wigs have been a necessary staple in the toolbox of props that aid an actor in assuming a character. They’ve allowed Elizabeth Taylor her austere and almost incomprehensibly silky Cleopatra hair, Cher her dowdiness and her dazzle in “Moonstruck,” and Steve Van Zandt a screen career that doesn’t require his E Street Band do-rag.

headline: Where the Avant-Garde Is Child’s Play
text: AT first glance the ensemble setting up in a fifth-floor classroom at the Kaufman Center on West 67th Street in Manhattan seems like any other student group and exactly what you would expect to find in a building that houses two music schools and Merkin Concert Hall. Teenage string and brass players tune their instruments and play fragments of pieces they are working on; saxophonists see to their reeds; percussionists contribute spiritedly to the din; and a guitarist and a bassist quietly pluck figures from the scores on their music stands.

headline: So, There Were These Three Storytellers
text: THE eight people in David Crabb’s Wednesday night class had been asked not to walk like themselves. So the students shuffled or pranced, puffed out their stomachs, clutched their backs. They all had their own gaits, and no one made eye contact.

headline: Online Show Wins Fans in High Places
text: THE moon morphs into a talking dog and implores a young man to kill his friend. A peyote-powered bachelor party goes majestically off the rails, leading to cross-dressing and cannibalism. An aspiring comedian in search of ever-stronger narcotics, bottles, then huffs the souls of the freshly dead in Hollywood.

headline: A Flamenco-Playing Sitar and an Asymmetrical Groove
text: Anoushka Shankar

headline: Wheelies: The $25,000 Question Edition
text: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: Ancient Hawaiians Caught More By Fishing Less
text: Centuries ago, Hawaiians caught three times more fish annually than scientists generally consider to be sustainable in modern times — and maintained this level of harvest for more than 400 years, researchers report in a new study in the journal Fish and Fisheries.

headline: Parental Quandary: Disciplining a Stranger’s Child
text: F. is a dad with a quandary — a social situation that’s bound to come up again. “The other day, my wife and I were in a restaurant with our three sons (ages 2, 3 and 7),” he writes. “This restaurant has an area designated for kids, with toys, TV, etc. Our sons were playing there and we were keeping an eye on them.”

headline: Book Review Podcast
text: This week, Jeanette Winterson discusses her new memoir; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; Jonathan Haidt talks about his new book, “The Righteous Mind”; Charles McGrath revisits a golden age of golf; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host.

headline: Friendly FRED
text: Joe Weisenthal has a very nice report about the wonderful FRED data website. I truly wish that Eurostat — an excellent source, which I’ve been using a lot — were a tenth as user-friendly.

headline: Police Commissioner Shares a Secret Recipe
text: In an annual City Hall tradition, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg invites the highest-ranking officials in his administration to a friendly bureaucrats’ night out. This year’s event took place last week at the Institute of Culinary Education in Manhattan, where New York City’s biggest municipal names prepared a three-course dinner of pasta, dessert, and an entree choice of char, chicken, or steak.

headline: Player Ratings: U.S. (6), Cuba (0)
text: Scoring a hat trick in an Olympic qualifier is a pretty big deal for a 21-year-old midfielder, but Joe Corona looked downright sheepish after his third goal flew past Odisnel Cooper and gave the United States a 6-0 victory over Cuba.

headline: Funny, You Don’t Look Fetish
text: Bryn Mawr, Pa.

headline: All-Access Hockey Broadcasts Spread to Campuses
text: In each of the last two seasons, HBO’s “24/7: Road to the N.H.L. Winter Classic” series has brought new viewers to the N.H.L., thanks to its storytelling, production values and access.

headline: Growth Spurts Considered
text: Kiernan Shipka, 12, plays Sally Draper on AMC’s “Mad Men,” which starts its fifth season on Sunday. She was born in Chicago and began acting professionally when she was 6. BEE-SHYUAN CHANG

headline: ‘If I Had a Son, He’d Look Like Trayvon,’ Obama Says
text: As my colleague Michael Shear reports, at the White House on Friday morning, President Obama briefly addressed the national uproar over the killing of Trayvon Martin, an unarmed African-American high school student who was shot by a neighborhood watch captain in Florida last month.

headline: Business Day Live | March 23, 2012
text: Edward Wyatt reports on the JOBS Act; columnist James. B. Stewart looks at Representative Paul Ryan's tax cut plan; and American energy production is on the rise.

headline: A Spelling Champ Whose E-U-O-N-Y-M Should Have Been 'Joy'
text: Rebecca Sealfon, the last New Yorker to win the National Spelling Bee, has some advice for the two winning New York students who will head to Washington for the finals in June.

headline: Preparing to Face a Shot Swatter
text: DES MOINES — As McNeese State of Louisiana prepared to face top-ranked Baylor and its 6-foot-8 center, Brittney Griner, in December, the Cowgirls had no way to simulate Griner’s height and reach on a basketball court. So their coach took a kayak paddle to practice.

headline: Weekend Fare
text: A barbecue contest called Grillin’ on the Bay and the Brooklyn Chili Smackdown is on Saturday from 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. at St. Mark School, East 18th Street (Avenue Z), in Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn. There will be barbecue for sale starting at 11 a.m. and the chili competition kicks off at 1 p.m. Guests can taste and judge for $10.

headline: World Bank Nominee … and Rap Star
text: As my colleague Annie Lowrey reported, the Obama administration announced its nomination for the next World Bank president: Jim Yong Kim.

headline: World Bank Pick Rapped at Dartmouth
text: President Obama’s pick to be the next leader of the World Bank, Jim Yong Kim, has a hidden talent: he raps.

headline: Shopping for Art in Hong Kong
text: Much can be learned about Chinese art at Hong Kong’s auctions, museums, galleries and shops.

headline: President Obama on Trayvon Martin Case
text: At a press conference in the Rose Garden Friday, President Obama was asked to comment on the killing of Trayvon Martin.

headline: Apps, Anyone? Managing Your Energy Consumption
text: Amid the debate in Washington over federal energy policy, at least one of the administration’s ideas seems to be gaining widespread support. On President Obama’s four-state tour to promote his “all of the above” energy agenda, nine of the country’s largest utility companies pledged to support the White House’s Green Button program by making information on energy usage available to their customers. The announcement came on Thursday during an event at Ohio State University where several of the utilities’ chief executives appeared with the president.

headline: The Haves Who Gave
text: Edith Minturn Stokes and Isaac Newton Phelps Stokes are best known today as the patrician subjects of this 1897 portrait by John Singer Sargent, which hangs in the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Banking and shipping heirs, Newton and Edith were at once wealthy globe-trotters and reform-minded New York liberals whose good deeds have endured even as the couple themselves drifted into obscurity. In a brisk, admiring dual biography, “Love, Fiercely” (Houghton Mifflin Harcourt, $26), Jean Zimmerman argues that theirs was perhaps “the greatest love story never told.”

headline: How the West Was Filled With Loss
text: FOR his 1948 “Fort Apache,” the first movie in his celebrated cavalry trilogy, John Ford brought together four of the five leading men most closely associated with his career: George O’Brien, the star of “The Iron Horse” (1924), Ford’s first major critical and commercial success; Victor McLaglen, whose 12 films with Ford include an Oscar-winning performance in “The Informer” (1935); Henry Fonda, the Tom Joad of Ford’s “Grapes of Wrath” (1940); and John Wayne, who first worked with Ford as a prop man and extra in the late 1920s but only became an A-list actor with Ford’s “Stagecoach” in 1939.

headline: Marquez Back and Red Bulls Back at Home
text: HARRISON, N.J. — With a flip of a switch on Friday, Rafael Marquez of the Red Bulls will ignite the tower lights at the Empire State Building in Manhattan in the team’s colors (red, white and blue) and at the same time hope to set alight the club’s foundering 2012 Major League Soccer season. The Red Bulls are off to an 0-2 start after two losses on the road, and they open at home Sunday afternoon against Colorado at Red Bull Arena.

headline: The View from St. Bonaventure: Ready for the Challenge of Notre Dame
text: During the N.C.A.A. tournament, The Quad will feature posts from reporters at newspapers on campuses of teams that have the potential to be the Cinderellas of 2012.

headline: India in One, Two or Three Weeks
text: THE connection between travel and a Coco Chanel dictum may not be that obvious. The French designer once purportedly said that a woman should stop before leaving the house, gaze in the mirror and then remove one piece of jewelry. The operative principle was to simplify.

headline: Off the Charts: Among the Best Presidents or the Worst, in Economic Terms
text: Measured by stock market performance since he entered office, President Obama’s administration has been among the most successful of the last hundred years. Measured by economic growth, it ranks near the bottom.

headline: Chamberlain Dislocates Ankle and Has Surgery
text: TAMPA, Fla. — Joba Chamberlain, the charismatic Yankees relief pitcher whose career has gone through a variety of peaks and valleys, sustained an ankle injury Thursday afternoon that required surgery, General Manager Brian Cashman said, casting in doubt his season, if not his career.

headline: After Stock Debut, BATS Pulls I.P.O.
text: 3:46 p.m. | Updated It should have been a day of celebration for BATS Global Markets.

headline: Russia to Ease Law on Forming Political Parties
text: MOSCOW — Responding to the outcry over disputed parliamentary elections in December and the huge street protests in Moscow that followed, Russian lawmakers on Friday unanimously approved legislation to make it easier to form and maintain new political parties.

headline: Mothers of Children With Autism Earn Less
text: Mothers of children with an autism spectrum disorder are less likely to be employed than mothers of children with no health limitations. They work seven hours less per week, on average, and they earn less: 35 percent less than mothers of children with another health limitation, and 56 percent less than the mothers of children with no health limitations.

headline: Judge a Tax Plan by Its Loopholes
text: Having touched the third rail of American politics last year — proposed cuts to entitlements like Medicare — and lived to fight another day, Representative Paul Ryan was back this week with a revised Republican budget proposal and another storm of criticism. His budget “slashes the safety net to pay for tax cuts mostly for wealthy Americans“(a column in The Washington Post); is one in which “the rich pay less in taxes than the unfairly low rates they pay now” (an editorial in The New York Times); and “would shower the wealthiest few Americans with an average tax cut of at least $150,000” (the White House).

headline: Book Review Podcast: Jeanette Winterson on the ‘Operatic Dimensions’ of Her Mother
text: In the New York Times Book Review, Kathryn Harrison reviews Jeanette Winterson’s wonderfully titled new memoir, “Why Be Happy When You Could Be Normal?” The book addresses Ms. Winterson’s difficult childhood with her troubled, abusive mother, a subject that also appeared in fictional form in her 1985 debut novel, “Oranges Are Not the Only Fruit.” Ms. Harrison writes:

headline: ‘If I Had a Son He’d Look Like Trayvon’
text: After President Obama spoke with Sandra Fluke, the Georgetown Law student that Rush Limbaugh called a “slut,” he explained his concern in personal terms. He said he reached out to Ms. Fluke because he had his two daughters in mind.

headline: Republicans Cry Foul on Obama Catchphrase
text: As taglines go, “All of the above” is not exactly phenomenal, lacking the sex appeal of its energy-policy sister, “Drill, baby, drill,” and the historic resonance of, say, “Where’s the beef?” It conjures a standardized test more than economic stimulus.

headline: From the Police Commissioner, a Mysterious Meatball
text: You could call it a police procedural: the favorite meatball recipe of New York City’s police commissioner, Raymond W. Kelly (right). But by Dining section standards, the thing is a bit short on procedure.

headline: Lawmakers Ask Apple App Makers About Privacy
text: Two members of Congress are pushing ahead with an investigation into privacy issues in Apple’s App Store. After contacting Apple earlier this month with questions about app privacy, the lawmakers have now sent letters to 34 app developers requesting information about their data-collection techniques.

headline: The View from Ohio University: The Focus Will Be on Speed
text: During the N.C.A.A. tournament, The Quad will feature posts from reporters at newspapers on campuses of teams that have the potential to be the Cinderellas of 2012.

headline: Public Theater Artistic Director Says ‘Our Audience Was Misled’ by  Daisey
text: Oskar Eustis, the artistic director of the Public Theater, has put more distance between the theater and the monologist Mike Daisey, who was found to have fabricated details in his one-man show “The Agony and the Ecstasy of Steve Jobs,” which just finished a hugely successful run at the Public.

headline: Landbrot, a German Bakery Times Two
text: A new German bakery, unlike any other in New York City, has its roots in Swabia, a region of Bavaria. Its name, Landbrot (which means country or farm bread), is that of its signature loaf, a round dark rye that is briefly baked a second time to bestow a distinctive heavy crust. The bread is one of about two dozen varieties baked on the second floor of the marble-sheathed shop, cafe and bar, which opens on April 1 in Greenwich Village.

headline: Wrestling Empire Joins Tag Teams With Studios
text: STAMFORD, Conn.

headline: Owner of Historical House Injured as Floor Gives Way
text: There was much to discover in the nooks and crannies of the massive Revolutionary War-era sandstone house on Staten Island. An October listing by the Gateway Arms Realty Corporation proclaimed the historical relevance of the Neville-Tysen house, named for a retired naval officer on land overlooking the Kill Van Kull.

headline: Steps Set for Livestock Antibiotic Ban
text: The Obama administration must warn drug makers that the government may soon ban agricultural uses of some popular antibiotics that many scientists say encourage the proliferation of dangerous infections and imperil public health, a federal magistrate judge ruled on Thursday.

headline: Arts Club’s Ex-President May Return, Judge Rules
text: Did somebody say reset button?

headline: What Stocks and G.D.P. Say About Obama’s Chances
text: AS the presidential election campaign heats up, two measures of the economic success of President Obama’s administration provide drastically different views of how he has done.

headline: Pope Arrives in Mexico, Lamenting Drug Violence
text: SILAO, Mexico — Pope Benedict XVI landed here Friday, starting his first trip to Spanish-speaking Latin America with a warm greeting from Mexico’s president, Felipe Calderón, and thousands of Roman Catholics from all over Mexico who waved flags, shouted and cheered at the mere sound of his approach.

headline: Biodiversity, and Green Slugs, in Action
text: Aliette Frank, a postdoctoral scholar at Royal Roads University, explores sustainable community development on the coast of British Columbia.

headline: A Midnight Bonanza for ‘The Hunger Games’
text: And the money came rolling in: “The Hunger Games” took in about $19.7 million at 12:01 a.m. shows on Friday — the highest midnight screenings total ever for a nonsequel, not accounting for inflation, according to Paul Dergarabedian, a box office analyst for Hollywood.com.

headline: Pengrowth Energy to Buy NAL Energy
text: OTTAWA — Pengrowth Energy, a producer of oil and natural gas, said Friday that it would acquire NAL Energy, a smaller competitor based in Calgary, Alberta, in an all-stock transaction valued at 1.3 billion Canadian dollars.

headline: A Times Sq. Ad for Greek Tourism, Financed by a ‘Crowd’
text: Greeks around the world, in an effort to help the beleaguered economy of Greece, have teamed up to buy digital advertising in Times Square that promotes Greek tourism.

headline: Guest Post | 10 Ways to Talk to Students About Sensitive Issues in the News
text: This week it might be the Trayvon Martin shooting, while last week it could have been the “Kony 2012″ viral video, the soldier in Afghanistan accused of massacring women and children, or the outcry over Rush Limbaugh’s criticism of Sandra Fluke: In a “flat” social media world, parents and teachers are no longer the gatekeepers, and news of all kinds reaches children — sometimes even before it gets to adults.

headline: TimesCast | March 23, 2012
text: A black teenager's death raises questions on on "Stand Your Ground" law | Dartmouth's president is nominated to lead the World Bank | President Obama projects an everyman image.

headline: Suspect Called French School Attack ‘Improvised,’ Spy Chief Says
text: TOULOUSE, France — The director of a French intelligence service said Friday that the confessed killer of seven who was slain after a 33-hour standoff with security services had “improvised” his attack on a Jewish school after failing to find a soldier to kill the same morning.

headline: Recession’s Lasting Effects
text: More grim ruminations on our economic prospects: What if recessions do permanent damage, diminishing a nation’s productive capacity?

headline: Forget the Plot. What Nail Polish Is She Wearing?
text: IT made me laugh. It made me cry. It made me buy lip gloss.

headline: Lead Producer of ‘Smash’ Is Said to Step Down
text: Executives at NBC are confirming reports that the playwright Theresa Rebeck, who is listed as the creator of the network’s Broadway-based drama “Smash,” has stepped down as the lead producer on the series.

headline: Business Day Live: The Energy Rush
text: Edward Wyatt reports on the JOBS Act; columnist James. B. Stewart looks at Representative Paul Ryan’s tax cut plan; and American energy production is on the rise.

headline: T Spring Design | Must Haves
text: Fresh color, floral pattern and subtle texture bring spring home. More…

headline: Recipes From the Cabbage Patch
text: Farmers’ markets have a reputation for being on the pricey side at times. But as Martha Rose Shulman points out in this week’s Recipes for Health, one vegetable that often presents a bargain is the cabbage.

headline: Before a Carousel’s 100th Birthday, a Visit From the Doctor
text: When Todd W. Goings travels from his home in Ohio to tend to his patients in New York City, he knows he faces a heavy lift. Many are centenarians, with creaky limbs, unsteady gaits and wan complexions. Some are missing their tails.

headline: Bulgari Family Tries to Become a Name in Wine
text: PALAZZONE, Italy — The Bulgari name has long been associated with luxury jewelry worn by some of the most famous celebrities in the world, like Elizabeth Taylor and Julianne Moore.

headline: Notre Dame Women Take Aim at Another Final Four
text: This is not the time for Notre Dame women’s basketball staff to worry about looking well-rested.

headline: Less of a Frenzy for Lin in Toronto This Time
text: TORONTO — Jeremy Lin’s last trip to Canada began with a standing-room-only news conference and ended with a standing-room-only news conference, with a game-winning 3-pointer in between.

headline: North Korean Orchestra Visit to United States Seems Unlikely
text: A small Atlanta aid organization that works mainly in North Korea wants to bring an orchestra from the isolated dictatorship to the United States, but comments from the State Department indicate that it won’t be happening soon.

headline: Jets’ Tebow Can Trace His Lineage to New Jersey
text: Tim Tebow arrives in New Jersey, where the Jets practice and play, as the world’s most famous backup quarterback. It is a homecoming, of sorts, centuries in the making, because Tebow appears to be the great-great-great-great-great-great-great-great-grandson of a man from Hackensack.

headline: Helping Small-Business Owners Find the Perfect Mentor
text: VICE ADM. EDWARD M. STRAW was a bit skeptical when he was asked to donate his time and expertise to a program that helps small-business owners. He had mentored students hoping to get into his alma mater, the Naval Academy, and service members on their way out of the military.

headline: A Shorebird, a Crab and a Call to Action
text: The red knot has begun its 9,300-mile migration from its wintering areas in the Patagonia and Tierra del Fuego regions of Argentina to its mating grounds in the Canadian Arctic. Like clockwork, the shorebird makes a crucial two-week stop each May in Delaware Bay; it is estimated that nearly 90 percent of the surviving Atlantic red knot population can be found there on a single May day.

headline: Arcade Fire and the World Bank
text: Not a connection you might have expected — and yes, there’s a bit of Kevin Bacon about it. But when I heard about the (inspired) choice of Jim Kim for the Bank’s presidency, I immediately saw it. Kim is a co-founder of Partners in Health, an organization profiled in Tracy Kidder’s Mountains Beyond Mountains. And the book in turn inspired an Arcade Fire song off their latest album (AF are big PIH supporters, and Regine Chassagne is of Haitian ancestry):

headline: Praise Is Fleeting, but Brickbats We Recall
text: MY sisters and I have often marveled that the stories we tell over and over about our childhood tend to focus on what went wrong. We talk about the time my older sister got her finger crushed by a train door on a trip in Scandinavia. We recount the time we almost missed the plane to Israel because my younger sister lost her stuffed animal in the airport terminal.

headline: Police Blotter Tweet of the Day
text: After earlier reports on social networks, Maryland’s Montgomery County Police Department confirmed on Friday that a caped crusader was indeed stopped by officers two days ago, for driving through the town of Silver Spring with a license plate on the rear of his vehicle that bore only the stylized logo of a bat.

headline: Elaborate Weddings, Minus the Guests
text: IT was minutes before the wedding, and the planner left nothing to chance. The reception hall, a plank-floored farmhouse in the Santa Barbara, Calif., wine country, had been decorated in peonies. The dinner menu, rendered in calligraphy, promised wild mushroom tortellini and halibut with verjus. In a field outside, a photographer and videographer stood at the ready, near a ceremonial canopy draped in velvet and the aisle strewn with guinea feathers.

headline: The Tennessee Monkey Bill
text: The Tennessee Senate approved legislation this week that some are calling a “monkey bill” — after the Scopes Monkey Trial, which also took place in Tennessee. In fairness to the state, it’s not quite that bad.

headline: Santorum Refines Comments About Obama and Romney
text: WEST MONROE, La. — Rick Santorum on Friday recalibrated a remark he made a day earlier suggesting that the United States would be just as well off re-electing President Obama as it would be electing Mitt Romney in November.

headline: Will Geithner or Paulson Occupy Dartmouth?
text: The news that Jim Yong Kim, the president of Dartmouth College, is the front-runner to run the World Bank raises a question: if Mr. Kim leaves Dartmouth, who will replace him?

headline: After Wisconsin’s Exit, Taylor Praises His Teammates
text: BOSTON — The Wisconsin Badgers’ season ended with a heartbreaking thud Thursday night once Jordan Taylor’s last-second heave fell short, but it began with outside expectations that made a a Round of 16 berth seem laughable.

headline: Marina Salye, Politician Who Tried to Prosecute Putin, Dies at 77
text: MOSCOW — Marina Salye, a Russian politician and former Soviet dissident who in the early 1990s led a thwarted inquiry into corruption in the office of Vladimir V. Putin, then a little-known deputy to the mayor of St. Petersburg, died on Wednesday in Ozero, Russia. She was 77.

headline: More Than a Throwaway
text: Unlike many companies, the Vermont yogurt maker Stonyfield Farm has made significant inroads in recycling through a partnership with Whole Foods.

headline: The Comeback and the Fall
text: A year after his return to racing, the legendary jockey Jacky Martin was paralyzed from the neck down after being thrown from his horse.

headline: When Booze Comes Off the Battlefield
text: Editors’ note: This post follows one on Thursday that discussed alcohol use and regulation in combat zones. Alcohol clearly looms large in the minds of some service members in the wake of the killing of Afghan civilians in the Panjwai district of Kandahar Province and accusations that the man accused in the shootings, Staff Sgt. Robert Bales had been drinking.

headline: The Most Dangerous Track
text: Labor Day weekend is the climax of the horseracing season at Ruidoso Downs in New Mexico. Last year, the weekend also underscored the dangers of horseracing in America.

headline: Seriously Retro: Some 78s for Record Store Day
text: Record Store Day, the annual retail promotion started in 2008 to help struggling independent record stores, has to a great degree been about the fetish of collecting vinyl records. If you’re interested in that Pavement or Big Star record available only on that day you better get in line early, because there may be 500 collectors ahead of you trying to get one of the 300 copies available (and then put it on eBay).

headline: Soccer Hooligans in Israel Bring Racist Chants to Shopping Mall
text: Updated | 7:42 p.m. Notorious for their racist chants at soccer matches, hooligan supporters of the Israeli team Beitar Jerusalem flooded a Jerusalem mall this week and beat up several Arab employees, Israeli media reported.

headline: Republican Hopefuls React to Trayvon Martin Killing
text: The Republican candidates for president on Friday condemned the shooting of an African-American teenager in Florida that occurred several weeks ago, calling it a tragedy that demanded further investigation.

headline: Companies Pick Up Used Packaging, and Recycling’s Cost
text: Brushing your teeth with a yogurt container? Wiping your mouth with a coffee cup?

headline: What an Early Spring Has Sown on City Streets
text: Spring weather usually tosses a lot of bad fashion trends onto the city’s sidewalks. But this year, with our strangely early spring, the journey between my house and Bergdorf’s is absolutely perilous. I worry — I do! — about those late-middle-aged women in super-high platforms and skinny J Brand jeans. A ballerina in toe shoes would have more contact with the pavement than these babes do.

headline: The Munchkins Are a Problem: There's No Place Like Home
text: All of the Dorothys, Scarecrows and even poppies have been cast. The fifth-grade's performers are officially in rehearsals for "The Wizard of Oz."  And the household of the amateur co-producer, Helene Stapinski, is in a tizzy. Her husband, she writes in the latest installment of her school musical saga, says she always loads too much on her "metaphorical life plate," then takes her frustration and exhaustion out on him. "“He has a point," she writes, "but I fight with him anyway. Because I always take it out on him."

headline: In India, Palaces, Markets and History
text: The plans you made at home when you were planning your trip to India are seldom the final word on the matter.

headline: No Need to Fear the Common Core Standards
text: One principal worried that implementing the new common core standards would place another burden on students and teachers, who already have to contend with Regents and A.P. exams and other standardized tests. But instead, the principal at Harry S. Truman High School in the Bronx has found that the new standards encourage ''teaching for understanding,'' which helps prepare students for all future learning.

headline: In the Philippines, Missoni’s First Condo
text: From Milan to Kuwait City to Dubai to Edinburgh, Italian luxury fashion houses have clearly conquered the hotel business. Now it seems condominiums might be their next avenue of expansion. This week, the polychromatic money machine Missoni released renderings for its very first residential project, a condominium tower in a $315 million master-planned community in the Philippines.

headline: Northern Soul, Revived Again
text: A short film by Elaine Constantine of a seventies dance craze to sixties music, brought to modern-day London.

headline: Gambling’s in the Air
text: In case further evidence is needed that ours is the Age of Gambling, a few recent random headlines help stack the deck some more:

headline: Gulf Dolphins Exposed to Oil Are Seriously Ill, Agency Says
text: Dolphins in Barataria Bay off Louisiana, which was hit hard by the BP oil spill in 2010, are seriously ill, and their ailments are probably related to toxic substances in the petroleum, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration suggested on Friday.

headline: Once Imperiled, U.S. Aid to Egypt Is Restored
text: WASHINGTON — An intense debate within the Obama administration over resuming military assistance to Egypt, which in the end was approved Friday by Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton, turned in part on a question that had nothing to do with democratic progress in Egypt but rather with American jobs at home.

headline: Spain Is Not Out of the Woods Yet
text: MADRID — Officials from Washington to Frankfurt have recently declared that the worst is over for the euro zone.

headline: Panel Extends Ethics Reviews of 2 House Members
text: WASHINGTON — The House Ethics Committee announced on Friday that it was extending its reviews of two members of Congress who have been accused in separate cases of improprieties involving their outside business interests.

headline: After Tragedy, a Fresh Start for IndyCar
text: On Sunday, the Izod IndyCar Series begins its 2012 season on the street circuit of St. Petersburg, Fla. The event will feature a redesigned car, renewed competition among engine suppliers and not a negligible measure of sorrow.

headline: Shrinking School Budgets Have Parents Filling the Gaps
text: Parents who are responding to a SchoolBook survey are ticking off their expenses: Overnight trips. After-school programs. School photos. And of course glue sticks and disinfecting wipes. To top it all off, many parents say, they are being asked for a "suggested" contribution to the school fund or to the PTA, or a donation to the school fund-raiser, which can run into thousands of dollars. What are you paying for? Respond to our survey.

headline: Sara Gartland and David Lomelí
text: WHEN an opera audience eagerly watches a young tenor excel as Alfredo, the conflicted young lover in “La Traviata,” its joy and exuberance can radiate through the sort of applause and cheers that rang in David Lomelí’s ears when he made his San Francisco Opera debut in the role in June 2009.

headline: Flying High Without the Wings
text: TESTED: 2012 Mercedes-Benz SLS AMG Roadster

headline: A Solid Luxury Option With a Lot of Options
text: EACH morning as the sun rises over Stuttgart, Mercedes-Benz executives must give thanks for the rise, fall, evolution and endurance of the S.U.V.

headline: Getting the Hang of This S.U.V. Thing
text: Today’s luxury S.U.V. buyers want comfort and safety, a combination that Mercedes-Benz is well suited to provide. With the ML350, the company does just that.

headline: TimesCast | Self-Defense Law Questioned
text: March 23, 2012 -  The controversial shooting of 17-year old Trayvon Martin raises questions about the 'Stand your Ground' defense law.

headline: Read This, or Be the Worst Parent Ever
text: When my wife was pregnant with our first child, I read every parenting and pregnancy book I could get my hands on. Then I panicked.

headline: For Boston College, the Focus Is on the First Round
text: Throughout the college hockey season, Slap Shot will feature reports about some of the country’s top-ranked teams.

headline: A Birthday Present: Accepted to the School of My Dreams
text: I received the good news on my birthday: The school I’ve been waiting for has finally accepted me. I will be attending San Diego State University in the fall. The stress is finally over! I can’t wait to officially become an Aztec.

headline: Wedding Bells Still Chime
text: If you believe marriage is in decline, think again. A new government report has found that 8 in 10 women will get married by the time they turn 40, a figure that is virtually unchanged from the 1990s, before the drop in middle-income jobs reduced the supply of marriageable men.

headline: Real ‘Mad Men’ Pitched Safety to Sell Volvos
text: THE fifth season of “Mad Men,” the acclaimed drama series that depicts the fiercely competitive world of Madison Avenue advertising in the 1960s, will begin Sunday night on the AMC cable channel.

headline: The Man Who Helped ‘Volvo’ Mean ‘Safe’
text: Volvo’s reputation for crash safety was solidified in its advertising from the 1960s to the ’80s under the direction of Ed McCabe, a co-founder of the agency Scali, McCabe, Sloves.

headline: In the N.C.A.A. Tournament, Baylor Is All Business
text: Krista Pirtle of The Lariat at Baylor University will file reports about the top-ranked Baylor Lady Bears throughout the season for The Quad.

headline: Spring Staples | Back to Flats
text: Seasons change and so must accessories.

headline: Auditioning for Real Chase Scenes
text: AS if the dispatcher had just barked out a “10-13” — the New York police radio code for an officer needing assistance — Capt. Anthony J. Raganella put the cruiser in gear and floored the accelerator. Seconds later, he was cornering hard. The tires were squealing.

headline: Readers’ Photos — My First Car
text: The attitude young people have toward cars is vastly different from a time when the car was at the center of youth culture. Take a look at a selection of photos sent by readers of their first cars.

headline: Drafting Tebow for Social Scene
text: IT didn’t take long. Within hours of the signing of Tim Tebow by the Jets, People magazine was already polling its readers about who was now the hottest Jets quarterback, Mark Sanchez, 25, or Mr. Tebow, 24 (as of Friday afternoon, Mr. Tebow had the clear lead), and Manhattan publicists were starting to strategize about how to attract the city’s newest sports star to their red carpet events.

headline: N.Y.U.’s 1997 National Title Team Is Still Doing Well
text: Fifteen years ago this week, Marsha Harris’s hands delivered a basketball through the net and made New York University history.

headline: TimesCast | Obama Courts 'Everyman' Vote
text: The Obama campaign has been polishing up the President’s ordinary-guy image.

headline: Variety Is Being Put Up for Sale
text: 7:12 p.m. | Updated Variety, the trade publication that has chronicled the entertainment industry for more than a century but has struggled financially in recent years, will be put up for sale, its parent company, Reed Business Information, said Friday.

headline: Time to Tune Up the Portfolio
text: So much of our financial lives requires regular maintenance — whether it’s updating who’s going to inherit what, checking that you’re not paying too much for car insurance or making sure your investments, particularly your retirements savings, are still working for you.

headline: Andalusia Looks Ready to Overturn Socialist Power
text: MADRID — The governing Popular Party of Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy seemed poised to extend its control over Spain on Sunday, when voters in Andalusia, the country’s most populated region, were expected to overturn three decades of Socialist Party dominance.

headline: Arrival of Pujols Brings Joy, and Risk, to Angels
text: Tempe, Ariz.

headline: Even Bigger in Japan | Tokyo Gets Its Own Dover Street Market
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: More Partners Leave Dewey & LeBoeuf
text: Six partners at Dewey & LeBoeuf resigned on Friday, the latest in a series of defections at the embattled New York law firm.

headline: A Program That Matches Mentor to Small Business
text: Paul Sullivan writes this week in his Wealth Matters column about a mentoring program that matches small-business owners with successful business people. The program, a joint venture of the Clinton Foundation and UBS, is one of dozens that aim to help small businesses. And some are more successful than others.

headline: The Predators of the Corporate Depths
text: “Sharks Before Drowning,” a dance by Molly Shanahan, opens and closes with the not-so-subtle sound — given the title — of lapping water. At the start, three dancers stand upstage, their outlines traced in shadow on the back wall. Inching forward, they assume the stances of nightclub singers, with gestures that include resting their hands on their hearts, pointing their fingers and reaching their arms imploringly.

headline: Graphic Books Best Sellers: Wolverine Leads X-Force on a Mission
text: When the title of a comic purposely evokes one of the most-beloved X-Men stories of all time, “The Dark Phoenix Saga,” it can lead to exceedingly high expectations and cynicism about whether those expectations will be met. “Uncanny X-Force, Vol. 4,” which contains the second half of “The Dark Angel Saga” and comes in at No. 7 on our hardcover graphic books best-seller list this week, does not have this problem. It’s a worthy successor to that classic tale in both execution and scope.

headline: Decency Battles Debauchery, as a King Takes on a God
text: As the many empty seats for the New York Philharmonic’s subscription concert at Avery Fisher Hall on Thursday evening clearly showed, conservative audiences often still shun unusual or contemporary repertory.

headline: A Smartphone Future? But Not Yet
text: THE occasion of taking out my cellphone has provoked considerable mockery in the last 18 months or so.

headline: Providers That Make It Easy to Rebalance Your Investment Portfolio
text: This week’s Your Money column examines the best approach to rebalancing your investment portfolio — in other words, reshuffling your investments back to their original mix to reduce your risks in the market.

headline: The Animals That Make Us Human
text: Temple Grandin, the extraordinary expert on animal behavior who wrote “Animals Make Us Human,” is remarkable in many ways — among them through her ability to surmount, and to some extent enlist, her autism in creating a career in livestock management, research and authorship.

headline: Heat Players Wear Hoodies as Statement in Martin Slaying
text: Miami Heat players have delved into an area athletes usually strenuously avoid, making a strong political statement in the outrage over the shooting death of the unarmed teen, Trayvon Martin, in Sanford, Fla. After the Heat posed together in hoodies, Dwyane Wade and LeBron James made quick work of publicizing the photo via their vast audience on Twitter. Wade also changed his Twitter photo to one of him in a hoodie.

headline: A Kitchen Garden Worth the Digging
text: Despite its bucolic title, the new issue of Country Living magazine contains some wonderfully graphic food pornography. Specifically, produce porn, in the form of a detailed feature on “The Ultimate American Kitchen Garden.”

headline: The Week in Pictures for March 23
text: Subjects include the St. Patrick’s Day Parade, a building collapse in Upper Manhattan and a City Hall photographer.

headline: Europe Moves to Phase 2 in Review of Universal Bid for EMI
text: The European Commission said Friday that it had moved into the second phase of its review of Universal’s $1.9 billion bid for the recorded-music division of EMI, a move that was expected but could still cause problems for the Universal Music Group.

headline: Israeli Officials Denounce U.N. Rights Council Bid to Study Effects of Settlements
text: JERUSALEM — Israeli officials on Friday rejected any prospect of cooperation with an inquiry called for a day earlier by the United Nations Human Rights Council into how Israeli settlements affect the rights of Palestinians.

headline: DealBook’s Week in Review: The Electric Car’s Future
text: We visited a financial crisis SWAT team in Athens, met some electric car owners and found out why Wall Street firms had such boring Twitter feeds. A look back on our reporting of the last week’s highs and lows in finance.

headline: A Democratic Embrace for ‘ObamaCare’
text: After two years, “ObamaCare” is an epithet no more. The Obama campaign says so.

headline: No-Fear Celery Root
text: Don’t know what to do with celery root? Melissa Clark shows you how to work with the aesthetically challenged root vegetable.

headline: From Exile to Everywhere
text: AT 8 p.m. on a rainy Tuesday last month, Salman Rushdie strode into Junoon, a Flatiron district restaurant where 90 people awaited his arrival, some sipping chamomile-infused vodka cocktails. Mr. Rushdie, the Indian-born British author, was the guest of honor at a dinner sponsored by Dom Pérignon and Booktrack, the maker of an app that synchronizes music to e-books.

headline: Fête Accompli | Wild for ‘Rewilding’
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Young, and Grappling With Black Identity
text: Since early February, Danspace Project has played host to the choreographer Ishmael Houston-Jones as a curator, with his revisiting of “Parallels,” the thoughtful and thought-provoking program he created 30 years ago to interrogate ideas surrounding black dance. The ghost of the 1982 “Parallels” has been marvelously present in this Platform series, with many of its original participants contributing to this iteration.

headline: A Program Matches Small Business Owners With Mentors
text: Paul Sullivan, who writes The Times’s Wealth Matters column, has written an article about a new mentorship program that was developed jointly by the Clinton Foundation and UBS that pairs small-business owners with successful business people. The column gives several examples of businesses that have received mentoring. If you have thoughts about the effectiveness of these kinds of programs, you can leave a comment on the Bucks blog.

headline: Gay Marriage Effort Attracts a Novel Group of Donors
text: LOS ANGELES — On a warm Friday afternoon three years ago, Rob Reiner, the director, arrived for lunch at the Beverly Hills estate of David Geffen, the entertainment mogul. Mr. Reiner and his political adviser, Chad H. Griffin, had spent six months drafting an ambitious legal campaign aimed at persuading the United States Supreme Court to establish a constitutional right of same-sex marriage.

headline: Mastering Celery Root
text: In this week’s video, I demonstrate how to master celery root. Once you’ve done that, here’s something you can make with it. Celery roots will soon be pushed to the sidelines as new spring vegetables start showing up in markets, so try this salad now. Or, save it for next winter when celery roots are pretty much all you can get.

headline: The Week’s Business News in Pictures
text: A new leader was nominated for the World Bank, the United States added tariffs to Chinese solar panels and Britain’s new budget maintained austerity measures.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Somalia and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Somalia, Tunisia, and Washington, D.C.

headline: After Hospitalization, Mental Trouble for Elderly Patients
text: Many older people fear that a hospital stay could leave them even more disabled than they were before. Unfortunately, there’s new reason to believe this fear is justified. Elderly patients who are hospitalized are at much higher risk of cognitive problems afterward, according to a study published on Wednesday in the journal Neurology.

headline: If ‘Forever’ Doesn’t Work Out: The Same-Sex Prenup
text: WHEN Ellen DeGeneres and Portia de Rossi were married in 2008, people wanted to know two things: What did they wear? And was there a prenup?

headline: Utah Asks U.S. to Return 20 Million Acres of Land
text: DENVER — The conservative political movement that has rallied behind the cry of states’ rights in recent years on fronts including immigration and health care is now focusing its energies on a much older question in the American West: public lands.

headline: A Lower-Cost Filling Solution for the Mercedes-Benz ML350 Bluetec
text: For Sunday’s Automobiles section, I review gas- and diesel-burning versions of the third-generation ML350, the midsize sport utility vehicle from Mercedes-Benz.

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, March 23
text: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, March 23
text: More Photographs

headline: Polenta Lasagna, Buoyed by Noodles
text: SOME dishes come together as easily on the plate as they do in my head. I envision something and cook it for dinner, and the resulting recipe more or less matches what I craved.

headline: History Carved Out of the Hills
text: SALT LAKE CITY — All museums are temples of sorts, monuments to collectors or cultures, declarations of identity, gathering places for tribute. But museums of natural history have an even more distinctive stature. Their focus is not human history, measured in centuries, but natural history, measured in eons. And their subject is not a particular culture and its accomplishments, but a world that seems to stand beyond culture altogether. Natural history museums seek their ground in the earth itself.

headline: The Road to Gardiner’s Store
text: On New Year’s Day, 1862, Col. George Crook led six companies of his 36th Ohio Infantry out of Summersville, Virginia — now West Virginia — and raced north into what one local paper, The Marietta Home News, called “the very heart of Africa.”

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Restaurants Hacked, and Employers Seeking Passwords
text: Here are some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web on Friday. There are more here.

headline: An Ordinary Bulb Turns Up the Wattage With Tarts
text: AS we wait impatiently for spring vegetables to arrive, it’s nice to remember that the all-season onion is standing by, like a good friend. Yes, the ordinary onion.

headline: Maastricht Art Fair Draws Well-Heeled Buyers
text: The sort of buyers one sees at the Maastricht art fair are not only gratified by their own monograms or cyphers, but also have titles and crests.

headline: New Details Emerge on MF Global, but No Smoking Gun
text: New details have emerged about MF Global’s chaotic final days and a critical transfer of customer money that has become a central focus in the wide-ranging federal investigation into the firm’s collapse.

headline: At the Maastricht Art Fair, a Flight to Beauty
text: Maastricht, the Netherlands

headline: Boy Bands Are Back, Wholesome or Sexy
text: When the boy band One Direction this week became the first British group to top the Billboard 200 chart with its debut album — a feat not even the Beatles or Coldplay could pull off — many music fans caught onto a trend that tech-savvy teenage girls have known about for months: Boy bands are hot again.

headline: Chic in Review | The Kate Moss Diet
text: All the fashion news of the week that’s fit to reprint.

headline: Santorum’s Catholicism Proves a Draw to Evangelicals
text: Carissa Wilson began paying attention to Rick Santorum last fall, when her high school class in American government was assigned to watch several of the Republican presidential debates. About three weeks ago, she attended a campaign speech that Mr. Santorum delivered at her school near Dayton, Ohio. The next day, March 6, Miss Wilson cast the first vote of her life, balloting for Mr. Santorum in the Ohio presidential primary.

headline: Yeasted Dough for a Rustic Tart
text: This week’s City Kitchen column focuses on an onion tart. Well, actually, there are two onion tarts. Both are based upon the classic Alsatian tarte flambée, which is a simple pizza-like treat. The topping is lightly stewed onions, flecked with smoked bacon and dabbed with crème fraîche. Though this kind of tart is delicious year-round, it is sometimes associated with cooler weather. So I also made a vegetarian onion tart that is somewhat lighter, with green olives, thyme and goat cheese. Long story short, each version was so good, it seemed a shame not to offer both. The recipe gives details for the slight differences between the two.

headline: Cage and Cunningham, Reunited, Restaged
text: It is 100 years since the composer John Cage was born, 20 since he died, and 70 since he began an enduring relationship, both artistic and personal, with the dancer-choreographer Merce Cunningham.
