In the years following Cage’s death, Cunningham (who died in 2009) made two new pieces that were accompanied by Cage music; he also made a few whose choreography suggested, with characteristic ambiguity, aspects of death, transcendence, different realms of existence.

headline: Niese Gives Up 4 Runs; Mets Happy
text: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla. — Jon Niese gave up two triples in the first inning of the Mets’ 9-4 loss to the Atlanta Braves on Friday afternoon.

headline: Syrian Activists Respond to Report on Rights Abuses by Armed Rebels
text: As my colleagues Rick Gladstone and Stephen Castle report, a United Nations inquiry commission on rights abuses in Syria offered grim new details on Friday of the continuing crackdown by forces loyal to President Bashar al-Assad.

headline: At the Co-op, Tofu, Kale and Cocoa Puffs
text: NEW HAVEN

headline: Excerpt: 'Ball Boys'
text: The ABS series explores the sports memorabilia business.

headline: Blends Stand Out at a Tasting
text: Richard Olsen-Harbich of Bedell Cellars, a Long Island winemaker since 1981, favors blends over single-grape wines. “An instrumental solo, while beautiful, cannot be as complex as chamber music,” he said in an e-mail.

headline: Blekko Works With Lavasoft on Spam-Free Search
text: The search engine Blekko is not content to be the underdog. It wants to be your guard dog too.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Pow
text: The award for the week’s best dressed goes not to any pedestrian, as stylish as the ones here were, but to Mother Nature.

headline: An Unfriendly Greeting at America’s Door
text: To the Editor:

headline: Neighbors Win Court Round Over Wind Farm Noise
text: A legal petition aimed at reinstating a state rule for limiting noise at a controversial wind farm in Maine can proceed, a judge ruled on Friday, denying a motion from the farm’s developer, Fox Islands Wind, for dismissal.

headline: A New Italian Spot, Quartered in History
text: ERIC LOMANDO has done it again. The talented, young chef-restaurateur, responsible for the success of Kitchen a Bistro and Kitchen a Trattoria, has added a rustic Italian spot in Miller Place to his collection: Orto.

headline: Week in Pictures for March 23
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include the St. Patrick’s Day Parade, a building collapse in Upper Manhattan and a City Hall photographer.

headline: Girardi Not Yet Rising to Red Sox’ Bait
text: TAMPA, Fla. — In an almost identical repeat of the minor flap that occurred earlier this spring, Yankees Manager Joe Girardi refused to respond to criticisms leveled on him and the team by Bobby Valentine, the new manager of the Boston Red Sox.

headline: Spring North American Championships
text: MEMPHIS — At the Spring North American Championships here on Wednesday, the Rockwell Mixed Pairs was won by Sheila Gabay of Newton, Mass., and Pat McDevitt of Brookline, Mass. They finished about half a board ahead of Bernace De Young of Miami and Richard Reitman of Los Gatos, Calif. Third were Les and Gloria Bart, a married couple from Bradenton, Fla.

headline: The Tournament Pays Off
text: ATLANTA — The N.C.A.A. tournament is a bonanza for conferences that can get multiple teams into it. Each game a university plays is worth $242,204 for six years. So each game is worth $1,453,224.

headline: In Arsène They Trust — Again
text: At roughly 2 p.m. on Feb. 26, a chant of “You don’t know what you’re doing” — aimed at Arsène Wenger — rang through the Emirates Stadium in London.

headline: For Ohio State’s Craft, Defensive Mind-Set Was Nurtured at Home
text: BOSTON — When watching Ohio State point guard Aaron Craft on the court, it is easy to imagine that he was born in a defensive position: feet apart, arms up, eyes watching for the slightest sign of movement.

headline: Sentencing for Juvenile Offenders
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Czech Ensemble Makes Its New York Debut With Sounds of Native Sons
text: At times you can believe, or at least hope, that classical music, after decades spent mainly in the splendid isolation of major institutions, is reintegrating itself into the fabric of New York’s cultural life. The club scene is thriving, with an emphasis on new music; early-music groups have added salon presentations to their rich activity in churches; and now significant international events are sprouting in unexpected, intimate locations.

headline: Art Has Legs
text: IT may seem an insignificant power spat in the small village of Sag Harbor, on Long Island. It isn’t. It is a quintessential example of a continuing, centuries-old battle over what can be deemed art, what can’t and who can rightfully judge the difference. I should say who among the living, for time has a way of sorting it all out.

headline: Maher’s Attacks on Women
text: To the Editor:

headline: With a Poison Tongue, Putting a Smile on a Nation’s Aging Faces
text: KOBE, Japan

headline: Syrians in the U.S. Are Given Protected Immigration Status
text: Homeland Security Secretary Janet Napolitano on Friday granted temporary immigration status to Syrians in the United States, sparing them from having to return home, in a new sign that Washington believes security conditions in Syria are going from bad to worse.

headline: With Tebow in Fold, Jets Trade Stanton to Colts
text: Drew Stanton’s tenure as Mark Sanchez’s backup lasted precisely one week, and it was a successful turn. He did not throw an incompletion or turn the ball over or create locker-room disharmony. For his troubles he received a nice consolation prize: a $500,000 signing bonus.

headline: Downtown Atmosphere Meets a Varied Menu
text: THE restaurant MK Valencia is one of those places that seem to be popping up all over northern New Jersey these days: a combination of upscale watering hole with happy-hour specials and $11 litchi martinis, and a serious, sleekly designed dining establishment that might have emigrated from Gansevoort Street in Manhattan.

headline: Chávez Strengthens Cuban Ties With Plan for Ice Cream Factory
text: CARACAS, Venezuela — Venezuela sends Cuba oil. Now Cuba will send Venezuela ice cream.

headline: The John Demjanjuk Case
text: To the Editor:

headline: Mets Sold! (But Check the Fine Print)
text: For a few minutes — O.K., a few seconds — the report of a new buyer for the Mets sounded plausible. Well, maybe not plausible. But worth checking out because, well, you never know. Last year, the Mets nearly sold one-third of the team to one rich guy, only to recently complete the sale of a big chunk of the franchise to a hodgepodge of rich guys, family members and business partners.

headline: Bohemian Hub for Entertainment, Still Unprotected
text: Connoisseurs of Greenwich Village may believe that it is a singular neighborhood that is well protected by landmark designations. But, in fact, preservationists say a vital piece in the Village jigsaw is still at risk — the raffish quarter of coffeehouses and nightclubs where Bob Dylan warbled, Lenny Bruce told off-color jokes, Allen Ginsberg tried out his poems and a variety of nonconformists and wannabes forged the nation’s avatar of bohemia.

headline: Greener in New York
text: To the Editor:

headline: State-Run Pension Plans?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Extravagant Cuisine, Without the Pretension
text: ON a recent visit to North Star, in Pound Ridge, looking to confirm that the two shining meals I had eaten there in late winter hadn’t been a fluke, I ordered an extravagant lobster dish that is a signature of the chef, Franz Fruhmann. Described on the menu as “meat from a 1 ½-pound butter-poached lobster, English pea tortellini, chorizo, glazed salsify, lobster beet sauce,” it left me with an even higher regard for Mr. Fruhmann, a native of Austria who has cooked at Lespinasse and Raoul’s, in Manhattan; at Blue Hill at Stone Barns, in Pocantico Hills; and at the Dressing Room, in Westport, Conn.

headline: Torre Returns to Commissioner’s Office Post
text: Joe Torre returned to the commissioner’s office as the executive vice president for baseball operations. He left in early January to be part of a group that tried to buy the Los Angeles Dodgers.

headline: Florida’s Disastrous Self-Defense Law
text: Manama, Bahrain

headline: Contractor Offers Explanation for Building Collapse in West Harlem
text: A contractor at the West Harlem site where a worker was killed on Thursday in a building collapse said Friday that an “unusual” condition in a structural beam was to blame.

headline: Court Reverses E.P.A. on Big Mining Project
text: WASHINGTON — In a sharp rebuke, a federal judge on Friday reversed a decision by the Environmental Protection Agency to revoke a critical permit for one of the nation’s largest mountaintop removal mining projects.

headline: Dog’s Life Is Upended After Murder of His Owner
text: Police officers from the Bronx crossed into Manhattan and drove to the animal shelter on 110th Street with a dog in a cage. It wore no tag. Workers at the shelter passed a scanner across the scruff of his thick neck, looking for a microchip. Nothing.

headline: Nimble Wordplay and Wink at History
text: There are two ways to approach “Travesties.” You can put your brain on red alert, sit up straight and listen intently to all of Tom Stoppard’s clever wordplay, spoken by and about Lenin, James Joyce, a Dadaist poet named Tzara and a few lesser-known figures. Or you can relax, sit back and allow the play to wash over you, appreciating the verbal gems that come through clearly and letting the others pass. I did a bit of both on the opening night of the McCarter Theater Center’s beautifully done (but still highly challenging) new production.

headline: 19th-Century Themes, Some Resonant Today
text: Stony Brook, N.Y.

headline: Who Doesn’t Love a List?
text: The ONLY SIX THINGS you need to know right now about the presidential race:

headline: St. John’s No Longer Has to Dream of California
text: FRESNO, Calif. — Da’Shena Stevens, a Connecticut snowbird, gazed lovingly at a long row of palm trees in front of the Save Mart Center here. Shenneika Smith, a daughter of Brooklyn, adored the sunny skies over her head and the lack of earthquakes going on under her feet.

headline: A Bizarre Outcome on Generic Drugs
text: Dozens of suits against drug companies have been dismissed in federal and state courts because of a decision by the Supreme Court last year that makes it virtually impossible to sue generic manufacturers for failing to provide adequate warning of a prescription drug’s dangers. This outrageous denial of a patient’s right to recover fair damages makes it imperative that Congress or the Food and Drug Administration fashion a remedy.

headline: Woods Shares the Lead; McDowell Is One Back
text: ORLANDO, Fla. — With 36 holes to play, Tiger Woods finds himself in a strange but familiar position at the Arnold Palmer Invitational. Woods shot a seven-under-par 65 on Friday, moving into a tie for the lead with Charlie Wi, who carded a 68, at 10-under 134.

headline: New Leader, Old Tactics
text: The Obama administration refrained from exulting over last month’s modest nuclear deal with North Korea for good reason. The North has a long history of provocations and violating commitments. But nobody expected the deal would be pushed to the verge of collapse in a mere 17 days.

headline: Readers’ Favorite Mini-Narratives
text: This is a follow-up to Tuesday’s column “The Sentence as a Miniature Narrative.”

headline: A Fast-Paced Stock Exchange Trips Over Itself
text: The stock market claimed an unlikely victim on Friday: one of its own.

headline: Sex Discrimination and Medical Leaves
text: In 2003, the Supreme Court held that state governments could be sued for violating their employees’ right to take time off for family emergencies, guaranteed in the Family and Medical Leave Act of 1993.

headline: A View of the 2012 American Crossword Puzzle Tournament
text: The 2012 American Crossword Puzzle Tournament is a wrap, but now you can enjoy selected moments from the tournament.

headline: Pieces of the Civil War With the Power to Unsettle
text: Two flags tell much of the story. One is the familiar stars and stripes, spangled with only 34 stars. It’s smudged with dirt and dotted with the bullet holes it acquired in 1863, when it flew over a Union ironclad trying to pierce the defenses of Charleston harbor. The second flag is in even worse shape: a shredded, grimy Confederate banner with holes a cannonball could pass through and several of its 11 stars missing one or more of their points. It was captured 150 years ago this month, when Union soldiers defeated a contingent of Confederates at New Bern, N.C.

headline: Now, Syracuse Guard Restricts Clashes to the Court
text: BOSTON — Everything should come easily for Syracuse guard Dion Waiters. His knack for scoring makes him a projected top 20 pick in the N.B.A. draft. His chiseled frame, with 4 percent body fat, looks genetically engineered to play professional basketball. Waiters has a blazing first step, an uncanny ability to make difficult shots and a confident aura on the court.

headline: An Ex-Housing Official Took $2.5 Million in Bribes
text: A former senior official of the New York City agency that helps build housing for people with moderate incomes pleaded guilty on Friday to accepting about $2.5 million in bribes and other benefits since 1998 — more than four times the $600,000 he was at first alleged to have accepted.

headline: For-Profit Education Scams
text: Attorneys general from more than 20 states have joined forces to investigate for-profit colleges that too often saddle students with crippling debt while furnishing them valueless degrees. The investigations have just begun. But it is already clear from testimony before a Senate committee that Congress must do more to rein in the schools and protect students.

headline: Could This Be the End of Health Care Reform?
text: What if the Supreme Court declares unconstitutional the Affordable Care Act’s requirement that everyone buy health insurance? What if it strikes down all the act’s insurance provisions, including the requirement that insurance companies cover everyone, regardless of pre-existing illnesses? Would this totally put an end to the health care reforms we have passed in the last three years?

headline: When a South Bronx Collective Went International
text: PURCHASE, N.Y.

headline: Private Comey Steals Away to Battle
text: A feeling of impending victory swept over the Union forces assembled in Virginia’s Shenandoah Valley, on the outskirts of the hamlet of Kernstown, on Sunday morning, March 23, 1862. Stonewall Jackson and his rebels would be whipped on their home turf in Virginia, and the war would soon be over!

headline: Corrections: March 24
text: NATIONAL

headline: To Clear Space, a Pit Orchestra in the Basement
text: The latest experiment in New York theater is taking place in a tiny, L-shaped third-floor room with water-stained ceilings and dirty gray carpeting that served for decades as a dumping ground for old props. At 8:05 p.m. on a recent Saturday, seven musicians, squeezed nearly knee to knee there in the Lucille Lortel Theater, struck the opening chords to the musical “Carrie,” as the actors stepped onstage two floors below.

headline: A Coaching Reunion That Neither One Wanted
text: PHOENIX — The police pulled over the bus that carried the Providence basketball team from New York City to Rhode Island on March 8, 1987, and asked Coach Rick Pitino and his wife to step outside. They walked to a nearby pay phone, shaken, scared.

headline: Call Me Ehsaan
text: A look at the war in Afghanistan through the eyes of Lt. Col. John Darin Loftis, one of the U.S. Air Force’s prized experts in Afghan language and culture, who was killed in Kabul on Feb. 25, 2012.

headline: The Joys of Couch Time
text: The pop singer-songwriter Ingrid Michaelson’s latest release, “Human Again,” made its debut at No. 5 on the Billboard charts. As a fortuitous bit of executive-level preparation for her coming 28-date tour, she performed this month at the fund-raiser for President Obama hosted by Deepak Chopra and Russell Simmons at ABC Kitchen in Manhattan. Ms. Michaelson, 32, a native of Staten Island, lives in Prospect Heights, Brooklyn, with her husband and fellow musician, Greg Laswell, 37, and their Border terrier, Shep Proudfoot (named for the addled character in “Fargo”). Her tour concludes at Terminal 5 in Manhattan on May 17.

headline: Ex-Goldman Worker Said to Seek Book Deal
text: Greg Smith, the former Goldman Sachs executive who resigned in spectacular fashion last week by blasting the firm in an Op-Ed page article in The New York Times, is now shopping a book proposal to major publishers in New York, several people with knowledge of the conversations said.

headline: Leaders of Mali’s Military Coup Seem to Have Uncertain Grasp on Power
text: DAKAR, Senegal — Mali’s military coup leaders struggled on three fronts Friday, as international condemnation mounted, an insurrection by nomadic tribesmen in the north gained ground and the junta was forced to condemn looting by its own troops in the capital, Bamako.

headline: A Personal Note as Obama Speaks on Death of Boy
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama did not mention race even as he addressed it on Friday, instead letting his person and his words say it all: “If I had a son, he’d look like Trayvon.”

headline: Razzamatazz
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — Gorgeous. Fun, tough and clean. The very definition of what a Saturday crossword puzzle should be. Or maybe I’ve finally recuperated from the A.C.P.T. and am in an exceptionally good mood. But I think it’s the puzzle.

headline: ‘Call Me Ehsaan’
text: “Call Me Ehsaan” is a look at the United States war in Afghanistan through the eyes of Lt. Col. John Darin Loftis, who was killed in February while working at the Ministry of Interior in Kabul. I met Colonel Loftis when he was a public information officer attached to the provincial reconstruction team in Zabul Province in 2010. He told me he was one of only three Pashto speakers in the United States Air Force. He was deeply interested in the Afghan people and their culture, learning the poetry of Rahman Baba and reciting it at a poetry reading in Zabul. His Afghan name was Ehsaan, a name he picked out of a hat, which has been translated variously as “to owe someone a favor” or “beholden under obligation.”

headline: Inconsistent Florida Is Consistent in Tournament
text: PHOENIX — Florida is perhaps the most confounding team remaining in the N.C.A.A. tournament. To that end, the Gators have been asked about their inconsistency dozens of times, a consistent line of questioning, including Friday.

headline: For Baylor Big Man, an Effort Even Brighter Than His Uniform
text: ATLANTA — Baylor walked on the floor Friday night in uniforms that looked as if they required batteries. They were a loud lime green, but they were still not as loud as the dunks and message sent by the Bears’ Quincy Acy.

headline: Traded for M&Ms, Only on Twitter
text: OVER one long day, he was celebrated, mocked, untraded, lamented, traded again in a Twitter hoax, hailed briefly by the city of Jacksonville, Fla., traded again for real and — at long last, late on Wednesday — the Denver Broncos’ Tim Tebow was welcomed to the woebegone New York Jets.

headline: Standing Up to the N.C.A.A.
text: Over the past few months, I have used this column to explore the various injustices perpetrated by the N.C.A.A. I have written about the way it terrorizes the parents of athletes it is investigating — athletes, I should note, who are invariably suspended before they are even told the charges against them. I have questioned the N.C.A.A.’s lack of due process and its indifference to the most rudimentary concepts of fairness. I have pointed out that its rules enforcing amateurism discriminate against black athletes from disadvantaged backgrounds.

headline: Chamberlain Hurts Ankle, Jeopardizing His Career
text: TAMPA, Fla. — When Joba Chamberlain came on the scene in electric fashion in the second half of the 2007 season, the Yankees were so protective of his health that they devised the so-called Joba Rules, a set of guidelines intended to maximize his talent while avoiding the dangers of throwing too many pitches.

headline: Want a Cab? He Owns the Keys
text: MOST mornings at 3:45, Stanley Wissak, 84, leaves his Sutton Place apartment on the East Side of Manhattan and drives across the Queensboro Bridge in his Mercedes-Benz sedan with a license plate that reads, “OFFDUTE.”

headline: First Loss for Woodson as Toronto Halts Knicks’ Streak
text: TORONTO — For eight days, across five games and three cities, the Knicks scrambled and scrapped, chasing after their own lost identity in the wake of a debilitating losing streak and the stunning resignation of their coach.

headline: Friends With Yogi, and Other Tales
text: JUST in time for opening day, Harvey Araton, a sports reporter for The New York Times, recalls the enduring friendship between the Yankees’ Yogi Berra and Ron Guidry.

headline: On the Right, Santorum Has Women’s Vote
text: MANDEVILLE, La. — Rick Santorum was running late, and about 250 people were growing restless at a rally sponsored by the Tea Party. So the Harris sisters, a country singing duo, took the stage.

headline: Uproar Over Shooting of Teenager Spreads Online and in the Streets
text: Updated | Saturday | 11:35 a.m. LeBron James joined the online protest over the fatal shooting of 17-year-old Trayvon Martin in Florida when he uploaded a photo onto Twitter of himself and other members of the Miami Heat wearing hoodies on Friday.

headline: I’m Just Walkin’
text: Matt Green is determined to walk every street in all five boroughs of New York City. The distance is around 8,000 miles and is expected to take him over two years to complete.

headline: After a Scare, North Carolina Prevails in Overtime
text: ST. LOUIS — The frantic finish and the subsequent overtime left North Carolina drained of emotion, joy, even a sense of accomplishment. Center Tyler Zeller, after one of the most dominant performances by a big man in Tar Heels history, refused to savor North Carolina’s 73-65 victory over Ohio on Friday in a Midwest Regional semifinal, because he knew how close his team had come to losing.

headline: After Unity Over a Rampage in France, Politics Drives In Wedges
text: TOULOUSE, France — Shock and solidarity gave way to political recrimination and criticism here on Friday, one day after the police killed a 23-year-old self-proclaimed jihadist, as government officials were put on the defensive about whether intelligence failures cost his seven victims their lives.

headline: The Out-of-View Orchestras of ‘Carrie’ and ‘Spider-Man’
text: Musicians play not from a pit but from a third-floor office space and a basement.

headline: Al Ross, Cartoonist for The New Yorker, Dies at 100
text: Al Ross, whose droll cartoons featuring married couples, bar habitués, anthropomorphic animals, philosophizing prisoners, art and publishing world denizens, anachronistic mythological figures and loyal Mets fans appeared in The New Yorker for more than 60 years, died on Thursday in the Bronx. He was 100.

headline: Leaving His Footprints on the City
text: IN 2010, Matt Green, 31, a former civil engineer, walked across the United States from Rockaway Beach, Queens, to Rockaway Beach, Ore. The journey took five months, during which he averaged 20 miles a day, pitched his tent on front lawns and wore through three pairs of Timberland Chocorua Trail boots.

headline: African Union to Make Push Against Rebels
text: KAMPALA, Uganda — The African Union announced Friday that it would launch a new regional military operation against the Lord’s Resistance Army, the vicious Ugandan rebel group that has been terrorizing parts of central Africa for more than 20 years.

headline: Abdullahi Yusuf Ahmed, Former Somali Strongman, Dies at 77
text: MOGADISHU, Somalia — Abdullahi Yusuf Ahmed, a cantankerous former warlord who led Somalia’s beleaguered transitional government as president from 2004 to 2008 and was forced to resign as the country sank deeper into chaos, died on Friday in Abu Dhabi. He was 77. The cause was complications of pneumonia, his family said. Mr. Yusuf, who was granted asylum in Yemen after he stepped down, had gone to Abu Dhabi for treatment, government officials said. He had undergone a liver transplant in 1996.

headline: Rangers Are Overwhelmed by Sabres’ Rushes
text: Enduring a night of watching his team repeatedly outnumbered on the rush can take the smile off even one of the league’s most jovial goaltenders. After the Rangers lost to the Sabres, 4-1, Friday night, the usually bright-eyed Henrik Lundqvist was dour in the quiet of the home team locker room at Madison Square Garden.

headline: David L. Waltz, Computer Science Pioneer, Dies at 68
text: David L. Waltz, a computer scientist whose early research in information retrieval provided the foundation for today’s Internet search engines, died on Thursday in Princeton, N.J. He was 68.

headline: Russia: Police Begin Investigation of a Restyled Political Activist
text: The Moscow police on Friday opened a criminal case against Kseniya Sobchak, a television star, after her altercation with a journalist this month. Ms. Sobchak is accused of destroying the journalist’s camera and taking a flash drive, a police spokesman said. Ms. Sobchak, whose family is close to Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin, made waves last year when she spoke at antigovernment rallies. She has attracted attention from a pro-Kremlin Web site, Lifenews.ru, which has run exposés of protest leaders. From Miami, where she is traveling, Ms. Sobchak said she would sue the Web site’s owner for disseminating misinformation. “It is unfortunate that I live in a country of absurdity and lies,” she wrote.

headline: John Payton, Lawyer Who Fought for Civil Rights, Dies at 65
text: John Payton, who as president of the NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund guided it to several major victories before the Supreme Court, died on Thursday in Baltimore. He was 65 and lived in Washington.

headline: Officer in Bell Killing Is Fired; 3 Others to Be Forced Out
text: The New York City police detective who fired the first shots in the 50-bullet barrage that killed Sean Bell in 2006 has been fired, and three others involved in the shooting are being forced to resign, law enforcement officials said on Friday.

headline: The Liberator of Dead Dog Beach
text: Christina Beckles, who lives in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, is the founder of the Sato Project, a rescue organization that brings abandoned and abused dogs to the continental United States from Puerto Rico.

headline: Albuquerque Mayor Urges Police Union to Stop Payments to Officers in Shootings
text: The mayor of Albuquerque called Friday for an end to a police union practice of paying officers involved in fatal shootings as much as $500 — a program that critics have compared to a bounty system that promotes and legitimizes brutality.

headline: The Formerly Routine Is Now the Tendentious
text: WASHINGTON — Some things that Congress does are meant to be difficult: budgets, tax law changes, the health care overhaul, the undoing of the health care overhaul.

headline: N.C.A.A. Tournament Photo Replay: March 23
text: North Carolina survived an upset scare from Ohio in overtime, and Baylor outlasted Xavier with dominant play from its big men.

headline: Santorum on Defensive Over Remark on Romney
text: WEST MONROE, La. — Rick Santorum on Friday recalibrated a remark he made a day earlier suggesting that the United States would be just as well off re-electing President Obama as it would be electing Mitt Romney in November.

headline: Operation Paws
text: ON a Sunday morning in March, the cavernous arrival hall at Terminal 8 at Kennedy International Airport was virtually deserted save for a cluster of people wearing white T-shirts with black “Sato Project” logos huddled near the cargo entrance. But when American Airlines Flight 648 from San Juan, P.R., touched down and a small, tanned woman wearing a white fedora and blue sweat pants emerged, the group snapped to attention. Christina Beckles, 39, a former Golden Gloves boxing champion and the founder of the Sato Project, a rescue organization that brings abandoned and abused dogs to the continental United States from Puerto Rico, had just landed with 17 animals in tow.

headline: Man Hit by Train in Brooklyn After Fight Spills Onto Tracks
text: A man was seriously injured late Friday night when he was hit by a train in Brooklyn after an apparent tussle that sent him and another man tumbling onto the subway tracks, the authorities said.

headline: Not-So-‘Mad’ Ideas About Taxes
text: This month, the Roosevelt Hotel, on East 45th Street, initiated a special offer in commemoration of “Mad Men,” whose return to television on Sunday night for a fifth season is something surely known now even to preschoolers of merely middling sophistication. For $495 a night, guests at the Roosevelt receive a room, a DVD of the fourth season of “Mad Men,” a “Mad Men” cookbook and period cocktails — the period, of course, being 1960s New York, when, in the show’s imagination, any Scotch consumed after 10 a.m. betrayed a restrained and focused temperament. (I didn’t call the hotel to learn how many drinks were included in the price for fear that any answer short of “unlimited” would have compelled me to accuse management of purveying historical falsehoods.)

headline: Top-Seeded Wildcats Use Talented Cast to End Hoosiers’ Run
text: ATLANTA — No. 1 Kentucky did not survive Friday night solely with their usual play above the rim or bursts of speed and shot-making. The Wildcats showcased their talent in as calm a place as can be found inside a Dome with 24,731 feverish fans: at the free-throw line.

headline: Events in Westchester
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: Events in New Jersey
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Events on Long Island
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: Events in Connecticut
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: On a Special Night, Coming of Age
text: Rebecca Greenfield, 36, began photographing quinceañeras three years ago, documenting the elaborate festivities celebrating budding womanhood.

headline: Implications Are Far-Reaching in States’ Challenge of Federal Health Care Law
text: WASHINGTON — A major issue in the Supreme Court battle over the new health care law is whether Congress can force states to make a huge expansion of Medicaid, to add millions of low-income people to the rolls.

headline: Neighbors Join in Modest Efforts to Embrace Abandoned Properties
text: SOUTH BEND, Ind. — When the grand Queen Anne on Portage Avenue lost its last occupants a few years ago, plunging into foreclosure and abandonment, the century-old gem risked the same fate as hundreds of empty houses here: collapse or demolition. Either way, what had been a lumber baron’s masterpiece was bound to become just another forgotten lot on the Rust Belt.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: March 23, 2012

headline: Kim Jong-un May See Rise in His Power
text: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea said Saturday that its Parliament would convene on April 13 for a session that should give the country’s new leader, Kim Jong-un, an opportunity to further consolidate his grip on power.

headline: Nothing’s the Matter With Kansas
text: ST. LOUIS — For the first few minutes Friday night, Kansas’s Midwest Regional semifinal with North Carolina State suspiciously resembled its third-round tussle with Purdue. The Wolfpack, like the Boilermakers, jumped out to an early lead and made the second-seeded Jayhawks sweat right to the finish.

headline: Restoring South Bend
text: Neighbors in Indiana put free labor and their own money into revitalizing the shabby and historic homes left for dead in their small town.

headline: Union Calls on Speaker Silver to Save the Teacher Centers
text: New York City's teachers' union is calling on state lawmakers to restore money for teacher centers, which function as the training and development arm of some city schools. Although the program received $20.4 million last year, discussion of its future has been absent from this spring's budget negotiations.

headline: Raising the Bar for Vetting a No. 2
text: WASHINGTON — Let’s say you’re moving steadily toward wrapping up the Republican presidential nomination and you allow yourself to begin thinking ahead to the question of a running mate.

headline: A Lawyer Who Can Simplify the Complex Draws a Big One: Obama’s Health Overhaul
text: WASHINGTON — If history is any guide, Donald B. Verrilli Jr. will hole up in a hotel close to the Supreme Court building, eat only salmon for dinner because it is said to help brain function, and give his undivided attention to the final preparations for what promises to be the biggest case of his life.

headline: Islamist Victors in Egypt Seeking Shift by Hamas
text: CAIRO — As it prepares to take power in Egypt, the Muslim Brotherhood is overhauling its relations with the two main Palestinian factions in an effort to put new pressure on Israel for an independent Palestinian state.

headline: Trayvon Martin Furor Echoes British Campaign for Justice
text: LONDON — The outcry in the United States over the fatal shooting of Trayvon Martin, a black Florida teenager, by a crime watch volunteer has prompted parallels with a British case that forced a shake-up in policing and public attitudes on issues of justice and civil rights.

headline: Saints’  Payton Is Sorry for ‘What Has Happened’
text: Two days after the N.F.L. suspended him for the 2012 season, New Orleans Saints Coach Sean Payton issued a statement Friday in which he never used the word “bounty” while saying that he was sorry “for what has happened.”

headline: Spring in Barcelona Means It’s Calçot Season
text: Each year, the calçot, a sweet onion variety similar in appearance to the leek, is harvested all over Catalunya just before spring and served by the dozens in restaurants and on dining room tables across the region. Translated, the tradition known locally as la calçotada would be something like, “the eating of the spring onion.” That doesn’t quite capture it, though.

headline: The Weekend Word: Trayvon
text: In Today’s Times:

headline: Space Station Crew Scrambles as Debris Passes Nearby
text: HONG KONG — Crew members aboard the International Space Station temporarily scrambled into spacecraft capable of returning them to Earth early on Saturday as remnants of a discarded Russian satellite passed nearby, the latest episode spotlighting the growing amount of space debris encircling the planet.

headline: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
text: Jammu and Kashmir: A car blast rocked southern Kashmir on Thursday, killing one person and injuring 14 others including four security personnel, the Hindustan Times reports. The 27-year-old driver who was blown up in the blast was a resident of south Kashmir’s Pulwama district.

headline: Don Draper, Gearhead?
text: In this Sunday’s Automobiles section, Stuart Schwartzapfel profiles Ed McCabe, a real-life advertising star of the “Mad Men” era who was responsible for many of Volvo’s brand-making campaigns of the 1960s and ’70s.

headline: Lotus Position in Paddock and a Qualifying Again Dominated by McLaren
text: KUALA LUMPUR — Interesting that the Lotus Formula One team of this season finally won its case against the Malaysian-based Lotus Formula One team of last year — now known as Caterham — and all it took for Lotus this year to find a little bad luck was to come to Malaysia. The team — which is based in Enstone, England — had a fire in its hospitality “building” overnight when a refrigerator short-circuited. No one was injured, but the team ceased all hospitality for the rest of the weekend, and its media staff set up office amongst the journalists in the media center of the track.

headline: 2012 N.F.L. Mock Draft
text: Jonathan Bales is the founder of TheDCTimes.com and will help analyze draft prospects for The Fifth Down in his Scouting the Draft preview series.

headline: Illegal Immigrants Number 11.5. Million
text: About 11.5 million illegal immigrants were living in the United States in January 2011, a figure essentially unchanged from the 11.6 million in 2010, according to the latest estimates by the Department of Homeland Security, which were based on 2010 census figures. Georgia saw the greatest increase between 2000 and 2011, with the number of illegal immigrants there increasing by 95 percent to 440,000. The number of illegal immigrants in the country peaked in 2007 at 11.8 million, the demographers found, and has been declining.

headline: California: Charges in Coliseum Scheme
text: Six people have been indicted on charges that they siphoned millions of dollars from the Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum. The indictment, unsealed on Friday, details schemes in which concert promoters are accused of paying officials at the Coliseum in exchange for lower costs and other perks. Two concert promoters, Insomniac and Go Ventures, are accused of paying more than $1.8 million to Coliseum officials to ensure that they could continue to hold raves at the venue, even after a 15-year-old girl died of a drug overdose there during an Insomniac event. Four defendants have pleaded not guilty; they are Patrick Lynch, the former general manager of the coliseum; Todd DeStefano, the former events manager; Pasquale Rotella, the owner of Insomniac; and Reza Gerami, the owner of Go Ventures. The other two defendants are out of the country and have not been arrested.

headline: JetBlue and Korean Air Combine, Electronically
text: JetBlue and Korean Air recently announced a partnership allowing fliers to book trips that combine legs on both airlines on a single ticket.

headline: Travel Is Behind West’s Early Edge in M.L.S.
text: Major League Soccer commentators and fans have been quick to condemn the Eastern Conference after Western teams won 9 of 11 interconference games during the new season’s first two weeks

headline: On Hollywood
text: I began with the concept of psychogeographical dérive, an approach analyzed by the French writer Guy Debord.

headline: Macroeconomic Chutzpah
text: Chutzpah, according to the old definition, is when you murder your parents, then plead for mercy because you’re an orphan. I found myself thinking of that definition when reading Justin Fox’s description of recent remarks by Jean-Claude Trichet. (Via Mark Thoma).

headline: Macroeconomic Policy Wagers
text: One of key arguments made by the proponents of fiscal austerity, even in a deeply depressed economy, has involved a sort of macroeconomic version of Pascal’s wager. Yes, the more open-minded admit, borrowing costs are very low in the US and the UK. Yes, the arithmetic suggests that cutting spending now will do very little to improve the long-run fiscal prospect. But you never know – maybe the last trillion dollars of spending will be what causes a sudden loss of market confidence, turning you into Greeeeeeece. (Cue scary noises).

headline: Singapore Is Widening Its Cruise Ship Berth
text: Singapore is opening a cruise terminal by midyear to accommodate a growing number of cruise passengers and larger ships like Royal Caribbean’s Oasis of the Seas, its tourism board announced recently.

headline: The Electric Car, Unplugged
text: THE future would appear bright for the electric car. Gasoline prices are high. The government is spending billions on battery technology. Auto companies are preparing to roll out a dozen new electrified models. Concern is growing about the climate impacts of burning oil. And tough new fuel economy standards are looming.

headline: Monti Braces for a Fight Over Labor Law Changes
text: ROME — In his effort to turn around the Italian economy, and Italy’s deeply ingrained workplace culture, Prime Minister Mario Monti is gearing up for a struggle in Parliament over his proposal to change Italian labor laws.

headline: Romney Advisers Have History With the Candidate
text: Until Wednesday, few Americans knew Eric Fehrnstrom as a top adviser to Mitt Romney. Now, his name is (apologies) etched into the public consciousness.

headline: James Murdoch Resigns From Another Corporate Board
text: In a continuing effort to distance himself from News Corporation’s embattled British newspaper unit, James Murdoch has stepped down from the board of Times Newspapers Holdings.

headline: Variety: An Eloquacious Acrostic
text: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE — If you go strictly by the quote in today’s acrostic puzzle, the author doesn’t appear to have much faith in the evolutionary power of language. She compares the tenacity of emergent words — some plausible, some not — to the power of belief in fairies bringing them closer to reality, yet she spent nearly a quarter century hunting these words down in her column in The Atlantic Monthly.

headline: The End of an Era in Indiana
text: ANDERSON, Ind. — At its peak, the Wigwam attracted 5,000 season-ticket holders to Anderson High School boys’ basketball games. The teams and the crowds measured up to the gym’s 8,996-seat capacity. That made the Wigwam the second-biggest high school gym in America, but Anderson athletic directors still found themselves testifying in divorce hearings over the custody of season tickets.

headline: After Payton’s Suspension, Saints Scramble to Fill Void
text: Little more than two years ago, hours after the New Orleans Saints won the Super Bowl, Sean Payton held a bleary-eyed morning news conference. With Mardi Gras beads around his neck and the Lombardi Trophy slung over one shoulder, Payton appeared to be celebrating the sublime revival of a city brought low by Hurricane Katrina as well as the dominance of a defense against three likely Hall of Fame quarterbacks. Near the end, Payton noted that with quarterback Drew Brees in his prime, the Saints burned to separate themselves further from the rest of the N.F.L.

headline: Insuring Hollywood Against Falls (but Not Flops)
text: HERE’S one for “The Hunger Games” crowd: What if, in that blood-tingling climactic scene near the Cornucopia, Katniss Everdeen (Jennifer Lawrence) had skewered poor Peeta Mellark (Josh Hutcherson) with a wayward silver arrow?

headline: Just the Facts. Yes, All of Them.
text: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif.

headline: Syria Continues Drive to Retake Rebel Strongholds as Diplomacy Suffers a Setback
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Syrian troops continued their drive on Saturday to retake rebel strongholds, even as there were indications that diplomatic efforts to end the violence could still prove elusive just days after Western officials had claimed a breakthrough.

headline: A Bailout by Another Name
text: ED DeMARCO is a marked man.

headline: As Displaced Return to Iraq, New Tensions for Neighbors
text: BAGHDAD — Even after death squads began killing his neighbors, after corpses appeared in the streets around his home and his family fled in fear, Walid al-Bahadli still believed in his once affluent and diverse neighborhood of Al Adel.

headline: Want to Innovate? Feed a Cookie to the Monster
text: This interview with Terry Tietzen, founder and C.E.O. of Edatanetworks, a developer of customer loyalty software, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: Suicides Highlight Failures of Veterans’ Support System
text: Francis Guilfoyle, a 55-year-old homeless veteran, drove his 1985 Toyota Camry to the Department of Veterans Affairs campus in Menlo Park early in the morning of Dec. 3, took a stepladder and a rope out of the car, threw the rope over a tree limb and hanged himself.

headline: Hiring the Blind, While Making a Green Statement
text: WHEN Chris Yura, chief executive of the apparel company SustainU, was looking for a factory to produce 24,000 T-shirts, it was important that it be within 200 miles of where the fabric was made.

headline: Avalanches of Words, Sifted and Sorted
text: IT just keeps growing — the vast electronic archive of books, journals and scholarly literature stored on the Web. But scientists are aiming to keep up with this trove of collective knowledge by devising computer-based tools to winnow and quantify it.

headline: Two Striking Exceptions to the Power of Free Swingers
text: Goodyear, Ariz.

headline: Both Coasts Watch Closely as San Francisco Faces Erosion
text: SAN FRANCISCO — The explosive waves of Ocean Beach, a 3.5-mile stretch separating the city from the gray edge of the Pacific Ocean, have long been a draw for tourists, local families and an international tribe of surfers.

headline: Counting the Mets Up to Opening Day
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — A yellow legal pad on Mets Manager Terry Collins’s desk at Digital Domain Park bears a handwritten record of his preoccupations.

headline: The Age of the Shadow Bank Run
text: I RECENTLY asked a group of colleagues — and myself — to identify the single most important development to emerge from America’s financial crisis. Most of us had a common answer: The age of the bank run has returned.

headline: ‘Pink Slime’ Is Vanishing From School Cafeterias
text: BOSTON — Andy Gomez, a ninth grader at Brighton High School, was not sure why hamburgers and meatballs had disappeared from the cafeteria, but he was not happy about it. “Today I just ate peanut butter and jelly,” he said. “I don’t like the chicken patty.”

headline: Passing Flaws May Negate Tebow’s Physical Gifts
text: Denver’s playoff victory against Pittsburgh in January showcased the best, and the worst, of Tim Tebow.

headline: This Bull Market Is Hard to Pin Down
text: HISTORY says that standard bull markets typically have a shelf life of less than four years. So when the bull that sprang to life in March 2009 turned 3 this month, it understandably raised some concerns.

headline: What’s Your Sign? It Could Be a Cram
text: WE return in this episode to that perpetual source of digital age fury, the cellphone bill.

headline: Lessons From The Great Canadian Slump
text: So, is there still a lot of slack in U.S. labor markets? On the face of it, that seems an absurd question to ask, given the persistence of very high unemployment and an employment-population ratio far below pre-crisis levels. Yet it is being asked, partly because we don’t see strong evidence of falling inflation.

headline: The Tebow Party Moves Its Big Tent East
text: I was not a Jets fan on Wednesday morning. Like many football fans around the country, I was reveling in the schadenfreude of the Jets’ folly, of Rex Ryan’s busted guarantees, of the circular firing squad in the locker room, of Mark Sanchez’s high-profile failures.

headline: Russian TV Broadcast Besmirching Protesters Draws a Furious Reaction
text: MOSCOW — “Anatomy of a Protest,” a pseudodocumentary broadcast this month on Russia’s NTV television station, had the familiar earmarks of a hatchet job against opponents of the Kremlin — a darkly insinuating voice-over, accusations of shocking treachery and blurry surveillance film acquired from law enforcement services.

headline: Political Geography: Louisiana
text: Louisiana, where Republicans are holding a presidential primary on Saturday, is a Deep South state with a small twist. The state’s Republican voters are similar to Mississippi’s and Alabama’s, however, there are modest differences that could lead to a substantial electoral difference.

headline: Overseas Internships Can Benefit, for a Price
text: AS the world becomes more interconnected, employers are clamoring for global experience in their work forces. So it should come as no surprise that college internships are going global, too.

headline: Voter Turnout Appears Light in Louisiana Primary
text: METAIRIE, La. — As Louisiana became the 28th state to head to the polls in a drawn-out Republican presidential race, turnout appeared very light at several sites around New Orleans, a combination perhaps of campaign fatigue and the competition of a lovely Saturday morning ideal for gardening and visiting crawfish festivals, which are back in season.

headline: Towering Figure Still Reaching Out
text: Kareem Abdul-Jabbar is the only athlete to be voted the most outstanding player of the N.C.A.A. tournament three times — he was known as Lew Alcindor as his U.C.L.A. teams won three championships. He received the first Naismith Award as the college player of the year in 1969 and went on to a 20-year record-setting N.B.A. career.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: The Jets’ trade with Denver for quarterback Tim Tebow to back up Mark Sanchez drew reactions from many readers. Here are a few of their letters and online comments.

headline: For Horse and Jockey, Risks Vary by State
text: The estimated breakdown and injury rates at the 62 tracks where thoroughbreds or quarter horses race.

headline: Experience in Israel Fuels an N.B.A. Dream
text: TEL AVIV — Before Chinese-Americans had Jeremy Lin, Jews had Jon Scheyer. Nicknamed the Jewish Jordan as a high school phenomenon in the Chicago suburbs, Scheyer personified the hoop dreams of a people with few basketball role models.

headline: What I Learned at Age 8
text: I GREW up in a suburb of Richmond, Va., and attended an all-black school in first and second grade. In 1954, the Supreme Court abolished segregation in schools, and in 1966, when Virginia acknowledged that decision, I had the choice of going to an all-white school in third grade. I remember sitting on the floor outside my bedroom and crying when my parents insisted that I switch schools.

headline: Letters: My Own Space
text: To the Editor:

headline: At UConn, Playing Defense Is the Key to Playing at All
text: Women who play basketball usually go to Connecticut with spectacular dossiers that highlight their abilities to put a ball into a basket. Coach Geno Auriemma likes it that way because he can get them to concentrate on less glamorous responsibilities, like playing defense.

headline: Letters: No Obstacle to Regulation
text: To the Editor:

headline: Delays Keep Former Qaeda Child Soldier at Guantánamo, Despite Plea Deal
text: WASHINGTON — When Omar Khadr, a former child soldier for Al Qaeda, agreed to plead guilty in a high-profile case before a military commission 17 months ago, the terms of his plea deal strongly signaled that after November 2011 he would be transferred to his native Canada to serve the remainder of his sentence.

headline: After Falling Behind Early, Lady Vols Rally for the Victory
text: DES MOINES — A season hung in the balance. So, perhaps, did Pat Summitt’s peerless career. Tennessee appeared listless in the women’s N.C.A.A. tournament on Saturday. Kansas was quicker, more determined. Not once all season had the Lady Vols won a game after trailing at halftime.

headline: Chamberlain Is Expected to Leave Hospital, and the Early Signs Are Encouraging
text: LAKELAND, Fla. — Joba Chamberlain is expected to be released from St. Joseph’s Hospital in Tampa on Sunday, three days after he had surgery to repair an open dislocation of his right ankle, Yankees Manager Joe Girardi said.

headline: Coup Leaders in Mali Struggle to Assert Their Control
text: DAKAR, Senegal — Residents of Bamako, the capital of Mali, waited in tension and uncertainty on Saturday for the outcome of a military coup d’état that overthrew the country’s elected government last week, ending more than 20 years of democracy in the nation.

headline: Breakdown: Disarray at the Track
text: Some say a culture of drugs and lax regulation at racetracks is behind the nation’s high fatality rate for horses.

headline: Breakdown: A Jockey’s Story
text: Jockeys are on the front lines of the risky business of horse racing. Twenty-four horses a week die at racetracks around the country.

headline: A Mother and Her Wiggly Children
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Isner, New to the Top 10, Credits College Play for His Team-First Attitude
text: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla. — The pro-wrestling fan and tennis player John Isner knows what his character should be were he ever to take to the ring.

headline: Sandusky Investigation Drew Psychologist’s Alert in 1998, Report Says
text: More than a decade before the former Penn State football assistant Jerry Sandusky was charged with child sexual abuse, a psychologist warned the university police in an investigation into a suspected assault of an 11-year-old boy that Sandusky’s actions in that case fit a “likely pedophile’s pattern.” But the university seemed to do nothing about Sandusky in the wake of that report in 1998.

headline: Mangled Horses, Maimed Jockeys
text: RUIDOSO, N.M. — At 2:11 p.m., as two ambulances waited with motors running, 10 horses burst from the starting gate at Ruidoso Downs Race Track 6,900 feet up in New Mexico’s Sacramento Mountains.

headline: Jockeys on the Front Lines
text: An always-dangerous sport has become even more so as the economics of racing have changed. Racetracks facing a steep loss of customers have increasingly added casinos. That has brought higher purses but has given trainers an incentive to race unfit horses, putting both horse and rider at risk. New Mexico jockeys have been hit particularly hard.

headline: Baylor Coach’s Family All In During Big Win
text: ATLANTA — By the standards of major college basketball, Baylor Coach Scott Drew has been remarkably adaptable this season. For example, Drew instituted a three-guard lineup in late February that changed the look of his team, an admission that the plan for his high-profile but underachieving team was not working and needed adjustments midflight.

headline: How the Times Analyzed Data on Horse Injuries
text: To assess how often horses break down or get injured, The Times purchased official data covering more than 150,000 race results from 2009 through 2011. The data are compiled by trained “chart callers,” and used to compile result charts that bettors use to evaluate horses. The Times searched the data for terms indicating that a horse encountered a physical problem: broke down, vanned off, injured, lame, euthanized, died, collapsed, bleeding or went wrong.

headline: When Poverty Was White
text: CARRIE BUCK, or rather her last name, appears just once in the books of Charles Murray, the conservative sociologist and author of the recent work “Coming Apart: The State of White America, 1960-2010,” his portrait of the decline of poor white Americans. To find it, you have to look through the endnotes for the introduction to his most famous book, “The Bell Curve,” in which he cites Buck v. Bell, the 1927 Supreme Court case that approved Ms. Buck’s involuntary sterilization.

headline: G.O.P. Campaign Could End Soon — But Not in Louisiana
text: Rick Santorum is likely to win the Louisiana Republican primary on Saturday. He has had a clear and fairly consistent lead of about 14 percentage points in recent polls there.

headline: The Thrill of Disaster
text: MY college roommates and I chased firetrucks.

headline: A Fly Crawls Into a Bar ...
text: “Fruit flies apparently self-medicate just like many humans do, drowning their sorrows or frustrations for some of the same reasons. ...Male flies subjected to what amounted to a long tease ... preferred food spiked with alcohol far more than male flies that were able to mate.”

headline: NATO’s Secrecy Stance
text: SOMETIME late last Aug. 8, NATO warplanes flying from Europe arrived over the Libyan farming village of Majer, where forces loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi were withdrawing and anti-Qaddafi forces were claiming ground. Civilians were in motion, too — seeking pockets of safety away from the roaming sides, neither of which fought with precision or clear rules. This is the type of situation in which air support can be especially risky and in which, even with a careful calculus of modern target planning, mistakes are likely.

headline: Manic Wednesday Leaves N.F.L. Gasping for Breath
text: Robert Griffin III rescheduled his pro day workout at Baylor University to Wednesday from Thursday so he could have the day all to himself. He would perform passing drills one day before Andrew Luck, another top prospect, and with no N.C.A.A. basketball or other diversions on the schedule, Griffin’s workout could command the undivided attention of the sports news media.

headline: Sunday Dialogue: Equitable Health Care
text: Readers respond to a writer’s defense of the health reform law.

headline: The Case for Sleep Medicine
text: ACCORDING to a new study in the journal BMJ that has received wide media coverage, people who regularly took sleeping pills were nearly five times more likely to die over a two and a half year period than those who didn’t take them.

headline: Turkey’s Challenges
text: In Istanbul and Ankara, high-rise apartments and office towers are changing the landscape. With recent economic growth rates that exceed those in many European countries, Turkey is often cited as a success story in a region in turmoil.

headline: How Much Was That Treatment?
text: Analysts are finding huge disparities in the amounts that private insurance plans pay for common medical procedures. This goes largely undetected by patients and their doctors because hospitals and private insurance plans treat their negotiated prices as confidential.

headline: The Full-Employment Congress
text: Representative Ron Paul’s signature libertarianism takes on a whole new meaning with the disclosure that he has paid more than $300,000 in salaries and fees to his daughter, brother, grandson, daughter’s mother-in-law, granddaughter and grandson-in-law. There is no Congressional ethics rule against employing family members in the pursuit of public service, as the office of Mr. Paul, Texas Republican and presidential candidate, points out.

headline: A Boy to Be Sacrificed
text: Paris

headline: Managers Search for Meaning in Meaningless Games
text: PORT CHARLOTTE, Fla. — When diligent scouts from opposing teams arrived early at Tampa Bay Rays training camp recently, they found they were locked out. For the first several days of camp, they had been allowed in the stadium at 9:30 a.m. to watch batting practice and roam free. But now their entry was barred until 10:20 a.m.

headline: A Moment of Truth for Health Care Reform
text: The Supreme Court’s decision on the Affordable Care Act will have immense political importance. The law, which rivals Medicare in scope, is the biggest achievement of the Obama administration. Striking it down has become a Republican crusade.

headline: Things I Saw — No. 1
text: Suggestions for what you’d like Jason to see and draw may be sent to thingsisaw@nytimes.com.

headline: On Hollywood
text: A series of photographs of women who live in Los Angeles.

headline: In Pope’s Mexico Visit, the Pastoral Is Political
text: LEÓN, Mexico — Pope Benedict XVI met with President Felipe Calderón on Saturday evening in what was described by the Vatican as a courtesy visit in the middle of a purely pastoral trip to Mexico and Cuba.

headline: Quirk Often Penalizes Better Teams
text: The N.H.L. has long maintained that there is no perfect postseason format, but the shortcomings of the current system are becoming more evident.

headline: Boston University Aims to Rise Above Scandal
text: Throughout the college hockey season, Slap Shot will feature reports about some of the country’s top-ranked teams.

headline: China Attacks Dalai Lama in Online Burst
text: BEIJING — As the Chinese government’s relationship with the Dalai Lama, the exiled Tibetan spiritual leader, has gone from bad to worse over the years, Beijing’s propaganda machine has churned out increasingly florid descriptions of him. He has been called a “jackal,” a “wolf in sheep’s clothing” and, routinely, a “splittist.”

headline: Giant Movers in the Cloud
text: Last week three of the biggest companies in technology were busy positioning themselves for the future. Collectively, their actions tell you a lot about the kind of turmoil headed for the rest of the business world.

headline: The Brain on Love
text: A RELATIVELY new field, called interpersonal neurobiology, draws its vigor from one of the great discoveries of our era: that the brain is constantly rewiring itself based on daily life. In the end, what we pay the most attention to defines us. How you choose to spend the irreplaceable hours of your life literally transforms you.

headline: The Outsourced Party
text: Who speaks for the Republican party? The answer is that everyone does — and therefore, no one does.

headline: Knee Injury Knocks Agudelo Off U.S. Team
text: U.S. Soccer revealed Saturday that Red Bulls striker Juan Agudelo sustained a torn meniscus in his left knee during the under-23 team’s 6-0 win over Cuba Thursday in its opening game of Olympic qualifying in the Concacaf region.

headline: Vincent Kartheiser
text: Vincent Kartheiser is an actor probably best known for his role as Pete Campbell on “Mad Men,” which begins its fifth season on AMC tonight.

headline: Text to Driver: That’s My Space
text: ANYBODY who has ever hunted for a parking space along a city street or in a shopping mall garage knows how the choreography is supposed to work. Driver seeking a precious spot crawls along, sees someone climbing into a car, then pumps fist to celebrate good fortune.

headline: How Oedipus Wrecks
text: WHEN Mike Nichols had his dazzling comedy act with Elaine May, one of their sketches began with a Jewish mother calling her son and saying, “Hello, this is your mother, do you remember me?”

headline: Rethinking His Religion
text: I MOVED into my freshman-year dorm at the University of North Carolina after many of the other men on the hall. One had already begun decorating. I spotted the poster above his desk right away. It showed a loaf of bread and a chalice of red wine, with these words: “Jesus invites you to a banquet in his honor.”

headline: Tebow in Babylon
text: THE Prophet Jonah was sent to Nineveh. St. Paul was sent to Athens, Macedonia, Rome. And now Tim Tebow has been sent to New York City.

headline: A Festival of Lies
text: THE historian Victor Davis Hanson recently wrote a brutally clear-eyed piece in The National Review, looking back at America’s different approaches to Iraq, Iran, Libya, Syria, Egypt, Pakistan and Afghanistan and how, sadly, none of them could be said to have worked yet.

headline: The False Debate About Attacking Iran
text: I WONDER if we in the news media aren’t inadvertently leaving the impression that there is a genuine debate among experts about whether an Israeli military strike on Iran makes sense this year.

headline: A Long Road to Regulating Derivatives
text: If there is one lesson from the financial crisis that should be indelible, it is that unregulated derivatives are prone to catastrophic failure. And yet, nearly four years after the crash, and nearly two years since the passage of the Dodd-Frank law, the multitrillion-dollar derivatives market is still dominated by a handful of big banks, and regulation is a slow work in progress.

headline: Rival N.B.A. Siblings Share the Room in Los Angeles
text: LOS ANGELES — When the first bus of Utah Jazz players and team personnel arrived at Staples Center for a 6:30 p.m. game against the Los Angeles Lakers last Sunday, players made their way to the locker room, only to stop and remain in the hallway.

headline: For Lawyer in Afghan Killings, the Latest in a Series of Challenging Defenses
text: SEATTLE — The Vietnam War was raging, and John Henry Browne believed it was unjust. When his draft number came up, he refused to go.

headline: Chandler Approaching Historic Pace
text: Studies of N.B.A. statistical records often eliminate Wilt Chamberlain from consideration because he was so dominant, and so far ahead of his time, that his numbers were almost comical.

headline: Payments to Albuquerque Officers Are Called a ‘Bounty System’
text: ALBUQUERQUE — Mike Gomez has been angry with the police officer here who shot and killed his 22-year-old son, Alan, last year, after officers responded to a report that the young man was acting erratically and firing a rifle. But Mr. Gomez became even angrier just days ago after he learned that the officer, Sean Wallace, received a $500 payment from the Albuquerque police union shortly after the shooting.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, March 25
text: The presidential race will share the spotlight with several other issues on the Sunday talk shows, including the coming Supreme Court decision over the health care law and the shooting of an unarmed Florida teenager by a neighborhood watch volunteer.

headline: Years After Ten Commandments Fight, Ex-Justice Plans Return
text: BIRMINGHAM, Ala. — On the campaign trail, Roy Moore wears a metal pin of a cross on his suit jackets, praises “almighty God” and refers to the United States as a “Christian nation.”

headline: In Europe, Where Art Is Life, Ax Falls on Public Financing
text: European governments are cutting their support for culture, and American arts lovers are starting to feel the results.

headline: Pelfrey Gives Up Five Runs; He’s Happy
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. —Mike Pelfrey, who has been hit hard in spring training, said he was happy with his start against the St. Louis Cardinals on Saturday afternoon, crediting his comfort on the mound to a minor adjustment in his mechanics.

headline: Man, 20, Dies After Impact With L Train
text: Investigators were searching on Saturday for a man who was involved in a fight with a young Queens man who fell to the tracks in a Brooklyn subway station and was killed by a train, the authorities said.

headline: Two-for-One Special
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — I’m not exactly sure what to call this theme, but we certainly do get two-for-one today with Patrick Berry’s puzzle.

headline: Ailments Found in Gulf Dolphins
text: Dolphins in Barataria Bay off Louisiana, which was hit hard by the BP oil spill in 2010, are seriously ill, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration said Friday.

headline: Obama Arrives in South Korea for Nuclear Meeting and Visit to DMZ
text: PANMUNJOM, South Korea — President Obama landed here shortly after dawn on Sunday for a three-day visit during which he will promote efforts to secure the world’s nuclear stockpiles and get a firsthand look at one of the world’s most unpredictable nuclear states, North Korea.

headline: A.C.C. Looks to Get Back in Women’s Final Four
text: RALEIGH, N.C. — The Atlantic Coast Conference usually produces its share of Top 25 and even Top 10 teams each year, but you have to go back to 2007 to find the last time an A.C.C. team (North Carolina) made it to the Final Four in the N.C.A.A. women’s tournament. And the A.C.C. has captured only one national championship in the last 17 years — Maryland in 2006.

headline: Santorum Unveils ‘Obamaville’ Video, Scary Music Included
text: In a new video from Rick Santorum, it is hardly morning in America. It is more like apocalypse in America.

headline: U.S. Plans No Charges Over Deadly Strike in Pakistan
text: WASHINGTON — The United States military has decided that no service members will face disciplinary charges for their involvement in a NATO airstrike in November that killed 24 Pakistani soldiers, an accident that plunged relations between the two countries to new depths and has greatly complicated the allied mission in Afghanistan.

headline: Thumbs Down From Calipari
text: ATLANTA — Don’t tell this to Jonah Hill and Channing Tatum, but Kentucky Coach John Calipari is not in their demographic.

headline: Groups Blanket Supreme Court on Health Care
text: WASHINGTON — Justice Clarence Thomas likens all the outside political pressure that the Supreme Court is facing over its review of the Obama administration’s sweeping health care law to the distraction faced by a free-throw shooter confronted with fans waving wildly behind the basket. Neither, in his view, has much impact in the end.

headline: Sexual Abuse Case Clouds The Pope’s Visit to Mexico
text: LEÓN, Mexico — The shadow of the disgraced Mexican founder of a powerful religious order darkened the visit of Pope Benedict XVI here this weekend, as former victims and authors organized news conferences to call attention to the church’s failure to combat what they called a systemic culture of sexual abuse.

headline: When Packaging Oversteps the Facts
text: A NEWS article ultimately is judged on much more than its raw factual ingredients. Its points of emphasis, headline, length and position on the page combine to couch the article in a way that delivers its intended meaning and significance.

headline: Agudelo Sustains Knee Injury in U.S. Game
text: U.S. Soccer revealed Saturday that Red Bulls striker Juan Agudelo had sustained a torn meniscus in his left knee during the under-23 team’s 6-0 win over Cuba Thursday in its opening game of Olympic qualifying in the Concacaf region.

headline: Who’s in Center (Not on First)?
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — The Mets have found themselves cautiously feeling their way through a murky situation in center field.

headline: Louisville Storms Back Late Against Florida and Into Final Four
text: PHOENIX — Peyton Siva Sr. stood in the front row at the US Airways Center, clad in his lucky jersey, the black one — Louisville, No. 3. The stains on the jersey told the story of the Cardinals’ last eight games, all victories, many of them upsets.

headline: For Santorum, It’s Three Strikes in a Row in Wisconsin
text: SHEBOYGAN, Wis. – Rick Santorum often says that he offers the clearest contrast with President Obama, and on Saturday, he was able to prove that — in at least one way.

headline: Griner Leads Baylor to Rout of Georgia Tech
text: DES MOINES — Brittney Griner, Baylor’s dominant 6-foot-8 center, scored 35 points, grabbed 10 rebounds and blocked six shots as the top-seeded Bears defeated fourth-seeded Georgia Tech, 83-68, in the semifinals of the Des Moines Region.

headline: Kennedy Helped Shape Romney’s Career, and Still Haunts It
text: BOSTON — When Gov. Mitt Romney signed legislation in April 2006 requiring most Massachusetts residents to have health coverage, Senator Edward M. Kennedy stood by his side, beaming like a proud father. They were onstage at historic Faneuil Hall in Boston, a setting that had a special resonance for the two.

headline: Kentucky Braces for a Zone Not of Its Own
text: ATLANTA — John Calipari, the Kentucky coach, is convinced Baylor is going to play a zone defense in Sunday’s N.C.A.A. South Region championship game. The Bears play a 1-3-1 and that must cause immediate heartburn for Kentucky fans.

headline: Trying to Divide Six Into Five
text: LAKELAND, Fla. — With a little less than two weeks remaining until opening day, there is no resolution yet to the issue of the starting rotation. The Yankees have six viable pitchers for five positions, and that includes Freddy Garcia, who had a terrific outing on Saturday.

headline: Reader Comments on Iran
text: My Sunday column argues that there isn’t a real debate over a military strike on Iran, but a false debate: experts overwhelmingly think a strike now would be an abominable idea. And I cite some reasons why that’s so.

headline: For Cheney, 71, New Heart Ends 20-Month Wait
text: Former Vice President Dick Cheney had a heart transplant on Saturday after 20 months on a waiting list, and was recovering in a Virginia hospital, a statement from his office said.

headline: Arrests at Occupy Wall Street Rally
text: The police arrested several people on Saturday during an Occupy Wall Street march that organizers said was meant to protest police tactics and brutality. In part, protesters said, the march was meant to object to the police decision last Saturday to close Zuccotti Park and arrest more than 70 people gathered there.

headline: Afghan Shootings Carried Out in 2 Operations, Inquiry Finds
text: WASHINGTON — Military investigators suspect that the American soldier charged with 17 counts of premeditated murder and other charges in connection with the attacks against Afghan civilians this month committed the shootings during two separate operations, a United States official said Saturday.

headline: Man Tries to Climb Times Building
text: A 31-year-old man who appeared to be psychologically unstable attempted to climb the outside of The New York Times Building on Saturday morning, the police said.

headline: North Carolina’s Marshall Practices
text: ST. LOUIS — Sitting in front of his locker after practice Saturday, North Carolina point guard Kendall Marshall had ice wraps on his right wrist and his right elbow. The wrist — the broken scaphoid bone from his third-round tumble against Creighton last Sunday — everyone knows about. But the elbow?

headline: St. Bonaventure Takes On a Women’s Basketball Titan
text: RALEIGH, N.C. — Notre Dame Coach Muffet McGraw could not help marveling that some of the titans of women’s basketball were all placed in the N.C.A.A. tournament’s Raleigh Region.

headline: Paraguay’s Fading Forest
text: A surging land rush is threatening Paraguay’s Chaco forest. As cattle ranchers from Brazil and German-speaking Mennonites prosper, indigenous people and the environment suffer.

headline: Vast Tracts in Paraguay Forest Being Replaced by Ranches
text: FILADELFIA, Paraguay — The Chaco thorn forest, a domain with 118-degree temperatures so forbidding that Paraguayans call it their “green hell,” covers an expanse about the size of Poland. Hunter-gatherers still live in its vast mazes of quebracho trees.

headline: Can Anybody Beat Kentucky?
text: ATLANTA — No. 1 Kentucky scored 102 points against Indiana and committed just 6 turnovers.

headline: Confident on the Greens, Woods Has the Lead
text: ORLANDO, Fla. — Much has happened to Tiger Woods since he won the Arnold Palmer Invitational for the sixth time in 2009. His aura of invincibility suffered a total eclipse as a result of injuries and the intrepid play of Y. E. Yang, who chased him down to win the 2009 P.G.A. Championship, and Graeme McDowell, who charged from behind to defeat Woods in a playoff at the 2010 Chevron World Challenge.

headline: Santorum Gets a Boost in Winning Louisiana
text: Rick Santorum easily won the Louisiana Republican primary Saturday night, capturing a deeply conservative state with a hefty portion of the kind of evangelical Christian voters who have helped him claim victories in 10 other states.

headline: Homicides in El Salvador Dip, and Questions Arise
text: MEXICO CITY — Suddenly, killings have plummeted in El Salvador, one of the most violent countries in Central America and a source of growing worry over gangs and organized crime.

headline: Victory in Defeat
text: In March 1862, the South’s experiment in disunion seemed destined to meet a near and violent end. February had brought a numbing string of strategic defeats in the vast Western Theater (the area between the Appalachian Mountains and the Mississippi River.) Spearheaded by Maj. Gen. Ulysses S. Grant’s victories at Forts Henry and Donelson, Union forces had overrun Kentucky, Missouri and the greater part of Tennessee. Equally troubling, European recognition had eluded the Confederacy. “Recent defeats have depressed the weak and are depriving us of the aid of the wavering,” lamented Confederate President Jefferson Davis. “The military paradox, that impossibilities must be rendered possible, had never better occasion for application.”

headline: A Tar Heel Needling
text: ST. LOUIS — North Carolina Coach Roy Williams apparently can’t resist needling his backup point guard Stilman White, who played 32 minutes in his first college start while filling in for the injured Kendall Marshall on Friday.

headline: Taking the Game to the Smaller Screen
text: Chess promoters have long searched for a way to make the game suitable for television. But there are two problems: it can be hard to understand, and it moves too slowly (except for blitz games).

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: March 24, 2012

headline: Kansas Center’s Reach Has Foes Grasping at Straws
text: ST. LOUIS — It takes a lot to deter Kansas guard Tyshawn Taylor, a normally fearless senior from Hoboken, N.J., who starred for Coach Bob Hurley at St. Anthony High School. Three years ago, in one of Jeff Withey’s first practices after transferring from Arizona, Taylor sized up the soft-spoken 7-footer and decided, just for giggles, to go Michael Jordan on him.

headline: Corrections: March 25
text: SPORTS

headline: Cris Alexander, Actor and Photographer, Dies at 92
text: New Yorkers tend to believe that creative people trapped in America’s hinterlands hunger to come to their big, pulsating city to fulfill their dreams. In the case of Cris Alexander, it was true.

headline: Melvyn Kaufman, Whimsical Developer, Dies at 87
text: The Sopwith Camel at 77 Water Street was in customary repose on the roof last week, the naked lady at 747 Third Avenue held court in her usual place in the lobby, and the chess game in progress on the wall outside 767 Third Avenue looked like the image shown here.

headline: Rangers Find Victory, but Still Seek Rhythm
text: TORONTO — Being a hockey goalie can be the cruelest job in sports. Even if a player succeeds 90 percent of the time, it is not really good enough.

headline: Louisiana Results Suggest a Two-Man Race
text: Is the Republican presidential contest now a two-man race?

headline: Buckeyes Zero In on Orange’s Weak Spot
text: BOSTON — The artwork on the bathroom wall of the Ohio State star Jared Sullinger showed just how much a trip to the Final Four meant to him. After last season’s upset loss in the Round of 16 to Kentucky, Sullinger printed out a photo of Wildcats guard Brandon Knight’s winning shot and hung it up for motivation.

headline: Lincoln Hall, Climber Who Survived on Everest, Dies at 56
text: Lincoln Hall, an Australian mountaineer who in May 2006 was rescued on Mount Everest after being left for dead and surviving a night alone at more than 28,000 feet, died on Tuesday in Sydney. He was 56.

headline: Shall He Dance?
text: RALEIGH, N.C. — Those who were frightened by the sight of Gary Blair, the Texas A&M women’s basketball coach, doing the “dougie” dance after last year’s national championship better hope the Aggies don’t win it all again this year. Blair is threatening to dance once again if they repeat.

headline: Knicks Rout Detroit; Stoudemire Exits With Sore Back
text: It was a Saturday night affair that felt as if it had a case of the Mondays for most of the first half. It was the Knicks, playing their fourth game in five nights, against a Pistons team that had lost four straight, including a Friday night defeat at the hands of the Miami Heat.

headline: Samiramis Imports
text: For decades, Samiramis Imports has been a go-to for Middle Eastern breads, music, films and its revered Turkish coffee. Craving zaatar? The grocery carries four varieties of that popular spice, made from salt, sesame seeds and herbs.
