The Syrian mix is spicy and the Lebanese blend is salty, but the store’s manager, Wadee Imseeh, says the Palestinian blend is perfect on pita with a drizzle of Jordanian olive oil.

headline: Similar Show for New Coach, With Lin Still in Picture
text: In 11 days as the Knicks’ coach, Mike Woodson has done everything that was expected, except for the part where he burns Mike D’Antoni’s playbook and buries Jeremy Lin.

headline: Sheriff Is Set for Classes in Antiviolence
text: Sheriff Ross Mirkarimi of San Francisco called Hamish Sinclair last week to inquire about enrolling in Man Alive Violence Prevention Services. Man Alive conducts domestic violence prevention classes around the Bay Area, and works inside the jail that Mr. Mirkarimi’s department operates.

headline: Oakland Police Try to Fill the Ranks, but Keep Falling Behind
text: About 930 police recruits lined up last week outside the Oakland Convention Center to take the entry-level examination to become an Oakland police officer.

headline: Syracuse’s Season of Excellence Amid Turbulence Ends in Opportunity Gone Awry
text: BOSTON — Syracuse Coach Jim Boeheim insists that coaching isn’t fun. He acknowledged that he does it for the money. Fun for him, he said, is a round of golf, which he will now be able to enjoy at his convenience after Syracuse’s 77-70 loss to Ohio State on Saturday night in the East Region final.

headline: Doubts in Cold Case That Was Thought Solved
text: For 26 years, the beating death of Natalie Antonetti remained a mystery. The Austin police could not find anyone with motive to hurt the 38-year-old mother who thrived on music and who often invited friends over for haircuts and home-cooked meals.

headline: Razing of a Rodeo Arena Closes the Door on History
text: With barely a peep from preservationists, another piece of Texas history was razed in mid-January as bulldozers unceremoniously demolished the prison rodeo arena in Huntsville.

headline: Vessel Tossed to Sea in Japan’s Tsunami Nears Canada
text: Updated | 11:09 a.m. A Japanese fishing boat, lost at sea last year after an earthquake and tsunami killed several thousand people, has been spotted off the coast of British Columbia in western Canada.

headline: Duke Women Put a Stop to St. John’s Run
text: FRESNO, Calif. — The senior Da’Shena Stevens came back from off-season knee surgery, helped stall Connecticut’s home winning streak at 99 games and carried St. John’s to its first Round of 16 showing.

headline: Jenifer Marsh, Thomas Nassim
text: Jenifer Jo Ann Marsh and Thomas Edward David Nassim were married Saturday at the Little Sanctuary of St. Albans School on the grounds of the National Cathedral in Washington. The Rev. William P. Billow Jr., an Episcopal priest and the former senior chaplain of the school, performed the ceremony.

headline: Nicholas De Baun and Peter Noah
text: Nicholas Hall De Baun and Peter Francis Noah were married Saturday at Eleven Madison Park, a restaurant in New York. Bruce Allen, an acting State Supreme Court justice in New York, officiated.

headline: Lucy Moore and Harald Fuller-Bennett
text: Lucy Eleanor Moore and Harald Fuller-Bennett were married Saturday evening at Home Moravian Church in Winston-Salem, N.C. The Rev. Carl S. Southerland, a Moravian minister and a pastor at the church, led the ceremony.

headline: Robert Burns, Gary Schiro
text: Robert Burns and Gary Schiro were married Friday in the Parish Hall of the Church of the Messiah in Rhinebeck, N.Y. Judge Laura Taylor Swain of the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York officiated.

headline: Jessica Fox, James Bergman
text: Jessica Loren Fox and James Henry Bergman were married Saturday evening at the de Seversky Mansion at the New York Institute of Technology in Old Westbury, N.Y. Joseph P. Spinola, a former New York State Supreme Court justice, officiated.

headline: Sara Friedlander, Matthew Siegel
text: Sara Ariana Friedlander, a daughter of Rabbi Joy D. Levitt of Manhattan and Rabbi Lee M. Friedlander of Roslyn, N.Y., was married Saturday evening to Matthew Louis Siegel, a son of Maxine Siegel and Joel Siegel of New Rochelle, N.Y. Rabbi Sharon Kleinbaum officiated at the Metropolitan Building, a restored factory in Long Island City, Queens.

headline: Bonnie Williams, Marco Anasetti
text: Bonnie Faye Williams, a daughter of Dale B. Williams and Guy T. Williams of New Orleans, was married there Saturday to Marco Alan Anasetti, the son of Simone Anasetti and Dr. Claudio Anasetti of Tampa, Fla. The Rev. David Crosby performed the ceremony at the First Baptist Church.

headline: Julie Yufe and Michael Dreyer
text: Julie Leeat Yufe, the daughter of Avivith Oppenheim of New York and Dr. Robert Yufe of Toronto, was married on Saturday evening to Michael Dreyer, a son of Louise Dreyer and Stephen Dreyer of London. Cantor Howard M. Stahl officiated at the Solage Calistoga Resort in Calistoga, Calif.

headline: Kelly Zimmerman, Stephen Rickard
text: Kelly Na’amah Zimmerman and Stephen Fletcher Rickard are to be married Sunday in Frederick, Md. The Rev. Jasmine Loney, an interfaith minister, is to officiate at the Ceresville Mansion.

headline: Rebecca Riddick, Daniel Ostrovsky
text: Rebecca Shendelman Riddick, a daughter of Deborah Shendelman and Thomas Riddick of Dunwoody, Ga., is to be married Sunday to Daniel Ostrovsky, the son of Nora Ostrovsky of Manhattan and Michael Ostrovsky of Brooklyn. Rabbi Fred Margulies, the uncle of the bride, is to officiate in Monterey Square in Savannah, Ga., which has a monument to Count Casimir Pulaski, a general who died fighting the British in the Battle of Savannah.

headline: Rachel Butler, William Kamens
text: Rachel Darcy Butler, a daughter of Jamie G. Butler and Stuart M. Butler of Washington, is to be married Sunday to William Munroe Kamens, the son of Mary Ellen Miller and Edward B. Kamens of New Haven. Rabbi James E. Ponet is to officiate at the McLean Gardens Ballroom, an event space in Washington.

headline: Robert de Michiell and Jeffrey Wilson
text: Robert de Michiell, an illustrator, and Jeffrey Michael Wilson, a theatrical general manager, are to be married Sunday evening in the lobby of the Al Hirschfeld Theater in New York. The theater producer Roger Horchow, who is also a Universal Life minister, is to officiate. Poetry readings are to be performed by the actor Richard Chamberlain and the actress Judith Light, friends of the couple.

headline: Lisa Robateau and Stephen Epps
text: Lisa Diana Robateau and Stephen Emmanuel Epps were married Friday evening at the Astor House, an event space in Manhattan. The Rev. Alvin O. Jackson, a Disciples of Christ minister, officiated.

headline: Victoria Namkung, Timothy Koch
text: Victoria Kerry Namkung and Timothy Roger Koch were married Saturday evening at the Viceroy Hotel in Palm Springs, Calif. Andrew Woodfin Jones, a friend of the couple who was named a temporary deputy marriage commissioner for the event by San Diego County, officiated.

headline: Fight Over Lawsuits Now Shapes State Politics
text: Ross Ramsey, the managing editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

headline: Heather Baharestani, Peter Hopkins
text: Heather Rachel Baharestani and Peter Edwin Hopkins were married Saturday evening at the Tribeca Rooftop in Manhattan. Rabbi Roger Ross officiated, with the Rev. Deborah Steen Ross, an interfaith minister, taking part in a ceremony incorporating Jewish and Christian traditions.

headline: Candidate Is the Issue in a Democratic Race
text: HOUSTON — Both candidates seeking the Democratic nomination for the Congressional seat held for two decades by Tom DeLay, the former House majority leader, are unusual.

headline: N.C.A.A. Tournament Photo Replay: March 24
text: Rick Pitino bested his protégé Billy Donovan as Louisville defeated Florida, and Ohio State beat Syracuse after leading most of the game.

headline: U.S. Falls to Canada, Complicating Its Plans to Qualify for the London Olympics
text: NASHVILLE — The United States under-23 national team lost to Canada, 2-0, on Saturday night, jeopardizing its chances of qualifying for this summer’s Olympics in London.

headline: Player Ratings: U.S. (0), Canada (2)
text: The United States under-23 squad’s 6-0 thrashing of Cuba on Thursday raised a number of intriguing questions. Were the Americans really that good? Or was it just that Cuba was that bad? And what would happen when the Americans faced stiffer competition on their path toward the 2012 Olympic Games?

headline: Pro-Beijing Elite Elects Chief Executive of Hong Kong
text: HONG KONG — Leung Chun-ying, a pro-Beijing real estate surveyor, won election on Sunday morning to become the next chief executive of Hong Kong.

headline: In Japan, Lonely Deaths in Society’s Margins
text: HONG KONG — The utilities are cut off. The mail piles up. No sounds come from the apartment. The neighbors don’t knock. Nobody comes. Nobody goes.

headline: In South Korea Visit, Obama Visits Border and Warns North
text: PANMUNJOM, South Korea — President Obama warned North Korea on Sunday that its threats and provocations would only deepen its international isolation and jeopardize the resumption of American food aid, and he called on the North to scrap its plans to launch a satellite next month.

headline: Checking Out the Militarized Zone
text: HONG KONG — First of all, calling it the Demilitarized Zone, they got the name all wrong.

headline: Newswallah: Long Reads Edition
text: The latest piece by Booker Prize-winning author and activist Arundhati Roy in Outlook Magazine is titled “Capitalism: A Ghost Story.” It is a story that begins at Antilla, “the most expensive dwelling ever built,” which belongs to the richest man in India, Mukesh Ambani, Ms. Roy writes.

headline: Greg Cosell on Luck, Griffin and Tebow
text: Greg Cosell, the executive producer of ESPN’s “N.F.L. Matchup,” is widely respected as a film evaluator. When he speaks, people around the league listen.

headline: Hong Kong, Divided Over Future, Gets a New Leader
text: HONG KONG — After the political and business elite of Hong Kong elected a real estate surveyor with close ties to Beijing and the Chinese Communist Party on Sunday to become the territory’s next chief executive, the victor quickly tried to allay fears that he would restrict civil liberties in Hong Kong or interrupt its gradual progress toward greater democracy.

headline: Intergenerational Transportation
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Luxury Hotels Lay Out Welcome Mats in India
text: Luxury hotels like the Oberoi and the Taj Mahal have long been part of the fabric of the Indian hospitality industry, but several high-end hoteliers are starting new outposts in the country.

headline: U.S. Pays Families of Afghan Victims in Massacre by Soldier
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — The families of 16 Afghan villagers who were killed this month by a rampaging American soldier were given $50,000 by the United States for each of their relatives who died, Afghan and American officials said.

headline: Romney and Kennedy: Strange Bedfellows
text: Politicians and analysts in Massachusetts explain the nuances of a relationship that brought together the Republican candidate and the iconic Democratic senator.

headline: ‘Hunger Games’ Ticket Sales Set Record
text: LOS ANGELES — “The Hunger Games” hit the box-office bull’s-eye over the weekend, taking in a record $155 million in North America and setting up what promises to be one of the biggest film franchises of this decade.

headline: Despite Victory, Santorum Delegate Haul Is Modest
text: Former Senator Rick Santorum may have scored big in the popular vote in Louisiana on Saturday, but he netted only five delegates more than Mitt Romney, doing little to advance himself in the all-important delegate race to claim the Republican presidential nomination.

headline: Pitino’s Record Puts Him in Rare Territory
text: PHOENIX – When Rick Pitino coached Louisville, the fourth seed in the West Region, past seventh-seeded Florida on Saturday, he ascended higher into the realm of history’s most successful college basketball coaches.

headline: In Slain Teenager’s Case, a Long Route to National Attention
text: Trayvon Martin, an unarmed 17-year-old, was fatally shot on Feb. 26 in Sanford, Fla. The next day his death was a top story on the Fox-affiliated television station in Orlando, the closest big city to Sanford. Within a week it was being covered by newspapers around the state.

headline: Killing of Iraqi Woman in San Diego Draws Global Condemnation Online
text: The death in San Diego on Saturday of an Iraqi immigrant, the victim of what appeared to be a hate crime, provoked a wave of outraged comments from bloggers who compared the killing to the shooting of an unarmed Florida teenager last month. The woman, Shaima Alawadi, died three days after her daughter discovered her body in a pool of blood inside their home along with a note that said, “Go back to your country, you terrorist.”

headline: French Authorities File Charges Against Brother of Gunman in Toulouse Killings
text: PARIS — Investigating judges on Sunday filed preliminary murder and terrorism charges against the older brother of the man who confessed to killing seven people in southwest France, saying that the killer acted with the guidance of his brother, an Islamic radical who reportedly had ties to at least one jihadist network. The brother denies involvement in the fatal shootings, his lawyer said.

headline: Disruptions: At Amazon, the Robot World Comes a Little Closer
text: Last week Amazon, the online retailer, announced it was buying a robot maker called Kiva Systems for $775 million in cash. Before you get excited that Amazon may offer a robot that can tuck you into bed at night and read Kindle books to you, this isn’t that kind of robot company. Instead, Kiva Systems’ orange robots are designed to move around warehouses and stock shelves.

headline: Lanier Voices Support for St. Bonaventure
text: RALEIGH, N.C. — Bob Lanier, who averaged 20 points and 10 rebounds in a 14-year N.B.A. career that led him to the Basketball Hall of Fame, also led tiny St. Bonaventure to the 1970 Final Four. The Reilly Center basketball court is named after Lanier.

headline: Defense Hides Many of Louisville’s Flaws
text: PHOENIX – On paper, Louisville does not possess a frightening basketball team, nor a Final Four-caliber one.

headline: Boston College’s Kreider Gets Tournament Wake-Up Call
text: Throughout the college hockey season, Slap Shot will feature reports about some of the country’s top-ranked teams.

headline: Finding Clues in the Fearful Brain
text: A few weeks ago I wrote in this series about the difference between fear and anxiety. In simple terms, I described fear as a response to an immediately present stimulus and anxiety as a worry or rumination about something that has yet to occur, or may never occur. These are normal, adaptive processes that have evolved in the brain because they help animals, including humans, survive and thrive.

headline: At Belmont, a Place to Keep the Workers’ Children Safe
text: Maria Flores and her husband, Marco Muñoz, finished work one recent afternoon and embarked on a short drive to pick up their son, Sebastian, at a nearby day care center in the Elmont section of Nassau County.

headline: Bay Hit in Arm by Strasburg
text: VIERA, Fla. — Jason Bay exited the Mets’ game against the Washington Nationals at Space Coast Stadium on Sunday after getting hit in the right forearm by a fastball from Stephen Strasburg.

headline: Problematic Panemetrics
text: Stressful column-writing, so no substantive posts today.

headline: Lessons Learned in a Loss to Federer
text: Before Roger Federer was Roger Federer, he was Ryan Harrison.

headline: At Mass in Mexico, Pope Urges Humility and Trust
text: LEÓN, Mexico — Speaking before more than half a million people at an open-air Mass here in a nation wracked by drug violence, Pope Benedict XVI urged the faithful to seek a humble and pure heart and trust in God in the face of evil.

headline: In Health Care Case, Lawyers Train for 3-Day Marathon
text: WASHINGTON — The three days of Supreme Court arguments that start Monday on the constitutionality of President Obama’s health care law will be a legal marathon, and the lawyers involved have been training.

headline: Character and Its Discontents
text: Yes, that’s what I like about me, at least one of the things, that I can say, Up the Republic!, for example, or, Sweetheart!, for example, without having to wonder whether I should not rather have cut my tongue out, or said something else.

headline: Maryland Eliminates Defending National Champion Texas A&M
text: RALEIGH, N.C. — It has been six years since Maryland reached the N.C.A.A. women’s Final Four. But the last time the Terrapins were there, they won it all.

headline: Industries Fear the Ripple Effects of Proposed Postal Service Cuts
text: WASHINGTON — Wine wholesalers and amateur beer makers want Congress to repeal a law that makes it illegal to ship alcohol by mail.

headline: Home Video Company Cashing In on British Revivals
text: Spurred on by new episodes of the British serial “Upstairs, Downstairs” on PBS last April, many viewers went in search of the 40-year-old original. They found it in the catalog of Acorn Media, which had released the vintage series a month earlier as a complete 21-disc DVD set.

headline: Stretching Vocal Cords Across Time
text: With its sweeping survey of vocal groups from the early 1930s into the mid-’70s the 92nd Street Y’s Lyrics & Lyricists series moved further into rock ’n’ roll territory on Saturday evening than I can remember it venturing. At the first of five shows, songs by Abba, the Beatles, the Beach Boys and the Ronettes shared common ground with the Boswell Sisters, the Andrews Sisters and the Mills Brothers. The unlikely host and artistic director, the gifted conductor and musical theater archivist Rob Fisher, was not the person you would expect to oversee such a project.

headline: A Broad Sampling of New Classical Works
text: It has always been the American Composers Orchestra’s mandate to explore the full range of American classical music, and in its 35 seasons it has done so without a trace of dogmatic ax grinding. Still, the orchestra has often compartmentalized, devoting a program to one or two approaches, and the next to a couple more. That makes sense. If you try to show everything at once, you may end up with the kind of motley program that George Manahan led on Thursday at Zankel Hall.

headline: Proxy Fight Looming, Yahoo Names 3 to Board
text: 8:29 p.m. | Updated

headline: Looking Back, With Little Hope of Going Back
text: Every March for the last several seasons, Dwane Casey has looked from his perch as an N.B.A. coach to see how the N.C.A.A. tournament is treating his Kentucky Wildcats. After all these years, Casey’s heart still bleeds Kentucky blue.

headline: Sharing a Legacy of Loss Among Three Generations
text: After experiencing the warmly satisfying revival of “Lost in Yonkers” at the Beckett Theater it seems inconceivable that it has taken two decades for this Pulitzer- and Tony-winning 1991 Neil Simon play to return to a New York stage.

headline: Tar Heels Missing Marshall
text: ST. LOUIS — North Carolina point guard Kendall Marshall (broken right wrist) was not in uniform for Sunday’s Midwest Region championship game against Kansas, according to a Tar Heels spokesman.

headline: New Gant Ads Focus on Old School Tie
text: For those consumers who did not go to Yale but wish they could have, a new shirt may be all that is needed to fill the void.

headline: In 2008 Crane Collapse, Scrutiny on Supplier of Part
text: The worker began scouring the Internet, following his boss’s orders to find someone who could build a turntable for a crane, and finish it faster and for less money than the estimates given by two American companies.

headline: Volleys of Words From a Writer of No Brevity
text: A field of bright yellow tennis balls greets audiences at the Chocolate Factory in Long Island City, Queens, where the director Daniel Fish and a cast of five are lobbing the words of the celebrated writer David Foster Wallace in staggering doses. The show, in which the performers repeat verbatim thick slices from Wallace’s nonfiction prose as well as interviews with him, bears the appropriately lengthy title “A (radically condensed and expanded) SUPPOSEDLY FUN THING I’LL NEVER DO AGAIN (after David Foster Wallace).”

headline: Notre Dame Rolls as St. Bonaventure’s Run Comes to End
text: RALEIGH, N.C. — The team records St. Bonaventure set this season might never be matched, the heights perhaps never reached again. And that is what the Bonnies can take from a season in which they made the N.C.A.A. women’s tournament for the first time in history and advanced all the way to the Raleigh Region semifinals.

headline: Bell Tones Are Ringing in Percussion and Piano Program
text: The composer George Crumb, in program notes for a classic 1975 recording of his “Music for a Summer Evening (Makrokosmos III),” cited as a primary influence Bartok’s groundbreaking Sonata for Two Pianos and Percussion. “It is curious that other composers did not subsequently contribute to the genre,” he wrote. Not so curious, perhaps, if you consider the labor entailed in transporting and arranging the disparate, bulky equipment involved.

headline: Serenity That Barely Masks the Passion and the Whimsy
text: Yefim Bronfman, an accomplished, admired and much-traveled pianist, did not have the best 2011, it would seem. The last time he was scheduled to present a solo recital at Carnegie Hall, almost a year ago, he canceled because of exhaustion. In October he missed an Oregon engagement because of an ear infection, and he fractured a finger during a recital in Berkeley, Calif., that month, causing further cancellations.

headline: Kentucky in Final Four; Its Next Goal Is a State Title
text: ATLANTA — Kentucky was not bothered by Baylor’s height or its players’ wingspans, and it was not bothered by the Bears’ 1-3-1 zone defense. Nor were the Wildcats unnerved by their ragged play in the second half, which enabled Baylor to make a brief challenge in the N.C.A.A. tournament’s South Region championship game on Sunday. Kentucky also handled a scary fall by its all-American center, Anthony Davis, and the strain of second-half foul trouble on its seven-man rotation.

headline: TNT Promotes New Version of ‘Dallas’ Series
text: The cable channel TNT will bring a new meaning to April showers to promote the return of a familiar series known for the most celebrated shower scene since “Psycho.”

headline: Living Large and Falling Out in Deepest Brooklyn
text: There is no rest for the defenders of Italian-American dignity in the greater New York area. MTV’s “Jersey Shore” may have finished its season, but on the horizon are TLC’s “Mama’s Boys of the Bronx” (April 9), about Arthur Avenue homeboys who live with their mothers, and A&E’s “Rambug” (May 5), about “a brawny group of hard-working, over-the-top Italian exterminators from Brooklyn.”

headline: Vanderbilt Knockout Teams Final
text: MEMPHIS — The 64-board final of the Vanderbilt Knockout Teams was played in Memphis on Sunday, the last day of the Spring North American Championships.

headline: A Far-Off Island Where the American Dream Curdles
text: The main character in P. F. Kluge’s stingingly funny new novel, “The Master Blaster,” isn’t a person. It’s a location: Saipan, a very small island with a big, bizarre place in history. Saipan is one of the Northern Mariana Islands in the western Pacific, north of the Solomons and west of the Marshalls. It was a site of brutal fighting during World War II, grimly commemorated by one cliff nicknamed Suicide and another called Banzai. Its neighbor is Tinian, the island from which the Enola Gay took off to bomb Hiroshima.

headline: A Down Dog
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Follow That Grid
text: Administrivial New Puzzle Book Alert! My Fearless Leader from the Onion/A.V. Club puzzles, the highly talented and extremely dangerous Ben Tausig, has a fabulous new puzzle book out called “Crosswords From the Underground”, a compilation of his work in alternative newspapers. These puzzles, along with his commentary, are Not Safe For Work or the Easily Offended, but if you want to try some grids that are very different from your New York Times fare, clicky here.

headline: They Work Hard For The Money
text: OK, I wasn’t going to post anything else, but as Robert Farley says, this WaPo piece on underworked college teachers is outrageous.

headline: Fiona Apple Performs
text: Images from Fiona Apple’s concert at the Music Hall of Williamsburg.

headline: Fiona Apple Returns to the Faithful
text: Fiona Apple has control. That’s clear from the moment she took the stage on Friday night at the Music Hall of Williamsburg in Brooklyn. She opened with some patter about missing her dog (of whom she had a painting), an insistence that people in the crowd not talk during the show and then announced, “I will give you everything I can possibly give you,” before opening her first New York concert in five years with a staggeringly loud, brightly alive “Fast as You Can,” spitting out her syllables in carefully measured cadences, her body shivering with vigor.

headline: From Stage to Screen, Still Intact
text: During the intermissions of the live broadcast of the Royal Ballet’s “Romeo and Juliet” on Thursday from the Royal Opera House in Covent Garden, enthusiastic tweets were streamed onto the screen from viewers in Prague, Buenos Aires and New York, as well as parts of Britain. Here’s hoping this series of transmissions continues to develop. They do much to give us an immediate sense of how dance companies far away are looking.

headline: Obama Warns North Korea
text: At a news conference in South Korea, President Obama urged China to use its influence to stop North Korea from proceeding with plans to launch a satellite.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

text: To the Editor:

text: To the Editor:

text: To the Editor:

headline: In Malaysia, Alonso Wins Race but Perez Wins Stardom
text: KUALA LUMPUR — Just when it seemed that Formula One could not come up with any more fairy-tale race scenarios, the rain in Malaysia produced a race like none other we had seen before, with the unlikely revival of Fernando Alonso and the Ferrari team winning while in the throes of a tortuous season debut, and the even more unlikely surfacing of a new star. That was Sergio Perez, the 22-year-old Mexican driver who finished second in the race in the Sauber car.

headline: Measuring Quality of Care
text: To the Editor:

headline: Benefits of Natural Gas
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Game Explodes and Changes Life Overnight at a Struggling Start-Up
text: At a cocktail party on the second floor of the expensive Bowery Hotel in Manhattan on Thursday night, as trays of stuffed mushrooms and thinly sliced filet mignon circulated, Charles Forman was marveling at how quickly things can change.

headline: With Summit of Arab Leaders, Iraq Seeks to Shift Image
text: BAGHDAD — As Arab leaders converge on Baghdad for a landmark summit meeting this week, they will be treated to carefully chosen glimpses of a new Iraq: gleaming hotel lobbies, renovated palaces and young palm trees lining an airport highway once called the Road of Death.

headline: Indian Activist Attempts Revival of Antigraft Drive
text: NEW DELHI — The activist Anna Hazare returned to the spotlight with a protest on Sunday, wearing his familiar white Gandhian cap and sitting cross-legged for a one-day hunger strike against corruption. The crowds again chanted his name and again wore “I Am Anna” hats, as his cohort of advisers shouted slogans against the government.

headline: Rehabilitating the Alienated and Addicted
text: The second half of the 41st annual New Directors/New Films has arrived with more yowzas than yawns. What a relief! In recent years this venture of the Film Society of Lincoln Center and the Museum of Modern Art, which aims to showcase worthy emerging filmmakers, has at times struggled to find enough good movies to fill out its 12 days. This week’s lineup includes several standouts, notably “Oslo, August 31st” (yes, from Norway) by Joachim Trier, one of the discoveries from the 2011 Cannes Film Festival. Just as crucial, even some of the lesser selections offer something for viewers to consider, if only an aesthetic or a worldview to argue against, or maybe hate.

headline: Dance in India
text: Images of some of the dance companies in India.

headline: Visions of India Dancing and Dancing and Dancing
text: When an illustrious Indian dance company performs in New York, as the Nrityagram Dance Ensemble did at the Joyce Theater last week, we can take both pleasure and instruction from it. Music and dance operate in thrilling proximity; the visual sensuousness is in many ways exceptional; the levels of technical achievement and stylistic polish are high. Best of all we’re given a window into a culture far from our own.

headline: Auriemma Growls, and UConn Roars to a Convincing Win
text: KINGSTON, R.I. — Penn State started slowly Sunday, the players’ nerves jangled by the size of the challenge in front of them. But this is a team that fashions itself as an offensive dynamo, and it cut a 14-point deficit to 5 in hardly any time at all.

headline: Filmmaker in Submarine Voyages to Bottom of Sea
text: James Cameron, the filmmaker whose credits include “Avatar” and “Titanic,” plunged on Sunday in a minisubmarine of his own design to the bottom of the planet’s deepest recess, sinking through the dark waters of the western Pacific to a depth of nearly seven miles.

headline: When a Parking Lot Is So Much More
text: Cambridge, Mass.

headline: Anita Steckel, Artist Who Created Erotic Works, Dies at 82
text: Anita Steckel, whose playful and sometimes unsettling erotic works were little known outside the mostly underground world of feminist art until she was discovered in her 70s and her creations acclaimed as masterly and groundbreaking, died on March 16 in Manhattan. She was 82.

headline: Looking Ahead to Economic Reports This Week
text: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data will include pending home sales for February (Monday); the Standard & Poor’s/Case-Shiller home price index for January and consumer confidence for March (Tuesday); durable goods orders for February (Wednesday); weekly jobless claims and the final gross domestic product for the fourth quarter (Thursday); and personal income and spending for February, the Chicago Purchasing Managers Index for March and the Thomson Reuters/University of Michigan consumer sentiment index for March (Friday)

headline: The Rich Get Even Richer
text: NEW statistics show an ever-more-startling divergence between the fortunes of the wealthy and everybody else — and the desperate need to address this wrenching problem. Even in a country that sometimes seems inured to income inequality, these takeaways are truly stunning.

headline: After 923 Days, It’s Official: Woods Ends Tour Drought
text: ORLANDO, Fla. — For the 54-hole leader, the final round of a PGA Tour event is a mirror that reflects his flaws, his fears, his focus and his facility. On Sunday at the Arnold Palmer Invitational, the eyes of the golf world were on Tiger Woods to see which face he put forward.

headline: U.S. and Turkey to Step Up ‘Nonlethal’ Aid to Rebels in Syria
text: BEIRUT — Turkey and the United States plan to provide “nonlethal” assistance, like communications equipment and medical supplies, directly to opposition groups inside Syria, and will urge other allies to do so as well, the White House deputy national security adviser said on Sunday, after President Obama met with the prime minister of Turkey at a nuclear security conference in Seoul, South Korea.

text: Accounts

headline: Queens G.O.P. Endorses Halloran for Congress
text: The Queens Republican Party on Sunday endorsed Councilman Daniel J. Halloran III as its Congressional candidate in a new district that has been carved out of the one represented by Gary L. Ackerman, a veteran congressman who abruptly announced his retirement this month.

headline: Pitching the Ad Life to the Digital Set
text: THE leading trade organization for advertising agencies is intensifying efforts to cast a wider net when recruiting employees with an initiative aimed not only at students, but also at talented younger people who work in other industries.

headline: Hashtag Activism, and Its Limits
text: If you “like” something, does that mean you care about it?

headline: With North Carolina Cracking, Kansas Keeps Its Cool
text: ST. LOUIS — Roy Williams cries as easily as some people take jump shots. Williams, the North Carolina coach, figured to be teary after the Tar Heels let a chance at their 19th Final Four appearance slip away in the final minutes on Sunday against Kansas. And the worst part was admitting what happened.

headline: Chávez in Cuba for Treatment, but Hasn’t Sought Visit With Pope
text: CARACAS, Venezuela — President Hugo Chávez of Venezuela flew to Cuba over the weekend to begin radiation therapy to treat the return of his cancer, he said Sunday. He will be there during Pope Benedict XVI’s visit to Cuba, which begins Monday.

headline: No Longer Burning, the South Bronx Gentrifies
text: When William Casari moved to the Grand Concourse seven years ago, some people passing him on the sidewalk figured he was either an undercover police officer or a Yankees fan who had wandered off from the stadium.

headline: What Gender Gap? Washington State Has a History of Women Who Lead
text: SEATTLE — It was 2009, floods had inundated western Washington and the state’s politicians were flown up to survey the damage. When asked who would scoot down to the open end of the C-17 cargo plane, where they would have to be tethered down for safety, Gov. Christine Gregoire and Senators Maria Cantwell and Patty Murray volunteered.

headline: Israel’s Top Court Orders Settlers to Leave Outpost
text: JERUSALEM — Israel’s Supreme Court on Sunday ordered a West Bank settlers’ outpost built on private Palestinian land to be dismantled by Aug. 1, rejecting a government compromise with the settlers that would have allowed them to stay put for another three years.

headline: Bringing an Open-Source Ethos to Bands
text: When Maggie Vail first heard about open-source software, she said, “it felt like punk rock.”

headline: Tough End for Baylor, but Future Is Promising
text: ATLANTA — Baylor warmed up for its regional final matchup with Kentucky on Sunday wearing matching T-shirts that read, “One Team, One God, One Goal.”

headline: How a Short Sale Works
text: An investor who expects a stock to fall in price may execute a short sale. If the price of the stock does fall, he can make a profit.

headline: BATS Trading Error Bolsters Case for Curbs
text: The exchange operator BATS Global Markets styled itself as the future of stock trading — faster, more efficient — when it began in 2005. Its name stood for Better Alternative Trading System.

headline: Tebow May Play Various Roles, Ryan Suggests
text: PALM BEACH, Fla. — Tim Tebow will be at the center of the most well-attended news conference in backup quarterback history Monday. But on Sunday, Jets Coach Rex Ryan opened the door to something more: that Tebow could be used at other positions.

headline: A Turbulence-Free Election in Senegal
text: DAKAR, Senegal — The elderly president of this West African nation conceded defeat after elections here on Sunday, a rare example of a prompt and peaceful political turnover in a region tormented by coups and leaders who refuse to give up power.

headline: Transcript of Depositions in Case (Note: Some passages include vulgar language)
text: Testifying recently in a lawsuit that is unrelated to Copper River’s closing, Marc Cohedes maintained that actions taken in the fall of 2008 by Goldman Sachs had done irreparable damage to his fund. (Note: Some passages include vulgar language).

headline: Lobbyists, Guns and Money
text: Florida’s now-infamous Stand Your Ground law, which lets you shoot someone you consider threatening without facing arrest, let alone prosecution, sounds crazy — and it is. And it’s tempting to dismiss this law as the work of ignorant yahoos. But similar laws have been pushed across the nation, not by ignorant yahoos but by big corporations.

headline: Pineda Hits the Gas, and His Fastball’s Speed Jumps
text: TAMPA, Fla. — With a solid performance Sunday, Yankees pitcher Michael Pineda might have quelled for now some of the near panic over the mysterious loss of three or four miles per hour on his fastball.

headline: I Regret Eating My Placenta
text: It’s not as gross as it sounds, but then, it couldn’t possibly be, right? As a first-time pregnant lady living in crunchy Santa Monica, Calif., next to a raw food restaurant and a seemingly oxymoronic homeopathic pharmacy, hiring a so-called celebrity placenta processor seemed to make sense. Even the hospital birth class had suggested the practice of eating one’s own placenta as a natural way to ward off postpartum depression. It’s normal. It’s natural. Even January Jones is doing it.

headline: Santorum Calls Romney ‘Worst Republican’ to Run Against Obama
text: RACINE, Wis. – Rick Santorum urged Republicans here Sunday evening to carefully study the record of Mitt Romney, declaring: “He is the worst Republican in the country to put up against Barack Obama.”

headline: Wagner Promotes Assistant to Replace Hurley
text: Wagner has promoted assistant Bashir Mason to be its head basketball coach, replacing Dan Hurley, who left for the Rhode Island coaching job.

headline: Anger at Goldman Still Simmers
text: Just before the financial crisis began in September 2008, a prominent hedge fund appeared well positioned to take advantage of any turmoil in the markets. That fund, Copper River Partners, had made sizable bets months earlier against companies whose stocks it expected to suffer.

headline: In Pakistan, Hindus Say Woman’s Conversion to Islam Was Coerced
text: GHOTKI, Pakistan — Banditry is an old scourge in this impoverished district of southern Pakistan, on the plains between the mighty river Indus and a sprawling desert, where roving gangs rob and kidnap with abandon. Lately, though, local passions have stirred with allegations of an unusual theft: that of a young woman’s heart.

headline: Passing Motion Evolves, but Scrutiny Is Constant
text: Tim Tebow’s tenure at Florida was defined by team greatness and individual excellence, a stretch of success epitomized by his final game with the Gators, when he completed 31 of 35 passes for 482 yards in a Sugar Bowl victory against Cincinnati. His dazzling college career complete, Tebow did what anyone else in his position would do: he set off to rebuild himself.

headline: In Jackson Heights, Movers Respect Turf Rules
text: It is a well-established fact in Jackson Heights, Queens, that the moving men of La Noventa and the moving men of La Ciento y Tres do not mix.

headline: Waiting (and Sleeping) in Line, for View of Health Care History

headline: Not Worth the Paper It’s Built On
text: DUBLIN — As an emblem of the modern Irish condition, Frank Buckley is almost too apt. Dead broke, he lives in a house made of money.

headline: Red Bulls Quickly Change the Mood at Home
text: HARRISON, N.J. — After a sputtering, mistake-laden start to their season in which they lost two games on the road, the Red Bulls needed a mere six minutes Sunday afternoon to turn Red Bull Arena into a nearly impregnable fortress.

headline: After Detective’s Firing, Tensions Linger in Bell Case
text: The dismissal of the undercover detective who fired the first of the 50 police bullets when Sean Bell was killed more than five years ago may close the final chapter of that drawn-out story. But on the Queens streets near the site of Mr. Bell’s shooting, residents expressed anger, and resentments that remain unresolved.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: March 25, 2012

headline: E-Mail to Corzine Said Transfer Was Not Customer Money
text: Jon S. Corzine, the former chief executive of MF Global, was told during the brokerage firm’s final day of business that a crucial transfer of $175 million came from the firm’s own money, not from a customer account, according to an internal e-mail.

headline: Young Met Faces a Peer; Similarities End There
text: VIERA, Fla. — The humdrum days of spring training can be enlivened by games like these, ones that invite observers to imagine the future through a lens of intrigue.

headline: Catholic Church Deals With a Diminished Role in Cuban Life
text: HAVANA — At an evangelical church booming with pounding drums, crashing cymbals and a throaty bass, members of an overflow crowd danced in the aisles, sang over a soaring trumpet and swept their arms in prayer. One woman shook violently, her hand aloft as if to say enough, or perhaps more.

headline: Egypt Ruling Council Says Brotherhood Is Trying to Undermine It
text: CAIRO — Egypt’s ruling military council lashed out at the powerful Muslim Brotherhood on Sunday, accusing the group of trying to undermine the government and of questioning the motives of the military rulers. The statement was a sign of mounting tensions between the country’s increasingly assertive Islamists and often intractable military rulers, as Egypt prepares for a presidential election to begin in May.

headline: Abduction and Hotel Attack Spotlight Libya’s Disarray
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — Fighters from the town of Zintan stormed into and shot up the luxury hotel that is the de facto base for members of Libya’s ruling Transitional National Council over the weekend, days after members of the council acknowledged that a rival militia from Misurata had kidnapped and briefly detained two of its members last week.

headline: Summitt Retains Her Essence but Lets Go of the Reins
text: DES MOINES

headline: When Other Voices Are Drowned Out
text: The Supreme Court’s 5-to-4 ruling in Citizens United in 2010 was shaped by an extreme view of the First Amendment: money equals speech, and independent spending by wealthy organizations and individuals poses no problem to the political system. The court cavalierly dismissed worries that those with big bank accounts — and big megaphones — have an unfair advantage in exerting political power. It simply asserted that “the people have the ultimate influence over elected officials” — as if campaigns were not in the business of influencing and manipulating voters.

headline: ‘Good Wife’ Watch: Alicia Florrick v. the Patriarchy
text: Which was worse in “Blue Ribbon Panel,” Sunday night’s episode of “The Good Wife” (which began 20 minutes late, this time because of college basketball)?

headline: The Wall Between Contractors and Politics
text: Since 1940, it has been illegal for federal government contractors to contribute to federal political campaigns or parties. But in the new unregulated, unlimited jungle of campaign finance, Mitt Romney’s super PAC is allowing some contractors to violate that historic ban, taking yet another dangerous step toward a culture where government business is done on a pay-to-play basis.

headline: At Ailing Brooklyn Hospital, Insider Deals and Lavish Perks
text: In recent years, Wyckoff Heights Medical Center in Brooklyn has often gone hat in hand to the city and state, lamenting cuts in government assistance and questioning whether officials truly understood the burden of running a nonprofit hospital in Bushwick, one of the city’s poorest neighborhoods.

headline: Wielding Fire, Islamists Target Nigeria Schools
text: MAIDUGURI, Nigeria — The teenager in the immaculate white robe stood in the ruins of what had been his school. There were no classrooms, no desks or chairs, no intact blackboards — there was, in fact, no longer any reason for him to be there.

headline: Once Neighboring Congressmen, Iowans Compete for Same Seat
text: URBANDALE, Iowa — Representative Tom Latham cut into a frosted cinnamon roll roughly the size of his face and listened intently as a group of small-business owners lit into him about sprinkler rules and federal financial regulations. It was the second of a dozen meetings on a recent Wednesday in one of the counties in his native Iowa that Mr. Latham, a Republican, has not represented before in Congress.

headline: Dementia Behind Bars
text: The get-tough-on-crime and mandatory sentencing policies that swept America beginning in the 1970s did more than drive up the inmate population and prison costs. They also ensured that inmates who once might have been seen as rehabilitated and given parole would grow old and even die behind bars. As a result, prisons are struggling to furnish costly, specialized care to ever more inmates who suffer from age-related infirmities, especially dementia.

headline: Is the Court Being Thoughtful or Partisan?
text: Are the Supreme Court justices giving due consideration to the health care law, or preparing to engage in “judicial activism” to reduce federal power?

headline: London Suddenly Further Away for U.S. Soccer Team
text: NASHVILLE — After a surprising 2-0 loss to Canada on Saturday night put its Olympic hopes in jeopardy, the United States under-23 team is preparing for a must-win game against El Salvador on Monday.

headline: Red Bulls Get a Win; U.S. Under-23s Need One Badly
text: On Sunday afternoon, the Red Bulls won their home opener, beating the Colorado Rapids, 4-1, to give their fans something to think about other than their poor performances in two season-opening losses on the road. (Highlights here.) On Monday night, the United States under-23 team will face El Salvador in Nashville in a game critical to its hopes of playing in the London Olympics this summer. Jack Bell of The Times was at the Red Bulls’ win, and Brian Sciaretta previewed the Olympic team’s predicament.

headline: N.C.A.A. Tournament Photo Replay: March 25
text: Kentucky reached the Final Four with a dominant win over Baylor, 82-70. Kansas defeated North Carolina, 80-67, to earn its second berth in five years.

headline: Gingrich Is Soldiering On, Despite Dearth of Victories
text: Primary by primary, Newt Gingrich’s reasons for remaining in the presidential race keep getting knocked down.

headline: Santorum Ignores Pressure to Bow Out to Romney
text: RACINE, Wis. — Mitt Romney remains his biggest foe, but Rick Santorum is increasingly confronting an even more daunting obstacle: a rising chorus of Republicans calling for the divisive presidential contest to end so the party can turn its full attention to defeating President Obama.

headline: Fighting to Control the Meaning of ‘Obamacare’
text: How the parties have used or tried to use an invented word to shape public opinion.

headline: ‘Mad Men’ Recap: In the Season 5 Premiere, After a Long Layoff, a Party
text: Season 5, Episode 1Our initial “Mad Men” recap of Season 5 will be brief; for a more complete examination of Sunday’s two-hour-plus season premiere and the return of AMC’s wildly popular show after a 17-month hiatus, please refer to Alessandra Stanley’s TV Watch from this past Friday.

headline: Police Critically Wound Man Who Shot at Them in Harlem
text: A man was critically wounded by the police Sunday night after an exchange of gunfire with one of two officers who had been following him in West Harlem, the authorities said.

headline: Qantas in China Venture for Budget Airline
text: HONG KONG — Qantas Airways of Australia announced Monday that it was teaming up with one of the biggest carriers in China to form a low-cost airline based in Hong Kong, the latest in a string of airline ventures in Asia as carriers race to position themselves in anticipation of a major increase in air travel.

headline: Putting Babies to Bed Safely
text: Nearly two decades after a public health campaign began promoting sleep safety for babies, many parents and caretakers are still unaware of the habits that can lead to sudden infant death syndrome, or SIDS, a new study suggests.

headline: Microsoft Raids Tackle Internet Crime
text: SEATTLE — Microsoft employees, accompanied by United States marshals, raided two nondescript office buildings in Pennsylvania and Illinois on Friday, aiming to disrupt one of the most pernicious forms of online crime today — botnets, or groups of computers that help harvest bank account passwords and other personal information from millions of other computers.

headline: Word of the Day | forestall
text: forestall •\fȯr-ˈstȯl\• verb

headline: Venus Williams Saves Match Point and Rallies to Win
text: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla. — Though Venus Williams has been playing professional tennis since 1994, it is nearly impossible to know what comes next from her.

headline: BATS Chief on Friday’s Troubles: ‘My Stomach Sank’
text: Friday morning did not go quite the way Joe Ratterman had expected.

headline: For Cheney, Pros and Cons in New Heart
text: It was the first time he was offered a transplant in the 20 months he had been on the waiting list, and Dick Cheney, the former vice president, decided to take it, his principal cardiologist said in a telephone interview Sunday, the day after the successful seven-hour operation.

headline: Building a House Brings Members of a Community Closer
text: In Glastonbury, Conn., a series of interactions that led to the construction of a veteran’s new home is seen as more than just luck.

headline: Irving Louis Horowitz, Sociologist and Ideological Critic, Dies at 82
text: Irving Louis Horowitz, an eminent sociologist and prolific author who started a leading journal in his field but who came to fear that his discipline risked being captured by left-wing ideologues, died on Wednesday in Princeton, N.J. He was 82.

headline: Town Jumps on Board to Embrace a Marine
text: GLASTONBURY, Conn. — Ask people in this Hartford suburb how the campaign to build “Manny’s house” went viral, and they may consult a spreadsheet or sketch a Venn diagram or two. Trust them when they say, “It’s complicated.”

headline: The Ups and Downs of the Game’s Greats Who Moved On Late
text: Old soldiers never die, Gen. Douglas MacArthur once said, they just fade away. Old quarterbacks also never die, they just fade into a different uniform.

headline: Sisters on Stanford Take the Teammate Bond to Another Level
text: FRESNO, Calif. — The play-by-play sheet did not mark the exact moment, and there was no telephone changing booth in sight. Just the same, Nnemkadi Ogwumike somehow switched from Stanford teammate to Super Sister the split second Chiney Ogwumike crumpled with a yelp to the hardwood floor of the Save Mart Center on Saturday night.

headline: Chamberlain Exits Hospital With a Positive Prognosis
text: TAMPA, Fla. — Joba Chamberlain was released from St. Joseph’s Hospital on Sunday and will spend the next six weeks in a cast as he recovers from surgery to repair a dislocated right ankle.

headline: The Renegade Republicans
text: For nearly three decades, South Carolina served as the bulwark of the Republican establishment. The state has been the killing ground of insurgent presidential bids again and again: John Connolly’s 1980 challenge to Ronald Reagan, who finally had the backing of the party establishment; Pat Buchanan’s attempt to oust George Bush in 1992; John McCain’s bid to push aside George W. Bush in 2000; and most recently Mike Huckabee’s 2008 assault on McCain.

headline: Neither Phones, Nor Cameras, Nor Tweets in the Court
text: WASHINGTON — There was a time — before Twitter, cable TV, bloggers and mobile apps — when political reporters in Washington waited until the end of a big campaign rally, court case or Congressional hearing before rushing to tap out their stories or call in their scoops.

headline: Anna Hazare Tries to Renew Anticorruption Movement
text: The activist Anna Hazare returned to the spotlight with a protest on Sunday, “wearing his familiar white Gandhian cap and sitting cross-legged for a one-day hunger strike against corruption,” Jim Yardley writes in The New York Times. “The crowds again chanted his name and again wore “I Am Anna” hats, as his cohort of advisers shouted slogans against the government.”

headline: Rushworth M. Kidder, Journalist Who Studied Ethics, Dies at 67
text: Rushworth M. Kidder, an academic-turned-journalist who founded a research institute dedicated to mapping approaches to ethical dilemmas and propounded his ideas in books, speeches and seminars, died on March 5 at a nursing home in Davie, Fla. He was 67.

headline: ‘Socialists.com’ Yields a Presidential Result
text: The evidence is unmistakable, the president’s opponents say. Type “socialists.com” into your Web browser. Press “enter.” And behold the smiling face of President Obama, greeting visitors to his campaign Web site.

headline: School District Told to Replace Web Filter Blocking Pro-Gay Sites
text: CAMDENTON, Mo. — Students using the computers at Camdenton High School here in central Missouri have been able to access the Web sites for Exodus International, as well as People Can Change, antigay organizations that counsel men and women on how to become heterosexual.

headline: Debate Shifts From the Trail to the Capital
text: For months, the political debate in Washington has been defined largely by the seemingly constant confrontations on the Republican presidential campaign trail. That is about to change, at least for a while.

headline: Your Suggestions for ‘India in One, Two or Three Weeks’
text: “India in One, Two or Three Weeks,” an article by Guy Trebay in the Travel section of The New York Times, advises “a policy of less is more is always sensible in India, in order to limit the shock the place inevitably delivers to an average Westerner’s system.”

headline: Giants’ Mara Defends Ruling Against Cowboys and Redskins
text: The Washington Redskins and the Dallas Cowboys, two of the N.F.L.’s highest-profile and richest teams, have filed for arbitration in their dispute with the league over its decision to strip them of a combined $46 million in salary-cap space.

headline: Visions of India Dancing and Dancing and Dancing
text: New York hosts several first-rate Indian companies or dance soloists each year, Alastair Macaulay writes in The New York Times.

headline: Paying a Price Amid the Fog of War
text: HONG KONG — Call it assistance, call it regrettable, call it $50,000 for each dead body, but do not call it compensation.

headline: Obama Urges China to Restrain North Korea as He Praises South’s Successes
text: SEOUL, South Korea — President Obama took North Korea’s untested new leader, Kim Jong-un, to task on Monday, demanding that China curb his belligerent behavior and declaring that South Korea’s economic and democratic achievements would inevitably triumph over the failure and isolation of the North.

headline: News Quiz | March 26, 2012
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s front page. Good luck!

headline: NYT Front Page for 03/26/2012
text: NYT Front Page for 03/26/2012

headline: Britain Seeks Investigation of Businessman’s Death in China
text: BEIJING — Britain has asked China to open an inquiry into the death in November of a British citizen linked to the family of Bo Xilai, the Chinese Politburo member whose dismissal this month as Communist Party secretary of Chongqing was widely said to reveal a deep split among the nation’s leaders.

headline: Spain’s Ruling Party Disappointed in Regional Ballot
text: MADRID — Prime minister Mariano Rajoy of Spain insisted on Monday that his government would forge ahead with further austerity cuts and economic reforms, even after his Popular Party suffered its first disappointment at the polls since taking office, failing to win an absolute majority in an election in Andalusia, the country’s most populous region.

headline: March 26, 1979 | Israel and Egypt Sign Peace Treaty
text: On March 26, 1979, in a ceremony hosted by U.S. President Jimmy Carter at the White House, Israeli Prime Minister Menachem Begin and Egyptian President Anwar Sadat signed the Israel-Egypt Peace Treaty, the first peace treaty between Israel and an Arab country.

headline: Mumbai Gets Its Own Walk of Fame
text: If staring at Bollywood stars’ houses, waiting patiently for them to go grocery shopping, or living vicariously through gossip columns is not enough for you, there’s India’s brand-new, star-studded walk of fame.

headline: Test Yourself | Math, March 26, 2012
text: Test your math skills with this question created by Pete Diamantis at Math for America from the article “N.C.A.A. Builds Solid Brackets From a Shaky Foundation.”

headline: Lelyveld on Writing About Gandhi
text: In a talk hosted by India Ink and Caravan Magazine last month, Joseph Lelyveld, author of “Great Soul: Mahatma Gandhi and His Struggle With India,” spoke with Ananya Vajpeyi, a visiting fellow at the Center for the Study of Developing Societies, about the inspiration behind his book and how he researched his study of one of the 20th century’s most written about men.

headline: In Moscow, Little Girl Soldiers
text: They prepare for classes and make their beds together, gently setting a teddy bear and a stuffed crocodile on pillows. They look intently at themselves as they fix oversize white bows, meant to symbolize purity, in their hair.

headline: 3 NATO Soldiers Killed by Afghan Security Officers
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Three NATO soldiers were shot to death on Monday in two separate confrontations involving Afghan security forces, officials said, adding to a string of “green on blue” killings that have complicated the relationship between Afghanistan and its Western allies.

headline: Turkey and Norway Shut Embassies in Syria; New Shelling Is Reported in Homs
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Turkey and Norway closed their embassies in Syria on Monday and ordered all diplomatic staff withdrawn in response to the government’s harsh repression of the year-old uprising, as opposition activists reported a new spasm of army shelling in Homs, the rebellious city that Syrian security forces had proclaimed purged of insurgents just a few weeks ago.

headline: Health Act Arguments Open With Obstacle From 1867
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday starts three days of hearings on the constitutionality of the 2010 health care overhaul law, an epic clash that could recast the very structure of American government. But it begins with a 90-minute argument on what a lawyer in the case has called “the most boring jurisdictional stuff one can imagine.”

headline: Roche Extends Deadline for Illumina Offer
text: Roche Holding is not taking no for an answer.

headline: Every Block, Every Borough

headline: The Start of BigFuture, a New College Planning Web Site
text: The College Board, the nonprofit association of colleges and universities that oversees the SAT and Advanced Placement program,  has introduced a new college planning Web site that it hopes will help a wide range of students, including first-generation college students who may not know much about the college admissions process.

headline: The Early Word: Marathon

headline: Fantasy Focus: Five Big Questions
text: As fantasy owners look toward opening day, a number of questions remain on playing time, roles and the merits of spring statistics in determining regular-season performance. Here’s a look at five situations on many an owner’s mind:

headline: Robert Bales and the Twin Lessons of Afghanistan, 170 Years Apart
text: It was already very old news when William Tecumseh Sherman remarked in 1872 that war is hell. In the specific case of Afghanistan, armies have been seeing that firsthand since Alexander the Great gave up on Kandahar in the third century B.C.

headline: ‘Bullitt’ Shadow Looms Large Over ‘Alcatraz’ Finale
text: “The series takes place in San Francisco, so we thought we’d tip our hat to it and do an homage,” Jack Bender, an executive producer of Fox’s science-fiction series “Alcatraz,” said in an interview. Mr. Bender’s hat was tipped toward “Bullitt,” the 1968 film starring Steve McQueen, in particular its chase scene, perhaps the most closely studied car sequence in cinema.

headline: What Can Other Schools Learn — and Copy — From Your School?
text: Think about your school–its routines, schedule, even traditions and unofficial habits that are all part of the average day. How does it work? How many teachers do you have? How much time do you spend in each’s classroom? Do your teachers collaborate with each other on projects? What successful aspects of your school could other schools could learn from?

headline: Fragile Freedoms in Myanmar
text: YANGON, Myanmar — Until just recently, I would have said that if you didn’t want to risk getting arrested in Myanmar, you should stay away from that red and gold insignia with the fighting peacock.

headline: Monday Morning Beauty Tip: A Second Life for Your Manicure
text: Manicures chip— and fast. But recently — and quite by accident — I discovered how to wring a few more days out of my Nars polish in Night Breed ($18), a limited-edition deep plum with a hint of sparkle.

headline: Daily Report: Microsoft Takes Down Botnets
text: Microsoft employees, accompanied by United States marshals, raided two office buildings in Pennsylvania and Illinois on Friday, aiming to disrupt one of the most pernicious forms of online crime today: botnets, or groups of computers that help harvest bank account passwords and other personal information from millions of other computers.

headline: The Hummingbird on West 81st Street
text: New Yorkers weren’t the only ones who enjoyed the mild winter this year. Thanks to the warm temperatures and absent flurries, a Rufous hummingbird called the American Museum of Natural History home, to the delight of museumgoers and staff members alike.

headline: Poll: 47 Percent Disapprove of Health Care Law
text: More Americans continue to disapprove of the federal health care legislation than support it, with a deep partisan divide underscoring their views, according to a New York Times/CBS News poll.

headline: Survey Suggests Domestic Demand Is Rising in Germany
text: FRANKFURT — Germany’s famously thrifty consumers may finally be more willing to spend, according to data released Monday, raising the prospect that domestic demand could take the place of flagging exports and help pull the rest of Europe out of recession.

headline: Districts Moving Against 'Pink Slime'
text: Even as the United States Department of Agriculture says it will begin offering schools alternatives to products that contain so-called "pink slime," an ammonia-based filler for ground beef, parents are pressing school districts around the country to stop serving the products now -- and some school districts are responding, The New York Times reported this weekend.

headline: Monday Reading: Schools Drop ‘Pink Slime’ From Cafeteria Menus
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: Bernanke Says Faster Growth Is Needed to Bolster Job Market
text: WASHINGTON — In a speech that sought by turns to deflate optimism and pessimism about the labor market, the Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, said Monday that the Fed’s efforts to stimulate growth were gradually reducing unemployment, but that the scale and duration of the problem could leave lasting scars on the economy.

headline: What the Tebow Billboard Says
text: The introductory news conference for Tim Tebow will occur later Monday, at noon, but the billboard is already here, on the New Jersey side of the Lincoln Tunnel.

headline: Britain Fines Coutts Over Rules Against Money Laundering
text: LONDON — British regulators on Monday fined the private bank Coutts £8.75 million ($13.9 million) over failing to follow standards intended to fight money laundering.

headline: Afghan in Army Uniform Kills 2 NATO Troops
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — A man wearing an Afghan military uniform turned his weapon on British soldiers in southern Helmand Province on Monday, killing two of them before being shot to death himself, officials said, in what appeared to be the latest in a disturbing string of retaliatory attacks against Western forces in Afghanistan.

headline: An Inventor of Russian Democracy
text: MOSCOW — I wanted to write her story for a long time. To be precise, I wanted to write this story: She was Vladimir Putin’s oldest enemy, and she lived to see his demise.

headline: Mike Daisey Apologizes for Falsehoods in Monologue About Apple
text: After several days at the center of a storm of controversy and often heated debate about the boundaries between journalism and theater, the performer Mike Daisey has offered an apology for the exaggerations and falsehoods in his show “The Agony and the Ecstasy of Steve Jobs,” writing on his blog that he had “failed to honor the contract I’d established with my audiences over many years and many shows.”

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: ‘Hunger Games’ Changes the Rules, and How News of Trayvon Martin Spread
text: “The Hunger Games” took in $155 million over the weekend, a huge total that broke new ground in box office results, Brooks Barnes reported. First, it was the largest weekend for a spring release, demonstrating that blockbusters don’t have to open in the summer; also, with the end of the Harry Potter series, and the coming finale of the “Twilight” series, it positions “Hunger Games” as the next popular movie franchise.

headline: Remembering DiMaggio as More Than Just a Ballplayer
text: There was an exquisite side-by-side placement of two obituaries in this newspaper just before the weekend, one of Murray Lender and the other of Samuel Glazer. Mr. Lender, who was 81, made bagels, lots of them. Mr. Glazer, 89, was a creator of Mr. Coffee, once the hottest thing in coffee since Juan Valdez.

headline: Jimmy Kimmel to Host Emmys Telecast
text: The Emmy Awards, to be televised on ABC in September, will be hosted by Jimmy Kimmel, the network’s late-night comedian. ABC announced the booking on Monday morning, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Kimmel has never hosted the Emmys before.

headline: Congress Keeps Its Focus on Jobs
text: The House is expected this week to give the final nod to a bipartisan jobs bill as Congressional attempts to encourage employment continue in this election year.

headline: Permira Said to Be Considering Sale of Frozen Food Company
text: LONDON — The European private equity firm Permira is exploring a sale of the Iglo Group, a frozen food company, for as much as 3 billion euros ($4 billion), according to people briefed on the matter.

headline: Image of the Day: March 26
text: India’s decision to double gold import duty could cut gold imports by a third in 2012.

headline: Creepy Cronyism
text: Just a small note about today’s column: doing the research, I found myself feeling as if I had turned over a rock and found a lot of creepy-crawly things underneath. This is really upsetting stuff.

headline: On Our Radar: The State of the Planet
text: Some 2,500 experts gather in London for a three-day conference on the state of the planet and on how global sustainability might be assured. Some 150 public events are planned around the world in tandem with the forum, called “Planet Under Pressure.” [Dot Earth]

headline: Supreme Thoughts
text: I haven’t been weighing in on the ACA hearing at the Supreme Court; I’m not a lawyer, and while most legal experts seem to think that the case for striking the law down is very weak, these days everything is political.

headline: Updates on the Supreme Court Hearings on the Health Care Law
text: On Monday, The Lede followed the first of three days of Supreme Court hearings on the constitutionality of the 2010 health care overhaul law. As our colleague Michael Shear explains, during the hearings, reporters will not be allowed to file from the chamber. Updates below mix breaking news alerts from journalists who leave the courtroom with reports from our colleagues in Washington on demonstrations outside the court and reactions from scholars, advocates and experts.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: The San Francisco Chronicle: Real newspapers grow wine grapes on their roofs. Jon Bonné reports. — Eric Asimov

headline: Morning Buzz, March 26: Fines for Delaying a Flight
text: Good morning. Expect a sunny yet windy Monday, with a high of 53 degrees.

headline: Leading Off: Bluegrass Blues
text: Kentucky is the greatest team in college basketball. Maybe ever. John Calipari is a great coach, an incredibly smart hire by the Wildcats despite all those niggling N.C.A.A. investigations and vacated Final Fours. That his players hang around campus only slightly longer than the average grocery store visit, this is unimportant. See how fired up the faithful are? This is Kentucky. Anything less is unthinkable.

headline: Tibetan in Delhi Sets Self Alight to Protest Chinese Leader’s Visit
text: A protest march in New Delhi took a dramatic turn after a Tibetan exile self-immolated Monday afternoon.

headline: Profile in Style | Tom Delavan
text: The New York designer is known for effortless-looking rooms in which comfy upholstered pieces cohabitate happily with classical 18th- and 19th-century furniture and art and design from the 1960s and ’70s. For Delavan, who is the creative director of the online shopping site Gilt Home and the former editor-at-large of Domino magazine, it’s important that a house reflects the history of its inhabitants. His own home — an Anglo-Italianate town house in downtown Manhattan — showcases his aesthetic roots (“I grew up in Connecticut in the ’70s, with that WASPy ‘Ice Storm’ sort of décor,” he says) and contains works by his favorite artists and furniture designers (Joe Colombo and Vico Magistretti, to name two). Most precious, though, are pieces made by his friends — a vase by Hugo Guinness, a box by John Derian. “These are the things that make a house a home.” More…

headline: The Last, Lush Hours of Bill’s Gay Nineties
text: Bill’s Gay Nineties Restaurant and Piano Bar did not go into that good night with a bang, or a whimper, but with a proclamation. Posted above the heritage bar of the 88-year-old watering hole — which shut its doors for good at 57 East 54th Street after 3 a.m. on Sunday — was a mayoral proclamation declaring Saturday “Bill’s Gay Nineties Day.”

headline: Microphone Picks Up Obama’s Private Exchange With Medvedev
text: A live microphone caught a private moment of candor by President Obama on Monday as he told President Dmitri A. Medvedev of Russia, during a discussion of the contentious issue of missile defense, that “after my election I have more flexibility.”

headline: Tebow Meets the Press
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Striking a hopeful tone about his whirlwind arrival, Tim Tebow formally began his career as the Jets’ backup quarterback on Monday, saying he looked forward to joining the at-times dysfunctional team and believed he would mesh with the starter Mark Sanchez.

headline: Bayan Cadotte: Have Teachers Share the 'Wows and Wonders'
text: The principal of Public School 186 in Bensonhurst roams the halls of her large school constantly, giving feedback and cheering on students and teachers as they work hard to do well on test scores, but she says she wants them to have fun in school, too.

headline: Numberplay: Where’s the Moon?
text: The planets are aligned. Where is the moon?

headline: U.S. Agency Seeks Tougher Consumer Privacy Rules
text: The government’s chief consumer protection agency said on Monday that it intended to take direct aim at the vast industry that has grown up around the buying and selling of information about American consumers.

text: A court case raises questions about Goldman Sachs’s handling of clients’ stock sales; a former commodities regulator discusses oil speculation; raids aim to break up computer crime rings.

text: With his 2007 victory on “Dancing With the Stars” looking increasingly like a career highlight, Helio Castroneves was overdue for some on-track success.

headline: Agudelo Optimistic About His Recovery
text: HARRISON, N.J. — All things considered, Juan Agudelo would rather have been in Nashville, but there he was Sunday, bushy mohawk hairdo and all, surrounded by news media in the locker room after the Red Bulls’ 4-1 win against Colorado.

headline: Parkour Traceurs, Take Your Mark
text: My latest Global Athlete column focuses on Ryan Doyle, one of the world’s most prominent practitioners of the sport of parkour, who can be seen here in action in Santorini. Also known as free running or street tumbling, parkour is basically a form of outdoor gymnastics that originated in France and has become a global phenomenon over the past decade.

headline: Street Style: The Flat
text: The best of readers’ photos from the week of March 19.

headline: Building a Criminal Case in the MF Global Affair
text: Whether criminal charges will be filed over transfers of customer funds in the final days before MF Global collapsed in October 2011 may hinge on what was said by executives at the firm trying to keep it alive.

headline: Is It O.K. to Joke About Occupy Now?
text: Time was, you had to tread lightly when making fun of Occupy Wall Street.

headline: Land Rush Decimating Remote Chaco Forest in Paraguay
text: Huge tracts of the Chaco forest are being razed by local Mennonite farmers and Brazilian cattle ranchers amid a surge in the global demand for beef.

headline: Surgery for Diabetes May Be Better Than Standard Treatment

text: Students from the Hunters Point edible schoolyard get to harvest vegetables and cook “garden tacos.”

headline: A.F.L.-C.I.O. President Calls for Romney Adviser’s Dismissal
text: The A.F.L.-C.I.O.’s president, Richard Trumka, called on Monday for Mitt Romney to dismiss Peter Schaumber as co-chairman of his campaign’s advisory labor committee because Mr. Schaumber, according to an inspector general’s report, had regularly received material improperly leaked by a Republican official at the National Labor Relations Board.

headline: A Curious Patch of Trees Before the Descent
text: Kevin Anchukaitis, an assistant research professor at the Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory at Columbia University, is conducting a tree-ring study to analyze drought patterns in Guatemala.

headline: Breaking Down the N.B.A.’s Transition Specialists
text: There is no greater fuel for an offense than the live-ball turnover. By its very nature, it stilts the orientation of opposing defenses before they can be properly established; switches are forced, driving lanes open, and the offense is positioned to exploit an opponent in flux.

headline: Behind the Cover Story: Nathaniel Rich on New Orleans’s Changing Landscape
text: Nathaniel Rich wrote this week’s cover story on the Lower Ninth Ward in New Orleans. He is the author of “The Mayor’s Tongue”; his second novel will be published next year by Farrar, Straus & Giroux. His last article for the magazine was about the annual Turkey-Lurkey Bowl in Central Park.

headline: For Schoolyard Gardens, a Global Network
text: It’s hard to find fresh produce in San Francisco’s Hunters Point district, classified as an urban “food desert” by the Department of Agriculture because of a lack of supermarkets and an abundance of toxic soil. Many of the neighborhood’s 34,000 residents live below the poverty line, a legacy of separation from the rest of the city and the area’s history as a former naval shipyard where radiological research and ordnance testing were carried out.

headline: Statins and Heart Health
text: Q. Has the rate of death from heart attacks in the United States been going down in the years since people have been taking statins?

headline: Justices Hear Argument That Health Case Is Premature
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday appeared ready to clear away the last remaining obstacle to a historic ruling on President Obama’s health care overhaul.

headline: Nokia’s Lumia 900 Gets a Price and Release Date
text: The moment of truth has come for Microsoft and Nokia. On April 8, they will release the new Windows phone, the Lumia 900, at a bold $100 price tag for its high-end features. The question is: Will Americans be tempted by this phone, which runs Microsoft’s new mobile operating system, Windows Phone 7, and choose it over the wildly popular Apple iPhone and phones using Google’s Android operating system?

headline: Knicks Defeat Milwaukee, but Mounting Injuries Raise Concerns
text: The Knicks showed on Monday night that they could win without two of their top players. What they do not want to find out is if they can make the playoffs similarly short-handed.

headline: A 600-Horsepower Dodge Dart, Coming to a 70-Foot Gap Jump Near You
text: On Monday, Dodge announced that its recently introduced Dart compact sedan would compete in the Global RallyCross Championship. The race format, which began as an X-Games demonstration and became a full-fledged series last year, combines European-style rallycross with X-Games-inspired stunts. The closed-circuit tracks where the events take place include dirt, asphalt and a 70-foot gap jump.

headline: Helping a Species That Leaves Few Feeling Warm and Fuzzy

headline: Crowdfunding and Social Entrepreneurs

headline: New Site Wants to Make the Serious as Viral as the Shallow
