headline: Wife of Soldier Accused in Afghan Massacre Gives Interview
text: The wife of an American soldier charged in the massacre of 17 Afghan civilians said that her husband did not exhibit signs of post-traumatic stress disorder before his deployment to Afghanistan and that she doubted his involvement in the killing.

headline: Justices Decline to Say if Jerusalem-Born Americans Can Claim Israeli Birthplace
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday ordered a lower court to decide whether Congress has the authority to allow Americans born in Jerusalem to claim Israel as their birthplace on their passports.

headline: Universal Acquires Movie Rights to Trilogy of Erotic Novels
text: “Fifty Shades of Grey,” the erotic novel that went from X-rated underground sensation to mainstream literary phenomenon, is poised to become a Hollywood movie.

headline: Flash-Sales Web Site Is a New Outlet for Madonna’s Album
text: Fab.com, a fast-growing flash-sales Web site that specializes in art and design, has joined iTunes and Amazon in selling music online, and its first artist, fittingly, has ties to high fashion: Madonna.

headline: India’s Top Army Official Alleges Corruption in Deals
text: The Indian Army’s top official has alleged that he was offered a bribe by a lobbyist selling vehicles to the military, raising new questions about how defense contracts are  handled by India, the  world’s top arms buyer.

headline: Progress Toward a  Single Gambling Commission for New York
text: ALBANY — As the state moves toward legalizing full-scale casinos, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and lawmakers have agreed to overhaul the regulation of gambling, concentrating power in a panel that would be largely controlled by the governor.

headline: In Pakistan, Hindus Say Woman’s Conversion to Islam Was Coerced
text: “In the predawn darkness on Feb. 24, Rinkel Kumari, a 19-year-old student from a Hindu family, disappeared from her home in Mirpur Mathelo, a small village off a busy highway in Sindh Province,” Declan Walsh writes in The New York Times. “Hours later, she resurfaced 12 miles away, at the home of a prominent Muslim cleric who phoned her parents with news that distressed them: Their daughter wished to convert to Islam, he said.”

headline: Gunman’s Account of Beating by Teenager Is Detailed
text: SANFORD, Fla. — In an account given to the Sanford police that was passed on to the state attorney’s office, George Zimmerman, the neighborhood watch volunteer who shot 17-year-old Trayvon Martin on Feb. 26, said that Trayvon had punched him and then repeatedly slammed his head into the sidewalk in the moments leading up to the shooting.

headline: Hype at The Wall Street Journal
text: For a minute there, it sure looked like The Wall Street Journal had itself quite the little scoop. Late Friday afternoon, the paper moved a story claiming that “former MF Global CEO Jon Corzine gave specific instructions to an MF Global employee in Chicago to move $200 million from a segregated customer account” just days before the firm’s collapse. As I’ve noted before, taking money from a segregated customer account is the sin of sins for anyone in the brokerage business, and brokerage executives who do so knowingly are committing a crime and should go to jail. As I’ve also noted, Corzine has been emphatic in saying that he had no knowledge that segregated customer accounts had been raided in those final, chaotic days—which, if true, would mean that he could not be charged with any crime. Thus, the Journal’s story was incendiary—perhaps even the smoking gun prosecutors have been looking for.

headline: Introspection for a Pop Star: Just Remember Her Name
text: “I’m gonna be O.K./I don’t care what people say,” Madonna sings on her new album, “MDNA.” That may be the least necessary assurance in pop-music history.

headline: The Trouble With Data That Outpaces a Theory
text: The British astrophysicist Arthur S. Eddington once wrote, “No experiment should be believed until it has been confirmed by theory.”

headline: Louisville’s Unconventional Approach to Success
text: It’s down to the Final Four in the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament.

headline: Amid Good Company, the Wildcats Still Stand Out
text: By any measure, this is a Final Four for heavyweights. The best barometer may be the smiles on the faces of the CBS executives, who know there is nothing better for ratings than the draw of brand names.

headline: Facebook Asks Court to Dismiss Ceglia Suit
text: 4:00 p.m. | Updated  Adding details of the forensic investigation.

headline: It’s Never Quiet on the Newt Front
text: As the inevitable Republican nominee, Mitt Romney, gets closer and closer to becoming the actual nominee, Newt Gingrich is surely, but very slowly, dropping out of public view. Soon he’ll go back to sitting on the front porch of the right-wing, shaking his fist at passing ideas. He’ll go back, in other words, to the post he’s occupied since he was drummed out of the House Speaker’s job in 1998.

headline: Romney Assails Obama Over Chat With Medvedev
text: SAN DIEGO — Mitt Romney criticized President Obama on Monday for telling President Dmitri A. Medvedev of Russia, in remarks caught over an open microphone, that “after my election I have more flexibility” on missile defense.

headline: On Trayvon Martin: A Guest Post From a Teenager, and Some Teaching Suggestions
text: Updated | April 1, 2012

headline: Kentucky Women Look to Match Men in Final Four
text: While the women’s basketball world focuses on the impending Baylor-Tennessee game, or on Stanford and Connecticut cruising along, there is another team who is quietly, but steadily advancing: No. 2 seeded Kentucky.

headline: Santorum Uses Clash With Reporter in Fund-Raising Pitch
text: Rick Santorum tried on Monday to turn a tense and profane exchange with a New York Times reporter to his benefit, using the encounter as a rallying cry and a fund-raising plea.

headline: Photo Replay: March 26
text: A view of the day in sports, with figure skating training and Tim Tebow’s introduction as a Jet.

headline: Really? Ulcers Increase the Risk of Diabetes
text: THE FACTS

headline: Models Based on ‘Fundamentals’ Have Failed at Predicting Presidential Elections
text: The 1988 presidential election was a victory for political science. Michael Dukakis had led George Bush in the polls for much of the spring and summer. But Mr. Bush had some fundamental advantages — the economy was sound, and he was the vice president to a popular incumbent, Ronald Reagan. As the fall came, Mr. Dukakis’s numbers wilted, and Mr. Bush captured a decisive victory, winning 426 electoral votes and taking the popular vote by about nine percentage points.

headline: Julie Otsuka Wins PEN/Faulkner Award
text: 2:49 p.m. | Updated Julie Otsuka is the winner of the 2012 PEN/Faulkner Award for Fiction for her novel “The Buddha in the Attic” (Alfred A. Knopf), the directors of the award announced on Monday. The book, which traces the lives of six Japanese mail-order brides who sail to San Francisco in the early 20th century, was chosen from more than 350 novels and short-story collections, all by American authors and all published in 2011.

headline: Checking a Bank Balance on Your Phone, No Log-In Needed
text: For a remote island nation, New Zealand produces some cool stuff (The director of “Lord of the Rings,” Peter Jackson, for instance).

headline: ‘Mad Men’ Draws Its Largest Audience
text: “Mad Men” rode a flood of publicity — and praise from critics overcome with longing for the series after an extended absence — to reach its largest audience on Sunday night.

headline: Learning to Drive With A.D.H.D.
text: The first time Jillian Serpa tried to learn to drive, the family car wound up straddling a creek next to her home in Ringwood, N.J.

headline: Elementary Students in Large Classes Tripled, Report Shows
text: The number of students in classes of 30 or more has tripled in the last three years as a result of teacher attrition and budget cuts to public schools, according to a report released by a city councilman.

headline: Bert Sugar, Boxing Writer and Commentator, Is Dead at 75
text: Bert Sugar, boxing’s human encyclopedia, a prolific writer and editor and a flamboyant and ubiquitous presence in the world of the ring, died on Sunday in Mount Kisco, N.Y. He was 75.

headline: Raúl Castro Greets Pope Benedict at Start of Closely Watched Visit
text: SANTIAGO DE CUBA — Pope Benedict XVI arrived in Cuba on Monday, declaring himself a “pilgrim of charity” and urging the island to move toward greater openness, freedom and religious devotion.

headline: France Says It Will Bar Some Clerics From a Conference
text: PARIS — France will bar certain Muslim clerics who are considered too radical from entering the country for a conference next month, President Nicolas Sarkozy said on Monday.

headline: Securing an Apartment With Help From a Love Letter
text: David Motta and Michele Pagnotta met on 87th Street between Amsterdam and Columbus Avenues six years ago while they were out walking their dogs, Jake and Pancho. Slowly, after many walks, they started dating. A few years later, they were married.

headline: Digital Notes: After Steep Declines, Music Sales in 2011 Held Steady
text: Two of the music industry’s top trade groups on Monday released detailed sales reports for 2011, and for the most part they tell a familiar story. After many years of steep declines, overall music sales are starting to level off in many parts of the world, or at least not fall quite so hard. In the fine print the reports point to rapid expansion of digital services around the world.

headline: Wright Plays Four Innings, and Says He Feels Good
text: JUPITER, Fla. — Playing in his first spring training game, Mets third baseman David Wright got in a good mixture of action at the plate, on the base paths and in the field. Wright played through two at-bats, and it was enough to get in a variety of situational baseball.

headline: Johnny Hallyday to Perform in New York
text: The French rock star Johnny Hallyday will perform a concert at the Beacon Theater in October, and it will be one of only a few New York appearances of his 50-year career. Heavily influenced by Elvis Presley, Mr. Hallyday is famous in France as one of that country’s best rock ’n’ roll singers, known for his deep, raspy voice, his energetic shows and his wild lifestyle. (He has 21 platinum albums.)

headline: Female Condom Giveaway Is Expensive, but Still Cost-Effective, Report Says
text: An experiment in giving away free female condoms in the nation’s capital is a “highly productive use of public health investment,” according to a new study by scientists at the Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health.

headline: Others in the I.P.O. Hall of Shame
text: After the horrible, ruinous Murphy’s Law-abiding fiasco that was the initial public stock offering of BATS Global Markets, many are wondering if the company’s glitch-filled offering was the biggest I.P.O. botch in history.

headline: Spiegelworld Tent to Go Up in Midtown in May
text: After previously pitching its lavishly decorated tent at the South Street Seaport, the traveling troupe Spiegelworld will be moving uptown for a 15-week summer engagement with a new work, “Empire.” The show will display Spiegelworld’s circus, cabaret and burlesque acts in a 440-seat tent, which will be erected on West 45th Street, near Eighth Avenue. Previews are set to begin May 22, with opening night scheduled for May 31. Tickets can be purchased at (212) 239-6200 or telecharge.com.

headline: A Smaller Route to Solar Success
text: There are at least a dozen major ways to turn sunlight into electricity, but one of the more interesting is using a field of mirrors to focus the sun’s energy on a “power tower” where the heat is captured and used later to spin a turbine and turn a generator. As I have previously written, two companies are now planning to build such systems in the desert Southwest with hardware that will store the heat for a rainy day or for the period right after sunset when power demand is still high.

headline: BMW Recalls Nearly 1.3 Million Vehicles Worldwide for Battery-Cable Flaw
text: 4:10 p.m. | Updated

headline: Galvanized by a Court Case
text: The Supreme Court began hearings on the 2010 health care overhaul law on Monday, attracting crowds of demonstrators.

headline: Jury in Officer’s Trial Is at an Impasse Over Rape Charges
text: The jury deliberating the charges against a police officer accused of raping a woman at gunpoint in Upper Manhattan last August indicated on Monday that it had reached a verdict on several of the charges, but was stuck on others.

headline: Justices Send Back Gene Case
text: The Supreme Court on Monday ordered an appeals court to reconsider its decision to uphold patents held by Myriad Genetics on two genes associated with a high risk of breast and ovarian cancer.

headline: Drilling Down: What Small Businesses Should Know About Pinterest
text: In this week’s Dashboard, we quoted from a guide to using Pinterest prepared by Jay Ehret, a marketing specialist. As you may have heard, Pinterest is a fast-growing new Web site where users can create sites of photos “pinned” from other parts of the Web. We went back to Mr. Ehret with a few questions about how small businesses can use Pinterest.

headline: Times in Food Fight Over Cookbook Ghostwriter Story
text: I am not a foodie, to be candid. Food and I have a transactional relationship. I eat it but I don’t contemplate it.

headline: Annie’s Lifts Price Range of I.P.O.
text: Annie’s Inc. apparently expects to reap a bounty in its initial public offering: The pasta maker has raised the price range for the sale, according to an amended prospectus filed on Monday. The company now expects to price its shares between $16 and $18, up from a previous range of $14 to $16.

headline: Does Helping a Student Add to My Value?
text: An E.S.L. teacher at a Queens high school writes: 'It’s not often you can get in the middle of something and make such an immediate difference. We didn’t have to do this, and none of us got paid extra for it -- but things like these, not merit pay, not test scores, make us love what we do. Still, I have to wonder what would happen under the new paradigm in New York State and New York City. Would Stephanie help our value-added scores? Would Mom keep her home the day of the test? If she were on our registers, would that affect our ratings?'

headline: Driving With Attention Deficit Disorder
text: Learning to drive can be a difficult task for teenagers. Distractions on the road are abundant, and driving is one of the most dangerous activities for adolescents.

headline: For Li Na, a Focus on the Olympics
text: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla. — After becoming the first Asian woman to win a Grand Slam singles title at the 2011 French Open, Li Na struggled to put together wins for the rest of the season. She began her 2012 season strongly, winning three matches in the Hopman Cup and making the finals in Sydney. But she then suffered a devastating loss at the Australian Open to Kim Clijsters, in which she failed to convert on four match points, and walked out of her postmatch news conference in tears.

text: To the Editor:

text: To the Editor:

text: To the Editor:

headline: Invading Your Privacy
text: It’s a security-hawk cliché that if you’ve done nothing wrong, then you have nothing to fear from ever-more aggressive surveillance tactics. When the National Security Agency was caught eavesdropping without a warrant on international communications, the Bush administration assured critics that if the agents scraped up information on innocent Americans, they would delete it. When the F.B.I. announced its Next Generation Identification database—the world’s biggest biometric archive—Thomas E. Bush, the FBI assistant director in 2007,  told the BBC that  “what we deal with is bad guys … suspected terrorists and criminals,” and that for everyone else it was a non-issue.

headline: Seeing Bogeymen in the Fog Around Brain Death
text: Like creatures battling undersea, pro-life and right-to-die forces are locked in mortal but only intermittently visible combat. The last prominent battle ended almost seven years ago, after the death of Terri Schiavo, the Florida woman with brain damage whose feeding tube was removed by court order in the spring of 2005. Since then, all has been quiet on the surface, belying the continuing turmoil in hospitals and courtrooms over what, exactly, marks the end of life.

headline: Snowe Praises Brown for His Work on Women’s Issues
text: BOSTON – Senator Scott P. Brown of Massachusetts appeared alongside a fellow moderate Republican, Senator Olympia Snowe of Maine, on Monday to kick off a “Women for Brown” committee, the latest step in his concerted effort to appeal to female voters in his campaign for re-election.

headline: Hawk Cam: A Rat in the Nest
text: A rat in the nest high above Washington Square Park, as captured by the City Room Hawk Cam.

headline: High Line May Mix Past With Koons’s Vision
text: Visitors to the High Line, the elevated park on a formerly derelict rail line, might someday be greeted by a vision even more improbable than the park itself, which has become one of Manhattan’s top tourist draws: A massive locomotive dangling from a crane.

headline: Trayvon Martin and ‘the Talk’ Black Parents Have With Their Teenage Sons
text: Late last week, a colleague asked me if there would be a Motherlode post about “the talk” black parents have with their sons after the shooting of Trayvon Martin, who was killed last month in Sanford, Fla., while walking from a convenience store to the home of his father’s girlfriend.

headline: Sometimes All the Rooms Look the Same
text: BECAUSE I travel so much for Kiwi Collection I have learned not to bring a lot of clothing and other things with me. I can make do with a carry-on bag, even if I’m gone for more than a week or so. My itinerary is such that I jump around either from country to country or to different locations within the same country to review hotels. If my checked bag got lost, no one would ever find me, and I really don’t have time to go buy new clothes if my bag got lost.

headline: Arguing That Health Mandate Is Not a Tax, Except When It Is
text: WASHINGTON — Throughout the two-year history of the health care litigation, judges have mocked the Obama administration’s have-your-cake approach to the central question debated at the Supreme Court on Monday: whether the constitutional challenge is even ripe for judicial review before the law takes full effect in 2014. During the opening 90 minutes of oral argument, the justices found that they too could not resist.

headline: Drug to Cut Cholesterol Tests Better Than Statin
text: An experimental drug that works in a novel way to lower cholesterol proved even more effective than statins and had few undesirable side effects, newly released data shows.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Washington and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Washington, India, Myanmar and South Korea.

headline: Noise Pollution Is Changing Forests
text: A few years ago, researchers discovered that in areas polluted by human-made noise, a species of hummingbird seemed to increase in population, while a jay species seemed to decrease.

headline: Victims of Tighter Tipping
text: Tipping for hotel concierges, bellhops and housekeepers moves up and down with the economy, but lately it has also been affected by changes in corporate, airline and hotel policies.

headline: Gentleman Who Finds Terrorism Amusing
text: An Evelyn Waugh-inspired satire that uses Sept. 11 at its end for a kicker? A comic novel about terrorism featuring a misanthropic hero striving to take credit for deadly bombings around the world? This is the off-putting premise of Lionel Shriver’s very unfunny new novel, “The New Republic.”

headline: The Get | Ishvara Sandals
text: In Hindu philosophy, ishvara is the Sanskrit word for lord or god. “There must be soul in what you do,” says Jose Marco, the designer of the sandal brand that bears the name. “Whatever it may be — cooking, caring for a plant, choosing a beautiful piece of leather to make sandals — soul is needed.” Having designed and sold Ishvara’s classic tanned-leather Mediterranean sandals from a tiny beach storefront in Formentera, Spain (the brand is based in Ibiza), since 1982, Marco is finally bringing his casual, colorful flats to the states. These python albarcas, modeled after ones commonly worn by fishermen in the Balearic Islands, are a standout. Sole (or should I say soul) searching has never been easier.

headline: Michaels Stores Prepares for an I.P.O.
text: Michaels Stores, the arts and crafts retailer owned by the Blackstone Group and Bain Capital, plans to file to go public as soon as next week, according to people briefed on the matter. The initial public offering could be one of the biggest of the year.

headline: Ask About A.D.H.D., Asperger’s and Driving
text: Learning to drive is tough for many teenagers, but tougher for those with an attention disorder or learning disability — and for their parents. In today’s Science Times, “Learning to Drive With A.D.H.D.,” I examine the situation for young people with attention deficit hyperactivity disorder. But learning to drive can also be challenge for those with Asperger syndrome or other forms of autism.

headline: Ballet Fans Truly Know How to Feel the Moves
text: Ballet lovers may “truly feel that they are dancing” when they watch a performance, researchers have found after measuring the brain activity of experienced spectators.

headline: Death Penalty Death Watch: Angela Johnson
text: Until last week, Angela Johnson was one of only two women on federal death row – for the 1993 murders of five people, including two children.

headline: Spring Veal Stew
text: Mark Bittman prepares a veal stew loaded with spring vegetables.

headline: The Chocolate Diet?
text: Chocolate may not be as hazardous to your waistline as you think — at least in moderation.

headline: City Will Add Seats to Schools, but Still Fall Short of Demand
text: New York City's Education Department says it plans to add a total of 34,000 seats for students over a five-year period. But the number lags behind an estimated 50,000 seats needed to meet demand.

headline: FX Landed Louis C.K. With Creative Freedom and by Wiring $200,000
text: Rather than invest millions of dollars in its original comedies, the basic cable channel FX traffics in a different, rarer currency: creative freedom. “We take small bets economically, but big bets creatively,” said John Landgraf, president and general manager of FX Networks.

headline: The Minimalist: Spring Veal Stew
text: I don’t cook veal very often, but this dish is one of my favorites. It’s a wonderful springtime stew loaded with spring onions or shallots, fresh tarragon and peas (over the years, I’ve increased the amount of vegetables and decreased the amount of veal). Much of the flavor comes from browning the veal cubes, but because I’m not a fastidious cook in the least, I brown the veal extremely well on just one side, then add the onions and shallots. In my experience, there will be more than enough crusty, meaty bits to scrape off the bottom of the pan.

headline: In Pakistan, No Quick End to Islam Conversion Case
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Hopes for the rapid resolution of a controversy over the conversion of a Hindu woman to Islam that has seized the Pakistani public were dashed on Monday, when the Supreme Court declined to decide the matter for at least three more weeks.

headline: At Bottom of Pacific, Director Sees Dark Frontier
text: No sea monsters. No strange life. No fish. Just amphipods — tiny shrimplike creatures swimming across a featureless plane of ooze that stretched off into the primal darkness.

headline: Decades-Old Housing ‘Emergency’ Continues, and So Does Rent Regulation
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg signed a bill on Monday that extended the city’s participation in rent regulation for another three years by redeclaring a state of housing emergency, even as a challenge to rent regulation laws looms in the United States Supreme Court.

headline: The Real Estate Mogul as an Artist
text: What to do when you’ve been accused, by various publications and Web sites, of all manner of misbehavior: money laundering, blowing $5 million on your daughter’s wedding and massacring mustangs to use their skins for upholstery?

headline: MF Global C.F.O. Says He Was ‘Not Involved’ in Customer Money
text: MF Global’s current chief financial officer, Henri J. Steenkamp, is to appear again before Congress on Wednesday in the latest hearing to examine the collapse of the brokerage firm.

headline: Frank E-Mails Reveal Negotiations at Art Gallery
text: Of the adjectives often used to describe the art market — complex, unregulated and opaque — the last has always been truest. Glimpses into negotiations between high-end galleries and collectors are rare. But a lawsuit in state court in Manhattan is providing a view into the dealings of not just any gallery, but the world’s most successful one, owned by Larry Gagosian.

headline: German Leader Agrees to More Bailout Money for Euro Zone Nations
text: BRUSSELS — The European Union took a big step on Monday toward building a financial firewall strong enough to prevent the spread of fiscal contagion to major economies like Spain. The move came after Germany dropped its opposition to bringing the Continent’s total bailout capacity to more than 690 billion euros ( $916 billion).

headline: It Could Be a Garden Party, Even the Final One
text: The layers of information come fast and furious in David Neumann’s work. And what finally arrives is never straightforward; the messages are scrambled, sometimes hopelessly so.

headline: How Much Aspirin Is Too Much of a Good Thing?
text: More than 40 million American adults already take an aspirin a day to prevent heart disease. Now many more are weighing the pros and cons of daily aspirin use in light of new studies finding that it also may reduce the risk of many cancers and stop the spread of tumors.

headline: A Piano Virtuoso Balanced and Buoyant
text: There are some composers, like Chopin, whose works almost all pianists perform publicly during their careers. Many soloists, on the other hand, never play Bach in recital. Murray Perahia, who has made a specialty of Bach since the 1990s, is one of the most rewarding interpreters both live and on disc.

headline: Added to a Program, the Sound of Opportunity Taken
text: A little more than midway through a concert at Alice Tully Hall on Sunday evening the refined tenor Michael Schade went off script to reflect on words a distinguished friend, the conductor Nikolaus Harnoncourt, once shared with him: “Out of the greatest impossibilities rise the greatest possibilities.”

headline: Meditations on a Borough’s History, Through Booms and Bad Times
text: “It’s particularly meaningful to see so many of you here tonight in light of the financial panic that has made all of our lives so terribly difficult,” the conductor Alan Pierson said as he welcomed audience members to a Brooklyn Philharmonic concert presented at Roulette in downtown Brooklyn on Saturday evening.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: iPad Heat Test and Windows Phone Updates
text: Here are some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web on Monday. There are more here.

headline: Prevention: Easy Way to Head Off Altitude Sickness
text: A small randomized trial has found that acute mountain sickness — the headache, fatigue, dizziness, nausea and vomiting that can occur at altitudes above 8,000 feet — can effectively be prevented with a common and inexpensive over-the-counter medicine: ibuprofen, sold as Advil and other brands.

headline: Support in U.S. for Afghan War Drops Sharply, Poll Finds
text: WASHINGTON — After a series of violent episodes and setbacks, support for the war in Afghanistan has dropped sharply among both Republicans and Democrats, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.

headline: Bausch & Lomb to Buy ISTA Pharmaceuticals for $500 Million
text: Bausch & Lomb, the eye care company, agreed on Monday to acquire the eye drug maker ISTA Pharmaceuticals for about $500 million.

headline: Another Passion Rises to Prominence This Season
text: Of Bach’s two surviving Passions, the “St. Matthew” is the more widely revered and usually the more often performed. In recent decades, especially, the “St. John” has been deemed problematic, and undoubtedly avoided by some, for its text’s many references to “the Jews” as those clamoring for Jesus’ death (references stemming from Luther’s translation of John’s Gospel).

headline: A Man Caught Up in Bo Xilai’s Crackdown
text: Fan Qihang was arrested during one of Bo Xilai’s crackdowns in 2009. His lawyer made this video public, hoping to dissuade the court from the death sentence.

headline: Risks: Older Kidneys Work Fine for Transplants
text: For most transplant patients, a kidney received from a donor as old as 64 is just as likely to be successful as one from a younger person, according to a new analysis.

headline: A Composer and Virtuoso Dresses Up the Mandolin
text: Is the mandolin about to have its moment as a classical solo instrument? Its repertory back catalog is slim — a couple of Vivaldi concertos and some early Beethoven, most notably, as well as parts in Mahler’s Seventh Symphony and “Das Lied von der Erde” — but its contemporary repertory is colorful and growing.

headline: Results of The New York Times/CBS News Poll
text: Poll finds support dropping for the Health Care law and the war in Afghanistan.

headline: Childbirth: Slight Risk in Vaginal Birth After C-Section
text: Women who choose to have a vaginal birth after a previous Caesarean section may be at a slightly increased risk of complications.

text: At the opening of three days of arguments challenging the constitutionality of the 2010 health care law, the justices heard 90 minutes of arguments from three lawyers about whether they should be hearing the case at all.

headline: How the Poll was Conducted
text: The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted March 21 through 25 with 986 adults throughout the United States.

headline: Most Oppose at Least Part of Overhaul, Poll Finds
text: Two-thirds of Americans want the Supreme Court to overturn some or all of the health care law, even though large majorities support a few of its major aspects, according to a poll by The New York Times and CBS News.

headline: G.O.P. Calls Democrats’ Bluff on Oil Subsidies Bill
text: The Senate voted Monday evening, 92 to 4, to proceed with a politically tinged debate on repealing tax subsidies for the oil industry after Republicans called Democrats’ bluff and agreed to take up a bill designed as more of a political statement than a legislative initiative.

headline: Forging Social Connections for Longer Life
text: It is now two years since I lost Richard, the man I lived with and loved for 44 years, and I have to admit, the second year was harder than the first.

headline: A Start-Up Airline Finds Its Place in the Maldives
text: BEIJING — At a time when many airlines are filing for bankruptcy or consolidating routes, George Weinmann is jumping into the industry with a start-up.

headline: Analysis of the Arguments — The Supreme Court Health Care Challenges
text: Times reporters offer analysis of the arguments before the Supreme Court challenging the constitutionality of the 2010 health care law.

headline: A Racing Sideshow for Basketball Fans
text: The rivalry between Kentucky and Louisville will be dissected and analyzed this week, but there is one thing that the two fan bases have in common: an appreciation of horse racing.

headline: A Cézanne Resurfaces, Shedding Light on a Series
text: For nearly six decades a Cézanne watercolor depicting Paulin Paulet, a gardener on the artist’s family estate near Aix-en-Provence, was familiar to scholars only as a black-and-white photograph. No one knew if the actual work, a study for Cézanne’s celebrated “Card Players” paintings, still existed and, if it did, who owned it.

headline: Exploring Our Own Alien World
text: SAN DIEGO

headline: Americans on the 2010 Health Care Law
text: Two years after President Obama’s overhaul of the health care system was signed into law, Americans are still disapproving.

headline: The Catholic Vote
text: How Catholics have voted in general elections and in this year’s primaries.

headline: Tasty Burgers, Without the Meat
text: It was just a coincidence that I had decided to broaden my repertory of vegetarian burgers for this week’s column and was busily testing recipes on the same day that a new Harvard School of Public Health study linking red meat consumption and early death was released. Then there was the news about pink slime in ground beef used in school lunches. The timing couldn’t have been better.

headline: L’Arc-en-Ciel at Madison Square Garden
text: The performed with all the trappings of an arena-rock band that’s 20 years into a million-selling career.

headline: A Debut in New York, 20 Years in the Making
text: L’Arc-en-Ciel, the band that sold out Madison Square Garden with its New York City debut on Sunday night, performed with all the trappings of an arena-rock band that’s 20 years into a million-selling career.

headline: Loss’s Sting Drives Notre Dame to Win After Win
text: RALEIGH, N.C. — A replay of last year’s N.C.A.A. women’s tournament championship game was on television Monday morning as Notre Dame’s players waited in their hotel rooms to leave for practice.

headline: Attention deficit on the road; a human ally for the world’s sharks; and 200 years of fossils, fish, flamingos and more.
text: Attention deficit on the road; a human ally for the world’s sharks; and 200 years of fossils, fish, flamingos and more.

headline: Step to the Center
text: On May 23-24, 1865, the victorious Union armies marched through Washington. The columns of troops stretched back 25 miles. They marched as a single mass, clad in blue, their bayonets pointing skyward.

headline: As Health Law Is Contested, Developing a Plan B
text: State officials and insurance executives are devising possible alternatives to the coming federal requirement that most Americans buy health insurance, even as the Supreme Court hears arguments about the constitutionality of the mandate.

headline: Tebow Can Push Sanchez, but Where?
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.

headline: Chief of Canadian Firm Steps Down After Inquiry
text: OTTAWA — The chief executive of SNC-Lavalin, a major Canadian engineering and construction firm that had extensive business operations in Libya, left the company on Monday after the release of a report indicating that he had authorized 56 million Canadian dollars in improperly documented payments to unidentified agents, the company’s chairman said Monday.

headline: Across Africa, Steady Steps Toward Democracy
text: DAKAR, Senegal — After 50 years of independence, the path to democracy does not follow an obvious, straight line in this region, just as it did not in the West — the model for most citizens here — where it was centuries in the making.

headline: A Farewell to Newt
text: It’s not easy letting him go. Not easy at all. Sort of like swearing off bedtime Ben & Jerry’s: there’s valor and the promise of self-improvement in the sacrifice, but also the sad awareness that the world just got a little less naughty. A little less fun.

headline: Citing Chapter and Verse: Which Scripture Is the Right One?
text: The topic this past Sunday on the show “Up w/ Chris Hayes” (MSNBC) was the statistical correlation between deniers of global warming and religious believers. Participants included such luminaries as Richard Dawkins, author of “The God Delusion,” and Steven Pinker, author of “The Better Angels of Our Nature,” a new book arguing that the world has gotten less violent as the tide of fundamentalist faith has receded and given way to the dictates of reason. It was no surprise that the panel’s default position, stated almost explicitly by Susan Jacoby, was that religion clouds the mind of those who, if they were only sufficiently educated, would arrive at the conclusion supported by the overwhelming preponderance of scientific evidence and reject the blind adherence to revealed or ecclesiastical authority that characterizes religious belief.

headline: Judged a Failure by the Data, a School Succeeds Where It Counts
text: Aniah McAllister was a lost girl of New York, one of tens of thousands of children edging toward an adulthood drained of hope.

headline: Financing for M.T.A. Projects Is Shored Up
text: New York State lawmakers and Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo have reached an agreement to finance the remaining three years of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority’s five-year capital plan, preserving some of the region’s largest transportation projects, transportation officials said Monday.

headline: Sticking to Business as Others Celebrate Her Career
text: DES MOINES

headline: Private Jets, Buffett and Taxes
text: Get this: Uncle Sam is suing Warren Buffett’s company over taxes. Yes, taxes.

headline: Priscilla Buckley, Editor at National Review, Dies at 90
text: Priscilla L. Buckley, a journalist who was the longtime managing editor of National Review, the conservative magazine founded by her brother William F. Buckley Jr., died on Sunday at her home in Sharon, Conn. She was 90.

headline: Getting to the Merits
text: Before ruling on whether Congress has power to require Americans to obtain health insurance, the Supreme Court must decide whether it is barred from taking up that question by the federal Anti-Injunction Act, which prohibits courts from hearing lawsuits that seek to block a tax before the tax is actually paid.

headline: Rangel and His Campaign to Pay $23,000 Fine Over Misuse of Rent Law
text: WASHINGTON — Representative Charles B. Rangel and his campaign have agreed to pay a civil fine of $23,000 stemming from his use of a rent-stabilized apartment as a campaign office, according to Federal Election Commission records.

headline: Boycott Plan at Food Co-op Is Opposed by City Officials
text: Many of New York City’s leading politicians said Monday that they opposed a boycott of Israeli products by the Park Slope Food Co-op in Brooklyn, speaking out on the day before the market is expected to hold an initial vote on the proposal.

headline: MF Global’s Top Lawyer Will Break Her Silence
text: MF Global’s top lawyer is expected to break her five-month silence on Wednesday to tell Congress that she was unaware of a gaping shortfall in customer money until hours before the brokerage firm filed for bankruptcy on Oct. 31.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: March 26, 2012

headline: In a Dozen Plans, Ideas for Restoring the Thrill to a Westchester Amusement Park
text: RYE, N.Y. — Would Playland still be Playland without rides?

headline: A Continent Apart, Two Quarterbacks Vow They Will Work Together
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Missing from the spectacle at Jets headquarters Monday was a Goodyear blimp circling overhead, transmitting panoramic images of this woodsy suburban pocket that was overtaken by something no organization had ever done. The wide-angle views could have captured the scope — lines of cars at the security booth seeking entry; drive-through credential stations; satellite truck after satellite truck, a dozen in all — without intruding into the event itself.

headline: Microphone Catches a Candid Obama
text: President Obama found his private moment of political candor caught by a live microphone on Monday as he told President Dmitri A. Medvedev of Russia that he would have “more flexibility” to negotiate on the delicate issue of missile defense after the November election, which Mr. Obama apparently feels confident he will win.

headline: A Picture of Language
text: The curious art of diagramming sentences was invented 165 years ago by S.W. Clark, a schoolmaster in Homer, N.Y. [1] His book, published in 1847, was called “A Practical Grammar: In which Words, Phrases, and Sentences Are Classified According to Their Offices and Their Various Relations to One Another.” His goal was to simplify the teaching of English grammar. It was more than 300 pages long, contained information on such things as unipersonal verbs and “rhetorico-grammatical figures,” and provided a long section on Prosody, which he defined as “that part of the Science of Language which treats of utterance.”

headline: Government’s Not Dead Yet
text: Washington

headline: Enabling Egypt’s Military Rulers
text: The United States has built its relationship with Egypt around the Army, which it has supported with more than $39 billion in military aid over the last three decades. Egypt’s year-old, pro-democracy revolution gave Washington a chance — and a reason — to alter that relationship to support civil society. The Obama administration made a serious error in choosing not to do so. Even worse, the purpose was largely to protect American arms manufacturers who produce the weapons sent to Egypt.

headline: Private Schools Mine Parents’ Data, and Wallets
text: Shortly after she enrolled her 3-year-old son in a prestigious, $21,000-a-year Upper East Side preschool, Rachael Combe, an editor at Elle, received an invitation from the head of the school to come by for a visit. She assumed the meeting was to discuss how her son was adapting to the school’s curriculum.

headline: HSN Plans Event to Sell ‘Snow White,’ the Merchandise
text: IN the continuing quest for ardent fans and movie ticket sales, studios are expanding their marketing arsenal to appeal to home shoppers, a largely female audience of proven purchasers.

headline: An Incomplete DNA Deal
text: A major expansion of New York State’s DNA database signed into law last week by Gov. Andrew Cuomo will enhance the ability of law enforcement to convict the guilty and, in some cases, exonerate the innocent. But, disappointingly, the measure still leaves New York State without certain protections to avoid wrongful convictions.

headline: Symantec Dissolves a Chinese Alliance
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Less than four years after Huawei Technologies and Symantec teamed up to develop computer network security products, the joint venture is being dismantled because Symantec feared the alliance with the Chinese company would prevent it from obtaining United States government classified information about cyberthreats.

headline: Survey Gives Glimpse Into Minds of Recent Veterans
text: The 2012 edition of Iraq and Afghanistan Veterans of America’s annual survey of its members came out on Monday. The largest such survey by the group to date, its results provide some interesting insights into what’s on the minds of recent veterans today.

headline: Vindication for Challenger of Health Care Law
text: WASHINGTON — When Congress passed legislation requiring nearly all Americans to obtain health insurance, Randy E. Barnett, a passionate libertarian who teaches law at Georgetown, argued that the bill was unconstitutional. Many of his colleagues, on both the left and the right, dismissed the idea as ridiculous — and still do.

headline: Two Powers Raise Rivalry to New Heights
text: As the governor of Kentucky, John Y. Brown Jr. once revived a rivalry that now ranks among the greatest in college basketball. It is an in-state affair that started in 1913, stopped in 1922 and went dormant, save the rare chance meeting, for more than six decades.

headline: Horses to the Slaughter
text: Thoroughbred racing trades on bucolic imagery and glossy beauty, but a report in The Times on Sunday documented the real pillars of its success: the casual and continual mistreatment of vulnerable, overmedicated and ultimately disposable athletes. Reporters who analyzed tens of thousands of races and combed through reports of injuries and medical tests found a culture of rampant cheating and feeble regulation, where injured and fragile horses are forced to run while drugged, to the great peril of both animals and jockeys.

headline: New Ideas on Pensions: Use States
text: As growing numbers of baby boomers face retirement with inadequate savings, some state officials are considering a novel proposal to rebuild America’s ailing retirement system — having state pension funds run retirement plans for companies.

headline: Crime Crackdown Adds to Scandal Surrounding Former Chinese Official
text: BEIJING — As Bo Xilai, the dismissed Chongqing party chief, becomes immersed in an ever-more tangled scandal, disturbing details are emerging about one of his best-known initiatives, a crusade against organized crime on which he built a national reputation.

headline: A Grid in the Hand
text: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — If this puzzle doesn’t convince you that it’s spring, no puzzle will. As soon as I spotted the ROBIN in the circled squares of Todd McClary’s grid, I knew we were about to work a puzzle that was strictly for the … well, you know.

headline: In Queens, Taking a Step Back From Numbered Streets
text: Forty-four years ago, Bill Sievers moved into his neo-Colonial house in Douglaston, Queens, on bucolic Poplar Street, lined with stately trees and equally stately homes. A few years later, the oak and Norwegian maple trees and the manor houses were still there, but the street was no more.

headline: Cuomo and Top Legislators Near Accord on the Budget
text: ALBANY — Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and legislative leaders were nearing a deal on Monday night on a spending plan of about $132.5 billion for New York State’s next fiscal year, slightly reducing overall spending while increasing financing for schools and accelerating scores of public works projects.

headline: Outside the International Spotlight, but Still Something to Play For
text: NIAGARA FALLS, Ontario — As the final seconds ticked down, the team in the familiar bleu, blanc et rouge sweaters threw down sticks and gloves and gathered in a joyous embrace, famous international players ready to lift the cup again.

headline: Seeking a Softer Justice System, Closer to Home, for New York’s Juvenile Offenders
text: The teenage boys living in a Brooklyn row house board a van every morning to go to school. When they return, they cook their own meals, do their own laundry, play video games and discuss life. They receive visits from their families each week and sometimes take field trips to the movies or to a bowling alley.

headline: The Face, and Arm, for Left-Handers Everywhere
text: Left-handers are amply represented in the successful ranks of nearly every walk of life. Five of the last seven presidents have been left-handed. Albert Einstein was left-handed. So were Benjamin Franklin, W. C. Fields, Julius Caesar and Michelangelo. Sports have overflowed with left-handed stars, from Babe Ruth to John McEnroe to Larry Bird to Pelé.

headline: Tibetan Exile Sets Self Afire in Protest Act
text: NEW DELHI — Over the past year, nearly 30 Tibetans in remote areas of western China have set fire to themselves to draw attention to what they call Chinese government repression, but the visual images of their protests have seldom been seen by outsiders. Censorship authorities in China, which regards the immolation as a form of terrorism, have made sure of it.

headline: Colorado Revisits Law That Gives Prosecutors Wide Power to Try Youths as Adults
text: DENVER — It was called the summer of violence: a rash of crime that swept through Denver in 1993 and prompted state lawmakers to pass tough legislation intended to crack down on juvenile offenders. Nearly 20 years later, Colorado is revisiting a law that gives prosecutors the power to charge youths as adults in serious crimes without first getting approval from a judge.

headline: Stopping Assad, Saving Syria
text: How should the United Nations Security Council address the escalating violence in Syria?

headline: Supervising Priest Goes on Trial in Abuse Case
text: The landmark trial of a senior official of the Philadelphia Archdiocese who is accused of shielding priests who sexually abused children and reassigning them to unwary parishes began on Monday with prosecutors charging that the official “paid lip service to child protection and protected the church at all costs.”

headline: Tunisia Says Constitution Will Not Cite Islamic Law
text: CAIRO — Tunisia’s ruling Islamist party, Ennahda, said on Monday that the country’s post-revolution constitution would not mention Islamic law as a source of legislation, signaling a forceful break with ultraconservatives who have been demanding an Islamic state.

headline: Bounty Investigation Remains Open, Goodell Says
text: PALM BEACH, Fla. — N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell said Monday that the league continued to investigate the possibility of bounties on teams other than the New Orleans Saints, whose coach, Sean Payton, was suspended for a year for his role in a bounty system on his team.

headline: Michigan Governor Sees Hope for a Deal With Detroit
text: DETROIT — With time running out on this city’s dismal finances and tensions bubbling over, Gov. Rick Snyder of Michigan said Monday that he was hopeful a deal could still be worked out in the next few days to avoid appointing an outside emergency manager to run Detroit.

headline: Bariatric Surgery
text: Two studies found that obese and overweight people who had an operation to modify the stomach and small intestine were more likely to have a complete remission of Type 2 diabetes than people given non-surgical treatment.

headline: Late Goal Ends U.S. Bid for Place in the Olympics
text: NASHVILLE — The American players, almost to a man, sank to their knees in shock and exhaustion.

headline: Corrections: March 27
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Santorum Fails to Capture Catholic Vote
text: Cathy Willauer, who is Roman Catholic and a mother of four, says that her religion is important to her and that she shares the same values as Rick Santorum.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,898 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

headline: Silencing the Guns
text: When Gabrielle Giffords tendered her resignation from the House of Representatives to Speaker John Boehner because she did not feel she could continue to serve at her current level of disability, the entire House erupted in a rare moment of bipartisan unity, supporting their brave colleague who had survived a bullet through the brain at point-blank range.

headline: Ogwumike and Stanford Return to Final Four
text: FRESNO, Calif — Nnemkadi Ogwumike is taking Stanford back to the Final Four, and all Duke’s zone concepts, double-team defenses and elbows to the face would not convince her otherwise.

headline: Word of the Day | don
text: don •\ˈdän\• noun and verb

headline: Wright and Santana Progress by Playing Without Pain
text: JUPITER, Fla. — They sat side by side in the visitors’ training room at Roger Dean Stadium, one with the left side of his abdomen wrapped in ice and the other with his left shoulder entwined the same way. From outside, the faint sounds of a spring training game whispered into the Mets’ clubhouse.

headline: Queen Elizabeth’s Common Touch
text: Our colleague Alan Cowell in his new Page Two column writes about Queen Elizabeth II and her effort to reconnect her reign and her family to her subjects as her Diamond Jubilee year picks up steam.

headline: Brazil’s Unique Culture Group Stays Busy Sharing the Wealth
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — All over the world cultural organizations are tightening their budgets and paring back productions. But Danilo Miranda faces a different challenge, one that makes him the envy of his peers. As the director of the leading arts financing entity in Brazil, his budget is growing by 10 percent or more annually, and he must figure out ways to spend that bounty, which amounts to $600 million a year.

headline: NYT Front Page for 03/27/2012
text: NYT Front Page for 03/27/2012

headline: New Limit Pending on Emissions
text: After months of delay, the Obama administration is about to unveil the first federal standards to explicitly limit greenhouse-gas emissions from new electric power plants — one of the chief sources of carbon dioxide emissions linked to climate change.

headline: In North India, Palaces, Markets and History
text: We recently asked for your suggestions for one, two and three week trips through India, inspired by this article by Guy Trebay.

headline: Two Pedigreed Players Find They’re a World Apart
text: TAMPA, Fla. — On Field No. 1 at the Yankees’ minor league complex, Dante Bichette Jr. ripped a double into the right-field corner Monday. Bichette, the son of a former major league standout and the Yankees’ top draft pick last June, is only 19, but he has stardom projected for him.

headline: From Exile to Everywhere
text: “At 8 p.m. on a rainy Tuesday last month, Salman Rushdie strode into Junoon, a Flatiron district restaurant where 90 people awaited his arrival, some sipping chamomile-infused vodka cocktails,” Laura M. Holson writes in The New York Times. Mr. Rushdie, the Indian-born British author, was the guest of honor at a dinner sponsored by Dom Pérignon and Booktrack, the maker of an app that synchronizes music to e-books, Ms. Holson writes.

headline: The Pope in Cuba
text: Pope Benedict XVI arrived in Cuba on Monday, declaring himself a “pilgrim of charity” and urging the island to move toward greater openness, freedom and religious devotion.

headline: For Soccer Fans, Showing Support in Song
text: If you watch the Champions League quarterfinals Tuesday and Wednesday, you will hear soccer fans in their full-throated glory. Here is a look at popular chants among supporters of Tuesday’s home teams.

headline: Roddick Stuns Federer at Sony Ericsson Open
text: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla. — After an easy first-round win at the Sony Ericsson Open on Saturday, Andy Roddick said, “I feel like something good is coming.” It did not take long for his premonition to be proved right.

headline: Canada: Brothel Ban Illegal, Court Says
text: An appeals court upheld a ruling striking down most Canadian laws that prevent prostitution, including a ban on brothels. While prostitution is legal in Canada, several laws effectively make it impossible for sex workers to engage in the practice without facing the prospect of arrest. The Court of Appeal for Ontario ruled that most of those laws were unconstitutional, saying that they endangered prostitutes by forcing them to work on the streets rather than in controlled circumstances indoors and prevented them from taking certain safety precautions, like hiring bodyguards. But the court did uphold laws against soliciting. The federal government is likely to appeal the ruling to the Supreme Court of Canada.

headline: France: Strauss-Kahn Is Charged in Connection With Prostitution Ring
text: Dominique Strauss-Kahn, the former managing director of the International Monetary Fund, was released on bail on Monday after he was charged with involvement in a prostitution ring in Lille. The filing of the preliminary charges allows for further investigation. His lawyer, Richard Malka, has argued that Mr. Strauss-Kahn did not know that the women in question were prostitutes hired by his hosts, including for evenings in Washington and Paris, and that he did not pay them. His lawyers will also be in court on Wednesday in New York for the first hearing in a civil case brought against him by Nafissatou Diallo, a hotel housekeeper who has accused him of sexually assaulting her.

headline: Winnipeg’s Playoff Hopes Suffer Blow
text: WINNIPEG, Manitoba — The Jets’ playoff dream was all but dashed Monday night, and their defeat will probably put another Canadian club out of Stanley Cup contention.

headline: When Daycare Slips Into Night Care
text: This new bi-monthly column on India Ink will track the lives of the men and women who have flocked to Bangalore in recent years, making it one of the country’s fastest-growing, youngest metropolises. We’ll look at rapid changes afoot in the working, playing, thinking, eating and mating habits in Bangalore.

headline: Bucks Squander Chance to Gain Ground, but Remain Threat in Playoff Race
text: The Milwaukee Bucks, the team with the most realistic chance of catching the Knicks for the eighth and final playoff spot in the Eastern Conference, are vastly different from the Knicks, who beat them by 89-80 on Monday night at Madison Square Garden.

headline: Turkey: Trial of Ex-Chief of Army Starts
text: Turkey’s former military chief, Gen. Ilker Basbug, went on trial on Monday, charged with leading an illegal network that aimed to overthrow the government. He is the most senior officer to face trial in an investigation that began in 2008 and has resulted in the jailing of hundreds of suspects, including military officers, academics and government critics. The government defends the prosecution as necessary to defend Turkey’s democratization process, but human rights groups have criticized legal irregularities in the case, including long imprisonments without convictions.

headline: Larry Stevenson, Innovative Skateboard Designer, Is Dead at 81
text: Larry Stevenson was working as a lifeguard in Southern California in the early 1960s when he noticed surfers darting around a parking lot on crude skateboards cobbled together from planks and roller skates on days when the waves were tame.  Mr. Stevenson, an avid swimmer and surfer, thought he could do better.

headline: The Tortuous Path to Justice in Cambodia
text: HONG KONG — To watch the court proceedings, to hear the lawyers’ objections, to sit through the delays and the quibbles and the endless parsing of words, it’s enough to make a good number of Cambodians want to simply unshackle the prisoners and set them free. Game over.

headline: News Quiz | March 27, 2012
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s front page. Good luck!

headline: Henry S. Ruth, Who Helped Lead Watergate Prosecution, Dies at 80
text: Henry S. Ruth Jr., who helped lead the criminal prosecution of Nixon administration officials involved in covering up the Watergate break-in and kept it on track when President Richard M. Nixon fired the special prosecutor Archibald Cox, died on March 16 in Tucson. He was 80.

headline: Player Ratings: U.S. (3), El Salvador (3)
text: United States national team coach Jurgen Klinsmann has made the point early and often: he believes the Olympics are an important international tournament, and he felt strongly that the United States should put its best foot forward in the upcoming London Games.

headline: Strauss-Kahn Charged in Prostitution Case
text: PARIS — Dominique Strauss-Kahn, the former managing director of the International Monetary Fund, was released on bail on Monday after he was charged with involvement in a prostitution ring in Lille. The filing of the preliminary charges allows for further investigation.

headline: Bosman and the Champions League: Win-Win
text: The quarterfinal first legs of the UEFA Champions League will be played this week and a new study from the University of Illinois-Chicago written by John J. Binder, an associate professor of finance, and Murray Findlay, vice president of Soccer Success in St. Charles, Ill., asserts that the Bosman ruling, which gave European players a new form of free agency, has helped transform the competition into one of the most, if not the most, compelling soccer tournaments in the world.

headline: Nuclear Conference in Korea Collides With U.S. Election
text: SEOUL, South Korea — Politics, diplomats like to say, stops at the water’s edge. But this week, the American presidential campaign crashed into a nuclear security summit meeting half a world away.

headline: March 27, 1958 | Nikita Khrushchev Consolidates Power and Becomes Soviet Premier
text: On March 27, 1958, Nikita Khrushchev became Soviet premier in addition to First Secretary of the Communist Party. The March 28 New York Times wrote, “Mr. Khrushchev has now succeeded to the posts that Stalin had formally combined. He is not only the acknowledged architect of all Soviet foreign and domestic policies but the leader of the disciplined party ranks and the extensive ministerial apparatus that administers and enforces the policies.”

headline: Test Yourself | English, March 27, 2012
text: This question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article “Both Coasts Watch Closely as San Francisco Faces Erosion.”

headline: Health Ruling Hinges on How Justices Frame the Core Issue
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Tuesday is hearing arguments on the central question in the constitutional challenges to President Obama’s health care overhaul law. How it answers the question depends in large part on how the justices decide to frame the core issue.

headline: A Victory for Tiger Woods
text: WHO is Tiger Woods?WHO is Graeme McDowell?

headline: The Real Oil Shock
text: Like a lot of carless New Yorkers, I am generally confused by bursts of populist outrage over high gas prices. But I have always assumed that the anger is genuine — that hard-working Americans, who already spend a lot on gas, are thrown into turmoil when they have to spend even more. After all, 63 percent of Americans insist that these price increases have caused them some financial hardship.

headline: Kazakhstan’s Capital, Outside and In
text: Astana, Kazakhstan’s young and gleaming capital, has quickly become known for its space-age look: vibrant, toylike buildings pop against the frosty landscape. It is, as Rowan Moore wrote for The Observer in Britain, “a rare but persistent type, the capital from zero.”

headline: What Do You Hope to Be Doing the Year After You Graduate From College?
text: The Sunday Magazine analyzed what 226 members of the class of 2011 at one college, Drew University, are doing now, nearly a year after graduation, and the news is not good: most have acutely felt the stresses of the bad economy. Read what several of them are doing and why, then tell us what you dream you’ll be doing the year after you graduate from college.

headline: Assad Accepts Cease-Fire; Opponents Are Skeptical
text: AL QAA, Lebanon — Seeking to project an image of responsibility and reason, President Bashar al-Assad of Syria formally accepted a United Nations envoy’s cease-fire proposal on Tuesday and conducted a televised walking tour through the shell-shocked city of Homs, a center of the year-old uprising against him.

headline: North Korea Reaffirms Plan to Launch Satellite
text: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea intends to press ahead with its plan to launch a satellite into orbit next month, according to a government statement issued Tuesday, rebuffing President Obama and other world leaders who have told the country to cancel the launching or face the loss of food aid and additional sanctions.

headline: Europe Urged to Increase Firewall to a Trillion Euros
text: BRUSSELS — The European Union should increase its financial firewall to about 1 trillion euros to restore market confidence in the euro zone and prevent the spread of fiscal contagion, the head of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, Ángel Gurría, said on Tuesday.

headline: Student Debt Collectors Are Incentivized to Violate Federal-Aid Laws, Bloomberg Reports
text: People who have defaulted on their student loans are sometimes forced into paying back more per month than they can afford — and more than the federal government requires — because private debt collectors are given incentives to violate federal-aid laws, Bloomberg reported this week.

headline: Fantasy Focus: Stars and Scrubs, and How
text: For most of this spring, my colleague Jeff Erickson and I have been running mock drafts during our Sirius-XM radio show, often replicating the 15-team mixed league formats used by the National Fantasy Baseball Championship. That process allowed us to determine where we would like to draft in the main event, as draft slots are chosen Kentucky Derby style, meaning that the first choice simply affords an owner to pick his own seat.

headline: Britain’s Experience in Raising the Top Tax Rate
text: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of “The Benefit and the Burden: Tax Reform – Why We Need It and What It Will Take.”

headline: The Early Word: Constitutionality
text: Today’s Times

headline: The Long Arm of Beijing
text: It was supposed to be a boring exercise in non-democracy. Since the decision rested with a 1,200-strong Election Committee largely under Beijing’s yoke, the election — or selection — of Leung Chun-ying as new chief executive of Hong Kong, the territory’s highest office, was a foregone conclusion.

headline: With Tebow Arriving, Revisiting Contract for Sanchez
text: Mike Florio of ProFootballTalk.com first reported in December that the Jets were “beginning to realize that Sanchez may not be the answer at the position.”

headline: When Will India Get the Cricket Board it Deserves?
text: It is hard to believe how much the fortunes of Indian cricket have swung in the last 12 months. This time last year the team, and by extension everyone else in the country, was immersed in the 2011 World Cup. That tournament, of course, ended well for India.

headline: Tebow Lights Up When Speaking About Foundation
text: Tim Tebow handled his news conference skillfully Monday. Yes, he might have overdone his expressions of excitement about being a Jet. But beyond that script, he was polite and charming and disciplined in avoiding controversy. He might have been most excited to answer the question about whether he would establish a foundation in New Jersey.

headline: Al Jazeera Will Not Show French Rampage Video
text: PARIS — The Al Jazeera broadcaster said on Tuesday that it would not broadcast gruesome footage received by its Paris bureau that appears to show the killings of three Jewish schoolchildren, a rabbi and three French soldiers in southwestern France earlier this month.

headline: Parcells Considered as Replacement for Saints’ Payton
text: PALM BEACH, Fla. — Saints Coach Sean Payton may address his yearlong suspension with the news media during the annual N.F.L. meetings, but first he may discuss his job with his mentor, Bill Parcells. ESPN reported Monday that Payton planned to talk to Parcells about filling in for him during his suspension. Parcells attended the Mets’ spring training game against the Cardinals on Monday, and when asked about the possibility that he could join the Saints, he responded, “I have nothing to say.”

headline: Karen Mills, S.B.A. Chief, Takes Reader Questions
text: Much has changed since Karen Mills, the administrator for the Small Business Administration, first sat down with us back in the fall of 2009. The economy is improving, unemployment is falling, and S.B.A. lending is back to pre-recession levels. Ms. Mills’s agency, however, still faces pressing challenges. Fewer S.B.A. loans are reaching the smallest, underserved businesses. And both the agency and the Obama administration are under intense pressure to show that they are creating jobs, even as the White House proposes new cuts to the S.B.A. budget.

headline: Answering Cries of Longing for Poetry’s Return to the Subway
text: Goodness only knows what was rattling around F. Scott Fitzgerald’s brain when he said there were no second acts in American lives. As often as that line is quoted, that’s about how often it has been proved wrong. Now, the flaw in Fitzgerald’s train of thought is being demonstrated yet again.

headline: Attack of the Prison People
text: Update: OK, by popular request, the text of the letter after the jump.

headline: Beware, We’re Having a Heat Wave
text: LONDON — Northern Europe is “basking” in record springtime temperatures, to use the headline writers’ favorite weather word. “Wall to wall sunshine,” the Irish Times gushed, as the mercury rose higher than in Mediterranean sunspots such as Barcelona and Crete.

headline: Report of Bomb Plot Puts Afghan Defense Ministry in Lockdown
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — The Afghan Defense Ministry went into a near-total lockdown on Tuesday after the discovery of 10 suicide vests and the arrests of more than a dozen Afghan soldiers suspected of plotting to attack the ministry and blow up commuter buses for government employees, Afghan and Western officials said.

headline: The Challenger’s Deep-Sea Brethren
text: On Monday, the film director and explorer James Cameron became the first human to travel on his own to the world’s deepest abyss, the Challenger Deep, which lies 62 miles southwest of Guam in the Pacific Ocean. (As William J. Broad writes in The Times, Mr. Cameron found a bleak terrain that was all but barren of life.)

headline: Answer for N.F.L. Replay Review Is Up in the Booth
text: All of the N.F.L. power players are in Florida for the owners’ meetings. Being discussed, among other things, are possible rule changes for 2012 and beyond. One proposal from the Buffalo Bills is for the replay process to be confined to the booth. This idea is long overdue. It was written about in the Fifth Down blog in December after a replay procedure took over 10 minutes in a Raiders-Packers game.

headline: Words We Love Too Much
text: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style. (Some frequently asked questions are here.)

headline: Words We Love Too Much
text: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style. (Some frequently asked questions are here.)

headline: Sony Offers Concessions to Win Approval for EMI Bid
text: LONDON – A group of investors led by Sony has submitted concessions to win European regulatory approval for its $2.2 billion purchase of EMI’s publishing unit.

headline: Harry Potter’s New Adventure: Going Digital in E-Books
text: The fantasy series that sent droves of eager children to buy hardcover books at midnight parties at bookstores is finally for sale as e-books.

headline: Private School Parents Targeted for Giving
text: Parents of public school students in the city are responding to a SchoolBook survey by reporting expenses of up to thousands of dollars to support their child's school or school-related activities. But that apparently is nothing compared to what is being asked of parents of private school students.

headline: Foxconn Gets Japan Foothold With Stake in Sharp
text: TOKYO — In another sign of China’s manufacturing ascent as Japan struggles, the Taiwanese giant Foxconn Technology will become the largest shareholder in Sharp, a former exemplar of Japan’s electronics empire that has fallen on hard times.

headline: Opinion Report: The Anti-Injunction Act
text: From the editorial page

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: MF Global’s Top Lawyer to Break Her Silence  |  MF Global’s top lawyer is expected to break her five-month silence on Wednesday to tell Congress that she was unaware of a gaping shortfall in customer money until hours before the brokerage firm filed for bankruptcy on Oct. 31.

headline: A Language Lesson in Arabic
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Will Santorum’s Flashes of Anger Help or Hurt Him?
text: Can showing anger help get a candidate elected president?

headline: At Edge of Paris, a Housing Project Becomes a Beacon
text: PARIS — Hard by the noisy highway, overlooking a cemetery and a former garbage dump, La Tour Bois-le-Prêtre glimmers on a spring morning. Sheathed in a fresh cloak of glass balconies and corrugated aluminum panels, it rises on the edge of this city amid a landscape of decaying cement-and-brick housing blocks.

headline: A Conversation With: Gorkha Leader Bimal Gurung
text: Bimal Gurung has been a major force in the movement to carve out a separate state for Nepali-speaking Indians, or Gorkhas, from West Bengal, since 2007.

headline: Now Reading | Plan of Action
