headline: Tuesday Reading: Can Chocolate Aid Weight Control?
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: K.K.R. Hires Mack as Senior Adviser
text: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts said on Tuesday that it had hired John J. Mack, a former chairman and chief executive of Morgan Stanley, as one of its most prominent senior advisers yet.

headline: Morning Buzz, March 27: A Path Through Midtown
text: Good morning. Today will climb only to a sunny 50 degrees, down from last week’s blast of heat, which is probably for the best.

headline: Image of the Day: March 27
text: A woman makes garlands from marigold flowers in north India.

headline: A Matter of Character
text: I’ve always keenly appreciated Matt Zoller Seitz’s criticism, and I can’t think of anyone better qualified to judge the inevitable “The Sopranos” or “The Wire” final round of New York Magazine’s tournament of television. But I can also pinpoint the exact moment when his discussion of the two series goes astray. He’s comparing the two shows as exercises in characterization, and he gives the advantage to David Simon’s Baltimore drama:

headline: Documentary on Bullying to Open With No Rating
text: LOS ANGELES — After weeks of storm, stress and no small amount of pressure — online and otherwise — over the R rating assigned to the antibullying documentary “Bully,” the Weinstein Company said late Monday that it would release the film without a rating.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: ESPN.com: Here, now, the engineering specifications for the new Tim Tebow sandwich at the Carnegie Deli. Name: The Jetbow (surely not Carnegie’s cleverest moniker). Weight: 3.5 pounds. Ingredients: corned beef, pastrami, roast beef, lettuce, tomato, American cheese (naturally), white bread (of course), mayonnaise (necessarily). Price: $22.22 (mystifyingly, the sum of Mr. Tebow’s number 15, Mark Sanchez’s number 6, plus another unexplained $1.22). — Glenn Collins

headline: The Pope Is Dead. Long Live the Pope.
text: CAIRO — Thousands of distraught Christians gathered on March 20 for the funeral of Pope Shenouda III, the only pope many of them had ever known. Shenouda led the Coptic Church of Egypt for four decades, becoming both the leader and the symbol of the country’s Christian community of about 10 million. Without him, many now worry about their future in an increasingly Islamic Egypt.

headline: Day Two: Updates on the Supreme Court Hearings on the Health Care Law
text: The Lede followed the second of three days of Supreme Court hearings on the health care law. As our colleague, Adam Liptak reports, the justices asked skeptical questions about the individual mandate provision of the health care law during Tuesday’s hearing. In a news analysis, David Leonhardt, Washington Bureau Chief, notes that many court experts expressed surprise at the apparent agreement among the conservatives, including Justice Anthony M. Kennedy, the likeliest swing vote. Updates below include a mix of breaking news alerts from journalists who leave the courtroom, reports from our colleagues in Washington on demonstrations outside the court and reactions from scholars, advocates and experts.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Rules for Data Trackers, and a Familiar Script for FX
text: The Federal Trade Commission released its long-awaited report on privacy on Monday and the results could be bad news for the burgeoning online advertising industry, write Edward Wyatt and Tanzina Vega. The commission wants to regulate data brokers like Experian and Acxiom that collect and sell personal information. It also wants to push the industry to respect the wishes of consumers who not only don’t want to be tracked online but want no data collected on them whatsoever. One technology executive, who declined to be identified talking about negotiations for the government, said that “do not collect is basically death for online advertising.”

headline: Financial Watchdog Is Answering Questions Online
text: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau has been encouraging consumers to contact it with complaints about various financial products, including mortgages, credit cards and student loans.

headline: On Our Radar: Gas Leak in the North Sea
text: Gas leaking from a platform forces the evacuation of a second drilling rig operated in the North Sea by the French oil giant Total, and the authorities ban ships and aircraft from traveling within miles of the accident off Scotland’s eastern coast. Total says the leak is the worst problem it has encountered in the North Sea in a decade. [Agence France-Presse]

headline: Group Led by Magic Johnson Wins Auction to Buy Dodgers for $2.15 Billion
text: In a quick, dramatic end to the year-long financial crisis of the Los Angeles Dodgers, the team’s owner, Frank McCourt, agreed to sell the team Tuesday night for $2.15 billion to a group headed by Magic Johnson, the Lakers’ Hall of Famer.

headline: Daily Report: Security Issues Break Up Symantec-Huawei Venture
text: Less than four years after Huawei Technologies and Symantec teamed up to develop computer network security products, the joint venture is being dismantled, Nicole Perlroth and John Markoff report in Tuesday’s New York Times. Symantec feared that the alliance with Huawei, a major Chinese telecommunications company, would prevent it from obtaining United States government classified information about online security threats.

headline: A Bold Move
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Florida’s New Election Law Blunts Voter Drives
text: Florida, which is expected to be a vital swing state once again in this year’s presidential election, is enrolling fewer new voters than it did four years ago as prominent civic organizations have suspended registration drives because of what they describe as onerous restrictions imposed last year by Republican state officials.

headline: Business Day Live | March 27, 2012
text: States prepare alternatives in case the health care law is struck down; proposed restrictions on the selling of personal information; and the chief of the Small Business Administration on loans.

headline: Wheelies: The Crucible Edition
text: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: Business Day Live: Plan B for Health Care
text: States prepare alternatives in case the health care law is struck down; proposed restrictions on the selling of personal information; and the chief of the Small Business Administration on loans.

headline: Invitation to a Dialogue: America’s Global Role
text: To the Editor:

headline: Putting a 7-Year-Old on a Diet
text: Let us say that your 4-year-old needs size 8 clothing — not for the length, but for the width. That when she’s 5, friends and family are directly addressing what usually goes unspoken: her desserts, her juice intake, the way you handle her meals. Her teacher notes that she “doesn’t self-regulate” at snack time. By the time she’s 6, the pediatrician is in on it: you need to “do something” about her weight. And at 7, after a year of inconsistent effort, with a daughter who is 4 feet 4 inches tall and weighs 93 pounds, you put your child on a diet.

headline: Tester Up With First Ad in Montana
text: Senator Jon Tester, the endangered Montana Democrat with the farm-state buzz cut, launched the first television ad of his first Senate re-election campaign on Monday, reintroducing his folksy ways and never mentioning his party.

headline: Calling All Start-Ups
text: Have you heard about our Make Your Pitch contest? Yes, that’s right: We here at The Times’s Small-Business Desk are hosting a special contest for our entrepreneurial readers. All of the videos that meet our guidelines will be published, and the lucky winners will be featured on You’re the Boss, their pitches evaluated by a business strategist, Carol Roth.

headline: The Meaning of Religious Freedom
text: During the recent debate over birth control insurance coverage, the United States Conference of Catholic Bishops defined religious freedom as their freedom from government.

headline: Mandate’s Impact May Be Limited, Report Says
text: WASHINGTON – In legal terms, the issue before the Supreme Court on Tuesday could not be more momentous. The court’s ruling on the constitutionality of the health care law’s requirement that most Americans obtain medical insurance may define the boundaries of Congress’ authority to regulate interstate commerce for generations.

headline: The Tracks of an Author’s, and a Reader’s, Tears
text: It’s not very manly, the topic of weeping while reading. Yet for a book critic tears are an occupational hazard. Luckily, perhaps, books don’t make me cry very often — I’m a thrice-a-year man, at best. Turning pages, I’m practically Steve McQueen.

headline: $1.2 Million Fine for Indian Point Fire
text: The owner of the Indian Point nuclear plant has agreed to pay a $1.2 million penalty for a transformer explosion at its Unit 2 reactor that spilled oil into the Hudson River in November 2010. The New York State Department of Environmental Conservation said that “longstanding structural conditions” led to the failure of a containment system that should have prevented the oil from flowing into the river.

headline: Ask the ‘Hunger Games’ Director Your Questions
text: After a record $155 million opening weekend, “The Hunger Games” is poised to become Hollywood’s next major franchise. Its director Gary Ross, whose filmography includes “Seabiscuit” and “Pleasantville,” was presented with a few challenges when adapting the popular novel, including how to portray the child-on-child violence in a PG-13 way and how to give visual shape to characters and scenes that existed so vividly on the page for readers.

headline: Arbitron Agrees to Improve How It Counts Minority Radio Listeners
text: Arbitron, the largest radio ratings service, has settled a lawsuit in California over how it measures minority audiences, agreeing to pay $400,000 and to abide by certain research methods in tracking black and Latino radio listeners.

headline: For a Romney Running Mate, Don’t Bet on a Governor
text: Governors might make for better presidential candidates than senators do, but they have not had an advantage when it comes time for a party to pick its vice-presidential nominee.

headline: S.E.C. Told to Share Notes in Insider Trading Case
text: A federal judge has ordered Securities and Exchange Commission lawyers to turn over their notes to federal prosecutors handling the criminal case against Rajat K. Gupta, a former director of Goldman Sachs.

headline: Group Manages to Post Live Updates From Health Care Arguments … for a While
text: 3:58 p.m. | Updated Want to know what is happening inside the Supreme Court in real time as the health care law is debated? You are out of luck. The court’s rules strictly prohibit any communication from inside the building during the arguments.

headline: MF Global Executive Saw Early Warning Sign on Customer Money
text: An internal MF Global document suggested that the firm was putting customer money at risk days before its bankruptcy filing, an executive said in prepared testimony that was released on Tuesday for a Congressional hearing on Wednesday.

headline: Poll: Support for the War in Afghanistan Falls
text: In Tuesday’s New York Times, Elisabeth Bumiller and Allison Kopicki write about findings from the latest New York Times/CBS News poll, which found two-thirds of those polled — 69 percent — thought that the United States should not be at war in Afghanistan.

headline: Hilton Kramer, Art Critic and Champion of Tradition in Culture Wars, Dies at 84
text: Hilton Kramer, whose clear, incisive style and combative temperament made him one of the most influential critics of his era, both at The New York Times, where he was the chief art critic for almost a decade, and at The New Criterion, which he edited from its founding in 1982, died early Tuesday in Harpswell, Me. He was 84.

headline: Minsky and Methodology (Wonkish)
text: Steve Keen has a new post up (with a link to a new paper) about Minksyan (Minskyite?) economics, and how people like me get it wrong. Good for him; debates like this are always productive, and I wish domestic responsibilities weren’t keeping me from going to the Berlin conference.

headline: SAT and ACT to Tighten Rules After Cheating Scandal
text: Stung by a cheating scandal involving dozens of Long Island high school students, the SAT and ACT college entrance exams will now require students to provide a photograph when they sign up for the exams, and officials will check those images against the identification the students present when they take the test.

headline: The Challenge of Driving With Asperger’s
text: Over the last two decades, researchers have examined the risks faced by young drivers with attention deficit hyperactivity disorder and tried to find ways to help them to learn to drive safely, an issue explored in this week’s Science Times. Now those researchers and driving instructors are finding themselves faced with a new challenge: the growing number of teenagers with Asperger syndrome and other forms of autism, conditions defined by deficits in social skills and obsessive interests that can make learning to drive especially difficult.

headline: A Deservedly Smug iPhone Photo App
text: Update: Addresses new features added today.

headline: It’s Singers Over Dancers on Monday Night
text: The fight between two branches of performing arts — voice and dance — tipped decidedly to the singers Monday night in the area that counts most in television, younger adult viewers.

headline: In Court, Sharp Questions on Health Care Law’s Mandate
text: WASHINGTON — With the fate of President Obama’s health care law hanging in the balance, a lawyer for the administration faced a barrage of skeptical questions on Tuesday from four of the Supreme Court’s more conservative justices, suggesting that a 5-to-4 decision to strike down the law was a live possibility.

headline: The Get | Valextra’s Avietta 48h Case
text: In the spirit of Valextra’s original “24h” travel bag — a prize-winning attaché created in the 1950s by the founder Giovanni Fontana for quick overnight trips — the steel-frame “Avietta 48h,” first introduced in 1964, accommodates a two-night stay in an equally elegant way. The compact carrier, which is about the size of a pillow and nearly as light, features a proper briefcase handle (no lazy elbow hooking here), buttery soft leather and the company’s signature rhodium brushed zippers and pulls (so discreet and smooth to use). Inside, buckled straps secure things in place. Luxury, meet efficiency at its finest.

headline: A Counterfeiting Conspiracy?
text: In March 1862, an unusual ad began appearing in Northern newspapers. Among the shops selling pianos and patent medicines, sheet music and sewing machines, this one stood out: it promised “perfect fac-similes” of Confederate currency. There were seven kinds of notes for sale, and testimonials from The New York Tribune and others praising the replicas for their high quality and low prices. Five cents bought you one. Two dollars bought a hundred. Fifteen dollars bought a thousand. The word “counterfeits” never appeared. These were “Mementos of the Rebellion,” sold by a Philadelphia shopkeeper named Samuel Curtis Upham.

headline: Where Have I Seen You Before?
text: ADAPTATIONS, a k a blatant knockoffs, have always been a part of fashion, but they used to occur at a more civilized pace. Coco Chanel was famously relaxed about the issue; despite banding with Madeleine Vionnet to sue one particularly shameless copyist in the 1930s, when Paris was the undisputed center of the industry, she later authorized American dressmakers like David Kidd of Jablow to clone her signature nubby tweed suits for the common folk.

headline: Hawk Cam Video Highlight: Cooperation in the Nest
text: On Sunday, a reader known as HawkTalk in the Hawk Cam 2012 chat room witnessed an interesting bit of cooperation between the mates in the nest. An edited version of the events appears above. (Please ignore the “Please stand by while we adjust the Hawk Cam” overlay. It was captured as part of the archived segment, and cannot be removed.)

headline: New Insight Into a 1973 Mayoral Hopeful’s Losing Gambit
text: Former United States Representative Mario A. Biaggi’s mayoral campaign imploded in 1973 after the release of grand jury testimony confirming that he had refused to testify about certain financial matters and later lied by denying that he had invoked the Fifth Amendment. A new biography of a federal judge suggests that Mr. Biaggi, a Democrat from the Bronx, came a lot closer to getting elected than most New Yorkers realized.

headline: Business Day Live | Small Business Loans
text: March 27, 2012 - Karen Mills, chief of the Small Business Administration, answers questions about loans.

headline: War Over a One-Horse Town
text: About 125 millennia ago, the southern end of the strait between Africa and Arabia was much narrower, and may have been the springboard for one of early humanity’s great migratory leaps. [1] A big deal for everyone who has come along since, but the question of where, exactly, those first people out of Africa came from matters immensely to two very antagonistic neighbors. At this moment, in some Internet chat room, the locals are fighting over the nationality of those Red Sea pedestrians: did they originate in Eritrea, or in Ethiopia?

headline: Getting Your Media Retina-Ready
text: Now that the new iPad supports so-called “retina” resolution — namely the uber-HD 2048×1536 pixels that delivers crisp text and and great 3-D gaming — most of the video media you’re probably viewing on your older devices will probably look like an unmitigated mess. What to do?

headline: App Smart Extra: Gardening Apps
text: Strangely enough, there are few great gardening apps available, as last week’s App Smart column pointed out. But this is such a big market opportunity that niche media companies will inevitably join the fray.

headline: In Paris, a Housing Tower Transformed
text: La Tour Bois-le-Prêtre, a public housing tower on the outskirts of Paris, has been upgraded and now features an exterior of glass and aluminum.

headline: Anti-Gay Marriage Group Recommends Creating Tension Between Gays and Blacks
text: 9:05 p.m. | Updated An internal memorandum from one of the country’s leading organizations against same-sex marriage outlined a plan to help its cause by exploiting unease among blacks over the issue.

headline: The History Damaged Tree Rings Might Tell
text: Kevin Anchukaitis, an assistant research professor at the Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory at Columbia University, is conducting a tree-ring study to analyze drought patterns in Guatemala.

headline: Equipment Stolen From Romney Campaign Vehicle
text: SAN DIEGO — It’s hardly Watergate West, but Mitt Romney‘s campaign faced a break-in of its own on Friday night in California.

headline: Grieving for Pets and Humans: Is There a Difference?
text: Can the death of a pet hurt as much as the loss of a relative? The Washington Post food editor Joe Yonan recently wrote about his grieving process after the death of his dog Red compared with his feelings after losing two human family members. He writes:

headline: Hints of a $199 Tablet and 3-D Chromebook
text: Nvidia is a scrappy semiconductor company that used to be known for chips that richly rendered gaming graphics, but is now getting its advanced chips inside tablets and supercomputers. Last week the company released a new computer chip architecture that promises sharper graphics and less power consumption in desktops and ultrabooks.

headline: TimesCast | March 27, 2012
text: The Supreme Court holds the second day of hearings on the 2010 health care law | Upholding or repealing the law could have surprising political implications.

headline: The Muppets Strike Back at Goldman Sachs
text: The resignation manifesto read round the world – the Op-Ed page article published two weeks ago in The New York Times by Greg Smith, the disheartened Goldman Sachs executive – has already spawned more than its share of parodies, most of them in mock-serious epistolary prose. But the comedy Web site “Funny or Die” has gone these parodies one better with a slickly produced short sketch starring Kyle MacLachlan as a Goldman Sachs honcho bemoaning the firm’s bad press when his meeting is suddenly interrupted by three Muppets bearing their own grudge.

headline: Which Crowdfunding Bill Will It Be?
text: The most ballyhooed part of the House JOBS bill — and the only part changed by the Senate when it passed the legislation last week, is the so-called crowdfunding proposal to allow small companies to raise small amounts of money from large groups of small investors. It’s backed by the president, and by high-profile entrepreneurs, like Steve Case.

headline: Asylum Claims Rose 20 Percent Last Year, U.N. Refugee Agency Says
text: Escapees from new uprisings in the Middle East and Africa, combined with a rising tide of people fleeing chronic conflicts like those in Afghanistan and Iraq, contributed to a 20 percent increase in requests for asylum in industrialized countries last year, the United Nations refugee agency reported Tuesday.

headline: A Victory for Pat Summitt, Even in Defeat
text: The end of the Baylor-Tennessee game in the women’s N.C.A.A. tournament was hard for everyone, with the 400-pound elephant in attendance at Des Moines’s Wells Fargo Arena representing the scary question of what the loss meant for Tennessee Coach Pat Summitt, whether it spelled the end of her legendary career and how big a toll her early-onset dementia would take on her in the coming years.

headline: Join Our Live Discussion About the Supreme Court Health Care Debate
text: At noon Eastern time on Thursday, Adam Liptak, the Supreme Court correspondent for The New York Times, and Reed Abelson, a reporter covering health care for the paper’s Business Day section, will be answering readers’ questions on Facebook about the legal battle over the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act, President Obama’s signature legislative achievement, which is being challenged in historic Supreme Court arguments.

headline: Iraqi Immigrants in California Town Fear a Hate Crime in a Woman’s Killing
text: EL CAJON, Calif. — Shaima Alawadi’s family says they found the first note taped to the front door of their house on a quiet suburban street here. It said: “This is my country. Go back to yours, terrorist,” according to her 15-year-old son, Mohammed.

headline: A Surge in Learning the Language of the Internet
text: Parlez-vous Python? What about Rails or JavaScript? Foreign languages tend to wax and wane in popularity, but the language du jour is computer code.

headline: Driving With A.D.H.D.
text: Distracted driving is a problem for anyone, but clinical disorders like Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder make both learning to drive and earning a driver’s license feel nearly insurmountable for many. John O’Neil writes about the challenges for the Science  section  of The Times today: “young drivers with A.D.H.D. are two to four times as likely as those without the condition to have an accident — meaning that they are at a higher risk of wrecking the car than an adult who is legally drunk.”

headline: Timely | Sophie Aschauer: Knotty, Knotty
text: Sophie Aschauer has been fascinated by puzzles since she was a child. But it wasn’t until she picked up a book of sailor’s knots last year on a trip to Nantucket, Mass., that she put this interest to any practical use. “I was mesmerized,” says Aschauer, a New York-based, Austrian-born graduate of Central Saint Martins, who designs under the label SerpentSea. “Right away, I knew I was going to make them into mats.” Each of her small but weighty rugs incorporates about 150 feet of repurposed nautical and mountaineering rope, which she coaxes into intricate patterns that loop and twine like baroque infinity symbols. The hands-on process takes about four hours per rug; devising the patterns can take considerably longer. She has three models available, all named for famous pirates — Drake, Bonny and Morgan — and a larger area rug is in the works. “People love them as bathmats,” Aschauer says. “They feel very nice under bare feet.”

headline: In Paradise, and Closer Than Ever to Disaster
text: For many of us who live in temperate zones, inland regions and the industrialized West, global warming is a source of anxiety — even terror — and something of an abstraction. The mildness of this past winter on the Eastern Seaboard might have seemed ominous, yes, but it was also pleasant, and much of the time other social, economic and political problems have a way of seeming more urgent than human survival.

headline: Q&A: iOS Printing Without AirPrint
text: Q.

headline: WIC’s Fresh Produce Program Cut 30 Percent
text: In the appropriations bill for 2012, funding for the Women, Infants and Children Farmers Market Nutrition Program (WIC FMNP) was cut by approximately 30 percent. WIC’s FMNP helps provide underserved families across the country with fresh produce, and is not only a critical subsidy for families that might not otherwise have sufficient access to high-quality, nutritious food, but also for the small and mid-scale farmers and farmers markets that operate in low-income communities and rely on WIC’s FMNP dollars as a major source of revenue. By some estimates the 30 percent cut will decrease benefits for 300,000 families.

headline: On New Zealand’s South Island, Farm Stays With Friendly Hosts
text: Jogging down a rural stretch of road on the scantly populated and mountainous South Island of New Zealand last week, I noticed a herd of cattle staring at me.

headline: National Archives Announces Discovery of Nazi Looted-Art Volumes
text: The National Archives announced Tuesday that two new leather-bound volumes of an infamous catalog of looted art compiled for Hitler during World War II had been discovered among the possessions of former American soldiers. The albums were compiled by a special Nazi task force, the Einsatzstab Reichsleiter Rosenberg, to document the plundering of French museums and private collections undertaken in part for a museum Hitler planned to build in his hometown, Linz, Austria.

headline: F.D.A. Approves New Anemia Drug
text: It has been one of the most lucrative monopolies of all time, yielding the biotechnology company Amgen roughly $40 billion in sales over 23 years.

headline: Supreme Court Health Care Arguments: Day 2 Transcript
text: On the second day of arguments challenging President Obama’s 2010 health care law, conservative members of the Supreme Court asked skeptical questions about the individual mandate, a core provision of the legislation.

headline: New Way to Raise Cash: A Picture With Gingrich for $50
text: Newt Gingrich, who has encouraged donations of as little as $2.50, has turned to an unusual tactic for his financially troubled campaign: charging $50 for a photograph with him.

headline: Del Negro Gets Vote of Support from Clippers
text: It can’t be an N.B.A. season, even a lockout-shortened one, without some Los Angeles Clippers drama. The current brouhaha involves the fate of Coach Vinny Del Negro, who may or may not be in danger of losing his job. The Clippers are 28-21, second in the Pacific division and are safely occupying a playoff spot. But the Clippers are 8-9 in March, including a three-game losing streak over the past week, putting some heat on Del Negro.

headline: In the Court, Split Seems Partisan
text: Many legal scholars, including some conservatives, have been predicting that the Supreme Court will uphold the 2010 health care overhaul. But after Tuesday’s arguments, when several justices asked skeptical questions about the heart of the law, a political lens seemed relevant, too.

headline: Adam Liptak on the Health Care Hearings
text: The Times's Adam Liptak discusses the fallout from the second day of hearings at the Supreme Court on the 2010 health care law.

headline: A Fateful Superman Check Is Up for Auction
text: Is a check for $412 really worth $412? That’s a question that has comic book fans intrigued this week. The check in question is the one endorsed by Jerome Siegel and Joe Shuster when they signed over their rights for creating Superman, whose adventures are published by DC Comics. Now the auction site Comicconnect.com is putting the check up for sale. The auction began on Monday and ends on April 16. The 12 bids have already pushed the price to $25,500.

headline: Square’s Mobile Payment App Gets New Name and Look
text: The next time you stop into a small business, Square hopes you will Pay With Square. That’s the new, more straightforward name for Square’s mobile payments app, previously called Card Case.

headline: Creative License
text: The most inspired — and inspiring — fashion show of the spring 2012 season took place not in Paris, Milan or London but on a makeshift runway in Oakland, Calif. On March 16, Creative Growth, the nonprofit organization that serves adult artists with developmental, mental and physical disabilities, presented “Beyond Trend,” a fund-raiser that kicked off with a street parade and culminated in a runway show. As if anyone needed further evidence of the incredible talent on display that day, many of the looks were not only designed, but also modeled, by Creative Growth artists. The filmmaker Cheryl Dunn captured the magic.

headline: Pilot’s Erratic Behavior Forces Flight From Kennedy to Be Diverted
text: Updated, 5:03 p.m. | A JetBlue flight to Las Vegas from John F. Kennedy International Airport was diverted to Amarillo, Tex., on Tuesday morning when the captain started behaving erratically and had to be removed from the cockpit, according to the Federal Aviation Administration.

headline: Quietly, a Budget Deal Is Reached in Albany
text: ALBANY — No flash. No sizzle. No last-minute protests, and no late-night dramatics.

headline: Parking Lots, Ready for a Close-Up and a Spruce-Up
text: As he argued in a piece that appeared Monday in The Times’s Opinion Pages, Eran Ben-Joseph, a professor of landscape architecture and planning at M.I.T., claims that the world’s parking lots are deeply flawed.

headline: Kadima Party in Israel Replaces Livni as Leader
text: JERUSALEM — Tzipi Livni, who not long ago was a popular and leading force in Israeli politics, lost the leadership of her centrist Kadima Party on Tuesday by a large margin to an archrival, according to results of the primary election.

headline: Olympic Mascots Inspire Imitations
text: The 1968 Winter Games in Grenoble, France, opened the floodgates for Olympic mascots by giving the world Schuss, a cartoon character that became known as the Skiing Sperm. All manner of misshapen and barely identifiable creatures have followed, from Waldi the multicolored dachshund (Munich, 1972) to Magique the star-shaped snow imp (Albertville, France, 1992) to Izzy the computer-generated ... something (Atlanta, 1996).

headline: A Clearer Picture of Tropical Carbon
text: Tropical forests, alongside boreal forests and wetlands, are prime ecosystems for storing carbon. Now, researchers have created a new high-resolution map of carbon storage in tropical forests that could play an important role in effective forest management.

headline: A Mayor Who Never Slept Here (Gracie Mansion) Says No Successor Should
text: It has been a shipping magnate’s country residence, has housed public restrooms and classes for immigrants and has even done a stint as an ice cream shop. But for the past 70 years, Gracie Mansion has been home to nine New York City mayors, from Fiorello H. La Guardia to Rudolph W. Giuliani.

headline: Before the Law: Understanding the Supreme Court Case on the Affordable Care Act
text: Overview | What are the issues at stake in the Supreme Court challenges to President Obama’s health care law? In this lesson, students create a television news segment to inform their school’s community about the questions regarding Affordable Health Care Act that are being considered by the Supreme Court.

headline: Computer-Hacking Allegations Made Against News Corporation
text: News Corporation faced fresh scrutiny in Britain on Tuesday after a BBC documentary reported that a company affiliated with the media conglomerate used computer hacking to advance the business interests of the broadcaster BSkyB.

headline: Wines of Europe Look to Asia to Offset Slowdown at Home
text: VERONA, Italy — Long gone are the days when French soldiers or Italian farmhands were issued their daily ration of a liter of wine. Even the three-hour Parisian lunch, accompanied by a few glasses of red, white or sparkling, is threatened by the ravages of globalization.

headline: Bronx Museum to Be Free to Visitors
text: Joining a sizable roster of museums around the country, the Bronx Museum of the Arts has decided to go free. As a way of marking its 40th anniversary, the museum, on the Grand Concourse not far from Yankee Stadium, will eliminate its suggested admission fee of $5 beginning March 29.

headline: Video of Assad in Battered City Is Broadcast on Syrian State Television
text: Updated | 7:32 p.m. As my colleagues Anne Barnard and Alan Cowell report, Syrian state television broadcast footage of President Bashar al-Assad on Tuesday in the city of Homs, touring the ruined neighborhood of Baba Amr, which was recently brought back under government control after a weeks-long military assault.

headline: JPMorgan Promotes Lawyer
text: JPMorgan Chase promoted Matthew Biben to general counsel for all of the bank’s consumer businesses, according to an internal memo on Tuesday. Mr. Biben joined JPMorgan Chase last March as general counsel, overseeing the bank’s mortgage banking operations.

headline: Begin the Bidet
text: The bidet may be a fixture in bathrooms the world over, but it has never really caught on in the United States. Instead of washing with water after relieving ourselves, we’d rather deforest millions of acres to produce toilet paper. We think bidets are too European, maybe. Or we suspect that they have something to do with s-e-x.

headline: In Pursuit of EMI, Sony and Universal Will Sell Music-Publishing Assets
text: The purchase of EMI by Sony and Universal, if approved, would result in further consolidation of the music industry, which over the last 15 years has gone from six major players to four. But as a byproduct of this deal, hundreds of millions of dollars in music assets will be hitting the market, either to help those companies finance the purchase or to appease regulatory authorities in the United States and Europe.

headline: For Romney, a Four-Car Garage With Its Own Elevator
text: SAN DIEGO — If the news last summer that Mitt Romney had a $12 million expansion planned for his oceanfront property here helped portray him as a member of the top 1 percent, the new disclosure that the renovation includes elevators for his four-car garage is not likely to burnish his image as a man of the people.

headline: Officer Convicted in Sexual Assault
text: A New York City police officer was found guilty on Tuesday of predatory sexual assault in an attack on a 25-year-old woman at gunpoint in Upper Manhattan in August, and faced a possible sentence of life in prison.

headline: Baby Boomers’ Confidence Dented by Recession
text: The last five years have been tough on Americans’ financial confidence, particularly among baby boomers thought of as upbeat and affluent, a new survey has found.

headline: TimesCast: Supreme Court Hearings Continue
text: David Leonhardt reports on developments from the second day of hearings on the 2010 health care law at the Supreme Court, and Michael D. Shear breaks down the political implications of the eventual ruling on the 2012 presidential campaign.

headline: Look of The Moment | January Jones
text: The Look: Party Pieces. A peekaboo back and thigh-high slit add drama to a minimally adorned black dress.

headline: Cost Complaints, an Olympic Rite, Voiced in Britain
text: LONDON — Money was so scarce at the 1948 London Olympics that the athletes brought their own towels, shipped food in from abroad and slept in army barracks and college dormitories. The £760,000 budget was paid by sponsors after Prime Minister Clement Attlee declared that a depleted country struggling in the aftermath of World War II should not have to shoulder the burden of the Games, too.

headline: Cuban Official Rules Out Reforms Urged by Pope
text: HAVANA — Just after Pope Benedict XVI prayed at a revered shrine in Cuba on Tuesday, calling for the country to move forward “along the way of renewal and hope,” a top government minister made clear that the sweeping economic changes under way here would not be accompanied by political reforms that the pope has urged.

headline: Photo Replay: March 27
text: The day in sports included the world team table tennis championships in Dortmund, Germany, and the world figure skating championships in Nice, France.

headline: For New Generation of Power Plants, a New Emission Rule From the E.P.A.
text: The Obama administration’s proposed rule to control greenhouse gas emissions from new power plants — the first ever — could go far toward closing out the era of old-fashioned coal-burning power generation.

headline: Beyond Trend: Creative Growth Art Center
text: A runway event for Creative Growth Art Center.

headline: Styling Steve Kazee
text: The actor Steve Kazee in trend-centric polka dots for T’s photo shoot.

headline: Learning to Breast-Feed From an Avatar
text: When two Northeastern University professors, one in health sciences and the other in computer and information science, came together to try to develop a system to help women breast-feed more successfully, their project joined their common interest and their two worlds. They created a lactation avatar: Tanya.

headline: Food Co-op Rejects Effort to Boycott Israeli-Made Products
text: Members of the Park Slope Food Co-op voted overwhelmingly on Tuesday night against a motion that would have moved the organization closer to joining an international boycott against products made in Israel. The vote settled a debate that had embroiled the venerable neighborhood institution for many months and divided its membership.

headline: This Little Piggy Stayed Home
text: BACON has nudged its way into every cranny of culinary fashion, be it vodka cocktails, short-rib braises or caramel cupcakes. It’s everywhere. Still. And for good reason: A little bit of bacon packs an umami-rich punch for simple salads, soups or pots of otherwise virtuous greens — not to mention the role it plays in Sunday morning’s alchemy of coffee and newsprint.

headline: Banking Mysticism
text: Reading the comments on my Steve Keen post, I had an insight: banking is where left and right meet. Both the Austrians — who believe that whatever the market does is right, unless it’s fractional reserve banking, which is somehow terrible — and the self-proclaimed true Minskyites view banks as institutions that are somehow outside the rules that apply to the rest of the economy, as having unique powers for good and/or evil.

headline: Good Golly, Miss Molly
text: Molly Ivins award dinner, June 7.

headline: Artifacts | The Rondinone Spirit
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Tibetan Exiles Rally Around Delhi Self-Immolator
text: DHARAMSALA, India — By Tuesday afternoon, posters of the man in flames were plastered along the narrow streets of this town adopted by Tibetan exiles. Monks, merchants and tourists stared. In the early evening, more than 200 people walked through the town center waving Tibetan flags and carrying banners that proclaimed the critically injured man, Jamphel Yeshi, a martyr.

headline: Pairings: Stuffed Trout With Porter Sauce
text: Porters are deceiving. They show dark richness in the glass, but on the palate, the beers are refreshingly dry, not heavy, and can harmonize with more foods than a fruit-forward cabernet. Every match is welcome, from a plate of briny oysters to a rack of ribs rimmed with char. If the dish mirrors some of the beer’s subtle notes of chocolate, coffee, spice, toast and smoke, all the better. I roasted a good-size trout seasoned with soy sauce — another flavor that showed up in the beers — and stuffed it with toasted bread crumbs. A healthy splash of porter also went into the pan to make a sauce. The fish can be readied for roasting well in advance. And the recipe can easily be doubled, serving four or more for a dinner party.

headline: Ale to Usher in Baseball Season
text: I’VE been a baseball fanatic most of my life. When I was a child I knew the starting lineup of every team in both leagues. Statistics slipped through my lips as easily as lies would through a politician’s.

headline: U.S. Navy Program to Study How Troops Use Intuition
text: The United States Navy has started a program to investigate how members of the military can be trained to improve their “sixth sense,” or intuitive ability, during combat and other missions.

headline: For Kevin Anderson, Concerns About Tennis in South Africa
text: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla.–Now at his career-high ranking of No. 28, the 6-foot-8 South African Kevin Anderson is one of a growing number of tall, big-serving players blasting their way to the upper echelon of tennis.

headline: Hilton Kramer’s Provocative Time at The Times
text: Hilton Kramer, who died Tuesday at 84, arrived at The New York Times in 1965, and became the paper’s chief art critic in 1973. His 1981 review of an exhibit of Milton Avery’s paintings included this distillation of his preference for the aesthetic over the political in art:

headline: Watch ‘Bullitt’ Homage, and a Making-of Minidocumentary, From ‘Alcatraz’
text: As John Pearley Huffman wrote Monday, the season finale of “Alcatraz,” which was broadcast Monday night on Fox, contained an homage to the chase scene from “Bullitt,” the 1968 police drama starring Steve McQueen.

headline: Off Limits
text: If you’re a Republican candidate for the presidency, and you’re trying to figure out if you’ve reached the limits of acceptability in attacking Barack Obama, here’s an easy marker: Even House Speaker John Boehner thinks you’re tactless.

text: A Whiskey Tasting

headline: The Case for Raising Top Tax Rates
text: The wealthy are feeling defensive about their taxes. Most Americans may think the rich pay too little but, not surprisingly, only 30 percent of the rich agree. More than two-thirds of families earning a quarter of a million dollars a year or more tell Gallup’s pollsters that their taxes are too high.

headline: Passover Seder, Smoothly Done
text: MY 98-year-old mother calls my Passover seder a gantzeh megillah — a big production. She’s right. For me, the seder is the hardest event of the year to prepare for. Yet it is by far the most meaningful because it commemorates the defining chapter in Judaism, when the Jews fled slavery in Egypt to freedom in the promised land.

headline: Joan Nathan’s Matzo Balls
text: Joan Nathan, the Jewish cooking maven, shares her matzo ball recipe with Melissa Clark.

headline: Dewey Overhauls Leadership Amid Financial Difficulties
text: The troubled New York law firm Dewey & LeBoeuf has overhauled its leadership amid questions about its financial condition and a stream of partner defections.

headline: Bernanke, the Anti-Garbo
text: Investors are said to hang on every word spoken by the chairman of the Federal Reserve. The current chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, must be testing their patience.

headline: Resetting the Table
text: FOR a lot of people who spent the Clinton years eating in and around Midtown Manhattan, 1996 was all about the crackling pork shank.

headline: Pettitte’s Positive Day
text: TAMPA, Fla. — Andy Pettitte inched closer to pitching in a game Tuesday when he threw 35 pitches of batting practice to Nick Swisher and Chris Dickerson, and came away with a glowing review of his performance.

headline: Are Taxes Too High? People Invariably Think So
text: A study shows that Americans thinks the tax rate needs to be lower.

headline: Show Time: The Cooking Comes Tableside
text: WHEN a revamped Maloney & Porcelli opens its doors next week, diners will be able to order martinis from a cart wheeled around the dining room. If they’re hungry for the Bronson Pinchot, a revved-up steak au poivre, a chef will create that at a tableside cart, too. The same goes for the grasshopper pie, whose rich topping of boozy cream will be whisked a few inches from your seat.

headline: The Reinvented Maloney & Porcelli
text: Inside the chophouse, founded in 1996, that is looking back at retro styles in order to get ahead.

headline: Don Draper and the Delicate Art of Restaurant Renovation
text: I’m sorry, readers. I know I’m supposed to be focused on writing this blog post, but I can’t stop murmuring zoobeezoobee zoo, zoobeezoobee zoo. Or, more precisely, “ZouBisouBisou.”

headline: Senate Defers Work on Post Office Overhaul
text: The Senate on Tuesday voted down a motion to begin work on legislation that would have overhauled the financially ailing Postal Service, a measure that postal officials said did not go far enough in allowing them to cut costs, and that some postal unions said would make the post office’s financial situation even worse.

headline: Administration Faces Questions on Health Care
text: On the second day of arguments challenging President Obama’s 2010 health care law, conservative members of the Supreme Court asked skeptical questions about the individual mandate, a core provision of the legislation.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: ‘Mad Men’ GIFS and iPad Charging
text: Here are some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web on Tuesday. There are more here.

headline: Giddy Beats Celebrating Female Empowerment
text: When the women of Nimbaya! start breaking taboos, taboos should watch out. This all-female company comes from Guinea, West Africa, where tradition dictates that only men play drums. Every time these women perform, they smash that prohibition and dance to celebrate.

headline: SAT Reforms May Have Negative Impact on Students, Counselors Say
text: Students who take the SAT and ACT will soon be required to upload photos of themselves when they register for the college entrance exams, our colleagues report.

text: Inside the Manhattan outpost of Peruvian restaurant chain, housed in the former Tabla space.

headline: Storming New York With Ceviche
text: ON one of the few nights this winter when the temperature sagged below freezing, the host at La Mar Cebicheria Peruana led my party to an upstairs table without offering to take our coats. This was a surprise, because the coat check had been in full swing on a warmer night weeks earlier.

headline: A Striver Comes to an Ignoble End
text: Massenet’s “Manon” clings to a place in the standard repertory, though just barely. It is a popular but problematic work. The title role of an alluring French girl from a small town with a fatal attraction to riches and pleasures has long been an irresistible vehicle for a star soprano.

headline: Final Approval by House Sends Jobs Bill to President for Signature
text: WASHINGTON — The House gave overwhelming final approval on Tuesday to a package of measures intended to ease access to capital and investments for entrepreneurs, sending the bipartisan legislation to President Obama, who has said he will sign it.

headline: Overlooked Songwriter Finally Gets His Due
text: When the New York Philharmonic meets Broadway, wonderful things can happen. At the orchestra’s spring gala at Avery Fisher Hall on Monday evening, the songs of the chronically overlooked Frank Loesser received well-deserved royal treatment. Conducted by Ted Sperling, the concert sustained an ideal, acoustically perfect mixture of brassy confidence and vaulting romanticism.

headline: Rucola
text: 190 Dean Street (at Bond Street), Boerum Hill, Brooklyn; (718) 576-3209, rucolabrooklyn.com.

headline: On Way to Worlds, a Stop in North Korea
text: The world championships will be in Nathalie Péchalat’s home country, France, this week, and so the ice dancer will apply tape to her broken nose and makeup to cover the bruising, and glide onto the ice with the requisite smile to compete in Nice on Wednesday.

headline: This Year, It’s ‘Idol’ Chasing the Voice
text: A couple of weeks ago on “The Voice,” during one of the battle rounds, Adam Levine was twisted into one of his signature poses meant to communicate agony and indecision. Angel Taylor and Katrina Parker had just squared off singing Leona Lewis’s “Bleeding Love,” and Mr. Levine, their coach, was being pulled in conflicting directions. Should he choose Ms. Taylor, a telegenic singer with a wispy voice who’d previously been signed to a major label? Or should he choose Ms. Parker, the less obvious star of the two, but who outsang Ms. Taylor during the battle?

headline: Bring Out Your Ringtones, and Other Requests for Accompaniment
text: Instead of the usual admonition about silencing cellphones, So Percussion prefaced its concert at Zankel Hall on Monday evening by telling listeners to turn theirs on, to make sure that the volume was all the way up, and to set an alarm — the more obnoxious the better — for 1 hour 18 minutes into the program.

headline: Cochinita
text: 922 Fulton Street (St. James Place), Clinton Hill, Brooklyn; (718) 789-7700; tacoscochinita.com.

headline: A Lacy Tribute to Italian Jews
text: Judith Norell, an owner of Silver Moon Bakery on the Upper West Side, has baked matzos for a few years. But now she is expanding the line to include whole wheat, poppy seed and sesame seed matzos, in addition to plain.

headline: Homemade Marshmallows, Not Just for Kids
text: Commercial marshmallows pale next to these big, handmade ones from California. Their subtle flavors, dazzling colors and firm yet supple texture make them treats for all ages. Pop a few into the Easter basket, or pile them in a dish to accompany dessert at a brunch. The company that makes them, Split Bean Coffee in Van Nuys, Calif., also specializes in alfajores, the delicious South American filled shortbread cookies, using a family recipe.

text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,899 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American this week:

headline: School Administrator Resigns After Inquiry Into Wife's Job
text: A city investigation found that Angel Namnum, the executive director of the Department of Education’s finance division, had arranged for his wife to be hired for a job at the department.

headline: Detention Is No Holiday
text: MiamiLAMAR SMITH, the chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, is presiding over a hearing Wednesday on new guidelines for immigration detention that were issued last month and are now beginning to go into effect. The official (and facetious) title of the hearing is “Holiday on ICE,” in reference to the more humane treatment undocumented immigrants should now receive after being picked up by Immigration and Customs Enforcement.

headline: Yankees’ Chamberlain Reflecting on an Injury, Minus Regret
text: TAMPA, Fla. — While a distraught Joba Chamberlain was lying in his bed at St. Joseph’s Hospital, recovering from surgery to repair a severe ankle injury, a nurse came in last weekend and asked what had happened.

headline: Expected Flood of Opportunities in Europe Is Still a Trickle
text: LONDON — American private equity firms are playing a waiting game in Europe.

headline: Comcast Streaming Service Raises Net-Neutrality Concerns
text: 12:35 p.m., March 31 | Updated  Adding statement from Comcast at end.

headline: Bad Wire in Heart Device Led to 22 Deaths, Study Says
text: A defect in wires that connect hearts to defibrillators caused at least 22 deaths, possibly as a result of a short circuit that is difficult to detect during routine monitoring, according to a study in the journal Heart Rhythm.

headline: Slain Teenager’s Parents Appear on Capitol Hill
text: The parents of Trayvon Martin called on the public on Tuesday to refrain from violence and from trying to apprehend the man who fatally shot their son last month. “We recognize that a lot of people are doing things on behalf of Trayvon Martin,” his mother, Sybrina Fulton, said at a news conference after briefly appearing at a forum on Capitol Hill organized by House Democrats. “We decided that we want this done peacefully. We want you to protest, we want you to rally. But we want to make sure it’s a peaceful rally so your voices can be heard.” A lawyer for the family, Benjamin Crump, said relatives “don’t want anyone making an arrest of George Zimmerman,” the man who shot the teenager on Feb. 26, “other than the authorities.” A group called the New Black Panthers has said it will give a $10,000 reward to anyone who captures Mr. Zimmerman, who has been in hiding.

headline: Schools Will Be Protected From Cuts Next Year, Walcott Says
text: After years of painful cuts and threats of teacher layoffs, city officials on Tuesday laid out a decidedly more optimistic portrait of financing for city schools next year, saying they expected that principals would have enough money in their budgets to retain most of their teachers and other school employees.

headline: Judge Bars Imported Drugs in Executions
text: A federal judge has prohibited the use of imported death penalty drugs and has ordered the Food and Drug Administration to collect the drugs from any states that have imported them. Judge Richard J. Leon of the Federal District Court in Washington ruled Tuesday in a case brought on behalf of death row inmates in Arizona, California and Tennessee. States that use sodium thiopental to render prisoners unconscious as part of their execution protocols reached out to foreign suppliers when the sole domestic manufacturer stopped producing the drug, which had not been approved for importation. The F.D.A. said it had no jurisdiction over execution drugs. Judge Leon wrote that the agency “appears to be simply wrapping itself in the flag of law enforcement discretion to justify its authority and masquerade an otherwise seemingly callous indifference to the health consequences of those imminently facing the executioner’s needle. How utterly disappointing!” Bradford Berenson, a lawyer for the inmates, said the decision proved that “even death row inmates are entitled to the protection of the law.”

headline: Excerpts From Dickey’s New Book
text: R.A. Dickey’s new memoir, “Wherever I Wind Up: My Quest for Truth, Authenticity and the Perfect Knuckleball,” written with the Daily News reporter Wayne Coffey, is a refreshingly frank look at his troubled childhood, his success as a high school and college player, and his rocky 16-year professional career. Here are some excerpts:

headline: Payton Continues to Plan for the Off-Season: His Own and the Saints’
text: PALM BEACH, Fla. — The setting seemed incongruous for such an unsavory subject. But nearly a week after he was suspended for the 2012 season amid revelations of a bounty system employed by the New Orleans Saints, Coach Sean Payton stepped in front of a towering arrangement of pink blossoms in the lobby of the Breakers Hotel and publicly addressed for the first time his role in the scandal that has shaken the franchise and preoccupied the rest of the N.F.L.

headline: Giants and Cowboys in Opener
text: PALM BEACH, Fla. — The Giants will host the Dallas Cowboys in the N.F.L.’s season opener Sept. 5 at MetLife Stadium in East Rutherford, N.J. Since 2004, the Super Bowl champion has hosted the opener, with the home team going 8-0 in those games.

headline: Doctors Have Feelings, Too
text: IT was a little bit like looking in the mirror. We were the same height and build, the same age — mid-30s — and both of us had two young children at home. In another world, had we been friends, we could have easily shared clothing. But today it was me with the white coat, and her with the death sentence.

headline: Get a Deal and a Reward, Just by Using Your Card
text: GIVEN that the market for daily deals is saturated with offers from Web sites like Groupon, flash sale sites like Gilt.com and credit card companies offering cash back and airline miles, it might appear that small businesses are raking in profits from customers seduced by such great deals.

headline: Warning Flags Were Raised in MF Global Transfers
text: Some MF Global employees were aware of a shortfall in the firm’s customer accounts days before filing for bankruptcy on Oct. 31, according to people involved in the case, a revelation that raises questions about why the firm failed to safeguard client money and whether it withheld information from authorities.

headline: Passengers Restrain Captain After Crisis on JetBlue Flight
text: HOUSTON — The captain of a JetBlue flight from New York to Las Vegas suffered a bizarre midair breakdown on Tuesday morning, forcing passengers to restrain him as the plane made an emergency landing in Amarillo, Tex., where he was removed from the aircraft and hospitalized.

headline: Foreclosure Deal Credits Banks for Routine Efforts
text: In February, JPMorgan Chase donated a home to an Iraq war veteran in Bucoda, Wash., and Bank of America waived the $140,000 debt that a Florida man still owed after the sale of his foreclosed home. Over the last year, Wells Fargo has demolished about a dozen houses in Cleveland.

headline: The Right to Sell Kids Junk
text: The First Amendment to the Constitution, which tops our Bill of Rights, guarantees — theoretically, at least — things we all care about. So much is here: freedom of religion, of the press, of speech, the right to assemble and more. Yet it’s stealthily and  incredibly being invoked to safeguard the nearly unimpeded “right” of a handful of powerful corporations to market junk food to children.

headline: Independent Agency Gets New Powers to Prosecute New York Police Officers
text: Lawyers for the independent agency that investigates allegations of police abuse in New York have been given wide new powers to prosecute officers in misconduct cases under an agreement city officials reached on Tuesday.

headline: Parents of Florida Teenager Killed in Shooting Call for Peaceful Protest
text: The parents of Trayvon Martin called on the public on Tuesday to refrain from violence or trying to apprehend the man who fatally shot their son last month.

headline: Witness Testifies How Plot to Kill Officer Was Set Up
text: An admitted hit man for the Mafia recalled a ride he took with his boss through the streets of Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn.

headline: Knowing Cost, the Customer Sets the Price
text: P. T. Vineburgh has a sense of how much things should cost, and on a recent trip to the Boston jeweler Shreve, Crump & Low, he was not afraid to say so.

headline: Massachusetts Residents Who Don’t Comply With the Health Coverage Mandate
text: A demographic breakdown of the 2 percent of Massachusetts residents who illegally abstain from having health insurance

headline: Soccer Rivals Face Off in Verse
text: If you watch the Champions League quarterfinals, you will hear soccer fans in their full-throated glory. Here is a look at popular chants among supporters of Wednesday’s home teams.

headline: With Empty Homes All Over the Globe, an Easy Position to Take
text: Ever since Gracie Mansion became the official residence for New York mayors, in 1942, very few of the 10 eligible tenants have turned up their noses at the chance to live, rent free, in the stately riverside home.

headline: The Ryan Budget: Policy, or Just Politics?
text: Paul Ryan and the House Republicans have offered a radical outline, and it is drawing fire from the right as well as the left.

headline: In Massachusetts, Insurance Mandate Stirs Some Dissent
text: BOSTON — Wayde Lodor is part of the 2 percent: the roughly 120,000 residents of Massachusetts who lack health insurance despite the state’s landmark 2006 law requiring almost every adult in the state to have it. He is likely to face a penalty this year, having made enough money under the state’s guidelines to afford a health plan. But Mr. Lodor, an independent product development consultant from Leominster, remains defiant.

headline: Elephants Down Under
text: Christchurch, New Zealand

headline: On ‘Tonight Show,’ Romney Is Quizzed on Potential Vice Presidents
text: BURBANK, Calif. — Mitt Romney came on “The Tonight Show With Jay Leno” to tape an appearance set to broadcast Tuesday evening, and found himself in a game of word association pegged to some potential vice presidential picks, should he win the Republican presidential nomination.

headline: The Supreme Court’s Momentous Test
text: In ruling on the constitutionality of requiring most Americans to obtain health insurance, the Supreme Court faces a central test: whether it will recognize limits on its own authority to overturn well-founded acts of Congress.

headline: Tebow, a Careful Evangelical
text: Tim Tebow may be the most popular Christian in sports. He is a cross-cultural phenomenon, a preacher in a football player’s body.

headline: Food Start-Ups Find a Home in Brooklyn
text: The rise of artisanal food like small-batch pickles, basement-cured charcuterie and hand-churned ice cream has been a boon to Brooklyn’s image. Now those products are helping the borough revive its manufacturing base, in a former pharmaceutical factory in South Williamsburg.

headline: Israel’s Top Court vs. Outposts
text: Israel’s Supreme Court made an important contribution to justice and kept alive hope for a two-state solution with the Palestinians, when it ruled this week that Migron, an illegal outpost built by Israeli settlers, must be dismantled by Aug. 1. Now it is up to Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu to comply promptly, while making clear to the settlers that violent resistance will not be tolerated.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: March 27, 2012

headline: A Dream Act Without the Dream
text: Republican politicians have overwhelmingly embraced an approach to immigration reform that offers only misery, arrest and punishment to the undocumented. That is popular with party’s hard-right base, but toxic with Hispanic voters — which has led some Republicans to come up with proposals that seem to shimmer with promise but lead to the same no-future dead end.

headline: Swedish Golfer Confronts Toughest Foe: Her Stutter
text: PHOENIX — On a recent Tuesday, the golfer Sophie Gustafson set about videotaping a six-and-a-half-minute speech she had composed for an awards dinner in conjunction with the Masters in April. Alone with a video camera in her Orlando, Fla., home, Gustafson expected the taping to go off without a hitch.

headline: Fugitive Slave Mentality
text: Before he temporarily stepped down from his position last week as chief of the Sanford, Fla., police department, Bill Lee Jr., gave an explanation of his decision not to arrest George Zimmerman for killing Trayvon Martin. Lee said he had no reason to doubt Zimmerman’s claim of self-defense. Though Lee is no longer in the spotlight, his words linger for at least one compelling reason: his explanation bears an eerie resemblance to cases brought under the Fugitive Slave Law during the Antebellum period. Today, a legal standard that allowed the police chief to take Zimmerman at his word recalls the dark past of slave-owners claiming their property. The writings of Martin Delany, the African American political philosopher and activist, shed light on the uncanny resemblance.

headline: Rezoning Transforms Character of Harlem Boulevard
text: The fragile yet promising community of new businesses around Frederick Douglass Boulevard from 110th to 125th Street in Harlem is struggling to maintain the charm that has attracted new residents, shoppers and diners in the face of large-scale development nearby and a still-shaky economy.

headline: At Wagner, a New Coach’s Rapid Rise
text: Bashir Mason’s first call after he was hired as the Wagner’s men’s basketball coach Sunday night was to his mother, Kathy, in Jersey City.

headline: Clean Water and the Spruce Mine
text: The Obama administration’s decision last year to revoke a permit for a huge mine in West Virginia inspired hope that mountaintop mining, which has caused immense environmental damage across Appalachia, would soon be coming to an end. Now a Federal District Court judge in the District of Columbia has ruled that the Environmental Protection Agency exceeded its legal authority in blocking the mine. The administration must appeal. The Clean Water Act is on its side, as are the people of West Virginia.

headline: Ex-Firefighter Hurt in 1989 Still Fights for Full Pension
text: Until that day in 1989, when he was badly injured in a fall while battling an arson fire at a vacant synagogue in Brooklyn, Firefighter Michael T. Romanelli was always ready for the next call.

headline: Two Are Accused of Holding Woman Captive in Queens
text: When Nicole Nettleford had not seen her next-door neighbor for about a year, she assumed that the woman had left Rockaway Beach, Queens, for Pennsylvania with the rest of her family. A month ago, Ms. Nettleford said, she realized her mistake: The neighbor, Maureen Murray, was at a window, screaming for help.

headline: Hal Fetner
text: Mr. Fetner, 51, is the president and chief executive of Durst Fetner Residential, a partnership formed in 2008 between Sidney Fetner Associates and the Durst Organization. The company focuses mainly on rentals, and its portfolio includes the 400-unit Epic in Midtown South and the Chesapeake on the Upper East Side.

headline: 2 Israeli Leaders Make the Iran Issue Their Own
text: JERUSALEM — Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and Defense Minister Ehud Barak have turned into the odd couple of Israeli politics in whose hands sits the prospect of an attack on Iran. From opposite political traditions with distinct experiences and worldviews, the two have forged a tight bond, often excluding the rest of the Israeli leadership.

headline: A Vintage Postcard From Splitsville, U.S.A.
text: “Regrets,” a new play by the British writer Matt Charman, is set in a humble motel near Reno, Nev., in 1954. It’s a dusty, depressing way station for men whose marriages have hit the skids. Here they must park themselves for the requisite six weeks to earn official residency in the state of Nevada, which has always made it easy to untie the bonds of matrimony.

headline: They’ve Got Us Surrounded
text: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — Wow. At first, probably because of the way I solved it, I thought this was the most feminine grid I had ever worked. A tribute to us womenfolk, as it were. Then I ran into ED.

headline: In Memoir, Dickey Details Sexual Abuse
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — If R. A. Dickey felt any anxiety Tuesday as reporters approached him at his locker, he did not let it show. With his familiar forthright demeanor, with teammates in earshot, he answered one question after another about being sexually abused as a child, and cheating on his wife as an adult, all of it revealed in his newly published memoir.

headline: Strength and Weakness in the Campaign of Ron Paul
text: BURBANK, Calif. — Whatever happened to Ron Paul?

headline: Fish Is Discovering His Best Form
text: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla. — It took a few months, but Mardy Fish, the No. 8 player in the world and top American, is finally playing up to his billing.

headline: Gas Leak on Offshore Platform Forces Evacuation in North Sea
text: LONDON — A major gas leak on an offshore platform in the North Sea forced crews to evacuate it and other equipment in the area on Tuesday because of the risk of explosion, and ships and aircraft were ordered to stay miles away. Total, the French energy company that operates the platform, said it might take as long as six months to stop the release of gas.

headline: Though Battered, Hayes Lifts UConn to Final Four
text: KINGSTON, R.I. — As she was ripping down another rebound early in the second half, the Connecticut senior Tiffany Hayes was fouled hard, and her head bounced off the floor. She went to the bench for all of 15 seconds, then returned, just as ferocious as before.

headline: Link to Starry Past Lifts Stanford to Final
text: In his fifth season at Stanford, Josh Owens is a bridge to better times, when the Cardinal were still an N.C.A.A. tournament regular and a powerhouse in a strong Pacific-10 Conference.

headline: Group Allied With Cuomo Tops Albany Spending List
text: ALBANY — Highlighting a shift in the way money is spent to influence government, the group that spent the most on lobbying in New York last year was a coalition of business leaders allied with Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, according to a report released on Tuesday by the state’s Joint Commission on Public Ethics.

headline: U.S. Judge in Michigan Acquits Militia Members of Sedition
text: DETROIT — Members of a Christian militia accused of plotting an antigovernment uprising were acquitted on sedition and conspiracy charges on Tuesday by a federal judge who said prosecutors had failed to prove that the group had concrete plans to attack anyone.

headline: Could Defeat in Court Help Obama Win?
text: If the Supreme Court decides to strike down the new health care law’s individual mandate to purchase insurance, it will represent a remarkable election-year rebuke for President Obama – the rejection, by the nation’s highest court, of a central provision of his main domestic policy accomplishment.

headline: Contingency Plans Are Few if Court Strikes Down Insurance Requirement
text: WASHINGTON — After a day punctuated by seeming skepticism from Supreme Court conservatives about the constitutionality of requiring Americans to buy health insurance, the justices will turn their attention on Wednesday to how much of the 2010 health care law might survive if they strike down that mandate.

headline: With Late Goal, Rangers Find Bit of Breathing Room at the Top
text: ST. PAUL — As the nights of the regular season dwindle to a precious few, the Rangers’ coaches and players profess almost no interest in whether they can stave off the surging Pittsburgh Penguins and finish first in the Eastern Conference.

headline: Polish Ex-Official Charged With Aiding C.I.A.
text: WARSAW — The former head of Poland’s intelligence service has been charged with aiding the Central Intelligence Agency in setting up a secret prison to detain suspected members of Al Qaeda, a leading newspaper here reported on Tuesday, the first high-profile case in which a former senior official of any government has been prosecuted in connection with the agency’s program.

headline: On Street, Crowd Gives Louder Side of Health Law Argument

headline: U.S. and Pakistan Take Step to Mend Relations
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — President Obama took a symbolic step toward improving ties with Pakistan on Tuesday when he met with Prime Minister Yousaf Raza Gilani on the sidelines of a nuclear summit meeting in South Korea.

headline: Gingrich Is Cutting Staff to Shift Focus to Convention
text: Newt Gingrich is acknowledging that it is impossible for him to win the Republican presidential nomination outright and is cutting back on his staff and campaign schedule to focus on emerging victorious at the party’s convention this summer.

headline: After Killings in France, Muslims Fear a Culture of Diversity Is at Risk
text: TOULOUSE, France — As near to the Spanish border as it is to the Mediterranean, this sunny red-brick city has long been known as a place of welcome and diversity, far removed from the divisive politics of Paris. In contrast to much of the French south, the far right, with its virulent anti-immigrant stance, has little presence here. Nor does radical Islam.

headline: Perception and Peak Performance
text: Like many of us during March Madness, Jessica Witt is a college basketball fan. She is also a professor of psychology at Purdue University. Those interests converged recently at a Purdue basketball game, as she watched fans noisily try to distract the opposing players during free throws. The fans hooted, stomped and waved streamers — but it didn’t seem to have any effect on the outcome.

headline: The Closer: Baseball Begins, Quality to Follow
text: American League play — yes, the regular season — begins Wednesday, when the Oakland A’s and the Seattle Mariners face off in Japan starting at 6:10 a.m. Eastern. In reality, though, there is likely to be better baseball played in both the Cactus and Grapefruit Leagues as spring training begins to wind down.

headline: When Home Is No Refuge for Women
text: “This month, two women’s stories, told courageously, helped to underline the reality of domestic violence in India,” Nilanjana S. Roy writes about Nita Bhalla, a journalist, who wrote for the BBC about being physically assaulted by her partner and Meena Kandasamy, a poet and writer on social issues who wrote in Outlook, a national newsmagazine, of surviving a violent marriage: “My skin has seen enough hurt to tell its own story,” Ms. Kandasamy wrote.

headline: Iran: U.S. Broadens Sanctions
text: The United States added an Iranian cargo airline, three officials from Iran’s Revolutionary Guards and a Nigerian trading agent to its Iran sanctions blacklist on Tuesday, on evidence they had conspired to funnel illicit weapons shipments to Syria and Africa disguised as humanitarian aid and building materials. The Treasury Department said the airline, Yas Air, had tried to transport AK-47 rifles, machine guns, mortar shells and ammunition to Syria as part of Iran’s support for Syria, which is also subject to American sanctions. David S. Cohen, under secretary for terrorism and financial intelligence, said the Treasury’s action “exposes Iran’s malign influence in the Middle East, Africa and beyond.” Iran has previously denied sending weapons to Syria.

headline: Italian Monti Seeks to Avoid Catching the Spanish Disease
text: MADRID — After Prime Minister Mario Monti of Italy last month held his first meeting with Mariano Rajoy, his Spanish counterpart, the Italian leader said that he had been “positively very impressed” by the reforms undertaken by Mr. Rajoy.

headline: Egypt: Brotherhood Reaches No Consensus on Candidate
text: Leaders of the Muslim Brotherhood met Tuesday to decide whether the group should field its own candidate for president, a proposition that would require the Islamist group to abandon a pledge to back an outside candidate. But the meeting broke up late Tuesday without reaching a consensus, said Mahmoud Hussein, the Brotherhood’s secretary general. A decision by the Brotherhood, Egypt’s most popular political organization, to run its own candidate could upend the presidential race, which is scheduled to begin in May. Mr. Hussein said the group would reconvene next Tuesday.

headline: Eric Lowen, Half of a Singing-Writing Duo, Dies at 60
text: Eric Lowen, a singer and songwriter who was half of Lowen & Navarro, the duo that wrote “We Belong,” a pensive, urgent lover’s plea that became a hit for Pat Benatar in 1984, died on Friday in Los Angeles. He was 60.

headline: U.N. Leader Presses Assad on Peace Plan
text: AL QAA, Lebanon — The United Nations secretary general, Ban Ki-moon, “strongly” urged President Bashar al-Assad of Syria on Wednesday to immediately put into effect a peace plan he is said to have accepted that would rein in security forces in advance of negotiations to end a year of bloody revolt, but activist groups reported more assaults throughout the country.

headline: March 28, 1979 | Nuclear Accident Occurs at Three Mile Island Plant
text: On March 28, 1979, America’s worst commercial nuclear accident occurred inside the Unit Two reactor at the Three Mile Island plant near Middletown, Pa.

headline: The Abominable Snowman
text: MONTREAL — Nobody much minded Borough Mayor Luc Ferrandez’s campaign to green up his hip Montreal neighborhood so long as it was a matter of planting flower beds and widening sidewalks near schools. Plans to slow traffic by changing circulation rules in residential streets did create some blowback, but nothing like the storm he set off when his brand of urban environmentalism took a turn for the radical.
