headline: Shares Dip Lower, Led by Oil Prices
text: The Wall Street rally of 2012 lost some steam on Wednesday as commodity prices fell, sending stocks lower as investors weighed the possibility that the time had come for the market to pull back.

headline: Day Three: Supreme Court Hearings on Health Care
text: The Lede followed the third and final day of Supreme Court hearings on the health care overhaul law. Our colleague, Adam Liptak reports that several justices were considering either striking down the so-called individual mandate, or the entire law. On Thursday, please join Mr. Liptak and Reed Abelson, a reporter covering health care, for a discussion on Facebook at noon Eastern Time. They will be answering readers’ questions for an hour on The Times’s Facebook page.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Bertelsmann Mulls an I.P.O., and Obama Is on Pinterest
text: Bertelsmann, the Germany-based media company that owns, among other things, the TV company RTL and the publisher Random House, said it was considering an initial public stock offering to finance the expansion of its digital and international businesses, DealBook reported Wednesday morning. The move would represent a major change in thinking by the Mohn family, which controls Bertelsmann.

headline: Wednesday Reading: Get Your Harry Potter E-Books, Finally
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: Lending Growth Slows in Euro Zone
text: FRANKFURT — Bank lending to consumers and businesses continued to grow very slowly in the euro zone in February, according to figures issued Wednesday, a sign that the so-called wall of money unleashed by the European Central Bank in recent months has not yet reached borrowers.

headline: Ford Appoints New Director of Global Interior Design
text: As reported by Car Design News, Amko Leenarts, a 12-year veteran of Peugeot, was recently appointed to lead interior design strategy for Ford. The report was confirmed by Francesca Montini, a Ford spokeswoman.

headline: The Enduring Consequences of Unemployment
text: Our economic malaise has spurred a wave of research about the impact of unemployment on individuals and the broader economy. The findings are disheartening. The consequences are both devastating and enduring.

headline: Why the Debt Deal Failed
text: Matt Bai offers a primer in less than 60 seconds.

headline: Leading Off: The Accidental Billionaire
text: O.K., let’s see if we’ve got this straight. As Los Angeles Dodgers owner, Frank McCourt turned a storied franchise into a ridiculous melodrama centered on his dissolving marriage, alienated its loyal fans, let the iconic stadium languish, arguably turned a blind eye to the darkness gathering in Chavez Ravine’s parking lots, oversaw the whole Mannywood fiasco, ran up debt like a spoiled teenager with a parent’s platinum card, angered nearly everyone in Major League Baseball by being arrogant about it and then just escaped bankruptcy by selling the team for more than $2 billion.

headline: Stoudemire Expected to Be Out Four Weeks
text: The Knicks are beginning a daunting playoff push, with 15 games remaining, 9 against probable playoff teams. And they must equip themselves for much or all of that time without Amar’e Stoudemire, who will be sidelined for at least two to four weeks with a bulging disk, the team said Wednesday.

headline: Annie’s Shares Soar on Debut
text: 5:21 p.m. | Updated  includes closing price of stock.

headline: Settlement in Battle Over Astor Estate Is Reached
text: Brooke Astor’s only son saw his inheritance slashed in half and had his control of the estate’s powerful charitable contributions stripped away as part of a settlement that ended a bitter, five-year dispute over the family’s millions.

headline: Comeback Keeps Rangers on Track
text: WINNIPEG, Manitoba — Brian Boyle, a fresh gap adorning his grin, scored a strange goal 3 minutes 7 seconds into the third period Wednesday night, sparking the Rangers to a 4-2 victory over the Winnipeg Jets.

headline: ‘Avengers’ to Close Tribeca Film Festival
text: While the Tribeca Film Festival has never been shy in scheduling Hollywood studio movies for its opening or closing nights (like “The Interpreter” with Nicole Kidman or “Baby Mama” with Tina Fey and Amy Poehler), blockbuster action pictures are not typically part of its usual fare. But this year, Marvel’s superhero team “The Avengers” will be the final act of the annual gathering, on April 28. “The Avengers,” starring Robert Downey Jr., Chris Evans, Mark Ruffalo, Scarlett Johansson and Samuel L. Jackson, was directed by Joss Whedon, best known for the television series “Buffy the Vampire Slayer.” The comic, first published in 1963, unites Iron Man, the Incredible Hulk, Thor, Hawkeye, Black Widow and Captain America to battle evildoers. The movie, which will be released nationally on May 4, is expected to be one of the biggest box-office draws this summer.

headline: Borrowers, Beware of Mortgage Relief Fraud
text: Mortgage relief fraud schemes are still around, according to the Federal Trade Commission.

headline: Trying to Let Go of My Wandering (Adult) Son
text: When my 22-year-old, world-traveling son was a toddler, he was already an inveterate wanderer. In the playground, he would seem engrossed in a game of follow-the-leader, and I would let down my guard and start a conversation with another mother. Seconds later, I would glance up to find my son on the edge of the park, chatting up the man with the four giant dogs.

headline: ‘The Daily Show’ Visits the Food Co-op
text: This could have been predicted. The torturous, rancorous debate among members of the Park Slope Food Co-op over joining an international boycott against products made in Israel became fodder for a segment on Tuesday’s episode of “The Daily Show With Jon Stewart” on Comedy Central.

headline: Santorum Loses Ground to Romney in Pennsylvania, Poll Finds
text: Rick Santorum, who once held a wide lead in the polls in his home state of Pennsylvania, has lost substantial ground to Mitt Romney among Republican voters over the last month, according to a new poll.

headline: When the World Tackled an Environmental Threat, and Won
text: In 1974, Dr. Sherwood Rowland, a young research scientist, warned the world that chlorofluorocarbons, man-made chemicals found in aerosol sprays and refrigerators, were damaging the earth’s ozone layer. It took 13 years of bitter debate among governments, business leaders, scientists and concerned citizens before the world accepted his findings and moved to ban these chemicals through an international treaty, the Montreal Protocol, in 1987.

headline: Business Day Live | March 28, 2012
text: MF Global executives will appear before Congress; the market for instruction in computer programming is booming; why higher taxes for the rich makes economic sense.

headline: Business Day Live: Raising Top Tax Rates
text: MF Global executives will appear before Congress; the market for instruction in computer programming is booming; why higher taxes on the rich makes economic sense.

headline: Town Hall Named National Historic Landmark
text: The Town Hall on West 43rd Street, whose stage has featured speakers from Eleanor Roosevelt to President Obama and performers like Billie Holiday and Bob Dylan, has been designated a National Historic Landmark. The announcement, made by the secretary of the Interior, Ken Salazar, makes the Town Hall the only new entry to the list of National Historic Landmarks in New York City.

headline: New York Police Dept. Is Sued Over Stops in Private Buildings
text: A civil rights group filed a federal lawsuit on Wednesday accusing the New York Police Department of illegally stopping tens of thousands of people in privately owned buildings across the city where officers had been given permission to enter by landlords.

headline: James Nares at Work
text: Meredith Danluck visits Nares in his studio and discovers that his process is as mesmerizing as the work itself.

headline: Pilati: Past, Present and Future
text: Making his first public comments since his final fashion show for Yves Saint Laurent, the designer Stefano Pilati, interviewed onstage at the French Institute Alliance Française on Tuesday evening by Pamela Golbin, made some witty remarks about his tenure at the house. When Ms. Golbin noted that the occasion marked the one-month anniversary of the announcement of his departure, Mr. Pilati replied, “Yes, I thought it was quite chic to be here.”

headline: Your Knees, Their Seat: Discuss
text: GETTING a good seat in coach is a hot topic among fliers these days. Responding to the March 14 Practical Traveler column, “How to Avoid That Cramped Seat,” more than 200 readers weighed in on the subject, posting comments at nytimes.com/travel.

headline: A Baghdad of Fresh Flowers, New Paint and Armored Delegations
text: BAGHDAD — These days, I barely recognize my hometown of Baghdad. It has been spruced up, painstakingly manicured for the Arab League’s first meeting here in two decades — as my colleague Jack Healy writes.

headline: JPMorgan Lawyer Says MF Global Gave Assurances About Transfer
text: MF Global employees repeatedly gave oral assurances to JPMorgan Chase that a crucial payment to cover an overdraft at the bank was not funded by customer money, a lawyer for the bank is expected to tell a Congressional panel on Wednesday.

headline: The Source | Bright Ideas
text: With these chandeliers and sconces, everything is illuminated. More…

headline: For Sabres Fans, a Welcome Rerun
text: When it was all over, the only fans left in Washington’s Verizon Center were on their feet, decked out in blue and gold giving the visiting team a rousing ovation. Their team, all but dead and buried nine weeks ago in last place in the conference, had just pummeled the Capitals 5-1 on their home ice in what both teams acknowledged was their biggest game of the season.

headline: Elder George Bush to Endorse Romney
text: The elder George Bush is set to officially endorse Mitt Romney in Houston on Thursday, campaign officials confirmed.

headline: Forget ‘Zou Bisou Bisou,’ ‘the Sarkozy Trade’ Is the Hot French Export
text: If Nicolas Sarkozy loses France’s presidential election, he may want to set up a hedge fund.

headline: Brittney Griner Has a Fan in Lisa Leslie
text: In her college days, Lisa Leslie occupied the space Baylor’s Brittney Griner does now: she was not only college basketball’s It girl, but represented the next step up in the evolution of the game. She was a 6-5 center with all-court athleticism who could dunk and flash a 500-watt smile. She would go on to star in the W.N.B.A., winning two league championships with the Los Angeles Sparks, and win four Olympic gold medals with Team USA.

headline: Greenery
text: At this time of year, grown-ups who have lived through many winters peer anxiously at treetops, yearning for even the barest indication of spring, and sigh in relief when those tiny buds first begin to swell. (Or maybe not, if they have allergies.) But for young children, each new spring seems like the very first, an occasion for wonder.

headline: Reducing Nuclear Arms Is Not ‘Alarming.’ It’s Necessary.
text: A couple of readers have compared President Obama’s live-microphone remark about  flexibility after the election to the Etch A Sketch line from Mitt Romney’s political adviser, and wondered why I came down harder on the latter than the former.

headline: On Day 3, Justices Weigh What-Ifs of Health Ruling
text: WASHINGTON — The day after the Supreme Court suggested that President Obama’s health care law might be in danger of being held unconstitutional, the justices on Wednesday turned their attention to the practical consequences and political realities of such a ruling.

headline: Banking Regulator Calls for End of ‘Too Big to Fail’
text: An annual report from a regional Federal Reserve bank is typically a collection of banalities and clichés with some pictures of local worthies who serve on the board.

headline: Court Rules Against Pilot Penalized for Hiding His H.I.V. Status
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court ruled on Wednesday that a private pilot whose H.I.V.-positive status was improperly shared between government agencies cannot collect damages for the emotional distress he suffered when he was punished for hiding his medical condition from the Federal Aviation Administration.

headline: New Polls Show Worries Over Gas Prices
text: New national and state polls show that the Republican candidates are still struggling to capture the attention and backing of voters, and while the public sees President Obama more favorably, he continues to face serious challenges to his re-election, particularly with the economy, gas prices and Afghanistan.

headline: Dance Comes to MoMA
text: The Whitney isn’t the only museum to involve dance artists in its programming. The Museum of Modern Art has commissioned the artist and choreographer Ralph Lemon to create a three-week program of dance performances entitled “Some Sweet Day” to be presented in the Donald B. and Catherine C. Marron Atrium Oct. 15 to Nov. 4.

headline: Scene City: Dining by Design
text: Ralph Lauren and others are honored at a benefit for DIFFA.

headline: Fighting on Fumes
text: The two armies, so evenly matched, could not have been more different as they set out to find each other on the cold New Mexico morning of March 28, 1862.

headline: A Dizzying Display, by Design
text: CONSIDER the dining table. Then consider it again and again, and you have Dining by Design. The benefit dinner for Design Industries Foundation Fighting AIDS, the event brought 460 guests to Pier 94 in Midtown on Monday to eat at 44 tables designed and set with dizzying and kaleidoscopic imagination by industry insiders.

headline: Hogwarts on 42nd Street? Speedy Potter Parody Show Has Eye on New York Run
text: Following popular runs in Toronto and London, the stage play “Potted Potter” – an unauthorized parody of the seven “Harry Potter” books, performed by two actors at a breakneck 70 minutes – may arrive in New York this summer in time to capitalize on the family tourist market.

headline: The Malevolent Metropolis
text: When you have a book or movie phenomenon on the scale of “The Hunger Games,” you invariably have a story that straddles multiple fault lines at once, tapping into more than a few of life’s broadest and most enduring conflicts, accommodating several allegorical interpretations. The more that can be taken away from it, the more it draws audiences in.

headline: Coastal California Fog Carries Toxic Mercury, Study Finds
text: Fog blankets the coast of central California each summer, hydrating the region’s majestic redwood trees and chilling beachgoers. New research out of the University of California, Santa Cruz shows that the moist air also carries methylmercury, an especially toxic form of the heavy metal mercury.

headline: On ‘Mad Men,’ an Opening Scene Straight From Page 1
text: The opening scenes of the Season 5 premiere of “Mad Men,” set in 1966, depicted a sort of knucklehead-racism at work, when young men from the advertising agency Young & Rubicam dropped bags filled with water on protesters picketing on the Madison Avenue sidewalk below. Wet and angry, several protesters came upstairs to demand to know who at the firm had dropped the water bombs.

headline: A Buzz Below: Cadillac Creates a Vibrating Seat Cushion, for Safety’s Sake
text: If you feel a tingle in your backside while driving the Cadillac XTS sedan, you ought to pay attention.

headline: Listen: SNY.tv Metro Hockey Podcast, Islanders Edition
text: In this special edition of the SNY.tv Metro Hockey Podcast, Brian Compton of NHL.com joins Christopher Botta in studio and Scott Cullen of TSN calls in to discuss all things Islanders.

headline: Stedelijk Museum Announces Reopening Plans
text: Closed for nearly a decade, the Stedelijk Museum in Amsterdam is set to reopen to the public this fall, on Sept. 23, with a grand exhibition of its permanent collection.

headline: How ‘New Girl’ on Fox Lost Its Ratings Mojo
text: What’s happened to “New Girl”? The Fox sitcom that exploded at the start of the fall season with bona fide hit ratings has moved into a pattern that is approaching a tailspin.

headline: Moral Arguments
text: David: Oh my, my. We spend years arguing about Obamacare (now its official bipartisan name) and after all that muss and fuss it may be struck down. That’s certainly how it looks as the oral arguments come to a close. The view among people who know about this stuff was that the lawyer for the opponents of the law, Paul Clement, was like LeBron James on a fast break while the Solicitor General, Donald Verrilli, was like, well, me on a fast break. Somehow less than impressive.

headline: Pope Calls for ‘Authentic Freedom’ in Cuba
text: HAVANA — In the heart of Revolution Square in Cuba, with towering images of guerrilla heroes staring back at him, Pope Benedict XVI called Wednesday for “authentic freedom” in one of the world’s most authoritarian states.

headline: Fossil Foot Indicates New Prehuman Species
text: Now it seems that Lucy shared eastern Africa with another prehuman species, one that may have spent more time in trees than on the ground.

headline: Beyond Kony: How to Prevent Atrocities Before They Happen
text: The last few weeks have brought more evidence of the power of individuals—whether movie stars like George Clooney in Sudan or the little known creators of the Kony 2012 viral video–to shine a light on the world’s worst crimes. This kind of attention is usually for the good, forcing government leaders to confront dire situations that do not typically get the kind of policy focus they deserve.

headline: Mushroom and Grain Cheeseburgers
text: Barley is a traditional hearty partner for mushrooms, but brown rice is just as tasty in this burger.

headline: Mistrial on Final Charges Day After Officer’s Conviction in Sex Attack
text: A day after a New York City police officer was convicted of sexually attacking a woman at gunpoint last August, a judge declared a mistrial on Wednesday on the remaining two counts of rape and related charges that had left the jury deadlocked.

headline: On Our Radar: The Maldives Movie
text: Writing in The Times, Vikas Bajaj recounts how the political turmoil in the Maldives overtook “The Island President,” a new film about how climate change is threatening that island country and the planet. Reviewing the movie, A. O. Scott writes: “The hope that infuses this movie makes it all the more upsetting to walk out of the theater and contemplate a looming disaster that the world’s leaders seem unable to prevent.” [The New York Times]

headline: Kentucky’s Overlooked Weapon: Calipari’s Offense
text: It does not take much insight to note that the Kentucky Wildcats are the most athletic team in the country. It pops off the screen; the Wildcats are bigger, stronger and faster than their opponents. That advantage starts with Anthony Davis but continues on through a roster that has five probable first-round picks in the next N.B.A. draft.

headline: Vain Glorious | Aedes de Venustas Signature Eau de Parfum
text: Karl Bradl and Robert Gerstner established their jewel-box store on Christopher Street, Aedes de Venustas, as a premier source for elegant and avant-garde fragrances years ago. So it comes as no surprise that the aroma experts have now created a namesake Signature Eau de Parfum. Enlisting the help of the master perfumer Bertrand Duchaufour, whose previous credits include collaborations with L’Artisan Parfumeur, the duo decided against a traditional perfume pyramid structure, which features top, base and bottom notes, in favor of a more even equation: hints of rhubarb and Madagascan vetiver meld in unison with rich incense of wood and leaf. The fragrance is contained in a decadent burgundy glass decanter with a gold atomizer and crest, a suitable match for the store’s grand, gilded interior. A candle ($85) in a matching scent will be available on May 1. Get a whiff!

headline: TimesCast | March 28, 2012
text: As Pope Benedict XVI wraps up his three-day visit to Cuba, a government official rules out some of the reforms urged by the pontiff.

headline: Style.com/Print Returns for Season Two
text: The second issue of Style.com/Print (the new physical magazine from the editors of Style.com) is already printed, just 20 days after the end of the fall fashion season, and headed to newsstands next week. While it’s a bit thinner than the first issue, it’s more readable, partly thanks to a cleaner font used for the articles, and partly because it was an awfully newsy season, what with the departures of Stefano Pilati at YSL and Raf Simons at Jil Sander.

headline: On House Floor, a Sweatshirt in Honor of Trayvon Martin
text: Breaching House decorum, Representative Bobby L. Rush donned a hooded sweatshirt and sunglasses on the House floor on Wednesday in honor of Trayvon Martin, the teenager fatally shot in Florida in a case that has gained national attention.

headline: Moral ‘Crimes’ Land Afghan Women in Jail
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Asma W., 36, ran away from her husband after he beat her, threw boiling water on her, gave her a sexually transmitted disease and announced that he would marry his mistress.

headline: Team of Action Figure Designers Soldiers On
text: Last week, we published a case study that looked at a team of four toy designers — Chris Dahlberg, H. Eric Mayse, Jim Preziosi and Eric Treadaway — faced with a quandary: how to expand their business so that they are not so dependent on their one big client, Mattel. Their company, the Four Horsemen Toy Design Studio, has revenue of more than $500,000 a year, most of it from its contract work for Mattel. They have a staff of three to help with sculpting, painting and shipping in their workshop in Butler, N.J.

headline: Business Day Live | Coding Catches On
text: March 28, 2012 - The market for instruction in computer programming is booming.

headline: Language Deemed Offensive Is Removed From F.B.I. Training Materials
text: WASHINGTON — Training material used by the Federal Bureau of Investigation said agents had the “ability to bend or suspend the law and impinge on freedoms of others,” but that language has now been removed, according to a briefing the bureau recently provided to Congress.

headline: The Danes Do Murder Differently
text: LAST June the first season of “The Killing” on AMC ended without a bang. A gun was pointed at a murder suspect’s head, and then there was a quick cut to the credits. The explosion came later, when complaints poured in that the show had failed to solve the season-long mystery the network had advertised with the teasing slogan “Who Killed Rosie Larsen?”

headline: Maple Leafs Miss Playoffs Again, Draw Fans’ Ire
text: It seems to be a rite of spring in Toronto: the tulips come up and the trees flower, the birds start building their nests, and the Maple Leafs are mathematically eliminated from the playoffs.

headline: Reaction to the Final Hearing on the Health Law
text: Reaction to Wednesday morning’s Supreme Court hearing on the health care overhaul was more varied than reaction to Tuesday’s hearing. Adam Liptak covered the hearing for The Times, and The Lede is following the case with a live blog. A sampling of other analysis and reaction follows.

headline: Photo Replay: March 28
text: A view of the day in sports, with Canada holding its Olympic swimming trials in Montreal, and the world figure skating championships continuing in Nice, France.

headline: Blast Risk Declines at Leaking Gas Rig, Company Says
text: LONDON — After the risk of explosion forced the evacuation of a leaking offshore platform in the North Sea, the French oil company Total said Wednesday that the situation was “stable” but that it was still examining how to stop the gas leak.

headline: Business Bets on the G.O.P. May Be Backfiring
text: WASHINGTON — Big business groups like the Chamber of Commerce spent millions of dollars in 2010 to elect Republican candidates running for the House. The return on investment has not always met expectations.

headline: Controversial Leonardo Restoration to Be Unveiled in Major Louvre Show
text: PARIS — When London’s National Gallery mounted its blockbuster Leonardo da Vinci exhibition late last year, advance tickets sold out the first week, online scalpers pocketed up to $400 per ticket and crowds lined up around the block at dawn for the paltry number of tickets still for sale.

headline: Loeb to Yahoo’s Chief: I’m Not a Short-Term Shareholder
text: The head of Third Point, Daniel S. Loeb, would like Yahoo to know that he is concerned about the technology company’s long-term health, and is not pursuing an activist campaign just to generate short-term profit.

headline: The Best Thing for the Democrats?
text: Now that the conventional wisdom on the health-care hearing has shifted—from a 6-3 or even 7-2 ruling in favor of the individual mandate’s constitutionality to a 5-4 ruling against—the Democrats have to be thinking, if nothing else, about a public relations plan.

headline: American Dance Festival Unveils New Executive Director’s First Lineup
text: This summer’s 79th edition of the American Dance Festival, the first under its new director, Jodee Nimerichter, will feature world premieres from Jodi Melnick, Helen Simoneau and Reggie Wilson along with performances from festival regulars including the Paul Taylor Dance Company and the Mark Morris Dance Group. Ms. Nimerichter took over the modern dance festival set in Durham, N.C., earlier this year, replacing Charles L. Reinhart, who retired at the end of 2011 after 43 years as director.

headline: Ford Explorer Gets EcoBoost V-6 and a Touch of Swagger
text: On Wednesday, Ford introduced the 2013 Ford Explorer Sport, a performance version of its bread-and-butter S.U.V.

headline: TiVo and DirecTV: Together Again
text: It’s been three years since TiVo promised that a high-definition version of its DirecTV-compatible digital videorecorder would be available shortly. And now, it finally is.

headline: N.F.L. Adopts Playoff Overtime Rule for the Regular Season
text: PALM BEACH, Fla. — Last season, the N.F.L.’s postseason overtime rule got its first and only tests in two games, when the Denver Broncos beat the Pittsburgh Steelers with a touchdown pass on the first play of overtime in their playoff matchup and the Giants beat the San Francisco 49ers with a field goal in the N.F.C. championship.

headline: Eiko Ishioka’s Otherworldly Creations
text: The work of costume designer Eiko Ishioka, who died in January, has fascinated designers as diverse as Alexander McQueen, Issey Miyake and Viktor Horsting and Rolf Snoeren.

headline: On the Road to Recovery? Analyzing Economic Indicators
text: Overview | How do we know when the economy is recovering? What key indicators do economists and politicians use to judge the health of our economic system? In this lesson, students use New York Times resources to investigate and chart the current state of key economic indicators like household income and unemployment. By researching and analyzing each indicator and sharing their results, students develop a sense of how we identify economic recoveries.

headline: For Group of 5 Nations, Acronym Is Easy, but Common Ground Is Hard
text: NEW DELHI — As the shock waves of the global recession convulsed Europe and the United States three years ago, the leaders of Brazil, Russia, India and China gathered for a meeting that seemed to signal a new era. They had global buzz as rising economic powers, a catchy acronym, BRIC, and an ambitious agenda to remake an international monetary system long dominated by the West.

headline: City Submits Plans to Close and Reopen 33 Schools
text: With only three months left until the end of the school year, city education officials are proceeding with plans to close and reopen 33 schools this summer. On Tuesday, officials sent their proposals to the State Education Department, kicking off a review process that could take months and wind up in court.

headline: Summoning the Fairest of Them All
text: NOW, I am no film critic, but I can say with some certainty that a sizable portion of the audience for “Mirror Mirror,” the Snow White film set for release on Friday, will be more interested in the clothes than the acting. This is because the film, starring Julia Roberts and Lily Collins, contains the final work of the costume designer Eiko Ishioka, who died in January and whose otherworldly creations have fascinated designers as diverse as Alexander McQueen, Issey Miyake and Viktor Horsting and Rolf Snoeren.

headline: Family Visits Rights Lawyer Held in China
text: BEIJING — Gao Zhisheng, the Chinese human rights lawyer whose whereabouts and well-being have been something of a mystery for the past two years, is alive and in good health, according to relatives who visited him in prison last weekend.

headline: United MileagePlus Club Card’s Perks for Frequent Fliers
text: Frequent fliers may want to take a look at the new United MileagePlus Club Card from Chase, which offers 1.5 miles for every dollar spent, membership in United’s airport clubs and a menu of other perks.

headline: Europe Levies Big Fines for Freight Cartel
text: BRUSSELS — The participants in a freight cartel were caught not so much red-handed as green-fingered.

headline: Bank of America Chief’s Pay Jumps to $8.1 Million
text: Brian T. Moynihan, chief executive of Bank of America, earned $8.1 million in 2011, a sharp increase from the $1.9 million payout he received in 2010.

headline: ‘The Old Rabbi’ Authenticated as a Rembrandt
text: For more than 50 years the portrait of an old man hung high on a wall in the private library of Woburn Abbey, the family home of the dukes of Bedford in Bedfordshire, England. Although the art collection there is world famous and includes 10 paintings by Van Dyck, 12 by Reynolds, 3 Gainsborourghs and a room wallpapered with 24 Canalettos, this painting was not considered anything special, just one of scores of lesser old masters lining the walls.

headline: Divining the Supreme Court Health Care Arguments
text: There is no tea-leaf reading like Supreme Court tea-leaf reading. And in the immediate aftermath of Tuesday’s landmark argument on the constitutionality of the health care law’s insurance mandate, there was no shortage of attempted divination among the legal commentariat. The subject of obsessive fascination, not surprisingly, was the every utterance by the two justices considered most in play, Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. and Justice Anthony M. Kennedy.

headline: Only Provoke | Helmut Newton at the Grand Palais
text: “Throw your chest out,” Helmut Newton bellows to Cindy Crawford on a photo shoot in Monaco, in a scene from the documentary “Helmut by June,” currently on view at the Grand Palais in Paris in the first major show since the photographer’s death in 2004. “The more chest I get, the better it will be.”

headline: JFK Library Unveils Hemingway Letters
text: Ernest Hemingway first met Gianfranco Ivancich at a bar in Venice in 1949, where the two struck up a conversation about their war experiences. It was the beginning of a epistolary friendship. Hemingway remained close to Mr. Ivancich and his sister, Adriana, whom he credited with inspiring his 1952 Pulitzer-prize winning novel “The Old Man and the Sea” during her visit to Cuba in 1950. Now the John F. Kennedy Library Foundation is making available 15 letters it bought from Mr. Ivancich, now in his early 80s, that Hemingway wrote between 1953 and 1960 as he wandered through Cuba; Ketchum, Idaho; Kilimanjaro; Nairobi; Paris; and Madrid. The library also acquired a manuscript of “The Faithful Bull,” a tale that Hemingway wrote for Mr. Ivancich’s nephew.

headline: Digital Notes: Sirius XM Claims ‘Industrywide Conspiracy’ on Licenses
text: Last year, Sirius XM Radio drew criticism in the music industry for its decision to pursue direct licensing deals with record companies instead of dealing with SoundExchange, a nonprofit agency set up to process royalties for online streams and satellite radio. Now Sirius is suing SoundExchange and the American Association of Independent Music, a trade organization, saying those groups have violated federal antitrust law and “erected an industrywide conspiracy” to prevent it from making direct deals with labels.

headline: Baghdad’s Last Summit, and the Very, Very Important People Who Never Came
text: TORONTO — How much Iraq, my home country, has changed. And I know all too well that the changes did not happen overnight. It was, and is, systematic destruction, and for me it started three decades ago during the run up to Baghdad’s last planned summit.

headline: Motivation, Now at Hand
text: A friend lost 45 pounds and crowed that he owed his life to a fitness gadget the size of a lipstick. I had to investigate.

headline: A Bevy of Beauties, and So PC
text: What’s an ultrabook?

headline: Bringing Up an E-Reader
text: Julianna Huth, a second grader at Green Primary School, in Green, Ohio, is a convert to the digital word.

headline: Harsh Words as Lawmakers Begin MF Global Hearing
text: The latest round of “what happened at MF Global” has just started, and already the sparks are flying.

headline: Tracking Major League Baseball, a Perfect Sport for an App
text: Apps for football, basketball or hockey fans suffer from a nagging built-in problem: who wants to stop watching the game to take in more information through the app?

headline: Starting Early, and Young
text: DR. AMI SHAH NAGARAJAN, 38, a specialist in integrative medicine who lives in Manhattan, estimates that she spends $150 a month on Mustela and California Baby products for her 3-year-old twins. “I spend more on my kids than I do for myself,” she said. “It’s worth it to me to get something pure for them.”

headline: Tablets for Children, Including Apps
text: Ready or not, here comes a swarm of Android touch-screen tablets just for children.

headline: Test Results You Can't Rely On
text: Almost everybody who is interested in education can agree that accountability is a good thing. But many people are growing angry that testing used by many school systems is flawed or at best imprecise, a parent writes.

headline: Manhattan School of Music’s Robert Sirota to Step Down
text: Robert Sirota, a composer and longtime educator, will step down as president of the Manhattan School of Music next fall, the school announced on Wednesday. Mr. Sirota took the job in 2005 with a commitment to serve for five years.“Increasingly,” he says in a statement, “my opportunities as a composer have become more than I can handle on a part-time basis, and I am eager to pursue new commissions and projects.”

headline: Newly Released Books
text: Literary writers can sometimes forget their obligation to entertain. But this month brings a selection of novels and short stories that can hold their own with a thriller, in this case the third installment of Olen Steinhauer’s brisk Milo Weaver spy series.

headline: Super Linda
text: NEGOTIATING the space between food and fun, New Yorkers could ask for no better architects than Matt Abramcyk — owner of Smith and Mills, the Bunker and Tiny’s — and Serge Becker, whose design credits include Miss Lily’s and La Esquina. In February, they opened Super Linda, a tribute to South American food and drink in TriBeCa.

headline: Goldman’s Passage to India
text: 10:36 a.m. | Updated

headline: Marketing Obesity to Children
text: What gives corporations the right to market junk food to children? The First Amendment, of course, which guarantees us all, and particularly those with lots of money, the right to express our views about everything from politics to the way Pop Tarts so deliciously fit our busy lifestyle.

headline: Four New (Very Old) Landmarks
text: New York City’s newest landmarks are among its oldest.

headline: Chris Rock Sells Late-Night Show to FX
text: FX is adding a new late-night show from Chris Rock featuring the comedian W. Kamau Bell to its lineup of original comedy series. During the weekly half-hour, of which the network has ordered six installments, Mr. Bell will take on provocative issues including politics, race, religion, media and sex, said Nick Grad, the executive vice president of original programming at FX. Mr. Bell is a founding member of the comedy group Laughter Against the Machine. “I think Kamau is one of the funniest guys out there,” said Mr. Rock, who is the show’s executive producer.

headline: Supreme Court Health Care Arguments: Day 3 Transcripts
text: The Supreme Court heard two cases on the third and final day of arguments challenging President Obama’s 2010 health care law.

headline: Academic Built Case for Mandate in Health Care Law
text: After Massachusetts, California came calling. So did Connecticut, Delaware, Kansas, Minnesota, Oregon, Wisconsin and Wyoming.

headline: 5-Foot-8? Designed for You
text: AT 5-foot-8, Peter Manning isn’t remarkably short. Still, he said, he has struggled to find clothes that fit him well since he was 10. “My pants always had to be shortened,” Mr. Manning said. Over the years, he guessed that he has paid hundreds, maybe thousands, of dollars in what he called a “tailor tax.”

headline: Homes for $350,000
text: Properties in Charlotte, Phoenix and New Hampshire.

headline: What You Get for ... $350,000
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C.

headline: A Three-Bedroom Contemporary In Mexico City
text: This two-story glass-walled modern house pays homage to the stark and the industrial.

headline: House Hunting in ...Mexico City
text: THREE-BEDROOM CONTEMPORARY IN MEXICO CITY

headline: Brooke Astor Estate Settlement
text: The settlement documents in the court battle over the estate of Brooke Astor.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Lebanon and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Lebanon, Cuba, India and Spain.

headline: Report Shows Syrian Video Activists at Work, Breaking Some Rules
text: A new report by a French photographer who was in the Syrian city of Homs last month, during a period of intense shelling by government forces, shows that some of the activists who risked their lives to document the bombardment on video also embellished some of their footage, to make the dire situation seem worse.

headline: An Artist in the Moment
text: AT the Paris opening earlier this month of “Louis Vuitton Marc Jacobs,” the exhibition at the Musée des Arts Décoratifs contrasting the Vuitton founder with its artistic director since 1997, a 6-foot-4 bearded fellow was explaining a tableau. It was a group of mannequins, one suspended from the ceiling on wires, with electric blue resin balloons for heads.

headline: Wing Chairs
text: Kerry Joyce, a Los Angeles-based interior designer, searched for chairs that engulf you in their wings.

headline: City Council Approves Wage Bill and Condemns Florida Killing
text: The City Council approved a measure on Wednesday that would require higher wages for some private-sector blue-collar workers, taking a step long advocated by labor unions but opposed by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and the business community.

headline: Polls Show Romney on Track for Win in Wisconsin
text: If Mitt Romney was harmed by the “Etch A Sketch” comment made by one of his advisers or by his loss in Louisiana over the weekend, it doesn’t seem to be preventing him from being in position to win in Wisconsin, which holds its primary on Tuesday.

headline: Council Bans Stickers of Shame, Overriding Mayor’s Veto
text: Neon colors may be back in fashion, but neon stickers are officially out — at least at the city’s Sanitation Department.

headline: Augusta’s New Issue: A Woman Runs I.B.M.
text: It has been nine years since a rather futile protest brought the issue of Augusta National’s lack of female members to the fore, but this year it has risen again — in a much thornier form for the club that hosts the Masters.

headline: Silent Partners No Longer
text: WHATEVER happened to omertà? For decades, Mafioso from Joseph Valachi (“The Valachi Papers”) to Henry Hill (“Wise Guys” and “Goodfellas”) to Salvatore Gravano (“Underboss”) have violated the traditional code of silence, looking to cash in on their criminal pasts with potentially lucrative careers as newly minted truth-tellers.

headline: An Updated ‘Vertical Garden’
text: “The Vertical Garden: From Nature to the City,” by Patrick Blanc, the French botanist who has devoted his life to turning the bare walls of buildings, inside and out, into green living worlds, has been revised and updated by W. W. Norton, which published the first English edition in 2008.

headline: Just Opened | American Two Shot
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Where Math Teachers Go to Get Energized
text: Students can tell when a teacher is excited by what they're teaching. But sometimes, especially with only three months left in the year, excitement can be hard to come by. For some New York City math teachers, an after-school math class gives them the jolt they need to stay inspired.

headline: Don Draper on the White Carpet
text: During the premiere of the fifth season of “Mad Men” on Sunday, one thing was clear: Don Draper finally has a home befitting a 1960s ad executive.

headline: A New Vintage Marketplace From One Kings Lane
text: For those who like to decorate their homes themselves, two of the best-known online sources for vintage furnishings can present problems. Sifting through eBay’s vast selection can yield bargains, but it can also eat up a lot of time. And shopping on 1stdibs yields treasures but can eat up your whole budget. So Susan Feldman, a founder of the home-furnishings flash-sale site One Kings Lane, decided to create an online marketplace that could function as a cross between an edited-down version of eBay and a marked-down version of 1stdibs.

headline: Nike Sues Reebok Over Tebow Apparel
text: 9:39 p.m. | Updated Nike won a temporary restraining order on Wednesday against Reebok, stopping it from selling Tim Tebow shirts and other apparel.

headline: MF Global Employees Say They Are Cooperating With Investigation
text: Three of the four executives at MF Global called to testify before a House panel on Wednesday said that they were cooperating with federal authorities.

headline: Stone Links
text: A gathering of recent philosophy-related links.

headline: Economic vs. Political Change in Cuba
text: Marc Lacey, a deputy foreign editor, and Harvard University’s Jorge I. Domínguez discuss whether Cuba can continue to evolve economically, but stay the course politically.

headline: Motherlode Book Club: Accepting an Adult Child’s Choices
text: The writer Anne Lamott has always struggled with acceptance. It’s her modus operandi, her general state of being: she would prefer that things be one way, yet things, be they political or health-related or her only son’s choices in life, persist in being otherwise. I’d argue that we all feel that way, but Ms. Lamott experiences and articulates it with an intensity that most of us will never achieve.

headline: Tortilla Factory Owner Arrested Over Business Practices
text: The owner of a Brooklyn tortilla factory where a worker died after falling into a mixing machine has been arrested on charges of underpaying employees, falsifying business records and violating workers’ compensation and unemployment insurance laws, the authorities said on Wednesday.

headline: Life on the Other Side of the Lens
text: FOR a while, the photographer Maxwell Snow’s favorite subject was people with guns. He hung out and took pictures with gang members in South Central Los Angeles, attended a meet-up of white supremacists in Kentucky, embedded with an Army unit in Afghanistan and did an S-and-M-inspired fashion shoot in which one of the well-dressed models pointed a rifle at his head.

headline: A Trio’s Fourth Member Is Intuition
text: Erudition and clarity come naturally to the jazz pianist Enrico Pieranunzi, who has led a charmed career in his native Italy stretching back some 40 years. A fluid technician with a foothold in the classical tradition, he has always done well to indulge his exploratory urges, pushing beyond the respectable sprawl of his comfort zone. Otherwise he runs the risk of sounding dry and a little calculating, too much like a figure of the conservatory.

headline: Arranging the Garden, Inside and Out
text: Almost any flower, leaf or branch can look good in the right vase. The combination is a study in texture, color, shape, the reflection of light.

headline: The Weird World of Sports
text: While other sports photographers head to Florida for spring training, Sol Neelman drives through the mountains of Idaho looking for K-9 keg pulls and a skijoring event (skiers, pulled by horses). His itineraries are not shaped by the N.F.L. season or the P.G.A. tour, but by the schedules of weekend warriors pursuing oddball pastimes.

headline: Bill-Signing Ceremonies? Oh, My!
text: President Obama next week will perform a function of his office that he has eschewed since November: signing legislation in public and in the presence of the lawmakers who helped pass it.

headline: Going on Hikes and the Web in Search of Black Dance
text: “I’ve lost control of the platform I’m curating,” the choreographer Ishmael Houston-Jones said at Danspace Project on Tuesday. He was referring to “Parallels,” a performance series he organized to pursue questions about black dance, questions he first raised in a series also called “Parallels” in 1982. This iteration, which has been running since early February, is in its last week, and Tuesday’s program was a pleasant miscellany.

headline: For Skittles, Death Brings Both Profit and Risk
text: Skittles are the candy of the moment.

headline: Google’s Driverless Cars Can Now Fetch Food
text: In late 2010, John Markoff of The New York Times broke the story that Google had developed cars that could drive themselves. Now, two years later, the company has taken this innovation to a new level, teaching the cars to do something really useful: Navigating a fast food restaurant drive-through.

headline: Old-School Keyboard, Expressive Still
text: The pianist Alexei Lubimov has an unusually broad range of specialties, and he touched on the extremes during a short residency at the Baryshnikov Arts Center. Last week he demonstrated his fascination with new music in two performances of John Cage’s 55-minute “Four Walls” (1944) in a staging of “Four Walls/Doubletoss Interludes,” with choreography created by Cage’s longtime partner, Merce Cunningham.

headline: How War Came Home to Stay
text: A squabble is a noisy quarrel over a trivial matter. A polemic is an aggressive attack on the opinions and principles of others. A screaming match is a contest in which contradictory points are stubbornly reiterated, with no regard for whatever else has been said. A political talk show is a gladiatorial contest in which squabbles, polemics and screaming matches are exploited for their entertainment value.

headline: Principal Named to Children's Aid Charter
text: Ife  Lenard, the new principal of the Children’s Aid College and Prep, officially started her role in mid-March. Early worries about low application numbers have passed. She said the school has received more than 300 applications for 120 spots. Now she’s looking for staff.

headline: Military Injustices Stay Fresh in Memory
text: “Court-Martial at Fort Devens,” at the Castillo Theater, depicts a little-remembered insurrection in the waning months of World War II. A detachment of black members of the Women’s Army Corps, who had enlisted to be trained as medical technicians at Fort Devens in Massachusetts, had their classifications changed and were reassigned to work as hospital orderlies. After striking, then refusing orders to return to work, two of the women faced a court-martial. While largely overlooked, the conflict was covered by the black press, with an N.A.A.C.P. lawyer taking part in what was considered a battle for racial equality in the military. Even Eleanor Roosevelt got involved.

headline: Romney’s ‘Humorous’ Tale of a Factory Closing
text: Mitt Romney opened a “tele-town hall” with Wisconsin voters on Wednesday afternoon with what he described as a “humorous” story highlighting his connections to the state. But not everyone found the story, about his father closing a Michigan factory, quite so funny.

headline: A ‘Trek’ Script Is Grounded in Cyberspace
text: For “Star Trek” fans it was like finding a lost Shakespeare play — only to have it snatched away by the playwright’s heirs.

headline: On Location | Athens
text: Peter Poulos has filled his 1,500-square-foot apartment with an eclectic mix of vintage finds.

headline: Street Style, in Athens
text: IF it’s Sunday morning in Athens, Peter Poulos will most likely be on his way to the flea market. In five years of living in Greece, he has rarely missed it.

headline: Clashes Raise Global Worries Over Sudan and South Sudan
text: KHARTOUM, Sudan — After a brief, halting step toward reconciliation, military clashes along the long, disputed border between Sudan and newly independent South Sudan have stirred fears of a renewed conflict between the two sides.

headline: A Settlement in the Astor Case
text: The Times reported on Wednesday that a settlement had been reached in the court battle over the estate of Brooke Astor, the queen of New York society who died in 2007 at age 105 after a long struggle with dementia. Her son, Anthony Marshall, and Francis X. Morrissey Jr., a lawyer who did estate planning for Mrs. Astor, were convicted in State Supreme Court in Manhattan of defrauding and stealing from her. Both have appealed.

headline: Mattresses Without the Spring
text: For a city that doesn’t sleep, New York has a lot of mattress stores. The latest, Coco-Mat, opens Thursday in SoHo, in a 5,650-square-foot space on Mercer Street. The company was founded in 1989 and has 60 stores in 11 countries. Its mattresses are all handmade in Greece, from natural materials like seaweed, horsehair, goose down, wool and coconut or cactus fibers. No metal is used.

headline: The Only Guy Out There
text: LUCIN, Utah

headline: Sales at Broadway Panhandler, Hastens and Others
text: Some cookware and knives are up to 60 percent off at Broadway Panhandler, through April 1 (a Wüsthof Classic forged six-inch cook’s knife, originally $210, is about $90 and comes with a free paring knife, pictured); 65 East Eighth Street (Broadway), (212) 966-3434, broadwaypanhandler.com.

headline: Wooing and Celebrating With Seasonal, Sustainable Blooms
text: True love and the convenience-store rose: One is perishable, the other oddly undying. (And both, in the end, can feel cheap and disposable.)

headline: In Remote Utah, the Ultimate Man Cave
text: Ivo Zdarsky, who escaped from Communist Czechoslovakia in an aircraft he built himself, has made a home in an airplane hangar.

headline: Son of ‘Jersey Shore’ Hangs a Left
text: Paul DelVecchio, a k a Pauly D of MTV’s “Jersey Shore,” belongs to a select category of performers who have turned their haircuts into careers. (He’s in the great tradition of Jennifer Aniston, before she became more famous for her breakups.)

headline: Some Like It Hotter
text: IT was 105 degrees — as hot as a typical steam room — at Pure Yoga on the Upper East Side on a recent Saturday, but for the 16 women already perspiring through a series of plié squats in a ballet-based barre method workout, it wasn’t blistering enough.

headline: Outlaws Who Play It a Little Bit Safe
text: Eric Church came out in a puff of smoke, alone, baseball cap pulled low over his eyes, at the beginning of his sold-out concert at the Hammerstein Ballroom this month, singing “Country Music Jesus”: “We need a second coming worse than bad/Some long-haired hippie prophet preaching from the book of Johnny Cash.”

headline: A Critical Test of the Health Care Law
text: To the Editor:

headline: Hawker Beechcraft Is Said to Be Preparing for Bankruptcy Filing
text: The business jet maker Hawker Beechcraft is readying a bankruptcy filing, people briefed on the matter said on Wednesday, dealing a blow to its private equity owners, Goldman Sachs and Onex Partners.

headline: New Editor at Billboard Magazine
text: Joe Levy, the veteran music journalist, was appointed the editor of Billboard magazine, the magazine reported on its Web site on Wednesday. He replaces Danyel Smith, who was appointed editor in early 2011 and stepped down in February.

headline: Giants West:  Brandon Jacobs Joins Niners
text: The Giants already knew they would be seeing one familiar face in their visit to San Francisco next season. Now they will go against two.

headline: Rexnord Prices I.P.O. at $18, at Bottom of Expected Range
text: The Rexnord Corporation, an industrial parts maker owned by Apollo Global Management, priced its initial public offering at $18 a share, at the bottom of its expected range.

headline: Sluggish Venus Williams Falls to Radwanska
text: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla. — Venus Williams stared straight ahead, her left hand resting on her leg, waiting for the half-dozen fresh balls needed for the 17th game of the match to be rolled out.

headline: ‘Hunger Games,’ the Soundtrack, Also a Hit
text: “The Hunger Games” cleaned up at the box office over the weekend, and its soundtrack has been a hit too. The album, featuring songs by Taylor Swift, Arcade Fire and Maroon 5, sold 175,000 copies in its first week, Nielsen SoundScan reported.

headline: Playwright, Producer Will Stretch in Premiere at Dallas Theater Center
text: The playwright Rajiv Joseph, a Pulitzer Prize finalist for “Bengal Tiger at the Baghdad Zoo,” and the Tony Award-winning musician Bill Sherman are collaborating on the new musical “Fly,” a darker re-telling of the Peter Pan story, which will have its world premiere in July 2013 at Dallas Theater Center, executives at the theater plan to announce on Thursday.

headline: The Lighter Side of Destroying Jobs
text: Another candidate might have stayed away from a joke about closing auto plants. Considering that Mitt Romney’s private equity company forced thousands of layoffs at companies it purchased, and that he opposed a bailout of the auto industry that saved hundreds of thousands of jobs, it’s a subject he would be well-advised to avoid.

headline: Physical Culture | Gear Test, Hot Yoga Clothes
text: Inspiration for dealing with hot yoga's perspiration.

headline: Designs for the Digital Age
text: Furniture that accommodates new technology and the changing ways we live with at home.

headline: Furniture Meets the Digital Age
text: PHILIPPE STARCK was in town last week, ostensibly to introduce the Zik wireless headphones he designed for the French company Parrot. But Mr. Starck, who had just flown in from Paris, seemed more interested in holding forth on the future of design.

headline: Market Ready
text: Q. I want to replace my bathtub with a luxury walk-in shower. Would that be good or bad for resale?

headline: The Arts and Humanity
text: To the Editor:

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Facebook I.P.O. and Superfast Security Cameras
text: Here are some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web on Wednesday. There are more here.

headline: Building Your Own Pit
text: IN 1968, Thurman Roberts and his son Scott built the first barbecue pit for the family business, the Salt Lick, in Driftwood, Tex. That pit, which is still in operation, helped establish the Salt Lick as one of the nation’s premier barbecue destinations.

headline: Gearing Up to Grill
text: I’M surrounded by neighbors who grill and smoke meats year round. I like to think it’s a coincidence that every time they grill, the wind blows in my direction.

headline: Airport Screeners
text: To the Editor:

headline: Outlaws in New York
text: Jason Aldean performed at Izod Center in East Rutherford, N.J., on Saturday, and Eric Church performed at the Hammerstein Ballroom earlier this month.

headline: Unflinching View of a Wandering Mind, No Breadcrumb Trail in Sight
text: Perhaps years from now, after a scientific breakthrough has turned Alzheimer’s disease into a memory as distant as polio wards are to younger Americans today, someone will stumble upon Scott Kirschenbaum’s hard-to-watch documentary, “You’re Looking at Me Like I Live Here and I Don’t,” and be stunned. “I’ve read about Alzheimer’s,” this person will say, “but I had no idea what it was actually like.”

headline: Wing Chairs
text: AFTER a run of springlike weather, Mother Nature threw New York City a curve ball this week with winterlike temperatures. It’s the kind of weather that makes you want to sit in front of a fire in a comfortable chair. A wing chair, perhaps.

headline: Further Reading on Mr. Mandate
text: I have a profile now online about Jonathan Gruber, an economics professor at M.I.T. He helped design both the universal health care overhaul in Massachusetts and the Affordable Care Act, and is probably the economist most closely associated with the idea of an individual insurance mandate.

headline: The States’ Ethics Record
text: To the Editor:

headline: When Reacting Isn’t Enough
text: William C. Rhoden discusses the protests by N.B.A. players over the Trayvon Martin killing.

headline: Video: When Reacting Isn’t Enough
text: William C. Rhoden discusses the protests by N.B.A. players over the Trayvon Martin killing.

headline: When Stealing Isn’t Stealing
text: THE Justice Department is building its case against Megaupload, the hugely popular file-sharing site that was indicted earlier this year on multiple counts of copyright infringement and related crimes. The company’s servers have been shut down, its assets seized and top employees arrested. And, as is usual in such cases, prosecutors and their allies in the music and movie industries have sought to invoke the language of “theft” and “stealing” to frame the prosecutions and, presumably, obtain the moral high ground.

headline: Adrienne Rich, Influential Feminist Poet, Dies at 82
text: Adrienne Rich, a poet of towering reputation and towering rage, whose work — distinguished by an unswerving progressive vision and a dazzling, empathic ferocity — brought the oppression of women and lesbians to the forefront of poetic discourse and kept it there for nearly a half-century, died on Tuesday at her home in Santa Cruz, Calif. She was 82.

headline: The Politics and Poems of Adrienne Rich
text: In 1973, reviewing Adrienne Rich’s seventh book of poems, “Diving Into the Wreck,” Margaret Atwood called it “one of those rare books that forces you to decide not just what you think about it; but what you think about yourself. It is a book that takes risks, and it forces the reader to take them also.” Ms. Rich, who died on Wednesday at 82, spent her career forcing such confrontations.

headline: The Radon Threat Is Still With Us
text: Iowa City

headline: Once Payton’s Status Settled, Coaching Move Could Occur
text: PALM BEACH, Fla. — Tom Benson, the owner of the New Orleans Saints, headed home from the N.F.L. meetings Wednesday with the immediate future of his franchise still in flux. One thing seems clear, though: Bill Parcells is strongly considering the chance to coach, or at least consult for, the Saints while his friend Sean Payton is suspended for his role in the team’s bounty program.

headline: 3 Titles Won at North American Championships
text: On Sunday, the last day of the American Contract Bridge League’s Spring North American Championships in Memphis, three major titles were decided.

headline: Business Major Adds Marketing Deal to Major Title
text: RANCHO MIRAGE, Calif. — Standing on the tee box with their futures stretched in front of them like a long dogleg par-4, more women are choosing to try to cut the corner. Following the lead of pros like Jennifer Johnson and Natalie Gulbis, they are leaving their college programs early. Or, like Lexi Thompson and Jessica Korda, they are choosing not to attend college at all.

headline: Claim of Fraud as Votes Are Counted in Brooklyn Special Election
text: What began as a pleasant day of official vote-counting in the undecided special election for state senator in south Brooklyn devolved into claims of fraud and disenfranchisement from both campaigns on Wednesday afternoon.

headline: Bizarre Insights From Big Data
text: Sometimes unexpected data sources offer big insights.

headline: Few Minds Are Changed by Arguments in Court
text: The morning arguments before the Supreme Court had grown tense just as the lunch crowd was packing into the food court at a downtown Atlanta office complex to watch news coverage of the hearing.

headline: Fracas on JetBlue Flight Shows Gap in Screening
text: Airplane cockpits are meant to be the last line of defense from outside aggressors. But what if the threat comes from the cockpit itself?

headline: Boehner Asks Obama for More Clarity on ‘Flexibility’ Message to Russia
text: The House speaker, John A. Boehner, has asked President Obama to provide a better explanation of a private message he asked the Russian president to pass along to his successor.

headline: Facelift Project for Hollywood Stirs Divisions
text: LOS ANGELES — Hollywood, once a sketchy neighborhood in a spiral of petty crime and decay, has been well on its way over the past 10 years to becoming a bustling tourist destination and nightlife district. But now it is on the verge of another transformation: to a decidedly un-Californian urban enclave pierced by skyscrapers, clustered around public transportation and animated pedestrian street life.

headline: SAT’s Student Photo Database Draws Comparisons to Facebook Profiles
text: The advice college counselors give to students is consistent: Don’t put anything online that you wouldn’t want your mother to see. If upheld, the principle would help college applicants keep a clean public image, especially if college admissions officers ever investigate students’ photos online (they rarely do, says one admissions official).

headline: From South Sudan to Yale
text: NEW HAVEN

headline: A Young Spin on Incontinence, in Spots Skirting Images of Aging
text: SINCE its introduction in 1984, advertising for Depend, the adult incontinence brand by Kimberly-Clark, has tended to feature elderly actors golfing, gardening or fawning over grandchildren. The message, naturally, was that the products enabled them to be active without fear of embarrassment.

headline: Details Offered on How Suspect Could Have Left Afghan Base
text: It is among the more intriguing mysteries swirling around the killings of civilian villagers in southern Afghanistan: How could the Army staff sergeant charged with 17 counts of murder have left his combat outpost, located in a dangerous region, not once but twice in the middle of the night to commit the shootings, as the Army says he did?

headline: News Corp. Said to Weigh a Channel to Rival ESPN
text: News Corporation is in discussions to create a cable sports network that would compete with the industry leader, ESPN.

headline: The Never-Ending Cold War
text: Two decades after the end of the cold war, Mitt Romney still considers Russia to be America’s “No. 1 geopolitical foe.” His comments display either a shocking lack of knowledge about international affairs or just craven politics. Either way, they are reckless and unworthy of a major presidential contender.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: March 28, 2012

headline: Parties Brace for Fallout in Court’s Ruling on Health Care
text: WASHINGTON — The law professor side of President Obama is highly intrigued by the Supreme Court hearings over the constitutionality of his health care law. He studied a summary of the arguments aboard Air Force One as he flew back from a nuclear summit meeting in South Korea.

headline: Stock Market Flaws Not So Rare, Data Shows
text: Stock market disruptions like the ones last week that temporarily shut down part of the nation’s third-largest exchange and briefly halted the trading of Apple shares are more common than investors may think.

headline: Silence, Then Frustration at MF Global Hearing
Things I Saw — No. 2
text: Suggestions for what you’d like Jason to see and draw may be sent to thingsisaw@nytimes.com.

headline: More Guns, Fewer Hoodies
text: The debate over the shooting death of Trayvon Martin seems to be devolving into an argument about the right to wear hoodies, but it really does not appear to be a promising development.

headline: As His Numbers Go Up, Cano Moves Up in the Batting Order
text: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla. — Robinson Cano talks about how it does not matter where he bats in the Yankees’ lineup. Of course, he can talk all he wants. It is his smile that belies him.

headline: Activism and the Roberts Court
text: The ideological nature of the health care case was obvious on the last day of oral argument. By the time the proceedings were over, much of what the conservative justices said in court seemed like part of a politically driven exercise — especially because the issues addressed on Wednesday were not largely constitutional in nature. In fact, they were the kinds of policy questions that are properly left to Congress and state governments to answer, not the Supreme Court.

headline: Second Suit Accuses Knoedler Gallery of Selling Fake Art
text: A South Carolina family filed a $25 million lawsuit in Manhattan Federal Court on Wednesday against what had been New York’s oldest art gallery, Knoedler & Company, charging that the dealer and its former president conspired to sell it a fake Mark Rothko painting.

headline: New Rules for New Power Plants
text: Power plants account for about 40 percent of America’s global warming emissions — with the bulk of that coming from coal-fired plants. On Tuesday, the Obama administration took another important step for public health and the environment, proposing the first nationwide limits on carbon dioxide from new power plants. If approved, the new limits will accelerate the shift from coal to natural gas and cleaner alternative fuels.

headline: Young Takes First Steps Into Uncertain Future
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Chris Young said after his start on May 1 last season that he was likely to remember the night for a long time.

headline: Third Day of Arguments on Health Care
text: On the third and final day of Supreme Court arguments over President Obama’s health care overhaul law, the justices continued their questioning.

headline: Where Are the Good-Government Republicans?
text: Senator John McCain recently denounced the Supreme Court’s Citizens United decision as “naïve and politically ignorant,” telling Roll Call, the Capitol Hill newspaper, that “the consequences are manifesting themselves every day in what will someday be, sooner rather than later, a huge scandal.” But Mr. McCain has no corrective, and the rest of the Republican Party seems determined to block any reform. Meanwhile, checkbook politicking has already hijacked this year’s Republican primary campaign.

headline: A Team’s Huge Price Tag Is Tied to a TV Windfall
text: By agreeing to buy the Los Angeles Dodgers for $2.15 billion, the group led by Magic Johnson is paying nearly two and a half times the $845 million paid to acquire the Chicago Cubs in 2009. The price tag is so big that it eclipses by around 50 percent what Malcolm Glazer and his family paid for the soccer giant Manchester United in 2005.

headline: A Stamp Collection With Rare Delights Leaves a Family’s Holdings for Auction
text: Many families have some treasures in the attic. Fred Frelinghuysen knew he had something, too, but he realized its significance only when the time came to let it go.

headline: A Place in the Universe for a Daffy Musical
text: Good news, ardent fans of offbeat musical theater. The lovable gang from “[title of show]” is back with an endearingly goofy new diversion called “Now. Here. This.” Thin as a vanilla wafer but just as sweet, it opened on Wednesday night at the Vineyard Theater, where the same collaborators’ first show played before its little-engine-that-could chug to Broadway. (It closed pretty quickly, but still: Broadway!)

headline: Sing Along With Milo
text: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — If you ever attended kindergarten, you’ll appreciate this one.

headline: Diplomatic Moves Increase Pressure on Assad
text: With his country unraveling in what looks like a sectarian civil war, President Bashar al-Assad of Syria has been projecting himself as a confident and popular leader on the verge of victory, possibly, analysts said, borrowing lessons drawn from his only remaining regional ally, Iran, on how to resist outside pressure in a crisis.

headline: Espada Aide Is Inconsistent as She Testifies in Fraud Trial
text: She was a prosecution witness, a longtime aide to former State Senator Pedro Espada Jr. who was granted immunity to testify against the man she loved like a brother.

headline: Examining Fans’ Rights to Jeer at Games
text: At a North Carolina State men’s basketball game last month, the former Wolfpack stars Tom Gugliotta and Chris Corchiani were ejected from the arena — at the request of a referee — for protesting the officials’ calls. Gugliotta and Corchiani were seated behind the scorer’s table, and officials from both teams and others seated nearby said neither one used vulgarity or threatened the referees.

headline: Anthony Takes Control, and Knicks Win Again
text: Amar’e Stoudemire was already a Knicks star when Carmelo Anthony came to the team last year. A season later, while Anthony was sidelined to injury, Jeremy Lin became a national sensation. What the Knicks were before Anthony arrived and what the Knicks have been in his absence has stubbornly framed the substance and the appraisal of Anthony’s entire tenure with the Knicks.

headline: Taking Heed of Criticism, Santorum Tones Down Attacks
text: LA CROSSE, Wis. — Rick Santorum has eased up on using phrases like “worst Republican in the country” when tearing into Mitt Romney. And he is no longer saying that a vote for Mr. Romney would be basically the same thing as a vote for President Obama.

headline: For Top Judge, Tough Lessons on Family Court Bench
text: The couple stood awkwardly in front of the judge in Queens Family Court. “He put his hands around your neck and choked you,” the judge read from claims the woman had made. “He told you if you ever left him, he would kill you.”

headline: Councilman Weighing Run for Comptroller
text: Daniel R. Garodnick, a Democratic councilman from the East Side of Manhattan, has told labor leaders, elected officials and others that he is likely to run for comptroller in 2013, even if that means challenging the embattled incumbent, John C. Liu, according to people who have talked to Mr. Garodnick in recent weeks.

headline: Strauss-Kahn Wants Judge to Dismiss Accuser’s Lawsuit
text: Lawyers for Dominique Strauss-Kahn, whom prosecutors accused of raping a hotel housekeeper before dropping charges against him last year, asked a judge on Wednesday to dismiss a civil lawsuit against their client, saying his former position as head of the International Monetary Fund bestowed “absolute immunity” upon him.

headline: Will Ferrell, No, Make That Ron Burgundy, Announces ‘Anchorman’ Sequel
text: Will Ferrell donned the 1970s period garb (and mustache) of the titular newscaster he portrayed in the 2004 hit “Anchorman: The Legend of Ron Burgundy” to announce on “Conan” Wednesday night that he would be making a follow-up to that film.

headline: Ron Stewart, Star of Maple Leafs Champs, Dies at 79
text: Ron Stewart played 21 seasons in the National Hockey League, was an All-Star wing and was on three Stanley Cup championship teams with the Toronto Maple Leafs. He also played for the New York Rangers and coached them. From the 1950s to the 1970s he had 276 goals, but he did a lot more than score.

headline: Fit for Climbing
text: Paleontologists have found a partial foot of a prehuman species that lived at the same time as Lucy’s species.

headline: In Congo, Self-Defense Can Offer Its Own Risk
text: CHULWE, Democratic Republic of Congo — When his brother was kidnapped and cut to pieces in the forest in 2008, neither the Congolese Army nor the United Nations peacekeepers stationed here did anything to protect him, said Guillaume Sadiki Bantu. When his nephew was killed in another attack just last month, he added, it was the same.

headline: Union Chief Says New U.S. Rules for Immigration Detention Are Flawed
text: The leader of a union representing thousands of federal officers responsible for detaining and deporting illegal immigrants said Wednesday that new rules issued by the Obama administration for immigration detention centers nationwide were flawed and would make the system “more dangerous.”

headline: Syrians Find Refuge in Lebanon
text: Sunni Muslims who have fled Syria described a government crackdown that is more pervasive and more sectarian than previously understood.

headline: Weather Runs Hot and Cold, So Scientists Look to the Ice
text: Some people call what has been happening the last few years “weather weirding,” and March is turning out to be a fine example.

headline: Zynga Prices Secondary Offering at $12 a Share
text: Zynga‘s insiders are set for a generous pay day.

headline: Rubio Endorses Romney, Dismissing Vice Presidential Talk
text: Senator Marco Rubio of Florida endorsed Mitt Romney on Wednesday night on Fox News’s “Hannity” show, calling Mr. Romney, the former governor of Massachusetts, “a stark contrast to the president’s record.”

headline: Managing the Risks of Extreme Events and Disasters to Advance Climate Change Adaptation
text: Special report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change

headline: Neighbors Said to Be at Violent Odds in Syrian Crackdown
text: AL QAA, Lebanon — Sunni Muslims who have fled Syria described a government crackdown that is more pervasive and more sectarian than previously understood, with civilians affiliated with President Bashar al-Assad’s minority religious sect shooting at their onetime neighbors as the military presses what many Sunnis see as a campaign to force them to flee their homes and villages in some sections of the country.

headline: The Power of Young Adult Fiction
text: The Hunger Games: Why have young adult books become so popular so quickly — even with not-so-young adults?

headline: Hollywood’s Small-Town Charm Meets Mini-City Planning
text: A rezoning plan that would turn parts of Hollywood into a mini-city has won the support of key Los Angeles officials and set off a storm of opposition from residents.

headline: Video Shows Man Who Shot Trayvon Martin Arriving at Police Station
text: Police surveillance video obtained by ABC News shows George Zimmerman, the Florida man who has sparked national outrage over his killing of an unarmed teenager in February, as he arrived at the Sanford, Fla., police station on the night of the shooting.

headline: Feedback From Students Becomes a Campus Staple, but Some Go Further
text: BOSTON — Every other Monday, right before class ends, Muhammad Zaman, a Boston University biomedical engineering professor, hands out a one-page form asking students to anonymously rate him and the course on a scale of one to five.

headline: Take Back the Senate, Senators
text: The current condition of the Senate constitutes a national emergency. Not long ago, Americans looked to the Senate to be, in Walter Mondale’s words, the “national mediator,” reconciling regional and ideological differences through thoughtful legislating, serious debate, hard bargaining and principled compromise. Today, however, after a 20-year downward spiral, the once great Senate is polarized, paralyzed and dysfunctional. Last month, as she announced her decision to retire, Olympia Snowe, Republican of Maine, described a Senate that “routinely jettisons regular order,” “serially legislates by political brinksmanship” and “habitually eschews full debate and an open amendment process in favor of competing, up-or-down, take it or leave it proposals.” In The New Yorker, George Packer described the Senate as “the empty chamber.”

text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Brutality Jolts Russia Into Action on Police
text: KAZAN, Russia — Even now, after the police officers who brutalized him have been fired and jailed, after federal investigators swooped in from Moscow to take charge of a widening abuse scandal, after an avalanche of attention from major human rights organizations and the international media, Oskar Krylov is still afraid — afraid of the police, afraid to live in Russia.

headline: The Closer: Van Gundy’s Views Refreshing
text: It is often easy, especially in March, to get carried away when talking about college basketball. The hype surrounding the N.C.A.A. tournament  tends to be all-encompassing.

headline: Elevator Worker Electrocuted in Midtown
text: An elevator worker was electrocuted in a commercial building in Midtown Manhattan on Wednesday night, the authorities said.

headline: Life, Interrupted: Facing Cancer in Your 20s
text: I was so excited for what lay ahead, I nearly forgot to wave goodbye to my parents. Armed with a college diploma, my first job offer, a one-way ticket to Paris and a new pair of heels, I was ready to take on anything. Little did I know, I would be back in New York seven short months later. But my parents would not be taking pictures at the airport or chatting about my future plans. I would be in a wheelchair, too weak to walk.

headline: New U.S. Research Will Aim at Flood of Digital Data
text: The federal government is beginning a major research initiative in big data computing. The effort, which will be announced on Thursday, involves several government agencies and departments, and commitments for the programs total $200 million.
