text: moodiness •\ˈmü-de-nəs\• noun

headline: Goldman’s Passage to India
text: Nestled in the diplomatic enclave of the capital city here sits the Leela Palace hotel. This week, its ninth floor has been home to the board of Goldman Sachs.

headline: BRICS: Policy Block or Photo Op?
text: “The new BRIC era has yet to arrive,” Jim Yardley writes in The New York Times ahead of the meeting of the group’s leaders in New Delhi Thursday.

headline: Waiting to Exhale in Myanmar
text: HONG KONG — The last time Burma held an election that was anything close to being fair, the military didn’t care for the results and tossed them aside, as if the whole thing had never happened. The generals went about their jackboot business, cozied up to China and kept the main opposition leader under arrest for most of the next two decades. It was North Korea Lite.

headline: Campaign Treasurer Accused in Fraud Will Enter a Plea
text: Kinde Durkee, the former campaign treasurer accused of embezzling millions from the campaigns of Senator Dianne Feinstein and other California Democrats, will enter a plea this week to multiple felony charges, according to a statement from the United States attorney’s office in Sacramento.

headline: Charles de Gaulle on Board for an Upgrade
text: PARIS — Charles de Gaulle is Europe’s second-largest airport in terms of passengers — 61 million last year — and the seventh largest worldwide. Yet it doesn’t get much love.

headline: A Fashion Magazine Unshy About Baring a Bit of Piety
text: ISTANBUL — Across a neon-lighted corridor in a hyper-designed modernist loft here, a group of Eastern European models posed coquettishly for a magazine spread, their heads covered in brightly colored scarves.

headline: Germany’s New President Offers a Counterpoint in Style to the Chancellor
text: ROSTOCK, Germany — Now that Joachim Gauck has been sworn in as Germany’s 11th postwar president, the country’s two highest-ranking officials share a worldview shaped by decades spent longing for freedom from East Germany’s Communist system. But the paths of Mr. Gauck and Angela Merkel, Germany’s chancellor since 2005, diverged once democracy dawned.

headline: How India Sold Outsourcing to the United States
text: “An inoffensive history of the Indian software industry, written by a good-natured man who frequently uses the word ‘proactive’ in its telling, was released this week,” Manu Joseph writes in The International Herald Tribune about the book “The Coalition of Competitors,” by Kiran Karnik.

headline: Canada: Coins Pour Onto Highway
text: About one million Canadian dollars spilled across a remote portion of the Trans-Canada Highway when a Brink’s tractor-trailer hit a rocky outcropping early Wednesday, the police said. Constable Marc Depatie of the South Porcupine detachment of the Ontario Provincial Police said a minivan and two more trucks plowed into the wreck. One of the other trucks broke apart, mixing its load of candy with the one- and two-dollar coins, which the police estimated to be worth more than $1 million. The Royal Canadian Mint, which was shipping the money from its plant in Winnipeg, Manitoba, declined to confirm the value of the coins. The driver of the Brink’s truck and a passenger were critically injured. Constable Depatie said that a crane with a large electromagnet would be used to collect the coins.

headline: NYT Front Page for 03/29/2012
text: NYT Front Page for 03/29/2012

headline: Pakistan: A Summit of Generals
text: The Pakistani Army chief, Gen. Ashfaq Parvez Kayani, met with American military commanders — Gen. James Mattis, the central command leader, and Gen. John R. Allen, the top commander in Afghanistan — for the first time since American warplanes killed 24 Pakistani soldiers last November, in a visit that was seen as a first step in clearing the air between uneasy allies. The Pakistani news media reported that General Kayani told his visitors that he rejected the American military inquiry into the Nov. 26 airstrikes — a position the army has previously expressed in public. The American report found fault with both sides for the episode, which caused Pakistan to close NATO supply lines into Afghanistan. Pakistan insists that United States forces were entirely at fault and has demanded an apology. The meeting coincided with the official start in Islamabad of a parliamentary debate on diplomatic relations with Washington.

headline: Yemen: Saudi Diplomat Abducted
text: A Saudi Arabian diplomat was kidnapped from the port city of Aden on Wednesday, in another sign of the breakdown of the rule of law, especially in the south. A Yemeni government spokesman, Mohammed Albasha, confirmed that the diplomat, Abdullah al-Khaldi, who works at the Saudi Consulate in Aden, was abducted as he left his home. Kidnappings as a means of extortion by tribes are relatively frequent in Yemen, and Saudi diplomats have been targets before.

headline: Earl Scruggs, Bluegrass Pioneer, Dies at 88
text: Earl Scruggs, the bluegrass banjo player whose hard-driving picking style influenced generations of musicians and helped shape the sound of 20th-century country music with his guitar-strumming partner, Lester Flatt, died on Wednesday in a Nashville hospital. He was 88.

headline: Crackdown on Tibetans in Delhi Includes Young Women
text: Tight security has gripped India’s capital since the Wednesday afternoon arrival of the Chinese president for an economic summit.

headline: $7 Billion Public-Private Plan in Chicago Aims to Fix Transit, Schools and Parks

headline: March 29, 1961 | District of Columbia Awarded Right to Vote in Presidential Election
text: On March 29, 1961, the 23rd Amendment was ratified, granting residents of the District of Columbia the right to vote for electors in presidential elections for the first time. The number of electors was fixed at the number awarded to the smallest state.

As the justices heard arguments for the third and final day, they focused on the real world consequences of invalidating all or part of the law.

headline: Syrian Rebels Continue Assassination Campaign, Killing 2 Military Officials
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Syrian insurgents appear to have stepped up a campaign to assassinate senior military officials with a series of attacks that reinforce and exacerbate the hostility between the Syrian government and rebel fighters who argue that armed struggle is their only chance for survival.

headline: Indian Students Look Regionally for Higher Education
text: “While finishing high school near Pune, India, Pooja Modi started looking for university engineering programs online. Eighteen years old at the time, she knew she wanted to become a solar energy expert,” Christopher F. Schuetze writes in The International Herald Tribune.

headline: Peter Dinklage Was Smart to Say No
text: In January, the actor Peter Dinklage surprised himself during his own Golden Globe acceptance speech. Dinklage had won the award for best supporting actor in a TV series for his portrayal of the complex, sharp-tongued Tyrion Lannister, who’s the closest thing to a hero in HBO’s epic swords-and-sex hit “Game of Thrones,” which returns for its second season on April 1. As he took the statue from the presenter, Piper Perabo, the onstage microphone stand quietly lowered into the floor to accommodate the 4-foot-5 actor.

headline: The Corn Bread Matters Most
text: Chris Schlesinger opened the East Coast Grill in Cambridge, Mass., in the late summer of 1985, Tears for Fears on the radio and wood smoke in the air. It was a casual restaurant serving beach-town cuisine prepared over live fire by a classically trained chef with a surf rat’s bona fides. The food was bold and full-flavored, a menu born in the South but educated in the Caribbean, Asia — wherever waves crash and the sun-kissed sit barefoot, eating with their fingers as salt dries on their skin.

headline: The Customer Is Always (Convinced That He’s) Right
text: I’m sitting in the Milwaukee airport, having just met with a client near Sheboygan. This is the second visit I’ve made to this client. The first was in late December, when I went to close a deal for a new boardroom table. I wouldn’t normally jump on a plane to make a sale, but this was a decent-sized job for us — a little more than $50,000 — and it’s for a company you may have heard of that has more than a billion dollars a year in sales. The company was building a new boardroom that would include video conferencing.

headline: Europe Cracks Down on Cybercrime
text: LONDON — The European Union is preparing new steps to crack down on bot-herders, identity thieves, web hijackers and other online fraudsters who are skimming millions of euros a day from a growing number of its half billion citizens.

headline: Leonardo’s Saint Anne, After Her Makeover
text: PARIS — When London’s National Gallery mounted its blockbuster Leonardo da Vinci exhibition late last year, advance tickets sold out the first week, online scalpers pocketed up to $400 per ticket and crowds lined up around the block at dawn for the paltry number of tickets still for sale.

headline: Daily Report: New U.S. Research Aims at Digital Data Flood
text: The federal government is beginning a major research initiative in big data computing. The effort, to be announced on Thursday, involves several government agencies and departments, and financial commitments that total $200 million, reports Steve Lohr of The New York Times.

headline: Little Talk of Tough Issues at Arab League Meeting
text: BAGHDAD — The last time leaders from the Arab world gathered for their annual summit meeting, a cozy ritual of speeches and self-congratulation, the date was March 2010, the host was Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi and the venue was a seaside Libyan town named Surt. The main topic was Jerusalem. Change and reform were not high on the agenda.

headline: Time Is Nigh for Global Action, Manifesto Warns
text: An era has dawned in which humanity’s impact on the earth could prove to be as great as ice ages or meteoric collisions, scientists, government officials and business leaders warned this week at a big environmental conference in London. The world’s approach to tackling environmental problems therefore must change rapidly if disaster is to be avoided, they said.

headline: Helen Chaitman Doesn’t Know When to Quit
text: Last week, in writing about the settlement between Irving Picard, the Madoff trustee, and Fred Wilpon and Saul Katz, the owners of the New York Mets, I mentioned the ongoing litigation brought against the trustee by a lawyer named Helen Davis Chaitman, who claims to represent some 800 Madoff victims, both net losers and net winners (who, I should point out, have very divergent interests). Inevitably, I received some emails from Chaitman clients who chastised me for daring to criticize, as one of them put it, “a woman who has been a champion to so many elderly victims, logging many pro bono hours, fighting for victims whose gains would mean her own loss, and giving those victims a voice in the courts.” Et cetera.

headline: Off the Deep End
text: Just because the artist Jason Hackenwerth can create almost anything — including a frighteningly tentacled cyclops — out of balloons, doesn’t mean he’ll work your child’s birthday party. A graduate of the Savannah College of Art and Design, Hackenwerth formed a 13-foot-tall “T” out of thousands of inflated latex balloons. Like all of Hackenwerth’s creations, his “T” will deflate in a matter of months. Such impermanence is a big part of the artist’s practice. “We need to learn how to let go,” he says, “because everything in life is temporary.”

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: Silence, Then Frustration at MF Global Hearing  |  Top MF Global executives and their lawyers have been meeting with federal authorities investigating the collapse of MF Global and the firm’s misuse of customer money, according to testimony before a Congressional panel on Wednesday.

headline: Amazon Web Services’ Big Free Genetic Database
text: Amazon’s cloud computing unit, Amazon Web Services, will store for public use the entire contents of the National Institutes of Health’s 1000 Genomes Project, a survey of genetic information from 1,700 individuals that is some 200 terabytes in size. Anyone can access the information for free, and there is no requirement to share any research results.

headline: Deciding Foreign Policy in the Aisles of the Co-op

As a result of their vote Tuesday night, there will be no referendum — not now, anyway — on whether their Park Slope Food Co-op should join an international boycott of those products, whose cardinal sin is that they are made in Israel.

headline: Gefilteria: Upscale Fish Without the Fuss

headline: Best Use of the 3? In Moderation
text: The 3-point shot has become one of basketball’s most exciting ways to close a gap late in the game. Jeremy Lin launched Linsanity with key 3s that sealed Knicks wins. But if you are on the 3-point bandwagon, you might want to jump off. The team shooting a lower percentage from beyond the arc won 32 of the first 48 N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament games this season (after the play-in games), won 7 of 8 Round-of-16 matchups and all four regional finals. That’s 11 of 12 down the stretch to the Final Four, in the games that expose any weakness a team has and rewards strengths.

headline: Fantasy Focus: Interpreting Past Performance
text: There’s not a huge range of values for established, healthy prime-age players like Dustin Pedroia or Robinson Cano. Maybe you get them for $1 cheaper than you thought, or someone pays $2 more, but for the most part, we know where they slot. The more interesting and variant players are those whose past performance (as measured by their stats) made a sharp jump or decline last year, and also those who because of youth and inexperience, or injuries and age, might change drastically. The question when evaluating these more difficult players is how to interpret their past performance. Or, put differently, how much to ignore it.

headline: British Review Faults Banks for Weak Checks Against Corruption
text: LONDON — A review of 15 investment banks released on Thursday by Britain’s financial regulator showed that a majority lacked adequate anticorruption and bribery checks.

headline: After 4 Years, Woman Accused in Baby’s Death Leaves Rikers
text: A Rikers Island correction officer looked confused on Wednesday morning when a group of Chinese immigrants – trailed by a crush of reporters from local Chinese news outlets – arrived to pick up an inmate who had been in the jail for four years.

headline: $1 Million Gift to PBS’s ‘Masterpiece’
text: After attracting record ratings for its British drama “Downton Abbey,” PBS’s “Masterpiece” has received a $1 million gift from a San Diego donor.

headline: Behind Every Harassed Child? A Whole Lot of Clueless Adults
text: “Bully,” Lee Hirsch’s moving and troubling documentary about the misery some children inflict upon others, arrives at a moment when bullying, long tolerated as a fact of life, is being redefined as a social problem. “Just kids being kids” can no longer be an acceptable response to the kind of sustained physical and emotional abuse that damages the lives of young people whose only sin is appearing weak or weird to their peers.

headline: Royals Have an Emerging Star Without a Supernova Salary
text: SURPRISE, Ariz.

headline: $200-a-Month Beauty Products for Babies?
text: In writing about the $180,000-a year nanny in The Times Magazine last week, Adam Davidson referred to “credence goods”: things whose value to the consumer can’t be determined. “You’re more likely to overpay for a credence good in the hope that a higher cost increases the likelihood of a benefit,” he explained.

headline: Off the Deep End
text: Jason Hackenwerth creates a sculpture for T Magazine's Spring Design issue.

headline: What Might Replace ‘Pink Slime’?
text: Like many Americans, I have been both fascinated and repulsed by the recent discussion about so-called “pink slime” — low-cost, ammonia-treated beef trimmings that are used in making some hamburger patties.

headline: James Endler, Who Oversaw Construction of World Trade Center, Dies at 82
text: James R. Endler, an engineer who helped manage some of the biggest construction projects of the 1970s, ’80s and ’90s, including the World Trade Center, Epcot Center at Walt Disney World, and the Renaissance Center in Detroit, died on Saturday in Manhattan. He was 82.

headline: Business Day Live | March 29, 2012
text: The $2.15 billion price tag for the Los Angeles Dodgers; stock exchange disruptions occur frequently; and how airlines screen pilots for fitness to fly.

headline: Maneuvering for an Immunity Deal
text: When a witness has valuable information and may be implicated in a violation, there are delicate maneuvers between prosecutors and defense lawyers. That is playing out behind the scenes for Edith O’Brien, an assistant treasurer at MF Global, who could have crucial information about how millions of dollars of customer money went missing in the firm’s final days.

headline: How to Teach Art in 89 Simple Lessons
text: When the American painter, sculptor and installation artist Paul Thek (1933-88) taught art classes at Cooper Union in the late 1970s, he wrote and then gave to his students a long, provocative and now famous list of questions and marching orders he titled “Teaching Notes.”

headline: The Politics of the Mandate
text: In my Campaign Stops column this week, I make a version of the fashionably counterintuitive case that it would actually be good news for the president’s re-election hopes if the Supreme Court were to strike down the individual mandate while leaving the rest of the health care bill intact. (Notwithstanding the tenor of the oral arguments, this still seems to me like the second-likeliest outcome from the case — less likely, even after the last few days, than an Anthony Kennedy-led decision affirming the mandate’s constitutionality, and more likely than a decision striking down the bill completely)

headline: Business Day Live: The Value of a Sports Team
text: The $2.15 billion price tag for the Los Angeles Dodgers; stock exchange disruptions occur frequently; and how airlines screen pilots for fitness to fly.

headline: A Bet on Mobile, Millennial Media Soars on Debut
text: Millennial Media, a mobile advertising network, surged in its debut on Thursday, as investors placed a big bet on the future of mobile communications.

headline: China’s Rumor Mill
text: BEIJING — A milestone in the history of Weibo, China’s most popular microblogging platform, came and went rather quietly on March 16: a new requirement to register with your real name, ending the ability of China’s netizens to post anonymously.

headline: In Defense of Presidential Forecasting Models
text: Nate Silver has criticized election forecasting models before, but his latest post is perhaps the most thorough critique. I am not an elections forecaster, but I am a political scientist and consumer of these models. Nate has kindly let me abuse my privilege as an occasional guest blogger here at FiveThirtyEight to respond to his critique.

headline: Obama Repeats Call to End Oil Subsidies
text: 3:25 p.m. | Updated President Obama called on Congress to end $4 billion in tax subsidies for oil and natural gas companies on Thursday, casting the issue as a choice between plumbing scarce resources versus investing in clean energy research.

headline: Scientists Call for Practical Steps to Smooth Humanity’s Journey
text: Planet Under Pressure, a four-day conference exploring how science can identify and limit risks in the face of increasing human impacts on the Earth, has ended* with a call for “urgent action” against the the unrelenting buildup of greenhouse gases. [April1, 9:17 a.m. | Update | An excellent summary has been posted on the Green blog.] But the prime focus, refreshingly, was on boosting science education and interdisciplinary inquiry and maintaining investments in systems and agencies devoted to comprehending environmental change.

headline: Aerosmith Plans New Album and Tour
text: Aerosmith has teamed up again with Jack Douglas, who produced the band’s blockbuster albums of the 1970s, and plans to release a long-delayed collection of new songs this summer to coincide with a North American tour.

headline: GDF Suez Offers $9.5 Billion for Remaining Stake in British Utility
text: PARIS — GDF Suez, the giant French utility, is bidding $9.5 billion for the 30 percent of the British utility International Power that it does not already own, the two companies said Thursday.

headline: Calling All Artists
text: A new book, “Draw It With Your Eyes Closed: The Art of the Art Assignment,” published by Paper Monument, is a collection of art teacher folk wisdom — the best classroom assignments that the contributors, most of them artists or art teachers, have given or received or even heard of.

headline: Digital Notes: Spotify Extends Unlimited Free Listening in U.S.
text: When Spotify opened in the United States last summer, it offered new users six months of free listening without limits. After some confusion early this year about whether it would begin to add restrictions, as it has in Europe, the company announced on Thursday morning that it had “extended the honeymoon for unlimited free listening.”

headline: Among Doctors, Fierce Reluctance to Let Go
text: The conversation took place two years ago, but Dr. Daniel Matlock still recalls it quite vividly. You tend to remember when a physician colleague essentially brands you a Nazi.

headline: Illumina Shares Rise Above Roche’s New Offer as Fight Continues
text: Despite a new and higher offer from Roche Holding, the battle for Illumina appears to be far from over.

headline: Around the Corner of Loss
text: The corner of McGuinness and Kent, in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, has undergone a minor face-lift in the seven years since my aunt Liz was struck and killed there. The Budget Rental Center that occupied the east corner is now an Enterprise Rent-A-Car, and there’s a new BP service station across the street from it, in what used to be a vacant lot. You can no longer park on the east side of McGuinness, because the gas station’s driveway flows out into the street there. Seven years ago, before the gas station, a row of parked trucks lined the curb, and it is for that reason that the driver of the Budget rental van, turning left onto Kent, was unable to see Liz as she rode her bike from the sidewalk to the street.

headline: From Joe, a Richly Stocked Shop for Coffee Pros
text: The new store that Joe will open in Chelsea on Wednesday will be less a coffee shop than a coffee workshop. The shallow storefront will have a brew bar, a lever espresso machine and carry a comprehensive selection of home and professional gear.

headline: Survey Points to Fragile Recovery in Euro Zone
text: FRANKFURT — An official gauge of the mood among consumers and businesses showed Thursday that the euro zone economy remained fragile, with manufacturers and builders growing more pessimistic about their prospects even though the sovereign debt crisis seemed to have eased.

headline: Is the Economy Growing Faster Than We Knew?
text: There is a pleasant surprise in the latest batch of economic data released Thursday by the Bureau of Economic Analysis. Buried deep inside the government’s revised estimate of fourth-quarter growth (revised but unchanged at 3 percent annualized) is an alternate measure of economic activity that is winning increased attention. And by that alternate measure, gross domestic income, the annualized pace of growth in the final three months of 2011 actually climbed to 4.4 percent.

headline: News Corp. Steps Up Defense in TV-Code-Hacking Accusations
text: News Corporation fired back late Wednesday night against accusations that the NDS Group, a technology firm that it has a minority stake in, had hacked into satellite TV rivals in Britain and Australia.

headline: Japan Nuclear Plant May Be Worse Off Than Thought
text: TOKYO — The damage to one of three stricken reactors at the Fukushima Daiichi plant could be worse than previously thought, a recent internal investigation has shown, raising new concerns over the plant’s stability and complicating the post-disaster cleanup.

headline: Wheelies: The Long Arm of the Law Edition
text: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: Cologne, Germany
text: One of the oldest cities in Germany, Cologne has been drawing visitors since at least 50 A.D.

headline: A Short History of Blood Chits: Greetings From the Lost, Seeking Help
text: Today, At War looks at the use of blood chits, a little-known and partially classified American military system designed to help lost or stranded service members find their way to safety.

headline: On Our Radar: Organized Environmental Crime
text: At a conference in France, a high-ranking Interpol official calls for a crackdown on “serious, organized and often transnational” environmental crimes like elephant poaching for ivory, the killing of rhinos for their horns and illegal logging. “Ounce for ounce, rhinoceros horn is now more valuable than gold,” an expert on trade in endangered species tells delegates. [The Guardian]

headline: 36 Hours: Cologne, Germany
text: ONE of the oldest cities in Germany, Cologne has been drawing visitors since at least the year 50 A.D., when it was officially founded as the Roman outpost of Colonia. Today the big attractions are the city’s ancient (and gargantuan) cathedral, vibrant night life, a great native beer called Kölsch, and eau de cologne, invented here in 1709, not to mention the ever-present Rhine River. But the city the Germans know as Köln is hardly resting on its former achievements. New surprises just keep showing up. After crossing off bucket-list items like exploring the cathedral and crawling through legendary Kölsch pubs, you can easily spend an entire weekend focusing on the shops, restaurants and hotels that have opened (or reopened) within the past few years.

headline: London Underground | Domestic Arts
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: 2-Year College, Squeezed, Sets 2-Tier Tuition
text: SANTA MONICA, Calif. — For years now, administrators at the community college here have been inundated with woeful tales from students unable to register for the courses they need. Classes they want for essential job training or to fulfill requirements to transfer to four-year universities fill up within hours. Hundreds of students resort to crying and begging to enroll in a class, lining up at the doors of instructors and academic counselors.

headline: A New Payment Plan
text: My husband, who is long divorced, pays his ex-wife much more than required child support. And he’s financed their children’s college accounts by twice the agreed amount. He does this because his ex-wife claims she is broke, even though she remarried a rich man and lives a lavish life. Worse, he’s started hiding his payments from me. It’s admirable that he’s so generous, but after six years of marriage, with my own child entering college, I feel taken advantage of. Do I have the right to speak up?

headline: Under Woodson, Genuine Signs of Improvement
text: When the Knicks rattled off five consecutive wins under Mike Woodson, it appeared as if the players were merely experiencing a honeymoon effect under their new coach. It seemed normal to think the novelty would wear off and the team would return to its mediocre ways.

headline: Woman Grazed as Officer’s Gun Discharges in Raid a Floor Away
text: 6:37 p.m. | Updated A woman sleeping inside a Brooklyn apartment was grazed by a bullet or small debris on Thursday after a plainclothes New York City police officer’s gun discharged during a drug raid in an apartment a floor above her, the police said.

headline: Unions Relish Idea of Romney as Nominee
text: Many Republican leaders are eager for Mitt Romney to clinch the presidential nomination, but an unlikely group — the nation’s union leaders — also relishes that prospect.

headline: Second Afghan Insurgent Group Suspends Peace Talks
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Stalled peace efforts in Afghanistan suffered another setback on Thursday when a second insurgent faction — one that has squared off against both the American-led coalition and the Taliban — announced it was suspending formal peace negotiations with the Afghan government, as the Taliban did earlier this month.

headline: Stop Worrying About Raising a Mama’s Boy
text: What’s a “mama’s boy”? A wimp, of course, a child tied too tightly to his mother’s apron strings, overly sensitive, incapable of detaching, ready to “run to mama” at the slightest hint of adversity. Norman Bates. Oedipus. Robert, the awkward brother on “Everybody Loves Raymond.” The men are ineffectual, the “mamas” domineering — and if you’re looking for an analogous stereotype in the world of fathers and daughters (think father-daughter dances and “Daddy’s Girl”), you won’t find one.

headline: Old Power Plants Need New Rules
text: THE Environmental Protection Agency’s proposal earlier this week to reduce greenhouse gases from new power plants was hailed by many environmentalists, but unless steps are taken quickly to bring existing plants under the rule, it will create a perverse incentive for companies to keep running older, more heavily polluting power plants. That’s bad economics that could lead to dirtier air.

headline: Where the Hiring Is Strongest
text: Hiring started to pick up toward the end of last year, but you might be surprised to learn which cities were strongest in job creation.

headline: Diagnoses of Autism on the Rise, Report Says
text: The likelihood of a child’s being given a diagnosis of autism, Asperger syndrome or a related disorder increased more than 20 percent from 2006 to 2008, according to a report released on Thursday by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

headline: Trying to Inject Entrepreneurship Into the Greek Economy
text: It’s not easy being Greek. That’s doubly so if you’re an entrepreneur.

headline: TimesCast | March 29, 2012

headline: Ivanka Trump’s Turn on the Runway
text: My favorite look from the Ivanka Trump fashion show that took place on the fifth floor of Lord & Taylor on Wednesday evening, before an audience of everyday customers and most of the Trump clan, was the one Ivanka herself was wearing, a loose and light orange blouse tucked into tight off-white pants with equestrian patches. It was a little strange, though, to also see a model wearing the same pants on Ms. Trump’s runway.

headline: When Less Treatment Is More
text: The patient, a slender middle-aged woman who’d had multiple operations and radiation for a cancer in her belly several years earlier, was struggling with nausea and vomiting again. Initially, the pattern was familiar: She would vomit every time she tried to eat. After a day or two, the problem, probably a kink in her intestines caused by residual scar tissue, would resolve on its own.

In composite, the six may stir memories of a scene in the first “Toy Story” film, when parts of the playthings are indiscriminately mixed and matched, with surreal results.

text: MY daughter and I were halfway through the new “Making of Harry Potter” studio tour when we met Dan, whose job was to attend to our Harry Potter needs.

headline: Restaurant Review: Upstairs at the Ten Bells in London
text: There’s a neon sign next to a dingy staircase in the back corner of the Ten Bells, a lively pub opposite Spitalfields Market in East London with Victorian-era tilework and a salacious history (the lore: two victims of Jack the Ripper were last seen drinking here).

headline: Britain’s Nuclear Plans Suffer Setback
text: LONDON — Britain’s plans for a new generation of nuclear reactors suffered a serious setback Thursday when two German energy companies decided to abandon a multibillion-dollar nuclear power project because of costs.

headline: After Santorum Jokes About Pink Bowling Ball, Critics Pounce
text: LA CROSSE, Wis. — If you’re Rick Santorum, making a crack about a pink bowling ball is sure to draw some unwanted attention.

headline: Into the Wild With a Dog at Your Side
text: AS a nature writer and former wilderness ranger, Ceiridwen Terrill has spent a lot of time roaming the wilderness, often with her dogs. Her treks with Inyo, a wolf and husky mix she adopted as a traveling companion, are the subject of her new book “Part Wild.” And her shepherd mix, Argos, has been trained to carry his own backpack. “Even at 12 years old, he can put in the miles,” she said on the phone from Portland, Ore., where she lives and teaches at Concordia University.

headline: Letters to the Travel Editor
text: To the Editor: Did I miss the secret frugal way of getting to New Zealand (“In Auckland, New Zealand, a Frugal Trifecta,” Frugal Traveler blog, March 20)? I’ve been dreaming about visiting for years but the airfare has always been a show-stopper.

headline: Double Improvisation: Trinity Choir Changes Plans for ‘Improvised Passion’
text: The Trinity Choir, which had announced a performance of an “improvised Passion” based on a text of the “St. John Passion” created by the National Conference of Christians and Jews (now the National Conference for Community and Justice) at Trinity Wall Street on Sunday morning, has changed its plans.

headline: Join Us to Talk About the Coming Baseball Season
text: The Final Four and the smell of cut grass mean only one thing: the start of the baseball season is upon us. The Times’s baseball writers — Tyler Kepner, David Waldstein and Andrew Keh — will preview the 2012 season during a Google-plus video hangout on Monday, April 2, at 11:30 a.m. EDT. And we’d like to invite selected readers to join them in the conversation. If you are available for 30 minutes beginning at that time and would like to hang out with us, use the comment area below to tell us what kind of a  baseball fan you are, who you root for, and what questions you have about the upcoming season. Please also include a link to your Google-plus profile page and note that to participate in the hangout you will need a Google-plus profile and a video camera-enabled computer. We look forward to it.

headline: St. Helena, ‘Cursed Rock’ of Napoleon’s Exile
text: I STOOD on the aft deck of the 128-passenger Royal Mail Ship St. Helena in the gloom of a predawn morning last fall, my eyes riveted to an island that seemed to rise from the scalloped sea, a ruined cathedral of volcanic rock shrouded in mist. It was a steep natural fortress augmented by man-made battlements, bristling with rusty cannons that commanded the far reaches of the surrounding ocean. As the sun rose, its palette morphed from black to slate to tawny.

headline: 2 Studies Point to Common Pesticide as a Culprit in Declining Bee Colonies
text: Scientists have been alarmed and puzzled by declines in bee populations in the United States and other parts of the world. They have suspected that pesticides are playing a part, but to date their experiments have yielded conflicting, ambiguous results.

headline: Euro Zone’s Next Debate: How Big of a Bailout Fund?
text: COPENHAGEN — How big is big enough for a permanent bailout fund for the euro zone?

headline: Secrets and Lies
text: Governments have good reasons for keeping secrets – to protect soldiers in battle, or nuclear launch codes, or the identities of intelligence sources, undercover agents and witnesses against the mob. (Naturally that’s not an exhaustive list.) Governments also have bad reasons for keeping secrets – to avoid embarrassment, evade oversight or escape legal accountability.

headline: Hard Line on Iran Places White House in a Bind
text: WASHINGTON — As American and European diplomats prepare for crucial negotiations with Iran over its nuclear program, the White House finds itself caught in a bind: for the diplomatic effort to work, American officials say, the Iranian government must believe that President Obama is ready and willing to take military action.

headline: In New Orleans, Hotels Lure a Local Fan Base
text: MIDWAY through a Friday happy-hour gig, the bandleader Shannon Powell started taking requests.

headline: The Trouble With Exchange Traded Notes
text: Over the past week or so, the market for exchange traded notes has become a bit unhinged – with two notes in particular coming in for wild trading swings.

headline: Getting to That Safe Place
text: I MET him at the coffee place where I was working after I’d dropped out of graduate school out West, many states and several states of mind away from the New England college town to which I’d returned. I was floating between Gen X jobs, living in the aftermath of an emotionally and physically abusive relationship that had left me dazed and shaky, still absently rubbing my arms where bruises had marbled them, unable to look much in mirrors because I felt exposed, vulnerable.

headline: Mark Leyner’s Other Other Career
text: In last Sunday’s magazine, Adam Sternbergh wrote about the re-emergence of beloved cult novelist Mark Leyner. Not included in Sternbergh’s account of Leyner’s whereabouts over the years is the author’s stint at George, the politics and pop-culture magazine founded by John F. Kennedy Jr. For the second issue of the magazine in late 1995 — that is Robert DeNiro dressed up as George Washington on the cover, somewhat less fetching than Cindy Crawford was on the debut issue — Leyner wrote about John Brabender, a political media guru who had just recently guided an unknown Rick Santorum to the U.S. Senate. Brabender, as you may know, is still very much a Santorum man, recently inaugurating a series of apocalyptic ads on the theme of “Obamaville.”

headline: Artifacts | Bat-Sugar Bombshell
text: She’s the life of the party and she’s going bats. Her golden hair fanning out in the wind and ribbons — or are they cocktail straws? rivulets of blood? — flying from her mouth, she kicks up her heels and heads into the dark, dive-bombing the target of her vampire’s kiss.

headline: Met Opera to Broadcast ‘Ring’ Cycle in Movie Theaters in May
text: The Metropolitan Opera has announced that concurrent with its final live presentation of the Robert Lepage production of Wagner’s “Ring des Nibelungen” this spring (May 5-12), it will begin broadcasting the complete “Ring” cycle to movie theaters around the world, recycling the HD transmissions of the individual operas as they appeared over the last two seasons. On May 7, in the United States, Canada and some other countries, the Met will present “Wagner’s Dream,” a documentary on the production by Susan Froemke. The opera screenings will take place in the United States on May 9 (“Das Rheingold”), May 14 (“Die Walküre”), May 16 (“Siegfried”) and May 19 (“Götterdämmerung”). Screenings abroad will take place at various times, extending in some cases into summer and, in Japan, through August. This is said by the Met to be the first time a “Ring” cycle has been presented on a big screen, though the production will not be entirely unified, since the first two operas were recorded with James Levine conducting, the last two with Fabio Luisi.

headline: Creation and Expression: Reflecting on Text and Context in Art
text: Overview | What does art tell us about the time and place of its creation, and what does the context tell us about an artwork? In this lesson, students consider the work of Keith Haring in the late 1970s and early 1980s, which can be used as a framework for studying any artist and era. Students research historically and culturally significant events as a potential means to understand artists and their works. They create and present slide shows that incorporate images of the work with commentary that place the pieces in their historical and cultural context. Finally, they trace the legacy of their chosen artist via the work of artists who came later or their effect on culture.

headline: An Online Tool  for Comparing Checking Account Fees
text: Comparing checking account fees isn’t easy to do, as you know if you’ve ever tried to shop for a new account. Account disclosure formats vary, despite recent attempts at simplifying the way in which banks present information about fees, minimum balance requirements and other details to consumers.

headline: Special Poetry Pairing | Adrienne Rich
text: We’re posting a second Poetry Pairing today to honor the life of Adrienne Rich, who died on Tuesday.

headline: Congress Extends Road Funds by 90 Days
text: WASHINGTON — Unable to come to agreement on highway funding and eager to start a two-week recess, Congress on Thursday passed a 90-day stopgap measure to continue paying for the nation’s highways and infrastructure programs, averting a halt in road and infrastructure projects because of the inability of lawmakers to agree on a broader transportation measure.

headline: Duke Study Finds Miseducation From History-Based Movies
text: LOS ANGELES — This just in: Movie history can be hazardous to your intellectual health.

headline: Couric on ‘Good Morning America’ Could End No. 1 Streak at ‘Today’
text: With the news that Katie Couric will be co-hosting “Good Morning America” on ABC next week, the prospect that the “Today” show could finally lose a week has suddenly become more real than at any time in the last seven years.

headline: A 1971 Armstrong Performance to Be Released as Album
text: Just five months before he died, Louis Armstrong gave a performance at the National Press Club in Washington, singing and playing the trumpet for nearly a half-hour at a party for the club’s newly elected president. That concert was recorded by CBS newsmen who attended the event, and the press club later pressed about 300 vinyl copies and distributed them to journalists who had attended. It was never released as a commercial album, even though it was one of the last times the jazz trumpeter performed before his death in July 1971.

headline: A Reader’s Companion to Ultrabooks
text: In my Times column today, I reviewed practically the entire marketplace of ultrabooks. That’s Intel’s name for MacBook Air-type, superthin, metal-clad, $1,000-ish high-end luxury laptops. In all, I tried out models from seven companies.

headline: A Coho Salmon’s Journey
text: Aliette Frank, a postdoctoral scholar at Royal Roads University, explores sustainable community development on the coast of British Columbia.

headline: A Very Long Road for Military Nuclear Waste
text: Slowly, slowly, the Energy Department is moving forward with solidifying the liquid nuclear wastes left over from cold-war weapons production. On Thursday, the department said it had closed two more of the 51 underground tanks at the Savannah River Site in western South Carolina. The high-level waste was mixed with molten glass to keep it chemically locked up for millennia, and the lower-level material was mixed with a kind of cement that is supposed to keep it in place until the radioactivity dies down.

headline: In a Shift, the World Bank’s Next Likely President Is Facing 2 Rivals
text: WASHINGTON — For the first time, the World Bank is considering more than one candidate for its five-year presidency — a change that reflects the fast-growing clout of emerging economies, even as it raises questions over whether that change is coming quickly enough.

headline: Snapguide Makes Anyone a Guide
text: This weekend I’m going to learn how to make tofu. I’m not going to take a class, or use a cookbook, I’m going to follow instructions from a new iPhone and iPad application called Snapguide.

headline: Five-Ku: Golden Age of the American Action Film Edition
text: What Rambo teachesAbout Green Berets. They doEverything shirtless.

headline: Gingrich Backer Says Candidacy Is Nearing End
text: 8:59 p.m. | Updated Sheldon Adelson, the Las Vegas billionaire who has been the biggest backer to a group supporting Newt Gingrich, said this week that Mr. Gingrich had reached “the end of his line” in his bid for the presidency.

headline: Albany Money Will Aid Effort to Remember the War of 1812
text: The War of 1812 is finally getting some respect.

headline: Burk: Augusta Gender Issue Is Now I.B.M.’s
text: For the second straight day, I.B.M. has taken the no-comment route on whether its new chief executive, Virginia M. Rometty, should be extended an invitation to join Augusta National as I.B.M. chief executives traditionally have been. This is, of course, an issue because Augusta National has rather vehemently defended its male-only membership over the years and now that tradition clashes with an important corporate sponsor.

headline: Wedding Q. and A.
text: How to Let People Know They’re Not Invited

text: A scene from Nanni Moretti’s film about a newly elected pope who has an anxiety attack.

headline: House Passes Republican Budget Plan
text: A fierce two-day debate over a Republican budget plan portrayed as either a path to prosperity or a road to ruin ended Thursday with House passage of a blueprint that would transform Medicare, cut domestic spending to levels not seen since World War II and order up a significant overhaul of the tax code.

headline: Leah & Seth
text: In this homemade video, Leah Raful and Seth Goldberg tell the story of their first date which they arranged through an online singles website.

headline: Sitting on Cash and a Reason to Hire
text: Even when the recovery was in a much more sluggish mode, corporate profits stood out for their blistering growth, and companies were sitting on large piles of cash.

headline: Collection of 24 Lotus Cars to Be Auctioned at Goodwood
text: One of the largest private collections of Lotus cars will be dismantled in June during the 2012 Goodwood Festival of Speed, the annual motoring celebration at the grounds of Goodwood House in West Sussex, England.

headline: ‘Colorful Realm’ at the National Gallery
text: A new exhibition in Washington brings together for the first time outside of Japan a suite of paintings that Ito Jakuchu made between 1757 and 1766.

headline: Electronic Giant Vowing Reforms in China Plants
text: Responding to a critical investigation of its factories, the manufacturing giant Foxconn has pledged to sharply curtail working hours and significantly increase wages inside Chinese plants making electronic products for Apple and others. The move could improve working conditions across China.

headline: Parental Quandary: Telling My Daughter About My Abusive Mother
text: E. writes that she comes from a pretty messed-up background. She never met her father, and her mother “was a very difficult woman and estranged from most of her family.”

headline: Coach’s Frank Approach Appeals to the Rangers
text: John Tortorella had a point to make to Ryan McDonagh, and he was not about to let the locker room celebration after the Rangers’ overtime victory over Columbus stop him.

headline: Harry Crews, a Darkly Comic Novelist, Dies at 76
text: Harry Crews, whose novels out-Gothic Southern Gothic by conjuring a world of hard-drinking, punch-throwing, knife-fighting, snake-oil-selling characters whose myriad physical, mental, social and sexual deviations render them entirely normal and eminently sympathetic, died on Wednesday at his home in Gainseville, Fla. He was 76.

headline: Laboring at Foxconn
text: The Fair Labor Association found widespread problems in labor practices at Foxconn, the electronics giant that supplies Apple and other companies.

headline: Sprawling, Digital Roots Behind a Syrian Uprising
text: Karam Nachar wants to topple President Bashar al-Assad of Syria.

headline: Teeming With Transcendent Life
text: WASHINGTON — Have you ever felt put off by the imperturbable serenity exuded by the Buddha in countless artistic images? Maybe it is my American DNA or my underdeveloped consciousness, but I sometimes feel almost as alienated by his Teflon-like immunity to excitation as by the idealized agony of the crucified Jesus. They both seem so unnaturally abstract.

headline: The Super PAC Pact
text: Congress desperately needs to overhaul the campaign finance system. Like most other things Congress desperately needs to do, it probably won’t—at least not in the near-term.

headline: Wholesome Songsmiths Visit Steinbeck’s Brothel
text: Unless you happen to be a marine biologist, “Pipe Dream” is probably not your favorite Rodgers and Hammerstein musical. This little-cherished 1955 show, based on John Steinbeck novels and set among the bottom feeders of Cannery Row in Monterey, Calif., had a troubled gestation — Richard Rodgers underwent surgery for cancer just as it went into rehearsals — and it played just seven months on Broadway after a cool reception from the critics.

headline: The Brightest of Creatures
text: The fact that living creatures produce sounds is not particularly startling, nor is the fact that they emit smells. But light is another affair. It is just as incorporeal, but there is something uncanny about the idea of organisms creating light, as if occult powers were at play. Such beings are so rare in human experience, and their habitats so distant and fragile, that they can even seem exotically angelic — or, in some cases, demonic.

headline: ‘Creatures of Light’
text: The exhibition, opening Saturday at the American Museum of Natural History, explores bioluminescence.

headline: Harry Crews, Beyond the Bravado
text: “How do you like your blue eyed boy, Mr. Death?”

headline: Telling Scary Stories and Then Living Them
text: The monster that creeps into the satisfyingly shivery horror film “Intruders” doesn’t just hide under the bed, it also lurks in dark corners, including those dimmed by your own imagination. The Spanish director Juan Carlos Fresnadillo knows that cinema is, like campfire tales and radio shows once were, a wonderful training ground. The movies are where many of us first learn to shudder at creaking floorboards, slow-turning doorknobs and all the other delicious, familiar frights that repeatedly bring us back for another genre helping. Horror stories, in other words, teach you how to be afraid and how to conquer your fear, which turns out to be the deft, amusing moral of this one.

headline: City’s Jobless Rate Continues to Rise Faster Than Job Creation Rate
text: Updated 5:45 p.m.  New York City keeps on adding jobs but not fast enough to stop its unemployment rate from rising.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Spain and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Spain, Yemen, Indonesia and Mali.

headline: Half of American Mobile Customers Own Smartphones, Says Nielsen
text: In the United States, smartphones are on track to outnumber traditional cellphones in 2012. As of February, about half of all Americans with cellphones were using smartphones, according to Nielsen, a research firm.

headline: Parachuting to Land of Post-its and Cage
text: No conductor talks about music more engagingly than Michael Tilson Thomas. But he was curiously mum on Tuesday night, when the San Francisco Symphony opened a series of four American Mavericks programs at Carnegie Hall. With works by Cage, Cowell and Varèse, and a new piece by John Adams on the program, I expected Mr. Thomas to be at his chattiest.

headline: Who’s the Most Self-Absorbed of Them All?
text: Is it possible for filmmakers to still peddle the old “once upon a time” in the age of Katniss Everdeen, the ferocious teenage warrior from “The Hunger Games”? The answer, from the evidence of Tarsem Singh’s “Mirror Mirror,” a would-be comic and cheeky redo of Snow White, is yes, but not persuasively. The princess (Lily Collins) here smiles obligingly while flouncing about in a gown, but she also helps write her own happily ever after with a sword. Whether that makes her a feminist heroine or just another self-actualized Disneyesque waif may depend on your idea of empowerment. (In June the fairy tale gets another makeover in “Snow White and the Huntsman.”)

headline: BlackBerry Maker Posts Another Loss as a Former Chief Leaves Its Board
text: OTTAWA — Research in Motion, the beleaguered BlackBerry maker, is open to selling or licensing parts of its business, its chief executive said Thursday after the company announced a fourth-quarter loss of $125 million and a higher-than-anticipated decline in BlackBerry sales.

headline: Tavern on the Green Draws At Least Two Bidders — and Many ‘No, Thank You’s
text: After kicking the tires of Tavern on the Green, the site of the former glamorous landmark in Central Park, at least two restaurateurs say they will put in a bid on Friday with the New York City Department of Parks and Recreation for a 20-year license to establish a restaurant and bar there.

headline: Apollo’s Leon Black Donates $48 Million to Dartmouth
text: The financier Leon Black and his wife, Debra, are contributing $48 million toward a new visual arts center at Dartmouth College, the school announced on Thursday.

headline: Sacred Music for the Holy Season
text: A sampling of noteworthy musical presentations planned for the holiday season at churches and other sites in New York, from Friday through Easter Sunday, compiled by Anne Mancuso. All are free unless otherwise noted. (Churches accept donations. Unless noted, church choirs are featured in church concerts.)

headline: Capturing the Body
text: No one person gets credit for inventing photography. The honor tends to be spread among several individuals, mostly in France and Britain in the 1830s and ’40s, who were responsible for the innovations that set the medium in motion toward its many modern incarnations.

headline: In SoHo, OnStar Stages a Show for Helicopter Parents
text: To demonstrate its new Family Link feature, OnStar, the in-vehicle safety and connectivity system, employed some method acting in New York this week.

headline: Budget Analysis: Charter Spending Squeezing Education Budget
text: New York City's Education Department will spend $51 million to open 26 new charter schools next year, according to a report released on Thursday by the Independent Budget Office. The analysis of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's preliminary budget also found that the city had slightly overestimated how much the Department of Education's budget would increase next year, while minimizing the amount by which general education spending may have to be cut to cover rising costs in other areas.

headline: Out There | Pati Hertling’s Night Job
text: Pati Hertling occupies a position in the art world that is both organic and anomalous. She is webbed among family, friends and lovers who populate a rising bicontinental scene: her twin brother, Alexander, is a co-owner of the upstart Parisian gallery Balice Hertling, which in 2011 opened a branch in New York called Balice Hertling & Lewis; her girlfriend is K8 Hardy, the chameleon performance artist whose photographs are in the current Whitney Biennial; her ex-girlfriend is Elizabeth Peyton, the portraitist-bard of high culture hipsterdom. Born in Berlin, Hertling exudes German reserve and discretion (though usually not in the eye makeup department), perhaps exaggerated by the fact that she is a practicing restitution lawyer. What ties it all together, loosely enough, is that she moonlights as a curator. A group show she organized is on view at the Swiss Institute in SoHo until April 15.

headline: Is Gambling Immoral?
text: Michael Sokolove’s cover article on casinos initiated a debate among our readers over the impact casinos have on communities and whether gambling is morally wrong.

headline: Mets’ Cuts Resolve Some Positional Battles
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. – There were more empty lockers, more upturned clubhouse stools, as the Mets on Thursday continued to winnow their roster before opening day.

headline: Artists in Dialogue at the Kitchen
text: The kitchen of the Miser’s childhood home was the place to discuss life. I confided in my mother as she prepared dinner, and debated with my father while he washed dishes — and sometimes a grubby child — in the sink. It was where they taught me about where I came from, and where we argued about where I was going, with a constant stream of commentary from siblings and grandparents as they passed in and out to refill their coffee cups.

headline: Looking at the Body Through the Lens
text: “Naked Before the Camera,” which opened this week at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York, is a sweeping examination of photography showcasing the naked body. The show presents works mostly from Europe and the United States from 1850 to the present, including photographs by Nadar, Eakins, Muybridge, Brassaï and Mapplethorpe.

headline: Online Features Expanded
text: AS buyers begin searching for mortgages this spring, they may notice that many of the major online shopping sites have been adding new user-friendly features. And if they look hard enough, they will also find another new service joining the crowd — this one from a man who calls himself the “mortgage professor.”

headline: Dr. John Revamped
text: FOR decades Dr. John, the New Orleans pianist and songwriter, has stubbornly inhabited the psychedelic voodoo stage persona he created in the late 1960s. He still walks around with an African staff adorned with totems, bones, an alligator tooth, a vial full of a friend’s ashes and a juju bag.

headline: Sectarian Killings In Syria
text: March 29, 2012 – Syrian refugees who have fled to Lebanon say the Assad regime is leading a sectarian military campaign.

headline: Morphing Figures, Mismatched and Distorted
text: In the Surrealist parlor game exquisite corpse, artists build a figure on an absurd assembly line. Typically a piece of paper is folded into sections and passed around; the challenge is that each artist must work on one particular segment without having seen the others. The results are often monstrous, or at least mismatched.

headline: Former Ambassador to U.S. Cites Threats in Pakistan Over Memo Case
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Husain Haqqani, the former Pakistani ambassador to the United States, has told his country’s top court that he faces threats to his life if he returns from Washington to testify before a judicial inquiry into whether the government sought American help to stave off a military coup last year.

headline: Collectors’ Personal Connections Lead to a Special Auction
text: It all started on their honeymoon in Rome. “We were having breakfast at the Hassler, and all of a sudden my husband got terribly excited,” Geraldine Pincus, a Philadelphia philanthropist and collector, recalled during a recent telephone interview. “Henry Moore was sitting right near us. He was an artist David really admired.”

headline: Etch A Sketch Starts Its Own Campaign
text: The maker of Etch A Sketch is trying to put a positive spin on its status as a political insult with a new advertisement campaign.

headline: Panel Recommends More Testing for Obesity Drugs
text: Obesity drugs should undergo clinical trials to ensure that they do not cause heart attacks, federal advisers said Thursday, a requirement that could make it harder for such drugs to gain approval.

headline: For Hard-Hit Seniors, Rental Options
text: ON a fixed income, Antonio and Nan LaGuidice struggle to meet the $1,700-a-month rent for their two-bedroom apartment in New Rochelle, and the costs of doctor visits, cancer treatments and medication that Mrs. LaGuidice, 72, requires. The couple, who share their place with an adult daughter, manage only by cutting costs so close to the bone that Mr. LaGuidice, 90, a former building superintendent and school bus driver who needs a hearing aid, cannot spare the money for one.

headline: Closing Generation Gaps
text: In the post-everything era, whose advent coincided with the rise of digitization in photography, it has often seemed, paradoxically, as if nothing new can be done. The negative consequence of this is that contemporary photographs can look a lot like vintage ones; the positive outcome is that new and intriguing connections are often made between past and present. Luckily, there are many examples of the latter at the AIPAD Photography Show New York.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Google’s Android Earnings and Fewer AOL Servers
text: Here are some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web on Thursday. There are more here.

headline: Best Friends Rolling in the Hay (and in Flour, Too)
text: The youngish couples who swap partners in “Four Lovers,” Antony Cordier’s shallow erotic daydream, are so attractive that to observe them making love repeatedly and intensely doesn’t make you worry that you might be consuming soft-core pornography, although that’s really what it is. The movie, originally titled “Happy Few,” is French, after all. French culture is very relaxed when it comes to portraying sex without shame, and the actors going through the motions are very good at it.

headline: Challenge From the Right Tests Texas Speaker, Again
text: SAN ANTONIO — House Speaker Joe Straus easily quelled the Tea Party rebellion that threatened his reign in early 2011.

text: FOR those living or working near flood plains along New Jersey’s ocean or river fronts, it’s been nothing but bad news lately.
