text: NEW ORLEANS – Over the past two weeks, as Kentucky did not advance in the N.C.A.A. tournament so much as it obliterated all opponents, the drumbeat, however absurd, that these Wildcats could beat an N.B.A. team grew louder and louder. The Wildcats, supporters argued, were that good, were among the best college teams that has ever played.

headline: Homesick in the World
text: To the Editor:

headline: Conflict Over How Open ‘Do Not Track’ Talks Will Be
text: WASHINGTON — Technology companies want to talk with the government about protecting privacy on the Internet. They just want those talks to be private.

headline: It’s Official: Elder Bush Backs Romney
text: The elder George Bush formally endorsed Mitt Romney on Thursday, calling him “an old friend” and saying he would “make a great president.”

headline: Trying Out the Neighborhood
text: BACK in 2008, Jennifer Donatelli and her family sold their small “starter house” in southeastern Huntington in record time (the kind of thing that used to happen routinely before the housing crash) and had to get out in two months. “We wanted a better neighborhood and a bigger home,” said Ms. Donatelli, a former TV producer who now works at the Huntington Y.M.C.A.

headline: Swimming With Devils in the Deep
text: Kate Mathieson, Halle Berry’s character in the maritime adventure film “Dark Tide,” is a so-called shark whisperer. She is the rare individual with the courage, stamina and intuition to communicate with great white sharks well enough to be able to touch their snouts and even safely swim beside them.

headline: New Intensity, and Better Numbers, for Carmelo Anthony
text: Carmelo Anthony’s recent admission that the new coach Mike Woodson had succeeded in coaxing an admittedly dormant “energy” out of him  – particularly on the defensive end – raised eyebrows and ire in equal measure. Those certain that Mike D’Antoni’s sudden resignation pointed to a mutiny by Anthony finally, it seemed, had proof.

headline: What Do You Think the BRICS Can Build?
text: The leaders of Brazil, Russia, India, China and South Africa announced on Thursday that they would investigate establishing a system that would allow them to bypass the dollar and other global currencies when trading among themselves.

headline: Older Women Struggle to Make Ends Meet
text: The United States is aging, and a new report from Wider Opportunities for Women sheds some light on what that may mean and underscores the importance of saving for retirement.

headline: Another Good Day for I.P.O.’s as Millennial Media Nearly Doubles
text: The market for initial public stock offerings is riding high as another company has soared in its first day of trading.

headline: A Building as a Catalyst for Jewish Culture
text: WITH 110 units priced from $435,000 to over $1 million, the new condominium development at 371 Madison Street, in the long-dormant former Public School 12, is bound to make an impact on its quiet corner of the Lower East Side when sales start this spring.

headline: Stuck in a Roundabout on the Way to London
text: London is not calling for the United States under-23 men’s national team.

headline: The Hemming In of the Singer Tower
text: Q Ernest Flagg’s Singer Building was crowded right from the start by the City Investing Building, erected almost simultaneously just feet away. Why didn’t Flagg push his tower a little farther back? ... Arnold Merriam, New Rochelle , N.Y.

headline: A Bill to Loosen Hedge Fund Marketing
text: Investors may soon get a keyhole view into the cloistered world of hedge funds and private equity firms, thanks to a little-known provision in a new bill that would relax rules on how investment firms can market themselves to the public.

headline: A Good Kitchen, on a First-Home Budget
text: FOR four years, Vani Mehra had a pleasant roommate situation, sharing a large one-bedroom with two others. The two additional bedrooms, including hers, were created from temporary walls sectioning off the living room.

headline: No Need to Hide the Scary Spreadsheet
text: Ross Ramsey, the managing editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

headline: The Gated Community Mentality
text: AS a black man who has been mugged at gunpoint by a black teenager late at night, I am not naïve: I know firsthand the awkward conundrums surrounding race, fear and crime. Trayvon Martin’s killing at the hands of George Zimmerman baffles this nation. While the youth’s supporters declare in solidarity “We are all Trayvon,” the question is raised, to what extent is the United States also all George Zimmerman?

headline: In the Broadcast Booth, Hearing Her Late Husband’s Voice
text: RANCHO MIRAGE, Calif. – The voice in her ear told Judy Rankin it was time to return to the broadcast booth. It belonged not to any producer or director but to her husband, Walter, who died last month after an extended illness at the age of 71.

headline: Outraged by Fatal Assault on Young Woman, Ukrainians Force an Investigation
text: MOSCOW — The crime was shocking enough: an 18-year-old woman gang-raped, half strangled, set on fire and left for dead. But what sent hundreds of Ukrainians into the streets and rushing to her hospital to give blood this month was a police decision to free two suspects rumored to be politically connected.

headline: Key Official Would Trim N.Y.U. Plan to Expand
text: New York University is having a hard time selling its ambitious plan to expand its Greenwich Village campus to Scott M. Stringer, the Manhattan borough president, who is expected in the next two weeks to make a pivotal recommendation on the project’s future.

headline: Insight Into Louisville’s Pitino
text: NEW ORLEANS — As Rick Pitino readies Louisville for a national semifinal against heavily-favored Kentucky on Saturday, his closest coaching confidant, Ralph Willard, provided some insight into Pitino, his methods and his potential Hall of Fame induction this weekend.

headline: Philadelphia Newspapers Set to Be Sold to Local Leaders
text: A consortium of local business and political leaders is poised to purchase the Philadelphia Media Network, publisher of The Inquirer, The Daily News and Philly.com, according to several people familiar with the negotiations.

headline: Yankees Still Aren’t Certain About Rotation
text: TAMPA, Fla. — The Yankees are in the final week of spring training and are inching closer to a decision on the five pitchers who will comprise their starting rotation. But according to Manager Joe Girardi, the decision has not been made yet.

headline: Proudly Isolated Texas Power Grid Reaches Out a Bit
text: Last summer, when the brutal heat strained Texas’ electric grid and increased worries about blackouts, the grid imported a modest amount of power from Mexico and elsewhere in the United States.

headline: Supreme Court May Be Most Conservative in Modern History
text: If President Obama’s health care bill is stricken by the Supreme Court, liberals will take it as evidence of judicial overreach, or at least that the court has shifted far to the right. One statistical method for analyzing the Supreme Court, in fact, already finds that the current court is the most conservative since at least the 1930s.

headline: Burning Man’s Cry for Help
text: LOTS of people think that going to Burning Man for the art is like reading Playboy for the articles.

headline: For Renewed Wright, Sport Is a Game Again
text: RANCHO MIRAGE, Calif. — Lindsey Wright was buoyant Thursday after an opening-round five-under-par 67 brought her one step closer to the water’s edge of Poppie’s Pond, the hazard that beckons the winner of the Kraft Nabisco Championship.

headline: Netting Tiny Eels and Big Profits
text: The next two months will bring sleepless nights and high anxiety — and quite possibly an extraordinary windfall — for a small universe of people in Maine. They are the lucky few with licenses to catch elvers — young, tiny eels that look like cellophane noodles and by some accounts are fetching up to $2,200 per pound this spring.

headline: Home-Court Advantage Suits Sharapova
text: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla. — Long before Maria Sharapova won Wimbledon at age 17 to become a star in women’s tennis, she dreamed of winning the Sony Ericsson Open.

headline: Broccoli and Bad Faith
text: Nobody knows what the Supreme Court will decide with regard to the Affordable Care Act. But, after this week’s hearings, it seems quite possible that the court will strike down the “mandate” — the requirement that individuals purchase health insurance — and maybe the whole law. Removing the mandate would make the law much less workable, while striking down the whole thing would mean denying health coverage to 30 million or more Americans.

headline: Profile, Always High, Keeps Current Too
text: IT was sometime in the mid-1980s, Carol Peligian recalls, that she told her broker not to telephone her until she’d found her an apartment among the run-down, sparsely populated commercial blocks of Fifth Avenue between 14th and 23rd Streets. The broker’s response was succinct: “You’re out of your mind.”

headline: Living In | The Flatiron District
text: A wave of conversions has added over 1,000 housing units in the last decade.

headline: State Court Allows False-Confession Experts, but Bar Is High
text: ALBANY — New York’s highest court said for the first time on Thursday that expert testimony about false confessions should be allowed at trial if it is relevant to the facts of a case.

headline: Neighborhood Bookies Putting Lines Online
text: The local street bookie — whose illegal business for decades relied on little more than phones, pencils, notebooks and a burly goon to break the occasional leg — has finally been seduced by the modern conveniences of the Internet.

headline: House Passes G.O.P. Budget Plan, Mostly Along Party Lines
text: WASHINGTON — A fierce two-day debate over a Republican budget plan portrayed as either a path to prosperity or a road to ruin ended Thursday with House passage of a blueprint that would transform Medicare, cut domestic spending to levels not seen since World War II and order up a drastic overhaul of the tax code.

headline: Neighborhood Joint | King David Kosher Restaurant
text: For a Bukharian Jew, the festive eatery in Queens is a place not just for weddings and bar mitzvahs, but also for baby showers and first birthdays.

headline: A List of Labor Concerns at Foxconn
text: A list of labor concerns at Foxconn.

headline: Here to There, It All Hinges on One Person
text: No, the spokeswoman said, Pedro Espada Jr. is not currently serving as president of the Soundview Health Care Network that he set up in the Bronx more than 30 years ago.

headline: Charles de Gaulle Airport Hopes to Win Traffic With Smiles and Shorter Lines
text: PARIS — Charles de Gaulle is the second-largest European airport in terms of passengers — 61 million last year — and the seventh-largest worldwide. Yet it doesn’t get much love.

headline: On the Market in New York City
text: A two-bedroom Chelsea co-op and an Upper West Side two-bedroom.

headline: On the Market in the Region
text: A Mount Vernon colonial, a New Canaan co-op and a North Syosset colonial.

headline: ‘Low-Major Guy’ Hits Biggest Stage
text: NEW ORLEANS — Thad and Barb Matta were married in August on a sweltering Thursday evening in North Carolina, 11 days after their engagement. Barb bought a dress in Asheville, ordered a small white cake and planned a reception for a handful of family and friends in their $200-a-month faculty housing apartment.

headline: Nature-Deficit Disorder
text: TUCSON — Your day breaks, your mind aches for something stimulating to match the stirrings of the season. The gate at the urban edge is open, here to the Santa Catalina Mountains, and yet you turn inward, to pixels and particle-board vistas.

headline: A Place to Celebrate Bukharian Life
text: ANYONE stepping from the roar of Queens Boulevard into the din of the King David Kosher Restaurant one recent Tuesday evening could have been forgiven for thinking that he or she had just gate-crashed a wedding.

headline: Tied Together in Aisle 5: Country Acts and a Cause
text: MARKETERS working for record labels once commonly used in-store promotions, including advertisements near record bins and stand-alone product displays with cardboard cutouts of musicians.

headline: Jockey Club Proposes Ban on Race-Day Drugs
text: The Jockey Club, among the most influential groups in horse racing, on Friday will propose a ban on the use of drugs for horses on race day, along with stiff penalties, including a lifetime ban for repeat offenders.

headline: A Moderate Conservative Dilemma
text: Nathan Fletcher was raised in Arkansas, played college baseball in California and enlisted in the Marines as a reserve in 1997. He saw combat in 2004, based in the Sunni Triangle in Iraq.

headline: In Canada, the Lowly Penny’s Time to Shine Nears an End
text: OTTAWA — Jim Flaherty, the finance minister of Canada, pronounced a death sentence on the country’s penny during his budget speech on Thursday.

headline: Selling Condos? It’s Child’s Play
text: THE McDonald’s Happy Meal, which upended fast-food dining when it was first rolled out nationally in 1979, was a brilliantly simple concept: add a toy with some marketing tie-in to a colorful box with a burger, fries, a soft drink and cookies, and make children harass their parents until they steered for the double arches.

headline: Three Major Banks Prepare for Possible Credit Downgrades
text: Some of Wall Street’s biggest banks are bracing for fallout from a possible cut in their credit ratings.

headline: A Strategy to Vote Dead Shares
text: There was an old joke in which a man said that when he died he hoped to be buried in Chicago, so that he could continue to vote.

headline: NATO’s Duty
text: Tragic mistakes all too often accompany combat operations, even when the military objectives are humanitarian. That is what seems to have happened in the Libyan farming village of Majer last August. Amid the confusion of a rebel advance and a retreat by Qaddafi loyalists, successive NATO bomb runs there killed at least 34 Libyan civilians, including women and small children, according to journalists, human rights organizations and United Nations investigators.

headline: A Cruel Budget
text: In February, after embarrassing himself by saying he was “not concerned about the very poor,” Mitt Romney explained that the government’s safety net would take care of them, and he promised to repair any holes in the net. That promise didn’t last very long. On Thursday, House Republicans approved, on a party-line vote, a disastrous new budget that would leave millions of struggling families desperate for food, shelter and health care — and Mr. Romney has embraced it.

headline: With Tablet Plan, Google Goes After Apple and Amazon
text: Google’s long-awaited tablet might finally be on the way to becoming a reality. For at least two years, there have been reports that the search giant was working on something that could compete with Apple’s iPad. A Google employee briefed on the project now says it will be out later this year. The employee declined to be named because the product has not been announced.

headline: Q & A
text: When a Subtenant Brings in a Roommate

headline: Woodson a Reflection of His Famed Mentors
text: Eighteen summers ago, Mike Woodson was lured to Phoenix with the promise of brilliant blue skies, lush green fairways and a bottomless bucket of bright-white Titleists. He landed in a gymnasium, with a whistle in his mouth and a roster of N.B.A. rookies.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: March 29, 2012

headline: The Fatal Flaw in Florida-Style Gun Laws
text: As the investigation of the shooting death of the teenager Trayvon Martin by a self-appointed neighborhood watchman goes forward in Florida, news accounts are reporting a toll of shootings, knifings and other violent homicides in which the state’s dangerous Stand Your Ground law was successfully claimed as a defense.

headline: Pasadena Police Arrest 911 Caller After Unarmed Suspect Is Killed
text: LOS ANGELES — On a 911 call to the Pasadena police Saturday night, the caller said two young black men had put a gun in his face and had stolen his backpack.

headline: Combating Age Discrimination
text: In a 2009 ruling, the Supreme Court disregarded longstanding legal precedent and made it much harder for older workers who are victims of age discrimination to win in court. The 5-to-4 decision shifted the burden of proof under the federal Age Discrimination in Employment Act so that older workers have to show their age was the deciding factor in an adverse employment decision — an unfairly hard standard to meet. Previously, if a worker had showed that age bias was one of the factors in a dismissal or demotion, the employer would then have to demonstrate that it had acted for valid and nondiscriminatory reasons.

headline: BRICS Leaders Fail to Create Rival to World Bank
text: NEW DELHI — Leaders of five emerging world economic powers convened on Thursday for a one-day diplomatic meeting, pledging to expand mutual trade while urging faster reforms of the Western-dominated global financial system. They also called for dialogue, not military intervention, in addressing the violence in Syria and Iran’s disputed nuclear ambitions.

headline: In Hollywood, an ’80s Moment
text: LOS ANGELES — “21 Jump Street” is a hit. “RoboCop” and “Dirty Dancing” are on the way. Arnold Schwarzenegger is juggling a bunch of action flicks.

headline: Quinn Exempts Part of Hudson Yards From Living-Wage Bill
text: Christine C. Quinn, the City Council speaker, already facing skepticism over her handling of legislation that would raise wages for some private-sector workers, has decided to add an exemption for one of New York’s biggest pending developments, Hudson Yards.

headline: Louisville Roommates Have One Thing in Common: Winning
text: NEW ORLEANS — The most unlikely roommates in college basketball did not arrive at Louisville just from different cities. These sophomores came from different continents. In regard to size, personality, position, playing style, sleeping habits, musical taste and room décor, they might as well be from different planets.

headline: Romney Supporters Yearning for the Personal Side
text: YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio — The voters were pleading with Mitt Romney to share personal details of his life. They stood at town-hall-style meetings and chatted before rallies, clamoring for a story or an anecdote that would help them connect with the real Mitt Romney.

headline: Urchins With Punctuation
text: Since our subject today is newspapers and the people who hawk them, I’m going to ask you to try to imagine a special kind of supertabloid. It would consist of nothing but headlines, all set in extra-large type, all goal-posted with exclamation points and all proclaiming essentially the same thing.

headline: Rather Colloquial
text: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — A tough one, but with enough new stuff and fun wordplay to make me smile. I really enjoyed this Friday fare from Joe Krozel.

headline: Muddying of Beloved Creek Is Last Straw for Neighbors of a City Reservoir
text: SAUGERTIES, N.Y. — For years, the resentment simmered as residents of Ulster County endured development bans, flooded basements and ruined crops, all for the sake of protecting New York City’s water supply.

headline: Amid Jelly Beans, Santorum Wraps Himself in Mantle of Reagan
text: FAIRFIELD, Calif. – Rick Santorum asked cheering supporters on Thursday to “help me out here in the next few weeks,” and to “help us build a great organization in California.”

headline: Remembering Earl Scruggs
text: Earl Scruggs, the virtuoso banjo player, died on March 28 at the age of 88. Musicians, including Steve Martin, celebrated his legacy by playing his signature songs.

headline: Bay Looking Inward, Searching for Stroke
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — There is a popular image of Jason Bay as a lost soul, a man untethered from his true self.

headline: China’s Hierarchy Strives to Regain Unity After Chongqing Leader’s Ouster
text: BEIJING — China’s top leaders are retaking the initiative after the country’s worst political crisis in a generation, showcasing a united front and moving forward with plans for a major leadership reshuffle later this year.

headline: In Number of Questions Asked, Hints on the Court’s Views
text: Studies have found that justices tend to ask more questions of the lawyers whose positions they oppose. During arguments this week over three questions on the health care law, like-minded justices tended to focus their questions on the same lawyers.

headline: Stanford’s Resurgence Culminates in a Title
text: With the football team commanding the athletic spotlight on Stanford’s campus, it’s easy to forget that the basketball program was not long ago the perennial powerhouse in Palo Alto, Calif.

headline: Iran Suspends Reuters Over Faulty Headline
text: After being wrongly maligned as “assassins” in a Reuters news report last month, female ninjas in Iran may have found the pen momentarily mightier than the sword. But as Reuters discovered after correcting the report, the heavy hand of government can be even stronger in Iran.

headline: Bloggers Cherry-Pick From Social Media to Cast Trayvon Martin as a Menace
text: Last Updated | Friday | 5:19 p.m. For the second time in a week, a conservative blog has published excerpts from what it described as a Twitter feed maintained by Trayvon Martin, the Florida teenager who was shot and killed last month by a neighborhood watch volunteer patrolling a gated community.

headline: Brazil’s Racial Identity Challenge
text: Would this South American nation benefit from U.S.-style affirmative action?

headline: Six Sellers, Eight Dishwashers
text: Prewar apartments listed for sale in Manhattan, each of which has at least one dishwasher:

headline: Give the Sink a Break
text: AMONG the indignities that one may suffer when renting a Manhattan apartment — too little space for too much money, dismal natural light, tiresome flights of stairs, creepy neighbors — the lack of a dishwasher is high on many lists.

headline: Case Based in China Puts a Face on Persistent Hacking
text: SAN FRANCISCO — A breach of computers belonging to companies in Japan and India and to Tibetan activists has been linked to a former graduate student at a Chinese university — putting a face on the persistent espionage by Chinese hackers against foreign companies and groups.

headline: Williams Auction to Be Held at Fenway
text: For nearly 10 years since her father’s death, Claudia Williams has contemplated how and when to sell his collection of memorabilia and personal items.

headline: In Hiding, Bin Laden Had Four Children and Five Houses
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Osama bin Laden spent nine years on the run in Pakistan after the Sept. 11 attacks, during which time he moved among five safe houses and fathered four children, at least two of whom were born in a government hospital, his youngest wife has told Pakistani investigators.

headline: Corrections: March 30
text: BUSINESS DAY

headline: In Rural China, a Preserved Dynastic Village
text: Tourism companies are trying to preserve the lavish villas built by merchants of the dynastic era across the Huizhou region of China.

headline: In Rural China, Temples to Past Merchant Wealth Endure
text: XIDI, China — In the spring, as rapeseed flowers bloom, this fertile swath of central China is transformed into a sea of yellow. In the summer, when rainstorms descend, the fields pulsate emerald green and canals brim with brown water.

headline: Albuquerque Police Union to End Officer Payments
text: Under pressure over its policy of paying officers involved in shootings, the Albuquerque Police Officers’ Association said Thursday that it was ending the practice.

headline: She Lets Her Sexuality Loose, and the Phone Bills Mount
text: Our first glimpse of Alma (Helene Bergsholm), the hormonal 15-year-old heroine of “Turn Me On, Dammit!,” is from above, as she masturbates ecstatically on her living-room floor. In her ear, the chipper voice of a phone-sex worker eggs her on — Alma is one of his regulars at Wild Wet Dreams — while the family dog watches impassively.

headline: Tale of Card Reflects the Knicks’ Season
text: Yair Rozmaryn watched Jeremy Lin in his 25-point breakout game against the Nets in early February and was excited, and intrigued, by what he saw.

headline: Large Hedge Funds Fared Well in 2011
text: Hedge funds have endured a rough year. Tumultuous markets. Tighter regulations. An insider trading crackdown.

headline: Strung Out and Baked in Veracruz
text: Slow, deliberate and art house ready, “Paraísos Artificiales” (“Artificial Paradises”), the first feature by the Mexican director Yulene Olaizola, teeters between the dreamy and the soporific. The dreamy part makes sense. The title comes from Baudelaire’s book about the effects of intoxicants (hashish, opium, wine) on the mind, and drugs are the artificial paradises indulged in by Luisa and Salomón, the main characters in Ms. Olaizola’s film. The soporific part is a problem.

headline: Merger With Investigative Unit Likely to Mean Major Shift in Bay Citizen Coverage
text: As the journalism world looks to the nonprofit model for salvation in these challenging times for the industry, one of the oldest journalism nonprofits, the Center for Investigative Reporting, announced Tuesday that it would merge with one of the newest, The Bay Citizen.

headline: You Can’t Always Clone What You Want
text: No amount of therapy could fix the central characters in “Womb,” a morally ripe science-fiction tale remodeled as shockingly inert love story. If the 20-odd seconds of blank screen squatting pointlessly amid the opening credits aren’t enough warning that you’re in for some seriously sluggish storytelling, then the adoption of a snail as one of the central motifs should drive the point home.

headline: An Old Utopian Makes a Comeback, Domes and All
text: In the winter of 1975, R. Buckminster Fuller made a movie called “Everything I Know.” Over a two-week period, a crew filmed him sitting in a chair, speaking extemporaneously to the camera about anticipatory design, the geometry of the universe and his invention of the geodesic dome. By the time he had finished talking, the film was 42 hours.

headline: Young Is Paired With Old, and Slap Downs Ensue
text: The Grammy people are really taking their honor-thy-father-and-mother mission seriously these days. In February the Grammy Awards broadcast was peppered with performances that paired people like Glen Campbell and the Beach Boys with younger stars, and now the organization is pushing “Re:Generation Music Project,” a documentary by Amir Bar-Lev in which five D.J.’s were assigned unlikely partners, most of them several generations older, and ordered to make music.

headline: Toulouse Killer’s Path to Radicalism a Bitter Puzzle
text: TOULOUSE, France — During the long standoff that ultimately ended his life, a boastful Mohammed Merah told law enforcement officials that he had been trained by Al Qaeda. He described being driven to kill his seven victims in a shooting rampage that terrorized this city by his resentment over the fate of the Palestinians, and France’s military presence in Afghanistan and ban on the full Muslim veil.

headline: Berkeley Police Chief at Center of Free Speech Furor
text: On Tuesday, minutes after the end of a Berkeley Police Department promotion ceremony, reporters rushed over to interview Chief Michael Meehan.

headline: Fisherman Off to a Mission in the Underworld
text: Hey, Perseus! You’ve just dispatched Medusa, a horde of Furies and the dreaded Kraken, and rescued Andromeda and the city of Argos. Where are you off to now? Fishing?

headline: Auld Times
text: “City of Bohane,” the extraordinary first novel by the Irish writer Kevin Barry, is full of marvels. They are all literary marvels, of course: marvels of language, invention, surprise. Savage brutality is here, but so is laughter. And humanity. And the abiding ache of tragedy.

headline: ‘American Idol’ Recap: Heejun Han Is Cut From Top 9
text: Heejun Han, the loveable goofball from Queens, was voted off “American Idol” on Fox on Thursday night, after a week in which several of the remaining nine contestants gave strong performances and received standing ovations from the judges.

headline: A Death, a Conviction, and a Disputed Confession
text: “Scenes of a Crime” is a critical exploration of modern interrogation, specifically the Reid Technique, shown in a police training video, whose goal is to extract a confession using sophisticated psychological manipulation. Although the technique is far from the much rougher, old-fashioned method known as the third degree, which involved physical torture, its use still raises questions about what constitutes coercion.

headline: Photo Replay: March 29
text: A view of the day in sports, including Europa League quarterfinal matches across Europe and the N.I.T. men’s basketball championship at Madison Square Garden.

headline: What’s Landing Next at Charles de Gaulle
text: PARIS — Yesterday I wrote about the stiffening competition Charles de Gaulle and its operator, Aéroports de Paris, face from airports undergoing billion-euro facelifts. And I noted that Charles de Gaulle gets little love from international travelers.

headline: Suppress the Vote!
text: The grip of the super PAC on the Republican primary season has been well-documented. They are wrecking balls operating outside the candidates’ direct control, fueled by massive influxes of cash from a handful of wealthy patrons. The millions spent by the pro-Santorum Red, White and Blue Fund and the pro-Gingrich super PAC, Winning Our Future, have prolonged their respective candidates’ rivalry with the front-runner, Mitt Romney, whose own Restore Our Future has bludgeoned the competition from Iowa to Florida to Michigan.

headline: Trying to Prepare for the Toughest of Jobs
text: Inspector Ken Esposto is looking forward to retirement after 31 years on the San Francisco police force. He has spent the past seven of them working mostly by himself, staring at a computer screen in a closed room. Earlier this month he began training his replacement, Officer Andrea Weyl, an energetic 33-year-old who is willing to trade the excitement of chasing criminals on the street for Mr. Esposto’s lonely work.

headline: A Paris Boardinghouse Only a Beatnik Could Love
text: A well-worn stop on the timeline of American postwar culture, the Beats haven’t wanted for attention and citation by admirers of their work (or their play). The arts documentarian Alan Govenar takes his turn at burnishing the legend with “The Beat Hotel,” a mild-mannered primer centered on the cheapo Paris boardinghouse that was expat headquarters for Allen Ginsberg, William S. Burroughs, Gregory Corso and others who dug that establishment’s low rents and high tolerance.

headline: Word of the Day | laud
text: laud •\ˈlȯd\• verb

headline: All-Consuming Love Affair With Their Louboutins
text: Watching “God Save My Shoes,” Julie Benasra’s blithely blinkered documentary, is like gorging on empty calories: flavorful, diverting and with a slightly nauseating aftertaste.

headline: Sex and the City, From Hong Kong to Beijing
text: There’s charm aplenty in Pang Ho-Cheung’s “Love in the Buff,” a romantic comedy that is as interesting for its glimpse into contemporary urban China as it is for the charisma of its leads. A sequel to his “Love in a Puff,” from 2010, “Buff” follows a 30-ish Hong Kong couple, Cherie (Miriam Yeung) and Jimmy (Shawn Yue), as they struggle to maintain their bond, first as live-in lovers and then while seeing others in Beijing.

headline: U.S. and China Press for Influence in Myanmar
text: HSIPAW, Myanmar — As Chinese workers in hard hats and red overalls bulldoze deep trenches into the orange soil across northern Myanmar for gas and oil pipelines to China, China’s largest energy conglomerate is paying cash for land and trees in the pipelines’ path, and building schools and health clinics for some of the poorest people on earth.

headline: China’s Influence at Stake as Myanmar Eyes Democracy
text: As Myanmar loosens the grip of military dictatorship and improves ties with the United States, China fears a threat to its strategic partnership that offers access to the Indian Ocean.

headline: NYT Front Page for 03/30/2012
text: NYT Front Page for 03/30/2012

headline: GTT ★
text: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

headline: George Zimmerman’s Brother Defends Trayvon Martin Shooting as New Video Is Released
text: In an interview Thursday night on CNN’s “Piers Morgan Tonight,” George Zimmerman’s brother, Robert Zimmerman Jr., addressed the accusations against his brother of racial bias and unwarranted violence in the killing of Trayvon Martin, 17, last month, calling his brother “the neighbor that everybody would want to have.”

headline: Harry Crews, Writer of Dark Fiction, Is Dead at 76
text: Harry Crews, whose novels out-Gothic Southern Gothic by conjuring a world of hard-drinking, punch-throwing, snake-oil-selling characters whose physical, mental, social and sexual deviations render them somehow entirely normal and eminently sympathetic, died on Wednesday at his home in Gainesville, Fla. He was 76.

headline: Warren Stevens, Busy Character Actor, Dies at 92
text: Warren Stevens, a lanky, square-jawed actor with swept-back hair and a husky voice whose face became familiar through his more than 100 roles on television and in movies over six decades, died on Tuesday at his home in Sherman Oaks, Calif. He was 92.

headline: Chinese Grad Student Hacks Indian Military Research Firms
text: India’s military preparedness and the possibility of defense breaches has dominated the news after Army chief V.K.. Singh’s letter to Prime Minister Manmohan Singh surfaced recently calling India’s weapons “obsolete.”

headline: Tunisia: U.S. Offers Financial Assistance
text: The United States announced on Thursday that it would provide Tunisia a $100 million cash infusion to pay its debts to the World Bank and other international banks. Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton said that the assistance would allow Tunisia to spend its resources instead on economic development and jobs. A senior administration official said that improving Tunisia’s struggling economy was crucial to cementing the country’s transition toward democracy.

headline: El Salvador: Church Role in Gang Truce
text: A truce among gangs that has led to a precipitous drop in homicides this month was the result of mediation by the Roman Catholic Church and not a pact with the government, President Mauricio Funes said this week. Mr. Funes did say the government supported the church’s efforts and transferred 30 gang leaders from a maximum-security prison to lower-security jails to facilitate the gangs’ efforts to call a cease-fire. It was the latest of several explanations the government has offered for the transfer.

headline: In Health Case, Appeals to a Justice’s Idea of Liberty
text: WASHINGTON — The way to frame a Supreme Court argument meant to persuade Justice Anthony M. Kennedy is to talk about liberty. It is his touchstone and guiding principle, and his conception of liberty is likely to determine the future of President Obama’s health care law.

headline: News Quiz | March 30, 2012
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries in today’s newspaper.

headline: French Police Seize 17 in Raids After Killings in Toulouse
text: PARIS — Eight days after the police shot dead the self-confessed killer of four Jews and three French paratroopers in Toulouse, the French police on Friday detained 17 people described as Islamic militants in that city and other parts of France.

headline: Japan Readies in Case Rocket From North Korea Poses Risk
text: TOKYO — Japan is deploying guided-missile destroyers and antiaircraft batteries with orders to shoot down a North Korean rocket if it falls toward Japanese territory, Japan’s defense minister said Friday.

headline: South Asian Talent Showcase at ‘SubDrift’
text: A Nigerian rapper, a braces-wearing would-be Whitney Houston, and an Indian-American psychiatrist/stand-up comedian walked into a bar one Friday night.

headline: March 30, 1981 | President Reagan Is Shot
text: On March 30, 1981, President Ronald Reagan was shot and seriously injured outside a Washington hotel by John W. Hinckley Jr. Also wounded were the White House news secretary James Brady, who was left paralyzed by the shooting, a Secret Service agent and a District of Columbia police officer.

headline: Test Yourself | English, March 30, 2012
text: This question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article “The Officiant Among Us.”

headline: What Science Suggests About ‘Weather Weirding’
text: HOW has this March been a good example of “weather weirding”?

headline: With Images of Rare Diseases, a Hope to Spur Action
text: My head turned when I saw the poster.

headline: What Movies, Shows or Books Do You Wish Had Sequels, Spinoffs or New Episodes?
text: Will Ferrell has announced that an “Anchorman” sequel is in the works, Pauly D of MTV’s “Jersey Shore” has a spinoff reality show that began Thursday night, and “Star Trek” fans are hoping that a forgotten, unused script  will soon be produced. What movies, television shows or books have you loved so much that you wish they could continue in some way? How — whether through a sequel, spin-off, or missing chapter, episode or scene — would you bring the story or characters back?

headline: Pain Persists Among Europe’s Ailing Economies
text: LONDON — For anyone tempted to think that the ailing economies of Europe are over the worst, there were fresh indications in recent days that the pain would continue for a while yet.

headline: For BRICS, Bouquets and Brickbats
text: Whether the BRICS meeting in New Delhi Thursday was a massive triumph or a disappointment seems to depend a bit on who you ask.

headline: U.S. Envoy to Russia Accuses TV Station of Spying on Him
text: MOSCOW — The State Department on Friday formally expressed concern to the Russian Federation about the security of its ambassador to Moscow, Michael A. McFaul, who has complained that crews from state-controlled television have gained access to his schedule by hacking his e-mail or his phones.

headline: Disagreements Among Syrian Rebels Over Foreign Arms Shipments
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Just days before a major international meeting on how to aid Syria’s rebels, the country’s fractious opposition movement continued to bicker, most notably about a crucial question to be considered at the gathering: whether to provide arms to the rebel fighters.

headline: Fantasy Focus: Predictions for 2012
text: Hanley Ramirez Is a Top-Three Fantasy Player

headline: Light Blue Skies Ahead for Glasgow Rangers
text: GLASGOW — In the 140 years of Glasgow Rangers’ history, the past six weeks have arguably been the most turbulent, as the defending champions in Scotland’s Premier League faced the prospect of ceasing operations as the club went into administration (the British form of bankruptcy) because of financial mismanagement.

headline: Tibetan Protests in Delhi
text: When Jampa Yeshi doused himself in gasoline and lit a match, he became one of around 30 Tibetans who chose self-immolation as a form of protest over the past year. What set Yeshi apart is that he set himself alight in New Delhi, days before President Hu Jintao of China was scheduled to arrive in India. The image traveled the world. Eager to avoid embarrassing its guest, India’s security forces cracked down on potential protesters.Meanwhile, the rest of the world seems indifferent. “One self-immolation in Tunisia shocked the world and triggered the Arab spring,” writes Isabel Hilton in the Guardian. “Thirty self-immolations in Tibet have received little international attention.”

headline: Scouting the Draft: Michigan State’s Jerel Worthy
text: Jonathan Bales is the founder of TheDCTimes.com and will help analyze draft prospects for The Fifth Down in his Scouting the Draft preview series.

headline: Walking the Talk: Automakers’ Employees Champion Energy Efficiency at Work and at Home
text: Car companies have phalanxes of assembly workers, engineers, marketers and lawyers working to speed the adoption of energy-efficient vehicles. For some of these employees, the work of minimizing environmental impacts follows them home.

headline: The Early Word: Kennedy
text: In Today’s Times:

headline: The Supreme Court and the National Conversation on Health Care Reform
text: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton. He has some financial interests in the health care field.

headline: Who Died and Made You Pope?
text: THE Vatican is often portrayed as a hotbed of power politics and ecclesiastical intrigue. But does anybody really want to be pope? Following the most recent papal conclave, in 2005, it was reported that Benedict XVI had prayed that he wouldn’t be chosen. Back in the 1950s, when the future Pope John XXIII was the patriarch of Venice, he wrote to his sister, “Who wants to be more than a cardinal?” And few have made their aversion more apparent than Celestine V, the hermit-monk elected in 1294 by a deadlocked College of Cardinals.

headline: Questioned by a Coach, an Owner Rethinks Her Manufacturing Issues
text: In my last post, Susan Martin, a business coach, pressed Alexandra Mayzler to articulate her vision for her company, Thinking Caps Tutoring. Ms. Mayzler was clear that she wanted to see a “revolution in education” that elevated the importance of study skills. She was less clear, however, about what role her company might play in this revolution.

headline: Puberty Before Age 10: A New ‘Normal’?
text: One day last year when her daughter, Ainsley, was 9, Tracee Sioux pulled her out of her elementary school in Fort Collins, Colo., and drove her an hour south, to Longmont, in hopes of finding a satisfying reason that Ainsley began growing pubic hair at age 6. Ainsley was the tallest child in her third-grade class. She had a thick, enviable blond-streaked ponytail and big feet, like a puppy’s. The curves of her Levi’s matched her mother’s.

headline: Violence, ‘Mad Men’ and Football
text: Links for your consideration, amid the biggest off-season in N.F.L. history:

headline: Making Sense of the Wacky Weather
text: Like many people, I’ve been struggling to understand what is going on with the weather. As I flipped on my air conditioner one day in the middle of March to cool down an unbearably hot apartment, I thought, this is just weird. In recent years, we have lived through one weather extreme after another, sometimes whipsawing between them rather quickly.

headline: Europe Agrees to Bailout Fund for Euro of Over $1 Trillion
text: COPENHAGEN — Seeking to reaffirm their determination to put the two-year-old euro crisis behind them, European finance ministers agreed Friday to create a permanent bailout fund for the euro zone with an effective firepower of almost €800 billion.

headline: “Hi, Diane Keaton!”
text: “Everything I do is in the moment,” says Tierney Gearon, the photographer whose work appears in this week’s Look column. She came up with the idea for the colored-shapes project — which she hopes to turn into book — when she observed her son Walker place a clear plastic filing bin over her baby daughter Grace. (It sounds dangerous, but it was charming.)

headline: Militia Member Drugs and Kills Afghan Colleagues
text: KHOST, Afghanistan — A member of a militia promoted by the American military to protect rural villages drugged his Afghan colleagues and killed at least nine of them as they slept on Friday, a police official said, in the third deadly episode involving the irregular guard force in March.

headline: Paul Ryan Endorses Romney for President
text: GREEN BAY, Wis. — Representative Paul D. Ryan of Wisconsin on Friday endorsed the presidential candidacy of Mitt Romney, saying Republicans do not have the luxury of waiting until the party’s convention this summer to rally behind a nominee and start confronting President Obama.

headline: Sound Garden
text: A man who makes films about people who never stop moving would seem unlikely to set down roots. Yet the artist Doug Aitken has built himself a house in Venice, Calif., that is too much fun to leave — even to go to the nearby studio where he created “Black Mirror,” his film project with Chloë Sevigny as a nomad who spends her days checking into and out of anonymous motels.

headline: Humanity’s Discomfort, Punctured With a Pen
text: Oakland, Calif.

headline: Chickpea Nostalgia
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Doug Aitken’s Acid Modernism
text: The artist Doug Aitken’s house, a block away from the Pacific Ocean, is in tune with its surroundings in more ways than one. In an exclusive video, Aitken, with the help of his girlfriend Gemma Ponsa and a few of their friends, activate its more hidden charms, revealing that it’s a house that sounds as cool as it looks. More…
