headline: Friday Reading: Two-Year College to Charge More for Top Classes
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them togjobless benefitsether here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: Sealy’s Governance Attacked by Second Investor
text: The mattress maker Sealy faced another round of investor criticism over its corporate governance on Friday for appearing to allow Kohlberg Kravis Roberts to wield deep influence over its board.

headline: Reporter Q. and A. on the Health Care Arguments
text: On The Times’s Facebook page on Thursday, Adam Liptak, the newspaper’s Supreme Court correspondent, and Reed Abelson, a reporter covering health care for the Business Day section, hosted a discussion with readers about the legal battle over the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act. Below is a transcript of highlights from the question-and-answer session.

headline: Oaktree I.P.O. May Raise Up to $517.5 Million
text: The Oaktree Capital Group said Friday that it expected to price its initial public offering at $43 to $46 per stock unit, potentially raising up to $517.5 million in its market debut.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Foxconn Vows to Change, and an ’80s Rewind
text: Foxconn, the giant China-based electronics manufacturer that supplies products to Apple and others, pledged to sharply curtail working hours and significantly increase wages inside its factories after an investigation found widespread problems, Charles Duhigg and Steven Greenhouse reported. On Thursday, the Fair Labor Association, a monitoring group, issued a report detailing violations of Chinese laws and regulations, and numerous instances where Foxconn defied industry codes of conduct.

headline: Beyond the Meadow
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: How the White House Thinks It Can Bring Jobs Back to America
text: Call it the triumph of Rhineland capitalism. For decades, the Anglo-Saxon consensus has been that manufacturing was in decline and that its replacement by the service sector — as most glitteringly represented by finance — was both inevitable and welcome. Only dirigiste Europeans, the transatlantic conventional wisdom had it, thought the government could or should try to hang on to its industrial base.

headline: In Nod to Past, MTV Revives ‘Art Breaks’
text: In its never-ending quest to reach young viewers, MTV is going back to the past, and to a generation weaned on its early videos. The network announced Friday that it is reviving “Art Breaks,” a pioneering 1985 series that broadcast TV spots created by a vanguard of downtown artists.

headline: Wisconsin Primary Overshadowed by Recall
text: For most of this year, the arrival of the Republican presidential contest in town has quickly become the biggest political story of the day in those places.

headline: Fill-In | Olympic Mascots — and Mash-Ups
text: Directions: Fill in the blanks in this sports section article,  “Olympic Mascots Inspire Imitations.”

headline: Crankocracy
text: Timothy Noah makes an interesting point: at least so far, the most visible effect of the Citizens United decision has been not so much a flood of corporate cash into politics as a flood of cash from billionaire cranks into politics. Rich crackpots of the world, unite!

headline: Image of the Day: March 30
text: Tibetan exiles pay homage to self-immolator Jamphel Yeshi in Dharamsala, Himachal Pradesh, India.

headline: Compensation for Ford Chief Rose to $29.5 Million Last Year
text: DEARBORN, Mich. — Alan R. Mulally, the chief executive of the Ford Motor Company, received compensation for 2011 of $29.5 million, the most in his six years in the position, the automaker disclosed in a regulatory filing Friday.

headline: School Budget Picture Evolving
text: With conflicting budget figures rolling around, the city continues to insist: not to worry. Chancellor Dennis M. Walcott said Tuesday at a City Council hearing on the preliminary budget that he intended to protect schools from cuts and planned to keep the schools' budgets stable. If that is so, it means  principals -- who control their own budgets in New York City -- can avoid more of the painful cuts of this school year and maintain a similar level of service and staffing.

headline: We Don’t Need No Education
text: Jared Bernstein has a heartfelt lament about the priorities of the American right, and in particular the way it’s determined to slash taxes for the wealthy while slashing student aid. And he gives us this chart:

headline: On Our Radar: Cuts in German Solar Subsidies
text: Germany’s parliament approves deep cuts in subsidies for solar power. The government argues that the subsidies have driven up electricity prices for consumers while propping up photovoltaic panel prices for domestic manufacturers. [Bloomberg Businessweek]

headline: The Cartoonist’s Goal
text: The best-selling graphic novelist Daniel Clowes talks about his art.

headline: The FT Does Iceland
text: I think I was one of the first econopundits to point out that Iceland, the poster child for financial excess, was actually having a surprisingly non-catastrophic aftermath thanks to heterodox economic policies. I got many attacks over this observation, with the usual accusations of cherry-picked data and failure to understand the wonders of austerity in, say, Latvia.

headline: Morning Buzz, March 30: No More Synthetic Marijuana
text: Good morning. Today promises sunny skies and a high of 56 degrees. Prepare for rain tonight, though.

headline: After First-Quarter Rally, Prospect of a Slip Looms
text: Stocks shot out of the gate in 2012 to post their best first quarter in 14 years, but a familiar anxiety is creeping back into the markets.

headline: The Shape of Things
text: People and pets in Plexiglas boxes.

headline: Market Watch | Baselworld 2012
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Vice: Panic attacks, nausea, skin rashes — it’s bananaphobia! A chat with those who fear and loathe the elongated yellow fruit. — (Via Grub Street.) …

headline: Leading Off: The Great Final Four Debate
text: As you get ready for the weekend’s action, we’d like to welcome you officially to the one-and-done men’s Final Four. You can get started by wringing your hands earnestly, as everyone will in New Orleans while contemplating the scourge of college basketball. No, this is not a new issue and yes, college basketball has a long list of other scourges, but this one will take center stage because everyone recently noticed that Kentucky has become the fast-food stop of the college basketball world, its players not sticking around long enough for their fries to get cold, and Kentucky is the overwhelming favorite to win this national championship.

headline: The Rise of Mofaz
text: TEL AVIV — I live not far from Tzipi Livni’s home, and Wednesday morning, as I was driving in the neighborhood, photographers were laying on the street, awaiting the defeated politician to emerge and say something, anything, about her future plans.

headline: Daily Report: Hacking Attacks Are Linked to Man at Chinese Firm
text: A breach of computers belonging to companies in Japan and India and to Tibetan activists has been linked to a former graduate student at a Chinese university, Nicole Perlroth writes on Friday in The New York Times. The case puts a face on the persistent espionage by Chinese hackers against foreign companies and groups.

headline: In Europe, Starbucks Adjusts to a Cafe Culture
text: PARIS — On a recent sunny morning in this city’s chic Marais district, Marion Bayod squeezed behind a tiny table at Le Cactus, a neighborhood cafe she has frequented for years. She cast a sidelong glance at a Starbucks across the street.

headline: Up Front
text: Ben Macintyre contributes a weekly column to The Times of London on history, art, politics, foreign affairs — and espionage. Although he has never written a novel, his books are filled with colorful characters, from Adam Worth (“the real Professor Moriarty”) to Ian Fleming, creator of James Bond. The first volume of Macintyre’s World War II espionage ­trilogy, “Agent Zigzag,” featured a real-life criminal and double agent who played a pivotal role in the early part of the war. The second, “Operation Mincemeat,” told the story of a secret plan involving a corpse carrying forged papers in the run-up to the invasion of Sicily in 1943, a deception made famous by the film “The Man Who Never Was.”

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: WHY BE HAPPY WHEN YOU COULD BE NORMAL?,  by Jeanette Winterson (Grove, $25.) Winterson’s unconventional and winning memoir wrings humor from adversity as it describes her upbringing by a wildly deranged mother.

headline: Paperback Row
text: SO MUCH PRETTY,  by Cara Hoffman (Simon & Schuster, $16.) The disappearance of a local waitress foments an atmosphere of paranoia in an upstate New York town in Hoffman’s first novel, which addresses rural poverty, domestic abuse, teenage violence and pollution. Over the course of 17 years, the story moves among the town’s inhabitants, many of whom remain willfully blind to the deeper causes of the tragedy.

headline: ‘Religion for Atheists’
text: To the Editor:

headline: What Russia Is Reading
text: To the Editor:

headline: That Parachute Anchor
text: To the Editor:

headline: ‘Satantango,’ the Movie
text: To the Editor:

headline: On the Defensive
text: Given the mounting evidence of long-term and even fatal effects of brain injuries incurred by professional football players, is it ethical for us to watch the games? JENNA BEDNAR, ANN ARBOR, MICH.

headline: Former Goldman Executive Is Said to Complete Book Deal
text: Greg Smith, the former Goldman Sachs executive whose book proposal about his 12 years at the firm set off a fierce bidding war among New York publishers, has made a deal with Grand Central Publishing, part of the Hachette Book Group, a person with knowledge of the negotiations said Friday.

headline: ‘Freedom’s Gardener’
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Trip Across Water, and Time, From Seattle
text: UNBEKNOWNST to the rest of us, the Washington State Department of Transportation has invented a time machine. Sure, it looks like a ferry, running the route between Seattle and Vashon Island dozens of times a day. But how else to explain what you find when you arrive on Vashon?

headline: Riding the Subway, From A to Z in 22:52:35 or Bust
text: It’s an endeavor many train enthusiasts have dreamed about trying: ride every inch of a transportation network, traversing every subway line and station — and do it all, not in a week or a month, but in a day.

headline: Rockers at Sea
text: THINGS were a little weird from the moment I stepped onto the Weezer Cruise. Like a lot of my fellow passengers — indie-rock fans who had signed up for a three-day voyage full of bands and beverages — I’d never been on a cruise before. So I don’t know whether most of them begin with a staff member high-fiving each and every person who comes off the gangway. But I’m relatively certain most don’t have a welcome center with a D.J. playing a reggae version of Nirvana’s “Heart Shaped Box.”

headline: Lohan’s Long-Running Probation Comes to an End
text: To the consternation of tabloid editors everywhere, a judge on Thursday ended Lindsay Lohan’s long-running probation for a 2007 drunk driving case after a string of violations, jail sentences and rehab stints, wire services reported. Ms. Lohan, 25, remains on informal probation for taking a necklace without permission last year, but she no longer must report to a probation officer, limit her travel or show up for weekly cleaning shifts at a morgue.

headline: Romney Leads in Wisconsin, but Republicans’ Focus Is on Recall Election
text: Mitt Romney has a seven-point advantage over Rick Santorum in the Wisconsin presidential primary, according to an NBC News/Marist poll released Friday.

headline: Birds Do It, Bees Do It (Fill Screens)
text: IT’S unclear if humans are any more fascinated with animals than they ever have been, but it’s safe to say that the visual manifestations of this fascination are on the rise. Blue-chip wildlife documentaries like “Planet Earth” and the current “Frozen Planet,” feats of extreme-condition, high-definition shooting, are blockbuster events. On the lowbrow end of the spectrum animal attacks and rogue pets are staples of cable television, and YouTube is an infinite virtual menagerie of cat videos and creature memes.

headline: To Play Judy, Sing Till It Hurts and Be Fearless
text: JUDY GARLAND pops a great many pills in Act II of “End of the Rainbow,” the new Broadway show about the consequences of her fame, set six months before her fatal overdose in 1969. Yet at a recent rehearsal Tracie Bennett, the actress portraying Garland, wasn’t feeling sufficiently strung out as she sang “Come Rain or Come Shine” with her six-man orchestra in the show, which weaves famous Garland numbers with scenes set in her London hotel suite.

headline: Haunted by Ghost Tale? Call an Expert
text: ATLANTA

headline: Broccoli Mandates and the Commerce Clause
text: “If the government can do this, what, what else can it not do?” asked Supreme Court Justice Antonin Scalia this week in arguments on the constitutionality of the requirement that nearly all Americans buy health care insurance or face a penalty.

headline: A New Leaf
text: In the vibrant hothouse that is Chris Garofalo’s Chicago studio, nearly every surface holds carefully composed displays — natural specimens, souvenir postcards, family photos and random objects, like a petrified frog or lurid blue ceramic eggplants. A framed, somewhat faded dinosaur mural reigns over the space; herds of small plastic animals roam the shelf above her worktable. Sometimes it’s hard to tell the found objects from the art.

headline: Our Third Annual New York Times Found Poem Student Contest
text: Update: May 2012 We are publishing the winners every day through May 25 here. You might also be interested in our reflections on this year’s contest. Thanks for participating!

headline: Honda Recalls 554,000 CR-Vs and Pilots for Headlight Failure
text: Following an investigation initiated last year by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, Honda announced Friday that it would recall about 554,000 of its 2002-4 CR-Vs and the 2003 Pilot sport utility vehicles because the low-beam headlights might fail.

headline: Book Review Podcast
text: This week, Mark Leyner discusses his new novel, “The Sugar Frosted Nutsack”; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; Meg Wolitzer on the cultural reception of fiction written by women; Tim Weiner talks about his new history of the F.B.I.; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host.

headline: Helping Girls Through Early Puberty
text: Are girls going through puberty earlier? Yes and no, and maybe — as Elizabeth Weil writes in  Puberty Before Age 10: A New ‘Normal’? for The New York Times Magazine, it depends on how you define puberty. “Well-respected researchers at three big institutions — Cincinnati Children’s Hospital, Kaiser Permanente of Northern California, Mount Sinai School of Medicine in New York — published [a] study in Pediatrics, finding that by age 7, 10 percent of white girls, 23 percent of black girls, 15 percent of Hispanic girls and 2 percent of Asian girls had started developing breasts.”

headline: Whisper of the Wild
text: I lived in the Fairbanks, Alaska, area for almost 14 years and spent a great deal of time in the bush. I appreciated the silence there, psychologically depended on it. I spent many hours just sitting in places where quiet filled my ears, but there were also many times that the sounds of nature were almost deafening (the mosquitoes!). I always found that nature’s “silence,” that is, what remains when the din of human presence is subtracted, far superior as an affirmation of being. Only there can I really become aware of the effect of my presence. Here in the New York-Boston corridor, noise is everywhere, almost impossible to bear. I can’t separate my presence from the noise. I miss the silence and my absence within it.

headline: When Countries Fail
text: In addressing the question of why nations fail, economists would do better to abandon the search for the one answer. Being neither scientists nor theocrats, they would be better advised to explore how different facts interact under different circumstances. This would yield more explanatory light than rhetorical heat.

headline: Meet the New Lefty Dreamboat
text: Last year, you started a liberal antidote to the Tea Party that is now called Rebuild the Dream. You said, “Hold onto your hats” for an “October offensive.” Then I didn’t hear much else. . . .  We were pointing at the possibility of a very explosive populist movement from the left. It happened at the grass-roots level, and it was called Occupy. Rebuild hasn’t got the same press attention, but we have 600,000 members and a presence in every Congressional district.

headline: Who Made That Whoopee Cushion?
text: Some insist that the whoopee cushion originated in medieval courts where jesters turned pig bladders into flatulence simulators. It’s likely an apocryphal story, but “it stands to reason,” says Jim Dawson, the author of “Who Cut the Cheese.” The real story behind the prank’s rise to April Fools’ Day pre-eminence begins in another locus of bathroom humor: 1930s Canada. It was there that JEM, a Toronto rubber company, introduced a contraption known alternatively as the “poo-poo cushion” and the “boop-boop a doop,” until, in 1932, it settled on “whoopee.” A collector named Stan Timm owns an early model: it’s green, with a wooden mouth and a drawing of a gun-toting boy wearing a devious smile and a kilt.

headline: Survivalist Instinct
text: Heather Havrilesky’s Riff on pioneer life is based on a false premise: a distinction between self-reliance and community. We live as a family in the wild woods. This does not mean that we spend our time staring at one another or at bears — we spend our time growing community. We have more solid relations (and communities) “out here” than what I ever found in city.

headline: A Big Bet Gone Bad
text: Large-scale gambling used for tax revenue is bad economics and worse public policy. A casino is an economic “win” for a region only if most gamblers come from elsewhere. If most come from nearby — as is now common, with casinos in so many places — then as one gambling scholar said, “You simply cannot grow an economy by taking money out of it.” You drain local wallets while shifting the tax burden to the lower-income folks who are hurt most by their losses. Then add the sad stories I’ve heard from public officials in casino areas across the country. Bankruptcies, embezzlement, broken families — we’re seeing it now, here in Pennsylvania.

headline: How the American Action Movie Went Kablooey
text: The action film — like automobiles, televisions and team-oriented basketball — is an American invention that is now produced much better elsewhere in the world. The latest example of this (and there are many examples from points all over the globe) is “The Raid: Redemption,” a modest but irresistible action film from Indonesia that recently high-kicked (and punched and stomped and shot and throttled) its way into American theaters. The film has been rapturously celebrated; at last glance, its positive rating at Rotten Tomatoes hovered around 90 percent. In a rare dissenting opinion, Roger Ebert wrote: “This film is about violence. All violence. Wall-to-wall violence,” which is true but also a bit like complaining that a comedy is too full of jokes.

headline: The High Road
text: In the summer of 1995, a 26-year-old woman who had never been backpacking before set out to hike the Pacific Crest Trail. She had already separated from her husband, quit her waitressing job and sold most of her belongings. Now she went to the outdoors store REI to purchase almost everything she could possibly think of for her three-month journey: fleece pants and an anorak, a thermal shirt, two pairs of wool socks and underwear, a sleeping bag, a camp chair, a head lamp, five bungee cords, a water purifier, a tiny collapsible stove, a canister of gas and a small pink lighter, two cooking pots, utensils, a thermometer, a tarp, a snakebite kit, a Swiss Army knife, binoculars, a compass, a book called “Staying Found” to teach herself how to use the compass, a first-aid kit, toiletries, a menstrual sponge, a lantern, water bottles, iodine pills, a foldable saw (“for what, I did not know”), two pens and three books in addition to “Staying Found”: “The Pacific Crest Trail, Vol. 1: California,” William Faulkner’s “As I Lay Dying” and Adrienne Rich’s “Dream of a Common Language.” She also bought a 200-page sketchbook to use as a journal.

headline: Business Day Live | March 30, 2012
text: Starbucks struggles to make headway in Europe; a look at mobile mapping software; James B. Stewart on the Supreme Court and the health care bill.

headline: Pawn’s Move
text: Comrade Col. Xin Zhu, obese spy and head of the Expedition Agency within the Sixth Bureau of the Ministry of State Security, suspects there is a C.I.A. mole burrowing into China’s secrets. But he is under threat from Wu Liang and his ally, Yang Qing-Nian, of the Supervision and Liaison Committee, an offshoot of the Central Committee’s Political and Legislative Affairs Committee. Zhu believes Zhang Guo of the Supreme People’s Procuratorate is on his side, probably, but he is less sure of the veteran schemer Comrade Lt. Gen. Sun Bingjun.

headline: Signs of Life
text: How dead would you like to be before your organs are harvested for donation? According to Dick ­Teresi in “The Undead,” “pretty dead” is good enough for transplant surgeons. “If you wait for every­thing to be a hundred percent,” a physician tells him, “you’d never have organ donation.”

headline: Ye Gods
text: Mark Leyner writes in a genre that could be called Mark Leyner: gun-to-the-head comedy delivered with a stratospheric I.Q. Leyner’s fiction isn’t narrative so much as a thundering procession of twisted skits, pinging from brainiac literary theory to the latest disgraces of reality TV. Just when it seems that, line by line, there might be no smarter writer on the planet, Leyner indulges in gleefully juvenile sprees of lewdness, asserting the sublime pleasures of the absurd. He is either a genius or a freak, and it may not matter which, because his books are compulsively readable, created by a literary mind that seems to have no precedent.

headline: Plenty to Go Around
text: The past few years have been trying ones for the world’s optimists. In rapid succession, our global crises have ranged from the environmental to the economic — from tsunamis leveling entire regions of Asia and destroying seemingly impregnable nuclear reactors, to debt and unemployment crushing ostensibly healthy nations. Meanwhile, as the planet warms, ice caps melt, oceans acidify and dry regions desertify. To choose just one metric of doom, about 30 percent of the world’s fish populations have either collapsed or are on their way to collapse; to choose another, global carbon emissions rose by a record 5.9 percent in 2010, a worrisome development considering that the period was characterized by slow economic growth. (What happens when things start booming again?) I could go on, but you get the gist. It seems self-evident that things are getting worse, doesn’t it?

headline: Foiled Again
text: On Dec. 31, President Obama signed the National Defense Authorization Act, which allows for the indefinite military detention, without trial, of any American citizen “who was a part of or substantially supported Al Qaeda, the Taliban or associated forces that are engaged in hostilities against the United States or its coalition partners.” This act effectively abrogates the Bill of Rights and removes one of the cornerstones of Western liberty.

headline: The Ground Beneath Her Feet
text: Running an Ivy League university isn’t all it’s cracked up to be, at least not for Meredith Ruth Neukirchen, known as M.R., the protagonist of Joyce Carol Oates’s new novel. She’s the first woman to be president of an unnamed school in New Jersey, an obvious stand-in for Princeton, where Oates is the Roger S. Berlind distinguished professor of the humanities. M.R. is “renowned in academic circles,” an eminent philosopher, a diplomatic administrator and a selfless hard worker. But a creeping distress threatens to engulf her. Living by herself in the museumlike president’s house has proved lonely and uncomfortable. She has no intimate friends. Her secret, much older lover is not only long married to someone else and ensconced at far-off Harvard, he has begun staying away entirely, seeming less than thrilled by her professional ascent. In unguarded moments, M.R. admits that even her nonstop work is a trial, her laptop attached to her “like a colostomy bag.”

headline: Winging It
text: Megan Mayhew Bergman’s first story collection, “Birds of a Lesser Paradise,” begins with a woman driving hundreds of miles to see a parrot. She can’t stand the bird, which sings Patsy Cline tunes and tells off imaginary telemarketers, but it has one trick worth listening to: It sounds just like her dead mother. The two women didn’t get along, but now that the mother is gone, the daughter longs to hear her familiar voice, even coming from a beady-eyed mimic.

headline: In the Pink
text: “For a long time, I assumed that bow ties — not regular ties — were the usual thing for men to wear,” Charlotte Silver writes in her wistful memoir, “Charlotte au Chocolat.” Such were the perils of growing up in the same building as the Hasty Pudding Club, Harvard’s oldest social club, where for 20 years Silver’s mother, Deborah Hughes, along with a business partner, Mary-Catherine Deibel, ran the four-star restaurant Upstairs at the Pudding, housed on the club’s third floor.

headline: Chaos Under Heaven
text: By the time Qing imperial forces caught and dismembered Hong Rengan in late 1864, an estimated 20 million to 70 million people had perished in the turmoil of the Taiping rebellion. Hong, once a bookish assistant to European preachers, ended up the “prime minister” of a Chinese movement that almost deposed the Qing dynasty of the Manchus, who had conquered China more than two centuries earlier.

headline: Enchanted Hunter
text: Shortly before coming to America in 1940, on a ship that would be sunk by Nazi U-boats on its next voyage, Vladimir Nabokov wrote a novel about biography and art entitled “The Real Life of Sebastian Knight.” In it we are advised to “remember that what you are told is really threefold: shaped by the teller, reshaped by the listener, concealed from both by the dead man of the tale.” No words might be better kept in mind while reading Brian Boyd’s “Stalking Nabokov.”

headline: The Second Shelf
text: If “The Marriage Plot,” by Jeffrey Eugenides, had been written by a woman yet still had the same title and wedding ring on its cover, would it have received a great deal of serious literary attention? Or would this novel (which I loved) have been relegated to “Women’s Fiction,” that close-quartered lower shelf where books emphasizing relationships and the interior lives of women are often relegated? Certainly “The Marriage Plot,” Eugenides’s first novel since his Pulitzer Prize-winning “Middlesex,” was poised to receive tremendous literary interest regardless of subject matter, but the presence of a female protagonist, the gracefulness, the sometimes nostalgic tone and the relationship-heavy nature of the book only highlight the fact that many first-rate books by women and about women’s lives never find a way to escape “Women’s Fiction” and make the leap onto the upper shelf where certain books, most of them written by men (and, yes, some women — more about them later), are prominently displayed and admired.

headline: Easter Among Strangers
text: Upon leaving the Finnish fundamentalist faith of my youth, I made my parents a promise that I would still attend church on Christmas and Easter. It was my fifth such Easter, but I was still anxious, aware that everyone would be looking to see what unbelieving had done to me. I removed my nail polish and earrings, arriving late to avoid conversation, only to discover that the church was full — there was not even space by the bad kids in the back. I was forced instead to parade to the front, feeling underdressed and like the prodigal child, and take a seat next to my little cousins.

headline: Tracking Twitter, Raising Red Flags
text: The business plan of Varsity Monitor is simple. Major universities like North Carolina, Nebraska and Oklahoma pay $7,000 to $10,000 a year and Varsity Monitor keeps an online eye on their athletes.

headline: The Munchkins Are a Problem: Parent Power, Power Parents
text: It's set-building time in the land of Oz, which has been temporarily transported to P.S. 29 in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn. Helene Stapinski, who has volunteered, reluctantly, to co-direct the fifth-grade musical, finds herself surrounded by talented fellow parents who are nailing, painting, grommeting and creating. She writes: "When the assistant principal sees the sets and the Kansas house with its trick spring, she starts to worry. Maybe we’re putting too much work into the show, that the sets will outshine the children. She says this to Gina, who then calls me in a rage. 'Can you believe her? We’re making the sets look too nice! What does that even mean?'  ''The Board of Ed is used to mediocrity,' I say, calming her, a strange role I’ve taken on lately."

headline: On Vashon Island, Farms, Art and Country Roads
text: In the island’s main town, shopkeepers greet their patrons by name, and the only traffic jams are found on the sidewalk.

headline: Parnell’s Knuckle-Curve Makes a Difference
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. – As the Mets revamped their bullpen this winter, Bobby Parnell found himself at the start of spring training once again battling to prove his worth.

headline: Inside the List
text: HELP, THANKS, WOW: There was a time, three or four years ago, when it seemed every novelist had a blog, and why not? Blogging gave writers another way to reach readers, to promote their work or air their grievances or test their ideas in mini-essays that played to their strengths. But technology evolves, and despite some notable holdouts (Elif Batuman is one) Twitter has killed the blogging star. Now writers connect with their publics in 140 characters or fewer. The medium especially favors authors with distinct voices, preferably funny ones, who can toss off pithy observations or one-liners — authors like Anne Lamott, say, whose new book, “Some Assembly Required,” enters the hardcover nonfiction list at No. 9. Lamott’s best writing has always had the dashed-off immediacy of a good tweet; her excellent 1993 book “Operating Instructions” strung together one punch line after another to capture the joys and anxieties of her son’s first year of life. The new book is a sequel — her son (and co-author), Sam, now has a son of his own — and to promote it, Lamott has been posting her daffy, neurotic, inspirational shtick in the telegraphic shorthand that Twitter followers are used to. From an airplane on the first leg of her recent book tour, she wrote: “New low @ 30,000 feet — checked Amazon sales rank of ‘Some Assembly . . . ’ @­samlamott trying to wrestle iPad out of my hands. I need air marshal.” Later, in Washington, she was more reflective: “D.C.; cherry blossoms in full pink pyrotechnic bloom. Humbling & convincing (but I’m easy). 3rd great prayer, after Help and Thanks, is Wow!” Almost 20 years ago I sat in on Lamott’s writing class in Marin County, Calif., where one of the students turned out to be her former elementary school principal. Even in second grade she’d been a bundle of comic nervous energy, he told me. “We all knew she was going to be a star.”

headline: Ahead of I.P.O., Mark Zuckerberg’s Lawyers Expedite Disclosures
text: Facebook’s chief executive, Mark Zuckerberg, is rushing to clear all his paperwork ahead of the social network’s highly anticipated initial public offering.

headline: Turning a Bloody Attack Into a Musical
text: It was a grisly story of two immigrant cabdrivers whose taxi-sharing partnership ended with one attacking the other with a meat cleaver and then jumping to his death from the Robert F. Kennedy Bridge.

headline: Weekend Fare
text: The fourth annual New Jersey Wine and Food Festival, at Crystal Springs in Hardyston, N.J., runs through Sunday, with many New York City chefs participating. The chef Thomas Keller is being honored this year. Some events have sold out, but tickets are still available for various lunches, meet-and-greet sessions with chefs, wine seminars and more. The festival benefits the James Beard Foundation and Bocuse d’Or USA. Tickets are available online or by calling (973) 827-5996, extension 3.

headline: Video: A Bluegrass Tribute to Earl Scruggs
text: The death of Earl Scruggs, the virtuoso banjo player, in Nashville on Wednesday was mourned throughout the tight-knit bluegrass music world.

headline: A Rivalry Moves Downcourt to Center Stage
text: SOMETHING felt wrong to Magic Johnson when he watched a recent rehearsal of “Magic/Bird,” a new Broadway play about his rivalry turned friendship with Larry Bird, the fellow basketball superstar with whom he is indelibly linked.

headline: Inside the 3-D Conversion of ‘Titanic’
text: Using a frame from “Titanic,” James Cameron explains elements of the work that went into converting the film to 3-D.

headline: For Struggling RIM, Sale Prospects Appear Tough
text: It took an awful quarter for Research in Motion to acknowledge on Thursday that it needed to explore “strategic opportunities,” something the BlackBerry maker scoffed at even two months ago.

headline: A More Diet-Friendly Doughnut, Baked by Butterfield
text: The venerable Butterfield Market, a carriage-trade grocer on the Upper East Side, traces its beginnings to 1915 but is now focused on innovation: doughnuts that are baked, not fried.

headline: Why ‘Bully’ Is a Family Film
text: In a widely publicized decision, the ratings board of the Motion Picture Association of America insisted on an R rating for the movie “Bully,” a documentary about children who are bullied, their tormenters and the adults who let both of them down, because of profanity in the film. An R rating means the children who could most benefit from the film would not be able to see it without their parents.

headline: With Lamb, Flavor Comes in Small Packages
text: WE think of spring as the season of the lamb, but in truth, the term “spring lamb” is a misnomer. The lamb you see in shops now is from animals 6 to 9 months old, which means they were born last fall at the earliest. The exception is suckling or milk-fed lamb, only a few weeks old, which is a delicacy prized in Europe but rarely available in the United States. If you can find it, it is extraordinary.

headline: In Portugal, a Street in Porto Finds Its Groove
text: In Porto, Portugal, the faded town houses on Rua do Rosário are filling with upstart designers and fine food.

headline: An Impeccable Étoile Dared to Be More
text: PARIS

headline: Putting In Their 2 Cents
text: ON a weeknight in mid-March, a room in the Park Slope Armory Y.M.C.A. that is frequently used for children’s birthday parties was packed with tables draped in pale yellow, 99-cent-store, vinyl coverings and topped with propped-up tri-fold poster boards.

headline: Chic Relief | Fashion Girls for Japan Benefit Sale
text: Last year, in the wake of Japan’s devastating earthquake and tsunami, a group of enterprising New York women (many of them Japanese American) working in the fashion industry wanted to do something tangible to help recovery and relief efforts. They formed Fashion Girls for Japan and quickly organized a benefit sale of designer clothes. More than 60 designers pledged to donate one rolling rack each of clothing and accessories and the Fashion Girls raised an astonishing $275,000, all of which was donated to the Japan Society’s Japan Earthquake Relief Fund.

headline: A Career That Moves in Mysterious Ways
text: Geneva

headline: At NoMad, Bottle Service Goes D.I.Y.
text: Bottle service doesn’t have a good reputation in self-respecting bartender circles. It conjures up images of ill-mannered but well-moneyed night trollers loudly swilling $500 bottles of Grey Goose vodka in the cordoned-off V.I.P. corners of ostentatiously swanky clubs and lounges. It’s not the style of drinking a genteel bartender condones.

headline: The Steward-Turned-Spy
text: During the last weeks of March 1862 some 121,000 troops from the Army of the Potomac — the Union’s largest military force — began arriving on the Virginia Peninsula, the first step in what Northerners hoped would be a successful jab at Richmond, the Confederate capital. For over three weeks, hundreds of boats transported the men, 14,000 horses and incalculable tons of matériel southward down the Chesapeake Bay to Union-held Fort Monroe on the peninsula’s tip.

headline: Liberty and Justice for Non-Muslims
text: Since the attacks on Sept. 11, 2001, genuine concerns about national security as well as politicking and fear have led to a shift in the balance between civil liberties and law enforcement. That much is indisputable, and widely discussed. Yet it’s rarely acknowledged that the attacks have also led to what’s essentially a separate justice system for Muslims.

headline: Upstate vs. Downstate: A Slow Boil Over Water Issues
text: As I report in The Times, upstate-downstate tensions have soared over New York City’s management of the watershed that supplies drinking water to its residents.

headline: Michaels Stores Files for I.P.O.
text: Michaels Stores, the Texas-based purveyor of knitting needles and pipe cleaners, is planning to raise as much as $500 million in its public debut, according to a filing made with the Securities and Exchange Commission on Friday.

headline: April 1 — 7
text: HOW much do you know about Philadelphia’s contemporary performance scene? I’m embarrassed to admit that I know very little, despite how close the city is to New York and how regularly I hear reports of cross-pollination.

headline: Rethinking the Value of Pets
text: Think an elderly family member is better off with a pet? You may want to think again.

headline: Business Day Live | Mobile Mapping
text: March 30, 2012 - A look at mobile mapping software, Steve Jobs' personality, and the iPad's high video resolution.

headline: Quandary Considered: Disciplining a Stranger’s Child
text: F. has what amounted to a social parenting quandary: unknown kids, in a public play area, bothering his child enough that he felt the other parent ought to step in, but with no other parent in sight. The last time it happened, he intervened — only to face the angry fellow parent later, accusing him of “traumatizing” the other child. Should I, F. asked, have tried harder to find the absentee parents of the offending child, or was it O.K. to speak up?

headline: Recall Election for Wisconsin Governor Who Battled Unions
text: Wisconsin officials announced on Friday that critics of Gov. Scott Walker had met the requirements for a recall election, starting a bitterly contentious campaign cycle all over again.

headline: A Vegetarian Burger Bash
text: For burger lovers who want to cut back on meat, vegetarian burgers can be a tasty and healthful way to recreate the burger experience. In this week’s Recipes for Health, Martha Rose Shulman offers five ways to create vegetarian burgers at home. She writes:

headline: Another View: March Badness
text: As March comes to an end and the NCAA basketball tournament heads into the Final Four, most office pools are likely to be in tatters. But Joshua Brown — a financial adviser for Fusion Analytics Investment Partners who blogs and tweets as The Reformed Broker — is giving Wall Street fans another chance at bracket dominance.

headline: Burmese Dissident Resumes Campaign
text: YANGON, Myanmar — As campaigning for a landmark election in Myanmar reached its final days, the leader of the country’s democracy movement, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, emerged from a week of convalescence on Friday still feeling “delicate” but hopeful that the election would help lay “a foundation stone for the future of democracy.”

headline: Right Eye, Meet Left Eye
text: “THE ship still sinks,” the director James Cameron said back in October when he was in New York to present some scenes from the updated “Titanic” to the news media. While the version returning to theaters on Wednesday is the same cut that was released 15 years ago, the film’s 4K digital remastering and its meticulous 3-D conversion make for a fresh visual experience. The process spanned over 60 weeks and cost about $18 million to achieve a look that seems as if it had been originally shot with 3-D cameras.

headline: About Those Lifeboats ...
text: THE coming 100th anniversary of the Titanic disaster (on April 15) hasn’t escaped the notice of the home video industry, whose eagle-eyed marketing executives have pounced on the opportunity to release what seems to be every known basic-cable documentary, television mini-series and feature film to examine the subject.

headline: Book Review Podcast: The Culture’s Beliefs About Fiction Written by Women
text: In The New York Times Book Review, Meg Wolitzer addresses an ongoing debate about the lack of attention for female fiction writers. Ms. Wolitzer writes:

headline: TimesCast | March 30, 2012
text: Mexico’s presidential campaign begins | More endorsements for Mitt Romney | The actor Frank Langella speaks on his new book, “Dropped Names.”

headline: What Baseball Does to the Soul
text: IT was long before baseball ever enchanted me, and long before I ever knew anything of the Yankees, and long before I learned that a pitch could swerve, yet it came back to me, years later, sitting in the bleachers at Yankee Stadium, a curveball from the past.

headline: In Store | Stijl Council
text: Piet Hein Eek’s World At the Dutchman’s sprawling Eindhoven studio-factory-storegallery-restaurant, great design extends from bureaus to brooms. More…

headline: Fire Safety for Passover Traditions
text: In 2004, four people were hurt after a fire that erupted during a Passover bread-burning ritual on a Brooklyn street, officials said.

headline: In Afghanistan, Businesses Plan Their Own Exits
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — America may be struggling to come up with a viable exit plan for Afghanistan, but Abdul Wasay Manani is sure of his.

headline: Big Ticket | Sold for $16,500,000
text: One of Park Avenue’s oldest surviving town houses, once the home of the abstract painter and philanthropist Judith Rothschild, has sold for $16.5 million, making it the biggest sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: In Afghanistan, a Rush for the Exits
text: With the United States preparing to wind down aid and troop levels, Afghan entrepreneurs are starting to relocate their businesses and assets out of the country. And international interests are also beginning to pull out or reduce their investment.

headline: Anthony Is Hurt Late and Knicks Fade Fast
text: ATLANTA — Carmelo Anthony said he felt the twinge of pain in his groin in the fourth quarter after he stripped the ball from Atlanta’s Josh Smith and saved it from going out of bounds. He knew he was in trouble, and so were the Knicks.

headline: For Stanford’s Joslyn Tinkle, a Chance to Have an Impact
text: A year can definitely change many things, as Stanford’s Joslyn Tinkle can attest. She’s one of the important parts of Stanford’s 2012 Final Four team, serving as its main 3-point threat. The No. 1-seeded Cardinal (35-1) will play another top seed, Baylor, on Sunday at the Pepsi Center in Denver. The winner advances to play the either Connecticut or Notre Dame, also both No. 1 seeds, for the N.C.A.A. title on Tuesday.

headline: Adrienne Rich, Beyond the Anger
text: American poets rarely become public figures, and those who do — Allen Ginsberg, Robert Frost — usually pay a price for it. Sometimes that price is measured in a temporary decline in their literary reputation (other poets find fame hard to forgive), but more often it’s a simple matter of becoming papered over with expectations. The more the public looks at a poet, the harder she becomes to see.

headline: Video: Mobile Mapping
text: Nick Bilton and Quentin Hardy appeared on Business Day Live to talk mobile mapping software, Steve Jobs’ personality, and the iPad’s high video resolution.

headline: Habitats | Red Hook
text: The décor of Joseph Hart and Anika Selhorst’s apartment is spare, but weaves together multiple strands of their professional and personal lives.

headline: Where New York Comes Up for Air
text: JOSEPH HART and Anika Selhorst were the ultimate college sweethearts. They have been an item ever since they crossed paths 13 years ago in a college darkroom in Providence, R.I., in a meeting that Ms. Selhorst describes as “a scene out of a movie.”

headline: Tribunal Suspends Approval of Posco Steel Project in India
text: MUMBAI — An Indian tribunal dealt a fresh blow on Friday to a long-delayed, high-profile steel project proposed by the South Korean company Posco by suspending its environmental approval and directing regulators to review the project again.

headline: Q. and A.: North Korea’s Choked Environment
text: Although it remains one of the world’s most implacably closed societies, North Korea has become more open to gingerly discussing its environmental problems in recent years in the hope of finding solutions.

headline: Consumer Budgeting Around the World
text: The Bureau of Labor Statistics recently released a fascinating report on how American consumers spend their money, and how that compares to spending behavior of their counterparts in other rich countries.

headline: Party Affiliations in Car-Buying Choices: A Thorny Patch of Consumer Analysis
text: Are some vehicle models more popular with Democrats, and others with Republicans? That is the suggestion of a study conducted by Strategic Vision, a marketing research and industry forecasting firm.

headline: The View from Kansas: Toughness and Energy
text: The Quad asked writers at newspapers on the campuses of teams that made the Final Four for reports on what to expect on Saturday.

headline: It’s Gotta Be the Shoes
text: Have you ever wanted to see Cristiano Ronaldo try to juggle with a tennis ball? What about getting a chance to see Rafael Nadal try his hand (or foot) at soccer? If so, you are in luck.

headline: Spring Staples | Happy Feet
text: The latest spring accessory: bright, petal-colored pumps pour les pieds. Here, the actress Stacey Dash beams in a daffodil yellow dress with matching platforms; Blake Lively puts a prim spin on a polished color-blocked look with rosy toes; and Beyoncé adds a pop of sunny color to all-gray with forsythia-like stilettos and sweet, tulip pink lips.

headline: Obama Finds Oil in Markets Is Sufficient to Sideline Iran
text: WASHINGTON — After careful analysis of oil prices and months of negotiations, President Obama on Friday determined that there was sufficient oil in world markets to allow countries to significantly reduce their Iranian imports, clearing the way for Washington to impose severe new sanctions intended to slash Iran’s oil revenue and press Tehran to abandon its nuclear ambitions.

headline: With Lin Out, Davis Re-Enters the Spotlight
text: Baron Davis’s off-season arrival in New York was initially met with the highest of expectations. But his inability to take the court (missing the first 31 games of the season) left the Knicks in a vulnerable spot. The void raised questions about the team’s overall prospects for the season, and if not for the emergence of Jeremy Lin, perhaps the Knicks would have only a lottery-type finish to show for it.

headline: Palestinians and Israeli Troops Clash Amid Protests
text: JERUSALEM — Thousands of Palestinians protested on Friday against Israeli policies of land seizure and control of Jerusalem, leading to clashes with Israeli troops in which a 20-year-old was killed and scores of others were injured.

headline: Tibetan Exiles March for One of Their Own Who Died in Flames
text: DHARAMSALA, India — The body was late for the funeral. It had left New Delhi on Thursday morning for the winding 12-hour drive to this Himalayan hill town. The Tibetan exiles here talked with anticipation about a mourning ceremony on Thursday night. But the ambulance carrying the body stopped overnight in the town of Chandigarh, and in the early morning continued the climb toward the snow peaks.

headline: Backup to Starter to Phenomenon. Repeat.
text: JACKSONVILLE BEACH, Fla. —  The sometimes surreal, always entertaining movie that is Tim Tebow’s life played most famously in Gainesville, Fla., and Denver before opening in New York last week. As always, Tebow’s arrival prompted an immediate and frenzied curiosity, and it did not take long for the typical questions to percolate:

headline: Shushannah & Ari
text: In this self-made video, Shushannah Walshe and Ari Yasgur share the story of how they met through Ari's sister. Despite not having much in common, after several dates they fell in love.

headline: Nila Do and Joshua Simon
text: FOR Nila Do a good time is eating grilled chicken wings (she once ate 52 at one meal during her college days), playing soccer or flag football and watching University of Florida sporting events.

headline: John Patrick Shanley’s ‘Storefront Church’ Gets Its Congregation
text: Fresh from his gripping performance as Gustavo Fring in the television drama “Breaking Bad,” Giancarlo Esposito has been cast as the lead in John Patrick Shanley’s new play, “Storefront Church,” which the Atlantic Theater Company will produce this spring, the company said Friday.

headline: U.S. Denies Visa Renewal for Red Bulls’ Rodgers
text: The Red Bulls are in the market for another striker after the United States government quashed the visa renewal for the English striker Luke Rodgers. The league’s transfer period end April 15.

headline: MasterCard and Visa Investigate Data Breach
text: Visa and MasterCard are investigating whether a data security breach at one of the main companies that processes transactions improperly exposed private customer information, bank officials said Friday. The event highlighted a crucial vulnerability that could affect millions of credit card holders.

headline: What’s So Funny About Whoopee Cushions?
text: In this week’s Makers feature Who Made That Whoopee Cushion? in the Magazine, the flatulence expert Jim Dawson — who has authored books like “Who Cut the Cheese?” “Blame It on the Dog” and, most recently, “Did Somebody Step on a Duck?” — says that the fake-flatulent noises made by the toy are funny “because they deflate people.”

headline: The View from Ohio State: It Could Be a Classic
text: The Quad asked writers at newspapers on the campuses of teams that made the Final Four for reports on what to expect on Saturday.

headline: Business Day Live: Starbucks Struggles
text: Starbucks struggles to make headway in Europe; a look at mobile mapping software; James B. Stewart on the Supreme Court and the health care law.

headline: Graphic Books Best Sellers: Zombies, Mutants and Bats
text: The hardcover graphic books best-seller list this week has one new title, but you have to scroll past a lot of zombies to get to it. The top seven slots on the list belong to “The Walking Dead,” the epic about a world overrun by zombies, by Robert Kirkman, Tony Moore and Charlie Adlard. The seven collected editions, published by Image Comics, will get readers from the first issue to No. 84 of the series. Issue No. 95 hit comic book stores this week. New to the hardcover list, at No. 10, is “X-Men: Season One,” by Dennis Hopeless and Jamie McKelvie. It’s a modern take on the early days of Marvel’s favorite mutants. While my colleague Adam Kepler and I enjoyed “Fantastic Four: Season One,” we were less thrilled by the X-Men’s turn.

headline: Jon Gruden Interrogates Andrew Luck
text: Programming alert: ESPN begins Jon Gruden’s “QB Camp” series tonight at 7, with Andrew Luck as the first quarterback in the interrogation dock. This link will take you to a longer version of the video above, and is highly recommended. Gruden dissects a late interception thrown by Luck against U.S.C. on a routine Stanford play called “Spider 3 Y Banana.”

headline: Gary Ross Answers Reader Questions About ‘The Hunger Games’
text: You asked and he answered. Gary Ross, the director of “The Hunger Games,” took on a wide range of questions from readers about his film version of the Suzanne Collins novel. Mr. Ross selected some of the best questions and  has responded below.

headline: Spanish Government Calls for Budget Cuts to Reassure Investors
text: MADRID — The government of Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy of Spain introduced sharp budgetary cuts on Friday to reassure investors that Madrid would meet its deficit-reduction pledges and avoid deepening the European debt crisis.

headline: For Romney, a Widening Gap Between Urban and Rural Support
text: After several early roadblocks, Mitt Romney now has a fairly certain path to the Republican nomination. He has received less support, however, among rural and more conservative voters – the base of the Republican Party in recent elections.

headline: Samurai Shopper | True Grit
text: The Samurai Shopper is decidedly laissez-faire about spring cleaning: dust bunnies, Easter bunnies, it’s all good. But now it’s time to exorcise winter with a brisk facial scrub. Trouble is, every skin-care line has an exfoliator to banish dead skin cells, unplug pores, impart radiance, etc. From the eco-impeccable Kiss My Face Start Up Exfoliating Face Wash to St. Ives’s innumerable specialty scrubs. You can hit the high notes with La Prairie’s Cellular Microdermabrasion Cream, where mildly abrasive diamond and pearl powders exist in perfect ratio to velvety creams laced with botanical extracts.

headline: For Baylor, Reaching the Final Four Is Not Enough
text: Krista Pirtle of The Lariat at Baylor University will file reports about the top-ranked Baylor Lady Bears throughout the season for The Quad.

headline: The Motherwell Is Real, but There’s a Hitch
text: When a German art conservator recently sought to authenticate an early painting by Robert Motherwell that she had inherited, the director of the artist’s New York foundation told her there was both good news and bad news. The work, “Figuration,” a charming 1947 oil on masonite, was real. But, the art conservator was told, the painting was stolen.

headline: West 50th Street Near Broadway, 1:32 P.M.
text: People lining up to buy MegaMillions lottery tickets in Manhattan for Friday night’s drawing.

headline: 6 Tips About College Admissions Results
text: For students, the results of the college application process can be both an exhilarating and painful experience. There are the surprises of being accepted into reach schools, and the rejections from colleges once considered shoe-ins. And, of course, the purgatory of the wait list.

headline: For Asian-American Couples, a Tie That Binds
text: WHEN she was a philosophy student at Harvard College eight years ago, Liane Young never thought twice about all the interracial couples who flitted across campus, arm and arm, hand in hand. Most of her Asian friends had white boyfriends or girlfriends. In her social circles, it was simply the way of the world.

headline: Maryland Lacrosse Has a Winning Streak, and Challenging Games Ahead
text: The Maryland women’s lacrosse team is nearing the end of its regular season, and despite a few hiccups, its play has been just as impressive as it has been in recent years.

text: March 31, 11:18 p.m. | Updated below |I encourage you to pop over to Shawn Otto’s blog below and read “A Message from a Republican Meteorologist on Climate Change,” a guest post in which Paul Douglas, an experienced meteorologist, energy entrepreneur and founder of the Web site Weather Nation, explains that acknowledging evidence of a growing human influence on climate “doesn’t make you a liberal.” (Hat tip to Climate Progress.) text: Mary Stallings

headline: When a Beloved Teacher Is Also a Rapist
text: This is the thing I don’t want to say: My son’s beloved community theater teacher raped one of his former students.

headline: TimesCast | Mexico's Elections Begin
text: March 30, 2012 - Mexico's presidential campaign began at midnight with a campaign rally for the leading contender, Enrique Peña Nieto.

headline: A Little Lamb, a Lot of Vegetables
text: With all the arguments about meat-eating, I almost hesitated to write this week’s City Kitchen column about lamb. But I am an omnivore, which means at times I am a carnivore. Certainly I could live without meat and often do, and vegetables make up a large part of my diet. I prefer and recommend meat that is sustainably and humanely raised, and I agree with others that most people eat too much of it. For me, the ideal balance is a meal with a little meat and a lot of vegetables, along with the old-fashioned notion that meat is something for special occasions.

headline: Honoring a Service Member’s Ultimate Sacrifice, Whether It Was Made on the Battlefield or Not
text: In a post on March 15 , Gary Farwell eloquently described how some families of our fallen military personnel are issued different types of gold star pins or not “allowed” to have gold star license tags by the states that issue them. At the heart of this issue is the memorialization of our fallen military. Gold star license tags are only the tip of the iceberg.

headline: MTV2 to Resurrect “Hollywood Squares”
text: MTV2 plans to resurrect the game show “Hollywood Squares” with a twist: producers will fill many of the nine spots in the giant tic-tac-toe grid with figures from the hip-hop world, the network announced on Friday. The new show will be called “Hip Hop Squares” and will be hosted by Peter Rosenberg, a D.J. from the radio station Hot 97 (WQHT-FM) in New York.

headline: Want an Active Investment Manager? Here’s What to Look For
text: IF there is one warning label that seems to have little effect, it is the one on the bottom of a securities prospectus: “Past performance is no indication of future results.”

headline: Arrest Made After Death of Woman Who Plummeted From 14th-Floor Balcony
text: 12:18 a.m. | Updated The 911 operator knew immediately that the situation was serious. Whoever phoned for help was silent, but in the background, several female voices were making threats.

headline: Rajaratnam Prosecutor Andrew Michaelson to Join Boies Schiller
text: One of the lead prosecutors in the insider trading trial of the hedge fund manager Raj Rajaratnam is leaving public service for private practice.

headline: Marriage Maintenance When Money Is Tight
text: Chronic unemployment is putting many couples’ marital vows to the test — particularly the part that refers to “for richer, for poorer.”

headline: Protesters Scuffle with Forces
text: Thousands of Palestinians protested on Friday against Israeli policies of land seizure and control of Jerusalem, leading to clashes with Israeli troops in which a 20-year-old was killed and scores of others were injured.

headline: DealBook’s Week in Review: Reading MF Global’s E-Mails
text: We watched a stock exchange trip over itself, found the irony in Warren Buffett’s tax problem, read MF Global e-mails and braced for credit downgrades at big banks. A look back on our reporting of the past week’s highs and lows in finance.

headline: He’s Awful. But I’ll Be His Running Mate.
text: This week, the not-Romney presidential candidates are taking a slight break from their relentless effort to persuade Republicans that the frontrunner is a liar, an elitist and a fake conservative who will bring the world to a shuddering halt if he is nominated. Instead, they’re entertaining discussion about serving as his vice president.

headline: CBS and Fox Split Ratings Spoils
text: In the battle for Thursday ratings supremacy, Fox and CBS split the spoils, as the former finished first in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic loved by advertisers and the latter reached the highest overall viewership. Fox’s “American Idol” averaged 15.3 million total viewers and at least temporarily ended its slide in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic after a month of drops.

headline: Editor’s Letter
text: Last winter I had the pleasure of visiting the studio of Chris Garofalo, an artist from Chicago whose works in porcelain had come to my attention when they were exhibited in a show curated by Thomas Demand. Garofalo creates her fantastical botanically inclined pieces — her sculptures resemble plant life but are in no way beholden to nature’s designs ­ — in a neat sliver of a building, designed by her late husband, that sits at the edge of her back garden. The portrait by Brooke Hodge and Jason Schmidt reveals it as the most wonderful place, crammed with porcelains, photographs, children’s party favors, cactuses and shells. One feels as though one has entered a terrarium, a feeling that lingers as one crosses the garden back to her house and spies, nestled in the plantings, more of Garofalo’s delightful porcelain wonders. It’s marvelous to encounter such a harmonious place where there are no walls between that which is interior (creativity and love, for a start) and that which is exterior.

headline: Prolific Forger Gets an Exhibition with His Name Attached
text: One of the most prolific art forgers in America is getting a show this weekend at the University of Cincinnati. Curators say they are putting on display more than 90 forgeries by Mark A. Landis, an eccentric painter who donated dozens of phony works to museums around the country for more than 25 years before being found out in 2008.

headline: Air Force Officials Discussed Burial at Sea for Remains From Pentagon Attack
text: WASHINGTON — American military officials discussed scattering at sea some unidentified remains of victims of the Sept. 11, 2001, attack on the Pentagon, but the officials were overruled and the remains were burned and dumped in a landfill, according to Defense Department documents released on Friday.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Gaza and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Gaza, the West Bank, Jerusalem and France.

headline: A Singular Influence
text: BARELY a year and a half has passed since the release of “Pink Friday,” the platinum debut album by Nicki Minaj, but her style is well honed. She’s a sparkling rapper with a gift for comic accents and unexpected turns of phrase. She’s a walking exaggeration, outsize in sound, personality and look. And she’s a rapid evolver, discarding old modes as easily as adopting new ones. This hard and complex work has paid off: when she releases her second album, “Pink Friday: Roman Reloaded,” this week, it will be as the most influential female rapper of all time.

headline: Nicki Minaj’s Singular Influence
text: Less than two years after releasing her debut album, Ms. Minaj has become the most influential female rapper of all time.

headline: Pitino Flashes Back to Role of Underdog
text: When the team from 1987 gathered earlier this season to celebrate the 25th anniversary of Cinderella, Jodi DiRaimo made the trip back to Rhode Island and couldn’t help noticing how joyous the occasion was for his old friend Rick Pitino.

headline: A View From Kentucky: Rivalry Ratchets Up
text: The Quad asked writers at newspapers on the campuses of teams that made the Final Four for reports on what to expect Saturday.

headline: A Basic, but Often Ignored, Rule of Investing
text: Paul Sullivan writes this week in his Wealth Matters column this week about a basic rule in investing that many people don’t heed — “past performance is no indication of future results.”

headline: The Bologna Is on Bass
text: If, as people keep saying these days, food is the new indie rock, then it was probably only a matter of time before the two cultural fixations fused in a heretofore unseen way.

headline: Older Works Made Fresh in Company of Youth
text: At his death in 1972, the choreographer José Limón left behind “The Waldstein Sonata,” a work that would have remain unfinished if not for the efforts of Daniel Lewis, a former member of the Limón company who completed it and set it for the Juilliard Dance Ensemble in 1975.

headline: When ‘For Richer, For Poorer’ Is Put to the Test
text: This week’s Your Money column discusses how long-term unemployment can take a toll on couples’ relationships.

headline: Three Mallards, a Merganser and a Bufflehead
text: Aliette Frank, a postdoctoral scholar at Royal Roads University, explores sustainable community development on the coast of British Columbia.

headline: A Martyr for Tibet is Mourned
text: Jamphel Yeshi set himself on fire on Monday in New Delhi during a large protest before a visit by President Hu Jintao of China. He died two days later.

headline: Old Miami Beach: Sun, Schmaltz, Murder
text: BEN DIAMOND, known as the Butcher, a suntanned sociopath, grew up in an Orthodox Jewish orphanage. He orders sable by the pool and in passing conversation mentions the story of Abraham, Isaac and Jacob.

headline: Prom Night
text: The photographer Mary Ellen Mark documents a rite of passage for American youth.

headline: The Shelby Cobra at 50, an Icon of Sex and Power
text: FIFTY years have passed since the first Shelby A.C. Cobra, CSX2000, landed, heralding the emergence of an automotive sex symbol and a racetrack legend from a modest display stand at the New York auto show.

headline: A Half-Century of Horsepower
text: With voluptuous lines that continue to transcend time, and blistering performance, the Shelby Cobra readily achieved canonization in the car-collecting church.

headline: Prom Night
text: THE prom is a rite of passage that has always been one of the most important rituals of American youth. It is a day in our lives that we never forget — a day full of hopes and dreams.

headline: A Complex Choreographer’s Retrospective, With Unusual Breadth
text: The Paul Taylor Dance Company’s first season at the David H. Koch Theater at Lincoln Center ends this weekend. Over the season 22 dances were performed, including “Esplanade,” Mr. Taylor’s best-loved work, which I saw on Wednesday.

headline: At the Factory, BMW Tries to Minimize Its Carbon Footprint
text: BMW is pursuing goals to reduce the environmental footprint of its plant in Spartanburg, S.C. Sean Noonan, chief financial officer at the BMW Manufacturing Company and head of sustainability program planning, said in an interview Thursday that much of the heavy lifting had already been done and that further progress at the plant would be measured in smaller steps.

headline: Young Lives, Big Night
text: Mary Ellen Mark went to the prom in 1958. She wore a white patterned dress with pearls and open-toed shoes. In a snapshot taken that evening, she beams besides her date, Stuart — just a friend. It was, she said, a less formal, less elaborate event than what many proms are today. No stretch limos. No ballgowns.

headline: Girls Around Me: An App Takes Creepy to a New Level
text: 2:23 p.m. | Updated Added comment from Foursquare.

headline: After Bill’s Gay Nineties Closes, a Fight Over Its Antiques
text: Bill’s Gay Nineties, a Prohibition-era piano bar and restaurant in Midtown Manhattan, closed last week. But as regulars mourned the loss, the owner, Barbara Bart Olmsted, assured them that the watering hole would rise again: She would simply move the pub’s signature wooden bar top, swinging doors and assorted memorabilia to a new home.

headline: Current TV Dismisses Keith Olbermann
text: 10:06 p.m. | Updated For nearly a year now, Al Gore and Joel Hyatt have been building their liberal cable news channel, Current TV, with the mercurial television anchorman Keith Olbermann at its center.

headline: Now Online | T Design Spring 2012
text: Bold statements set the tone for the spring 2012 issue of T Design. The artist Doug Aitken’s house in Southern California sounds as striking as it looks, while a London town house contrasts historic architecture with opinionated, contemporary decorating. T visits a wind-swept West Coast garden with a personal style and a Chicago artist whose ceramic plants evoke a garden on another planet. We also meet a design-world style maker, a guru of bespoke speakers, an artist whose subject is almost everything, a couple who made a big move to the Midwest and, courtesy of The Selby, we stop in at the delightfully primal Brooklyn restaurant Isa. See all the stories here.

headline: The Week in Pictures for March 30
text: Subjects include a heated battle at the Park Slope Food Coop, a rescue of abused and abandoned dogs from Puerto Rico and a new plan for Midtown pedestrians.

headline: Jewish Rogues Gallery
text: Jewish villains are rare on television but there are some examples.

headline: Keren & Landis
text: In this self-made video, Keren Sachs and Landis Kauffman share the story of how they worked at the same company but their romance began after they ran into each other at an airport.

headline: Brighter Skies and a Flying Car, Too
text: THE New York auto show opens for press previews on Wednesday with spring in the air — and not just because of the weather.

headline: Designers’ Big Dreams Roll Into Manhattan
text: DREAMS have always been the currency of auto shows, where the admission price buys unlimited fantasies of awe-inspiring cars that never get dirty, break down or gulp premium unleaded at $4.50 a gallon.

headline: Five Visions of the Future
text: Five designers share their inspirations for cars that will move audiences at the Javits Center when the New York auto show opens on Friday.

headline: Claire & Ethan
text: In this self-made video, Claire James and Ethan Ravetch tetl the story of how they met in High School and despite some missed signals in senior year, they became a couple.

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, Mar. 30
text: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

headline: Banking Mysticism, Continued
text: Update: It’s obvious that many commenters don’t get the distinction between the proposition that banks create money — which every economics textbook, mine included, says they do (that’s what the money multiplier is all about) — and the proposition that their ability to create money is not constrained by the monetary base. Sigh.

headline: Panel Says Flu Research Is Safe to Publish
text: After a public furor over experiments that made a dangerous flu virus more contagious, a panel of scientific advisers reversed itself on Friday and recommended that full details of the research be published in scientific journals.

headline: Health Overhaul Is Backdrop as Obama Returns to Stump
text: BURLINGTON, Vt. — President Obama made no mention of this week’s closely watched Supreme Court hearing on the constitutionality of the 2010 health care overhaul when he delivered his standard stump speech at a fund-raiser attended by the party faithful here on Friday.

headline: The Wedding Expo Is Over. Now It’s Time for Divorce.
text: At the Metropolitan Pavilion on West 18th Street, divorce is following marriage, just as it does in life.

headline: Not Your Sunny Summer Fantasy
text: The sweet melodies that open Alfred Schnittke’s unsettling “(K)ein Sommernachtstraum” (“[Not] a Midsummer Night’s Dream”) sound later as if they had been filtered through shards of glass. An acidic undercurrent darkens the work’s playful exterior; cheery Neo-Classical and Baroque allusions soon become dissonant and even nightmarish. At one point a creepy tuba melody lurches below what sounds like a deranged circus band.

headline: Forestry Company From China Is Bankrupt
text: OTTAWA — Sino-Forest, a Chinese company that trades on the Toronto Stock Exchange, filed for bankruptcy protection in a Toronto court on Friday and said that it would try to sell or restructure its operations.

headline: Taming the Tiger of Achievement
text: One high-performing Stuyvesant High School graduate reflects on what motivated her to do well, and she is asking other top graduates from colleges and universities to tell her what drove them to succeed. Hint: Tiger Mom-style parental pressure is usually not involved.

headline: Saving a Dynasty From Enemies Both Familiar and Not
text: I knew when my son had to die.

headline: Just Try to Get This One on a Plane
text: A spring warning for puttering-in-the-garden types who have occasionally been startled by a garter snake as they pull the weeds: Soon you may be seeing a cousin of that garter lolling in your flowerbed. This snake will be fairly easy to distinguish from the other. It’ll be the one that’s longer than your house.

headline: Chasing Ghosts of Poets Past
text: ON 12th Street between Avenue A and First Avenue in the East Village, there is an empty lot, a dusty, fenced-in patch next to a school playground. On a recent sunny afternoon, some children were tossing around a baseball there, beneath two wildly flowering cherry blossom trees, oblivious to the history around them.

headline: Chic in Review | Lady Gaga Unveiled
text: All the fashion news of the week that’s fit to reprint.

headline: Lawyer Says Zuccotti Park Demonstrators Broke No Law
text: When hundreds of police officers entered Zuccotti Park early on Nov. 15, they dismantled tents and other structures that had been erected by Occupy Wall Street protesters in defiance of rules established in September by the park’s owner, Brookfield Properties.

headline: Friday Night Music: Sour Times
text: Special double-shot edition, original artist and cover:

headline: New York State’s 2012 Budget Sails Through Albany
text: ALBANY — The State Legislature approved a $132.6 billion spending plan on Friday for the fiscal year that begins Sunday, bringing to a punctual conclusion one of the smoothest state budget negotiations at the Capitol in years.

headline: Groupon’s Shares Fall on Revision
text: Groupon revised its financial results on Friday, an unexpected restatement that deepened losses for the daily deals site and once again raised questions about the accounting practices of the newly public company.

headline: Previewing the 2012 New York Auto Show
text: In Sunday’s Automobiles section, Jerry Garrett previews the New York auto show, which visits the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center next week, with press previews beginning Wednesday.

headline: Irrelevant Dirt on Trayvon Martin
text: It was inevitable that the media blitz on the killing of Trayvon Martin, an unarmed black teenager, would breed skepticism in some circles. No story that seems so open-and-shut—that seems like such a textbook example of criminalized walking-while-black—can, or should, pass without scrutiny.

headline: Plush Short Ribs Displace Stringy Brisket
text: SEVERAL years ago, my family banished brisket from our Seder.

headline: All You Can Eat, and Then Some
text: FOR almost 20 years, Churrasqueira Bairrada Rodizio Restaurant has been a popular spot in Mineola for all-you-can-eat Portuguese-style barbecue. So when Brasa Rodizio, with a similar format, opened not far away in September, I had to wonder, does the town need another restaurant serving the same kind of food? To judge from the size of the crowd and the smiles on customers’ faces at the new place on a recent Friday, I’d say the answer is yes.

headline: That Thing Called Good Taste
text: Before brands were brands, they were just companies with stories and nice carpeting. I remember going into the Mark Cross store on Fifth Avenue with my parents. (This was in the late ’60s.) There was an unfussy elegance to that store, just as there was to the main floor of Tiffany up the street, and it’s not hard to picture guys in sack suits and skinny ties, maybe a rumpled khaki raincoat, going to check out the desk blotters.

headline: Where Voter Turnout Was Up, and Down
text: The total number of voters in the Republican primary contests this year has increased from 2008, but turnout as a percentage of the eligible voting population is down.

headline: Flavors of Cuba, With a Haven for Cigars
text: THE restaurant Azúcar — Spanish for sugar, and the rallying cry of the queen of salsa, Célia Cruz — has the ingredients of a fine place. It has a lively bar scene. It offers a glimpse of sailboats’ masts, if not the boats themselves, along the Hudson nearby. And its executive chef and owner, Nick Vazquez, won the Food Network’s “Throwdown! With Bobby Flay” with his Cuban sandwich last year.

headline: A Firm Look for Exercise
text: TODAY, when you hear the words “poker face,” you don’t think of Senate subcommittee hearings. You think of Lady Gaga. But when it comes to doling out credit, one would have to hand out a goodly share of responsibility for our real-world poker-face pandemic to Dr. Fredric Brandt, a dermatologist. Some 15-odd years ago, Dr. Brandt burst onto the scene as a leading practitioner of (and proselytizer for) an alarming-sounding method of easing wrinkles by paralyzing subcutaneous muscles with injections of botulism toxin.

headline: Spring Nationals in Memphis
text: On the final day of the Spring Nationals in Memphis, the Jacoby Open Swiss Teams was decided in the last round. The leaders, Kasper Konow, Anders Hagen, Gregers Bjarnarson and Michael Askgaard from Denmark, played against the team lying second, Gaylor Kasle of Boca Raton, Fla., Larry Kozlove of Louisville, Ky., Peter Boyd of Darnestown, Md., Steve Robinson of Arlington, Va., Fred Stewart of Bloomington, N.Y., and Kit Woolsey of Kensington, Calif.

headline: Behold the Speckled Eggs
text: Shortly after 5:30p.m. on Friday, Bobby arrived on the ledge with a rodent for his mate, Rosie, who was busy brooding the eggs. He stood sentinel for several minutes before diving out of sight with the long-tailed creature clutched in his beak. Rosie slowly roused herself from the nest to join him, leaving two speckled eggs exposed to the world, but not for long. In flew Bobby, who briefly took over warming duty, while Rosie stretched her wings and had an evening meal.

headline: Search Is On in New Mexico for Revered Ultrarunner
text: Micah True, a mythic figure among extreme-distance runners, went for a 12-mile run Tuesday morning and has yet to return, setting off a search in the Gila Wilderness of southwestern New Mexico.

headline: Baby, It’s Cold (Hot?) Outside
text: EUGENIA GONZALEZ RUIZ-OLLOQUI was not happy. Both a stylish young socialite used to having her photo in Vogue and the longtime public relations director for the designer Michael Bastian, Ms. Ruiz-Olloqui had a problem that, until lately, was new to her. She just couldn’t figure out what to wear.

headline: Let’s Talk About Early Puberty
text: Elizabeth Weil’s article on girls starting to show signs of puberty as young as 6 and 7 has already generated some great discussion in the comments section.
