headline: For Passover, Something Old or Something New?
text: I’m gearing up for Passover cooking, trying to plan the menu for the seder meal. A few things have already been decided. For a main course, my family braises short ribs in place of the usual brisket. Of course, there will be matzo ball soup, made by my mother (though Joan Nathan’s matzo balls were delicious). We will have three kinds of charoset: Ashkenazi, Sephardic and possibly one from Yemen made with dates, figs and spices, and then rolled into balls. We’ll serve gefilte fish, garnished with salmon roe (so pretty!).

headline: Week in Pictures for March 30
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. The subjects include a heated battle over at the Park Slope Food Co-op over whether to boycott Israeli-made goods, a rescue of abused and abandoned dogs from Puerto Rico and a new plan for Midtown pedestrians.

headline: Montreal’s Marsch Speaks M.L.S. Fluently, French Haltingly
text: It would not be entirely accurate to say that Montreal Impact Coach Jesse Marsch sat in his hot-tub time machine many years ago when he was in middle school contemplating the value of taking French.

headline: Gas Costs More, or Less?
text: Are gas prices soaring, or collapsing? It depends which gas you are talking about. Gasoline prices are up sharply, but natural gas prices in the United States have fallen to their lowest levels in a decade.

headline: Money Behind Campaigns
text: To the Editor:

headline: One on One: Clay Johnson, Author of ‘The Information Diet’
text: Clay Johnson, the former director of Sunlight Labs, a group within The Sunlight Foundation, a non-profit that uses data to promote transparency in government, discusses his new book, “The Information Diet”. He says consumers have to take responsibility for the type of information they consume, much like consumer must take responsibility for the foods they eat. He says we have to create a sustainable news movement, much like we’ve created a sustainable food movement. Here is an edited version of my interview which covers bias, data and why reading about Snooki is like smoking in public:

headline: Not Waiting to Say Goodbye
text: BOB BERGERON was so relentlessly cheery that people sometimes found it off-putting. If you ran into him at the David Barton Gym on West 23rd Street, where he worked out nearly ever morning at 7, and you complained about the rain, he would smile and say you’d be better off focusing on a problem you could fix.

headline: The Perils of the American Racetrack
text: To the Editor:

headline: In Wisconsin Speech, Romney Makes His Case Against Obama
text: APPLETON, Wis. — Just days before the Republican presidential primary, Mitt Romney swept into Wisconsin, sounding general election themes and offering a forceful, and at times lyrical, speech laying out a stark and clear contrast between himself and President Obama.

headline: A Voice That’s So Sultry You Might Get Burned
text: Gregory Generet has a voice so strong and forceful that it seems to erupt from deep within. As he performed at the Metropolitan Room on Wednesday evening, several inner storytellers jostled to be heard in a show made up equally of jazz, soul and blues. In his more volcanic performances, your impulse was to run for cover.

headline: Another Feast for the Jilted Bride
text: Just when “Downton Abbey” made America fall back in love with British costume dramas, here comes “Great Expectations” to break the spell.

headline: Tiger Mom, Meet Diet Enforcer
text: THE high-achieving mother publicly laid out her methods, strict and punishing. She wrote of how her young daughter, told that she needed to change, resisted, rebelled, sometimes threw a tantrum. But in the end, the mother proclaimed, her tactics triumphed.

headline: Why One Gas Is Cheap and One Isn’t
text: THE price of gas has risen rapidly this year.

headline: NATO and Libya Deaths
text: To the Editor:

headline: Ah, the Beloved Cars of My Youth
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Vegan Retreat for Carnivores, Too
text: THE décor at G-Zen — mandalas and other Eastern art forms, wooden tables with woven place mats — gives this Branford restaurant the feel of an upscale spiritual retreat center. The menu is entirely vegan, with lots of gluten-free dishes and a few raw ones. As noted on its Web site, G-Zen aims to appeal to a nonvegan audience, too: a tall order for a restaurant offering vegan versions of well-loved classics, like pizza and crab cakes, in addition to familiar vegetarian fare. But G-Zen often succeeds, and many of the best dishes here are the most daring.

headline: Romney Won’t Play the Lottery
text: FOND DU LAC, Wis. — At an unplanned stop at Schreiner’s Restaurant here Friday evening, Mitt Romney bought four slices of cherry pie, chatted with diners and waded into the fever over the Mega Millions lottery, whose jackpot is estimated at $640 million.

headline: Turning Trout Into a Trophy Dish
text: THE first day of April marks the opening of trout season in Westchester and nearby counties. But if you aren’t ready to pull on hip waders and venture into the area’s well-stocked streams, you might want to try your luck with one of the many trout dishes surfacing this spring on local restaurant menus.

headline: 2 Families Tangle Over Diamonds
text: In the mezzanine gallery of the Natural History Museum in London are some of its cherished treasures: the 1,384-carat Devonshire Emerald; a replica of Queen Victoria’s Koh-i-noor diamond; and the Aurora Pyramid of Hope, a rare collection of 295 naturally colored diamonds.

headline: Taking Responsibility for Death
text: I WAS standing by my 89-year-old mother’s hospital bed when she asked a doctor, “Is there anything you can do here to give me back the life I had last year, when I wasn’t in pain every minute?” The young medical resident, stunned by the directness of the question, blurted out, “Honestly, ma’am, no.”

headline: Top Derby Contender Lightly Tested, and Healthy
text: Despite a narrow loss in the Breeders’ Cup Juvenile, Union Rags exited 2011 with his reputation intact. Most thought he was the best 2-year-old in the sport and the most likely winner of the 2012 Kentucky Derby. All that the trainer Michael Matz had to do was to get him there, healthy and on top of his game.

headline: Pragmatism on the Prairie
text: REPUBLICANS often accuse Democrats of being socialists. But in North Dakota, socialism has been thriving for decades. It is the only state with a state-owned bank and a profitable state-owned grain elevator and flour mill, both of which the good people of North Dakota, who mostly vote Republican in presidential elections, embrace and value. Both institutions began embroiled in controversy. With all the vitriol about socialism and radicalism in the national debate today, is there anything we can learn from North Dakota?

headline: A German Playboy, With a Well-Kept, Earnest Past
text: BERLIN

headline: In Myanmar, an Election Doomed to Fail
text: Provo, Utah

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Facebook Ban and Jumping Robot
text: Here are some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web on Friday. There are more here.

headline: Trying to Rein In a Shakespearean Fury
text: If only King Leontes, the main character in Shakespeare’s dark romance “The Winter’s Tale,” were a little more like Hamlet! He would think twice before jailing his queen, the spotless Hermione, on charges of treason, conspiracy and adultery. He would pause before insisting that their newborn daughter be left to die far from their home in Sicilia. And he would shrink from ordering the murder of the man he is sure is Hermione’s paramour, his lifelong best friend, King Polixenes of Bohemia.

headline: The Biggest Stage, Literally
text: NEW ORLEANS — They say the N.C.A.A. tournament is the biggest stage in college basketball.

headline: Fighting Terrorism, French-Style
text: PARIS

headline: Friday Food Links
text: A federal court ruled last week that the F.D.A. must finally decide whether the routine practice of feeding antibiotics to healthy farm animals poses a serious danger to human health. If the F.D.A. concludes that it does, they must ban the practice. (My best guess is that the F.D.A. will hold true to form and wind up caving to the meat industry, but if I’m wrong I’ll apologize and join the celebration.)

headline: Warned of an Attack on the Internet, and Getting Ready
text: SAN FRANCISCO — On a quiet Sunday in mid-February, something curious attracted the attention of the behind-the-scenes engineers who scour the Internet for signs of trouble. There, among the ubiquitous boasts posted by the hacking collective Anonymous, was a call to attack some of the network’s most crucial parts.

headline: Tale of Love and Illness Ends in Deaths
text: His was a love story, Charles D. Snelling wrote — a tale of a shiftless dreamer and the woman who saved him, of the life they built over six decades and the disease that stood no chance of erasing it. By the end, he said, their time together had become a case study in reciprocity.

headline: A Cardboard Fountain, Braving the Elements
text: DOLPHINS dance in cresting waves alongside scaly-tailed seahorses bearing trumpeting angels and a wild-haired harpy. Conches rest on boulders that emerge from the sea, where Poseidon grips his trident and towers 14 feet above them all.

headline: Knee Injury Leads Nadal to Pull Out of Semifinal
text: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla. — With a shot at a record seventh French Open title two months away, Rafael Nadal passed up a chance at the biggest title he has failed to win.

headline: Linking Multiple Shootings to One Gun, With a Microscope and a Great Memory
text: The trigger of a semiautomatic pistol is pulled, and a firing pin in the back of the gun darts forward, slamming into the primer on the rear of the cartridge holding the bullet and causing a small explosion. This ignites the gunpowder in the cartridge, blasting the bullet out of the barrel with tens of thousands of pounds of pressure. That blast goes both ways, driving the left-behind shell casing backward hard enough to leave an impression from the inside of the gun on the shiny brass.

headline: Training in Baseball’s Cradle? It’s a Spring Break Option
text: For years, some New York private schools have sent their baseball teams for “spring training” in Florida, using their spring break week to play some warm-weather ball and live out a Derek Jeter fantasy, with chaperones.

headline: Overcoming ‘Physics Envy’
text: HOW scientific are the social sciences?

headline: New ‘Trophy Video’ Recorded by Syrian Soldier Is Leaked to Activists
text: Disturbing video posted online by Syrian activists on Friday, said to have been recorded recently in the Damascus suburb of Eastern Ghouta, appeared to offer fresh evidence of the brutal crackdown by forces loyal to President Bashar al-Assad.

headline: After Howls of Protest, WTA Will Address Shrieks
text: Years ago, grunting in sports was the province of wrestlers, shot-putters and linemen in football.

headline: An Enduring Tale of Bigotry and Justice
text: Scanning a listing of theater productions can be like looking at a menu. What do you feel like having? Are you in the mood for something new? Or craving some familiar comfort food?

headline: After a Merger, a Show About Rebirth
text: MARK SPINA and Bev Sheehan have crossed professional paths frequently over the years. He is the founder and artistic director of the Theater Project, which was based for many years in Cranford; she was until recently the artistic director of her own company, What Exit?, in Maplewood.

headline: In Manhattan Pizza War, Price of Slice Keeps Dropping
text: In the amped-up war of commerce and 75-cent pizza on the Avenue of the Americas in Midtown, a perilous moment is approaching. Circumstances suggest that ravenous New Yorkers might soon witness 50-cent pizza, 25-cent pizza or, yes, free pizza.

headline: Celebrating Poetry Out Loud
text: APRIL is National Poetry Month, which means different things in different places on Long Island, but at least three events will celebrate Walt Whitman, the island’s own “good gray poet,” who was born in West Hills in 1819.

headline: Saints Coach Files Appeal of Suspension; Decision Is Expected Soon
text: New Orleans Saints Coach Sean Payton, who was scheduled to begin a one-year suspension on Sunday for his role in the team’s bounty system, appealed the ban Friday.

headline: Rape-Case Juror Called District Attorney ‘Wonderful’ Friend in Note
text: In late 2008, Lloyd E. Constantine, a lawyer and longtime adviser to former Gov. Eliot Spitzer, nearly gushed with affection when he explained in a letter to two candidates that he was not choosing one over the other in the election for Manhattan district attorney.

headline: Limit on Public Sector Unions Is Voided
text: A federal judge concluded on Friday that parts of a law limiting public sector unions in Wisconsin — the law that started a political battle between Republican officials and labor leaders in the state a year ago — violate the Constitution.

headline: Groucho Lives! (In Two Places)
text: For the Groucho Marx fans of this column who continue to plead for more, the information contained herein, if new to you, might just make your day.

headline: Competitors on the Court, but Economic Teammates
text: LEXINGTON, Ky. — The rivalry between Kentucky’s two best college basketball teams, which will face off in the N.C.A.A. semifinals on Saturday night, is nothing short of a state civil war. Team flags are flying from car windows, mayors have wagered, and a brawl between two fans, one of them hooked up to a dialysis machine, had to be stopped by the police.

headline: Time to Elect the Worst Idea
text: Our topic today is picking the worst new trend of the political season.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Adagio
text: Women seem to be taking cues from the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum's Renaissance portraits, experimenting with elaborate hairstyles decorated with jewels.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: March 30, 2012

headline: Chinese Company and Employee Deny Any Involvement in Hacking Attacks
text: SHANGHAI — Tencent, a Chinese Internet company, denied on Friday that one of its employees had been involved in a recent breach of computers belonging to Japanese and Indian companies, as well as Tibetan activists.

headline: Orwell and March Madness
text: If you’ve been watching the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball championship — a k a March Madness — you’ve undoubtedly seen the commercial. It’s an N.C.A.A. ad that shows college athletes pumping iron, running sprints and playing games. The voice-over, though, talks not about athletic achievement but academic accomplishment. “African-American males who are student-athletes are 10 percent more likely to graduate,” says the narrator. As the ad concludes, a female athlete looks into the camera and says, “Still think we’re just a bunch of dumb jocks?”

headline: Primary Turnout Could Signal Trouble for G.O.P.
text: After presidential primaries or caucuses in 28 states, voters are sending a potentially troubling message to the Republican Party: We aren’t necessarily as excited about the campaign as you think.

headline: Bottling Up the Big Men
text: NEW ORLEANS — This year, the Final Four is about the big men. There has been too much talk of rivalries instead of post moves and famous coaches instead of box-outs. The best player on the three best teams remaining is a big man; Kentucky’s Anthony Davis, Kansas’ Thomas Robinson and Ohio State’s Jared Sullinger all expect to be N.B.A. lottery draft picks. Louisville’s post stalwart is no slouch. Gorgui Dieng has excelled in tournament play and anchors the country’s stingiest defense.

headline: Big Oil’s Bogus Campaign
text: President Obama and the Senate Democrats have again fallen short in their quest to eliminate billions of dollars in unnecessary tax breaks for an oil industry that is rolling in enormous profits. A big reason for that failure is that some of those profits are being continuously recycled to win the support of pliable legislators, underwrite misleading advertising campaigns and advance an energy policy defined solely by more oil and gas production.

headline: Gov. Cuomo Budgets His Way
text: Gov. Andrew Cuomo of New York and state legislators are celebrating the completion of a new state budget — on time, for a second year in a row. This budget increases much-needed funds for schools and relieves local governments of increases in Medicaid costs, saving New York City alone more than $1 billion in the next five years. Public transit in the city did O.K., as did upstate residents who will get some help with roads and bridges.

headline: Inside Republican Primary Zaniness, Actual Debate
text: Much media attention has been paid to some of the more outlandish aspects of the Republican nominating contest, writes Anand Giridharadas in his latest Page Two column: Newt Gingrich‘s call for colonizing the moon, Mitt Romney baptizing dead non-Mormons long ago, or Ron Paul half-joking that New York ought to be renamed Welfaria, Rapetown or Dirtburg.

headline: Leading the World Bank
text: President Obama’s nomination of Jim Yong Kim to head the World Bank is an inspired choice. The South Korean-born medical doctor and president of Dartmouth College has a stellar reputation as a global health expert.

headline: Shirley May France Setters, Long-Distance Swimmer, Dies at 79
text: “Shirley May Dares the Sea,” the headline in The New York World-Telegram declared on Aug. 1, 1949 — one of hundreds in publications on both sides of the Atlantic that trumpeted the derring-do and physical attributes of a 17-year-old girl from Somerset, Mass., who tried, and tried again, to conquer the roiling currents of the English Channel.

headline: Chickens on the Loose
text: On fair days, I’ve been letting the chickens have the run of the farm. I come out of the house, and the birds are waiting at the chicken-yard fence like petitioners in some Russian novel but with boundless optimism instead of resignation and despair. Out they come, except for the hens, who are busy laying. It is a 30-bird flock of many breeds — Appenzeller, Penedesenca, Orpington, Campine.

headline: Pressel’s Fashion Statement
text: RANCHO MIRAGE, Calif. — It’s a match made in heaven, as was obvious to anyone who saw Morgan Pressel walking arm in arm with her fiancé, Andy Bush, on Friday at Mission Hills Country Club.

headline: Italy: A Warning on Corruption
text: Italy lacks effective safeguards against corruption, the global anticorruption organization Transparency International said Friday. Lorenzo Segato, director of the Research Center on Security and Crime, which carried out the study for Transparency International, said Italy fell short on many counts, with questionable institutional integrity, weak regulations, biased news media and a social code that condones certain illegalities. Officials say corruption costs Italy about $80 billion a year. The organization called for Italy to set up an independent anticorruption agency.

headline: Two Sides to Labor in China
text: HONG KONG — The shorter workweeks and higher pay that Apple’s biggest contract manufacturer, Foxconn, has promised would mean fundamental changes to factory work in China — assuming enough workers can be found in the first place.

headline: Labor Audit on Foxconn Is Thorough, Experts Say
text: The Fair Labor Association, the global monitoring group, has for many years weathered criticism from workers’ advocates that it is cozy with the companies it audits and soft in its findings.

headline: Worker Presumed Dead After Fall From Throgs Neck Bridge
text: A 35-year-old construction worker on his second day as a painter on the Throgs Neck Bridge was killed on Friday, the authorities said, when he slipped from a platform and fell 130 feet into the water below.

headline: Corrections: March 31
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Disabled Britons Say Changes to Aid Endanger Them
text: LONDON — Prime Minister David Cameron says he wants to end Britain’s “sick-note culture” of fraudulent disability claims. But his new get-tough policy has left his coalition government in conflict with thousands of ill and disabled Britons.

headline: Local Chamber Music, World-Class Fare
text: CHAMBER music long ago left the chamber, migrating to the concert hall and all manner of modest stages. But even in this age of musical democratization, it is noteworthy when ordinary music lovers year after year band together to bring first-rate chamber fare to their communities. That is what Friends of Music has done.

headline: Role Player Tailors Abilities to Fit Mets’ Needs
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — The Temple of Apollo at Delphi had inscribed on its portico an aphorism that went tragically unheeded by numerous figures in Greek mythology: Know thyself.

headline: The Grid Menagerie
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — This one was tough, as Saturdays are wont to be, but it wasn’t a brain breaker. Your mileage might have varied. But there sure were a lot of animals in this puzzle, right?

headline: This Time, Sullinger Will Play
text: NEW ORLEANS — As Kansas and Ohio State prepare to meet for the second time this season, they are constantly reminded about their earlier encounter. Kansas won that first meeting, at home, fairly easily. The score was 78-67, advantage Jayhawks, last Dec. 10.

headline: Canadian Gave Intelligence to Russia, U.S. Officials Say
text: WASHINGTON — A Canadian naval officer accused of a major security breach had access to secrets circulating in a five-nation intelligence alliance and was passing information to Russia, American officials confirmed this week.

headline: Speak Up? Raise Your Hand? That May No Longer Be Necessary
text: When sororities elect officers, this is how they typically conduct voting: Members write names on paper slips, which are then folded, collected, unfolded and counted. And if there are runoffs? Repeat process. When you’re electing 13 officers, the evening becomes a triumph of sisterly dedication over marathon tedium.

headline: Pineda, Sore and Struggling, Could Be Odd Man Out
text: TAMPA, Fla. — The mystery surrounding the Yankees’ starting rotation might have finally been settled Friday night, but certainly not in a good way for the team.

headline: Looking for the Right Blend in Europe
text: The performance of Starbucks stores in Europe has been lackluster.

headline: Pressed on All Sides, Leader of Coup in Mali Digs In
text: BAMAKO, Mali — The motorcade bristles with guns, just for him. Freshly minted buttons with his photograph are pinned to his officers. The new Constitution makes him supreme boss and wipes out Parliament. The harassment and imprisonment of the opposition are under way.

headline: Events in Connecticut
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: Albert Hadley, High Society’s Decorator, Dies at 91
text: Albert Hadley, a renowned interior designer whose brave and creative eye, distilling both classic and contemporary styles, made him a standard-bearing decorator for the rich and powerful in American society, died on Thursday in Nashville. He was 91.

headline: Sense of Peril for Health Law Gives Insurers Pause
text: As the Supreme Court considers the constitutionality of the federal health care law, one option that had seemed unthinkable to its designers and supporters now seems at least possible: that the court could strike down the entire law.

headline: Events in Westchester
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: Activist Presses for Inquiry Into Senior Putin Deputy
text: MOSCOW — Aleksei Navalny, Russia’s most prominent anticorruption activist, added to the pressure on the Russian government to investigate allegations of what he called corrupt financial practices by a senior deputy to Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin.

headline: Letter From Lloyd E. Constantine
text: Lloyd E. Constantine, a juror in the Michael Pena rape case, sent this letter to Cyrus R. Vance Jr. and Richard Aborn in 2008.

headline: Events in New Jersey
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Merger of Performers’ Unions Approved
text: LOS ANGELES — Members of two performers’ unions have overwhelmingly approved a merger plan, creating a combined union representing about 150,000 actors, broadcasters, news writers and others in the entertainment and media industries, their representatives said on Friday.

headline: Prosecutors Seek Life Sentence for Arms Trafficker
text: Federal prosecutors in Manhattan asked a judge on Friday to impose a life sentence on Viktor Bout, a former Soviet military officer convicted in November in an arms trafficking and terrorism conspiracy, a court filing shows.

headline: Rangers Move Closer to Clinching Top Mark in East
text: Ryan Callahan, the Rangers’ captain, was handed the Steven McDonald Extra Effort Award before Friday’s game. As if he needed to show he was really worthy, Callahan made a sharp pass, checked an opponent to the ice and thwarted a rush with a poke check — all within 30 seconds.

headline: Nuclear Commission Clears Reactors in South Carolina
text: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission voted 4 to 1 on Friday to approve a plan to build two reactors at a power plant in South Carolina, the second nuclear plant construction permit to be in granted less than two months after a 34-year hiatus. The Scana Corporation plans to build the reactors at the Virgil C. Summer plant northwest of Columbia. The company plans to cover 55 percent of the project’s estimated $10.2 billion cost, with Santee Cooper, South Carolina’s largest power producer, paying the remainder. Based in Cayce, S.C., Scana, which submitted its application to the Nuclear Regulatory Commission in March 2008, said its first unit would not begin operating until 2017, about a year behind schedule, because of delays in the commission’s licensing process. The second is expected to start running in 2018.

headline: Events on Long Island
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: A Legacy of Solitary
text: California has for decades used long-term solitary confinement as a way to combat the gang violence in its overcrowded prisons. But the state is now proposing changes in its policy that could decrease the use of isolation.

headline: Fighting a Drawn-Out Battle Against Solitary Confinement
text: ATWATER, Calif. — Ernesto Lira is not a murderer. He has never participated in a prison riot. The crime that landed him behind bars was carrying three foil-wrapped grams of methamphetamine in his car.

headline: Senate Confirms 2 for Justice Department
text: WASHINGTON — The Senate voted Thursday night to confirm Michael E. Horowitz to be the Justice Department’s inspector general and Kathryn Keneally as the assistant attorney general for the tax division, filling two important vacancies.

headline: Photo Replay: March 30
text: A view of the day in sports, from figure skating in France to swimming in Indianapolis.

headline: Keeping Up With Tseng
text: RANCHO MIRAGE, Calif. — By the time Lindsey Wright teed off Friday afternoon, Yani Tseng had posted her second straight 68 to move to the top of the leader board at the Kraft Nabisco Championship, the first women’s major of the year.

headline: Blogs, Books and Biscuits
text: Ed Hamilton, 51, runs the Living With Legends: Hotel Chelsea Blog out of his 220-square-foot room on the eighth floor of the hotel, which once housed Leonard Cohen, Dylan Thomas, Sid Vicious, Jack Kerouac and Patti Smith, among many luminous others. It was shut to guests last summer, before new owners began renovating. Mr. Hamilton, the author of “Legends of the Chelsea Hotel: Living With Artists and Outlaws in New York’s Rebel Mecca,” and his wife, Debbie Martin, 51, both from Kentucky, have shared the wee room at the hotel since 1997 and, along with other residents, are fighting eviction efforts. They spend their Sundays ambulating the city, trying to avoid crowds and tracking down Southern food.

headline: Rodgers Won’t Return to Red Bulls
text: The Red Bulls are in the market for a striker after the United States denied a visa renewal for Luke Rodgers of England. No reason was given for the denial. Rodgers scored nine goals for the Red Bulls last season and energized the offense. The club must quickly find another striker, especially with a knee injury to Juan Agudelo that will sideline him for six weeks and perhaps more. Late Friday, the Red Bulls sold Rodgers to Lillestrom of the Norwegian first division.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,902 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American recently:

headline: ‘Hunger’ Talk, Topped With Ham
text: The muse at Tertulia, a rustic simulation of the taverns and cervecerías that Seamus Mullen, the chef and owner, frequented in northern Spain in his younger days, is the Ibérico ham, which studs the menu like confetti. A hunk of it sits in a slicer at the end of the marble bar for patrons in need of instant salty gratification with their $16 Martinez (Plymouth gin, Perucchi vermouth) and $14 medley of Tanqueray and sparkling cider served via spigot from an oak cask.

headline: Answers to Questions About New York
text: Take the 8 Train?

headline: Romney Skips G.O.P. Rivals in Anti-Obama Speech
text: APPLETON, Wis. — Four days before the Republican presidential primary here, Mitt Romney swept into Wisconsin, sounding general election themes and offering a forceful — and at times lyrical — speech laying out a stark and clear contrast between himself and President Obama.

headline: The Week’s Business News in Pictures
text: Republicans have proved less receptive to some business groups’ aims and a crucial Apple supplier pledged to improve its factories’ conditions.

headline: Where Would You Live if Life Were an App?
text: APP Upwardly Mobile

headline: U.S. Soldier’s Lawyer Says Access Denied to Evidence
text: The lawyer representing Staff Sgt. Robert Bales, the soldier charged with 17 counts of murder in the deaths of Afghan civilians this month, said that military prosecutors had denied members of his legal team access to witnesses at a Kandahar hospital, as well as to investigative files, medical records and surveillance video.

headline: The Word of God, on Mixtape
text: TWENTY-FIVE years ago, when bulky twin-speaker cassette players were still popular, Leyland E. George bought a nice, loud Panasonic for $90, clipped a shoulder strap to it and began his boombox ministry in Bushwick, Brooklyn.

headline: Campaign Treasurer Is Guilty of Fraud
text: LOS ANGELES — Kinde Durkee, a former campaign treasurer for a number of California Democrats, pleaded guilty on Friday to five counts of mail fraud involving a long-running scheme in which she stole millions of dollars from candidates.

headline: Young, in School and Employed
text: Emily Berl, a photographer based in Brooklyn, turned her lens on young people juggling demanding jobs and the rigors of high school.

headline: Giants Running Back Is Suspended
text: Andre Brown, a reserve running back for the Giants perhaps best known for coming up with a song celebrating the team’s Super Bowl championship, was suspended for four games for violating the N.F.L. policy on performance-enhancing drugs, the league announced. Brown, who spent last season on the practice squad, is eligible to participate in off-season and preseason activities and exhibition games but cannot take part in regular-season work until after the Giants’ Week 4 game.

headline: Muamba Posts Picture on Twitter
text: The picture was posted on Muamba’s Twitter account on Friday. He looks pretty good for a man who doctors said was “effectively dead” for 78 minutes after he collapsed on the field during an F.A. Cup match on March 17.

headline: U.S. Has No Need to Test Atomic Arsenal, Report Says
text: WASHINGTON — The United States does not need to explode nuclear weapons in order to be sure its aging arsenal is still potent, and its ability to detect weapons tests by others is good, according to a report released Friday by the National Academy of Sciences.

headline: Childbirth Is Taking Longer, Study Finds
text: Women spend much more time in labor than they did 50 years ago, a new study has found, and one reason may be that obstetric practices have changed.

headline: Building a Business on Churches for Sale
text: AZUSA, Calif. — In better economic times, workers in this dusty inland town east of Los Angeles built motor homes in the low-slung complex at 975 West First Street.

headline: Excited for the Playoffs? How About Now?
text: Here’s a look at the latest spot in the N.H.L.’s Stanley Cup playoffs advertising campaign “Because It’s The Cup.” Called “Outside,” it will make its TV debut during Sunday afternoon’s Philadelphia Flyers-Pittsburgh Penguins game on NBC.

headline: Tibetan Exiles March for One of Their Own Who Died in Flames
text: “It was with some fanfare that the body of Jamphel Yeshi arrived beneath cloudless skies at the main temple of Dharamsala on Friday morning,” Edward Wong writes in The New York Times.

headline: Barenboim Presides Over Berlin Music Festival
text: The 10-day classical music festival Staatsoper Festtage returned to Berlin on Friday with a roster of performances featuring international stars. Even in Berlin’s crowded music calendar, the festival stands out with its lineup of high-profile collaborations with La Scala and other European heavyweights. The events include not only brand-new productions, but also the previous year’s headliner, Die Walküre, which was met with enthusiastic cheers (as well as loud boos) during its premiere in 2011.

headline: The Early Word: Oil
text: Today’s Times

headline: Coup Rumors Spur China to Hem in Social Networking Sites
text: BEIJING — China started a sweeping crackdown of its vibrant social networking media over the weekend, detaining six people, closing 16 Web sites and shutting off the comment function for two gigantic microblog services.

headline: Tribunal Suspends Approval of Posco Steel Project in India
text: An Indian tribunal dealt a fresh blow on Friday to a long-delayed, high-profile steel project proposed by the South Korean company Posco by suspending its environmental approval and directing regulators to review the project again, Vikas Bajaj writes in The New York Times.

headline: Ryan Leaf’s Statement After His Arrest
text: The former Chargers quarterback Ryan Leaf, who has battled an addiction to prescription drugs but who had appeared to right his life recently, was arrested Friday in his hometown in Montana, Great Falls, on burglary and drug possession charges, the police said. He later released a statement:

headline: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
text: Jammu and Kashmir: Mirwaiz Umar Farooq, chief of the moderate faction of Hurriyat Conference, a coalition of separatist groups in Kashmir, is “supported and controlled” by Pakistan’s spy agency, Inter-Services Intelligence (ISI), an American attorney said before a U.S. district court in Alexandria, Virginia, Kashmir Live reports. This claim was made on Friday by the attorney ahead of the scheduled sentencing of Syed Ghulam Nabi Fai, an American citizen, charged with illegally working for the ISI and promoting the cause of self-determination in Kashmir (Hindustan Times).

headline: What Price a Dead Shark?
text: LONDON — Don’t know much about art, but you know what you like? Well, what do you think of Damien Hirst, he of the pickled shark and diamond-encrusted skull?

headline: TurboTax for iPad Was Better Than My Accountant
text: For years, I used to go to a fancy accountant to get my taxes done. It cost me around $750, and I always wound up owing at least $1,000 in the end. Very annoying.

headline: Floodgates
text: Once again, we’re hearing warnings — including from some people who should know better — that the “floodgates” of inflation may be about to open. It’s funny how repeated total failures of prediction don’t seem to diminish the confidence of inflationistas in their insights.

headline: Let Them Eat Charity
text: The other day, at my daughter’s private school in Sunnyvale, California, a parent handed me a flier soliciting donations for a 7-year-old boy, Ujjwal Sharma, who was recently diagnosed with leukemia. The leaflet showed Ujjwal (who lives in Jhansi, Uttar Pradesh) on a hospital bed, hooked up to all sorts of medical equipment. His parents, the flier said, are nearly broke.

headline: It’s Panem in N. Carolina For ‘Hunger Games’ Fans
text: Fans of “The Hunger Games” books whose thirst for the trilogy wasn’t slaked by the opening of the blockbuster film last weekend can still visit the country of Panem, where teenagers are pitted against one another in deadly fights. It takes only a vivid imagination and transportation to North Carolina, where the movie was shot. The North Carolina Division of Tourism has published a four-day self-guided tour as well as a list of spots of interest. Included on the list is the abandoned Henry River Mill Village, outside Hildebran, which was the site of District 12, where the main characters live.

headline: U.S. Women Stop in Japan on the Way to the Olympics
text: The United States women’s national team is playing two games this week in Japan — Sunday against the hosts in Sendai and Tuesday against Brazil in Chiba — that are part exhibition (what is being called the inaugural Kirin Challenge Cup), and part commemoration of last year’s earthquake and tsunami that devastated parts of the country.

headline: Art Makes a Statement for Business, Too
text: THE artwork that organizations choose for their buildings, or for their grounds, is as important as the art that people select for their homes.

headline: Military Metamorphosis
text: MY father, William G. Long Sr., was part of the crew charged with loading the atom bomb into the Enola Gay in World War II. His unit was the 509th Composite Group,  reporting to Col. Paul W. Tibbets Jr., the pilot. Dad’s military service shaped his life, and consequently it shaped mine.

headline: At Element Hotels, Power Your Laptop As You Pedal
text: In a green twist on multitasking, Element Hotels has introduced a power-generating stationary bike at its Miami location, offering guests the opportunity to plug in and recharge their cellphones, laptops, MP3 players or other electronic devices while burning calories.

headline: The Driver in Ford’s Amazing Race
text: IN 2008, the Ford Motor Company seemed caught in a death spiral.

headline: Computer Science for the Rest of Us
text: READING, writing and — refactoring code?

headline: Why Gas Prices Are Out of Any President’s Control
text: EVERYONE knows it’s dangerous to ingest gasoline or to inhale its fumes. But I am starting to believe that merely thinking about the price of gasoline can damage cognitive processing. Thus I may be risking some of my precious few remaining brain cells by writing about that topic.

headline: Tiger and the Stock Market, Together Again
text: WHAT do Tiger Woods and the S.& P. 500 have in common?

headline: United Arab Emirates Shutters U.S.-Backed Group
text: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia — As Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton worked hard on Saturday to focus attention on deepening security ties with the Arab nations of the Persian Gulf, she found herself having to deal with a surprising act of diplomatic defiance: the decision by the United Arab Emirates, an ally, to shutter the offices of an American-financed group that promotes democracy.

headline: The Best Scorecard Is the One You Keep for Yourself
text: This interview with  Charlotte Beers was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant. Ms. Beers, former chairwoman and C.E.O. of Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide,  now runs seminars called “The X Factor” for women who are leaders.

headline: A Suspicious Event in the South Bronx, Maybe
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Released but Never Exonerated, a Man Fights for Freedom
text: A couple of Fridays ago, Kerry Max Cook, who was released from Texas’ death row in 1997 after two decades, went to pick up his 11-year-old son, Kerry Justice, from his North Dallas school. Class was just letting out. As Mr. Cook approached a group of children and their parents, a little girl squirmed out of her mother’s arms and ran toward him. “Mr. Kerry!” she called. He laughed as she jumped into his arms. “Haleigh!” he shouted, and began tickling her. “She adores Mr. Kerry,” her mother said.

headline: The Human Voice, as Game Changer
text: Burlington, Mass.

headline: Distressed Cities Weigh Bold Tactics in a New Fiscal Era
text: PHILADELPHIA — Amid all the sobering discussions of what happens when cities run out of money, fiscal sleight of hand and time, the most telling detail at a conference on distressed municipalities here last week just might have been the one about the fire truck that was the wrong color.

headline: How to Prevent a Financial Overdose
text: THE Food and Drug Administration vets new drugs before they reach the market. But imagine if there were a Wall Street version of the F.D.A. — an agency that examined new financial instruments and ensured that they were safe and benefited society, not just bankers.

headline: A Wary Mexico Sizes Up Contenders for the Presidency
text: GUADALAJARA, Mexico — It is essentially a battle, cynical commentators joke, between the Pretty Boy, the Quinceañera Doll and the Tired Has-Been.

headline: The Wildcats in So Many Words
text: NEW ORLEANS — Jerry Tipton answered what seemed like an innocuous radio question last week about which Final Four team could give Kentucky the most problems. Tipton, the longtime Wildcats beat reporter for The Lexington Herald-Leader, said Ohio State.

headline: Hayden and Madden Will Be in the Spotlight for Baylor
text: Krista Pirtle of The Lariat at Baylor University will file reports about the top-ranked Baylor Lady Bears throughout the season for The Quad.

headline: Variety: Split Decisions
text: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE — Welcome to our somewhat semi-annual “Split Decisions” Variety puzzle. I really don’t need to tell you what to do here, do I?

headline: Out of One Frying Pan, and Into Another
This Year’s Final Four Could Be the Last One for an N.C.A.A. Official
text: NEW ORLEANS — Few people who fill out tournament brackets and tune in to N.C.A.A. games on television would recognize Greg Shaheen. His official title with the N.C.A.A. is the interim executive vice president for championships and alliances, a jumble of words that essentially means he runs the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament and the organization’s 88 other championships.

headline: 3 States Sold Winning Mega Millions Tickets
text: What is $640 million divided by three? More math than jackpot winners in Illinois, Kansas and Maryland will ever have to do again.

headline: The Fire and the Glow
text: DENVER — Before Baylor left Waco, Tex., for the women’s Final Four, Coach Kim Mulkey announced that she had Bell’s palsy, a treatable nerve disorder that causes weakness or paralysis of the facial muscles.

headline: Targets, Instruments, and the Zero Bound (Wonks Only)
text: I’ve been rereading Larry Ball’s impressive and disturbing what-happened-to-Ben-Bernanke analysis — an analysis that, I happen to know, has caused much consternation in some circles. (“Surely it can’t be just groupthink! There must be very good reasons the Fed hasn’t done more!”) And I think there’s a way to further refine Ball’s analysis, making more sense of Bernanke’s retreat from earlier positions — albeit one that still doesn’t cast a very flattering light on the Fed.

headline: A Changed but Familiar Woods
text: A book arrived in the mail for Tiger Woods, one promising insight into his upended life. Not “The Big Miss,” the work of pulp friction by his former swing coach Hank Haney, but “The Noticer,” a thin novel heavy on perspective.

headline: In Wisconsin, Romney Nears the Tipping Point
text: WASHINGTON — Mitt Romney is on the cusp of taking firm control of the Republican nominating contest for the first time, neutralizing his most powerful critics and rallying a broad spectrum of conservatives behind him as party leaders grow increasingly eager to take on President Obama.

headline: The Birth of ‘Dixie’
text: In a New York apartment on a rainy day in March 1859, Daniel Decatur Emmett sat down at his desk to write a song for his employer, Bryant’s Minstrels, and its upcoming stage show. Then 44 years old, Emmett had been composing minstrel songs — to be performed primarily by white actors in blackface — since he was 15. Looking out his window at the dreary day outside, Emmett took his inspiration from the weather. A single line, “I wish I was in Dixie,” echoed in his mind. Before long, it would echo across the country.

headline: Syria Won’t Pull Out of Rebel Centers
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Syrian forces will not pull out of towns and cities that have been centers of the yearlong uprising until “normal life” resumes there, a Syrian government spokesman told state news media, raising new questions about prospects for carrying out a United Nations-backed peace plan as Western and Arab leaders prepared for a high-level meeting in Turkey on the Syrian crisis.

headline: After Threats, No Signs of Attack by Hackers
text: A threat to attack a crucial part of the Internet on Saturday by members of the mercurial, leaderless hacker collective called Anonymous appears to have had no discernible impact so far.

headline: The Next Big Idea
text: Twenty years ago, under a glorious canopy of sunshine at Baltimore’s Inner Harbor, Rick Sutcliffe threw the first pitch of a baseball revolution.

headline: Uranium Mines Dot Navajo Land, Neglected and Still Perilous
text: CAMERON, Ariz. — In the summer of 2010, a Navajo cattle rancher named Larry Gordy stumbled upon an abandoned uranium mine in the middle of his grazing land and figured he had better call in the feds. Engineers from the Environmental Protection Agency arrived a few months later, Geiger counters in hand, and found radioactivity levels that buried the needles on their equipment.

headline: An Uprising in the East
text: As metaphors go, it was powerful and painful. While making the final out of the Philadelphia Phillies’ season last October, the team’s slugging cleanup man, Ryan Howard, broke awkwardly from the box and crumpled to the ground in agony. Howard had ruptured his Achilles’ tendon. Down went the champs.

headline: Tigers Poised to Break Through
text: Follow the blue and orange paw prints on the carpet to the far corner of the Detroit Tigers’ clubhouse in Lakeland, Fla. They lead to the smoke-filled office of Manager Jim Leyland, whose desk, strewn with lineup cards and Marlboros, faces a five-foot-tall poster bearing the stern face of Ty Cobb.

headline: Industry in India Helps Open a Door to the World
text: LAHORE, Pakistan — On the day the Indian trade delegation came across the border, Pakistan was having another political crisis. The prime minister was embroiled in a showdown with the country’s Supreme Court. Early elections were rumored. And Islamists had just staged a rally in Karachi to protest “foreign intervention” on Pakistani soil.

headline: Roger C. Molander, Nuclear Protest Leader, Dies at 71
text: Roger C. Molander, who abandoned what he called the “priesthood” of cold warriors in the White House and the Pentagon to organize one of the nation’s largest and most colorful protests against nuclear arms, died on March 25 in Washington. He was 71.

headline: Hitchcock Rethinks His Ways and Rejuvenates the Blues
text: ST. LOUIS — Eight St. Louis Blues players formed a circle near a freight elevator at Scottrade Center and kept a soccer ball aloft with their feet and knees. It is a fashionable pregame time-killer, the modern take on the dressing room table tennis, and these Blues went at it with gusto.

headline: Patience Abbe, Chronicler of Her Childhood Travels, Dies at 87
text: Patience Abbe was not quite 10 by the time she had waltzed standing tiptoe on Fred Astaire’s feet, charmed literary critics with her conversation and been promised in marriage to the son of a handsome couple of her parents’ acquaintance, Hadley and Ernest Hemingway. She and Jack Hemingway, also known as Bumby, were toddlers at the time, living with their expatriate American parents in Paris.

headline: Edson W. Spencer, Who Turned Honeywell’s Attention to the Skies, Dies at 85
text: Edson W. Spencer, who as chief executive and chairman of Honeywell shifted the company away from computers and into aeronautics and industrial controls, died on March 25 at his home in Wayzata, Minn. He was 85.

headline: Giffords Keeps Campaign Money, Prompting Talk of a Possible Comeback
text: LOS ANGELES — When Gabrielle Giffords announced that she would step down from Congress in January, she did not shy away from the possibility that she would one day run for office again.

headline: Junior, the Kid, the Fight
text: Fifty years later. If you are Lucy Paret, though, the impoverished widow of Benny, a two-time welterweight champion of the world, you’re hardly calling this an anniversary. Fifty years ago, you decided to stay home in your Bronx apartment building the night your 25-year-old husband was pummeled to death — March 24, 1962 — by the challenger Emile Griffith, a former champion, on live television, an ABC “Friday Night Fights” special.

headline: Watching the Bouncing Balls, College and Pro
text: Steve Kerr, one of the busiest men in basketball this time of year, does not play or coach. He is a TNT game analyst for the N.C.A.A. men’s tournament and the N.B.A.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: In Wisconsin, Santorum Tells Conservatives Not to Give In
text: PEWAUKEE, Wis. — His status as a formidable challenger to Mitt Romney diminished in recent days, Rick Santorum took the stage at a gathering of religious conservatives on Saturday morning and implored them not to sell their convictions short.

headline: Alchemists Needed for Mets’ Golden Anniversary
text: A 50th anniversary is a great time to remember why you fell in love in the first place — the rush of joy, then the recognition that, over the long run, nobody is perfect.

headline: In Brazil Cyclist’s Death, a Clash Between Wealth and Life on the Fringes
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — It started out as just another Saturday night in Brazil.

headline: A Monotony of Excellence, an Atrophy of Passion
text: Most fans look ahead on opening day, with anticipation and relish. I’m no different, I suppose. Now early in my second half-century rooting for the Yankees, I can think of a few intriguing questions about this season. How are the Yankees going to squeeze seven legitimate starting pitchers into a five-man rotation, for instance, and will Joba Chamberlain pitch this year after mangling his ankle in a trampoline accident? (A flabbergasting event. I mean, has any professional athlete ever been so badly hurt playing with a 5-year-old?)

headline: Good Deeds in Afghanistan Interrupt the Grim Narrative
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — The story of Specialist Dennis Weichel could easily serve as a counternarrative to the gruesome account of the American soldier charged with 17 counts of murder in Kandahar on March 11.

headline: If Bynum Practiced 3-Pointers, He Could Make Fans Forget Wang Zhizhi
text: The latest striking turn in the Los Angeles Lakers’ tumultuous season came when Andrew Bynum, the team’s young center, was benched after a failed 3-point attempt.

headline: Less Visible Occupy Movement Looks for Staying Power
text: WASHINGTON — Six months after the Occupy movement first used protests and encampments to turn the nation’s attention to economic inequality, the movement needs to find new ways to gain attention or it will most likely fade to the edges of the political discourse, according to supporters and critics.

headline: Singular Approach to a Signature Hobby
text: If you wanted to buy an official Rawlings baseball from MLB.com, it would cost $16.99. But if you were willing to let Hayden Penn write his name on it first, the same ball could be had for $5. For those scoring at home, that would make the value of Penn’s autograph negative $11.99.

headline: Islamist Group Breaks Pledge to Stay Out of Race in Egypt
text: CAIRO — The Muslim Brotherhood nominated its chief strategist and financier Khairat el-Shater on Saturday as its candidate to become Egypt’s first president since Hosni Mubarak, breaking a pledge not to seek the top office and a monopoly on power.

headline: Long, Cold Summer for Maple Leafs and Canadiens
text: Two of the N.H.L.’s oldest and most renowned franchises — the Montreal Canadiens and the Toronto Maple Leafs — will be missing from the postseason, once again unable to build on their increasingly distant championship traditions, and having alienated their local and worldwide followings.

headline: Panic in Paradise
text: When friends ask about my Maui honeymoon, I tell them that Brian and I didn’t leave our hotel. Wink, wink. “You must have had a really great time!” everybody chuckles. I want them to imagine that we enjoyed a tantric Hawaiian escapade, frolicking like soap stars in 600-thread-count sheets.

headline: 30 Seconds: Steve Kerr Watches the Bouncing Balls, College and Pro
text: Steve Kerr, one of the busiest men in basketball this time of year, does not play or coach. He is a TNT game analyst for the N.C.A.A. men’s tournament and the N.B.A.Kerr, 46, played 15 N.B.A. seasons. He won three championships with the Chicago Bulls and two with the San Antonio Spurs before retiring in 2003, then moved to the Phoenix Suns’ front office from 2007 to ’10.

headline: How the Cholera Epidemic Spread
text: The outbreak started in the mountains of central Haiti, where untreated sewage from a United Nations camp is believed to have contaminated a tributary of the Artibonite River in October 2010.

headline: Cholera Grips Haiti
text: A devastating cholera epidemic struck Haiti 10 months after the earthquake of 2010. The New York Times traces the origins of the outbreak.

headline: Education’s Hungry Hearts
text: Batesville, Va.

headline: Sharapova Loses in Final, Making 45 Unforced Errors
text: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla. — Agnieszka Radwanska was an 18-year-old unknown from Poland the first time she defeated Maria Sharapova, during the 2007 United States Open.

headline: Why Am I The One
text: The latest video from the band Fun. An interview with the lead singer, Nate Ruess, is featured in this week's Sunday Review.

headline: Yankees’ Pineda Heads to Disabled List
text: KISSIMMEE, Fla. — Before leaving to have a magnetic resonance imaging test on his right shoulder, Michael Pineda sat at his locker in the Yankees’ clubhouse Saturday with ice strapped to the affected joint and worry creasing his face.

headline: Experts Recommend Single Registry to Oversee Kidney Transplant Donations
text: HERNDON, Va. — Leaders in the field of kidney transplantation recommended last week that a single nationwide registry should oversee the complex matching process needed to expand the use of transplant chains and other forms of paired donation.

headline: Santana Sets His Sights on Opening Day Start
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — The classic rock that boomed from the loudspeakers and washed over an otherwise empty field gave the moment the feel of a cinematic sports training montage.

headline: A Sontag Sampler
text: Art Is Boring

headline: A Recipe for Heartbreak
text: Kati Jo’s Heartbreak Pie Crust (makes one 9-inch crust)

headline: Regular-Season Supremacy Not Enough for Rangers
text: The Rangers can clinch the Eastern Conference title, and the top playoff seed that goes along with it, as soon as Sunday. They might even become the first Rangers team to win the Presidents’ Trophy as the N.H.L.’s top regular-season team since Mark Messier’s group in 1994, not that Coach John Tortorella or any current Ranger has even mentioned it.

headline: In Haiti, Global Failures on a Cholera Epidemic
text: MIREBALAIS, Haiti — Jean Salgadeau Pelette, handsome when medicated and groomed, often roamed this central Haitian town in a disheveled state, wild-eyed and naked. He was a familiar figure here, the lanky scion of a prominent family who suffered from a mental illness.

headline: A Conversation With Nate Ruess
text: Singer Nate Ruess takes more questions.

headline: Nate Ruess
text: Nate Ruess is the lead vocalist for the indie-pop band Fun. The group’s hit single “We Are Young” has topped Billboard’s Hot 100 and Digital Songs charts with more than two million downloads.

headline: Finance Ministers Clear Way for Credit Rating Competition in Europe
text: COPENHAGEN — European Union finance ministers agreed on Saturday to increase competition among credit ratings agencies and to continue difficult discussions on taxing certain financial transactions.

headline: Where Have All the Neurotics Gone?
text: SOME cultural archetypes leave the stage with a flourish, or at least some foot stomping. All those pith-helmeted colonialists, absinthe-addled poets and hippie gurus founding 1970s utopias: They made some noise, if not always much sense, before being swallowed by history.

headline: Romney Makes His Pitch to Social Conservatives and Attacks Obama
text: PEWAUKEE, Wisconsin — At a Faith and Freedom Forum here Saturday morning just three days before the Wisconsin primary, Mitt Romney continued his attack on President Obama, but also sounded some more socially conservative themes, which were popular with the attendees of the Christian conference.

headline: Young Writers Dazzle Publisher (Mom and Dad)
text: The television news feature about Ben Heckmann, an eighth grader from Farmington, Minn., was breathless in its praise. “At 14 years old, he has accomplished something many adults can’t achieve,” the reporter said. “Ben is a twice-published author.”

headline: The Roberts Court Defines Itself
text: For anyone who still thought legal conservatives are dedicated to judicial restraint, the oral arguments before the Supreme Court on the health care case should put that idea to rest. There has been no court less restrained in signaling its willingness to replace law made by Congress with law made by justices.

headline: Tax Fantasy
text: Congressman Paul Ryan, the author of the House Republican budget, is not the first politician to go long on promises and short on details. But his budget, which passed the House last week with no Democratic votes, takes untruth in taxes to a new level.

headline: Let N.Y.U. Expand in Its Backyard
text: New York University’s 44,000 students and 16,000-plus employees need more space. Over the next two decades, the university wants to expand ambitiously, with new sites around the city, but mostly with another 2.5 million square feet in Greenwich Village.

headline: Now, the Seventh-Inning Swim
text: Good riddance, March, and take your upside-down weather with you: the bizarre heat, the early blossoms in Detroit, the hailstones in Hawaii. Welcome, April and baseball! After a couple of season-opening games in Tokyo, the major leagues come home this week, starting on Wednesday night in Miami, where the Marlins are breaking in a new name, new uniforms and a brand new downtown ballpark against the World Series champion St. Louis Cardinals.

headline: Who’s the Bully in Wisconsin?
text: The Wisconsin primary on Tuesday is widely seen as Rick Santorum’s last chance of stopping Mitt Romney from winning the Republican nomination. The state’s Republicans, however, are far more concerned with the furiously contested recall election of Gov. Scott Walker, now set for June 5.

headline: The Grilling Season
text: The members of Congress, 535 of them, return home for two weeks of pulse-taking and pre-election campaigning. Those brave enough to venture beyond their circle of political allies should not expect cheers. What they deserve are pointed questions about why they spend so much time in ideological posturing and so little in actually helping people.

headline: Sunday Dialogue: How We Decide When to Go to War
text: Readers debate how recent military interventions abroad have swayed public sentiment.

headline: Why a Haggadah?
text: I SPENT much of the last several years working on a new Haggadah — the guidebook for the prayers, rituals and songs of the Seder — and am often asked why I would want to take time away from my own writing to invest myself in such a project.

headline: About All That War Buzz
text: Re “Lessons From Another Way” (March 11):

headline: A Triangle of Racial Identity
text: Which other racial groups do blacks, whites, and Latinos in Durham, North Carolina each identify with most?

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, April 1
text: The Sunday talk shows will again focus on the presidential race just a couple of days ahead of the Wisconsin primary.

headline: Training Materials for Tracking Cellphones
text: Law enforcement in three states use educational materials to learn how to track cellphones and text messages.

headline: In Florida, a Death Foretold
text: Tampa, Fla.

headline: Why Nations Fail
text: I’M reading a fascinating new book called “Why Nations Fail.” The more you read it, the more you appreciate what a fool’s errand we’re on in Afghanistan and how much we need to totally revamp our whole foreign aid strategy. But most intriguing are the warning flares the authors put up about both America and China.

headline: Fan Power: Hunger Is Not a Game, Revisited
text: “The Hunger Games” film, which debuted just over a week ago, has exceeded all box office expectations, taking in nearly $200 million to date and making Lionsgate, its distributor, very happy. But it isn’t just the on screen battle that has caught the attention of fans.

headline: The Genius of the Mandate
text: WHEN the Obama White House set out to make the liberal dream of universal health coverage a reality, it faced two obvious political obstacles. The first was the power of the interlocking interest groups — insurance companies, physician associations, pharmaceutical companies — that potentially stood to lose money and power in a comprehensive reform. The second was the price tag of a universal health care entitlement, which promised to be high enough to frighten vulnerable members of Congress.

headline: She’s Fit to Be Tied
text: WHEN I was 14, I sneaked into the empty bedroom of my scholarly older brother to poke around in his bookcase. Tucked behind his law school tomes and Winston Churchill memoirs, I found the “Story of O.”

headline: The Bleaker Sex
text: THE first time you see Lena Dunham’s character having sex in the new HBO series “Girls,” her back is to her boyfriend, who seems to regard her as an inconveniently loquacious halfway point between partner and prop, and her concern is whether she’s correctly following instructions.

headline: Naked in New York
text: Lena Dunham, the 25-year-old star, writer and director of the new HBO series “Girls,” has extensive, definite thoughts about sex. The weekly half-hour show, which debuts on April 15th, makes that clear. A recent interview with her made it even clearer.

headline: Financiers and Sex Trafficking
text: THE biggest forum for sex trafficking of under-age girls in the United States appears to be a Web site called Backpage.com.

headline: Women’s Final Four Matchups
text: Taking a deeper look at the pairings for the Women’s Final Four, which will be held in Denver:

headline: A Quantum Theory of Mitt Romney
text: THE recent remark by Mitt Romney’s senior adviser Eric Fehrnstrom that upon clinching the Republican nomination Mr. Romney could change his political views “like an Etch A Sketch” has already become notorious. The comment seemed all too apt, an apparent admission by a campaign insider of two widely held suspicions about Mitt Romney: that he is a) utterly devoid of any ideological convictions and b) filled with aluminum powder.

headline: Patience Abbe, 1924-2012
text: Ms. Abbe co-wrote books about her family’s world travels and became a celebrity at age 12 in 1936 with the publication of “Around the World in Eleven Years.”

headline: Call Me Irresponsible — Please
text: Paul McCulley has written a magisterial survey (pdf) of “responsible” and “irresponsible” policies in liquidity traps past and present, making the case — familiar to my regular readers — that there are times when violating orthodoxy is very much the right answer. And this is one of those times.

headline: In Event Full of Mishaps, No. 4 Seed Does Himself In
text: The European Individual Chess Championship has become one of the strongest tournaments in the world, partly because the top finishers earn spots to the World Cup. But this year’s event, which ended Saturday and had more than 175 grandmasters in competition, seemed to have been jinxed.

headline: Of Course!
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — And you thought it was going to be an April Fool’s Day puzzle. April Fool!

headline: As Mayor Cultivates New Business, Treatment of Backer Is Questioned
text: Two days after the Nov. 8, 2011, San Francisco mayoral election, Mayor Edwin M. Lee and his top campaign contributor, the Silicon Valley investor Ron Conway, met for a two-hour dinner at Café des Amis in San Francisco’s tony Marina District.

headline: Police Are Using Phone Tracking as a Routine Tool
text: WASHINGTON — Law enforcement tracking of cellphones, once the province mainly of federal agents, has become a powerful and widely used surveillance tool for local police officials, with hundreds of departments, large and small, often using it aggressively with little or no court oversight, documents show.

headline: A Big Day for Bichette
text: KISSIMMEE, Fla. — Dante Bichette Jr. grew up in Orlando, about a 20-minute drive from Osceola County Stadium here, and played many games here as a child and a teenager. But on Saturday, instead of being on a local travel team, he was playing for the Yankees, and the manager was Joe Girardi, one of his father’s closest friends, while his parents and younger brother watched from box seats next to the dugout.

headline: Ghosts of Iraq Haunting C.I.A. in Tackling Iran
text: WASHINGTON — At the nation’s top spy agency, the ghosts of Iraq are never far away.

headline: Knicks’ Push for Playoffs Will Go On Without Lin
text: Jeremy Lin’s rise was swift and magical, an N.B.A. fairy tale played out on a global stage, one enchanting chapter at a time, its conclusion a captivating mystery. That epilogue came Saturday night, much sooner than anticipated, with a shockingly cruel twist.

headline: As Kitten Season Approaches, City Agency Finds New Partner to Help Adoptions
text: Spring has sprung — in all its rainy glory in the Bay Area — but animal shelters are steeling themselves for the beginning of a dreaded annual event: kitten season.

headline: As Logjam at Top Weakens, Republican Ambitions for State Offices Break Loose
text: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

headline: No One Else for Animals, So Retirement Must Wait
text: For 40 years, Roberto Margo has been the only veterinarian in the border town of Rio Grande City, which not long ago had more cattle than people.

headline: Masked Figures Invite Riders at 8 Subway Stations to Ride Free
text: A group of masked individuals gave subterranean vandalism an activist tinge this week: They tampered with subway entrance equipment with the aim of letting commuters in Manhattan and Brooklyn ride free, the police said on Saturday.

headline: After 100 Years, Muni Has Gotten Slower
text: The San Francisco Muni is turning 100 this year. And in that century of great technological progress, in which an aircraft broke the sound barrier in 1947 and a supersonic car did the same in 1997, Muni has actually become slower.

headline: The Caucus Click: The Week in Pictures
text: A look back at the week on the campaign trail in Wisconsin, Vermont and California.

headline: The Caucus Click: The Week in Pictures
text: A look back at the week on the campaign trail in Wisconsin, Vermont and California.  Go to the slide show.
